title: AIR CONTROL STRIKE DEADLINE IS SET FOR MONDAY AS TALKS ARE RENEWED
description: Federal air traffic controllers threatened today to begin a nationwide strike Monday morning if the Government does not offer an acceptable new contract. They demanded benefits beyond those in a $40 million package worked out in June and then rejected by union members.

title: TRAILSIDE ASSAILANT IS SOUGHT
description: Sheriff's deputies searched today for a man thought to have been badly injured by two women he tried to abduct at Point Reyes National Seashore, the site of four so-called trailside slayings.

title: Kennedy Center Names 5 to Be Given Honors
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has announced the recipients of the fourth Kennedy Center Honors for career achievement in the performing arts.

title: Decision to Be Delayed On Unser's Indy Appeal
description: An appeal hearing on the official outcome of the 1981 Indianapolis 500 ended today, but a decision in the matter will not be made until late September or early October, the appeal board chairman said.

title: JAZZ: STEVE SACKS OCTET LEANS TOWARD THE MIDDLE GROUND
description: Since the mid-1940's, groups that have mixed jazz and Latin musical roots have usually drawn on Cuban or Afro-Cuban music for their Latin source. Guanabara, an octet led by Steve Sacks, an American saxophonist and flutist, that played Tuesday at Seventh Avenue South, the jazz club at 21 Seventh Avenue South, uses a slightly different Latin coloration, supporting a front line of jazz horns with a basically Brazilian rhythm section.

title: POLISH CHIEF PUTS 2 MORE GENERALS IN CABINET
description: Poland's Prime Minister shuffled his Cabinet today, dropping his deputy, who was in charge of economic affairs, and naming two more generals to Cabinet posts.

title: THE WESTWAY PROJECT: ITS HISTORY AND FUTURE
description: The agreement reached yesterday on the Westway calls for a sixlane Interstate System highway extending from 42d Street to the Battery on 234 acres of Hudson River landfill. Its completion is expected in 10 years.

title: STATE EMPLOYEES' STRIKE ADDS TO MINNESOTA WOES
description: Minnesota has long been touted as a model of progressive yet efficient state government that enjoys good relations with labor. But many of the social programs that helped create that image have been cut back as a result of mounting budget deficits in the last two years, and now an 11-day-old strike by state employees is turning labor relations sour.

title: JACKSON BECOMING A LEADER FOR JETS
description: Bobby Jackson makes a point of congratulating each Jet defensive back after a pass is knocked down or intercepted, and, because he is only 5 foot 9 inches tall, he stands on tiptoes to give them a high-five handshake.

title: Family Feud in Brazil Brings 6 New Killings
description: Archbishop Avelar Brandao, the Roman Catholic primate of Brazil, has offered to mediate a 32-year feud between two rural families that has accounted for six new murders in the last month and a half.

title: Patents; Upjohn Researcher Receives 20 Patents
description: A large number of patents were received this week by John C. Sih, who assigned them to the Upjohn Company, Kalamazoo, Mich., for which he does experimental chemistry research. Mr. Sih got 19 patents under his own name and a 20th with Udo F. Xaxen.

title: STRIKE LOSSES HEAVY AND WIDESPREAD
description: Before the 50-day baseball strike was settled, the Los Angeles Dodgers, financially the most successful of the 26 major league teams, had lost approximately $7.6 million in ticket revenues and concessions alone. The game's highest paid player, Dave Winfield of the Yankees, had lost approximately $388,500 in salary.

title: OWNERS FACE TASK OF DEVISING A FORMAT FOR SEASON
description: The major leagues moved quickly yesterday to piece together the shreds of their baseball season: All 26 teams will hold workouts today, most were lining up exhibition games for late next week, the All-Star Game will be played next Sunday in Cleveland, and the regular season will be resumed the following day, Aug. 10.

title: The Region; Cattle Dealer Loses License
description: ALBANY (UPI) - The State Department of Agriculture and Markets permanently revoked the operating license of Ernest Mendel, a Putnam County cattle dealer.

title: YOU CAN READ MY METER ANYTIME
description: To the Editor:

title: A FAN'S FORGIVENESS
description: STILL wearing her black funeral dress, Maryanne Exizian drove to Yankee Stadium yesterday just a few hours after she heard that the baseball strike was over. She came to buy tickets.

title: THE PROMISE OF SLUDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Tremor Hits Italian Village
description: A sharp earth tremor caused panic, but no casualties or damage, early today in this fishing village 60 miles south of Salerno, the police reported.

title: Congressmen Recovering
description: Representative Dante Fascell, Democrat of Florida, was reported out of danger today after undergoing emergency surgery last night for removal of a blood clot in his head.

title: Bonn Video Deal Halted
description: The West German newspaper and publishing concern Axel Springer, has broken off negotiations with Sony Deutschland on a planned joint video venture that was to start in September, a Sony Deutschland spokesman said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CRITICS ATTACK REAGAN ON IMMIGRATION REFORM
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed reforms of the nation's immigration policy came under attack today from a broad spectrum of critics. They asserted that elements of the plan were either too large in scope or too small, were unfair to illegal aliens and native Americans alike, and contained both too little provision for enforcement and too much.

title: ACRIMONY CONTINUES OVER HAITIAN REFUGEES' FATE
description: Last week, just after the Government moved 286 Haitians from an overcrowded detention facility here to similar quarters in New York, West Virginia and Texas, and just after Florida's Governor sued the Justice Department to alleviate the overcrowding, and just after attorneys representing the Haitians brought suit to keep them here within reach of legal counsel, and just before another group of boats bearing 463 more Haitians washed up on south Florida shores, the Kiwanis Club of Miami held a meeting.

title: Uncertain Signals in Nicaragua
description: The foundation is beginning to crack in the halfway house that is Nicaragua. Three fissures seem particularly unsettling. The main opposition newspaper, La Prensa, was recently closed for two days, in what was clearly a warning pour les autres. By widening state control over exports and the private sector, the Sandinist-led junta is jeopardizing an alliance that has brought Nicaragua domestic tranquillity and foreign support. And there has occurred a Soviet-supported military buildup, only partly justified by fears of an exile invasion from Honduras.

title: NEW SPLIT LOOMS ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: The House Judiciary Committee approved an indefinite extension of the Voting Rights Act today after a bitter debate that fractured a bipartisan consensus on the bill.

title: Howard Coonen, 86, Is Dead; Ex-Postal Official in New York
description: Howard Coonen, a former regional director of the New York Post Office and the acting postmaster of New York from 1957 to 1958, died July 18 at his home in Omaha, it was learned yesterday. He was 86 years old.

title: U.S.-Spain Treaty Talks End
description: The United States and Spain ended a fourth round of talks today on renewing the bilateral treaty that gives American forces the use of four military bases in this country in exchange for military and economic aid. Officials reported progress on scientific, technical and cultural questions but not on military questions. Neither side would give details.

title: SEVENTH ULSTER HUNGER STRIKER DIES HOURS AFTER ANOTHER GETS TREATMENT
description: A seventh nationalist prisoner died in the Irish hunger strike early this morning, just hours after one of his fellow hunger strikers had begun receiving medical treatment, presumably including nourishment, at the request of his family.

title: Patents; Re-usable X-Ray Tube Said to Cut Radiation
description: Prof. Robert S. Ledley of the Georgetown University Medical Center here was awarded Patent 4,281,269 this week for a re-usable medical X-ray tube that generates a large number of rays in relatively short time. He said he believed that the device would make images significantly sharper and reduce the radiation dose to the patient.

title: THE PEOPLE BEHIND THE SCENE AT BATTERY PARK CITY
description: The Aboriginal Artists of Australia loved the vast expanse of sand, skyscrapers and river that forms the stage at the Battery Park City Landfill at Chambers and West Streets. They were probably the first performers in the innovative Art on the Beach outdoor summer arts festival, sponsored by Creative Time Inc., to feel that it was just like home.

title: Patents; A PACING TIMER FOR RUNNERS
description: WASHINGTON A NEW YORK lawyer who is a devoted distance runner has invented a pacing timer to be worn on a special glove. By sound and displayed data, the mechanism tells the runner how fast he is going and how far he has gone.

title: AMID CONTROVERSY, AMERICAN PLANS A PASSION PLAY IN ISRAEL
description: Amid growing controversy, an American director is preparing a production of a passion play, the first to be staged in Israel for large audiences.

title: EX-IM CREDIT FOR AUSTRALIA
description: The Export-Import Bank said today that it will guarantee a private credit for a $63.7 million purchase of heavy duty mining equipment from Dresser Industries Inc. by an Australian company. it said Theiss Dampier Mitsui Coal, a joint venture Australian mining concern, will purchase drag lines, drills, shovels, haulers and other equipment from Dresser to develop an open coal mine in Queensland.

title: MINIMIZING PESTICIDES IN HOME GARDENS
description: To spray or not to spray? It is a serious question and one that many gardeners may be confronting right now. Leaves that turn rusty yellow from mites, flowers that are here today but chewed to bits tomorrow - these are typically frustrating problems that mar a gardener's pleasure.

title: MINIMUM BENEFIT IN SOCIAL SECURITY WINS IN THE HOUSE
description: The House voted today, 404 to 20, to preserve the Social Security minimum benefit for the two million retired people it now protects, rejecting President Reagan's recommendation that the floor be abolished.

title: The Season at a Glance
description: STAR GAME: Sunday, Aug. 9, at 8:35 P.M., in Cleveland (where it was originally scheduled for July 14). REGULAR SEASON: Resumes Monday, Aug. 10.

title: 150 Barges Knocked Loose
description: A tugboat towing 15 barges snapped its towline early today, causing a chain reaction that knocked loose 150 barges tied up on the Mississippi River, the United States Coast Guard said.

title: TOHMPSON POSTS A RECORD 62
description: Leonard Thompson, an 11-year tour veteran, shot 62 today, a record for the Canadian Open, and took a four-stroke lead in the second round of the national championship. Thompson, who tied for second here last year, has scored 62 or better on other occasions, but never on the pro golf tour.

title: Governor Carey In Trouble
description: Governor Carey recognizes that he is in deep political trouble but says that what has put him there is a distorted public image of his behavior.

title: SERVICE IN JERSEY IS SET FOR LAWYER KILLED IN AFRICA
description: HO-KUS, N.J., July 31 - As the police in Durban, South Africa, continued their search for clues to the slaying of a New York lawyer on vacation there, a memorial service was being planned for her Monday evening at a church near her family's home in this Bergen County community.

title: FORD OFFERS DEALERS A SALES INCENTIVE
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it is offering its dealers up to $1,000 a car in incentives to help increase new car sales.

title: AROUND THE NATIONf; Perdue Workers Reject Proposal to Join Union
description: Employees of a chicken-packing plant here owned by Frank Perdue voted today, 606 to 326, to remain nonunion and reject as their bargaining agent the United Food and Commercial Workers.

title: INDUSTRIAL ACCIDENTS IN ELIZABETH AREA
description: Following are some recent industrial accidents in the Elizabeth, Linden, Rahway and Carteret area: March 20, 1979 - Explosion in Exxon processing unit in Linden. Seven workers and firemen injured. March 28, 1979 - Explosion at G.A.F. Corporation, an industrial chemical manufacturer in Linden. One worker killed, two others injured and two truck drivers burned.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item in Notes on People on Thursday about a dispute between Lynn Redgrave and Universal Television misstated Universal's policy on television actresses who take their infants onto sets. Universal does not bar infants.

title: Nuclear Power Plant In Connecticut Shuts
description: Northeast Utilities' Millstone II nuclear power plant shut down automatically today when a water-level control system malfunctioned.

title: WHAT FOSTER CARE IN NEW YORK NEEDS- AND DOESN'T
description: NEEDTo the Editor:

title: Watergate Postscript
description: At least one of the convicted Watergate conspirators, Charles W. Colson, has had a reconciliation with John W. Dean, the Nixon White House staff member whose testimony before the Senate Watergate Committee implicated several of his Administration colleagues.

title: Texas State Legislator Hurt in Shotgun Attack
description: Someone who was lying in wait fired a shotgun four times early today at State Representative Mike Martin, a Republican from Longview.

title: Company Earnings; AETNA POSTS 19.4% DROP
description: Aetna Life and Casualty reported today that operating earnings declined 19.4 percent in the second quarter. It was the second consecutive quarter in which Aetna's earnings declined. A 21.4 percent decline was recorded in the first quarter compared with the first three months of 1980.

title: DEFENSE STOCKS LEAD MODEST RALLY
description: Defense stocks, a former group favorite that ran into heavy profit-taking this year, led a modest rally on Wall Street yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.23 points, to 952.34, extending Thursday's advance of 7.71 points. Volume increased to 43.5 million shares yesterday, from 41.6 million in the previous session. For the second straight day, stock prices generally were buoyed by Congressional approval this week of President Reagan's tax-cut package.

title: CONNECTICUT APPROVES NEW DISTRICTS
description: A plan for new state legislative districts for the next decade that would erode urban strength while generally protecting incumbents was approved today by the General Assembly.

title: Nets Noncommittal On Abdul-Jabbar
description: Bob MacKinnon, the general manager of the Nets, was noncommittal yesterday about whether the Nets would be interested in obtaining Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers center, who has asked to be traded immediately to either the Knicks or the Nets.

title: Your Money; TAX-EXEMPT CERTIFICATES
description: NOW that Congress has just about completed action on the Administration's tax bill, new tax-exempt deposits are likely to become available to individuals beginning Oct. 1.

title: MOST TAX-FREE GROUPS RETAIN STATUS IN REVIEW
description: Despite a long review of the tax-exempt status enjoyed by thousands of private, nonprofit organizations in New York City, the Koch administration has generated little revenue and has restored relatively few groups to the tax rolls.

title: FACTORY ORDERS RISE BY A SHARP 0.9%
description: New orders for manufactured goods rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in June from May, well ahead of the previous month's gain and the fifth consecutive monthly increase, the Commerce Department said today.

title: IT COSTS JUST $3 MILLION, AND IT TELLS THE TIME
description: Without even a smile at the obvious phrase, Yves Piaget says, ''It's for the woman who has everything.'' It certainly is, especially if the woman happens to have $3 million lying around in a numbered bank account in Mr. Piaget's native Switzerland.

title: U.S. IN PACT ON REACTOR WASTE
description: The Federal Government might take charge of radioactive wastes to be removed from the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear reactor if the utility agrees to pay for disposal, an interagency agreement said today.

title: Joffrey Ballet Plans 25th-Anniversary Run
description: The Joffrey Ballet will celebrate its 25th anniversary with a monthlong engagement at the City Center-55th Street Theater from Oct. 21 to Nov. 22. The season will open with a gala retrospective, details of which will be announced; the premiere of a ballet by Gerald Arpino, the full version of Robert Joffrey's ''Postcards'' and the company premieres of Jiri Kylian's ''Verklaerte Nacht'' and John Cranko's full-evening ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' as well as revivals of Mr. Arpino's ''Trinity,'' Kurt Jooss's ''The Green Table,'' Jerome Robbins's ''Moves'' and Arthur Saint-Leon's ''La Vivandiere Pas de Six.''

title: Three Cleared in Big Rigging
description: The first black to serve an Alabama State Cabinet since Reconstruction and two Georgia businessmen were acquitted today on Federal charges of bid-rigging and mail fraud. Jesse Lewis, of Birmingham, Ala., former head of the highway and traffic safety office, and Ron and Roary Snider, both of LaGrange, Ga., had been charged in connection with sales of ambulances to 13 local Alabama governments.

title: SYNTHETIC FUELS CALLED A PERIL TO THE ATMOSPHERE
description: Rapid development of synthetic fuel production could accelerate the heat-sealing effect of carbon dioxide on the atmosphere and threaten the nation's ability to grow food, scientists warned Congress today.

title: COURT ENJOINS N.Y.R.A. FROM BANNING SAUMELL
description: The jockey Larry Saumell was granted a preliminary injunction yesterday by State Supreme Court Judge Martin Rodell, enjoining the New York Racing Association from barring Saumell from the association's tracks.

title: HOW THE POLICE WOULD COPE WITH CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: The Heat Is Off
description: In the end even the Democrats were agreeable to the death of the New Deal, which took place this week at the Capitol. Just before the fatal vote on the tax bill, a Republican friend phoned from Washington to say, ''This week we're going to kill the New Deal and give you a tax cut,'' but he spoke not for the Republicans alone but as the collective voice of the Congress, Democrat as well as Reaganist.

title: I.T.&T. to Award $3.5 Million To Victim of Electric Shock
description: A 33-year-old man who became a quadriplegic after receiving an electric shock from an extension cord has won a $3.5 million pretrial settlement from the manufacturer of the cord.

title: PRICES PAID FOR CROPS FALL 0.7%
description: Prices paid to farmers for raw products fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in July from the month before but still averaged 4.4 percent higher than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: REGGAE: PETER TOSH AT RITZ
description: Simply because he was a founding member of the Wailers, along with Bunny Livingston and the late Bob Marley, Peter Tosh, the Jamaican singer and writer who appeared at the Ritz on Tuesday and Wednesday, has earned himself a place in the reggae pantheon. But Mr. Tosh's work as a solo artist hasn't always been consistent.

title: News Summary; News Summary
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 1, 1981 International Poland's Cabinet was reshuffled. Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski added two generals to his Cabinet, which now has four generals among its members, and he dismissed Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Jagielski, who had been in charge of economic affairs and chief negotiatior of the Gdansk labor agreements. He had been an appointee of Edward Gierek, the deposed Communist Party leader. The shuffle had been expected and partly resulted from a recent decision to separate governmental and Communist Party responsibilities. Mr. Jagielski was replaced by Janusz Obodowski, former Minister of Labor, Wages and Social Affairs. (Page 1, Columns 3-5.) The staging of a passion play in Jerusalem by an American director raised controversy among Jews, who have regarded such depictions of the last days of Jesus as anti-Semitic because they have appeared to hold Jews responsible for His death. The Passion Play of Jersualem is scheduled to have its premiere tomorrow. Its director is Francisco de Araujo, founder of several choral groups in Washington. (1:1-2.)

title: LEGACY OF MOSES HAILED
description: Robert Moses, the builder of so much that is now New York, was memorialized here today in a church that is virtually surrounded by examples of the bridges, causeways and parkland he left as his legacy.

title: A PEEKSKILL WOMAN AND MAN CONVICTED IN SLAYING OF GIRL, 4
description: A Peekskill woman and her boyfriend were convicted today of manslaughter in the beating death of the woman's 4-year-old daughter.

title: Twins in the Swim
description: James and Jonathan diDonato, 27-year-old identical twins from Wantagh, L.I., will attempt to swim the English Channel Aug. 9, and set some records.

title: De Gustibus; FASHIONS IN FOOD, LIKE THOSE IN CLOTHES, FOLLOW THE TRENDS
description: Fashion shapes our tastes in food almost as surely as it does in dress, and in much the same way. In both, interestingly enough, France has been the leader, and the concept of a formalized, conscious attempt at originality and ultimate artistry has distinguished the haute cuisine as it has the haute couture.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Surprising Mecca By ANATOLE BROYARD LOURDES: A Modern Pilgrimage. By Pat- rick Marnham. 225 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $12.95.

title: Quotati
description: ''We will have an area that will be the jewel of the city.'' - Mayor Koch. (1:6.)

title: NEW ABORTION LAW IS HALTED
description: A Federal judge today temporarily blocked a new state law that would have required that parents be notified before abortions could be performed on unwed minors.

title: POP: TOM PETTY AND HEARTBREAKERS IN JERSEY
description: Most arena rock concerts aren't exactly concerts. They are carefully staged spectacles in which the music often takes a back seat to special effects and showmanship. Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, whose two most recent albums have won them a following large enough to fill arenas and stadiums, have announced their opposition to this trend. They are, in Mr. Petty's words, a group for ''people who just want to hear a rock-and-roll band.''

title: Envoy to Pakistan Named
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Ronald I. Spiers, a career Foreign Service officer, to be Ambassador to Pakistan. Mr. Spiers, 56 years old, director of Intelligence and Research in the State Department since 1980, would replace Arthur W. Hummel Jr., who has been named Ambassador to China.

title: BOLIVIAN CURB ON FOREIGN CURRENCY
description: Bolivia has imposed controls on foreign currency transactions for the first time in 10 years in an apparent attempt to slow the flow of dollars from the South American country.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY UNCHANGED
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday afternoon that the nation's basic money supply was unchanged in the week ended July 22, a development that analysts said left the Fed with little reason to change monetary policy or short-term interest rates in the near future.

title: Murder Suspect Plans Plea
description: A man who the police say has confessed to killing as many as 25 ''loose'' women he met in singles bars will plead not guilty to two murder charges, his attorneys say. Frank Anthony Canonico, 39 years old, was indicted by a Broward County grand jury Wednesday in the deaths of Phyllis Schwartz, 43, of Lauderhill, Fla., and Willine Wall, 60, of Fort Lauderdale.

title: Japan Permits Cartel
description: The Japanese Fair Trade Commission authorized 13 Japanese medium- and low-pressure polyethylene producers to form a cartel to hold down production for three months beginning tomorrow, commission officials said today.

title: SCHLITZ CLOSING MILWAUKEE PLANT
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company said it will close its strikebound Milwaukee brewery, effective Sept. 30.

title: William Mackie, 50, Executive With Ingersoll-Rand Company
description: William A. Mackie, an executive vice president of the Ingersoll-Rand Company in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., died yesterday at New York Hospital. Mr. Mackie, who was a resident of Summit, N.J., was 50 years old.

title: NEW JERSEY MAN IS SUSPECTED OF HELPING A SOVIET SPY FLEE
description: A New Jersey man who served time in the same Federal prison from which a man convicted of spying for the Soviet Union later escaped is believed by the Federal authorities to have helped the spy flee to South Africa.

title: Pakistani Train Derails, Killing 43 and Injuring 50
description: Six coaches of a passenger train derailed today near Bahawalpur, killing 43 people and injuring at least 50, Pakistan radio reported.

title: South Africa Bans Head Of Journalists' Group
description: The South African Government has served a two-year banning order on Charles Nqakula, president of the Media Workers' Association of South Africa, an organization of black journalists.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration is introducing new reassuring language into its discussions of trimming the Social Security System, but wary members of Congress do not seem to be responding with additional support for the President.

title: Radioactive Water Escapes At Minnesota Nuclear Plant
description: Radioactive water leaked into the ground and into the Mississippi River from the Monticello nuclear power plant, the Northern States Power Company said today.

title: PENNWALT'S TROUBLES IN NICARAGUA
description: Nicaragua's Sandinist revolution is two years old, but for Robert P. Ogden, vice president of chemicals for the Pennwalt Corporation, the smoke is only now beginning to clear.

title: GIANTS FIND REECE IS VERSATILE PLAYER
description: In his five years in the National Football League, Beasley Reece has played wide receiver, cornerback and mostly strong safety. This year, the Giants have switched him to free safety and Reece is exuberant.

title: CLARENCE B. BOUTELL
description: Clarence B. Boutell, who wrote the column ''Authors Are Like People'' for The New York Post in the postwar years, died July 29 in Norwalk, Conn.

title: GAMBIA REBELS CALL ON SENEGAL TO OMVE TROOPS
description: Encircled leftist rebels in Gambia's capital city threatened to execute Cabinet ministers and the President's former wife today unless troops from neighboring Senegal withdraw from the tiny West African nation and end their attempt to crush the rebellion.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 'WIZ KIDS'

title: Dentist Convicted in Test Of 'Deadly Force' Law
description: In a case involving Pennsylvania's ''deadly force'' law, a jury today convicted a dentist of voluntary manslaughter for shooting a young intruder.

title: DUPONT'S CONOCO BID IS CLEARED
description: The Justice Department, in a move that apparently gives the Du Pont Company an advantage in the three-way takeover battle for Conoco Inc., yesterday granted tentative antitrust clearance to the chemical company to proceed with its bid.

title: WQXR to Broadcast Five Early Verdi Operas
description: Five early Verdi operas will be broadcast by WQXR-AM and FM on Saturday afternoons this month from 2:05 to 5.

title: Strike Two
description: It's been a long All-Star break. Unless ballplayers suddenly mistake themselves for air controllers, they'll ratify the deal and let major league baseball sheepishly toss out the first ball for its second 1981 season.

title: U.S. SUED IN SALVADOR FARM SEIZURE
description: An American family is seeking $20 million in a lawsuit against the United States under the Fifth Amendment for what it says was the State Department's role in the seizure of its 4,500-acre coffee plantation in El Salvador.

title: OFFICIAL FINDS F.B.I. DISCRIMINATED IN HIRING
description: A Justice Department special officer has ruled in a four-year-old complaint that the Federal Bureau of Investigation discriminated against women in hiring, training and assignment to cases.

title: Timberland Suit
description: The Timberland Company said it had sued the Stride Rite Corporation, Uniroyal Inc., and the Sperry Topsider Company, on charges of making false patent claims for Sperry Topsider boating shoes. The suit says the defendants have continued to claim in advertising that Sperry Topsider shoes are patented although the patents expired 20 years ago. The suit seeks an injunction to prohibit this advertising as well as damages to Timberland, as a competitor of Topsiders, for profits on sales lost as a result of the advertising.

title: OM BOMBAY'S SIDEWALKS DREAMS OF LIFE IN A SLUM
description: Nearly one week after a municipal force of several thousand began smashing their huts and plastic tents and driving them out into monsoon rains, the sidewalk dwellers are drifting back to stake out their bits of pavement along a busy thoroughfare in the central Bombay neighborhood of Dadar.

title: Statistics Ruling Awaited
description: Since major league baseball will have lost approximately one third of its scheduled games when regular-season play is resumed on Aug. 10, a decision is needed on the guidelines to be adopted for statistics.

title: Nuclear Regulatory Panelist To Take State Advocacy Job
description: Peter A. Bradford, a member of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said today that he would quit before his term expires next year to become State Public Advocate representing Maine consumers in utility rate cases.

title: Hot-Dog Vendor Slain On a Corner in Harlem
description: A 50-year-old hot-dog vendor was shot and killed last night while he worked a street corner in his Harlem neighborhood, the police said.

title: The Region; Carey Vetoes Bills To Test Mechanics
description: Governor Carey announced that he had vetoed legislation that would have established a program to certify auto mechanics as competent in their field of repair.

title: Consumer Saturday; DIRECTORIES FOR CALLING TOLL FREE
description: F OR one entrepreneur the effort was a simple reaction to a recurring frustration, for the other merely a case of trying some other line of work. Regardless of the inspiration, however, both have made a success of a rather esoteric bit of publishing.

title: The City; MAN SHOOTS OFFICER AND THEN IS SLAIN
description: A plainclothes Housing Authority police officer was shot in the leg and his assailant was chased and critically wounded by another housing officer yesterday afternoon in stairwell of an apartment building on the Lower East Side, according to a spokesman for the authority.

title: Psychiatrists Submit Report On Reagan-Shooting Suspect
description: Government psychiatrists have submitted a confidential report to a Federal District judge on John W. Hinckley Jr., the man accused in the assassination attempt on President Reagan March 30.

title: MANAGERS TO START SHAPING UP TEAMS
description: With only nine days to work out before the baseball season resumes on Aug. 10, Joe Torre and Gene Michael are most concerned about the condition of their pitchers. Torre, the Mets' manager, is confident that his players will be fit, but Michael of the Yankees is a bit worried about the readiness of his aging team.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE GIVE FINAL VOTES OF APPROVAL TO REAGAN BUDGET CUTS
description: The House and Senate gave final approval today to a package of $35.2 billion in budget cuts sought by President Reagan in his effort to reverse the Federal Government's expansion of the last half century.

title: B.P. SETS CUTS IN REFINING
description: British Petroleum, one of the world's biggest oil companies, announced today that it plans to cut its oil refining capacity in Western Europe by 25 percent in the next 18 months.

title: TRIAD REPORTS PHONE CONTACT WITH MISSING MCNELL BROTHER
description: The board of directors of the Triad Energy Corporation announced yesterday that at least two of its members ''had recently been in telephonic contact'' with Thomas McNell. Mr. McNell is one of two missing brothers whose charges of fraud led to the resignation of Max C. Hugel as chief of clandestine operations for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: BROOKLYN PASTOR ASSAILS MORAL MAJORITY'S LEADER
description: A Brooklyn minister who is president of the National Black Pastors' Conference has charged the leader of the Moral Majority with perverting the Christian faith.

title: Total Solar Eclipse Darkens Part of Soviet
description: A total solar eclipse darkened a 4,300-milelong swath of the southern and eastern Soviet Union today and yielded extensive data about the sun's influence on the weather, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Index; International
description: Bombay sidewalk dwellers return after demolition attempt fails 2 U.S. and India plan further talks on nuclear rift 2 South African says raids have dis- rupted insurgent forces 3 Rebels in Gambia demand re- moval of Senegalese troops 3 Soviet rebukes U.S. Congress over resolution on Poland 4 Around the World 5 Family suing U.S. for Salvadoran seizure of coffee plantation 5 title: JUDGE BARS PART OF PLAN TO END INTEREST CEILINGS
description: A Federal judge ruled late yesterday that the Government's plan to eliminate the interest rate ceiling on savings certificates with maturities of four years or more was illegal.

title: TREES' RINGS AND HISTORY'S CYCLES
description: .2,2LEXINGTON, Ky. - On Saturday, the 8th of July, 1580, a citizen of Bordeaux, one Michel de Montaigne, age 53, was in Pisa in the dukedom of Tuscany. He was rolling in his ungainly coach from spa to spa looking for a cure, or at least some alleviation of the trying pain of ''the stone.'' Being Montaigne, greatest of essayists after Plutarch, he was also making note of everything he saw: table manners, customs, bedclothes, napkins, furniture, people.

title: FOUNDER OF BONI & LIVERIGHT
description: Albert Boni, one of the historic and flamboyant figures in American publishing, who in the post-World War I period brought out the work of Thornton Wilder, Ford Madox Ford, Theodore Dreiser and Leon Trotsky, and who was one of the pioneers in the paperback and book-club field, died yesterday in his home in Ormond Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: REPORTERS NOTEBOOK: DEFENDING GUILT
description: The ultimate challenge for a criminal defense lawyer is to get a jury to acquit a guilty client who was caught in the act.

title: U.S. AND INDIA PLAN MORE ATOM TALKS
description: The United States and India today agreed to hold at least one more series of talks on their differences over American nuclear fuel shipments. There were indications that both sides were eager to liquidate a disputed agreement on nuclear cooperation in the most amicable way possible.

title: COMPUTER RECRUITING RACE
description: The drastic shortage of engineers is hitting hard in the computer and semiconductor industries. It has caused executives to scale back investment plans or contemplate new plants beyond American borders. But they are not throwing in the towel without a fight.

title: Kaiser Drops Complaint Against ABC's '20/20'
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said Wednesday that it was dropping a complaint lodged with the Federal Communications Commission against ABC News over a segment of ''20/20'' that questioned the safety of aluminum wiring produced by Kaiser.

title: TEXT OF THE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE STATE AND CITY ON THE WESTWAY PROJECT
description: Following is the text of the agreement reached by Governor Carey and Mayor Koch on the Westway: Introduction

title: Soviet Carrier Enters Baltic, Joining a Major Navy Buildup
description: The largest ship in the Soviet Navy, the aircraft carrier Kiev, sailed into the Baltic today, adding to a naval buildup puzzling Western military and diplomatic analysts.

title: Dr. Laurence Schiff Weds Florence Faga, Health Aide
description: The marriage of Florence Faga, director of the family-care program at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens Village, Queens, to Dr. Laurence Schiff, a supervising psychiatrist at Creedmoor, took place yesterday in Bethpage, L.I. The Rev. Ralph D'Cruz and Rabbi David Benedict performed the ceremony in St. Martin's of Tours Roman Catholic Church.

title: HARVESTER UNIT SOLD TO CATERPILLAR
description: The International Harvester Company said it has completed the sale of its Solar Turbines International unit to the Caterpillar Tractor Company for about $505 million.

title: 2 Forced Conversions in Iran Are Reported by Bahai Group
description: Leaders of the Bahai sect in the United States say two teen-age girls of their sect in Iran have been abducted from their schools by Moslem religious instructors.

title: CAR ABANDONING BELIEVED DECLINING
description: Curious at the sight, a small group of men were gathered in the bright sunshine on the corner of Houston and Clinton Streets on Manhattan's Lower East Side. ''There's not too many of them on the avenues,'' one said, ''but on the side streets it's wall to wall.''

title: Saudis Said to Plan Oil Cut
description: Saudi Arabia is considering reducing its oil output gradually to the levels that prevailed before the Iraq-Iran war started about a year ago, the Iraqi oil minister, Tayeh Abdul Karim, said today.

title: House Panel Approves Start For Daylight Time in March
description: A bill to provide an earlier start for daylight saving time was approved today by a House subcommittee.

title: Planned Protest Halts Parley in New Zealand
description: The National Party's annual conference broke up today because of warnings from the police about possible violence resulting from planned protests against the tour of the Springboks rugby team of South Africa.

title: STATEN ISLAND POWER PLANT IS STILL A BAD IDEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Sally J. Broder Married To William E. Wilson
description: Sally Jane Broder, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold M. Broder of Westtown, Pa., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to William England Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence L. Wilson of Gladwyne, Pa. Judge D.T. Marrone of the Chester County Court of Common Pleas performed the ceremony in his chambers in West Chester, Pa.

title: JAZZ: CARLA BLEY'S BAND AT SEVENTH AVENUE SOUTH
description: Despite Carla Bley's close association with the jazz avant-garde in the 1960's, her music, even then, had an attractive, slightly exotic melodic quality along with colors and textures that were not merely attractive but, at times, compelling.

title: SOVIET AGAIN ACCUSES U.S. ON POALND
description: The Soviet press returned to the offensive on Poland today, strongly criticizing a resolution by the United States Congress that warned against use of force to crush the Polish democratization movement.

title: TIN PRICES LIFTED 6% BY NATIONAL
description: The National Steel Corporation, the fourth-largest steel producer in the nation, yesterday raised its prices of tin mill products , which are used in the manufacture of beverage cans, by about 6 percent, effective with shipments Sept.20.

title: CHARTER'S LOSS WIDER IN PERIOD
description: The Charter Company, a broadly diversified oil company based in Jacksonville, Fla., reported yesterday that it had a loss of $27.2 million in the second quarter of 1981, sharply wider than that of $8.7 million in the second quarter of 1980.

title: Baseball Strike Issues
description: PRIMARY ISSUES: Free-agent compensation (what a club shall receive when it loses a player to another team through free agency); service credit (whether the players shall receive credit for time during the strike, an issue injected late in talks).

title: Los Angeles Is Next Target Of Union in Equal Pay Strike
description: The union that won its battle to equalize pay between men and women who work for the City of San Jose is now charging Los Angeles with pay discrimination.

title: Maureen P. McMahon Wed
description: Maureen P. McMahon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Stephen McMahon of Spring Lake, N.J., was married there yesterday in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church to Samuel S. Budlong, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Post Reynolds Budlong of Irvington, N.Y. Msgr. John E. Grimes, the Rev. Jeremiah McGinley and the Rev. Anthony J. Bondi Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: BOSTON DEVELOPER STUDIES BID FOR WASHINGTON STAR
description: Mortimer Zuckerman, the Boston real estate developer who owns Atlantic Monthly magazine, said yesterday that he was considering buying The Washington Star before it closes next Friday.

title: Senator Delays Action On Federal Judgeships
description: Four of President Reagan's nominees to Federal judgeships were blocked yesterday by a Democratic member of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: 'Painful Vestige of McCarthyism' Rectified
description: Twenty-eight years after he was dismissed from Temple University for refusing to testify before the House Un-American Activities Committee, Dr. Barrows Dunham has been reinstated and given a lifetime $9,000 annual pension.

title: The City; Libyans Released With a Warning
description: Forty Libyans who occupied the offices of the Libyan Mission to the United Nations were released after an arraignment in Criminal Court in Manhattan and told to stay out of trouble for six months.

title: A Late Report on the Royal Honeymoon
description: The honeymooners have been out of the public eye since their spectacular wedding in St. Paul's Cathedral Wednesday, but they were expected to return briefly to the spotlight today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA GENERAL ASSERTS RAIDS INTO ANGOLA DISRUPT INSURGENTS
description: West Africa, July 30 - The commander of South African forces in this disupted territory said today that their assaults into southern Angola this month had shattered the command structure of two of the three regional headquarters of the insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization and forced the insurgents to regroup 30 to 35 miles from the border.

title: Patents; Device Rapidly Deflates A Balloon or Airship
description: Deflation equipment patented this week for the RCA Corporation permits a balloon or airship to be rapidly collapsed after landing. The equipment also prevents loss of the craft if a high wind breaks the mooring.

title: Union Oil Accord
description: The Union Oil Company of California said it has a contract to supply fuel from its Colorado shale oil project to the Department of Defense. Union said it will supply the department with 3,000 barrels a day of military aircraft turbine fuel and 7,000 barrels a day of diesel fuel when production begins in mid-1983. The price at delivery will be the market price.

title: PECITAL: DUO-PIANO SONATAS
description: Duo-piano recitals can often seem like a can of worms better left unopened, although sometimes a pair of sensitized musicians may overcome the mechanical clatter and ensemble imprecision that frequently beset such concerts. Christoph Eschenbach and Justus Frantz did not always make a convincing case that two keyboards are better than one at their Mostly Mozart appearance in Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, even though the two German pianists are an experienced team and they play with admirable technical coordination.

title: The Constitution on Guns
description: Foes of gun control keep writing to insist that the Constitution's Second Amendment proclaims a right of the citizen to keep and bear weapons without restraint. They are wrong. Judicial opinion and scholarship overwhelmingly assert that the Second Amendment is designed to protect the right of states to maintain a militia. It protects the possession of firearms only when that bears some relationship to the state militia.

title: VOLUNTARY INTEGRATION GETS OFFICIAL FROWNS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. CRITICIZES BONN'S PLAN TO CURB ARMS SPENDING
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger expressed regret and disappointment today at the approval in West Germany of a probable drop in real military spending for next year. An Administration official said that those feelings would be conveyed personally to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: Ohio Inmates Continue To Refuse to Take Food
description: Two of three inmates on a hunger strike to protest overcrowding at state prisons were taken to a hospital for tests last night, but were back in a prison infirmary today.

title: SOMALIA'S CASE AGAINST AN O.A.U. PANEL
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKE OVER, BASEBALL RESUMES AUG. 9
description: Seven weeks after it started, baseball's longest strike ended shortly before 6 A.M. yesterday, and the major league teams and players immediately began preparing to resume the season with the All-Star Game Aug. 9 in Cleveland.

title: U.S.-Held Corn Stocks Sold
description: The Department of Agriculture today announced the sale this week of 221,814 bushels of Government-held corn purchased last year in a controversial attempt to offset the impact of the curtailment of grain sales to the Soviet Union.

title: The Region; Ex-Officer Given 5 Years' Probation
description: A former Nassau County police officer received a sentence of five years' probation on a charge of assaulting a youth he had stopped for a speeding offense two years ago.

title: Fred J. Kroll, 45, Dies; Rail Union's President
description: Fred J. Kroll, president of the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks and a vice president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, died yesterday at the Hahnemann Medical College and Hospital after a long battle with leukemia. He was 45 years old.

title: ALL-STAR CLUBS ADD TWO PLAYERS EACH
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said today that rosters for the rescheduled major league All-Star Game would be increased from 28 to 30, with pitchers limited to two innings instead of the traditional three.

title: Newton of Tea Men Charged in Hit-Run
description: Bob Newton, an English forward with the Jacksonville Tea Men of the North American Soccer League, was arrested today and charged in a hit-run accident that occurred last night.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. The operation was performed before he was born and was the first successful surgical treatment in the womb. 2. The Palestine Liberation Organization. 3. The Minnesosta model is a plan to develop business-government partnerships to cope with community needs. Corporations with headquarters in the city pledge a percentage of their pre-tax profits to civic projects and charities.

title: Hospital Backs Cooley In Use of Artificial Heart
description: A committee of officials of St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital has endorsed Dr. Denton Cooley's emergency use of an experimental mechanical heart to save a life without approval from the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Iranians Demonstrate Outside French Embassy
description: Iran mobilized a mass demonstration outside the French Embassy in Teheran today to demand the return of former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr.

title: Messenger Stakes Won By Seahawk Hanover
description: Seahawk Hanover won the $224,955 Messenger Stakes tonight at Roosevelt Raceway after the favored Conquered went offstride late in the race.

title: U.S., MOSCOW DISCUSS GRAIN
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today he hoped the United States would be able to negotiate an expansion of grain sales to the Soviet Union when representatives of the countries meet Monday in Vienna.

title: CONTROLLED FRENZY IN THE PIT
description: Randy Warsager, a trader at the New York Mercantile Exchange, makes many of his business deals in less than 30 seconds. If they take longer than that, Mr. Warsager gets nervous, particularly since he receives no salary and has no clients or partners.

title: EX-FINANCIER IS SENTENCED
description: Edward Gilbert, a flamboyant former Wall Street financier, was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison for a 1975 stock fraud. United States District Court Judge Charles Haight, who described Mr. Gilbert's activities as a ''frontal attack on the marketplace,'' also directed that the 58-year-old former financier spend five years on probation after he completes his prison term.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52. 1. Eleven-week-old Michael Skinner, left, pictured with his mother, Rosa, and his twin, Mary, had surgery to relieve a blockage in his urinary tract. Why is that noteworthy?

title: Military Analysis
description: Ocean Venture '81, a naval exercise starting today and scheduled to last two and half months, is the most ambitious test undertaken by the Navy in many years. It will emphasize the scope of United States maritime commitments and the fleet's reliance in a war on its allies, both inside and outside the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: About New York; ROBERT MOSES IS REMEMBERED IN THE BRONX
description: From the Cross Bronx Expressway, the wounded borough of the Bronx looks almost majestic, a rise of terra cotta towers in the mists of 55 miles an hour. Only when there is a traffic jam, and the drivers slow, are the empty black window holes and the gutted interiors of the buildings clear as road signs.

title: Bridge: Vanderbilt Winners Upset In Spingold Knockout Play
description: As a result of a stunning upset in second-round Spingold Knockout team play, one top-ranked team was on the sidelines when 32 teams continued in action here this afternoon.

title: ROLL-CALL IN SENATE ON CUTS IN BUDGET
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate approved legislation to cut Federal spending. The House passed the measure by voice vote earlier today.

title: Bianca Saroya, Singer In San Francisco Opera
description: Bianca Saroya, an opera soprano until her retirement from the stage in the 1940's, died yesterday. The Philadelphia-born diva, who for more than a half century had refused to divulge her age or real name, starred in the first season of the San Francisco Opera in 1922.

title: KOCH AND CAREY SIGN A PACT FOR WESTWAY CONSTRUCTION UNLESS U.S. CUTS
description: 'AMENITIES' By EDWARD A. GARGAN

title: OFFICIALS IN CITY GENERALLY BACK POLICY ON ALIENS
description: New York City officials generally praised yesterday portions of President Reagan's proposed immigration policy, which would establish a legal status and a waiting period for full citizenship for many of the city's 750,000 undocumented aliens.

title: NEXT DOOR TO DANGER, A CITY COPES
description: The scaffolding and tanks of the oil refineries rise over this city and its Union County neighbors in a skeletal skyline.

title: Making Tracks
description: Between them, Betty and Harold Kendler had been working on the railroad for 78 years, until their joint retirement yesterday.

title: ON RENT CONTROLS
description: .8,2Rent control is regularly denounced as the cause of housing abandonment. If it is the cause, then it should be repealed, for it is senseless to promote abandonment in New York City, which is suffering from a critical housing shortage.

title: TAX COMPROMISES GAIN, BUT DIFFERENCES REMAIN
description: Congressional tax writers, working with unusual speed, composed their differences tonight on a broad range of issues on which the House and Senate had disagreed in the three-year, 25 percent tax reduction bills they approved on Wednesday.

title: NBC SPECIAL TO OPEN DRIVE ON DRUGS SEPT. 20
description: NBC-TV will begin a weeklong alternative-to-drugs campaign Sept. 20 with a one-hour special produced by Robert Evans, the movie producer, the network announced Wednesday.

title: MIXED REACTIONS BY FANS
description: From the South Bronx, through Harlem and the upper West Side, the reaction to the settlement of the baseball strike was a combination of anger and relief, mixed in with a little apathy about the whole thing.

title: Briefs
description: * Allied Corp. said the merger of Bunker Ramo Corp. into an Allied subisidiary was approved at a special meeting of Bunker Ramo shareholders.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Appointed Bob Gaillard, former basketball coach and athletic director at the University of San Francisco, as director of sales.; BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Signed Isiah Thomas, guard from Indiana and its No. 1 draft selection, to a multiyear contract.
description: KANSAS CITY (NBA) - Signed Joe C. M eriweather, forward-center, to a three- y ear contract. WASHINGTON (NBA) - Announced t hat Charles Davis, guard-forward from V anderbilt and a second-round draft selec- t ion, has signed a contract.

title: JUSTICE AIDE SEES LITTLE ANTITRUST SHIFT
description: Amid signs that the Reagan Administration may soften antitrust enforcement, a top Justice Department official said today that there would be no radical changes in direction.

title: ARIAS, MAYER LOSE JERSEY QUARTERFINALS
description: Jimmy Arias, the 16-year-old from upstate New York, today came to the end of his most successful stand as a professional player.

title: Bid for Ofrex
description: The Dennison Manufacturing Company of Waltham, Mass., a paper converter and stationery concern, said it had increased its bid for the Ofrex Group Ltd. of England to $2.98 a share.

title: Business Digest
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 1, 1981 The Economy

title: LESTER J. NORRIS
description: Lester J. Norris, a philanthropist who was one of the largest stockholders in Texaco Inc., died yesterday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 80 years old.

title: The Region; Suffolk Approves Pact for Workers
description: The Suffolk County Legislature approved a new one-year contract for county employees, giving them average salary increases of 10 1/2 percent.

title: STUDY CIRCLES AN AID FOR ADULT LEARNERS
description: THE Study Circle, an informal method of group learning that has been highly successful in Scandinavia, is being developed in New York State as a way of furthering adult education.

title: EISENHOWER
description: To the Editor:

title: WAITER NOT TIED TO STOUFFER FIRE, COURT IS TOLD
description: A defense attorney has asserted in court papers that laboratory tests conducted for the Westchester District Attorney ''fail to disclose any trace of the alleged accelerant'' used to start the fatal Stouffer's Inn fire last December.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Authors in August. This month, while you're relaxing in the country or at the shore, reading the current best sellers, here's what their authors are up to:

title: Browns Defeat Falcons By 24-10 in Exhibition
description: Paul McDonald, a reserve quarterback, threw two touchdown passes to Ricky Feacher in the second half today to lead the Cleveland Browns to a 24-10 victory over the Atlanta Falcons in the opening game of the National Football League exhibition season.

title: Home Clinic; SAVING TIME AND TROUBLE BY INSTALLING YOUR OWN SPRINKLERS
description: ONE chore that most homeowners have to do several times a week in summer is watering the lawn. While some of the more fortunate may have automatic underground lawn sprinkling systems to take care of this, most have to cope with dragging long, wet hoses around while periodically moving sprinklers from place to place in an effort to wet all parts of the lawn uniformly.

title: A PUSH TO LEASING THE FAMILY CAR
description: car prices have far outpaced trade-in values.

title: Iranian Cabinet Resigns So Rajai Can Pick Aides
description: Iran's Cabinet resigned today to allow the newly elected President, Mohammed Ali Rajai, a free hand in selecting his new ministers, the Iranian state radio reported.

title: THE OTHER CAPE COD CREATURES
description: COMMON GROUND A Naturalist's Cape Cod. By Robert Finch.Drawings by Amanda Cannell. 142 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $12.95. SHALLOW WATERS A Year on Cape Cod's Pleasant Bay.By William Sargent. Illustrated. 138 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $17.95.

title: The World in Summary; Bani-Sadr Hitches to France
description: Returning last week from his 2 1/2-year round trip - from exile in Paris to the presidential office in Teheran and back - Abolhassan Bani-Sadr was full of brave talk about a comeback. But the deposed president's nocturnal escape to France in a borrowed Iranian military jet seemed to reflect discretion as much as valor in his fight against ruling Islamic fundamentalists.

title: WALLETS BUTTONED SHUT
description: Although some economists expect rising disposable income - the product of recent declines in the inflation rate - to generate healthier retail sales during the third quarter and thereby help forestall a recession, a recent survey suggests otherwise.

title: WESTBROOK IS FIRST TO CONTROL NOISE
description: WESTBROOK THE Coral Sands Beach Store here was - until last year - a typical beach store. Located across the street from the beach, it carried everything from suntan lotion to popsicles to loaves of bread. It was the kind of place youngsters could browse around in with bare feet.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART High summer is a good time to renew acquaintance with works of art that are part of our local permanent collections but don't get hung up every day. Watercolors - which by the way should be hung up as rarely as possible - rank high in this particular category.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Corporate Heart
description: In an attempt to modify a popular belief that corporations are interested in only one thing - making money -the Xerox Corporation said in September 1971 that it would let 20 or more employees have a year off with full pay and benefits to pursue social projects in their communities.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary
description: If reducing ''mishaps'' in nuclear power plants to near zero is the goal, then 3,804 mishaps reported among 69 plants last year would seem unacceptable. It was for Critical Mass, an antinuclear group which last week issued a study of reactor safety that listed incidents ranging from improperly calibrated monitoring devices to leaks of thousands of gallons of radioactive coolant.

title: CONFEREES IN ACCORD ON FINAL PROVISIONS FOR TAX LEGISLATION
description: Working through the night, House and Senate conferees reached agreement this morning on unsettled issues in the multibillion-dollar tax bills that both houses of Congress passed this week.

title: HERE COMES TOM JONES AGAIN
description: straightforward, efficient and built to survive. He is also a man who has said more than once that free enterprise should be used to defend free enterprise. In other words, if a jet fighter is reliable, efficient and meets the needs of the market, it will sell. It doesn't need a handout from Uncle Sam.

title: About Westchester
description: WEST HARRISON IT is bingo night at St. Anthony's Church, and the players are arriving early. Game time is officially 7:30, but by 6:45, cars and taxis fill East Gainsborg Avenue, and women are filing into the parish's school building.

title: Joan Galbraith Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Joan Sanders Galbraith, daughter of Mrs. George Rose Galbraith of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Galbraith, to Andrew Mark Sereysky, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Wallace Sereysky of New York. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: Labor Bribery Jurors Return 2d Sealed Verdict
description: Jurors in the trial of Carlos Marcello, the reputed Mafia leader, and three other persons returned a second sealed verdict today and recessed for the rest of the weekend.

title: HONG KONG'S SUCCESS
description: Not long ago, the owner of a small knitting shop in Hong Kong discovered that its weaving machine had become unprofitable. He simply converted the machine into a noodle-making contraption. Such ingenuity is typical of the bustling British colony, which rebounded from a severe 1974-75 recession to register annual growth rates averaging 11.3 percent over the last five years.

title: LANDMARK COTTAGE AT ISSUE
description: SETAUKET BECAUSE it has been the target of vandals, the historic Victorianstyle boathouse known as Gamecock Cottage may be moved by Brookhaven Town from its picturesque location at the tip of West Meadow Beach to Longwood Estate in Middle Island.

title: Italian Legislation Would Let Women Serve in the Forces
description: The Italian Government has introduced legislation to open the armed forces to women, but only in noncombat jobs and on a voluntary basis.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Delicate Surgery For the Unborn
description: Doctors once offered good news or bad news in diagnosing suspected fetal defects: Where results of diagnostic tests were unambiguous, they could generally dispel fear of a defect or they would confirm it, leaving parents to make the agonizing choice for or against abortion. Evidence that other options are increasingly available came last week from doctors at the University of California at San Francisco, who reported that they had surgically cleared a urinary blockage in a fetus in the womb.

title: FLORIO FOCUSING ON AUTUMN
description: HADDON HEIGHTS TAPED to a brick wall at the entrance to Representative James J. Florio's campaign headquarters was a hand-printed sign soliciting participation in ''The 10-Day Club.'' It offered free, exclusive membership to anyone ''willing to traverse the unknown, explore the unmentionable, experience the unquestionable and devote 10 exciting days to the realization of our goal of electing Jim Florio on June 2, 1981.''

title: A FOUR-DAY CIRCUIT OF CAPE BRETON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- RALPH BLUMENTHAL is a reporter for The New York Times. By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

title: Pravda Raising Its Price
description: Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, is increasing its price by a third. A back-page announcement today said the price of the standard six-page issue would go up from 3 kopecks to 4 kopecks (3.9 to 5.3 cents) in January because of higher prices for newsprint. The eight-page edition, published at least once each week, will rise from 4 to 5 kopecks.

title: YONKERS BUDGET ALTERNATIVES
description: YONKERS STILL without a budget, Yonkers is exploring ways to cut expenses and increase revenue while awaiting an Albany decision on state aid. The strategy includes municipal layoffs, the level of which would depend on how much, or how little, money finally arrives.

title: NETWORK RADIO IS TUNING INTO SATELLITES
Dining Out; ITALIAN FARE IN A PLEASANT SETTING
description: LA GALLERIA in Westbury is a new Italian restaurant that, while fairly small, has style. The dining room is neatly whitewashed, trimmed in dark blue and decorated with attractive Art Nouveau posters, a nice touch. While the setting creates a certain formal elegance, the atmosphere at La Galleria is relaxed and friendly.

title: JUNE KEITH DRAKE TO WED SEPT. 12
description: The engagement of June Keith Drake to David Patrick Hayford has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Keith C. Drake of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Mr. Hayford is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Hayford of Winnetka, Ill. The wedding is planned for Sept. 12.

title: Theater Mailbag; MORE ON MUSICALS
description: To the Editor:$

title: The Careful Shopper; Trading Books Near Yale
description: Atticus is known for full-service bookshops in Middletown, near Wesleyan University; Heritage Village in Southbury, and the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven.

title: PAINT AND STEEL TRANSFORM A RUSTY, UNUSED BRIDGE
description: An artist and 30 union bridge painters applied 140 gallons of pink, plum purple and blue paint to a rusty bridge's base line and upper arc on the abandoned West Side Highway at Canal Street yesterday. The artist, A. Eric Arctander, called the piece ''Hudson Summer Sunset.''

title: Worker Dead and Second Hurt In 'Village' Scaffold Accident
description: One man was killed and another injured yesterday when one of the cables holding a scaffold snapped, sending them plummeting to the ground from outside the 10th floor of a building in Greenwich Village.

title: A CRISIS IN THE HUMANITIES
description: IT is hardly a secret that the Reagan Administration has proposed cutting the budgets of the National Endowment for the Humanities and the National Endowment for the Arts by 47 percent for next year. In the public consciousness there looms the threat of darkened stages, empty canvasses, stilled violins - a crisis in the arts.

title: Japan Cave-In Kills a Miner
description: A miner was killed and two others are missing in a cave-in at the Akabira coal mine in Hokkaido, the authorities said. Search parties digging through rock and coal powder freed two miners. The police said that one man was killed when a wall collapsed, apparently blown out by high-pressure methane gas.

title: The Region in Summary; Divvying Up; Connecticut
description: When the Connecticut General Assembly tried a decade ago to reshape state legislative and Congressional districts to reflect 1970 census figures, its members could not agree and the task fell to the courts. Thus, after a special session last week during which they sought agreement on districts for the 1980's, Assembly members could congratulate themselves on bettering their predecessors even though they got only half the job done.

title: Index; International
description: An disciplined Soviet, car drivers are an exception 3 Irish nationalists unperturbed by decision on hunger striker 3 Around the World 5 Senegal said to reinforce troops opposing rebels in Gambia 6 Pope, recovered from virus, to undergo second operation 8 Several cities on the Continent plagued by youth riots 8 Private enterprise is reviving in Shanghai 8 East Germany, in shift, is now aiding the churches 9 Government/Politics Senator Tower says Congress will reject air basing of MX 12 Court upholds rights of critics of strip mining to speak out 12 General Around the Nation 10 Providence getting by despite city workers' strike 10 Conflicts intensify over use of vast park in Utah 10 California in wide dispute over pesticide use 10 Giant oceanic worms are a new family of the animal kingdom 11 700 black women gather to renew activism 11 Black family settles into Chicago suburb after winning suit 11 Some law graduates to be paid $43,000 next year 12 Voluntary flight cutbacks asked in case of strike 13 Bail sought for suspect in Stouff- er's Inn fire 16 36 suspects arrested in garment center theft operation 16 Arts/Entertainment Mostly Mozart Festival Orches- tra plays at Avery Fisher Hall 18 A debut in La Scala Ballet's ''Romeo'' 18 ''I Hate Blondes,'' Italian farce, at the Plaza 18 Style She heals ailing neighborhoods 18 A party for Babar, the elephant king 18 Obituaries Irwin D. Davidson, judge and legislator 14 Sports MacPhail seen as playing impor- tant role in baseball settlement 19 Rams' Haden finally has the job he wants 19 Mets have a quiet and joyless workout 19 Steinbrenner attends Yankee workout and looks ahead 19 Thompson has one-stroke lead in Canadian Open 19 George Blanda among inductees in Pro Football Hall of Fame 20 Lam Jones, Jets' young receiver, is gaining confidence 20 Stockton, seeking a comeback, gains Jersey tourney final 21 Kathy Young, unheralded player, has her finest round 21 Views of Sport: Controversy over a South African rugby team 22 Red Smith on the baseball strike 23

title: FLOWER STALL, CLOSED IN '66, IS REOPENED
description: The Yan Li flower shop at 260 Changshou Road was a neighborhood favorite of both Chinese and foreigners before the start of the Cultural Revolution in 1966, when it was forced to close down for selling symbols of bourgeois decadence.

title: REAGAN'S ENERGY PLAN: PAPER PROMISES
description: Paul W. MacAvoy is Frederick William Beinecke professor of economics at Yale University and was a member of President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers. By PAUL W. MACAVOY

title: Camera; SOME POINTERS ON CHOOSING YOUR SECOND LENS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lou Jacobs Jr. is the author of several books on photography and a frequent contributor to this column.

title: Westchester Housing; RECYCLING: ITS FUTURE IS CLOUDY
description: DURING the week, William G. Baddeley of Bronxville wears a jacket and tie and works as a salesman for the Continental Can Company. On Saturdays, he puts on overalls, hiking boots and heavy gloves and spends four hours crushing bottles and stamping on cans in a shed at the Eastchester dump.

title: About Long Island
description: THE Jones Beach of my early childhood was huge and golden. In the photographs of memory, the sky is limitless and blue, the sand is endless and clean, the rented umbrellas and beach chairs are generously sized and brightly striped, the vast ocean curls up and comes down with a satisfying crash.

title: BUILDING WESTWAY, NOW THAT IT'S REAL
description: WITH the stroke of their pens, Governor Carey and Mayor Koch last week ended nearly a decade of often acrimonious debate and established West way as ''the official policy'' of the state and the city. Getting it built, though, will take at least another decade.

title: No Bang for Business...
description: Analysts are not expecting big things from business as a direct result of the Administration's triumph last week. More generous depreciation schedules will be welcome, says Lawrence Chimerine, chief economist at Chase Econometrics, and consumer spending should rise as a result of individual tax cuts. But economic growth is likely to be far below Administration pro- jections, and budget deficits far higher, he predicts. The combination will keep interest rates high and temper investment enthusiasm. Continuing high rates of interest will not only make external financing difficult, but will keep the dollar strong, Mr. Chimerine expects, hurting exports and jeopardizing industries vulnerable to imports. Since fighting inflation seems to be Mr. Reagan's first priority, Robert Gough of Data Resources, Inc. doubts the Administration would be greatly concerned if investment showed only modest growth over the next few years. At present, he predicts the tax cuts will boost fixed investment 5 percent next year and 7 percent in 1983. ...And Worse Ahead?

title: IRWIN D. DAVIDSON, 75, LEGISLATOR AND JURIST WHO SERVED 40 YEARS
description: Justice Irwin Delmore Davidson, whose career on the bench, in the New York State Assembly and in the House of Representatives spanned some 40 years, died yesterday of cancer in his home at Premium Point in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Homage to Pasternak
description: Readers of Andrei Voznesensky's article, ''A Russian Poet's Homage to Boris Pasternak'' (June 28), may be interested to know that in The New York Times translation Vladimir Nabokov and Ivan Bunin are described as writers decidedly fortyish and early autumnal, whereas in the Russian original only Bunin is so defined. Who made the change? The translator? Or Voznesensky, restoring a name censored from the original? In any case, one can only wonder whether to be an autumn leaf, like Bunin and Nabokov, adrift from Mother Russia, may not be at least as attractive as Pasternak, described as the eternal adolescent by Andrei Voznesenky, whose hairline in Serge Schmemann's photograph also is thinning. RUTH RISCHIN, San Francisco Editor's Note: The addition of Vladimir Nabokov's name to the text was made by Andrei Voznesensky when he was in Paris earlier this year.

title: Penelope Oliver Wed To Edward Stettinius
description: Penelope Elizabeth Oliver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Oliver Jr. of Houston, was married in New Orleans yesterday to Edward Trafford Stettinius, son of Edward Reilly Stettinius of Middleburg, Va., and Mrs. Peter Smith of Mill Neck, L.I. The Rev. Edward Donahue performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel of the Academy of the Sacred Heart.

title: WEDDING ON THE SCEPT'RED ISLE
description: EGYPT's dethroned King Farouk once remarked wryly on the prospect that only five monarchs would be left in the world - the Kings of Spades, Hearts, Diamonds and Clubs, and of England.

title: CUTBACKS DRAW THE VOLUNTEERS
description: SOCIETY'S needs are the aspirations of its people, and in most cases the needs exceed the resources available. In the 1960's and 70's government increasingly stepped forward, providing resources in the form of limited-purpose grants to meet many of the public's articulated needs. But such grants have, while providing needed services, caused fragmentation, developed special interests and induced intense competition for resources.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A Shorter Future For Widowed Men
description: The merry widow may be mostly a fictional phenomenon. A merry widower, according to the results of a study announced last week, would be an even less realistic creation - unless he remarried.

title: ACCIDENTS AMONG STATE WORKERS ON INCREASE
description: New York State's Comptroller, citing a rising number of workrelated accidents among state employees, has proposed the adoption of a comprehensive safety program for them and improved procedures for handling compensation claims.

title: Stamps; WORLD ISSUES CELEBRATE THE GLORIES OF NATURE
description: It is the peak of summer, and on stamps as as well as in nature it is the time when birds are on the wing and flowers are in full bloom. Color abounds as Aitutaki, one of the larger Cook Islands and a dependency of New Zealand, has put out 24 stamps, all picturing beautiful birds of the South Pacific area in brilliant multicolors. Aitutaki, though remaining part of the Cook Islands, has been issuing its own stamps since 1972. There are 12 denominations because the stamps are in setenant pairs, with like values appearing on every two stamps. The 24 stamps represent the major part of a new definitive series.

title: Seashore Concerns Charged
description: A dozen seashore businesses have been charged with violating New Jersey's Child Labor Law. The State Commissioner of Labor and Industry, John Horn, said today that the charges had been brought as the result of investigations by a special task force that was formed to enforce the child-labor statute. The businesses charged with violating the law are in Absecon, Atlantic City, Ocean City, Avalon, North Wildwood and Wildwood.

title: PHEASANTS GROWN TO ORDER
description: SHARON THIRTY years ago, Bill Wilbur, a poultry farmer, shot a ring-necked cock pheasant a few hundred yards from his home with a 12-gauge shotgun. When he reached the bird, he found only the tip of one wing had been broken. He gingerly carried the bird to his farm and placed it in one of his chicken coops. A neighboring farmer, hearing about the lone bird, presented Mr. Wilbur with four more pheasants - all hens - to keep the convalescing bird company. Thus began what has become a sizable new industry in this small, northwestern Connecticut town.

title: Kathy Kivelson Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Kivelson of Lawrence, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Kathy L. Kivelson, to Robert S. Hecht, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hecht of Roslyn Heights, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: New Jersey Housing; HOW 'CREATIVE FINANCING' WORKS
description: PERHAPS ''creative financing'' has always been a euphemism for techniques that, under ideal circumstances, might not have been necessary to put together a real-estate deal. Surely, most of the socalled ''creative financing'' methods used in the residential market today have long been used in the more-sophisticated commercial realestate field.

title: RAILROAD BUFFS ADD TRACK TO MEMORIES
description: CANAAN THE Connecticut Railroad Historical Association, which is bringing to a close its ''Canaan Railroad Days'' festivities this Saturday, has added cause to celebrate this summer.

title: Connecticut Guide; SoNo ARTISTS' COLONY
description: SoNo - the South Norwalk equivalent of SoHo in Manhattan - will celebrate its success as a thriving artists' colony by producing an arts festival on the streets and inside the Palace Performing Arts Center from 10 A.M. to sunset Saturday and Sunday.

title: Practical Traveler; DISCOUNTS GROWING FOR OLDER PEOPLE
description: The number of vigorous elderly people who travel extensively is increasing. No longer do such individuals -some of them in their 80's or even 90's - stand out in tour groups, to be fussed over for their stamina. No longer do they just tag along, like fifth wheels, on the vacations of their children and grandchildren. Instead, they are striking out on their own, seeking adventure and recreation in their retirement years and taking advantage of special discounts that are being offered to older people by operators of bus lines, hotels, resorts, restaurants and sightseeing attractions.

title: Lisa Mary Hull Bride Of Scot B. Weicker
description: Lisa Mary Hull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Nelson Hull of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday in the Round Hill Community Church to Scot Bickford Weicker, son of Mrs. Godfrey Weicker, also of Greenwich, and of Senator Lowell Palmer Weicker Jr. of Mystic, Conn., and Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Dr. Walter Wagoner performed the ceremony.

title: Reading and Writing; SOCIAL-SCIENCE FICTION
description: Readers have a seemingly boundless appetite for facts, whether in fictionalized reporting or ''factionalized'' novels. The recent appearance on the best-seller list of ''The Hite Report on Male Sexuality'' by Shere Hite and ''The Cinderella Complex'' by Colette Dowling suggests that a new genre is satisfying this craving for facts, or what passes for them. Call it ''social-science fiction,'' for it is to genuine sociology and social psychology what sci-fi is to real science.

title: INTENTIONALLY OR NOT, TAX POLICY IS A SOCIAL POLICY
description: Congress and the American people have learned through experience that it can take years before the full effects of new Government programs make themselves known. Less obvious, perhaps, is the fact that broad social consequences - intended and unintended - flow from changes in the tax system. Indeed, it may turn out that President Reagan's huge tax cuts, due to get final Congressional approval this week, will alter personal and institutional patterns of behavior more dramatically than his budget cuts.

title: Geraldine Redmond Ryan Wed to Lawrence L. Zipf
description: Geraldine Redmond Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Ryan of Brightwaters, L.I., was married yesterday to Lawrence Robert Zipf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Zipf of Haddonfield, N.J. The Rev. John H. Melton performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bay Shore, L.I.

title: Harry Chapin: More Than a Singer
description: I first met Harry Chapin on a spring day in 1973, when I was a 15-year-old high school student and he was a rising pop star.
