''Taxi,'' perhaps the best-known hit of Mr. Chapin's career, had been popular the previous year, and I loved it. I was delighted to be able to meet and be with the man who wrote and sang it.

title: Dining Out; GLOWING FRESHNESS AT DOCKSIDE
description: DWARFED by the looming Storm King Mountain immediately across the Hudson River, the tiny shore-hugging village of Cold Spring offers visitors both quaintness and majesty. Its streets hold a wealth of Victorian and pre-Victorian houses, both large and small, and of curio shops that follow in the wake of architectural charm. When visitors tire of examining finials, verandas, iron gates and such - man's efforts to beautify - there is always the profound vista of mountains and river, nature's grandeur, to contemplate.

title: A BAD YEAR IS EXPECTED BY CASINOS
description: The slot machines and untraditional bluefelt gaming tables of the Claridge Hotel's split-level Hi-Ho Casino have been busy all week, the first full week of business for the city's eighth casino. It has been the same kind of week all over town, as summer vacationers crowd the boardwalk and casino hotels.

title: College Enrollments in Fall Seen Rising 'Substantially'
description: Despite the dwindling number of 18-yearolds, this fall's freshman class at the nation's four-year colleges and universities may be ''substantially larger'' than last year's, according to The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: ARAFAT JUGGLES FACTIONS AND SPONSORS TO BUILD P.L.O.
description: BEIRUT, LEBANON THE Palestine Liberation Organization, its chairman, Yasir Arafat, is fond of saying, is ''the missing number in the differential equation.'' By this somewhat strained metaphor, Mr. Arafat is attempting to suggest that only by recognizing and dealing with his organization can the problem of the Middle East be solved. With the unlikely aid of Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin, Mr. Arafat appeared to have come a step closer to his goal in recent days.

title: SAFETY PRECAUTIONS TAKEN FOR FASTNET
description: By JOANNE A. FISHMAN

title: Wedding on L. I.  For Dr. Saunders Dr. Deborah Sue Saunders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Saunders of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there yesterday to Dr. Bruce Z. Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Kaplan, also of Rockville Centre. Rabbi Lewis Littman performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue of Nassau County.
description: The bride, an alumna of Mount Holyoke College, is a fellow in adolescent medicine at the Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx, where her husband is a fellow in ambulatory-emergency room medicine. She received her M.D. from the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine in 1978.

title: JOY AND TZORES
description: THE PATRIARCH By Chaim Bermant. 424 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95. By ANNIE GOTTLIEB

title: AN EXERCISE IN AVOIDING EXERTION
description: MY swimsuit has refused to be given the same company as my cellulite. It didn't say so explicitly, but when I tried it on the other day, it protested at my knees and adamantly refused to move upward another inch. Cellulite is the accumulation of fat bumps you try dieting off, pounding off and rubbing off, but nothing seems to work. With summer here, I knew my last hope was - I hate to say the word - exercise.

title: Gallery View; A CELEBRATION OF PICASSO AS DRAFTSMAN
description: PHILADELPHIA It was primarily as a draftsman that Picasso first presented himself in a one-man exhibition. (It was in Barcelona, and he was 18 at the time.) It was as a draftsman that he mooted many of his memorable ideas over the next 70 and some years. And it was primarily as a draftsman that he brought his long career to a close. In the etchings of his 80's, and in drawings made in his early 90's, he reinvented himself in ways that were no longer possible for him in painting.

title: GARMENT THEFT RING INVESTIGATION CONTINUING
description: An investigation into a major theft and fencing operation that preyed on the city's garment industry has brought 36 arrests and is expected to lead to more indictments, according to law enforcement officials.

title: 22 FOREIGN MINISTERS DRAWING UP AGENDA FOR TALKS ON POVERTY
description: The foreign ministers of 22 industrialized and developing nations met in closed session today to prepare for a conference here in October on the problems of world poverty.

title: Passwords
description: To the Business Editor: The use of the word ''hacker,'' in ''Case of the Purloined Password'' (July 26), to describe a bright young programmer is not universal. I, for one, have never heard it. I have heard bring young programmers called ''bit mechanics,'' ''animals,'' but never hackers. G.F. VANDERSCHMIDT Jamaica Plain, Mass. July 26, 1981

title: WHAT AMERICANS BRING TO AMERICA
description: ETHNIC AMERICA A History. By Thomas Sowell. 353 pp. New York: Basic Books. $16.95. By DAVID HERBERT DONALD

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: Sidney Zion fails to note that we, the rock generation, are the adult market today and are responsible in part for the recent resurgence of interest in Sinatra and friends. He fails to note that accompanying this new interest in the music of the 1930's and 40's is the rekindling of the careers of veteran rock and rollers like Chuck Berry, Gary U.S. Bonds and groups that were part of the English sound in the early 1960's. I don't know about Mr. Zion, but I don't feel compelled to apologize for being able to appreciate Brahms and Benny Goodman and the Beatles and Talking Heads. TERENCE POLTRACK

title: Design; OPEN TO AN OLD IDEA
description: Edith Wharton and Ogden Codman Jr., in their 1897 classic, ''The Decoration of Houses,'' bemoaned the fate of the door in the modern American house. ''Had the other chief features of the house -such as windows, fireplaces and stairs -been pursued with the same relentless animosity by architects and decorators, we should no longer be living in houses at all.'' Probably for fear of stretching hyperbole too thin, Mrs. Wharton and Mr. Codman failed to include walls in their list of hypothetical expendables.

title: VOLUNTARY CUTS AT 23 AIRPORTS TO BE ASKED IN CASE OF STRIKE
description: In the event of a strike by air traffic controllers tomorrow, the Federal Aviation Administration will ask airlines to reduce voluntarily the number of flights at the New York metropolitan area's three major airports and 20 other of the nation's busiest airports. If the voluntary reductions do not work, the Federal agency is prepared to become involved in scheduling flights.

title: THE C.I.A. AND LUMUMBA
description: Madeleine G. Kalb is author of the forthcoming book ''The Congo Cables: From Eisenhower to Kennedy,'' from which this article is adapted. By Madeleine G. Kalb On Sept. 19, 1960, the Central Intelligence Agency's station chief in Leopoldville, capital of the newly independent Congo, received a message through a top-secret channel from his superiors in Washington. Someone from headquarters calling himself ''Joe from Paris'' would be arriving with instructions for an urgent mission. No further details were provided. The station chief was cautioned not to discuss the message with anyone.

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: If one platinum album by Frank Sinatra constitutes a ''resurgence'' of music of the 1930's and 40's, surely the 35-plus platinum rock albums on the recent Billboard chart constitute proof that rock-androll is here to stay! JENNY ABRAMS

title: THE SUN BREAKS THROUGH FOR COOPERSTOWN'S BIG DAY
description: maybe ever. Baseball Scoreboard Strike Settled That news had brought a sense of joy to the fans who were heading to Cooperstown for the annual pilgrimage. They clogged this handsome lakeside town yesterday in anticipation of today's induction of Rube Foster, Bob Gibson and Johnny Mize into the Hall of Fame.

title: Photography View; IS THERE STILL A 'SOUTHERN' STYLE?
description: What do people think about when they think about the South today? Magnolias and moonlight? Rednecks, sharecroppers and the Ku Klux Klan? The Old South of romance and legend as memorialized in ''Gone with the Wind'' and the novels of William Faulkner? The New South of Henry Grady and the Atlanta Constitution as anatomized in the novels of Walker Percy?

title: Theater in Review; 'VICTIM' MISSES, BUT 'COLD STORAGE' HITS
description: ''SEX and violence'' is what the management tells customers who ask what ''Victim'' (at East Farmingdale's Arena Players Repertory Theater through next Sunday) is about. That sells tickets. ''Victim'' is audience-grabbing, but don't be too titillated: it's a come-on, a cop-out and a let-down.

title: Notes; A HIGH-SPEED TRAIN FROM PARIS TO LYONS
description: If you plan on being in France in September, you could be among the first Americans to ride a new high-speed train from Paris to Lyons. The French National Railroads will dedicate the southern section of its new Paris-Southeast high-speed line on Sept. 27, a 127-mile segment extending from St. Florentin (about 100 miles south of Paris) to Lyons.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; ROBERT J. RINGER
description: Many small publishing houses would be satisfied with even one best selling book a year, but Robert J. Ringer's small Stratford Press is having an unprecedented run of best sellers.

title: LAM JONES PROJECT: BUILDING CONFIDENCE
description: Sensitive. And awesome. These are the words Joe Walton uses, repeatedly, to describe Johnny (Lam) Jones. But Walton says that because Jones is sensitive, he did not reach the awesome potential the Jets hoped for when they made the receiver their first selection in the draft a year ago.

title: Jersey Gives Special Permit
description: A special permit has been conditionally granted by a state environmental board to a West Long Branch company for the construction of 120 town houses in Oceanport in Monmouth County. The Department of Environmental Protection said the permit had been granted under the Coastal Areas Facilities Review Act. The condition attached to the permit requires the developers of the 21.6-acre site to offer units featuring energy-saving systems.

title: PRICES OF HOME-BUILDING LOTS FOUND STABILIZED NATIONWIDE
description: After a decade of rising prices, the price of land for new-home construction has generally stabilized in the United States and actually declined in some areas, according to a new survey by the Homer Hoyt Institute in Washington.

title: Critics' Choices
description: MUSIC Heinz Holliger occupies a place by himself in the virtuoso world of music. With his strong musical personality and pioneering grasp of technique, Mr. Holliger - by concensus music's most important oboist - is creating a glamorous career by playing a seemingly unglamorous instrument.

title: Thompson Retains Lead by 1 As Hayes Double-Bogeys 18th
description: Leonard Thompson, whose 62 yesterday set a record for the Canadian Open, faltered in the third round today but finished with a one-stroke lead when Mark Hayes double-bogeyed the 18th hole. Thompson, second in this tournament last year, had entered with a four-shot lead.

title: Justice Dept. Plans to Open Prison Personnel Academy
description: Heeding a call from Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, the Justice Department announced yesterday that it would open a national academy for prison personnel this fall in Boulder, Colo.

title: THE NUMBERLESS PRESIDENTIAL CHART
description: ''The lines on these charts say a lot about who's really fighting for whom.'' - Ronald Reagan Maybe, but with charts, reality tends to be in the eye of the artist. The one President Reagan was showing off with such pride Monday night on national television showed two widely diverging lines, the gap between them in shrieking red, that represented the Administration's estimate of how much more one would be paying in taxes under the House Democrats's bill than under the President's.

title: The Region in Summary; Casino Cash - A; Nice Diversion; For Bookkeepers
description: Many are the government functions to which a politician may apply imagination and thereby earn praise. Bookkeeping is not one of them, critics of a section of Governor Byrne's new budget said last week.

title: MOBIL'S REPLY...
description: ''B Y virtually every traditional measure of concentration, the oil industry is considered to be competitive. In 1978, the United States oil industry four-company market shares or concentration ratios were: 28.1 percent for crude oil and condensate production, 31.4 percent for refining capacity and 29.4 percent for gasoline marketing. Last year, in the United States no single oil company had more than 9.9 percent of crude oil and condensate production, 9.21 percent of refining capacity or 7.7 percent of gasoline marketing. These market shares are well below the thresholds of antitrust concern about market power.''

title: SECOND ALBUMS PROMPT SECOND THOUGHTS ON BANDS
description: Andy Warhol's celebrated dictum that everyone should be famous for fifteen minutes seems to have been taken to heart by England's rock subculture. Sometimes it seems that England produces a new rock band every fifteen minutes, and while just as many new bands may be sprouting in various corners of America, by and large it's the English bands that are getting heard, here as well as on their home turf.

title: WERE MEN REALLY DANCING 40,000 YEARS AGO
description: There are times when events of strong dance interest do not take the form of performances in the conventional sense. One of several such occasions was the visit this month by the extraordinary company of Australian Aboriginal dancers and musicians now touring the country for the first time.

title: HER LEGACY TO CHICAGO WAS AN OPERA COMPANY
description: Carol Fox was one of the most tyrannical, imperious, single-minded people I have ever come across in all my years as a music critic. From the first I admired her grit, as most people in the opera world did, and from a safe distance came to have a grudging fondness for her. When she was forced to resign earlier this year as general manager of the company she helped found 26 years ago, Lyric Opera of Chicago, I had trouble imagining what that city would do without her. I still do. She was one of those unswervable people who plow ahead, pushing everything out of the way and creating a wake in which the timorous are swept along behind. Somehow, her death the other day at age 55 of a heart attack, the last in a series of illnesses and accidents that left her crippled in body and somewhat subdued in spirit, did not seem as surprising as it should have. For more than a quarter century, Lyric Opera had been her life, and she had lost that life when she was forced to quit. It always had been impossible to think of the company without thinking of Carol Fox. She wanted it that way, and that is how it was. ''Domineering'' was the complaint that was regularly raised against her, and it was a fair charge. A jutting chin helped the image, and so did Miss Fox's prickly temperament and formidable size.

title: Five Star Flight Beats Lord Avie at Monmouth
description: Five Star Flight set the pace, then held on to defeat Lord Avie by five lengths in the $200,000 Haskell Invitational Handicap for 3-year-olds at Monmouth Park today.

title: Pattern of Abuse Found On Ship of Dead Sailor
description: The death of a jailed sailor on the aircraft carrier Ranger was the result of a pattern of abuse of ship prisoners by 16 guards, Navy legal officers have charged.

title: ULSTER'S LOST GENERATION
description: John Conroy is a Chicago-based freelance writer. He received an Alicia Patterson Fellowship to report on the troubles in West Belfast, where he lived for more than a year. By John Conroy The first killing Sean Nolan remembers took place about 1 o'clock of an August morning 12 years ago when police opened fire on the Divis Flats housing project in Belfast. Sean was 6 years old. He remembers mattresses against the windows of the family's flat and the noise of machine-gun fire. He crept under his bed and wept. Later he learned that his playmate Patrick Rooney had been killed when a bullet passed through his head.

title: Bridge; A SLY DEFENSIVE COUP OF OLYMPIAN QUALITY
description: It is regrettable that the Olympic Games excludes bridge and chess from its activities by virtue of a rule that insists on physical exertion: Whether a few pulls on a pistol trigger is more exhausting than lifting some 2,000 playing cards could be argued.

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: Sidney Zion placed a great deal of emphasis on the kind of music he prefers as being ''sophisticated,'' which prompted me to look the word up - the Oxford English Dictionary gives as its primary definition: ''mixed with some foreign substance; adulterated, not pure or genuine.'' A small point. JAMES T. PENDERGRAST

title: ROBERT MOSES' RICH LEGACY FOR L.I.
description: OLIVER WENDELL HOLMES once said, ''I find the great thing in this world is not so much where we stand, as in what direction we are moving. To reach the Port of Heaven, we must sail sometimes with the wind and sometimes against it -but we must sail, and not drift, nor lie at anchor.''

title: Donald Barrett to Wed Shawna Deery
description: Shawna Elizabeth Deery, a member of the retail promotion staff of Revlon Inc. in New York, and Donald Vail Barrett, a lawyer, will be married on Aug. 29 in Marblehead, Mass. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John A. Deery of Marblehead, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Barrett is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Halsey V. Barrett of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Critic's Choices
description: DANCE The people at Guild Hall's John Drew Theater in East Hampton weren't joking when they called their dance festival ''50 Years of American Dance.'' The lineup for the festival, which runs from Tuesday through Saturday, touches a surprising number of bases.

title: TRANSIT PANEL DROPS THREATS OF DISMISSAL FOR PUBLIC CRITICISM
description: The Transit Authority has agreed to withdraw a longstanding order that prohibited subway and bus employees from talking publicly about the maintenance and operation of the city's transit system.

title: Zemma C. Mastin To Marry Sept. 5
description: Zemma Crawford Mastin and Edmund James White plan to be married Sept. 5. The future bride is the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles O'Fallon Mastin of Easton, Md., who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Matthew White of Middlebury, Conn., and Brownsville, Vt.

title: Other National Events; Environmental Decisions Delayed
description: Washington's environmental climate is, not suprisingly, turning out turbulent. Because of internecine debate on whether to subject current clean air standards to cost-benefit analysts and because of Congressional quarrels over how current clean water programs should proceed, the Administration last week deferred making recommendations on the former and reiterated its opposition to any more money for the latter.

title: MULTI-TOWN PROJECT GETS A DEADLINE AS GARBAGE MOUNTS
description: THE Supervisors of Huntington and Babylon are expressing confidence in officials of the Multi-Town Solid Waste Management Authority who have been under fire and who could be removed under new state legislation.

title: BIG LAW FIRMS TO PAY $43,000
description: Law school graduates starting their first jobs at some large New York law firms this year will be paid as much as $43,000 annually, according to a survey released by The National Law Journal.

title: No Headline
description: The Yankees announced a revised promotional schedule Saturday for the remainder of the 1981 season.

title: 26,000 Steelworkers Strike in Canada
description: About 26,000 steelworkers demanding higher wages walked off their jobs today, shutting down two companies that together accounted for more than half of Canada's steel production last year.

title: Rebecca Singer Married
description: The marriage of Rebecca Singer, president and designer-director of the Rebecca Singer Studio Inc., film design in New York, to Frederick Yestadt, a senior designer with the Gruzen Partnership, architects in New York, took place yesterday. Rabbi Arnold Kaiman performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Heisler, brother-in-law and sister of the bride, in Evanston, Ill. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. David Singer of Wheeling, Ill., and Mr. and Mrs. James Yestadt of Baton Rouge, La.

title: EARTHLY DANGERS
description: THE MONTAUK FAULT By Herbert Mitgang. 285 pp. New York: Arbor House. $12.95. By PETER ANDREWS

title: Diana Leslie Kirk Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Diana Leslie Kirk to Harry Livingstone Barrett 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Barrett Jr. of Wayland, Mass., took place yesterday at the Concord (Mass.) Academy Chapel. The bride is a daughter of Eleanor Huser Kirk of Bronxville, N.Y., and John Grayson Kirk of New York and a granddaughter of Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, president emeritus of Columbia University. The Rev. Kenneth Sawyer of the First Parish Unitarian Church in Wayland performed the ceremony.

title: Ana Borgersen, Ernest Biddle Jr., Artist, Are Wed
description: Ana Christina Borgersen and Ernest Law Biddle Jr. plan to be married Sept. 19.

title: WHAT HATH SUN AND SOIL WROUGHT?
description: THE first summer, their backyard was typically suburban, just like every other one in the neighborhood. Those few essential tomato plants flourished in a sunny corner, marigolds predominated in a group of easy annuals, a couple of climbing roses embraced the splitrail fence that separated our two properties and three hybrid teas bloomed well into autumn. There were also a well-used set of backyard swings, assorted tricycles and four lively youngsters.

title: Jupiter and Saturn Not Visible Together at Night Until 2000
description: Jupiter and Saturn will disappear from the night sky in September, not to be clearly seen together again until the year 2000, an Adler Planetarium astronomer says.

title: On Language; IN DEFENSE OF GENDER
description: So pervasive is the neutering of the English language on the progressive West Coast, we no longer have people here, only persons: male persons and female persons, chairpersons and doorpersons, waitpersons, mailpersons - who may be either male or female mailpersons - and refuse-collection persons. In the classified ads, working mothers seek child-care persons, though one wonders how many men (archaic for ''male person'') take care of child persons as a fulltime occupation. One such ad, fusing nonsexist language and the most popular word in the California growth movement, solicits a ''nurtureperson.''

title: RIGHTS GROUPS APPALUD HOUSING BIAS RULING
description: When William P. Phillips began househunting here two years ago, he was an affluent man in search of confirmation. Mr. Phillips, the owner of a chain of car washes in Chicago, lived in a $175,000 home in the leafy suburb of Homewood, but he wanted one in Oak Brook

title: Television Week
description: GBS From PBS ''The general opinion of Shaw,'' said Edwin Burr Pettet, ''is that he was a curmudgeon, a nasty sort of person. This is, of course, a popular misconception.

title: Jersey Bell Granted Increase In Its Charges for Installation
description: State utility regulators have approved a request from New Jersey Bell to increase rates for installing, moving and changing telephone service, the company said today.

title: Headliners; Past Differences
description: Asked by The Paris Review to comment on a recent article, Martha Gellhorn responded with a broadside that included an attack on Lillian Hellman and her account of how things were in Spain in the late 1930's, and, in various places and times, in the company of Ernest Hemingway. Miss Gellhorn, once married to Hemingway, maintained that Miss Hellman's recollections - contained in a memoir written 12 years ago - were mostly fancy. Miss Hellman, who a year ago sued Mary McCarthy (for calling her a ''dishonest writer''), asserted that she would shrug it all off.

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: Mr. Zion will be happy to know that, from 1973 to 1977, the singing group I belonged to at Yale opened every concert and happy hour with ''Alexander's Ragtime Band'' and closed with ''Istanbul.'' Out of a dozen or so songs I helped arrange, the most popular were ''Goody, Goody,'' ''Your Feet's Too Big'' and ''Let's Do It.'' Many other groups at Yale (most notably the Whiffenpoofs) and other colleges all had similar repertories. RICHARD BROOKHISER

title: OUTLOOK STILL UNCERTAIN FOR LAW-OF-SEA TALKS
description: The United Nations Law of the Sea conference, the most ambitious treaty-making effort ever undertaken by the world body, reconvenes here Monday with no assurance that it can escape the doldrums into which it was plunged by the advent of the Reagan Administration.

title: Art; NEWARK MUSEUM OFFERS AN ARTIST'S TOUR OF ROME
description: ROME is a city of mightiness and monumentality. Its leaders have been caesars, emperors and popes. In antiquity and during the Renaissance and Baroque periods, they embellished the city with the most majestic of buildings and fountains and the grandest of paintings.

title: Politics; IF WILLIAMS LEAVES
description: POLITICS, like nature, abhors a vacuum, and so there is more talk these days about who might succeed Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. than who might be the state's next Governor.

title: Sports; A LONG SHOT AIMS FOR JETS
description: HEMPSTEAD EACH year, an average of two make a team, sometimes three. Pro football calls them free agents - players who did not graduate from college, or who weren't drafted by a National Football League team, or who played weekend football in semipro leagues in mill towns. In other words, they're hoping for a job.

title: DAVID RIZZO IS FIANCE OF REBECCA ANN KIRBY
description: Rebecca Ann Kirby and David Paul Rizzo, marketing representatives for the International Business Machines Corporation in Boston, will be married in September. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Kirby of Chicago, parents of the future bride. Mr. Rizzo is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Rizzo of Armonk, N.Y.

title: Smothered Onions
description: After reading William Safire's article, ''Carte Before the Horse'' (On Language, July 5), I realized he needs a culinary education, and menu writers deserve an apology. Alas, the poor onion is truly smothered.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 13 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, 2 2 17 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 3 6 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood. 4 4 8 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 5 7 3 THE CLOWNS OF GOD, by Morris West. (Morrow, $14.95.) What happens when the Pope has a revelation that the end of the world is near and the Cardinals force him to abdicate. 6 1 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 7 5 15 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.)

title: STOCKTON AND GLICKSTEIN IN JERSEY FINAL
description: Dick Stockton, a former world-class player who is seeking a return to form, reached the final round of the $125,000 Mutual Benefit Life Open today by beating Nick Saviano, 6-3, 6-2, at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: CAR STEREO SYSTEMS BREAK NEW GROUND
description: For motorized listeners, the pleasures of summer are sometimes marred by molten cassettes. Leave them in he glove compartment on a sunny day, close the windows and lock the car, and when you get back from the beach or the golf course your music may be twisted into a pretzel. Baking in the sun, your car becomes an oven with temperatures high enough to soften the plastic shells of your stereo cassettes. As a result, the alignment of the tape within the shell gets skewed and it will no longer play properly. At best, the highs are lost due to improper contact between the tape and the magnetic head in your car stereo player or the music fades in and out erratically. At worst, the tape may jam altogether.

title: Long Islanders; MAKING HER IMPRINT ON PUBLISHING
description: ''I ALWAYS wanted to have something to do with books,'' said Eleanor Friede as she discussed her childhood in Valley Stream. Mrs. Friede got precisely what she had hoped for. The day after her graduation cum laude from Hofstra in 1942, she entered publishing. Now she can look back on such jobs as sales correspondent; assistant to the president (in her mid-20's); head of promotion, advertising and publishing; reader and book reviewer (during a ''retirement'' from 1961 to 1965, when her husband, Donald Friede, died); marketing director, and editor (including one of the great best sellers of all time) with such companies as McGraw-Hill, Funk & Wagnalls, World and Macmillan.

title: READY TO SAY 'My Friend Ron'
description: President Anwar el-Sadat will get acquainted with President Reagan this week at a moment when events have forced the United States to take a fresh look at its Middle East priorities. Mr. Sadat, already popular in Washington, can be expected to make the most of the ambiguities injected into Reagan Administration policies after the shocks of Israeli bombing raids on Iraq's nuclear reactor and on targets in Lebanon, where hundreds of civilians were killed.

title: SCHOOL BUS DRIVERS SOUGHT
description: ''WE now have more openings for school bus drivers than at any time in our history,'' said John Silvanie, general manager of Vanguard Tours, in announcing the opening of the company's drive to recruit school bus drivers.

title: The World in Summary; Mideast Truce Is Sticking, Mostly
description: Judging that restraint was more profitable than reprisal - at least in the present international context -Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Palestinian leaders kept alive their limited cease-fire last week. Though the truce passed a stress test, it was not without violence.

title: YOUTHS STEP UP AT ARTS WORKSHOP
description: GREAT NECK THE beat is gospel, and the chorus line of 12 youngsters is really projecting the music and the movement. It is a rehearsal of ''Don't Plan for Me,'' the latest musical to survive the rigors of a beginning at the Writers in Residence program. After a performance Saturday at Eisenhower Park's Lakeside Theater, the participants hope it will end up Off Broadway.

title: The Region in Summary; Tank Car Fire Disrupts Newark
description: Of all the ways in which hazardous materials are shipped, Federal officials say, railroads are by the far the safest. It would have been hard to convince firefighters in New Jersey last week, though, as a 26,000-gallon tank car loaded with highly volatile ethylene oxide was punctured while being coupled at a Newark freightyard, caught fire and burned for 40 hours.

title: Fashion; THE HAVE-TO-HAVES
description: For each new season, there are a few basics - special separates and accessories - that a woman has to have to bring her wardrobe up to date. This fall, there are several musts: a wide, leather wrap belt; a full wool skirt; a large shawl; flat- or low-heeled boots or shoes, and several pairs of opaque or knit stockings.

title: ATLANTIC CITY AWAITS GOVERNORS
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE 73d annual meeting of the National Governors Association, to be held next week, is expected to be the most heavily covered event here since the Democratic National Convention of 1964, and this resort city is striving to put its best image forward.

title: D. F. Winter, Miss Stillger Are Married
description: Delphine Marie-Pierre Stillger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter M. Stillger of Muttontown, L.I., and Windham, N.Y., was married at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L.I., yesterday to Duncan Forbes Winter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Burritt Winter of Garden City and Windham.

title: James Colthup to Wed Margaret Gray
description: The engagement of Margaret Anne Gray to James Cameron Colthup has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Steele Gray Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. James Frederick Colthup of Englewood, N.J., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I., and the late Mr. Colthup.

title: Footnotes
description: The one new hardcover novel on this week's list, Lawrence Sanders's ''The Third Deadly Sin,'' continues in the Sanders digital tradition. Besides the first and second deadly sins, Mr. Sanders has found titular inspiration in the Sixth and Tenth Commandments.

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: While as music lovers we enjoyed Sidney Zion's piece and took heart in his premise that melody has begun to ''slip back in,'' one point needs clarification: CBS Records did not (in 1972) ''drop Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic.'' In fact, Mr. Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic have recorded for Columbia Records (CBS Masterworks) as recently as 1980, with the release of the Shostakovich Symphony No. 5. FRANCIS LITTLE Director, Advertising and Public Information

title: Kristin Hubbard Bride of Lawyer
description: Kristin Kuhns Hubbard of New York was married yesterday to Richard Warren Gerrity of Albany at St. James' Episcopal Church in Arlington, Vt. The Rev. Douglas Culton performed the ceremony.

title: The World in Summary; Mrs. Thatcher Bows to Realities
description: Margaret Thatcher's initial response to British rioting was morally unassailable but not very practical. She urged parents to teach their children respect for law and order.

title: 2 EVENTS ADVANCE RACING
description: EAST RUTHERFORD TWO events are scheduled this week that should end any doubts about the major-league caliber of harness racing and standardbred breeding in New Jersey.

title: AND SEAGRAM'S IRE
description: IN the ''Battle for Conoco'' few issues are less relevant than the ''Canadianization'' red herring. Let's talk facts.

title: Mount St. Helens Toll Rises
description: The Skamania County Coroner has issued presumptive death certificates for five of 25 persons still missing in the May 18, 1980, eruption of Mount St. Helens. The action by the coroner, Robert Leick, brought the official death toll to 40. Twenty other persons still are officially listed as missing.

title: MacPHAIL'S ROLE IN STRIKE SETTLEMENT CALLED CRUCIAL
description: Discussing the baseball strike and the plodding negotiations that stretched it to seven weeks, one owner said yesterday, ''You've got to wonder why, all of a sudden, the thing got settled.''

title: PRO HALL INDUCTS 4 MEMBERS
description: It was a rewarding day for the elderly citizens of professional football today, as well as for the Green Bay Packers.

title: No Headline
description: Owing to a mechanical error, a line was omitted from Gabriel Garcia Marquez's article on Ernest Hemingway in last week's Book Review (July 26). The affected sentence, which began in the left-hand column at the bottom of Page 16, should have read: ''In his historic interview with George Plimpton in The Paris Review, (Hemingway) showed for all time - contrary to the Romantic notion of creativity -that economic comfort and good health are conducive to writing; that one of the chief difficulties is arranging the words well; that when writing becomes hard it is good to reread one's own books, in order to remember that it always was hard; that one can write anywhere so long as there are no visitors and no telephone; and that it is not true that journalism finishes off a writer, as has so often been said - rather, just the opposite, so long as one leaves it behind soon enough.''

title: 'I HATE BLONDES,' ITALIAN COMEDY AT PLAZA
description: A comedy with a title like ''I Hate Blondes'' is bound, of course, to be full of blondes. And nobody hates them at all. The leading character would like, if anything, to have a blonde of his own. But he's a hard-boiled sort, or at least he's supposed to be. He's a writer of best-selling detective novels, and ''I Hate Blondes'' is the title of his latest tough-guy story.

title: ROYAL COUPLE EMBARK ON HONEYMOON CRUISE
description: Elated by a frenzied reception from the 30,000 people of this tiny but strategic British colony, the Prince and Princess of Wales sailed this evening into the Mediterranean twilight on a two-week honeymoon cruise.

title: KEAN SEEKS $100,000 A WEEK
description: UNION AT THE Kean for Governor headquarters here recently, staff members were still introducing themselves to each other, and the only hints of the frenetic activity to come were dozens of shiny black telephones and the electrical outlets for typewriters that lined the orange carpet. One filing cabinet stood alone in the corner of the main room of the two-story office building, and there were no placards, posters or other material to remind a visitor that Thomas H. Kean is the Republican candidate for Governor.

title: Architecture View; A PLAN TO PRESERVE THE UPPER EAST SIDE
description: The problems of building cities are enormous, and the way they are built has profound and inescapable consequences. Construction - and its converse, preservation - not only shape the city, they determine its future. Buildings form the framework for all the city's activities; their size, quality and distribution create its appeal and amenity, and control its financial and functional health.

title: WHAT ABOUT A FLYER IN C.D. FUTURES?
description: The arrival of a futures market in banks' certificates of deposit, in no fewer than three commodity exchanges since July 9, has presented small speculators with yet another way of playing the interest rate game. For a relatively small amount of money, they can now match wits with bankers and other money market operators in trying to call the turn in short-term interest rates.

title: Miss Forbes Is Married
description: The marriage of Moira Hamilton Forbes, editor of the Leader newspapers in Newtown Square, Pa., to Kenneth Bruce Mumma, a law student at Villanova University, took place in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday. The Rev. Alfred M. Niese Jr. performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. John on the Mountain Episcopal Church.

title: IS CHICAGO LOSING OUT IN THE ART WAR
description: CHICAGO Muriel Kallis Steinberg Newman has a big-league contemporary art collection with all the right stuff from the New York School. There's a de Kooning great, ''The Attic''; an enviable Jackson Pollock, ''Number 28''; a classic Franz Kline, ''Nijinsky,'' the requisite Motherwell ''Elegy,'' and lots of other things that any museum involved with the 20th-century would want. And when last December Mrs. Newman announced that her holdings would go at her death to the Metropolitan in New York instead of her native city's museum, the Art Institute of Chicago, art lovers here mourned as baseball fans might if the Cubs or the White Sox decamped for another city. (The Newman collection is now on view at the Metropolitan, through Sept. 27.)

title: CLASSES ON CHILDBIRTH
description: TO help prospective parents deal with the stress of an unexpected operation, childbirth educators on the Island are holding special Caesarean preparation sessions in which they explain the procedure and inform patients of the options they may discuss with their doctor.

title: Theater Mailbag; MORE ON MUSICALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish Communists Re-elect Carrillo Leader
description: The Spanish Communist Party today reelected Santiago Carrillo as its leader, a job he has held for the last 21 years.

title: APPLE GROWERS EXPECTING FROST TO COST $40 MILLION
description: The income of New York State apple growers will drop about $40 million this year because of freezing weather that cut the 1981 crop by almost a third, according to a Cornell University fruit expert.

title: Sunday Observer; BEING RICH
description: In this fantasy I am a poor, shabby, but upright young man and appear at the entrance of the flossiest restaurant in town. Don't ask me why I want to go to a fancy restaurant since actually I hate to eat out, but anyhow I am greeted - in the fantasy, that is - by a snooty headwaiter who bars the door, saying, ''We do not traffic here with persons of your ilk.''

title: Mary Ellen Wenk Fiancee of John Fell, a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Wenk of Old Brookville and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ellen Wenk, to John Keith Fell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Fell of Garden City and Quogue, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: FRESH AIR FUND TRAVELERS RETURN AMID JOYFUL DIN
description: Around this time every year, a distinctly youthful tone is added to the usual commotion of arrivals and departures at Manhatan bus and train stations. The noise comes from the hundreds of children traveling out of town under the auspices of the Fresh Air Fund.

title: EAST GERMANY EASING CONTROLS ON CHURCHES
description: Communist East Germany, in a move away from trying to isolate the country's Christian believers, has embarked on an ambitious program of building new churches, restoring old religious buildings and honoring historic church leaders.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL BATTLES OBSCURITY
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY'S 38th Attorney General takes pleasure in telling this anecdote about himself: A County Prosecutor, teaching a class of 100 police officers recently, printed the name James R. Zazzali on the blackboard.

title: A NEW SET OF PRINCIPLES, PURSUED IN TOUGH TERMS
description: IT has been a little more than six months since Ronald Reagan's celebratory inauguration with its proclamations of ''heroic dreams'' and new beginnings. The Week in Review asked two political analysts to talk about the images and the realities of those first six months and what they may mean for the future -Harry C. McPherson Jr., a Washington attorney and former special counsel to President Johnson, and Ben J. Wattenberg, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and chairman of the Coalition for a Democratic Majority, formed in 1972 by Democrats opposed to the McGovern movement in their party. Excerpts of their discussion with Leslie H. Gelb, national security correspondent for The New York Times, Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, and Hedrick Smith, Washington correspondent for The Times, follow.

title: On The Isle; PHILHARMONIC REPRISE
description: Completing its weekend doubleheader on the Island, the New York Philharmonic appears at Eisenhower Park's Meadow today at 8 P.M., where, under the baton of Edo de Waart, it will perform Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique,'' Barber's ''School for Scandal'' and Tchaikovsky's ''1812 Overture.'' Bring your own seating to this free concert in East Meadow. DAY LILY FESTIVAL

title: TOFU, TOFU EVERYWHERE
description: Turn down the Sony and take a deep breath - yet another product from the Orient is sprouting in the West. Tofu (pronounced variously TOE-foo or DOE-fu) long a staple food in China, Japan and environs, is fighting for a place in the home of the Big Mac.

title: A POLITICAL REALIGNMENT JUST MAY BE UNDER WAY
description: With his latest dazzling legislative triumph on tax reductions, President Reagan has done far more than outwit the Democrats in the 97th Congress. For even if they somehow regroup and defeat him on some other important issue, this victory has changed the field of play for politics in Washington and the nation. Mr. Reagan's tax and spending cuts together mean there will be much less room to maneuver in Government, especially for running left.

title: Raider Jury Recesses
description: The jury in the trial of the antitrust suit brought by the Oakland Raiders and Los Angeles Coliseum Commission against the National Football League completed its fourth day of deliberations today without reaching a verdict. Court Clerk Richard Johnson said the jury, which received the case after 55 days of testimony, will resume deliberations Monday.

title: ARCHEOLOGISTS REPORT FINDING SACRED ARK FROM 3D CENTURY AT SITE IN
description: ISRAEL BY JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

title: Long Island Housing; HOUSING EASES FOR COLLEGE STUDENT
description: THERE is still a shortage of housing for college students, but at some of the schools, new construction and other measures such as leasing space have substantially narrowed the gap between supply and demand.

title: THE QUIET REPEAL OF THE CORPORATE INCOME TAX
description: WASHINGTON CORPORATE income taxes may soon be a relic, the lingering remnant of a once mighty revenue flow. President Reagan has won for business the largest tax reductions in memory, and as prodigious as they are, they are also a kind of culmination of a quieter trend, a decades-old ebbing of income taxes on business corporations. By the close of this decade, economists and tax specialists say, taxes on the profits of big business will have faded to a trickle.

title: Mary Runser, Film Aide, Bride of Kevin Marrazzo
description: Mary Ray Runser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Runser of Hightstown, N.J., was married there yesterday to Kevin Marrazzo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Marrazzo of Yardville, N.J. The Rev. Thomas S. Triggs, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the nondenominational Ayer Memorial Chapel of the Peddie School, the couple's alma mater.

title: GLAMOUR IN THE BOARDROOM, CAUTION IN THE FOOD GAME
description: PITTSBURGH T HE air was thick with rumors of multibillion-dollar acquisitions, and Tony O'Reilly, his suitcase packed, was headed to New York to attend a meeting last month of the board of directors of Mobil Oil. The outcome of the meeting was, indeed, a multibillion-dollar bid for Conoco.

title: CONGRESS NOW SUFFERS FROM LOSS OF MEMORY
description: WASHINGTON AS House Democratic Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. has lost round after round to President Reagan, the patterns of his mind have often seemed more rooted in poignancy than in strategy. His appeals to fellow Democrats to stand up to the White House have been expressed in terms of memory and time, not victory and defeat. ''This is a horrendous thing to do to these people,'' he said, summoning up the needy hordes of the faded New Deal in trying to protect Democratic social programs from cuts. ''Here's a group that was born in the '20's, suffered in the '30's Depression, went to war in the '40's, came back, raised families, and helped make America great in the '50's and '60's.''

title: 'We've Lost Control of Our Borders'
description: After several false starts, President Reagan has finally proposed his immigration reform. But the package is so disappointing one wonders what took so long. Key features are seriously flawed, almost ludicrously in the matter of regulating immigrant labor. Congress will not find it helpful in drafting legislation. And it displays an Administration so irresolute that it raises doubts about whether whatever Congress enacts will be fairly and vigorously enforced.

title: Carol Heilshorn Bride of Lawyer
description: Carol Lee Heilshorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Heilshorn of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Charles Roberts Ebersol Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ebersol of Litchfield, Conn. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg performed the ceremony at the Garden City Community Church.

title: UNPUBLISHED POEMS
description: Sylvia Plath's reputation as one of America's finest contemporary poets was achieved with the posthumous publication of ''Ariel'' in 1965, two years after her suicide in London. Popular interest in her life was aroused in 1971 by the American publication of ''The Bell Jar,'' an autobiographical novel about the nervous breakdown she suffered in college. (The novel had been published pseudonymously in England in 1962.) This fall Harper & Row will bring out ''The Collected Poems,'' a gathering of all of Plath's mature poetry and some juvenilia. The three poems below, previously unpublished, have been taken from this volume. Copyright c 1981 by Ted Hughes.

title: Crafts; CERAMICS FIRES ARTIST'S ELOQUENCE
description: week master ceramics class at the prestigious Haystack Mountain School of Crafts on Maine's idyllic Deer Isle. With luck, Mrs. Dintenfass may have the opportunity between her classes to relax and enjoy the surroundings, a welcome respite from the frenetic pace she has been maintaining during the last few weeks.

title: Edward J. Marshall Jr.  To Wed Ann Driscoll
description: Announcement has been made by Catherine Ridder Wetzel of Belford, N.J., and John Ryder Driscoll of East Norwich, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Ann Elizabeth Driscoll, to Edward John Marshall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.

title: SMOTHERED ONIONS
description: William Safire's observations remind me of my grandfather's story about a butcher shop on the Lower East Side. Beneath the large, printed Yiddish sign - ''Fresh Kosher Chicken'' - there was a handwritten assurance in English - ''I kill myself twice daily.'' STEVEN S. KRON, M.D.

title: EISENHOWER
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAKESPEARE'S COMMONERS GET THE ROYAL TREATMENT
description: LONDON Reflecting the current English concern with royalty and history, this season the London theater has been reconsidering its own past - Shakespeare, his contemporaries and their immediate successors. In many ways this has been a celebratory time, with an abundance of classical poetry readings and a revival by the Royal Shakespeare Company of ''The Hollow Crown,'' its collage view of the monarchy. Not only Farquhar, but Ben Jonson, George Chapman, John Marston and Thomas Dekker have all been represented on various stages.

title: Correction
description: In a chart accompanying the article, ''Boom Times for the Builders of New York'' (July 26), it was incorrectly re ported that Tishman Realty and Construction built the John Hancock Building in Boston.

title: GIANT NOSE TACKLE JOB STILL WIDE OPEN
description: Hello, my name is George Small and I'm the starting nose tackle for the Giants. Hello, my name is Jim Burt and I'm the starting nose tackle for the Giants. Hello, my name is Bill Neill and I'm the starting nose tackle for the Giants. To tell the truth, any of those salutations could be true because the Giants are still undecided on who will start at nose tackle. The position is important because it is the middle spot of the defense Coach Ray Perkins has been trying to install from the first day of camp.

title: POLISH POLITBURO SEES GREAT DANGER IN STREET MARCHES
description: Reacting to a wave of demonstrations and calls for strikes to protest food shortages, the Polish Communist Party's ruling Politburo warned the independent trade union today that unrest could lead to ''an explosion of nationwide conflict.''

title: SLOWLY, WOMEN PROGRESS IN COMMERCIAL BROKERAGE
description: When George Israel suggested to his daughter Ellen that she forgo graduate work in Soviet studies and join him as a commercial real estate broker, it was because he wanted to assure her financial success. But neither he nor his colleagues at N. Peter Burton, a small Manhattan brokerage company, would have guessed that the 23-year old Miss Israel would negotiate a $40 million sale as one of her first deals.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 IF THERE BE THORNS, by V.C. Andrews.

title: PLAN THE GARDEN FOR A FAMILY'S NEEDS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Anna Browder is a freelance writer who gardens in New England. By ANNA BROWDER

title: CAESAREAN BIRTHS RISE ON L.I.
description: THE dedication next Friday of Nassau Hospital's $14 million Maternity and Child Care Center, the newest medical facility of its kind on Long Island in 10 years, comes at a time when the Island's Caesarean birth rate is climbing faster than the national rate.

title: Raccoon Rabies Is Detected In Virginia and West Virginia
description: Widespread rabies in raccoons has been detected in Virginia and West Virginia, representing a 300-mile rise in the lethal infection from the nearest recognized focus of the disease in South Carolina.

title: MISS KENNEDY, BANKER, FIANCEE
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kennedy of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sean Kennedy, to Paul Dominick Console, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick J. Console of Wethersfield, Conn.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT'S IMPACT DEBATED
description: WATERFORD EVEN more than OPEC price-setting sessions, the Millstone 3 nuclear ower plant here, now 40 percent complete, may determine what Connecticut consumers will pay for energy in the years ahead.

title: The Viewpoint Of Another Generation
description: Among recent Opinion Page articles were three concerned with children: One couple will retain their suburban home as an intermittent haven for their children; another parent agonizes as well as delights in the turmoil his college-age daughter brings home with her for the summer; the third has very real problems making ends meet while rearing three children.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CABARET Two unusually piquant singer-songwriter-pianists will team up when Blossom Dearie and Dave Frishberg move into Michael's Pub on Tuesday for a four-week engagement.

title: Music; ETHNIC CELEBRATIONS SCHEDULED BY PARKS
description: ETHNIC groups in the county are celebrating their heritage - enjoying special foods, dances and crafts and sharing their customs with their county neighbors, all courtesy of the Westchester Parks system.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW
description: August 2, 1981 NONFICTION COMMON GROUND: A Naturalist's Cape Cod. By Robert Finch. 13 ETHNIC AMERICA: A History. By Thomas Sowell. 1 GET REALLY RICH IN THE COMING SUPER METALS BOOM.

title: AUTO INSURANCE: TRENTON'S VIEW
description: THE June 28 article on the recent order by Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran directing automobile insurers to change their ratemaking methodologies is a monument to the misinformation upon which the industry has relied in perpetrating the present system for so many years.

title: Claire D. Blaine Married to Lawrence C. Robert Jr.
description: Claire Denise Blaine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Blaine Jr. of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday to Lawrence Charles Robert Jr., son of Mr. Robert and Marie W. Robert, both of New Orleans. The Rev. Thomas Gillin performed the ceremony at St. Katharine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Antigobbledygook
description: Not too long after taking office this year, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige set out to vanquish a formidable Washington foe: bureaucratic language. He ordered his executive staff to shun such words as ''prioritize'' and to favor ''short sentences and short words, with emphasis on plain English, using no more words than effective expression requires.''

title: IDLE DICE WINS AGAIN
description: Idle Dice, 18 years old and the greatest show-ring money winner in history, won the $5,000 Grand Prix qualifyi

title: Dining Out; HIGH MARKS FOR SOPHISTICATED INN
description: OLD LYME WHEN the Old Lyme Inn was first reviewed in this column three and a half years ago, it won a well-deserved three-star accolade. Some time after that, the inn's gifted chef, Steve Wilkinson, left to open his own restaurant (Fine Bouche) a few miles away, and there was apprehension among devotees that the Old Lyme, still a new venture at the time, might not be able to weather the loss.

title: AN EDUCATIONAL PANACEA PROPOSAL
description: I HAVE the solution to all of the problems facing New Jersey public education. The solution, if I may speak with some pride of discovery, is dazzling in its simplicity, simple in its implementation and, hard as it is to believe, does not require additional funds.

title: JACOBO TIMERMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen McGrath to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. David J. McGrath of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Ann McGrath, to Walter Franklin Morris, son of Mrs. Lawrence Drake of Phoenixville, Pa., and the late Caspar Wistar Morris Jr.

title: Food; ELEGANT CHICKEN
description: Whenever we visit the meat counter of our favorite supermarket, we are always impressed with the fact that chicken breasts are one of the least expensive of all meats sold. We are doubly impressed by the fact that chicken breasts, throughout a long period of culinary history, have been considered one of the most elegant basics of cooking.

title: NEWARK PLANS COURT APPEAL ON POLICE CHIEF
description: NEWARK CONTROVERSY over the appointment of Police Chief Charles M. Zizza continued to boil here last week, with officials preparing an appeal of a court ruling that declared unconstitutional a state law that authorized Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson to appoint a chief outside the ranks of Civil Service.

title: Food; ONE-STOP SHOPS FILL PARTY NEEDS
description: ISLAND PARK WITH more than a hundred different bottles of California cabernet sauvignon displayed in a local liquor store and a neighboring specialty shop offering French goat cheeses, 25-year-old vinegars and homemade broccoli pasta, a strip along this small village's main street attracts customers who enjoy one-stop shopping for home entertaining.

title: STRIP-MINING FOES WIN SUIT ON RIGHT TO SPEAK OUT
description: A coal company's libel suit against two environmental groups and one of their leaders has been halted by a ruling from the West Virginia Supreme Court.

title: Heart-Lung Transplant Fails and a Patient Dies
description: The Stanford University Medical Center today reported the first death among its heart-lung transplant patients.

title: JAWORSKI DETERMINED TO WIN SUPER BOWL
description: Ron Jaworski says the terms in the National Football League are pretty close to equal and that what made his team, the Philadelphia Eagles, so distinctive last season was "attitude and hard work." Jaworski had his best season and the Eagles their best in 31 years as they won the National Conference championship before losing to Oakland in the Super Bowl.For the Eagles, it was not enough.

title: Mary Woolverton And David Sims, A Reporter, Wed
description: Mary Chadwick Woolverton, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John Frederick Woolverton of Alexandria, Va., and Center Sandwich, N.H., was married yesterday to David Lewis Sims, son of Bishop Bennett J. Sims of the Episcopal Diocese of Atlanta and Mrs. Sims. The fathers of the couple performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Federated Church of Center Sandwich.

title: Donna J. Kanner To Wed Dec. 19
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kanner of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Wellfleet, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Jean Kanner, to James Richard McGowan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. McGowan Jr. of Morris Township, N.J. and Siesta Key, Fla.

title: 34 FOOD OUTLETS CITED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health has cited 34 food establishments for violations of the Health Code. In addition, it said that three establishments had reopened after new inspections and that five had been closed for failing to comply with regulations.

title: Television Week
description: Mortal Peril Terrorists have seized an oil tanker in New York Harbor off the World Trade Center and informed the Government that its crewmen will be executed, its cargo spilled into the Hudson and the explosives-laden ship blown up unless their demands are met.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: LOVERS AND MOVIES
description: PAINTED DRESSES By Shelby Hearon. 270 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95. COMING ATTRACTIONS By Fannie Flagg. 320 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.95. By LAURA CUNNINGHAM

title: Catherine Murray Is Bride in Darien Of Ronald A. Jellison, Financial Aide
description: Catherine Bradley Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Murray of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Ronald Alan Jellison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Jellison of El Segundo, Calif. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: The Region in Summary; Prison System's; Musical Chairs
description: With empty cells as scarce as seats on the IRT at rush hour, the question of whether the punishment fits the crime sometimes seems less urgent to New York officials than whether prisoners will fit in the prison. Last week, a Federal judge who had already ruled that the city jail on Rikers Island had more than its share ordered 530 of the inmates transferred to facilities run by the state.

title: Eye Bank in New York Selects New President
description: The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration Inc. has elected Wendy Hatch as its president, succeeding Dr. Donald M. Shafer. Mrs. Hatch has been a director of the organization since 1975 and a member of its executive board for more than a year. Dr. Shafer was named chairman of the medical advisory board, a new organization of doctors that was established to provide more structured supervision of the medical and research aspects of the eye bank's work.

title: Other National Events; Contract Proposal Doesn't Fly
description: The air traffic controllers' union overwhelmingly turned down an agreement with Washington, a vote count last week showed.

title: Headliners; Berrigans Sentenced
description: ''We are willing to go to jail for our version of the truth,'' Philip Berrigan said last week as he and his brother, the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, and six other members of the Plowshares Eight appeared in a Pennsylvania state court for sentencing.

title: Children's Books
description: BRIDGES A Project Book. By Anne and Scott MacGregor. Illustrated. 56 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. Paper, $5.95.(Ages 9 to 12) By SHERWIN D.SMITH

title: Connecticut Journal
description: ANYONE wondering why the General Assembly created eight new Superior Court judgeships earlier this year might consider the report issued last Thursday by Justice John A. Speziale, the state's Chief Court Administrator.

title: Donna Caponi In Lead
description: Donna Caponi broke away from the pack with a third consecutive sub-par round today to take a three-stroke lead in a $150,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: LONG ROAD, ABRUPT HALT
description: An ''insult to the taxpayer'' is what Sue Long calls it.''It'' is a little something included in the House tax package that would exempt the Internal Revenue Service from complying with requests under the Freedom of Information Act to release data used by the agency to choose tax returns for auditing.

title: BROOKE SHIELDS AND COMPANY - MANUFACTURING A SUPERSTAR
description: She is the girl of the moment. The new goddess. The gold mine. Her new movie, ''Endless Love,'' together with her constant appearance on magazine covers, television commercials and in gossip columns speculating about romance with John Travolta, have made Brooke Shields one of those cultural phenomena of American society whose genesis demands scrutiny.

title: Tuition Tax Credits And Their Effect
description: In arguing for tuition tax credits for parents of children in nonpublic schools (Letters to the Editor), Eileen Horan presents some interesting data. Where she argues that ''the only tax monies involved are those of the individual who claims the credit,'' however, she is wrong.

title: Alison Hopfield, Charles C. Lifland Wed in Princeton
description: Alison Hopfield, daughter of Prof. and Mrs John J. Hopfield of Pasadena, Calif., was married yesterday to Charles Coleman Lifland, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Lifland of Princeton, N.J. Mayor Robert Cawley of Princeton Borough officated at the garden ceremony at the Princeton home of the bridegroom's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Abbot Low Moffat.

title: ENDURANCE RACES SIDETRACKED
description: By STEVE POTTER The appearance of endurance racing cars, the type of vehicles that compete at Le Mans and other long-distance races, is about to change. But American racing fans apparently won't get to see the new cars, except in photographs. A disagreement between the people who run the North American races and the Europeans who make the rules has led to the removal of the traditional Dayton 24 Hour and Watkins Glen six-hour races from the international calendar.

title: AS HE WALKED THE ISLAND, A VISION GREW
description: Following are excerpts from ''The Power Broker,'' Robert A. Caro's Pulitzer-Prize-winning biography of Robert Moses, who died last week at the age of 92:

title: A TALE OF LOVE AND IDOLTRY
description: THE TEMPTATION OF EILEEN HUGHES By Brian Moore. 211 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. By JOYCE CAROL OATES

title: Washington; A DECEPTIVE PAUSSE
description: At the beginning of August, Washington has a happy face. It is glorious in the sunshine. The news is good for a change. The Battle of the Budget is over. There is a truce in the Middle East. The baseball strike has ended and there was a fairy-tale wedding in London last week, a televised symbol of the more hopeful and amiable aspects of human life.

title: THEY MAKE MOVIES LOOK GOOD
description: One can go to the movies and even if one is turned off by the movie itself, one can be turned back on by the look of it. The ''look'' of it? What does that mean? I'm not exactly sure, though there seem to be a larger number of beautifully designed films available right now than at any time in the recent past. Maybe we're all just a little more conscious of what movie makers can do these days, especially when we compare the sort and amount of visual information we are given in films like Michael Wadleigh's ''Wolfen'' and Steven Spielberg's ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' with the run-of-the-mill stuff offered by television.

title: LUCE OF CON ED RECALLS CAREER, WORK IN COUNTY
description: WHEN I joined Con Edison in August 1967 two things especially struck me about our operations in Westchester County. Too many decisions affecting Con Edison's service to Westchester customers were being made at company headquarters in Manhattan. And the Westchester electric and gas distribution systems, and the equipment used to maintain them, needed improvement.

title: SHE HEALS AILING NEIGHBORHOODS
description: ''This is really a woman's profession,'' Megan Charlop said, thumbing her baggy bib overalls. ''It is women in the buildings, saving them from abandonment. They are the ones who stick with it, going through the first winters.''

title: Speaking Personally; WHOEVER SAID IT WAS SO PEACEFUL IN THE COUNTRY?
description: IDROVE to Princeton recently with a young woman who wants a house in the country just like mine. She is a single parent who works hard at a consuming job, and a place in the country - a place just like mine - is what she needs to return to each night to regain the vitality lost to the workaday world. Both she and her daughter could only benefit from life close to nature's earth, rather than suburbia's sidewalks.

title: SENEGALESE SAID TO CLOSE IN ON GAMBIA REBELS
description: Hours after Senegalese troops said they had recaptured the Gambian Government radio station from leaders of a leftist coup, the rebels resumed broadcasting today and issued new threats to kill a group of hostages unless the troops were withdrawn.

title: WATCH OUT FOR WALRUS MEAT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joseph Kastner writes frequently on natural sciences. A MATTER OF DEGREE Heat, Life, and Death. By Lucy Kavaler. 226 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95. BY JOSEPH KASTNER

title: ERROR VOIDS JUDICIAL PRIMARY IN PHILADELPHIA
description: A three-judge panel has thrown out the entire May 19 Democratic primary for judges of the Philadelphia Common Pleas Court, adding a confusing wrinkle to this city's lively politics.

title: Editors' Choice
description: IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER, by Italo Calvino. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) A novel about reading fiction, by the Italian master.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; States Rights Win In Off Shore Oil Leasing Dispute
description: The Reagan Administration's stepped-up search for coastal oil deposits last week slowed to a walk. A Federal judge held that California can veto Government programs deemed inconsistent with its coastal management plan.

title: PANAMA LEADER KILLED IN CRASH IN BAD WEATHER
description: Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's strongman, was killed in the crash of a Panamanian Air Force plane in bad weather over western Panama, the National Guard announced today.

title: Deborah Jean Pierce Wed To Wilburn O. Bonnell 3d
description: Deborah Jean Pierce, daughter of Mrs. Edith Lauxman Pierce of Rye, N.Y., and the late Wilbur Parker Pierce, was married yesterday to Wilburn O. Bonnell 3d, son of Mr& and Mrs. Bonnell Jr. of Chicago. The Rev. Howard Major of the Rye Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the Rye home of Mr. and Mrs. Werner Linz, friends of the couple.

title: DANCE: PREMIERES AT THE JACOB'S PILLOW FESTIVAL
description: Last week's program at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival was called ''A Week of World Premieres.'' If that has a fairly grand ring, Thursday's performance proved that the program was, as Liz Thompson, Pillow director, put it in her front-of-curtain speech, ''a celebration of hard work and artistic achievement.'' Each of the four dances drew on either students or faculty at the Pillow's summer dance school. And each succeeded on its own terms as satisfying and even exciting dance.

title: A TALE OF TWO GUNMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Making the World Safe for Whales
description: For several kinds of whales - blue, fin, humpback, gray - protections imposed in the last few years may have come too late, many experts fear, to replenish the decimated species. But for the sperm whale there may yet be hope, given the International Whaling Commission's decision last week to impose a virtual ban after the 1981 season on hunting them.

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: As the best surviving 1927 jazz pianist in the business, I would like to believe Sidney Zion's report on the resurgence of the dead. But this morning I asked my resident expert, my 17-year-old son, Eric, what he thought about the revival of the big-band era, playing the music of the Gershwin era, and he replied: ''Who's Gershwin?'' JOHN HOHENBERG

title: 10-1 FIO RITO SCORES UPSET IN WHITNEY
description: In a dream come true for upstate breeders and racing fans, locally bred Fio Rito, owned by a bowlingalley proprietor from Rochester, upset horses owned by the Mellons and the Phippses in winning the $175,500 Whitney Handicap today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: WHEN CRITICS OF TV NEWS GET TO TALK BACK
description: If you want to talk back to television, how do you go about getting a fair hearing? Network editions of the news reach more than 35 million people every day. Even the lowest-rated documentary can claim an audience of millions. A mistake, no matter how unintentional, can be devastating to an individual or organization. Furthermore, even if the facts are correct, they often can be interpreted, honestly and legitimately, in ways different from the television news report. Over the years, however, complainers have learned that the television news wall is very nearly unbreachable. The medium has been unable - some would say unwilling - to develop effective mechanisms for airing serious objections to its content. Unlike the print press, television does not have such outlets as an Op-Ed page or a daily corrections box or, with the periodic exception of CBS News, a letters-to-the-editor format.

title: Essay; REPORT TO ANDROPOV
description: Boris Grishinurn, ace operative of the K.G.B. in Washington, who works under cover as hors d'oeuvres specialist at Ridgewell's Catering Service, is filing this report explaining the Casey case to Yuri Andropov, his boss in Moscow:

title: TRACY AUSTIN GAINS FINAL
description: Tracy Austin gained a spot in the final of the $125,000 Wells Fargo TEnnis Open today, beating Kathy Jordan, 6-1, 6-2, today.

title: BOARD SAILING RIDES A WAVE
description: RYE IT ALL started at the Stamford, Conn., Boat Show in 1975. Tom Consolazio, a well-known Rye boat dealer in the Milton Point area, was heading for a dock in a high-performance power boat when he noticed someone sailing by while standing on a board with a sail attached to it.

title: THE DODECANESE, 13 (OR 14) PLACES TO UNWIND
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- GEORGE VECSEY is a reporter for The New York Times. By GEORGE VECSEY

title: SEAGRAM CO. STARTS BUYING CONOCO STOCK
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Company, one of three concerns seeking to take over Conoco Inc., began buying shares of the fuel company yesterday at $92 a share.

title: The Editorial Notebook; TALE OF THE RODENT
description: The startled movement of a young woman in one corner of the bus shelter indicated that something was wrong. She moved again, a gesture of discomfort, even fear. Then I saw what troubled her: an infant rodent - perhaps mouse, perhaps rat - a small ball of brown cotton, with a toothpick for a tail. It had somehow crossed Seventh Avenue, climbed the curb and was moving through the shelter and across the sidewalk.

title: OUTLOOK BRIGHT FOR 'TRAIL'
description: EFFORTS to rescue the Connecticut section of the Applachian Trail from the encroachments of development are still being pressed by the National Park Service despite the mandate by the Reagan Administration to cut back on the service's land acquisition program, Park Service officials said last week.

title: Children's Books
description: BEARS IN THE WILD An Audubon Reader. By Ada and Frank Graham. Illustrated by D.D. Tyler. 111 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $8.95. (Ages 10 to 14) BLACK BEAR The Spirit of the Wilderness. By Barbara Ford. Illustrated. 182 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 16) A KILLING SEASON By Barbara Brenner. 182 pp. New York: Four Winds Press. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 15) By GEORGESS McHARGUE

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: Sidney Zion insisted on dividing the pie between rock and popular music. He does not seem to notice the tremendous cross-fertilization that has occurred in the last 30 years, with popular music, rhythmand-blues, jazz, country, rock and classical music all taking and giving to each other.

title: Outlasting Rock
description: As a 21-year-old who has never listened to any metal heavier than the clash of Gene Krupa's symbols, let me say -let me shout - Bravo, Sidney Zion, Bravo (''Outlasting Rock,'' June 21)! ANDREW PATNER, Chicago

title: RESIDENTIAL HOTEL DISPUTE BUILDS
description: Several years ago Gloria Gilbert answered an ad for ''spacious studios'' at 24 Fifth Avenue - the former Fifth Avenue Hotel. ''I was surprised to see the ad because I knew the Fifth Avenue Hotel from when I used to stay there with my parents,'' she recalled. But she said she was told by the real estate agent and building manager that the hotel was being converted into a rent-stabilized apartment building. So she signed a standard two-year apartment lease with riders attached saying that the owner reserved the right to discontinue any hotel services, that electric meters were to be installed and that she could sublet her apartment.

title: ERICKSON TAKES U.S. JUNIOR TITLE
description: Scott Erickson of Villa Park, Calif., took an early three-stroke lead and went on to defeat Matt McCarley of Camden, S.C., 4 and 3, today to win the United States Golf Association junior championship.

title: Television Week
description: Littorally Speaking At the age of 24, Amanda Kissin, who graduated from Barnard College in 1978, has to her credit three Emmy awards for local documentaries. Not content to rest on her already considerable collection of laurels, Miss Kissin has been out beachcombing, and the results will be visible Sunday night at 8 on Channel 5.

title: George G. Woody 3d Weds Michelle Oliver
description: Michelle Andrea Oliver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Oliver of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to George Grant Woody 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Woody Jr. of Roselle, N.J. The Rev. Calvin O. Butts performed the ceremony at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in New York.

title: Cold Spring Harbor Is the Place
description: The recent article ''Coach Set for Israeli Games'' lists my son, John Sices of Villanova, as one of the basketball players representing the United States team, and, needless to say, we're very proud of him. However, you have him listed as being from Howard Beach, which is incorrect. He is formerly of Cold Spring Harbor and is now a resident of Wallingford, Pa. SONDRA J. SICES

title: The Reagan Paradox
description: One thing is surely settled: the Presidency is no feeble office. Let a shrewd President single-mindedly pursue a policy broadly grounded in his election mandate, and he can put it across.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: NEW YORK METS (NL) - Restored Tim Leary, right-handed rookie pitcher, to active roster and assigned him to Tidewa- ter farm team in the International League for conditioning. FOOTBALL

title: Dining Out; SOMETHING IS AMISS IN SEA BRIGHT
description: THOSE who equate sumptuousness with fine dining will love the three-month-old Peninsula House in Sea Bright. The former beach clubhotel at the edge of the ocean has been turned into a showcase that Jay Gatsby would have appreciated.

title: Numismatics; A MILESTONE FOR THE NATIONAL ORGANIZATION
description: The annual convention of the American Numismatic Association draws to a close in New Orleans today, and as usual this has been a week of perpetual motion for the thousands of hobbyists who attended. The closing of the A.N.A. convention seems an appropriate time to take stock of what that organization has done - and what it is doing - for the hobby in general, and for its 39,000 members in particular.

title: BUILDING A TEAM WITH 'EXPERIENCED YOUTH'
description: IF you live in Bronxville, N.Y., and you've been wondering why your mail delivery was so speedy last spring, you can thank the Mercy College pitching staff.

title: THE PRICE OF A HAIRCUT IS GROWING APACE
description: WHILE it is still possible to get a basic, no-frills haircut in a few Westchester barbershops for as little as $2.75 and $3 - a bargain these days - the usual price is $5. But higher prices appear to be coming.

title: CASTING ABOUT FOR THE RIGHT LINE
description: I DROVE down to the beach at the end of Highberry Lane after supper one evening to sketch the fishermen. That's one of the best spots on Shelter Island for surfcasting. The fishermen were there, all right, but instead of fishing, most of them were gathered around a new, bright yellow Jeep that was sitting in the middle of the inlet leading into the wetlands behind the beach.

title: SALES PITCHES RESOUND AGAIN IN SHANGHAI
