description: For the unbelievably low price of only 12 yuan ($6.75), Wang Jinzhen said solemnly, he would swallow his anguish and sell his prized black-feathered pigeon. It was, he told scrutinizing pigeon aficionados the other afternoon in People's Square, something of a sacrifice sale.

title: Other National Events; Joyless Task on Immigration
description: After six months of mulling, and with the air of doing its duty, the Reagan Administration last week produced its immigration policy. The mulling was because the problem is enormous.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Senior Graduate
description: At Adelphi University's graduation in May 1979, two Peggy O'Donoghues of Bayside, Queens, received degrees. One was the 51-year-old wife of Judge James F. O'Donoghue of Criminal Court in Queens, and the other was her daughter.

title: Art; NUANCES OF SEASONS CAPTURED ON CANVAS
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR ANUMBER of Long Island painters work hardest and most effectively in summer. They respond to the remarkable colors characteristic of the Island during the season, to its evocatively changing light and to its lavish landscape. After summer, however, they either move back to the city or let their palettes lie fallow until the season returns.

title: IF THE BRITISH DECIDED TO LEAVE ULSTER
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fight That Nobody Won
description: DURING negotiations on the baseball strike, Murray Chass reported in The New York Times that there was talk of a swap. Owners would grant the players full credit for time lost during the strike if the players would agree to an extension of the basic agreement, then due to expire Dec. 31, 1983.

title: LITTLE KNOWN INDUSTRY GAINS
description: NUCLEAR radiation and the utilization of energy released by decaying nuclear material are becoming one of New Jersey's most innovative and diverse industries, even though most people neither trust the new technology nor understand how it works.

title: REC VEHICLE REVIVAL
description: Performance in some industries occasionally defies economic logic. This year, the recreational motor vehicle business is a prime example.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 2, 1981
description: International The Polish union was warned by the Politburo that further unrest could lead to ''an explosion of nationwide conflict.'' The warning followed a wave of demonstrations and calls for strikes in protest against food shortages. The Politburo said that ''strikes, and especially street demonstrations, create enormous dangers for the country.'' (Page 1, Column 1.) Panama's leader was killed in the crash of a Panamanian air force plane during ''bad weather'' over western Panama, the National Guard announced. The plane carrying Gen. Omar Torrijos, who was leader of the National Guard, and three other people, was found in a jungle area between the town of Penonome, 31 miles west of the capital, and the village of Coclecito, 93 miles west of the capital, the announcement said. There were no survivors. The plane had been missing since Friday morning when it took off from Penonome. (1:2.)

title: AN AMERICAN ACTOR WITH THE SHAVIAN TOUCH
description: When Philip Bosco was an intense young speech-and-drama student at Catholic University, he used to practice his stage diction by declaiming speeches from Shakespeare's ''Henry V'' while trudging back and forth to class. Over and over, the air rang with ''Once more unto the breach, dear friends...''

title: BANKING CHANGES IN FAIRFIELD COUNTY
description: CONSUMER banking in Fairfield County is about to undergo the first of what may be two noteworthy changes this year. On Aug. 31, People's Savings Bank of Bridgeport will begin operating five offices in Stamford, according to Norwick R. Goodspeed, the chairman and chief executive officer. The offices, currently operated by First Stamford Bank and Trust Company, are being taken over by People's in what is the first acquisition of commercial bank by a savings bank in Connecticut history.

title: AMATEUR ATHLETES CAPITALIZE ON TALENTS
description: SYRACUSE CRAIG VIRGIN counted the oysters stacked neatly in front of him. He had ordered a dozen as a dinner appetizer at Scratch Daniels' restaurant but counted only 11 on his plate.

title: A SUMMER STILLNESS RECALLS A LIFETIME
description: SHE turned off the kitchen taps and dried her hands on the towel, idly glancing through the window over the sink. ''How hot and still,'' she thought, ''a perfect summer day.''

title: HADEN FINALLY HAS THE JOB HE WANTS
description: FULLERTON, Calif. THERE is no one here to invite Pat Haden to remove his face from a huddle, no threat to his job security as the quarterback of the Los Angeles Rams, and no need for him to wonder about his future. Before he left his wife and three young children last week for the relative peace and quiet of the Rams' training camp, Haden knew he would have the job he wanted without having to endure the stress of competition and weeks of daily speculation.

title: VETERAN MINOR LEAGUE OWNER GUARANTEED TO WIN
description: BRISTOL ''HI, kid. How are you?'' Joe Buzas is standing just inside the entrance at Muzzy Field here, greeting acquaintances as they pass through the gate of the old ball park to see the Bristol Red Sox and the Reading, Pa., Phillies in an Eastern League game. The salutation is a trademark of Mr. Buzas, one that he has been calling out to fans at his ball park for a quarter-century.

title: Court Refuses to Block Chicago Tax on Services
description: The Illinois Supreme Court late yesterday refused to prohibit the City of Chicago from imposing one of three new taxes scheduled to take effect today.

title: Art; ON THE ROADSIDES AGAIN
description: YONKERS SOME oil company missed a great financing opportunity in ''The End of the Road,'' at the Hudson River Museum (through Sept. 6). This is a selection of about 130 color photograhs by John Margolies that celebrates the good old days of cheap gas and roads that went through towns instead of around them. Supported by the National Endowment for the Arts, the New York State Council on the Arts, the Gilman Paper Company and several private patrons, the show laps around - nearly engulfs - a display by the painter, Robert Moskowitz. Circulated by the Walker Art Center of Minneapolis and supported by the National Endowment, this also runs through Sept. 6.

title: AN ALBATROSS CALLED 'DEAD PLEDGE'
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: The best of American popular music will outlast not only rock, but most of the symphonic and operatic music of our time as well. Kern, Berlin, Rodgers, Porter, Arlen, Warren - and many others of stunning achievement - are the true progeny of the Classical and Romantic greats. There is nothing in any form of contemporary music that equals their melodic genius, emotional validity and creative generosity. ARIEL BERLIN

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The sons and daughters of the Polish nation do not need anyone to give them lessons in patriotism or what it means to sacrifice for values more precious than life.'' - A Solidarity commentary marking the anniversary of the 1944 Warsaw uprising. (8:1.)

title: WATER QUALITY VEXES SUFFOLK
description: FACED with evidence that ground water on the Island's highly agricultural North Fork has become contaminated in places by nitrate fertilizers and pesticides, officials of the Suffolk County Health Services Department have begun meeting with local officials in Riverhead and Southold Towns to discuss solutions to what may prove to be a costly problem.

title: Theater; GERSHWIN REVUE HAS SNAP, SPARKLE
description: THIS seems to be a Gershwin summer in Connecticut. At the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, the George and Ira Gershwin musical, ''Funny Face,'' can now be seen, and on every Monday night in August the Goodspeed will have either a Gershwin concert or a film featuring the music and lyrics of the brothers.

title: Miss Franchi Wed To Dean Lynch
description: The marriage of Debra Franchi to Dean Lynch took place yesterday at St. Julia's Roman Catholic Church in Weston, Mass. The Rev. Joseph Casey performed the ceremony.

title: THE MANY JOANS OF ARC
description: JOAN OF ARC The Image of Female Heroism. By Marina Warner. Illustrated. 349 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: No Headline
description: Correction In the description of the Sea & Sea Underwater Camera last week, the price of the YS 20 strobe should have been $160. The macro lens attachment is priced at $30.

title: AT 31, A BUSY GUEST CONDUCTOR CONTEMPLATES SETTLING DOWN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: DANCERS WHO HAVE SCORED ABROAD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Mark Steinbrink is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance. By MARK STEINBRINK

title: INSURANCE COVERING LEGAL FEES SET TO START
description: BEGINNING Sept. 6, New Jerseyans will be able to buy insurance to cover lawyers' fees, just as they can now purchase health and hospital policies.

title: Mary Fleming Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Mary Gerard Fleming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Fleming Jr., to Stephen Andrew Madarasz, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Madarasz, took place yesterday. Both families live in Roslyn Harbor, L.I., where the ceremony was performed at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Michael C. Conroy. The bridegroom is a news producer for radio station WAMC in Albany.

title: DELANEY BID TO CITE POLICE DATA IS REJECTED
description: LAST January, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello assembled a ''blue ribbon'' task force to study the troubled Department of Public Safety Services. The Commissioner/Sheriff, Thomas J. Delaney, called it a ''kangaroo court.'' A month later, he was suspended by Mr. DelBello and now faces 42 counts of misconduct.

title: AN INFLATED MELANGE IN NEW BRUNSWICK
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WHEN a writer deliberately blends genres, styles and plots, the result can be captivating. Or, it can be as inflated as ''The Making of Chastity McDoogan,'' which is now being presented by the Rutgers Theater Company.

title: Art; A 'VANISHED' PARIS IN YALE PHOTO SHOW
description: NEW HAVEN PEOPLE who somehow intended to visit Paris this summer and didn't get there are in for a surprise at the Yale University Art Gallery here. An exhibition of photographs by Charles Marville (through Aug. 16) recalls a beautiful, intimate, almost medieval city that few of us have ever seen. In some respects, it's even better than the real thing.

title: 'BREAKFAST BOOM' RATTLES NORTH FORK
description: AT first, a few people thought they were hearing things early in the morning. Then, their neighbors heard things also. And now, what began as an occasional early morning boom has been heard at about 8:20 A.M. by so many North Fork residents that the phenomenon has acquired a name. It's called the ''breakfast boom.''

title: L.I. Motorcyclist Charged
description: A teen-age motorcyclist was charged with driving while intoxicated after an 81-year-old man was fatally injured yesterday by a motorcycle here, the police said. The motorcyclist - Donald Schlegel, 19, of New Hyde Park - was arrested after Frank Elliot was struck, the police said. Mr. Elliot, also of New Hyde Park, was crossing at the intersection of Jericho Turnpike and New Hyde Park Road at 8:40 P.M. when he was struck. He died about an hour later at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I.

title: BUILDER OFFERS A FLOATING HOUSE
description: Kitty Ellerman, a product manager for a chemical company, has had five job transfers in the last four years. Next time around, she hopes to take her three-bedroom, two-bathroom house with her.

title: BICYCLING IN CHINA'S BUSY CITIES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SAM FREEDMAN contributes to The Times from the Chicago area. By SAM FREEDMAN

title: Gardening; THE ALTERNATIVE TO A MANICURED LAWN
description: WHILE on the staff of a arboretum in the Middle West some years ago, I discovered that more money was being spent mowing 300 acres of grass than for the care of the trees and shrubs - the purpose of the institution. A proposal was presented to the trustees that outlying areas be mowed only as required to minimize the fire hazard from dried grasses.

title: THE DEAN OF SUMMER ANITQUES
description: THE chances are good that if you take in a country antiques show this summer, it will be one run by Russell Carrell. Beginning with the Westport show in April and concluding with the Weston flea market in Massachusetts in late September, Mr. Carrell's summer shows are held throughout New England and eastern New York. They include several in the county and nearby areas and attract both serious collectors and browsing families.

title: WOMEN AND THE SPOILS OF SUCCESS
description: Anne Taylor Fleming is a writer based in Los Angeles. By Anne Taylor Fleming Whenever I enter a room of people these days, I am conscious that it is the women, not the men, who give me the once-over, a quick, slightly veiled, not entirely ungenerous instant appraisal. I look back at these women across the room as if it were empty of men. Who are you, our eyes say to one another, what joys and sorrows have you known, what do you do, where do you work, where do you buy your clothes, but mostly, mostly, we ask each other, are you successful, do you have what you want, do you have what I want?

title: PUBLIC POWER
description: To the Business Editor:

title: The World; THE POOR NEED A LOT MORE THAN GOOD WILL
description: developed.'' At the same time, the economic relationship between these nations and those of the industrialized West - between the South and the North, as they are styled today - has steadily deteriorated.

title: U.S. HANDICAPS IN FOREIGN-POLICY ANALYSIS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING ON MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- STAN HART, who lives on Martha's Vineyard, is the author of ''The Martha's Vineyard Affair,'' a novel. By STAN HART

title: PRICE OF GAS HOLDS DESPITE NEW TAXES
description: After the New York State Legislature passed two taxes on oil companies last month to assist mass transit, most of the major oil companies announced price increases at the pump to pass the tax burden along to consumers.

title: WASTE-PLANT IN DISPUTE
description: NEWARK THE state's Department of Environmental Protection has tentatively approved a 10-story incinerator here for hazardous chemical wastes. Final approval will be subject to public hearings that, officials said, are to be scheduled before the end of the summer.

title: WHEN BONDAGE IS THE NET RESULT OF STATE AID
description: To the Editor:

title: Joan Alexandra Beerman Wed to Thomas Stephens
description: Jane Alexandra Beerman, daughter of Francis O. Beerman and Vivian Beerman, both of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Charles Stephens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. Stephens of Oak Creek, Wis.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN RUGBY TOUR
description: THE Springboks of South Africa are coming to the United States to play three rugby matches next month. As the president of the Eastern Rugby Union and a past international player for the United States, I invited the Springboks to play here in an effort to give our athletes better competition and upgrade our sport.

title: BROOKLYN BOY IS KILLED AND BROTHER WOUNDED
description: A 12-year-old Brooklyn boy was shot dead and his 14-year-old brother was wounded yesterday afternoon by the superintendent of a building near their home, the police said.

title: WHEN BONDAGE IS THE NET RESULT OF STATE AID
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SOUNDS OF SILENCE IN THE SUBURBS
description: SILENCE. A simple word. A straightforward word. A word of quiet dignity. Even standing alone the word demands respect. Silence is a word much used, rarely abused ... significant, in a way, because the word means different things to different people. For example:

title: FRIED ICE CREAM
description: To the Editor:

title: A DOZEN WEATHERPROOF EVERGREENS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Neil Jorgensen is author of ''Guide to New England's Landscape.'' By NEIL JORGENSEN

title: Rijsbergen Takes a New Role
description: Forwards in the North American Soccer League have found Wim Rijsbergen of the Cosmos to be a defender who plays aggressively all the time.

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant; Salmon Treaty A Confused Issue
description: THERE is disagreement between two members of this country's international Atlantic salmon treaty negotiating team over an issue that separates the United States and Canada.

title: Ehrich Twins Are Planning Marriages
description: Announcement has been made of the engagements of Marjorie Ehrich to Steven Lewis and of Rachel Marlene Baratzo to Miss Ehrich's twin, Dr. Marc Ehrich.

title: Seoul Charges 7 in a Family With Spying for North Korea
description: Seven members of a South Korean family face charges that they were involved in providing North Korea with military and economic information through clandestine radio transmissions for the last 24 years, the Agency for National Security Planning said today.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PIANISTS AUDITION TO ACT OUT A DREAM
description: With the music of Chopin in their heads and their hopes for discovery apparent in their faces, 15 young musicians took part in a piano competition in Manhattan yesterday sponsored by a wealthy stockbroker and his wife who said they wanted to ''fill our home with musicians and Chopin.''

title: THE POSSE ON CASEY'S TRAIL REINS IN FAST
description: WASHINGTON FOR a while, it seemed all too familiar. A newspaper account raised questions about a well-known public official. Influential senators called upon him to step down for the good of the country. A committee investigation was launched; probers and prey are followed around town by troops of reporters.

title: I.R.A. UNSHAKEN BY DECISION ON FAST
description: As black flags of mourning went up in Roman Catholic neighborhoods today to mark the death of a seventh prison hunger striker, militant nationalists said they were unperturbed by the fact that another of the hunger strikers had gone off his fast and was receiving nourishment.

title: G.F. Jones Weds Scottie Brown
description: Anne Prescott Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Brown Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Peru, Vt., was married yesterday to Gregory Franklin Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Franklin Jones of Phoenix. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan.

title: OPPISITION: SPORTS CANNOT OVERRIDE THE APARTHEID POLICY
description: LAST year, the publicity director for Monticello Raceway invited the Pennsylvania leader of the Ku Klux Klan to have a ''Klan night at the track.'' The invitation came at a time of the greatest resurgence in overt Klan activity since World War I. The publicity man was dismissed but only after being called an ''aggressive, hard-working and imaginative man'' by his boss.

title: Sports; JOCKEY OUT TO BREAK APPRENTICE RECORD
description: BAY SHORE WHEN Nicholas and Jean Migliore and three of their sons head for Saratoga, it will be for a monthlong vacation. However, for their other son, 17-year-old Richard, the nation's top apprentice jockey, rest and recreation will not be a priority during his stay upstate.

title: Cynthia J. Oakes, Princeton Alumna, Married to Benjamin Rauch, Banker
description: Cynthia Jane Oakes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Oakes of New York, was married in Chilmark, Mass., at sunset yesterday to Benjamin Brewster Rauch, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Stewart Rauch of Villanova, Pa.

title: SUFFOLK STUDIES WAYS TO OBTAIN CHEAPER POWER
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY'S lawmakers will take up their search for cheaper electricity again this month amid confusion over what to do about the Long Island Lighting Company and how well some other arrangement for power distribution might serve the county.

title: OIL TREASURE HUNT BEGINS IN NEW YORK STATE
description: Visions of oil wealth are wafting across the counties along the upper Hudson River and Lake Champlain. Agents for oil and gas companies are combing the hilly region, leasing the mineral rights of farmers; seismologists are taking soundings of the rock strata, and geologists are estimating that the chances of finding at least natural gas are rising as more of the underground rock structure is mapped.

title: JERSEY SHORE IS AWASH WITH ARCHITECTURAL GEMS
description: THE New Jersey beaches, from Sandy Hook south to Cape May, are among the most beautiful in the world. They are, among other things, magnificent centerpieces of summer fun, but even they can lose some of their radiant charm at this time of the year.

title: No Headline
description: Debbie Massey of the United States shot a two-under-par 72 today to retain her British Women's Open golf title.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: A SURPRISING REPORT
description: SOUTH AFRICA Time Running Out. The Report of the Study Commission on U.S. Policy Toward Southern Africa. Forward by Franklin A. Thomas. Illustrated. 517 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: University of California Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: The Region in Summary; Koch Rethinks; House Lottery
description: The question of who should benefit from urban gentrification was highlighted last month when Mayor Koch objected to a weighted lottery system that gave community residents a greater opportunity than nonresidents to buy abandoned city-owned brownstone houses in Harlem at bargain prices. Though the system would give equal opportunity to black and nonblack Harlem residents (there are indeed some of the latter) and lessen the chances of black outsiders as well as white, the Mayor said he opposed it because of his ''old-fashioned integrationist'' views.

title: Desert Trek
description: To the Editor:

title: PUB CINEMA AT NIGHT
description: NORTH HAVEN SATURDAY night at the movies, a drink and a bite to eat. There is nothing special about that except you usually don't find all three under one roof.

title: By TESSA MELVIN
description: WHEN the plumber arrived to install the new washing machine and remove the old one, the Westchester homeowner asked, ''Could I offer you $10 to move the dryer as well?''

title: METRO TASK FORCE MAY END
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH heralding as a success an experimental program that assigned members of the State Police to patrol in Trenton, state officials concede that the pilot Metro Task Force may be disbanded after the troopers leave the capital this fall.

title: The World in Summary; Poland's 'Limit' Of Resistance Is Approaching
description: Lech Walesa, visibly exhausted, was planning to spend a week in bed, but there was no rest for the leader of the Solidarity trade union or for the weary among Poland's Communist Party and Government officials. Public anger at the system's failure to deliver food and other necessities boiled over in Warsaw, Lodz and other cities and more protests were scheduled this week. ''The society's limit of resistance is approaching,'' a Warsaw newspaper warned, and the reformists' buoyant mood has ''given way to exhaustion, a sense of hopelessness and chaos.''

title: Wine; THE BATTLE OF THE BOTTLE
description: The dinner was small and splendid, prepared partly with leftovers, and we were going to gamble with an old, red Burgundy that had lain in the cellar for 11 years, a Nuits-St.-Georges 1953. It was a gamble because the label did not indicate that the wine had been estatebottled, which meant that the grower of the grapes had not supervised the bottling, that he had sold his grapes to a dealer who had created a blend in a winery far from the vineyard.

title: A Correction
description: A table in the July 26 issue of The Week in Review inadvertently omitted a category of respondents in a March 1979 Gallup Poll on attitudes toward the Middle East. Ten percent of those interviewed said they were not aware of the Middle Eastern situation.

title: BARTOK'S CENTENARY YIELDS NEW DISKS
description: As Bartok's centenary year draws to an end, few would dispute the fact that his music has been absorbed into the repertory to a degree unmatched by any other figure of his generation. Schoenberg, Stravinsky, Hindemith, Prokofiev and other important early 20th-century composers all wrote works that are part of our daily musical fare, but we choose selectively from their output, regularly performing only a handful of favorites. With Bartok, though, virtually his entire catalogue is now heard, and frequently.

title: SECURITY LOST, AND SOMETHING WITHIN US, TOO
description: ALINE in a Joni Mitchell song goes, ''You don't know what you've got till it's gone.'' I thought of that some weeks ago while standing on a nearly deserted L.I.R.R. platform at a particularly off-off-peak hour. There were very few people, yet I felt perfectly safe.

title: OCEAN STUDY HELD DEFECTIVE
description: SANDY HOOK THE Army Corps of Engineers and a group of New Jersey scientists are in disagreement over the efficacy of a $100,000 study, just ended, that seeks to determine the effects of some types of ocean dumping on the marine environment.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Connecticut Housing; ILLUSTRATING URBAN REVITALIZATION
description: URBAN revitalization. The words readily evoke jackhammers and bulldozers, reclaimed neighborhoods, and improved land values. Rarely, however, do they bring to mind images of the human side of renewal projects, of the many ways in which people can be affected by rapid change in the environments in which they live and work.

title: Clerc, Vilas Advance
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina overcame fatigue and defeated Eddie Dibbs today, 7-6, 6-1, in the quarterfinal round of the $175,000 Volvo International tennis tournament.

title: Elaine Brewer Is Bride Of Robert Martin Boyd
description: Elaine Renee Brewer, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Webster L. Brewer of Indianapolis, was married there yesterday to Robert Martin Boyd, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Boyd of the Bronx. The Rev. W.W. Reid performed the ceremony at the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church.

title: UNCERTAIN QUIET PREVAILS IN SEVERAL CITIES ON CONTINENT
description: While Britain's cities have been transformed into battlefields this summer, an uncertain quiet reigns in several cities on the Continent that had been racked by frequent and intense outbursts of youthful violence.

title: The Berkshires
description: To the Editor:

title: DEAN OF MUSIC AT STATE U. DESCRIBES HIS ROLES
description: ''IFELT like a drop of water in a hot pan, sometimes,'' Yehudi Wyner said in a small room at Tanglewood's Berkshire Music Center administration building, where he had just finished coaching a class of young musicians. ''I feel that I'm ricocheting off one into the other.'' Mr. Wyner was speaking of the many roles he fills in the world of contemporary and traditional classical music: composer, performer (pianist and harpsichordist), conductor, teacher, coach and Dean of Music at the State University College of New York at Purchase.

title: THE THEORY OF THE LEISURE STATE
description: SHOWING OFF IN AMERICA From Conspicuous Consumption to Parody Display. By John Brooks. 296 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $12.95. By LEWIS H. LAPHAM

title: AN UNLIKELY BOXING PROMOTER
description: ALMOST from the sport's inception in Connecticut, boxing promoters in the state have tended to fit the popular stereotype of a cigarchomping, tough-talking wheeler-dealer content to eke out a small profit on each boxing card. After years of struggle, though, most of them have either retired from boxing or have continued to promote fights on a part-time basis in a state in which the sport has failed to capture much attention since it was legalized in 1973, following an eight-year ban.

title: Mets Farm Out Leary
description: The Mets sent Tim Leary, the promising rookie who pitched only two innings in April before hurting his elbow, back to the minor leagues for conditioning yesterday.

title: HAMPTON BAYS POISED FOR SPURT
description: HAMPTON BAYS IN the 1930's and 1940's, as land bordering Peconic Bay just east of the Shinnecock Canal became popular, families bought small parcels for $2,000 to $5,000 and built beach houses overlooking the sparkling bay with a view of Plum Island and the North Fork.

title: SOME TOP BRIDGE TEAMS LOSE
description: Several top-ranked teams were on the sidelines here this afternoon in the Spingold knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Sixteen teams survived from an original entry of 151.

title: Antiques; A SHOW RICH IN HISTORY
description: GLASTONBURY THE drive along the main street of this historic town would by itself be worth leaving home any Saturday morning, for the old street, lined on both sides with handsome 18th-century homes, provides a visual treat for those who admire Connecticut's Colonial architectural heritage.

title: Antiques; SPOTLIGHT FALLS ON BARNEGAT LIGHT
description: BARNEGAT LIGHT IN 1962, storm-driven water cut Long Beach Island into three parts. Peter Colasante, an antiques dealer in this community at the northern tip of the island, remembers looking at the wreckage and thinking, ''The island will never be the same.''

title: THOUGHT FOR FOOD: AID IS ALSO POLITICAL
description: POLAND'S worsening food shortages have been as well-publicized as the nation's turbulent reform movement -and when a livestock feed crisis threatened to make the situation there even more desperate, the Reagan Administration responded with some quick help. Last week, the Secretary of Agriculture, John R. Block, announced that Poland would receive $55 million in new long-term credits to purchase American corn.

title: TOWER ASSERTS MANY IN CONGRESS OPPOSE AIR BASING OF MX MISSILES
description: Senator John Tower, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, asserted today that airborne basing for the MX nuclear missile would probably be rejected by Congress.

title: RIGHTS UNIT AGAINST FUNDS FOR WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT OPPOSITION by the State Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities appears already to have scuttled one effort by Westport to obtain Federal funds to buy open space in its downtown area, and now officials here are wondering whether the town may be permanently cut off from Federal assistance of this type.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE Reader's Digest Association has decided to take up some of the blacktop on its parking lot and grow grass instead. Because of a trend to smaller cars, coupled with the increasing use of car pools, van pools and buses by its employees, the parking space around its Chappaqua headquarters is bigger than necessary, the company said.

title: CAPE TOWN IS TRYING TO OUST HUNDREDS OF HOMELESS BLACKS
description: It is still winter here at the tip of the African continent, and last night the wind drove a steady, cold rain across a small patch of wasteland outside Nyanga Township. Hundreds of blacks have been living here without shelter for two weeks in defiance of warnings, jailings and court orders designed to make them go back to a rural black ''homeland.''

title: Sheila B. Donahue Engaged
description: The engagement of Sheila B. Donahue to Philip Barton Key Potter 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore P. Donahue of Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Potter is a son of Mrs. Potter Jr. of Washington and the late Mr. Potter, who was with the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Chess; IT'S FUN--BUT IS IT SAFE?
description: It is definitely more fun to counterattack with the Black pieces than to rely on pure defense, provided you can get away with it. The trouble is that the more aggressively Black plays, the more aggressively he invites White to play and that is often too much to cope with.

title: Players' Group Supports Pact
description: Major league player representatives today unanimously ratified the new basic agreement that ended the baseball strike, clearing the way for the players to approve the settlement by the middle of next week.

title: VIOLENT MAN DIES WHILE BEING SUBDUED IN QUEENS
description: A 30-year-old Pawtucket, R.I., man with a reported history of mental illness died in the entry of a garden apartment in Queens early yesterday in a struggle with a group of neighbors and police officers who tried to subdue him after an unexplained outburst of violence.

title: A PARTY FOR BABAR, THE ELEPHANT KING
description: The Nouvelle Observateur has labeled him a radical socialist, but then they would. Just because he believes in cradleto-the-grave social welfare. Actually, he much more closely resembles one of those affable Scandinavian monarchs who pedal bicycles into town and enter roses in competitions. He is plump, conservative and benevolent, a leader by calling and bourgeois by choice.

title: Day-Care Cutbacks: Potential Impact
description: In response to Tessa Melvin's article in the July 5 issue (''Assessing Social Aid Priorities''), it seemed unfortunate that there was no mention of the impact that cuts in day care will cause.

title: BLACK WOMEN CHART A NEW ACTIVISM
description: Such a gathering had occurred only once before in American history, participants said, and that was 86 years ago. And so when more than 700 women from around the country met this week in Washington for a Black Women's Summit Conference, many called the occasion historic.

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: Sidney Zion is correct in pointing out a resurgence of interest in the sounds of the 1930's, 40's and 50's. However, it isn't occurring at the expense of rock, or any other style.

title: A NEW SOURCE FOR COINS AND MEDALS
description: Spink & Son, the oldest and one of the largest antiques dealers in the world, has opened a New York office at 445 Park Avenue (at 58th Street). But New Yorkers will have to wait a bit longer to shop at Spink for fine art and antiques. That's because, at the outset, the London-based dealers are limiting stock in period wares in New York to coins and medals. Later, according to Douglas Liddell, managing director, Spink's New York office may expand into art and antiques.

title: CONOCO'S CASE AGAINST TWO BIDDERS...
description: C ONOCO is confronted with two unfriendly tender offers for its stock - one from Mobil involving a horizontal merger of the two major oil companies and one from Seagram, the Canadian liquor company, to take control of Conoco.

title: REAGAN'S BOON TO RETIREMENT SAVINGS
description: THE sweeping tax legislation hammered out by Congress last week will have far-reaching implications in dozens of respects. One notable change, which promises to benefit millions of Americans, involves much greater tax advantages for retirement savings.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: TO WIN A WAR 1918, The Year of Victory. By John Terraine. Illustrated. 268 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: Wage Inflation
description: To the Business Editor: William Nordhaus invented a new logical fallacy in his article, ''In the C.P.I. We Cannot Trust'' (July 12). It might be christened the ''ante-hoc'' fallacy to distinguish it from its cousin, ''posthoc.''

title: RIVALS TO TESTIFY ON SULFUR IN AIR
description: THE State Department of Environmental Protection this week will hold the first public hearings on its proposal to allow utilities and industries to burn fuel containing twice as much sulfur as is now permitted.

title: CALIFORNIA STRUGGLE OVER USE OF PESTICIDES EXPECTED TO HAVE NATIONAL EFFECT
description: The Mediterranean fruit fly drama that has aroused fears of economic disaster and environmental destruction in California is in a sense only one battle in a wider legal and political war over use of pesticides in the state.

title: BRECHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE Village of Lawrence has been served with a preliminary injunction by the Nassau branch of the American Civil Liberties Union asking that the village-owned golf course be prevented from enforcing its rule of denying men and women the right to play golf together during prime time on weekends and holidays.

title: THE URBAN PLANNER IN SPITE OF HIMSELF
description: If there is any doubt that things in New York are not working the way they did in Robert Moses' time, look at Westway. The $2.2-billion landfill, park and highway project for the Hudson River shorefront of Manhattan has been held back for nearly a decade by a mixture of political, social and legal opposition. Had Mr. Moses at the height of his power been behind it, 10 years would have been time enough not only to get such a vast public-works project started, but to bring it to completion.

title: Art; ARTISTS UNDER 30 GET A SHOWCASE
description: HEMPSTEAD THE Fine Arts Museum of Long Island, known by the acronym Famli, is a young institution. Founded in 1978, partly in response to the actions of the Nassau County Office of Cultural Development that led to the temporary closing and administrative reorganization of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor, the new museum opened last fall in the disused W.T. Grant store in downtown Hempstead.

title: LASERS, FINALLY, BEGIN TO LIVE UP TO EXPECTATIONS
description: By BARNABY J. FEDER

title: Boy Dies, 9 Others Hurt In Utah Propane Blast
description: An 8-year-old boy died today after being burned last night in an explosion at a propane storage plant that sent a ball of fire roaring into an adjacent campground.

title: METS, YANKEES START MIDSUMMER TRAINING CAMPS
description: On the day after the end of the longest strike in baseball history, 19 members of the Mets broke out the bats and balls yesterday for the first time in seven weeks and turned Shea Stadium into a kind of training camp in August.

title: Valerie B. Colton Is Bride in South
description: Valerie Beth Colton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Colton of New York and Durham, N.C., was married in Durham yesterday to Max TenEyck Woodbury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max A. Woodbury of Durham. The Rev. Dr. Barney Jones of the Duke University department of religion performed the interdenominational ceremony in the Duke Gardens.

title: Index; New York Times Magazine August 2, 1981
description: Cyra McFadden 9 On Language In Defense of Gender Russell Baker 12 Sunday Observer Being Rich John Conroy 16 Ulster's Lost Generation They live in Catholic ghettos in the slums of Northern Ireland. They have grown up without hope amid poverty and violence, and they risk their lives for the fun of it, stealing cars for joy rides.

title: KING OF THE HILL
description: THEY might not be remembered - as President Reagan suggested last week - as the opening shots in ''a revolution that promises to be one of the most exciting and noteworthy of our generation.'' But at the very least the Administration's legislative victories last week will probably be recalled as the start of a remarkable experiment in rolling back Government and changing its course.

title: AS A NEW HUMAN LIFE BEGINS TO DEVELOP
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY IS URGED TO RECONSIDER BUILDING 3D WATER TUNNEL
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, citing high inflation and a declining population in New York City, urged the city yesterday to study ''less costly alternatives'' to completing the long-delayed Third Water Tunnel.

title: POPE, RECOVERED FROM VIRUS, SET FOR NEW SURGERY
description: Pope John Paul II has fully recovered from the viral infection that he has had since mid-June and will soon undergo a second and final operation on his intestine, the Pope's doctors announced today.

title: FRIED ICE CREAM
description: To the Editor:

title: RECALLING 'WILD BILL'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: KEEP YOUR EYE ON ZIRCONIUM
description: GET REALLY RICH IN THE COMING SUPER METALS BOOM By Gordon McLendon. 254 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $4.95. By ANDREW TOBIAS

title: BACTERIA FOUND TO SUSTAIN GIANT OCEANIC WORMS
description: Giant worms discovered two years ago around hot springs on the floor of the Pacific Ocean have been found using colonies of bacteria to obtain food and energy in a manner never before observed. For this and their other remarkable characteristics, the worms have been recognized as a new family of the animal kingdom.

title: Fried Ice Cream
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYWRIGHT WON THREE OSCARS
description: The playwright Paddy Chayefsky, a winner of three Academy Awards, died of cancer yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 58 years old.

title: 12-DAY PROVIDENCE STRIKE CAUSES MINIMAL DISRUPTION
description: For more than a week city garbage trucks have rolled out of secret staging areas before dawn to make their rounds, usually with escorts of policemen carrying shotguns prominently.

title: Crime
description: This one's not exactly light summer reading - there are some rather disagreeable things about GETTING AWAY WITH MURDER by Alan Dennis Burke (Atlantic-Little, Brown, $12.95) - but it is very well written, ingeniously plotted and full of irony. The book is also a fine example of grubby realism.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: day landings in 1944, a movement that was marked by many individual acts of heroism, but comprised only 5 percent of the population and was weakened by the failure of the left and right to unite in a common purpose. Our reviewer Philip Hallie called it ''the most complete account in English and the most sensitive.'' Illustrated with 57 black-and-white photographs.

title: Politics; OFFICIALS BEGIN TO TALK PAY RAISES
description: HARTFORD THE timing may not be the best, considering the state's fiscal problems and the taxpayers' unhappiness with the new unincorporated business tax, but a move is under way to try to raise the salaries of the state's elected officials starting in 1983.

title: Headliners; Slips in the Desert
description: Loose lips apparently sank Robert G. Neumann, the United States Ambassador to Saudi Arabia who was fired last week, barely two months into his striped pants. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who bruises easily, learned that Mr. Neumann had criticized his grasp of Middle Eastern niceties and made some fun of the notion that the Vicar of Foggy Bottom still wants to be President. It was also reported that Mr. Haig discovered that Mr. Neumann had been conducting unauthorized back-channel chats with Richard V. Allen, White House national security adviser.

title: Donna Cohen Is Married to Dr. Charles Buthmann
description: The marriage of Donna Cohen, to Dr. Charles Buthmann took place yesterday at the Terrace in the Park in Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Michael Rosen performed the ceremony.

title: ARGENTINA IS NO ALLY
description: It is surprising that Argentina has been made a focus of the Reagan Administration's foreign policy. To justify more cordial treatment of its repressive regime, the Administration has advanced three premises -none of which stand up under close scrutiny: United States foreign policy should not needlessly antagonize a friendly ally merely because its regime treats its own citizens badly; we need Argentina's good will because it has resources important to our economy; we should placate Argentina because it occupies a strategic location with respect to vital sea routes.

title: What's in a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Television Week
description: Second Salvo ''The thing about running a five-part series is that frequently people don't get a chance to see the whole thing.''

title: THE SECOND QUARTER DIP
description: The economy is in an unappealing rut. For the third year in a row, real gross national product contracted in the second quarter, an unprecedented development in postwar economic history.

title: FIGHTING OVER BLOCK GRANTS CATCHES STATES IN THE MIDDLE
description: The foundation of Ronald Reagan's approach to government is ''the new federalism,'' a shifting of power from Washington to state and local governments. In a speech to the National Conference of State Legislatures in Atlanta last week he called it a ''quiet revolution.'' But as Congress passed its final version of Mr. Reagan's budget-cutting package, the revolution was still far from finished. The day of the new federalism was clearly closer at hand. But a bipartisan coalition had held the line in some areas and preserved a significant role for Washington in national life.

title: JAMES EARL JONES PREPARES TO MAP THE TORMENTED SOUL OF OTHELLO
description: eyed as James Earl Jones talks, seated in a parlor at the administrative offices of the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Conn. He will open at the festival on Wednesday in ''Othello,'' playing the betrayed Moor to Christopher Plummer's Iago in a production that will go out, following its Sept. 5 closing at Stratford, on a 14-city national tour that ends with a limited engagement on Broadway in March.

title: Violence Is Averted At Rugby
description: A cool display of crowd control by policemen, with help from protest leaders, today averted what could have been an ugly incident during another stop of the tour of New Zealand by a South African rugby team.

title: AS A NEW HUMAN LIFE BEGINS TO DEVELOP
description: To the Editor:

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT AND PRODUCTIVITY FALL
description: The Government's index of leading indicators fell 1.3 percent in June on the heels of a May decline, and productivity declined at an annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. The trade deficit narrowed to $1.2 billion in June, but the Commerce Department expects the dollar's strength to hurt exports and make this this year's deficit several billion dollars wider than last year's. In other news, factory orders rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted $170.89 billion, and June machine tool orders rose 34.8 percent but were down 32.8 percent from 1980.

title: 2 Men Killed in Long Beach; Queens Resident Is Charged
description: Two Long Beach men were shot to death by a Bellerose, Queens, man following an argument near the boardwalk here early today, the police said.

title: SORELY TESTED, NIGERIA TRIES FEDERALISM
description: raising session here recently. It was one of those ceremonies where the faithful compete to show the value of their loyalty and their gratitude for favors past and future.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: WITH a place like Fort Lee, New Jersey is no stranger to the condominium craze, which, from all accounts, has spread to virtually every part of the state. And now Governor Byrne has signed a bill giving the elderly and disabled some protection from the conversion steamroller.

title: The World in Summary; One Life Saved, One Lost in Ulster
description: The Irish Republican Army's grip over the families of imprisoned hunger-strikers loosened last week even as Kevin Lynch became the seventh striker to die. Hours before his death, and with another inmate, Kieran Doherty, sinking fast, the mother and sister of a third striker signed a waiver authorizing prison doctors to save his life.

title: The Region; GARBAGE IS GARBAGE, BURNING IT FOR ENERGY IS DIFFICULT
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. WHEN Europeans ran out of places to bury their garbage, they built incinerators to turn it into electricity and steam for their homes and businesses. With dumping grounds in the metropolitan area filling up, many American officials are finding garbage recycling an increasingly attractive alternative. But given the experience thus far on this side of the Atlantic, it may be an idea that simply doesn't travel.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Diamond Slump
description: Whatever they might have been to girls, diamonds were not very good friends of investors last January. With wholesale prices down 6 percent in a month and a total of 11 percent since their peak in March 1980, the market had lost considerable glitter.

title: GEORGE HAMILTON - THE ACTOR BEHIND THE DILETTANTE'S MASK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kirk Honeycutt, a freelance writer, frequently reports on the film scene. By KIRK HONEYCUTT LOS ANGELES George Hamilton came up with the idea so quickly that you just wonder if he hadn't planned it all along. A newspaper photographer had dropped by 20th Century-Fox Studios to take a picture of the actor for a story about his new comedy, ''Zorro, the Gay Blade.'' In the film, Mr. Hamilton plays the dual roles of Zorro's twin sons, who take up their father's cause as champion of the downtrodden peasants of Old Los Angeles and as the world's first graffiti artist, slashing Z's on hacienda walls, tree trunks and the alcalde's soldiers.

title: THREAT OF A STRIKE BY AIR CONTROLLERS RISES AS TALKS FAIL
description: The likelihood of a nationwide walkout tomorrow by Federal air traffic controllers grew stronger yesterday when negotiations were recessed after a perfunctory half-hour session in Washington.

title: FOR PAGE, NO FOND FAREWELL
description: This is the year that the deep questioning about his role in football finally ends for Alan Page, the year that his double life slowly comes to a close.

title: Arctic Highway
description: To the Editor:

title: PADRES GIVE FANS FREE GAME
description: Calling it a first in baseball and an official apology to the fans, Ray Kroc, owner of the San Diego Padres, said yesterday that all seats will be free for the club's Aug. 10 game at home against Atlanta, its first after the strike.

title: Uruguay Names General As Next President
description: Gen. Gregorio Alvarez, a retired Commander in Chief of the Uruguayan army, was today named the next President of Uruguay, the first military man to fill that position under the present regime.

title: The Careful Shopper; The Restaurant Store Features Housewares
description: Kitchen supplies vary in durability and design, often to the frustration of the home cook seeking tools of the trade at the nearest supermarket or hardware store. The Restaurant Store, a division of the Westchester Restaurant Supply Company in Elmsford, serves the public need for commercial-quality home supplies and for gifts of gadgets, copper, silverplate or glassware as well - selling either small quantities at wholesale prices, but no special orders, or wholesale quantities with volume discounts and custom specifications. The company moved to the present location four years ago after 50 years in Mount Vernon.

title: FRENCH HORSES FINISH IN DEAD HEAT
description: The two French horses in the field, Jorky and Ideal du Gazeau, finished in a dead heat tonight in the most exciting finish in the 23-year history of Challenge Cup trotting at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: FOR MOTORISTS IN MOSCOW, RANK IS ALL
description: Fly to Moscow, catch a taxi at the airport and something curious about this society is visible right away: If power corrupts, it does so just as surely behind a steering wheel as anywhere else.

title: Miss Stever Has Bridal
description: The marriage of Margarette Risley Stever to Lincoln Daniel Weed took place yesterday in the Randolph (N.H.) Church. The Rev. Stephen Crary, professor emeritus of religion at Brown University and a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Westchester Guide; EXHIBIT FOR CHILDREN
description: Two 45-foot trailers will lumber into the parking lot of the Yorktown Community Cultural Center at the corner of Commerce Street and Veterans Road this week. And as youngsters watch, workmen will transform the trailers into a 2,000-square-foot learning and play exhibit called ''Kaleidoscope.''

title: No Headline
description: Correction The dress by Oscar de la Renta that appeared in the fashion section of the July 19 New York Times Magazine (''The New Boot That Balances'') should have been priced at $660; the stole at $180.

title: CONFLICTS RISE OVER USE OF UTAH PARK
description: The great rivers flowing through Canyonlands National Park have done their work well. To the West, the Green carves its way past Upheaval Canyon; to the East, the Colorado skirts Dead Horse Point and continues its meandering ways. Water and 300 million years have sculpted a surrealistic profusion of red rock canyons, sandstone spires and arches, gorges and buttes.

title: A South African Rebel Is Killed in Zimbabwe
description: A prominent South African nationalist guerrilla leader, Joe Gqabi, was assassinated by gunfire today as he backed his car out of the gates of his home in a suburb of Salisbury, the Government announced.

title: J.H. Season to Wed Randi Loftsgaarden
description: Randi Tangen Loftsgaarden, a lawyer and vice president at the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York, will be married Oct. 17 to James Hobson Season, a director and assistant treasurer of the De Lorean Motor Company in New York. Mr. and Mrs. Beldin H. Loftsgaarden of Phoenix have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Season Jr. of Cleveland. The marriage will take place at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: DUPONT: TWO STEPS CLOSER
description: Du Pont may win the golden apple yet. Its bid for Conoco was conditionally blessed by the Justice Department, and as of late Friday it had received tenders for 56 percent of Conoco's stock.

title: LAWYER WHO INVESTED PROFIT FIRED
description: A jury convicted seven narcotics defendants in a Manhattan trial yesterday, including the head of a major heroin ring, but it acquitted a lawyer accused of investing some of the ring's profits in legitimate businesses.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 3, 1981; Companies
description: Burroughs agreed to buy Memorex for $106 million in cash in what was seen as a ''friendly'' merger. The move apparently overtook a Memorex takeover bid by Storage Technology. the offer of Burroughs is contingent, however, on the restructuring of Memorex's debt, which Burroughs would assume. (Page D1.)

title: Pearl Chertok, 63, Harpist Who Performed on Televison
description: Pearl Chertok, a harpist, television performer, music teacher and a founder and president of the American Harp Society, died Saturday at White Plains Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived in Armonk, N.Y.

title: INJUSTICE DEPARTMENT
description: .6,0,165.6,2,478.4,0WASHINGTON - President Reagan may be undecided about extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965, perhaps the most important civil rights legislation in United States history. But Justice Department policy across the entire spectrum of civil rights issues reveals a deep-seated hostility toward the laws that protect minorities and handicapped persons.

title: POLAND'S PREMIER AND ARMY LEADERS DISCUSS PROTESTS
description: A day after Poland's Communist Party issued a sharp warning to the independent trade union over the danger of new strikes and demonstrations, Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski was reported tonight to have held a meeting on the situation with senior military commanders.

title: Nowhere to Turn
description: Therese Boyle, a junior national volleyball standout, saw the hurt and tears. What could she say to the players on the United States Olympic women's volleyball team who had given up so much and received so little in return?

title: JERRY RUBIN PLANS FIRM
description: Jerry Rubin, the former Yippie who found a home on Wall Street, has left the brokerage house of John Muir & Company to form his own private money management firm. Mr. Rubin, however, will serve as consultant to Muir. He had held the position of director of business development at Muir.

title: 12 SOUTH BRONX BUSINESSES APPLY FOR CON ED DISCOUNTS
description: Twelve Bronx businesses have applied for discounted electricity rates that took effect July 1 in eight depressed areas of the South Bronx and Brooklyn.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of Paddy Chayefsky yesterday gave the wrong time for the funeral service. It is scheduled for 12:45 P.M. tomorrow at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Lucille Roberts Agency
description: The Lucille Roberts chain of health spas and diet centers, which has not previously had a real ad agency, now has gone to Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector - yes, the same agency that lost Old Bushmills - for both advertising and promotion. Billings could run from $1.5 million to $2 million.

title: FOR WHOM '911' HAS A RECORDED MESSAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH RIOTS 'SHARP WARNING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Coalition Partners Draft Policy Guidelines
description: The prospective partners in Israel's new governing coalition today drafted the policy guidelines Prime Minister Menachem Begin is to submit to Parliament when he seeks a vote of confidence for his new government.

title: 3 Men Escape Fire In Cabin Cruiser
description: Three men escaped injury when their 24-foot cabin cruiser burst into flames minutes after they had begun to heat some coffee, the marine police said.

title: Milosz to Open Season At the Y Poetry Center
description: The 92d Street Y Poetry Center will open its 43d season with a reading by Czeslaw Milosz, the 1980 Nobel laureate in literature, on Sept. 21 at 8 P.M. Mr. Milosz's reading will be the first of 30 evenings during the 1981-82 season.

title: WHAT'S UP--AND DOWN--AT OSHKOSH AIR SHOW
description: ''Oshkosh Tower, this is Cessna Forty-Niner Zero Zero Goss - '' ''Do not identify yourself by number,'' the tower interrupted in a rapid-fire stream of instructions, ''just by type and color only, blue and white Cessna rock your wings, O.K., follow the yellow biplane, the green Bonanza on short final, put it on the numbers, the black and silver Moony, land long, as soon as you land pull it on the grass and follow the flagman, the orange and white Piper, you're too high and too fast, get behind the red tail-dragger.''

title: GLICKSTEIN DEFEATS STOCKTON IN FINAL
description: Shlomo Glickstein of Israel won his first Grand Prix tournament of the year today, defeating Dick Stockton in a tensely contested match.

title: 12 Ethnic Albanians Receive Prison Terms in Yugoslavia
description: Twelve ethnic Albanians have been sentenced to jail terms ranging from 1 to 13 years in connection with disorders in Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province, according to reports in Belgrade today.

title: Sidewalk Gridlock
description: When does a peddler wear out his welcome as a charming addition to the urban landscape? When he gets rid of his cart and lays his goods out on the sidewalk, obstructing pedestrians and competing unfairly with taxpaying, rent-paying merchants.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 3, 1981
description: International A military meeting in Warsaw was reported to have been held by Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski and senior commanders, a day after Poland's Communist Party sharply warned the independent trade union Solidarity about the danger of new strikes and demonstrations over food shortages. The official announcement of the meeting of the military leaders said it was called ''in connection with the increasingly unfavorable and dangerous phenomena within the country's internal situation.'' (Page 1, Col. 1.) The U.S. appeared to be willing for the first time to participate in a global round of talks at the United Nations on the economic problems affecting the third world. A preliminary meeting over the weekend in Cancun, Mexico, set the agenda for a meeting there in October between the leaders of the leading industrialized nations and 14 developing countries. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. indicated that while the the Reagan Administration was giving priority to strengthening the American economy, it was ''impossible'' to wait for an American economic recovery before dealing with the questions of international cooperation. (1:1-3.)

title: WILLIAM C. KREGER
description: William C. Kreger, senior assistant managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, died Saturday at his home in Summit, N.J., apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: A TIME TO CURTSY, EVEN FOR AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Gridlock' Refuses to Disappear
description: It hasn't appeared in any major dictionaries yet, but ''gridlock,'' the term for terminal traffic congestion that gained currency during New York's transit strike last year, is well on its way.

title: Infinity Is Best Grand Prix Yacht
description: Infinity, a forest green 46-foot sloop owned by John B. Thomson of Sands Point, won the grand prix division of the 190-mile Around Long Island regatta today.

title: OUTDOORS: A LESSON ON THE WEAKFISH
description: hour before sundown and made the short run to the big bend in Lobsterville Beach.

title: Many Aids for Herpes Called Ineffective by U.S.
description: Federal health officials are warning the public about a long list of treatments for genital herpes they say are ineffective and, in some cases, dangerous to health.

title: NONPOLITICAL D.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: USE OF PONDS AS SOLAR ENERGY 'BANK' EXPLORED
description: The pond that embellishes the landscape in countless places may in years to come not be just a pond but a power plant in disguise.

title: INJURIES CAUSED DEATH OF MAN IN QUEENS STRUGGLE
description: A city medical examiner said yesterday that severe head and internal injuries caused the death of a Rhode Island man in Queens Saturday morning in a struggle with a group of neighbors and police officers who sought to restrain him after he became violent.

title: MEDIATING A LESS HOSTILE END TO A MARRIAGE
description: When Carol and Donald Krug of Westbury, L.I., decided to end their marriage in 1977, they were determined to avoid a court battle that would turn them into adversaries and which, they thought, might generate antagonism and hostility that could last forever.

title: Wounded Officer Kills A Man Who Shot Him
description: A 23-year-old man was shot to death by a transit policeman last night in the BMT station at 57th and Seventh Avenue after the man attacked the policeman with a knife and then shot him with the officer's own revolver, a Transit Authority spokesman said.

title: U.S.Yacht Is 12th In Channel Race
description: The United States and West Germany fell in the Admirals Cup standing as the 220-mile Channel yacht race, the third of the series, ended at Portsmouth early today.

title: Chinese Official to Visit U.S.
description: Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China will visit the United States in late October for talks with the Reagan Administration expected to focus on Chinese requests to buy American weapons, an Administration official said tonight. On a visit to Peking in June, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. announced an American agreement in principle to permit the sale of arms to China.

title: Golden Gate Plunge Survived
description: A young woman carrying no identification jumped off the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday and survived, the Coast Guard said.

title: SHAD OF S.E.C. FAVORS BRIGHT CORPORATE IMAGE
description: John S.R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, says corporations hurt their image by disclosing too much unfavorable information. He says he intends to try to limit the amount of such information required in S.E.C. public reports.

title: Kenyon & Eckhardt Gets Clairol Line
description: Kenyon & Eckhardt is picking up the Condition line of Clairol hair care products that exited a week ago from Ogilvy & Mather because of a conflict with a Chesebrough-Ponds brand. Billings are reported at around $7 million.

title: People
description: * Robert W. Hinson, executive vice president at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson Inc., elected to the additional post of chairman of the management committee.

title: The Chill From Dear Canada
description: Americans think of Canadians as good neighbors - when they think of them at all. But lately, good neighbor Canada has gotten decidedly fussy about who sniffs its rose bushes. The Trudeau Government's new national energy program is openly hostile to foreign investment in Canadian oil and gas and it is forcing American companies out. Angry business leaders on this side of the border call for reciprocal limits on Canadian purchases of American mineral wealth.

title: All-American Gregg
description: Forrest Gregg, the offensive lineman for the Green Bay Packers from 1956 to 1970 who earned a spot in the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1977, is beginning his second year as head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals. For the last year, he has been doing television commercials for the Toyota Dealers Advisory Council, extolling the virtues of the Japanese-made automobile.

title: Wolfhound Is Best
description: A black, 140-pound Irish wolfhound, Ch. Flying Fidil of Eagle, owned by Samuel Ewing of Glen Mills, Pa., earned her second best-in-show today when she triumphed at the 25th annual event of the Hunterdon Hills Kennel Club. Fidil is the seventh wolfhound that Mr. Ewing, a lawyer, has gaited to a top award.

title: A KOCH RIVAL HAS HIS SAY
description: Always seeking a broad range of opinion, pollsters for Mayor Koch dialed one of his opponents in the Democratic primary over the weekend in a random telephone search to see how the Mayor has been doing.

title: WARNER'S FORMER CHIEF OF DISCO BRANCHES OUT
description: Ray Caviano has long been considered a wunderkind in the frenetic record business, an image that was reinforced in 1979 when Warner Brothers Records made him executive director of its dance music department and gave him $6 million to start a disco division. Eight months ago, the 31-year-old Mr. Caviano took what he feels is another step forward when he left Warner to start his own orgnization, the impressively-named RFC Group of Companies.

title: Commodities; Quality Is A Factor In Pricing
description: OF all the factors that determine wheat futures prices, quality is usually not one of them. This season, however, the quality factor has not only become an important influence on prices, but in a most bizarre way. The fact is that high protein, top-quality wheat has been selling at deep discounts compared with the lower-grade ordinary grain for the last month or so.

title: S.I. Man Arrested In $11,000 Swindle
description: A man who posed as a company vice president and a psychotherapist has been arrested on charges of swindling a college professor out of $11,000, the police said.

title: ICE SHOW: DISNEY WORLD AT GARDEN
description: THE new ''World on Ice'' show of Walt Disney Productions, at Madison Square Garden through Aug. 16, is that rare show that may be enjoyed by the youngest child in the family. The girls are pretty and the acts novel, the music is appropriately loud and brassy, and the lights and costumes are colorful. But the show presents its host of favorite Disney characters and specialty skaters in a low-key, surprisingly soft-sell tone.

title: KEEPING INFORMANTS UNDER CONTROL
description: Do informants cause more crime than they help solve? It is fast becoming realized among law-enforcement experts that informants' misconduct, which is often serious, is a crime ''cure'' that is possibly worse than the ailment.

title: TEA MEN DEFEAT COSMOS
description: The Jacksonville Tea Men, one of the few teams in the North American Soccer League to have a winning record against the Cosmos, continued their domination tonight with a 2-1 victory at Giants Stadium.

title: MISSION DISTRICT SEEKS A NEW IDENTITY
description: For about 20 years Italian-Americans, who were there first, and Irish-Americans, who followed them, have been giving ground in San Francisco's Mission District to thousands of refugees and job seekers from Latin America.

title: NEW YORK PROBATION AIDES ASSERT OFFICE FAILS TO WATCH THOUSANDS
description: Thousands of people on probation in New York City are going virtually unsupervised because of severe budget and personnel cuts in the Probation Department, many probation officers and officials assert. And judges and department employees contend that the quality of presentence reports - another key responsibility for the agency - has deteriorated. Presentence reports are vital for judges in determining punishment.

title: Account
description: * Taylor Rental Centers of America Inc. to Creamer Inc./New England.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Grace Glueck GREAT DRAWINGS OF ALL TIME: THE 20TH CENTURY. Two volumes. Se- lected and edited by Victoria Thorson. 1,291 pages. Shorewood Fine Art Books. $295.

title: A GAMBLE IN CLEVELAND: SUNDAY PAPER Cole
description: A bold gamble, in the tradition of the highrolling industrialists who built this city, appeared on street corners and front porches this morning.

title: PIQUET OF BRAZIL WINS AUTO RACE
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil overcame damage to the skirting of his Brabham and won the West German Grand Prix today, clinching his third Formula One victory of the season and closing the gap on the championship leader, Carlos Reutemann of Argentina.

title: Astros' Richard Making Progress
description: J.R. Richard, the Houston Astros righthander who suffered a stroke on July 30, 1980, and then underwent two operations to clear obstructed arteries in his right shoulder, was one of the few major league players who may have benefited from the baseball strike.

title: OVERTIME PRACTICES CRITICIZED
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan yesterday renewed his criticism of a practice that has allowed most retiring bus drivers and maintenance workers in the Bronx and Manhattan to raise their base salaries in the last year of service by as much as 64 percent through working overtime, thereby giving them substantially higher pensions.

title: SUPRISING SURGE IN BOOK SALES
description: IN a turnabout that has taken much of the book-publishing industry by surprise, sales across the United States have risen significantly during the last month or two. The change is leading booksellers and publishers to think the industry's yearlong recession may be over.

title: G.M. Closes Corvette Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation said it has closed its assembly line that produced more than 700,000 Corvette sports cars in the last 27 years.

title: AN $18,500 ANSWER TO HOUSING COSTS
description: More and more, owners of mobile -or manufactured - homes around the country are enjoying such amenities as fireplaces, saunas, cathedral ceilings, sunken tubs, solar-energy equipment, swimming pools and nearby golf courses.

title: FREEDOM FELLA CAPTURES PACE
description: Freedom Fella, a medium-size bay colt, broke the track record today in winning the $210,000 seventh edition of the Monticello Classic for 3-year-old New York-breds with a 3 3/4-length victory over Brand New Fella.

title: Suspect in Slaying Victim of Thefts
description: Angry neighbors ransacked the apartment of a Brooklyn building superintendent accused of slaying a 12-year-old boy and wounding his 14-year-old brother, the police said yesterday.

title: BURROUGHS IN PACT FOR MEMOREX
description: The Burroughs Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Memorex Corporation, the ailing maker of data storage equipment and audio tapes, for about $106 million in cash.

title: Bentley, Barnes & Lynn Get New President
description: Kenyon & Eckhardt's former chaiirman, Stanley A. Tannenbaum, 53 years old, this week joins Bentley, Barnes & Lynn, a Chicago agency with over $33 million in billings, as president.

title: Grey Advertising Net Gained 18.2%
description: Grey Advertising's second quarter statement is a comparatively good one. Revenues were $29.5 million, an 11.7 percent increase from the $26.3 million in the same period last year, while net income rose 18.2 percent, to $2.6 million from $2.2 million, or $4.33 a share compared with $3.59.

title: 650 R-46 CARS TAKEN TO SHOPS TO BE CHECKED
description: The New York City subway system's fleet of R-46 cars was pulled out of service over the weekend so that mechanics could inspect and repair electrical devices that have led to three smoky subway fires in the last four months.

title: 8TH HUNGER STRIKER, AN IRISH M.P., DIES AFTER A 73-DAY FAST IN ULSTER
description: Kieran Doherty, a 25-year-old member of the Irish Republican Army, tonight became the eighth man to die in the Maze Prison hunger strike.

title: KEMP SCORES POINTS AT HOME BY ROLE IN REAGAN'S TAX PLAN; New York Political Notes
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp of Erie County is viewed by many Republican politicians as the big New York gainer from the stunning passage of President Reagan's tax package.

title: INQUIRY ON TEAMSTER IS RULED OUT
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan has told Senate investigators that his department has no authority to challenge Roy L. Williams's fitness to remain president of the teamsters, a Congressional panel said today.

title: Film Society to Honor Billy Wilder at Gala
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center will honor Billy Wilder at its spring gala May 3. Mr. Wilder, the writer, producer and director, has been involved with more than 40 movies, including ''The Lost Weekend,'' ''Double Indemnity,'' ''Some Like It Hot,'' ''Sunset Boulevard,'' ''Stalag 17'' and ''The Seven-Year Itch.''

title: U.S. Women Win Final in Softball
description: Kathy Arendsen pitched her second perfect game of the year today, leading the United States team to a 3-0 victory over Canada and the gold medal in women's softball in the World Games.

title: SOUTHERN BLACKS LOSING LAND AT PRECIPITATE RATE
description: The trees and brush of the Harris Neck National Wildlife Refuge have all but covered the traces of the community of slave descendants who once made their living by hunting, fishing, farming and trapping on its 2,687 acres of rich tidal land.

title: Pressure Building In Springbok Issue
description: Prime Minister Robert Muldoon threatened today to call a general election unless talks involving protesters, police and rugby officials result in an agreement on the future of the tour by the Springboks, a South African rugby team.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TYPECASTING

title: DISPARITIES ARE FOUND IN SCHOOL DISTRICTS' USE OF REMEDIAL AID
description: A study of the allocation of funds within New York City's community school districts shows wide disparities among schools in the same districts in the amounts spent on each pupil, raising the possibility that some neighborhoods have received favored treatment.

title: STAGE: SELF-STYLED 'TWO GENTLEMEN'
description: ''TWO GENTLEMEN of Verona'' is one Shakespearean comedy that can benefit from irreverent interpretation, as was proved some seasons ago in Central Park by the free-form musical modernization of John Guare and Mel Shapiro. The Riverside Shakespeare Company, which last spring presented a refreshing indoor ''Love's Labors Lost,'' is staging an outdoor ''Two Gentlemen of Verona,'' which opened Friday night in the courtyard of the American Theater of Actors. Unfortunately, Daniel O. Smith's self-styled commedia dell'arte production offers little commedia and less arte.

title: AS SOVIET DISSIDENTS CONTINUE TO SUFFER
description: To the Editor:

title: Ventura Picks Up Oui
description: Ventura Associates, a sales promotion agency, has picked up Oui magazine, the former Playboy property, that is now being published by Laurant Publishing in New York. According to Ventura, the sales promotion budget alone will be $1.5 million.

title: WHY I'M LATE
description: 1. The bus never came. 2. The bus came and then broke down. 3. The car broke down. 4. The car hit the bus. 5. The cat got sick and I had to take her to the vet. 6. The toilet wouldn't stop flushing. 7. The baby got sick and I had to take her to the doctor. 8. The Seventh Avenue IRT local (express) (entire line) wasn't running. 9. I didn't know it was raining, and had to go back for my umbrella. 10. The alarm clock didn't go off. 11. I was up half the night looking for the guinea pig, which got loose. 12. A filling came out and I had to go to the dentist first thing this morning.13. I had to stick around and wait for the stove-repair man (plumber), (painter) (new cleaning lady). 14. The elevator in my building broke and I had to walk down 17 flights. 15. I got a puzzling letter from the I.R.S. and had to go to my accountant before work. 16. You know how traffic is the day after a holiday. 17. My cab driver got lost going from Riverside Drive to West End Avenue. 18. I dropped my house keys down the elevator shaft. 19. One of my contact lenses fell out in the subway-token line. 20. There was a big demonstration blocking traffic on Third Avenue. 21.

title: STUDENT INTERNS SEE GOVERNMENT WORK editor Sharon Melton
description: The summer interns arrive in Washington in eager droves. As they cluster in Congressional corridors for briefings and seminars, Southern drawls mixing with Western twangs and New England accents, it would appear that Washington has become one big campus.

title: High Levels of DDT Reported in South Texas
description: Despite a ban on DDT in both the United States and Mexico, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has found concentrations of the deadly pesticide in drinking water in southern Texas, The Dallas Morning News reported today.

title: AIR CONTROL UNION BREAKS OFF TALKS AS A STRIKE LOOMS
description: Negotiations between the Federal Government and the air traffic controllers' union broke off about 2:30 A.M. as the clock moved toward the union's strike deadline of 7 A.M.

title: Curfew Eased in West India
description: Authorities relaxed a round-the-clock curfew for three hours today in the western town of Godhra, where three people were killed and eight injured in Moslem-Hindu rioting, the United News of India reported. The agency said that armed police units marched through city streets in shows of strength on the day after the violence, which arose as a result of construction of stalls in the community's main bazaar. Godhra is about 280 miles northeast of Bombay.

title: Brown-Forman Picks Two New Agencies
description: The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation in Louisville, Ky., which said in its annual report that it would spend $265 million on advertising over the next three years, last week decided on two big new agencies through which to spend some of it.

title: Welcome To the Hall
description: THE family of baseball and the fans of baseball welcomed Bob Gibson, Johnny Mize and the memory of Andrew (Rube) Fgster to the Hall of Fame yesterday - but added more than a few boos for the officials and players of today.

title: Coast Tournament To Tracy Austin
description: Top-seeded Tracy Austin, who had lost only five games in her previous four matches, struggled today but recovered to beat second-seeded Pam Shriver, 6-2, 5-7, 6-2, in the final of the Wells Fargo tennis tournament.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With a man on second base, a ground ball is hit to third. The fielder holds the runner on second, then throws to first in time to retire the batter. However, the runner on second now breaks for third. As the first baseman attempts to throw the ball to that bag, the batter-runner collides with him and prevents the throw. Assuming the first baseman was in the baseline beyond the bag, what is the ruling?

title: WILLOW HOUR, 18-1, WINS JIM DANDY
