description: Willow Hour finished first at odds of 18-1, and Summing, the Belmont Stakes winner, finished last today in the Jim Dandy Stakes.

title: NEW LIGHT ON WIFE BEATINGS
description: A LMOST since wife abuse began to be recognized as a widespread problem a decade ago, specialists in the field have known that a husband's wish to maintain control of his wife has been a major factor, along with stress, frustration and alcohol. The wife abuser, when he feels his dominant role threatened, uses power to maintain it, the experts say.

title: Czech Leader Leaves Soviet
description: The Czechoslovak leader, Gustav Husak, left for home today after what the official Soviet press agency Tass described as a period of rest and recreation in the Soviet Union. During his nearly two-week vacation, the 68-year-old Mr. Husak conferred in the Crimea with the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: No Headline
description: Bouchard Victor

title: OOSTERHUIS WINS CANADIAN OPEN
description: Peter Oosterhuis, an English golfer with 19 victories abroad, weathered late challenges by Jack Nicklaus, Mark Hayes and Andy North today to win the Canadian Open for his first victory on the PGA Tour.

title: Miss Wittenstein Bride of Student
description: Jessica Wittenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wittenstein of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to Frank David Barranco, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank H. Barranco of Solvang, Calif. State Supreme Court Justice Joseph J. Dowd performed the ceremony at the Wittensteins' summer home in Quogue, L.I.

title: 138 Million Mistake Seen In Big Air Force Project
description: The largest construction project in the history of the United States Air Force has made a $138 million mistake, The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported today. The $437 million Aeropropulsion Systems Test Facility, near Manchester, Tenn., was planned for a decade, but when the time came to install equipment, it would not fit, the paper's article said.

title: THE HAMBLETONIAN IS TAKING ITS URBAN TURN
description: haired ladies who sold chicken dinners from the lawns of Goshen's white churches, and the closest thing to Du Quoin's corn can be found eight miles to the East in the stalls of Ninth Avenue's produce markets. For better or for worse, the Hambletonian Trot has made it to Megalopolis Downs.

title: Index; International
description: Once again drought brings fear to Brazil's northeast A2 East German leaflet said to urge revolt A3 Sadat embarks on trip to U.S., Britain and Austria A5 Around the World A7 Government/Politics R-46 subway cars taken out of service for electrical repairs B1 State Comptroller assails pension practices of transit workers B3 A pollster for Koch inadvertently dials an opponent in primary B3 Jack Kemp shares the Republi- can tax-vote victory B6 General Around the Nation A8 Oshkosh air show scene of annual experimental aircraft ''fly-in'' A8 Michigan hunter finds $383,000 - and a major law suit A11 Blacks in South losing their land at precipitate rate A11 Three fires cause damage in Suf- folk County B2 Rhode Island man who died in Queens suffered head injuries B2 Morningside Heights wary of work on Columbia buildings B3 Businesses in South Bronx apply- ing for Con Ed discounts B6 Mobile homes becoming more of an answer to housing prayers D12 Industry/Labor Cleveland Press gambles by starting a Sunday edition A8 Health/Science Use of ponds to store solar energy is explored A9 Education/Welfare Student interns learn inner work- ings of Washington A13 Study finds education funds un- evenly distributed in New York B2 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Piquet captures West German Grand Prix C5 Baseball: Mets' Wilpon con- cerned with fans' reaction C7

title: 5 MUSICAL TAYLORS IN CONCERT AT THE SOUTH STREET SEAPORT
description: The musical Taylor family -James, Alex, Livingston, Hugh and their sister, Kate - will appear together in New York for the first time Wednesday night. They will give a benefit concert against the backdrop of the Brooklyn Bridge and the lights of Lower Manhattan's skyscrapers on Pier 16 at the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: THE MAKING OF A CELEBRITY: PATE JUMPS IN THE LAKE
description: iron approach to the 18th green that won the United States Open in 1976, a shot nearly as famous as Gene Sarazen's 4-wood for a double eagle in the 1935 Masters. Unlike Sarazen, Pate subsequently did something to attract even more attention than that glorious birdie: he celebrated his first victory in three years by diving, fully clothed, into a lake beside another 18th green.

title: LOFY YIELDS DISCOURAGE MANY NEW DEBT ISSUES
description: Corporations do not like to compete with the Treasury for longterm investors, so this week's calendar includes only one debt issue, and that is convertible into common stock.

title: SALVADOR LAND PROGRAM AIDS FEW
description: It has been nearly a year and a half since the Government of El Salvador inaugurated one of the most sweeping land redistribution programs ever attempted in Latin America. But here on this 1,500-acre farm, which has been converted to a peasant-run cooperative, the milking stalls are empty.

title: GAMBIAN LEADER RETURNS AS REBELS GIVE WAY
description: President Dawda Kairaba Jawara of Gambia flew back to his capital, Banjul, today from neighboring Senegal, confident that Senegalese troops had all but crushed an attempted coup by Marxist rebels.

title: Youngblood Back
description: Joel Youngblood, the leading batter in the majors at .359 when the baseball strike began June 12, was returned to the Mets' roster yesterday. Youngblood, named to complete the team's 25-man roster, replaced Tim Leary, the young pitcher, who was sent to Tidewater in the International League for additional work. Youngblood suffered a sprained right knee June 6 and was placed on the disabled list June 8.

title: News Analysis
description: The death of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera of Panama in a plane crash over the weekend has created a potentially dangerous power vacuum, with serious implications not only for his nation and the rest of the convulsed Central American isthmus, but also for the United States, which still has some 10,000 troops stationed in the country to protect the Panama Canal.

title: WORRIED TRAVELERS PREPARE TO SHIFT FROM AIRLINES
description: As the strike deadline set by the air traffic controllers neared, some airline passengers scrambled to change their plans yesterday, while bus lines, railroads and car-rental companies prepared for an increase in travelers.

title: MISS CAPONI TAKES TOURNEY BY 6 SHOTS
description: Donna Caponi moved closer to becoming the second woman to win $1 million on the golf tour today with a sixstroke victory in a $150,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Sue Berger Is Bride Of Peter Grossman
description: Sue Berger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Berger of Valley Strem, L.I., was married yesterday to Peter Grossman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert K. Grossman of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Paul R. Siegel performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill, in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Baker Sees a 'Difficult Fight' On Sale of Planes to Saudis
description: Senator Howard Baker, the majority leader, said today he expected President Reagan to give Congress informal notice next month of plans to sell electronic surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: LEGALLY, WAS BURIED $383,000, A TROVE, OR JUST LOST GOODS?
description: A struggle over a buried treasure containing $383,000 when it was found in 1974 that has grown to more than $650,000 through investment started with a day of squirrel hunting. A young hunter's discovery has become so enmeshed in conflicting claims that the eventual owner or owners may have to be decided by the Supreme Court of Michigan.

title: Khomeini Confirms Rajai As Iranian President
description: Mohammed Ali Rajai, Iran's new President, was confirmed in office today by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who warned him that there would be calls for his death if he ever betrayed the Islamic revolution.

title: Rebecca Fox Wed To William Green
description: Rebecca MacMillan Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Whiting Fox of Ithaca, N.Y., and Annisquam, Mass., was married in Ithaca yesterday to William Scott Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Green of Manchester, N.H. Rabbi Jacob Neusner, University Professor and Ungerleider Distinguished Scholar of Judaic Studies at Brown University, performed the garden ceremony at the home of the bride's sister and brother-in-law, Elizabeth Fox-Genovese and Eugene Dominic Genovese.

title: ILLEGAL HOOKUP: SILENT FOE OF A CABLE TELEVISION LINE
description: The wire that the police found trailing from a telephone pole into the home of John Weaver led them to charge him with the unusual crime of theft of a television signal. The charge reflects what some communications experts view as a growing national problem that few cable television companies want to publicize.

title: MILITARY IS TOLD TO PREPARE CUTS IN 1983 BUDGET
description: The Reagan Administration has instructed the military services to identify in their 1983 budget proposals a series of 5 percent cuts that might be made if needed to keep the Federal Government headed toward balancing the budget in 1984.

title: REICHHOLD NAMES 2 TOP EXECUTIVES
description: Donald G. McNabb, 62 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Reichhold Ltd., and Donald J. McLeod, 50, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Toronto concern. They succeed George L. Hagen, who held the top positions at the synthetic resins manufacturer and who took early retirement at the age of 58 after 30 years with the company and 15 years as its head.

title: A GRAVE TIME FOR POLAND
description: .6,0,165.6,2,515.2,0PARIS, Aug. 2 - Poland is facing as tense and dangerous a moment as any time since World War II. Now, it is the unorganized consumers, harrassed housewives who are massing in protest and taking to the streets.

title: Paralysis Tests Due for Turner
description: Landon Turner, the Indiana University basketball star who suffered a broken spine in an auto accident, is probably alert enough for doctors to determine the extent of his paralysis, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Washington Watch; Antitrust Sign Is Glimpsed
description: WASHINGTON THE Justice Department has given its first signals of the way it intends to enforce antitrust policy under the doctrine of Attorney General William French Smith that bigness is not necessarily bad.

title: 2 Rowing Titles To Ivy Leaguers
description: John Biglow and Ann Marden, a pair of Ivy League scullers, earned the right today to represent the United States in the world championships in Munich, West Germany, later this month.

title: Bridge: 3 New York Teams Remain In Spingold Knockout Play
description: When play resumed here this afternoon in the Spingold knockout team championship, three New York teams were still in the running for the premier title at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: NEWARK'S AIRPORT WILL ADD A HOTEL
description: The Port Authority is planning $100 million in major construction projects at Newark International Airport over the next four years, officials of the authority said yesterday.

title: Mine Merger Is Approved
description: The Sunshine Mining Company, a leading silver producer, announced that its plan to merge with the Silver Dollar Mining Company, Silver Syndicate Inc., Sunshine Consolidated Inc. and the Big Creek Apex Company had been approved by directors of the four companies, all silver-mining concerns based in Wallace, Idaho.

title: Your Team or Mine?
description: Ed and Michele Sprague of Stockton, Calif., may be the only twoteam husband and wife among baseball owners. Ed bought the Class A Stockton Ports in late 1979, and Michele purchased another California League team, the Lodi Dodgers, in March 1981.

title: 5 Scoring Passes Rout Alouettes
description: Joe Barnes threw five touchdown passes today that carried the Saskatchewan Roughriders to a 43-23 rout of the Montreal Alouettes.

title: Nancy E. Small Bride Of Gordon Rosenberg
description: Nancy E. Small, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Small of Middletown, N.J., was married there yesterday to Gordon S. Rosenberg, son of Prof. and Mrs. Nathan Rosenberg of Palo Alto, Calif. Rabbi Harry Weiner performed the ceremony at the Small home.

title: Youths and Adult Arrested in Theft
description: Nine youths and one man have been arrested, and the police said they expected to charge six more soon, in the burglary of 9,600 workmen's caps from the United Shop Cap Company.The hats were valued at $13,000.

title: ROAD TO REPAIR IS A LONG ONE FOR A HIGHWAY IN CONNECTICUT
description: After almost a quarter-century of controversy, plans for improving Route 7 have yielded to hard times. The stretch between Norwalk and Danbury is being repaired instead of being completely rebuilt.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday incorrectly described the control of Mortimer Zuckerman, the Boston real estate developer, over a string of suburban Boston newspapers. Mr. Zuckerman owns 10 percent of the outstanding stock of the chain.

title: MOSTLY MOZART: OPERA WORKS ARE CONDUCTED BY LEPPARD
description: THE Mostly Mozart Festival all too infrequently brings forward the seldom-heard scores of its eponymous composer, especially the earlier operas and choral music. On Friday night, Raymond Leppard made a gesture in the right direction by conducting concert performances of two one-act operas, ''Bastien und Bastienne'' and ''The Impresario'' - not exactly unexplored Mozartean terrain, perhaps, but a welcome departure from the more predictable fare.

title: DROUGHT AGAIN BRINGS FEAR TO NORTHEASTERN BRAZIL
description: otf881 By WARREN HOGE

title: OPERA: SANTA FE TROUPE GIVES STRAUSS'S 'DAPHNE'
description: ''Daphne,'' the 13th of Richard Strauss's 15 operas, has not in its more than 40 years of existence been able to establish itself in the international opera repertory. Such obscurity in music is usually well deserved. Still, anyone who experienced last night's transfixing performance of the work by the Santa Fe Opera must have gone away perplexed as to why this gorgeous work has had such a hard time making its way.

title: REUSCHEL FINALLY GETS YANKS UNIFORM
description: After 50 days as a Yankee, Rick Reuschel found out the baseball strike was over when he got a telephone call at dawn last Friday from the Chicago Cubs' player representative.

title: Archbishop Criticizes Regime in El Salvador
description: The acting archbishop of San Salvador sharply criticized El Salvador's ruling junta today for laxity in its investigation of the murders of four American women.

title: FOR JETS, CAUTION IS PEPLACING LAST YEAR'S OPTIMISM
description: guessing himself about last season's exhibition games, and he vows that this year he and his New York Jets will have a different approach.

title: Red Smith Farmer in the Big Town
description: AS classic races go, the Hambletonian is a pup. When it was started in 1926, the Kentucky Derby was already 51 years old, the Belmont 59 and the Travers Stakes 62. Nevertheless, the Hambletonian is a genuine classic, America's premier event in a sport that is indigenous to this country because it was on these shores that the light harness horse was originally bred.

title: PARIS COUTURE REFUSES TO BE UPSTAGED BY WEDDING
description: The French do not care to be upstaged in affairs of style, which is one reason there were so many parties during the last week when the fall couture shows were being presented. There was that wedding over in London, you see, and some of the most elegant women kept shuttling there for dinners and receptions.

title: GIANTS' KICKING DUO IS UNCHALLENGED
description: The quietest facet of the Giants' training camp has been the one with the least competition for jobs - the kicking game, securely in the hands of Joe Danelo and Dave Jennings.

title: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY SALES AND PROFITS AT 282 COMPANIES
Purchasers See Decline
description: Purchasing managers, who shop for the supplies used by the nation's industry, reported yesterday a sharp deterioration in the economy last month. Output levels, incoming new orders and employment, all key indicators, dropped in July, they said.

title: THE DAY A ROCKEFELLER SAW THRIFT IN ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Irving McKinley Levy Is Dead;
description: Office Equipment Executive

title: SOVIET BID FOR GRAIN EXPECTED
description: The Soviet grain harvest is now in full swing along country roads outside this city these days, and there is ample evidence as to why the United States Department of Agriculture is forecasting a relatively poor performance for the third year in a row.

title: No Headline
description: HAITIAN REFUGEES RELOCATED: Roger Atwell, the senior security officer at the Lexington Federal Correctional Institute, escorting some of 200 Haitians to their new quarters at the Kentucky prison yesterday. The refugees, all men, were transferred from Miami's Krome Avenue North camp to alleviate overcrowding.

title: Langer Is Victor
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany shot a one-over-par 72 today and delighted a huge patriotic crowd by winning the $85,000 German Open golf championship.

title: CONGRESS SET TO GIVE ADMINISTRATION TAX BILL FINAL APPROVAL
description: Congress is expected to give final approval this week to an Administration-sponsored tax bill that is replete with a wide variety of special tax breaks for individuals and business, including three years of cuts in individual income tax rates.

title: U.S. POLICY SHIFT SEEN ON THIRD-WORLD TALKS
description: Leading industrialized and developing nations agreed today to discuss their longstanding differences at a summit conference here in late October. There were also signs that the Reagan Administration may be softening its stance toward the negotiation of so-called North-South issues later at the United Nations.

title: Dr. D.R. Payne, at 45; Husband of Journalist
description: Dr. Donald Rollie Payne, husband of Jessica Savitch, an NBC News correspondent, was found dead in the couple's home today, the police said.

title: ANDREA DORIA: OLD MYSTERIES AND NEW QUEST
description: ABOARD THE SEA LEVEL 11, Aug. 2 - On the rolling dark sea 50 miles south of Nantucket, a small group of film makers, deep-sea divers and adventurers hover in two small boats above the wreck of the Andrea Doria, hoping to steal two of the secrets she has guarded for a quarter of a century.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS GAIN IN 2D QUARTER
description: Corporate profits in general advanced in the second quarter of 1981 from the depressed second three months of 1980, a compilation by The New York Times of the sales and earnings of 282 companies indicates.

title: Getty Cuts Prices In 2 Areas of State
description: The Getty Oil Company has reduced the wholesale price of its unleaded regular and leaded regular gasoline in the Albany and Newburgh, N.Y., markets to make its product more competitive.

title: A $6 Million Role
description: It was a smile that not only lit up the face but singed the mustache as well. Eddie Bracken had just closed a $6 million deal and didn't care who knew it.

title: CABLEVISION'S BRASH MAVERICK
description: When Cablevision decided to introduce a new cable network last year, the service was nothing if not novel: two nights a week of esoteric performing arts shows under the name ''Bravo'' and five nights a week of soft-core sex films in a package called ''Escapade.'' The concept - brash, risky, inventive and perhaps a bit ahead of its time - was fully consistent with the company's style.

title: AMPLE VARIETY DUE AT AUCTION
description: The words ''peak'' and ''record high'' have become worn with overuse in the credit markets, but the weight of this week's Treasury financings could provoke several more rounds of headlines proclaiming high rates.

title: Boat Returns to Port After Mutiny Is Reported
description: A fishing boat returned to port today, escorted by the Coast Guard, after an incident off Cape Cod in which the captain was reportedly forced to barricade himself on the bridge from crewmen wielding guns and knifes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe that there has been a real change in U.S. attitudes in the past month.

title: Advertising
description: JUST when the American executive is being drowned in business news and information, 88-year-old Dun's Review, a monthly business magazine, is repositioning itself as a lifesaver, offering ''Monthto-Month Resuscitation!'' according to its advertising.

title: 8-Concert Series Listed By Beethoven Society
description: The Beethoven Society has announced its program of concerts for next season at Alice Tully Hall. The concerts, on Sundays at 3 P.M., will begin Sept. 13 with a Beethoven piano recital by Grant Johannesen.

title: 3 BLAZES CAUSE HEAVY DAMAGES ON LONG ISLAND
description: Three early-morning fires, two set by arsonists in central Long Island and one declared suspicious near the eastern tip of the Island, caused heavy damage and were being investigated by Suffolk County arson detectives yesterday.

title: HEART RECIPIENT IS DEAD IN HOUSTON
description: A man who had been kept alive for 54 hours by an artificial heart implant, and then for a week on a transplanted human heart, died today of kidney failure, lung problems and infection.

title: An Appreciation
description: Whether he was writing for television, Broadway or the movies, Paddy Chayefsky, who died of cancer Saturday night in New York at the age of 58, was first of all a playwright, with a love of words. In Hollywood, he was that rarity, the writer as auteur; except for his most recent film, ''Altered States,'' his movies belonged to him, not to his director. The scope and style of his work changed dramatically over the years. One might say that as an artist he went through several altered states - from intimate domestic dramas during the early golden age of television to a theatrical naturalism that was sometimes filtered through with mysticism to the high-powered almost maniacal comic intensity of his satiric movies ''The Hospital'' and ''Network.''

title: Judge Has to Go Back to Step 1
description: It began in court, and now, it seems, it is going to end in court. John Kaufman, a 56-year-old Family Court Judge in Lake County, Ill., near Chicago, has filed for divorce from his wife, Crystal, 51, whom he met while hearing her divorce case six years ago.

title: Labor Party Offers 'Radical' Economic Plan
description: Britain's opposition Labor Party today released an economic blueprint that includes a proposed wealth tax aimed at what its national committee called a ''radical vision of a socialist Britain.''

title: AS COLUMBIA INSPECTS FACADES, SOME FEAR THEIR LOSS
description: On Riverside Drive the ornate, 12-story curve of the Colosseum Apartments sweeps grandly around the corner into 116th Street, forming part of the gateway to Columbia University.

title: Letter: On Federal Aid More Housing Funds Than Meet the Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: DUO PIANISTS TO PLAY AT STATE DINNER
description: In response to an invitation from President and Mrs. Reagan, Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale, the duo pianists, will perform Virgil Thomson's ''Walking Song,'' among other works, Wednesday night at the White House after a state dinner given for President and Mrs. Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt. ''Walking Song,'' a description of citizens walking to the voting booth, is from the score for the documentary ''Tuesday in November.''

title: EAST GERMANS URGED TO REVOLT
description: East German dissidents have issued bold demands for democratic rights and called on East Germans to rebel against their Communist leaders, the West German news magazine Der Spiegel said today.

title: Wilpon Concerned About Fan Reaction
description: Fred Wilpon looked across Shea Stadium from the third-base line yesterday and saw that the last of the truants had returned: Dave Kingman from his boat, Tom Hausman from his mountain, Dyar Miller from his farm and Doug Flynn from his country and western club in the bluegrass.

title: Hydropower to All the People
description: A homeowner in White Plains pays about $86 a month for 700 kilowatt-hours of electricity. A family in Plattsburgh, N.Y., pays just $11 for the same amount. This remarkable difference is due partly to the higher taxes and distribution charges in Westchester. But much of the difference is an accident of law and politics. For unlike Con Edison, which must generate power with expensive oil, Plattsburgh is guaranteed incredibly cheap hydropower sold by New York State.

title: IN LIEU OF TIGHT MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Cases of Dengue Fever Found Among Refugees
description: Dengue fever, a tropical disease that has killed 113 people in Cuba, has been detected among Haitian refugees but poses no danger to South Florida, officials said.

title: SADAT STARTS TRIP TO BRITAIN, US AND AUSTRIA
description: President Anwar el-Sadat left Egypt today on a trip to Britain, Austria and the United States in an effort to stimulate the resumption of comprehensive talks on a Middle East peace settlement.

title: DR. DAVID C. SHAPIRO
description: Dr. David C. Shapiro, minority leader of the Illinois state Senate, died yesterday at his vacation home in Montana.

title: NORTH CONWAY GETS ALL-ARGENTINE FINAL
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina, shooting for his third consecutive tournament victory, overcame a one-set deficit today and upset Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 6-4, 6-4, in the semifinals of the $200,000 Volvo International.

title: NORTHEAST PORTS SEEK SHELTER
description: New York-area ports, along with other northeastern United States ports, have been taking a competitive drubbing, American shipping experts say, from Montreal and other ports in Canada - thanks largely to the success of the Cast Group, an enterprising Canadianowned shipping organization.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/Jim Wilson and Keith Meyers Around Town: Weekend Diversions As visitors to Central Park got around on various wheeled and hoofed conveyances, the crowd at the beach at Coney Island was treated to an aeronautics show by the Navy's Blue Angels precision flying team.

title: I.O.C. FUND IS CHALLENGED
description: A three-day conference of the Association of National Olympic Committees ended today, with the association showing signs of rebellion against the International Olympic Committee.

title: Market Place; Ways to Select A Money Fund
description: MONEY market funds confuse many investors who find it difficult to choose among them. The selection process is usually a question of picking a fund for the highest yield. But at a time when the funds are growing almost too fast to keep up with new business, many investors simply settle for one with an open telephone line.

title: Bonn Steel Aid
description: The West German Government plans to provide $536 million between 1982 and 1985 to assist the nation's troubled steel industry, Kurt Becker, a Government spokesman, said.

title: OPERA: JESSYE NORMAN'S ISOLDE
description: This summer's Boston Symphony Orchestra schedule at Tanglewood is not replete with exciting novelties or grandiose special productions. But last night's concert promised something of unusual interest, nevertheless - one of Jessye Norman's first excursions into the heavy Wagnerian repetory.

title: THE CITY;
description: More than $200,000 in jewelry has been stolen from the Park Avenue apartment of George McFadden, an investment banker, the police said. The burglary of the apartment occurred sometime between 1 P.M. Thursday, when Mr. McFadden, 40 years old, left for a long weekend, and 6 o'clock last night, when he returned to his home at 812 Park Avenue, between 74th and 75th Streets, a police spokesman said.

title: A KOREAN IN PRISON
description: .2,0,248.4,2,248.4,0COLUMBUS, Ohio - A friend of mine, a law professor in South Korea, was arrested last year, imprisoned, and beaten so severely that he could not raise his arms. He was in solitary confinement; last winter in his cell he suffered frostbite on his face and on an ear. He can contemplate spending next winter in the same prison.

title: SEAGRAM BUYS 18% OF CONOCO
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, one of the three contenders in the costly battle to take over Conoco Inc., and the only one to have paid out cash so far, said yesterday that it had received 15.5 million shares, or roughly 18 percent of Conoco's outstanding stock.

title: Torrijos's Body Flown To Panama's Capital
description: A Panamanian Air Force helicopter today brought to Panama City the body of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, head of the Panamanian National Guard and effective ruler of the nation since 1968.

title: It's Another Bicentennial Year
description: Most Americans have forgotten that the nation's bicentennial celebration had originally been planned as a seven-year extravaganza, but not Peter Max.

title: CONCERT: TANGLEWOOD GOES CONTEMPORARY
description: Every summer since the days of Serge Koussevitzky and Aaron Copland, the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood has presented a week of contemporary music concerts. The concerts enlist student fellows attending the center for the summer, guests artists and the Boston Symphony, and are generously underwritten by Paul Fromm, the Chicago new-music patron.

title: Pope Prays for Victims Of 1980 Station Bombing
description: Pope John Paul II, recovering in the hospital from an assassination attempt, prayed today for the victims of Europe's bloodiest post-World War II terrorist attack - the bombing of the Bologna rail station in which 85 people died a year ago.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Company, Wayne, N.J., has named William L. Berry president of the organic chemicals division, and Gordon D. Sterling president of the Formica Corporation, a wholly-owned subsidiary.

title: Swedish Venture
description: Two Swedish industrial ad agencies are planning to open a joint venture agency in Stamford, Conn., early next year.

title: An Acting Director Is Chosen For Solar Research Institute
description: The Government's Solar Energy Research Institute has a new acting director, Dr. Harold Hubbard, who was named to the postition Saturday.

title: 'WOLFSEN': A CASE OF DIRECTOR'S RIGHTS
description: The ''Wolfen'' arbitration lasted 21 days, the longest case in the history of the Directors Guild of America. Unlike most movie disputes that end up in the legal system, money was not an issue. Michael Wadleigh, director of ''Wolfen'' - the offbeat horror film about a pack of superwolves that roams the decaying central cores of large American cities - challenged his employer, Orion Pictures, over his creative rights as a director.

title: BANKAMERICA SETS CANADIAN GROWTH
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said its Canadian subsidiary, BA Financial Services Ltd., acquired a Canadian federal charter and will become a new nationwide bank with 30 offices and authorized capital of $60 million (Canadian).

title: Farewell To Gallo
description: TWO YEARS after resigning the Bristol-Myers business, Young & Rubicam, the largest American advertising agency, yesterday quit $24 million worth of billings from the E.&J. Gallo Winery, which has a reputation of being one of the more difficult and demanding advertising clients.

title: NIMBLE COMMODITIES BROKER
description: Wall Street analysts have long found it difficult to explain to investors the style and management of the highly secretive Philipp Brothers trading company. In the end, they usually resorted to analogy.

title: Ukrainian Youth Seeks Permanent Residency
description: A 13-year-old boy and his adult sister who have been granted political asylum in the United States filed a formal request today for permanent residency.

title: CLEAN AIR: DEFENDING A LAW IN PERIL
description: The health of more than 35 million Americans is now in jeopardy because of dirty air. In addition, it is estimated that 100,000 to 200,000 Americans may die quietly and without publicity each year from air pollution.

title: Male Stereotyping TO SCIENCETIMES:
description: David Macdonald may take pride in his discoveries of the social behavior of foxes, but if his interpretations were accurately reported by Lois Wingerson, (Science Times, July 28), they reveal stereotypical male biases and two blatant contradictions. A careful reading of the factual evidence reported in the article can support a quite different anthropomorphic rendering of the ''surprising'' group life of foxes.

title: Citibank Lifts Loan Rates
description: Citibank, the nation's second-largest bank after the Bank of America, said yesterday that it was raasing consumer loan rates in the New York metropolitan area because of the ''persistently high cost of funds.''

title: Ashland Bonds Downgraded
description: The ratings on Ashland Oil Company bonds were reduced yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which expressed concern over the company's profit outlook.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DISNEY REMEMBERED

title: NEW YORK BANS AMPHETAMINES AS A DIETING AID
description: Governor Carey signed a bill today that would make it illegal for a physician to prescribe amphetamines for the sole purpose of helping a patient lose weight.

title: FULLBACKS' INJURIES ARE WORRY FOR JETS
description: The Jets' fullback unit, planned as one of their imposing weapons, loomed as a trouble spot today when Clark Gaines and his heir apparent, Marion Barber, were sidelined. There is a chance that neither will be ready when the regular season begins.

title: TANGLEWOOD: ISANG YUN AND LESTER TRIMBLE
description: The trouble with the Berkshire Music Center's Festival of Contemporary Music in recent years has been what this writer called ''conservatism'' in describing Saturday's opening concert. That might seem an odd word to use for the European-chromatic bias of the festival's organizers; they think of the word as better applied to the neo-tonal composers of recent years. But there is so much else going on in new music today - tonal, atonal, consonant and dissonant -that the Tanglewood festival's insistence on its own openness begins to sound either disingenuous or simply uninformed.

title: FUQUA ACTS TO BUY ALL COMPANY STOCK
description: Fuqua Industries Inc., the Atlanta-based conglomerate whose properties include an oil distribution company prominent in the South, announced yesterday that J.B. Fuqua, its founder and chairman, and other members of management intended to acquire all of the company's 12.9 million common shares for more than $500 million, or $20 a share.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (NL) - Optioned Carlos Lezcano, outfielder, to Des Moines of the American Association. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Waived Mike Sadek, catcher; recalled Bob Brenly, catcher, from Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League. BASKETBALL

title: Phillips Arranges $1 Billion Credit
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, the nation's 10th-largest oil company, said it has arranged a $1 billion revolving credit line with a group of United States and European banks led by Citicorp and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL SIGN PACT ON SINAI
description: Egypt and Israel formally signed an agreement today establishing a 2,500-member international peacekeeping force in the Sinai to police their peace treaty. Nearly half of the force will be composed of United States combat troops and civilian observers.

title: ACROSS U.S., AIRPORTS SHIFT OLD ROUTINES
description: By early evening it had become hard to tell that the airport here had been hit by a major strike. TV camera crews filmed lengthening lines at ticket counters, and crowds mobbed the coffee shop, game rooms and baggage claim area.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: People
description: * Peter Horst has joined D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/Chicago as a senior vice president.

title: Dow Dips 6.09 in Slow Session
description: Takeover situations dominated traders' attention on Wall Street yesterday as these issues shared in the day's best gains. But stocks overall declined in the face of competition from high-yielding money market funds and similar investments.

title: ISRAELI COALITION TALKS STALLED
description: Efforts by Prime Minister Menachem Begin to form a new coalition Government faltered late today over the demands of a small religious political group that Mr. Begin needs to gain a majority in Israel's Parliament.

title: Man Convicted In Subway Assault
description: A man whose gun misfired as he tried to shoot a Transit Police officer point-blank was found guilty of attempted assault and criminal possession of a weapon in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: SOLIDARITY THREATENS STRIKE ACTION
description: A demonstration against food shortages turned into a confrontation between the Polish authorities and the Solidarity union yesterday when the police halted a column of about 100 buses and trucks bedecked with flags and placards.

title: JELLYFISH'S FEARSOME REPUTATION IS WORSE THAN ITS
description: STING By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

title: BILL WOULD REQUIRE RESEARCH AID FOR SMALL COMPANIES
description: WASHINGTON SMALL high-technology companies, free of the bureaucratic fetters and institutional inertia of larger enterprises, are the wellspring of pioneering innovations in this country. But such firms, intrinsically fragile and risky, have found it increasingly difficult to make their way in these times of expensive research and high interest rates.

title: THOUSANDS ARE SEEKING ALTERNATIVES TO AIR TRIPS
description: Rail, bus and car rental transportation services in the metropolitan New York area were confronted yesterday with thousands of people seeking alternative ways to travel because of the air controllers' strike.

title: K.G.B.'S EXPERTISE IN 'DISINFORMNG' THE WEST
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Code of the Quipu: A Study in Media, Mathematics and Culture By Marcia and Robert Ascher. 166 pages. University of Michigan Press in Ann Arbor. $18.95 cloth, $8.95 paper.

title: STAGE AND FILM ACTOR
description: Melvyn Douglas, the actor, died early this morning at Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital after a short illness.

title: Jackson Comes Back on a Cheerful Note
description: Deep in the woods near Carmel, Calif., where there is no mail delivery and no telephone, Reggie Jackson spent the last seven weeks tinkering with his antique cars and trying to forget his troubles.

title: It's Time for Ricoh To Get Better Known
description: Having decided on aggressive marketing of its quartz analog watch in the highly competitive American market, Ricoh, the Japanese manufacturer, must first get its name known among consumers. To do that it has turned for help to Quasimodo to carry the ball.

title: Explosion at Church Wedding In Cairo Kills 3 and Injures 56
description: A bomb explosion ripped through a Coptic church during a wedding ceremony last night, killing 3 people and wounding at least 56, the Egyptian Attorney General announced today.

title: Article 218704 -- No Title
description: The Apex Holding Company, a privately owned St. Louis concern with oil interests, has offered to pay $535 million for the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation, including a 43.5 percent stake still owned by the Clark family.

title: SHADOW OF DEATH APPEARS, THEN GOES IN A FLASH
description: A burst of flaming yellow-white light exploded in my face. My legs started to buckle and my body went numb with the anticipation of pain. I instinctively brought up my arm to protect my face.

title: ABDUL-JABBAR STAYS ON LAKERS
description: At a meeting yesterday in Los Angeles, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Jerry Buss, owner of the Lakers, reached an understanding that will keep the star center with the Lakers.

title: YONKERS COUNCIL REJECTS PLAN BY WESTCHESTER COUNTY FOR AID
description: The Yonkers City Council early this morning rejected a revised municipal budget and a new effort by Westchester County to provide $1.1 million in aid to the city.

title: POP: FLASH AND FURIOUS 5
description: ''WE are not a band, we are seven guys and two turntables,'' announced Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five, at the end of their set at the Peppermint Lounge on Friday. Though this rap group from the South Bronx was treated derisively by the audience for the Clash when it opened for that band at Bond's two months ago, at the Peppermint Lounge it established an instant and total rapport with the packed house.

title: Leftist Rebels in Gambia Said to Free 2 Hostages
description: Leftist rebels in the West African nation of Gambia have freed two Senegalese diplomats among their 30 hostages, diplomatic sources said today.

title: PILOT REPORTS A 'NEAR MISS' IN NEW JERSEY
description: Two jetliners came within a quarter of a mile of each other over northern New Jersey yesterday morning, but the Federal Aviation Agency said the incident had ''nothing at all to do'' with the strike by air traffic controllers.

title: POP: STEPHANIE MILLS OFFERS A WIDE REPERTORY
description: soul hits as ''Sweet Sensation,'' Miss Mills wants to be all things to all people. And at Friday's opening she showed that she had the physical resources to accomplish that goal, as she performed with a vigor that was positively ferocious in its desire to please.

title: 'Don't Try to Top John Young'
description: Col. Richard H. Truly of the Air Force and Joe H. Engle, the astronauts scheduled to fly the second orbital test flight of the space shuttle this fall, say they expect to have a successful flight but doubt it will top the first mission.

title: Suspended License Leads to 3 Arrests
description: TRENTON (AP) - Three persons have been charged with bribery and conspiracy in what the police say was an attempt to illegally restore a suspended driver's license. One of those arrested was an employee of the State Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: NOT-SO-SAUDI
description: MONARCHYTo the Editor:

title: RELIANCE ABANDONS MOTOR PLAN
description: The books were closed yesterday on an unusually controversial technology failure when the Reliance Electric Company announced that it was abandoning efforts to develop energy-saving motor controls based on a device invented in 1979 by its parent, the Exxon Corporation.

title: BALLET: RENAT CALDERINI DANCES JULIET FOR LA SCALA
description: THE La Scala Opera Ballet waited until its next-to-last day at the Metropolitan Opera House to unveil one of its happiest assets. Last Friday, Renata Calderini, a soloist with the Italian company, made her New York debut as Juliet in Rudolf Nureyev's production of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' playing opposite the impetuous Romeo of Mr. Nureyev. And from her first moments as a sulky but well-mannered colt, ready to embark on the kind of romantic adventures she has observed her nurse indulging in, to her last moments as the tender vision of Romeo's weary travels, Miss Calderini had the audience entranced.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 4, 1981
description: International A Warsaw protest over food shortages turned into a confrontation between the Polish authorities and the Solidarity labor union. The police halted a column of buses and trucks bearing flags and placards in the center of the capital and the independent union's spokesman warned that if force was used to break up the demonstration, an immediate strike would be called. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) An accord on a Sinai peace force was signed by Egypt and Israel. The agreement establishes a 2,500-member international force in the peninsula to police the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. The United States will provide nearly half of the force. (A1:1.)

title: Korea-Zapata Pact
description: South Korea has signed an agreement to explore jointly for oil with the Zapata Exploration Company, a subsidiary of the Houston-based Zapata Corporation, Energy and Resources Ministry officials said today.

title: LEBANESE PHALANGIST VISITS US HOPING FOR TALKS
description: One of Lebanon's Christian rightist military leaders is in Washington hoping to meet with top State Department officials to discuss American policy on Lebanon and the Middle East.

title: A Loan Applicant Draws an Ovation
description: A $70,000 loan is a yawn for a big-time bank like Citibank, but Joseph Mulqueen, a loan officer at the bank's branch at Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street, wasn't yawning at the application for one such loan the other day. He was on his feet applauding, like everyone else in the bank.

title: AN EARLY INTRODUCTION TO FIGHTING CITY HALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Halliburton Net Up 32.3%
description: The Halliburton Company, a diversified oil well services concern based in Dallas, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter increased 32.3 percent, to $166.7 million, or $1.42 a share, from $126 million, or $1.08 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1980. Revenues rose 23.5 percent, to $2.1 billion, from $1.7 billion.

title: SUIT UNVEILS 9-YEAR COMPANY DEBATE ON WARNING FOR TOXIC PAINT ADDITIVE
description: For most of a decade, during an internal struggle between industrial hygienists and marketing executives, PPG Industries delayed changing the warning on one of its products, a toxic paint additive, in the face of mounting evidence that the product was causing illness among users and some of its own employees.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday as securities dealers aggressively cut prices to levels they hope will attract buyers at note and bond sales this week.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee New Buses Added to New York's Fleet On West 34th Street yesterday was one of the first installment of a fleet of 837 new General Motors buses that hit the streets in all five boroughs. The new coaches, which cost $147,000 each, are 40 feet long, have a graffiti-resistant white exterior, 40 seats and standing room for 64 additional passengers. Complete fleet should be delivered by Christmas.

title: Lawsuit in Utah Seeking To Halt Land-Based MX
description: Two citizens' groups and three Utah and Nevada state legislators asked a Federal court here today to order a temporary halt to planning and spending for a land-based MX missile system.

title: Holding Up America
description: ''Maybe we are crazy,'' said Michael Fermon, a vice president of the striking Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization. Then again, maybe the controllers, like most everyone else, would just like to work shorter hours for higher pay.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt EARLY AUDEN. By Edward Mendelson. 407 pages. Viking. $20.

title: Gminski Is Hospitalized With Severe Back Pains
description: Mike Gminski, the Nets' center, is undergoing tests at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., to determine the reason for the severe back pains that caused his hospitalization Saturday.

title: REAGAN GIVES 48-HOUR NOTICE ON STRIKERS OF DISMISSAL
description: Federal air traffic controllers began an illegal nationwide strike today, grounding about half of the normal 14,200 daily airline flights. President Reagan warned the striking controllers that, if they did not return to work by 11 A.M. Wednesday they would lose their jobs under terms of the law.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ''THE United States continues to be the only country where you can graduate from college without having had one year of a foreign language prior to and during the university years,'' wrote Representative Paul Simon in his recent book, ''The Tongue-Tied American.''

title: REAGAN GIVES 48-HOUR NOTICE train in Washington
description: OF DISMISSAL By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

title: Companies
description: Salomon Brothers will be taken over by Phibro under a surprise $483 million merger plan. The acquisition, set for Oct. 1, will be the year's third big merger in the securities industry. (Page A1.) Salomon, the nation's largest private investment banking firm, is one of the last of the partnership empires. (D4.) Phibro is a large commodity trading company known among analysts as ''aggressive, secretive and independent-minded.'' In fact, some used to call it the ''Salomon Brothers of the commodities trading business.'' (D4.)

title: COURT-MARTIAL SOUGHT IN SOVIET CONTACTS CASE
description: The commanding officer of Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke, the Air Force officer accused of unauthorized contacts with the Soviet Embassy, has recommended a general courtmartial, Air Force officers said today.

title: Apologizing to the Internees
description: At 2 A.M. a blip on the radar screen alerted antiaircraft gunners to a ''bogey'' bearing down on Los Angeles from the ocean. They called for a blackout, then blazed away at the California skies. In the morning, some claimed that as many as five unidentified aircraft had flown in, but others doubted there had been any at all: the radar blip was probably a weather balloon.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN TALK ON STRIKE
description: The following is a text of President Reagan's statement today about the strike by air traffic controllers:

title: LEGISLATORS ASK 'ACTIVE ROLE' BY REAGAN ON ULSTER
description: A group of politicians, expressing concern about the hunger strike by Irish Republican Army prisoners in Northern Ireland, urged the Reagan Administration today to ''play an active role in ending the current deadly impasse.''

title: EGYPT COAXES NILE FARMERS TO 'INVADE' THE DESERT
description: The official talk in this remote, peaceful desert oasis has a harsh military ring. People speak about ''invading the desert,'' ''attacking the land'' and obtaining ''food security.''

title: Engineers Sued Over Bridge Death
description: The wife of Akira Aimi, the 33-year-old photographer who died last month of injuries suffered when a Brooklyn Bridge cable snapped and struck him in the head, filed a $50 million lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Raider Jury Still Out
description: The Federal Court jury in the antitrust trial in which the Oakland Raiders and Los Angeles Coliseum Commission have sued the National Football League completed its fifth day of deliberations today without reaching a verdict. The jury will reconvene tomorrow morning.

title: MILITANT CONTROLLER CHIEF: ROBERT EDMOND POLI
description: Robert E. Poli, the union president who has taken the nation's air controllers out on strike, had to fight his way to the job where he would challenge the Reagan Administration and face the possibility of being sent to jail and fined thousands of dollars.

title: P.L.O. CANDOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Train Wreck Kills 12
description: A train carrying a cargo of hydrochloric acid hurtled off its track and crashed in northern Mexico, killing at least 12 persons and poisoning hundreds with acid fumes, military officials said yesterday. The train was derailed when the engineer failed to brake as the train entered a small station near here.

title: TAX CHANGES WILL AFFECT SAVING AND INVESTING
description: The New Tax Law First article of a series on how it affects investment and planning. By KAREN W. ARENSON

title: Japan Warns Iran on Oil
description: Iran has been warned that Japanese oil companies will stop buying Iranian oil by Sept. 1 if prices are not cut, European oil industry sources said here today.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 4, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 3 P.M.

title: SENATE APPROVES TAX-CUT BILL, 67-8
description: The Senate approved today, by 67 to 8, the 1981 tax-relief bill and sent it to the House of Representatives, which is expected to pass it tomorrow.

title: K.G.B'S EXPERTISE IN 'DISINFORMING' THE WEST
description: To the Editor:

title: Fluor Expects Reduced Net
description: The acquisition of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation by the Fluor Corporation will reduce Fluor's 1981 earnings by an undetermined amount, the chairman, J. Robert Fluor, told a special shareholders meeting.

title: BELL BEGINS ANTITRUST DEFENSE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company began its defense in the Government's six-year old antitrust proceedings against it today as a Bell executive testified that the communications giant's structure needs to be maintained for efficiency and security reasons.

title: Ex-Officer to Lead Omega Watch Unit
description: Hugh G. Glenn traded in his $2,000 Baume & Mercier wristwatch for a $1,500 Omega yesterday, when he was named president of the Omega Watch Corporation U.S.A. The American affiliate of the Swiss company has its headquarters in New York.

title: BASEBALL REUNION
description: Penn League, and it had kept Cincinnati and Oakland from appearing in the annual Hall of Fame game.

title: A Condominium for the Royal Family?
description: The Prince of Wales didn't exactly receive a royal welcome when he visited New York City last June, but there are reports that if he ever comes back he may at least be assured of regal quarters.

title: Fifth Avenue Mile Is Set
description: The New York Road Runners Club announced yesterday that three of the world's top track stars would participate next month in the Fifth Avenue Mile, described by the club as the first elite mile ever contested over a straight course.

title: London Tourists Jam Airport to Get Home
description: Hundreds of American tourists who came for the royal wedding camped out at Heathrow Airport today, stalled on their return home because of a strike by air traffic controllers in the United States.

title: MOBIL LIFTS ITS CONOCO CASH OFFER
description: With the Du Pont Company holding an apparent lead in the three-way battle to acquire Conoco Inc., the Mobil Corporation yesterday increased the cash portion of its takeover bid to $115 a share from $105 for slightly more than 50 percent of the stock outstanding.

title: Addendum
description: * Morag Hann & Company has merged into Newsome & Company. Both are public relations concerns.

title: TAUGHT ENGLISH AT COLUMBIA
description: Harrison R. Steeves, professor emeritus of English at Columbia College, where for many years he had been chairman of the English department, died Saturday at his home in Kingston, R.I. He was 100 years old.

title: Chevron Plugs Well
description: Chevron Petroleum Ltd. of Britain said today that it has plugged and abandoned its British North Sea well 3/7a-4, southwest of the Ninian Field, after disappointing production tests. Chevron, the operator, has a 12.5 percent stake, the state-owned British National Oil Corporation 43.6 percent, Deminex Petroleum Ltd. of Britain 20 percent, Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd. 13.5 percent and Murphy Petroleum Ltd. and Ocean Exploration Ltd. 5.2 percent each. Chevron added that it has since started to drill North Sea well 14/13-2, where target depth will be 7,300 feet.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Government cannot close down the assembly line, it has to provide without interruption the protective services which are government's reason for being.

title: Article 218623 -- No Title
description: The $1.7 million Woodrow Wilson Pace, the richest race in the world, was staged tonight at The Meadowlands and it proved to be as unusual as the size of the purse.

title: Arraignment of Williams Set By Atlanta Judge for Aug. 17
description: The arraignment of Wayne B. Williams on two murder counts was set today for Aug. 17 by Superior Court Judge Clarence Cooper, who will preside at the trial. Mr. Williams was expected to enter a plea of not guilty to both counts.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Avnet Inc. acquired all the outstanding shares of Loonam Associates for $6.3 million cash plus a share of Loonam's earnings during the next three years.

title: BONN TIES MILITARY CUTS TO OTHER BUDGET PROBLEMS
description: West German Government officials today rejected American criticism of Bonn's plans to reduce the rate of growth of military spending next year, arguing that severe cuts in social programs would have been @unachievable without similar cuts in military spending.

title: Chemical Plant Blast Hurts 3 in Louisiana
description: A series of powerful explosions ripped through a chemical plant tonight, severely burning three workers in flash fires that followed.

title: BRADY SUFFERS A MAJOR SEIZURE
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, had a major seizure today, a new side effect of the head injuries he suffered in the assassination attempt on President Reagan March 30.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Airlines Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw a previously proposed offering of four million units, each consisting of one common share and a warrant for the purchase of an additional common share by August 1986, because of a recent decline in the market price of its common stock.

title: Hudson's Bay Widens Offer
description: The Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company said it would offer $44.25 (Canadian) a share, or about $127 million, for the 2.9 million publicly held shares of the Cyprus Anvil Mining Corporation not covered under a previous purchase agreement. Hudson's Bay said the offer would commence Wednesday.

title: 1980 ELECTION GIFTS: $55 MILLION
description: Political action committees representing special interests spent $55 million on House and Senate election campaigns last year, the Federal Election Commission reported today.

title: An Opera Singer Who Wants to Be Seen
description: A follow-up: A couple of weeks ago, Johanna Meier won acclaim for her debut as Isolde in the Wagner Festival's new production of ''Tristan and Isolde'' at Bayreuth.

title: Bridge: Spingold Knockout Event Starts the Semifinal Round
description: With all the top-ranked teams on the sidelines, four strong teams with a majority of players from the New York area began play in the semifinal stage of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here this afternoon.

title: Former Envoy Coming Out of 'Retirement'
description: The ''retirement'' of Leonard Woodcock, who earlier this year completed nearly four years as the chief United States envoy to China, will end in the fall.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS OFF 1.5% IN JUNE
description: Spending on new construction fell for the fifth straight month in June, declining 1.5 percent as near-record interest rates continued to stifle builders, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AT JOSHUA LOGAN PARTY, LIFETIME OF LUMMINARIES
description: At last night's party in honor of Joshua Logan, the director who this summer is a visiting professor at American University, found himself surrounded by fictional characters from his long career. All the guests had been asked to come in costumes from a Logan production.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Saturday misstated the basis of the budget cuts approved by Congress Friday. The reductions bring spending $35.2 billion below the $740 billion that the Congressional Budget Office estimates would have been spent in the fiscal year 1982 if current laws and programs had been un- changed. The budget for this fiscal year is $632.4 billion, and Congress has set a preliminary spending goal of $695.5 billion for the 1982 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Why is the beagle regarded as the dog most closely resembling humans for experimental purposes?

title: DON'T SHORTCHANGE THE ARMED FORCES
description: To the Editor:

title: Internorth Net Slips
description: Internorth Inc., an energy-based concern involved in the wholesale and retail distribution of natural gas, announced yesterday that net income in the second quarter slipped 8.1 percent, to $39.9 million, or 89 cents a share, from $43.4 million, or 96 cents a share, in the corresponding three months of 1980. The Omaha company said that revenues increased 22.2 percent, to $738 million, from $603.9 million.

title: STATEMENT FROM LUPKIN ON BUS-SHELTER FRANCHISE AND RESPONSE BY GOLDIN
description: The Commissioner of Investigation, Stanley N. Lupkin, issued a report yesterday on the role of Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin in the struggle over the franchise to build and maintain New York City's bus-stop shelters. Following are excerpts from the report's conclusions and excerpts from a reply by Mr. Goldin.

title: PHILADELPHIA BULLETIN MIGHT BE SHUT
description: The publisher of The Bulletin, one of the nation's largest afternoon newspapers, issued an ultimatum to the paper's unions today, demanding $4.8 million a year in wage concessions and vowing to cease publication unless the demand was met by Aug. 16.

title: 26 Sent to Hospital After Yonkers Fire
description: YONKERS (AP) - Twenty-five firemen and a resident of an burning apartment building were taken to a hospital for treatment of smoke inhalation and burns.

title: KEY ISSUES IN WALKOUT
description: The major issues in the contract dispute between the air traffic controllers union and the Federal Aviation Administration are wages, the length of the workweek and the retirement plan. When the walkout began, the union's demands, by its own accounting, would have involved $575 million in new outlays in the first year.

title: Who the Strikers Are; Qualifications
description: Eighteen- to 30-year-olds are eligible to become air traffic controllers; most enter the profession when they are in their 20's. Applicants must be high school graduates, have three years of experience that demonstrate an ability to learn in an administrative or technical environment, and pass an aptitude test and physical examination.

title: TALKS RESUME ON LAW OF SEA
description: The Soviet Union accused the United States today of seeking to ''torpedo'' the United Nations conference that has been working since 1973 on a treaty setting global rules on use of the oceans and their resources.

title: Coming Home
description: Americans live in all sorts of homes, but one kind, above all, truly captures their imagination. Norman Bates of ''Psycho'' lived in such a house; so did the family in ''Meet Me in St. Louis''; so did the inhabitants of countless real Main Streets.

title: Borden Helmer, an Economist And Cooper Union Treasurer
description: Borden Helmer, former treasurer of Cooper Union and retired chief economist of the Union Carbide Corporation, died Sunday of a heart ailment at the Maine Coast Memorial Hospital in Hancock Point, Me., where he was vacationing. He was 80 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: LATIN REVIVAL TOUCHES ALL SCHOOL LEVELS
description: CALLED dead language was very much alive one day last week at the City University as 11 eager students debated the interpretation of the word ''nostrum'' in a phrase from the Satyricon of Petronius Arbiter.

title: No Headline
description: Associated Press MUSEUM TAKES A TALLY: Phil Angle examining elephant skulls at the Smithsonian Institution's natural history museum in Washington, where the first com-plete cataloging of the museum's collection in 150 years is being performed. The Smithsonian believes that it has about 78 million objects in its collection.

title: A First Boston Expert
description: Joy has been scarce in the bond market recently and nothing happened yesterday to alter that. The Treasury's $8.6 billion auction of three- and six-month bills ran into ''a nervous and weak market,'' said David G. Bunting, 39, a managing director of the First Boston Corporation.

title: Filter Cigarettes and Health
description: Smokers who switch to filtered cigarettes that are lower in tar and nicotine clearly lessen their chances of developing cancer, but suggestions of a similar benefit to the heart have remained unproved. Now, new findings from the famous Framingham Heart Study, which followed smokers for 14 years, have shown no reduction in risk of developing coronary heart disease among those who smoked filtered cigarettes in the 1960's and early 1970's.

title: Market Place; Singer Stock Gains Backers
description: THE Singer Company may be a candidate for a turnaround and even a renaissance as a blue-chip company. If this should happen, the rebirth will have been a long time in the making.

title: FREE FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS
description: The plazas around Lincoln Center and Damrosch Park will be the scene of 60 free events featuring musical stars as well as youthful actors, dancers, jugglers, clowns and mimes Aug. 11-30.

title: CASUAL SPRING WEAR FROM ARMANI, WITH AMERICAN AND ORIENTAL FLAVORS
description: The male models were not smiling last week at the showing of Giorgio Armani's 1982 spring and summer collection, and no one could figure out why. Perhaps it was the outmoded, skintight leather pants they had to wear, billed as the ''narcissist's trouser.'' Perhaps it was the equally outmoded leather jumpsuit. Or perhaps it was just too hot to do anything but grimace. No matter. There was enough there, aside from the above fashion anomalies, to keep everyone interested and to allow Girogio Armani to barely maintain his position as premier European menswear designer.

title: SCHOOL ORDER IN DALLAS ALTERED TO LIMIT BUSING
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Dallas Independent School District, the eighth largest in the nation, must find some way of desegregating its schools without the use of further busing.

title: KIRKLAND DEFENDS STRIKE DECISION
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., today defended the right of the air traffic controllers to strike, although the strike is illegal under Federal law.

title: THE CITY;
description: Jewelry, gold, stamps and pictures valued at $800,000, along with $125,000 in currency, were stolen from an apartment at 101 West 55th Street between July 28 and early yesterday, the police reported.

title: Talking Business with David Foster of Natural Gas Supply Decontrolling Natural Gas
description: David H. Foster, president of the Natural Gas Supply Association, came to New York last week to talk about natural gas. It is a subject, the 54-year-old lawyer says, that is edging back into the limelight.

title: IN PANAMA, RESPECT AND CRITICISM FOR TORRIJOS
description: As many Panamanians paid their last respects to Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, the man who in effect ruled their country for nearly 13 years, some political leaders who opposed him were organizing for a hoped-for return to democracy.

title: SWAN STILL HAS SHOULDER PAIN
description: Craig Swan, the No. 1 pitcher on the Mets, said yesterday that he still felt some pain and weakness in his right shoulder, even though he had spent most of the last year resting and preparing carefully for his comeback.

title: Soviet Warships Concentrate In Eastern Baltic for Exercise
description: An armada of Soviet warships was off the Soviet coast in the eastern Baltic Sea today, but Danish intelligence officials said an expected amphibious landing exercise had not begun.

title: Retired Trucker to Run Ailing Spector Red Ball
description: Emerson W. Swan, 67, who has three decades of experience in the trucking business, abandoned a comfortable retirement yesterday to become chairman of a faltering trucking concern, Spector Red Ball Inc.

title: BONN FISCAL POLICY REVIEWED
description: Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, has urged the Bonn Government to spend less time criticizing high United States interest rates, and more time putting its ''own house in order.''

title: CAPE COD AQUARIUM LOSES FEDERAL FUNDS AND WILL BE CLOSED
description: The Northeast Fisheries Center Aquarium, one of Cape Cod's major tourist attractions, is to close to the public Sept. 12.

title: Ogilvy & Mather's Net Down 25.4% in Quarter
description: Ogilvy & Mather International issued its second-quarter financial report yesterday. The company proved to be another victim of currency translations and foreign-exchange losses.

title: COUTURE: STYLES OF SPLENDOR
description: Mink, sable and fisher are handled as if they were squirrel and rabbit. Fabrics are sumptuous satins, sibilant taffetas and sybaritic cashmeres, further embellished with appliques and embroideries, often jeweled. The handwork and the glitter deserve special mention; they are applied so lavishly they seem worthy of an emperor's court. For the most part, silhouettes are long, flowing and of tent-like fullness.

title: EDUCATION DEPT. ASKS TO LIFT RULE ON SEX BIAS IN COLLEGE
description: The Department of Education, in an important test of Administration policy toward sex discrimination, has asked Attorney General William French Smith for permission to revoke rules banning such discrimination in the employment practices of schools and colleges receiving Federal aid.

title: New Military Uprising In Bolivia Is Reported
description: A new attempt to oust President Luis Garcia Meza was reported under way today, with rebel broadcasts saying that insurgent troops had taken control of the provincial capital of Santa Cruz.

title: B.P.-Frisco Venture
description: British Petroleum Ltd. said today that it and Frisco of Mexico have formed a new company, Minera Promet, to search for minerals in the states of Chihuahua and Durango in Mexico. Frisco will have a 55 percent stake and B.P. a 45 percent stake in the new company, which will explore two mineralized areas containing principally silver, lead and zinc. A B.P. spokesman said it is not yet possible to know how much capital will be involved or how long the project will take.

title: Owners Delay Meeting
description: Because of the air-traffic controllers strike, the owners of the 26 major league teams decided yesterday to postpone until Thursday their meeting on determining the format for the rest of the season.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIAL SEEKING CLUES IN SUBWAY CRASH
description: Patricia A. Goldman arrived in Brooklyn yesterday, donned an orange reflector vest, picked up a flashlight and began yet another inquiry into the origins and causes of a fatal accident.

title: Like Her Sister, Girl May Need A New Heart
description: Doctors at the Stanford Medical Center say they will wait at least several days before deciding whether a 13-year-old girl from Kansas City, Mo., needs a heart transplant, as her older sister did last week.

title: 28 IN MEXICO KILLED BY FUMES
description: A derailed freight train leaking chemical fumes has killed 28 persons and hospitalized over 1,000 at an isolated mountain village, officials said today. Tank cars carrying hydrochloric acid overturned late Saturday in the village of Montana, 240 miles north of Mexico City.

title: DISPENSABLE MALES
description: To the Editor:

title: Stoddard Stevens, Ex-Partner Of Sullivan & Cromwell Firm
description: Stoddard M. Stevens, former partner of the New York City law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, died Saturday at Nantucket Cottage Hospital in Nantucket, Mass., at the age of 89. He lived in Short Hills, N.J., and had a summer home in Nantucket.

title: FRANCE
description: Threatened with expulsion from France if he makes political statements, the former President of Iran, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, said today that he might go to Sweden or Austria to continue his campaign against the Moslem fundamentalist regime in Teheran.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amdisco Corporation, formerly the American Distilling Company, has elected Gerald S. Bush senior vice president, finance, administration and treasurer.

title: TAXES AND FAIRNESS
description: The Koch administration, recognizing that inaction could have a corrosive effect on public trust in government, is moving swiftly to try to cleanse the city payroll of several thousand workers who are evading income taxes by becoming bogus mail-order ministers.

title: CAUSE OF DEATH OF VETERINARIAN MYSTIFIES POLICE
description: The body of a Long Island race horse veterinarian was found on a secluded beach north of Chicago Saturday night. Results of an autopsy proved of no help yesterday to investigators, who now await a toxicology report that they hope will offer some clue.

title: CHRYSLER OFFERING REBATES IN AUGUST
description: The Chrysler Corporation, returning once again to cash incentives to sell cars, said today that it would give $300 to $1,000 to buyers of the 1981 models now clogging its dealers' showrooms.

title: CHANCELLOR ASSAILS TESTS USED TO SELECT PRINCIPALS
description: The city Schools Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, yesterday filed a Federal suit charging that recent tests for high school and junior high school principals were racially discriminatory. He asked that the school system not be required to hire anyone from the lists of those who passed the tests.

title: INFLUENTIAL BANKER
description: Last weekend, the 62 partners of Salomon Brothers, the nation's largest private investment bank, were called to a meeting at the Tarrytown Conference Center in Westchester, ostensibly to discuss routine matters. Yet the urgency with which the meeting was scheduled raised widespread speculation. It was made clear that vacations were to be interrupted if necessary and that all partners were expected to attend.

title: Death Rates for Nondrinkers Below Drinkers', Study Finds
description: People reporting two drinks or fewer a day fared better in a 10-year California study of death rates than nondrinkers, but heavy drinkers had a doubled mortality rate, three researchers said today.

title: 3 Prisoners Sought In Jersey Jailbreak
description: Three inmates remained at large yesterday after scrambling to freedom from a fourth-floor window in the Sussex County Jail. A fourth escapee surrendered early in the day, officials said.

title: Brother of Key Informer Slain by Red Brigades
description: The Red Brigades, in a bid to keep arrested members of their organization from cooperating with the police, today killed the brother of Patrizio Peci, a former terrorist leader who has been an invaluable police informer for the last five months.

title: A TELEVISION PRESIDENT
description: Ronald Reagan is the master of television. No politician in the brief history of the medium has known better how to use it, as campaigner first and now as President, or done so with more confidence. His prime-time appeal for support of his tax bill was the key to its success - vintage Reagan.

title: Home Loans Up to 16.95%
description: Interest rates on Americans' new home loans rose to another record in July, nearing an average of 17 percent, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Landslide in India Kills 12
description: A landslide triggered by heavy rains killed at least 12 people in southeast India today, bringing the nationwide death toll during monsoon rains in the last month to more than 300. In the states of Andhra Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Assam and Rajasthan, more than 100,000 people have been left homeless in some of the worst flooding to hit the areas in recent years.

title: Laker Airways Picks 3 Agencies for America
description: In a smaller but interesting development, Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, a J.Walter Thompson subsidiary, has been named the New York area agency for Laker Airways Skytrain Service.

title: 19-2 Pole-Vault Record Might Not Be Certified
description: Konstantin Volkov of the Soviet Union set a world record of 19 feet 2 inches in the pole vault yesterday, but, because it came during a local competition, the record may not be certified, Tass reported.

title: New 30-Month Certificate Rate
description: Beginning today, savings institutions may offer a rate of 15.8 percent on new 30-month small savers certificates, a sharp increase over the 12 percent maximum that was previously permitted.

title: LIBYA SUMMONS OIL CONCERNS
description: Libya has summoned oil companies that buy its oil to a meeting tomorrow in Tripoli with Maj. Abdul Salam Jalloud, a former prime minister now considered to be second in power to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Index; International
description: Egypt coaxes Nile farmers to ''invade'' the desert A2 Begin's effort to form a government in Israel hits snag A2 Soviet accuses U.S. of damaging law of sea negotiations A3 Lebanese Phalangist visits U.S. seeking State Department talks A4 Around the World A5 Politicians ask Reagan to take an ''active role'' on Ulster A6 In Panama, respect and criticism for Torrijos A6 Government/Politics Interest groups spent $55 million on 1980 Congress races A12 City Schools Chancellor challenges some tests for principals B3 Westchester County comes to the aid of City of Yonkers B3 Inquiry begun of ''harassment'' charges by trooper dropouts B20 General Around the Nation A8 Court-martial is recommended for accused Air Force officer A9 Fiscal crisis imperils opening of Chicago school A10 Cape Cod aquarium will close to public A12 Body of L.I. veterinarian found on Lake Michigan shore B3 Lawsuit unveils struggle over warning on toxic paint product B7 Two jetliners over New Jersey involved in a ''near miss'' B9 Industry/Labor Text of President Reagan's remarks about controllers' strike B8 Kirkland defends right of controller to strike B8 Bus lines and railroads are filling gaps created by strike B9 Features/Notes Notes on People B5 Man in the News: Robert E. Steeves, professor of English at Columbia College B10 Sports McKinzie Almahurst wins $1.7 million pace at Meadowlands C11 Shoulder injury has Swan con- cerned for his future C11 Abdul-Jabbar says he will remain with the Lakers C11 Joe Kapp's legal victory against N.F.L. looks empty now C11 Jackson returns to Yankees on a cheerful note C12 George Vecsey on baseball stars at the Hall of Fame C12 Rose in All-Star Game lineup at record fifth position C12 Injuries to Gaines and Barber, fullbacks, worry Jets C14 Johnny D., champion as 3-year- old, back after four-year layoff C14 Jeter returns to Giants' camp after hospital stay C14 Clerc defeats Vilas for third title in three weeks C15 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A14

title: Suspended for Touring
description: The Israeli Football Association has suspended 14 soccer players and fined their team for touring Bophuthatswana in defiance of an international boycott.

title: CITY REBUKES GOLDIN IN BUS-SHELTER STUDY BUT ALSO CLEARS HIM
description: Excerpts from the Lupkin report and the Comptroller's reply, page B4. By CLYDE HABERMAN

title: BRILAB JURY CONVICTS CARLOS MARCELLO AND FORMER LOUISIANA OFFICIAL
description: Carlos Marcello, reputed head of organized crime in the Gulf Coast region, was found guilty today of conspiracy in a trial that began in Federal District Court here four months ago.

title: NEW HAVEN LINE FARES RISING
description: Fares on Conrail's New Haven Line will go up an average of 25 percent tomorrow, a Conrail spokesman said yesterday. The increases were approved on July 2, at the same time that fares on New York City's subways were raised to 75 cents and other commuter fares were increased. But they were not put into effect pending a review by the Federal Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: CAREY'S 1978 CAMPAIGN STILL $922,000 IN DEBT
description: The Republican losers of the 1978 New York State gubernatorial campaign have halved their $850,000 debt in recent months. But the winner, Governor Carey, is still carrying a $922,000 debt from his re-election campaign.

title: Clerc Defeats Vilas For 3d Title in Row
