description: Jose Luis Clerc of Argentina extended his winning streak to 19 matches today, beating his countryman Guillermo Vilas, 6-3, 6-2, in the final of the $200,000 Volvo Interational tournament.

title: General Motors Sets Dividend
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it is paying a dividend of 60 cents a share on common stock in the third quarter, which ends Sept. 30.

title: A Day for Doubles in Twinsburg, Ohio
description: It was all the idea of Don Keith, a twin who just happens to be executive director of the Center for the Study of Multiple Births, a nonprofit organization in Chicago.

title: Exploding Keg Kills Host
description: A keg of beer exploded at a weekend fraternity party and killed the host, the police said today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: To begin with, everyone was wondering what, really, was the matter at Women's Wear Daily. Before the royal wedding, it published a drawing and description of The Dress to be worn by Diana, whom marriage was to make the Princess of Wales. But the drawing, as it turned out, was totally wrong, leading some to speculate that WWD was playing a joke on its readers. But according to Michael Coady, the editor, ''We never really said that this was The Dress. John Fairchild, our publisher, thought it was a hoax all along. And if you take off the overslip and the accessories and add the long train the Princess wore, the drawing could have been a very early draft of it.''

title: 8 Salvador Soldiers Killed In Drive on Guerrillas
description: Eight Government soldiers were reported killed today in a sweep against leftist guerrilla strongholds on the Guazapa volcano, 19 miles north of San Salvador.

title: Abrams Suit Charges Agway With Water Pollution Upstate
description: New York State filed suit today against Agway Inc., charging that the farm supply company had contaminated ground water in a rural area of Rensselaer County with pesticides and other agricultural chemicals.

title: Firebomb Kills 4 Teen-Agers
description: Firebombs thrown into a home early yesterday killed four teen-agers trapped in upstairs bedrooms. Two brothers, their sister and a visiting neighbor, ranging in age from 15 to 18 years, were killed. The police said the firebombing may have been connected to a dispute between the children's father and a neighboring family.

title: OPENING OF CHICAGO SCHOOLS THREATENED BY FISCAL CRISIS
description: Public schools here may not open on time next month for more than 450,000 pupils, officials say, because the fiscal crisis that closed the schools in 1979 and 1980 has worsened.

title: ACCORD TO LIMIT JET EXPORT SUBSIDY
description: In what was described as a breakthrough in efforts to reduce government-subsidized export credits, the United States, France, West Germany and Britain have agreed to charge a common minimum interest rate of 12 percent on loans to finance the purchase of commercial jet aircraft.

title: The Associated Press
description: The planets Uranus and Neptune are not covered with frozen ammonia and methane as some scientists say, but they might be covered with another kind of glittering ice - diamonds.

title: DIGITOMANIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Tharp Dancers: A 4-Week Season
description: Twyla Tharp Dance will return to Broadway next month for a second year at the Winter Garden Theater. Miss Tharp's company will appear in a four-week season, beginning Sept. 22, that features a new fulllength work by the choreographer and two additional premieres.

title: POLICE ROLE TROUBLING PARK RANGERS
description: On Thursday he helped in the arrest of three suspects in an automobile looting ring, and on Saturday there was a four-hour hike down a twisting canyon trail to rescue a teen-ager who became ill on a backpacking trip.

title: No Headline
description: The trainer Alex Fiore was again barred from New York thoroughbred tracks yesterday when Justice Martin Rodell of State Supreme Court in Queens vacated a stay that had enjoined the State Racing and Wagering Board from revoking his license.

title: CABARET: HAZEL SCOTT AT NEW RESTAURANT
description: WHEN Hazel Scott lets her sinuous, throaty voice ramble through Richard Whiting's old standard ''My Ideal,'' phrasing it to balance the song's poignant qualities with a positiveness that keeps it from being wistful, she is working in the great tradition of the afterhours singers. And she shows another facet of that tradition when she takes her piano rolling, rocking and kicking through a pair of Lil Green's songs, ''Why Don't You Do Right?'' and the lesser known ''Romance Without Finance.''

title: Life Term for Accessory In Providence Case
description: Rudolph E. Sciarra was sentenced today to life in prison on charges of supplying guns for a 1965 slaying that Raymond L. S. Patriarca, accused of being a leader in organized crime, is charged with ordering.

title: Degrees in Engineering Bring Top Offers for '81 Graduates
description: College graduates who received engineering degrees this year were offered salaries averaging about $25,000, again getting the highest offers of any group of graduates, the College Placement Council said today.

title: Chess: Slow Start and Fast Finish For Seirawan and Browne
description: Yasser Seirawan and Walter Browne started slowly en route to their shared victory in the United States Championship.Browne, a Berkeley, Calif., grandmaster, lost to Sergei Kudrin, an international master from New York, in Round 2 and to Joel Benjamin, another New York international master, in Round 4 while Seirawan, a Seattle grandmaster, was heaping up inauspicious draws. But the paper tigers turned out to be real in the second half, chewing up one opponent after another. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Browne 6 2 6 9 Seirawan 4 0 10 9 Christiansen 5 2 7 8 1/2 Kavalek 4 1 9 8 1/2 Reshevsky 4 1 9 8 1/2 Shamkovich 4 3 7 7 1/2 Peters 3 3 8 7 Byrne 1 1 12 7 Lein 1 2 11 6 1/2 Alburt 4 6 4 6 Kogan 3 5 6 6 Tarjan 3 5 6 6 Benjamin 3 6 5 5 1/2 Fedorowicz 1 5 8 5 Kudrin 3 7 4 5

title: COMMODITY EXCHANGES BRACE FOR IMPACT OF NEW TAX LAW
description: Anger and confusion swept the commodity trade yesterday, as traders and exchange officials braced for the impact of the Administration's new tax law on their industry.

title: FORMER CHAMPION BACK ON THE TRACK AFTER 4 YEARS
description: Lazaro S. Barrera was leaning over the rail of the training track across the street from Saratoga Race Track this morning watching some of the horses he trains gallop or work out. It seemed that every third horse that went around the crowded oval had a ''LAZ,' or an ''LSB'' stitched on its saddlecloth. The group included several young winners with promising futures and an unraced 2-year-old full sister to Affirmed, whom Barrera trained to the Triple Crown three years ago.

title: OPERA: SANTA FE REVIVES HINDEMITH 'NEWS OF DAY'
description: act opera ''News of the Day,'' which was first performed in Berlin in 1929, was revived Saturday night by the Santa Fe Opera. John Crosby's enterprising company, which gave the work its American premiere in 1961 with the composer conducting, staged it again in 1964. In New York, ''News of the Day'' was most recently heard in 1979 at the Manhattan School of Music, which Mr. Crosby heads, and it apparently enchanted some critics.

title: SALOMON BROS. INVESTMENT HOUSE TO BE SOLD TO COMMODITY TRADER
description: The nation's largest privately held investment banking firm, Salomon Brothers, announced yesterday that it would be acquired by the little-known Phibro Corporation, a worldwide trader of commodities.

title: SCHOOLS IN CITY PRAISED BY KOCH ON 4-YEAR GAIN
description: Mayor Koch pointed yesterday to better reading-test scores and a successful effort to control the rising cost of educating handicapped children as evidence that public schools have fared well during his four years in office.

title: JETER BACK IN CAMP AFTER HOSPITAL STAY
description: Gary Jeter, his enthusiasm undaunted, rejoined the Giants today after a one-week hospitalization because of back spasms.

title: OFFSHORE OIL: SURPRISE DISPUTE
description: To hear critics tell it, the Reagan Administration will not rest contented until the entire continental shelf of the United States is littered with oil wells.

title: To Keep Law Enforcement Lawful
description: When Attorney General William French Smith made violent crime his ''highest priority,'' he painted himself into a corner. Most crimes, and particularly violent crimes like robbery and murder, are state and local matters. The Federal anti-crime role is extremely limited, perhaps more than ever in these days of disenchantment with Federal subsidy of law enforcement.

title: THOSANDS WITH MENTAL HEALTH INSURANCE CHOOSE TO PAY OWN BILL
description: THOUSANDS of men and women all over the United States are paying for psychotherapy out of their own pockets instead of applying for the mental health insurance coverage provided by their employers. Their reason, according to psychiatrists and psychologists treating them, is that they dare not risk disclosure of their emotional problems in the workplace.

title: REAGAN WARNS CONTROLLERS TO RETURN OR FACE DISMISSAL
description: President Reagan's feelings against the strike begun today by air controllers were so strong that he came to a White House strategy session this morning with his mind made up that controllers who did not return to work within 24 hours should be dismissed, according to White House officials.

title: CHARGES OF BIAS IN TROOPER CLASS BEING CHECKED
description: The United States Justice Department and Governor Carey's office are looking into charges by some minority recruits who dropped out of the State Police Academy that ''harassment'' and a ''double standard'' had caused them to leave. The state police say academic problems were the cause.

title: KAPP VICTORY SEEMS EMPTY
description: As the limousine headed toward Capitol Hill, Joe Kapp leaned forward and asked Ed Garvey, executive director of the National Football League Players Association, how to handle himself before the group of Congressmen. ''Can I show some emotion?'' asked Kapp, the former quarterback, shifting uncomfortably in his blue blazer and polished black shoes.

title: FOR THE ROYAL FAMILY, WEDDING AND WEALTH BEFORE THE ISSUE OF POVERTY
description: A few days before the royal wedding, Debbie Hampson, whose wistful good looks are not unlike those of the new Princess of Wales, climbed onto a cupboard in her living room and screamed.

title: ENERGY ISSUES ARE DOMINANT AS DOW SLIPS 0.28,TO 945.97
description: The stock market's spotlight continued to focus on energy issues yesterday, while a late rally brought prices overall back almost to an even keel. In the news background, the House voted its final approval to the compromise tax-cut bill, which now goes to President Reagan for his signature.

title: INTREPID ISRAELI DEFENSE MINISTER
description: Ariel Sharon, Israel's new Defense Minister, is a retired general who won military fame in the 1950's and early 1970's by leading fierce reprisal raids against Arab villages and refugee camps in Jordan and Gaza.

title: For Whom Does the Midnight Bell Toll?
description: Because Frank J. Barbaro's lawyers were a few minutes late yesterday, his effort to be the sole opponent of Mayor Koch in the Democratic primary in September was dealt a severe setback.

title: Inmates Set Fires In Trenton Cells
description: A group of 38 inmates at the Trenton State Prison set fire to papers and ripped plumbing from the walls of their cells in a disturbance yesterday that lasted several hours.

title: MUSIC: MOZART OBOE CONCERTO
description: MOZART'S music demands a delicate mixture of display and argument. Sensuousness should be intertwined with sensibility; the suspense in a melodic line takes on structural implications. At Monday night's Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall, with James Conlon conducting the orchestra, the composer was just slightly out of kilter; the music sounded, at various moments, enticingly seductive, tediously recited or engagingly playful.

title: DANCE: ERICK HAWKINS
description: THE dance of Erick Hawkins is probably an acquired taste. It hasn't the urgency of most American modern dance of his formative period, from the late 1930's through the 50's. It hasn't the stringent verticality of classical ballet, in which Mr. Hawkins also trained. Its thoughtfulness reduces it, occasionally, to mere stasis.

title: BOTH SIDES CLAIM GAINS
description: A two-week strike by more than 1,000 city workers ended today with both sides contending that they had won.

title: MERGER OF SALOMON IMPRESSES ANALYSTS
description: As Wall Street sorted through Monday's surprise announcement about the proposed acquisition of Salomon Brothers, the nation's largest privately owned investment banking firm, by the Phibro Corporation, a large commodity trading company, analysts said they were as impressed by the potential power of the combination as by the multimilliondollar payments that the Salomon partners are to receive.

title: Robert Moses, the Empire Builder
description: WHEN the Giants and the Dodgers were leaving New York, Robert Moses said to a newspaperman, ''One of these days I want to give you a play-by-play account of this musical comedy that's been going on with the ball clubs in this town.''

title: TELEPHONE RATES GOING UP RAPIDLY
description: Rates charged for many telephone services are being increased dramatically as a result of major changes occurring in the telephone industry.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Applied Data Research Inc. filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 450,000 shares of Class B common stock. The underwriting will be managed by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.

title: FOR CUTTING AND STRUMMING; 1. Custom Clothes
description: So often, one sees the perfect outfit in a store, except that it's in the wrong fabric or the wrong size. A solution is having clothes custom-made in one's own fabric. Which is what Moisha Kubinyi does, in a small workroom tucked into the penthouse office of her husband, R.O. Blechman, the cartoonist. Miss Kubinyi's specialty is a quilted jacket with gathered-top sleeves and a lightly nipped-in waist, perfect for small-boned figures like hers. She also does skirts to match, which may be quilted or not. Fabrics such as challis, velvet, Viyella flannel or chintz work nicely. Although the designer will make some variations, she limits her dressmaking to her own designs and in sizes 4, 6 and 8. Jackets are $255, skirts $150. Her workroom, called Custom Closet, is at 2 West 47th Street. Call 869-1630 for details and appointments.

title: CBS CABLE BID CLEARED BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission granted CBS Inc. special permission today to purchase a cable television system to experiment in the cable field. The ruling made CBS the first of the three major networks to gain a toehold in the new and growing medium.

title: Cleveland Fares Increased
description: Trustees of the Regional Transist Authority today approved a plan that will raise bus and rapid transit fares by 33 to 50 percent beginning Sunday. The plan, designed to raise $8.7 million, means riders will pay 75 cents for a one-way train ride, 60 cents for a local bus and 25 cents for a downtown loop bus. Current fares are 50 cents, 40 cents and 10 cents.

title: 3 Seized in Guatemala In Slaying of U.S. Priest
description: Three men have been arrested on charges that they murdered the Rev. Stanley Rother of Oklahoma City, the police said today.

title: YANKS ARE CONFIDENT THEY'LL BE READY
description: The Yankees trudged up the runway from the field to the clubhouse yesterday, sweating and panting after a two-hour workout but confident after three days in uniform that they would be fit for Monday's opening game against the Texas Rangers.

title: Marilynn K. Yee Man Surrenders After Bomb Threat at British Diplomatic Office Tom Jack being escorted by police officers from British Mission to the United Nations. An Irish Republican Army sympathizer, Mr. Black entered the mission early yesterday and demanded a telephone interview with
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, saying he had a bomb strapped to his body. He surrendered two hours later after talking with a Veterans Administration doctor who had been treating him. Device was harmless.

title: ADRI OFFERS RESORT FASHIONS
description: Now that stores are filling up with fall and winter clothes, designers are presenting their designs for the next season, called resort. These are warm weather clothes for women in the Sun Belt or those who plan to travel south when the snow falls up north.

title: Death Penalty Ruled Out In Atlanta Slayings Case
description: Lewis Slaton, District Attorney here, said today he would not seek the death penalty for Wayne B. Williams, the photographer charged with murder in the slayings of two of the 28 young blacks killed here in the past two years.

title: DOCTOR'S REPROT BRADY'S SEIZURES HAVE ENDED
description: The series of brain seizures that affected James S. Brady, President Reagan's press secretary, has ended and doctors have increased his medication in an effort to ward off a recurrence, spokesmen at George Washington University Hospital said today.

title: ANALYST'S VIEWS ON NIJINSKY FINALLY PUBLISHED
description: Vaslav Nijinsky, the great Russian dancer who was driven from the stage by madness in 1917 at the peak of his fame, recorded his thoughts and ravings in the next two years in a diary that he signed ''God Nijinsky.''

title: PABST JOINS THE BIDDING FOR SCHLITZ
description: The Pabst Brewing Company yesterday entered the competition to buy the troubled Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, which last week accepted a lower offer from the G. Heileman Brewing Company.

title: FORTUNE SMILES FOR NELSON OF PATRIOTS
description: The New England Patriots open their four-game exhibition schedule Monday night against the Los Angeles Rams at Anaheim, Calif., and starting at tight end for the visitors will be Terry Nelson, a 30-year-old athlete from Arkadelphia, Ark., who continues to shake his head at the sudden turn of events in his life.

title: PURCHASE, N.Y.
description: IN ''Man Is Man,'' Bertolt Brecht studies the transformation of a man from docile waterfront porter to human fighting machine. The point of this barracks-room ballad about brainwashing is that identities can be interchangeable - soldiers are dogtags. Compared with other plays by Brecht, this early work is relatively small in scale. It could be presented in a chamber production on a portable stage. However, at the Center for the Arts of the State University College here, Brooks Jones has approached ''Man Is Man'' as an epic, somewhat on the order of ''Mother Courage.'' The production, a feature of the Pepsico Summerfare '81, is at the same time overblown and underdone.

title: News Analysis
description: Although unions and libertarians have long asserted that employees have a moral right to strike against private and public employers alike, it has been firmly established since a 1971 Supreme Court decision that they have no legal right to strike against the Federal Government.

title: Some Poverty Law Is Better Than None
description: There may yet be a chance to salvage the Federal Legal Services program for the poor. Facing a choice between a skimpy $100 million authorization by the Senate and not even a penny by the House budget bill, Congress has for now rejected both versions. That may be a gain for this important agency because another pending House bill authorizes a more generous $241 million - a reduction of 25 percent from the current budget.

title: AN ABUNDANCE OF POTENTIAL ARTS PATRONS
description: To the Editor:

title: YOKO ONO ASKS, 'WAS I SUPPOSED TO AVOID THE SUBJECT?'
description: YOKO ONO'S recent ''Season of Glass'' album, her first recording since the murder of her husband, John Lennon, last December, has been met with warmer reviews and brisker sales than any of her previous albums. But Miss Ono's work has been controversial since she first attracted attention as a mixed-media artist, in the early 60's, and ''Season of Glass'' has generated its share of controversy. The photograph on the album's cover depicts the blood-stained glasses that Mr. Lennon was wearing the night of his death, and the record includes several references to that night, including the sound of four gunshots.

title: Jurors in Raider Case Obtain Clarifications
description: The jurors in the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League completed a sixth day of deliberations today after having several legal definitions explained to them by the judge.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose $1.06 to $107.20 during the two-week period ending July 31, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs. That is an alltime high, the department said, and is $10.25 more than the 41-item food basket cost during the same period last year.

title: ADVISER IN MEXICAN GOVERNMENT ASSAILS REAGAN IMMIGRATION PLAN
description: Mexico's leading expert on migration, Jorge Bustamante, criticized President Reagan's immigration proposals today, saying they served the interests of United States employers and would institutionalize the inferior status of Mexican workers in this country.

title: LATINS GET TASTE OF KIRKPATRICK STYLE
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, whose ideas on authoritarian Governments in Latin America were provocative when she was a professor at Georgetown University, is leaving few doubts on her current tour that her views have not changed.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: QUEEN'S NAVEE

title: Air Strike Is A Boon for Jet Airways
description: For Brooke Knapp, the 36-year-old chairman and president of Jet Airways, Inc., the strike by air traffic controllers has been a boon. The small Los Angeles-based air chartercompany, which flies five Lear Jet and Navajo aircraft, is one of the many such carriers that has been doing capacity business since Monday, and Mrs. Knapp is thinking about leasing another plane.

title: Philippines Plans Metal Smelter
description: The Reynolds Aluminum Company and Shell Billiton International, a Royal Dutch/Shell Group subsidiary, are holding talks with the Government of the Philippines aimed at building a 140,00-ton-a-year aluminium smelter in the Philippines, officials at the Industry Ministry said.

title: Jets' Fields Back in Top Form
description: Until last season Joe Fields was slowly building a reputation for durability.

title: Bridge Reopened To Pedestrians
description: The pedestrian walkway on the Brooklyn Bridge, which had been closed since June 28 when two cables snapped, was reopened yesterday. City officials said workmen had finished installing small cables called retainers, which are intended to secure diagonal stay cables to vertical suspender cables.

title: The Evening Star
description: Time Inc. has announced the death of The Washington Star, but for over 100 years it was called by the most beautiful name in American journalism - The Evening Star - and everybody knows you cannot kill an evening star.

title: 9 in Radical Group Get Terms of 30 to 100 Years
description: A judge today sentenced nine members of the radical group Move to 30 to 100 years imprisonment each for shooting a police officer in an exchange of gunfire.

title: U.S. Studies Canada Trade
description: The Office of the United States Trade Representative said today that it has begun steps that might eventually lead to American trade retaliation against Canadian investment policies.

title: Ramos Gets 3-Year Term
description: Pedro Ramos, the one-time pitcher who won 14 games for the Yankees in 1958, was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison for violating probation on a concealed weapons charge.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT UTILITY KNIVES
description: THERE is one knife - it is often called a utility knife - that seems to exist in limbo. It has the same basic shape as the indispensable chef's knife, which is the cook's main chopping tool, and as the small paring knife, which is essential in preparing many garnishes. But, with its blade of about six inches, it is smaller than the former and larger than the latter.

title: WHO'S ON FIRST?  LIZ FROM INVENTORY
description: WHEN the women's softball team of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation beat its bitter rival, the Green Jeans from the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, 10 to 4 last week, there was much joy on the I.T.T. side of the sandlot. The players shrieked, and hugged and kissed one another. The center fielder threw her glove into the air. Several infielders did a victory jig.

title: 2 SUITORS AGAIN LIFT CONOCO BID
description: In hectic 11th-hour maneuvering, both the Du Pont Company and the Mobil Corporation yesterday increased the cash portion of their takeover bids for Conoco Inc.

title: New President For Emmerling
description: John Emmerling Inc., a $6 million ad agency, has acquired a company airplane and a new president and chief operating officer. The former's name is Beechcraft Bonanza, and the latter's is James R. Guthrie.

title: Meeting Fails to Resolve New Zealand Dispute
description: Government officials, antiapartheid protesters, the police and rugby union leaders ended a meeting today still at odds over the tour of New Zealand by a South African rugby team.

title: Doctor Convicted In Wife's Murder
description: A 57-year-old physician was convicted of second-degree murder in the 1979 slaying of his wife, whose body was found in a shallow grave beneath a picnic table in their backyard.

title: Tampa Fire Chief Slain, Two Firemen Wounded
description: A gunman shot to death a fire chief and wounded two firefighters at a downtown fire station today, the authorities said.

title: FREDERICK D. M. GILBERT
description: Frederick D. M. Gilbert, a tax lawyer and former partner of the New York City law firm of Burke & Burke, died Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Florida Commutes Ex-Officer's Term
description: Gov. Bob Graham and the State Cabinet freed Robert J. Glander, a former Stamford, Conn., police sergeant convicted of trying to smuggle marijuana into a Florida prison.

title: BLACKBERRIES, GOOSEBERRIES AND CURRANTS: TREATS OF SUMMER
description: Strawberries and raspberries are familiar favorites, but how many Americans know the taste of blackberries, gooseberries and red or black currants? These berries are the hallmarks of an English summer. There, they are made into unusual ice creams, jellies and pies, or stewed and served with creme fraiche.

title: AMID UNCROWDED BLISS, A TRIAL FOR THE STRANDED
description: While some long-delayed travelers were setting up housekeeping at the New York metropolitan area's three major airports yesterday, there were those who said they had never experienced more pleasant air travel.

title: Mrs. Katz Drops Suit
description: A major obstacle blocking the sale of the Philadelphia 76ers to Harold Katz was removed yesterday when his wife dropped legal action aimed at keeping her husband from purchasing the team. A day of meetings in the chambers of Montogmery County Court Judge Horace Davenport ended with a five-minute court session at which the agreement was announced.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 5, 1981
description: International A protest continued in Warsaw untroubled by the police. A column of buses and trucks blocked a key downtown intersection for a second day, and the independent labor union staged two brief strikes and a march in southern Poland, all in protest against food shortages. (Page A1, Column 3.) A Soviet Baltic fleet exercise was confirmed by the Defense Department. It said there seemed to be no link to the situation in Poland and that the amphibious fleet was apparently preparing for landing maneuvers. Pentagon officials said the fleet was capable of carrying more than 4,000 Soviet troops. (A8:1-4.)

title: MUSIC: CONTEMPORARIES
description: The Berkshire Music Center's Festival of Contemporary Music concert last night had its moments, but it did call into question just what the word ''contemporary'' means. The second half of the program consisted of Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire,'' which was composed in 1912, and there was also a work by Mario Davidovsky from 1964. It would seem that in this context ''contemporary'' means anything from the era that is now called ''modernism.'' If that is so, it explains why this festival has in some crucial sense become a museum - a sometimes enlightening, sometimes beautifully arranged museum, but a museum nonetheless.

title: AFTER A BAR EXAM, THE TRIAL BEGINS
description: ''You wake up with it,'' said Larry R. C. Stephen. ''You dream it. I'd wake up at 4:30 in the morning reciting the law. Even while you are studying, you are constantly wondering, 'Am I going to pass this thing?', or, 'What if I don't pass?' After that, taking the exam is the easy part.''

title: WHY THE U.S. MUST STRENGTHEN PAKISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 5, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M.

title: Riots Erupt in Belfast; Hunger Striker Buried
description: Rioters in Roman Catholic neighborhoods threw bricks, bottles and gasoline bombs at police and troops today after the funeral of Kieran Doherty, the Irish Republican Army member who died Sunday in a hunger strike.

title: Group Ends Its Effort To Find Paper a Buyer
description: A group of Washington business leaders and unions announced today that they had ceased trying to find a buyer for The Washington Star, which is scheduled to close Friday as a result of heavy financial losses.

title: Not the Kind of Splash One Likes to Make
description: San Francisco's Mayor, Dianne Feinstein, doesn't get to her weekend home in suburban Marin County as often as she'd like, but she did this past weekend and wishes she hadn't.

title: WARSAW PROTEST CONTINUES TO CLOG KEY INTERSECTION
description: A column of buses and trucks continued to block the center of Warsaw today while, in southern Poland, the independent trade union staged two brief strikes and a march against food shortages.

title: 26 Trotters Named For Hambletonian
description: A record field of 26 horses was named today for the 56th Hambletonian Trot, to be held Saturday for the first time at the Meadowlands. The largest previous field was 23 in 1953.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: Now is the time when horror stories about summer weekend guests proliferate like sandflies. Some of the ungrateful wretches expect room service, some flick ashes with abandon, some flirt with other people's spouses, and the number of towels flung on bathroom floors would apparently stretch from Cape Cod to Amagansett.

title: People
description: * Dr. Bruce Granovetter has been named senior vice president and medical director of Sudler & Hennessey, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam.

title: SHOPPING CENTER BUILDER IS HEADING BACK TO BROOKLYN
description: BACK in 1954, Louis L. Rosenberg bought a piece of land from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn on Butler Street in Park Slope. He built an industrial building and leased it to the Knickerbocker Toy Company.

title: Presidential Panel to Monitor Congress on Spending Limits
description: The White House gently scolded Congress today for failing to stay within its own spending limits and announced that it was setting up its own ''early warning system'' to monitor Federal outlays.

title: U.S. Gets Bids For Oil Leases In Atlantic
description: The Government said today that it received bids totaling some $561 million in its auction of prospecting rights to 285 submerged areas in the Atlantic Ocean 85 miles off the North Carolina coast - including a high bid of $103.8 million for a single tract.

title: POSTAL SERVICE REPROTS LAGS OF FEW HOURS
description: As the strike by air traffic controllers continued for a second day yesterday, Postal Service officials reported that airmail deliveries were being delayed only a few hours.

title: POP QUINTET: SQUEEZE
description: 1960's John Lennon and Paul McCartney. This sort of pop, which combines precise, wry imagery with carefully honed arrangements is rarely shown to its best advantage in a concert setting.

title: Careers; Therapists Treat Ills of Breathing
description: IF you hold your breath too long, an R.R.T. may get you. No, R.R.T. does not stand for a new malady, but it does denote Registered Respiratory Therapist, a new member of the modern health care team, who can provide emergency respiratory treatment, help for the chronically ill with breathing ailments and preventive training.

title: MEXICO LOWERS ITS OIL PRICES
description: Ending two months of rancorous negotiations with international oil companies, Mexico has lowered the price of its oil by an average of $2 a barrel.

title: P.B.A. Endorses Gold's Assistant
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and nine other uniformed unions endorsed Norman J. Rosen for Brooklyn District Attorney. Mr. Rosen is the executive assistant to the present District Attorney, Eugene Gold, who is retiring. He faces former Representative Elizabeth Holtzman in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary.

title: A.& P. PLANNING TO SHUT DOWN 16 OF 74 FOOD-DISCOUNT STORES
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said yesterday that it would close 16 of its 74 Plus food-discount stores this month in an effort to reverse the continuing unprofitability of that year-old division.

title: G.O.P.'S LEADER IN BROOKLYN SEES UPSWING IN FALL
description: Republicans in Brooklyn have been like the rear guard in a military retreat - their basic job has been to give ground grudgingly. They lose, yes, but by as little as possible, so that the party can stay within catching-up distance in that overwhelmingly Democratic area and, with respectable showings elsewhere, win citywide or statewide elections.

title: 280 BROADWAY: PAST SHAMES PRESENT
description: The white marble facade still gleams in the sun and the cast-iron columns above the street recall a grand past, but, inside, 280 Broadway is full of the signs of a grim present.

title: Companies
description: Du Pont increased the cash portion of its takeover bid for Conoco by $3, to $98 a share, while Mobil raised its bid by $5, to $120 a share. With the deadline for stockholders to take back their shares from Du Pont expiring last midnight, Mobil was maneuvering on several fronts to keep its bid alive. But many Wall Street analysts maintained that, unless Mobil could somehow gain more time, then Du Pont, which has already received tenders of 49 million shares, or about 57 percent of Conoco, would win the battle as early as today. (Page D1.)

title: CAUSE TORIES TO GRUMBLE PUBLICLY; BY STEVEN RATTNER
description: With little improvement evident in Britain's troubled economy and the unpopularity of the incumbent Conservative Party rising, voices of opposition to the economic policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher have risen to a chorus within her party.

title: Market Place; A Guide for Growth Stocks
description: PSYCHOLOGICALLY speaking, it is easier to buy shares with modest price/earnings multiples - those at 5 rather than at 30. But the latter are almost invariably growth companies. And high-multiple shares are more likely to reward investors than low-multiple shares - assuming the high rate of growth continues.

title: TO MY PROSPECTIVE SUMMER READING
description: Dear Book, I'm sorry to go about this so formally, but I would be embarrassed to address you in person. Yes, I think I'd like to spend the summer with you - but, first, let's discuss this maturely.

title: Soviet Embassy Official Ordered to Leave Britain
description: A member of the Soviet Embassy staff was ordered today to leave Britain because of ''activities incompatible with his status as a diplomat,'' the Foreign Office announced.

title: Brascade Obtains $1 Billion Credit
description: Brascade Resources Inc., a joint venture between Brascan Ltd. and an investment agency of the Quebec Government, said it has arranged a $1 billion (Canadian) credit for its tender offer for up to 20 million common and up to 1.8 million convertible preferred shares of Noranda Mines Ltd. A Canadian dollar is worth about 81 United States cents.

title: THE CASE FOR PAKISTAN
description: Pak istan is being made once again the victim of a propaganda campaign, this time over an American offer of $3 billion in economic assistance and military sales credits. Unwarranted suspicions are being raised about Pakistan's need to obtain a modest amount of sophisticated military equipment, including F-16 aircraft.

title: First $1 Million Issue For Colonial Homes
description: Russell S. Jackson, publisher of Hearst's Colonial Homes magazine, believes that the election of President Reagan is a positive portent for the magazine. That, he explains, is because the election indicates a rising conservatism and conservatives like Colonial homes.

title: Emerson's Net Up by 23.5%
description: The Emerson Electric Company, a major electrical and electronic products company, reported yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter ended June 30, 1981, increased 23.5 percent, while sales climbed 18.3 percent.

title: 5-1 Colonel Moran Wins Mile Race at Monmouth
description: Colonel Moran won his second stakes of the meeting at Monmouth Park today, easily capturing the $58,650 Salvator Mile Handicap.

title: Bridge:; Friesner and Katz Teams Meet in the Spingold Final
description: After appeals and slow play delayed the conclusion of semifinal play into the small hours this morning, teams led by Rich Friesner of Cambridge, Mass., and Ralph Katz of Steubenville, Ohio, clashed in the Spingold knockout team final here this afternoon. This closing action in the Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League concludes a week of play that began Wednesday with 151 teams.

title: 72% OF FLIGHTS IN
description: OPERATION By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

title: Glen 200 Is Postponed Until Early in October
description: The Glen 200 for Indy-style cars, scheduled for this weekend at Watkins Glen, has been postponed until Oct. 4, a track spokesman said today.

title: Dalton of Brewers Gets Three-Year Extension
description: The Milwaukee Brewers announced today that General Manager Harry Dalton's contract has been extended for three years past its 1983 expiration date. Dalton, who is also the club's executive vice president, signed a six-year contract when he came to the Brewers in 1977 from the California Angels.

title: Holmes Is Impatient Over Cooney Delay
description: Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, said today he would like a title match with the leading contender, Gerry Cooney, but that he does not like the way Cooney's handlers are trying to set up the bout.

title: Report Says 12,368 Fled Vietnam in June
description: Thousands of Vietnamese ''boat people'' continue to arrive at refugee camps throughout Southeast Asia each month, according to an official for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: Jersey Road Deaths Rise
description: Deaths on New Jersey highways for the first six months of this year increased by 5 percent over the same period last year, the New Jersey State Safety Council reported today. It made the announcement as it initiated a ''Make It Click'' campaign to increase the use of safety belts and child restraints in cars.

title: AN ABUNDANCE OF POTENTIAL ARTS PATRONS
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. TRACING FLOW OF DRUG FINANCING
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today disclosed a two-and-a-half-year undercover operation in which agents ''laundered'' millions of dollars in cash to gain information on the financial side of South Florida's multibillion-dollar narcotics trade.

title: Baseball Notebook Contract Ratification Begins
description: Three days after their team representatives voted unanimously to accept the settlement that ended their seven-week strike, major league baseball players yesterday started the ratification process on the agreement.

title: Lendl, Clerc Triumph
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia and a tired Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina scored first-round victories today in the $350,000 United States Clay Court tennis championships.

title: House Backs Tax Bill, 282-95
description: The House of Representatives approved the Administration's tax-relief bill today by a 3-to-1 margin and sent it to President Reagan for his signature after repelling an attempt by Northern Democrats to reopen consideration of the bill.

title: Letter: On Pollution Control Let Health, Not Cost, Set Air Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Views of Adler About Nijinsky
description: Following are excerpts from Alfred Adler's previously unprinted preface to Nijinsky's diary.

title: IDEAS OF TWO KOCH RIVALS FOR A CLEANER NEW YORK
description: Assemblymen Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and John A. Esposito of Queens, candidate for the Republican nomination, were asked by The New York Times for their views on major issues confronting New York City. Following are their replies on sanitation: Barbaro: 'People Offended'

title: WORLD WAR II'S 'INTREPID' AND THE PITFALLS OF POPULAR HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLAMIC PARTY LEADER NAMED NEW PREMIER BY IRANIAN PRESIDENT
description: Iran's new President, Mohammed Ali Rajai, named Mohammed Javad Bahonar as his Prime Minister today and asked Parliament to give him a vote of confidence, Teheran radio reported.

title: Founder of Clark Oil Prepares for Takeover
description: In 1932, Emory T. Clark, built a gasoline service station in the Milwaukee area and later found himself in control of it when the owner ran out of money. Now, if an acquisition proposal of the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation, the huge company created from that station, goes through, the 24 Clark family trusts, established by Mr. Clark in 1965, will gain nearly $200 million for the 41.8 percent share of the company that they own.

title: MARION PRESSES KELLEY FOR JOB
description: The Giants announced today their starting lineup for their first exhibition game, against the Bears Saturday night in Chicago, and the only real surprise came at inside linebacker, where Brian Kelley had been said to be secure.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DINKINS AND STEIN DEBATE, BUT HARDLY DIFFER
description: Portraying himself as a David out to vanquish an electoral Goliath, City Clerk David N. Dinkins said yesterday that at least one member of a minority group should sit on New York City's powerful Board of Estimate.

title: HARPER & ROW TO BUY STOCK
description: Harper & Row, the 164-year-old publishing company, agreed in principle yesterday to pay $20 a share for each of the million shares of its common stock held by the Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company. Those shares, representing about one-third of Harper's common stock outstanding, will be distributed among the company's 1,900 domestic employees, replacing the existing pension and profitsharing plans.

title: CABARET: MISS LEVINE
description: AUDREY LAVINE, who was singing the role of one of the Boswell sisters in ''Heebie Jeebies'' until that show closed last week and, earlier, scored a notable success singing the songs of Stephen Sondheim and Harold Arlen in the Salute to Great American Songwriters in the Citicorp Atrium, is doing a series of Monday evening performances at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, that will continue through next Monday.

title: Esso Chemical Order
description: Esso Chemical Ltd., a unit of the Exxon Corporation, has ordered three water tube boilers for its planned 500,000-ton-a-year ethylene plant at Mossmorran, Scotland, from Northern Engineering Industries, Northern Engineering said in a statement today. It said site construction is scheduled for completion in 1983.

title: No Headline
description: Joe Namath, the former Jet quarterback now appearing in the musical ''Damn Yankees'' at Jones Beach, dropped by the camp to watch the afternoon practice. Namath was accompanied by Paul (Bear) Bryant, the Alabama coach, who is on a business trip to New York. Bryant and the players he sent to the Jets - Namath, the Jets' No. 1 pick in 1965; Richard Todd, the quarterback drafted No. 1 in 1976, and Marty Lyons, the defensive tackle drafted No.1 in 1979 - posed for pictures together after the workout.

title: How to Wreck Low-Rent Housing
description: In San Francisco there is a public housing project that the police call a den of thieves. A third of its apartments are routinely vacant because qualified tenants are afraid to move in. By contrast, New York City's public housing, though imperfect, is fully rented. More than 100,000 families have registered for vacancies that occur only slowly.

title: HERBERT KADISON
description: Herbert Kadison, retired director of public information for the New York University Medical Center, died Sunday at University Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 1/4-Year Notes Bring 15.96%; U.S. Issue Sets Record
description: The credit markets flirted with a 16 percent yield at yesterday's auction of new 3 1/4-year Treasury notes, but as the time for bidding drew near, demand was great enough to reduce the average yield on the 15 7/8 percent notes to 15.96 percent. It was a record yield for a new Treasury issue of that maturity, exceeding the previous high of 15.81 percent for notes sold May 5.

title: DINING IN CHICAGO: A METAMORPHOSIS
description: TIME was when a visit to Chicago meant a solid diet of ribs and steak and little else. Carl Sandburg's appellation ''hog butcher for the world'' had special meaning for anyone elbow deep in barbecued ribs lacquered with a hot and pungent sauce.

title: No Headline
description: The second big night of Hambletonian Week saw another touching moment tonight.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''SUMMER means fun'' was one of the truisms of rock-and-roll during its innocent years. Those years came to an abrupt end during the late 1960's, when the world's rock idols, the Beatles, announced that they were experimenting with drugs and began making music full of disorienting psychedelic effects and surreal whimsy. But summer and fun have proved more lasting, and this summer they are back in a big way. ''The Beach Boys Medley,'' a single record that condenses parts of ''Fun, Fun, Fun,'' ''Good Vibrations'' and several other Beach Boys hits from the early and mid-60's, is sailing up the best-seller charts, with two similar Beach Boys medleys performed by copy bands - the Cantina Band and California - in hot pursuit.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp.'s subsidiary Eltra Corp. said it will acquire the West Coast refractory and minerals division of Interpace Corp. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: FAULKNER SIGNATURES FABRICATED
description: THE signature of William Faulkner on a 1956 letter, sent to enlist the support of other leading authors in a writers' program sponsored by the United States Information Agency, has been found to be a fabrication. In addition, four follow-up letters were signed not by the Nobel Prize-winning author but by a signature machine.

title: 3 Are Killed on Matterhorn
description: Three British climbers fell to their deaths Sunday on the 14,690-foot Matterhorn, the police reported today. The three, all 18 years old, were identified as Simon Smith of Nottingham and Janet Mulvaney and Stephen Creswell of Derby.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 19-year-old youth was shot in the face in a struggle with another youth who had stolen his portable radio in a Brooklyn schoolyard. The victim, Loxy Wright, was listed in stable condition at St. John's Hospital following the shooting in the yard of Public School 44 at 432 Sumner Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section. ... A telephone repairman found the body of a middle-aged woman who had been shot in the head in a black steamer trunk on the service road of the Whitestone Expressay between 14th and 20th Avenues in Whitestone, Queens.

title: A West Coast Defense Of Advertising Awards
description: Now the West Coast is contributing commentary on the matter of advertising awards.

title: THOUSANDS MOURN TORRIJOS AT FUNERAL IN PANAMA
description: Senior military commanders and government leaders from throughout the world, along with thousands of Panamanians, attended the funeral today of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's powerful leader for nearly 13 years.

title: Management Behind Bars
description: When a Federal judge ordered New York State to take its convicts out of New York City's crowded jails last week, he ended a legal battle but he hardly ended the problem. The state's prisons are just as full and dangerous. And with judges and prosecutors responding to the clamor for more jail terms for street criminals, the pressure on cell space will not abate.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: INSULATING A PRESIDENT
description: The United States withdrew $28 million in foreign aid from 12 poor countries today, and President Reagan celebrated the saving by appearing briefly in the Rose Garden with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and M. Peter McPherson, head of the Agency for International Development.

title: Newspaper Ad Revenue Up by 9.8% in June
description: In June, the country's newspapers increased their advertising revenues by 9.8 percent, even though there was one less Sunday than June a year ago, according to estimates made by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, based on data from Media Records. The total dollar figure for the month was put at $1.4 billion.

title: More Soviet Talks Seen
description: American negotiators at the trade talks with the Soviet Union held out little hope today that a new grain agreement could be reached before the present pact expired on Sept. 30.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Believe me, they're not going back to work.'' - Robert E. Poli, air traffic controllers' union president. (A1:6.)

title: Economic Scene; Interest Rates And Inflation
description: WALL Street's bond bears smile as they read their press clippings, count their profits and repeat their gloomy forecasts. They were right again in the first half of 1981. Interest rates on loans, bonds and mortgages continued to rise, with only brief pauses and short-lived reverses. True, the bears missed most of the oftensizable monthly ups and downs of interest rates. But they got the direction right. And that's better than many of us did.

title: Death Toll Reaches 4 In Utah Propane Blast
description: Three more people died today as a result of burns from a propane explosion last week, hospital officials said.

title: U.AS. CRIME PANEL TO PROPOSE REVISIONS FOR COURTS TODAY
description: Final recommendations for a set of sweeping changes in the criminal justice system that is designed to help law-enforcement agencies combat violent crime more easily will be issued today by an advisory panel appointed by the Reagan Administration.

title: PRESIDENT OF BOLIVIA RESIGNS IN FACE OF REVOLT
description: Bolivia, Aug. 4 (AP) - Gen. Luis Garcia Meza, bowing to the demands of army rebels, resigned today as President and asked the military junta to govern.

title: ACTOR, 80, WON 2 OSCARS
description: Melvyn Douglas, a debonair performer in scores of popular movie romantic comedies of the 1930's and 40's, who later became a forceful character actor and winner of two Academy Awards, died yesterday of pneumonia complicated by a heart ailment in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Hayakawa Denounces Claims Of Nisei for Internment Pay
description: Senator S.I. Hayakawa said today that demands for $400 million in reparations for the World War II internment of some 120,000 Japanese-Americans filled him with ''shame and embarrassment.''

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The bedroom in the back of the apartment in Elmhurst, Queens, was small and clean, except for the dark wet spots on the shag carpeting. On one wall was a turquoise sombrero with gold stitching; on the other was a round, almost decorative smear of blood. There was a bed, a desk, a dresser and, in the narrow space between those three, a young man in a pair of designer jeans and a knit shirt, with small change scattered around his body. It did not take a doctor, or even a genius, to tell that he was dead.

title: DESPITE PERILS AFLOAT, VIETNAMESE CONTINUE TO FLEE
description: Six years after the Communist victory in Vietnam, refugees are still coming to this camp in the Formosa Strait. After arduous crossings, most are exhausted and hungry; many are ill. All are grateful to be alive.

title: Saratoga Yearling Sale Sets First-Night Record
description: A yearling named Papal Bull brought $300,000 to help set a sales record tonight for the first night of the 61st annual Fasig-Tipton yearling sales.

title: CAREY SIGNS MEASURE PUTTING PRISON BOND ISSUE ON BALLOT
description: Governor Carey announced today that he had signed a bill calling for a referendum this fall on a $500 million bond issue for the construction and rehabilitation of state prisons and local and county jails.

title: MERGER MADNESS
description: Although the competition among three corporate giants to gain control of Conoco Inc. is dominating business news these days, the parade of other huge corporate mergers seems endless and is growing.

title: ADLER: STILL TRYING TO MAKE PHILOSOPHY ACCESSIBLE
description: SOME years ago, Mortimer Adler stopped at a jewelry store to pick up something for his wife. The jeweler, who had a passing acquaintance with his customer, was curious about something. ''What do you do, Mr. Adler?'' he asked. ''I'm a philosopher,'' Mr. Adler replied, without hesitation. The jeweler looked dismayed. ''No,'' he said, ''I meant what do you do for a living?''

title: Datapoint Buys 7 Distributors
description: The Datapoint Corporation, a manufacturer of computer systems, said it purchased for $85 million in cash seven international distributors for its products that were previously wholly or jointly owned by TRW Inc. Two more such acquisitions are pending under the agreement, the company said.

title: WAS CORRESPONDANT DURING WORLD WAR II
description: Richard W. Johnston, a war correspondent for United Press during World War II and a former executive editor of Sports Illustrated, died of cancer yesterday in Honolulu. He was 65 years old.

title: CHAYEFSKY PRAISED FOR PASSION IN EXPOSING LIFE'S INJUSTICES
description: At a funeral service yesterday attended by 500 people, including notables from the literary and theatrical worlds, Paddy Chayefsky, who died Saturday at the age of 58, was eulogized as a family man and friend, and as a writer who used his pen with passion to expose the injustices of ordinary life.

title: Some Greek Forest Fires Are Attributed to Arson
description: Scores of fires raged on throughout Greece today, many of them believed to be the result of arson by land speculators and political extremists.

title: THEATER: 'THE LAUNDRY HOUR,' A 2 MAN CABARET-TYPE SHOW
description: ''THE LAUNDRY HOUR,'' a small cabaret-style show that opened last night at the Public Theater, aims for bad taste and wild, anarchic humor. It succeeds in the first intent but, unfortunately, the amusement is only intermittent. This is a two-man comedy act (Mark Linn-Baker and Lewis Black), with music composed and played on the piano by Paul Schierhorn. The show is directed by William Peters. All four young men share authorship. One suspects that they laughed when they sat down to write ''The Laundry Hour.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BEGIN ANNOUNCES NEW COALITION AFTER CONCESSIONS TO MINOR BLOCS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin tonight announced the formation of a fragile new coalition Government that involves major concessions to Israel's three minority religious parties.

title: 3 Mail Fraud Convictions Upset in Pennsylvania
description: A Federal district judge today set aside a jury's conviction of three men accused of placing ''ghost workers'' on the State Legislature's payroll.

title: News Analysis
description: As Congress passed the final version of the tax bill today and its members left town for a five-week recess, the lawmakers could look back on an extraordinary session. Under the whip hand of a popular and persuasive President, Congress took a long step toward reversing the steady expansion of Government services and responsibilities that started with the New Deal almost 50 years ago.

title: Index; International
description: Vietnamese continue to flee despite perils at sea A2 Mrs. Kirkpatrick is outspoken on Latin American tour A3 Torrijos funeral in Panama City draws thousands A3 Mrs. Thatcher's economic plan causes grumbles from Tories A4 Islamic party leader named Prime Minister A4 Around the World A5 Government/Politics Reporter's Notebook: insulating Reagan from unpopularity A12 Reagan immigration plan assailed by adviser to Mexico A18 Brooklyn Republicans hope to move out of the background B2 Barbaro and Esposito gives views on sanitation issue B3 A Brooklyn Congressman runs afoul of rental authorities B3 General Around the Nation A10 The Region B2 280 Broadway: a glorious past and an uncertain future B2 The City B3 Industry/Labor City workers end two-week strike in Providence, R.I. A10 Health/Science Physicians say Brady's series of seizures ends A10 Obituaries Richard Johnston, war corre- spondent and magazine editor A21 500 attend service for Paddy Chayefsky A21 News Analysis Steven V. Roberts on the issues that await Congress A12 Stuart Taylor Jr. on legal implications of air controllers' strike A14 The Living Section Food From super sleuths, great meals to die by C1

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THOUGH often the butt of jokes in cartoons, dentures are a serious matter to the more than 50 million Americans who wear them and the 30 million who don't but should. By the age of 50, two in five Americans have already lost their teeth and by age 65, half are toothless.

title: Cholera Kills 10 in Indonesia
description: Ten people were killed and 40 were hospitalized in a cholera outbreak in the northern city of Banda on Sumatra island, the domestic news agency Antara said today. It said dozens more were feared dead from cholera in several nearby villages.

title: THE DOLLAR'S IMPACT ON PROFITS
description: The Ford Motor Company surprised many analysts last month when it surpassed their expectations by reporting a $60 million profit for the second quarter after six consecutive quarterly losses.

title: Grumman Net Drops 10.1%
description: The Grumman Corporation said today that earnings fell 10.1 percent in the second quarter ended June 30, in part because of losses related to the company's Flxible buses.

title: S.E.C. Closes Mobil Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has ended an investigation into relations between the Mobil Corporation and a company whose top official was a son of Mobil's president, Mobil said yesterday.

title: 72% OF FLIGHTS IN OPERATION
description: Virtually all 13,000 striking air traffic controllers closed ranks today in the face of a firm promise by President Reagan to dismiss any controller who has not returned to work by 11 A.M. tomorrow. The two-day-old strike is illegal under Federal law.

title: TORRE TESTS SHAKY PITCHING
description: Joe Torre tested his uncertain front-line pitching yesterday at Shea Stadium and got four innings from Craig Swan, his No. 1 starter and No. 1 question mark, whose comeback attempt may determine the extent of the Mets' success in the second half of the season.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard THE BIRDS OF THE AIR. By Alice Thomas Ellis. 152 pages. Viking. $9.95.

title: Advertising; Y.&R. Gets United Vintners
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM, which on Monday resigned the $24 million E.&J. Gallo Winery account, yesterday became the advertising agency for Heublein's United Vintners business, which last year billed more than $14 million.

title: Natomas Set To Buy Magma
description: The Natomas Company said it entered into a merger agreement under which Magma Power Company, a small California-based geothermal resources company, would become a wholly owned Natomas subsidiary. Natomas currently holds 83 percent of Magma Power's shares.

title: SCHEUER ASKS PERMIT FOR HOTEL RENTERS ON WASHINGTON SITE
description: Lawyers for Representative James H. Scheuer of Brooklyn argued before rental authorities today that he should be permitted to convert an apartment building he owns in southwest Washington into a hotel solely for transient renters.

title: A SEARCH FOR PRETTY FACES
description: Anyway you turned at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, there was a gorgeous young woman, a strikingly handsome young man, every feature perfect, and if you happened to have the slightest blemish on your face or even one chipped tooth, you had to believe that the world was against you. There were gorgeous children (as young as six) and there were gorgeous grandmothers (as old as 61), but mostly there were gorgeous teenagers.

title: Avis Chief Resigns; No Successor Yet
description: James F. Calvano, 44 years old, resigned abruptly yesterday as president and chief executive officer of Avis Inc., the big vehicle rental and leasing company and subsidiary of Norton Simon Inc. No successor was named, but operations of the New York-based concern will be directed temporarily by J. Patrick Barrett, a Norton Simon executive vice president and sector executive responsible for Avis.

title: U.S. CAUTIOUS ON GOALS IN SADAT TALK
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt arrived in Washington tonight for a visit that comes at a time when the Reagan Administration has considerable concern about the Middle East but only fragmentary ideas on what to do about promoting peace in the region.

title: FROM SUPER SLEUTHS, GREAT MEALS TO DIE BY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dilys Winn is the editor of the books ''Murder Ink'' and ''Murderess Ink'' (Workman Publishing). By DILYS WINN

title: LATE JULY AUTO SALES FALL 14.7%
description: New-car sales, hurt by high interest rates, fell 14.7 percent in the last 10 days of July, the nation's Big Three auto makers reported today. That pushed sales for the entire month down 8 percent from July 1980, to the lowest levels in 20 years.

title: While the Royal Couple Cruises, the Gifts Pile Up
description: Prince Charles and Princess Diana continued their Mediterranean honeymoon cruise far from prying eyes yesterday, but in London the public was getting a glimpse of some of what the couple has to come home to - $7.2 million worth of wedding presents, according to one estimate.

title: Liver Disease Linked to Death Of a TV Journalist's Husband
description: Dr. Donald Rollie Payne, the husband of Jessica Savitch, an NBC News correspondent, may have committed suicide by hanging because he suffered from acute depression caused by a chronic liver disease, the city medical examiner ruled today.

title: THE PRICE A TEEN-AGER PAYS FOR MARIJUANA
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS a professional chef I am often asked whether I ever resort to canned foods. The answer is yes, but in limited quantities. It just so happens that I have a fairly keen liking for canned tuna (as well as sardines and, on occasion, salmon) and during the summer months I use it in various salads or as fillings for sandwiches. It almost invariably goes into my salad Nicoise or into stuffed tomatoes, the basis for which is tuna.

title: PETS JOIN THE SUMMER STREET CIRCUS
description: MOVE over, Rover. From now on, this time of year can no longer be known only as the dog days. The recent spell of pleasant weather has turned the streets of New York into an exotic summertime menagerie and even the street musicians have been sneaking in a circus tune or two as the town's Tarzans and Janes parade by with their monkeys, tortoises and goldfish bowls.

title: THRIFT AID PLANS DIFFER
description: The Reagan Administration, for the second time in several months, has rejected most of a plan developed by the nation's banking regulators to deal with short-term problems in the ailing thrift industry.

title: UPSTATE TRANSPORT AID
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET SHIPS IN BALTIC MASS FOR AMPHIBIOUS GAMES
description: The largest Soviet amphibious fleet ever assembled in the Baltic Sea is apparently preparing for a landing exercise.

title: HIGH COURT IN MASSACHUSETTS SUSTAINS VOTE LIMITING TAXES
description: The State Supreme Court today upheld a proposition approved by Massachusetts voters last November to cut property taxes.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE proliferation of fine red table wines in California has tempted many consumers to begin laying them down for aging, just as generations of Europeans and some Americans stored French and Italian reds in years gone by, when prices were lower and the competition for the best bottles was less keen.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press from Detroit published in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the payment date for the dividend on General Motors' common stock. The correct date is Sept. 10.

title: Q&A
description: Q. = I have long contended that all ice cubes should be freshly made. My friends accuse me of being a ''purist'' and insist it is perfectly all right to use ''old'' ice cubes.What do you think?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMCA International Corp., Hanover, N.H., has appointed Michael J. Ucci a vice president.

title: SUNDAY SCHOOL IT'S NOT
description: The current issue of Harper's contains a testy article on our current literary biggies, people like Joyce Carol Oates, William Styron, Norman Mailer, John Updike and so on and on, the burden of which is that they are only 13th-raters whose skill at promotional flimflam has persuaded the world and themselves that they are a new race of Tolstoys.

title: AMERICANS IN PARIS WHO COOK TO LIVE
description: The call comes at 5:30 P.M., at the end of a physically exhausting school day: There's a cocktail party for 30 starting at 7. The message is simple: Be there. Sue Herrmann and Sco Betsill dutifully leave their posts as stagiaires, or student helpers, at the Paris cooking school La Varenne, head for their employer's kitchen and brace themselves for the inevitable: The cupboard will be bare, and they'll be expected to work culinary miracles, turning a loaf and a half of bread and a jar of mayonnaise into elegant cocktail fare.

title: Tyco Must End Ludlow purchases
description: Tyco Laboratories Inc. was ordered by the Secretary of State of Massachusetts to stop acquiring additional shares of stock in the Ludlow Corporation. Both companies are diversified manufacturers.

title: Adam Powell Is Focus of Carey's Creative Urge
description: How do Governors unwind? Well, Governor Carey is working on a play, or possibly a musical, about the life of the late Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the longtime United States Representative from Harlem.

title: ACF Increases Bid For Ladish Shares
description: The contest for control of the Ladish Company intensified yesterday when ACF Industries raised its previous tender offer for all of Ladish's common shares.

title: CABLE REQUEST
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it and five other carriers requested authority from the Federal Communications Commission to build a $72 million undersea cable system between Florida and the Virgin Islands. The cable, scheduled to go into operation in 1983, would be used for international communications services and would have about 1,900 circuits, A.T.&T. said. It would be the third link between the United States and St. Thomas, which serves as a hub for cables connecting the United States and parts of the Caribbean and South America.

title: Mississippi Quarterback Has Surgery on Hand
description: The Mississippi quarterback John Fourcade underwent surgery today for a broken right hand that could keep him sidelined for the Rebels' opener next month.

title: 50 YEARS IN HARNESS RACING; HAROLD R. DANCER SR.
description: Harold R. Dancer Sr., a member of the noted harness racing family, died of a heart attack at his home Sunday at the age of 69.

title: DRUGS, SUN: TROUBLE
description: Belladonna was once used by women as a cosmetic trick to dilate their pupils. As a drug called atropine, opthalmologists use it to dilate the pupil during eye examinations. It blocks the action of acetylcholine, a nerve-fiber chemical transmitter, inhibiting sweating and interfering with the body's temperature regulation.

title: THOUSANDS ARE DELAYED BY A FIRE ON IRT TRAIN
description: Service on the West Side IRT subway line was disrupted yesterday morning when power was shut off on all southbound tracks at Times Square to enable firefighters to extinguish a burning switch box aboard a No. 1 train.

title: A YOUNGSTER SAYS MOTORMAN YELLED BEFORE SUBWAY CRASH
description: The motorman who died in a subway crash last month cried out a moment before his train struck another, according to two youngsters who rode in the lead car with him the day of the accident.

title: FINE OF $100,000 AN HOUR IMPOSED ON CONTROLLERS
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ordered the air controllers union yesterday to pay a $100,000-an-hour penalty to the nation's airlines while the controllers' strike continued.

title: News Analysis
description: Prodded insistently by President Reagan, Congress has slashed or abolished this year dozens of Government programs originally enacted to cure or ameliorate a wide variety of social and economic problems.

title: Mental Patient Is Sought
description: A young mental patient who killed his step-grandfather by driving a wooden stake into his heart because he believed him a ''vampire'' disappeared nearly two weeks ago and is presumably at large in the St. Louis area. Dr. Kathleen Smith, superintendent of the Malcolm Bliss Mental Health Center, said officials notified the police only yesterday that Jeffrey Maness, 23 years old, had failed to return from a one-day pass July 24. The step-grandfather, William Ellis, 59, was killed July 26, 1980.

title: A BULB STORE WITH STYLE
description: BY coincidence, the building in which Phil and Shirley Brooks have just opened Just Bulbs, the Light Bulb Store, was once occupied by Brooks Brothers, according to James Rossant of Conklin Rossant Architects, which renovated its exterior, above. ''We're restoring it to its Art Deco design and did the glass block and the aluminum trim,'' said Mr. Rossant, shown at near left.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 6, 1981
description: Controllers' Strike The first dismissal notices were sent out by the Government to 55 striking air traffic controllers after they defied an ultimatum from President Reagan that they return to work or forfeit their jobs. The overwhelming majority of the more than 12,000 controllers who began the illegal strike Monday continued to hold ranks to compel the Government to grant their economic demands, raising the prospect that thousands of dismissal notices might be issued. The first jailings of striking controllers for failing to obey court orders took place in Alexandria, Va., and Kansas City, Kan. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The number of flights rose slightly yesterday and the nation's airlines reported that more passengers were filling previously empty seats. The Government reported that 75 percent of the normal 14,200 daily flights had been handled by supervisors and other nonstriking controllers. (D20:1-3.)

title: C.F.A. Conducts TV Talks
description: Officials of NBC Sports met yesterday with representatives of the College Football Association to discuss a possible television package involving C.F.A. members.

title: A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AN OLD HUNT CLUB
description: SOUTH HAMILTON, Mass. FROM under the luncheon tent, where the bottles were set out on Sunday and the silver bowl of ice glinted and dripped in the August heat, the vista from the clubhouse dropped through the warm blue haze down a curving driveway, across a graceful gray stone bridge to the polo field, a distant, shimmering green.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Jury Indicts 8 On Copyright Charges
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted eight persons on charges of criminal copyright infringement and mail fraud in a multimillion-dollar film piracy scheme.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Astradyne Computer Industries filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 675,000 common shares, to be sold through a Faherty & Faherty Inc. group.

title: Energy Price Talks Held
description: Canadian Energy Minister Marc Lalonde and his Alberta counterpart, Merv Leitch, refused to say today whether any progress had been made in their latest round of energy pricing talks that began earlier in the day.

title: PALESTINIAN LINKED TO MUNICH SLAYINGS WOUNDED IN WARSAW
description: A Palestinian guerrilla leader who was believed to be among those responsible for the 1972 Olympics massacre in Munich was shot and seriously wounded in the coffee shop of a hotel here Saturday night, the local representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization announced today.

title: GIRL, 12, MISSING FIVE MONTHS, TELLS OF CAPTIVITY IN COAST PIT
description: Twelve-year-old Jeana Rodriguez, who was last seen five months ago, returned home yesterday and said she had been held captive by a man who sometimes kept her in a pit, officials said.

title: LAKERS TRADE TWO TO OBTAIN KUPCHAK
description: The Los Angeles Lakers announced today that they have acquired Mitch Kupchak from the Washington Bullets for Jim Chones, Brad Holland and two draft choices.

title: Peru Oil Fields
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it has discovered two new oil fields in the Amazon jungle of Peru and that more drilling would begin immediately to determine the size of the find.

title: Advertising; ; Bon Jour Widening Its Focus
description: IN its new campaign by its new agency, Bon Jour International, which has been very much a part of the status jeans explosion, is sort of backing off from jeans and certainly from the racy tone of TV commercials for designer jeans. Romance, yes. Sex, no.

title: NEW HEAD OF FOX PLANNING FOR NEW TECHNOLOGIES
description: A crown is pasted onto the photograph of Alan Hirschfield, newly appointed chairman of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, and the legend on it reads, ''It's good to be the king.''

title: MUM'S THE WORD AT BAVARIAN OPERA
description: The audience at the Bavarian State Opera's performance of Wagner's ''Die Meistersinger'' last night was astounded when the chorus became inaudible.

title: No Headline
description: PRIVATE ENTERPRISE FAILS: A rocket exploding during a static engine test at Matagorda Island, Tex.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Topics; LITTLE WHITE LIES; Nanny and Mommy
description: Of all the scornful epithets hurled at Government regulators in recent years, none was more telling than ''national nanny.'' Don't drink saccharin, you'll probably get cancer.

title: OFFICIALS SAY AIR CONTROLLERS FACE AN UPHILL LEGAL BATTLE
description: As the Reagan Administration moved to dismiss thousands of striking air traffic controllers today and continued its legal onslaught against them in courts around the country, an attorney for the controllers' union acknowledged that the union members were fighting an uphill legal battle and were ''anticipating a political solution.''

title: HEALTH INSPECTORS CHECK LEVEL OF HEAT ON CONRAIL
description: An unannounced spot check last evening of 32 Conrail commuter cars found that interior temperatures ranged from 71 degrees to 93 degrees, county officials said today.

title: Big Ten Eases Penalties On University of Illinois
description: The Big Ten Conference tonight reduced sanctions it had imposed last spring against the University of Illinois for its handling of an eligibility case involving Dave Wilson, the former Illinois quarterback.

title: One Dies in Bogota Jail Riot
description: A prisoner was killed and 37 were badly wounded when policemen moved in to quell an eight-hour riot at a jail in Bogota last night, Justice Ministry sources said. Four policemen were also badly hurt when prisoners threw gasoline bombs and stones from the roof of the jail.

title: Small Business Shift Urged
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed changes in its rules so that small businesses could more easily raise money through securities offerings.

title: GRIFFIN GOES TO CUBS AS YANKS COMPLETE DEAL FOR REUSCHEL
description: The Yankees sent Mike Griffin, a right-handed relief pitcher, to the Chicago Cubs yesterday to complete the deal of two months ago that brought Rick Reuschel to New York for Doug Bird and cash. The departure of Griffin improved the prospects of Gene Nelson, another rookie, by trimming the Yankee pitching staff to nine.

title: Church Bus Wreck Hurts 48
description: A church bus taking children to a summer camp tumbled off a highway ramp today and rolled over several times, tearing the bus in two. All 48 passengers on the McElwain Baptist Church bus were injured and four of them were hospitalized.

title: ACHIEVING A EUROPEAN LOOK IN AN AMERICAN SETTING
description: THERE'S no denying that interior designers do things differently in Europe. In Italy, for example, both commercial and residential interiors can have a certain drama, a crispness and just plain stylishness that are often lacking in the United States.

title: NEW LAW TO SHIELD ART BUYER
description: The ''fine prints'' bill to toughen disclosure requirements in the sale of graphic works, photographs and other art multiples has been signed by Governor Carey. The bill had been opposed by some auction houses that feared that it would be difficult to trace the origin of some works.

title: CALENDAR: FLOWERS, BOTH DRIED AND URBAN
description: Drying and Preserving Flowers, The Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street. Pat Thorpe, a specialist in dried and fresh flower arrangements, will teach the best techniques for drying and preserving summer flowers next Wednesday in this two-hour workshop.

title: Mayoral Nominee For Huge Tax Cut
description: The Libertarian Party introduced its candidate for New York Mayor: a 33-year-old, Panamanian-born woman who believes in massive tax cuts, an end to ''victimless crimes'' and the use of private companies to provide key municipal services.

title: Business People; FIDUCIARY TRUST FILLS A NEWLY CREATED POST
description: Henry H. Moulton, 56, has been appointed to the new post of vice chairman of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York, which has $6 billion worth of assets under management and acts as an executor and trustee. He will be in charge of a new office that the company has just opened in Los Angeles.
