title: YONKERS ADOPTS BUDGET THAT DEFERS THE LAYOFFS
description: The City Council approved a balanced $192.7 million budget tonight that defers municipal layoffs until Dec. 1 and meets an Aug. 15 deadline to avert bankruptcy.

title: Business People; SCIENTIST TO BE PRESIDENT OF AIR PRODUCTS EUROPE
description: J. Robert Lovett, a 49-year-old scientist who holds 20 patents, has been named president of Air Products Europe, a unit of Air Products and Chemicals Inc. with headquarters near London. The position in Europe, an area that accounts for 22 percent of the parent corporation's sales, is a new one at the big chemicals maker.

title: BONN BACKS TRADE WITH EAST
description: West German Government officials and business leaders, both privately and in public statements, underscore Bonn's resolve to continue expanding trade with Eastern Europe, despite the misgivings voiced by President Reagan at the Ottawa economic summit meeting and reiterated by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in Senate testimony last week.

title: ANNAPOLIS TO READMIT YOUTH WHOSE ROOMMATE WAS KILLED
description: Michael R. Olmstead, ordered dismissed from the United States Naval Academy after an automobile accident in which his roommate was killed, will get a second chance to graduate.

title: Vote on Tobacco Quota
description: The International Trade Commission voted 3-1 yesterday against recommending that President Reagan impose import quotas on tobacco imports, an International Trade Commission spokesman said today. The agency found that flue-cured tobacco, a major cigarette ingredient, was not being imported at high enough levels to interfere with United States Agriculture Department programs intended to support prices for domestic growers.

title: I.C.C. Chief Pledges Deregulation Support
description: In a wide-ranging talk with reporters here today, Reese H. Taylor Jr., the new chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, disavowed frequently heard suggestions that he would take his marching orders from the large operators in the trucking industry and from the Teamsters.

title: TRANS-ATLANTIC AIR TRAFFIC BETTER ON WALKOUT'S 3D DAY
description: After two days of uncertainty and long delays caused by the air controllers' strike in the United States, airline traffic between major European airports and the United States was getting closer to normal today. The exception was London, where dozens of standby passengers had not yet found plane seats.

title: ON BREUER FURNITURE
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: For purposes of clarification, we would like to inform you that we have been distributing an authorized version of the B35 lounge chair by Marcel Breuer since 1973. The chair is available in wicker or leather. PAT HOFFMAN I.C.F. (International Contract Furnishings)

title: BRADY FACES A NEW PROBLEM
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, was reported in good condition today as he recovered from a severe brain seizure, but doctors said that he might require surgery to combat another problem.

title: DEVELOPER PICKED FOR RUPPERT PROJECT
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it had selected a developer for apartments to be constructed as the second and final part of the Ruppert Urban Renewal Project on the Upper East Side.

title: Currency Markets; Gold Up, Dollar Slips As Foreign Banks Act; The Associated Press
description: The dollar slipped from its lofty levels against most major currencies yesterday as central banks in West Germany, Italy and Switzerland moved to support their currencies.

title: In an Ill-Starred Miami Family
description: Raymond Southerland, whose family has been plagued by varying forms of cancer for more than 140 years, died today at a hospital two months after the death of his 16-year-old son.

title: Around the World; SOVIET DETAILS OBJECTIONS TO MARKET'S AFGHAN PLAN
description: The Soviet Union today spelled out its objections to a European Common Market initiative on Afghanistan and said it formed no basis for the withdrawal of its troops from the country.

title: Erick Hawkins Dancers At Tully Hall Sept. 14
description: A world premiere will highlight the Alice Tully Hall debut of the Erick Hawkins Dance Company on Sept. 14 at 8 P.M. The work, ''Heyoka,'' is choreographed by Mr. Hawkins and has music by Ross Lee Finney.

title: Power Disrupted in England
description: Failures in three major power lines cut electricity to millions of homes, factories and hospitals in south and southwest England and Wales today in the worst accidental disruption since 1962. Ten counties lost power for between 90 minutes and four hours, officials said. Cause of the failures was not immediately known.

title: Children and TV
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I pity the child whose mother thinks TV can be educational (''Limiting Children's TV Habits,'' July 30). The only thing educational about TV is when the set breaks. Then it can be educational for the child to repair it. LILY FLOM Forest Hills, Queens

title: REAGAN LETTER TO CONGRESS CHIEFS REAFFIRMS SALE OF AWACS TO SAUDIS
description: In a letter to the leaders of both political parties in Congress, President Reagan today restated his intention to press ahead with a proposal to sell Saudi Arabia five aerial surveillance and control aircraft.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No question we are in trouble and the public is going to be inconvenienced.

title: U.N. REVISES THE TOLL IN IRAN QUAKE TO 1,500
description: The United Nations has announced that the estimated death toll from the earthquake last week in southeastern Iran has been reduced sharply to 1,500.

title: U.S. SEEKS SEA-LAW CHANGES
description: The United States called on the United Nations conference on sea law today to make revisions in the proposed treaty on the use of the seas and their resources.

title: BEGIN'S NEW COALITION WINS VOTE IN PARLIAMENT BY A BARE MAJORITY
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin received the first vote of confidence in his new coalition late tonight during a rowdy, bitter session of the Israeli Parliament that underscored the fragile nature of his majority.

title: SCREEN: 'INDIA SONG' RETURNS
description: ''India Song'' was shown at the 1975 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Oct. 8, 1975. The film opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue and 56th Street.

title: Credit Markets; 10-YEAR U.S. NOTES SET MARK
description: The Treasury sold new 14 7/8 percent 10-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 14.98 percent - a record for that maturity and one that seemed to attract more buying interest as the day wore on.

title: Around the World; Fires Set by Extremists Still Burning in Greece
description: Several extremist groups took responsibility today for a series of devastating fires raging through the Athens residential suburbs and other parts of Greece, bringing angry threats from the Government that those responsible would be ''crushed.''

title: Advertising; Plans for Introduction Of 1982 Continental Set
description: Ford's Lincoln-Mercury division and its agency, Young & Rubicam, announced yesterday plans for the introduction of the 1982 Continental. And the agency is promising the same futuristic advertising that it has given the Lynx.

title: Pacific Telephone Gets Rate Increase
description: Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company was granted a $610 million annual rate increase by the California Public Utilities Commission, effective Aug. 29.

title: Robinson Still Trying Harder
description: They compete for the first time Friday, in an exhibition game: Richard Todd passing for the Jets, Matt Robinson for the Broncos.

title: BRIDGE OF SUBURBS UNIFYING FORT WORTH AND DALLAS
description: To appreciate the churning changes taking place these days in what is called the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex, the ninth most populous metropolitan area in the country and rising fast toward eighth, you have to understand the vast differences that Dallas and Fort Worth have long displayed.

title: Jolting End to a Dream
description: It was apparently a memorable vacation for 12-year-old Michael Schaetzle, but not as memorable as his dream about it. In the dream, Michael recalled, he was at Myrtle Beach, S.C., and, decided that the ocean was so appealing that he would dive in.

title: All-Star Debut for Pitchers
description: Six pitchers, including Len Barker of Cleveland, who pitched a perfect game earlier this season, will be making their first appearance in an All-Star Game as members of the American League staff.

title: CITY SLICKER VS. INDOMINATBLE GROUNDHOG
description: By FAYE MOSKOWITZ

title: UP 'SLIGHTLY' IN 3D DAY
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today sent out the first of what could be thousands of dismissal notices to air traffic controllers after they defied an ultimatum from President Reagan that they return to work or forfeit their jobs.

title: FLIGHTS UP 'SLIGHTLY' IN 3D DAY
description: Government and airline officials today predicted a long-term disruption of the nation's air traffic, with flights reduced for at least a year, unless substantial numbers of striking controllers return to work.

title: IN CALIFORNIA BEACH TOWNS, WATT IS LOSING FRIENDS
description: James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, asked communities around the country recently to nominate any adjacent Federal lands that they might want to take for parks, schools or other public facilities.

title: So That Whales May Survive
description: Commercial whaling the world over is no longer profitable and will eventually disappear, save perhaps by Eskimos. But the slaughter continues and may not end quickly enough to save the more vulnerable species of these remarkable creatures.

title: WARSAW STREET TIE-UP ENDS AFTER TWO-HOUR STRIKE
description: A column of 173 bus and trucks ended a two-day blockage of a downtown street intersection here today after workers in the Polish capital had staged a two-hour strike to protest food shortages.

title: POP: KRAFTWERK'S MINIMALISM
description: BECAUSE they were one of the earliest and most successful futuristic pop groups, the German quartet Kraftwerk, which appeared Monday and Tuesday at the Ritz, has earned itself at least a footnote in pop history. Kraftwerk's most famous composition, ''Autobahn,'' is a graphic, synthesized depiction of driving on a freeway, right down to the whooshing sound of cars.

title: ON BREUER FURNITURE
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: This is in reference to the Suzanne Slesin article about the Marcel Breuer exhibition (''The Furniture of Marcel Breuer: Classics and Some Surprises,'' July 23).

title: Around the Nation; Miami Police Follow Up F.B.I. in New Drug Raid
description: The police said that they smashed a ''white collar'' cocaine network today in the second major crackdown on Miami drug operations in two days.

title: STRIKE IS HURTING BUSINESSES THAT DEPEND ON AIR TRAFFIC
description: On taxi stands at La Guardia Airport, at hotels in midtown Manhattan, in the city's flower market and in the airline industry itself, the air traffic controllers' strike is beginning to take its toll.

title: Simplicity Merger Revision Accepted
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company and NCC Energy Ltd. announced approval of revisions to their previously announced merger agreement in principle. Simplicity is the world's leading manufacturer of paper patterns for clothing.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/Larry C. Morris St. Patrick's Cathedral Is All Aglow The Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral received a new lighting system from Harry B. Helmsley, the real estate executive. Above are the views before and after the lights were turned on, from the Helmsley Palace Hotel across Madison Avenue. The project began as an accident, when lights designed to illuminate the hotel courtyard fell on the chapel; when church representatives saw the effect, they agreed to make it permanent.

title: VIEWING THE MANHATTAN FRONT YARD: DIVERSITY AND CHALLENGE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang writes regularly about gardening for the Home Section. By LINDA YANG

title: Index; Controllers' Strike
description: General-aviation airports report few problems in strike D19 Businesses linked to air traffic feeling impact of strike D20 European-U.S. air traffic im- proves after 2 days of delays D20 International Argentina strides into the atomic age withput help from the U.S. A2 U.S. seeking revision of sea-law treaty draft A3 Begin's coalition wins bare ma- jority in Parliament A4 Palestinian, linked to Munich massacre, is shot in Warsaw A4 Reagan letter to Congress reaf- firms Awacs deal with Saudis A4 Around the World A6 Hiroshima Mayor bids Tokyo bar atom weapons from Japan A8 New study details longterm ef- fects of atomic bombings A8 Government/Politics G.A.O. calls U.S. unprepared to carry out nuclear strategy A9 Panel on violent crime urges relaxation of rules on evidence A12 Growing suburbs bring unity to Dallas and Fort Worth A16 U.S. plans raise in building subsi- dies for low-income housing A17 Yonkers Council considers second county budget offer B2 Audit says Creedmor chief mis- used state car B6 General Around the Nation A10 Reputed New Orleans mob leader indicted in bribery case A13 Doctors discover new problem for Brady A14 Abducted 12-year-old girl returns home on Coast A18 Police rookie shoots three in error in Nashville A20 Home Section Home Achieving a European look in an American setting C1

title: Susan Hammond Dies at 95; Once Headed Junior Leagues
description: Susan Sedgewick Swann Hammond, president of the Association of Junior Leagues of America Inc. in the early 1920's, died at her home in Manhattan Tuesday. She was 95 years old.

title: Advertising; Doyle Dane Bernbach Profits Increase 7%
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International reports that its net income rose 8 percent in the second quarter, to $4.4 million, or 80 cents a share, from $4.1 million, or 78 cents a share, in the similar quarter last year. Revenues were up 7 percent, to $43.2 million, from $40.2 million.

title: DOCTORS CALL FOR CONTROLS ON USE OF ANTIBIOTICS
description: An overuse of antibiotics such as penicillin and tetracycline has dramatically reduced their effectiveness, making treatment for some diseases more difficult and expensive, some physicians concerned with the problem said here yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: BY BERNARD GLADSTONE Q. We have moved into an old house that has oak floors with slats that are about 2 inches wide. In the recent humid weather some of these floor boards have begun to buckle and there is evidence that this has happened before (signs of extra nails having been driven in). When we step on these boards they go back down, but won't stay down. We were told that one of the floors got a drenching when a window was accidentally left open during a storm. Can you tell us what causes flooring to buckle in the same place, and what we can do to affect a cure? - K.W.H., Peekskill, N.Y.

title: YOUNGBLOOD AN ALL-STAR, BUT A MET QUESTION MARK
description: Joel Youngblood got two messages at Shea Stadium yesterday that intensified the joy, torment, satisfaction and anger of his mixed-up season as the revolving man of the Mets.

title: RECESSED CABINET PULLS
description: STREAMLINED cabinets for bathrooms, kitchens or general storage areas depend upon flush recessed pulls to create a smooth unbroken surface. There are many types of flush pulls available, from the simply functional to decorative.

title: Essay; DECEPTION MANAGERS
description: ''Deception management'' is the term of art applied to the decade-long campaign by Soviet officials to persuade American intelligence evaluators that the Soviet Union is not violating arms control agreements.

title: Tanker Leaks Toxic Fumes
description: A railroad tanker car that began leaking toxic nitric acic yesterday, forcing the evacuation of 200 people from this industrial community 20 miles southeast of St. Louis, leaked again today but the toxic fumes were blown away from nearby homes and no further evacuations were ordered. The police attributed the leak to a a faulty seal on the tanker. A faulty seal was also blamed for a nitric acid leak that forced nearly 2,000 people to flee their homes in Dupo and nearby Cahokia for up to seven hours on July 20.

title: Republic Bank Decision
description: United States District Court Judge Patrick Higginbotham has ordered Republic Bank to stop discriminating against blacks and female employees in a decision that could cost the bank as much as $50 million. Bank officials vowed to appeal the case to the Supreme Court, if necessary. The lawsuit was filed in 1969.

title: MCGUIRE AIR BASE SENDS 14 CONTROLLERS TO 2 CITIES
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., Aug. 5 - Maj. Jerome F. Simmer, commander of air traffic control operations here, sent 14 of his best men and women off to airports in New York and the Washington, D.C., area this week.

title: BRITAIN TO STOP POSTING MINIMUM LENDING RATE
description: The British Government said today that it will soon stop posting a key interest rate in an attempt to allow interest rates on consumer and business loans to move more freely.

title: Bridge: Katz Team Rallies to Win The Spingold Tournament
description: A sensational turnabout in the early hours of this morning gave a victory in the final of the Spingold knockout team championship to Ralph Katz of Steubenville, Ohio; John Sutherlin of San Francisco; Allan Stauber of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; Warren Rosner of Nanuet, N.Y.; Ron Gerard of White Plains, and Larry Cohen of Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: How Travelers Find Their Way
description: Many travelers searching for alternative transportation in the third day of the air traffic controllers' strike turned again to trains and buses.

title: SCENARIO FOR A TAIWANESE DEFENSE CRISIS
description: To the Editor:

title: SAYING IT WITH NOT-TOO-COSTLY FLOWERS
description: IN Europe, flowers come home with the bread, toted in regularly, fresh from the market. And just as slicing bread is second nature to anyone over 6 on the Continent, so is living with cut flowers.

title: A Tribute to Television's Golden Age
description: It was a time of nostalgia for many show business luminaries Tuesday evening, at a reception at WNET-TV headquarters to open a series called ''The Golden Age of Television.''

title: SUSPECT IN KILLING OF 2 IDAHOANS LEAVES COLD TRAIL
description: The footprints were barely visible in the frozen sand, and after 100 yards they faded and disappeared in the cold winter light. The trackers said there was no point in going on: Up ahead were thousands of square miles of bleak, untracked desert.

title: FOR A FILIPINO NURSE, ECONOMICS IS THE KEY
description: Julieta Julian is a shy 29-year-old Filipino nurse at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx who, patients say, has a ''beautiful bedside manner.'' Like thousands of other Filipino nurses who now staff American hospitals, she emigrated to this country, she said, to gain the professional, economic and social advantages that were not available in her own country.

title: GATX MAKES LEASING DEAL
description: The GATX Corporation said its leasing subsidiary arranged an Australian-based leveraged lease agreement valued at $218 million to finance the acquisition of three new Boeing 747 aircraft.

title: KEY ISSUES IN THE WALKOUT
description: The major issues in the contract dispute between the air traffic controllers' union and the Federal Aviation Administration are wages, the length of the workweek and the retirement plan. When the walkout began, the union's demands, by its own accounting, would have required $575 million in new outlays in the first year.

title: ON BREUER FURNITURE
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: For your information, we also sell Italian ''Breuer'' chairs - $44.99 for the side chair and $59.99 for the armchair. They are available in black, walnut and natural finishes. STEVEN SMITH Bon Marche

title: HERS
description: DOOM, while always ''impending,'' has never appeared to have so much clout. As the Continental Shelf drifts beneath our feet, acid rain drizzles upon our heads. We have heard the nuclear burp of Three Mile Island, seen the inflamed ooze of Mount St. Helens. If we're not yet at war, maybe we don't have to be, as buried missiles fire rudely ''by mistake.''

title: BILLY MILLS FINDS NEW CHALLENGES
description: Billy Mills still winces inside when people, trying to be friendly, call him Chief. But he no longer feels bitter or inferior. It is 17 years since he stunned the world for a few minutes as the unheralded, if not unknown, Sioux Indian who beat Ron Clarke to win the 10,000-meter race and a gold medal at the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo. But Mills has never lost the good feeling he got about himself on his most glorious day.

title: 3 DEAD FRUIT FLIES STIR FLORIDA FEARS
description: Three dead Mediterranean fruit flies turned up in a trap in a yard in East Tampa today, and state and Federal officials, fearing for Florida's $2 billion citrus crop, moved immediately to determine whether the flies came from California, where three counties have been battling a devastating infestation.

title: ROCK: SATIRE BY THE TUBES, COAST SEPTET
description: The Tubes, the West Coast rock septet who performed at the Palladium on Tuesday, have always been more interesting as entertainers than as musicians. A rock-and-roll circus with a satirical sensibility in the same adolescent mode as ''The National Lampoon,'' the Tubes specialize in building amusing show-business extravaganzas around their songs.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 6, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: City Council Lines Assailed as Biased
description: A suit filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn charges that newly adopted districts for the New York City Council are racially discriminatory and also violate the one-man, one-vote principal.

title: THE RIGHT KIND OF INSURANCE: A GUIDE TO THE MAZE
description: ''Insurance is not mysterious - it's just that a lot of things aren't black and white,'' said Bradley Brown, a Manhattan insurance executive, offering an appropriately paradoxical description. Home insurance is both gray and mysterious for most people. As a result, many homeowners have given up trying to figure out if their property is adequately insured or if the premium is reasonable.

title: NURSE SCARCITY FORCES CUT IN CARE IN NEW YORK MUNICIPAL HOSPITALS
description: A persistent shortage of nurses has become so critical in New York City's municipal hospitals that even routine nursing care is now largely reserved for the sickest patients while healthier ones are left to take care of themselves.

title: Utility Plan Dies In Westchester
description: Republicans on the Westchester County Board of Legislators last night defeated an effort by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello and other Democrats to place a proposal to create a county power agency before voters in November.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt ANGEL OF LIGHT. By Joyce Carol Oates. 434 pages. Dutton. $15.50.

title: Dr. Maurice R. Friend, A Child Psychoanalyst
description: Dr. Maurice R. Friend, former director of the Downstate Psychoanalytic Institute, now known as the Psychoanalytic Institute at New York University Medical Center, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.

title: Guerrilla Radio Says Troops Kill 138 Salvadoran Civilians
description: A guerrilla radio station said today that Government troops had killed 138 civilians, many of them women and children, in an army drive against suspected rebel positions on Guazapa, an inactive volcano 15 miles north of San Salvador.

title: DU PONT VICTOR IN COSTLY BATTLE TO BUY CONOCO
description: The most expensive corporate takeover battle in history ended yesterday with the Du Pont Company announcing that it had acquired a controlling interest in Conoco Inc., America's ninth-largest oil company.

title: THE SINKING CANADIAN DOLLAR
description: A proliferation here of orange license plates from New York and black ones from Michigan attests to the fact that Americans know a bargain when they see it.

title: Advertising; Burnett Shifts Management
description: After just five years in the job, C.R. Kopp, 60 years old and chairman of the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, is turning over the chief executive's post to John J. Kinsella, the 52-year-old president.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, AUGUST 6, 1981; Companies
description: Du Pont was the victor in the three-way battle for Conoco, settling the most expensive takeover struggle in history. The deal, worth $7.57 billion in stock and cash for the oil company, will create the nation's seventh-largest industrial corporation. Du Pont has started paying $98 a share for up to 38.7 million of Conoco's 86 million outstanding shares and will exchange 1.7 of its shares for all the remaining Conoco stock. (Page A1.)

title: STUDY OF ATOM BOMB VICTIMS STRESSES LONG-TERM DAMAGE
description: On the 36th anniversary of the dropping of an atom bomb on Hiroshima today, a ''white paper'' prepared two years ago by Japanese scientists and social workers, with several sections brought up to date to this February, has been published in English in New York, London and Tokyo. Though the evidence is presented factually, the findings are potent emotionally.

title: CHANGES PROPOSED FOR CLEAN AIR ACT
description: The Reagan Administration outlined its longawaited plans for revisions in air quality legislation today, proposing that standards for motor vehicle emissions be relaxed and that more responsibility for clean air be returned to the states.

title: Topics; LITTLE WHITE LIES; Feet Against Fear
description: In the good old days, many believe, the police deterred crime because instead of riding around in a patrol car they walked the neighborhood, checking shop doors and getting to know the people. But a recent Police Foundation study of foot patrols in Newark found that cops walking the beat did not significantly curtail crime.

title: Northwest Credit
description: Northwest Industries said it received more than $1 billion in standby revolving credits from domestic and foreign banks.

title: HOUSTON'S LIFELINE: TONS OF COOL AIR
description: ''Sauna'' and ''steam bath'' don't really do it justice, and comparing Houston in the summer to being slapped in the face with a hot towel also falls short of the reality. Simply put, Houston is one of the hottest cities in the country, and for six months a year there is nowhere more humid.

title: Market Place; A New Interest In 2d-Tier Oil
description: SHARES of some second-tier oil companies have surged during the battle to acquire Conoco. On Tuesday, Getty Oil, Marathon Oil and Superior Oil were standouts, with gains of 5 1/8, 4 and 3 points, respectively, in a largely lackluster stock market. Moreover, Superior Oil's 500,000-share turnover was second only to Conoco's 1.2 million shares.

title: Kaiser to Shut 2 Production Lines
description: The Kaiser Aluminium and Chemical Corporation said it will stop operating two aluminium-producing potlines Aug. 16 because of declining demand and escalating costs.

title: Advertising; Lipton Herbal Teas Moving to SSC&B
description: Only one kind of Lipton tea has not had its advertising done by SSC&B, its herbal teas. However, Thomas J. Lipton Inc., the Unilever subsidiary, is rectifying that situation by removing the herbals from Della Femina, Travisano & Partners and depositing them with the other Lipton products, which probably bill around $15 million.

title: BANK CASE FIGURE GIVEN BAIL
description: Harold J. Smith, the former boxing promoter under indictment in a $21.3 million Wells Fargo Bank embezzlement, has been granted bail of $50,000 on a bad check charge from North Carolina. Mr. Smith, who recently changed his name from Ross Eugene Fields, is to be arraigned in the bank case Aug. 10 in Federal District Court here.

title: Damage Closes Oswego A-Plant
description: The James A. FitzPatrick Nuclear Plant on Lake Ontario was shut down after the insulation on an electrical cable was damaged during maintenance work.

title: Surplus Butter Is Sold by U.S.
description: The United States has sold 220 million pounds of surplus Government-owned butter to New Zealand for 70 cents a pound, half of what it cost to stockpile it, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: STATE AUDIT ACCUSES CREEDMOOR CHIEF
description: The director of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens violated state policy by using a state car and driver for his personal convenience, a state audit reported yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: It was the biggest, most dramatic takeover battle in American corporate history, but the three-way fight for Conoco began not on Wall Street but with Canada's new energy policy. Conoco, America's ninth-largest oil company, was also a victim of its undervalued stock and an inflation psychology that makes it a better investment to buy an existing company than to pour capital into new production facilities.

title: Insulin Pump May Aid Children, Report Says
description: Children whose growth has been stunted by diabetes may be helped if they receive insulin through a mechanical insulin pump, a new study says.

title: MINORITY GROUPS AND MAYOR NEAR POLICE HIRING ACCORD
description: The Koch administration and black and Hispanic groups that had charged the Police Department with racial discrimination in hiring were near agreement yesterday on a plan to determine who is appointed to the Police Academy.

title: A QUESTION OF THE VALUE OF ART
description: As the United States Government has increasingly become an important patron of the arts through the National Endowment for the Arts, the nature and results of that patronage have come under increasing scrutiny and debate. Questions have been raised not only about the amounts of money being distributed, but also about the criteria by which art projects are selected for financing. Last year, for example, in a report on arts funds sponsored by the Heritage Foundation, Samuel Lipman and Hugo Weisgall criticized the endowment's ''flawed conception of art'' and the ''high-flown welfare and employment schemes'' that sometimes result.

title: MOSTLY MOZART: ADROIT OBOE
description: IT is hard to decide, really, whether the Tokyo Quartet was lucky or unlucky in the way the Mostly Mozart Concert at Avery Fisher Hall turned out Tuesday night. The ensemble was given principal billing, and three of the players did perform all evening. But when it was all over, one had the feeling, somehow, that the quartet ended up in an also-ran position. If it makes the players feel any better, they can comfort themselves with the thought that Misha Dichter, the pianist of the program, fared no better.

title: Large Increase in State Races Is Studied
description: The New York Racing Association is studying several major innovations that would increase significantly the number of thoroughbred races run in New York State.

title: CARTER AIDES DREW STRATEGY FOR A STRIKE 20 MONTHS AGO
description: It was more than 20 months ago that the Federal Government began planning its response to a nationwide strike by air traffic controllers.

title: Lambert Gives Strike Views
description: Jack Lambert, star linebacker for the Pittsburgh Steelers, said he would cross the picket lines if the National Football League Players Association strikes next summer over the issues that have been raised by Ed Garvey, the association's executive director.

title: The Sexually Wise
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Laura Cunningham's light-hearted depiction of the current sex scene (''Hers,'' July 23) is admirably perceptive except for her somewhat cavalier dismissal of the ''35-and-over'' group, to which I have belonged for some time.

title: RISES IN PRICE OF FOOD SLOW
description: Food prices this year are going up more slowly than expected and will probably rise less than the general inflation rate, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: General in Charge of Mission Into Iran Listed for Promotion
description: The Defense Department announced today that the Army general who was in charge of the aborted rescue mission into Iran last year, Maj. Gen. James B. Vaught, had been nominated for promotion to lieutenant general.

title: LOSSES LINKED TO STRIKE ARE ON RISE
description: The nation's major airlines increased their flights yesterday and reported that more passengers were filling previously empty seats. Spot checks around the country on the third day of the air controllers' strike showed that most flights were operating with only a few minutes' delay.

title: 21 Arrested as Drug Dealers In New Rochelle and Yonkers
description: The police in Yonkers and New Rochelle made 21 arrests yesterday in a campaign against dealers in heroin and cocaine in Westchester County.

title: Leader Says Unions at Paper Will Weigh Cost Concessions
description: A union leader at The Philadelphia Bulletin said yesterday that seven craft unions at the newspaper were willing to consider contract concessions.

title: Giscard in Canada
description: He doesn't have as much to do as he once did, but since leaving office in May, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the former President of France, has managed to keep busy anyway - as a vacationer.

title: FOR BAHAIS IN IRAN, A THREAT OF EXTINCTION
description: The Bahais in Iran are in danger of extermination. Not a week passes without a sinister incident. Already more than 60 people -storekeepers, artisans, teachers, Government employees, doctors and a distinguished university professor -have been lynched by mobs or executed by revolutionary firing squads. Hundreds have been dismissed from jobs; thousands have lost their homes and possessions.

title: FRANCE URGING ITS CITIZENS TO LEAVE IRAN
description: France today advised its citizens living in Iran to ''return quickly,'' and it recalled its ambassador in Teheran for consultations.

title: A SHORT DAY'S JOURNEY TO EUGENE O'NEILL'S CHILDHOOD HOME
description: IF you took a map of the United States and tried to locate a geographical point where the past and the future of the American theater intersect, you'd end up more than 45 minutes from Broadway. To be specific, you'd land a good two and a half hours by car from Manhattan - in the neighboring Connecticut towns of New London and Waterford, hard by the Long Island sound.

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO SHIFT ON VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: President Reagan said in an interview published today that he favored a 10-year extension of the Voting Rights Act directed primarily at Southern states.

title: JUDGE IN CALIFORNIA IS CHARGED WITH SOLICITING PROSTITUTION
description: Municipal Judge Lewis Wenzell was charged today with eight counts of soliciting prostitution. The charges say he had sex with five prostitutes in the past year.

title: HIROSHIMA MAYOR URGES RETENTION OF A-BOMB BAN
description: In a speech at a ceremony today marking the 36th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, Mayor Takeshi Araki called on the Japanese Government to maintain its three ''antinuclear principles'' - not to make nuclear weapons, possess them or allow them into Japan.

title: 17 Killed in Lebanon Clash
description: Two Moslem leftist groups, the Democratic Party and the Popular Resistance Front, clashed today in the Lebanese port city of Tripoli. The police said 17 people were killed and 36 wounded.

title: Contractor Killed In Car by Gunman
description: An electrical contractor was shot to death by a gunman who fired bullets through a window of the victim's car as he pulled out of the driveway of his Brooklyn home, the police said.

title: Executive Changes
description: * Allegheny Power System Inc. has elected Elmer B. Kaelin president of the Potomac Edison Co., a subsidiary.

title: SADAT BIDS REAGAN DROP U.S. REFUSAL TO TALK TO P.L.O.
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt urged President Reagan today to drop the longstanding American refusal to deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization as part of an effort to achieve a comprehensive peace in the Middle East. The idea was rejected, however, by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: CASINO AGENCY REBUTS ATTACK BY LOCAL UNION
description: The Casino Control Commission today rejected a contention that unions are not subject to regulation by the agency. It ordered Atlantic City's largest and fastest-growing union to appear for a hearing Sept. 9 on whether it should be barred from casino hotels.

title: No Headline
description: Canadian Ore for Japan TOKYO, Aug. 5 (Reuters) - Seven Japanese copper smelters are expected to start negotiations next month with Bethlehem Copper Ltd., an affiliate of Cominco Ltd., on importing copper ore from the Highland Valley mine in British Columbia, industry sources said today.

title: STRIKING BRASS WORKERS ACCEPT PACT AND SAVE JOBS
description: Union workers at Century Brass Products overwhelmingly ratified a three-year contract today, ending a four-day strike that nearly cost them their jobs.

title: Topics; LITTLE WHITE LIES; Growing Lyrical
description: Rhode Island is a very small state. In fact, as someone was cruel enough to point out recently, it fits very nicely into Utah's Great Salt Lake.

title: REPUTED MOB LEADER INDICTED IN BRIBERY CASE
description: A Federal grand jury indicted Carlos Marcello of New Orleans, a 71-year-old reputed figure in organized crime, and two other men today on charges that they tried to bribe a Federal judge with money or a valuable art object.

title: CHERRY IS A WOOD OFTEN CARVED IN STYLE
description: At one time cherry was known as mahogany's country cousin. I think I understand why. For sheer handsomeness, mahogany had no equal, and the established cabinetmakers in America and Europe were competing in the marketplace for it in the raw and with finished furniture. Transport costs made mahogany expensive and this coupled with its fine looks, made it quickly fashionable.

title: FEAR MONGERS IN THE KREMLIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Bombs in Ulster Injure 7 And Block Key Railway
description: Irish guerrillas set off bombs in six cities and towns in Northern Ireland tonight, injuring seven people and causing extensive damage.

title: DAUGHTER OF PROSECUTOR INJURED IN S.I. ABDUCTION
description: The 19-year-old daughter of the Staten Island District Attorney was seriously injured yesterday when she was abducted at gunpoint by a man who bound her to the steering wheel and accelerator of her car, the police said.

title: Lake Ontario Fish Show Taint Traces
description: ALBANY (AP) - Traces of poisonous dioxin have been found in 45 of 46 fish samples taken from Lake Ontario, State Health Department officials reported.

title: Brazilian Devaluation
description: The Central Bank of Brazil said today it had devalued the cruzeiro to 98.62/99.11 to the dollar from 96.40/ 96.88 previously. The adjustment is the 21st this year, and the accumulated devaluation since Jan. 1 totals 51.327 percent.

title: Living Close
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Leslie Aldridge Westoff seems to think it quite an accomplishment to live in one room ''so successfully.'' (''Starting Over in a One-Room Apartment,'' July 30).

title: KICKS DEFEAT COSMOS
description: Ron Futcher scored the winning goal at 8:25 of overtime tonight as the Minnesota Kicks defeated the Cosmos, 2-1.

title: 8 Banks Deny Polish Appeal
description: Executives of eight Western banks have rejected Poland's request for a further easing of terms to repay part of Poland's crippling debts, a banking executive said today.

title: SOVIET SPEEDING PIPELINE DEAL
description: Faced with the Reagan Administration's efforts to persuade its allies to scale down or abandon a huge pipeline project to carry Siberian gas to Western Europe, the Soviet Union appears to be hastening its efforts to complete the deal.

title: FARM AND CITY: GETTING TO KNOW YOU
description: When James George grew up in Des Moines, timber still fringed his neighborhood and city youngsters spent summers detasseling corn and baling hay on nearby farms.

title: HOT GROWING WEATHER IS DAMAGING GARDENS
description: Some vegetable gardens are in trouble. Flowers are dropping without setting fruit, especially on tomato, pepper, cucumber and squash plants. Many tomatoes that do form and turn ripe red have rotted black bottoms. Many squash and cucumber vines are falling over, completely wilted. Most flower dropping is caused by poor weather, not humidity, but heat. Vegetable plant flowers are fragile, particuarly those of tomato. According to the Cooperative Extension Service, the tomato is the crop most adversely affected by excessive heat. If daytime temperatures are over 90 degrees for several days, tomato flowers will drop off without setting fruit.

title: News Analysis
description: The American labor movement faces an extremely important and perhaps historic time in its existence, many labor leaders believe, if the Reagan Administration continues its strong, uncompromising policy toward the striking air controllers, forcing them from their jobs and perhaps destroying their union.

title: SOME WAYS TO WIN THE BATTLE AGAINST RUST
description: BY BERNARD GLADSTONE One continuous battle that the homeowner never seems to win is the ongoing struggle to try and stop - or at least control - rust. Wrought iron fences and gates, hinges, gate latches, garage door hardware, windows, metal furniture, toys, power tools, appliances, yard equipment, automobile bodies, bicycles -- all these and more are continually showing signs of rust, even when the homeowner thinks he is doing a good job of protecting them by painting regularly.

title: Around the Nation; Court Backs Government On Names of Union Foes
description: Federal labor officials have a right to find out who is contributing to antiunion activities in Southern textile mills, a Federal appeals court said today.

title: TALKS ON DESEGREGATION ENCOURAGE GOV. TREEN
description: Gov. David C. Treen of Louisiana said that talks today with Federal officials had left him encouraged that a settlement could be reached in the Justice Department's suit to desegregate the state's 17 college campuses.

title: CHILDREN AND TV; TO THE HOME SECTION
description: As a psychologist interested in whatever expands the individual's horizons - especially those of the child - I was heartened to read your discussion on the pros and cons of television.

title: ARTFUL CHART-MAKERS TO THE PRESIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; LLP Communications Units to Be Acquired
description: Grey Advertising is going to acquire for cash the two advertising agencies of LLP Communications, a British holding company that is deeply involved in promoting some of Rupert Murdoch's publishing properties.

title: NUCLEAR READINESS OF U.S. CRITICIZED
description: The General Accounting Office said today that the United States lacked the weapons and the communications to carry out the basic nuclear strategy formulated by the Carter Administration and adopted by the Reagan Administration.

title: Technology; USING WATER IN FINE CUTTING
description: PEERING into the Grand Canyon or simply surveying the damage a wave inflicts on a sand-castle wall, you may be impressed by the corrosive power of water, but you are unlikely to think of it as a finely honed scapel. Nevertheless, the rapidly growing use of water jets for cutting, trimming, and drilling suggests that the step from eroding natural or man-made structures to deftly carving them up is not a large one.

title: NEIMAN-MARCUS'S CHALLENGER
description: Robert Sakowitz, an invader in the land of the enemy, was a walking advertisement in his store's blue pin-striped doublebreasted suit by Ermenegildo Zegna and Calcutta lizard shoes. He gazed out across the street from the glass-walled elevator rising up the side of the stunning new Sakowitz specialty store.

title: BLOUNT GETS CHANCE AT STRONG SAFETY
description: In preparation for their first exhibition game against the Bears Saturday in Chicago, the Giants held their afternoon drills on the artificial turf of Giants Stadium today. But first Coach Ray Perkins announced who would not be practicing and who would not be making the trip.

title: Actors Meet Tomorrow On the Showcase Code
description: Actors Equity Association will hold a special membership meeting tomorrow to discuss the showcase code, which governs the participation of Actors Equity members in Off Off Broadway productions. The code has been in dispute between the actors union and Off Off Broadway theaters and playwrights.

title: U.S. PLANS TO RAISE BUILDING SUBSIDIES
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would increase subsidies to builders of low-income housing in an attempt to break a jam that has virtually halted the construction of apartments that receive Federal aid.

title: PARTNER OF OFFICER WHO SHOT 3 CALLS HER 'VERY, VERY CARING'
description: A rookie police officer who mistakenly shot a grocery store manager and two shoppers as they fled a robbery is a ''good officer'' and ''very caring,'' says the officer who was with her at the time.

title: Soviet Gets Loan
description: The First National Bank of Chicago said today it was participating in a $25 million syndicated loan to the Soviet Union. The bank said its London-based First Chicago Investment Banking Group unit was arranging the loan, but declined to give further details.

title: UKRAINIAN BOY SEEKS PERMANENT U.S. RESIDENCY
description: The year-old custody battle between the State of Illinois and the parents of Walter Polovchak, a 13-year-old Ukrainian boy who does not want to return with them to the Soviet Union, has taken a new turn with the boy's request for permanent residency in the Untied States.

title: GENERAL AVIATION REPORTS NO SNAGS
description: Problems caused by the air traffic controllers' strike eased yesterday at general-aviation airports in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Oosterhuis's Persistence Pays
description: Peter Oosterhuis had just finished practicing in 90-degree heat and was in the locker room, a towel draped around his sweat-drenched shoulders. One after another, golfers and others interrupted to congratulate him on his winning the Canadian Open last Sunday.

title: Heileman Contests Pabst's Schlitz Bid
description: The president of the G. Heileman Brewing Company, whose offer to acquire the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company was exceeded by the Pabst Brewing Company, charged today that the ''actual value'' of Pabst's bid ''may be significantly less than its stated value.''

title: The Shelter Shenanigans
description: Reading the report of New York City's investigation of the sordid business of bus shelters leaves a taste of ashes on the tongue. One almost longs for the simpler days of Boss Tweed, when crooked profiteering at least got the courthouse built.

title: ON PICKET LINE, WORDS OF BOTH UNITY AND FEAR
description: Michael DiGiovanni, Doug Carder, John Maizel and more than 490 of their fellow air controllers listened while a tape-recorded voice from behind the chain-link fence surrounding the New York Air Route Control Center urged them to return to their jobs.

title: U.S.-SOVIET GRAIN PACT EXTENDED
description: The United States and the Soviet Union, unable to reach a new long-term grain purchasing agreement, have decided to extend for one year the existing five-year accord that commits the Russians to buy at least six million tons of American wheat and corn annually.

title: POPE'S OPERATION IS CALLED SUCCESSFUL
description: Pope John Paul II underwent 45 minutes of surgery today to restore the normal functioning of his intestine, and doctors predicted that he would be able to leave the hospital in about 10 days.

title: Lightning Causes Power Failures
description: About 1,500 Northeast Utilities customers, mostly in Haddam, were without electricity, a spokesman said.

title: Raider Jury Recesses
description: Jurors in the antitrust suit brought by the Oakland Raiders against the National Football League completed their seventh day of deliberations today without reaching a verdict. The jury will resume deliberations tomorrow.

title: IMMIGRATION OFFICE WORKERS TO RALLY AGAINST U.S. POLICY
description: Employees of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service will hold a national day of protest Aug. 21 to demonstrate against President Reagan's approach toward immigration, a Federal union officer said today.

title: No Headline
description: Mel Gray, a wide receiver for the St. Louis Cardinals, will miss at least eight weeks because of a shoulder separation he suffered in practice yesterday.

title: DAY OF DEMOCRATIC DESERTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Earnings; I.T.T. NET SOARS 111% IN QUARTER
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that its profits in the second quarter soared 111 percent, while its revenues eased 1.7 percent from the similar period last year.

title: THE CHILEAN JUNTA'S ADVANCES IN REPRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: SUBDUED JOY AT DU PONT PARTY
description: Champagne glasses touched in the ornate hotel banquet room here shortly after last midnight as executives of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company quietly celebrated their $7.57 billion acquisition of Conoco.

title: Around the Nation; Park Service Sets Inquiry On Guardian Angel Case
description: Two United States Park Service detectives have been assigned to investigate charges by a founder of the Guardian Angels group from New York that he was abducted, beaten and thrown into the Potomac River, a Park Service spokesman said.

title: BOOKS: FROM 'H.M.S. PINAFORE' TO 'SWEENEY TODD'
description: AMERICAN OPERETTA, From ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' to ''Sweeney Todd.'' By Gerald Bordman. 183 pages. Oxford. $15.95.

title: Dismissed Pilot Sues Airline
description: A $4 million lawsuit has been filed by a former Eastern Airlines pilot contending that the airline dismissed her because of her sex-change operation. The suit was filed yesterday in Federal District Court by Karen F. Ulane, 39 years old, an Eastern pilot for more than 12 years.

title: Raise the Titanic?
description: He writes about sunken ships, in books like ''Raise the Titanic!'' ''Iceberg'' and the newly published ''Night Probe.'' But for Clive Cussler, an avid marine archeologist, actually finding a shipwreck is the ultimate joy.

title: TAX EASEMENTS BRING A DECLINE IN ASSESSMENTS
description: Various tax benefits designed to encourage real-estate development in New York City have contributed heavily to a drop of nearly $900 million in property assessments from tentative figures set last winter.

title: Around the World; Hostages Are Freed In Gambia, Reports Say
description: The wife and four children of President Dawda Jawara were rescued today from Gambian rebels, sources close to the Government said.

title: DIVERGENT GOALS FOR THE DEREGULATORS
description: When a Federal Court of Appeals recently struck down New York and New Jersey state taxes on oil companies, it dramatized the mounting conflict between two cherished conservative principles: deregulation and states rights.

title: JUNTA TAKES CONTROL IN BOLIVIA
description: A three-man military junta has assumed control of the country, but the two rebel generals who forced the resignation last night of President Luis Garcia Meza are holding out for further negotiations.

title: TANGLEWOOD: ANTONIOU LEADS
description: Last night's Tanglewood Festival of Contemporary Music program ranged farther afield than had its predecessors. It seems that every summer Theodore Antoniou, the composer and conductor who is assistant director of the Berkshire Music Center's contemporary music activities, gets one program he can conduct himself. Whereas the festival as a whole concentrates on a rather dogged kind of chromaticism, Mr. Antoniou seems to favor the coloristic, theatrical avant-gardism that was fashionable 10 to 15 years ago.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MCI Proposal
description: The MCI Communications Corporation is proposing to increase its interest in N-Triple-C Inc., formerly the Nebraska Consolidated Communications Corporation, from 95 percent to 100 percent.

title: Misses Jaeger and Ruzici Gain
description: Top-seeded Andrea Jaeger, trailing by 2-3 in the first set, won 10 straight games to beat Renee Richards, 6-3, 6-0, moments before a rainstorm halted today's play at the United States Clay Court tennis championships.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 2-PERSON ENSEMBLE

title: BARRY BECK REMEMBERS
description: BARRY BECK remembers the bad times. He was not the captain of the Rangers then, but rather a 17-year-old in trouble with the law. ''It wasn't murder, it wasn't rape, it wasn't drugs,'' he says. ''It was stealing. I started when I was 13. I took things so I could have money to have a good time.''

title: ENERGY TRADING LIFTS VOLUME
description: After spending most of the summer in the doldrums, the stock market sprang to life yesterday, as merger fever in energy issues created the heaviest trading in seven weeks.

title: Evidence Goes to Grand Jury In Drownings of Three Men
description: A grand jury today received a 500-page transcript from a hearing by a board of inquiry into the drownings of three men while in police custody at a black festival in Mexia.

title: RICHARDSON-VICKS REFOCUSES CONSUMER MARKETING EFFORTS
description: Natural phenomena as diverse as a severe coughing season last winter and New England's infestation of gypsy moths this summer have helped Richardson-Vicks Inc. begin a new corporate life.

title: MUSIC: WASHINGTON SQUARE IS THE SETTING FOR A CONCERT
description: THERE was a time when Washington Square Park would have presented a sylvan and subdued setting for music - a time, no doubt, when a stroll during intermission would not have included offers for a variety of pharmaceutical intoxicants - but outdoor music can still offer a welcome respite from such bustle, and the audience, at any rate, seemed to enjoy the Washington Square Music Festival Orchestra on Tuesday night as it played just east of the park's central fountain, directed by Maria Tunicka.

title: TEXT OF AIR CONTROLLERS' OATH
description: Following is the text of the oath taken and signed by all air controllers upon assuming office, including the provision specifying that they may not strike: I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which I am about to enter, so help me God.

title: U.S. BACKS SYNTHETIC FUEL PLANTS
description: President Reagan, stepping in to resolve a bitter policy dispute within his Administration, gave his approval today for $3.1 billion in Government loan guarantees for two synthetic fuel plants to be built in Colorado and North Dakota.

title: THE CITY;
description: A Manhattan jury has awarded $725,000 to a 63-year-old Mount Vernon woman and her husband for injuries she said she suffered while riding on a bumpy street in a New York City bus.

title: ARGENTINA STRIDES INTO ATOM AGE WITHOUT U.S. AID
description: It could be a campus in the Rocky Mountains, with granite classroom buildings and charming faculty houses in an idyllic setting surrounded by snowcapped peaks.

title: PANEL ON VIOLENT CRIME URGES RELAXATION OF EVIDENCE RULES
description: A advisory panel recommended to the Reagan Administration yesterday that evidence in a criminal case illegally obtained by a police officer should be admitted in court if the officer was ''acting in the reasonable, good-faith belief that it was in conformity'' with the provisions of the Constitution on search and seizure.

title: STOPPING A-BOMBS
description: It has always been something of a mystery why the United States seems less interested than the Soviet Union in a total ban on nuclear testing. The United States, which has conducted about a thousand nuclear tests compared with about 600 by the Soviet Union, is acknowledged to be far ahead in nuclear warhead and weapons technology. Consequently it would lock in its advantage if all tests were stopped. If testing continues, sooner or later the Soviet Union will catch up to the United States.

title: Death After Arrest Attributed To a Lack of Oxygen to Brain
description: A black man's death that led to a protest in the black community here was caused by lack of oxygen to the brain, the medical examiner ruled yesterday.

title: Around the Nation; White Arrested in Miami In Riot Killing of Black
description: A 35-year-old cook was being held today on a first-degree murder charge, becoming the first white charged in any of the deaths in last year's race riots here.

title: 'HOTEL' FOR FISH ENJOYS A BOOM IN CONNETICUT
description: There are thousands of dog kennels, hundreds of boarding farms for horses and lots of neighbors to watch a dog, cat or canary. There are, however, few places to which a fish fancier can turn when vacation time rolls along. Hence, the Norwalk Aquarium Fish Hotel.

title: TRADE DEFICIT WIDENS ON A 'PAYMENTS' BASIS
description: Despite a reduced volume of oil imports, the nation's merchandise trade deficit grew to $6.99 billion in the second quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TWO ROADS TO ARMS REDUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; LITTON'S PRESIDENT ADDS ANOTHER TITLE
description: Fred W. O'Green, 60 years old, president of Litton Industries for the last nine years, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Charles B. Thornton, 68, who has headed the Beverly Hills, Calif., conglomerate since it was founded in 1953 and who will remain chairman.

title: MOTHERS RETURN TO JOB SOONER THAN THEY LIKE
description: By United Press International Pregnant women are likely to stay on the job until just before their babies are born and return within three months of the births although many would prefer more time off, a survey showed this week.

title: TRACES OF DRUG FOUND IN BODY OF A MOTORMAN
description: Traces of a chemical constituent of marijuana were found in the body of Jesse Cole, the subway motorman who died at the controls of a train in Brooklyn last month, the city's Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday.

title: Company Briefs
description: * Coca-Cola declared a regular quarterly dividend of 58 cents, payable Oct. 1.

title: BO DEREK AS JANE IN 'TARZAN THE APE MAN' 'Tarzan the Ape Man'
description: ''YOU'RE like something out of a museum,'' says Jane (Bo Derek) as she runs her fingers lightly up and down the length of the perfectly muscled, temporarily unconscious, near-naked form of Tarzan (Miles O'Keeffe), ''but you're real.'' Jane puts a finger prettily to her mouth, as is her wont when something as rare as a thought crosses her mind. ''I'm still a virgin. Are you?''

title: U.S. DISCLOSES SOVIET FLEET DATA
description: The Department of Defense, which refused earlier to disclose the number of Soviet ships on maneuvers in the Baltic Sea, relented today and said that 17 major combatants and 52 to 54 smaller amphibious ships were taking part.

title: Around the Nation; Ex-Miami Officer Jailed For Refusal for Testify
description: Eric Seyman, a former Dade County police officer, has been jailed for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury that is investigating the 1979 death by beating of Arthur McDuffie, a black Miami businessman, which ultimately led to the riots in Miami last year.

title: China Bank Branch
description: The Bank of China will open a branch in New York by the end of the year, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: NEW ZEALAND'S PLAN: REPROCESS U.S. BUTTER
description: Millions of tons of surplus American butter sold to New Zealand on Wednesday probably will not be used as a table spread because it is not good enough to eat that way, a New Zealand Government official said today.

title: A Long Career
description: When Mary Larkin decided to give up her job at the Mercer Rubber Company in Trenton, effective July 31, she was hardly acting precipitately.

title: CITICORP PLANS A BANK IN DELAWARE
description: Citicorp, the nation's biggest banking organization and one of the largest employers in New York City, announced yesterday that it had taken steps to establish a bank in Delaware where the tax rate averages 3 percent compared with a 26 percent rate for big New York banks.

title: Around the Nation; Penthouse Wins in Court Against Falwell Suit
description: A Federal district judge dismissed the Rev. Jerry A. Falwell's $50 million damage suit against Penthouse magazine today, ruling that the publication's First Amendment rights could not be restricted solely because Mr. Falwell disliked the magazine.

title: Shell Halts Atlantic Well
description: The Shell Oil Company has temporarily suspended offshore oil drilling in the Georges Bank because of problems in protecting its 1,400-foot-deep hole, a company spokesman, Norman Alstedter, said today.

title: Auto Output Is Reported
description: United States automobile production declined for the second consecutive week as some plants remained closed for model changeover, but total production was ahead of last year, according to industry reports released today.

title: Hartford Names Education Adviser
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill announced the selection of Dr. Jacquelyn A. Mattfeld, former president of Barnard College, as executive director of the privately financed Commission on Higher Education.

title: Events and Openings; Friday Films
description: HEAVY METAL, directed by Gerald Potterton, at the Tower East. BEATLEMANIA THE MOVIE, directed by Joseph Manduke, at the Ziegfeld and other theaters. TARZAN, THE APE MAN, directed by John Derek; starring Bo Derek, at Loews State 2, Showplace 1, N.Y. Twin 2, other theaters. FILMOBILE, O'Donohue Park, Seagirt Boulevard and Beach 17th Street, Far Rockaway, Queens, 9.

title: Credit Markets; 30-YEAR BONDS BRING 14.06%
description: The credit markets seem to have digested the Treasury's three-part, $8.5 billion financing with less difficulty than many analysts feared. Yesterday, for example, the Treasury sold $2 billion of 13 7/8 percent bonds due 2011 at a record average yield of 14.06 percent, or less than the 14.15 percent and higher predicted earlier in the week.

title: CONOCO DISCUSSES ITS FUTURE
description: Du Pont exercised an option yesterday to purchase 15.9 million new shares of Conoco stock directly from the oil company for $1.4 billion, and Conoco's chairman turned aside rumors that Conoco's big coal subsidiary would be sold off after the merger with Du Pont.

title: HAIG AIDE SAYS U.S. OPPOSES SHARING THE WEALTH
description: A high-ranking State Department official said today that the Reagan Administration opposed shifting billions of dollars from rich to poor nations pressing for a global economic bargain.

title: Emily Goodman Is Married To Peter D. Morgenstern
description: The marriage of Emily Susan Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Goodman of Fair Lawn, N.J., to Peter Daniel Morgenstern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Morgenstern of San Diego, took place in Wayne, N.J., yesterday.

title: SPONSORS OF RICH-POOR TALKS TRY TO BYPASS U.S. OBJECTIONS
description: The co-sponsors of the conference of rich and poor nations are hoping to circumvent United States objections to a formal agenda by sounding out participants before the meeting in October.

title: THE STAGE: 'SUPPORTING CAST' Supporting Cast'
description: GEORGE FURTH'S new play, ''The Supporting Cast,'' which opened last night at the Biltmore Theater in defiance of the traditional August theatrical doldrums, is the show-business equivalent of a beach book. It is a featherweight summer-theater comedy that wilts in the Broadway spotlight.

title: ?SUB Cards; BRIDGE; AUSTRALIA MAINTAINS FLOW OF QUALITY BOOKS ON GAME
description: The recent flow of excellent books from Australia shows no sign of abating. The latest addition, and a delightful one, is ''The Golden Years of Bridge,'' by John Griffiths. A minor misfortune is that he has almost duplicated, by accident, a title used here three months ago. More bothersome to the reader will be the inflation resulting from British publication: the cost is $9.95, paperbound, for 127 pages, or about 17 cents for each deal.

title: Roone Arledge Sr., 86, Dies; Ex-Counsel to Equitable Life
description: Roone Arledge Sr., former associate general counsel of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died last Saturday after an extended illness. He was 86 years old and a resident of Hendersonville.

title: TRYING TO ASSESS WHY MOBIL LOST THE BIDDING WAR
description: Du Pont won. Seagram got a nice consolation prize. But Mobil, despite a bid for Conoco Inc. that once topped its adversaries' by more than $1 billion, left the auction with little more than its reputation for being aggressive intact.

title: Economic Scene; POLICY IN U.S. AND BRITAIN
description: OPPONENTS of President Reagan's program take a quick look at Britain and smile. They believe that after two years the United States economy will have many of the characteristics of the current British economy -high unemployment and uncertain recovery, low investment, a large budget deficit and double-digit inflation. They believe, in short, that Reaganomics will produce Thatcheritis.

title: OWNERS APPROVE A PLAN TO SPLIT BASEBALL SEASON
description: The owners of major league baseball's 26 teams voted today to split the season into halves with second-half divisional play starting Monday. The vote came after the owners ratified the agreement reached last week that ended the seven-week strike by the players.

title: C.A.B. BACKS TEXAS AIR IN ITS BID FOR CONTINENTAL
description: Texas International Airlines won a round today in its fight to take over Continental Air Lines, as the Civil Aeronautics Board instructed its staff to draw up an order approving the proposed acquisition.

title: ORIGIN OF FLORIDA FRUIT FLIES IS UNDETERMINED
description: California entomologists said today that they were unable to determine the origin of three Mediterranean fruit flies that turned up in Florida two days ago, but anxious officials of that citrus-rich state renewed their efforts to ban California produce and moved quickly to eradicate the flies with ground and aerial spraying of the pesticide malathion.

title: Cherry Hill Antiques
description: A ''surprise'' auction of 200 lots of antiques and collectibles will be a highlight of the Fourth Cherry Hill Antiques Show and Sale this weekend at the Cherry Hill Hyatt on Route 70 in New Jersey.

title: Military Analysis
description: American intelligence analysts, modifying earlier public assessments, now say they believe that the Soviet military forces in Afghanistan are in serious trouble and that their predicament will worsen over the next six months.

title: Dome Selects Shipyard Designer
description: A.& P. Appledore Ltd., one of Britain's leading marine consultants, said that its Canadian subsidiary has won a $2 million contract to design a shipyard for the Calgary-based Dome Petroleum Ltd. for the construction of Arctic gas tankers.

title: Chaplin is subject of a second planned musical.
description: IDEAS for new Broadway musicals are running in packs. Several shows based on Dickens are in the works, and so are shows on comic books and baseball. The latest craze is Charlie Chaplin. A musical called ''Charlie Chaplin'' was announced last week, and now comes word of another, called simply ''Chaplin.'' Both shows are racing to open on Broadway next spring.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: I T was called, modestly enough, a Chinese Folk Art Festival, but the other evening it turned out to be a sprawling midsummer party that began in the tiny gallery of the China Institute on East 65th Street and spilled out onto the sidewalk and into the Cosmopolitan Club next door.

title: Around the Nation; T.V.A. Plans Slowdowns And Halts Reactor Work
description: The directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority cut back the nation's largest program of building nuclear power plants today, halting work on one reactor and slowing three. More than 6,000 workers are expected to lose their jobs.

title: COETZEE REGAINS HIS INTEREST IN BOXING
description: Gerrie Coetzee, who often talks to his opponents in the ring, quietly sparred three rounds with a beefy partner in a small boxing area in the White Plains Youth Services Center. Coetzee's eyes and mustache were nearly hidden under his brown head protector. The headgear, smeared with Vaseline to make his opponent's blows slip instead of sting, glowed dully in the overhead light. The only sounds were the shuffling of sneakers on canvas, the thwack of leather and the snorts common to boxers and bulls.

title: AIR FORCE DETAILS U.S. SECRETS CASE
description: The Air Force asserted today that Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke, who has been accused of unauthorized contacts with the Soviet Embassy here, had admitted ''that for approximately a year he had been photocopying, copying and giving to the Soviets secret and top secret information relating to the American strategic nuclear employment.''

title: JUSTICE AIDES SAY FIRST PHASE IS OVER
description: Justice Department officials said today that they had basically completed the first phase of their legal offensive against the air traffic controllers' union.

title: WORKOUTS IN STRIKE PAYING OFF FOR SCOTT
description: Mike Scott, who has earned the starting pitching assignment for the Mets' second opening day of the season, knows that it's not quite the same as being named for the real opener in April. ''But,'' he said at the team's Shea Stadium workout yesterday, ''I'm glad to be the one starting. It says something.''

title: LET'S WATCH THE PREACHERS OF AUSTERITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Air New Zealand Credit
description: Air New Zealand has reached agreement for $218 million in credit to finance the purchase of three Boeing 747-219B aircraft, the agent bank, International Westminster Bank Ltd., said today.

title: CONNECTICUT BLAMES NEW YORK FOR ITS AIR POLLUTION
description: There is nothing wrong with Connecticut's air, say state officials, even if it was declared ''unhealthful'' or ''very unhealthful'' 50 times last summer. The dirt, they say, comes from New York.

title: Foreign Affairs; 'UNJUST, USELESS AND SHAMEFUL'
description: The lull in Middle East fighting and some delicate political shifts have created a moment when an act of will could bring a new breakthrough.

title: U.S TO SELECT FIRST TRAINEES FOR CONTROLLER
description: Officials at the Federal Aviation Administration's training academy said here today that they expected the first candidates in their new, more ambitious program for civilian air traffic controllers to be selected shortly from a Civil Service eligibility list of 7,500 people and to be sent here this month.

title: BRITISH AIDE UNVEILS PLAN TO HELP RIOT-TORN LIVERPOOL SLUMS
description: After spending two weeks studying conditions in the riot-torn slums of Liverpool, Environment Secretary Michael Heseltine yesterday unveiled a program designed to create new jobs there and to improve housing and other community facilities.

title: Girl, 10, Is Stabbed to Death; In Home While Mother Is Out
description: A 10-year-old girl was stabbed to death in her Bronx apartment last night when her mother left her alone for a few hours, the police said.

title: POP: TAYLOR FAMILY QUINTET
description: EVERYONE must know by now that James Taylor, the well-known singersongwriter, is the most successful member of a talented musical family. Mr. Taylor's brothers Alex and Livingston and his sister Kate also recorded on and off in the 1970's; only brother Hugh hasn't made a solo album. On Wednesday, all five joined to make their first public appearance together, at a three-hour benefit concert for the restoration and maintenance of the South Street Seaport's historic ships.

title: Interest Rates Soar in Canada
description: Canadian interest rates soared to record levels today as the sluggish Canadian dollar remained near its lowest level in 50 years.

title: POLITICS OF OIL
description: Any organization of suppliers or manufacturers that wants to raise prices and keep them up must be able to control its members' market actions. Once the members have agreed on a strategy, such as raising prices 10 percent, the group must be able to penalize those members who raise their prices only, say, 5 percent. This is the true test of whether such an organization has attained the status of a cartel, a much-abused word.

title: VOLUME STILL STRONG AS DOW SLIPS 0.67
description: Wall Street's search for the possible next big takeover target among energy companies sent oil and mining stocks higher yesterday. But the Dow Jones industrial average, after advancing 7.61 points Wednesday, edged off 0.67, to 952.91. For the overall market, winners outnumbered losers by nearly 4-to-3.

title: MINORITIES AND CITY SIGN ACCORD ON POLICE HIRING
description: An agreement creating a lottery system to select the city's next class of police officers was signed yesterday by the Koch administration and black and Hispanic groups.

title: Colonial Penn To Seek Layoffs
description: The Colonial Penn Group Inc., one of the nation's biggest insurors, said it would seek the voluntary layoff of 250 employees as part of an attempt to trim its staff by another 25 percent by mid-1982.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: Owners ap- p roved the sale of the Chicago Cubs to the C hicago Tribune Co. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Optioned Luis S anchez, right-handed pitcher, to Salt L ake City of Pacific Coast League.

title: Watt Opposes Stock Limits
description: Amid growing hostility to Canadian takeovers of United States companies, Interior Secretary James G. Watt today expressed reluctance about proposals that revoke the right of Canadians to own stock in corporations that have mineral leases on Federal lands in the United States.

title: OFFICIAL'S DAUGHTER, HURT IN ABDUCTION, GETS 24-HOUR GUARD
description: A 24-hour guard was placed outside the hospital room of the daughter of the Staten Island District Attorney yesterday after a telephone call was placed to her room from a man claiming to be her former husband, the police said.

title: Shell to Buy Japanese Steel
description: The Shell Oil Company has sent letters of intent to four Japanese steel mills to buy 170,000 tons of large-diameter 30-inch steel pipe for a United States gas pipeline project, according to industry sources in Tokyo.

title: Heavy Storms Hit Britain
description: Violent thunderstorms swept across Britain today, setting off widespread flooding but bringing some relief from the hottest weather of the summer. In Manchester, where 3 1/2 inches of rain fell in 24 hours, a landslide damaged a major suburban highway. In London flooding shorted out sections of the subway system, and operations at Heathrow Airport were disrupted.

title: EXCHANGING STANDARD CAREERS FOR DREAMS
description: Ina Garten's parents weren't at all happy. Their daughter, with a prestigious White House job, was resigning to open a grocery store. ''A grocery store!'' they chorused in bewilderment. ''Why?'' Why indeed? ''My job in Washington was intellectually exciting and stimulating but it wasn't me at all,'' said Mrs. Garten. Barry Wine's parents had a similar reaction when he gave up tailored suits for a white coat. ''They were appalled at their son, the lawyer, going to become a cook,'' he said. Trading In Prestige

title: RAY C. BLISS DIES IN OHIO AT 73, REBUILT G.O.P. AFTER 1964 ROUT
description: Ray C. Bliss, the former national chairman of the Republican Party who rebuilt it in the mid-1960's and helped elect President Nixon, died yesterday in Akron, Ohio, apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

title: Friday; WINE THROUGH A LENS
description: ''From Vines to Wines'' is the new photography exhibition opening today at the French Institute, 22 East 60th Street. The 51 black-andwhite and color pictures on view are the work of Peter Aaron, film maker and photographer. Mr. Aaron took his camera to the Bordeaux wine-growing region of France, where he photographed ''vignerons'' in the cellars of some of the most famous chateaus - Latour, Haut-Brion, Mouton-Rothschild. ''From Vines to Wines'' will be on display through Sept. 25. No admission charge. Hours: 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday through Friday. Information: 355-6100. PHILHARMONIC ROLLS ON

title: Seeds of Lawlessness
description: One recent morning a friend found herself sitting toe-to-toe in the subway with two young women eating a breakfast of sunflower seeds and spitting the shells on the floor and her toes. She denounced their behavior as unsanitary and unwelcome and was, of course, summarily told where she might get off -which she did at the next stop.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE world's three largest art-auction houses registered their highest sales ever this season, with dramatic increases at Sotheby Parke Bernet, moderate ones at Christie's and modest ones at Phillips, Son & Neale. In the process, the combined sales of Sotheby's and Christie's, New York's two major art-auction houses, eclipsed those of their London galleries.

title: Around the World; Adamson Murder Trial Hears Advisory Verdicts
description: Three assessors delivered a split verdict today at the murder trial of Paul Nakwale Ekai, a Turkana tribesman accused of stabbing the conservationist Joy Adamson to death.

title: Baseball Notebook Thomas, Garvey Named to Star Squads
description: Gorman Thomas of the Milwaukee Brewers, who leads the major leagues with 15 home runs, and Steve Garvey of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who for the first time in eight years will not be a starter, were among the two dozen players named as reserves yesterday for baseball's All-Star Game Sunday in Cleveland.

title: Eastern cuisine worth a trip west.
description: ''VERY good - considering it's near Lincoln Center'' has until now been the standard qualification for any halfway decent restaurant in the West 60's. But at last a ''very good'' without any qualifications is in order, for Shun Lee West, which opened just a little more than two months ago and is turning out more than enough delicious and savory Chinese food to make it worth a journey for its own sake, never mind about tickets to a musical event across the way.

title: Bell Policy Is Defended
description: The Reagan Administration today defended its new policy against breaking up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, saying international competition and national security were more important than antitrust considerations.

title: SAMUEL LIEBERMAN, 69, PROFESSOR OF LANGUAGES
description: Dr. Samuel Lieberman, professor emeritus of classical and Oriental languages at Queens College, died Wednesday at Triboro Hospital in Queens after a long illness. He was 69 years old and a resident of Bayside, Queens.

title: ART: A NICE, QUIET TIME FOR OLD-MASTER PRINTS
