description: August is in general a dozy time in the galleries, but through Aug. 21 we can see, Monday through Friday, the 20th annual ''Old Master Print Collection'' at the A.A.A. Galleries, 663 Fifth Avenue, at 53d Street. This is in essence a personal miscellany in which the concentrations lie heaviest in the 16th and 17th centuries and there is a nice balance between the names that everyone knows - Durer, Mantegna, Rembrandt, Jacques Callot, Canaletto - and the names that almost nobody knows. Nor is it always the case that the big-name, big-money pieces are the ones that we most want to take home.

title: Catskills Polka Festival
description: More than 40 polka bands from around the country will play through Aug. 16 at the fifth National Polka Festival in the Catskills at the Hunter Mountain Ski Slope, Route 23A in Hunter, N.Y. Participants can dance, enter song-and-dance competitions or watch Polish artisans weave wall hangings or carve wooden boxes. There will be free dancing lessons and demonstrations in the Ukrainian art of egg coloring.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Nicholas Maiale has been appointed senior vice president at Medicus Intercon, a subsidiary of Benton & Bowles.

title: Around the Nation; Autopsies of Teen-Agers Find No Trace of Drugs
description: No trace of marijuana has been found in autopsies on Carl Baker, 19 years old, and Anathony Freeman, 18, two of three black youths who drowned while in the custody of law enforcement officers. The autopsy report on Steven Booker, 19, has not been completed, the Dallas Medical Examiner's ofice said.

title: In the Nation; HE WHO LIVES BY THE SWORD
description: As chairman of the Agriculture Committee, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina has been a relentless foe of the food stamp program - not because he likes to hear old folks' stomachs growl with hunger, you understand, but to eliminate fraud, waste and graft.

title: U.S. SAYS GOAL NOW IS TO RECONSTRUCT AIR CONTROL FORCE
description: The Reagan Administration, dispatching dismissal notices to more of the 12,000 striking air traffic controllers, turned its emphasis today to ''rebuilding the system'' with accelerated training of recruits and better use of those available to work.

title: WATER POWER BEING REDISCOVERED
description: In scorn, they called it ''Clinton's Ditch'' when New York's Governor De Witt Clinton decided to construct it in the early 19th century. But the Erie Canal paid for itself within eight years of its completion, and state officials now hope to keep it productive by harnessing its water power to produce electricity.

title: A WALKING TOUR OF EARLIEST NEW YORK
description: Weekdays, New York City's financial district bustles with activity. Its streets are rivers of rushing humanity; its air is thick with the sounds of traffic. The bustle may approximate the climate of life of an earlier era, but in the hubbub the district's historical secrets and architectural jewels can easily go unheeded. On Sunday, however, New Yorkers will have a chance to walk into the past when the Museum of the City of New York presents ''The World of Wall Street: Tycoons and Tickertape,'' a walking tour down Broadway from City Hall. (The tour starts at 2 P.M., rain or shine, with tickets at $3 for museum members, $5 for nonmembers. Information: 534-1672.)

title: AN OUTDOOR-SCULPTURE SAFARI AROUND NEW
description: YORK By GRACE GLUECK

title: BIG BLUEGRASS PLAYOFFS AT SOUTH STREET SEAPORT
description: THE ninth annual New York City Bluegrass Band Contest, which will be held tomorrow and Sunday at the South Street Seaport Museum, will feature some of the finest semiprofessional bluegrass bands from the Northeast. Since it was started in 1973, the contest has steadily grown in size. Originally, eight local bands competed. Last year, 20 bands appeared, and annual attendance for the two nights has increased from the hundreds to nearly 2,000.

title: PUBLISHING: GAY TALESE ON THY NEIGHBOR'S CAR
description: FOR the last year and a half, Gay Talese has been visiting automobile showrooms across the country, attending auto dealer conventions, getting to know members of the United Auto Workers and hanging out with Lee Iacocca, chairman of the board of the Chrysler Corporation. Not surprisingly, the author of books on The New York Times, the Mafia and sexual mores plans to write his next book on the American automobile industry.

title: THE UPHILL BATTLE OF A BRITISH ALTERNATIVE TO TORIES AND LABORITES
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; Uihlein Family Studies Competing Schlitz Bids
description: The two rival offers to acquire the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, made by the G. Heileman Brewing Company and the Pabst Brewing Company have focused the investment community's attention on the company whose beer made Milwaukee famous.

title: TREVINO IS OUSTED IN SCORECARD MIXUP
description: The big names like Jack Nicklaus, Tom Watson and Lee Trevino did not fare well today in the opening round of the 63d Professional Golfers' Association Championship. But Trevino took the worst setback of all; after shooting a 74, four over par for the Atlanta Athletic Club course, he was disqualified for failing to sign his scorecard.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO DROP OFFICE SITE POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration is planning to scrap President Carter's August 1978 executive order requiring that centercity locations be given priority as sites for Federal agencies.

title: Reading Agrees To Settlement
description: The Reading Company said it had agreed to a Government settlement that provides $121 million for railroad properties transferred to Conrail and others in 1976. Included in the settlement was 8 percent interest on the principal amount compounded annually from April 1, 1976, Reading officials said.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. DEFERS ACTION TO BACK UP AIR CONTROLLERS
description: Leaders of the American labor movement adjourned their summer conference today without taking any strong action to support the striking air traffic controllers.

title: CORADINO D'ASCANIO, DESIGNED VESPA SCOOTER
description: Corradino D'Ascanio, an early designer of helicopters and of the Vespa motor scooter, died today, his family reported. He was 90 years old.

title: REAGAN BIDS FED TO EASE RESTRAINTS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Federal Reserve Board would have to ease up on monetary restraint to avoid a severe recession.

title: SOVIET IS SAID TO REJECT U.S. OFFER OF AFGHAN TALKS
description: The Soviet Union has recently rebuffed several efforts by the Reagan Administation to start secret discussions on a possible political settlement of the fighting in Afghanistan, according to State Department officials.

title: FUEL SHORTAGE AFFLICTS LEBANESE
description: Lebanon, relieved of fighting between Israeli and Palestinian forces, is in the grip of an acute fuel shortage that has played havoc with daily life and has threatened to cripple its already burdened economy.

title: Energy Watch
description: JULY 31, 1981 Crude oil supplies jumped to 393.6 million barrels.

title: PRETORIA FIRM ON BANNING CAPE TOWN SQUATTERS
description: Every night evicted blacks, mainly women and children, huddle together on bare, windswept ground where they have been forbidden to erect shelters.

title: DONOVAN INFLUENCE SEEN AID IN ACCORD
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan was discussing his second baseball assignment in the last few weeks - throwing out the ceremonial first ball at Yankee Stadium Monday night before the Yankees' game with the Texas Rangers.

title: SWEDES TAKE AIM AT HAMBLETONIAN
description: Sorin Nordin is 63 years old, rich from the proceeds of Swedish racing and living now in Florida. He wants very much to win a slice of Americana called the Hambletonian Trot, to be held at the Meadowlands Saturday. So do Hakan Wallner, Erik Engstrom, Pieter Ahl and Ulf Moberg.

title: Potential Trouble Spots For Summer Traffic
description: A. Palisades Interstate Parkway: Guide rail installation will cause intermittent lane closings just north of New York State Thruway.

title: Free Concert in Bronx
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble will play a free concert Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Van Cortlandt Mansion in Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway and 246th Street, in the Bronx. Robert Rogers will conduct the ensemble in Haydn's Octet in F major, John Freeman's Fantasy on a Theme of William Mayer for woodwind quintet and Gounod's Petite Symphonie in B flat. Information: 549-1899.

title: Executive Changes
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Kenneth A. Yarnell executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, AUGUST 7, 1981
description: Controllers' Strike The dismissal of all controllers taking part in the illegal four-day strike was proceeding as the Reagan Administration shifted its emphasis to training new recruits and ''rebuilding the system'' with a virtually entire new staff. The Administration said that the 12,000 strikers who had defied an ultimatum to return to work or forfeit their jobs would soon be off the payroll, except for a few with valid excuses. The Government also reported that air traffic continued to rise, reaching 79 percent of the 14,200 normal daily flights. (Page A1, Column 6.) Preparations to train new controllers were being made at the Government's academy in Oklahoma City. Officials said they were prepared to triple the nation's output of flight controllers to 5,500 or more a year. (A1:5.)

title: DONAL DONNELLY AND SHAW'S ASTONISHING SELVES
description: George Bernard Shaw - critic, playwright, political orator and social reformer - was many men in one, and Donal Donnelly is a oneman Shaw.

title: News Analysis
description: Although he has promised to make improved municipal services the hallmark of his second term, Mayor Koch has shied away from giving details about how he intends to achieve his goal if he is re-elected.

title: BROOKLYN LANDLORD CHARGED WITH HARASSING OF TENANTS
description: A landlord and his three sons were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court on charges of harassing, threatening and terrorizing their tenants and trying to murder a tenant's lawyer.

title: SERVED IN MID-70'S
description: Stanley M. Makowski, a one-time grain-mill worker who became Mayor of Buffalo, died yesterday in Deaconess Hospital here following exploratory surgery for a respiratory illness. He was 58 years old.

title: EFFECTIVENESS OF GUARDIAN ANGELS CALLED UNCERTAIN
description: It was a proud night for 61 young Philadelphians. Dressed in red berets, white T-shirts, camouflage trousers and black boots, they received their graduation certificates, and as their leader spoke their bosoms swelled under the emblem of the Guardian Angels, a winged, watchful eye.

title: POST-CONOCO GUESSING GAME
description: The current takeover favorite is Cities Service. Its shares surged 2 1/2 points on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. But the Marathon Oil Company, with that big West Texas oil field, looks awfully enticing. And how about Union Oil of California, which is swollen with natural gas? It's probably too big to swallow, but who knows? After Conoco, anything is possible.

title: BEFORE WE INVITE 'GUEST WORKERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Filly Draws $1.2 Million At Saratoga Auction
description: A chestnut filly by The Minstrel was sold for $1.2 million, a record for a filly, tonight in the third session of the Fasig-Tipton yearling sales.

title: IRAQ'S RISK IN ITS WAR
description: .6,0,266.8,2,266.8,0NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. - The outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war last September has increased the potential for sectarian strife between the country's Shiite majority in the south and the Sunni-dominated central Government in Baghdad. So far, such strife has not materialized. Nevertheless, the war has not gone well, and its continuation with indeterminate results is increasing opposition to the regime of President Saddam Hussein.

title: 3D BANK ENTERS BID IN HARTFORD
description: Connecticut's largest bank holding company has entered the bidding war for Connecticut National Bank, although two other competitors say the possible merger could face antitrust obstacles.

title: David Rockefeller Announces Creation of Americas Society
description: David Rockefeller, former chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, has announced the formation of the Americas Society, an organization designed to provide a ''focal point of contact'' for other institutions working in Western Hemisphere affairs.

title: Marketing, an imprecise tool.
description: MARKETING movies is not yet - and will probably never be - a science. Despite immense amounts of research aimed at identifying the prospective audience for a film, studios often discover that audiences do not behave predictably. On ''The Four Seasons,'' Universal got a pleasant surprise. On ''Endless Love,'' the surprise was less pleasant.

title: REAGAN'S STYLE: FOCUSING ON 'THE BIG PICTURE'
description: Only two weeks ago today, President Reagan's historic tax-cutting legislation was still being shaped at a White House negotiating session with key allies in Congress. As various options came up for discussion, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who was presiding, yielded on some items and rejected others.

title: JETS SEEK ANSWERS TO MANY QUESTIONS
description: Some day the Jets may start their exhibition season without half a dozen nagging questions. But not tomorrow night, when they face the Broncos in Mile High Stadium.

title: MAYOR RELIVES A FRIGHT TO SHOW CHOKING CURE
description: Dr. Henry J. Heimlich, the developer of a maneuver to aid choking victims, joined Mayor Koch in the Blue Room of City Hall yesterday to lend support to the effort to teach the method in the city's schools.

title: SADAT ASSURED OVER U.S. ROLE IN THE MIDEAST
description: President Reagan concluded two days of talks with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt today by assuring him of an active American role in future Middle East diplomacy but refraining from agreeing to a specific course.

title: Dynamics Net Off in Quarter
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's biggest defense contractor, announced yesterday that its second-quarter profits fell 56.3 percent and its sales gained 8.3 percent from the same period last year.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, AUGUST 7, 1981; Companies
description: Du Pont's takeover of Conoco has touched off speculation on Wall Street that other large oil companies might be next. The current favorite is Cities Service, with Marathon Oil and Union Oil of California close behind. (D1.) Du Pont will not sell Conoco's big coal subsidiary in return for Seagram's holdings in Du Pont, as some experts had suggested, Conoco's chairman, Ralph E. Bailey said. (D1.)

title: DIVORCE AND MILITARY PENSIONS
description: In 1945, Elizabeth D. Crandall married a lieutenant in the United States Navy. Twenty-four years and some 17 cross-country moves later, her husband left her. Today, seven years after a no-fault divorce, her former husband, now retired, is refusing to pay the alimony stipulated in the divorce settlement, his wife says. She says his stand is based on the recent Supreme Court ruling that military pension benefits may not become a part of a property settlement in a divorce.

title: CITY HALTS TALKS WITH HELMSLEY ON ARMY DEPOT
description: The city has suspended negotiations with Helmsley-Spear Inc., the developers, for the lease for the former Brooklyn Army Terminal. Kenneth S. Schuman, Commissioner for Economic Development, said yesterday that the city had decided to halt the talks when it learned that Harry B. Helmsley was concluding the sale of the Gair Buildings - two million square feet of Brooklyn waterfront property now used for light manufacturing.

title: Funds' Assets Up $2.6 Billion
description: The assets of the nation's 129 largest money funds rose $2.6 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 10th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: 2 Holes-in-One Scored By Golfer at L.I. Club
description: William D'Avanzo of Mineola scored two holes-in-one at St. George's Golf and Country Club today.

title: Canadian Sale by Rank
description: The Rank Organisation Ltd. said today that its Canadian subsidiary, Rank City Wall Canada Ltd., had accepted a cash offer of $110 million (Canadian) for its Sheppard Centre property development in Toronto. Completion of the sale is expected by Oct. 31, Rank said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As far as I'm concerned it's a nonstrike situation. It's over.

title: Stockman Finds Government 'Undernourished' by Reagan
description: David A. Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that as a result of President Reagan's policies ''the U.S. Government is going to be severely undernourished for the forseeable future.''

title: Business People; Gasification Loan Pleases Executive
description: Arthur R. Seder Jr., the 61-year-old chairman and president of the American Natural Resources Company of Detroit, says that he is a happy man. It is no wonder, since his corporation is the operator for the Great Plains Gasification Project in Beulah, N.D., a synthetic fuel plant sponsored by four companies that received a $2 billion loan guarantee from President Reagan on Wednesday. The documents were formally signed yesterday in Washington by Mr. Seder and Dr. James B. Edwards, the Secretary of Energy.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news item in Metropolitan Report on July 31 incorrectly reported the position of Alan Wiener. Until his resignation on June 19, Mr. Wiener was manager of the New York area office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Joseph D. Monticciolo, who was named regional administrator of H.U.D., filled a vacant position.

title: WHAT GOOD IS A YELLOW FIRE ENGINE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Strauss May Seek Presidential Nomination
description: As a politician he's done just about everything except run for office, and now, after years on the sidelines, Robert S. Strauss, the 63-year-old former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is under pressure to do just that - as a candidate for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: British Auto Output Up
description: British car production in July is estimated to have risen sharply to a seasonally adjusted monthly average of 105,000, from 80,000 the previous month and 101,000 in July 1980, the Department of Industry said today. Output of 534,000 vehicles in the first seven months of 1981, however, was 11.7 percent below the 605,000 in the same period last year, the department said.

title: POLISH TALKS ON UNREST INCONCLUSIVE
description: Talks between the Polish Government and the independent trade union Solidarity over the worsening political situation ended early today on an inconclusive note.

title: MIRIAM LEHMANN-HAUPT
description: Miriam Lehmann-Haupt, an actress who performed in Europe and the United States, died Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness.

title: WITH BEAUX ARTS TRIO, THE KEY WORD IS MUTUAL
description: ''There is the joy of a mutual success, but there is also solace in a mutual failure,'' says Menahem Pressler about his 26 years of sharing with the Beaux Arts Trio. Mr. Press-ler, an eminent pianist, will join his colleagues, Isidore Cohen, violinist, and Bernard Greenhouse, cellist, at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., this evening at 9 in a continuation of this long-running musical marriage. The music will be Beethoven's Triple Concerto, providing the three a rare opportunity to maintain their identity as a trio and still enter into the larger community of a symphony orchestra. The orchestra, of course, is the Boston Symphony. Kurt Masur will conduct both the concerto and the ''Eroica'' Symphony in this all-Beethoven evening.

title: Around the Nation; Virginia and U.S. in Pact On Revised Districting
description: Virginia officials reached tentative agreement with the Justice Department today on a revised redistricting of the state's House of Delegates to meet the department's objections that the plan would have diluted black voting strength.

title: ASIAN MUSICIANS SERVE UP A BLEND OF EAST AND
description: WEST By ROBERT PALMER

title: Adverising; Corporate Design Magazine
description: SOON after Interior Design magazine began selling on newsstands three years ago, its office began getting back subscription blanks from corporate chief executives. Since the publication was specifically and historically only for the profession, this really perked the interest of Lester Dundes, long-time publisher.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani CONVERSATIONS WITH KATHERINE ANNE PORTER. Refugee From Indian Creek. By Enrique Hank Lopez. Little, Brown. 326 pages. $14.95.

title: LINEBACKER'S DEBUT IS EAGERLY AWAITED
description: For Giant fans, it may rank in history with the Wright brothers' first flight or Reggie Jackson's first swing of a bat or Brooke Shields's first screen kiss. Lawrence Taylor, the rookie linebacker from North Carolina, will play his first professional football game Saturday night.

title: Oilers Beat Eagles, 13-10
description: The Houston Oilers, a team with a new coach and a new starting quarterback, relied on two old reliables - Earl Campbell and Toni Fritsch - and defeated the Philadelphia Eagles, 13-10 tonight in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: Iranians in Protest Face Deportation
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Deportation proceedings were begun yesterday against 60 Iranian hunger strikers arrested at an Englewood apartment for failing to identify themselves to Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service officials.

title: WHITHER OUR CORPORATE GIANTS?
description: To the Editor:

title: TOTAL FOR BUSES FALLS
description: The number of reported crimes in New York City subways rose 20 percent in the first six months of this year from the corresponding period last year, according to statistics released yesterday by the transit police.

title: BELL URGES SHIFT IN EDUCATION DEPT.
description: Education Secretary T.H. Bell has recommended to the White House that his one-year-old department be stripped of Cabinet status and turned into a foundation, Reagan Administration sources said today.

title: A Chance to Recoup in Bolivia
description: It is peculiarly appropriate that Bolivia celebrated its Independence Day yesterday in the throes of yet another coup. In the 156 years since it won freedom from Spain, Bolivia has averaged one governmental change every 10 months, most of them unscheduled. But despite the parade of comic-opera generals, Bolivia's politics deserve to be taken seriously. They are sensitive to foreign concern, and are bound to have some effect on friendly democratic regimes in neighboring Peru and Ecuador.

title: ACCORD IN CANADIAN POSTAL STRIKE
description: Alan Gold, a federal mediator, announced tonight that a tentative agreement had been reached in the 38-day-old Canadian postal strike.

title: Sports of The Times; Strolling Down Cauliflower Lane
description: ROBERTO DURAN, who used to be the best lightweight fist fighter since Ike Williams, is a gentleman of substance today, plump and prosperous and interested in world affairs. Recently he took a day off from the gym to mourn his friend and benefactor, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, but the chances are he will make 154 pounds in time to box his friend and idolater, Nino Gonzalez, in Cleveland Sunday.

title: Advertising; Thomson Press Adds CES Publishing
description: International Thomson Business Press, Radnor, Pa., owned by the International Thomson Organization in Toronto, has struck again.

title: ECCENTRICS: A TEXTURE LONG LOST
description: In the small Maine town where I spent years of growing and observing, we had at least a dozen characters who nowadays, in a larger setting, would be certified as insane or be thrown to the untender mercies of judges, psychiatrists and social workers.

title: Business People; New President Named At Jordache Subsidiary
description: Stanley Schwarz, 41, has been named to the new post of president of Jordache Licensee Promotions Ltd. The new unit, a subsidiary of Jordache Jeans Inc., will be responsible for the 32 apparel and accessory licensees of the Jordache label and its horsehead symbol.

title: No Headline
description: JEFFREY GLICK has never met Wilfrid V. Worland or A.G. van Metre. He has, in fact, never heard of them, nor they of him. It would therefore astonish those two gentlemen to learn that they have influenced the form and appearance of the low-rise housing development that Mr. Glick is building in the Bayside section of Queens, the largest low-rise project to be built in the city in many years.

title: BOOKS: MISSISSIPPI DELTA MUSIC
description: By Peter Guralnick DEEP BLUES. By Robert Palmer. 310 pages. The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: Advertising; Educational Television Programming Growing
description: On Sept. 26 the American Educational Television Network will for the first time be offering its programming fare to the nation via 52 TV broadcast stations and 300 cable systems with a potential reach of over 47 million households.

title: BEYOND CONCERN FOR THE BOG TURTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen I. Goldstein Wed To Gary J. Wasserson
description: Ellen Iris Goldstein, daughter of Judge and Mrs. M. Robert Goldstein of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Gary Joel Wasserson, son of Edward Wasserson of Philadelphia and Sara Billet of Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Freelander officiated at the Glen Head (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Linguistic Humility
description: ''Don't worry, they all speak English'' is the sentence with which most native-born Americans are sent abroad. Raised in a smaller, less powerful country, one might feel impelled to learn other languages. Raised in the United States, one assumes that ours is a universally accepted form of Esperanto.

title: NEW GAME SHOW, BELFAST AND ROCK
description: ANYONE not spending this weekend in search of the perfect wave or in search of the perfect rerun might do well to watch ''The Krypton Factor'' tonight at 8:30 on WABC-TV, television's first and only futuristic game show. ''The Krypton Factor'' is now a five-part pilot, but it may become a series if the audience-popularity ratings are right. They ought to be. The idea for the program is so preposterous, it's irresistible.

title: Around the World; Soviet Accuses the U.S.  At Law of Sea Talks
description: The Soviet Union accused the United States today of undermining negotiations for an international law of the sea treaty and then raised its own objections to parts of the proposal.

title: YANKEES QUESTION NEW PLAYOFF PLAN
description: As if there was not already enough to make life difficult for the manager of the Yankees, now there are the conditions for what remains of the 1981 season.

title: The Mineral Problem Is Not a Crisis
description: Fact: America imports more than half its supply of some 20 strategically important minerals.

title: GERALDINE PAGE REVIEWS A STAGE RARITY AT ADELPHI
description: ''I read this play so long ago, but it stuck in my mind, and when we @couldn't do nine-tenths of the plays we thought of, it sort of popped up -bong! - in my head.''

title: 'HEAVY METAL,' ADULT CARTOON
description: ''HEAVY METAL'' is bound to seem a big success to fans of the magazine on which it is based. Indeed, for anyone who doesn't think an hour and a half is a long time to spend with a comic book, ''Heavy Metal'' is impressive. Though it owes some slight bit of its toughness and nihilism to Ralph Bakshi, this animated feature is off on its own track, combining science fiction, mysticism, sex, violence and rock music. Much of the time, these elements do what the film makers want them to, and make for a heady mix.

title: FINES FOR TRANSIT STRIKE IN 1980 ARE STILL ON APPEAL
description: Heavy fines imposed on two labor unions involved in New York City's 11-day transit strike last year are still being appealed. As a result, the fines have not been paid, even though more than 16 months have elapsed since the walkout that paralyzed public transportation.

title: Market Place; Seagram Role In Du Pont
description: In 1802, a year before the Lousiana Purchase, E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company was established in Delaware's Brandywine Valley as the nation's first producer of explosive black powder. For more than a century, it was America's largest explosives manufacturer.

title: STAR EMPLOYEES PUT LAST ISSUE TO BED
description: First, the banner headline on the drawing board at The Washington Star read simply ''Goodbye.'' But that seemed too casual.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/ Edward Hausner Youths Work to Insulate Buildings Edwin Rodriguez, a member of the Youth Energy Corps, installing a storm window in an apartment building at 2076 Creston Avenue in the Bronx. The corps is employing 108 teen-agers this summer in Harlem, the Lower East Side and the Bronx. Page B3.

title: BLOSSOM DEARIE RETURNS IN A DUO
description: BLOSSOM DEARIE and Dave Frishberg are pianists, singers and songwriters. They sing each other's songs and, they say, they have the same audience. They once played on the same bill at the Great American Music Hall in San Francisco.

title: DEFENSE ROLE LAGS FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The opening of the launching complex at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California for the military space shuttle has been delayed more than a year, to October 1985, because of a shortage of civilian engineers, the Air Force said today.

title: Profit Up 26.1% At Lear Siegler
description: Lear Siegler Inc., a manufacturer of electronic, industrial and agricultural products, announced yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter ended June 30 rose 26.1 percent on a sales gain of 11.8 percent. It said that both sales and earnings were the highest in the company's history.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Ask Computer Systems Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 1.35 million common shares, to be sold through an L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin group.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: That'll Be 10, Please, Plus a Small Extra Charge

title: QUICKLY AND QUIETLY, MITTERRAND CHANGES FRANCE
description: The new Socialist Government of Francois Mitterrand has decreed and set in motion more economic and political change in France in the last two months than its predecessors of the right managed in the 23 years since the creation of the Fifth Republic.

title: Japan Solar Power Unit
description: The Electric Power Development Company of Japan was reported today to have succeeded for the first time in generating 1,000 kilowatts of electricity with a solar energy power plant.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SLIPPAGE IN THE NUMBER OF TRAVELERS EASES AIRLINE SCHEDULING PROBLEMS
description: At 2 o'clock on an ordinary weekday afternoon, the lobby of Houston's William P. Hobby Airport would be jammed with people. Many, fresh from business lunches, would be lined up six or seven deep at Southwest Airlines' five ticket positions, catching flights to Dallas, San Antonio, Austin or other Texas cities.

title: NEW UNLIMITED MARITAL DEDUCTION CHANGES ESTATE AND GIFT PLANNING
description: Of all the tax cuts provided in the new tax law, among the most generous are the new rules governing estates and gifts, which will save some people millions of tax dollars. And probably the most significant alteration in the estate tax is the provision - effective in 1982 -that will allow individuals to leave everything to a spouse completely tax-free.

title: JUDGE ASKS A BUSING LOTTERY
description: A lottery system for assigning students has been proposed by a Federal district judge to desegregate the South Park Independent School District here.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 7, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: R.J. REYNOLDS AD FORMAT TO SPONSOR NEWSPAPER SPORTS DATA
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's largest cigarette manufacturer and the country's largest newspaper advertiser, has proposed a new advertising format in which Camel cigarettes would, in effect, sponsor the tables of sports results most papers publish on Mondays.

title: Fire Routs Miami Guests
description: A fire in a 10-story Holiday Inn trapped a dozen guests on top-floor balconies early today, but firefighters led them to safety. At least two persons were taken to hospitals for treatment of smoke inhalation.

title: L.I. LOCAL ACTS TO BOLSTER SUPPORT
description: The union local representing air traffic controllers who normally work at the New York Air Route Control Center here said today that it had dispatched union ''missionaries'' to dissuade some members from returning to work.

title: U.S. CHAMBER OF COMMERCE SEES LITTLE EVIDENCE OF FISCAL HARDSHIP
description: In the fourth day of the air controllers' strike, the chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce said yesterday there was no evidence so far that the disruption in airline service was causing ''any great financial hardship'' on business.

title: Mission Seeking End to War With Iraq Arrives in Teheran
description: A mission seeking an end to the war between Iran and Iraq arrived in Teheran today and was welcomed by Foreign Minister Hossein Mousavi, the official Iranian press agency said.

title: Savings Unit Automation
description: Federal savings and loan associations will be allowed to set up 24-hour automated banking machines anywhere in the country under a regulation approved today.

title: Briefs
description: * American City Bank said it has had discussions with a foreign bank concerning the possible acquisition of American City Bank.

title: Coastal Corp. Cites Loss
description: The Coastal Corporation, a natural resources concern involved in gas, oil and coal production, said today that it posted a $35.7 million loss in the second quarter because of worldwide refining and marketing losses. The loss compared with earnings of $28.6 million, or $1.18 a share, in the same 1980 quarter. Revenues totaled $1.4 billion, compared with last year's $1.1 billion.

title: LANGEVIN GETS NEW CONTRACT
description: The Islanders announced today a contract extension for Dave Langevin, a 27-year-old defenseman whose steady if unspectacular play was a factor in the team's winning its second successive Stanley Cup championship last season.

title: Advertising; Ad Problems Minimal In Controllers' Strike
description: As far as the well-traveled crowd in the agency world is concerned, the air traffic controllers' strike couldn't have come at a better time. August is dead in adland.

title: AL CARMINES BEGINS HIS NEW LIFE AS A CLUB SINGER
description: THE Rev. Al Carmines has resigned from Judson Memorial Church after 20 years of writing, producing and performing in such musical shows as ''Peace,'' ''The Gorilla Queen,'' ''Promenade,'' ''Christmas Rappings'' and ''In Circles'' (with lyrics by Gertrude Stein). Tonight he starts a new, unaffiliated career as a nightclub performer at Snafu, 676 Avenue of the Americas, near 21st Street (691-3535), where he will appear tonight and tomorrow evening at 9 ($6 cover charge, with two-drink minimum at tables).

title: Deliberations Lagging In N.F.L.-Raiders Case
description: The jury in the antitrust trial brought by the Oakland Raiders against the National Football League told the judge today that it was stymied in its attempts to reach a verdict.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTROLLERS' GROUP BACKS STRIKE
description: By The Associated Press The International Federation of Air Traffic Controllers Associations asked its 60 member groups yesterday to deny clearance to aircraft flying to the United States, the federation president said in an announcement in Edmonton, Alberta.

title: DOMINION STORES SEEKS TO BUY HOLLINGER ARGUS
description: Conrad M. Black, the Canadian financier, moved yesterday to consolidate his far-reaching holdings. Under the terms of a tender offer made in Toronto, Mr. Black's Dominion Stores Ltd., Canada's largest supermarket chain, will pay more than $210 million for the 5.9 million shares of Hollinger Argus Ltd., another part of the Black empire.

title: 'HILL STREET BLUES' GARNERS 21 NOMINATIONS FOR EMMYS
description: The critically acclaimed ''Hill Street Blues'' received an overwhelming 21 nominations from the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences today.

title: IRAN WON'T ALLOW 62 FRENCH CITIZENS TO LEAVE COUNTRY
description: Iran refused today to permit 62 French nationals to leave the country or even to allow an Air France plane that had been sent to bring them home to land at the Teheran airport.

title: DELBELLO WIELDS POWER WITH EYE ON A THIRD TERM
description: Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, decided to take last week off as a brief vacation to renovate his new home in Lewisboro, N.Y. He almost got away with it.

title: Nabisco Dividend
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. yesterday declared its first payout, a cash dividend of 46 1/4 cents a share payable Oct. 9 to shareholders of record Sept. 18. Nabisco brands was formed in the recent merger of Standard Brands Inc. and Nabisco Inc. Nabisco had been paying 45 cents a share and Standard Brands 41 cents a share before the merger.

title: 'BEATLEMANIA,' THEIR LIVES, OUR TIMES
description: ACCORDING to a careful opening disclaimer, the four young men who star in ''Beatlemania'' are ''not the former members of the musical group known as the Beatles.'' This laughable announcement is made for legal reasons, not esthetic ones, because anyone fond of the real Beatles will immediately spot the fraudulence of the enterprise. ''Beatlemania'' was a horror on the stage, and it's even more of a horror at close range, where the seams really show. This isn't a loving impersonation, or even an honest one. It's cheap, disingenuous and loathsome.

title: Miss Jaeger Gains; Clerc Beats Gomez
description: Top-seeded Andrea Jaeger defeated Sue Barker, 6-1, 6-7, 6-2, today and advanced to a semifinal meeting with third-seeded Mima Jausovec in the United States Open Clay Court tennis championships.

title: Around the World; Gambian Hostages Freed In Assault on Barracks
description: Senegalese troops stormed the last stronghold of Gambian rebels today and freed more than 100 hostages held there since the start of an attempted coup a week ago, a Senegalese military official said.

title: c; TANGLEWOOD: SCHULLER LEADS A U.S. PREMIER
description: The Fromm Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood reached its climax last night with an orchestral concert in the Theater-Concert Hall. It was performed by fellows of the Berkshire Music Center, under Gunther Schuller.

title: YOUTHS LEARNING TRADE AND CUTTING FUEL COSTS
description: The two teen-agers grasped a new storm window and installed it into a repaired frame, the final step in insulating the Harlem apartment against the coming winter weather.

title: HISTORIC MOTH
description: It may not have been the first time mysterious mechanical failure was blamed on a ''bug,'' but Grace Murray Hopper says she was there when the term was first applied to a computer failure - and she has the bug to prove it.

title: Around the World; Rebels in Bolivia Defy New Ruling Junta
description: Rebel forces defied the country's new ruling junta today, a holiday marking Bolivia's independence, and continued their hold on Santa Cruz, the country's second-largest city.

title: Advertising; John Blair Expanding Cents-Off Coupon Area
description: John Blair Marketing, which knows its way around a cents-off coupon, is next going to be offering the package-goods crowd a way of reaching 18 million households whose inhabitants have an average of 4.1 members and an average annual income of $26,500.

title: CAREY SIGNS A MEASURE TO PROVIDE UTILITY CUSTOMERS NEW PROTECTION
description: Governor Carey signed a measure yesterday that creates a "bill of rights" for utility customers. It gives new protections to those whose service is about to be cut off and provides help for consumers in their dealings with utilities.

title: Economic Analysis
description: As the Du Pont Company wraps up its dramatic $7.57 billion takeover of Conoco Inc., business experts are describing the record-shattering acquisition as both a spotlight on current business trends and a cause to reconsider some ongoing controversies.

title: The Circle of Allied Defense
description: The Reagan Administration came to office with two major objectives: reforming the American economy and confronting Soviet adventurism with a strengthened alliance. But the monetarist methods chosen to achieve the first objective are now impeding the allied contributions to the second.

title: No Headline
description: The table of corporate profits published Monday in Business Day incorrectly listed the change in the Stauffer Chemical Company's revenue. The correct figure is 6 percent.

title: No Headline
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales sailed in and moored off the western Greek island of Ithaca tonight for a 24-hour visit, the Ithaca port authorities said. The royal yacht Britannia was expected to cruise around the Greek islands for most of next week, British Navy sources said. It was reported to have dropped anchor about one mile off the Ionian Sea island at 8 P.M. local time.

title: The City; CURBS ON WATER REMAIN IN EFFECT
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city's drought emergency regulations would remain in effect for the rest of August. The Mayor said that the reservoirs were only 74.4 percent full, compared wth the normal 88.4 percent at this time of the year.

title: BAR CONVENTION OFFERS CONTACT WITH REAGAN ADMINISTRATION AIDES
description: About 10,000 lawyers began gathering here today for the annual convention of the American Bar Association and for many of the participants their first direct contact with members of the Reagan Administration.

title: People's Traffic
description: People Express, a new discount-priced regional carrier based in Newark, said it had carried more than 250,000 passengers since it began operations three months ago. The carrier, which has reported losses for each of its three months in business, now flies to Baltimore-Washington, Boston, Jacksonville, Fla., Buffalo, Syracuse, Norfolk, Va., and Columbus, Ohio, from Newark.

title: Notes on People; Slips of the Lip
description: Several times in recent months, Alexander M. Haig Jr., the Secretary of State, has gotten words, phrases and facts mixed up. This week, for example, he referred to ''President Nixon'' when he meant to say ''President Reagan,'' and then compounded the slip by explaining,''That's because I'm thinking ahead, you see, and not keeping my feet on the ground.''

title: SADAT CALLS 'COOPERATION' BY U.S. AND P.L.O. ON LEBANON A KEY STEP
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt yesterday attributed the ceasefire in Lebanon to what he described as Palestinian cooperation with the United States, calling that cooperation a crucial step toward peace in the Middle East.

title: PROMINANT IN GROUP THERAPY
description: S. R. Slavson, retired director of the Department of Group Therapy for the Jewish Board of Guardians and founder and president-emeritus of the American Group Psychotherapy Association, died Wednesday at his Manhattan home after a long illness. He was 91 years old.

title: PARK LOCKERS FOR WOMEN
description: The first locker room for women in the 125-year-history of Central Park is scheduled to open next Wednesday at noon. The facility is situated at the northwest corner of the park's 97th Street Field-House, which is midway between the ball fields and the East Meadow.

title: NED ELLIOTT WILLIAMS
description: Ned Elliott Williams, a former editor of Downbeat Magazine and an entertainment publicist, died Wednesday in the Jennie Edmindson Hospital in Council Bluffs, Iowa, of emphysema complicated by bronchitis. He was 84 years old and had lived in Council Bluffs since his retirement in 1961.

title: PHILHARMONIC: UNDER AN OPEN SKY
description: Over the centuries, Western music has become a peculiarly indoor music. As it settled into the spacious confines of the church or the elegant surroundings of the court or extended into concert halls, our music has moved further and further away from the ceremonial, religious and folk sounds of other cultures that might be as at home under an open sky as under a closed roof.

title: Zimbabwe Army Chief To Head All Forces
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe has appointed the head of the army in Zimbabwe to the new post of overall commander of the country's military forces, it was announced today.

title: Notes on People; A Hat for Hank
description: Recalling the start of filming with Henry Fonda on the forthcoming ''On Golden Pond,'' Katharine Hepburn said: ''I knew that Hank would think that Spencer and I had been teamed so often and that I might be thinking, 'Where is Spencer?', when I played scenes with him, so I gave him Spencer's hat.''

title: U.S. Grounds the F-16 After Fatal Utah Crash
description: The Air Force grounded its 269 F-16 Falcon jet fighters today because of problems with the plane's flight control computer.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY DOWN; BOND PRICES EDGE UP
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that a key measure of the nation's money supply fell $200 million for the week ended July 29, an announcement that helped to produce slightly higher prices - and lower yields - in late trading of fixed-income securities.

title: REGIME IN POLAND ASSAILS SOLIDARITY OVER 'ARROGANCE'
description: In one of its most stinging attacks on the independent union Solidarity, the Polish Government accused the organization today of ''aggressive and arrogant behavior'' and of sabotaging talks aimed at ending the crisis over food shortages.

title: DANCE: JACOB'S YOUTHS
description: ''All That Glitters'' - a gathering of ballet wunderkinder presented this week by the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., and seen on Thursday - failed, happily, to live up to that glittery tag. Considering the number of young international ballet competition medalists performing, the program might well have been expected to include every razzle-dazzle bit of pyrotechnics that ever graced the competition stages. Instead, the Pillow presented a genuinely lively evening of dance that shone with a burnished glow.

title: H.N. OLIPHANT
description: H.N. Oliphant, an editor of Yank magazine in World War II, died Sunday at the age of 72.

title: FOES OF THE C.I.A., NOT THE COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Alcan Australia Cancels Smelter
description: Alcan Australia Ltd., a unit of Alcan Aluminium Ltd. of Canada, said it had shelved its plans to build a 300,000 ton-per-year aluminum smelter at Bundaberg, Queensland.

title: RISE IN CANCER MORTALITY FOUND FOR MEN IN JERSEY
description: A survey of cancer deaths in New Jersey over 27 years showed that the death rate was increasing for men and decreasing for women, but that the state's mortality rate was becoming more closely aligned with the national average.

title: 305,000 Fled Salvador, U.N. Agency Reports
description: At least 305,000 people have fled from El Salvador in the last year because of violence and hunger in the Central American nation, according to an official with the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: WATT, CITING COURT RULING, DEFERS OIL LEASING OFF CALIFORNIA'S COAST
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt announced today that he would not attempt to sell oil-drilling leases on 80 million acres of ocean floor off northern California until at least 1983. The leasing proposal has drawn strong opposition from Californians who fear environmental damage.

title: The City; COLUMBIA DEAN TO LEAVE POST
description: The dean of Columbia College, Arnold Collery, said he would retire from his position at the end of the 1981-82 academic year.

title: POP-DISCO: GRACE JONES
description: Grace Jones, the Jamaican-born model-turned-singer, who appeared at the Savoy on Wednesday and Thursday, is pop music's high priestess of androgyny. A very limited vocalist, Miss Jones won herself a cult following in homosexual discos through such stunts as entering on a motorcycle and taunting her admirers with the hauteur of a professional dominator.

title: RACE FOR COMPTROLLER'S POST HEATS UP SUMMER POLITICS
description: He used to call himself ''the young dynamo.'' Harrison J. Goldin, by all accounts, was a boy wonder. A valedictorian at the Bronx High School of Science. An honors graduate of Princeton. An editor of the law journal at Yale. State Senator at the age of 29.

title: Patents; Chief Vows Cut in Office Backlog
description: WASHINGTON THE backlog of the Patent and Trademark Office now consists of more than 200,000 patent applications and 100,000 trademark applications. The waiting time for a patent is nearly 23 months and for trademarks about 25 months.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT IN NEW YORK ROSE
description: The unemployment rate for New York City rose sharply in July, but went down slightly for New York State and fell to the lowest point in 17 months in New Jersey.

title: RUSSIANS CONDEMN THE POLISH UNION
description: Soviet press attacks on the independent labor movement in Poland have returned in recent days to an intensity not seen since before the emergency congress of the Polish Communist Party last month.

title: New Jersey's Insurance Risk Wrangle
description: Now it's up to New Jersey's Appellate Court to decide whether auto insurers can be barred from considering age, sex and residence in determining premiums. Insurance Commissioner Sheeran has held that they may not so dissect the pool of drivers, but the industry insists that such classifications are reliable indicators of risk.

title: U.S. URGED TO KEEP ATOM WASTE ROLE
description: A Presidential panel charged with finding ways to overcome political obstacles to the disposal of radioactive nuclear waste has recommended that the Government consult with state and local interests on possible sites but that it must have the final say if no agreement was reached.

title: BRAZILIAN WOMAN UPSTAGES FORD UNIT
description: It wasn't a fair fight. On one side was Ford Brasil, the fifth-largest private company in Brazil, with 20,000 employees. On the other was Sueden, an auto-components concern of 230 people that, according to ''Who's Who in the Brazilian Economy,'' ranks 4,357th in sales.

title: Polish Debt Reviewed
description: Government representatives from the United States, Britain, West Germany and France met today to review the possibility of rescheduling Poland's debt due next year, banking sources said.

title: De Gustibus; IT'S GETTING HARD TO FIND A REALLY GOOD PROSCIUTTO
description: Certain foods complement each other so well, that the mention of one automatically suggests the other. If one were free-associating gastronomically, it is almost certain that the word bread would evoke butter as an answer. Among other such combinations would be bacon and eggs, strawberries and cream, bagels and lox.

title: RED HOLZMAN'S SECRET
description: ''DID you see the Knicks signed Red Holzman to a new two-year contract?'' a fan asked the other day. ''I don't know why. The parade has passed and he's still waving at it.''

title: WESTCHESTER JAIL FILLED OVER ITS LIMITS AGAIN
description: Forty-three prisoners housed at a Federal correctional center since last month's uprising at the Westchester County Jail returned to the jail today, giving it more prisoners than at the time of the disturbance.

title: Cable Prices Unleashed
description: On its long and far-from-finished passage through Congress, the new Communications Act has now acquired a provision that would bar city and county governments from regulating the rates charged by cable television companies. Municipal and county officials are upset at this decision by the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: Washington Post Faces Suit Over Fictitious Addict Article
description: A member of the District of Columbia Board of Education, Calvin Lockridge, has filed suit in Superior Court here against The Washington Post, seeking $8.8 million in damages because of the newspaper's article about a nonexistent 8-year-old heroin addict.

title: An Appraisal
description: It was in 1970 that the New England Aquarium in Boston opened, and notions of what kind of building you visit fish in were changed dramatically. In Boston, fish were not merely arrayed in a series of small tanks but set into a huge, multistoried drum, something like an oil tank made of glass and filled with water, with a spiral ramp wrapped around it. The architects of the New England Aquarium were the firm of Cambridge Seven Associates. It was the success of the Boston project that led to their call to the Baltimore waterfront to design a second aquarium, which was commissioned as the Baltimore Aquarium but while under construction was given upgraded status by Congress and renamed the National Aquarium. Inside Is Foremost

title: Glass Houses at City Hall
description: Perhaps the most telling result of the two-and-a-half-year-long Federal and city investigations into the seamy bus shelter debacle is that though they have finally ended without indictments at City Hall, the odor of potential conflict and influence-peddling still clings there. And not just to the robes of Harrison J. Goldin, though the findings have given his integrity a sour smell.

title: TRUST FUND KEEPS LIVE MUSIC ALIVE
description: While attention focuses on the budget fate of the National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities, a little-known organization that has a tenuous link to Washington continues to thrive, helping to keep the sound of music live and alive.

title: Index; International
description: Royal couple's visit to Gibraltar may hasten solution 2 Dollar's strength a problem for some U.S.-based diplomats 2 Sadat calls P.L.O. cooperation with U.S. in truce crucial 3 Around the World 3 French wait anxiously for depar- ture of evacuees from Iran 3 Soviet forces land near Poland in their largest exercise in Baltic 4 Castro begins visit to Mexico 22 Government/Politics Florida begins spraying in Tampa to combat fruit flies 5 Panel urges Federal action to solve nuclear waste problems 5 Jobless rate in New York City rose last month 7 City's newest ferryboat founders on a practice run 23 John C. Dearie tries to redefine the City Comptroller's job 23 Harrison J. Goldin forgets the past and works on the primary 23 Carey orders financial disclo- sures by his appointees 24 City will spend $640,000 to repair Sanitation buildings 25 Convention offers lawyers con- tact with Reagan aides 43 Goldin says two Koch aides lobbied in bus-shelter case 44 Industry/Labor Controllers gain support from union leaders 6 General Around the Nation 5 Cleveland has bad luck with title: Brennan Clears Haitians To Go to Puerto Rico
description: Justice William J. Brennan of the Supreme Court cleared the way today for a transfer of 800 Haitian refugees from Florida to Puerto Rico next week.

title: SONGS: BLOSSOM DEARIE AND DAVE FRISHBERG
description: Blossom Dearie and Dave Frishberg, who are both singing pianists and songwriters, are so much alike and yet so vitally different that they make an ideal team in their performances at Michael's Pub, where they will be playing and singing together through Aug. 29.

title: FORMER CONGRESSMAN
description: Former United States Representative James A. Haley, who represented Florida's Eighth Congressional District for 24 years, died yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: TREASURY BILL RATE AT 14.54%
description: The Treasury completed an extraordinary week of financing yesterday with the sale of $4.5 billion of one-year bills at a near-record interest rate of 14.54 percent.

title: BUDGET SIGNING SET ON COAST
description: President Reagan plans to sign his sweeping tax-cutting and budget-cutting legislation into law next week at his ranch in the mountains here, White House aides said today.

title: GOLDIN SAYS 2 KOCH AIDES LOBBIED FOR BUS SHELTERS
description: The names of two former Deputy Mayors to Mayor Koch came up in the bus-shelter controversy yesterday when City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin released the transcript of testimony that he gave before a Federal grand jury two years ago.

title: WHERE TO FIND LIGHT AT BARGAIN PRICES
description: New York City has a marketplace for just about everything: a street or neighborhood where stores selling the same type of merchandise are clustered. Dedicated shoppers flock to these areas either for the best quality or for the best bargains, or both.

title: Bat, Ball And Snake Oil
description: Have you ever taken a summer house for a nice vacation? What's the first thing you do? You tell a lot of friends what a great place you've rented and then you invite them to come visit for a few days, right?

title: RISE ON SAVINGS BACKED
description: The Justice Department has given qualified support to three proposals to let banks and savings institutions pay more competitive interest rates, but the department says the proposals do not go far enough in deregulating such institutions. Among the proposals is one to increase the ceiling on savings account interest at commercial banks to 10 1/4 percent from 5 1/4 percent, and at savings institutions to 10 1/2 percent from 5 1/2 percent.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 8, 1981 International Solidarity was harshly attacked by the Polish Government, which accused the trade union of ''aggressive and arrogant behavior'' and of undermining talks aimed at ending the crisis over food shortages. One of the Government's strongest criticisms of the union was made public while several hundred workers in the southern industrial and mining region of Silesia struck for four hours over food shortages and the Government's handling of the country's economic troubles. It appeared that talks between the union's leaders and the Government might be halted, at least temporarily. (Page 1, Column 6.) Moscow renewed its harsh attacks on the independent union in Poland. The official newpapers have offered versions of events in Poland that suggested that Soviet leaders' forebearance is once again being strained. Western diplomats who have been observing the Kremlin's reaction to the Polish crisis doubt that any overt intervention is planned, despite the largest maneuvers ever held by the Soviet Navy off Poland's Baltic coast. (1:5.)

title: READY ALTERNATIVE TO MORE PRISONS
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESSURE ON SMALL BREWERS
description: Small breweries have been folding almost since anyone can remember. The growing national brands have swallowed them as acquisitions or have made it impossible for them to survive financially.

title: About New York; A LIFETIME IN BUSINESS DOOMED BY WESTWAY
description: When the surveyors arrived, young men peering through instruments on gangly tripods and writing their cabalistic symbols in bright colors on the street, Melvin Madison figured there was trouble coming.

title: BASEBALL'S ALL-STAR GAME JUST A HARD-LUCK STORY IN CLEVELAND
description: The Cuyahoga River has not caught fire in years and the stain of financial default was erased last October, but this city still doesn't seem to get the breaks.

title: Yankees Lose to Rookies
description: One night after defending their sense of pride and professionalism and denying that their half of a division championship would result in a lack of incentive, the Yankees lost to a rookie league team with a few players added from elsewhere in the organization.

title: ROYAL HONEYMOON MAY SPEED GIBRALTAR SOLUTION
description: The honeymoon visit by the Prince and Princess of Wales to Gibraltar last Saturday may hasten rather than delay a solution to the dispute over the Rock, which has bedeviled relations between Britain and Spain for decades.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY BASEBALL

title: REGAN GIVES APPROVAL TO BUDGET FOR YONKERS
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan today approved a 1981-82 municipal budget of $192.7 million for Yonkers, the final step necessary for implementing the budget by a deadline of Aug. 15.

title: G.O.P. STUDY SUGGESTS MORE BUDGET CUTS
description: Warning that the Federal deficit for the fiscal year 1982 might approach $90 billion and thereby far exceed Reagan Administration estimates, the House Republican Research Committee has brought up the possibility of $52.3 billion in additional cuts in the next budget.

title: THANKS TO BASEBALL (II)
description: To the Editor:

title: AS DOLLAR GAINS, ENVOYS AT U.N. ARE FEELING THE PINCH
description: The Austrian Mission here is trying to cut back on overseas phone calls. So is the West German Mission. The French information office is going to be doing less entertaining, and a Japanese diplomat will probably take a shorter vacation.

title: Books of The Times; DOMESTICATING DEATH
description: DEATH AND THE CREATIVE LIFE. By Lisl M. Goodman. 172 pages. Springer. $17.95.

title: No Headline
description: The Holmes Pace went to Freedom Fella, driven by Shelly Goudreau.

title: EUROPEAN CONTROLLERS BEGIN ACTIONS TO BACK U.S. STRIKE
description: European and Canadian air traffic controllers began scattered job actions in support of their striking American colleagues yesterday, but the American authorities said the show of solidarity had no major effect on international flights to or from the United States.

title: KODAK TO ACQUIRE ATEX IN $77 MILLION ACCORD
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, already a major supplier of materials for printing newspapers and magazines, announced yesterday that it will acquire Atex Inc., a major producer of computer systems and terminals used in editing.

title: Patents; New Turntable Spindle Allows Selectivity
description: Phonograph records can be stacked on a turntable with a vertical central spindle that allows them to be dropped one at a time for continuous playing. Antonio M. Lopez of Ventura, Calif., has invented an adaptor for the spindle that enables selection of particular records.

title: North Korean Body Returned
description: A body identified as that of a Chinese soldier killed in the Korean War was returned to North Korea today for burial there.

title: Jesuit Leader in Hospital In Rome After a Stroke
description: The Rev. Pedro Arrupe, Superior General of the Society of Jesus, was rushed to a hospital today with a stroke, a Jesuit spokesman said.

title: A SCENE FROM THE PASY YIELDS HOPE FOR CHINA
description: In the spring of 1967, while living and working in Peking, I had a friend who was a Red Guard. She was a pleasant young, working-class woman who, like many people, had accepted the ''honor'' of induction into the Red Guards because it afforded respect and safety relative to those, like myself, who came from ''bad'' families and therefore were not granted entry into the prestigious organization.

title: Texas School District Plans Appeal of Busing by Lottery
description: Officials of the South Park Independent School District said today that they planned to file a notice of appeal on a Federal district judge's order to integrate the schools by using a lottery system.

title: No Headline
description: Bombs exploded last night outside two French banks and an office of Air France in what a telephone caller said would be a worldwide attack on French interests unless France handed over former President Bani-Sadr.

title: No Headline
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization's representative here, Hatem Hassaini, said today that President Sadat's bid for American recognition of the P.L.O. was a meaningless ''media gesture to his own people and the Arab world.''

title: the City; BRONX MAN IS HELD IN MURDER OF GIRL
description: A 36-year-old unemployed Bronx man was arrested and charged with the fatal stabbing of a 10-year-old girl who had been left alone in her Bronx apartment by her mother, the police said.

title: POLICE IN LOS ANGELES SEIZE 8 IN BID TO CURB GANG VIOLENCE
description: In a continuing crackdown on gang violence, more than 150 Los Angeles police officers have raided 30 houses, arresting eight persons and seizing 50 rifles, shotguns and pistols.

title: Patents; Compounds Intended To Help During X-Rays
description: Compounds that were patented this week increase the sensitivity of cancer cells to X-ray treatment.

title: Company Briefs
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises said it had acquired 100,000 shares of the 11 percent cumulative convertible preferred stock of the Flexi-Van Corporation, or 8.3 percent of the outstanding stock, for $2.5 million. Bass Brothers said its purchases were for investment.

title: Patents; New Way of Producing Iodine for Industry
description: The Cetus Corporation, a large genetic engineering company in Berkeley, Calif., received a patent this week for a method of producing iodine.

title: Hunt Coal Tie To Shamrock
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said it had formed a joint venture with the Hunt Energy Corporation to mine coal in Alaska's Cook Inlet area near Anchorage.

title: MURPHY SHOOTS 69 AND LEADS BY SHOT OVER 3 TIED AT 136
description: Bob Murphy retained his lead today in the second round of the 63d Professional Golfers' Association Championship with a 69, one under par for the Atlanta Athletic Club course.

title: THE ANTI-IMPROVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: FESTIVAL: EMERSON QUARTET
description: The final concert of the 1981 Festival of Contemporary Music here last night served as a kind of decompression chamber from the rarefied atmosphere - not to say vacuum - of the festival's regular programming to the classical-music conventionalities normally offered at Tanglewood.

title: No Headline
description: The bodies of 79 people, all apparently murder victims, were found around the country in the last three days, the Government said today. No group claimed responsibility for the deaths.

title: DOW DROPS 10.37 AFTER JOBS REPORT
description: The stock market lapsed into decline yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average tumbling 10.37 points to 942.54, as hopes fell that interest rates might soon decline.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BANI-SADR'S BACKERS INVADE IRAN'S U.S. OFFICE
description: Supporters of Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the deposed President of Iran, seized Iran's diplomatic outpost here today in a one-hour takeover that ended with the shooting of one of the demonstrators.

title: CORONER REPORTS VETERINARIAN DIED OF AN ACUTE BARBITUATE OVERDOSE
description: Dr. Janice Runkle, a New York race track veterinarian whose body was found last Saturday in a secluded area of a state park in Illinois, died of an ''acute barbiturate overdose,'' officials in Illinois reported yesterday.

title: MIGLIORE SURPASSES APPRENTICE RECORD
description: Richard Migliore won three races today at Saratoga Race Track and surpassed Steve Cauthen's record for earnings in one year by an apprentice jockey.

title: Disturbance Halts Bout
description: A crowd disturbance in which a boxer was struck by a bottle forced termination of a lightweight fight at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum last night.

title: The Trouble With Drug Enforcement
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. '82 Car Prices Up an Average $507
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that its 1982-model passenger cars would cost an average of $507 more than comparable 1981 models.

title: Nurse Cleared in Inquiry In Coast Hospital Deaths
description: A judge today dismissed drug charges against a nurse linked to an investigation of more than two dozen hospital deaths in southern California that were considered suspicious.

title: No Headline
description: In an article in Business Day yesterday Ralph E. Bailey, chairman of Conoco Inc., was quoted incorrectly. Mr. Bailey said Conoco, after it became a division of Du Pont, would continue to sell certain coal properties ''with high market value and low earnings potential.''

title: LEON S. AVAKIAN
description: Leon S. Avakian, founder of Avakian Associates, which sponsored sessions at which institutional analysts reported in depth on corporate financial statements, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Ridgewood (N.J.) Hospital. Mr. Avakian, who was a resident of Saddle River, N.J., was 49 years old.

title: CAREY ORDERS TOP AIDES TO LIST FINANCIAL ASSETS
description: Governor Carey has issued an executive order requiring his appointees to disclose publicly their financial holdings and possible conflicts of interest. It will also bar them from running for elective office or holding a position in a political party while serving in his administration.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, AUGUST 8, 1981; The Economy
description: The nation's airlines reported a loss of revenue of $100 million so far as a result of the air traffic controllers' strike. A spokesman for the Air Transport Association called it ''devastating.'' The airlines' revenue and earnings are normally greatest during the summer months, he said, and 1981 earnings will be sharply below a prestrike estimate of $750 million. (Page 33.) Meanwhile, Federal officials assigned more military personnel to perform the work of the strikers, and the union called for support from other labor organizations in this country and abroad. (1.)

title: FOR STRAPHANGERS WITHOUT CALCULATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTROLLERS GAINING SUPPORT FROM LABOR LEADERS
description: Striking air traffic controllers began to pick up support from labor leaders around the country yesterday as two more officials of the controllers' union went to court in Brooklyn on charges of violating the ban on strikes by Federal employees.

title: Canadian Jobless Down
description: Canada's unemployment rate fell slightly in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.2 percent, compared with 7.3 percent in June and 7.5 percent in July 1980, Statistics Canada reported today. The agency said 835,000 people were unable to find work in July, down from 855,000 in June and 852,000 in July 1980. Canada's unemployment rate reached a five-year low of 7 percent last April.

title: Around the Nation; Suspect Pleading Guilty In Ribicoff Niece's Death
description: Anthony McAdoo, one of two suspects in the killing of the niece of former Senator Abraham Ribicoff of Connecticut, has agreed to plead guilty to first-degree murder and testify against his co-defendant, prosecutors said today.

title: Notes on People
description: As Mayor of Chicago, Jane Byrne earned $60,000 last year.

title: JAZZ 4: EDDIE VINSON
description: Eddie (Cleanhead) Vinson's performances this week at Sweet Basil, where he is leading a quartet through tonight, are an interesting study in contrasts. Mr. Vinson's blues shouting is fervent but polished, the end result of years of refining such songs as ''Just a Dream'' and ''Whiskey Head Woman'' to a point at which they have a touch of urgency even though the delivery is calculated to the slightest nuance. And his alto saxophone playing has be-bop enthusiasm on ''I'll Remember April'' and broad, romantic fluorishes on ''Laura.''

title: Koch Cancels Rugby Match
description: Mayor Koch, who had approved plans for a rugby team from South Africa to play a game on Randalls Island next month, reversed himself yesterday and ordered the game canceled.

title: OWNER-BACKED ITEM AIDS FREE AGENCY
description: Throughout the long and tedious negotiations on the free agent compensation issue, the players charged that the owners were trying to discourage teams from signing free agents. However, a provision inserted into the agreement at the last minute by the owners' negotiators could, in fact, encourage clubs to sign free agents.

title: GIANTS PLAN TO USE A FULL COMPLEMENT
description: Winning may be the only thing to a lot of football people a lot of the time. But this is still the exhibition season, and, to Coach Ray Perkins, winning will be only the third of three priorities when his Giants play the Bears in Chicago tomorrow night.

title: Brazilian General Quits As Head of the Cabinet
description: Gen. Golbery do Couto e Silva resigned as head of Brazil's civilian Cabinet today. He had held the post since 1974.

title: Mets Lose, 7-3, To Jays
description: The second half of the major league season, which starts Monday, is, according to Mets Manager Joe Torre, ''a reprieve and an opportunity.''

title: The Region; DRIFTER GIVEN LIFE IN DEATH OF BOY, 9
description: A young drifter from Maine, described by a Dallas detective as ''one of those double-bad people,'' received a life sentence yesterday for the rape and murder of a 9-year-old Vineland boy.

title: Earthquake Jolts Tennessee
description: An earthquake registering about 4 on the Richter scale jarred northwest Tennessee today. No injuries or damages were reported.

title: Molybdenum Find Reported by Exxon
description: The Exxon Corporation said its Exxon Minerals Company unit had discovered what it termed a ''substantial'' deposit of molybdenum in central Nevada.

title: No Headline
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday revoked the owner and trainer licenses of Alex Fiore, asserting that he committed perjury after discovery of an electrical device on the track at Belmont Park June 22.

title: NEW YORK CLOSES LOOPHOLE IN CITY REALTY TRANSFER TAX
description: Governor Carey has signed a bill that will prevent corporations from avoiding the New York City real-estate transfer tax by transferring stock in a property instead of the property itself.

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO DROP HIS PLANS TO NAME JERSEYAN TO DUBLIN POST
description: President Reagan has decided to drop his plans to nominate William E. McCann, a New Jersey insurance executive, as Ambassador to Ireland, Administration officials said today. The President is now expected to nominate a prominent Republican lumbercompany executive from Oregon.

title: BROTHER C. JUSTIN BRENNAN, 80, ARBITRATOR IN LABOR DISPUTES
description: Brother C. Justin Brennan, a labor mediator and professor emeritus of labor management at Manhattan College, died Wednesday in St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers after a brief illness. Brother Justin was 80 years old and lived at the college.

title: RURAL NUCLEAR SIREN IS CALLED A DISASTER
description: When Leslee Morrison came home from work last Monday evening, she was upset to find that a siren was being attached to a pole near her house.

title: Going Out Guide
description: COLONIAL TEA PARTY

title: THE OLD-TIME BAKERY: A STILL-PALPABLE THRILL
description: For the first time that anyone can remember, in a place where people have pretty good memories, there is no honest-togoodness bakery in Geneva, the small town in upstate New York where I was born 26 years ago. Two dozen churches, five funeral homes and two movie theaters but no bakery.

title: ON LICENSING APARTMENT MANAGERS
description: Should building owners or managers be licensed?

title: Jack Manning
description: PEKING OPERA IN NEW YORK: Atop China's United Nations Mission are two members of Shanghai troupe that will begin a run of 15 performances at Alice Tully Hall next Wednesday. At right is Zhou Shaolin, the leading player; at left, Ku Ixuan. The group is the foremost of 2,800 Peking Opera companies in China.

title: WHO'S HOLDING UP AMERICA?
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONALS TO LEAVE
description: The French Government will be spending an anxious weekend waiting to see whether the Iranian authorities will honor their promise to permit the departure of 116 French citizens starting Monday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I cannot hold an individual in contempt of court for not returning to work if the employer won't take the person back to work.'' - Federal Judge Marvin Aspen. (6:3.)

title: LIBYA MAY EASE STAND ON OIL PRICE
description: Libya has apparently told Western oil companies to try to find ways that Libya can effectively lower the price of its crude without taking the politically difficult step of reducing its official selling price, some company officials said yesterday.

title: LABOR'S LOOK TO THE FUTURE
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., was asked earlier this week whether the American labor movement would suffer serious and perhaps permanent injury if the air traffic controllers' union was destroyed. ''The labor movement has been destroyed and destroyed and destroyed,'' Mr. Kirkland said, speaking the words slowly, as though for emphasis. ''Yet we survive. We fulfill a basic human need.''

title: Controller Instructors Fear School Speedup
description: About 30 instructors at the Mike Monroney Aeronautical Center here, where civilian air traffic controllers are trained, conducted informational picketing today to protest efforts to speed up controller training.

title: Maze Prison Hunger Strikers Urge British to Go 'Halfway'
description: Irish nationalist guerrillas issued a statement today calling for changes that could end their hunger strike in Northern Ireland's Maze Prison. British officials said that it contained nothing new.

title: MORE CONTROLLERS FROM THE MILITARY CALLED UP BY U.S.
description: Federal officials, saying they were firm in their resolve to rebuild the nation's air traffic control system, called in additional military personnel today to perform the work of striking controllers.

title: Patents; Plane Simulator Uses Computer in Training
description: Training equipment that simulates an aircraft and provides verbal information and instruction from computer recordings has been invented by engineers of the Singer Company, Binghamton, N.Y. The work was done under an Air Force contract, so the Government holds rights.

title: No Headline
description: MIAMI POLICEMEN MOURN FELLOW OFFICER: The coffin of Raymond Southerland is taken into Wayside Baptist Church for funeral service.

title: CITY'S NEWEST FERRYBOAT HITS BOTTOM ON TRIAL RUN
description: The Andrew J. Barberi, already two and a half years late in joining the city's fleet of Staten Island ferryboats, ran aground briefly on her first attempt to go from one side of New York Harbor to the other yesterday.

title: AFRICARE JAZZ CONCERTS AID SOMALIAN REFUGEES
description: A Somalian refugee program sponsored by Africare, a 10-year-old American organization devoted to improving life in rural Africa, will benefit from jazz concerts to be held in Harlem at the former Renaissance Theater on four Sunday afternoons, beginning tomorrow.

title: SECRET CHINA PAPERS SELL FOREIGNERS ADS
description: Eager to earn foreign exchange at every opportunity, the Chinese Government has begun selling advertising space to foreign companies in one of its secret foreign-trade publications.

title: 24 SET FOR MEADOWLANDS' FIRST HAMBLETONIAN
description: A record 24 trotters are scheduled to compete tomorrow in harness racing's most prestigious event when the Meadowlands plays host to the Hambletonian for the first time.

title: CITY SCHEDULES REPAIRS FOR SANITATION GARAGES
