description: Mayor Koch and Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel announced yesterday that the city would spend $640,000 for emergency repairs to the Sanitation Department's garages and other work sites. The repairs will begin, Mr. Steisel said, ''probably Monday.''

title: LIMITED TV FOR FIRST GAMES
description: The second opening day of the major league baseball season, on Monday, will be accompanied by a television blackout of most games across the country.

title: Lowenstein Ends Talks With Allied
description: M. Lowenstein & Sons, the New York-based textile concern, said it had again broken off acquisition talks with the Allied Corporation, a major chemical company, because the two sides could not agree on terms for Allied's purchase of Lowenstein's fiberglass subsidiary, Clark-Schwebel.

title: Consumer Saturday; CLARIFYING RULES ON TAXICABS
description: It was one of those customary traffic-laden evenings in Manhattan: taxicabs clogging the streets of the Broadway theater district and seemingly meeting head on cars bound for the Lincoln Tunnel and New Jersey, which were in turn bumper to bumper with the public and chartered buses and rented cars of the tourist season. Nothing very out of the ordinary.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 29. 1. Vaslav Nijinsky, the Russian dancer. Alfred Adler. 2. The fragment is from a sacred ark that dates from the third century A.D. In the film ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' archeologists search for the original Ark of the Covenant.

title: CASTRO AND LOPEZ PORTILLO MEETING TO REAFFIRM TIES
description: President Fidel Castro arrived here today for two days of talks with President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico. The two leaders will apparently try to reaffirm their warm personal relationship despite the Cuban leader's annoyance at being excluded from a North-South meeting in Mexico in October.

title: Japan's Soviet Exports Rise
description: The Soviet Union replaced China as Japan's second-largest steel export market after the United States in the first half of this year, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on Page 30.

title: The Region; FATAL YONKERS FIRE IS CALLED SUSPECT
description: YONKERS (AP) - One person was killed and a baby girl was injured in a fire that was believed to have been intentionally set in an apartment building, the police said.

title: Your Money; Home Offices: Shift on Taxes
description: EVEN though the scope of the home-office deduction has been drastically limited by Congress and the Internal Revenue Service over the years, it nonetheless remains one of the most cherished - albeit difficult to claim - deductions available to taxpayers.

title: Mexican Loan Pact
description: Mexico signed a loan agreement for $700 million with a group of 63 international banks headed by the Union de Bancos Arabes y Frances, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS LOST $254 MILLION FOR YEAR
description: British Airways, the Government-owned airline, today reported a $254 million loss for the fiscal year ended March 31 in contrast to a $37 million profit in the 1980 fiscal year.

title: L.I. SLUDGE 'ADDITIVES'
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR STRIKE CUTS LINES' REVENUES
description: The nation's scheduled airlines reported yesterday that the air traffic controllers' strike had cost them more than $100 million in lost revenue from fewer flights and reduced passenger loads, with most of that loss in the first two days of the strike.

title: Deposed President in Bolivia Is Said to Prepare to Attack
description: The deposed President, Luis Garcia Meza, appears to be trying to make a comeback, personally directing preparations to attack rebels who forced his overthrow.

title: SHEEPSKINS TO WEAR 6 WAYS
description: It can be worn as a dress, a skirt, a jacket, a stole, a romper or a tunic. Someone who is very creative might even think of another way of wearing Carol Nolan's skin wrap, which is simply two sheepskins glued together to form a long, irregularly shaped piece of soft leather.

title: Misses Jaeger and Ruzici Gain Clay Court Final
description: Top-seeded Andrea Jaeger defeated Mima Jausovec, 6-3, 6-1, today to advance to the final of the United States Open Clay Court tennis championships.

title: FLORIDA BEGINS SPRAYING, BUT QUARANTINE IS DENIED
description: A ground-spraying program to ward off Mediterranean fruit flies began near here today, but a judge refused to let Florida reimpose a quarantine on California produce entering the state.

title: The Region; WESTCHESTER VOTE ON POWER PLANNED
description: WHITE PLAINS (UPI) - Westchester County officials announced the creation of a task force to schedule a referendum next March on creating a county utility agency to buy low-cost hydroelectric power.

title: Stalled Raider Jury Sent Home for the Weekend
description: The jury in the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League was sent home today for a long weekend's rest, and a lawyer in the case indicated the panel might be stymied by an 8-2 split.

title: HUTTON UP 5 ON MERGER RUMORS
description: The E.F. Hutton Group's stock jumped 5 points, to 41 1/2, yesterday, fueling speculation that the Wall Street brokerage firm was the target of a takeover attempt. However, company officials said they could not explain the activity in the stock.

title: 27 Claims to Estate Of Hughes Are Rejected
description: A judge today threw out the petitions of 27 persons who contended that they were distant relatives of the late Howard R. Hughes's mother and sought portions of his fortune,

title: 'Magic Flute' Today
description: Mozart's ''The Magic Flute'' will be sung in English by the Mozart Opera Project today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Robert F. Wagner Junior High School, 220 East 76th Street.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT DEFIES FORECAST, DECLINING TO 7%
description: The nation's unemployment rate, running counter to forecasts of a slumping economy, fell to 7 percent in July, the lowest point since April 1980, the Labor Department reported today.

title: BYRON PRICE, WARTIME CHIEF OF U.S. CENSORSHIP, IS DEAD
description: Byron Price, a reporter and editor who was the nation's Director of Censorship in World War II and an Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations in charge of administrative and budgetary affairs, died Thursday after a heart attack at his home in Hendersonville, N.C. He was 90 years old.

title: Judge Orders Chavez Freed
description: A judge ordered Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farm Workers, and nine followers released from jail without bail today despite their vow to remain behind bars until given access to a lettuce farm where they were arrested on trespassing charges. Judge Bernard B. McCullough of Justice Court issued the order when Mr. Chavez and his followers appeared before him for arraignment.

title: JETS ROUT BRONCOS
description: ''You really can't get excited about it; it doesn't mean a thing,'' said Richard Todd tonight, while all round him excited Jets' teammates talked of their imposing 33-7 victory over the Denver Broncos.

title: MOSCOW'S FORCES LAND NEAR POLAND
description: Soviet Navy forces landed in Lithuania today in their biggest amphibious exercise in the Baltic Sea, military analysts here said today.

title: A TRAP CALLED GASOLINE GLUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge:; SECOND LEG OF U.J.A. PLAY RAISES $35,000 FOR CHARITY
description: The second leg of the world's biggest charity game was played Thursday night at the Glen Oaks Country Club in Old Westbury, L.I., and raised $35,000. It was the conclusion of the annual United Jewish Appeal Federation game, which began in New York in May.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: word) biographical novel of Charles Darwin (1809-82) offers a year-by-year, sometimes day-by-day account of his growth as a scientist and his development of a theory that rocked the world. Our reviewer Webster Schott found that Irving Stone's research is vast, his psychological insights few, his style lacking in elegance; yet his narrative is ''ultimately overpowering and pleasurable.''

title: Leslie N. Bechtel Becomes Bride Of Steven Caruso
description: Leslie Noel Bechtel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Bechtel of Ridgewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to Steven Bruce Caruso, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy F. Caruso of North Woodmere, L.I. The Rev. Richard B. Andersen performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church.

title: CHAMBER-MUSIC SERIES
description: The 1981 chamber-music series at the Silvermine Guild of Artists in New Canaan gets off to an auspicious start at 8 this evening, when Igor Kipnis performs works by Schubert, Mozart, Haydn, Clementi and Beethoven on an instrument that some of those gentlemen might have envied. It is a fortepiano built in Dresden in 1793 by the Graebner Brothers and recently purchased by Mr. Kipnis.

title: REFORMING APARTHEID MAY BE A PROMISE BOTHA CAN'T KEEP
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha, a machine politician who came up through the ranks to lead the National Party three years ago, assured the all-white Parliament last week that he had a firm mandate from the electorate - also all-white - to continue his policies. But it was possibly the low point of Mr. Botha's tenure as Prime Minister; there was less clarity than ever about his policies and less certainty as to where they might lead.

title: A HANGING HERB GARDEN CAN BE A MOVABLE FEAST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Bonnie Fisher is a professional herbalist. By BONNIE FISHER

title: Sarah H. Davis Wed To Thomas Davidson
description: Sarah Hulme Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Graham Davis of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas Hartley Davidson, son of Mrs. Clement Olmsted Davidson of Madison, Conn., and Elizabeth, N.J., and the late Mr. Davidson. The Rev. Bradley C. Davis, brother of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: AT HOME
description: DEAR SUPERMAN, Being Superman, you will instantly recall my letter of 1943, the one printed in all 32 colors of my new Crayola set. As soon as I grew up, I told you, I was going to be a much prettier and smarter reporter for The Daily Planet than Lois Lane. She was a nag when you were Clark Kent and did so many dumb things when you were Superman, I was sure you'd love me more. Who needed the Lone Ranger with his asthmatic horse when you, Superman, could leap tall buildings at a single bound all by yourself? Wait, I begged you. Wait for me.

title: THE MAKING OF A WRITER
description: WRITERS are born, then discovered and variously judged. They feel adored or merely patronized. They feel ignored or misunderstood or maligned. They feel wonderful or dreadfully hurt. If they fall in love with themselves, or if they commit suicide, people suppose it was built into their vocation. In the South, it is said of a medical student, ''He is going to make a doctor.'' For writers, there is no comparable expression, no diploma, no conclusive evidence that anything real has been made of himself or herself. Once born, they are doomed to the grotesque labors of being reborn, rediscovered, and then they are judged again and again. Naturally, they tend to smoke, drink, etc.

title: HAND-WRINGING ABOUT TOWELS
description: THE party was over and our 37 guests had gone home. I went into the bathrooms and threw all the towels into the hamper. All the towels? Why not just the ones the guests had used?

title: HOBOKEN TERMINAL MAY BECOME STUDIO
description: HOBOKEN THIS riverfront city, whose rehabilitation of brownstones and row houses has been bringing it publicity - and new residents - since the early 1970's, may have a new claim to fame by the end of 1982.

title: Mary O'Gorman Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Lynn O'Gorman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. O'Gorman of Mendham Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Sean McDonnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan F. McDonnell of Wayne, Ill. The Rev. John McDermott performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. David L. Mahon and Msgr.

title: Television Week
description: Eyes on the Point ''Coming out of the 60's, we were rather suspicious of the military. But we came away from this production feeling impressed with the way young people respond to the training.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Campus Hiring Rules Challenged
description: The Department of Education initiated some deregulatory pruning last week, asking Attorney General William French Smith for permission to revoke rules banning sex discrimination in hiring by schools and colleges receiving Federal aid.

title: A HYPERMODERN APPROACH DEMANDS PRECISION
description: SOUTH BEND, Indiana, July 29. The hypermodern thought on an opponent's pawn advances in the center is that the harder they come, the harder they fall. Rather than be intimidated by aggressive central thrusts, the hypermodernist encourages them, intending to lure the ambitious pawn so far forward that it can be cut off from support and devoured.

title: CONTROLLER- F.A.A. CLASH TIED TO PERSONALITIES
description: Behavioral scientists at Boston University who did a five-year, Government-financed $2.8 million study of 416 air traffic controllers said that, based on the personality and emotional factors they had found, they believed controllers hired to replace those dismissed would begin to suffer the same morale problems found among the ones they studied.

title: TATE STOPS PARKER AT 2:47 OF THE FIRST
description: John Tate, a former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, stopped Claman Parker at 2:47 of the first round tonight.

title: Deborah Dwelley Becomes a Bride
description: Deborah Hill Dwelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Dwelley of Salisbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Wallace Joseph Gamber Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace J. Gamber of Largo, Fla. The Rev. Richard Taber performed the ceremony at the Salisbury Congregational Church.

title: Iraq Said to Plan Oil Pipeline
description: Iraq plans to build a pipeline linking its oilfields to a terminal on the Red Sea south of Aqaba, the Jordanian daily Al Rai reported today. The pipeline, which will run across Saudi Arabia's northern desert, will provide a new shipping outlet for Iraq's oil, the paper said.

title: BARRIERS TO SOLAR DEVICES WEAKEN
description: THE General Assembly, in its last regular session, passed a law that requires local planning and zoning commissions to consider the incorporation of passsive solar energy techniques when reviewing new subdivision proposals.

title: The Region in Summary; Testing Principals
description: A dozen years ago, a Federal court said tests prepared by the Board of Examiners for city high school and junior high school principals were racially discriminatory and threw them out. Last week Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola said the first such tests prepared by the board since then also were discriminatory and he asked the court to throw them out, too.

title: Pound Ridge Support For Group Home
description: Reference is made to the sensitive letter of Mrs. Joseph A. McDonnell, published July 19 (''Pound Ridge Criticized on Group Home''). It appeared a few days after we had written to Gerald A. Gould, Supervisor of the Town of Pound Ridge, pleading for the continuation of the group home for autistic children presently located on Lower Shad Road.

title: GREEN BERETS STEP UP HONDURAS ROLE
description: This village's isolated mountain valley, as oppressively muggy by day as it is bleak by night, is nonetheless attracting its share of visitors. They include peasant refugees fleeing from neighboring El Salvador, Salvadoran Government troops and American military advisers.

title: CHAMBER: OLYMPIAN BEAUX ARTS
description: The Beaux Arts Trio viewed Mozart, Mendelssohn and Schubert with Olympian detachment Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall, which is perhaps only proper, considering the fact that the three musicians have been performing these composers' piano trios to general acclaim for more than 25 years. Obviously their pre-eminent status in the chamber-music field is not a closely guarded secret, for this Mostly Mozart Festival concert was filled to capacity, including every available stage seat.

title: DOES WORKING MEAN NOT HAVING TO SAY 'WRONG NUMBER'?
description: AFTER 35 years on the job, I didn't know what to expect of my impending retirement. So I decided to keep a diary of some of the days immediately before and after R-Day.

title: WHY JESSE OWENS WON 4 GOLD MEDALS
description: FIVE years ago today, Jesse Owens won his fourth gold medal at the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games when he led off the victorious 400-meter relay team that included Ralph Metcalfe, Foy Draper and Frank Wykoff. It was a race Jesse Owens was not supposed to run.

title: Children's Books
description: GANESH By Malcolm J. Bosse. 185 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 16) By BRYNA J.FIRESIDE

title: Mary Walker Wed To Jeffrey Bunzel
description: Mary Elizabeth Walker, daughter of George Herbert Walker 3d of St. Louis and Mrs. Herbert Kasper of New York, was married in Kennebunkport, Me., yesterday to Jeffrey Hopkins Bunzel, son of Peter Duryea Bunzel and Jane Cole Bunzel, both of Los Angeles. The Rev. Laman Harmon Bruner Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Ann's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church.

title: CONCERT: MOSTLY MOZART
description: Serious musical business was the order of the evening Friday night at the Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall. The program contained only two works, both by Mozart, and they belong among his masterpieces - the Piano Concerto in C (K. 503) and the Requiem. James Conlon conducted the orchestra and the New York Choral Artists; the vocal soloists in the Requiem were Kathleen Battle, Florence Quivar, John Aler and John Cheek, while Andras Schiff tended to the piano part in the Concerto.

title: FOR THE BANKS, IT'S CHANGE OR PERISH
description: B ANKS will never be the same. The industry is facing one of its greatest economic challenges and, according to many banking officials and analysts, it will either change or perish. Whatever the outcome, things promise to be different.

title: RAIN FALLS TO DAMPEN SPIRIT OF JERSEY'S FIRST HAMBLETONIAN
description: Although the crowd was only 20,677 this rainy afternoon for the 56th edition of the Hambletonian, seasoned horsemen and fans alike welcomed the annual trotting event's first appearance at the Meadowlands.

title: GIANTS SETS BACK BEARS, 23-7
description: The Giants outpassed, outran and outkicked the Chicago Bears tonight. Neill Armstrong, the Bears' coach, said the Giants played with more intensity. With all that, plus two brave decisions by Coach Ray Perkins, the Giants won, 23-7, in the first exhibition game for the National Football League teams.

title: THE VENDORS TROOP BACK
description: For Eileen White and thousands of other vendors, this is a happy day. After seven weeks of the baseball strike, and of unemployment, it's ''Buy me some peanuts and crackerjacks, I don't care if I ever come back.'' The concessionaires are back in business. As the All-Star game gets underway today, vendors by the thousands will be streaming back to the job.

title: Realty News; Midtown Lease
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation has leased the 35th and 36th floors in the Pan Am Building at 200 Park Avenue with a total of 73,000 square feet of office space.

title: THE ART OF HORSE BREEDING
description: What made the July 12 issue of The New York Times Magazine special for me were the photograph of Affirmed on the cover and also the picture of Seattle Slew. AUD JENSEN

title: AN AGE OF ECONOMICS AND STILLED WATER PROJECTS
description: With a new President in the White House and many changes in Congress, a debate over the future of Federal water policy is beginning to take shape.

title: LABOR PRACTICES AND L.I.R.R. FARES
description: A number of Long Island's elected officials have been complaining that Long Island Rail Road fares have gone up by approximately the same percentage as city subway and bus fares. They thought the railroad fares should have been considered separately from subway and bus fares.

title: Catharine Hill and Kent Kildahl Wed
description: At the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday Catharine B. Hill, an international economist at the Congressional Budget Office in Washington, was married to Kent J. Kildahl, who teaches English at the St. Albans School in Washington. The Rev. John Nelson performed the ceremony.

title: A L.I. Insurance Broker, 26, Given 10 Months for Larceny
description: A 26-year-old insurance broker who admitted stealing $140,000 from two finance companies was sentenced yesterday to a 10-month term in the Nassau County jail.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CABARET The combination of a piano that is beautiful to see, beautiful to hear and beautifully played is the parlay that is available in Peacock Alley of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel Tuesday through Saturday evenings from 6 to 10. The piano is a fruitwood Louis XVI Steinway small grand on which Cole Porter composed from 1939 until he died in 1964.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The aim of Solidarity, as I see it, in bitter disappointment of my hopes of establishing a partnership, is not participation in joint responsibility of getting Poland out of the crisis, but deepening the crisis.'' - Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski. (1:5.)

title: MILWAUKEEANS FACE LOSS OF ONE OF THEIR OWN IN CLOSING SCHLITZ BREWERY
description: Ray Trost and John Schwoegler stepped off the picket line outside the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company and sought relief from the heat and humidity with cans of cold beer. The brand was Pabst Blue Ribbon.

title: AN APPEALING COUNTRY SPOT
description: WASHINGTON DEPOT AFTER a fire last year that consumed most of its frame building, Today's Depot has reopened with a new structure, decor, menu, chef and ownership. In fact, only two elements remain the same: half the name (Depot has been added) and generally high standards of food preparation.

title: Elizabeth Ashforth Married
description: Elizabeth Miller Ashforth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Adams Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Peru, Vt., was married yesterday to Edmund West Bacon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Bacon Jr. of Wayne, Ill. The Rev. G. Richard Lobs performed the ceremony in the Congregational Church of Peru.

title: On Language; PARLOR PARLANCE
description: My second day at college, a place only 60 miles from where I was born, I asked if anyone had extra cartons. The girls in my small dormitory - suburban princesses from Bronxville, West Hartford and Shaker Heights - were mystified. Why would anyone put an ''s'' on cotton? Until that moment, never having been anywhere, never having heard voices dissimilar to my own except at the movies or on the radio, I didn't know I had a regional accent. Southerners and Westerners talked funny, but the way I spoke was, I thought, the all-American norm.

title: U.S. Air Force Is Evacuating 80 Americans From Gambia
description: About 80 American tourists and members of diplomats' families were being evacuated from Gambia by the United States Air Force to nearby Senegal after the unsuccessful coup here, diplomatic sources said.

title: Topics; The Horn Dilemma
description: There must have been a time in evolutionary history when horns were clearly advantageous to the massive, near-sighted rhinoceros. They offer defense against other animals, if any be foolish enough to attack, and make handy tools for digging up bushes to munch on.

title: New Jersey Housing; HOW TENANTS KEPT THEIR HOME ALIVE
description: IF EVER there was an example of urban ''true grit,'' the saga of 66-68 Lenox Avenue, in East Orange, is it. Five years ago, the threestory, 12-unit building could have been a symbol of everything that plagues older apartment houses in the cities. It was deteriorating, services were minimal, and the owner had ceased correcting buildingcode violations.

title: JEWISH UNITS PLAN REGISTERY TO FIGHT TORAH THEFTS
description: In an effort to halt the growing number of thefts of Torahs, major New York and national Jewish agencies have agreed to establish a computerized Universal Torah Registry based on invisible numbers that will be stamped on the sacred scrolls without violating stringent religious laws.

title: Topics; Enterprising Con Ed
description: Although Congress has yet to provide for ''urban enterprise zones,'' President Reagan's remedy for urban blight is gaining support in various places. A few states have authorized tax relief for businesses in distressed neighborhoods.

title: Food; DINING ON A DIET THAT IS SALT-FREE
description: AS demanding as it may be to cope with the restrictions of a lowsodium or salt-free diet at home, finding acceptable dishes in restaurants and takeout shops is even more difficult. But recently, because an increasing number of people seem to be concerned about the amount of salt they consume, some restaurants and prepared-food shops on the Island have been making an effort to meet their needs.

title: GERMAN LESSONS
description: THE THIRTY YEARS PEACE By Peter O. Chotjewitz. Translated by Robert and Rita Kimber. 239 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95. By JOEL AGEE

title: McNeil and Jets Are Impressive in Debut
description: As dawn broke in New York yesterday, Freeman McNeil wore a sunny smile. It had been different for the Jets' running back going out to Denver Thursday, though, when the club's top rookie had sat by himself in a darkened airplane cabin and wrung his hands and looked ready to cry.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; White House Treads Lighter On Environment
description: Perhaps no issue facing the Reagan Administration has provoked more controversy than environmental policy, but at least the disputes may not have been entirely without effect.

title: UPSET BY 2 LOSSES, COSMOS' COACH WARNS OF LINEUP CHANGES
description: There will be some changes made when the Cosmos meet the Drillers in Edmonton, Alberta, this afternoon. That was the vow of Coach Hennes Weisweiler, whose team will go into the game against the Drillers (Channel 9 at 4:30 P.M. in New York) having lost two consecutive North American Soccer League games.

title: THE QADDAFI CONNECTION
description: Seymour Hersh's articles, ''The Qaddafi Connection'' (June 14, June 21), brought out two dangerous situations that should be of serious concern to the American public.

title: 605-Mile Fastnet Race Has 250 Yachts at Start
description: Two-hundred fifty yachts sailed from the Solent today at the start of the 605-mile Fastnet race. The start was delayed by strict new regulations designed to avoid a repetition of the 1979 disaster, in which 15 people died and 24 boats were abandoned or sunk.

title: A FURTHER VIEW ON MALPRACTICE CASES
description: Bernard Jeffery's recnet response (Letters to the Editor) to my letter requires a further answer.

title: Joan Laurie Pearlman Wed
description: At Temple Beth Israel in West Hartford, Conn., yesterday Joan Laurie Pearlman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernie Pearlman of Avon, Conn., was married to Stephen I. Mayo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Mayo of Douglaston, Queens. Rabbi Harold Silver officiated. The bride attended Northwestern University and was graduated from Syracuse University. Mr. Mayo is a graduate of Syracuse and the De-Paul University College of Law.

title: WOMEN'S RIGHTFUL ROLE IN THE DEFENSE OF A NATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSICOLOGY MAKES ITS MARK ON NEW MOZART DISKS
description: With the Mostly Mozart Festival in full swing at Avery Fisher Hall, it only seems appropriate to consider the latest batch of recordings devoted to the composer's music. As usual, an abundance of new releases is at hand, and this survey will necessarily be a selective one with the accent falling on disks that add to our knowledge of Mozart, either through performances of distinctive interpretive merit or special musicological insights.

title: LET'S BE GOOD SPORTS ABOUT THE ARENA'S NAME
description: IN THE recent rumblings of dissent and opposition raised against naming the new sports arena in the Meadowlands in honor of Governor Byrne, several points have yet to be made and considered.

title: At Home
description: DEAR SUPERMAN, Being Superman, you will instantly recall my letter of 1943, the one printed in all 32 colors of my new Crayola set. As soon as I grew up, I told you, I was going to be a much prettier and smarter reporter for The Daily Planet than Lois Lane. She was a nag when you were Clark Kent and did so many dumb things when you were Superman, I was sure you'd love me more. Who needed the Lone Ranger with his asthmatic horse when you, Superman, could leap tall buildings at a single bound all by yourself? Wait, I begged you. Wait for me.

title: Joseph Forshaw 4th Weds Liza Schlafly
description: Liza Schlafly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Schlafly of Alton, Ill., was married yesterday to Joseph Forshaw 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Forshaw 3d of St. Louis. John Joseph Cardinal Carberry performed the ceremony in the St. Louis Cathedral.

title: Long Islanders; HIS BEST TEACHER WAS EXPERIENCE
description: WHEN Irving Settel was studying for his bachelor's degree at Brooklyn College, he was already a member of the faculty at Pace Institute. When he entered New York University's School of Business soon afterward in pursuit of a master's degree in marketing and retailing, his teacher discovered that Mr. Settel was the author of the textbook for the course.

title: Dining Out; APPLE PIE? NO, CANTALOUPE (sic) PIE
description: THE Walpack Inn, nestled in the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, stands in the most pastoral setting imaginable. Tiny Walpack Center, in the northwest corner of the state, is something of an artists' colony, and the area's scenic beauty has long attracted painters and tourists alike.

title: On the Isle; CAN YOU CANOE?
description: This is the week when telling someone to go paddle his canoe may be quite the thing to do - if he, or she, likes to wield a competitive paddle, that is. Today from 9:30 A.M. to 3 P.M., the seventh annual Freeport Great Canoe Races will be held. The ideal vantage points for landlubbers will be from the foot of Woodcleft Avenue or Waterfront Park at the foot of South Long Beach Road. For registration information and fees, call 378-7402.

title: Essay; TEN YEARS LATER
description: Washington - Ten years ago this week, I was hustled aboard Marine One, the Presidential helicopter, to a secret rendezvous at the Catoctin Mountain retreat named after Richard Nixon's son-in-law.

title: ZAIRE ARMY GUARDS KEY KINSHASA SITES
description: Soldiers took up positions in central Kinshasa today, establishing an unusual, but low-key presence around the post office, the radio station and the palace of President Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: About Long Island
description: JONES BEACH THEY had never been backstage in a theater before. This was not Broadway. Still, the name of the show was ''Damn Yankees,'' and there was something like a Playbill, and drinks were served in plastic containers.

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC The Specials, a seven-man group from Coventry, England, created quite a stir when they first visited these shores early in 1980 as leading exponents of the British ska revival. Ska is a brand of Jamaican popular music that hit its stride in the mid-60's and has an irresistible, pumping dance beat, and many listeners dismissed the Specials as mere revivalists.

title: Film View; LOTSA LAUGHS--SOME INTENDED
description: It's not been a bad season for comedy, especially if one's gigglethreshold is not too high. But even if it is, there are three firstrate comedies available, which is unusual at any time of year. In addition, there are comedies that are tolerable or that depend on one's unreasonable but not disgraceful predisposition to find the star and/or the situation funny, whether or not they are. Plus, there are at least two movies that didn't start out to be funny but, what with one thing and another, became funny in spite of themselves.

title: REDISTRICTING, OR HOW 'I DIED'
description: HARTFORD REPRESENTATIVE Arthur A. Brouillet, a freshman Democrat from Hartford, got the news the night before the General Assembly convened in special session to approve a reapportionment plan for state legislative districts.

title: COE WINS 800 IN LONDON
description: Sebastian Coe overcame a painful blistered left foot today to win the British Amateur Athletic Association 800-meter run at the Crystal Palace.

title: Guy Morgan Sousa Marries Jan Hart on Coast
description: Jan Elyse Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Hart of Lafayette, Calif., was married there yesterday to Guy Morgan Sousa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Sousa of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. James Little performed the ceremony at the Lafayette-Orinda Presbyterian Church.

title: SOUTH AFRICA HOLDS 5 SUSPECTS IN DEATH OF NEW YORK LAWYER
description: Five men have been arrested as suspects in the murder last month of an American tourist, ending an intensive manhunt, a police spokesman said today.

title: Theater in Review; CAVORTING THROUGH THE LAND OF FABLES
description: LINDENHURST THE show they're doing at Studio Theater may not exactly be ''Paul Sills' Story Theater,'' as it was known on Broadway in 1970, but it is Studio Theater's ''Story Theater,'' and it works out just fine on its own agreeable terms.

title: STAKES HIGH IN REDISTRICITING RIFT
description: HARTFORD THE task of trying to redraw Connecticut's six Congressional districts, which now will be taken on by a nine-member commission, has become a high-stakes political struggle with national as well as statewide implications.

title: HARLEM GROUP AND TENANTS GET CITY BUILDINGS
description: In a brief City Hall ceremony designed to underscore the scope of the city's housing efforts in Harlem, Mayor Koch last week turned over the deeds of three apartment buildings the city owns there to tenants and a community group.

title: Winifred Mary Clark Wed To John Trant Curry 3d
description: Winifred Mary Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Paul Clark of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Trant Curry 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Curry Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. James P. Clark, an uncle of the bride, and Msgr.

title: Index; August 9, 1981
description: Mary Cantwell 6 On Language Parlor Parlance Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Tales for Cats Hedrick Smith 12 Taking Charge of Congress In six months, President Reagan has made a dramatic change in the political dynamics of Capitol Hill and has accomplished a radical shift in American economic policy. Michael Norman 22 The Rise of Gerry Cooney By knocking out Ken Norton in just 54 seconds, Gerry Cooney has become one of the most highly touted heavyweights since Muhammad Ali - and potentially the most highly paid ever. Craig Claiborne 38 Food with Pierre Franey Variations on Omelets 40 Fashion Snipped-Off Sweaters Marilyn Bethany 42 Design Home Boutiques Jane Ogle 46 Beauty Facing Up to the Heat 51 Puzzles Answers, Page 31 54 Letters Cover: Illustration by Robert Grossman Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Headliners; No Two-Bit Crook
description: Last April, in what was said to have been the largest bank robbery in the history of the United States, three men stole $3.3 million from the First National Bank of Tucson in Phoenix, Ariz. Two of the suspects got away; one didn't.

title: Dolphins 20, Vikings 6
description: Two Miami rookies, Brad Wright and Tommy Vigorito, combined on a five-yard scoring pass, and the cornerback Ed Taylor returned an interception 28 yards for a touchdown.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: DESPITE its dependence on the automobile, New Jersey has generally had a pretty good highway-safety record, but that record may be tarnished this year by an increase in traffic fatalities with a strange concentration in the southeast corner of the state.

title: WHEN NOMINEES COME TO CALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslav Courts Imprison 21 In Kosovo Nationalist Riots
description: Twenty-one university teachers and students were sentenced to prison terms in connection with nationalist riots by Albanians in the southern province of Kosovo earlier this year, the Yugoslav press agency said today.

title: NEW LINES OFTEN PUZZLE VOTER
description: FOR the voter who may be assigned new representatives in Hartford and Washington and for the politician who may inherit several thousand new constituents, reapportionment can be a confusing experience. It can also cause practical problems.

title: NO SIGNAL HERE FOR A SLOWDOWN
description: As worries about another recession mount, economists are focusing on a basic economic statistic - initial claims for unemployment insurance -for early signs of further weakness.

title: Cutbacks Challenged By Social Worker
description: As a professional social worker in both the public and private sector, I was quite concerned about the issues raised in the article about future cuts and priorities in county social-service programs (''Assessing Social Aid Priorities,'' July 5).

title: A MISSED OPPORTUNITY FOR A 5-MINUTE STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Plainfield's Mayor Sees Silver-Lined Cloud
description: The article on July 12 regarding Plainfield, the new Reagan budget and our utilization of Federal funds over the years was well-intended and generally accurate. Unfortunately, its thrust went in the wrong direction.

title: NELSON'S 202 LEADS P.G.A. BY 4
description: In the four tournaments Larry Nelson has won, he led going into the last round. So when the placid Georgian shot 66 today for a four-stroke lead after the third round of the Professional Golfers' Association Championship, the opposition had little reason to expect Nelson to falter.

title: FEATHERS FLY IN A WEEHAWKEN DISPUTE
description: WEEHAWKEN THE Democratic and Republican members of this township's governing body, who don't often agree, are doing so these days on at least one thing: This Hudson River community of 13,000 people, they all concede, is in deep trouble.

title: NURSES CITE HEAT AT LICENSE TESTING
description: PROMPTED by a number of complaints from student nurses who took their professional exam during a blistering heat wave early last month, state officials say they will renew their search for an airconditioned test site. Noting their limited budget, however, they are offering no guarantee of change.

title: Streater Ends His Stay In Rehabilitation Center
description: Steve Streater, the former University of North Carolina football star, ended his two-month stay at Charlotte Rehabilition Center yesterday and returned to his home in Sylva. Streater was paralyzed in an April 30 auto accident.

title: New Purported Will Is Found In the Howard Hughes Case
description: Another purported will of the late Howard R. Hughes has turned up, but lawyers in the probate case were quick to term it a hoax, it was reported today.

title: THIRD AVENUE DEVELOPING A DISTINCTIVE SIGNATURE
description: The Third Avenue Elevated has long since vanished, as have Third Avenue's cobblestones and bishop's crook lampposts. As the girded clutter was cleared, the saloons, shops and tenements that thrived under the El's trestles and web-like shadows gave way in the late 1950's to rectilinear office towers in midtown, many with little architectural distinction.

title: Diana Ritchie to Be Married
description: Diana Ritchie, assistant director of the Wheelwright Museum of the American Indian, in Santa Fe. N.M., and Jarratt Applewhite, a realestate and financial consultant in Santa Fe, plan to be married Sept. 19.

title: CASTRO, IN MEXICO TALKS, ACCEPTS U.S. REBUFF
description: President Fidel Castro of Cuba today wound up two days of private talks with President Jose Lopez Portillo in which he reluctantly accepted that his presence at a North-South summit conference here in October would result in its cancellation.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: SO REMORSELESS A HAVOC Of Dolphins, Whales and Men. By Robert McNally. Illustrated. 268 pp.. Boston: Little, Brown. $13.95.

title: YOUNG DEMOCRATS SHIFT TO THE RIGHT AT PARLEY
description: For an organization long known for its liberal stance, the Young Democrats of America made a distinct turn to the right when it emerged from its biennial convention with 29 resolutions that showed a spirited, if uncertain, determination to regain political power.

title: Dining Out; A BIT OF CALIFORNIA COMES EAST
description: En Brochette at the Hedges House in East Hampton is the East Coast branch of En Brochette in Beverly Hills. The Hamptons have played host to an increasing number of Manhattan restaurants, but this is the first time that dining California style has been attemped here.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 14 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, 2 2 18 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 3 7 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood. 4 4 9 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 5 6 2 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 6 5 4 THE CLOWNS OF GOD, by Morris West. (Morrow, $14.95.) What happens when the Pope has a revelation that the end of the world is near and the Cardinals force him to abdicate. 7 13 7 THE CARDINAL SINS, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Bernard Geis, $12.95.)

title: Index; Controllers' Strike
description: Strikers find fault with control- tower procedures 22 Study points to personality fac- tors in clash with F.A.A. 23 International South African rugby tour causes dispute in Commonwealth 3 Crowds flock to view royal gifts 4 Around the World 5 Saudi Arabia bids U.S. change its Middle East policy 6 Sadat suggests all nations urge Is- rael and the P.L.O. to negotiate 7 Fijians bring new fighting style to Mideast 8 Protests in U.S. over professor's death irritate Taipei 9 France optimistic Iran will free its citizens 10 Zairean soldiers guard key places in central Kinshasa 11 Poles find new freedom does not mean shorter lines for food 12 South African police arrest sus- pects in killing of American 14 Castro winds up talks with Mexi- can leader 15 Government/Politics Soviet envory denied right to travel to peace march 25 Young Democrats end convention with shift to the right 27 Judge protects jobs of some non- whites working for Boston 28 Hartford postpones talks on tax repeal plan 45 General Around the Nation 20 Closing of Schlitz brewery in Mil- waukee is blow to city 20 Retarded boy taken away from parents who opposed surgery 21 Traces of bubonic plague found near Reagan ranch 25 Woman said to have dual person- ality is aquitted of murder 25 Torah thefts to be combated by computerized registry 36 Harlem community group and tenants get city buildings 43 Member of fraud ring given 14- year prison term 44 Chicago suburb battles a day- care plan 46 Education/Welfare Bar unit reconsiders ban on Oral Roberts school 29 Arts/Entertainment Dance program by Karen Attix and Virginia Matthews 49 Beaux Arts Trio performs in Olympian manner 49 Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall 49 Style Resort fashions keep loose, longer look 50

title: Art; SOMEWHAT ENTICING LOOK AT CORPORATE ARCHITECTURE
description: WHITE PLAINS THE exhibition ''Building for Tomorrow,'' at the Museum Gallery of the White Plains Library through Sept. 9, can be taken at face value - as a celebration of the construction boom in Westchester and the corporate prosperity it bespeaks. And, by many visitors, it probably will be, for it is hard to dodge the enthusiasm projected by these architectural models and drawings and the promotional material accompanying them, all supplied, naturally, by the principals involved.

title: THE PRESIDENT, THE CONGRESS AND THE ARTS--CAN THEY LIVE TOGETHER IN HAPPINESS
description: President Reagan alarmed the arts community last Feb. 18 when he announced before a joint session of Congress that Federal aid to the arts and humanities would have to suffer severe cutbacks - at least as great as the cutbacks he was proposing for a host of other social programs. For example, instead of boosting the budget for the National Endowment for the Humanities to $176 million as had been proposed by President Carter, Mr. Reagan wanted Congress to chop that grant by $85 million. The Arts Endowment would be similarly dealth with.

title: Footnotes
description: Although there are no new titles on the hardcover fiction list, there are two runners-up. Clive Cussler's ''Night Probe!'' concerns a secret 1914 treaty between the United States and England; the only two copies have gone to the bottom in a sea disaster.

title: Miss Johnson And Anaylst Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hallett Johnson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Glendinning Johnson, to Donald A. Gooding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Gooding of Natick, Mass.

title: Herbert Smith Marries Barbara Jean De Laney
description: At St. George's by the River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J., yesterday Barbara Jean De Laney and Herbert Cortelyou Smith, graduates of the University of Denver, were marrried by the Rev. Alexander A. Aiton.

title: Reading and Writing; HOUSES
description: Right now there's a run of books on houses. Some of these are nostalgic, and others are ambivalent. In the first category are books about English country houses, American Victorian houses, the historic houses of our cities and houses that are being torn down or restored. The second category includes books like Louise Bogan's autobiography, ''Journey Around My Room,'' novels like Marilynne Robinson's ''Housekeeping'' and Nancy Hayfield's ''Cleaning House,'' sociological studies like Delores Hayden's ''The Grand Domestic Revolution: A History of Feminist Designs for American Houses, Neighborhoods and Cities'' and the late Jane Davison's ''The Fall of a Doll's House.''

title: No Headline
description: The author of the letter regarding Marc Leepson's review of ''Nam'' and ''Everything We Had'' (May 17) was incorrectly identified in the July 5 issue of The Book Review. The letter was written by Harvey J. Schwartz, M.D.

title: No-Guilt Cereal
description: To help relieve the guilt feelings some parents have in buying heavily sugared dry cereals for their children, the Quaker Oats Company offered a compromise in 1979: Halfsies, ''the first children's cereal with half the sugar of most sugar-coated cereals.''

title: GAME PARLORS FACE CURBS
description: LYNBROOK TO a great many young people on the Island, video game parlors have become the most exciting attraction since rock and roll, but a group of adult residents in this village regard them as a public nuisance and would like to have them banned.

title: KEEPING THE WILDERNESS WILD
description: NOT too many hikers and backpackers tackle the entire 2,050-mile distance of the Appalachian Trail, but among the 150 who are expected to do so this year is 21-year-old Greg Gage of Englewood.

title: A MISSED OPPORTUNITY FOR A 5-MINUTE STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPPLIER COUNTERSUING LILCO
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. THE Long Island Lighting Company's New Mexico uranium supplier says that the New York utility has illegally conspired with other creditors to force the ailing uranium company into involuntary bankruptcy, and it is asking $1.7 billion in damages.

title: CHILDREN IN NEED: NEW APPROACH
description: BELLEVILLE IN THE shadow of the Essex County Geriatric Center, 16 boys and girls play in the dirt next to their home, the county's Center for Abused and Abandoned Children.

title: The World in Summary; Not a Good Week For Coup Plotters
description: In the third world, where coups d'etat are often the only available means of changing occupants of the presidential palace, the kingmaker's objective is to move in without getting hurt. Not easily attained, rebels found last week in Bolivia and in the small West African country of Gambia.

title: DeBartolo Considering Rockingham Park Deal
description: Edward J. DeBartolo Sr., the Youngstown, Ohio, entrepreneur, will decide within a week if he will pursue plans to rebuild the burned out Rockingham Park race track, according to a spokesman for his corporation.

title: Article 225063 -- No Title
description: After pushing through the most far-reaching changes in government spending since Franklin Roosevelt, President Reagan has flown to California for a month-long holiday. As Mr. Reagan basks in triumph, his next step is likely to be much less palatable to him.

title: The Region in Summary; Goldin Emerges With a Clean But Cloudy Slate
description: For 30 months the City Investigation Commissioner inquired into the propriety of City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's request for a campaign contribution from a seeker after city business. The Commissioner, Stanley N. Lupkin, reported last week that he had found no evidence of wrongdoing on Mr. Goldin's part.

title: EAST END TOWER TO BE RAZED
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH THE Bellringer Tower, an East End landmark that was first loathed and then loved, will be demolished this month to clear the five-acre site for condominiums.

title: KEEPERS OF THE LIGHT: A PLEASANT DUTY
description: THEIR quarters have been battered by waves and jolted by lightning. But the keepers of the New London Ledge Lighthouse, the last manned lighthouse off the Connecticut-New York shore, say that, although theirs is a lonely job, it is generally a pleasant one.

title: U.S. JUDGE SAVES POLICE JOBS FOR 83 NONWHITES IN BOSTON
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the city of Boston to protect its black and Hispanic police officer and firefighters against a major round of layoffs planned by Mayor Kevin H. White.

title: THE 'COMING' COLLAPSE IS ALREADY HERE
description: E VERY week the real estate sections of Sunday papers and Realtors' multiple listing books announce major economic news that should shock or excite millions of Americans. But no one is listening or reading between the lines. After 35 years of ever increasing home values, prices are coming down, and they are falling fast and far enough to bruise a lot of homeowners.

title: TAKING CHARGE OF CONGRESS
description: Hedrick Smith is The Times's chief Washington correspondent. By Hedrick Smith ASPEN LODGE, CAMP DAVID, MD. - It had been raining most of the morning two Sundays ago when President Reagan came out of his personal lodge at the Presidential hideaway in the Catoctin Mountains to greet 15 Democratic Congressmen. He had invited them up for lunch and a bit of lobbying. As luck would have it, the sun came out, gleaming over the wet foliage, a few minutes before the cars arrived. The President, in cowboy boots, brown slacks and a beige, Westernstyle shirt, stood on his doorstep to shake hands with each Congressman personally. For half an hour they all swapped small talk over coffee, orange juice, and Bloody Marys on the flagstone patio overlooking a rustic country-club setting of terraced gardens, a swimming pool and nearby woods. Then the President walked them to Laurel Lodge where his chefs had set out a buffet of hot dogs, hamburgers, potato salad, chili beans and fresh corn.

title: Dance View; TIBETAN DANCES BLEND SPIRITUALITY AND EXPRESSIVITY
description: As the dance season draws to a close, it is impossible not to mention the little-publicized but greatly-appreciated visit of 16 Tibetan monks who stopped by New York to perform some ritual dances amid travels in this country with their leader, the Dalai Lama.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY, THE POOR AND PRESIDENT REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques; IDYLLIC SETTINGS NEAR THE DELAWARE FOR GOOD COLLECTING
description: TITUSVILLE LITTLE more than a mile south of the bridge at Washington Crossing, on the side of Route 29 away from the Delaware River, you'll see a small antiques sign beside a stone building.

title: Ellen F. Cary, G.C.F. Bearn Will Be Wed
description: Ellen Frederick Cary and Gordon C.F. Bearn, cum laude graduates of Williams College, plan to be married in North Stonington, Conn., Sept. 12.

title: Art; REALISM AT THE ROBESON GALLERY
description: NEWARK NOW that art has become so important a part of life for so many people, it may be time to remove some of its educational ''braces.'' This thought occurred during a visit to the realist show in the Robeson Gallery at Rutgers, Newark (which runs through Sept. 25).

title: DUPONT GETS THE MARBLES
description: Du Pont last week won the titanic battle for Conoco, the nation's ninth largest oil company.

title: Brain Drain
description: To the Business Editor: In the United States there is an estimated shortage of 2,000 faculty university members in technological subjects alone and a shortage of engineers is expected to run through the 80's. As rightly pointed in your article, ''Foreigners Snap Up the High-Tech Jobs'' (July 5), foreigners are not replacing Americans, but only filling in a small way the increasing shortage of technical personnel.

title: Long Island Journal
description: IN the latest go-around in the sex-discrimination suit filed by the Nassau County branch of the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of two golfers, Muriel and Bernard Greenfield, against the Village of Lawrence, tempers are aroused and petitions have been circulated in support of the village policy.

title: WHEN BIRDS COME HOME TO ROOST
description: PERCHED on the highest point of a telephone cable overlooking my 70-by-100-foot Levittown estate, a lone mourning dove (Zenaidure macroura carolinensis) wakes me at 6 A.M. with his interminable cooing, which varies from ''Coo-oo-a-coo-o-o-o'' to a more definitive ''Croo oh-croo croo.'' The saddest call I've ever heard, the mourning dove's lament may be due to either his melancholy disposition or to his seemingly vain vocal advertisements for a mate.

title: The Nation in Summary; Chicago Schools Deeper in Red
description: In the ''city that works,'' many things haven't lately, including the schools, whose opening may be delayed by a growing deficit. The budget squeeze, which forced Chicago's schools to close temporarily in 1979 and 1980, has reached a $74.5 million deficit, despite $120 million in cuts last year.

title: WHAT TO DO ABOUT PUBLIC ENEMY NUMBER 1?
description: ON Aug. 17 or soon thereafter, the Attorney General's Task Force on Violent Crime is due to submit its recommendations. Last week, after four months of hearings in six cities around the country, the panel issued its preliminary suggestions on how the criminal justice system should be changed to help law enforcement agencies more easily combat violent crime. As expected, the task force, which is headed by former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell and Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois, proposed a number of ways to facilitate prosecution, including elimination of bail in certain cases, curtailment of habeas corpus, modification of the rules of evidence in criminal proceedings and elimination of the insanity defense.

title: FARMLANDS PLAN, AT CROSSROADS, FACES KEY VOTE
description: Suffolk County's trend-setting Farmlands appears to have reached a crucial stage as the County Legislature prepares to vote on a measure to appropriate additional funds. If the Program is to proceed, the county must spend more money and must also continue to win the confidence of farmers and preservationists.

title: Atomic Language
description: To the Editor:

title: REMEMBERING HARRY CHAPIN
description: The loss of Harry Chapin is sharply felt by many around me. So I was gratified to read Tom Downey's excellent piece ("The Unsung Harry Chapin, July 26), where he reminds us of some of Mr. Chapin's more endearing aspects and tells us of efforts and exploits that attest to Mr. Chapin's devotion to his community. Sim Swan Southold

title: Leslie Hornig Bride of David Kleeman
description: Leslie Elizabeth Hornig, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald F. Hornig of Cambridge, Mass., and Little Compton, R.I., was married in Cambridge yesterday to David Woolpy Kleeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Kleeman of Washington. The Rev. Charles A. Baldwin, chaplain at Brown University, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Harvard University's Cronkhite Graduate Center.

title: FRANCE OPTIMISTIC IRAN WILL FREE ITS CITIZENS
description: The French Government said today that it was ''cautiously optimistic'' that the authorities in Teheran would allow French citizens to leave Iran on Monday.

title: WHEN CHICKEN IS CHEAPER, IT'S LEAN TIMES FOR BEEF PROFITS
description: On a wall of the National Cattlemen's Association office in Denver hangs a bumper sticker urging: SUPPORT BEEF - RUN OVER A CHICKEN! Facetious, of course, but the slogan reflects a new disquiet among America's cattle ranchers and cattle feeders as they struggle to survive in one of the most expensive and risky of farm industries.

title: PARENTS BAR SURGERY AND LOSE SON'S CUSTODY
description: A 14-year-old retarded boy has been taken from parents who refused to let him have an operation to extend his life and has been given to the custody of a couple who came to know him through their volunteer work with the retarded.

title: STAMFORD LANDMARK IS BEING DEMOLISHED
description: A familiar marker was missing last week in Stamford: the bright electric Hotel Roger Smith sign that stood as a reliable landmark for seamen in Long Island Sound for 53 years.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE A major dance series each summer is the ''Out-of-Towners'' season now in progress under Dance Theater Workshop's auspices at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street.

title: Georgiana Bulfinch Silk Wed to Lawrence Liggett
description: Georgiana Bulfinch Silk and Lawrence Irving Liggett were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Silk in Westport, Conn.

title: Radio 'Cold War'
description: On the edge of the frozen Beaufort Sea in Canada's remote Northwest Territories, radio station CFCT in Tuktoyaktuk was in financial hot water last May.

title: MEALS ON WHEELS NORUISHES BOTH BODY AND SOUL
description: Every weekday at noon, Hertha Fischer sits down in an easy chair in her living room to wait, listening for sounds in a hallway that has more plaster patches than paint.

title: The Nation in Summary; No State's Rights On Nuclear Waste
description: As the nation's pile of radioactive waste has grown, so has debate over how to dispose of it. So far, the answer has been ''anywhere but here,'' as state governments from Maine to Washington have tried to ban the burial of nuclear waste and refuse their neighbors' radioactive rubbish.

title: A HIGHER THRESHOLD OF PAIN OVER JOBLESSNESS?
description: From 1980 through 1983, if the Administration's reckoning is on the mark, unemployment will be at its highest since World War II except for the peak that followed the 1973-75 recession. The monthly figure once had the power to change political fortunes, but today it seems no more than a routine measure of the strength or weakness of the economy, a bland listing of the millions of Americans out of work.

title: CONDOMANIA: GOOD OR BAD?
description: ''CONDOMANIA!'' is the anguished cry of apartment renters in New Jersey and across the nation. They are referring to the increasingly accelerated pace of converting existing rental apartments to condominium or cooperative ownership.

title: ENAMAL WORK IN NEW FORMS
description: BROOKFIELD ''ENAMELS 50/80'' is the title of an exhibition on view at the Brookfield Craft Center until Aug. 30. The show embraces a wide variety of objects, many of them beautiful, some quite undistinguished, but all of them together make it clear that American enamel makers have enormously extended the traditional bounds of their craft.

title: J.L. Cobbs Weds Kathryn Wixon
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Swarthmore, Pa., yesterday Kathryn Ann Wixon and John Lewis Cobbs, who received Ph.D. degrees from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, were married by the Rev. Warren Skipp.

title: SARATOGA SALES: PROSPERITY AND MURMERS OF PROTEST
description: line cable snapped near a barn housing some of the young horses. The fallen cable dangled perilously close to stacked bales of hay, spitting white sparks onto an asphalt pavement only a yard away.

title: THE CUISINART EQUATION
description: You absolutely do not need to spend $200 or more on a Cuisinart.

title: LUXURIATING IN THE TRANQUILITY OF LUGANO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- HELEN LAWRENSON counts 70 American and British publications in which her work has appeared. She is the author of five books, and lives in New York City.

title: PANAMA WITHOUT CAESAR
description: In October 1968, the Guardia Nacional, Panama's sole armed force, deposed the country's last popularly elected President and took over. A minor figure in this action was Maj. Omar Torrijos Herrera. There followed a struggle for supremacy among the officers. Major Torrijos emerged. He did not seem to crave power very deeply, yet one by one he shipped opponents out. He had the gift of inspiring personal trust and a knack for playing forces against each other. He was a great deal smarter than he appeared. Major Torrijos promoted himself to brigadier general and became chief of Government.

title: FREDDIE PRINZE FAMILY AGREES TO SETTLEMENT WITH DOCTORS
description: The family of Freddie Prinze, the actor, whose death in 1977 was ruled a suicide, has agreed to a partial settlement of $950,000 in wrongful death and malpractice suits filed against two doctors.

title: Complaints Increase About Airport Noise
description: The Aircraft Noise and Safety Committee of the Town of Hempstead, L.I., which usually receives five to 10 complaints a day, said it got 125 during the first three days of the air controllers' walkout.

title: NEW ISSUE DESIGNED TO COMBAT ALCHOLISM
description: Alcohol has been a pleasure to drink and a problem to mankind since the beginnings of ancient civilization. Alcoholism is a disease, until recently a hidden and unrecognized disease.

title: The He-Man Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Finger Lakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridget M. Collett Engaged
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Bridget Mary Collett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Collett of Rickmansworth, England, to James D. Blackburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. J.V. Blackburn of Rochester. The wedding will take place on Oct. 3 in Southwold, England.

title: ON-AIR PSYCHOLOGISTS--HEALERS OR EXPLOITERS?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barbara Graustark is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the arts. By BARBARA GRAUSTARK

title: Illegal Trafficking in Rare Reptiles
description: SOME 100,000 venomous and nonvenomous snakes are shipped alive and illegally throughout the United States mails each year, according to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, and the Interior Department has just completed an 18-month investigation of illegal trafficking involving live snakes and live turtles.

title: DETERMINING THE WHY OF WARFARE
description: I wish to excerpt from comment a line from the address delivered by John H. Marburger 3d on his inauguration as president of the State University at Stony Brook (Opinion Page): "We do not understand human societies, or what motivates them to war..."

title: TAIPEI IRRITATED BY PROTESTS IN U.S.
description: Protests in the United States over the violent death here of a Taiwanese professor who taught at an American university have deeply irritated the Government of Nationalist China.

title: BEGIN RAISES A SECULAR STORM FOR A CRUCIAL POLITICAL EDGE
description: ''We never had a coalition so close to changing our country from a state of law to a state of religious law,'' Yediot Ahronot, a newspaper that has sometimes championed Prime Minister Menachem Begin's hard-line views, said last week. As Mr. Begin presented his new Cabinet to President Yitzhak Navon, many liberal and secular Israelis were indignant.

title: Conrail Executive Speaks Back
description: I want to respond to the article by Lorraine Pirro, in the Westchester section of The Times (''For Rail Commuters, Time to Speak,'' June 28), because, as new chairman of the Yonkers Rail Commuters Council, it is important that she and the commuters she represents know the facts and understand what we are trying to do as responsible operators of the commuter rail system.

title: A PITCHER MAKES HER MARK
description: STRATFORD KATHY ARENDSEN vividly remembers the first time she saw Joan Joyce, the legendary softball pitcher for the Raybestos Brakettes and, later, the Connecticut Falcons. ''I was 12 years old and had gone to see the Brakettes play in Lansing, Mich., not far from my home in Zeeland,'' Miss Arendsen said the other day. ''I couldn't believe how fast she was and what she could do with the ball. After that, she was always my idol.''

title: PESSIMISM LESSENS AT 'REPORTER'
description: THERE is less pessimism these days about the financial position of New Jersey Reporter, according to Thomas M. O'Neill, editor of the award-winning monthly since 1976.

title: Looting Reported in Sichuan After Region's Huge Floods
description: Looting followed recent floods in the southwestern Chinese province of Sichuan, a provincial newspaper reported.

title: 2 Gabon Jets Crash in Jungle
description: Two fighter jets of Gabon's Air Force crashed in almost impenetrable jungle east of here, the military commander said today. He added that rescuers were still trying to reach the site of the crash, which occured Wednesday on a training flight.

title: The Nation in Summary; Drug Snares In Florida
description: ''Cocaine cowboys'' and their sidekicks have also been running into tough posses. In June, a special Federal task force uncovered a nationwide ring of cocaine smugglers centered in New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The aim of Solidarity, as I see it, in bitter disappointment of my hopes of establishing a partnership, is not participation in joint responsibility of getting Poland out of the crisis, but deepening the crisis.'' - Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski. (1:5.)

title: ON THE FARM, THE MUSCOOT GANG REIGNS
description: SOMERS BEING a member of the Muscoot Gang has its hazards. The pigs chew their shoes, the ram considers them easy targets and Tinker the Shetland pony has been known to bite. Chewed, butted and bitten, the Muscoot Gang also takes countless licks and nuzzles in stride as they work on Muscoot Farm.

title: Kuwait Accepts OPEC Call
description: Sheik Ali al-Khalifa al-Sabah, the Oil Minister, said today that Kuwait had agreed in principle to attend a special meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to discuss the present glut in the world market. The meeting, for which a date and site are yet to be fixed, has been called by Nigeria, the country most affected by the glut, caused by excess production by Saudi Arabia.

title: CAREY SIGNS A 4-BILL DRUNKEN DRIVING PACKAGE
description: Governor Carey announced today that he had signed a series of bills to toughen the state's laws against drunken driving. One would require mandatory jail sentences for certain offenses.

title: Deirdre Guernsey Plans to Be Wed To T.C. Woodhull
description: The engagement of Deirdre Kent Guernsey to Timothy Corbin Woodhull has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Guernsey of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Kent Habor, Edgartown, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Woodhull 2d of Richmond and Chappaquiddick, Mass.

title: 7-2 Prismatical Wins Alabama
description: The 3-year-old filly division has more championship candidates this year than in any recent season, and today's 101st running of the usually definitive $110,000-added Alabama Stakes at Saratoga race track produced a new leading contender.

title: CITY SPENDING POWER
description: The Sun Belt states may be at the forefront of the nation's economic future, but the Northeast still has a large share of the most affluent markets.

title: KAREN BESCHERER ,STUDENT, FIANCEE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Bescherer Jr. of Wilton, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Karen Elizabeth Bescherere, to Christopher Paul Fisher, son of Lieut. COl. Thomas Fisher, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Fisher of Fort Collins, Colo.

title: Study Calls Block Grants To the Poor Effective
description: Reserchers in a four-year study by the University of Pennsylvania of block grants to poor city dwellers have reported that the programs are working.

title: About Westchester
description: YONKERS IT is 8 o'clock on a Monday night, and the teen-agers in the room are engaged in some ordinary activities for people their age - watching television, talking on the phone, gossiping about boys and dates and parents. There is, however, a major difference between them and the average adolescent: here, each youngster is attached to a dialysis machine that takes the place of his or her malfunctioning kidneys by filtering waste products from the blood.

title: Television Week
description: By the Numbers A young woman unwittingly joins the Army and winds up in all kinds of comic hijinks. Sound reminiscent of ''Private Benjamin,'' the situation-comedy CBS got on the home screen last spring almost before the Goldie Hawn feature film of the same name had finished playing neighborhood movie houses? Well, perhaps.

title: FOR BALTIMORE, A HIGH TIDE OF SUCCESS
description: This city, the one once called ''Washington's Brooklyn,'' the one still seen by passing motorists as only a tunnel on Interstate 95, continued its sassy, classy social climbing today by opening the country's newest and assertedly most exotic aquarium.

title: Lora Elderkin Fleming Wed
description: Lora Elderkin Fleming, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. T. Corwin Fleming of Boston, was married there yesterday in Trinity Episcopal Church to Clifford Gunther Walters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Walters Jr. of Cummaquid, Mass. The Rev. Edward Miller performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. David Myers. The couple are attending Harvard University, where the bride is a student at the Medical School and Mr. Walters is at the School of Dental Medicine.

title: AN AUDIENCE WITH MR. EXXON
description: T HE scene is an executive dining room on the 53d, and top, floor of the Exxon Building. Down the hall is the rolltop desk of John D. Rockefeller, the patriarch. Out the broad window, looking north, the view is Manhattan, then Connecticut, and in a real sense, the entire globe.

title: EMERGENCY NUCLEAR PLANNING: WHO IS RESPONSIBLE?
description: THE primary responsibility of government is to protect its citizens. This responsibility resounds with clarity when a public emergency occurs. In its October 1979 report, the President's Commission on the Accident at Three Mile Island found that the response of Pennyslvania and Federal officials to that radiological emergency ''was dominated by an atmosphere of almost total confusion.''

title: FINGER LAKES
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling on Yacht Acadia Late
description: The United States Yacht Racing Union is not expected to announce its verdict surrounding the reasons for the handicap irregularities of the yacht Acadia until the end of the month, according to Tom Ehman, the union's executive director.

title: NATION'S WATER IS BOUNTIFUL, BUT SUPPLIES ARE SQUANDERED;
description: Despite repeated water shortages reported from around the nation, experts believe America is endowed with bountiful water supplies that should be adequate to support the nation for generations.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Politics; HIGH COURT: A BYRNE LEGACY
description: TRENTON WHETHER Governor Byrne's name remains on the Meadowlands Sports Arena remains to be seen, but there is no doubt he has left an imprint on the state's judiciary that will last at least for the rest of the century.

title: RUGBY DISPUTE SPLITS COMMONWEALTH
description: The issue of racism is again creating serious strains within the Commonwealth, that fragile but enduring association of countries that once made up the British Empire.

title: Stowaway Gets $1,000 Fine
description: A woman who stowed away in the baggage section of a passenger plane to ransack valuables was fined $1,000 and given a one-year suspended sentence yesterday. Katharine Louise Hargan, 20 years old, of Royal Oak, Mich., had pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to a misdemeanor charge of unlawfully boarding a Delta Air Lines flight June 6. Federal authorities granted her immunity from further prosecution, apparently because she agreed to testify against three men accused in the plot.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY, THE POOR AND PRESIDENT REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEKLONG REVOLT IN BOLIVIA IS ENDED
description: A weeklong rebellion by a group of military officers who refused to support the three-man military junta that assumed power in Bolivia this week ended today after the two sides reached a compromise agreement.

title: Rodgers Wins in Jersey
description: Bill Rodgers won the first Asbury Park 10-kilometer race in 29 minutes 11 seconds yesterday on a course through parts of three New Jersey shorefront towns - Asbury Park, Allenhurst and Deal. Rodgers, who a week earlier had won a marathon in Brazil in 2 hours 14 minutes 13 seconds, took the lead from Luis Ostolozaga after two and a half miles and won by more than 200 meters.

title: THE TAX LAW: TROUBLE FOR COLLECTIBLES
description: I NDIVIDUALS who have increasingly been placing investment-grade stamps, coins, diamonds, art works and other collectibles in their Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans will not be able to do so because of a little known clause in the Reagan Administration's new tax-cut bill.

title: U.S. EASES FLIGHT CURBS ON SMALL PLANES
description: The Federal Government relaxed restrictions on flights by small, privately owned aircraft today after concluding that the small planes would not unduly burden the staff filling in for air traffic controllers who went on strike last Monday.

title: APPEAL CONSIDERED IN SLAYING
description: year-old physician who was found guilty last week of murdering his wife, will be sentenced on Sept. 11 but his lawyer said he would appeal on grounds that might include the use of tainted evidence.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Empire Unbuilding
description: While the Education Department was suggesting the diminution of its regulatory authority, Education Secretary T..H. Bell evidently was prepared to go a lot further. In an option paper sent to the White House last week, Mr. Bell was reported to have suggested the abolition of the department, fulfilling a Reagan campaign promise to get the Government out of the education business as far as possible.

title: Will the Air War End Labor War?
description: The air traffic controllers' strike is almost a week old and most planes are still flying safely. President Reagan, if not yet victorious, appears way ahead in this contest.

title: U.S. Loses in Volleyball
description: The Japanese national volleyball team lost two of the first three games but won the final two to defeat the United States last night in Friendship Cup competition.

title: Camera; NEW BOOKS TO HELP IMPROVE PHOTOGRAPHIC SKILLS
description: For the photographer, summer is not only a time of feverish picturetaking activity, it is also the chance to read some new books on their favorite subject, so here are recent new volumes that can help readers to sharpen their picture-taking skills:

title: State Waste Plant Opposed
description: A group opposed to state plans to build a $100 million hazardous-waste disposal plant in the Cayuga County community of Sterling delivered 14,000 petition signatures to the state Capitol Friday, calling for a halt to the project. The group said most of the signatures were from residents who argue that the plant could further contaminate Lake Ontario.

title: The Nation in Summary; Breather Before Washington's Next Round
description: Washington, like Paris, is not an August city. So last week, after final passage of the President's $750 billion tax reduction - interrupted only briefly by mostly liberal Democratic ire over the $11.8 billion cut written in for the oil industry - Capitol Hill headed for holiday. President Reagan stayed merely a day more, long enough to stuff his briefcase.

title: Gabrielle Porter Becomes Bride of B.M. Dennison
description: Violet Gabrielle Rathbone Porter, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. H. Boone Porter of Pine Lake, Wis., and Cuttyhunk Island, Mass., was married yesterday to Barry Matthew Dennison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew A. Dennison of Taunton, Mass. Dr. Porter, assisted by the Rev. John D. Ward, perfomed the Episcopal ceremony in the Cuttyhunk Church.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Nijinsky's Illness Adler's Diagnosis
description: If there is no great genius without a touch of madness, it is equally true that more than a touch can lay waste what genius there is. Such was the case with Vaslav Nijinsky, the acclaimed Russian dancer whose career was cut short by schizophrenia in 1917.

title: BORROMEAN ISLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANCIENT ICE YIELDING SECRETS OF CLIMATE
description: An international team of scientists is reading, in six-foot cylinders of ice, the story of the snows that fell when Cro-Magnon artists were painting the images of prehistoric animals on the walls of French caves.

title: C.P. Tutschek, Executive, Marries Joanne A. Murphy
description: Joanne Arnett Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William Arnett of Cookeville, Tenn., was married yesterday to C. Philip Tutschek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tutschek of Palm Coast, Fla., and Glen Wild Lake, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rev. Christopher L. Webber at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: KENNY RODGERS IN A FRESH VEIN
description: It is rare that the mainstreams of country and black music intersect, but when they do the results can be volcanic. Elvis Presley's classic Sun records fused blues, country and rock and roll into a rockabilly style that is still very much alive. Ray Charles's 1962 album, ''Modern Sounds in Country and Western Music,'' which blended country tunes, pop arrangements and black gospel singing, was largely responsible for introducing black Southern vocal inflections to the white pop mainstream. A decade later, Gladys Knight & the Pips had a similar success singing contemporary country ballads. With Elvis Presley a rare exception, however, the most commercially successful country and soul fusions have usually involved black singers doing country material, rather than the reverse.
