title: THE BUDDY BOYS
description: When I used to talk to Marilyn Monroe on those Thursday nights over the six-foot bar at Bill Chan's Gold Coin, she once mentioned ''The Seven Year Itch.'' ''I have good friends like Sidney Skolsky, Earl Wilson, Humphrey Bogart and Billy Wilder,'' I recall her saying, ''but the nicest is Tom Ewell, gentle and kind and worried.'' And here is Miss Monroe's tribute to Jack Lemmon, for she added that it was a tossup when Billy Wilder, in 1954, chose Ewell over Lemmon for the lead. JACK GASNICK

title: The World in Summary; Panama Awaits a New Strongman
description: Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera will be remembered for the treaties ceding control of the Panama Canal to Panama in the year 2000, but in other respects, his political legacy is uncertain.

title: CHILDREN'S STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUDI CALLS FOR CHANGE IN U.S. MIDEAST POLICY
description: Saudi Arabia has called for a change in United States policy toward the Middle East, including abandonment of peace efforts growing out of the Camp David accords, the ending of ''unlimited'' aid to Israel and recognition of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: BAR UNIT REVIEWS ORAL ROBERTS BID
description: A committee of the American Bar Association, under pressure from a Federal judge in a lawsuit brought by Oral Roberts University, today began reconsidering the association's tentative denial of the university's application for accreditation of its two-year-old law school.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL 'articulated bus'
description: TONIGHT'S outdoor concert by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra on the athletic field of Westchester Community College, an event that is expected to draw an audience of thousands, began inauspiciously enough last summer with a phone call by Judy Matson, the county's cultural coordinator, to Albert Webster, the orchestra's executive vice president and managing director.

title: Recollections Of Willie Pep
description: To the Sports Editor: In the article on Sandy Saddler-Tony Santana (''Saddler, Ex-Champion, Finds a Fighter,'' The New York Times, July 21) Michael Katz wrote, ''At 24, Santana was too young to have seen Saddler's four classic battles with Willie Pep.''

title: A FISHING CAMP IN MAINE TURNS OUT A 'COMPLEAT ANGLER'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SCOTT BRINCKERHOFF is employed in public relations at a military electronics firm in Connecticut. By SCOTT BRINCKERHOFF

title: The Miserly Little Diesels
description: FOR many shoppers these days, new-car fever is going to subside quickly, giving way to acute sticker-shock, an affliction that may wind up as the most memorable automotive malady of the 1980's.

title: Telvision Week
description: More From Katie In June, ABC presented a Barbara Walters interview with Katharine Hepburn. On Tuesday at 10 P.M., additional footage from that interview will be shown on ''The Barbara Walters Summer Special,'' along with ''encores'' of talks Miss Walters had with Burt Reynolds and Paul Newman.

title: The Region in Summary; If Anyone Comes, They'll Be Ready
description: Although many believe Newark International Airport is overbuilt, officials of the Port Authority apparently prefer to look on it as underused. Having erected a pair of sleek terminals seven years ago as part of a $400 million building program, and now completing a third terminal as part of $200 million plan, the agency last week said it would undertake $100 million in new construction in its effort to lure passengers across the Hudson.

title: FLXIBLE BUSES, BACK A MONTH, REMOVED WITH A NEW DEFECT
description: Less than a month after the troubled Grumman Flxible buses began returning to New York City's streets, the Transit Authority has ordered them out of service because of a new defect.

title: COLLEGES HOLD LINE ON TUITION PAYMENTS
description: WHILE some of the nation's private colleges are requiring students to make tuition payments earlier this year, schools on the Island are not following suit. Instead, they are instituting flexible policies designed to assist students - many of whom are in financial-aid programs - in paying their bills.

title: Oil Gluts
description: To the Business Editor: Philip Verleger's, ''All Gluts Are Not Created Equal...'' (July 19), missed the point as a response to Daniel Yergin's article, ''Lulled to Sleep by the Oil Glut Mirage'' (June 28).

title: MASSACHUSETTS SCHOOLS HARD HIT BY TAX LIMIT
description: When public school students here return to the classroom next month, they will find that many of their favorite teachers have been dismissed, six of the system's 57 buildings have been closed, most varsity sports have been eliminated and scarcely enough supplies will be available for courses in such subjects as industrial arts and home economics.

title: FICTIONS OF CLASS
description: GOOD BEHAVIOUR By Molly Keane. 245 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. A SUMMER IN THE TWENTIES By Peter Dickinson. 254 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $10.95.

title: HOUSING ILLS UNDER FEDERAL REVIEW
description: Like a patient stretched out on a table, the nation's ailing housing industry will get a comprehensive checkup this summer and fall from a variety of Federal policymakers, including two Congressional panels and a commission appointed by President Reagan last month.

title: PEKING OPERA--QUINTESSENTIAL THEATER
description: Splice Laurence Olivier with Mikhail Baryshnikov, expect Beverly Sills to be capable of a double somersault, and you have an idea of the combination of skills and sensibilities required for the Peking Opera Company (Ch'i Style) that on Wednesday will open a run of 15 performances at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Bank Robber Gets 30 Years
description: A Federal district judge has sentenced Douglas Bruce Fenimore to 20 years in prison for his role in the nation's largest bank robbery, the theft of $3.3 million from a Tucson, Ariz., bank. Judge William Stuart also sentenced Mr. Fenimore, 34, to five-year terms for jewelry store robberies in Phoenix and the San Francisco area in which about $2 million was taken.

title: Packers 21, Cowboys 17
description: Lynn Dickey threw two first-half touchdown passes for Green Bay, which held off a Dallas rally for its first exhibition victory in two years.

title: THE CUISINART EQUATION
description: If David Bromley would purchase a knife, grater and food mill, he would have the manual equivalent of a Cuisinart (Letters, July 19, in response to ''Mastering the Mini Dumpling,'' by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, June 21). His problem seems to be a combination of self-pity and a basic lack of cooking skills, neither of which is of any concern to Mr. Claiborne or Mr. Franey. ROBERT BLINDER

title: Topics; Schooling
description: Newark's parents, teachers and business leaders think their school system, for all its problems, offers quite a challenge to a tough, progressive educator.

title: The Lively Arts; IN HIGH HEELS, COMEDY IS QUEEN
description: CASSANDRA DANZ was called the ''thespian'' of North Valley Stream High School in the 1960's. Today, she's a High-Heeled Woman. Symbolically, a high-heeled woman stands for allure - when she is not tripping over gratings. There is another contradiction. A woman who wants to be independent puts on high heels - and walks precariously, feeling a bit helpless.

title: FILM MAKERS TURN CAMERAS ON CADETS
description: GARRISON ON a recent midsummer day, the 1840 whitewashed Tuscan-styled carriage house, home of the award-winning Hudson River Film and Video Company, was alive with creative work.

title: Jellyfish in Jersey Retreating
description: Jellyfish, which have been worrying New Jersey bathers in the last three weeks, appear to be leaving the state's shores because of cooler water, officials say.

title: BRIDGEPORT LOOKS TO SHIFT IN STORES
description: A CLASSIC case in the natural ebb-and-flow of business enterprise in urban America will occur in downtown Bridgeport on Nov. 1. Gimbels, the original anchor store in the city's Lafayette Plaza, will have closed long before then, after 12 years in that prime location. But on that date, it will be succeeded by the D.M. Read Company, the 125-year old Connecticut department store chain. Read's Department Store will shutter its own, long-running store diagonally opposite at Broad and John Streets when it occupies the Gimbel site.

title: THE BIBLE AND THE LEFT
description: Weston, Mass. - The Moral Majority uses the Bible to justify increasing nuclear weapons arsenals, ignoring the poor, the sick and the elderly, opposing equal rights for women and wasting public lands and resources. We on the left who disagree seldom refer to the Bible or speak of the morality of our cause. We cannot, however, create a just society while allowing a minority to claim virtue, family, religion and the Judeo-Christian tradition as their own.

title: 5,000 March in Nagasaki To Protest Arms Race
description: More than 5,000 demonstrators demanding an end to the arms race marched today through this rebuilt city, which was destroyed by an atomic bomb 36 years ago.

title: 1981-II*
description: AS expected, major league baseball has decided to go bush and adopt the Shaughnessy playoff system, which has been a fixture in the minors for years and years. It figured, and if the split season invites some genteel cheating and refined goldbricking, the men who voted for it will blame the players.

title: Headliners; ROCKETMAN'S COMPLAINT
description: His lawyers, F. Lee Bailey among them, contend that because Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke had been granted immunity early on and had cooperated with his interrogators, he shouldn't be hauled up in court and required to account for those 13 unauthorized contacts with the Soviet Embassy that Government agents say he made.

title: Antiques; A BUMPER CROP OF SPECIALTY BOOKS
description: Serious collectors depend as much on books as on museum and gallery exhibitions to expand their understanding of the art and antiques that they seek. Fortunately, there are publishers of books on the decorative arts and collectibles who do not wait for the Labor Day-to-Christmas period, when most such books appear, to issue new works on specialty fields. This summer's crop includes several catalogues of major interest to collectors of Americana - folk art, postcards and the Arts and Crafts style, volumes chock full of detailed information about each of these areas and offering new insights for all but scholars on the subjects covered.

title: RECALLING LE CORBUSIER
description: I was surprised to see that in discussing the establishment of modern architecture, David Gebhard omitted any reference to Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: WILLIAMS SIGNS NET CONTRACT
description: Buck Williams, the top power forward in last June's college draft and the Nets' No. 1 draft choice, reached agreement with the club today on a six-year contract worth a reported $2.5 million.

title: A MISSIONARY'S LEGACY ON THE ARIZONA-SONORA BORDER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- TOM MILLER, the author of ''On the Border: Portraits of America's Southwestern Frontier,'' lives in Tucson. By TOM MILLER

title: Miss Steele Plans Bridal
description: Margaret Jane Steele and Douglas Graham Moore plan to be married at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn., Sept. 19.

title: Julie M. Jones Has Nuptials
description: Julie Marie Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hawkins Jones of Short Hills, N.J., and Quechee, Vt., was married in Short Hills yesterday to Rick Alan Hopkins, son of Gerald Malone Hopkins of New Carlisle, Ohio, and Mrs. Donald Rose of Lakeside Park, Ky. The Rev. Paul E. Gilbert performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Design; HOME BOUTIQUES
description: There was a time, not very long ago, when department-store shoppers seeking a fashion ensemble had to go from one department to another, making knotty taste decisions as they bought. Today, much of the space on department-store fashion floors is organized into separate boutiques, each offering a different point of view for the shopper content with choosing from among elements precoordinated by such fashion luminaries as Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren, Perry Ellis and Yves Saint Laurent.

title: WOLVES IN CHIC CLOTHING IS JUST ONE GARMENT DISTRICT PROBLEM
description: Like each new campaign to clean up Times Square, it is a rite of political passage: the declaration of war on the problems of the garment industry, New York's largest manufacturing employer. Late last month, New York police arrested 26 persons and charged them with operating a ring responsible for the theft of garments worth tens of millions of dollars.

title: K. E. Banks Jr. Weds Dr. Virginia N. Payne
description: Dr. Virginia Newell Payne and Kenneth Earl Banks Jr. were married yesterday in Cleveland. The Rev. Horace Ward performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: A NEW COMMODITY: BOAT SLIPS
description: ''IF it happens here,'' said one boat owner as he relaxed under a canopy on a recent Saturday afternoon, ''I'll just have to haul my boat to New Hampshire.''

title: Defending Mr. Agee
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region in Summary; Yonkers Rejects; A Helping Hand
description: Once again facing layoffs and bankruptcy, Yonkers found itself cast in the role of a beggar last week, but that didn't mean it couldn't be choosy.

title: Around the Garden
description: THIS WEEK: Watering will be important unless there is adequate rainfall soon. If there are no local restrictions, priorities are vegetable gardens, shrubs, particularly new broadleaved evergreens, flower borders, newly seeded or sodded lawns and fruit trees...Get rid of weeds...Cut herbs and roses in late mroning to dry for potpourri...Finish planning next spring's garden and mail bulb orders. FEEDING SHRUBS There is a slight change in the old order of feeding ornamentals, particularly broadleaved evergreens. Traditionally, spring was considered the best time to feed these handsome plants. The theory was that nutrients would be ready to support that early spurt of growth. A second rule followed: Avoid use of fertilizer at this time of year because late summer feeding stimulates growth which does not have time to mature before cold weather and is subject to winter injury.

title: Town Officials Termed Callous
description: Your article on the Pound Ridge group-home dispute (''Pound Ridge Group Home in Dispute,'' June 28), although very embarrassing to most residents, served a real purpose. After all the talk, the $20,000 in legal fees, and the outrage of the Town Board over the presence of a home for autistic children on Lower Shad Road, the truth is finally out: the Supervisor and the board are ''offended'' by such people, whose presence should not be ''inflicted'' on anyone. If they must live among us, it would be better to put them in a more remote location where the property values are not as ''considerable'' as those of the Lower Shad area. The alternative site they have chosen, as they voted to evict the six young people, is more ''suitable'' because it is larger and on a safer road.

title: PADDY CHAYEFSKY, 1923-1981
description: Paddy Chayefsky died on Saturday, Aug. 1, in the final act of a life as complex and colorful as anything he wrote, and in the middle of his return to the theater he viewed with love and anguish.

title: FOUR NOVELS
description: SONS OF EARTH By Richard Rhodes. 238 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $13.95. SHAME THE DEVIL By Philip Appleman. 152 pp. New York: Herbert Michelman/Crown Publishers. $10. MINOTAUR By Benjamin Tammuz. Translated by Kim Parfitt and Mildred Budny. 210 pp. New York: New American Library. $11.95. MORGANA'S FAULT By Susan Lukas. 200 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $10.95.

title: DEATH AND THE RED BRIGADES TAKE NO HOLIDAY
description: The cold-blooded killing by the Red Brigades last week of the brother of Patrizio Peci, the most prominent former terrorist turned police informer, was one of a series of events demonstrating that Italy's terrorists are still far from defeated. The killing could have a disastrous effect on future antiterrorist operations.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY, THE POOR AND PRESIDENT REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: TV View; WHEN NEWS GOES SHOW BIZ
description: Adashing young man is chasing down corruption. He slips undetected into a series of garish low-lit gambling parlors in midtown Manhattan, gets the goods in hushed conversations with fellow patrons, then dramatically confronts a tough-looking thug outside one of the parlors with the news that the jig is up.

title: Westchester Housing; CHANGE SWEEPS SUMMER COTTAGES
description: THE summer people who used to flock to cottages in northern Westchester don't do that anymore, and the one-room bungalows with screened porches have just about disappeared.

title: SECURITY AT WOMEN'S PRISON QUESTIONED
description: NIANTIC THE Correctional Center for Women at Niantic could be mistaken for a college campus. Just down the road from Rocky Neck State Park, a popular beach spot, the prison's 14 buildings are spread out over 900 acres.

title: Letters; Praise for Mr. Katz
description: To the Editor:

title: OPEC'S TRADING POWER
description: Although rising supplies and weakening demand for petroleum late last year cut into revenues somewhat, oil price increases in late 1979 and early 1980 pushed the trade surplus of oil exporting countries to record levels in 1980.

title: 88 Arrested in New Zealand In Protest on South Africans
description: The police arrested 88 anti-apartheid demonstrators today after they temporarily blocked the runway at the Wellington airport in protest at the tour by the South African national rugby team.

title: Megan Follansbee Engaged
description: The engagement of Megan Follansbee to Peyton Randolph Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo John Smith Jr. of Wilmington, N.C., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Follansbee Jr. of Pittsburgh. An October wedding is planned.

title: The World in Summary; France's Turn To Be the Devil
description: President Francois Mitterrand didn't need the hint. Even before Teheran Radio declared last week that ''the words 'Death to France' should be the slogan of all oppressed people,'' he advised all French citizens in Iran to come home fast and recalled his ambassador for consultations.

title: Own Labels Stressed At Scarsdale Boutique
description: The workroom is larger than the selling area at Tailor Boutique on Route 22 where Scarsdale meets Eastchester, a measure of Irene and George Gimesi's stress on women's clothing with their own label in competition with other designer or manufacturer labels in the retail area. Their earlier shops were in New York City and Ardsley and one personal touch is a memento on display - an autographed photograph of Bette Davis. Gimesi designs can be made to order with fabric they provide and many styles are available as ready-to-wear clothing in a variety of interesting shades.

title: LOWER MARKS FOR DEFENSE
description: The Reagan Administration, feeling sorely provoked, last week broke its vow to avoid public criticism of perceived military burden-shirking by allies. West Germany had announced defense spending cuts in its latest budget, a decision that ''can't be anything but a disappointment,'' Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said.

title: LATE PAYMENTS IN HOME LOANS AT HIGH LEVEL
description: One of an increasing number of single parents in New Jersey recently had to explain to her banker that the reason she was slipping behind in mortgage payments was that her former husband had not been coming through with the alimony he had agreed to pay.

title: A NINTH HUNGER STRIKER DIES IN ULSTER
description: A ninth Irish nationalist hunger striker died today in Maze Prison near Belfast as pessimism deepened further over the prospects for a solution to the five-month-old dispute.

title: THE POET YOUNG
description: EARLY AUDEN By Edward Mendelson. 407 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $20. By DENIS DONOGHUE

title: FRESH AIR FUND TRAINING COUNSELORS
description: Camp Pioneer has no official motto, but a T-shirt won by one of its counselors puts the feeling of the place across perfectly: ''It's hard to be humble when you're the best.''

title: AN ACT OF REMEMBRANCE
description: THE JOURNEYS OF DAVID TOBACK By David Toback. As Retold by his Granddaughter Carole Malkin. 216 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $10.95. By TED SOLOTAROFF

title: Good Samaritans
description: To the Editor:

title: Monetarism
description: To the Business Editor: Jude Wanniski's article, ''The Burden of Friedman's Monetarism'' (July 26), demonstrates his lack of understanding of basic monetarist concepts. He places the proverbial cart before the horse in assuming that monetarists demand a floating dollar.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; MORRIS WEST
description: ''The Clowns of God,'' No. 6 on this week's fiction best-seller list, is Morris West's 16th novel, another in a long line of big sellers from the Australian-born author, including ''Proteus,'' ''The Sala-mander,'' ''The Shoes of the Fisherman'' and ''The Devil's Advocate.'' Not a bad record for someone who spent almost 12 years in a Christian Brothers monastery and didn't think seriously about becoming a full-time writer until he was in his 40's.

title: THE QADDAFI CONNECTION
description: Mr. Hersh's account of the relationship of Frank Terpil and Edwin Wilson with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi makes me wonder how men with the connections they had could be so inept.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MUCH like the homeowner beaming over the repairs done to modernize the exterior of his home, the State Capitol Restoration and Preservation Commission is looking with considerable pride on the two-year, $8 million renovation just completed on the exterior of the 102-year-old building. Now the commission members are gearing to seek an initial $10 million to update the interior.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 IF THERE BE THORNS, by V.C. Andrews.

title: Theater; HE LOATHES VIOLENCE BUT LOVES A GOOD FIGHT
description: ''Splat! Bang! Whack!'' It was the stuff of Marvel comics, but the protagonists were Shakespearean actors, and the sounds were emanating from a slender, mercurial, 41-year-old mustachioed Englishman named B.H. Barry. As he has done some 500 times before, Mr. Barry was staging a fight.

title: Cardinals 12, Chargers 10
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Neil Lomax, St. Louis's rookie quarterback, directed two fourth-quarter drives that set up field goals by Neil O'Donoghue.

title: WARSAW PACT'S SOVIET COMMANDER HOLDS TALKS WITH POLISH PREMIER
description: The Soviet commander in chief of Warsaw Pact forces was reported today to have met here with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish Prime Minister, apparently in an effort to stiffen the Polish Government's resolve to deal with spreading protests over food shortages.

title: GOLD NEAR RETIREMENT, ASKS JUSTICE SYSTEM AID
description: New York City's criminal-justice system is being overwhelmed by the rising number of violent crimes and it urgently needs more resources and efficiency, according to Eugene Gold, who plans to step down at the end of the year after 13 years as Brooklyn District Attorney.

title: Gromyko Assails U.S.  For Pakistan Arms Deal
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko accused the United States today of destabilizing Asia by agreeing to sell arms to Pakistan and possibly to China.

title: And Still the Palestinians
description: Israel has a new government. President Sadat has a new friend in the White House. The Sinai desert has a new peacekeeping force. And the old problem persists: What to do about the Palestinians?

title: PROGRAM ASKS AIDES FOR ELDERLY
description: ELDERLY residents of Westchester nursing homes and adult-care facilities now have available to them receptive listeners and advocates in the volunteers who work in the Long Term Care Ombudsman Program. Initially developed in 1977 by New York State, the Westchester program is one link in a chain that extends to 11 counties.

title: State Units Said to Have A Three Mile Syndrome
description: After reading many reports concerning the possibility that New Jersey's ''Cancer Alley'' will run directly through Bridgewater Township in Somerset County, I am concerned that a Three Mile Island syndrome exists in our protective agencies.

title: Home Clinic; DRAWING A STRAIGHT LINE ON A FLAT SURFACE
description: WHEN any project calls for drawing a long straight line on a floor, wall or similar flat surface, a professional mechanic will use a chalk line. A chalk line can be as long as needed, being limited only by the length of the line used. When stretched tight, it enables you to ''draw'' a perfectly straight line. It is also the best way to insure a plumb, or truly vertical, line on walls when putting up shelf standards or built-ins and cabinets.

title: Music View; DO YOU SPEAK CLASSICAL OR POP?
description: The great blue-chip foundations must be hardpressed to keep up with the demands that grant supplicants make on them, especially in these days of governmental bearishness. However, the Ford Foundation, recognizing the pressures that our system exerts on any child who must learn English as a second language, recently invested a total of $571,227 in four separate studies aimed at examining the pros and cons of bilingual education. This is heartening news. Perhaps Ford can now be persuaded to consider the plight of another disadvantaged group that until now has been scandalously neglected: the American citizens of all ages whose only musical language is Classical. Thousands, perhaps even hundreds, of people in our society are forced to go through life speaking and understanding only this esoteric tongue while all around them their countrymen are chattering away knowledgeably in the dominant language, Pop.

title: PHIBRO'S NEW COMMODITY: MONEY
description: A LMOST up to the very moment last Monday when the announcement was made that the Phibro Corporation, a $26-billion-a-year commodity merchant, agreed to buy Salomon Brothers, the pending deal was probably the best kept secret on Wall Street - where secrets aren't kept.

title: At Home
description: DEAR SUPERMAN:

title: Elizabeth Harper Counihan Is Married
description: Elizabeth Harper Counihan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Counihan Jr. of Pawtucket and Narragansett, R.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Cirgenski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Cirgenski Jr. of Lambertville, Mich. The Rev. Richard Valentine performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Narragansett.

title: THE BUDDY BOYS
description: We fans of Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau must thank John Culhane for his insights and updating (''Jack Lemmon: Behind the Smile,'' July 12). But what an opportunity was missed in not discussing the unique Lemmon-Matthau chemistry, especially in anticipation of their forthcoming film, ''Buddy, Bud-dy.'' In recalling such Lemmon-Matthau collaborations of the past as ''The Fortune Cookie'' and ''The Odd Couple'' one might say that theirs is truly a buddy-buddy relationship.DON WIGAL

title: TOXIC SUBSTANCES TO BE AUCTIONED
description: DESPITE what some critics have called a plethora of state and Federal regulations governing the transport, use and disposal of hazardous chemicals, the Department of Defense regularly sells to the general public thousands of gallons of toxic substances at auctions, the way it does surplus jeeps.

title: W. T. Comstock Weds Ann Simon
description: Ann Frances Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Simon of Ambler, Pa., was married in Maple Glen, Pa., yesterday to William Thomas Comstock, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Comstock of Largo, Fla. The Rev. Andrew Robberecht performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church.

title: TEACHING & LEARNING
description: WHY JOHNNY STILL CAN'T READ A New Look at the Scandal of Our Schools. By Rudolf Flesch. 191 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.95. ON BEING A TEACHER By Jonathan Kozol. 177 pp. New York: Continuum. $12.95. MAKING SCHOOLS WORK A Reporter's Journey Through Some of America's Most Remarkable Classrooms. By Robert Benjamin. 200 pp. New York: Continuum. $12.95.

title: CHICAGO SUBURB BATTLES A DAY-CARE PLAN
description: A Wilmette woman's attempt to open a day stirred an uproar in this affluent Chicago suburb. When Nance Kirch, a 39-year-old social worker, applied for the ''special use

title: 2 PLANS TO BE AIRED ON RTE. 7 EXTENSION
description: CONSTRUCTION of ''Super 7,'' the long-standing proposal for an expressway to replace Route 7 between Norwalk and Danbury, may still be 20 to 30 years away, but that hasn't stopped the State Department of Transportation from inching ahead with plans for another new segment of the highway.

title: Art View; AN AMBITIOUS SHOWING OF MODERN ART; COLOGNE, West Germany
description: At the entrance to ''Westkunst,'' the ambitious survey of art of the Western world from 1939 to date (appearing here through Aug. 16) is John Chamberlain's elephantine ''Couch,'' a rambling, upholstered mound that serves as a kind of bed on which dozens of visitors are flopped at any given moment. Its unwieldiness might be a metaphor for the show itself, a sprawling colossus comprising over 800 works by more than 200 European and American artists.

title: The Region in Summary; Random Choice Avoids Quotas
description: He seldom wears one, but Mayor Koch seems increasingly adept at pulling things out of hats. Faced with a Federal court order under which applicants who passed the most recent police department examination might have to be hired under a racial quota system, Mr. Koch last week produced an alternative hiring plan that apparently was acceptable to nearly everyone concerned yet did not smack of quotas.

title: SADAT ASKS ALL NATIONS TO URGE ISRAEL- P.L.O. TALKS
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt called on all nations today to urge Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization to end their refusal to recognize each other and agree to negotiations ''to settle their problems without shooting out their grievances.''

title: Pro Football Notebook Broadcast Revenue Continues to Rise
description: Six of the National Football League's 43 remaining exhibition games will be televised nationally for relatively insignificant broadcast fees beginning next Saturday night with the Dallas Cowboys meeting the Los Angeles Rams at Anaheim, Calif. But these six contests amount to the tip of the iceberg as revenues from television and radio for 224 regular-season and nine postseason games will bring $6 million this year to each of the league's 28 teams.

title: AT HOME
description: DEAR SUPERMAN, Being Superman, you will instantly recall my letter of 1943, the one printed in all 32 colors of my new Crayola set. As soon as I grew up, I told you, I was going to be a much prettier and smarter reporter for The Daily Planet than Lois Lane. She was a nag when you were Clark Kent and did so many dumb things when you were Superman, I was sure you'd love me more. Who needed the Lone Ranger with his asthmatic horse when you, Superman, could leap tall buildings at a single bound all by yourself? Wait, I begged you. Wait for me.

title: Dining Out; SOUTHERN ITALY WITH A TWIST
description: bag half their main course) and open minds, for although the Italian menu may sound familiar, the owner and inventive chef, Tony Licari, not content with a traditional rendering of southern-influenced offerings, cooks fast and loose. Be prepared for surprises, some quite creditable.

title: Sunday Observer; TALES FOR CATS
description: My cat refuses to jog or diet and has no interest at all in tracking down Nazis. I mention this only to explain why I have become disgusted with best-selling cat books.

title: Beauty; FACING UP TO THE HEAT
description: Sitting on a beach, riding the subway, working in an office with inadequate air-conditioning or just crossing the street on blistering August days, one finds oneself up against the same sticky problem: how to keep cool in the face of all this heat.

title: TEACHERS LEARNING ABOUT INTERACTION
description: three traditional subjects that teachers have concerned themselves with over the years - are being joined these days by regard for a fourth subject - relationships.

title: U.S. IS FINDING THAT NO ONE WANTS TO ACCEPT LAST CUBAN REFUGEES
description: Federal officials say it is virtually impossible to find a community anywhere in the country that is willing to accept the final group of 720 Cuban refugees who emigrated to this country a year ago.

title: Television Week
description: Star Pupil To balletomanes, Nancy Raffa is special. A mere 16 years old, she has inspired dance critics to turn verbal cartwheels for some time now. In 1979, when she made her professional debut at Brooklyn College, her performance in a solo from ''La Bayadere'' was called ''sparkling'' and ''dazzling.'' She won a gold medal at the 1980 Prix de Lausanne competition. And last fall, when Natalia Makarova presented her newly assembled company at the Uris Theater, Miss Raffa was promoted from being a member of the corps to principal dancer within a week after the season opened. She was partnered by Fernando Bujones and Peter Schaufuss.

title: RECALLING LE CORBUSIER
description: One of the limited benefits of aging is reminiscence (''A Corbusier Portfolio,'' by David Gebhard, July 5). For me, there is the memory of a quiet dinner party in the mid-1930's at which Le Corbusier and I were guests.

title: WEATHER VANES MASTERED BY 2
description: SHARON ON John C. Stark's resume, following an outline of 35 years as a marine and industrial model maker and as a museum exhibition artist, is the information that Mr. Stark retired in 1976 to his own studio ''to develop and make whatever I please.''

title: CASINO AGENCY DEFENDS ITS PRIVATE MEETINGS
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission has met in private several times recently to discuss matters of ''internal operation,'' its acting chairman says. However, he asserted that the meetings did not violate the state's openmeetings law.

title: Heidi B. Parker Becomes a Bride
description: Heidi Boyd Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Parker of Francestown, N.H., was married yesterday to Russell K. Roeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Roeder Jr. of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Jean Curtis performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Gordon Chapel of the Old South Church in Boston.

title: Atomic Workers Ratify Pact
description: Workers on strike at a nuclear weapons plant and a Government research laboratory since June 19 ratified a new contract yesterday by a margin of almost 5 to 1. The agreement covering 4,400 workers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory and the Y-12 nuclear weapon components plant was reached Tuesday with the Union Carbide Corporation, which operates the plants under contract with the Federal Energy Department.

title: Leslie Bergman Bride Of Robert A. Savage
description: The marriage of Leslie Ann Bergman, a market research analyst with John Blair & Company in New York, to Robert A. Savage, a member of the International Paper Company's corporate auditing staff in New York, took place yesterday. The Rev. Douglas Verdin performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Westport, Conn.

title: A GREAT GOOD MAN
description: MATTHEW ARNOLD: A LIFE By Park Honan. Illustrated. 496 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill. $19.95

title: Gold Snatching
description: Gold had rocketed to $850 an ounce before easing back to between $600 and $700, and every woman who wore a gold chain in New York risked having it ripped from her neck a year ago at this time. As such thefts soared, especially in the subways by fleet-footed youths, the police set up mobile teams with decoys to make arrests.

title: Fathers' Rights Upheld In Custody Settlements
description: Your article ''Custody Goals Pursued'' (July 5) is a giant step forward in bringing to light a concern of a huge section of the population.

title: CAN A SUPERB ACTOR SUCCEED AS AN OPERA DIRECTOR?
description: Donald Gramm - for this month at least - is directing opera rather than singing in it. Mozart's ''The Marriage of Figaro'' at the Wolf Trap Festival in Virginia next Thursday and Saturday will be his directing debut, and he is cautiously enjoying the perquisites of his new-found authority and feeling the burdens of its responsibilities.

title: AGAINST SCIENTISM
description: ENDEAVORS IN PSYCHOLOGY Selections from the Personology of Henry A. Murray. Edited by Edwin S. Shneidman. 641 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $35. By JOSEPH ADELSON

title: WOOING WHEEL
description: To the Editor:

title: FLIGHTS IN CANADA REPORTED DELAYED AS CONTROLLERS THERE JOIN JOB ACTION
description: As support by foreign air controllers for their American counterparts spread yesterday, delays from the strike were reported for the first time to have affected flights in Canada.

title: Guilty Plea on Drugs Entered by Kiner's Son
description: The son of Hall of Famer Ralph Kiner pleaded guilty yesterday to possession of cocaine and selling marijuana to an undercover narcotics agent.

title: Editors' Choice
description: ETHNIC AMERICA, by Thomas Sowell. (Basic Books, $16.95.) A study of how ethnic groups have fared in America. IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER, by Italo Calvino.

title: FOR A VIDEO GAME, NUMBER WAS UP
description: Paul badly wanted the video game. First he thought he would save his allowance to buy it. But at a meager $1.50 a week, that would take two years. He knew he couldn't wait that long for his own "Night Driver." He had to have it. It was an obsession.

title: 'SUMMERFARE' FINALE
description: The Pepsico ''Summerfare'' offers a wide range of music, dance and drama today, as the national lively arts festival presents its grand finale weekend of entertainment at the State University College of New York at Purchase.

title: Raiders 17, Falcons 16
description: Arthur Whittington ran 41 yards for a touchdown late in the third period, completing an Oakland comeback that gave the Super Bowl champions the victory over Atlanta.

title: CONTROLLERS DISCOVER THE CEILING AFTER REAGAN HITS IT
description: WASHINGTON FOR such a momentous decision, President Reagan's dismissal of more than 12,000 striking air traffic controllers last week was made in an uncommonly speedy and relaxed way. Moreover, even when it became clear that Mr. Reagan's back-to-work order would require a rebuilding of the nation's system for guiding commercial flights, White House aides reported that there was no evidence of soulsearching or second-guessing on Mr. Reagan's part.

title: FINGER LAKES
description: To the Editor:

title: 4th Cuban Refugee Is Freed From Center by Court Order
description: A fourth Cuban refugee has been released from a detention center under a Federal court order.

title: Alison Stone to Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Cudlipp Stone of Martinsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Elizabeth Stone, to Eugene Francis Murphy, son of Mrs. Patrick J. Murphy of Milton, Mass., and the late Mr. Murphy. An October wedding is planned.

title: Royal Couple Quit Greek Isle; Due in Egypt Next Wednesday
description: The British royal yacht Britannia sailed from this Ionian island today after the Prince and Princess of Wales stayed here as part of their Mediterranean honeymoon, harbor authorities said.

title: Practical Traveler; HEALTH PROTECTION ON FOREIGN TRIPS
description: Thanks to medical science, travelers do not have to worry about illness in most parts of the world, but many hazards remain, particularly for those who go on ''nature'' or ''adventure'' tours to remote areas where disease is rampant. Reliable tour operators warn of health risks, take precautions in the acquisition and handling of food and drink and suggest measures to prevent illness. But sometimes travelers ignore warnings and take risks they never would accept at home.

title: Owners Checking Leaks in Gag Rule
description: The gag rule on baseball's club owners expired with the agreement that ended the strike, but its ramifications linger. The board of directors of the owners' player relations committee, it was learned yesterday, has hired a New York law firm to investigate complaints that some owners violated the rule that prohibited management people from making public comments that conflicted with the negotiating position of the committee's board.

title: IN LIFE, THE SPORTS SEASON GO ROUND AND ROUND
description: LOSSOMS fall, skin wrinkles, and the child becomes father to the man. According to Ecclesiastes, everything has a season, and I find this particularly true in the life of a man.

title: U.S. TAX CUTS MAY COST NEW YORK MILLIONS UNDER PRESENT STATE LAW
description: New York State stands to lose $100 million next fiscal year as a side effect of the Federal tax cut enacted by Congress last week, officials here say.

title: FOR POLES, NEW FREEDOMS DON'T BRING SHORT LINES
description: Some people say that if it weren't summer, with fine sunny weather, this city would already have exploded. Others say no, that the freedom Poles have wrested for themselves is so precious that it will temper the growing frustration and anger over the long food lines and the stores whose shelves seem emptier each day.

title: Gardening; SOME TIMELY DOS AND DON'TS
description: BY now, the outcome of this year's gardening efforts will have been pretty well determined. However, there are still a few dos and don'ts to keep in mind. Some tasks performed now will still be of benefit this season; others will affect winter hardiness or next year's performance.

title: Elizabeth Heyert Planning Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Heyert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Heyert, to Douglas Bedford Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Bedford Johnson of New York, where a Nov. 14 wedding is planned.

title: PLAGUE NEAR REAGAN RANCH
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, are taking ''routine precautions'' this month to avoid the possibility of contracting bubonic plague, traces of which were found recently in dead rats in the vicinity of the Reagans' ranch, White House officials said today.

title: TAX-HAVEN MINISTRIES GAIN ON L.I.
description: ''If the Government is going to give a free ride to Billy Graham, then why not let everybody participate in these blessings?'' - Kirby J. Hensley, president, Universal Life Church. By ELLEN MITCHELL HAUPPAUGE LONG ISLAND is proving fertile ground for a bumper crop of mailorder ministries. At least four chapters of the Universal Life Church are now actively and openly recruiting members here - all of them eager to use freedom of religion as a tax haven.

title: Mets Lose 2 Pitchers, 1 Game
description: The Mets today suffered their first serious poststrike casualties and a blow to their aspirations for success in the second half of the regular season when two pitchers emerged from the exhibition series with the Toronto Blue Jays with injuries.

title: FAIRFIELD WATCHING RISING TENNIS STAR
description: FAIRFIELD THIS Essex County community is taking increasing note these days of the achievements of Pamela Casale, a sturdy 17-year-old who shows signs of becoming one of the best women tennis players ever to emerge from New Jersey.

title: Heather Hirson To Be Fall Bride
description: Heather Ann Hirson, an assistant analyst in the research department of E.F. Hutton & Company in New York, will be married in October to Michael Raymond Long, a vice president of the commodity division of Shearson American Express Inc., formerly Shearson, Loeb, Rhoades Inc., a New York brokerage firm. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Miles W. Hirson of Rye, N.Y. Mr. Long is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Long of Columbia, S.C.

title: Stage View; PETER BROOK RETURNS TO CHEKHOV'S VISION; PARIS In his 38 years as a director, Peter Brook has often altered our way of looking at theater. His production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' banished the fairy dust encrusting the text and turned the play into a bright, white acrobatic carnival. With ''Marat/Sade,'' audience and actors were confined in the insane asylum at Charenton for an evening of revolutionary theater. His production of ''Timon of Athens'' in Paris turned Timon into the equivalent of a modern political exile, scuttering crablike into the desert. Last year at LaMama, Mr. Brook took us on a mystical journey to ancient Persia in the epic ''The Conference of the Birds.'' Working with both his international experimental company and the Royal Shakespeare Company, staging plays from Persepolis to Broadway, Mr. Brook has remained unpredictable. The range of his work is perhaps unmatched by that of any other contemporary di
description: After playing four months to capacity audiences at theater Bouffe du Nord, a somewhat derelict structure in a working-class district of Paris, ''The Cherry Orchard'' closed to make room for the director's next project, the opera ''Carmen,'' but it has been taped for French television and may return to the stage next year. An Englishlanguage production is a possibility. Those who were fortunate enough to see Mr. Brook's first ''Cherry Orchard,'' an audience that included in its final week the new prime minister, Francois Mitterrand, are unlikely to forget it.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 9, 1981
description: International Full production of neutron weapons was unexpectedly decided on by President Reagan at a White House meeting Thursday, Administration sources said. He ordered that the nuclear material tritium, which is now being bottled separately, be combinaed with the Lance missile and eight-inch artillery shells to make complete enhanced radiation weapons. These are designed to produce far more radiation and far less blast and heat than other tactical nuclear weapons and to kill people without severe damage to their surroundings. The President adopted the new weapons policy despite warnings that it would lead a storm of protests in Western Europe, the officials said. (Page 1, Column 6.) A top Soviet commander conferred in Warsaw with Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski, who is also Poland's Defense Minister. The visit by Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, the Soviet commander in chief of Warsaw Pact forces, coincided with a stepped-up press campaign in Moscow against the Polish trade union. The announcement said Marshal Kulikov and the Prime Minister had discussed ''current activities of the armed forces, including issues pertaining to the combat readiness of the Polish Army, which is a reliable link in the defense system of the Warsaw Pact.'' (1:4-5.)

title: GEORGIA GOVERNOR SAYS STATES NEED FEDERAL AID
description: Gov. George Busbee of Georgia, chairman of the National Governors Association, warned today that the association would firmly resist further turning over of Federal programs to state governments unless the Reagan Administration accompanied the transfer with adequate consultation and money.

title: INQUIRY PRESSED ON APPOINTMENT OF NEWARK AIDE
description: NEWARK IN the wake of an incident, caused by vandalism, that nearly left the state's largest city without water, a special grand jury will be convened next month to investigate allegations that an aged former Newark politician who is chief of security chief for the city's Pequannock Watershed did little or no work in his $24,255-a-year job.

title: Critics' Choices
description: PHOTOGRAPHY As an artist Frederick Sommer is essentially a surrealist, but his main influence on today's photography has been his ingenuity in formal matters. Few picture makers have fashioned careers from such a diversity of means: Sommer's oeuvre includes landscapes, collages, assemblages, abstract light studies, cliche verre prints, drawings and musical scores (the latter two being non-photographic).

title: JOBLESS RATE DIPS, CONFOUNDING THE FORECASTERS
description: The jobless rate fell to 7 percent in July from 7.3 percent in June. The drop, to the lowest point in 15 months, was unexpected, countering forecasts of a slowing economy. The Administration hailed the job increase but cautioned about drawing overly optimistic conclusions.

title: BRAZIL'S ARMS FIND WILLING BUYERS IN THE THIRD WORLD
description: SAO JOSE dos CAMPOS, Brazil - The little six-wheeled armored vehicle skittered across sand dunes, sluiced through a swamp and then belly-flopped into the sea. Four snorkel tubes snaked into the air, water sputtered aft into its wake and the squat olive-drab object plied its way past the breakers. A 90-millimeter cannon spun around on its turret, paused at 9 o'clock and fired a round.

title: John Kaercher Weds Mary Jennifer Wechter
description: The marriage of Mary Jennifer Wechter to John Robert Kaercher took place yesterday at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence McCall Horton performed the ceremony and the Rev. Edward J. Howley, a Roman Catholic priest, gave the blessing.

title: Crafts
description: ATLANTIC CITY AWOODEN pig on a bicycle, a car pool spilling from a satin limousine and a whittled baseball team surrounded by its fans will be on hand here today along with the chief executives of most of the 50 states for the 73d annual gathering of the National Governors Association.

title: COAST BIKERS RIDE TO STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD THREE brothers, making their first bicycle trip - one that began in their hometown of Seattle - arrived here last Saturday night, grimy and tired, yet exhilarated.

title: RECALLING LE CORBUSIER
description: If David Gebhard can classify Le Corbusier's ''early pristine cubes'' as symbolizing the machine, he should take this view further ''to observe, and finally perhaps to discover...'' that the ideal of the machine is the same as that for a building: perpetual motion in machinery equates to perpetual practicability in architecture and design.

title: Student Never Forgot Moynihan's Lessons
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, promised last month at a hearing of the Senate Water Resources Subcommittee that the Reagan Administration would soon turn its attention to formulating water policy. The hearing was enlivened by the opening statement of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and by Mr. Stockman's own opening remarks.

title: DANCE: KAREN ATTIX AND VIRGINIA MATTHEWS
description: Dance, they say, is a universal language. The Dance Theater Workshop's annual Out-of-Towners series, which presents dance from around the United States at the American Theater Laboratory, offers a chance each summer to test that theory. The series opened this year with a program, seen Friday, by the San Francisco-based Mattix Dance. The language is recognizable. But the reception from the West Coast seems poor.

title: BUSTER KEATON'S COMIC GENIUS ON DISPLAY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Harvey is coordinator of special film projects at these Museum of Modern Art's Department of Film. By STEPHEN HARVEY

title: Cleveland Transit Fare Rises
description: Mass transit fares in Cleveland, long among the nation's lowest, go up 50 percent tomorrow, with one-way train trips jumping to 75 cents. One-way local bus fares will go up to 60 cents from 40 cents.

title: Jeffrey Justus Keenan To Wed Claudia Magat
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Magat of Bronxville, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Juno Magat, to Jeffrey Justus Keenan, son of Robert Keenan of Chicago, and the late Nancy Keenan. The wedding is planned for September.

title: A MISSED OPPORTUNITY FOR A 5-MINUTE STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: AN APE TAKES A SWING AT 'TARZAN'
description: ''It's the oldest story in the world, I know,'' the star sighed. ''But that woman made a monkey out of me.'' The speaker was C.J. the orangutan, who co-stars with Bo Derek in ''Tarzan, the Ape Man.'' In a hotel suite decked out with gift baskets of bananas and potted palms, C.J. spoke ruefully about his experiences in making ''Tarzan'': the initial thrill of working with Miss Derek, the subsequent disappointments, and the heartbreak of watching what he had thought would be ''the role of a lifetime'' become ''barely a crawlon.''

title: Inquiry Due in Slaying Of Miners' Leader in '69
description: The Washington County authorities say they will open an inquiry next week into charges of perjury and deception in the 1969 slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski.

title: IN CONNECTICUT, MANY ARE RUNNING BUY FEW ARE CHOOSING
description: The two-room walkup above a children's clothing store that serves as headquarters for Citizens for Moffett is filled with the signs of a campaign. Telephone books are stacked on the floor, posters from past races adorn the walls and young workers sort through piles of mail.

title: 'GHOST HOSPITALS' PERSIST
description: CENTRAL ISLIP THE huge psychiatric hospital, looming on the horizon like a Gothic fortress, is an idea whose time has passed. Patients are no longer given ''life sentences,'' and state hospitals have unlocked most of their wards. But the shift from closed settings to outpatient treatment programs has thrown the three psychiatric centers on the Island - Central Islip, Kings Park and Pilgrim State - into confusion. Decentralization has emptied many buildings and created such anomalies as more staff members than patients.

title: Patricia Thomas Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah L. Thomas Jr. of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Conway Thomas, to Douglas Lewis Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene H. Brown of New York. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned. Miss Thomas is a commercial banking representative in the metropolitan division of the Bank of New York.

title: Hollis Stacy Leads by 2
description: Hollis Stacy overcame three bogeys on the back nine today and widened her lead to two strokes in the West Virginia Classic.

title: GENETIC COUNSELING IS MAKING STRIDES
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IN THE Cytogenetic Laboratory of Rutgers Medical School, in Middlesex General Hospital, a technician appeared to be cutting and pasting pictures of worms.

title: FIJIANS BRING NEW FIGHTING STYLE TO MIDEAST
description: The small but tough Fijian Army, blooded in Lebanon and now preparing for new peacekeeping duties in Sinai, has brought to the Middle East a style of fighting new to that arid area half a world away from the lush South Pacific islands.

title: Barbara Calahan Married To Edward J. Brown Jr.
description: At the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y., yesterday Barbara Calahan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Calahan of Chappaqua, N.Y., became the bride of Edward J. Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Little Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Charles Kavanagh, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Costumes and Masks Fit for a Ball
description: This week, Josi Russell and her son Robert will be in Cincinnati for a competition at the Costumers' Convention, recreating J.L. David's painting of Napoleon crowning Josephine. Mrs. Russell's tiara, gold and white dress with leg o' mutton sleeves and long red robe and her son's gold-trimmed white suit with red toga were easy to find. She and her son work with the 20,000 adult costumes in stock at the Costume Bazaar in New Haven, founded 20 years ago by Mrs. Russell's husband, Joey, and his brother Herman.

title: State vs. Dentist
description: In an exercise of eminent domain that Governor Carey would rather forget about today, New York State seized an acre on Shelter Island in November 1980 on which a dentist had started to build a home adjacent to the Governor's summer home. The state said the rising structure was a threat to the Governor's ''security.''

title: Cynthia Marione Wed To Kevin G. Wallach
description: Cynthia Ann Marione, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Marione of Wyckoff, N.J., was married there yesterday to Kevin Gibbons Wallach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Wallach of Elmhurst, Ill. The Revs.

title: DURAN BACK, BUT IS HE READY?
description: Roberto Duran comes back tomorrow. Presumably, his stomach cramps have disappeared; the question is whether his hunger has reappeared.

title: THE ART OF HORSE BREEDING
description: As a longtime horse lover and owner of a three-quarter-thoroughbred pleasure horse, I was delighted to see Steve Cady's article on the thoroughbred breeding industry (''The High-Stakes World of Horse Breeding,'' July 12). While computers can provide information on breeding and performance records, somehow I doubt that they will ever replace that combination of art, experience and intuition that produces the greatest horses. MELISSA S. WINEHOLT

title: U.S. AID CUTS TO RAISE RENT COSTS TO THE POOR
description: Federal cuts in housing aid will force poor families receiving Government subsidies to spend more of their personal income for rent, according to state and city housing officials in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: CROWDS FLOCK TO VIEW GIFTS TO ROYAL PAIR
description: From the stone portico of St. James's Palace this afternoon, a queue of people six abreast stretched down Marlborough Street and The Mall almost to Buckingham Palace, a 10-minute walk away. Even that horde paled in comparison to yesterday's assemblage, a 1 1/2-mile-long human pipeline that twisted back on itself twice and took up to five hours to endure.

title: Notes; TIPS FOR VACATION MOTORISTS
description: At the height of the summer travel season, those who are planning automobile trips would do well to consider a few suggestions that can make for safe and enjoyable driving and relieve worry about leaving a house unprotected. From the American Automobile Association comes the following advice:

title: Food; VARIATIONS ON OMLETS
description: henever we are asked to recommend a dish that can be made on the spur of the moment or one that can be hastily improvised, we almost invariably suggest an omelet. The reasons are simple: Because eggs figure largely in everyday cookery, nearly everyone has a few eggs in the refrigerator at any given moment. And omelets are conceivably the most versatile of any dish. There is almost no limit to the number of leftovers or raw foods that can be incorporated into an omelet; the filling depends on the imagination and inventiveness of the cook. One may saute leftover potatoes in a little butter to make a ''peasant'' omelet. Or one may use leftover tomato sauce, excess crumbled bacon or almost any raw vegetable to dress it up. Even leftover sandwich fillings, such as chicken or tuna in mayonnaise, make unexpected, tasty additions to the basic omelet.

title: Guatemalan Aide Resigns
description: Brig. Gen. Anibal Guevara Rodriguez, the Guatemalan Defense Minister, resigned today to clear the way for his nomination as a candidate for President in elections scheduled for next March. He is expected to be officially nominated in the next few days by a coalition of three right-wing parties.

title: Dave Allen Will Open One-Man Show Sept. 14
description: ''An Evening With Dave Allen,'' a one-man show with the British humorist, will begin a five-week engagement Sept. 14 at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. Mr. Allen is known for delivering witty commentary and monologues with an empty stool, a lighted cigarette and a glass as his only stage props.

title: Realty News; TIME, INC. UNIT SIGNS BIG LEASE
description: In a major expansion move, Home Box Office Inc., the pay cable television subsidiary of Time Inc., will become the sole office tenant at 1100 Avenue of the Americas, an existing building undergoing a total conversion into a modern 15-story office building on the northeast corner of 42d Street overlooking Bryant Park.

title: Speaking Personally; FOR MAMA, AS VAN GOGH WENT, SO WENT HER SON
description: MY MOTHER was never a great reader until my father died. Then she was left with a lot of time on her hands, and so she began investigating the 25-cent reprints of some of the best-sellers that were suddenly making their appearance alongside Zane Gray and Earl Derr Biggers on drugstore counters.

title: LEE KRASNER: BEYOND POLLOCK
description: SPRINGS EVEN now, 25 years after her husband's death, Lee Krasner bristles noticeably when she recalls being identified as ''Jackson Pollock's widow, an artist in her own right.'' Yet this strong, independent woman, who after years of standing in the shadow of her husband is finally gaining recognition as a leader among the Abstract Expressionists, has agreed to participate in ''Krasner/Pollock: A Working Relationship,'' an exhibition that opens today at East Hampton's Guild Hall. It pits Miss Krasner against Pollock by chronologically hanging their works side by side to show their interaction and growth in their years together.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WITH Congressional passage of the biggest tax cut in history following $37 billion in budget cuts, most of the Reagan economic recovery program is in place. The White House does not expect instant revitalizaton, however. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan last week said little effect would be felt until the fall of 1982, and, in a comment that appeared to signify a policy shift, said that the Federal Reserve Board will have to ease up on monetary restraint -though just a little - to avoid a severe recession.

title: Pope in 'Good' Condition; To Go Home in a Week
description: Despite a lingering fever, Pope John Paul II is recovering well from abdominal surgery and will leave the hospital in about a week, his doctors said today.

title: SEAS: TO WASTE OR NOT
description: Most laws on waste disposal protect the ocean at the expense of the land. Some scientists, including oceanographers such as myself, would like to see the ocean lose its preferential status and be treated as just another piece of the ecosystem -neither more nor less sacred than land or air. We would like to see a dispassionate, reasoned study of our waste disposal options and to see the proper choices made on scientific grounds rather than the currently legislated solutions that seem to lack justification.

title: Photography View; SHOULD PHOTOGRAPHY GALLERIES EXHIBIT PAINTINGS?
description: ''The Last Edward Weston Show'' is a title designed to shock even the most casual observer of photography. Weston was, after all, the great modernist photographer - his hard-edged, detailed close-ups of vegetables and the nude revolutionized the medium in the late 1920's and early 30's - and for an exhibition to claim to be his last is incontestably presumptive. Why, then, would the Witkin Gallery choose such a title for its current exhibition (41 East 57th Street, through Aug. 21)?

title: HAMBLETONIAN TO SHIAWAY ST. PAT
description: Shiaway St. Pat became the winner today of the first Hambletonian held at Meadowlands, but it took a fourth race to decide the outcome.

title: GOSSAGE SHOULDER AILING
description: Rich Gossage, who said his shoulder throbbed ''like a toothache'' after one inning on the mound on Friday, will be replaced in tonight's All-Star Game by Ron Davis and will probably not be available when the Yankees resume regular-season play tomorrow night.

title: DINERS CHANGE IN CHANGING WORLD
description: NEW ROCHELLE KNOWN as the Queen City of the Sound, New Rochelle has a long and noble history. But for the hash slinger who shouts, ''Clean up the kitchen with repeaters,'' which in layman's language means ordering a hamburger with a side dish of baked beans, New Rochelle signifies something special. It was here, in the early 1900's, that Pop Tierney manufactured some of the first diners. It remains the only city in New York State where these traditionally American eateries continue to be produced.

title: BOYS FROM BRADENTON COME TO TOWN
description: SINCE he was 6 years old, Bruce Morrison has been a Yankee fan. His uncle, Lenny Guerriero, who was like a father to him, used to take him from Staten Island to Yankee Stadium, where they cheered for Mantle and Murcer and Jackson.

title: The Nation in Summary; Another Scam Finds Its Mark
description: Carlos Marcello, long suspected by law enforcement officials as the chief of mob operations all along the Gulf Coast, once mistook a Federal agent for a newspaper reporter and slugged him. It cost him five months in prison.

title: Bridge; RECOLLECTIONS OF CULBERTSON'S SLAM-BIDDING
description: Half a century ago, for the first and last time, a bridge book headed the list of non-fiction best-sellers. It was Ely Culbertson's ''Blue Book'' on bidding, and right from its initial appearance in l930 it was in constant demand, going through 85 printings in two years.

title: The World in Summary; Sadat Presses Reagan to Talk With Palestinians
description: Ronald Reagan was ''a willing listener,'' but Anwar el-Sadat didn't make a sale when he arrived at the White House last week with a pitch for the Palestine Liberation Organization. The Egyptian President urged the United States to build on the cease-fire it had arranged (through intermediaries) with the Palestinians on Israel's Lebanese flank by bringing the P.L.O. into negotiations on autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza.

title: ISLAND AIDES DRIVE ON 'ALIEN INSECTS'
description: WHEN insects enter this country from other lands, they are considered illegal aliens. Unless they are discovered and eradicated promptly, troubles often follow because these insects have no natural enemies here to keep them in check.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Young publisher. A teen-ager who goes into business for himself and makes a go of it is a rare bird in any industry, particularly in the chancy game that is book publishing. Several years ago, we reported the case of Marc A. Michaud of West Warwick, R.I., who was a junior in high school when he came across some uncollected pieces by a writer whose work he greatly admired, the fantasist H.P. Lovecraft (1890-1937). Marc borrowed some money from his father, a machinist, and set up the Necronomicon Press to publish them in book form. The edition sold out fast to members of the Lovecraft cult, and he was soon able to repay the loan.

title: BIG COLLEGES DEFY N.C.A.A. OVER TV
description: The College Football Association moved closer to a direct confrontation with the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday when Chuck Neinas, the C.F.A.'s executive director, signed a four-year, $180 million television contract with NBC Sports. The move also could result in a split with the N.C.A.A.

title: HAM INJURED
description: Cliff Stoudt, who has spent his five National Football League years in the shadow of Terry Bradshaw, took advantage of the exhibition-game spotlight by scoring two touchdowns and throwing for three more in leading the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 35-31 victory over the Cleveland Browns tonight.

title: AIRLINES ESTABLISH SCHEDULES AT 75% OF NORMAL LEVEL
description: The nation's airlines have established new schedules providing for about three-quarters of the flights that were available before the air controllers' strike. The schedules are expected to remain in effect through Labor Day, airline officials said yesterday.

title: ... BUT GOOD NEWS ON CAPITAL GAINS
description: O NE of the most dramatic changes in the new tax law is the sharp reduction in the maximum tax rate on capital gains, which has been slashed to 20 percent from 28 percent. Although the cut on profits from the sale of appreciated assets - anything from securities and closely held businesses, to the family home - is only 8 percentage points in absolute terms, it represents an effective rate reduction of almost 29 percent.

title: THE ART OF HORSE BREEDING
description: Why is it necessary for Steve Cady to put down standardbred horses in his article on thoroughbreds? Harness horses are no more ''mixed breed'' than thoroughbreds that descend from English runners, Arabians and God knows what else.

title: Speaking Personally; THE WAITING GAME, PLAYED IN EARNEST
description: THEY told her she was a displaced homemaker and seemed generally glad to see her. They were young women whose salaries depended on a displaced homemaker grant. So in a way she was good news to them.

title: A TIME TO WRITE FOR THE E.R.A.
description: IT is frustrating to be a New York State resident in favor of the proposed equal rights amendment. We want the amendment; so, according to public-opinion polls, do the majority of the American people. Yet we cannot directly bring about the adoption of this measure. That is up to a handful of legislators in a few states, mostly in the Southern part of the country.

title: AT LONG LAST, ALL-STARS
description: CLEVELAND POSTPONED twice by the seven-week baseball strike, beset by the air-traffic controllers' strike, crowded by a football game between the Cleveland Browns and Pittsburgh Steelers, surrounded by the return of Ro-berto Duran to the prize ring and even by conventions of nurses, bridge players and locomotive engineers, the 52d All-Star Game will finally be staged here tonight with 60 possibly rusty stars and 75,000 decidedly curious fans.

title: Fashion; SNIPPED-OFF SWEATERS
description: A reason to look forward to chillier days is what promises to be one of the fall's most eye-catching items: the woolly sweater dress that stops well above the knee. Worn with knit leggings or opaque, ribbed stockings and flat-heeled boots or shoes, thigh-high sweater dresses such as these are fun for fashion watchers as well as warm and cozy for young women with good- looking legs.

title: HOW TO BE GOOD
description: THE PHILOSOPHY OF MORAL DEVELOPMENT Moral Stages and the Idea of Justice. Volume One. Essays on Moral Development. By Lawrence Kohlberg. 441 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $21.95.

title: Miss Ziegler Wed To F.T. Barrows
description: Susan Glenn Ziegler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander Ziegler of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Frederic Thomas Barrows, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin H. Barrows of Cincinnati. The Rev. Claude L. Peters performed the ceremony at the Talmadge Hill Community Church.

title: REAGAN ORDERS PRODUCTION OF 2 TYPES OF NEUTRON ARMS FOR STOCKPILING IN THE U.S.
description: At a White House meeting on Thursday, President Reagan decided to go forward with the full production of neutron weapons in the face of warnings that the surprise move would lead to a storm of protest in Western Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS, CUSTOM-MADE
description: The decennial gerrymandering festival is in full swing, as state legislatures go about protecting their friends and sometimes their parties, often using computers to justify their election-district mapmaking.

title: Children's Books
description: THE STORIES JULIAN TELLS By Ann Cameron. Illustrated by Ann Strugnell. 71 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $7.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By NATALIE BABBITT

title: The Region; WHILE OTHERS STUDY CAREY'S PROSPECTS, SO DOES HE
description: If Governor Carey runs best as an underdog, as his aides and advisers have often held, he should conduct quite a campaign if he decides to seek re-election next year. His apparent vulnerability has potential challengers, Republicans and fellow Democrats alike, assessing their chances with new fervor.

title: OLD LYME EXHIBITS VOORHEES
description: OLD LYME FOR many years, Impressionism has had for Americans an almost fatal fascination, especially, it seems, in the summer. One supposes it must be the flowers, but why it should be that painted flowers should find favor precisely during the season that they are widely available outdoors is something of a puzzle.

title: Baseball Notebook Valenzuela, Morris Get Starting Roles
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the rookie star of the Los Angeles Dodgers, and the veteran Jack Morris of the Detroit Tigers were named yesterday as the starting pitchers for tonight's All-Star Game in Cleveland.

title: SOUTHOLD PONDERS LAUREL LAKE SAFETY
description: WHEN the Southold Town Highway Department put up a guard rail across the dirt road that leads to Laurel Lake in mid-July, the rail was yanked up and tossed aside within hours.

title: BOARD KEEPS UTILITY PLAN OFF FALL BALLOT
description: TWO years ago, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello was the major proponent of Proposition 1, the referendum that would have established a county utility agency to distribute electricity. It was rejected, 55 percent to 45 percent, with many voters apparently concerned about the possible $754 million to $1.3 billion cost of acquiring or constructing distribution facilities.

title: WINTER BRIDAL SET FOR FERN MORGAN
description: David E. Morgan of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Fern Lisa Morgan, to Charles John Lindsay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Joseph Lindsay of Weston, Conn. A winter wedding is planned.

title: FLATTER DEDUCTION FOR THE GOLD WATCH HANDSHAKE
description: WASHINGTON An obscure addition to the new tax bill which does nothing more than increase a business deduction by $300 is being hailed in certain Congressional and business circles as a most effective way of meeting the vision of increased productivity set forth by the Reagan Administration.

title: STRIKERS CRITICAL OF TOWER PRACTICES
description: John Guida sat in his car in a parking lot at Kennedy International Airport yesterday and listened to his battery-powered radios, each tuned to a different frequency. He said he did not like what he heard.

title: GUN INDUSTRY'S ROLE IS SHRINKING
description: NEW HAVEN THE gun manufacturing business, the bedrock on which Connecticut's prowess as a supplier of everything from machine tools to jet engines was built, is showing signs of old age.

title: The Borromean Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbara Duffy Bride Of Edward M. Korry
description: Barbara Jane Duffy, daughter of Lieut. Comdr. Joseph Albert Duffy, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Duffy of Westerly, R.I., was married in Misquamicut, R.I., yesterday to Edward Miller Korry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Korry of Stonington, Conn. Msgr.

title: FOR SOLIDARITY LEADERS TOO, IT'S A TIME OF RISKY CHOICES
description: Poland's capital, already the liveliest in Eastern Europe, was offered three days of political street theater last week as the Solidarity union and Communist leaders squared off, but once again did not fight.

title: A FINAL ACCOUNTING OF THE DEATH AND DESTRUCTION
description: HIROSHIMA AND NAGASAKI The Physical, Medical, and Social Effects of the Atomic Bombings. By the Committee for the Compilation of Materials on Damage Caused by the Atomic Bombs in Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Translated by Eisei Ishikawa and David L. Swain. Illustrated. 706 pp. New York: Basic Books. $37.50.

title: Freedom Awards Returned
description: Freedom awards that were presented to two Argentine women by the Rothko Chapel but seized by their government when the women returned home last month have been returned, officials said yesterday. The women, Maria Adela Gard de Antokoletz and Hebbe de Bonafini, are members of a group protesting the disappearance of family members taken away by government officials. Several senators had written to President Roberto Viola of Argentina protesting the confiscation.

title: Miss Jaeger Wins; Clerc to Meet Lendl
description: Andrea Jaeger, playing a steady and patient game from the baseline, routed Virginia Ruzici of Rumania today, 6-1, 6-0, to win the United States Open Clay Court women's championship, her first major victory as a professional.

title: IZVESTIA CONDEMS POLISH UNION
description: The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia tonight condemned the wave of protests over food shortages in Poland and said they were playing into the hands of enemies of the Communist state.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LITTLE ROCK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DAVID R. PALMER is a business and financial writer for The Arkansas Gazette in Little Rock. By DAVID R.PALMER

title: TO CREATE MORE HOUSING, SIMPLIFY
description: NEVER in the world of housing has there been so little to satisfy the demands of so many. Yet houses don't have to remain unbuilt in record numbers, and Americans with below-average incomes don't have to reconcile themselves to a houseless future.

title: Jeralyn Ann Seiling a Bride
description: At St. Sylvester's Roman Catholic Church in Concord, S.I., yesterday Jeralyn Ann Seiling and Todd Elliott Thompson, students at the Boalt Hall School of Law of the University of California at Berkeley, were married by Msgr. Daniel Sullivan. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Glen Seiling of Emerson Hill, S.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thompson of Peru, Ind.

title: Table of Contents
description: August 9, 1981 NONFICTION CIVIL WARS. By June Jordan. 8 EARLY AUDEN. By Edward Mendelson. 8 ENDEAVORS IN PSYCHOLOGY: Selections from the Personology of Henry A. Murray. Edited by Edwin S. Shneidman. 10 HIROSHIMA AND NAGASAKI: The Physical, Medical, and Social Effects of the Atomic Bombings. By the Committee for the Compilation of Materials on Damage Caused by the Atomic Bombs in Hiroshima and Nagasaki. 1 THE JOURNEYS OF DAVID TOBACK: As retold by his Granddaughter Carole Malkin. By David Toback. 7 MAKING SCHOOLS WORK: A Reporter's Journey Through Some of America's Most Remarkable Classrooms. By Robert Benjamin. 10 MATTHEW ARNOLD: A LIFE. By Park Honan. 9 ON BEING A TEACHER. By Jonathan Kozol. 10 THE PHILOSOPHY OF MORAL DEVELOPMENT: Moral Stages and the Idea of Justice. Volume One. By Lawrence Kohlberg. 11 SO REMORSELESS A HAVOC: Of Dolphins, Whales and Men. By Robert McNally. 14 SOCIETY, STATE, & SCHOOLS: A Case for Structural and Confessional Pluralism. By Gordon Spykman and Others. 14 THREE LEVELS OF TIME. By Harold T.P. Hayes. 15 WHY JOHNNY STILL CAN'T READ: A New Look at the Scandal of Our Schools. By Rudolf Flesch. 10 FICTION AND POETRY GOOD BEHAVIOUR. By Molly Keane. 13 MINOTAUR. By Benjamin Tammuz. 12 MORGANA'S FAULT. By Susan Lukas. 12 PASSION: New Poems, 1977-1980. By June Jordan. 8 SHAME THE DEVIL. By Philip Appleman. 12 SONS OF EARTH.

title: SCHOOLS: TENURE IS ASSAILED
description: VINELAND AHIGH SCHOOL dropout who last month ended a three-year term as president of the New Jersey State Board of Education says he believes the public school system now is more than holding its own against the incursion of private and parochial school enrollment and is ''regaining the public respect and support that we let slip away in the past few decades.''

title: Major News in Summary; Plenty of Circus Too Little Bread
description: Like flower children ten years too late, strikers in Warsaw last week turned street protests against food shortages into a Polish equivalent of a be-in.
