But the mood quickly soured when talks broke down between the Government and the Solidarity union on how to ease the shortages and a half million miners shut down the coal fields of Silesia for four hours.

title: U.S. REVISES INCOME FIGURES
description: Alaska still leads and Mississippi remains on the bottom in the Government's newly revised figures on per capita personal income in the 50 states and the District of Columbia.

title: 'PRINCE OF THE CITY' EXPLORES A COP'S ANGUISH
description: An ethicist is an ethicist, and a cop is a cop, and the two are not always the same. A moralist, however, is something else, and cops, along with politicians and certain preachers, are often moralists. It is a tricky difference, but an ethicist is concerned with his own sense of right and wrong, and a moralist with someone else's. Former Detective Second Grade Robert Leuci is now an ethicist, a lonely position, which next week will be celebrated, or at least explored, in a new movie. The movie, ''Prince of the City,'' opening Aug. 19 at the Cinema 1, 2 and 3 theaters, is based on his life in the Police Department. He exposed other cops in wrongdoing, and finally admitted wrongdoing himself.

title: Elizabeth A. Sullivan Wed To Mark William Hansler
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ann Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Sullivan of Manhasset, L.I., to Mark William Hansler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Hansler of Pepperdike, Ohio, took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset by Msgr.

title: OPINIONS AND POEMS
description: CIVIL WARS By June Jordan. 188 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $12.95. PASSION New poems, 1977-1980. By June Jordan. 100 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. Cloth, $20.95. Paper, $4.95.

title: Steyn, Andrews Gain
description: Top-seeded Cristo Steyn of South Africa defeated ninth-seeded Howard Sands of Los Angeles, 4-6, 6-3, 7-6, today in the semifinals of the American Dairy Association Penn National men's tennis championship at North Hollow Hills Racquet Club.

title: RULING AWAITED ON SCHOOL REORGANIZATION
description: NEW ROCHELLE WITHIN the next few weeks, a State Supreme Court Justice will decide whether to halt a controversial school-reorganization plan, under which four of this city's 10 elementary schools would be closed.

title: THE RISE OF GERRY COONEY
description: Michael Norman is a frequent contributor to The New York Times Magazine. By Michael Norman The crowd was braced and standing. The promise of something big was in the air, something sudden and violent. ''Welcome to Madison Square Garden,'' said the ring announcer, ''and tonight's 10-round, heavyweight, main event. In the corner to my left, 225 pounds, the former W.B.C. heavyweight champion of the world - Ken Norton. ... In the corner to my right, undefeated in 24 professional fights with 21 knockouts, 225 1/4 pounds - Gentleman Gerry Cooney.''

title: WOMAN WITH 2 IDENTITIES ABSOLVED OF MURDER
description: When she first took the stand at her murder trial, Juanita Maxwell, who pyschiatrists say has a split personality, did not remember much about the beating death of 73-year-old Inez Kelly.

title: Burmese Leader to Quit After 19 Years in Power
description: Gen. Ne Win, who has led this Southeast Asian nation for 19 years, announced today that he would resign from the presidency in November.

title: TV'S BENEFACTOR COMES UNDER FIRE
description: WASHINGTON T HE name of Clarence L. James Jr. remains on the tenant directory that hangs in the lobby of the white-stone office tower that the United States Copyright Royalty Tribunal calls home. A lot of people wish it would go away. Mr. James already has.

title: Pact to Allow Capture Of Condors for Breeding
description: The California Fish and Game Commission has approved a permit for Federal officials to capture nine of the remaining 25 California condors in the coming year.

title: Writer of Book About C.I.A.  Loses a New Bid for Material
description: A Federal appellate court ruled yesterday that classified material obtained by Victor Marchetti, the author of a book about the Central Intelligence Agency, should remain secret unless disclosure was essential.

title: BOARDS MUST RESIST
description: I N their article, ''When Shareholders Become the Victims'' (July 12), Frank H. Easterbrook and Daniel R. Fischel argued that ''acquiescence'' should govern the directors and management of a company that becomes the target of a tender offer, effectively prohibiting any resistance to the offer. This would be a drastic change from the current law, called the business judgment rule, which requires the directors of a target company to evaluate the offer in good faith and determine whether it is in the best interest of the company's shareholders. Such a suggestion strikes me as very unwise and very undesirable.

title: Major News in Summary; Airlines Mostly On Schedule Despite Walkout
description: ''The system cannot work without us, and they know it,'' Michael W. Fermon, a regional vice president of the air traffic controllers union, said last week. ''There's absolute chaos at the towers.'' But the system - the Government's coast-to-coast network of radar stations and communications centers that tracks airplanes in flight - appeared to be holding up. As a result, the strike by more than 12,000 of the nation's 17,500 air controllers showed signs of turning into a kamikaze mission.

title: ROBERTS IS BEST KNOWN FOR KENNEDY HALF
description: When coin collectors think of Gilroy Roberts, they inevitably think of the Kennedy half dollar, a coin he co-designed. The sense of identification pleases Mr. Roberts, now 76 and retired, for he views his work on that coin as the highlight of his long and distinguished career.

title: U.S. BARS SOVIET AIDE'S TRIP TO PEACE MARCH
description: International politics reached into this tiny Green Mountain village today when the State Department barred a Soviet official from speaking to activists who were calling for a freeze on production and deployment of nuclear weapons.

title: You Can't Fool Laws of Gravity
description: To the Sports Editor: Here we go again! In the article ''Kathy Arendsen Shows Off Superior Fastball at Festival'' (The New York Times, July 25) about the sensational softball pitcher, we learn from a player's quote that, ''her rise ball jumps a foot to a foot and a half.''

title: FOREIGN CIGARETTES RIDE AN EASY ROAD TO SALES
description: Multimillion-dollar advertising budgets, new brand offerings, cutthroat competition for market share -nothing avails in the American tobacco industry. A cancer-conscious public, sensitized by the 1964 Surgeon General's report, isn't buying. While the smoking-age population has risen 5.5 percent in the past decade, sales of cigarettes have gone up only 4 percent.

title: HARVARD SETS UP FOUNDATION FOR RACIAL ISSUES
description: Harvard University, which has been criticized by black and other minority students for its racial policies, has created a foundation ''to foster racial understanding,'' the university disclosed yesterday.

title: FINGER LAKES
description: To the Editor:

title: HARTFORD POSTPONES TALKS ON TAX REPEAL PLAN
description: A special session to repeal Connecticut's tax on unincorporated businesses appears to have been ruled out for now, but politicians say repeal is more likely when the General Assembly convenes in October for a special session on spending cuts.

title: Art; WORKS THAT DELIGHT CHILDREN AND ADULTS
description: SETAUKET EXHIBITIONS of children's art are fairly common occurences nowadays, but a less routine offering is art for children, created especially to appeal to their juvenile sensibilities. That it can also provide plenty of delights for the adult viewer is evident in the current show at Gallery North.

title: MANY AGENCIES HELP CHILDREN
description: The Division of Youth and Family Services is the children's protective services agency of the state's Department of Human Services.

title: Realty News; Partnership
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has entered into its first partnership agreement to own real estate with a Japanese life insurance company.

title: Headliners; Brady Suffers a Setback
description: In the case of James S. Brady, no news was good news.

title: Sound; PERIL: SONIC EXCESS
description: As any Puritan knows, danger lurks in our pleasures, and the trouble is that sometimes the dangers are real. After this column reported on the current popularity of lightweight earphones (June 21), we received a cautionary letter from Dr. Jane Reger Madell, warning of possible injury to the ear. The risk, Dr. Madell points out, does not lie in the use of earphones as such, but rather in listening at excessive loudness levels. Too often, it seems, earphones tempt their users to sonic excess.

title: Carol Gallione Is the Bride of David Andrew Knapp
description: At Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Park Ridge, N.J., yesterday Carol Jean Gallione and David Andrew Knapp, graduates of Dartmouth College, were married by the Rev. James Turro, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: PITTSBURGH'S TOP BRASS ALL LOVE THE DUQUESNE CLUB
description: PITTSBURGH I T is noon, and the revolving doors of the Duquesne Club spin nonstop as a seemingly endless stream of men and women spills into the small foyer. They wait for their luncheon partners under murals of cherubim engaged in pursuits that are not usually associated with the chubby nudes, but are dear to the members' hearts: golfing, fly casting, hunting. Many of the women, however, slip discreetly toward the side staircase and what is still known - despite rechristening a year ago as the Crystal Room - as the Ladies' Dining Room.

title: Mailbag; DOUBTS ABOUT TCHAIKOVSKY
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Stacy Beats Four In Playoff
description: Hollis Stacy shot a birdie on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today and won the West Virginia Classic after she had finished in a five-way tie in regulation play.

title: FORBIDDEN FRUIT WITHOUT A NAME
description: To the Editor:

title: SMITHSONIAN SHOWS WOMEN'S LOT AT WORKSHOP
description: Sarah Breedlove Walker's Madame C.J. Walker Pomade for the hair sold so well that she became America's first black millionaire, and Laura Keane -who was a successful actress and theatrical producer - became a footnote to history when she cradled the dying President Lincoln's head in her lap after he was shot during her company's performance of ''Our American Cousin'' in Washington's Ford's Theater.

title: U.S. TIES GROWING FOR JAPAN'S TRADERS
description: Nestled in a lushly upholstered chair in his Park Avenue office, Toshihiro Tomabechi, the 65-year-old president of the Mitsubishi International Corporation, marveled the other day at how much things have changed since he first came to the United States in 1951.

title: A Vote Buyer's Lament
description: His boast is not likely to be challenged, but for the record, Dana Lawson contends that he has bought more votes than any man alive. ''There were people who outdid me,'' he concedes, ''but they're not living.'' Mr. Lawson, an 84-year-old former jailer in Lincoln County, W. Va., discussed such matters in an interview in The Lincoln County Journal.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS IN CANADA REFUSE MOST U.S. FLIGHTS
description: The Canadian Air Traffic Controllers Association announced last night that its members would no longer handle air traffic to and from the United States, except in emergencies. The union said it had acted because of what it regards as unsafe conditions created by the six-day-old strike of American controllers.

title: German-Iraqi Contract
description: Maschinenfabrik Augsburg-Nurnberg, or M.A.N., announced a $110 million, two-year contract with the Iraqi-Jordanian Overland Transport Company to set up a transport service between Iraq and the port of Aqaba, Jordan. M.A.N. will supply 400 60-ton trucks, repair facilities, offices and housing.

title: Perkins Sees Small Strides for Giants
description: Last night, moments after the Giants had soundly beaten the Bears, 23-7, in Chicago in their exhibition opener, Coach Ray Perkins offered this assessment:

title: No Headline
description: Kuwait has lowered the premium on oil exported to South Korea to $1 a barrel from $2.75, officials at the Energy and Resources Ministry said yesterday.

title: 61 French Citizens Set To Leave Teheran Today
description: Sixty-one French citizens were preparing to leave Iran tomorrow aboard the first of two evacuation flights set up under an agreement between Paris and Teheran. A total of 116 French citizens are expected to leave on the Iran Air flights tomorrow and Wednesday.

title: A CRISIS IN ENERGY OF WOOD
description: Time and energy are running out for more than two-thirds of the planet's population. There is a spreading energy crisis affecting billions of people that has almost nothing to do with petroleum. Still in the shadow of its unyielding opposition to United Nations restrictions on the marketing of infant formula, the United States is again poised to veto desperately needed solutions.

title: Barkum to Work Out
description: Jerome Barkum, the tight end who had been hospitalized with back spasms, will have his first workout in more than a week Monday.

title: YANKEES SELECT JOHN FOR OPENER NO. 2
description: With Tommy John on the mound, Reggie Jackson in the designated hitter's slot and a guaranteed berth in the playoffs, the Yankees resume the season tonight at Yankee Stadium against the Texas Rangers after a 59-day hiatus.

title: GOVERNORS GRUNT AND GROAN TO TIE
description: A handful of the nation's governors grinned, grunted and groaned through a pickup basketball game in a parking lot today in the cause of charity.

title: FLIGHTS REPORTED CLOSE TO SCHEDULE
description: Light Sunday air traffic across the nation gave airport controllers on duty a respite yesterday. The reduced flight schedules were reported on time or close to it in the New York metropolitan area and around the country.

title: BEFORE THERE WERE MOVIES, THERE WERE DICKENSES
description: AS a young man, Charles Dickens dreamed of becoming a great actor, and though he never realized that ambition, he put his mimetic genius to good use in his novels. According to biographers, he would assume the roles of various characters as he wrote, muttering fiercely to himself as he jotted down their words. Occasionally, he would rush over to a mirror and gesture and make faces; when he returned to his desk, he'd carefully copy down what he had seen.

title: An Author's Thoughts on Captivating the Young
description: Of the more than 500 letters he receives weekly from children who read his books, said Roald Dahl, about 80 percent say they love the gory parts of his stories best.

title: Kialoa Reported Leading Fastnet
description: After a slow start, in which a mass of boats drifted slowly with the tide, the pace picked up today on the second day of the 605-mile Fastnet yacht race.

title: Power Cut to 1,400 in Jersey
description: About 1,400 residents in two northern New Jersey communities lost electric power this morning when a squirrel climbed onto a power line. A spokesman for Orange and Rockland Utilities said the squirrel shorted out a power substation at 7 A.M.

title: Bridge: Hungrily Sought Slam Key To Spingold Event Victory
description: Just before midnight in Boston last Tuesday, four young men sat down facing, like Horatius dealing with a different kind of bridge, fearful odds.

title: KNICKS, WILLIAMS DO A DISCO DANCE
description: THERE is a new mating dance in the National Basketball Association. It is called The I-Can't-Afford-You-But-I-Can't-Let-You-Go, Rightof-First-Refusal Disco.

title: BOLIVIANS PONDER REVOLT: WHO WON?
description: A weeklong struggle for control of the Government has ended as it began: a shadowy and mostly military affair that appears to hold little relevance for the lives of most of Bolivia's six million people.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Suffers Earnings Drop
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, another victim of currency exchanges, suffered a drop of 24.3 percent in earnings in the second quarter.

title: PLAY BALL!
description: In 1911 when Ring Lardner wrote ''Gee, It's a Wonderful Game,'' he was still a baseball fan, although three years as a daily sports reporter had tempered his enthusiasm and he would eventually be unable to stomach the game.

title: Native Courier and Great Neck Win
description: Native Courier and Great Neck came from off the pace today to win their divisions of the Bernard Baruch Handicap on the main turf course at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Suits Follow Hyatt Mishap
description: Forty-six lawsuits seeking more than $1.2 billion have been filed in the aftermath of the collapse of two walkways last month at Kansas City's Hyatt Regency Hotel.

title: Jury Back on Job In Raiders' Trial
description: Deliberations in the trial of the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit will begin again tomorrow after jurors spent the weekend at home.

title: Victim of Park Fall Identified
description: The National Park Service has identified the victim of a climbing accident on Friday as Judith Ellen McCade, 22 years old, a summer employee of the park from Williamsville, N.Y. Park rangers said that she died after falling 100 feet from Tenaya Peak here.

title: NEW YORK AREA FIGHTS COMPLEX WATER WOES
description: Water in America: Solving the Quandary Second of five articles

title: TAXI PANEL UNSURE OF SURCHARGE'S EFFECT
description: Three months after the start of a 50-cent surcharge on nighttime and Sunday taxi fares, the Taxi and Limousine Commission has been unable to get any data from the independent cab drivers on whether more drivers have been encouraged to work during those times.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 10, 1981
description: International One of the toughest Soviet attacks on the Reagan Administration followed the report over the weekend that the United States would proceed with the full production of neutron weapons. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said the American move was ''a step designed to bring the world closer to nuclear catastrophe,'' and that the Soviet Union would respond in the manner required by its own security interests. (Page A1, Column 6.) West Germany responded cautiously to the Reagan Administration's plans to produce neutron weapons. A Government spokesman said that the decision was an ''exclusively American affair.'' Influential members of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Party who believe that the Administration is not taking disarmament efforts seriously indicated there would be increased resistance to support of its armaments policy. (A6:3-6.)

title: PORTUGUESE PREMIER TO RESIGN
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao today announced plans to resign after failing to silence his critics in the governing Social Democratic Party.

title: REVISED CODE OF ETHICS FOR BAR STILL FACES DEBATE
description: Four years after it began work, a special commission of the American Bar Association has unveiled what it calls a final draft of a new code of ethics for the legal profession.

title: SELF-HELP BENEFITING POOR LANDS
description: Developing countries have made considerable progress helping themselves, yet they face an uncertain future because of the slower growth of world trade and less generous aid policies of industrial countries, the World Bank said today.

title: POP: DENVER PLAYS TO SOLD-OUT HOUSE
description: ALTHOUGH John Denver's records sell only a fraction today of what they sold six or seven years ago, Mr. Denver is still a major concert attraction, and his Saturday appearance at the Meadowlands Arena was sold out well in advance.

title: MR. WATT AND HIS CRITICS
description: The knives are out for Interior Secretary James Watt. Environmental groups issue thick indictments and circulate recall petitions. Editorial writers and Democratic Congressmen call on the President to fire him. Even some Republican politicians are whispering that he's become a political liability.

title: It's Water as Usual For Newark Again
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Newark's water system, which was vandalized a month ago, is back to normal, according to officials.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: STRIKERS HAVE VALID POINTS, LEWIS SAYS
description: Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis acknowledged today that air traffic controllers now on strike, all of whom are to be dismissed, probably had some legitimate grievances. But Mr. Lewis said he would not negotiate with the controllers' leader even if he ended the strike.

title: Austin in Final
description: Unseeded John Austin advanced to the final of the $75,000 National Revenue Tennis Classic today with a 7-5, 7-5 victory over Hank Pfister. Austin will face top-seeded Brian Teacher of Los Angeles for the title tomorrow night.

title: 2 Sisters Are Resting After Heart Transplants
description: Two young sisters from Kansas City, Mo., were resting today in intensive care units at the Stanford Medical Center after receiving new hearts 11 days apart at the medical facility.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Brunswick Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $75 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2006, to be sold through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: SUSAN A. EGERTER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Susan Anne Egerter and Stephen Elliott Creager, doctoral students in epidemiology and economics, respectively, at Yale University, were married in Radnor, Pa., yesterday. The Rev. Morris W. Hudgins, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Willows.

title: Snipes Is Awarded Unpopular Decision
description: Renaldo Snipes, the unbeaten heavyweight from White Plains, extended his victory string to 22 today by surviving two knockdowns and gaining a split decision over Gerrie Coetzee of South Africa.

title: ADOLPH J. AMMON
description: Adolph J. Ammon, retired vice president and controller of American Book-Stratford Press Inc. of New York City, died Thursday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Linda Beth Schwimmer Married to Mark M. Stern
description: Linda Beth Schwimmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Schwimmer of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Alan Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Stern of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony in the garden at the Stern home.

title: Chenoweth Wins Hydroplane Cup
description: Dean Chenoweth, driving Miss Budweiser, set lap and heat records as he won his second consecutive Gold Cup regatta for unlimited hydroplanes today. It was the fourth Gold Cup victory for Chenoweth.

title: IS BRITAIN A WARNING?
description: Paris, Aug. 9 - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's political glow is badly tarnished just as President Reagan's triumph appears brilliant as a sunburst. The British experiment with monetarist economics is in grave trouble, while the United States has completed tooling up for the same kind of effort.

title: TENT CARS SALES AID CHRYSLER
description: From the highways, the events seemed like another weekend carnival or a revival meeting. Balloons swayed in the air to the rhythm of country music. Crowds milled around under colorfully striped tents. And announcers with the cadence of auctioneers welcomed the multitudes to the midway.

title: CREDIT MARKETS After Treasury's Refunding
description: The completion of the Treasury's August refunding leaves the credit markets with a host of worries that are keeping interest rates high.

title: METS' PITCHING STAFF DEPLETED BY INJURIES
description: The Mets will re-open the major league season against the Chicago Cubs tomorrow with an ailing pitching staff that they will patch up by recalling one or more minor league pitchers.

title: News Analysis
description: Tom Gautherat, an air traffic controller for 15 years, was standing outside O'Hare International Airport in Chicago one warm afternoon last week, and engaging in actions that at first glance appeared decidedly uncharacteristic for a man of middle-class views and aspirations, walking a picket line and expressing harsh, uncompromising views of his Government.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeronca Inc., Pineville, N.C., has named Hal Brundage vice president, operations.

title: 4 HOMERS GIVE NATIONAL LEAGUE 5-4 ALL-STAR VICTORY
description: Major league baseball clattered back onto the national scene after eight weeks tonight with a display of razzle dazzle and a burst of home runs that raised the curtain on the second half of the split season.

title: COMPUTERS: FRIENDS OR FOES?
description: M ILLIONS of American workers who once interacted with other workers are now ''interfacing,'' as they say, with computerized machines. As a result, the people are beginning to feel a bit like machines and the machines are becoming what is termed ''user friendly.''

title: Douglass Arts Center Is Facing Budget Cuts
description: The teaching and performing programs of the Frederick Douglass Creative Arts Center, which trains aspiring writers and artists, are threatened by cutbacks in government and private financing, according to Fred Hudson, the center's president and artistic director, and Budd Schulberg, the novelist. They established the center 10 years ago as an East Coast counterpart of the Watts Writers Workshop in California.

title: Cubs Option Tracy
description: The Chicago Cubs have optioned Jim Tracy, an outfielder, to the Midland Cubs of Class AA Texas League, a Chicago spokesman said today.

title: Red Smith That Kind Of Town
description: CHARLES PATRICK is a tennis coach and horseplayer with a special fondness for Saratoga, whose charms have attracted visitors since buffalo roamed on Phila Street. Starting in 1767, people with gout or rheumatism have come here to get rid of their burden, and ever since 1863, pilgrims with money have been coming for a similar purpose.

title: Commodities; Behind the Volume Figures
description: SOME time this week, the Futures Industry Association will issue its report on commodity trading volume for last month. It will show that the turnover for July fell 5 percent to 8.6 million contracts, the first such decline since June 1980, when the volume dropped 14 percent from the 1979 level. The F.I.A. will also report that volume for the first seven months was 56.1 million, a gain of 18 percent from the 1980 level.

title: GARY MICHAEL UNGER MARRIES ROBIN MILLER
description: Robin Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Miller of Laguna Niguel , Calif., was married yesterday to Gary Michael Ungar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Ungar of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Bernard Cohen officiated at the Beverly Hills (Calif.) Hotel.

title: THE NURSES' DISCONTENT
description: There are 1.4 million registered nurses in the United States, but only 400,000 of them choose to work full time in hospitals - 100,000 fewer than the hospitals need. In New York's municipal hospitals, the shortage is acute; to maintain even minimal standards they say the corps of 5,600 has to grow by a thousand. Patients everywhere suffer as overworked nurses limit their attentions to the most critical cases.

title: Watanabe Wins
description: Jiro Watanabe of Japan, the World Boxing Council's ninth-rated junior bantamweight contender, scored a 10-round decision over Lee Hwang-I of South Korea today in a non-title bout. In the seventh round, Watanabe knocked down Lee, Korea's No.3 flyweight, with a series of short left and right punches to the face. Both boxers weighed 114 3/4.

title: GYPSY MOTH CAUSED RECORD LOSSES IN '81 IN NORTHEASTERN U.S.
description: Gypsy-moth caterpillars did a record amount of damage in the Northeast in 1981, eating the leaves off trees covering at least nine million acres from Maine to Maryland, according to estimates by forestry experts. That was twice the area defoliated last year, they said.

title: Continental Air Chief Dies, Apparent Suicide
description: A.L. Feldman, president of Continental Airlines, was found dead tonight at his office at Los Angeles International Airport, apparently by his own hand, according to the director of airport operations, John Smith.

title: A Friend in Need
description: Since June 10, when Thomas Bonner, president of Wayne State University in Detroit, recommended that his college drop football as a money-saving measure, much effort has been expended to save the program.

title: FROZEN MICE EMBRYOS BANKED
description: One day, about a hundred years from now, some mice may be born of fathers and mothers that lived and died here in 1981.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 10, 1981; Energy
description: President Reagan is being urged to decontrol prices on all domestically produced natural gas by the beginning of 1985, rather than just a portion of it. The move is expected to meet heavy Congressional opposition because of higher costs to the consumer, but it has a fair chance of gaining the President's support because of his recent budget and tax victories. (Page A1.)

title: The Lee Approach
description: When the baseball strike began, Bill Lee, the articulate eccentric who pitches for the Montreal Expos, said he would not play for money again this year, strike or no. Last week, with almost predictable unpredictability, Lee showed up at the Expos' West Palm Beach, Fla., training camp several days late and began to play.

title: McEnroe Winner
description: John McEnroe won the Carre d'As exhibition tennis tournament by beating Thierry Tulasne, 6-2, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, in the final yesterday. Although the Riviera tournament was only a series of exhibitions, McEnroe lost his temper in the third set and twice hit balls into the crowd, which began jeering him.

title: Venpub, New Concern, Now Controls Venture
description: Venpub, a new company formed by Joseph D. Girraputo, founder and publisher of Venture, The Magazine for Entrepreneurs, has acquired the majority equity in the magazine from the Christiana Companies.

title: 3 Southern States Have Half of the Condemned
description: More than half the 714 prison inmates awaiting execution in the United States last year were in three Southern states, Florida, Texas and Georgia, Justice Department statistics showed today.

title: No Umpire Walkout
description: A walkout threatened by the major league umpires for tonight's All-Star Game was averted today in negotiations between their union chief, Richie Phillips, and the presidents of the National and American leagues.

title: A PROPER FEDERAL ROLE ON FIRE ISLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Russell B. Stearns, Executive Who Headed War Dept. Board
description: Russell Bangs Stearns, a business executive who was the first chairman of the War Department's Price Adjustment Board in the 1940's, died Thursday at New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. Mr. Stearns, who had lived in Dedham, Mass., for more than half a century, was 87 years old.

title: CLERC WINS U.S. CLAY COURT TITLE
description: Jose-Luis Clerc won his 25th consecutive match and his fourth straight tournament today with a 4-6, 6-4, 6-2 triump over Ivan Lendl in the final of the United States Clay Court Championships.

title: WHAT CETA CAN DO: ONE NEW YORK WORKER'S STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: TROUBLED LIBERTY CITY PONDERS SECESSION
description: One hot Friday night a month ago, outside a crowded pool hall south of the southern rim of Liberty City, Miami's black ghetto, a white policeman shot and killed a black man who had been shooting at people when the officer happened along. By all accounts, the policeman acted in self-defense. Nevertheless, to the officer, bystanders screamed, ''I hate you.''

title: THE COMPLAINTS OF A BUS-SHELTER BUILDER
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Nixon Aide Leaves Law Practice for Ministry
description: He's been a Sunday-school teacher and a church leader for most of his adult life, but now Harry S. Dent, a one-time aide to former President Richard M. Nixon, has decided to give up his law practice to enter the ministry.

title: A Confused Hambletonian Day
description: ''Geez,'' said the high roller from the Bronx, ''I don't know what's going on here. I'm gonna pass this one up.''

title: OPEC SETS PRICE TALKS NEXT WEEK
description: Oil ministers from the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will convene a special meeting Aug. 19 in Geneva, a senior Kuwaiti official said Sunday.

title: News Analysis
description: Five years without enough money, an even longer period without proper coordination and, ironically, recent tougher penalties for serious crimes have put every part of New York State's criminal justice system in crisis.

title: Index; International
description: Children of the A-Bomb: Stunted bodies and lives A2 South Africa admits it knew of po- lice efforts against trade unions A3 Despite discontent, Mobutu adroitly keeps peace in Zaire A3 Bolivians ponder revolt: Who won? A4 Two civilians are killed in rioting after death of hunger striker A4 Polish workers march despite Solidarity's appeal for a delay A5 Around the World A7 Government/Politics City's horse licensing measure opposed by some owners B1 Three debates to be held before mayoral primary in September B3 General Around the Nation A8 Centralia, Pa., mine fires leave residents bitter and fearful A8 Solutions being sought to prob- lems that led to Miami riot A8 Revisions fail to allay suspicions about lawyer ethics code A10 Three Supreme Court justices speak at bar meeting A10 Governors struggle through pickup basketball game A12 Underground explosions hit part of flooded upstate town B2 Adults move in on a Connecticut sand-sculpting competition B2 A woman was charged with stran- gling her two children B3 Some career-counseling agencies are subject of complaints B3 Army meets quota for medical scholarships B12 Industry/Labor A light Sunday flight schedule gives controllers a respite D10 Features/Notes Notes on People A12 Going Out Guide C12 SportsMonday Baseball: Major leagues resume with All-Star Game C1

title: 'Percent for Art'
description: To be against anything that appears to benefit artists is like being against virtue. But it is possible to care for the arts and still be unhappy about the ''Percent for Art'' movement, which has been remarkably successful at getting public authorities to set aside up to 1 percent of the cost of public construction for the purchase of works of art.

title: THREE HIGH COURT JUSTICES SPEAK TO LAWYERS BUT SHUN CONTROVERSY
description: Speeches by three Supreme Court Justices today and last night have been perhaps the biggest attractions of the potpourri of programs for the more than 8,000 American Bar Association lawyers convening at the Hilton Hotel here. They have ranked above even the gustatory and musical delights of nearby Bourbon Street.

title: Motorola Ad Campaign Takes on the Japanese
description: In a rare move, Motorola Inc., a major producer of high technology and electronics for industry, has begun a multimillion dollar communications campaign that takes on the Japanese competition.

title: Advertising Are the Europeans Coming?
description: WHAT the Japanese auto makers did to Detroit could be repeated in the nation's supermarkets by European package goods companies, according to Gerald Schoenfeld, a one-time agency head who is now a new products pioneer.

title: Winnipeg Tops Alouettes, 58-2
description: Dieter Brock threw four touchdown passes last night to pace the Winnipeg Blue Bombers to a 58-2 victory over the Montreal Alouettes.

title: Motorcycle Crown Lost by Roberts
description: Kenny Roberts, the defending road racing champion in the 500cc class, was dethroned today when he placed only seventh in Finland's motorcycle grand prix.

title: Washington Watch; World Bank And Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON EVEN though Taiwan has one of the fastest growing economies of the third world and is a major force in international trade, it rates not even an asterisk in the World Bank's latest development report.

title: OWNERS' BRIDLING AT 'WAGNER ACT' FOR CITY HORSES
description: From the private barns of Staten Island to the commercial stables of Manhattan, the city's 2,000 or so horses would be required to wear license tags costing $25 a year, under a recently passed bill headed for mayoral hearings.

title: PLAN TO RENAME DATSUN DRAWING FIRE
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's secondlargest auto maker, is ready to bet that its target market of young, upscale buyers would just as soon be driven in a Nissan as in a Datsun. But its dealers are not so sure.

title: CHILDREN OF THE A-BOMB: STUNTED BODIES AND LIVES
description: Kazuko Sakuma was born on Jan. 11, 1946, but she looks about 12 years old and mentally she is barely 5, if that.

title: BROZNOWSKI CAPTURES CYCLING TITLE
description: Tom Broznowski of Seattle, who had not finished better than ninth in four previous races, won the United States Cycling Federation senior men's 106-mile road race today at Harriman State Park. The victory qualified him for the world championships Aug. 25 in Brno, Czechoslovakia.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: On behalf of my client, Saul P. Steinberg, I am writing to you to protest your lead editorial of Aug. 6. While I understand that the editorial purports to comment upon the recent report prepared by the Investigations Commissioner of the City of New York, please be aware that in our view it contains serious misstatements of fact.

title: POP: ANNE CALLOWAY, SINGER ANMD PIANIST, AT ALGONQUIN
description: THERE are two sounds that stand out in Anne Hampton Calloway's performance in the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, where she is singing and playing piano Wednesdays through Sundays. One is a throaty slur that suggests Humphrey Bogart's lisp. The other is the kind of high shriek ending that Annie Ross, when she was a member of the team of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, used as a vocalized equivalent of Count Basie's trumpets.

title: U.S. Women Lose
description: The University of Kentucky women's basketball team lost its opening game to the Japanese national squad, 72-59, today.

title: ROBIN HERMAN BRIDE OF PAUL F. HORVITZ
description: At the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I., yesterday Robin Cathy Herman and Paul Fisher Horvitz were married by Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg.

title: OPERA: 'RIDI PAGLIACCIO,' ONE-MAN CARUSO SHOW
description: Enrico Caruso should have been grateful that of all the difficult tenor roles he had to sing, he never had to play himself. Imagine a tenor trying to sing the role of ''Caruso.'' He'd have to be able to shape a phrase with sensuous power and ease; his tone would have to caress the ear; he'd have to give a performance of ''Pagliacci'' full of stirring weeping, and he'd have to do it all without the help of the static and distortion of old wax recordings, which give a legendary patina to every sigh.

title: Florio Assails Plan On Cutting Taxes
description: Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate for New Jersey Governor, said that a ''supply side'' economic plan similar to that proposed by his Republican opponent, Thomas H. Kean, had already failed in Minnesota.

title: 27 GOVERNORS SEEK DEMOCRATIC GAINS
description: The nation's 27 Democratic Governors today said their party's flagging fortunes have placed the responsibility for leading a comeback squarely on their shoulders.

title: Norse Go West
description: When the Rangers come home late next month from Finland and Sweden, after training abroad for the first time, they are expected to have five Scandinavian-born players with them. In addition to the Swedes Anders Hedberg, Ulf Nilsson and Peter Wallin, the team should have signed two Finns, Reijo Ruotsalainen, a defenseman, and Mikko Leinonen, a center.

title: HANK MCGRAW VENTURES BACK TO THE GAME
description: after months of discussion and hesitation - hired Hank McGraw as a coach with their Bend rookie league team, but first they asked him to cut the ponytail that extended to his waist. He did. They asked him to trim his walrus mustache, and the droopy loops were soon snipped.

title: Ex-Firefighter Dies Awaiting A Town-Paid Heart Transplant
description: A retired Brookline firefighter who was voted $75,000 by town selectmen to help pay for a heart transplant died yesterday of a heart attack, Beth Israel Hospital said.

title: EARLY JAZZ FIGURES TOAST BIX BEIDERBECKE
description: Of all the legendary figures in jazz, none is more legendary than Bix Beiderbecke, the cornetist from Davenport, Iowa, who blazed briefly but memorably in the 20's and died of pneumonia aggravated by alcoholism on Aug. 6, 1931, at the age of 28 - leaving behind a host of admirers and even worshipers, some recordings and the legend. The legend reached its height, perhaps, in the Dorothy Baker novel ''Young Man With a Horn,'' which was made into a 1950 movie starring Kirk Douglas that disappointed admirers of Beiderbecke.

title: TREASURY FINANCING KEEPS DEPUTY BUSY
description: There was a heavy calendar of Federal financings last week and no one was busier seeing them through than Mark E. Stalnecker, the 30-year-old Deputy Assistant Secretary-designate of the Treasury, specializing in Federal finance. The regular three- and six-month bill auctions were held on Monday, three- ,10- and 30-year refundings were completed on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday and one-year bills were sold on Friday.

title: A NEW-LOOK TONY DORSETT
description: gray haze hangs over Los Angeles, 45 miles to the southeast, but not here. The rains almost never come, at least not in the summer, when it is time to endure training camp. The Cowboys chose the perfect place when they arrived on the campus of California Lutheran College in 1963. Coaches could say it is peaceful and quiet here. Players could say it is boring. There were few places for muscular and economically attractive young men to get into any kind of trouble at all.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's a Wagner Act for horses. The only thing it doesn't give working horses is a mandatory retirement age.''

title: BALLET: THE LOS ANGELES
description: THE Los Angeles Ballet that made its New York debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last November, as part of the Academy's Ballet America series, was a very different company from the one that performed on Saturday afternoon at the Pepsico Summerfare '81 arts festival at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: Sleepwalker Dies in Fall
description: Sleepwalking is suspected in the death of a 17-year-old boy who plunged 12 stories from a dormitory window at Louisiana State University, the police said today. The body of Kirk G. Givins of Pineville, La., known to be a sleepwalker, was discovered yesterday by officials outside East Kirby Smith dormitory, housing site for participants in Boy's State, a conference on government for teen-agers.

title: Abraham Bordon, Ex-Justice Of Connecticut's High Court
description: Abraham S. Bordon, a retired Supreme Court justice in Connecticut, died Friday at his home in Hartford. He was 89 years old.

title: SILVANO ARIETI, PSYCHOANALYST AND WRITER ON SCHIZOPHRENIA
description: Dr. Silvano Arieti, a psychoanalyst who wrote extensively on schizophrenia and creativity, died Friday of cancer at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JOB-SEEKERS COMPLAIN OF ABUSES BY CAREER-COUNSELING GROUPS
description: More than a year ago, Thomas Walsh, an out-of-work publicrelations executive with 25 years' experience, answered an advertisement for Franklin Career Search International Inc. that included a ''results or refund'' conditional guarantee.

title: DURAN WINS, BUT IT'S A CLOSE ONE
description: The decision was unanimous, but the judgments were reserved. Roberto Duran, this time eating only a small steak before his fight, returned to a ring today for the first time since he walked out of one nine months ago and outpointed Mike (Nino) Gonzalez in a 10-round bout. Duran was hit a lot more than Sugar Ray Leonard touched him in their now-infamous rematch.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN DISCLOSES BID TO 'BREAK' BLACK UNION
description: Only days after legislation was introduced in Parliament to legitimize further the status of black trade unions, South Africa's Minister of Police has acknowledged that a security officer circulated a memorandum on union-busting tactics among corporations in East London, where a militant black trade union has succeeded in organizing a mass membership.

title: GROWING UP IN NAZI GERMANY: A BACKWARD LOOK
description: One fog-shrouded Sunday in November 1978, Wendelgard von Staden returned for the first time in many years to her family's farm in the southwest of West Germany. She saw a cemetery that had not existed before. There were many tombstones, but on most of them there were only numbers. One said: ''Saul Silvermann, born in Radom, died here in 1945.''

title: ZAIRE SLUM IS POWDER KEG FOR MOBUTU
description: It was Saturday night, so they were dancing in the discos of La Cite, the vast slum that sprawls around Kinshasa like a coiled reptile.

title: Israel Officially Rejects Saudi Peace Proposals
description: Israeli officials today dismissed Saudi Arabia's Middle East peace proposals as a plan to destroy Israel. Officials said the plan outlined yesterday by Crown Prince Fahd in an interview with the official Saudi press agency ultimately envisaged an all-out attack on Israel by Arab nations led by the Palestinians.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday on Soviet maneuvers in the Baltic Sea incorrectly stated where Soviet naval forces landed. They landed in the former East Prussia, which is now part of the Soviet Union's Russian Republic.

title: COSMOS LOSE THIRD STRAIGHT
description: The Cosmos, who had not been shut out this season, have lost a third straight game for the first time since the 1974 season. The Edmonton Drillers, getting first-half goals from the striker Edi Kirschner and the defender Dwight Lodeweges, scored a 2-0 victory today before a crowd of 14,781.

title: Month Off
description: If you wouldn't think of putting a computer terminal in your bedroom ... if no one has ever called you a workaholic ... if magazine quizzes reveal you to be a Type B and possibly bovine and not an upwardly mobile Type A ... if, in short, you like to sniff the flowers along the way, you can stop feeling guilty. Your President has said you're O.K.

title: Good Samaritan
description: A few minutes before Fio Rito won the Whitney Handicap Aug. 1, he almost lost his chance to run. A big gray New York-bred horse, famous for bad manners around the barn and in the post parade, Fio Rito has never liked waiting around in a starting gate either.

title: JEROME I. UDELL
description: Jerome I. Udell, retired board chairman of Max Udell Sons & Company, which had been a manufacturer of men's clothing in Manhattan, died Saturday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. Mr. Udell, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 83 years old.

title: Californian Wins Ashe Singles Title
description: Fifth-seeded Jerome Jones of Los Angeles beat fourth-ranked Tom Jones of the Bronx, 6-4, 6-1, yesterday for the men's singles title in the Arthur Ashe tournament at the National Tennis Center.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE LUCK OF HUEMAC. A Novel About the Aztecs. By Daniel Peters. 657 pages. Illustrated with maps. Random House. $16.95.

title: NELSON WINS P.G.A. BY 4 SHOTS ON 71-273
description: Larry Nelson won the 63d Professional Golfers' Association championship today with a workmanlike job of hitting fairways and greens. The idea was to let his closest competitors take their chances by pursuing him; none of them ever threatened.

title: U.N.'s Parley on Energy To Open in Kenya Today
description: Oil-consuming industrialized nations and firewood-burning developing countries will meet tomorrow at the first United Nations conference on unconventional energy sources.

title: A TURNAROUND, NOT JUST IN SPORT
description: The baseball strike is over and the second season has begun. Yet the underlying causes of baseball's transformation from an island of tranquillity into a sea of litigation remain as obscure as ever.

title: FLXIBLE'S DEFECTIVE PART ALSO USED ON G.M. BUSES
description: The defective rubber insulators found on the engine mounts of nine Grumman Flxible buses are the same as those used on the new General Motors buses recently put into service by the city, the president of the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: BIG CREDITS STIR DEBATE BECAUSE MONEY IS TIGHT
description: A new elite club has been established in the business world. Its members are companies that have obtained lines of credit of $1 billion or more.

title: 10 GAMBIAN REBELS SEIZED
description: Senegalese troops invited into Gambia by President Dawda Jawara continued mopping-up operations against rebels today. Their commander, Lieut. Col. Abel Ngom, said that 10 armed rebels were arrested yesterday in the forest of Sokutu, near the Senegalese border. No figures have been given for the total number of arrest since the Senegalese crushed a leftist-led revolt, but military sources said more than 100 rebels had been taken into custody.

title: WRITERS PLAN A CONGRESS ON THEIR PROBLEMS
description: An American Writers Congress, backed by an inviting committee that includes 200 prominent authors, will be held at the Roosevelt Hotel from Oct. 9 to Oct. 12. The sponsors said the aim was to help writers deal with ''bread-and-butter problems as well as political and economic trends that threaten the vitality of our written culture.''

title: ARMY MEETS QUOTA FOR MEDICAL SCHOLARSHIPS
description: For the first time since it began awarding scholarships to medical students nine years ago, the United States Army has recruited its full student quota for the coming academic year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INCOMPARABLE

title: Nurses Go on Strike At Cape Cod Hospital
description: Registered nurses at Cape Cod Hospital went on strike today after rejecting a last-minute contract offer by the hospital. The facility evacuated 240 patients last week in anticipation of the walkout.

title: JONES STARTS SHEDDING WALKER'S SHADOW
description: On the one hand, there is Wesley Walker and his career average of 23 yards a reception. On the other hand there is Bobby Jones, the former auto mechanic who once answered, ''Texaco Tech,'' when the Jets asked what college he attended.

title: WEDDING POSTSCRIPT
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK ADDS SIX LAWS TO HELP WOMEN
description: The financial and protective rights of women involved in marital and divorce disputes were expanded significantly under six laws passed during the last session of the Legislature and signed by Governor Carey last Thursday at a ceremony at his New York City office.

title: 3 TELEVISED DEBATES SLATED FOR HOPEFULS IN MAYORAL CONTEST
description: Three television debates have been scheduled among candidates in the Sept. 10 mayoral primary.

title: G.I.  BILL URGED FOR MEN JOINING COMBAT GROUPS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to propose a new G.I. bill of educational benefits that would favor young men who join the ground combat arms for the military services, according to the Defense Department's senior manpower official.

title: LINDA PETTE KUJAN MARRIED
description: Linda Pette Kujan, daughter of Janet Pette Kujan of Forest Hills, Queens, and Edward Kujan of Reno, was married yesterday to Stephen Paul Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Morgan of Garden City, L.I., and White Haven, Pa. The Rev. Francis X. Mulhall performed the ceremony at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills.

title: David M. Noyes, 83, An Adviser to Truman
description: David M. Noyes, an adviser, biographer and friend to Harry S. Truman for 30 years, died Friday of a heart attack at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83 years old.

title: Diplomats Win
description: Clive Haywood and Trevor Hebberd scored goals as the Washington Diplomats kept their playoff hopes alive today by beating the Atlanta Chiefs, 2-0, before a crowd of 6,003 at R.F.K. Stadium.

title: Schwartzott Takes Volkswagen Race
description: Peter Schwartzott beat Paul Hacker by the length of a car hood today to win the Volkswagen Rabbit-Bilstein Cup race at Brainerd International Raceway.

title: Tate Stops Parker
description: John Tate had little trouble defeating Claman (Sandman) Parker in a heavyweight bout last night, but afterward said he thought Parker had been a worthy opponent.

title: CABINET GROUP URGES END TO PRICE CONTROLS ON ALL GAS
description: President Reagan's top energy advisers have recommended unanimously a plan to decontrol the price of all natural gas produced in the United States, a move that would raise consumer prices much more sharply than under the partial decontrol now taking effect.

title: 3 Charged in Torah Thefts
description: Three Centereach teen-agers have been charged with stealing two Torahs from the Temple Beth Shalom in Smithtown, L.I., the Suffolk County police said today.

title: Grich, Kison Back
description: The California Angels today reactivated Bobby Grich and Bruce Kison. Grich, a second baseman, broke his left hand June 6 and has been on the disabled list.

title: SHIFTS AT AUTO INSURER
description: Paul A. Donald, 52, has been appointed president and general manager of the Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, the nation's fourth-largest automobile insurer and a major component of the giant Nationwide Insurance organization. The appointment is effective Oct. 1.

title: YOUNGSTERS' SANDY EVENT LURES ADULT ARTISTS, TOO
description: It used to be for children, but many of the people wielding trowels and plastic shovels today at the Great Milford Sand Castle and Sculpture Competition on Silver Sands Beach were adults - and some were professional artists.

title: Market Place; Gauging Bids For Takeover
description: SOPHISTICATED valuation methods are in use throughout the investment community these days - methods that often turn up potential takeover candidates.

title: CHANGE IS A DU PONT TRADITION
description: First, there was Du Pont. And then Du Pont begat gunpowder, and the gunpowder business begat chemicals. Chemicals begat nylon, and the nylon business begat fibers. Fibers begat diversification, and the diversification begat Conoco. Conoco?

title: EXPLOSIONS IN FLOODED WATERTOWN FORCE SOME PEOPLE OUT OF HOMES
description: A series of at least three underground explosions, which officials believe were caused by the dumping of gasoline into sewers, led to the removal of residents from their homes in a five-square-block area of this flooded upstate city's east side today. No injuries were reported.

title: F.L. SULZBERGER, BUSINESSMAN AND A CHICAGO PHILANTHROPIST
description: Frank L. Sulzberger, a businessman and philanthropist whose beneficiaries included a broad range of institutions, died Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 93 years old.

title: FOLK FESTIVAL BEGINS TOMORROW AT NATHAN'S
description: The first New York Folk Festival, which will be presenting Buffy Sainte-Marie, Odetta, Richie Havens, Oscar Brand and other performers in concerts at Town Hall and Greenwich Village's Folk City club tomorrow through Sunday, begins at noon tomorrow with an event in an unusual location - Nathan's Famous, the hot dog emporium in Times Square.

title: CHINESE PREMIER IN MALAYSIA
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China arrived in Malaysia today on the second leg of a Southeast Asian tour. Mr Zhao, who flew here from Manila, is scheduled to leave for Singapore on Tuesday and he will also visit Thailand.

title: A Wedding March to the Stamp of Elephants' Feet
description: It's not often that the bride and bridegroom ride elephants to their wedding, but for Nina Pasko and John Cox, it seemed the natural thing to do.

title: Carolyn Widmer Is Married to Brian Holmes Jaffe
description: Carolyn R. Widmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Widmer of New York and Perth, Australia, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Brian Holmes Jaffe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Jaffe of Earlysville, Va. Mayor Josie Hall of Princeton Township performed the ceremony at Prospect House on the Princeton University campus.

title: 40 Injured at Concert After Thousands Panic
description: Audio equipment fell on spectators at a rock music concert today, triggering a ''stampede'' among thousands of concertgoers that left more than 40 people injured, the state police said.

title: United We Stand
description: While the Cosmos took a plane from Minnesota to Canada for weekend play in the North American Soccer League, New York United, the other professional outdoor soccer team in the metropolitan area, boarded two silver vans for a trip to Rochester.

title: FIRE AND FEAR SURFACE AS CENTRALIA MINES SMOLDER
description: Tony and Mary Androtti were standing beside a mobile home in an abandoned schoolyard, their refuge from a man-made disaster, talking about the blow that had fallen on them and their town and a new fear that has spread along its sloping streets.

title: MOTHER IN BRONX HELD IN SLAYING OF HER CHILDREN
description: A 7-year-old girl and her infant brother were found dead in their home in the Bronx yesterday. The police later charged their mother, who had a history of mental illness, with the apparent strangulation of the children.

title: MOSCOW CONDEMNS U.S. MOVE TO MAKE NEUTRON WEAPONS
description: The Soviet Union today called President Reagan's decision to proceed with full production of neutron weapons an extremely d) - A report by Tass, the Soviet press agency, said Mr. Reagan's action was "designed to bring the world closer to a nuclear catastrophe."

title: Jersey Cites Need For 250 Troopers
description: TRENTON (UPI) - New Jersey needs 250 more troopers to deal with the pressures of Atlantic City's casinos, the Meadowlands Sports Complex and urban crime, Col. Clinton L. Pagano Sr., the Superintendent of the state police, said yesterday.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With two out and a man on second, the batter hits a high fly that sends the shortstop to his left. The ball comes down directly over second base and the runner, who has not moved off the bag, ducks. The shortstop collides with the runner and misses the ball. Is this interference?

title: 2 Civilians Are Killed In Rioting in Belfast
description: Two civilians were killed in widespread rioting in Roman Catholic districts of Belfast and in other towns in Northern Ireland today after the death yesterday of a ninth hunger striker in Maze Prison, the police said.

title: MEIER & FRANK'S CHIEF
description: Judith K. Hofer, 40, has been named president and chief executive officer of Meier & Frank, a Portland, Ore., department store group and a division of the May Department Stores Company. She succeeds Robert J. Rieland, who resigned after running Meier & Frank for five years.

title: STAGE: A SAKAMOTO PLAY, 'YELLOW IS MY FAVORITE COLOR'
description: IN ''Yellow Is My Favorite Color,'' the diversity of theatrical talent in the Asian-American community is demonstrated far less in the writing than in the performances in leading roles by Henry Yuk and Raul Aranas. Edward Sakamoto's new play, a production of the Pan Asian Repertory Theater at the SoHo Rep, is basically a rudimentary reworking of a stockpot of cliches.

title: Rates Down on Treasury Bills; Six-Month Yield 15.12%
description: Interest rates declined for new three- and six-month Treasury bills yesterday and yields fell for longer-term Treasury notes and bonds. At the Treasury's regular Monday auction of new three- and sixmonth bills, average rates were 15.24 percent and 15.12 percent, respectively. Those rates were down sharply from the previous week's near-record averages of 15.67 percent for three-month bills and 15.57 percent for six-month bills.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS NEUTRON WEAPONS ARE BEING BUILT
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that neutron weapons were already in production and that the United States would shortly have the capability to deploy them overseas within a few hours of a decision to do so.

title: Market Place; A Look at Bids For Schlitz
description: THE competing bids for the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company are closer than they might appear at first glance. The G. Heileman Brewing Company has made the lower of the two bids at $17 a share. This bid is likely to appeal to those Schlitz holders who want to continue their investment in the brewing industry. Schlitz holders would get Heileman stock and cash with a total value of $17 a Schlitz share at the time the deal closes. The Heileman offer is thus valued at $493 million.

title: ADJUSTING TO CRIME
description: What happens when the private mind and the public consciousness wearily accept the inevitability of a crime wave? Herewith some impressions of the new realities, from a day of wandering through the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street:

title: Davis Publications Sells 2 Magazines
description: Davis Publications, which publishes more than 20 titles, has announced the sale of two of them: Camping Journal, which has been acquired by Travel Holiday Magazine, and Creative Computers (formerly Science and Electronics), sold to Creative Computing.

title: SCOTT STOPS ROYSTER IN SEVENTH ROUND
description: James Scott, serving a life sentence for a murder in Newark, resumed his professional boxing career tonight after a 15-month layoff by stopping Lee Royster at 52 seconds of the seventh round in a light-heavyweight bout.

title: Shots Claim 2d Firefighter
description: A shooting last week at the Tampa fire department headquarters has claimed the life of a second firefighter. Isaac Royal, 26 years old, one of three shot at Fire Station No. 1, died last night at Tampa General Hospital. Anthony L. D'Arcangelo, 26, a dismissed firefighter, is being held without bond as the shooting suspect..

title: MCQUEEN IN 1976 'ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE'
description: WHEN the late Steve McQueen appeared in ''An Enemy of the People'' in 1976, only to find that Warner Bros. was unwilling to release the film the following year, it sounded as if Mr. McQueen's brush with Ibsen might have been genuinely disastrous. It wasn't, but neither was it exciting enough to warrant an expensive, big-studio publicity campaign or to lure a large audience.

title: STRIKE SEEN IMPOSING AIRLINE CHANGE
description: As an ironic side effect of the air controllers' strike, overall constraints will be imposed on the airline industry -despite passage of the the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978, industry experts said yesterday. They voiced hope that as a result, the airlines' profitability would be enhanced in the coming months.

title: ROBERT LAWRENCE, FOUNDER OF FRIENDS OF FRENCH OPERA
description: Robert Lawrence, founder and musical director of the Friends of French Opera, died of a brain tumor at St. Luke's Hospital on Sunday. He was 69 years old.

title: GALANOS: LUXURY TUNICS, PANTS...
description: James Galanos showed one of his watershed collections yesterday afternoon. It started at 3:20 P.M., 20 minutes late - an acceptable delay for both dinner parties and fashion shows - and an hour and a half later, he had changed the face of fashion.

title: CONSUMER DEBT UP $1.93 BILLION IN JUNE
description: American consumers bought $1.93 billion more on credit than they paid off in June, even though they were paying off old installment debt at a record level, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: NABISCO'S MERGER SPARKS REVAMPING
description: A month after Nabisco and Standard Brands merged to form Nabisco Brands Inc., a food processing concern, the two independently operated companies have been abolished, effective Sept. 1, and two new operating units have been established.

title: Matthews Steps In As Giants' Fullback
description: Bo Matthews, once one of the brightest prospects in professional football, has become the Giants' No.1 fullback by default. And, though he is not thrilled that the reason is the injury suffered by Leon Perry during Saturday night's 23-7 exhibition victory over the Bears at Chicago, he makes it clear that he is happy to have the job.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: IF ALL CRIMINAL ACTS WERE JUDGED INSANE
description: To the Editor:

title: THIRD WORLD NATIONS ASSAIL U.S. POSITION IN LAW OF SEA TALKS
description: Representatives of third world nations today accused the United States of displaying a ''cavalier attitude'' toward eight years of negotiations on a treaty to regulate the use of the oceans and said they were unwilling to reopen negotiations on issues already agreed upon in a draft treaty.

title: LOAN PROGRAM WILL SOON GO TO 14 PERCENT
description: THE offer is good for only a few more weeks. It is for one of the last remaining ''bargains'' in higher education: 9 percent loans to parents that will soon become 14 percent loans.

title: Is It Safe to Fly?
description: ''It's like the movie 'Airplane,' '' says one striking air controller. ''The people up in the tower just aren't handling things very well.'' But that's not the view of Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis. ''The airways have never been safer,'' he claims.

title: BRITISH COMPANIES SELLING MORE EQUITY
description: British companies are moving into the stock markets to raise record amounts of new money. This year has already seen more equity offerings than in all of 1980, and the total so far - $2.6 billion - has already surpassed the previous record year, l975, when $2.53 billion was raised. The 1981 figure has been somewhat bloated by the record $1.18 billion stock offering by BP Ltd. in June, but even apart from that, British companies are clearly turning to the equity market in greater numbers.

title: FATE OF BINGHAMTON'S SEALED TOWER STILL UNCERTAIN
description: Meeting in the shadow of an 18-story state office tower contaminated by toxic soot, state officials tried to reassure the residents of this quiet community today that the state's plans for cleaning the building would leave Binghamton's downtown a safe place to live and do business.

title: Wyoming Man Is Fined In Theft of Indians' Oil
description: Howard M. Smith, a Lovell businessman, was fined $2,500 today for his part in the theft of 5,600 barrels of oil from the Wind River Indian Reservation.

title: DEARIE COLLECTS $601,837 FOR PRIMARY CAMPAIGN
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie has obtained contributions and loans totaling $601,837 for his primary campaign against City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, according to his financial report filed yesterday with the City Board of Elections.

title: A PSYCHIATRIST WHO WOULDN'T TAKE NO FOR AN ANSWER
description: PHILADELPHIA FOR years, Aaron T. Beck had to struggle. In the 1970's he published his own journal to, as he puts it, ''bootleg'' reports of his studies that other psychiatric journals rejected. He wrote a textbook, too, to get the word out about the discipline he called ''cognitive therapy.'' Now, in an era when therapeutic approaches form and fade like so many snowflakes, Dr. Beck's cognitive therapy is finally being taken seriously by mental-health professionals. The 60-year-old University of Pennsylvania psychiatry professor's work is reported regularly in both psychological and psychiatric journals and the Federal Government is beginning a major study to compare the success of cognitive therapy to that of another promising approach in treating depression.

Cosmos' slump C15 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A16

title: HOW TO IMPROVE THE CLEAN AIR ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Up 1.14 in Slow Trading
description: The stock market closed mixed yesterday in continued slow trading with energy issues posting the best gains. Wall Street's concern over the direction of interest rates kept many investors on the sidelines.

title: HOW ATLANTIC ROUTES ARE AFFECTED
description: The shortest way to Europe from the United States is through airspace controlled by Canada. So when some Canadian air traffic controllers refused to handle planes into and out of the United States, the effect was to disrupt air travel on the world's busiest intercontinental flight routes.

title: Energy Parley Opens With Third-World Plea
description: The United Nations conference on unconventional energy sources opened here today with third-world leaders calling for a global energy strategy to break through the barriers between the rich North and the poor South and provide alternatives to dwindling hydrocarbon fuels.

title: TWO BROTHERS KILLED IN SUBWAY ACCIDENT AT STATION IN BRONX
description: Two brothers were killed by a northbound IRT train as it pulled into the station at 138th Street and Grand Concourse in the Bronx yesterday evening, a spokesman for the Transit Authority said.

title: GEORGE SCHAEFER, MOVIE HEAD
description: George J. Schaefer, who started in the movie industry in 1914 as a secretary and later became president and chief executive officer of RKO Radio Pictures, died at White Plains Hospital on Saturday. His age was 92. He lived in Larchmont, N.Y. and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: South African Car Deal
description: The new R-9 Renault will be manufactured under license in South Africa by a subsidiary of BL Ltd., the British state-owned auto maker, Regie National des Usines Renault said today. The vehicle should be on the South African market by 1983, it added.

title: MUIR SAYS IT WILL QUIT RETAIL BROKER BUSINESS
description: John Muir & Company, the controversial Wall Street brokerage firm propelled by Raymond L. Dirks from obscurity to prominence, announced yesterday that it will withdraw from the retail brokerage business.

title: ENIGMATIC F.A.A. CHIEF: J LYNN HELMS
description: Soon after he took over as the new head of the Federal Aviation Administration, J. Lynn Helms asserted that the agency ''will, at my direction, stay out of the press as much as possible.''

title: BODY'S MANY RHYTHMS SEND MESSAGES ON WHEN TO WORK AND WHEN TO PLAY
description: IF you need to hammer some nails, the best time to do it may be at 3 P.M. If you're running a 50-yard dash, you'll probably do it fastest at 4 P.M. If you're about to have a baby, chances are you'll go into labor around midnight.

title: ...CALVIN KLEIN: SUEDE AND MIDRIFFS FOR RESORTS
description: Resort collections, more than any others, concentrate on clothes for play and leisure hours. They are, most of them, destined to compete with tropical foliage under southern skies while farther north women huddle shivering under furs and sweaters.

title: Israeli Mission in Athens Is Damaged by Bombs
description: Two bombs exploded outside the Israeli mission here early today, causing minor damage and no injuries. An Israeli spokesman said the Palestine Liberation Organization claimed responsibility in two phone calls to the mission.

title: NEIGHBORS BACK INDIANS IN FIGHT ON DEPORTATION
description: Except for such characteristics as their Hindu religion, Shailesh K. Patel and his family would blend right into this Main Line community, where he runs a service station, and the suburban Chester County township, where they have a two-story house, a broad lawn and a patio and redwood table for cookouts.

title: U.S. READY TO END SUIT ON A.T.&T.
description: In a further indication of the Reagan Administration's desire to end the Government's antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Justice Department's chief antitrust enforcer said today that the suit would be dropped as soon as a telecommunications deregulation bill is ''pretty well along'' in Congress.

title: Krugerrand Sales Up
description: International Krugerrand sales rose to 447,076 ounces in July, more than double the 207,011 ounces sold in June and well above the 255,170 sold in July 1980, the International Gold Corporation, South Africa's marketing agency, said today. The agency said that the July sales total was the highest since December 1979, when 695,030 one-ounce coins were sold. International Gold said the increase was the result in part of a significant revival of sales in the United States.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Conrail Cuts Rates on Steel
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation announced today that it would reduce rates for iron and steel shipments on Sept. 1 by as much as 23 percent.

title: Holding Company To Buy Lightolier
description: The Bairnco Corporation, a New York-based holding company formed earlier this year, said it had agreed to acquire Lightolier Inc., a leading designer and manufacturer of commercial, institutional and residential lighting fixtures and portable lamps based in Jersey City, N.J., for $28 a share in cash.

title: Esso Resources Canada
description: Esso Resources Canada Ltd., a unit of Imperial Oil Ltd., said today that its Issungnak 2-0-61 delineation well in the Beaufort Sea flowed at a combined rate of more than 6,400 barrels of oil and 49.6 million cubic feet of natural gas per day. The company said existing information was not sufficient to permit a definitive calculation of recoverable reserves and producing capacity. Additional delineation drilling would be necessary to determine the reserve potential, it said.

title: Finders Keepers for Navy Radioman
description: His commanding officer was so impressed with Gerald W. Bentz Jr.'s honesty that he gave him a one-day leave yesterday so he could fly from Charleston, S.C., to Cincinnati to pick up the $1,000 he found on a street there a month ago.

title: UNIONS' AID ABROAD LAID TO TRADITION
description: Nearly all of the scattered support that the nation's striking air traffic controllers have received so far has come from foreign workers, not from American workers or American unions, and labor experts in this country say that this fact is due in large part to deeper, more intense traditions of worker solidarity abroad.

title: DEPLETION OF UNDERGROUND WATER FORMATION IMPERILS VAST FARMING REGION;
description: In 30 years, drawing on a vast underground water formation called the Ogallala Aquifer, High Plains farmers have transformed a barren dust-bowl landscape into one of the richest agricultural regions of the world. Now, in many areas, the formation is nearly drained; everywhere, the water table dropping away from the irrigation pipes and pumps at a rate that has begun to frighten officials and farmers alike.

title: American Leads Jesuits During Superior's Illness
description: A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Jesuit order said today that the Rev. Vincent O'Keefe of the United States was leading the worldwide order during the illness of its Superior General, the Rev. Pedro Arrupe of Spain.

title: ESTEE LAUDER CHANGES
description: Louis Urvois, 40, has been appointed president of Estee Lauder International, a subsidiary of Estee Lauder Inc. that is responsible for about half of all corporate sales. He succeeds Robert M. Worsfold, 55, who took early retirement from the big cosmetics manufacturer ''to pursue non-business interests.''

title: G.T.E. Awards RCA Contract
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation said it has awarded a contract valued at more than $100 million to the RCA Corporation to build three satellites as part of a new G.T.E. satellite communications system.

title: Tribune Co.  Net Dips 16.1%
description: The Tribune Company, a privately held company that publishes The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, said today that its second-quarter profits slid 16.1 percent, reflecting lower operating profits at its newsprint and forest products division in Canada and operating losses at The Daily News.

title: Five in Court in South Africa In the Slaying of U.S. Lawyer
description: Five farmworkers appeared briefly in the Amanzimtoti magistrate's court today in connection with the murder July 29 of Catherine Julia Tobin, a New York lawyer.

title: EX-DIPLOMAT OF CYPRUS
description: Nicos G. Dimitriou, the Cypriot Ambassador to the United States from 1974 to 1979, died today in Cyprus after a cerebral hemorrhage, the Cypriot Embassy announced. He was 61 years old.

title: GENUINE RISK DISPLAYS A RETURN TO FORM
description: The Genuine Risk who won the Kentucky Derby last year, not the one who struggled home third against mediocre turf horses in her last start, returned to the races today.

title: MCA Inc.'s Net
description: MCA Inc., a major film entertainment concern, yesterday reported that net income for the second quarter was $30.9 million, or $1.30 a share.

title: A SMALL BUT NOT A ONE-HORSE TOWN
description: Indignation building within him, Frank T. Robbins, unofficial mayor of this resort community, scanned The Racing Form and brooded over his first beer of the day at Barclay's sidewalk cafe.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COUNTING A FESTIVAL

title: Product Introductions In Summer Slump
description: New-product introductions suffered the usual summer slump last month, according to the New Product News newsletter published by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

title: Ethics Code Urged For School Boards
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The State Attorney General, finding potential conflicts of interest by Essex County's Schools Superintendent, recommended yesterday that the State Education Department draw up a code of ethics for local districts.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International Inc., Los Angeles, has elected Terrance J. Bruggeman vice president, finance and administration.

title: Iowa-Wisconsin Bridge To End 7-Month Closing
description: The U.S 18 bridge spanning the Mississippi River is to reopen Wednesday, ending seven months of frustration for commuters who saw their two-mile trip extended to a 67-mile detour because of a crack in a steel support beam.

title: THE MAYOR'S LOWER EAST SIDE STORY: TENEMENTS INTO CO-OPS FOR ARTISTS
description: A program for turning abandoned tenement buildings on the Lower East Side into cooperative housing for artists of moderate income is being developed by the city's Department of Housing, Preservation and Development. The buildings, on Forsyth Street between Rivington and Stanton Streets and East Eighth Street between Avenues B and C, are part of the city's stock of some 9,000 residential structures abandoned by landlords in tax arrears.

title: Network TV Ads Up by 6.7% in Quarter
description: Advertising on network television rose 6.7 percent, to $1.4 billion, in the second quarter of 1981, the Television Bureau of Advertising has reported.

title: RCA Americom Wins U.S. Contract
description: RCA Americom Communications Inc. said it has received a $15.3 million contract from the General Services Administration to provide an additional 608 satellite circuits between six cities for Government communications.

title: Drugs for Weight Loss
