description: The use of appetite-suppressant drugs to help people lose weight may actually be counterproductive in the long run, according to the findings of the first large-scale, long-term study comparing drug therapy with behavior modification.

title: ASSAYING THE BIDDING WAR FOR CONOCO
description: Ralph E. Bailey, a big sandy-haired man who rose through the ranks of the coal industry to become chairman of the nation's ninth-largest oil company, looked tired and distracted as he sank into an armchair in his corner office.

title: FEW CHANGES EXPECTED SOON IN NUCLEAR AGENCY'S POLICIES
description: Peter A. Bradford's decision to leave the Nuclear Regulatory Commission next winter will give Reagan Administration appointees an earlier chance than had been expected to dominate the agency, which has primary responsibility for regulating nuclear power.

title: Soviet Accuses Reagan Of Playing 'With Fire'
description: The Soviet Union said today that President Reagan's decision to produce neutron weapons was ''a dangerous game with fire'' that Western European nations should oppose in their own interests.

title: SOME AIR ROUTES TO EUROPE SHUT FOR HOURS AS STRIKERS GET CANADIAN GROUP'S HELP
description: The Federal Aviation Administration shut down several trans-Atlantic air routes from six major cities in the United States for three hours today.

title: SPECIAL PANELS WILL ARBITRATE LOCAL DISPUTES
description: Neighborhood disputes could be resolved by special arbitration panels rather than the courts under a measure that has been signed by Governor Carey.

title: Atlantic City Asks For Truancy Fines
description: ATLANTIC CITY (UPI) - City school officials, concerned about high truancy rates, said they had asked a judge to enforce a seldom-used state law imposing fines on parents of students who miss too much school.

title: 'THE US VS. THEM DEBATE IS LONG DEAD'
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AMERICANS ARE BACK ON ROADS, BUT GAS PRICES ARE SHORTENING THEIR TRIPS
description: Before the revolution in Iran disrupted its oil exports, leading to long lines and much higher prices for gasoline in the United States, Harold and Virginia Burens would drive almost 350 miles from their home in Pittsburgh to Wildwood on the Jersey Shore for their vacation.

title: Harvester to Close Truck Plant Soon
description: The International Harvester Corporation announced that it would close its Wagoner, Okla., truck plant within 60 days because of a decline in demand, leaving 170 persons without jobs.

title: 57 FRENCH CITIZENS LAND IN PARIS AFTER BEING DELAYED BY IRANIANS
description: Fifty-seven French citizens, whose departure from Iran had been held up by the Iranian Government since last week, arrived here tonight.

title: PEKING OPERA: INTENSE ACTING
description: PEKING OPERA isn't all that old, as art forms go. Its rigidly prescribed conventions, maintained by generations of highly trained actors through 200 years of shifting tastes and the brutal shock of the Cultural Revolution suffered in China from 1966 to 1977, have given Peking Opera the aura of ancient, inviolable tradition. But Peking Opera in the Ch'i Style, which opens in its American debut season at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night for 15 performances, dares, as they say, to be different.

title: High School Player Dies
description: A 17-year-old high school football player died today of an apparent heart attack on the first day of football practice, Fairfax County authorities said.

title: La Quinta Account
description: Cunningham & Walsh will be opening an office in Dallas to service the La Quinta Motor Inns account just landed by its Chicago office and also Lenox Industries of Dallas, a longtime client. La Quinta, based in San Antonio, has 103 inns in 24 states. The ad budget may exceed $1 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Apex Oil said a subsidiary began its previously announced tender offer for shares of Clark Oil and Refining Corp. at $37 net per share. Apex, which owns 9.9 percent of Clark's outstanding shares, recently acquired the right to purchase an additional 53.5 percent of the outstanding shares from certain members of the Clark and Dawes families.

title: U.S. CANADA FLIGHTS ARE CANCELED IN TURBULENT DAY ON 2 CONTINENTS
description: Trans-Atlantic air travel was thrown into confusion yesterday as international airlines and governmental aviation officials reacted to a report that Canadian air traffic controllers would refuse to guide American flights over the western Atlantic.

title: CABDRIVERS TO ANSWER SURVEY
description: New York City's independent taxi-driver organizations announced yesterday that they would survey their 5,000 members to try to determine if the 50-cent night surcharge had encouraged drivers to work in the evenings and on Sundays.

title: Storm Churns in Atlantic
description: A tropical storm called Dennis, carrying top winds of 65 miles an hour, churned westward through the Atlantic toward the island of Barbados today but showed no signs that it was strengthening into a hurricane, forecasters said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Although most older elm trees have fallen victim to Dutch elm disease, the younger elm trees seem healthy. Is it possible that the American elm tree has achieved an immunity to this disease?

title: Nurses Picket on Cape Cod
description: Eighty registered nurses walked picket lines outside Cape Cod Hospital for a second day today, despite pleas from Dr. Gerald W. Hazard, chief of the medical staff, that they return to the emergency room and intensive care units. The emergency room, staffed by two doctors and a dozen nurse supervisors, continued to operate. But all seriously ill patients were sent to other hospitals for admission.

title: Kidporn, Outrage and the Law
description: Courts often make people angry, but few rulings have stirred so much hostility as the ''kidporn'' decision by the New York Court of Appeals last May. It struck down one portion of a 1977 law concerning the use of minors in a ''sexual performance.'' Letters of protest against the ruling, and against our approving editorial, have poured in ever since. Some represent an organized outrage; many are anguished personal complaints; all ask the same questions:

title: Judges Report On Arbitration
description: Arbitration panels of lawyers reached out-of-court settlements in 13,599 civil cases statewide in the first four months of 1981 at an ''appreciable'' saving of time and money for litigants and the court system, according to a New York State judicial report.

title: CANADA THREATENS DISCIPLINARY ACTION AGAINST CONTROLLERS
description: The Canadian Government moved today to crack down on air controllers who refused to handle flights to and from the United States.

title: Washington and Oregon Endure 5th Day of Heat
description: The Pacific Northwest's typically gray, damp summer has burned away in a rare heat wave that has sparked forest fires, sent air-conditioner sales soaring and driven residents to beaches in search of relief.

title: Reagans' Attire as Carter Threw In the Towel
description: It was late afternoon in California and the polls were still open, so Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy thought it would be a good time to get ready for the long election night ahead.

title: TENSION DECLINES AS POLES RESUME TALKS
description: An atmosphere of confrontation that had sharpened in the last few days eased somewhat today as the Government sent a Cabinet minister to Gdansk for talks with the Solidarity union.

title: Patience, Accuracy Mark Nelson Game
description: Judging by the way they were shouting with pride, you'd have thought kit was Ty Cobb or Bob Jones walking up the fairway. There were perhaps 20,000 Georgians massed around the 18th fairway and green Sunday at the Atlanta Athletic Club course in Duluth, Ga. And although the man they were cheering was not Cobb or Jones, he was one of their own - Larry Gene Nelson, from nearby Acworth.

title: HOOVER REALIGNING OVERSEAS OPERATION AS PROBLEMS GROW
description: During the 1920's it was not unusual for 2,000 or more of the Hoover Company's door-to-door vacuum cleaner salesmen to gather in William H. Hoover's pasture for several days and nights to sing company songs, listen to spirited pep talks from sales managers and hear about the fast-growing young company's latestmodel electric floor sweeper.

title: Two Men Indicted In Textile Scheme
description: A Nassau County grand jury accused two men of stealing more than $2 million in textile products from their employer and selling them through their own company.

title: CHEMISTS MAKE STEADY GAINS IN FILM SPEED AND
description: SHARPNESS By JOSEPH WILLIAMS

title: Sports of The Times; The Game Is Back
description: THE boys, waiting for the players, were perched on the wooden barricades like swallows who knew the game had returned to Capistrano. For eight weeks they had gone without baseball - no games on television, no scores in the morning paper, no crowds outside Yankee Stadium. But yesterday, on a muggy afternoon in the Bronx, the sign said ''Opening Night,'' and the ritual of baseball began anew for everybody -players, police, vendors and fans.

title: A LEADER IN EFFORTS TO SAVE LANDMARKS
description: Edward Steese, a retired architect and a leader in the movement to preserve New York City's historic and architectural landmarks, died Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: Chess: Reshevsky May Be 69, But Don't Underestimate Him
description: Age did not wither Samuel Reshevsky in the last round of the United States Championship: The 69-year-old Spring Valley, N.Y., grandmaster needed one last victory to tie with Larry Christiansen and Lubomir Kavalek for third place, and he got it.

title: Turner Ads Placed
description: McDonald & Little, the biggest ad agency in Atlanta, which is soon to be bought by Ted Bates & Company, has just been chosen by Ted Turner to do advertising for Turner Broadcasting and the Cable News Network. The two previously had their promotion done by Communications Trends, which will continue with a few projects, while the McDonald shop spends the next three months getting up a long-term marketing and communications plan for the client.

title: Colonial Penn Posts a Loss
description: The Colonial Penn Group Inc. today reported a net loss of $3.1 million for the second quarter, compared with net income of $17.2 million, or $1.06 a share, in 1980's second quarter.

title: Hotel Planned in Buffalo
description: Governor Carey joined local officials and businessmen today in announcing plans for a new 400-room hotel in downtown Buffalo. The Governor - who was here also to attend the funeral of a former Mayor of Buffalo, Stanley Makowski - and the other officials announced that a $36.6 million Hyatt Regency Hotel is to be built at Main and Genesee Streets. Financing for the hotel, which is scheduled to open in 1984, includes $11 million in Urban Development Action Grant funds.

title: CONTINENTAL WITHOUT ITS CHIEF
description: The apparent suicide of Alvin L. Feldman, chairman and chief executive officer of Continental Air Lines, comes near the end of the 53-year-old executive's bitter struggle to prevent Continental from being taken over by another airline - a struggle Continental now seems to be losing.

title: HALF OF THE CITY'S NEW HIRES ARE MINORITY WORKERS
description: More than 50 percent of the new workers hired by New York City in the last three years were members of minority groups, who now make up 36 percent of the city's full-time work force, the Koch administration says.

title: POOR AIM IN WAR ON BIAS
description: Adam Smith and John Rawls each say that justice is the paramount virtue of society, but they mean very different things. Adam Smith's argument is that without some justice in the society, the society cannot survive. There cannot be a society without some predictabilty, and that predictability must be based upon some principle. John Rawls makes the very different argument that every increment of justice is categorically more important than any increment of any other benefit.

title: BOUNCING WHEEL KILLS DRIVER OF A BUS ON L.I. EXPRESSWAY
description: A wheel broke off a car yesterday morning, bounced off the bumper of a truck and then smashed through the front window of a crowded bus, killing its driver and sending the driverless vehicle roaring down the Long Island Expressway with its passengers screaming.

title: Carter Gets Decisive Double As Expos Topple Pirates, 3-1
description: Gary Carter and Tim Wallach each drove in a run in the eighth inning tonight and led the Montreal Expos to a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. A crowd of 37,275 attended the game at Olympic Stadium on the starting day of the second-half of the major league baseball season.

title: Caracas Oil Output
description: Venezuelan oil production for 1981 through Aug. 5 averaged 2 million barrels a day, a decline of 69,000 from average daily output in 1980, the Mines and Energy Ministry said today.

title: Testing Principals and Principles
description: The perennial battle over how best to choose principals for New York City's schools has erupted again. And the battleground, deplorably, is again the courthouse rather than the schoolhouse.

title: Secret Site Is Planned For Springboks Match
description: The hosts of a rugby match involving a touring South African team say the game will be played in secrecy because of anticipated protests over apartheid.

title: Bridge: East Regaining Its Status As a Stronghold of Players
description: The center of gravity of playing strength, once firmly in New York and Philadelphia, shifted in the last two decades to Texas and California. Recent events in national knockout team championships, however, suggest that it has shifted back East.

title: 16 HURT IN COLLISION OF 2 VESSELS IN FOG NEAR MASSACHUSETTS
description: Sixteen persons were injured when two vessels collided in dense fog off Woods Hole this morning. The 229-foot steamer Naushon, with 350 passengers and a lower deck full of cars, and the 156-foot freighter Aurige, carrying 16 passengers and several vehicles, collided bow to bow while attempting to pass one another about a mile and a half offshore, according to the Coast Guard. The Aurige had just left Woods Hole headed for Vineyard Haven. The Naushon was going to Woods Hole.

title: Landlord Indicted In 'Terror' Drive
description: A landlord and his three sons were indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn grand jury on a long list of charges stemming from what was described in the indictment as a terror campaign to drive tenants from rentcontrolled apartments.

title: SEOUL MAY FREE KIM DAE JUNG
description: The South Korean Government is making preparations to free Kim Dae Jung, Seoul's most prominent political prisoner, on Saturday, dissidents and Korean diplomats here said today.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 11, 1981
description: Controllers' Strike Several trans-Atlantic routes were temporarily shut down at six major airports by the Federal Aviation Administration in response to reports that Canadian air traffic controllers were refusing to handle flights in and out of the United States. After the three-hour shutdown, new routes were arranged, permitting a resumption of flights between the United States and Europe. The F.A.A.'s order was the most dramatic indication that the eight-day-old strike by 12,000 controllers was beginning to have some effect. Members of the Canadian controllers' union said they considered airspace over the United States to be unsafe. New York, Washington, Boston, Chicago, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh were affected. (Page A1, Col.6.) Trans-Atlantic air travel was marked by confusion as international airlines and governmental aviation officials reacted to a report of action taken by Canadian air traffic controllers. In addition to the disruptions, almost all flights between the United States and Canada were grounded and some domestic and other international flights were delayed. (A1:4-5.)

title: ROCK CONCERT: PAT BENATAR
description: TWO brands of nuts-and-bolts rock music shared the bill at the Dr Pepper Festival over the weekend. Pat Benatar, who headlined, is probably the most popular female rock singer in America right now, her third album, ''Precious Time,'' having soared to No. 1 on the charts in only three weeks.

title: People
description: * Fergus O'Daly has been named president of Poppe Tyson Inc., succeeding Fred C. Poppe, who becomes chairman and chief executive officer, a new position.

title: HERMAN GOLLOB MOVING TO SIMON & SCHUSTER
description: Herman Gollob, vice president and editorial director of the Doubleday book clubs as well as editor in chief of the Literary Guild, will join Simon & Schuster next month as a vice president, senior editor and member of the editorial board.

title: TV Earnings Down in 1980; Revenues Up
description: Despite an 11.8 percent rise in revenues, the American television industry's pretax earnings declined last year for the first time in a decade, the Government says.

title: Canned Roast Beef Recalled
description: A voluntary recall of vacuum-packed cooked roast beef has begun by the Vincent Giordano Prosciutto Company of Philadelphia after tests on samples showed bacteria that could cause food poisoning, the Agriculture Department said today. The company distributes products in the Northeast under the brands of Vincent Giordano, Joy, Lapin, Twin Brothers, Big Apple and Allied Farms.

title: FROM YALE TO BROADWAY
description: David Alan Grier, a recent graduate of the Yale School of Drama, who has never before appeared on Broadway, will portray the late Jackie Robinson in the new musical ''The First,'' which will open at the Martin Beck Theater on Nov. 12.

title: IN ERA OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY, PRAISE FOR THE SIMPLE TESTS
description: IN an era when medicine has become increasingly dependent on machinery and technology, it is refreshing to learn that doctors have devised a simple, and significant, diagnostic test they can do with the patient's hands.

title: A BUILDUP IN DISARRAY
description: Ronald Reagan is out West cutting brush and chopping wood in a well-earned glow of satisfaction at having established his economic program and his dominance over Congress. Behind him, however, he has left his proposed military buildup - the other most prominent part of his 1980 mandate -in considerable disarray.

title: Army Drafts Ayer Again
description: The United States Army still wants N.W. Ayer. The Army Recruiting Command announced yesterday that, after considering a bid by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, it has again chosen as its agency N.W. Ayer Inc., which has been handling its advertising since 1967.

title: Soviet Talks On Grain Due
description: It probably will be late September or early October before the United States is ready to tell the Soviet Union how much grain it will be allowed to buy in the coming year, a senior Agriculture Department official said today.

title: Nader Urges a Stockman Trip for Budget 'Reality'
description: Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, is opposed to many of the Reagan Administration's budget cuts, and yesterday he suggested a remedy - a series of field trips for the President's budget director, David Stockman.

title: U.S. Home to Buy Golden West
description: The U.S. Home Corporation, the nation's largest on-site builder of single-family homes, said it will acquire Golden West Homes, a prefabricated housing manufacturer, in a share exchange valued at $45 million.

title: McGraw-Hill Names New Editor in Chief
description: McGraw-Hill, the publishing company, has been undergoing a series of high-level shake-ups lately, and they continued yesterday with the announcement that Gladys Justin Carr, a McGraw-Hill senior editor, would take over as editor in chief of hardcover trade books and chairman of the editorial board of a newly restructured general books division.

title: CLIMATE CYCLES STUDIED IN EFFORT TO CURB DROUGHT
description: Despite widespread hardships caused by recent droughts, and despite predictions of radical climate changes, there is growing evidence that the climate of the United States has been relatively stable for the last four centuries.

title: PRICE OF WOMAN IN INDIA: $306 AND MUCH SORROW
description: Three months ago, Ashwini Sarin, a reporter for The Indian Express, the country's largest-circulation daily, purchased a woman for $306 and wrote about the experience.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are not going to be at the ransom of air controllers for the rest of the life of this country.'' - Jean-Luc Pepin, Canada's Transport Minister. (A1:5.)

title: MINNESOTA ACCORD REPORTED BY UNION
description: State and union negotiators today reached tentative agreement on a new contract to end a 22-day walkout by more than 14,000 of the state's 31,000 employees, and union officials said the workers would return to their jobs tomorrow.

title: POWER CORP. SELLING TRANSPORTATION UNIT
description: The Power Corporation, one of Canada's largest conglomerates with control of some 195 companies, announced today that it was selling its transportation business, the C.S.L. Group Inc., and buying into Canadian Pacific Ltd., the nation's largest enterprise.

title: Cabinet Says Premier Is Resigning in Portugal
description: Portugal's Cabinet announced today that Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao had resigned. The three parties in his center-right coalition pledged to remain in power.

title: Nixon Museum Plans To Go Out of Business
description: The museum dedicated to Richard M. Nixon's Presidency is going out of business, at least at its present location.

title: JETS' PLOY HAS HAPPY ENDING FOR SALAAM
description: It's called the end game, and it is the move that got Abdul Salaam, a defensive tackle, the Jets' only sack in their exhibition opener against the Broncos in Denver last Friday night, a 33-7 victory.

title: AMAX TO POSTPONE MOLYBDENUM MINE
description: Amax Inc. said yesterday it would postpone for at least two years its planned development of a controversial molybdenum mine in a mountain overlooking the ski-resort town of Crested Butte, Colo.

title: U.S. PRISONS CHIEF SAYS MORE CELLS MAY BE BUILT
description: The number of people in Federal prisons has begun to rise rather sharply after dropping steadily for several years. The director of the Federal prison system says that a new emphasis on prosecuting volent crime and narcotics cases is one reason for the increase.

title: Pan Am Asks Workers for 10% Pay Cut
description: Pan American World Airways, its finances strained by growing losses, has asked its 33,100 airline workers to take a 10 percent pay cut as soon as possible and to agree to freeze wages at the new level until the end of 1982.

title: HEAD OF CONTINENTAL AIR LINES
description: Alvin L. Feldman, the chairman and chief executive officer of Continental Air Lines, the nation's ninth-largest carrier, died Sunday night apparently by a self-inflicted gunshot. He was 53 years old.

title: Accord Ends Coke Boycott
description: A boycott of the Coca-Cola Company by a civil rights group ended today after the soft-drink concern promised to put $30 million into black-owned businesses and place a black on its board of directors.

title: P.&G. Earnings Are Up 19%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the giant food, soap and personal care concern, said today that earnings in the fourth quarter ended June 30 rose 19 percent to $144 million, or $1.74 a share, from $121 million, or $1.46 a share, in the same period a year ago. Sales rose 3.7 percent to $2.8 billion, from $2.7 billion.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SHUN CONFLICT IN TALKS TO BAR GROUP
description: Vice President Bush, Attorney General William French Smith and an array of other high Administration officials paid their first courtesy calls on the American Bar Association today, carefully skirting legal and political issues likely to generate controversy with the nation's largest organization of lawyers.

title: COST OF CARS ON THE IRT IS ASSAILED
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday that the low bid to build 325 new subway cars for the IRT lines was 67 percent higher than the Transit Authority's original estimate for the new cars. She suggested that the authority consider using the money, instead, to rehabilitate existing cars.

title: Marathon Well's Flow
description: Marathon Oil (U.K.) Ltd., the British unit of Marathon Oil, said that a test well in the Brae area of the North Sea yielded 3,624 barrels of crude oil and 26.1 million cubic feet of natural gas daily from a depth of 12,000 feet. Marathon also said that the well yielded 4,582 barrels a day of crude and 15.1 million cubic feet of gas at about 12,550 feet.

title: ASCAP TRAINING PROGRAM TO PRODUCE MUSICALS
description: Young composers, lyricists and librettists who have been studying in the training program of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the Dramatists Guild will have their works presented next winter in readings and workshops produced by Playwrights Horizons.

title: INDEPENDENT 5 YEARS, TRANSKEI IS TRAPPED BY LEGACY OF POVERTY
description: Five years ago, this black republic became the first of South Africa's 10 tribal ''homelands'' to be granted independence. But today, Transkei has little to show for its sometimes outlandish efforts to reduce the international ostracism, rural poverty and dependence on its wealthy, white-ruled neighbor that made up its birthright as a supposedly sovereign state.

title: Borg to Skip Tourney To Comfort Ailing Wife
description: Bjorn Borg withdrew from the Canadian Open tennis championship tonight to remain in New York with his wife, Mariana Simionescu, who was suffering from a kidney ailment, tournament officials said.

title: Tyler to Acquire Parts Distributor
description: The Hall-Mark Electronics Corporation and the Tyler Corporation, both of Dallas, announced agreements under which Tyler will purchase all Hall-Mark stock for $50 million. The acquisition is scheduled for completion about Oct. l and Hall-Mark will operate as a wholly owned subsidiary, the companies said.

title: ON-BOARD RADAR COULD INCREASE AIR SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Business with Peter K. Nevitt of BankAmerilease; New Rules In Tax Leasing
description: Peter K. Nevitt is president of the BankAmerilease Group, the leasing subsidiary of the Bank of America. From this position, Mr. Nevitt has closely followed the changes being wrought in the $30 billion tax leasing industry as a result of the Administration's new tax plan.

title: SEARCH BY MOTHER LEADS TO SETTLEMENT IN DAUGHTER'S DEATH
description: A mother who could not understand why her 12 1/2-year-old daughter died at a hospital took a job there as a nurse trainee and spent three years searching medical books for the reason.

title: HALFWAY HOUSE UNOBTRUSIVELY PREPARING PRISONERS FOR SOCIETY
description: The promise of a job brought him to New York City from Connecticut two months ago. Now he works as the sales manager for a concern that manufactures heat exchangers, commuting every day from his Manhattan residence to a factory on Long Island.

title: Accounts
description: * Van de Kamp's Frozen Foods, Santa Fe Springs, Calif., to DiIorio, Wergeles Inc. for the development and introduction of a number of product lines.

title: EUROPEAN RESPONSE A WEAPON IS COOL
description: West European governments, with the exception of France, reacted with marked reserve today to the Reagan Administration's decision to proceed with full production of neutron weapons.

title: Note Threatens Court Officers
description: A note threatening unnamed judges and court officers was left over the weekend in the administrative wing of the Manhattan Criminal Court building at 100 Centre Street, authorities said.

title: SOME FLIGHTS TO EUROPE DELAYED AND CANCELED
description: Confusion and delays were reported today on trans-Atlantic flights after job actions by Canadian air traffic controllers in support of their American colleagues, Some flights were canceled, others were delayed for up to eight hours and still others were rerouted in an effort to get travelers to their destinations.

title: A SCHISM ON THE NILE
description: Isolated from his neighboring Arab brethren for his peace initiative with Israel, embarrassed by Prime Minister Menachem Begin's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor and faced with mounting opposition from the Socialist Labor Party in Egypt, the last thing President Anwar el-Sadat anticipated was an internal conflict that would threaten Egyptian national unity. Yet, this is exactly what happened on June 18 when a quarrel between two Egyptians, a Moslem and a Christian Copt, over whether a vacant tract of Government land should be used for a church or a mosque degenerated into a major sectarian confrontation.

title: FOREIGN EXCHANGE UNIT OF FED GETS NEW CHIEF
description: Sam Y. Cross, 54, has been appointed by the Federal Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System to run its foreign exchange operations. He has also been named by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, where he is a senior vice president, to supervise a newly formed group overseeing the bank's foreign exchange and foreign relations functions.

title: GOVERNORS LOOK AT CITIES' GREIVANCES
description: The National Governors' Association extended a peace overture today to the nation's mayors and county officials, but received a harsh response that indicated the feud between state and local governments over decreasing Federal funds would not end soon.

title: AWACS PROTECTED SADAT, U.S. AFFIRMS
description: The United States provided President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt with the one-day use of an American Awacs surveillance plane for his protection during a trip he made to Khartoum, the Sudan, on May 25, the State Department said today.

title: Teacher Beats Austin In Final by 6-3, 6-2
description: Top-seeded Brian Teacher of Los Angeles captured the $75,000 National Revenue Tennis Classic tonight with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over John Austin of Bakersfield, Calif.

title: U.S. HEADQUARTERS OF SALVATON ARMY ARE GOING TO JERSEY
description: The Salvation Army national headquarters, after more than 50 years on West 14th Street, will be moved Jan. 1 to Verona, N.J., near Montclair.

title: 16 COUSINS DECLARED HEIRS TO HUGHES ESTATE
description: Sixteen cousins of Howard R. Hughes on his mother's side today were declared legitimate heirs to half of the eccentric industrialist's estate.

title: 315 Vacant Lots in Chicago To Be Sold for as Low as $1
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne announced a plan today in which the city would sell 315 vacant lots on the South Side and West Side to next-door neighbors for as low as $1.

title: DECERTIFICATION BEGINS FOR CONTROLLERS' UNION
description: An administrative law judge ruled today that the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization was engaged in a strike, the initial step toward an effort by the Federal Government to decertify the union as bargaining agent for air traffic controllers.

title: Raider Jury Completes 10th Day Indecisively
description: The jurors in the trial of the Oakland Raiders antitrust suit against the National Football League completed their 10th day of deliberations today without reaching a verdict.

title: Domtar's Net Falls
description: Domtar Inc., the chemical and paper company, said today that earnings in the second quarter fell 30.6 percent, to $14.3 million (Canadian), or 81 cents a share, from $20.6 million, or $1.17 per share, a year earlier, despite an 8.1 percent rise in sales to $430 million from $397.7 million. The company claimed that strikes in its various divisions slashed first-half earnings at least 78 cents a share. A Canadian dollar is worth about 81 United States cents.

title: YANKEES BEAT RANGERS 2-0, BEFORE 40,373 AT STADIUM
description: After 59 days and 54 missed games, 40,373 appreciative New Yorkers welcomed their team home to Yankee Stadium last night, and the Yankees responded with a 2-0 victory over the Texas Rangers, losers of two opening games here this season.

title: Horses Conserve Energy
description: Traditional studies of the energy required by horses when walking, trotting, running or galloping showed that the faster the gait the more energy was required. But recent studies have shown that horses, by changing gait at the right time, use less energy than expected and could keep the energy cost of locomotion to a minimum as their speed increased.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 11, 1981; The Economy
description: The F.A.A. suspended all flights to Europe from six major airports when Canadian controllers refused to handle flights into and out of the United States. A few hours later, after a new route bypassing Canadian air space had been worked out, the suspension was lifted. (Page A1.) In the interim, however, trans-Atlantic air travel was thrown into confusion, with some flights canceled, others delayed, and still others rerouted or turned back en route. (A1.)

title: JOAN OF ARC'S 2D TRIAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Terms Set for Playoffs
description: The office of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday that the following conditions would be in effect for a team that wins its division in both halves of baseball's split season:

title: CHINAGLIA ANGERED BY SLUMP
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the captain of the Cosmos, tried to hide his anger and emotion, but he couldn't. ''Yes, we're in trouble,'' Chinaglia said yesterday. ''A lot of trouble.'' The Cosmos have scored two goals in their last three games, and their 2-0 loss to Edmonton on Sunday marked the first time they failed to score this season. It was also the first time since 1974 that the Cosmos have lost three straight games in the North American Soccer league.

title: PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND COLLEGES SEEK TO FORM A NEW ALLIANCE
description: COLORADO SPRINGS ''WE told them we didn't like what they are sending us and they told us they didn't like the teachers we sent them.'' The speaker was Sheldon Knorr, Maryland's commissioner for higher education, and Mr. Knorr's ''we'' were representatives of the colleges and universities. ''They'' were leaders of the public school establishment.

title: High Acid Levels Are Found In Colorado Mountain Lakes
description: Rain and snow with acidity almost as strong as undiluted vinegar have been detected in some high Colorado mountain lakes, scientists reported over the weekend.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Herbert Mitgang THE SAGE OF MONTICELLO. By Dumas Malone. Illustrated. 512 pages. Little, Brown. $19.95. THE JEFFERSON SCANDALS. By Vir- ginius Dabney. 155 pages. Dodd, Mead. $8.95.

title: EX-WELLS FARGO AIDE ADMITS EMBEZZLEMENT ROLE
description: A former officer of the Wells Fargo Bank, Lloyd Benjamin Lewis, pleaded guilty today to three felony counts in a $21 million embezzlement scheme and agreed to cooperate with the prosecution in the case.

title: Seoul Reports Loans
description: South Korea has obtained $4.5 billion in foreign loans so far this year, accounting for 58 percent of this year's annual loan target of $7.7 billion, Government officials reported today. Government economic planners have said that South Korea would have to borrow about $7.7 billion this year to help cover the nation's current account deficit and maintain a reasonable level of foreign exchange reserves.

title: U.S. PRESSES FOREIGN NATIONS TO KEEP ALL AIR ROUTES OPEN
description: The United States today pressed Canada, New Zealand and other nations where air controllers are supporting their striking American colleagues to take whatever steps were necessary to keep air routes open, State Department officials said today.

title: ANTI-REBEL PROPAGANDA IN BOLIVIA COMES WITH AN ARGENTINE ACCENT
description: The 15-minute cartoon showed a cynical bear and a vulture plotting to take over a tiny, far-off country. The bear was never identified, but its headquarters looked distinctly like the Kremlin.

title: Orioles Win in 12th On Lowenstein Hit
description: John Lowenstein stranded two runners as a pinch-hitter in the ninth inning, but made up for it by driving home the winning run with a single in the 12th as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Kansas City Royals, 3-2, before 19,850 fans tonight.

title: METS SCORE 2 IN 13TH TO DEFEAT CUBS BY 7-5
description: The Mets, who beat the Cubs to open the season April 9, did so again today as they reopened the split season with a 7-5 victory at Wrigley Field.

title: Judge Refuses to Block Haitian Ouster Hearings
description: A Federal judge today rejected an effort to block United States immigration officials from holding deportation hearings for Haitian refugees scheduled to be sent to a camp in Puerto Rico.

title: TRAVELERS ADVISED TO CALL
description: Though airlines said yesterday that they expected to maintain regular overseas service today, they advised passengers holding regular or excursion tickets to call for information about delays or other problems.

title: Hearst Purchases 30 Newspapers
description: The Hearst Corporation has acquired 30 Los Angeles County newspapers as part of a program to create a community network in conjunction with the Los Angeles Herald Examiner, officials announced.

title: Keeping Pollutants at Home
description: The best way to cope with increasing use of coal, according to a chemistry professor at the State University of New York at Syracuse, is to eliminate tall smokestacks. Instead of costly measures to control emissions, using such devices as scrubbers, precipitators, washers, cyclones and catalytic oxidizers, he would allow the emissions to spread locally.

title: AIRLINES SEEKING CONTEMPT JUDGMENT AND $25,000 DAILY FINE FOR PICKETING
description: The nation's airlines sought yesterday to have the striking air controllers' union declared in contempt of court and fined $25,000 a day for its picketing activities.

title: Ship Order in Britain
description: State-owned British Shipbuilders Ltd. said today that its subsidiary, Govan Shipbuilders Ltd., had obtained a $130 million (Canadian) contract for three 35,000-ton bulk carriers from Canadian buyers.

title: ROSE BREAKS MUSIAL'S CAREER HIT RECORD
description: Pete Rose, the Philadelphia Phillies' first baseman, broke Stan Musial's National League record for career hits tonight just when it seemed that he was going to disappoint a near capacity crowd of 60,561.

title: Heroin Seized in West Berlin
description: West German police have seized nine pounds of heroin with a black-market value of $4 million. A police spokesman said today that the heroin was discovered in the West Berlin apartment of two Turks last Tuesday by a trained bloodhound.

title: RETIRED COUPLES' BUDGET REPORTED UP 10.2%
description: The expenses of a typical retired couple increased 10.2 percent in the year that ended last November, lagging behind the inflation rate of 12.6 percent, the Department of Labor reported today.

title: FORKLIFT HITS SHUTTLE, CAUSING LITTLE DAMAGE
description: One minor mishap marred the transfer today of the space shuttle Columbia from its hangar to an assembly building where it will be fitted with the remaining components for its second space mission.

title: Transit Report
description: A cross-tie fire on the IRT tracks just north of Times Square at 6:48 A.M. disrupted northbound service and temporarily eliminated local stops between 42d and 72d Streets. Normal service on the No. 1 line was restored at 7:45 A.M.

title: Thrifts' Board Sets Bond Sale
description: In an indication of continued heavy borrowing demand by savings and loan associations, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday announced plans to sell $3 billion of new bonds to refund $1.8 billion of maturing bonds and raise $1.2 billion of new cash.

title: Advertising; Virtues Of Radio Marketing
description: SOMETHING for everyone. That's what radio merchandising is, according to Norman Raber, a marketing man who is trying to sell packaged goods companies on the idea. The concept, which Mr. Raber also describes more elegantly as ''triangular marketing,'' is a way of wooing consumers, tradespeople and the client's sales force, all for the price of radio time.

title: G.O.P. LEADER EXPRESSES HOPE ON PARTY FUTURE
description: Staten Island Republicans chose a comfortably familiar friend, a selfdescribed member of the local party's ''older guard,'' when they picked George M. Hart as their new leader.

title: Addenda
description: * Creamer Dickson Basford Inc., a subsidiary of Creamer Inc., has opened a Washington office.

title: NUCLEAR DISARMAMENT: TIME FOR STEP ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HERE was an awful lot sailing by last week: political asides at Oscar de la Renta; news that Johnny Carson's wife, Joanna, is now a partner at Michaele Vollbracht, the designer, and a birthday party for Count Crespi. There, Jerry Zipkin, playing gin rummy with Count Romanones and Reinaldo Herrera, said he would shuffle if nobody minded, thanks, and voiced the opinion that dark shirts and light ties look terrific. But first, there was the Model of the Year Contest, held in the garishly ornate Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf.

title: THE ROBERT MOSES FEW GOT TO KNOW
description: To the Editor:

title: FATAL CRASH NORTH OF L.I. RECOUNTED
description: The owner of a 36-foot cabin cruiser that was struck by a barge and sank in Long Island Sound Sunday night said yesterday that he had no warning he was in the way of the other craft, and disputed the tugboat company's version of the conversation between the two vessels in the minutes before the accident.

title: SOUTH KOREA SEEKING $10 BILLION FROM JAPAN
description: South Korea is seeking $10 billion in aid and loans from Japan over a five-year period starting in 1982, according to South Korean officials here.

title: REAGAN RESOLUTE ON STRIKE POLICY
description: Despite the increasing problems in the air traffic controllers' strike, President Reagan is determined not to alter his stand against either rehiring or negotiating with the more than 12,000 controllers whom he decided to dismiss for staging the strike, a senior White House official said today.

title: Soviet-Japan Steel Snag
description: The Soviet Union is asking Japanese steelmakers to renegotiate lower interest rates in a tentative agreement on steel-plate exports reached last month, industry sources said here today.

title: JURY WEIGHS KILLING IN CROWD
description: Four weeks after Kenneth Rex McElroy was surrounded by an angry mob and fatally shot, a grand jury here began its investigation today into the death of the part-time farmer known to some as the bully of Skidmore, Mo.

title: MARGARET PARTON, EX-REPORTER FOR NEW YORK HERALD TRIBUNE
description: Margaret Parton, a former reporter and foreign correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, died Sunday at her home in Sneden's Landing, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 66 years old.

title: Delay Due to Death Brings IND Uproar
description: A man fell to his death between two subway cars on the southbound IND line just north of 116th Street yesterday morning, setting off an outbreak of window-smashing vandalism by passengers on a following train that was delayed by the accident.

title: FOR FAST MEALS AND QUICK CLEANUPS
description: In one of the introductory sections to her new book, ''Keep It Simple'' (William Morrow, $11.95), Marian Burros quotes a speaker at a recent food editors' conference who said: ''For the household of the 1980's faster meal preparation and cleanup will be critical.''

title: CLAUDETTE COLBERT, AT 77: STARTING ALL OVER AGAIN
description: THERE are ladies who lunch; there are women who work. Claudette Colbert, having the option, works. If she does not work, she gets nervous, she says, hearing about people who are doing things, and then wondering why she isn't doing things, too. Lunch is an interlude then, and even life at home in Barbados grows stale. ''There's the restlessness,'' Miss Colbert says. ''It's, what do I do now?''

title: Real Estate; New Co-op Developer In City
description: "We wanted to work in the city,'' said Wayne L. Kasbar. ''We know it. We're comfortable in it. The market is good.'' That more or less summarizes the attitude that brought the Enterprise Development Group to bid - successfully, as it turned out - for the right to develop a 1.5-acre site on the east side of Third Avenue between 93d and 94th Streets, the final part of the Ruppert urban renewal area. Last week, the Koch administration announced the selection of the Enterprise Development Group with the Tishman Realty and Construction Company as the sponsor of 372 new cooperative apartments, with 20 percent set aside for lower-income tenants.

title: Tampax Net Gains
description: Tampax Inc., the leading maker of tampons, yesterday reported a 32.5 percent gain in second-quarter profits, reflecting increased sales after the Procter & Gamble Company was forced to withdraw a competing product from the market.

title: NEW LUSTER FOR STOCK OPTIONS
description: Top executives who receive stock options from their companies will find the new tax code treats these options quite handsomely. Moreover, employees who do not normally receive stock options may find it easier to win them as part of their compensation packages as a result of the new tax bill, benefit specialists predict.

title: U.S. Spy Balloon Goes Adrift
description: An Air Force balloon used to eavesdrop electronically on Cuba has broken its tether and is adrift somewhere over the Gulf of Mexico, the authorities said today. The balloon was anchored to a ground winch when it snapped its tether late yesterday as it was being cranked down, the Air Force said.

title: Cheese Industry Sets A Fall Campaign
description: D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/Chicago is starting a $5 million fall cheese industry promotion campaign for the American Dairy Association, to run for 12 weeks starting in September. The budget is 16 percent larger than it was a year ago for the original ''Cheese adds a slice of life'' campaign.

title: WALTKE STUNS CONNORS
description: Trey Waltke, ranked 52d in the world, defeated Jimmy Connors, 6-4, 6-3, tonight in a major upset at the Canadian Open tennis championships.

title: Sonny Mae Sets Bond Sale
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sonny Mae, announced plans yesterday to sell $100 million to $125 million of single-family home mortgage revenue bonds. The issue is scheduled for the last half of September through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: SENATE PANEL SAYS U.S. AIDES BUNGLED A TEAMSTER INQUIRY
description: A Senate subcommittee has sharply criticized the Labor Department's five-year investigation of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' Central States Pension Fund. The subcommittee report said that officials had wasted a ''historic opportunity'' to reform the fund and rid the union of the influence of organized crime.

title: STRAINERS
description: Oh, I know you already own a strainer, and chances are it is adequate. Strainers, after all, are the simplest of devices: a bowl of wire mesh suspended on a metal frame. They are most commonly used for the separation of liquids from solids, and just about every one I've ever seen, unless it had been punctured in some way, did the job well enough.

title: FOR KAZIN, LIFE TURNED FROM NOTES INTO BOOKS
description: ''THIS is a room I know very well but I never expected to eat my dinner here,'' said Alfred Kazin, the literary critic and teacher, at a recent function in the Main Reading Room of the New York Public Library. The NYPL (the library's scholarly abbreviation in a million footnotes) has just acquired his papers.

title: PERSICO SUBMITS A PLEA OF GUILTY TO A CONSPIRACY
description: Carmine Persico, who law-enforcement officials say is a top figure in organized crime in New York City, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to a conspiracy charge that carries a five-year prison term.

title: Fellowship at N.Y.U.  Honors Oscar Dystel
description: Bantam Books has endowed a fellowship at the Gallatin Division of New York University, in honor of Oscar Dystel, the company's former chief executive officer and an N.Y.U. graduate. The fulltime two-year course of academic study, for qualified students seeking careers in book publishing, will enroll its first student in the fall 1982 academic year.

title: REACTOR IN INDONESIA
description: Interatom Internationale, a unit of Kraftwerke Union, the West German steelmaker, has received a letter of intent from Indonesia to supply a $50 million nuclear research reactor, West German officials said today.

title: WALTER MANN
description: Walter Mann, a former New York City businessman and investor who had helped reorganize numerous financially distressed companies during the Depression, died Saturday at his home in Cypress Gardens, Fla. Mr. Mann, who was 83 years old, had been a resident of Manhattan.

title: EATING IN EDINBURGH: BEYOND HAGGIS
description: EDINBURGH SIXTEEN years ago a farmer's wife named Janet Henderson trekked in from the Scottish countryside with baskets full of her homegrown produce and loaves of whole-meal bread, put out her shingle on hilly Hanover Street and opened Henderson's Salad Table, thus starting a local culinary trend.

title: LONGER SENTENCES GIVEN IN WORST MISDEMEANORS
description: Career criminals in Manhattan who consistently commit the most serious misdemeanors - crimes punishable by up to a year in the Rikers Island jail -are getting longer sentences, according to statistics obtained from the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Cox Enterprises Must Resell Site
description: Cox Enterprises, an Atlanta-based holding company and the developer of a proposed $1 billion oil refinery here, must resell the site to the Norfolk & Western Railway, a Circuit Court judge has ruled.

title: HONDA'S NEW U.S. CHALLENGE
description: The commercial shows a sleek Honda machine running a grueling obstacle course, around trees and hedges. The voice-over uses the words ''maneuverability'' and ''handling'' to compare the small machine to its larger counterparts.

title: New Chief Chosen At Sears of Mexico
description: Guillermo Weidmann, 54 years old, will be running Sears Roebuck de Mexico, the Mexican subsidiary of the giant American retailer. He succeeds Jorge Lemus, who retired from the 43-unit chain at the age of 63, as its president and chief executive officer.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE soybean has been the ''meat of the Orient'' for more than 4,000 years. Considering its nutritional merits and extraordinary versatility as a food, the growing list of potential health benefits associated with its consumption and the cost of its competition, it could become an important factor in the American diet as well.

title: Spanish Food Poisoning Toll From Cooking Oil Rises to 89
description: Spain's poisonous cooking oil scandal entered its 100th day today having taken 89 lives and forced 11,000 people to seek hospital treatment.

title: India Seeks Record Loan
description: India is seeking a record $4 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund to help pay its soaring oil bills, I.M.F. officials said today.

title: OTTAWA AIDE ASSERTS COMPLETE AIR SERVICE TO U.S. IS RESUMING
description: Transport Minister Jean-Luc Pepin announced early this morning that full air traffic service would be restored between the United States and Canada at 8 A.M. eastern daylight time today.

title: Consumers' Confidence Up
description: A growing number of consumers expect business conditions to improve in the next six months, according to a nationwide survey released yesterday by the Conference Board, a business-sponsored research organization.

title: POP: THE NEVILLE BROTHERS
description: MONDAY evening saw one of the year's more extraordinary pop events as the Neville Brothers, the legendary musical family from New Orleans, turned the Savoy into a Mardi Gras festival. Working with a conductor and a dozen backup musicians, including a powerful horn section, the four brothers - Art, Charles, Aaron and Cyril - rewrote the dictionary of soul, uniting funk, doo-wop, reggae and salsa under the banner of New Orleans rhythm and blues.

title: THEATER: 'PEEP,' ABOUT PORNOGRAPHY
description: JAMES MURRAY'S ''Peep'' at the South Street Theater returns Theater Row to the sordid days of yesteryear when this stretch of West 42d Street was a seedy strip of peep shows and porno parlors. ''Peep'' takes us backstage at the Fantasy Theater to watch seven women prepare to go through their various erotic paces. To Mr. Murray's credit, the play avoids sensationalism. There is neither nudity nor simulation of sexual acts, although, necessarily, much of the language is blunt and vulgar.

title: CABLE NEWS SERVICE IS PLANNED BY ABC AND WESTINGHOUSE
description: ABC and Westinghouse intend to announce a plan today to create a 24-hour news network for cable television fashioned after the allnews approach used by many radio stations.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bristol-Myers Co. has elected Marion A. Klein vice presidentmarket research and Patrick F. Crossman vice president-corporate affairs.

title: FLXIBLE BUS CONTRACT IS APPROVED IN JERSEY
description: Directors of the New Jersey Transit Corporation recommended today that the commuter transportation operating agency proceed with a contract to purchase 271 Grumman Flxible buses.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MOZART: LEE LUVISI PIANO SOLOIST
description: AS Avery Fisher Hall's Mostly Mozart Festival threatens to turn Mozart into a common commodity, blurred into a background of summertime leisure, it was refreshing on Monday night to hear the pianist Lee Luvisi play the Piano Concerto No. 22 in E flat.

title: U.S. PLANS TO GIVE SOME UNUSED LOCKUPS TO STATES
description: Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's counselor, said today that the Administration hoped to turn over jails and prisons on some unused military bases to state and local governments in the next few months to help relieve overcrowding among inmates.

title: END OF AN ERA AT JOHN MUIR
description: Business goes on as usual at John Muir & Company. Orders are being taken by brokers, and the trading desk continues to function. But, to a large extent, the excitement is over. The heady rush of underwritings that made a name for this controversial small firm has halted. And the burgeoning retail sales network, in offices only months old, is up for sale.

title: Imported-Car Dealers on Rise
description: The number of auto dealers in the United States offering imported cars during the first half of 1981 rose by 566, to a total of 17,247, Automotive News said today.

title: HOW TRAVELERS CAN REACH DESTINATIONS IN OTHER COUNTRIES
description: Following is information on ways that international travelers can cope with disruptions caused by the air controllers' strike in the United States and by the job actions taken by controllers elsewhere. General Information for Travelers

title: Air Controllers' Leader Fails to Show in Court
description: Robert E. Poli, president of the striking controllers' union, failed to heed a judge's order that he appear in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday for questioning about his organization's assets.

title: A POLICE INSPECTOR PREPARES FOR THE UNTHINKABLE
description: New York is a city of disasters, some of them manageable. For red wine on white carpeting, the first date who never calls back, mice in the kitchen or a car that gets a flat tire on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in the evening rush, the city is equipped with, respectively, cleaning services, good friends, exterminators or traps, and tow trucks.

title: Cooper Gets 2 Homers, 7 Hits In Brewers' Sweep of Indians
description: Cecil Cooper went five for five, with two homers, and Mike Brouhard contributed a two-run pinch single to spark a 16-hit attack tonight that sent the Milwaukee Brewers to a 6-1 victory and a doubleheader sweep of the Cleveland Indians.

title: Bethlehem Steel Planning Layoffs
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it will lay off about 300 salaried workers this weekend at its plant in this city just south of Buffalo.

title: Chase Cuts Broker Rate
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday lowered its broker loan rate to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent. The rate is 20 percent at most other banks, although the Chemical Bank also quotes 19 1/2.

title: Harlem Hospital Gets New Director
description: An official of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation was named to head Harlem Hospital, a position that has been vacant for nearly three years.

title: A Lovely Morning Under the Elms
description: walkers led horses in lazy circles between the barns, while other horses stood relishing the flow of cool water from garden hoses trained on their forelegs. Grooms swabbed horses with soapy sponges and rubbed them dry. The rhythmic throbbing of hooves could be heard from the track itself, where horses were working.

title: Chairman Is Selected for Landerbank
description: Franz Vranitzky, 43, who was elected recently as chairman and chief executive officer of the Osterreichische Landerbank, the second-largest bank in Austria, with 140 branches and about $7 billion in assets, knows that he has his work cut out for him.

title: Berkshire Weighs Handy Bid
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., a diversified company engaged primarily in insurance, said yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might buy as much as 40 percent of the common stock of Handy & Harman, a silver and gold refining company.

title: Moynihan Adds to a Record Word
description: A couple of years ago, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan had a lot of fun with reporters in Washington when he used a word listed in the Guinness Book of Records as the longest in the Oxford English Dictionary.

title: Defrosting
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: When I read James Barron's ''Defrosting? Don't Use An Ice Pick'' (July 22) I wondered how many who read that sulfur dioxide was potentially explosive became alarmed.

title: HAIG, REVIEWING POLICY ON SOVIET, SAYS U.S. SEEKS FAIR AGREEMENTS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., asserting that the Reagan Administration's military buildup would encourage Soviet moderation, said today that the United States sought fair agreements with Moscow that recognized legitimate interests on both sides.

title: Employees to Aid Republic Airlines
description: Republic Airlines employees have agreed to a ''stock-for-pay'' plan to help the airline with cash flow problems resulting from the air traffic controllers strike, the Minneapolis-based airline said.

title: 2d Man Pleads Guilty In Wells Fargo Case
description: A second man charged in a $21.3 million embezzlement at the Wells Fargo Bank has pleaded guilty and agreed to testify for the prosecution.

title: WHAT SOVIET OIL PRODUCTION DOESN'T LACK
description: To the Editor:

title: This Summer, Clerc Rules the Courts
description: The hideaway was in Nogales, Chile, a small, unpretentious town where Patricio Rodriguez owned a farm with an all-weather tennis court. Every day, Jose-Luis Clerc, the visitor from Argentina, ran for one hour, played three to four hours of tennis and then relaxed at a nearby beach or went horseback riding.

title: NATIONAL PASTIME? TRY TWIRLING THE DIAL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Cleveland Amory's latest book is ''The Trouble with Nowadays.'' By CLEVELAND AMORY

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: WIDE-OPEN POLL
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In sum, American strategy toward the Soviet Union is proceeding on two fronts simultaneously.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.Time for Traveling Cartier has been famous for its Santos and Tank wristwatches for the better part of a century. Louis Cartier made the first Santos in 1904 for an aviator friend, Alberto Santos Dumont. The Tank watch was originally intended for the American tank corps of World War I. Now, with a legion of fans for the wristwatches, Cartier has translated the same designs into travel clocks, with the company's C's forming the legs the clocks stand on. The rectangular tank clock is banded in black, wine, ivory or blue enamel; the square Santos clock is set in plain and gold-plated steel. Both have Roman numerals on white faces and alarms that sound like pizzicato on a violin. They're in the Les Must boutique at Cartier, priced at $275 for either model. 2.Shoes in Hues Victor Favuzza, president of the Fast Feet boutique, thought he had just about all the gear that joggers and other athletes might want. But customers kept asking for running shoes in colors to match their outfits, while the big shoe manufacturers confined their output to just a few standard shades. So Mr. Favuzza, who has a father in the textile business and a father-in-law in carpets, consulted with them about dyeing shoes in unstandard colors. What he has done is take the Nike ''Spirit'' shoe in its original white and dye it in wonderful shades such as bright yellow, pink, lavender, pale blue and brick red.

title: Doctors Expecting the Pope To Leave Hospital Tomorrow
description: Pope John Paul II will probably leave Gemelli Hospital Thursday, exactly three months after the assassination attempt in St. Peter's Square May 13, doctors said today.

title: Trainee Controllers Convene
description: The first class of hastily called trainees hired to replace 12,000 air traffic controllers who were dismissed last week met this morning for initial briefings at the Mike Monroney Aeronautical Center, the nation's only training center for air traffic controllers. The 144 students who met for the first time today received less than a week's notice to report to the school. Another class of 200 students is scheduled to begin Aug. 31.

title: Jersey Casino Winnings Up
description: Atlantic City's eight legal casino hotels, with the help of a new gaming hall, won a record $118 million in July, the state reported today.

title: DR. LEWIS LONGWORTH, CHEMISTRY RESEARCHER
description: Dr. Lewis Gibson Longsworth, a professor emeritus at Rockefeller University who perfected a technique for studying the chemical structure of proteins, died of a stroke Sunday during a vacation in Estes Park, Colo. He was 76 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Team Reaches Bottom Of Greenland Ice Sheet
description: An international team of scientists drilling through the ice sheet covering central Greenland has reached its bottom at a depth of 6,683 feet, it was reported yesterday from the site near a radar outpost known as Dye 3.

title: A WIDOWER'S LOT
description: To the Editor:

title: PRETORIA'S RAIDS IN ANGOLA IMPEDED
description: The commander of South African forces in SouthWest Africa said yesterday that a Soviet-made radar system and surface-to-air missiles had been installed in southern Angola and that they were making it more difficult for the South African Air Force to support his troops in strikes across the border against insurgent bases.

title: Rugby Decision Criticized
description: The executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday urged Mayor Koch to reverse his decision not to allow the Springboks, a South African rugby team, to play in a city stadium.

title: ISRAEL DEBATES HOW BEST TO RESPOND TO SAUDI PLAN
description: A Saudi Arabian statement on terms for a Middle East peace has been rejected by a broad spectrum of Israeli politicians and news organizations. But it has prompted a debate on how the Saudi comments should be handled because a portion of them implies tacit acceptance of the existence of the state of Israel.

title: Reds 7, Dodgers 6
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Dan Driessen slugged a three-run homer in a decisive four-run Cincinnati rally in the seventh. Fernando Valenzuela, the Dodger rookie pitcher, was removed in the fifth inning with the score tied, 3-3.

title: New Airline Selects Campbell-Mithun
description: Air Chicago, a new airline scheduled to begin service Oct. 1, has appointed Campbell-Mithun/Chicago as its advertising agency.

title: MIAMI CRIME RISES AS DRUGS POUR IN
description: Over the weekend, a man was sprayed with bullets and died, another man's jugular vein was slit with a knife, and he died, another man was shoved out of a car and shot, and died, a young woman was shot with a pistol, and died, and the Dade County medical examiner's office rented a refrigerated truck from Ryder to ease the overcrowding in the morgue.

title: CHAPIN REMEMBERED
description: He had been a catalyst in mobilizing the Long Island business community to support the arts and in raising money to fight world hunger, and yesterday business leaders and other friends of the late Harry Chapin joined Governor Carey and New York's Secretary of Commerce, George G. Dempster, in a tribute to the folk singer, who was killed in an automobile accident last month.

title: STATE WORKERS IN MINNESOTA RETURN AFTER A 22-DAY STRIKE
description: State employees began returning to work today after reaching a tentative agreement to end their three-week strike.

title: 16-Year-Old Jockey Wins 5 Straight Races
description: Jack Kaenal, who lost his jockey license earlier this year when officials discovered he was not 16 years old, won five consecutive races at Timonium Race Course today, one short of the track record.

title: LETTER: ON A BOND PROPOSAL
description: The Job Amendment Deserves Support To the Editor: In ''The B-Plus Legislature,'' your July 15 editorial appraisal of the recently concluded legislative session in Albany, you gave the Legislature credit for refusing to submit to the voters a constitutional amendment to legalize casino gambling but neglected to mention another constitutional amendment, which the legislators did agree to submit to the voters.

title: U.S., JAPAN, EUROPE SET SPECIAL FORUM ON TRADE TENSIONS
description: The United States, the European Common Market and Japan have worked out a special early-warning arrangement to tackle trade and investment issues before they erupt into major international disputes, a high-ranking Administration official said today.

title: SOY FOODS: VERSATILE, CHEAP AND ON THE RISE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lorna J. Sass's latest historical cookbook, ''Christmas Feasts,'' will be co-published by Irena Chalmers Cookbooks and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in September. By LORNA J. SASS

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic City Electric Company announced that its board authorized the filing of a petition with the New Jersey Board of Utilities and a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 1.5 million common shares.

title: STAGE: 'MEMORIES CAN'T WAIT' EXAMINES MODERN MARRIAGE
description: ''MEMORIES Can't Wait - A Romance,'' an examination of a modern marriage by the young Berlin playwright Uwe Frohling, opens with a man in white sports clothes straining at a locked door, a figure of gleaming white in the dim, spotlit room. The play closes, 10 ''fragments'' later, with the man and a woman, both battered, trudging into spotlighted oblivion.

title: BEST BUYS
description: SUMMER vegetables are at their peak now. Corn, cucumbers, tomatoes, peppers, eggplant and zucchini are plentiful and in good supply. But lettuce, most popular at this time of year, is scarce. Prices on California iceberg lettuce will be going up in the next few days. Supplies are light.

title: Boston Mayor Offers Budget With Money to Rehire Police
description: Mayor Kevin H. White proposed a $245 million supplemental city budget yesterday that would allow Boston to rehire 250 police officers and 208 firefighters who were laid off to save money.

title: SALES BY CITY RETAILERS UP A MODERATE 7.5% IN JULY
description: Sales by retailers in New York City, after advancing strongly in recent months, edged up an average 7.5 percent last month over July 1980, according to a monthly spot-check. It was the smallest year-toyear increase in the last five months.

title: HOW TO BUY AND STORE TOFU
description: A four-ounce piece of tofu (bean curd) sells for about 30 cents, contains approximately 90 calories and provides 10 grams of protein, or about 14 percent of the recommended daily adult protein requirement. When purchasing tofu, be sure that the cake is whitish in color and that the soak water is clear and not brackish.

title: Seahawks Get Motivator
description: The Seattle Seahawks, a team with a 4-12 record last year that included an 0-8 mark at home and nine straight losses to end the regular season, have hired a former Green Beret as a motivational expert.

title: VIOLATIONS OF BUILDING CODE BEFORE STOUFFER'S FIRE CHIEF
description: Several building-code violations existed at Stouffer's Inn last December when a fire took 26 lives there, the Westchester County District Attorney said today, but he added that there was no evidence that the violations had been produced by any criminal act.

title: INDUSTRY ON COMPUTER DEFENSES
description: The National Security Agency has formed a new center to cooperate with business in evaluating methods devised by scientists to prevent unauthorized access to computer systems. Its goal is to allay industry fears that such developments would be stamped secret, preventing their marketing.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Dip Again
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell yesterday as the credit markets continued to move away from the much higher yields that prevailed last week.

title: WILL THE POUCH BE THE NEW TIN CAN?
LESTER L. JAY
description: Lester L. Jay, a New York City lawyer and a specialist in antitrust regulations, died Saturday at Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: PORTUGUESE PREMIER STEPS DOWN, CITING CONFLICT IN COALITION
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes accepted the resignation today of Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao, clearing the way for a successor to be named later this week.

title: NORTON SIMON NET RISES 2.8% IN PERIOD
description: Norton Simon Inc., the diversified consumer goods and services concern and parent of Avis Inc., reported yesterday that a soft rental-car business and a depressed packaging industry held its profit increase in the fourth fiscal quarter ended June 30 to 2.8 percent, as revenues increased 3.7 percent.

title: Dutch Bank for Canada
description: Algemene Bank Nederland said today that it had been granted permission to start full banking activities in Canada. Its Canadian unit, ABN Bank Canada, has representative offices in Toronto and Vancouver and plans to open one in Montreal. The Bank of America also was recently authorized to start full banking activities in Canada.

title: Raiders Jury Reports Deadlock in Discussions
description: The jurors in the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League told the judge today that they have been unable to reach a verdict on two of the three issues in the case.

title: GOLD IN TRAILS IN CAMPAIGN DONATIONS
description: Harrison J. Goldin, the New York City Comptroller, has raised only about half the campaign funds collected by Assemblyman John C. Dearie of the Bronx, his challenger in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary,

title: BUM TIPS AND SPIES
description: Washington - A year ago the disinformation activities of the K.G.B. and its proxy services in Western news organizations were not even deemed worthy of debate.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S SPEECH ON RELATIONS BETWEEN U.S. AND SOVIET UNION
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the American Bar Association in New Orleans. The text was made available here by the State Department.

title: Mistler May Fill Giants' Need
description: John Mistler, the Giants' rookie wide receiver from Arizona State and a No. 3 draft selection, is not a brash young man. He wouldn't dream of boasting about his football credentials although they are considerable.

title: WEISWEILER OF COSMOS PLANS LINEUP CHANGES
description: The Cosmos, who will try to break a three-game losing streak when they play the Washington Diplomats at Giants Stadium tomorrow night, will make several lineup changes for the game, Coach Hennes Weisweiler announced.

title: Elf Aquitaine Unit Goes to Texasgulf
description: Texasgulf Inc. said its board of directors approved a $56 per share merger with a subsidiary of France's state-owned oil company, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, and called a special shareholders' meeting for Sept. 25 to consider the agreement.

title: CASINOS STEAMING OVER TOWN'S RANKING AS NATIONAL HOT SPOT
description: John Baudouine, the man who put Bullhead City on the national weather map, finds himself these days in the middle of a dispute between local businessmen and the Federal Government.

title: 2 DISCOUNT BROKERAGES TO MERGE
description: Fidelity Brokerage Services, the country's third-largest discount brokerage firm, has reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Source Securities Corporation, another discount broker. No price was disclosed for the merger.

title: MOTOROLA EXPANDS PLANT IN SCOTLAND
description: Motorola Inc. yesterday announced a $120 million expansion of its East Kilbride, Scotland, semiconductor plant, bringing to some $600 million the value of new investment announced by electronics concerns in Scotland's booming version of California's Silicon Valley in the last two years.

title: Allegheny Enters In-Flight Films
description: Allegheny International Inc., which last year divested itself of its cornerstone company, the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, said it has gone into a completely new field through the acquisition of a major interest in Trans Global Films Inc., a New York-based producer of a new in-flight film entertainment service called World on Parade.

title: 4TH COOK GETS OUT OF KOCH'S KITCHEN
description: Some people cannot hold a job, but Mayor Koch, it seems, cannot keep a cook. Cindy Volper, the Mayor's chef since November, has quit, complaining of overwork and underpay.

title: 4 RANGER PITCHERS STOP YANKS, 1-0
description: Yankee Stadium continued to be a safe place for major league pitchers last night. The Texas Rangers, after being held scoreless in their first meeting of the resumed baseball season Monday night, reversed that result by shutting out the Yankees, 1-0, behind Rick Honeycutt and three relievers.

title: Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
description: A reputed crime figure, Samuel Orlando Sciortino, has pleaded not guilty to charges that he unsuccessfully attempted to bribe a Federal judge. Mr. Sciortino, 62 years old, one of three men with alleged ties to organized crime who were indicted in the case, entered his plea yesterday before Federal District Judge Robert Kelleher. Trial was set for Sept. 15.

title: Simmons Fentress, 56; Correspondent at Time
description: Simmons Fentress, a long-time Washington correspondent for Time magazine, died today of cancer at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 56 years old.

title: CALIFORNIA WIDENS ITS BATTLE AGAINST THE FRUIT FLY
description: California agricultural officials widened their war against the crop-destroying Mediterranean fruit fly in the South Bay area today and worried about a new threat to crops in southern California from the Oriental fruit fly, a larger cousin of the Mediterranean variety.

title: Transfer of Nerve Gas Is to Start This Week
description: The transfer of 888 Weteye nerve gas bombs from the Rocky Mountain Arsenal in Colorado to Utah will begin this week, the Army said yesterday.

title: ONE KILLED, 12 HURT AS LIGHTNING STRIKES AT UPSTATE FAIR SITE
description: One man was killed and 12 other persons were injured yesterday when lightning struck a group of people who had gathered around a piece of farm equipment at an agricultural fair in central New York State, according to the police and hospital spokesmen.

title: SUFFOLK DOCTORS FILE A PROTEST ON MALPRACTICE RATE REQUEST
description: An organization representing almost 1,400 doctors in Suffolk County yesterday challenged the need for a 52 percent increase in malpractice insurance rates requested by the company that underwrites the majority of such insurance.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1981
description: Controllers' Strike Air travel was chaotic between the United States and Europe for a second day as Canadian air traffic controllers refused to handle aircraft on the route in support of controllers who were striking illegally in the United States. Only a trickle of North Atlantic traffic to and from this country operated, and the possibility was raised that these flights might also be halted by a sympathetic job action. The disruption of trans-Atlantic routes added the biggest measure of strength yet to the cause of the United States controllers. But there was no sign that the development was swaying the Reagan Administration from its intent to rebuild the traffic system without the employees who struck. (Page A1, Column 6.) Transport Canada officials announced a new controllers' agreement to resume ''normal air traffic service operations'' at Gander, Newfoundland. Earlier, an agreement with the controllers collapsed and the Canadian Government said that its airspace would remain closed to flights to and from Europe. (A1:6.) Passengers were stranded by the thousands in airports across Europe as widespread flight delays and cancellations of transatlantic flights were again reported as a result of job actions by Canadian controllers. (A1:3.)

title: WASHINGTON DECREES A SOLAR ECLIPSE
description: Golden, Colo. - For its first three years, the Solar Energy Research Institute carried a blazing sun atop its stationary. A couple of months ago, to cut printing costs, the Department of Energy ordered the sun changed to a dull gray. It was an omen.

title: Court Says Rights Laws Embrace Religious Bias
description: Federal civil rights laws, while designed to protect the rights of members of minority groups, may also be applied to religious discrimination, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit ruled today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE soybean has been the ''meat of the Orient'' for more than 4,000 years. Considering its nutritional merits and extraordinary versatility as a food, the growing list of potential health benefits associated with its consumption and the cost of its competition, it could become an important factor in the American diet as well.

title: Advertising; Packaging The Light Product
description: AMERICANS are seeing the light. First it was low-tar cigarettes. Then came light beer. Now food manufacturers such as Nestle, General Foods and Del Monte (a subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds, which should know all about the trend) are developing lines of light foods, with reduced calories, less sugar and fewer fats and starches.

title: WASHINGTON BUSES A HIT WITH NEW YORK RIDERS
description: The red, white and blue buses from Washington, which arrived here eight months ago for ''emergency use,'' have become something of a hit on Broadway and other New York City streets.

title: LEROY SAYS HE IS BUYING FOUQUET'S
