description: IT all began about a year ago when Warner LeRoy dropped in on Paris to scout locales for Gallic versions of his two somewhat flamboyant New York restaurants, Maxwell's Plum and Tavern on the Green.

title: Bridge: Rosner and Stauber Enjoy Impressive Record in 1981
description: Two quiet young men from New York State have been building an impressive record in national tournaments in the last nine months. They are Warren Rosner of Nanuet and Allan Stauber of Poughkeepsie, who won the blue ribbon pair title in Lancaster, Pa,, last November, the open pairs in Detroit and the Spingold knockout teams this month in Boston.

title: NONCAUSES, NONCURES
description: Along with the "causes" of poverty there are many cures which, again, reflect the moral emphasis - and some self-interest as well. One finds education offered as a panacea - by the educators. When the Campbell Soup Company tells us how great it is to have soup for lunch, we tend to take that with a grain of salt. Yet when educators tell us the very same thing about their product, we seem to think that they are public-spirited citizens trying nobly to solve our social problems.

title: FLIGHT TROUBLES SNARL TRANS-ATLANTIC FREIGHT
description: Businesses dependent on trans-Atlantic freight-carrying services of airlines reported widespread delays, confusion and anxiety yesterday as the huge disruption of flights across the Atlantic continued through the day. But airlines reported that certain time-sensitive shipments had arrived without excessive delays.

title: A FEUD IN COLORADO PITS 'NATIVE' AGAINST 'ALIEN'
description: Sometimes, Eleanor Hazelwood says, she feels like a stranger in her own home. ''People are always saying, 'Why, you're the first person I've met who was actually born in Colorado.' I tell you, it makes you feel like some kind of endangered species.''

title: A Pitcher's Curve
description: As a pitcher, Tommy John of the Yankees is a sinker-ball specialist, but in conversation he prefers the curve.

title: Careers; Real Estate Appraisers In Demand
description: THE fine art of real estate appraising depends on the eye of the beholder, which is why two or more appraisals are often made of the same property.

title: REVISED FLIGHT SCHEDULE VOWED SOON BY AIRLINES
description: Airline executives today enthusiastically endorsed the Reagan Admnistration's response to the air traffic controllers' strike and said that the industry would soon publish revised schedules designed to restore a degree of certainty to air travel.

title: MUSIC: SOUNDS OF MONADNOCK FESTIVAL
description: some paved, some not - bringing 40 concerts each summer to churches and meeting houses in 15 towns across the Monadnock region.

title: RATE MOVE BY F.C.C. STUDIED
description: A House subcommittee has begun an investigation of whether the Federal Communications Commission followed proper procedures last April in approving a major rate increase for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, a committee official said yesterday.

title: Two Missing After Blast Of Rocket Propellant
description: An explosion ripped through a rocket propellant laboratory along the Potomac River late yesterday, scattering debris more than 1,000 feet and leaving no trace of two workers apparently killed in the blast, officials said.

title: Consumer Magazines Report 0.5% Ad Rise
description: The nation's top 100 consumer magazines recorded a lackluster five-tenths of 1 percent gain in advertising pages sold in the first half of 1981, according to a semi-annual study published by The Gallagher Report.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Government of President Augusto Pinochet today expelled four opposition politicians, including Jaime Castillo, the president of Chile's Human Rights Commission, an official statement said.

title: RAPID POPULATION AND FARM GROWTH MAY STRAIN SOUTHWEST'S WATER SUPPLY;
description: As a northbound traveler plunges down through the Tejon Pass, the golden-brown peaks of the Tehachapi Mountains flash by on either side, etched with brilliant clarity against an unforgivingly sunny sky. The very look of the place, the desolate aridity, is a constant reminder that water, or the lack of it, is the basic governor of activity in the vast, dry quarter-continent stretching from southern California to Texas.

title: THOUSANDS REMAIN STRANDED AT AIRPORTS IN EUROPE
description: Thousands of trans-Atlantic passengers remained stranded in airports across Europe today as further widespread flight delays and cancellations were reported when Canadian controllers again refused to handle flights to and from the United States that use Canadian airspace.

title: WHEN GOVERNMENT IS BOSS
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Life in Mexico City: Adapting to the impossible A2 South Korea seeking $10 billion in aid and loans from Japan A3 Senior U.S. official in Nicaragua for talks A3 Excerpts from Haig's speech on relations with the Soviet Union A4 Reagan decision on Israeli planes expected next week A6 Around the World A7 Portugal's President steps down, citing conflicts in coalition A9 Canada's postal strike ends after 6 weeks A20 Government/Politics Governors vow to resist burden of ''safety net'' welfare programs A14 Airline executives back Reagan's response to controllers' strike A23 Carey approves bill to split Man- hattan-Bronx judicial district A25 Barbaro and Esposito give their views on race relations B4 Goldin campaign funds only half the amount raised by Dearie B4 General Around the Nation A10 California may face a widened war against fruit flies A10 Colorado bumper stickers wage native-vs.-alien war A10 Casino industry steaming over town's ranking as a hot spot A15 Bar association backs voting act extension A16 Grand jury begins in killing of re- ported bully A16 Ways for travelers to try to reach their destinations A24 City forms special traffic unit to fight red light violations B3 Carmine Persico, a top crime fig- ure, pleads guilty to conspiracy B4 Man killed at upstate New York fair when lightning strikes B4 Boat owner gives his version of fatal L.I. Sound crash B4 Living Section Food Soy foods: versatile, cheap and on the rise C1

title: British Van Heusen
description: Kevin T. Loftus, a 39-year-old American, is the new managing director of the British Van Heusen Company, a leading men's apparel manufacturer in Britain, effective next month. He succeeds Derik Wheal, who will become managing director of Lee Cooper Ltd. after 41 years with Van Heusen, including 10 as its head.

title: Augustyniak Seeks A Job - With Jets
description: Mike Augustyniak failed to survive the final cut with the New Orleans Saints last year, so he was not there when the Saints beat the Jets for the only New Orleans victory in 1980.

title: A Rose by Any Other Number
description: Everyone was left hanging by the baseball strike, but no one more so than Pete Rose. The pugnacious infielder had gotten 73 hits so far this season, leaving him one short of the National League record of 3,630 total hits in a career.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 12, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Exercise of the In- alienable Rights of the Palestinian People - 10:30 A.M.

title: 2 Sentenced in Blanton Case
description: A former chairman of the Tennessee Alcoholic Beverage Commission and an aide to former Gov. Ray Blanton were sentenced to prison terms today for their roles in a liquor licence conspiracy. The former chairman, S.J. King, was sentenced to 60 days in prison, and the former aide, Robert E. Townes, was given 30 days. The two testified for the Government at Mr. Blanton's recent trial, which ended in the former Governor's conviction on extortion, conspiracy and mail fraud charges.

title: Hearing Is Ordered by Smith On Seattle Newspaper Plan
description: Attorney General William French Smith today ordered a public hearing on a proposed joint operating agreement between The Seattle Post-Intelligencer and The Seattle Times.

title: Taipei Trade Surplus Set
description: Taiwan today reported a trade surplus of $400.7 million for July, in contrast to a deficit of $195.1 million a year earlier.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE SOUL OF A NEW MACHINE. By Tracy Kidder. 293 pages. Atlantic-Lit- tle, Brown. $13.95.

title: VIEWS OF 2 KOCH RIVALS ON RACE RELATIONS ISSUE
description: Assemblymen Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and John A. Esposito of Queens, candidate for the Republican nomination, were asked by The New York Times for their views on major issues confronting New York City. Following are their replies on race relations: Barbaro: 'Working Together'

title: Mr. Reagan's Clean Air Hedge
description: Everyone can, and will, put his own gloss on President Reagan's vague principles for revising the Clean Air Act. And that is all to the good. The President has abandoned his plan to offer Congress a detailed legislative proposal, scuttling many fea-tures of the act. Instead, he has suggested some broad guidelines that are read with encouragement both by the proponents of cleaner air and those who have complained about the high costs of the effort. Congress thus remains free to write neces-sary and sensible amendments.

title: POLISH CHIEF SAYS DISORDERS COULD BRING 'TRAGEDY'
description: Stanislaw Kania, the Polish party leader, said today that further street demonstrations could lead a national tragedy.

title: ENDERS IN NICARAGUA FOR TALKS
description: A senior American official arrived here today for the first high-level talks between the United States and Nicaragua's revolutionary Government since the Reagan Administration took office.

title: KRZYSZTOF ZANUSSI'S 'CAMOUFLAGE,' SET IN A POLISH UNIVERSITY
description: THE political machinations of Krzysztof Zanussi's ''Camouflage'' unfold in an academic setting, as a summertime linguistics competition takes place at a Polish university. While the students present their papers and angle for advantage, an idealistic young teacher falls under the sway of an older and more cynical professor.

title: Peat Fires Trouble Moscow
description: Moscow city authorities are increasingly worried by peat fires that have smoldered underground for six weeks and sometimes burst into flame at factories and farms. A newspaper compared the dangers to those of a similar dry summer in 1972 when smoke drifted over the capital from uncontrolled peat fires.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SEAPORT JAZZ

title: 3 MEN KILLED IN COLLISION OF MASSACHUSETTS TRAINS
description: Two trains of the Boston & Maine Railroad collided here today, killing three trainmen and injuring 27 people. The accident, involving a northbound freight train and a southbound passenger train heading to Boston from Gloucester, Mass., occurred at about 4:30 P.M. in the wealthy estate country around Prides Crossing. A trainman and 26 passengers were taken by ambulance to Beverly Hospital, about five miles away, where they were treated for various injuries.

title: Repairs on Bridge Cause Congestion
description: The State Department of Transportation said that repair work had caused congestion on the Queens side of the Queensboro Bridge and that it would would continue for six weeks.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alba-Waldensian Inc. said it has been advised that 5.6 percent of its shares have been purchased by Shamrock Associates of Far Hills, N.J.

title: 700 FORCED TO FLEE IN NEVADA AS RAINS BURST RIVER'S DAMS
description: An elderly woman was found buried to her hips in mud this morning, cattle were drowned and 700 Moapa Valley residents spent the night at evacuation centers after several earthen dams on the Muddy River collapsed in the midst of a storm that dumped more than an inch of rain over southern Nevada.

title: GOVERNORS WARN ON WELFARE CUTS
description: The National Governors Association ended its 73d annual meeting here today with a warning to the Reagan Administration not to attempt to force states to pick up full responsibility for financing major Federal welfare programs.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE is something about the casual nature of cooking in summer that has a special appeal to me. It probably has to do with the fact that I'm out in my boat a lot, I garden with enthusiasm and the combination of these whets the appetite. My handiest and one of the most used cooking apparatus for those months of the year is my outdoor charcoal grill, which is kept fired for numerous hours in the course of a week. I keep it directly outside the kitchen door for ready access at noon or in the evening. The foods that I cook on that grill are, generally speaking, of a quick-cooking variety - a split chicken half, a steak, a slice of veal, even hamburgers and hot dogs.

title: Safety Agency Accused Of Secret Auto Recalls
description: The Reagan Administration is allowing automobile manufacturers to keep secret some of their safety-related recalls, Joan Claybrook, head of automobile safety in the Carter Administration, said today.

title: DOME BIDS FOR REST OF OIL SHARES
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. announced yesterday that it would bid $1.8 billion (Canadian) in preferred stock for the 47.1 percent of the shares in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company that it did not acquire June 1 from Conoco Inc.

title: Zimbabwe Hero Is Reburied
description: The remains of Herbert Chitepo, a Zimbabwe nationalist assassinated in Zambia six years ago, was reburied today with military honors at a nationalist shrine, Heroes Acre, in Salisbury.

title: SAFETY DICTATES CUTBACK IN NORTH ATLANTIC TRAFFIC
description: Even under normal circumstances, aircraft crossing the North Atlantic maintain courses that keep them more widely separated in time and distance from other traffic than is the practice on routes over land. This is a precaution dictated by the fact that for 1,100 miles of the flight over water the airplanes are beyond radar range and thus beyond the continuous surveillance of air traffic controllers.

title: Market Place; 'Death Service' Stocks on Rise
description: SOME analysts wax enthusiastic over prospects of a ''baby boomlet'' in the 1980's and the good things it can mean for companies that have products to cater to this demographic trend. But there also is a growth trend of a sort at the other end of the age scale.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ALTHOUGH Randi S. Londer rides the rails from Brooklyn Heights to her job in Manhattan accompanied by other straphanging mortals, there is something very different about her. ''Entirely not by choice,'' she says, ''I have become a Transit System Confidante.''

title: MORE JETS FOR ISRAEL HELD UP AS REAGAN RULING IS AWAITED
description: President Reagan has suspended delivery of all sophisticated American aircraft to Israel pending a decision by him next week on what to do about the planes, the State Department said today.

title: PACT MAY RESTORE ; AIR LANES
description: Air travel between the United States and Europe suffered a second day of chaos yesterday as Canadian air traffic controllers, supporting controllers who began an illegal strike in this country nine days ago, refused to handle aircraft on the route.

title: JAPAN APPROACHED ON PLANE PROJECT
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and Fokker of the Netherlands have invited Japan to join a project to develop a 150-seat medium-range passenger aircraft, Japanese trade ministry officials said.

title: JERSEY APPELLATE JUDGE
description: Judge Merritt Lane Jr. of the New Jersey Superior Court's Appellate Division died Monday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J., after a short illness. He was 60 years old and lived in Monmouth Hills, Middletown Township, N.J.

title: Bombing the Alliance
description: President Reagan's decision to assemble neutron weapons is militarily sound but diplomatically disastrous. There is no rational reason why the NATO allies should deprive themselves of this useful battlefield weapon, an effective deterrent to Soviet armored attack. But years of irrational debate and effective Soviet propaganda have made the weapon an explosive political issue for friendly governments. They should have been consulted and, as Secretary of State Haig was urging, asked to help choose the time for decision.

title: ENTERPRISE ZONES WILL GO EASY ON RED TAPE
description: To the Editor:

title: MORTGAGE AID BY CITY PENSION FUNDS
description: New York City employee pension funds are on the verge of assisting the area's housing market by purchasing mortgage securities backed by pools of local mortgages.

title: INDUSTRY SEEKS ENTIRELY NEW IDEAS ON CONSERVATION
description: When drought threatened northern New Jersey with a severe water shortage last fall, Governor Byrne ordered industrial water users to cut consumption by 25 percent.

title: CAREY APPROVES BILL TO SPLIT A CITY JUDICIAL DISTRICT
description: Governor Carey announced his approval today of a bill that will split Manhattan and the Bronx into two judicial districts. Mr. Carey vetoed a virtually identical bill last year.

title: KENNEDY AIRPORT
description: It was a day of waiting yesterday at Kennedy International Airport. Some trans-Atlantic flights were running up to 12 hours behind schedule and some friends and relatives waiting for travelers from Europe had been at the airport for more than 20 hours.

title: 6 WEEKS' MAIL AWAITS SORTING
description: A six-week strike by postal workers that had p aralyzed Canada's mail service ended today.

title: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1981; International
description: Thousands of trans-Atlantic airline passengers were stranded throughout the United States and Europe in the second day of serious disruption caused by Canadian air traffic controllers' refusal to handle flights to or from the United States. (Page A1.) The Canadian Government decided after meeting with air traffic controllers that its Eastern airspace would remain closed to all flights to or from Europe. (A1.) In Washington, the airlines enthusiastically endorsed the Administration's tough response to the strike. Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis said that trans-Atlantic flights were using a Southern route to bypass Canadian air space. However, only four flights an hour could operate in each direction, 20 percent of the normal peak, and they were subject to delays of up to eight hours. (A22.) Businesses dependent on trans-Atlantic freight flights reported widespread confusion, but added that time-sensitive shipments had arrived without excessive delays. (A22.)

title: WINE TALK
description: THE zinfandel is one of California's most prolific grapes, growing in vineyards all over the state. It is also a grape that produces wines of many-faceted personalities. Some are intense, robust, richly flavored and high in alcohol, perhaps best consumed after a meal, in place of a vintage Port.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: DURING the worst weeks of the inner-city rioting that flared up in Britain last month, that country's number one single was ''Ghost Town,'' an eerily prophetic song by the Specials. ''Why must the youth fight against themselves?'' the Specials asked, and they provided an answer: ''Government leaving the youth on the shelf. No job to be found in this country / Can't go on no more, people getting angry / This town is coming like a ghost town.'' (Plangent Visions Music, Ascap).

title: A SLAVE TO FASHION
description: Ever on to keep up with the changing fashions, I am now preparing to become rich. Rich is the fashionable thing to be nowadays since President Reagan has taken charge in Washington. When President Kennedy took charge I started wearing Ivy League suits and reading James Bond potboilers. Under Lyndon Johnson I learned to talk about standing in mighty tall cotton and gave my loyalties only to men you could go to the well with.

title: Colombia Agrees to Send Battalion for Sinai Force
description: Colombia announced today that it had agreed to send an infantry battalion to the Sinai Peninsula to participate in an international peace force recently agreed to by Israel and Egypt.

title: Ford Rebates On Trucks Set
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it has begun offering cash rebates of $500-$700 to buyers of the company's light trucks.

title: Tiant Recalled By the Pirates
description: Luis Tiant, who has won 225 major league games but started this season in the minors, was purchased by the Pittsburgh Pirates today from their Portland team of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Royal Couple to Be Dinner Hosts to the Sadats
description: The royal honeymooners have kept pretty much to themselves on their Mediterranean cruise, but Prince Charles and his wife, Diana, are expecting company today after the yacht Britannia arrives at Port Said, at the northern end of the Suez Canal.

title: Seagram Gains Du Pont Stake
description: Directors of the Seagram Company Ltd. voted to tender the company's 28 million shares of Conoco Inc. stock to the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, giving the Canadian liquor distiller a 20 percent interest in the chemical giant.

title: Thomson, Muir in Talks
description: Representatives of Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. met yesterday with John Muir & Company officials to discuss the possiblity of buying some of Muir's retail accounts.

title: CONTINENTAL NAMES NEW CHIEF
description: George A. Warde, who joined Continental Air Lines less than two weeks ago as president and chief operating officer, was named to the added job of chief executive today at a somber meeting of the company's board. He succeeds Alvin L. Feldman, who was found dead Sunday in his office, an apparent suicide.

title: LIFE IN MEXICAN CAPITAL: ADAPTING TO THE IMPOSSIBLE
description: The summer rains have arrived and the traffic jams take longer than ever to untangle and the noisy buses never seem to move on and the stinging pollution is trapped by the clouds. Yet the 15 million inhabitants of Mexico City remain impassive.

title: VIOLATIONS
description: With pedestrian deaths rising in New York City and more motorists apparently running red lights, the Koch administration yesterday assigned a band of police officers and traffic enforcement agents to crack down on drivers who ignore traffic signals.

title: BAR GROUP BACKS VOTING ACT, OPPOSES COURT CURB
description: The American Bar Association today formally endorsed renewal of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and opposed legislation to limit the jurisdiction of the Federal courts over school prayer, abortion and other issues of social policy.

title: COSTLY AMTRAK RIDES FOR THE TAXPAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a garden full of horseradish and am not quite certain about how to prepare it for the table. Can you tell me?

title: METS BEAT CUBS, 4-2
description: For the fourth time in 13 months, Craig Swan went on the disabled list today, jeopardizing his pitching career as well as the Mets' chances of capitalizing on the split season.

title: Parts of 5 Bodies Found on Mount Rainier
description: A search party found parts of five bodies today in a crevasse on Mount Rainier where 11 climbers were killed June 21 in the nation's worst climbing accident.

title: Economic Scene; A New Burden For Business
description: RECENT Federal budget and tax cuts should worry business leaders who seem to have ignored the many substantial questions about the effectiveness of the Reagan economic program, which was characterized by the Senate's Republican Majority Leader as a ''riverboat gamble.''

title: There Always Has to Be a First Time for Furth
description: George Furth never gives interviews. Never? ''Never,'' Mr. Furth said in an interview the other night, ''that's the reason I have a happy life.'' Mr. Furth, looking happy enough, was at the Milford Plaza Hotel celebrating the opening of his new play, ''The Supporting Cast.''

title: FOOD FOR MOVIE CREWS IS RATED G, AND GOOD
description: The other midnight, Jay Pulvino had a buffet dinner at the Port Authority Bus Terminal for Gene Wilder, Sidney Poitier and more than 250 others. The following morning, in a Tarrytown estate owned by the Rockefellers, she served breakfast and lunch to Woody Allen and Mia Farrow. Earlier that week, she fed John Cassavetes, Gena Rowlands, Vittorio Gassman plus over 200 more on the grounds of Manhattan's Sacred Heart Convent and, in an estate on Sands Point, L.I., a crowd that included Jerry Lewis, Robert DeNiro and Martin Scorsese.

title: LEARNING MORE ABOUT SOY: A LISTING OF USEFUL BOOKS
description: The following is a list of useful books about soy products. ''The Soybean Book: Growing and Using Nature's Miracle Protein,'' by Phyllis Hobson (Garden Way Publishing, Charlotte, Vt. 05445; 172 pages; $6.95 postpaid) is of special interest to gardener-cooks. The author discusses choosing seeds, planting and harvesting and then provides clear and practical instructions for making soy grits, flour, milk, sprouts and more than 275 interesting soy-based dishes from soup to coffee.

title: Western Forest Fires Spread to New Territory
description: By The Associated Press Forest fires that have charred parts of five Western states claimed thousands of acres of new territory yesterday, but firefighters put out some of the blazes and closed in on others.

title: Weak Rates Help Lift Stocks
description: The stock market, buoyed by a slight decline in certain interest rates, rose modestly yesterday in accelerated trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, ended 5.62 points higher, at 949.30. Advances outscored declines by a ratio of almost 9 to 5. The strongest gainers were energy stocks and interest-sensitive issues, such as those of utilities and banks.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BURNS A BLACK CAMPSITE AND BARS U.S. VISITORS
description: The South African police raided a black squatter camp at dawn today, a few hours before it was to be visited by an American Congressional delegation, and set on fire its flimsy shelters of plastic sheeting and tree branches.

title: PRISON OFFICIALS IN JERSEY STRIVE FOR MORE SPACE
description: New Jersey prison inmates are sleeping in storage rooms, lavatories, recreation rooms, hallways, classrooms and trailers as state corrections officials try to cope with an overcrowded system that almost erupted in rioting last month.

title: 'Voice of the Trees' to Open Friday at St. Peter's
description: ''The Voice of the Trees,'' a play by Don Weiss about a young man who wishes to change his identity, will open on Friday at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street.

title: A Milk Myth
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The unfortunate reference to milk as ''strictly taboo at midday meals'' for the ''ravenous'' New York Giants (''Football Food: Not Just Steak,'' July 29) perpetuates a myth that I thought had long since been permanantly debunked.

title: Bronfman Case Figure Leaves Prison
description: Mel Patrick Lynch, after spending nearly six years in prison for his involvement in the 1975 disappearance of Samuel Bronfman 2d, heir to the Seagram whisky fortune, was released from the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., yesterday.

title: Iran's New President Is Critical of Mitterrand
description: President Mohammed Ali Rajai of Iran, angered by a telegram from Francois Mitterrand congratulating him on his election, accused the French President today of turning his country into a plotting base against the Iranian revolution.

title: Six Escape on Rikers Island; All but One Quickly Retaken
description: Six inmates escaped last night from a cell block in the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island and all but one were recaptured on the island within the hour, the Correction Department reported.

title: Bechtel in Pursuit Of Mountain of Ore
description: The Bechtel Corporation, a San Francisco-based engineering concern, said today that it would join with Morrison-Knudsen International of Boise, Idaho, in a $1.5 billion, 10-year project to exploit a mineral bonanza in the jungles of Papua New Guinea, north of Australia.

title: Runaway Balloon Downed
description: The United States Air Force has shot down a runaway military balloon carrying $3.5 million worth of radar equipment after it was located over the Gulf of Mexico, officials said.

title: COSMOS TRIUMPH BY 4-2
description: Roberto Cabanas helped the Cosmos stop a three-game losing streak tonight by figuring in every goal in a 4-2 victory over the Washington Diplomats at Giants Stadium.

title: JOIN STUDY OF SAFETY
description: Dissident Canadian air traffic controllers, whose work stoppages stranded thousands of travelers on two continents in recent days, returned to work in full force across Canada today.

title: News of Music; HOROWITZ IS SWITCHING CONCERT MANAGEMENTS
description: IT'S not usually news when a performer switches concert managements. Artists change managements with ease. Managements ease performers off their rosters. But last month, Vladimir Horowitz left Harold Shaw and Shaw Concerts Inc., after a seven-year association in which Mr. Horowitz's reputation as today's reigning piano virtuoso had been confirmed season after season.

title: RED SOX GET SIX HOMERS, 2 BY RUDI, AND BEAT WHITE SOX, 8-1
description: Joe Rudi hit two homers and Dwight Evans, Gary Allenson, Dave Stapleton and Jim Rice hit one each tonight, powering the Boston Red Sox to an 8-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: 50 MORE FRENCH CITIZENS ARRIVE IN PARIS FROM IRAN
description: French officials ended a tense week tonight when the second and last planeload of French citizens arrived here from Iran.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CRAFTS AND WILDFLOWERS
description: Crafts Fair and Open House, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp. said it had acquired United Wine and Spirits Co. for an undisclosed amount of Alco Standard preferred stock.

title: BIRTHPLACE OF WOMEN'S RIGHTS HOPES FOR ITS DAY
description: Residents of this declining manufacturing community with a population of 8,500 never used to pay much attention to local history. Women would lug their wash to the coin laundry on Fall Street each week, unaware that the women's rights movement in the United States began in the same building in 1848 when the first suffragists convened there.

title: Serge Savard Retires
description: Serge Savard, the star defenseman who helped the Montreal Canadiens win eight Stanley Cup championships from 1968 to 1979, retired today. Despite his outstanding play, Savard, a 35-year-old veteran of 15 National Hockey League seasons who scored 100 goals and made 312 assists, was selected to the league's All-Star team only once, always overlooked by selectors who usually favored defensemen with an offensive touch such as Bobby Orr and Denis Potvin. But in 1972 and 1976, Savard's talent was recognized by the organizers of the Canada Cup team who selected him both years.

title: Indian Oil Contract
description: The Indian Government signed a fouryear consultancy contract with a French oil company today to increase oil production from the country's west coast offshore fields. Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles will provide technology and industrial experience to raise oil output from the fields to 380,000 barrels a day by 1984-85 from about 160,000 barrels now, an Indian official said. He said the company's payment would likely be less than $50 million.

title: VIEWS FROM THE COCKPIT
description: Airline pilots around the country asserted yesterday that the 10-day-old strike of the country's air traffic controllers had created no noticeable safety problems for them. They offered little sympathy for the strikers, expressing concern that the walkout could cost some airline workers their jobs.

title: FIRST HAITIANS TAKEN TO PUERTO RICO
description: An Air Florida DC-9 brought 125 Haitian refugees from an overcrowded detention center in Miami to a former United States Navy Base here before dawn today, the first of several planeloads expected in the next week.

title: Around the World; I.L.O. Tells of Increase In Attacks on Teachers
description: An increase in violence against teachers, which has become ''ominous'' in some countries, has contributed to making stress a ''significant occupational hazard in teaching,'' according to the International Labor Organization.

title: PILOT IS SAID TO DEFECT FROM TAIWAN TO CHINA
description: A Taiwan Air Force major the Chinese say defected to the mainland was given a $433,000 reward and a position in China's Air Force today, the Peking radio reported.

title: CABLEVISION GETS BOSTON FRANCHISE
description: Cablevision, one of the few remaining privately held cable companies, was awarded the Boston cable franchise yesterday on the basis of a proposal to provide subscribers with 52 basic channels of service for $2 a month, one of the lowest rates in the country.

title: BEYOND THE WALL IN BERLIN
description: Today is the 20th anniversary of the building of the Berlin wall.

title: Books of the Times
description: IN THE HEAT OF THE SUN. By Robert Bernen. 133 pages. Hamish Hamilton. $17.50.

title: Notes on People; SCALING THE HEIGHTS, SUCH AS THEY ARE
description: The World Trade Center it is not, but the 27-story United American Bank Building is the tallest Knoxville has, so that is the one Ron Broyles tried to climb yesterday morning.

title: Brigham Accepts Unpaid City Post
description: James R. Brigham Jr., the former City Budget Director, has been appointed chairman of the city's Public Development Corporation, Mayor Koch announced.

title: WHIFF OF IMPROPRIETY MAY IMPERIL REPUBLICANS' CHANCES IN VIRGINIA
description: Compared with most state governments, the Commonwealth of Virginia has been pristine, at least in fiscal matters. So the whiff of impropriety involving the Republican nominee for Lieutenant Governor in a possible conflict of interest is front-page news here, and may have important political consequences in the election of three top state offices here this November.

title: MUSIC: MARCEL MOYSE, AT 92, CONDUCTS A PAIR OF SERENADES
description: MARCEL MOYSE, at the age of 92, appears somewhat frail, and as he walked out on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night he was assisted by a member of the ensemble from the Marlboro Music Festival that he was to conduct in a Mostly Mozart concert. But once seated in a chair facing the players, he was ready to go with the music, and Dvorak's Serenade No. 2 in D minor had scarcely begun when it became clear that Mr. Moyse was totally involved with the work and the interpretation of it.

title: WESTWAY GAME PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ORLEANS EXCHANGE ELECTS TOP EXECUTIVE
description: About a month after the resignation of Thomas Webber as president and chief executive officer of the New Orleans Commodity Exchange, apparently after a dispute with the board, Robert L. Martin has been elected to the post. Mr. Martin has been a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission since 1975.

title: POOL PLAYING IN NEW YORK COMES ALIVE (BRIEFLY)
description: Only the most intrepid of the city's surviving hustlers are sidling up to strangers in poolrooms this week to ask if they'd like to shoot some nine-ball.

title: Reading Test Set For Failing Pupils
description: The Board of Education announced that public schools throughout the would administer reading tests tomorrow, starting at 9 A.M., for children in Grades 4 and 7 who were informed last June that they would not be promoted because of deficiencies in reading.

title: A BROKEN OATH
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ASSESSMENTS BILL APPEARS TO BE IN LIMBO
description: A bill to make it easier for homeowners to challenge their tax assessments that was overwhelmingly approved by the Legislature is trapped between the State Senate and the Governor's office as the result of a rarely used technique for killing or delaying legislation.

title: Benton & Bowles Unit
description: Benton & Bowles has created a new direct-marketing unit, Benton & Bowles Direct Inc. Its president is Richard Colligan, 29 years old, who joined B.&B. last May in the newly created position of manager, direct marketing. Mr. Colligan was previously a vice president at Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline.

title: JAMES FISK, BELL LABS EXECUTIVE AND LEADER IN RADAR, DIES AT 70
description: James B. Fisk, former chairman and president of Bell Laboratories and a key figure in the development of radar, died Monday at the Elizabethtown (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: ALASKAN OIL EXPORT ISSUE IS REVIVED
description: One of the more bitter energy debates of the past decade - whether to allow the export of Alaskan oil to Japan - is again being heard in Congress and the White House.

title: Brazil-Soviet Ore Pact
description: Brazil will deliver another 100,000 metric tons of bauxite to the Soviet Union over the next two months, the state mineral company, Vale do Rio Doce, announced today. The sale, valued at $3 million, is in addition to 109,000 tons already shipped to the Soviet Union in July, the company said.

title: Hello, Moscow
description: Slowly, Secretary of State Haig is finding his voice and using it, firmly but respectfully, to address the Soviet Union. After the belligerence of the early Reagan days, that is progress.

title: SUMMER LIVING UNDER A TENT IN THE WOODS
description: SALISBURY, Conn. WHEN the stars and the moon come out, they shine right through the house in the woods where Marietta Whittlesey and Nic Osborn dwell. The young couple are part of nature but snugly dry whether the weather outside be dappled sunlight and shadow or crashing thunderstorm.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Columbia Air Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 1.5 million shares of common stock, to be sold through an E.F. Hutton group.

title: Blinka Dispute Ends
description: Stan Blinka, the Jets' third-year middle linebacker, did not get the club to renegotiate his contract, but he did get a written commitment from the personnel director, Jim Royer, to have what he called contract extensions worked out after this season.

title: Advertising
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM, which has somehow missed having any hightechnology accounts despite being America's largest advertising agency, yesterday corrected that oversight. It has been named the agency for Atari, the personal computer and video games designer and manufacturer that is a subsidiary of Warner Communications.

title: ACCORD IN CANADA REOPENS AIR LINES CROSSING ATLANTIC
description: The plan under which the Federal Aviation Administration has kept airplanes flying during the strike by air traffic controllers has made the airways at least as safe as normally, airline executives and many pilots say.

title: Legal Entanglements Snarling Raiders Trial
description: Legal complexities mounted today in the trial of the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League, with one juror's impartiality being challenged.

title: Gerulaitis Eliminated; McEnroe, Lendl Gain
description: Steve Denton of Driscoll, Tex., who ususally specializes in doubles, upset eighth-seeded Vitas Gerulaitis, 1-6, 7-6, 6-4, in the second-round today of the $200,000 Canadian Open men's tennis championships.

title: A LOSS FOR STRIKERS
description: The two-day disruption in trans-Atlantic air travel broke up rapidly yesterday after air traffic controllers in Canada ended a boycott of United States flights in return for a joint inquiry with their Government into whether the Aug. 3 walkout by American controllers had raised safety hazards.

title: IN EUROPE, CARRIERS STRUGGLE TO GET ATLANTIC JETS ALOFT
description: Trans-Atlantic air carriers struggled today to restore ample plane service to North America and to move several thousand passengers who have clogged airports across Europe for two days.

title: AUSTRALIAN HORSE MEAT IS INVESTIGATED BY U.S.
description: Some horse meat from Australia may have been passed off in the United States as imported beef, a spokesman for the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: Aug. 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Libya Is Said to Aid Lebanon
description: Ambassador Saleh Darouki of Libya said today that Lebanon had accepted a Libyan offer of an air defense system to defend the country against Israeli attack, the state-run news agency reported. He said Libya had accepted Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan's condition that the system be operated by Lebanese. About 300 people died in an Israeli air raid on Beirut last month.

title: MEETING WITH U.S. IS SET ON COUNCIL REDISTRICTING
description: New York City officials plan to meet here Friday with Justice Department lawyers to discuss the challenged new boundaries for City Council districts to be used in the primary election Sept. 10.

title: THE PLANET IN 2000
description: Several recent reports have warned that stresses on the earth's resources and environment are severe and increasing, particularly in the underdeveloped countries. Most prominent among these is ''The Global 2000 Report,'' issued last year by the Carter Administration. The report warns that unless something is done to reduce worldwide pressures on cropland, pastures, forests, mineral and water resources, the world will become even ''more crowded, more polluted, less ecologically stable and more vulnerable to disruption than the world we live in now.''

title: BREZEZINSKI URGES TALKS WITH P.L.O.
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was President Carter's national security adviser, said today that the time had come for the United States to end its boycott and ''talk to the Palestine Liberation Organization.''

title: REALITY DAWNS FOR THE WHITEY FORD OF MEXICAN BASEBALL
description: THIS summer Mike Paul admitted there would be ''no more nibbles.'' In his six summers in Mexico, Paul has become the Whitey Ford of Juarez, a trim left-hander with one of the best earned run averages in the history of the Mexican League. Even last year, when Mexican baseball split apart in a bitter labor dispute, Paul clung to his dreams of one last call from what Mexicans call ''los mayores,'' the major leagues.

title: REV. LAWRENCE L. DURGIN, 63, EX-BROADWAY CHURCH PASTOR
description: The Rev. Lawrence L. Durgin, vice president for development at Tougaloo College in Mississippi and pastor emeritus of the Broadway Church of Christ in New York City, died Tuesday at Hines General Hospital in Jackson, Miss., after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Tougaloo.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN a do-it-yourselfer thinks about interior alterations that involve a new wall, he will usually think in terms of a frame of wooden studs.

title: Anthony Oppersdorff Weds Whitney Wing
description: Whitney Canfield Wing and Anthony Thomas Oppersdorff were married yesterday at the Vesper Hill Chapel in Camden, Me. The Rev. Donald W. Henderson of the Congregational Church of Camden performed the ceremony.

title: DR. JOHN CONNORTON, SERVED AS DEPUTY MAYOR IN 1960'S
description: Dr. John V. Connorton, City Administrator-Deputy Mayor under Mayor Robert F. Wagner, died Tuesday after suffering a stroke at his summer home in Carmel, N.Y. He was 68 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Judges Rules for Jones In Compensation Case
description: An administrative law judge ruled today in favor of the former St. Louis running back, Steve Jones, in his injury claim against the Cardinals.

title: Gardening; SOME NEW THOUGHTS ON PRUNING TREES
description: SUMMER is a good time to prune trees, big ones and little ones, for many reasons. August and September are great months to work outdoors. Also, unlike in winter (the other best time), the trees have leafy canopies and their densities or weaknesses can be seen. Further, the trees are not in that dynamic period of spring growth when sap is flowing and those such as maples and dogwoods bleed.

title: Topics; Car Stop
description: ''What do you think of New York?'' someone asked a 6-year-old girl visiting the city for the first time. ''It's a place,'' she responded brightly, ''where people stop on the green and go on the red.''

title: FOR ELDERLY, THE TRIUMPH OF HAVING A PLACE TO CALL THEIR OWN
description: MORE than anything else, the atmosphere on the moving-in days was like the first day of college -even if the new tenants looked more like returning alumni than incoming freshman. There was not a carton in sight. Books were neatly arranged on shelves, curtains covered windows and photographs of children and grandchildren hung proudly on walls.

title: Sage Energy Weighs Sale
description: The Sage Energy Company, a San Antonio-based oil and gas company, announced late yesterday that it was holding ''preliminary discussions concerning the sale of the company.''

title: RYAN RESIGNED TO BENCH ROLE
description: Pat Ryan is the Jets' second-string quarterback, and because Richard Todd, the starter, was healthy all last season Ryan's regular-season statistics read zero across. In fact, in the last three years Ryan has played quarterback in only three regular-season games.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported a change in Chase Manhattan Bank's broker loan rate. The bank lowered the rate Tuesday to 19 percent from 19 1/2 percent.

title: Soviet Reports Attack By 700 Afghan Rebels
description: The Soviet press agency Tass gave a rare insight today into the strength of anti-G@overnment forces in Afghanistan, reporting that a unit of 700 guerrillas had attacked a single border post.

title: Home Savings Posts a Loss
description: The H.F. Ahmanson Company, parent of the nation's largest savings and loan company, today reported a second-quarter loss of $15 million, its first loss since becoming a public corporation nine years ago.

title: Price Decline May Cut Malaysia Rubber Sales
description: Low natural rubber prices on world markets may jeopardize plans by Malaysia, the world's leading producer, to increase exports in coming years and cash in on rising world demand, rubber traders say.

title: President of Ford Sees Stronger 1982
description: Donald E. Petersen, president of the Ford Motor Company, said that 1980 marked a turnaround for Ford and that the No.2 auto maker will strengthen its earnings performance in 1982. For the second quarter ended June 30, the auto maker earned $60 million, or 50 cents a share, on sales of $11.2 billion, its first profit in six consecutive quarters,

title: Mayanesian, $22.20, Winner in Sanford
description: Anyone looking for an early lead on next year's Kentucky Derby among the 2-year-olds racing in New York this year will have to keep looking. The first six stakes races for juveniles this year were won by six different colts. Today's running of the Sanford Stakes at Saratoga was the seventh, and another new prospect was the winner.

title: Index; Controllers' Strike
description: In Europe, carriers fight to get Atlantic jets aloft D22 Gander control tower at hub of Trans-Atlantic traffic D22 The strike as seen from the cock- pit D23 International Escapes over Berlin wall decreas- ing sharply A2 Clergymen hopeful about reli- gious freedom in China A4 Around the World A5 Second planeload of French citi- zens arrives in Paris from Iran A8 Doctors say Pope faces two months' convalescence A8 Mitterrand frees 21 imprisoned mothers A9 Sadat said to seek 100 to 150 more F-16's A10 Vietnamese orphan tells harrow- ing tale of escape voyage A10 Government/Politics U.S. questions Detroit's sale of bonds to pension funds A12 125 Haitian refugees taken to new center in Puerto Rico A17 Hint of impropriety hangs over Virginia G.O.P. contest A18 Chicago school board votes to sell Midway Airport to city A19 Bill on property assessment chal- lenges is in limbo B2 General Around the Nation A12 Army moves 128 nerve gas bombs from Denver to Utah desert A12 Lawyer says U.S. will let boy's parents take him to Soviet A13 Policewoman dismissed for wounding 2 in market robbery A15 Six elderly missing from board- ing home in Miami A16 Bar changes rule denying Oral Roberts school standing A21 Seneca Falls, N.Y., in tangle over a Women's Rights Park B2 Home Section Home Summer living under a tent in the woods C1

title: CAROL BELLAMY WILL ANNOUNCE FOR RE-ELECTION
description: It was hardly meant as an afterthought, but rather late in this municipal political season Carol Bellamy will get around today to announcing formally that she is a candidate for re-election as President of New York's City Council.

title: Notes on People; A New High for a High-Flying High Diver
description: ''When I was in my late teens and early 20's, I used to get my 'fix' from high-diving and breaking aviation records,'' Col. Frank Kurtz said yesterday. ''Nowadays, the greatest fix for me is seeing my daughter, Swoosie Kurtz, giving people in the audience a wonderful time when she performs onstage in 'Fifth of July.' ''

title: Armco to Close Plant in Ohio
description: Armco Inc., as yet unable to find a buyer for its reinforcing bar plant in Marion, said it would close the facility in mid-November.

title: POP: 'ORIGINAL HILDEGARDE'
description: IN Marty's Garden Room, she is still introduced as ''The Incomparable Hildegarde.'' But on a placard outside the restaurant at Third Avenue and 73d Street, she is now described as ''The Original Hildegarde''

title: Doctors Say Brady Is Facing A Likelihood of More Surgery
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, faces an increasing possibility of surgery in the near future because of continued leakage of spinal fluid from his nose, physicians said yesterday.

title: BAR CHANGES RULE DENYING STANDING FOR ORAL ROBERTS SCHOOL
description: The American Bar Association, faced with a lawsuit that could threaten its dominant role in supervising the nation's law schools, changed its rules today to permit accreditation of a law school that requires its students and faculty to pledge adherence to the school's religious precepts.

title: Robert Landau Names Consumer Goods Head
description: Morton C. Goldberg, 34, a vice president and member of the executive committee of Robert Landau Associates, a New York-based marketing firm, has been named president of its consumer package goods division. Clients include Nabisco Brands, Quaker Oats, Hunt-Wesson Foods, Hershey Chocolate, Starkist Foods, Kal Kan Foods, the Carnation Company, Becton Dickinson Consumer Products, Squibb and Citicorp

title: BOTTLED WATER A HEALTH AID?  U.S. AND INDUSTRY AGREE: NO
description: Taste and fashion contribute to its popularity, but a big reason sales of bottled water are expanding 15 percent a year is that many people presume it is more healthful than tap water. But is it?

title: Reagan's Hiring Freeze Loses a Court Decision
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has given more than 20,000 Government job appointees a second chance to challenge the revoking of their appointments in President Reagan's Federal hiring freeze last January.

title: No Headline
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim received a report in London today on the attempt by his special envoy, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to resolve the Afghanistan problem, a United Nations spokesman said. No details were available on the envoy's talks with Afghan leaders in Kabul and Pakistani officials in Islamabad.

title: Kornhauser Selected For Crane Account
description: Kornhauser & Calene has done it again. The agency, which last month won the Commodore Computer Systems account, has now been chosen to handle corporate and some divisional advertising for the Crane Company, a manufacturer of steel, cement, fluid and pollution control equipment, building products and aircraft and aerospace systems.

title: Katharine Lamb Tait, Designed Stained Glass
description: Katharine Lamb Tait, a designer of stained-glass windows, died Tuesday in the Dunroven Nursing Home in Cresskill, N.J. She was 86 years old and lived in Cresskill.

title: 2 Indicted by U.S.  In Medicare Fraud
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan indicted a psychiatrist and a psychologist on charges of filing false Medicare claims in a 15-month period at the Beacon Hall Home for Adults in Beacon, N.Y.

title: Notes on People; One Small Hand for Mankind
description: A follow-up: Ashita Furman, who a week ago aborted an effort to set a record of 50 hours of continuous applause, succeeded in his second attempt yesterday.

title: AIR OFFICER FACES A COURT-MARTIAL
description: The Air Force announced today that it would convene a general court-martial in the case of Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke, the missile officer who has been accused of passing sensitive data to the Soviet Union's Embassy.

title: Children and TV News
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Elin McCoy's long article on children's TV habits (''Limiting Children's TV Habits,'' July 30) didn't mention the word news even once despite the fact that news is available on several channels for about one and a half hours before most children go to bed.

title: COLOMBIANS COMBAT CUBAN INTERFERENCE
description: Alarmed by the discovery that Cuba has been training guerrillas to fight here, Colombia is rapidly shifting its policies to help combat Havana's initiatives in the hemisphere.

title: Official Institutes Suit In Shot-Put Accident
description: A man hit in the head by a 16-pound shot during the 1980 national track and field championships filed a personal injury suit yesterday against the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the University of Texas.

title: Group Plans Zaire Smelter
description: An international consortium of eight companies plans to build an aluminum smelter in Zaire capable of producing at least 150,000 tons annually, a spokesman for the consortium said today.

title: GOING FROM PRUDENTIAL TO LEHMAN BROTHERS
description: Raymond A. Charles, one of the deans of corporate finance in the insurance industry, will leave the Prudential Insurance Company of America later this month to join the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb to run its private placement and project finance groups. He will become a managing director, which is roughly equivalent to a partner in a partnership, on Oct. 1.

title: Pennsylvania Justice Refuses To Reverse Abortion Ruling
description: A Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court refused today to reverse a lower court's order blocking a 1980 state law banning most state-financed abortions.

title: Design Notebook
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paula Deitz, co-editor of The Hudson Review, is a guest columnist. By PAULA DEITZ

title: Around the Nation; New Spraying Planned To Protect California
description: By United Press International California decided yesterday to begin a new round of aerial spraying tomorrow night in its campaign against the Mediterranean fruit fly after the infestation moved closer to the state's major agricultural area. Florida sprayed more than 10,000 acres and turned to laying traps and enforcing a quarantine on produce in the Tampa area.

title: Volvo Truck Plant Site Is Reported
description: Volvo of Sweden has tentatively picked Greensboro as the site for its United States truck plant if a Federal court in Ohio lets it acquire the White Motor Corporation, according to sources here.

title: THURSDAY, AUGUST 13, 1981; The Economy
description: A two-day logjam in trans-Atlantic air travel cleared up swiftly after Canadian air traffic controllers called off a boycott of United States flights. In return, Ottawa promised to take part in an inquiry into the controllers' contention that the strike by American controllers had created safety hazards. (Page A1.) Airline executives and many pilots say that flights during the strike, carried on under a contingency flight plan developed by the F.A.A. last year, are as safe as in normal times. (A1.)

title: Elf Fiber Venture
description: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the French state-owned oil concern, said it had agreed with the Union Carbide Corporation and Toray Industries of Japan to study the feasibility of building a carbon fiber plant in France to meet growing European demand. No details of the agreement were given, but Japanese sources said that Elf Aquitaine would be the largest shareholder in the factory, likely to be in southwestern France.

title: Time's Film Unit Sold to Columbia
description: Time Inc. said it had sold the television production operations and other assets of its Time-Life Films subsidiary to Columbia Pictures Television, a division of Columbia Pictures Industries.

title: COURT REVERSES $104,000 AWARD FOR EX-COMPANION OF LEE MARVIN
description: The State Court of Appeal has ruled that Lee Marvin, the actor, does not have to pay $104,000 to Michelle Triola Marvin, a former singer who lived with him for six years.

title: SADAT SAID TO SEEK 100 F-16'S
description: Egypt has asked the United States to consider providing the Cairo Government with 100 to 150 more F-16 jet fighters and other modern military equipment in an expanded and accelerated buildup of Egypt's military forces, Administration sources said today.

title: Q & A
description: Q. We have aluminum sliding-track combination storm-and-screen windows that contain two glass panels and one screen panel. When the glass panels are both in place for the winter there seems to be quite a large amount of heat built up between the glass panes, so now I am confused about the best position for the panels during the summer. If both panels of glass are up and the screen panel is down, does this permit a loss of cooler air from inside, or is there some other position you would suggest for each of the panels? - M.W.S., Frederick, Md.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Technology; Multiple-Beam Antennas
description: THE dish-shaped antennas used to transmit and receive signals from satellites have what in humans would be called tunnel vision. They can ''see'' only one satellite at a time.

title: BIG I.B.M.'S LITTLE COMPUTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, once slow to recognize that computers were getting smaller, is apparently determined not to make the same mistake in the emerging personal computer market.

title: Pleasant Task for Perkins
description: After one game of the exhibition season, Coach Ray Perkins continues to grapple with a pleasant problem: In the Giants' 3-4 defense, which of two rivals for the job should he team with Harry Carson at inside linebacker?

title: Critic's Notebook; OPERAS IN MUNICH AND STUTTGART TO VACATION BY
description: MOST music critics set off on vacation resolutely determined to avoid the sounds of music at all costs. Some actually achieve this elusive goal, but unless plans call for a trip to the tundra or Antarctica, fate is bound to put musical temptations in his path. So predictably this inveterate listener, during a recent four-day spin through West Germany, found himself face to face with a pair of operatic events far too tantalizing to resist.

title: MEDICARE ALTERNATIVE STUDIED
description: The Reagan Administration is examining the feasibility of a voucher system that would enable the 29 million beneficiaries of Medicare to buy private health insurance, a spokesman said today.

title: Sohio Unit Drops Uranium Project
description: A spokesman for the Sohio Western Mining Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), said the concern had dropped plans for uranium exploration in the Santa Fe National Forest, although it might decide to go ahead with drilling later.

title: Koch Defends Decision
description: In a letter to the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, Mayor Koch has defended his decision to prohibit the use of a city stadium for a rugby match between the Springboks, a South African rugby team, and the Eastern Rugby Union because he feared an outbreak of violent demonstrations at the match.

title: Yanks Demote Brown Again
description: In a familiar move, the Yankees sent Bobby Brown to their Columbus farm team yesterday and called up Dave Wehrmeister, a 28-year-old pitcher with an 11-3 record. It was the sixth time that Brown, an outfielder, had been demoted since being purchased from the Blue Jays in 1979.

title: Around the World; Rights Group Charges Massacre by El Salvador
description: A regional human rights group says the Salvadoran Army killed 96 unarmed civilians last week, including 46 children, at a guerrilla stronghold near San Salvador.

title: Foreign Investment In U.S. Down
description: Foreign investors spent slightly less than $10 billion to buy or start businesses in the United States last year, a 35 percent drop from 1979, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: REMOTE GANDER IS STORM CENTER ON FLIGHT CONTROL
description: The Air Control Center here is an unlikely looking place, a squat modern concrete-and-glass structure that looks more like an office building than one of the nerve centers of North Atlantic aviation.

title: 4 CONCERNS CITED OVER ADDITIVES
description: Four major companies violated antitrust law by finding ways to charge identical prices for a gasoline additive, a Federal Trade Commission judge ruled today.

title: Iowa Beef Merger Backed by Holders
description: The $800 million acquisition of Iowa Beef Processors Inc. by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation was approved by shareholders of the two companies.

title: BORK HELD TO BE CHOICE FOR COURT
description: President Reagan plans to name Robert H. Bork, the Solicitor General in the Nixon Administration, to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. CLERICS OPTIMISTIC ON CHINA
description: The leader of a group of American clergymen who recently returned from a two-week visit to China said yesterday that the delegation felt hopeful about the apparent relaxation of Government restrictions on religious freedom there.

title: Notes on People; HONOR FOR A TAXI DRIVER
description: At the height of the civil-rights movement in the 1960's, black Americans made their objections to what they considered the racial stereotypes of ''Amos 'n Andy'' so well-known that the program was dropped from television.

title: Conoco Oil Find
description: Conoco Inc. reported that a subsidiary had made what it called a ''significant'' oil discovery at a well in the Netherlands North Sea sector and also confirmed an earlier discovery. The unit, the Continental Netherlands Oil Company, which is operating for itself and six other concerns, said the new discovery well tested at a combined flow rate of 8,145 barrels of oil a day from two separate reservoirs. The company said additional drilling would be needed to determine the extent of the field.

title: ARMS BUDGET IN SOUTH AFRICA IS BEING RAISED BY 40 PERCENT
description: The South African Government today increased its military spending by 40 percent in 1981-82 to counter what it described as external threats.

title: Around the Nation; Records Studied in Crash Of Trains That Killed 4
description: Officials today studied dispatch records involving a Boston & Maine Railroad freight train to determine why it collided with a commuter train yesterday, killing four persons.

title: News Analysis
description: The Soviet Union has responded to President Reagan's decision to produce and stockpile neutron weapons with some of the most intense press reaction since the new Administration took office. But Western diplomats believe that the basic political response will continue to stress talks rather than a rapid buildup in the already burdensome Soviet arms programs. With a brief respite around the time of the attempted assassination of President Reagan in March, Soviet commentators have increased their condemnation of what they describe as the ''military adventurism'' of the President and his team. In a typical cartoon appearing this week in Pravda, the party newspaper, Mr. Reagan was depicted as a cowboy with saddle in hand attempting to mount the globe. In place of stirrups, the saddle trailed a nuclear bomb.

title: COONEY SET ON PLANS FOR HOLMES
description: Gerry Cooney, reportedly angered by criticism that he was ''ducking'' Larry Holmes, told his co-managers yesterday to forget about plans for an interim fight and proceed with plans for a heavyweight championship bout between the two undefeated boxers.

title: Topics; Stop and Go; Bus Stop
description: Passenger report from a woman boarding a GM bus for the first time: ''Was pretty thrilled when I saw it coming - reminded me of the Flxible Darth Vaders, which I loved. But was a little disappointed that the sign just said 159th Street.

title: Unnamed Architect
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Suzanne Slesin's article on the West 57th Street Valentino-Cidat showroom (''Achieving a European Look in an American Setting,'' Aug. 6) made no mention of the architect of the 1922 ''palazzo-like architectural detailing'': Wilfred E. Anthony, who worked for Cram, Goodhue & Ferguson and who was in fact a Gothic specialist.

title: New Act Makes Milk The State's Beverage
description: Governor Carey announced today that he had signed a bill making milk the official beverage of New York State. But the Governor - conscious that producers of other beverages, such as New York State wine, might feel hurt at being overlooked - said in his message approving the bill that he had nothing against them.

title: Meade of Avon Books Is Now Also Publisher
description: Walter Meade, publisher of Avon Books, has been appointed to the additional post of president of that paperback book company. Mr. Meade joined Avon as editorial director in 1976 after having been managing editor of Cosmopolitan magazine.

title: Margaret Casey Is Married
description: Margaret Casey and retired Justice William J. Sullivan of the State Supreme Court, both of Rockville Centre, L.I., were married yesterday.

title: TRANSIT UNION OFFERS PLAN TO DROP ITS 'NO CONTRACT, NO WORK' POLICY
description: The leader of the union representing most of New York City's 33,000 subway and bus workers said yesterday that he would be willing to abandon the Transport Workers Union's traditional policy of ''no contract, no work'' in exchange for the same right to arbitration that city employees already have.

title: Bridge:; DOUBLE BY KATZ IN BOSTON A FIRST FOR MODERN GAME
description: There are three national championships in each calendar year, and in theory it is possible for a single player to win three or four titles in one tournament. In practice, it is rare to win twice, but when this happens the happy victor is almost invariably a player of international reputation who can attract partners and teammates of proven talent.

title: A VIETNAMESE ORPHAN TELLS OF KILLINGS AND CANNIBALISM IN 52-DAY SEA ESCARE
description: Dao Van Cu is a 15-year-old Vietnamese orphan whose ribs, collarbone and shoulder blades protrude from his emaciated body so sharply that one fears they will cut through his skin. His head is swathed in a large bandage, and his body is marked with angry scars.

title: U.S. QUESTIONS PART OF DETROIT'S FISCAL RESCUE PLAN
description: The Treasury Department has raised questions about the proposed sale of $56.5 million in bonds by the City of Detroit to two of its municipal pension funds, thereby threatening a key part of the financial package designed to avert the city's fiscal insolvency.

title: Cities Service Volume High
description: Stock of the Cities Service Company jumped sharply in heavy trading yesterday amid unconfirmed conjecture that a new takeover battle might be developing.

title: AIRLINES POST BEST STOCK GAINS
description: Stock market prices showed very little movement yesterday in active trading, with some of the airline issues posting the best gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed down 4.09 points, to 945.21. However, in the overall market, winners on the New York Stock Exchange just barely outnumbered losers by 760 to 721.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL, IN NICARAGUA, TIES AID TO POLICY SHIFTS
description: In the first high-level talks between the Reagan Administration and Nicaragua's revolutionary Government, the United States has said that any improvement in relations and resumption of economic aid depends upon a change of Nicaragua's policies in Central America.

title: Radical Rage and Chic
description: ''No one, not even you (but you have come the closest ...) has ever held out a hand to help me to be a better man.''

title: Baldwin's Net Up 24.7%
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, the financial conglomerate and piano maker, today reported a 24.7 percent rise in earnings, to $18.2 million, or $1.58 a share, in the second quarter, from $14.6 million, or $1.29 a share, in the comparable 1980 quarter. Revenues surged to $500.4 million from $239.9 million, the company said.

title: 16 ARE HURT AS STAIRS COLLAPSE
description: Sixteen people were injured, two of them seriously, when a staircase collapsed at the Ellington Ridge Country Club this evening, authorities said.

title: President Named At Central Savings
description: Richard A. Kraemer, 37 years old, has been named president of the Central Savings Bank, which has eight branches in the New York metropolitan area and nearly $1 billion in assets. He succeeds Verne S. Atwater, 61, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: CONNECTICUT BANK'S SUITORS
description: It's no Conoco, but a new hot bidding war has erupted in Connecticut, riveting attention on an unusual takeover target: a bank.

title: Office Computer
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company has introduced a desk-top office computer, the HP 125, with prices starting at $7,500. It said the model combined functions of a personal computer, word processor, computer terminal, financial calculator and graphics work station. The company broadened its product lines to include general-use office equipment when it introduced its first laser printer last December.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Company, Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Sal J. Giudice to the new post of executive vice president-corporate relations.

title: MITTERRAND FREES 21 JAILED MOTHERS
description: President Francois Mitterrand ordered 21 mothers released from jail today in the latest in a series of clemency and amnesty orders that have emptied France's prisons of one of every six inmates in less than four weeks.

title: U.S. REJECTS PROPOSAL TO FORM WORLD BANK ENERGY AFFILIATE
description: The Reagan Administration has rejected a proposal by Robert S. McNamara, former president of the World Bank, to set up a special energy affiliate as the vehicle for expanded lending to developing countries for energy projects.

title: YANKS WIN BY 5-4 AS NETTLES HOMERS
description: The hitters began to overtake the pitchers yesterday at Yankee Stadium in a 5-4 victory for the Yankees over the Texas Rangers that had almost all the classic pre-strike ingredients.

title: EAST GERMANY CUTS DOWN ON ESCAPES TO THE WEST
description: In the 20 years since East Germany built the Berlin wall, more than 185,000 East Germans have fled the country. But the number of escapees has dropped sharply in recent months, largely because of tough new security measures, according to a private fact-finding organization here.

title: Weidenbaum on Recession
description: President Reagan's chief economic adviser said today that the economy might be in a recession ''right now,'' and predicted unemployment would near 8 percent by the end of the year.

title: RETAIL SALES IN U.S. UP 1.3% IN JULY
description: Sales by American retailers rose 1.3 percent in July, the second consecutive sizable monthly gain, the Commerce Department reported today. However, private economists said they did not yet see a resurgence in the lagging national economy.

title: Home Beat; ROOF GARDEN WITH NO PLANTS
description: THE clients had access to a 25-by-15-foot roof garden in Chelsea and wanted to be able to use it without having any maintenance problems. They happened to see the large outdoor pieces of Jeffrey Owen Brosk and commissioned the 34-year-old sculptor to create a roof garden for them.

title: AN ACCREDITED SCHOOL FOR CHIMNEY SWEEPS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Samuel G. Freedman is a journalist in Chicago. By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN ADDISON, Ill. CHIMNEY sweeps, originally plucked from debtors' prisons for probably the grittiest work-release program imaginable, now can earn formal recognition for training in the craft.

title: SIX FORMER PROSECUTORS CALL MISS HOLTZMAN UNSUITABLE
description: Six former local prosecutors, including the city's Fire Commissioner and Mayor Koch's coordinator for criminal justice, described former Representative Elizabeth Holtzman yesterday as unsuited for the post of Brooklyn District Attorney, for which she is seeking the Democratic nomination in the primary Sept. 10.

title: BIG CROPS FORECAST FOR CORN, WHEAT
description: The Agriculture Department predicted today that the corn crop this year would be the second largest in the nation's history. The department also forecast a record wheat crop and a bumper harvest of soybeans, and a sharp rise in the peanut crop.

title: WOULD-BE NURSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Valerie McNitt, Violist, Married
description: Valerie McNitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas McNitt of Shrewsbury, N.J., and Robert William Vernon, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Harold C. Vernon of Detroit, were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Shrewsbury. The bridegroom's father, minister of the Trumbull Avenue Presbyterian Church in Detroit, performed the ceremony.

title: REVOLUTION AND MYTH
description: Historical turning points give rise to myths, and myths are an unsound basis for the understanding of world politics and the development of foreign policy. For example, it is a myth that Cuba sent troops to Angola because Moscow ordered it. All the available evidence suggests that Moscow attached overriding importance at that time to detente and the strategic arms limitation negotiations and was completely taken by surprise by the Cuban decision. It is unlikely that Moscow would have risked American anger over Angola. The Soviet Union's subsequent decision to support Cuba in its selfassigned role is a completely different matter. Common sense and my own extensive conversations with Fidel Castro on the matter satisfy me that the Soviet Union did not order Cuba into Angola.

title: More Than Bugs
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I was disappointed to see that in your discussion of electric insect killing lanterns (''Electric Lamps to Kills Insects in Your Yard,'' July 20) you made no mention of some of the environmental problems associated with these devices.

title: Empire Games Open
description: The fourth annual Empire State Games, New York's version of the Olympics, opened tonight with a parade of 5,600 athletes and a torch-lighting ceremony followed by fireworks.

title: Water in America: Solving the Quandary Last of five articles.
description: Contamination of the ground water in this nation represents a problem of a still undetermined but potentially vast magnitude, Federal, state and local environmental and health officials have started to realize in the past two or three years,

title: CARING FOR DEVICES THAT CURB FIRES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan A. Froetschel is a freelance writer. By SUSAN A. FROETSCHEL

title: Teleprompter Merger Stalled
description: The United States Court of Appeals issued a temporary restraining order today against the Teleprompter Corporation's merger into the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, stalling the biggest merger in cable history.

title: GREEN AIMS TO REGAIN WINNING TOUCH
description: Hubert Green recognizes that his golf swing is not pretty, but long ago, facing the choice between having a graceful swing and earning a livelihood as a professional golfer, he decided to retain the unorthodox style. No matter how short and fast the takeaway, no matter how awkward the follow-through, it was this style that helped Green achieve quick prominence on the PGA Tour.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are standing at a crossroads for the first time. Should we be a typical trade union which puts forward demands or should we, as Poles and as citizens, undertake the attempt to go forward in a major different direction?'' - Lech Walesa. (A6:3.)

title: THE EXPANDING ROLE OF TV NEWS ON CABLE
description: THE announcement yesterday by ABC and Westinghouse that they intend to create a 24-hour news channel on cable televi News Analysis ion is only the latest evidence that news programming is breaking out of its historically limited role in a medium long dominated by entertainment.

title: AN UNEASY TIME FOR STRIKERS
description: ''I'm tired and broke,'' said Philip Stewart. ''I'm a little scared,'' said Jon Maizel. ''I'm angry,'' said Dennis Eckie. For the striking air traffic controllers, many of whom now refer to themselves, with a bitter little laugh, as ''former air traffic controllers,'' this is a time of roller coaster emotions, of rising anxiety over shrinking bank balances, of trying to reassure wide-eyed children that everything will be all right when they themselves are beginning to wonder if anything will ever be right again.

title: CRANE CRASH ON QUEENSBORO BRIDGE SNARLS TRAFFIC
description: A 50-foot-high construction crane tipped over on the upper level of the Queensboro Bridge yesterday morning, crashed down onto the bridge's railing and remained immovable for seven hours, backing up thousands of vehicles that would have used the bridge to get out of Manhattan at the start of the evening rush.

title: Going Out Guide
description: ABOARD JAZZMOBILE

title: Shot-Putter, Sprinter Face Ban Over Steroids
description: A Hungarian shot-putter and an Austrian sprinter have been found guilty of taking illegal drugs at the European Cup semifinals last month and face lifetime bans, Arthur Gold, president of the European Athletic Association, said today.

title: POPE, DUE TO LEAVE HOSPITAL, WILL CONVALESCE FOR 2 MONTHS
description: Pope John Paul II, on the eve of his scheduled discharge from Gemelli Hospital in Rome, faces a further convalescence of at least two months before he can resume his full, normal routine, his doctors said in telephone interviews yesterday.

title: BAR PRESIDENT OUTLINES PLANS TO SPEAK UP FOR PROFESSION
description: David R. Brink, who earns his living as a specialist in estate planning, today stepped into an unsalaried job in which he will help the legal profession plan its future.

title: COMMON FLU VIRUS CAN KILL NEWBORN
description: Common viruses that cause outbreaks of summer flu can fatally infect newborn babies, but the infants will escape serious illness if they receive natural immunity from their mothers before birth, a study here shows.

title: Defining 'Creaseproof' Eyeshadow
description: How ''creaseproof'' must an eyeshadow be to say it in advertising?
