According to Revlon, which made the claim in print advertising last spring for its Formula 2 Eyecolor Pencil, it simply means that the stuff does not collect in the creases of the eyelid in the course of six hours of wear. But a panel of the National Advertising Review Board declared yesterday that no one knew how the public interpreted the term ''creaseproof.''

title: JUDGE IN ALBANY DENIES LIMIT ON STATE INMATES
description: A State Supreme Court justice today refused to grant a preliminary injunction sought by the state prison guards' union to limit the number of inmates in state prisons.

title: SCHOOL BOARD TO SELL AIRFIELD TO CHICAGO IN $4.5 MILLION DEAL
description: The school board voted unanimously last night to sell Midway Airport to the city for $41.5 million, but the board president said the sale proceeds could not be applied directly to a projected deficit of $74.7 million in the 1981-82 school budget.

title: ARMY FLIES 128 NERVE GAS BOMBS TO UTAH FACILITY
description: Two huge Air Force C-141 cargo planes, each bearing 64 bombs filled with lethal nerve gas, flew 400 miles from Denver to this remote western Utah installation today, bringing a four-year political controversy closer to conclusion.

title: U.S. BEGINS DEREGULATION REVIEW ON RIGHTS AND ECOLOGY GUIDELINES
description: The Reagan Administration has started a review that could lead to abolishing Federal civil rights policies and guidelines that protect women from sexual harassment on the job and from discrimination in collegiate athletics.

title: CRAFTSMAN MAKES 'ANTIQUES OF THE FUTURE'
description: BEDMINSTER, England John Makepeace may sell handcrafted wooden furniture for a living, but you could not call him an ordinary country craftsman. His contemporary, expensive and singular creations make him more like the Saint Laurent of the business.

title: GREAT BUS FOR EVERYONE BUT THE RIDER
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Magazine For Black Business
description: Better Business, a bimonthly magazine for black men and women in business, has been started by the National Minority Business Council. The control-paid, circulated magazine had previously been published as the quarterly newsletter of the council. The initial press run will be 5,000 copies.

title: Around the Nation; Nashville Police Rookie Dismissed for Shooting 2
description: A rookie policewoman was dismissed today for wounding two customers in an attempted robbery of a market, but Police Chief Joe Casey said she violated no department rules by killing the market's manager.

title: Spanish Trade Deficit
description: Spain's foreign trade deficit widened to $6.8 billion in the first six months of this year from $5.2 billion in the same period of 1980, the Directorate General of Customs said today. Imports in the January-June period amounted to $16.4 billion and exports were $9.6 billion. Spain's trade deficit in 1980 was $13.7 billion.

title: RATE RISE ENDS 3-DAY RALLY
description: Interest rates rose yesterday, ending a three-day rally that had substantially lifted prices and cut yields after last week's heavy Treasury financing.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE RULES LAW OFFICE BUGGING BY F.B.I. WAS ILLEGAL
description: A Federal district judge today rejected as illegal the Government's bugging of a law office frequented by reputed leaders of organized crime in New England.

title: Hers
description: IT'S now or never: You must get into that bikini by Labor Day or write off the 1981 season. The bikini, bought in March, will continue to languish with its price tag in the bureau drawer, be recycled as a neckerchief, or perhaps be stuffed into a picnic hamper as a convenient sling for carrying hard-boiled eggs. Now is the time to choose: You can give up the bikini idea, buy a commodious caftan and dive deeper in Haagen-Dazs, or you can take a deeper breath and edging toward the pool, covered with a shred and a prayer.

title: MAKING HOME MORE COMFORTABLE FOR OLD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elizabeth Lincoln is a freelance writer. By ELIZABETH LINCOLN

title: Building Time Is Money
description: Incredible as it may seem, New York State officials are questioning whether to approve completion of a nuclear power plant on which more than $1 billion has already been spent. The problem is runaway costs.

title: NEW JERSEY'S WAY OF COMPLYING WITH THE CLEAN AIR ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: Spending Increase Planned by Socal
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said it plans to increase its capital spending budget for 1981 to $5.4 billion, up 29 percent from the $4.2 billion level of last year. At the same time, George M. Keller, the company's chairman, told securities analysts that the company expects to spend $30 billion over the next five years, more than double the amount invested in the previous five years.

title: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS: 'I KEEP WRITING. SOMETIMES I AM PLEASED
description: IT has been just over a year since Tennessee Williams's last play, ''Clothes for a Summer Hotel,'' closed after a sad, brief and disastrous Broadway run, and now the playwright is back in New York again to have another go at yet another play. He was somewhat hurt and saddened by the reception accorded ''Clothes,'' and he says he is all too aware of the ''declivity of my reputation.'' Still, he points out, he has always been a survivor: he survived the time his first play was booed off the Theatre Guild's stage in Boston; he survived the ''disastrous decade of the 60's,'' when drink and drugs and poor reviews darkened his career and life; and at 70 years of age, he has apparently survived the disappointment of ''Clothes'' as well.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday on changes in the tax law governing employee stock options gave an incorrect date for existing options to qualify for the new tax treatment. To qualify, the stock options must have been given by employers after 1976.

title: JERZY NEYMAN
description: Jerzy Neyman, professor emeritus of statistics of the University of California at Berkeley, died Aug. 5 at Kaiser Hospital in Oakland.

title: Rumanian Loan Woes
description: Rumania is having difficulty raising $400 million (Canadian) to finance construction of its second Canadian-built nuclear power plant, banking sources said here today.

title: People
description: * Barry L. Smith has been elected executive vice president of W.B. Doner & Company, Baltimore.

title: A NEW CHAPTER AT BRENTANO'S: CHAIN PLANS MARKETING SHIFT
description: Brentano's was the chain that could have been. Back in 1971, Brentano's, B. Dalton and Waldenbooks were fairly tightly bunched in terms of the number of books each sold. If anything, Brentano's, the oldest chain in the country, was easily the more familiar name among the reading public.

title: CHILDREN, A JOB, AND NO TIME
description: THEY have been told repeatedly that it's not the quantity of time a parent spends with a child that counts, it's the quality. And on those occasions when working mothers must stay in the office late to finish a report, or go to the hospital on a weekend to check a patient, or miss the class play because they are trying a case in court, they comfort themselves with that adage of quality.

title: G.M., SUZUKI AND ISUZU AGREE TO 'MINI-CAR' DEAL
description: The General Motors Corporation will cooperate with Isuzu Motors Ltd. and the Suzuki Motor Company in the production and marketing of new ''mini-cars,'' smaller than the Chevrolet Chevette, leaders of the three corporations announced today at a news conference here.

title: Barbaro Asks an End To Some Tax Breaks
description: Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Mayor, said yesterday that he favored ending tax abatement programs that had been introduced by Mayor Koch for development in midtown and the Wall Street area.

title: Thomas R. Carver, 52, Dead; Princeton Physics Professor
description: Dr. Thomas R. Carver, a professor of physics at Princeton University, died of a heart attack last Saturday at his summer home in Maine. He was 52 years old and a resident of Princeton.

title: Earnings Slide At Beneficial
description: The Beneficial Corporation, a diversified financial services company, said today that its secondquarter earnings, hurt by high borrowing costs and a large foreignexchange loss, plunged 41.6 percent from last year's second quarter.

title: Italy Arrests 4 as Forgers
description: The Italian police broke up a major counterfeiting ring today and arrested four men. Forged dollar bills, travelers checks, revenue stamps and bills of exchange worth more than $1 million were seized in dawn raids on two illicit printing presses in a Rome suburb, the police said.

title: AIRLINES CHALLENGING UNION ON ITS ABILITY TO PAY FINES
description: The president of the air traffic controllers' union was closely questioned yesterday by a lawyer for the nation's airlines who sought to show that the union had nearly $3 million in assets that could be used to pay court-ordered penalties.

title: THE AIR CONTROLLERS' STRIKE SHOULD BE LEGALIZED
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation
description: District Attorney John Van de Kamp of Los Angeles asked the state today to revoke Sirhan B. Sirhan's parole in 1984, saying that the convicted assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy had made threats against his victim's brother, Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: WILLIAM K. WILSON
description: William K. Wilson, former director of publications and literature for the United Church of Christ, died Tuesday in Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital.

title: WORLD GROUP CRITICIZES FOREIGN AIR CONTROLLERS
description: The International Air Transport Organization, which represents most airlines that fly international routes, today criticized foreign air traffic controllers who refuse to clear flights to the United States.

title: British Output Up
description: Industrial production in Britain increased in June for the first time in four months, the Government said today, raising hopes that the country's deep recession might be ending. The figures showed that output in June was 1.3 percent higher than in May for all industries, and 2.1 percent higher for manufacturing industries.

title: ABOUT THE WRITING OF A CALLAS BIOGRAPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH UNION ASKS SUPPORTERS TO END PROTESTS ON FOOD
description: In a major step aimed at easing Poland's political problems, the national leadership of Solidarity, the independent union, appealed to its branches and supporters today to halt strikes and demonstrations over food shortages and ration cuts.

title: Notes on People; United Press International
description: ROYAL COUPLE GREET SADATS: The Prince and Princess of Wales with President Anwar el-Sadat and his wife, Jihan, before having dinner aboard the royal yacht Britannia yesterday in Port Said, Egypt. Afterward, the newlyweds left for a trip through Suez Canal. They are scheduled to fly back to Britain tomorrow.

title: Around the World; MRS. GHANDI BIDS TALKS SEEK WIDE ENERGY POLICY
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India called for a world energy policy today and expressed the hope that a United Nations conference here would take the first steps toward achieving that goal.

title: ADVERTISING
description: International Thomson Business Press of Radnor, Pa., a subsidiary of the International Thomson Organization in Toronto, is expanding the publishing empire.

title: Essay; REAGAN CRYSTAL BALL
description: Here is the fearless forecast for Phase II of the Reagan Revolution, wherein ideas that were considered jejune in January will, this fall, become the top ten items on the nation's domestic agenda.

title: HOW TRAVELERS CAN REACH DESTINATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES AND ABROAD
description: Following is information on how travelers can cope with disruptions caused by the air traffic controllers' strike in the United States. To Europe

title: Hyatt Faces New Suits
description: Five more lawsuits seeking a total of $125 million in damages in the collapse of two skywalks at the Hyatt Regency Hotel have been filed in Jackson County Circuit Court. The suits, filed yesterdy, brought to at least 51 the total filed as a result of the July 17 accident, in which 111 persons died. The suits seek over $1 billion in damages.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO YIELD TO PARENTS OF SOVIET BOY
description: The Justice Department has agreed not to prevent the parents of a 13-year-old boy from taking him back to the Soviet Union if a court grants them custody, the youth's lawyer said today.

title: 4 Japanese Programs at Asia Society
description: To mark the opening season of its new theater, the Asia Society will offer four programs beginning Sept. 15 that will include classical Japanese plays, music and dancing. The series is being presented by the Classical Performing Arts Friendship Mission of Japan and is co-sponsored by the College of Fine Arts of the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: Ales Bebler Dies at 74; Yugoslav Ex-Diplomat
description: Ales Bebler, a former Yugoslav diplomat, died here today, the Tanyug press agency said. He was 74.

title: Ex-Im Bank Loan
description: The United States Export-Import Bank has authorized a $14.25 million loan to partially finance an underseas telephone cable between Egypt and Greece, according to an announcement released here today. The cable will link Alexandria with Athens and is scheduled for operation early in 1984. It will be built and installed by the international operating unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for Egypt's National Telecommunications Organization and Greece's Hellenic Telecommunications Organization.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, AUGUST 13, 1981
description: Controllers' Strike Trans-Atlantic air travel resumed after air traffic controllers in Canada ended their boycott of flights to and from the United States in return for a Government inquiry into their charge that the walkout of 12,000 American controllers Aug. 3 had reduced air safety. With the resumption of work by the Canadian controllers, the American strikers lost their most effective outside support. (Page A1, Column 6.) The F.A.A.'s airways safety plan, which was prepared more than 18 months ago, has made the airways system at least as safe as it normally is, airline executives and many pilots agree. However there is some concern that in time, fatigue may affect the controller's alertness. (A1:5.)

title: Market Place; Middle West: Land of Hope
description: ''COMPANIES in the Midwest tend to think conservatively and, while they are not the stemwinders of the world, many of their stocks have performed well in a difficult economy,'' says Elliott Schlang, a partner in the Cleveland-based brokerage firm of Prescott, Ball & Turben.

title: KENNEDY SLUMBER PARTY TURNS TO TRAVEL BEEHIVE
description: Heavily loaded passenger planes were arriving from Europe throughout the day yesterday at Kennedy International Airport, refueling and then heading out again with nearly all their seats filled as the airlines struggled to overcome huge backlogs on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: 6 ELDERLY DISAPPEAR AT MIAMI BOARDING HOME
description: Six elderly persons, including one whose bank account was dwindling at an unaccountable rate, have vanished from a Miami boarding home whose director is also missing, state officials said today.

title: METS WIN, 7 to 4, FOR 3D STRAIGHT
description: The injured but reborn New York Mets won their third straight game of the split season today when they scored three runs in the 10th inning to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 7-4.

title: A 60'S ECHO IN THE 80'S LOFT: THE CONVERSATION PIT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jane Geniesse is a journalist and novelist. By JANE GENIESSE

title: Jersey Suspends Boxer For Quitting in Bout
description: New Jersey boxing authorities said today they had suspended Al Collins and were continuing an investigation into the South Carolina fighter who ''failed to give a good account of himself'' during a bout last night that lasted only 59 seconds against James Broad.

title: Helpful Hardware; SEVERAL ALTERNATIVES TO WINDOW DRAPERIES
description: TWO interesting fabric window coverings can provide attractive alternatives to draperies. One is a do-it-yourself window-shade kit, and the other is a new drapery system by Kirsch called Paneltrac.

title: TOOTH MARKS OF SUSPECT KEY IN MURDER OF GUARD
description: A prisoner's teeth may be a vital factor in whether he is indicted for murder in the death of a prison guard and whether he is the first person in four years to face the death penalty in New York State.

title: L.I. 'Red, Hot and Blue'
description: A revised version of ''Red, Hot and Blue,'' the 1936 Cole Porter musical, with book by Howard Lindsay and Russell Crouse, will be performed by the Port Washington, L.I., Teen Summer Theater this weekend at Schreiber High School on Campus Drive.

title: Advertising; Holiday Inns Ready To Start Magazine
description: Inn America, an advertising-supported magazine for Holiday Inn guests, with a projected annual circulation of more than 63 million, is being prepared for publication by Holiday Inns and King Network Publications.

title: Mitsubishi-Mexico Deal
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said today that it had won a $200 million order from Mexico for equipment related to expansion of Mexico City's subway network. About 60 percent of the equipment will be shipped from Japan by mid-1984, when the expansion project will be completed, the company said. The balance will be manufactured in Mexico at Mitsubishi's joint venture, Melco de Mexico, and other local concerns, Mitsubishi added.

title: Notes on People; Royal Move Celebrated
description: It wasn't exactly a royal wedding, but for Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands and her family yesterday was moving day and that was cause enough for celebration in The Hague.

title: A BENEFIT FOR MANY SAVERS
description: Consumers considering whether to invest in the tax-exempt savings certificates created by the new tax law are going to find only limited information available now to elp them decide.

title: 3 EX-MEMBERS OF HOUSE GIVEN TERMS IN PRISON
description: Three former members of Congress received three-year prison terms yesterday in the first sentencing of defendants convicted in the Federal Government's two-year Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: FORWARD WITH JAPAN
description: The United States and Japan, wartime opponents and postwar allies, economic rivals and political partners, have a unique partnership. From time to time there have been strains and misunderstandings, yet both of us know that the ties between us are vital and that, as they come under stress, it is essential that we protect them and keep them strong.

title: AN AMERICAN COLONY?
description: In his 1980 campaign Ronald Reagan promised to take the lead in obtaining statehood for Puerto Rico. But the promise was abandoned and the Reagan Administration now faces the embarrassing possibility that the next United Nations General Assembly will declare the island one of the world's few remaining colonies, and demand that something be done about it.

title: Auctions; ORIENTAL ART SETS RECORDS
description: AAUCTIONS of Oriental art were more successful this season than ever before, setting new price levels in a variety of categories. Christie's sales in New York rose 11 percent, to $4.3 million, from $2.9 million. At Sotheby's in New York, sales of Oriental art soared to $14.5 million, from $7.9 million, with Chinese art rising to $10.1 million, from $5.6 million, and Japanese art to $4.4 million, from $2.3 million.

title: EX-T.W.A. OFFICIAL TO HEAD THE L.I.R.R.
description: Robin H. H. Wilson, until recently a senior vice president for operations at Trans World Airlines, has been chosen as the new president of the Long Island Rail Road, officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: Advertising; Rapp & Collns Ends Tie To RCA Music Service
description: Rapp & Collins, the direct-marketing subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach, and RCA Music Service have mutually agreed to terminate their relationship after six months.

title: CAREER RELOCATION: COMPANIES TEST A SEMINAR
description: Assume you're at a cocktail party and there are six groups of people scattered around the room. Given a choice, which would you join? The artistic, creative people? The people who like to work with data? Or perhaps the men and women who like to inform and enlighten are more up your alley, or those who persuade and influence, observe and investigate, or work with objects, machines, and animals.

title: A 3-Way Channel Swim
description: John Erikson, a 26-year-old physical education teacher from Chicago, has become the first person to swim the English Channel three times nonstop, the Channel Swimming Association said today.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC AFFAIRS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference on the signing of the budget bill and tax cut program, held yesterday at his ranch in Santa Barbara, Calif., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News. Part of the recording was inaudible, but the first two paragraphs were obtained from a White House transcript. OPENING STATEMENT

title: RUTH BROWN IS BELTING OUT SONGS AT THE COOKERY
description: RUTH BROWN has all the luck - good luck, bad luck and luck that swings from one extreme to the other. Now, Miss Brown, one of the great rhythm-and-blues stars of the 1950's, who has been a television actress in recent years, is riding the crest of a wave of good luck that has given impetus to her singing career: an unexpected eightweek engagement singing at the Cookery, University Place at Eighth Street, her first New York appearance in nine years.

title: Advertising; National Advertising Costs May Rise 9.3%
description: The average national advertiser can expect a 9.3 percent unit cost increase in 1982, according to a survey of top agency media directors and media researchers by Marketing & Media Decisions, a national advertising and marketing publication.

title: Rise in U.S.  Drilling Seen
description: The Hughes Tool Company said today that it expected drilling activity in the United States to be about 35 percent higher in 1981 than in 1980.

title: 'Wilde' at the Griffith
description: ''The Trials of Oscar Wilde,'' a 1960 British film starring Peter Finch, James Mason, Lionel Jeffries and John Fraser, will begin a three-week engagement today at 1:30 P.M. at the D.W. Griffith Theater, 239 East 59th Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

title: GAF SELLING GRAPHICS BUSINESSES
description: The GAF Corporation said it had sold its graphics arts business to a group of investors headed by Andlinger & Company for about $40 million.

title: EAST BERLIN PARADE HONORS WALL
description: East Germany celebrated the 20th anniversary of the Berlin wall today with a show of force in which troops, police units and thousands of armed militiamen marched past Erich Honecker, the Communist Party leader, and others in the party hierarchy.

title: A Superb Regulation!
description: Some of the most inventive writing in America could, until 1972, be found in theater and movie advertisements quoting the critics. Misquoting, actually, as was once documented in a magazine article by William Honan, now editor of The Times's Arts and Leisure section. For example, consider Walter Kerr's review of a play called ''Isobel,'' starring Shirley Booth.

title: FREE EVENTS TO CELEBRATE HARLEM WEEK
description: A Jazzmobile concert at Amsterdam Avenue and 162d Street by the Ray Baretta Orchestra tonight at 7 begins a weekend of free festivities celebrating Harlem Week, which runs through Aug. 23.

title: Hoboken Pier Fair
description: There will be free activities aplenty this weekend for sailors and landlubbers alike at the fourth River City Fair in Hoboken, N.J. Visitors may board the sloop Clearwater and other vessels docked at the pier. Daylong entertainment will be provided by rock bands, a jazz ensemble, an old-time string band, a steel-drum calypso band and other groups.

title: Cujo
description: Everything begins so simply in Stephen King's latest novel, ''Cujo,'' perhaps the cruelest, most disturbing tale of horror he's written yet. One day this 200-pound St. Bernard named Cujo is chasing a rabbit in back of his owner's house, which happens to lie at the end of a dead-end road outside a small town in Maine.

title: Funds' Assets Up $2.23 Billion
description: The assets of the nation's money funds climbed by $2.23 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 11th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: CHILDREN PART OF SHOW AT LABORATORY MUSEUM
description: Many New York museums have revolving exhibitions, but there is one that changes with virtually every visitor. It is the Manhattan Laboratory Museum for children, where young visitors can add art works of their own to the collection or become part of the exhibition themselves.

title: 8 INDICTED IN FULTON FISH MARKET PAYOFFS
description: A union leader, two former union officials and five businessmen were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges of racketeering, extortion and labor payoffs in the Fulton Fish Market.

title: A FUTURE SEEN DIMLY
description: President Reagan wants to play tough, standing up to the air traffic controllers and standing up to the Soviet Union. While we will probably survive the disruption in airline schedules, the consequences of an American foreign policy confronting the Soviet Union pose a greater danger. This Administration has made significant changes in American foreign policy, changes leading to a world that will be more secure for neither nations nor individuals.

title: Pop Jazz; HILDEGARDE, BEAUCOUP AS ALWAYS AT MARTY'S
description: IT was roses all around. Hildegarde's dress was a rose-colored chiffon by Halston. Atop the piano on stage, 13 pink roses fanned out from a crystal vase, the last put in just before show time by the singer as ''my talisman.'' A tablecloth draped over a railing separating her dressing room from the passage to the stage was thickly imprinted with roses. On her dressing table was a terry-cloth towel with rose patterns. Her hand mirror was rose-colored, and the padded hangers for the 18 gowns she had brought with her were, of course, rose satin. A deep rose-red towel with her named embroidered in gold thread was tossed over one end of her sofa.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, AUGUST 14, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan acknowledged that future budget deficits might be wider than he had projected, as he signed his economic package into law. He blamed changes in his program by Congress. (Page A1.) The tax-exempt savings certificates authorized by the tax law could prove a boon to those in 30 percent-plus brackets. (D1.)

title: The City; Suit Threatened In Bridge Death
description: The city was formally notified that $50 million in damages would be sought for the ''wrongful death'' of Akira Aimi, a 32-year-old Japanese photographer who was fatally injured June 28 when a cable snapped on the Brooklyn Bridge while he was walking across it.

title: WARD BLAMES MISTAKES BY GUARDS
description: A second inmate in as many days escaped from Rikers Island Wednesday, and New York City's Correction Commissioner yesterday attributed both escapes to mistakes by guards.

title: Index; Controllers' Strike
description: Trans-Atlantic travel is returning to normal at airports A12 Views of the air controllers' strike from 33,000 feet A12 Trans-Atlantic air travel returns to near-normal A12 International Lowly Hindus in India see Islam as their salvation A2 Ex-prisoner tells of harsh life in Vietnam 're-education' camp A3 East Berlin marks anniversary of the wall A4 Around the World A5 Lebanon accepts 'in principle' Libyan offer of defense system A6 Government/Politics White House seeks ways to shift welfare programs to states A8 New York State increases penalty for late tax payments B2 U.S. cuts to cause layoffs of 600 in New York's job service division B4 General Ukrainian boy's parents call asy- lum official kidnapping A3 Around the Nation A8 Reporter's Notebook: Linda Greenhouse on bar convention A13 Health/Science Voyager 2 transmitting sharp photos of Saturn A13 Weekend Lincoln Center goes out of doors C1 Weekender Guide C1 Metropolitan Baedeker: Fire Is- land C1 A hands-on West Side children's museum C12 Art: Jackson Pollock and Lee Krasner show in Hamptons C1

title: 600 IN JOBS UNIT FACE LAYOFFS
description: About a fifth of the employees of the state division responsible for helping the unemployed find jobs will lose their own jobs next month because of Federal budget cuts, officials of the State Labor Department said today.

title: The City; Stein Undergoes Appendix Surgery
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan, who became ill while campaigning, had his appendix removed last night at Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: ON FIRE ISLAND, MILES AND MILES OF ACTIVITIES
description: THERE is a story about Fire Island that goes like this: a newspaper correspondent from a far off country visits the island and, as ordered by his editor back home, writes a first-impression piece, the kind that is supposed to give a fresh, unjaded look at a place. ''The land has a poor underdeveloped economy,'' he types on his portable. ''The residents use small carts. The automobile has not yet been introduced. Indeed, most of the natives are so poor they wear no shoes at all.''

title: Nicaragua, Lost and Found
description: Not too long ago, the Reagan Administration seemed ready to declare Nicaragua lost to the Soviet camp. Its military aid to El Salvador's guerrillas was denounced.

title: Japan's Trade; Surplus Rises
description: Japan's world trade surplus rose 3.8 percent, to $1.53 billion in July from $1.47 billion in June, the Ministry of Finance said today. The surplus in trade with the United States rose to a record $1.35 billion.

title: Zimbabwe Planning to Close Schools Serving Only Whites
description: Private ''community schools,'' regarded by the Zimbabwean Government as a means of continuing whites-only education in an officially desegregated society, will be abolished at the end of the month, Education Minister Dzingai Mutumbuka announced today.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Buitoni Foods Corporation to Chester Gore for two of its divisions, Perugina Chocolates and Confections Inc., and Carlyle Importers Inc.

title: LINCOLN CENTER GOES OUTDOORS FOR A SPREE
description: THE 10th free Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival is upon us, spilling music and laughter across the great open spaces of the city's cultural capital. It is running for three weeks, day and night, through Aug. 30, with bands and orchestras of every beat, mimes, clowns and jugglers, children's theater and dance companies. The festival is particularly active this weekend.

title: News Summary; News Summary
description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 14, 1981 Controllers' Strike No immediate boycotts or other actions to support striking air traffic controllers in the United States will be undertaken by the 61-nation international controllers' organization. But it appealed to President Reagan to reopen talks to end the strike. The appeal, which was made at an emergency meeting of the group's executive board in Amsterdam, was immediately rejected by the Administration. Later, the President reiterated his refusal to grant pardons or amnesty to the fired controllers. Meanwhile, air travel across the North Atlantic, which had been thrown into chaos earlier in the week, returned to almost normal. (Page A1, Column 1.) A cooling-off period and an immediate resumption of negotiations in the air traffic controllers' strike were called for in an emergency meeting of the executive board of the International Federation of Air Traffic Controllers' Organizations in Amsterdam. (A12:1.)

title: FUQUA REPORTS POSSIBLE TAKEOVER
description: Fuqua Industries, a diversified manufacturer based in Atlanta, said it had received an indication that another company would make an offer of more than $20 a share for its stock.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS NEUTRON DECISION
description: President Reagan, defending his recent decision to produce neutron warheads, said today that the weapon was defensive in nature and that it would not be deployed in Europe without ''full consultations'' with America's allies.

title: MUIR'S ACCOUNTS IN NEW YORK TO BE SHIFTED TO ROONEY PLACE
description: John Muir & Company, the Wall Street firm that announced earlier this week that it was withdrawing from the brokerage business, said yesterday that it would transfer its New York accounts to Rooney Pace Inc. and sell its Sarasota, Fla., branch to Herzfeld & Stern.

title: COPING AT FEDERAL EXPRESS
description: Just as they have done every morning for the last five years, hundreds of eager part-timers at 12:15 A.M. today manned the maze of conveyers and chutes in the Federal Express complex at the Memphis International Airport.

title: MRS. THATCHER'S OPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 232695 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHANCE TO RANT AND BE A JERK
description: PHILIP spends several nights a week with Lisa and they go bicycling every Sunday. But when someone calls her his girlfriend, he hastens to deny it. He yelps as if in pain when the word ''commitment'' enters the conversation, and when Lisa suggests exchanging keys to their respective apartments, he is aghast at the prospect of curtailing his rendezvous with other women. ''See, I like to say I'm having my cake, and I'm having my cupcake, too, if you know what I mean,'' he tells a friend.

title: WEINBERGER SAID TO OFFER REAGAN PLAN TO REGAIN ATOMIC SUPERIORITY
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has prepared for President Reagan a comprehensive proposal to expand the nation's strategic nuclear deterrent forces that goes well beyond previous plans to strengthen those forces, according to senior Administration officials.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: TV Weekend; ANALYZING SOME PILOTS THAT DIDN'T FLY
description: ON lazy summer evenings, when the sun doesn't set until after 8 o'clock and families stay out barbecuing or playing tennis instead of watching television, the networks play the pilots for series that did not make the fall schedule. This isn't necessarily a loss to viewers who are otherwise occupied, because the pilots are plainly not the best the networks have to offer.

title: Business People; New Head At Wood, Struthers
description: Charles E. Harris, 38, is the new chairman of the Wood, Struthers & Winthrop Management Corporation, a Wall Street firm that manages more than $1 billion in assets. Mr. Harris will also head a new division of the firm bearing his name that will perform investment management.

title: Petrie to Acquire Hartfield Stores
description: The Petrie Stores Corporation, the nation's second-largest chain of women's apparel specialty shops, and Hartfield-Zodys Inc., a diversified retailer based in Los Angeles, said they had reached an agreement for Petrie to acquire the 68-store Hartfield junior apparel chain for $10 million in cash.

title: APPLAUSE FOLLOWS CAREY IN EL BARRIO
description: If Governor Carey was not running for re-election yesterday, he was at least walking very fast. With his wife, Evangeline Gouletas-Carey, at his side and a coterie of public officials in tow, the Governor barnstormed through El Barrio, East Harlem's Hispanic community, shaking hands and delivering fiery speeches reminiscent of his last campaign, in 1978. His present term ends next year.

title: POLISH CHIEFS TO SEE BREZHNEV
description: The Warsaw radio confirmed today that Poland's Communist Party leader, Stanislaw Kania, and Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski would make a ''short working visit'' to the Soviet Union soon to meet with President Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Advertising; Ad World Is Setting For a Play
description: WHEN Madison Avenue comes to Broadway, and the publicist has a name like Fred Hoot, you can be fairly sure that the event will be hard to ignore.

title: Energy Watch
description: AUGUST 14 1981 Crude oil supplies fell to 384.7 million barrels.

title: HANOI STILL HOLDS THOUSANDS IN CAMPS
description: More than six years after the Communist victory, countless thousands of Vietnamese who served the former Saigon Government remain imprisoned in jungle camps, uncharged, untried and unsure whether they will ever be released.

title: The Region; Plant Faces Fines In Scalding of 2
description: Federal officials said a chemical plant here faced $1,500 in fines for safety violations in a July 23 accident in which two workers were scalded, one critically.

title: Notes on People; A Costly Cash Crop
description: All Jane Schimpff had in mind, she said, was a little hedge against inflation, which was fine, but the cash crop the police found in the backyard of her home in La Jolla, Calif., was made up of 56 marijuana plants, and that, she discovered this week, is against the law.

title: LOWLY HINDUS IN INDIA SEE ISLAM AS THEIR SALVATION
description: In many villages in southern India, Hindu untouchables have begun staging large-scale conversions to Islam to escape what their leaders say is oppression by higher castes.

title: U.S. STARTS SEEKING MIDEAST ATOM BAN
description: The United States has begun to seek an accord to keep the Middle East free of nuclear weapons, the new director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said today.

title: The Region; 2 BILLS ON WATER SIGNED BY BYRNE
description: The state took control of future planning for New Jersey's water supplies as Governor Byrne signed two bills into law.

title: Monsanto to Cut Nylon Production
description: The Monsanto Company, one of the nation's biggest producers of nylon fiber, announced it was cutting production by almost 23 percent because of slack demand for nylon for carpets.

title: Business People; 3 Quit in Shake-Up At Pantry Pride
description: A shake-up in the top management of Pantry Pride Inc., the supermarket chain formerly known as Food Fair, came to light yesterday with the announcement of the resignation of three top officers, including the president and chief operating officer. The new president is Roger L. Galassini, 42 years old, who joined the company, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., two years ago.

title: Kidnappers Free Italian
description: Kidnappers freed a shipping owner's 25-year-old son today after holding him for eight months, the police said. The police did not say whether a ransom had been paid for the release of Gianluca Grimaldi, a university student who was abducted Dec. 2 in Naples.

title: Notes on People; One First Lady Held More Equal Than Another
description: As First Ladies of the United States and the Philippines, Nancy Reagan and Imelda Marcos are considered by the United Nations to be equals, a spokesman said yesterday, but one of them is a bit more equal than the other.

title: HIT-AND-RUN ACCIDENT INQUIRY FAILS IN CONNECTICUT
description: An investigation to find the hit-and-run driver who killed a 20-year-old New London student eight years ago failed for a second time as a one-man grand jury today declared the inquiry closed.

title: Soviet Sales Of Oil Rise
description: High fuel prices worldwide raised the Soviet Union's earnings from oil and gas exports last year by almost a third, to $27.3 billion, according to trade statistics released today.

title: Coach Denies Charges Laid to Temple Football
description: Temple University, during a 10-year drive to improve its football team from mediocrity to national contention, engaged in questionable academic and financial practices, The Philadelphia Bulletin reported today.

title: Bridge; 2 NEW YORKERS JOINED LIST OF TITLEHOLDERS IN BOSTON
description: The Summer National Championships, which ended in Boston last week, resulted in a total eclipse of the established stars who have dominated the game the past two decades. They were nearly all there, but none of them won a major title and few came close.

title: NIXON SAID TO HAVE PAID $140,000 TO AVOID TRIAL
description: Richard M. Nixon paid a Pentagon official $144,000 last year to avoid a trial of a lawsuit seeking damages from the former President for dismissing him in 1969, according to papers filed with the Supreme Court today.

title: STAGE: SIMPLICITY OF PEKING OPERA
description: THE opening of the Peking Opera, Ch'i Style, at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday was a gala East-West social event, but in terms of art being communicated to a Western audience, the evening represents a severe cultural gap. Despite all the anticipation, the 200-year-old performance technique, as offered for the first time in America by a Shanghai company, seems more esoteric than exotic.

title: BEIRUT TO ACCEPT AIR DEFENSE PLAN
description: Lebanon has accepted ''in principle'' an offer from Libya of an air defense system, including missiles, to guard against Israeli aircraft, according to a Libyan dpilomat here.

title: 5 WOMEN MISSING FROM MIAMI BOARDING HOUSE TURN UP AT DETROIT HOSPITAL
description: Five elderly and confused women missing from a Miami boarding house were abandoned at a Detroit hospital today by a mysterious man and woman in a black Cadillac, the authorities said.

title: THE NEUTRON MUDDLE
description: The main thing wrong with President Reagan's decision to go ahead with the neutron warhead is that it hasn't been clearly enough explained. The argument about the weapon has been muddled from the start by emotional misconception and political clumsiness.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS ECONOMIC PROGRAM WITH A WARNING
description: President Reagan signed his historic package of tax and budget reductions into law today, and for the first time he acknowledged that changes Congress made in his program raised the possibility of future Federal budget deficits even wider than those he originally projected.

title: INQUIRY IS ASKED IN SEIZURES OF 3 AS POLISH ALIENS
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd said today that he had asked the Immmigration and Naturalization Service to investigate ''claims of excessive force and hostile behavior'' by its agents in arresting persons suspected of being Polish aliens.

title: American Slain in Guatemala
description: Leftist rebels besieged by Government troops at a hideout west of the capital today killed Clifford Bevins, a kidnapped American executive, before the soldiers stormed in and killed the five guerrillas, the Government said. Mr. Bevins, 56 years old, of Portland, Ore., was the manager of Ginza, a subsidiary of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. He was abducted Dec. 7, 1980.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 14, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M.

title: U.S. MAY BUY MEXICAN OIL
description: The Energy Department confirmed today that talks were under way with Mexico about the possibility of buying oil for the Government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: PRICES ON STOCKS ARE MOSTLY UNCHANGED
description: The stock market, with traders confused over the direction of interest rates, closed practically unchanged in slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column most of the session, closed off 0.86 point, to 944.35. In the overall market, declines on the New York Stock Exchange barely outnumbered gains, 715 to 701.

title: Singapore Group Buying U.S. Bank
description: American City Bank, the state's 22d largest, said it had reached an agreement to be acquired by a unit of the United Overseas Group, Singapore's largest banking conglomerate, for $83 million.

title: Pemex to Raise;
description: The Mexican state-controlled oil concern, Petroleos Mexicanos, is to raise $500 million in a six-year finance package that combines aspects of both a credit facility and a bond issue, the lead manager, the European Banking Company, said today.

title: GRIM ROW OF FACES IN COURT
description: Grim-faced and silent, they sat in a row at a long table, surrounded by their lawyers. Once they were among the highest elected officials in the land; yesterday the six men who have come to be known as Abscam defendants were simply convicted felons about to be sentenced for their crimes.

title: Economic Scene; Housing Crisis Is Worsening
description: , low- and moderate-income people seeking to rent or purchase shelter will find a housing industry in crisis and unable to meet their needs.

title: CAREY ACTS ON ALL BILLS HE WAS GIVEN THIS YEAR
description: Governor Carey's office announced today that he had completed action on the hundreds of bills passed this year by the State Legislature. Altogether, Mr. Carey signed 1,006 bills - more than in any other year of his term - and vetoed 132.

title: Star Is on Sale Again, Briefly
description: When The Washington Star ended publication Friday, speculators grabbed thousands of copies of the last issue and advertised them for sale in The Washington Post at prices up to $750 a copy.

title: Girl, 10, Wins A Gold Medal
description: Debbie Black, a 10-year-old from a Buffalo suburb, became today the youngest gold-medal winner in the four-year history of the Empire State Games.

title: U.S. BARS LOAN FOR GUYANA
description: The Reagan Administration, in an action described as representative of a more rigorous approach to lending to the third world, today vetoed a $20 million loan to Guyana that came before the board of the Inter-American Development Bank.

title: Sohio Increases '81 Capital Outlays
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it had increased its 1981 capital spending budget to $2 billion from $1.6 billion.

title: SHIRK FIGHTING FOR A JOB
description: The numbers game has begun in the Giants' camp, and Gary Shirk is a central figure. ''Everybody is playing it,'' Shirk said today. ''Everything is magnified. Everybody is edgy.'' This numbers game has nothing to do with picking three or four digits and winning big in the lottery. It has to do with how many players are on a professional football team.

title: Business People; Tandycrafts President Seeks New Directions
description: Kenneth L. Gregson, 52, a veteran employee of Tandycrafts Inc. and the company from which it was spun off, the Tandy Corporation, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Tandycrafts. He succeeds George R. Nugent, 63, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: NOTEBOOK: WHEN LEGAL ELITE MEET, WHO IS REPRESENTED?
description: At their semiannual conventions, members of the American Bar Association often refer to themselves as speaking and acting for ''the bar'' or ''the profession.'' That is technically correct some of the time, and as a matter of public perception it is probably true a great deal of the time. But it is hard to stroll through one of these diffuse gatherings without wondering what relevance all the activity has to the vast majority of lawyers who choose, convention after convention, to stay home.

title: JAZZ: VINCE GIORDANO AND NEW BAND AT RED BLAZER TOO
description: WHEN Vince Giordano's New Orleans Nighthawks first began playing on Tuesday nights at the Red Blazer Too, Third Avenue between 87th and 88th Streets, three-and-a-half years ago, the fact that this ninepiece band was playing arrangements of the decade between 1925 and 1935 with knowledgability and a sense of authority gave it immediate distinction. At that time the Nighthawks included such notable musicians as the clarinetist Clarence Hutchenrider of the Casa Loma Orchestra and Jimmy Maxwell, a Benny Goodman trumpet star.

title: Restaurants; 2 FACES OF VANESSA AND A FIFTH HISAE
description: IT would not be hard to believe that there are two entirely different restaurants named Vanessa, both on the same site on Bleecker Street, just east of Seventh Avenue South, and both with the same handsome and romantic deep-purple walls and gleaming Art Deco brass lighting fixtures. One Vanessa is quiet, cool and airy, with well-paced service and pleasantly pretty food in the style best described as nouvelle American, and it attracts a mild-mannered young and informal following. The other Vanessa is jam-packed, crashingly noisy, often stifling, with painfully slow and inept service and food so contrived that it is difficult to swallow more than a few bites. In the later hours when the restaurant is most uncomfortable, oddly enough, the crowd is older and more seriously and stylishly dressed.

title: Fugitive Held in Death Of Woman in Yacht Case
description: An escaped convict is being held without bond in the murder of a San Diego woman who disappeared with her husband while yachting in the South Seas seven years ago.

title: Accord Set on Jobs For Cincinnati Police
description: The Justice Department obtained an agreement from the Cincinnati Police Department today for special efforts to hire and promote more blacks and women.

title: PUBLISHING: KOCH BOOK IS DOING FINE
description: WITH money tight and politicians suspect, who would want to buy a collection of quotations from the speeches, news conferences and impromptu remarks of a mayor? A good many people, to judge from the success of ''How'm I Doing?: The Wit and Wisdom of Ed Koch'' (Lion Books), a $4.95, 107-page paperback now in its third printing with 70,000 copies in print.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: East rubbed elbows with West, politely of course, on 57th Street the other night at the buffet reception Michael Chow gave for the Shanghai Peking Opera Troupe's American debut. Mr. Chow, the owner of the restaurant that bears his name, also happens to be the brother of Zhou Shaolin, the troupe's principal performer, and, along with the Melpomene Foundation Ltd., he is presenting the current engagement at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Fannie Mae Sets 17% Rate
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, announced yesterday a 17 percent interest rate for $700 million of new three-and-a-half-year debentures and 16 3/8 percent for $300 million of new seven-year debentures. Comparable three-and-aquarter-year and seven-year Treasury issues were yielding about 15.88 percent and 14.91 percent, respectively.

title: MEXICO SNARED BY GUATEMALAN STRIFE
description: The increasing violence in Guatemala is posing serious diplomatic and even moral quandaries for Mexico, which has traditionally sympathized with the revolutionary movements of Central America but is also anxious about avoiding political problems along its southern border.

title: JOE CHARBONEAU HAS TO GO, FOR A WHILE
description: *Copyright c 1980, Cleveland Indians. Who's the newest guy in town? Go Joe Charboneau. Turns the ballpark upside down. Go Joe Charboneau .... Who's the one to keep our hopes alive? .... Straight from seventh to the pennant drive .... Raise your glass, let out a cheer

title: UNLIKELY APPROACH TO ARMS REDUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Concerts Sunday
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble will play two free performances Sunday. At 2 P.M., the site will be the lawn outside the Van Cortlandt Mansion in Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway and 246th Street.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly identified the airline that George A. Warde formerly served as president. It was American Airlines.

title: S.E.C. ACTS ON PAYMENT
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused a Dallas contracting company today of giving $1.4 million in bribes since April 1980 to a foreign government official to help the company obtain overseas business.

title: FOR ELITE, SUMMER MEANS MORE WORK
description: By John Duka

title: OPEC WILL TRY AGAIN TO SETTLE PRICE DISPUTE
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are reported to be negotiating behind the scenes this week in an attempt to fashion a pricing agreement that would require African producers to cut their official oil prices as much as $3 a barrel.

title: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES UP MODERATELY
description: Interest rates rose modestly in quiet trading yesterday as dealers said the credit markets were depressed by the absence of large buyers and by high financing costs.

title: California Plans Spraying Near Quarantined Zone
description: State officials said today that they would order aerial spraying of pesticide over an area north of Santa Cruz outside a federally imposed quarantine zone.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Home Depot Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 600,000 shares of common stock, to be sold through a Bear, Stearns group.

title: BRASCAN IN $1.1 BILLION NORANDA ACCORD
description: Brascan Ltd., a holding company controlled by Edward and Peter Bronfman, all but won a bitter two-year battle yesterday to increase its stake in Noranda Mines Ltd., the Canadian mining and forest products giant.

title: REAGAN PLANS WELFARE SHIFT TO STATES
description: The Reagan Administration has begun a search for ways to shift major responsibility for welfare programs to state governments, a White House official said today.

title: When Ma Bell Drops the Other Shoe
description: Phone 100 cities at half price ... pay for long distance by the hour ... unlimited calls coast-to-coast for $60 a month. ... As the ads make clear, Ma Bell isn't the only game in town anymore. People can chat across a thousand miles for little more than a call to the suburbs. And they can do it on handsets purchased at department stores.

title: No Headline
description: Mark Fidrych will not return to the Detroit Tigers this season, and he may be finished with the team, General Manager Jim Campbell said.

title: TIANT IS A 7-2 LOSER IN RETURN TO MAJORS
description: Luis Tiant, who at age 40 was making a return to the major leagues and his first appearance in the National League, worked six and two-thirds innings and was the losing pitcher tonight as the Montreal Expos defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7-2.

title: Market Place; Bullish View On G.M. Stock
description: IS General Motors' stock currently a ''buy'' at nearly 80 times earnings? Some of the company's followers, looking ahead rather than at the price/earnings ratio for the last 12 months, say it is. One condition, they add, is that investors be willing to accompany the stock for a long ride.

title: MUSIC: A BRASSY 'CORSAIR' AT CONCERT IN PARK
description: IF there is one thing the outdoor New York Philharmonic concerts in the parks remind us of, it is that a concert can be a special occasion. There was, no doubt, a time before middle-class concerts became the rule in urban society, when any concert in any concert hall would have had such an aura. But in contemporary New York, with its plethora of concert halls and world-class performers, a concert is merely a night out like any other.

title: FOLK FESTIVAL WITH A TOUCH OF DIXIELAND
description: WHEN jazz criticism was in its infancy, a reporter asked Louis Armstrong if jazz was folk music. Mr. Armstrong is said to have summoned considerable hauteur and replied that he had never seen a mule playing it. His bon mots have never been accepted as a serious definition of folk music, but what is to be made of the eclectic schedule for the first New York Folk Festival, which presented a program of new-wave rock bands this week and which moves into high gear today and tonight with programs that include Dixieland jazz and vocal group rhythm and blues, as well as performances by Buffy Sainte-Marie, Richie Havens, Odetta, Tom Paxton and other artists who are better known to folk enthusiasts? Do the Persuasions, David Amram, and Tubby the Tuba really qualify as folk performers?

title: Briefs
description: * Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway placed orders for two largescale computer systems valued at more than $18 million from Sperry Univac, a division of Sperry Corp.

title: SRIF ACKERMAN IS THE BRIDE OF DR. YOEL COHEN, TEACHER
description: Sara Rivka Ackerman, daughter of Elsa Ackerman of Rego Park Queens, and the late Harry Ackerman, was married yesterday to Dr. Yoel Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. A.S. Cohen of London.

title: ART: WHITNEY DISPLAYS ITS 10 GEORGIA O'KEEFES
description: ''CONCENTRATIONS'' is a series of shows that focuses on major figures in the permanent collection of the Whitney Museum of American Art. Started last year and sponsored by Champion International Corporation, the displays are the work of Patterson Sims, associate curator of the collection, and they are staged in the museum's small ground-floor gallery. So far, eight notables have been examined, including John Sloan, Gaston Lachaise, Maurice Prendergast and Stuart Davis. Now, the spotlight is on Georgia O'Keeffe (through Oct. 4).

title: ARABIAN HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: INVENTORIES STEADY IN JUNE
description: The value of inventories stockpiled by American businesses rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, largely as a result of an increase in unsold cars held on dealers' lots, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SOVIET PARENTS ASSAIL SON'S STAY IN U.S.
description: The parents of a 13-year-old Ukrainian boy who left his family in Chicago a year ago rather than return to the Soviet Union arrived in Moscow without him today and offered a nightmarish account of what they called the ''kidnapping'' and possible drugging of their son by United States officials.

title: 'EYE FOR AN EYE' IS SOFT-CORE VIOLENCE
description: ''CHUCK NORRIS doesn't need a weapon ... he is a weapon!'' That's the ad copy for ''An Eye for an Eye,'' and it certainly is catchy - but it gives a slight misimpression. Mr. Norris, star of such martial-arts movies as ''The Octagon'' and this one, isn't as savage as that line makes him sound. He has fluffy blond hair, performs his stunts in chinos and a down vest, and looks less like a killer than a good-natured golf pro.

title: At the Movies; PAVAROTTI PREPARES FOR A DEBUT
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI was at the Metropolitan Opera the other day. That might seem old hat, except that this time, ''the king of the high C's'' was performing in a movie, not in an opera. He was making his film debut in a romantic comedy about a world-famous Italian tenor named Giorgio Fini, who has a romance with an eminent Boston throat specialist (played by Kathryn Harrold) called in to treat his vocal cords during a triumphant tour of the United States. The film, called ''Yes, Giorgio!'' is being directed by Franklin J. Schaffner for M-G-M.

title: JUDGE DECLARES A MISTRIAL IN RAIDER CASE
description: A mistrial was declared late tonight after a United States District Court jury deliberated 13 days and could not reach a verdict in the antitrust case involving the Oakland Raiders afd the National Football League. A new trial was scheduled to begin Sept. 21.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Voortrekkerhoogte military complex near Pretoria, South Africa's largest, was hit by four 122-millimeter rockets last night, and a search was under way today for three black nationalist guerrillas believed responsible.

title: IF THE RIGHT TO STRIKE MUST BE DENIED
description: To the Editor:

title: Aid Offered Thrift Units
description: Federal regulators today proposed that the nation's financially troubled savings and loan associations be given broad leeway in the way they account for sales of old, lowyield home loans, a move that would give them new access to tax benefits.

title: INTEREST RATES ON LATE TAX PAYMENTS RAISED
description: Changes in state tax law that took effect today seek to make it less profitable for people to pay their taxes late in order to invest the money for a time in high-yield securities.

title: RECORDING: TOTICO, STREET-CORNER RUMBA
description: TOTICO Y SUS RUMBEROS. Eugenio F. Arango, with percussion, chorus and bass. Montuno Records, 1470 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10036. $7.98.

title: MORE CONCERNS LIFT STEEL PRICES
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, and the eighth-ranked Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation matched price increases on products used in food and beverage cans announced previously by other steelmakers.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: King's Hospitalization Forces Delay in Talks
description: The meeting scheduled yesterday to set the date for a Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney heavyweight championship fight was postponed because Don King, one of the promoters, was in a Cleveland hospital for a checkup.

title: RESIDENTS ASSAIL CITY PROPOSAL TO HOUSE DERELICTS IN GATEWAY PARK
description: Last month, the Koch administration quietly asked Federal authorities for permission to shelter 400 derelicts in a former naval barracks inside the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: BRUBECKS AND OTHER ALFRESCO MUSICIANS
description: Besides the usual bounty of outdoor music about town, this weekend will offer something of a homecoming by the Brubeck family. The jazz pianist Dave Brubeck and his three sons will appear in various musical combinations tonight and tomorrow in New York City and on Long Island.

title: State Will Prosecute In California Stranglings
description: The California Attorney General's office announced today that it would prosecute Angelo Buono in the so-called hillside strangler case despite the reluctance of District Attorney John Van de Kamp of Los Angeles to go ahead with a trial.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Business Day Wednesday incorrectly reported a change in Chemical Bank's broker loan rate. Chemical lowered the rate Tuesday to 19 percent from 19 1/2 percent. A correction published yesterday attributed the rate change to the wrong bank.

title: Danish Trains Disrupted
description: Power failures at a computerized control center disrupted rush-hour rail traffic today, making tens of thousands of commuters late for work.

title: Pleasant Colony Fit For Travers Stakes
description: John Campo has a perfect record with Pleasant Colony, not as his trainer but as a handicapper. Campo predicted victories before the Wood Memorial, Kentucky Derby and Preakness and Pleasant Colony won all three. Campo continued to bluster about him before the Belmont but pointedly refused to forecast a victory, and Pleasant Colony was upset by Summing. What, then, is Campo's tip on Pleasant Colony's return to the races Saturday in the 112th Travers?

title: Rebels Report Seizing A Salvadoran Garrison
description: A clandestine guerrilla radio station said today that rebel forces had overrun a National Guard garrison in the town of Perquin, 122 miles northeast of San Salvador.

title: AUG. 1-10 AUTO SALES UP 30.8%
description: With the help of dealer and customer incentive programs, the Big Three auto manufacturers reported today a 30.8 percent jump in car sales in the first 10 days of August compared with the similar period last year, when sales were in a severe slump.

title: Soviet Wheat Imports
description: Official trade figures released today showed that the Soviet Union almost doubled the value of its wheat imports last year, to the equivalent of $2.35 billion from $1.26 billion the year before. importing $1.96 billion worth of oil, up from $1.2 billion.

title: Article 232691 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: VOYAGER 2 SENDS CLEAR SATURN PHOTOS
description: Four years out from Earth and now 7.2 million miles away from Saturn, the Voyager 2 spacecraft was reported yesterday to be ''in good health'' for its rendezvous Aug. 25 with the giant ringed planet and was already transmitting photographs superior to those returned last November by the trail-blazing Voyager 1.

title: '82 EL GRECO TOUR SCHEDULED
description: The first major exhibition of the paintings of El Greco, the 16th-century Spanish artist, will tour Washington, Toledo, Ohio, and Dallas next year.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Lon Nielsen shot an eight-under-par 63 today and took a two-stroke lead as the $300,000 Greater Hartford Open completed its opening round with 99 of the 156 golfers breaking par.

title: Iran's Premier Presents 22-Member Cabinet List
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar of Iran presented a 22-member Cabinet list to Parliament today, Teheran radio announced.

title: India Defends Loan Request
description: India's Finance Minister, Ramaswami Venkataraman, said today that a record $5.65 billion loan that India is seeking from the International Monetary Fund would not hinder the country's ability to service its debts.

title: Mark for Mary Meagher In 200-Meter Butterfly
description: Mary T. Meagher bettered her world record tonight in winning the women's 200-meter butterfly race at the United States long-course swimming championships.

title: VIETNAM'S FIRM STAND ON CAMBODIA TALKS
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKS WIN, 3-0, AS GUIDRY ALLOWS 1 HIT IN 5 INNINGS
description: Ron Guidry pitched without pain and Reggie Jackson played right field for the first time since May 27 as the Yankees beat the Tigers tonight, 3-0, to begin their first road trip since the end of the 50-day baseball strike.

title: Broadway; NEIL SIMON PLANS A LITTLER 'LITTLE ME' FOR END OF YEAR
description: ONE of Neil Simon's pastimes over the years has been tinkering with ideas for a new, smaller version of ''Little Me,'' the 1962 Broadway musical he wrote with Cy Coleman, the composer, and Carolyn Leigh, the lyricist. About eight years ago Mr. Simon went so far as to write a new book for the show, which was based on Patrick Dennis's novel, but put it aside to do other things. Recently he wrote another version, and his original collaborators jumped into the project. The new ''Little Me'' will open Dec. 29 at Mr. Simon's own Broadway theater, the Eugene O'Neill. Emanuel Azenberg is the producer.

title: The Redcoats Lose Again at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. PETER HAYNES= said he liked America. ''People here will do anything for you,'' he said. ''In England, they wish you hadn't asked.'' Peter Haynes is a slender, smiling Englishman of 30 with thin red hair brushed flat across his brow. He earns his living falling on that haircut or, rather, trying not to fall on it when the horse he is riding jumps fences in steeplechase races. He and Derek Kent, a trainer, hoped they would be airborne for home Wednesday night after their second visit to this month's Saratoga meeting.

title: FIRM SPECIALIZES IN BUYING, SELLING SEATS ON EXCHANGES
description: Samuel Weiss has found a better way to make money on the stock exchange than trading stocks and bonds. He is selling seats. Mr. Weiss is selling interests in New York Stock Exchange seats, and eventually memberships on other exchanges, through a new company, Stock Exchange Services. Last month, the Big Board approved Stock Exchange Services' proposal to become the first member firm to deal exclusively in acquiring memberships for leasing and investment.

title: Two Athletes Banned
description: Lazlo Szabo, a shot-putter from Hungary, and Evelyn Ledl, a sprinter from Austria, have been banned for life for using drugs in the European Cup semifinals last month. The penalties were announced by Arthur Gold, president of the European Athletic Association. Gold also said, ''Eighteen months from now we shall review their case, and they could be re-admitted into competition.''

title: TEXACO CANADA UP
description: Texaco Canada stock surged sharply this week because of rumors that Texaco Inc. would buy out the minority shareholders of its Canadian unit.

title: Washington - Summer is a time for memory, and I remember with peculiar vividness the summer of 1912 when my brother Ogden was born in the St. Regis Hotel in New York. My sister Mary and I went in to see him, but we were more impressed by the hotel, the first we had seen, than by the baby, a pale little gray-faced creature with black eyes like prunes.
description: We would spend the whole summer in the country. Life in Bernardsville, N.J., seemed so secure, so ordered, so endless. We went out, except in the hottest summer days, dressed in khaki bloomers and middies, brown stockings and sneakers. Underneath we wore underdrawers and ''waists'' -white cotton bodices with yellow horn buttons and garters advertised by Buster Brown and his dog, Tige.

title: No Headline
description: Because of an editing error, David Langdon, a spokesman for the Assembly Speaker, was quoted incorrectly in some editions of Metropolitan Report yesterday about the position of the New York State Assembly on a bill to make it easier for homeowners to appeal their tax assessments. The Assembly raised no objections to the bill.

title: F.C.C. DROPS LENDING CASE
description: The Federal Trade Commission, reversing its earlier position and a decision by an administrative law judge, today dismissed a complaint that had accused the Household Finance Corporation of breaking the law in computing some finance charges.

title: Britain Clinches Victory In Admiral's Cup Races
description: Britain won the five-event Admiral's Cup from 15 other nations today at the end of the Fastnet ocean race, the event that claimed 15 lives in gales that caused the world's worst yacht race disaster in 1979.

title: Feminists Say Reagan Reneged on a Promise
description: Feminists dismayed by a decision of the Administration to take another look at a rule barring sex discrimination in school sports are accusing President Reagan of reneging on a campaign promise to uphold women's rights.

title: Andrea Fenton Wed To Bruce R. Gilbert
description: The marriage of Andrea L. Fenton to Bruce R. Gilbert took place last evening at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold N. Fenton, parents of the bride, in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Glenn Porcelain performed the ceremony.

title: Notes on People; Jack Carter Moves
description: Jack Carter, a son of Jimmy Carter, the former President, has moved his family from Georgia to Illinois following the failure of a grain elevator business he owned with four associates in Calhoun, Ga.

title: Emery Spending
description: The Emery Air Freight Corporation, a major forwarding operator, said it would add $32 million to a previously announced $63 million aircraft equipment program. The company said it would purchase an additional seven Boeing 727-100's from the Boeing Equipment Holding Company, raising to 19 the number of aircraft it has acquired this year.

title: CHESTER M. BROWN, EXECUTIVE, IS DEAD
description: Chester M. Brown, retired chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Allied Chemical Corporation, died Wednesday at Southeast Missouri Hospital in Cape Girardeau, Mo.. He had suffered a stroke on July 25. Mr. Brown was 73 years old and had lived in Cape Girardeau, where he was born, since 1979.

title: LEE KRASNER AND POLLOCK PAINTING SHOW IN HAMPTONS
description: THE South Fork of Long Island has an ancient and honorable history where American art is concerned. It has also had a vivid if intermittent fascination for the European visitor. Max Ernst never forgot his times there. More recently the Swiss novelist and playwright Max Frisch spent a weekend in Montauk from which a whole book - and a very good one, too - emerged not long after.

title: BRONX ZOO BIRTH COULD AID RARE SPECIES
description: A baby gaur, a wild ox native to India, was born to a Holstein dairy cow at the Bronx Zoo this week in the successful culmination of an experiment that could ultimately increase the chance for survival of a number of endangered species.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt CUJO. By Stephen King. 319 pages. Viking. $13.95.

title: TRANS-ATLANTIC TRAVEL RETURNING TO NORMAL AS BACKLOGS CLEAR UP: DELAYS AT KENNEDY PERSIST
description: Trans-Atlantic air travel moved closer to normal yesterday, but delays as long as six hours were still being reported on some arriving and departing flights at Kennedy International Airport.

title: About Real Estate; RESIDENTIAL RECONSTRUCTION COMES TO WEST MIDTOWN
description: When the Manhattan Plaza middle-income housing development at Ninth Avenue and 42d Street was conceived a decade ago, the expectation was that it would lead to the re-use of underutilized west midtown land as a residential location. But in the poor market of the middle 1970's pessimism ran high, and there was doubt that enough people would pay the rents required to support the city-backed mortgage. So Manhattan Plaza obtained a Section 8 rent subsidy from the Federal Government, with the beneficiaries limited to practitioners of the arts.

title: Executive Changes
description: * AM International, Los Angeles, has elected Jerry O. Williams a senior vice president.

title: Advertising; FCB Executive Named
description: James Tucker, the 53-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Foote, Cone & Belding office in Australia since 1979, has been named an executive vice president of FCB International. He has additional responsibility for FCB's Australia/Pacific region, which is expected to be a high-growth area for the agency.

title: Earnings; TANDY, QUAKER POST BIG GAINS
description: The Tandy Corporation, a leading retailer of electronics equipment, said yesterday that earnings in its fourth quarter had soared 78.9 percent and sales had climbed 28.9 percent.

title: FETAL TREATMENT VS. ABORTION
description: The abortion debate may take a poignant twist as medical advances increasingly enable doctors to treat defective human fetuses still in the womb, a medical journal says. In deciding whether to abort a defective but treatable fetus, doctors will have to struggle with the fact that the fetus could also be a patient.

title: The Region; L.I. Inquiry Opens Into Boat Crash
description: District Attorney Patrick Henry of Suffolk County has opened an investigation into the sinking of a cabin cruiser in Long Island Sound last Sunday.

title: FEDERATION URGES TALKS BE RESUMED
description: The executive board of the International Federation of Air Traffic Controllers' Associations called today for a cooling-off period in the strike by American air traffic controllers, and urged immediate negotiations to end the deadlock.

title: TRANS-ATLANTIC TRAVEL RETURNING TO NORMAL AS BACKLOGS CLEAR UP: CONDITIONS EASE IN EUROPE
description: Officials at airports across Europe reported full trans-Atlantic service available and only relatively modest delays today after three days of turmoil.

title: DR. MARK M. PLATT
description: Dr. Mark M. Platt, associate chairman of neurology at Children's Hospital in Washington, died Monday at Georgetown University Hospital after being stricken Friday with an unexplained viral illness. He was 39 years old.

title: MARGARET FISHER BRINGS INSECT-INSPIRED DANCE TO LAB
description: It was four years ago that Dance Theater Workshop started a monthlong summer series called ''The Out-of-Towners'' at the American Theater Laboratory in the Chelsea section. The aim was to present dance by dancers and choreographers working in the kinds of lively theater groups and community-arts networks that have proliferated across the country, but that seldom get a showing in New York.

title: RAY HARRISON, 64, A DANCE TEACHER AND CHOREOGRAPHER
description: Ray Harrison, a Broadway dancer, choreographer and dance teacher, died on July 27 in Boston. He was 64 years old. Mr. Harrison, who was born in St. Louis, studied ballet with Helene Platova and modern dance with Hanya Holm, in whose company he performed. He also appeared with the Katherine Litz Dance Company. Of his performance as Jonathan Harker, the hero in Miss Litz's ''Dracula,'' The New York Times dance critic John Martin wrote: ''He had grasped so completely the essential viewpoint of Miss Litz that he could run all the required gamuts of action and emotion and convince us with something like easy eloquence.''

title: U.S. PANEL SAYS INDOCHINA REFUGEES MAY INCREASE
description: The United States must be prepared for continuing and possibly increased flows of refugees from Indochina, particularly Vietnam, according to a State Department report released today.

title: NEWS IS SAID TO PLAN ENDING OF AN EDITION AND A 10% STAFF CUT
description: The Daily News plans to close its year-old afternoon edition and impose staff cuts of up to 10 percent by Labor Day in an effort to reduce fifancial losses, News staff members and outsiders familiar with the paper said yesterday.

title: THE UPSHOT OF PHONE DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can understand their anguish. They are squealing like they're sitting on a sharp nail simply because we now are showing the world that we are not going to let them get to the point of dominance where they can someday issue to the free world an ultimatum of 'surrender or die.'

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; SCIENCE FILMS IN NEWARK
description: The Newark Museum has borrowed three science films originally televised on the PBS ''Nova'' series and will show them free Fridays at 12:30 P.M. this month. The first, this afternoon, is ''Anatomy of a Volcano,'' which concerns the devastating eruption of Mount St. Helens in Washington. The film examines events leading to the explosion and analyzes the fiery blast frame by frame. The series continues with ''The Water Crisis'' next Friday and ''The Asteroid and the Dinosaur'' on Aug. 28. For information about this series and other free summer programs, call (201) 733-6600. The museum is at 49 Washington Street in downtown Newark. NOVELLA NELSON SINGS

title: The City; CO-OPS PLANNED FOR CITY ARTISTS
description: Some abandoned buildings owned by the city on the Lower East Side will be converted into cooperative housing for artists, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development announced.

title: SLIGHT REPRIEVE AT THE BULLETIN
description: The Bulletin has extended for five hours, until 5 P.M. Sunday, the deadline set for its unions to decide if they will accept economic concessions that the newspaper management says will save the 134-year-old publication.

title: Dennison Raises Offer for Ofrex
description: The Dennison Manufacturing Company of Waltham, Mass., said it had increased its cash offer for the Ofrex Group, a British manufacturer of stationery and industrial products, to $3.06 a share from $2.88 a share, raising the total value of the transaction to about $60 million.

title: WORLD AIR GROUP PUTS OFF ANY CALL FOR NEW BOYCOTTS
description: The 61-country international air controllers' organization decided yesterday against any immediate boycotts or other actions to support strikers in this country, and it appealed to President Reagan to reopen talks to end the 11-day-old labor struggle.

title: GOODRICH WILL SELL CANADA UNIT STOCK
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said today that it would make a public offering in Canada of up to one-third of the equity in B.F. Goodrich Canada Inc., its wholly owned subsidiary.

title: Judge Said to Approve Ban on Political Spying
