description: An agreement in which the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency promise not to engage in political spying against Chicago organizations or their members has been approved by a Federal District Court judge, a lawyer in the case said today.

title: 'THE UPRISING,' TALE OF NICARAGUAN WAR
description: ''The Uprising'' is an earnest but stilted political tract, a film that feels more like a pageant than a drama. Peter Lilienthal, a German director, went to Nicaragua in 1979 to make a feature film about the populist rebellion in the city of Leon. Several months after the actual upheaval had occurred, he asked the participants to re-enact their roles for the camera.

title: Notes on People; Time for a Change at the Historical Society
description: Since 1960 James J. Heslin has been the director of the New-York Historical Society, and that, he said yesterday, is just about long enough.

title: Cubs Halt Mets' Streak, 6 to 1
description: The Mets' three-game winning streak came to an end today when they lost to the Chicago Cubs, 6-1, for their first defeat in the second half of the split season.

title: U.S. Group Said to Get Missing Fliers' Remains
description: A representative of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia today turned over to American officials skull fragments that were said to be the remains of three American airmen missing in action over Laos since the Vietnam War. The remains are to be sent to forensic experts in Hawaii for identification.

title: Amritraj Upsets McEnroe
description: Vijay Amritraj, pulling off the third major upset of the tournament, eliminated John McEnroe, 5-7, 7-6, 6-1, today in the $200,000 Canadian Open. That left Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia as the only one of the top four seeded players remaining after three rounds.

title: VIEWS OF THE STRIKE FROM 35,000 FEET
description: ABOARD AMERICAN AIRLINES FLIGHT 75, Aug. 12 - Flanked by lush Virginia greenery, the DC-10 lifted away from Dulles International Airport a few moments after an Aeroflot jet bound for Moscow. Over the radio headsets in the cockpit of the DC-10, an air traffic controller could be heard, in the ritual farewell of his trade, bidding the departing Russian pilot ''good day.''

title: Mayor Koch's Rugby Game
description: Mayor Koch's refusal to let South Africa's rugby stars meet an American team on any of New York City's playing fields is producing a right result - no game - but for questionable reasons.

title: Bush Supports Dismissals
description: Vice President Bush said today that President Reagan had no choice but to dimiss the air traffic controllers who went on strike. ''If the President had knuckled under on this, what would come next?'' he said at an airport news conference before making an appearance at a Republican fundraising dinner and dance in Newport.

title: TINY HOMELAND STRAINS A SOUTH AFRICAN POLICY
description: Of the 10 tribal states South Africa has established within its borders as its answer to demands for black political rights, the tiny self-governing state of Qwaqwa can be seen as the most extreme example of the determined efforts white bureaucrats have made to force social reality to conform to a political theory.

title: 9 IN HOSPITALS DIED OF DRUG OVERDOSE
description: Nine of more than two dozen patients who died suspiciously in two small rural hospitals earlier this year were killed by overdoses of the heart-regulating drug lidocaine, the authorities announced today.

title: A.M.C. Sales Incentives
description: The American Motors Corporation, encouraged by consumer response to the rebate programs of the Big Three auto makers, said it had begun its own summer clearance sale. The cash incentives range from $100 for some A.M.C. models to $600 for Jeep models sold by Sept. 23 and $100 to $1,000 for Renault 181 models sold by Sept. 30, the company said.

title: FORD CHAIRMAN PREDICTS BETTER AUTO SALES RATE
description: Philip Caldwell, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said today that because of weak overall demand for autos this year, export restraints put into effect by Japan last spring had ''probably had no effect at all'' on improving the sales of domestic auto makers.

title: HONORED AUSTRIAN CONDUCTOR
description: Karl Bohm, the Austrian conductor who gained world renown as one of the most esteemed and honored musicians of his generation, died yesterday in Salzburg, Austria. Mr. Bohm had been ill for several weeks after suffering a stroke. He would have been 87 on Aug. 28.

title: SYDNEY FACHER
description: Sydney Facher, director of development for the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, died Wednesday in Beth Israel Hospital after suffering a heart attack.

title: RONALD REAGAN, CALVIN COOLIDGE AND THE AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT PATIENTS DON'T GET FROM THEIR DOCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILADELPHIA SUFFERS IN MANUFACTURING JOB EXODUS
description: At the Eaton Corporation's forklift plant here, they used to call him Big Bad Leroy Brown after the words of Jim Croce's popular song, ''Bad, Bad Leroy Brown.'' That was because he is truly big, his first name is Leroy and in World War II he represented his outfit as a boxer.

title: 0.3% RISE IN OUTPUT LED BY COAL
description: Despite forecasts that the American economy was entering a recession, the nation's factories and mines increased their production by three-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Ali Says He Will Seek South Carolina License
description: Muhammad Ali said today in a telephone interview that he would come here next week to secure a boxing license to make a comeback and fight a top heavyweight opponent in November.

title: Rock Brawl Prompts Curfew
description: A fight involving 1,000 people leaving a benefit rock concert has prompted officials to impose curfews at two recreational areas.

title: Around the Nation; Presley Estate Ordered To Sue Singer's Manager
description: A judge ordered the Elvis Presley estate today to stop payments to the late entertainer's longtime manager, Col. Tom Parker, and also ordered the estate's lawyers to file a lawsuit to recover an unspecified amount of money from Mr. Parker.

title: COST OF AUTO INSURANCE TO RISE 12.6% IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Department of Insurance yesterday approved an increase in automobile insurance premiums of 12.6 percent for all of the 250 companies that provide such coverage in the state.

title: PRODUCERS' PRICES UP BY 0.4% IN JULY AS INCREASE SLOWS
description: The Government's Producer Price Index for finished goods, a rough measure of the level of inflation consumers will face in the future, edged up by only four-tenths of 1 percent in July, despite a large increase in the price of food, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Around the Nation; Bus Strike in Cincinnati Leaves 90,000 Stranded
description: Hundreds of Queen City Metro bus drivers and mechanics stayed off the job today in defiance of a court injunction against a wildcat strike, which stranded 90,000 passengers in rush-hour traffic.

title: North Korea Charges Spying
description: The North Korean press agency said a United States SR-71 ''spy plane'' infiltrated North Korean airspace today to commit espionage.

title: POPE OUT OF HOSPITAL, BACK AT VATICAN
description: Pope John Paul II, declared ''clinically recovered'' by his doctors, walked out of the hospital today three months after being seriously wounded in an assassination attempt.

title: WALKER IS INSURED ON A 'FINAL' INJURY
description: While his Jet teammates packed this morning at their Long Island training camp for the flight here and tomorrow night's exhibition game against the Falcons, Wesley Walker considered going swimming at Jones Beach, to ''stretch my legs.''

title: Around the Nation; Layton Says Testimony Was Forced in Guyana
description: Larry Layton, a former Peoples Temple member, testified at a pretrial hearing today that he was starved and beaten into admitting responsibility for the 1978 killing of Representative Leo Ryan.

title: A VILLAGE CALLED THE BRONX
description: They say that home is where the heart is. But you won't find my heart anywhere among the sad wrecked buildings that line the street where I once lived. My heart is with the Bronx of memory, a Bronx that even then we knew was just a stepping stone to Bigger and Better.

title: YAMANI HOPEFUL ABOUT OIL PRICE PACT
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, said yesterday that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would ''succeed in unifying prices'' at an OPEC conference next Wednesday in Geneva.

title: SOUTH KOREA GRANTS AMNESTY TO 1,000 FELONS AND JUVENILES
description: The South Korean Government announced the release today of more than 1,000 prisoners, mostly common criminals and juvenile offenders, in an amnesty to mark the 36th anniversary of Korea's liberation from Japan in 1945.

title: FRUIT FLIES FOUND IN NEW COAST AREA
description: California's war against the Mediterranean fruit fly was sharply stepped up today with the disclosure that the crop-destroying pest had escaped a three-county quarantine area and was infesting the San Joaquin Valley, heart of the nation's richest farming region.

title: Briefs
description: * Denison Mines Ltd. said it had raised its stake in Campbell Taggart Inc., to 9 percent of the common shares outstanding from 7 percent, through the acquisition of 219,200 shares bought between July 13 and Aug. 10 at an aggregate purchase price of $7.4 million.

title: CITY AGREES TO DETAIL ITS GATEWAY PLAN FOR HOUSING DERELICTS
description: Opponents of a proposed shelter at the Gateway National Recreation Area for 400 derelicts persuaded the city yesterday to prepare a detailed report of its plans for a former naval barracks at the Floyd Bennett Field.

title: Notes on People; A Marvin Analysis
description: She wasn't really surprised when a California appeals court overturned a judgment in her favor in her precedent-setting ''palimony'' suit, Michelle Triola Marvin said yesterday in New York.

title: Around the World; Strikers in Sierra Leone Protest Economic Policy
description: A strike protesting soaring prices and food shortages crippled the capital and other areas today in the biggest challenge ever mounted by unions to the economic policy of President Siaka P. Stevens.

title: Ceausescu Sees U.S. Group
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania discussed agricultural cooperation and other international issues with a United States Congressional delegation today in Bucharest, the Rumanian press agency Agerpres reported. It said the Rumanian leader and members of the House Agriculture Committee had stressed the importance of developing agriculture, especially in the third world.

title: 2 Jerseyans Killed in Wreck
description: The wife and daughter of the principal of Passaic (N.J.) High School were fatally injured when their car collided with an empty gasoline truck on Interstate 17 here, authorities said. The two were identified as 44-year-old Marie Jarkesy, who died early today at a local hospital, and her daughter, Susan, 17, who died in the crash on Wednesday night. The principal, Samuel G. Jarkesy, 50, received multiple injuries and was listed in stable condition tonight.

title: By Mary Cantwell
description: The Editorial Notebook Plagues Old and New

title: SCREEN: IN EL SALVADOR
description: There's a terrible credit at the conclusion of ''El Salvador: The People Will Win'': a list of those who appeared in the film and have since been murdered. The four men named are the most articulate, energetic leftist spokesmen who appear on screen. Long before this final horror, the film has established the climate of danger in which it was made. There is footage of mutilated corpses, of grieving widows, of a man dying slowly and agonizingly after being shot in a raid. Much of this footage was obtained clandestinely. The last shot in the movie is one of a woman concealing a movie camera in her laundry basket.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I wanted first of all to thank St. Peter for wishing to keep alive his latest successor. I thought there might have been one more tomb.'' - Pope John Paul II. (3:1.)

title: Singer Flight Unit
description: The Singer Company of Stamford, Conn., said it would expand its simulation business into the flight-training market through a new subsidiary, Sinuflite Training Inc., which will entail about $35 million of direct investment over the next three years.

title: NIGERIA, RICH WITH OIL, IS DEPENDENT ON U.S. AND OTHER NATIONS FOR FOOD
description: There was drought in Nigeria in the early 1970's and it decimated the peanut crop. Then the rains came, but the crop did not grow properly because of disease.

title: DAILY NEWS SAYS IT WILL END ITS TONIGHT EDITION ON AUG. 28
description: The Daily News announced yesterday that it would close its costly and unsuccessful Tonight afternoon edition on Aug. 28, and it told union leaders that costs would have to be brought under control.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on l[TEXT OMITTED]

title: REAGAN ADVISER TO SEEK TAX AID FOR ARTS DONORS
description: One of President Reagan's key advisers on the arts said today that he planned to seek changes in the tax law to encourage middle-income and higher-income individuals to make taxdeductible contributions to the arts and humanities.

title: WILCOX, TIGERS STOP YANKS, 1-0
description: Rudy May lost his fifth game in a row tonight as Milt Wilcox and the Tigers shut out the Yankees, 1-0. May, who has not won in 10 starts, pitched a respectable seven innings, allowing six hits, but was not helped by New York's offense, which has scored only 10 runs in five games.

title: NEW ISSUES ARISE ON AIRWAY SAFETY
description: New questions over the safety of the nation's airways were raised yesterday as Federal investigators said they were looking into 17 false radio transmissions to pilots and striking air traffic controllers gave accounts of what they called scores of near-collisions in the sky.

title: Around the Nation; Convictions Upheld In Eagleton Extortion
description: A Federal appeals court today affirmed the convictions of a niece of Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, and her attorney on charges of attempting to extort more than $200,000 from the Senator.

title: Boards Approve Reliance Bid
description: A bid by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York financier, to acquire and take private the Reliance Group Inc. and the Leasco Corporation won the unanimous approval of both boards yesterday after Mr. Steinberg and members of his family raised their offer for Reliance common stock by $3 a share.

title: Second Planeload of Haitians Arrives at Fort in Puerto Rico
description: A second planeload of Haitians arrived in Puerto Rico from a crowded Florida refugee camp today, and a spokesman for the Haitians said that they would demand lawyers to fight deportation. The first group of Haitians arrived in Puerto Rico Wednesday.

title: LABOR JUDGE ACTS TO REVOKE POWERS OF CONTROL UNION
description: A Federal administrative law judge recommended today that the air traffic controllers' union be stripped of its right to bargain on behalf of the controllers. He said the union's 12-day-old strike was an ''open and flagrant'' violation of Federal law.

title: CLEAN AIR ACT NEEDS AN EFFICIENT DECISION
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Liberia Executes Four Charged in Plot on Doe
description: Maj. Gen. Thomas Weh Syen, ousted last weekend as deputy head of government, and four former members of Liberia's ruling People's Redemption Council, were executed at dawn today for plotting to kill the head of government, Samuel K. Doe, the state radio reported.

title: News Analysis
description: With much pride, the Koch administration released figures this week showing that more than half of the workers hired by New York City in each of the last three years were black, Hispanic or Asian-American, raising the proportion of those groups in the municipal work force to 36 percent.

title: French Auto Aid Urged
description: The French Federation of Free Labor Unions today called for a parliamentary debate and a ''rescue plan'' for the French auto industry.

title: SURGING REGIONAL AIRLINES
description: Regional airlines have been surging this year, logging higher operating profit margins than established trunk airlines and increasing their market share while that of the trunks has declined.

title: POLISH AND SOVIET CHIEFS HOLD 'FRIENDLY' MEETING
description: Poland's Communist Party leader, Stanislaw Kania, paid a flying visit to the Crimea today for what the official press agency Tass described as a ''friendly working visit'' with the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: LOS ANGELES (NL) - Placed Rick S utcliffe, right-handed pitcher, on 21-day d isabled list. Recalled Tom Niedenfauer, p itcher, from San Antonio of Texas L eague.

title: DANBURY INSTALLING METERS AS WATER SUPPLY DWINDLES
description: A resumption of near normal rainfall aided by conservation has eased the water shortages in New York, northern New Jersey and most of southwestern Connecticut, but this city is running out of water at an alarming rate.

title: Bette Davis to Play Title Role in TV Film
description: Bette Davis has been signed to play the title role in a made-fortelevision movie, ''A Piano for Mrs. Cimino,'' based on a novel by Robert Oliphant.

title: Ruling on Alligators Eased
description: The Fish and Wildlife Service announced yesterday that it was removing the alligator from the list of threatened species in Louisiana. The action will allow Louisiana officials to permit regulated hunting of alligators throughout the state, where it has been permitted only in certain areas since 1975.

title: ROCK: KRIS KRISTOFFERSON
description: Even though Kris Kristofferson made his name as a singersongwriter, today he is probably better known as a movie star. And judging from his performance on Thursday at the Savoy, where he appeared with a seven-piece rock band, Mr. Kristofferson would be better off devoting his full energies to acting instead of continuing to make music. Mr. Kristofferson never had much of a voice, but 10 years ago his droning baritone could put over powerful first-person narrative songs like ''Me and Bobby McGee,'' and ''Help Me Make It Through the Night,'' in stark acoustic renditions that allowed him to be casually anecdotal.

title: New York Phone Gains
description: The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter rose 11.8 percent, to $150.6 million from $134.7 million. Revenues increased 12.2 percent, to $1.47 billion from $1.31 billion. The company is a wholly owned subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Smithfield Near Gwaltney Link
description: Smithfield Foods Inc. is negotiating to buy the Gwaltney Company, a meatpacking and processing concern owned by the ITT Continental Baking Company, an International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation official said.

title: Correction
description: A report on the Style Page yesterday about a reception in honor of a Peking opera troupe featuring Zhou Shaolin was accompanied by an incorrect photograph. It showed Tong Zhiling, another star of the troupe.

title: Notes on People; Pressures and Problems of a Former Hostage
description: From the moment they were released after 444 days in captivity in Iran, said Donald Hohman, he and his fellow hostages were under persistent pressure to ''act like a hero.'' In his case, he said, that created problems that still remain with him.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday gave an incorrect description of plans for the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital in Manhattan. Long-term nursing care for the aged will be added to its present facilities for the developmentally disabled.

title: New York; AMEX SAVES OUR CASTES
description: At a time of profound social confusion, with the values of family and church and respect for authority all going to pieces before our eyes, American Express has come to our rescue once again. The creditcard company, often unfairly accused of being an impersonal giant, has redefined the middle-class. And just in time.

title: BRAZIL'S CATHOLICS JOIN CRUSADE FOR FAMILY PLANNING
description: For generations, Brazil has resisted the worldwide drive for family planning. But now the urgency has become so compelling in the world's largest Roman Catholic country that even the church has found a way to join in.

title: Notes on People; A New Cable-TV Network With a Difference
description: ''Most people think we're a little touched in the head,'' said Mother Angelica. ''They say: 'You've got to be joking. A network run by 13 nuns?' ''

title: Bullied Books
description: Survivors of childhood's rainy afternoons will recall the hours passed looking up racy words in the dictionary. The same parents who'd hidden ''Tropic of Cancer'' from innocent eyes never seemed to have grasped the wanton possibilities of a walk through Webster.

title: Lord Avie's Summer Derby
description: Danny Perlsweig could be forgiven if he shows up at the Travers Stakes tomorrow with a mint julep in his hand and ''My Old Kentucky Home'' ringing in his ears.

title: SAUDI ARMS SALE TO GO TO CONGRESS ON AUG. 24
description: A White House official said today that President Reagan would give Congress written notice on Aug. 24 of his intention to sell Saudi Arabia a $5 billion package of advanced military aircraft and aircraft equipment.

title: Following are excerpts from a letter written on Jan. 5 and 7, 1981, by the Rev. Stanley Rother, a 46-year-old Roman Catholic priest who was shot to death on July 28 in the rectory of his mission in Santiago Atitlan, Guatemala. According to the Rev. David Monaghan, a spokesman for the Oklahoma City diocese, which sponsors the mission, Father Rother ''learned in mid-January that he was targeted for death and left Guatemala for about three months.'' He returned on April 11. This letter, written to a friend of Father Rother in Oklahoma City, was made available by William L. Wipfler, the director of the human rights office of the National Council of the Churches of Christ.
description: Things have been pretty quiet the past couple of weeks until just last Saturday night. Probably the most sought-after catechist has been staying here in the rectory off and on, and almost constantly of late. He had been eating and sleeping here, and usually visiting his wife and two kids in late afternoon. He had a key to the house, and as he was approaching Saturday night about 7:45, he was intercepted by a group of four kidnappers. Three apparently tried to grab him at the far side of the church. He got to within 15 feet of the door and was holding on to the bannister and yelling for help. The other priest heard the ruckus outside and stepped out to see them trying to take him. He considered trying to help, but was scared by their height. He called me from the living room where I was listening to music but also heard the noise, and by the time I realized what was happening, grabbed a jacket and got outside, they had taken him down the front steps of the church and were putting him in a waiting car. In the process they had broken the bannister where the rectory porch joins the church, and I just stood there wanting to jump down to help, but knowing that I would be killed or taken along also. The car sped off with him yelling for help but no one was able to do so.

title: Around the World; Salvador Denies Report That Rebels Took Town
description: A Salvadoran military spokesman confirmed today that guerrillas had attacked the town of Perquin, in the northeastern province of Morazan, but denied a claim by a rebel radio station that the town had been overrun.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption Aug. 8 referred incorrectly to Spaniards waiting to enter the British enclave of Gibraltar. The border between Spain and the British zone was closed in 1969.

title: READING TEST GIVES PUPILS LAST CHANCE
description: They clutched their pencils. Some prayed. And when it was done, at least one boy put his head down on his desk and cried. A reading test was given yesterday to thousands of children throughout the city, with much more at stake than good marks on a report card. The consequences were immediate, and few did not understand what they were.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15.

title: Your Money; How to Choose An Accountant
description: AT a university career day with a panel of professionals fielding questions from students, one student raised his hand and asked one of the panelists, ''How much money do you make?'' Embarrassed to disclose her salary, the panelist answered, ''Enough to hire an accountant.''

title: Bridge: Husband and Wife Team Plays 'Can You Top This?'
description: Voyaging around the world in one of the few surviving great passenger liners can be a confusing experience. It is hard to remember in which direction you are headed, and even harder to remember the day of the week, especially near the international date line.

title: Observer; GARDENS BY KARL
description: Yuri invited me to a garden party. ''We are celebrating the 20th birthday of our Berlin Wall,'' he said. ''Come join the merrymaking.''

title: MARINERS' BURROUGHS CLOUTS 3 HOMERS
description: Jeff Burroughs hit three homers and drove in six runs as the Seattle Mariners defeated the Minnesota Twins, 13-3, tonight in the second game of a doubleheader.

title: FUQUA PLANS TALKS ON TAKEOVER BIDS
description: Fuqua Industries, a diversified Atlanta based company with interests ranging from lawn mowers to movie theaters, will hold a special directors' meeting on Monday in an attempt to iron out a dispute over competing takeover bids that has resulted in the suspension of its president and three other top officers.

title: Patents; Display Collates Flight Data
description: WASHINGTON A DISPLAY device for use in an airplane cockpit is designed to instantly give the pilot information that formerly was available only from several instruments. A miniature aircraft on the screen discloses any flight errors, based on data from computers and other commercial devices that provide flight parameters and navigation signals.

title: Consumer Saturday; WHERE TO MAKE COMPLAINTS
description: ''W HEN you can't get anyone to fix your new washing machine, where do you make a complaint?'' said Roger Goldblatt, director of the Federal Complaint Coordinating Center, part of the Office of Consumer Affairs. ''Most people don't know how to complain effectively,'' he said.

title: FALTERING BOLIVIA FACES FUNDS CRISIS
description: The Bolivian Government is apparently suffering a severe shortage of cash, having issued $10 million in checks in the past four weeks that foreign banks have refused to honor, according to private bankers and Government officials.

title: Lehman Pact With China
description: Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., the investment firm, signed agreements yesterday to provide financial advice to the Bank of China and the China International Trust and Investment Corporation, a spokesman for Lehman Brothers said.

title: Going Out Guide
description: PULLING STRINGS

title: Index; International
description: South Korea announces release of more than 1,000 prisoners 2 Brazilian Catholics work harder for birth control 2 Pope, declared ''clinically recov- ered,'' leaves hospital 3 Nigeria is paying the price of sud- den oil wealth 3 Taiwan worries over U.S. moves to strengthen ties with Peking 3 Tiny black state strains South African theory 4 Around the World 4 Government/Politics Michigan clears way for tax to bail out Detroit 8 City agrees to detail its Gateway plan for housing derelicts 27 General Around the Nation 6 Manufacturing exodus hurts older cities like Philadelphia 6 Coca-Cola officials revise cost of agreement 6 A view from the flight controller's tower in Los Angeles 7 Health/Science Nine hospital deaths on Coast laid to drug overdoses 8 Study suggests excessive implan- tations of heart pacemakers 8 Industry/Labor Activist defeated in bid to head oil and chemical workers' union 24 Text of statement by Daily News publisher on ending of edition 26 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the Roman Catholic Feast of the Assumption, alternate- side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other parking rules are in effect. Arts/Entertainment Limbs dance company performs at Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors 9 Reagan adviser to seek tax relief for arts donors 9 Cape and Islands Chamber Music Festival at Wellfleet 9 Music of the 1920's, 30's and 40's at Once Upon a Stove 10 Kris Kristofferson and band rock at the Savoy 10 ''Deadly Blessing,'' horror film, opens at Cinerama 11 Film ''El Salvador: The People Will Win'' presented 11 McCullough's ''People, Books & Book People'' is reviewed 12 NBC puts off start of Mickey Roo- ney show 48 Style Consumer Saturday 16 The long and short of it for fall styles 16 De Gustibus: Choosing a basic cookbook library 16 Obituaries Everly Driscoll, science journal- ist 47 Joseph Curran, founder of the National Maritime Union 47 Dr. Luther Burns MacKenzie, N.Y.U. professor emeritus 47 Sports Tigers and Wilcox stop Yankees on 3 hits, 1-0 17 Mets lose to Phillies; Youngblood injures knee again 17 Prospect of losing intentionally to make baseball playoffs raised 17 Plan to review Title IX no sur- prise to women officials 17 After mistrial, Davis of Raiders calls one juror a ''plant'' 17 Ira Berkow on rugby and the Mayor's decision 19 Burroughs hit 3 homers in game for Mariners 19 Features/Notes Saturday News Quiz 12 Notes on People 15 Going Out Guide 15 Man in the News: Robin H.H. Wil- son, new president of L.I.R.R. 27 About New York 27 Religion Church deacon gets 20 years in in- voluntary servitude case 8 News Analysis Michael Goodwin discusses city's minority-hiring practices 26 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: MICHIGAN BOARD CLEARS WAY FOR TAX RISE TO HELP DETROIT
description: With a litle help from a Republican friend in the state capital, Detroit's Mayor Coleman A. Young, a Democrat, has yanked his city back from a perilous financial ledge.

title: Bomb Explodes Near Springboks Game Site
description: A bomb blast awoke residents but caused no damage or injuries early today near the park where the South African Springboks are to play a rugby match against a New Zealand club tomorrow, officials said.

title: NBC REVAMPS FALL SCHEDULE, DELAYS MICKEY ROONEY SHOW
description: TV announced a revamping of its fall program schedule yesterday, putting off two shows that were scheduled, adding one and shifting others.

title: CITY'S PROSTITUTES INVADE RESIDENTIAL COMMUNITIES
description: Prostitution in New York City has reached beyond such areas as Times Square into residential neighborhoods of working families with children, professional couples and older retired couples.

title: NATIONALISTS FEAR THEY ARE LOSING AS U.S. AND PEKING IMPROVE TIES
description: Despite an official facade of confidence, the Nationalist Government is worried by a growing realization that the Reagan Administration's moves to solidify its ties with Peking are not being matched by compensating signs of friendship for America's former Chinese ally.

title: Around the World; Jewish Activist Loses An Appeal in Soviet
description: Viktor Brailovsky, a prominent member of the Soviet Jewish emigration movement, lost an appeal today of a fiveyear term of internal exile for defaming the state, his wife reported.

title: CHICAGO FED'S NEW LEADER
description: The advocates of tight money have a staunch new ally on the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee in Silas Keehn, the recently appointed president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

title: F.T.C. Studies Allied-Fisher Link
description: The Allied Corporation and the Fisher Scientific Company said the Federal Trade Commission had asked them for more information concerning Allied's planned $330 million acquisition of Fisher.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, AUGUST 15, 1981; The Economy
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods edged up four-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported. Such a moderate increase, coming despite a jump in the price of food, surprised many economists. One saw it as an indication that inflation would remain in single digits for the foreseeable future. (Page 1.)

title: CABARET: SOME NOSTALGIA
description: All through the 1970's, camp, parody and nostalgia for the music of the 1920's, 30's and 40's was a staple of cabaret performers. Usually the music was doled out a little bit at a time, but Ira Guttman, the manager of Once Upon a Stove, a restaurant at 325 Third Avenue, has put together a three-act survey that covers all three decades in one evening.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY UP $5.1 BILLION
description: A key measure of the nation's money supply rose $5.1 billion in the week ended Aug. 5, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. Fed officials cautioned, however, that some of the unusually large increase was related to bank loans extended during the Conoco merger battle waged by Du Pont, Mobil and Seagram.

title: PACEMAKER USE CALLED EXCESSIVE
description: Pacemakers, designed to control the human heartbeat in patients with cardiac problems, are being implanted in some people who do not really need them, a new study suggests.

title: DAVIS LABELS ONE HOLDOUT JUROR A 'PLANT'
description: Al Davis, the chief executive of the Oakland Raiders, vowed today to continue his effort to move the team to Los Angeles, and he accused the National Football League of having placed a ''plant'' in the jury so as to obtain the mistrial that was declared late last night in the Raiders' antitrust suit against the league.

title: INDIA PROHIBITS STRIKES IN ASSAM
description: The Government imposed a six-month ban on strikes in some essential services today in the oil-producing state of Assam, an official communique said.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, AUGUST 15, 1981
description: Controllers' Strike Stripping the controllers' union of its bargaining rights was recommended by a Federal administrative judge on the ground that the controllers' strike was an ''open and flagrant'' violation of Federal law. John H. Fenton, chief administrative law judge of the Federal Labor Relations Authority, which oversees the Government's labormanagement relations, urged the agency to revoke the union's ''exclusive recognition status.'' If the recommendation is accepted by the three-member board, the union's right to represent the controllers would immediately be taken away. (Page 1, Column 1.) Flight attendant unions rallied to support the striking controllers, although many of the union members individually expressed little sympathy for the controllers' strike. As notices of impending layoffs of pilots, attendants and ground crews were being issued by some airlines, representatives of six flight attendants' unions conferred urgently, concerned that if the controllers' union is broken their own unions might be imperiled. (7:4-5.)

title: Miss Caulkins Wins 33d Title
description: Tracy Caulkins achieved her 33d national swimming title tonight, taking the women's 400-meter individual medley in 4 minutes, 43.66 seconds at the United States long-course championships.

title: Canada Price Index Up
description: Canada's consumer price index rose ninetenths of 1 percent in July, down from a 1.5 percent jump in June, Statistics Canada said today. The increase left prices up 13 percent over the past 12 months, the largest gain in 30 years.

title: ACTIVIST LOSES BID TO LEAD CHEMICAL WORKERS
description: Anthony Mazzocchi, an activist who gained widespread notice in the labor movement for imagination and assertiveness, was defeated yesterday in a bid for the presidency of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union by the incumbent, Robert F. Goss.

title: 11-STORY PLUNGE IN ELEVATOR SHAFT FATAL TO WOMAN
description: A 29-year-old Brooklyn woman fell 11 stories to her death down an elevator shaft in a Manhattan building yesterday after she jumped from an overcrowded car that was stuck between floors, the police said.

title: JOSEPH CURRAN, 75, FOUNDER OF NATIONAL MARITIME UNION
description: Joseph Curran, a former deck boy who founded the National Maritime Union of America and served as its president for 36 years, died of cancer yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: YOUNGBLOOD HURT
description: The Mets' midsummer night's dream of being a pennant contender in August received a jolt last night when they lost their leading hitter and a pitcher as well as a share of first place.

title: THE DEFECTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: REVIEW OF TITLE IX IS NO SURPRISE
description: When the Reagan Administration announced that it would review Federal guidelines that are intended to protect women from discrimination in collegiate athletics, reaction from women varied. There were words of shock and indignation and the almost blase statement of Margo Polivy. ''It must have been a dull day with Congress out of session and nobody had anything else to do,'' Miss Polivy said.

title: N.F.L. PLAYERS STARTING REVIEW OF ISSUES FOR '82
description: Individual team meetings have begun in the National Football League to discuss proposals that might be made to the league owners next year when negotiations begin for the new collective bargaining agreement.

title: East Germans Honor Brecht on Anniversary
description: East German cultural and political figures laid wreaths at the grave of the writer, dramatist and poet Bertolt Brecht today to mark the 25th anniversary of his death.

title: TAKING ON THE L.I.R.R.
description: When you take on a job like the presidency of the Long Island Rail Road, Robin H. H. Wilson said yesterday, it is hard to know just where to begin making improvements.

title: THE LONG AND SHORT OF IT FOR FALL STYLES
description: The main direction of clothes coming into the stores in the next few months is longer and looser, with plenty of festive styles offered for evening. Most designers are acting as if the millenium has indeed arrived and are showing very short styles in addition to the predominant long ones. There are even some knee lengths. The theory is that women today are sophisticated enough to cope with the variations and to pick the length that suits them.

title: Wife of Striker Gets Job as Air Controller
description: The wife of a striking air traffic controller has finally found a job after a 10-month search.

title: New Giant Starters Face Colts Tonight
description: With several regular-season positions undecided little more than two weeks before their roster must be down to the 45-player limit, the Giants oppose the Baltimore Colts in an exhibition tomorrow night at Giants Stadium with four new starters. Tom Mullady will be at tight end, Bo Matthews at fullback, Frank Marion at inside linebacker and Larry Flowers at strong safety.

title: Bolivia Frees a Jailed Priest; 27 Prisoners Facing Release
description: Bolivia last night released the Rev. Leonidas Sanchez, the first of 28 political prisoners the junta promised yesterday to free.

title: Block Those Block Grants
description: New York's Governor Hugh Carey, during a basketball game with other governors, joshed that his style of play resembles a block grant. ''You don't know what I am until I hit you.'' The joke generates bitter laughter from state and local officials, who feel betrayed by Washington's recent performance on aid to states and cities.

title: LUTHER MACKENZIE, N.Y.U. FUND-RAISER, DOCTOR AND TEACHER
description: Dr. Luther Burns MacKenzie, professor emeritus of clinical medicine at the New York University College of Medicine and a leading fundraiser for the college, died Thursday at Victoria General Hospital in Halifax, Nova Scotia. He was 101 years old and lived in nearby Bedford.

title: FARM CHILDREN'S AID TO CONSUMERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLIED NOW SEEKS ALL OF GARFINCKEL
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the nation's largest department store operators, said yesterday that a subsidiary had made a cash tender offer of $48 a share for the common stock of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., for a total of about $210 million.

title: Around the Nation; May Day Plaintiffs Given $2.5 Million in Damages
description: Checks ranging from $925 to $3,245 have been mailed to about 1,000 demonstrators who were arrested on the Capitol steps in the 1971 May Day antiwar protests, representing damages won in their lawsuit against the Government.

title: Sports of the Times; MAYOR'S RUGBY DECISION
description: RUGBY is a dirty game. That is all most Americans know about the sport, since it is played by relatively few in this country. Whenever we see pictures of rugby players, they are invariably splattered with mud.

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANT LEADERS CONFER ON STRIKE'S EFFECT ON THEIR UNIONS
description: Representatives of six flight attendants' unions, concerned about layoffs affecting many of their members and fearful of their future if the air traffic controllers' union is broken, conferred urgently today on ways of supporting the controllers.

title: TEHERAN EXILES SEIZE GUNBOAT BOUND FOR IRAN
description: A patrol boat sold to Iran by France was hijacked off the coast of Spain yesterday as an Iranian crew was sailing it to its new home port. An Iranian monarchist group based here took responsibility.

title: POLICE OFFICER CHARGED WITH DRUG DISTRIBUTION
description: A 38-year-old New York City police officer was arrested yesterday and charged with distributing cocaine. Three other persons, including a 23-year-old postal worker, were also arrested as a result of an undercover investigation carried out by the New York Drug Enforcement Task Force, which comprises Federal agents and city police officers.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times The Creators of Books By HERBERT MITGANG PEOPLE, BOOKS & BOOK PEOPLE. By David W. McCullough. 182 pages. Har- mony. Cloth $12.95; paper $5.95.

title: Losers Could Be Winners
description: Major league baseball was confronted today with what appeared to be a strong possibility that some teams would intentionally lose late-season games to keep their playoff chances alive.

title: EX- CONTROLLER RELISHING RETURN TO RADAR SCREEN
description: The room was dark, except for the soft green glow of radar screens. And it was quiet, except for a few voices, almost whispers, issuing commands to airliners traveling through some of the most heavily traveled skies in the world.

title: DANCE: LIMBS COMPANY OFFERS INNOVATIVE BLEND
description: The Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival presented its first dance program of the season on Thursday at Damrosch Park, and it was a winner. Limbs, a four-year-old dance troupe from Auckland, New Zealand, more than lived up to its advance billing as an ''innovative and sparkling'' young dance company. Its blend of classical ballet, jazz, acrobatics, modern dance and improvisational techniques is that true - and rare - fusion of styles that achieves something beyond its parts: streamlined movement with the energy of jazz dance, the elegance of ballet and the thematic focus of modern dance. Add to that wit, a refreshing simplicity of approach and a very stylish sense of slapstick, and you have Limbs.

title: Agency Says Air Force Illegally Hid Imbalance
description: The Air Force spent as much as $210 million above its budget in the past 10 years and violated the law by not reporting the deficiency, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: CHAMBER: MUSIC BY THE SEA BY THE SEA
description: There is a saying among coastal dwellers that ambition dwindles as one comes nearer the sea. The same might be said for the power of art. Music recreated in an urban, man-made setting can achieve impressive proportions. Place it next to the larger elements of nature, however, and it is easily overwhelmed.

title: 'DEADLY BLESSING'
description: ''In the rolling hills of a simple farming community, untouched by time, a gruesome secret has been protected for generations.'' So begins ''Deadly Blessing,'' which was shot in such a flat part of Texas that there isn't a rolling hill in sight, but never mind. ''Deadly Blessing'' is a better-than-average horror film, in large part because it isn't about terrified coeds being stalked by an axwielding loon. Its story is more original than that -although where horror-movie ingenuity is concerned, it's only a thin line that separates the original from the bizarre.

title: About New York; CALIFORNIANS MAKE A PILGRIMAGE IN WALTZ TIME
description: It is a summer afternoon as bright as new sterling silver, and the world is whizzing by on West 52d Street. But inside Roseland Dance City, it is cool and dim. No one perspires, and the pink lights make soft all the hard edges of jaw and hairline, the hard shades of red in chiffon and lipstick and nail polish. The atmosphere is indigo, like the hour just before sunset, like a dream sequence in a movie musical.

title: A NEW OPPORTUNITY ON THE WATERFRONT
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES PLANS LAYOFFS OF 1,650 AS A RESULT OF THE STRIKE
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it was planning to lay off 1,650 of its 36,000 employees, including 200 pilots, because of reductions in its flight operations since the air traffic controllers struck 12 days ago.

title: The Purpose of Pain
description: Heroin is moving out of the slums and into the suburbs, and one expert thinks the spreading popularity of the drug is explained by a culturally reinforced need to avoid pain.

title: Lapham Resigns From Harper's
description: Lewis H. Lapham resigned yesterday as editor of Harper's Magazine, a position he has held since 1975. ''I said I'll stick around for a couple of months or until we can find a successor,'' he said, ''but I've been doing it long enough and now I want to devote my time to writing.''

title: De Gustibus; CHOOSING A BASIC COOKBOOK LIBRARY
description: That too much can be as frustrating a condition as too little can easily be proved by looking at the endless rows of cookbooks in bookstores. With such a bewildering and ever-increasing choice, selectivity becomes a problem, especially for anyone trying to build a useful but limited cookbook library from scratch. Which books are worth buying and what does a minimally complete collection consist of? That, in essence, is a question often asked by readers, especially neophytes in the kitchen.

title: Quanex to Build Two Steel Plants
description: The Quanex Corporation of Houston, a manufacturer of specialty steel tubing, said it would build an $85 million specialty steel plant in Fort Smith, Ark., to produce seam-free bars at a rate of 280,000 tons a year.

title: COCA-COLA REVISES COST OF BLACK PACT
description: A plan by the Coca-Cola Company and Operation PUSH to increase slightly the dollar volume of trade the company does with black-owned businesses has stirred confusion, praise and resentment, its developers said today.

title: SCHLITZ BOARD APPROVES HEILEMAN TAKEOVER BID
description: The board of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company yesterday approved a definitive $494 million merger agreement with the G. Heileman Brewing Company, rejecting a $588 million offer from the Pabst Brewing Company.

title: STATEMENT BY NEWS ON COST-CUTTING ACTIONS
description: Following is the text of a statement by Robert M. Hunt, president and publisher of The Daily News, on the closing of the newspaper's Tonight edition and other cutbacks announced yesterday:

title: HAIG TO PRESS REAGAN TO ABANDON WEINBERGER'S AIRBORNE MX PLAN
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. plans to see President Reagan Sunday to argue against Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's plan for mounting the new MX missiles on aircraft, Administration officials said today.

title: THE ETHYL CORPORATION IS DIVERSIFYING TO ALTER ITS ONE-PRODUCT IMAGE
description: The name of the Ethyl Corporation has long been synonymous with lead-based antiknock additives in gasoline. This identification has sometimes plagued the company as the additives, a major source of company earnings, have been phased down under Government regulatory orders.

title: Mortgage Rates Raised
description: The Housing and Urban Development Department and the Veterans Administration today raised permissible interest rates by 1 percentage point across the board on all mortgages they insure. Effective Monday, the maximum permissible rates will range from 16.5 percent for conventional, level-payment mortgages for single-family homes to 20 percent for multifamily construction loans and land development loans.

title: Jersey Inmates Transferred
description: Three of the 38 Trenton State Prison inmates who tore the plumbing out of their cells last week were transferred today to the Federal penitentiary in Lewisburg, Pa., the State Corrections Department said. Three other inmates were sent to Lewisburg on Aug. 5, the day after the damage occurred. The damaged cells have been repaired and are occupied.

title: EVERLY DRISCOLL, 40, WAS SCIENCE WRITER FOR FEDERAL AGENCY
description: Everly Driscoll, an American science journalist, died yesterday of a gunshot wound after a car in which she was riding was attacked by thieves in Nairobi, Kenya. She was 40 years old.

title: DEACON CONVICTED IN SLAVERY CASE
description: SALEM, N.C., Aug. 14 (AP) - A man described as a church deacon was found guilty today of holding eight teen-agers in involuntary servitude and was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. The reporter who wrote the expose had purchased the woman for 2,300 rupees, which are worth $306, after posing as a doctor looking for a wife for his farm foreman.

title: DOW DROPS 7.42 POINTS, TO 936.93
description: The stock market declined moderately yesterday with some of the technology and energy-related issues registering the biggest losses. The Dow Jones industrial average, which increased its losses as the session progressed, closed down 7.42 points, to 936.93. For the week the key barometer lost 5.61 points.

title: Couple Win Gold Medals
description: Craig Holm and Kare Cossaboon-Holm, a husband-and-wife running team, each won a gold medal today in distance races at the Empire State Games.

title: Muir Florida Units To Be Acquired
description: The four remaining John Muir & Company branch offices in Florida will be acquired by Ross Stebbins Inc., a small Wall Street retail brokerage house, and by Lawrence Monberg Jr., a salesman in Muir's Fort Lauderdale office.

title: THE SIRIUS READER
description: June 8, 1981 Dear John and Maryanne: I have been very impressed over the past four or five weeks how smart your new dog, Prince, is. ''How does Ed know our dog is so smart?'' you are asking yourselves.

title: HOSPITALS COPING WITH THE NURSE SHORTAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyco Sees End To Heinicke Suit
description: Tyco Laboratories Inc. announced an agreement that it said would settle a Federal court suit brought against it by the Heinicke Instruments Company over Tyco's $13-a-share tender offer for Heinicke.

title: EX- TENNESSEE GOVERNOR SENTENCED TO 3 YEARS
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton was sentenced today to three years in prison and was fined $11,000 for extortion and conspiracy in selling liquor licenses while he was in office.

title: POLISH PRELATES AND UNION ASK FOR MODERATION
description: With appeals for moderation from the leader of the Solidarity labor union and the Roman Catholic Church, Poland today marked the anniversary of the Gdansk shipyard strike that gave birth to the independent union.

title: WARDEN AND AIDE AT RIKERS ARE DEMOTED AFTER ESCAPES
description: The warden and an assistant warden of the Anna M. Kross Detention Center on Rikers Island were demoted yesterday as the result of an escape by an inmate on Wednesday, the second escape there in two days.

title: Patents; New System Detonates Bombs at Both Ends
description: The Navy received a patent this week for a detonation system that causes simultaneous explosions of warheads at both ends. Patent 4,282,814, which was obtained by Fredric L. Menz and Gordon A. Greene, scientists at the Naval Weapons center in China Lake, Calif., explains that it is important to achieve directional detonation to get the maximum destructive effect.

title: Training and Technology
description: While virtually all of the statements about science and technology in William Stockton's article ''The Technology Race'' (June 28) are true, the emphasis on innovation as opposed to effective performance in technology-based industries obscures a very important point. Much of the current industrial weakness of the United States as compared, for example, to the strength of Japan, has very little to do with the level of support for research.

title: CANADIANS COUNT MAIL STRIKE'S COST
description: Twenty-four million Canadians will be reconnected by mail with the rest of the world starting Monday, when the aftereffects of the country's six-week postal strike are supposed to end.

title: Joan Henn to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Henn of Paoli, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Elizabeth Henn, to Christopher James Basile, son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Basile of Lincoln, Mass. A Nov. 28 wedding is planned.

title: Food; FISH COOKERY DEMYSTIFIED
description: It has always struck us as odd that so many Americans seem intimidated by the cooking of fish, for, to us at least, it is - at its most basic - one of the easiest of all forms of cookery.

title: Suzanne Dunn Is Married
description: The marriage of Suzanne Dunn and Peter Mendes Oppenheimer, graduates of Brown University, took place at the Harrison Inn in Southbury, Conn., yesterday. Justice of the Peace Barbara Amatruda performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. Edward Dunn of Woodbridge, Conn., and Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Oppenheimer of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: IN INDIA, SIKHS RAISE A CRY FOR INDEPENDENT NATION
description: A 49-year-old former teacher sits cross-legged in the room he dares not leave for fear of arrest and explains passionately if seditiously how he advocates the creation of a Sikh nation to be wrenched violently from India.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Rights Provisions Under Pressure
description: The wall of protections against discrimination erected by the Civil Rights Act of 1964 has increasingly come under attack by deregulatory pressure. Contending they are superfluous, the Department of Education recently asked Attorney General William French Smith to revoke Title IX rules under the act, which ban sex discrimination in hiring by schools and colleges receiving Federal aid.

title: POP: TERRY BURRELL SINGS AT SWEETWATERS
description: When Terry Burrell opened on Broadway in ''Eubie'' in September 1978, she had only a single song to sing, ''Weary.'' But she made such a vivid impression with that one song that she was given three more.

title: Sunday Observer; WHERE HAVE ALL THE ULCERS GONE?
description: The papers say the American stomach ulcer is becoming an endangered species. The incidence of ulcers, both peptic and duodenal, has declined so notably in recent years that doctors can no longer assemble enough patients to obtain significant data about causes and treatment.

title: The World in Summary; More Working, Less Marching Urged in Poland
description: Lech Walesa ordered his union followers off the bricks and back to work last week, trying to reassert control and redirect Poland's agenda for change. At a meeting in Gdansk, Solidarity's national commission called for a two-month moratorium on strikes and demonstrations until after the union's national congress ends in October. Among the marches Solidarity wanted canceled were some planned this week on behalf of ''political prisoners'' that the Government had threatened to block by all means.

title: ALTERNATIVE SCHOOL TRIES TO FUND ITSELF
description: WINSTED WHEN Peter B. Keefe, a local surveyor, saw Howard B. Bennett, the schools superintendent here, in a downtown coffeeshop last month, he offered his sympathy. Mr. Keefe knew, as did almost everyone else in this city of 8,900, that Dr. Bennett's pet project, the three-yearold Winchester Alternate High School, might not reopen in September because most of its funds had been cut from the school budget.

title: David Conway to Wed Ellen S. Mobley Oct. 11
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Linen 3d of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Scranton Mobley, to David Conway of Wilton, Conn.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: Aware that the state does not have the funds for wildlife preservation and a variety of restoration work, the Connecticut Audubon Society has organized a team of prominent residents to work with governmental officials specifically on non-game species.

title: Theater in Review; 'VANITIES' AT CENTER STAGE
description: PARAMUS Center Stage deserves a solid round of applause. Its production of Jack Heifner's ''Vanities'' is a sharp and perceptive evening of theater that heightens the script's searching inquiry into certain aspects of human illusion.

title: TIGERS DEFEAT YANKEES BY 8-5
description: The Yankees, maneuvering their pitchers like chess pieces, got caught in an unruly hitters' contest tonight and lost to the Tigers, 8-5.

title: Headliners; It Was Only a Suggestion
description: It's bad all over, of course, but for Gretchen Palmer, the housing market has been downright dangerous.

title: NEW LURES IN RESALE MARKET
description: ONE of the attractions for home buyers looking at a new-home development is browsing through model houses without feeling pressured or obligated in any way. Another attraction is that builders arrange the financing, often at interest rates that are 1 to 3 points below market rates, allowing more buyers to qualify for a house.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: BYRNE POLICY ON TRANSIT IS A DISASTER
description: TWO recent articles in The New York Times convinced me that the Byrne administration has conspired to impose the ultimate solution for New Jersey's transportation problems on our people - make everybody walk!

title: THE PLEASURES OF BEAUPORT, AUTHENTIC AND ECCENTRIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- LISA HAMMEL is a writer who divides her time between New York and Massachusetts' North Shore. By LISA HAMMEL

title: Environews
description: MANASQUAN ONE of the last natural waterfront areas along the New Jersey coast between Sandy Hook and Island Beach State Park is being damaged by off-the-road vehicles and may be commercially developed.

title: SOUTH DAKOTA LOVES CITIBANK, BUT THERE'S NO STAMPEDE
description: It took nearly two years, but Citibank credit cards have finally taken up official residence in Sioux Falls, S.D., a locale unmarred by usury ceilings. With a ribbon-cutting in June and other proper ceremony, the newcomer professed itself pleased with the Coyote State. The state, flush with new jobs, beamed, and looked for more.

title: BUMPER CROPS...
description: WE have a coterie of fair-weather friends who each year, following the summer solstice, emerge from their reclusiveness into a state of high sociability. Like the ancients who bore offerings of food to the gods at harvest time, our friends grow magnanimous when their land and sea edibles begin to yield.

title: NORTH AFRICAN NATIONS SPLIT ON REAGAN POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration's inclination to extend explicit support for friends and to just as clearly oppose those it regards as foes is having a discernible impact on the Arab countries along Africa's northwest and north central Mediterranean coast.

title: NEW CON ED CHIEF DELINEATES THE ISSUES
description: making group'' over a period of years means that there will be no dramatic change as a result of the shift.

title: Bridge; A COURAGEOUS AUSSIE
description: Perhaps the saddest bridge story of the year comes from New Zealand, which has had few opportunities to take part in the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl. In past years, the play-off match to determine the right to represent the South Pacific zone has nearly always been won by Australia. This year, apparently, it was different.

title: 2 Hurt and Property Attacked In Sri Lankan Ethnic Violence
description: Two people were seriously hurt and shops and vehicles were set on fire yesterday in fresh outbreaks of violence between two Sri Lankan ethnic groups, a Government spokesman said today.

title: ALBANY PASSED 81 OF 251 KOCH BILLS THIS YEAR
description: Mayor Koch got 81 of the 251 measures for New York City he sought from the Legislature this year, according to an analysis by the Mayor's legislative office.

title: MAJOR GAINS MADE IN CATARACT SURGERY
description: ''THE eye is a miraculous organ.'' Daniel Eichenbaum, an opthalmologist who lives in Chappaqua, made that statement with excitement in his voice and then went on to explain why he has been working to inform the public about revolutionary methods in eye surgery.

title: 'THOU STAR OF POETS'
description: That we are still curious about Shakespeare is suggested by the popularity of the current exhibition ''Shakespeare: The Globe and the World'' at the Museum of Natural History. Published in conjunction with that exhibition is a volume bearing the same title, by S. Schoenbaum, who has become a brilliant Shakespeare industry in himself with his ''William Shakespeare: Records and Images,'' ''A Compact Documentary Life'' and ''Shakespeare's Lives.''

title: CASINO STATUS PROVES A BURDEN
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE gulls like it fine, and now all of it - those spacious piers and walkways, even a carnival-type midway - belongs to the birds, and to an occasional fisherman.

title: Jerald Ball Weds Miss Henderson
description: Elizabeth Frederick Henderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Frederick Henderson of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jerald DeForest Ball, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Ball 3rd of Big Piney, Wyo. The ceremony was performed by the bride's uncle, the Rev. Stuart H. Henderson of Charlottesville, Va., at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: FUTURE UNCERTAIN FOR ALEUTS DEPENDENT ON U.S. AID
description: Last-minute maneuvering by two key Alaskan members of Congress has, for the moment, given a reprieve to the 689 Aleuts who live on the Pribilof Islands and hunt the Bering Sea fur seal, but their way of life, two centuries old, may soon end, a casualty of the Reagan Administration's budget cuts.

title: CONTROLLERS STRIKE SHOWS LIMITS OF PUBLIC WORKERS
description: When President Reagan denounced the air traffic controllers for conducting an illegal strike, he highlighted one of the many differences between labor relations in the Federal Government and in private industry.

title: DANCE: MARGARET FISHER IN 3 PIECES
description: There's something strange but very potent going on at the American Theater Laboratory this weekend. Up the stairs, through a corridor and on to your seat in the little loft theater, and suddenly you are plunged into a bizarre but magical world: the dance of Margaret Fisher.

title: ROOKIES EXCELLING ON NASCAR CIRCUT
description: It has been an unusual year in stock car racing. Not only are cars smaller, but after a decade in which the same half-dozen drivers took turns being first under the checkered flag, new faces have been appearing in the winner's circle. Only five rookies have ever won Grand National races on the Nascar circuit; two of those victories have come this season.

title: REAGAN AIDES SHOW CAPITAL LUXURY STYLE
description: William French Smith tied on his black tie, stepped into a chauffered sedan and went to a party one night not long ago.

title: COASTAL LAW UPSETS EAST END
description: EAST HAMPTON THE five East End towns are seeking to have the State Department of Environmental Conservation replaced by the Suffolk Regional Planning Board in administering funds for coastal improvement and development under a state law signed by Governor Carey on Aug. 1.

title: Kimball Tops Louganis In U.S. 10-Meter Diving
description: Bruce Kimball of Ann Arbor, Mich., halted Greg Louganis's bid to sweep the titles at the national outdoor diving championships today with a narrow victory in the 10-meter platform event.

title: HEADQUARTERS MOVE FROM CITY TO MIAMI STUDIED FOR PAN AM
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday it was considering moving the headquarters of its airline division with 500 employees from Manhattan to Miami in another effort to cut losses that have been averaging more than $1 million a day.

title: TRAINING AND TECHNOLOGY
description: The sputnik fix seems to be in vogue these days. Would another sputnik spur the long-range technological development necessary to modernize our industry and strengthen our economy? Since I have difficulty saying yes to this question, allow me another scenario.

title: Dining Out; VICTORIAN AIR AT SHORE MANSION
description: OLD SAYBROOK THE potential at The Castle Inn is considerable. Situated at Cornfield Point with a sweeping view of Long Island Sound, this fieldstone mansion, built in 1906, has the dated charm of late Victorian decor both inside and out. Fieldstone dominates, covering, in fact overwhelming, the walls of the medium-sized dining room, whose other attractions are a large fireplace along one wall and period stained-glass windows in the alcove opposite.

title: A Woman's World
description: To the Editor:

title: Lindley Rawlins, Broker, Bride of James Mitchell
description: Lindley Townsend Rawlins, daughter of M. Morgan Rawlins of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., and Joyce W. Rawlins of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Alexander Mitchell, son of Mrs. James M. Mitchell of Greenwich and the late Mr. Mitchell. The Rev. Sherman Beattie, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.

title: Battling the Press
description: In another press freedom case, John Bowman, editor of The Streator (Ill.) Times-Press, said last month: ''I've had people react angrily in letters to the editor or in conversations over the phone or even in person.

title: NOT ALL AIRPORTS USE CONTROLLERS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration operates control towers at six New Jersey airports: Newark, Teterboro, Morristown, Atlantic City, Trenton and Essex County in Caldwell.

title: Garcia's 4 Hits Spur Jays to 4-3 Victory
description: Damaso Garcia capped the first four-hit game of his major league career with an eighth-inning single that scored the winning run as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 4-3, for their fourth victory in a row. Garcia also got a double and two other singles.

title: Television Week
description: Echoes of Fame Irene Cara sounded almost resigned. In ''Fame,'' Alan Parker's 1980 film set in New York's High School for the Performing Arts, she played a talented young singer intent on ''making it'' in New York - for which she won considerable praise - and everybody, she says, assumed she was merely playing herself.

title: AN ABUNDANCE OF SOVIET FRIENDS OF AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in Summary; No Progress for Haitian Pilgrims
description: For most of the nearly 30,000 Haitians who have fled the poorest nation in the Western Hemisphere for the promise of America, Washington's distinction between political and economic refugees is more than academic. The former are treated as potential immigrants; those merely seeking to improve their living conditions are deported.

title: Dining Out; DINING WHERE DUFFERS USED TO BE
description: THE Florham Park County Club no longer operates as a private club. The golf course now belongs to the Borough of Florham Park and houses are being built on what were formerly the club grounds. But the white Colonial-style clubhouse is still owned by Bernard Kruth, as it has been for the last 20 years, and the catering facilities are intact.

title: Correction
description: A recent Personal Finance column incorrectly described the maximum contributions that self-employed persons can make to Keogh retirement plans. Currently, they can contribute $7,500 a year, or 15 percent of their first $100,000 in net income, whichever is less.

title: Camera; AN UPDATE ON MOTOR DRIVES FOR ACTION PICTURES
The Curry Clue
description: May I offer a possible reason for Craig Claiborne's fruitless search for Senegalese soup in a French reference work (''Cold Soups for Summer,'' July 5)? Would not the presence of curry in the soup indicate that the name Senegalese has become a popular misspelling of Singhalese, referring to Ceylon, now Sri Lanka, which shares with its neighbor, India, an affinity for curry in its cuisine?

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: NEW FERRY SLOOP BOWS IN
description: YONKERS IT RAINED on and off all day, sometimes gently, sometimes a downpour, and the sun never had a chance. But for the dozens of volunteers who turned out, the day could not have been brighter.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: CHIEF JUSTICE Robert N. Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court indicated last week that he felt the state needed ''a more selfstarting and aggressive program from within the judiciary to let the public know what we're doing at all levels of our court system.''

title: THE HOUSE OF ATREUS NOW
description: ANGEL OF LIGHT By Joyce Carol Oates. 434 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $15.50. By THOMAS R. EDWARDS

title: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO SERVAN-SCHREIBER
description: THE WORLD CHALLENGE By Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber. 302 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: SHIFTING GEARS ON BRIBES ABROAD
description: Just because the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act spotlights a sensitive subject - corporate bribery abroad -some people turn a blind eye to its shortcomings rather than risk being accused of being ''soft on bribery.''

title: Numismatics; THE MARKET MOOD IS DECIDEDLY DOWNBEAT
description: The coin market boom of 1979 and 1980 was fueled to a great extent by an influx of well-heeled investors. Now those same investors appear to be exiting in sizable numbers and once again their movements are having a major impact on the market.

title: WHAT SAFETY NET?
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; 'Palimony' Reversed
description: It may have been delayed, but as far as Lee Marvin is concerned, justice hasn't been denied.

title: GROUP SESSIONS HELP PHOBICS COPE
description: THE fear of being in crowds or open places, or agoraphobia, is often associated with housewives who are afraid to leave their homes. But it is not that simple -or that unusual. According to a spokesman at the Connecticut Mental Health Association, there are perhaps as many as one in 100 people with some form of the phobia. And interviews with agoraphobics and people who are trying to help them (often former phobics), indicate that it is a problem that is just now becoming understood.

title: AMONG THE GIANTS IN THE HIGH SIERRAS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- STEPHEN SOLOMON is a contributing editor of Science Digest. By STEPHEN SOLOMON

title: Kevin Bransfield, Monte McQueen Set Fall Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. McQueen of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Monte Louise McQueen, to Kevin F. Bransfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Bransfield of Lynn and West Dennis, Mass.

title: On Teaching The Learning-Disabled
description: After almost two decades of teaching learning-disabled children, I was interested in the article ''Handicapped Gain Normal Class Spots.''

title: MUSEUM DISPLAYS BOGUS ART GIVEN BY UNWITTING SPONSOR
description: Starting this weekend, an exhibit at the University of Arizona Museum of Art is displaying four works of art donated in the mid-1970's by Edward J. Gallagher Jr., a Baltimore businessman who, before he died in 1978, made nearly 200 such gifts to the school.

title: PAYING MORE TO DRIVE
description: Motorists are not only driving less, but also paying more to do so. According to a Hertz Corporation annual survey, the cost of owning and driving a car rose to more than $2,600 last year, a 12 percent increase from 1979.

title: Art; 'TOURIST ART' IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK PITY the poor tourist with no one to show his photographs to. Vacation pictures, more than any other kind, need to be shared (or imposed) and, judging from ''Americans Abroad,'' at the Newark Museum, they always have.

title: BILTMORE CLOSES, SURPRISING GUESTS
description: The Biltmore Hotel, for 68 years a celebrated hub of the Grand Central neighborhood, surprised guests, employees and city landmark officials by closing its doors Friday night and bringing in scores of workers to begin demolishing its interior.

title: Speaking Personally; THE BATTLE OF THE BULGE, OR HOW I LOST THE WAR
description: ALTHOUGH death and taxes are considered life's only certainties, I have another. Come winter, I will gain 20 pounds.Even though I will lose them in the spring, I will inevitably find them again the following winter. I eat, eat, eat and when I no longer recognize the stranger in the mirror, I diet, diet, diet.

title: Around the Nation; Oil Company Demands Workers Speak English
description: Champlin Petroleum Company officials have posted a memorandum requiring refinery employees to speak only English while on the job, a newspaper reported today.

title: PLAN FOR HOSPICE STIRS ROSLYN
description: DISAPPOINTED by the state's rejection of its plan to establish a hospice in Roslyn, Friends of Hospice Inc., a group of private citizens that organized the care-facility project, is turning to community members and local politicians for support.

title: Strategically, Weinberger Thinks Big
description: Reagan Administration dreams no little dreams. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger would like to spend about $200 billion over five years on strategic nuclear forces alone. His plan, to be presented to President Reagan in California tomorrow and no doubt to be debated in Congress and the nation for months to come, proposes to move toward revising fundamental assumptions, notably giving up acceptance of East-West nuclear ''parity.'' Instead, the United States would strive for nuclear ''margins of safety'' that imply outright nuclear superiority. The plan, as reported by The New York Times and confirmed in large part by a White House spokesman, would blur the edges of the classic nuclear defense ''triad'' of bombers, missilefiring submarines and land-based missiles in silos. Existing Minuteman and Titan missiles would stay in silos, but the new MX missile might not.

title: Mother Faces Mental Tests
description: A woman who took her 15-month-old daughter from a New York hospital in July has been ordered hospitalized for further psychiatric tests, court sources said. A Family Court judge in Queens is trying to decide whether the baby, Jody Powers, should be returned to her mother, Pat Powers, or remain with foster parents. Mrs. Powers faces possible charges of child neglect.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: ETHNIC AMERICA, by Thomas Sowell. (Basic Books, $16.95.) A study of how ethnic groups have fared in America. IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER, by Italo Calvino.

title: LOVE AND DEATH
description: THE LOVE HUNTER By Jon Hassler. 311 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.95. By RANDOLPH HOGAN

title: New Orleans - For some weeks now the White House has been pressed to enter negotiations with the Soviet Union on arms control in Europe. President Reagan has thought it necessary to delay. Along with many other Americans, the President clearly would prefer to wait until our military strength is so overwhelming that we could not possibly lose out in a negotiating process. The new military budget is the price we pay for a strong negotiating position.
description: Implicit in this attitude is the notion that whenever Soviet and American negotiators sit down together, we end up the losers. This view was heard frequently during the debate on the second strategic nuclear arms treaty. Not without pride, critics of the treaty pointed out that Soviet leaders, with no need to respond to domestic opinion, could plan and execute their strategy with the freedom of chess players while American negotiators had to contend with the intrusion of Congressional activists. It was also argued that democratic elections, because they cause us to change negotiating teams frequently, give the unchanging Soviet negotiators a further edge. According to this pessimistic view, democracy at home requires that we be babes-in-the-woods in negotiations abroad.

title: Amy Goodman Engaged
description: The engagement of Amy Beth Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome S. Goodman of Cherry Hill, N.J., to Jeffrey Keith Harrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Harrow of Woodmere, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. An April wedding is planned.

title: 24-1 WILLOW HOUR CAPTURES TRAVERS
description: Upsets are so common at Saratoga Race Track that when Willow Hour won the Jim Dandy Stakes at odds of 18-1 two weeks ago, apparently nobody took the race seriously. But Willow Hour proved that performance was no fluke today. Sent off at 24-1, he held off Pleasant Colony, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, and the 2-year-old champion Lord Avie on a rain-soaked track to win the 112th running of the Travers.

title: Retirement and Leisure Are Not for Men Only
description: ''Is Retirement Really for Everyone?'' (July 5) says ''women seem to handle retirement better.'' I have been casting about in my mind for a woman I know who has retired.

title: Relocated Birds Thriving
description: Several endangered red-cockaded woodpeckers are thriving after being relocated to an island off the Georgia coast. State and Federal biologists relocated the birds to St. Catherines Island near Savannah last year after learning that a new Army firing range at Fort Stewart would have destroyed the pine trees the birds lived in. Twelve of the birds were relocated and four were killed by predators, but the survivors quickly adapted to their new home, a state natural resources biologist says.

title: Virginia Drewry Wed to Curtiss Martin
description: Virginia Watkins Drewry, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Watkins Drewry of Richmond and the late Mr. Drewry, was married yesterday to Howard Curtiss Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Gwynne Martin of New York and Wainscott, L.I. The Rev. Frank Stafford Davis and the Rev. David Lee Morgan performed the ceremony at the Second Presbyterian Church in Richmond.

title: AS SUSSEX COUNTY GROWS IT BECOMES HARDER TO FIND
