description: Twenty-three-year-old David Miller was raised in the lone house on a country road, not far from this speck on the map in Sussex County. Now there are 47 more houses next to his, he said, all put up by ''the new people'' in the years since ''the big road,'' Interstate 80, opened.

title: Notes; COUNTRY-FAIR SEASON BEGINS IN THE NORTHEAST
description: Across the Northeast, dairy and fruit farmers, horse lovers, vegetable growers and craft workers are putting the finishing touches on their products and preparing them for display in the scores of communities that hold county, town and grange fairs. The events range from the New York State Fair, held on the 365-acre fairgrounds at Syracuse, which lasts for 10 days, to one-day affairs that take place in a meadow in towns like Guilford, near Brattleboro, Vt.

title: MISS STEPHENSON LEADS BY ON 69-134
description: Jan Stephenson of Australia overcame 103-degree heat and shot a three-under-par 69 today to take a five-shot lead after two rounds of the Mary Kay Classic.

title: WHY I WON'T HAVE AN AFFAIR
description: IT'S not that I haven't been asked; it's just that I never wanted to, was afraid to, didn't have the time to - or thought my mother would find out. It's also probably too much trouble, possibly inconvenient, mildly terrifying and no doubt fabulously exciting.

title: HARDY COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: OPTING FOR SOBRIETY; ROBERT BYRNE
description: As the United States Championship in South Bend, Inc., proceeded, Lev Alburt, a New York grandmaster, continued to rely exclusively on the Alekhine Defense against 1 P-K4. However, his early misadventures with unreliable, excessively ambitious variations of this opening gradually sobered him and pointed him toward orthodox play.

title: SUMMER GUESTS,
description: ANYONE who has ever owned a home relatively close to the water knows that this time of year brings forth house guests as predictably as in the old days the warm weather heralded the arrival of the neighborhood ice cream truck.

title: CUBS WIN ON ERROR IN 15TH, 4-3
description: An error by Phil Garner at second base in the 15th inning allowed Jody Davis to score from second today and gave the Chicago Cubs a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: EMPLOYEE PRIDE IS THE GOAL AT A VOLKSWAGEN PLANT
description: After Volkswagen of America announces its first employee discounts next week on Rabbits built here, the plant's huge parking lot will begin to fill with cars made by the company's 5,700 workers, predicts Roy H. Langenbach, manager of the only foreign-owned car assembly plant in the United States.

title: RAIL SPILL OF PCB'S PROBED
description: MAYOR John C. Mandanici of Bridgeport demanded an explanation last week of why Conrail failed to notify city officials that 160 gallons of PCB's (polychlorinated biphenyl) had leaked from the transformer of the 8:05 A.M. train out of New Haven on July 23.

title: Realty News; Park Avenue
description: The law firm of Morgan Lewis & Bockius has leased about 100,000 square feet of office space on the 43d through the 46th floors at 101 Park Avenue for 20 years.

title: FOOTBALL'S PAIN A REMINDER TO JIM OTTO
description: YUBA CITY, Calif. FOR 15 seasons Jim Otto was the center for the Oakland Raiders. He played well, he played recklessly and, too often in the later years, he played hurt.

title: Druggist Is Held in Poisoning Of Competitor's Customers
description: Lloyd Sellers of Opp, a pharmacist, has been indicted on charges of poisoning or attempting to poison four Covington County children who had prescriptions filled by his competitor and former business partner, Ted Roquemore.

title: THE HERE THAT'S EVERYWHERE
description: THERE was a time when it seemed that only the privileged or exotically deprived had ancestries worth noting. But it's become part of our national pride to trace our family trees. And all people should - except, I used to think, if they come from Long Island.

title: NEW TOWER FOR REPUBLIC NATIONAL BANK
description: The Republic National Bank has begun construction on a 27-story skyscraper on Fifth Avenue. It will be the largest project to be developed on Fifth Avenue south of 42d Street since the Empire State Building was built a half-century ago.

title: Dance
description: THE GENESIS OF 'AFTERNOON OF A FAUN' AS RECALLED BY NIJINSKY'S SISTER

title: Miss Rand Is Married
description: The marriage of Jennifer Jewett Rand to William Stapleton Griffis took place yesterday at the summer home in Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario, of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Calvin G. Rand of New York. The bridegroom is a son of Lawrence W. Griffis Jr. and Patricia Stapleton Griffis, both of Buffalo.

title: Tiffany Windows
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in Summary; Abscam Judge Sets Sentences
description: It was sentencing time in a Federal courtroom in Brooklyn last week for several convicted veterans of Abscam political corruption trials - four former members of the House of Representatives, a New Jersey state legislator and a Philadelphia city official. All in all, they could have done worse.

title: Index; New York Times Magazine August 16, 1981
description: William Safire 9 On Language Boll Weevils Whomp Gypsy Moths Russell Baker 14 Sunday Observer Where Have All the Ulcers Gone? Jonathan Raban 22 River Log: Travels of a Modern Huck The author, an Englishman who borrowed the idea from Mark Twain's Huckleberry Finn, sets out on a small craft for a voyage of discovery down the Mississippi River. He finds, in the towns and cities along the way - from Minneapolis to New Orleans - undercurrents of an American culture that are as quirky and powerful as the open water of the great stream itself.

title: The Region in Summary; The Gypsy Moths' Biggest Bite Yet
description: Experts concluded last week what many homeowners and nature lovers already knew: It has been hard to see the forests for the gypsy moths. Basing their estimate on aerial inspections undertaken earlier this summer, Federal officials said the ravenous caterpillars have spread through at least nine million acres from Maine to Maryland, including 2.4 million acres in New York, 1.5 million in Connecticut and nearly 800,000 in New Jersey.

title: DISRUPTION OF AIR TRAFFIC TERMED SLIGHT
description: AIR travel in or out of Connecticut last week involved day-to-day uncertainities and varying frustration as some flights were delayed or canceled, but according to Government and private air transportation officials, the state's eight airports suffered few disruptions as a result of the nationwide air traffic controllers' walkout.

title: STORE SUN POWER TO GARDEN OFF SEASON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul King is a retired manufacturer who gardens in New Hampshire. By PAUL KING

title: Dennis E. Glazer, Lawyer, Marries Janet M. Di Fiore
description: Janet M. Di Fiore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Di Fiore of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y., yesterday to Dennis E. Glazer, son of Mrs. Kenneth H. Glazer of Roslyn Heights, L.I., and the late Dr. Glazer. Judge Irving B. Kendall of the Mount Vernon City Court performed the ceremony.

title: Design; MORE PALOMA THAN PICASSO
description: The apartment I had before, my first real apartment, was like a big hotel in the south of France -grand, but not too comfortable. I think lost space, rooms you never enter, protect you from the world,'' says Paloma Picasso.

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO GET BRUSHES CLEAN WITH MINIMUM EFFORT
description: PROBABLY the messiest and most annoying part of any paint job is cleaning out the brushes after the job is done - at least when working with an oil or alkyd base paint. With latex paint, cleaning tools is much less of a problem; you can simply rinse them out in running water. But cleaning brushes, rollers and other tools that have been used in a solvent-base paint seems to be more of a challenge for most people - and that is why so many buy cheap ''throwaway'' brushes that they can discard when the job is done.

title: The Careful Shopper; D'Agostino Planning 'Greatest Carpet Show'
description: What is billed by D'Agostino Carpet as ''The Greatest Carpet Show on Earth'' will fill the County Center through this week. Setting-up time is tomorrow, and selling is from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. Tuesday through Friday and from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturday. The festive atmosphere will come in part from balloons and in part from hundreds of pillows decorated with Miss Piggy, Kermit and Gonzo that will be awarded, one each, with a receipt for a purchase of more than $50.

title: ESCHER EXHIBIT AND SALE
description: The Artists Market in Norwalk is conducting an exhibition and sale of rare prints of the Dutch artist M.C. Escher that will continue through Saturday. The show, entitled ''The Magic and Mastery of M.C. Escher,'' will feature original prints, lithographs and woodcuts of the late artist.

title: Practical Traveler; RULES ON SMOKING ALOFT TO BE EASED
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board is preparing to loosen its rules that guarantee a seat in a nonsmoking section to any airline passenger who asks for one.

title: Counting Iranians
description: Six days after Iranian students seized the United States Embassy in Teheran and took its occupants hostage, President Jimmy Carter ordered a crackdown on Iranian students in this country. Four days later, Nov. 14,

title: WELCOME TO THE SHORE, VACATIONERS
description: MASSES of people, snarled traffic, raucous noises, mobbed beaches! Is this what summer at the seashore is all about? I used to be one of those all-year-round Long Beach Island dwellers who resented the summer people who stopped dead at an intersection when the light was green or who crashed through red lights, who slung shopping carts into impassable blockades in the supermarkets, who cluttered our beaches with their oil-soaked bodies.

title: MORE THAN A BOOKKEEPER, LESS THAN A MAYOR
description: In a political season otherwise unmarred by excitement, the race for Comptroller of New York City has produced a surprising measure of rhetorical acrimony. The incumbent, two-term Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, entered the campaign sure-footed and confident, but intimations of impropriety stemming from a recent Department of Investigation inquiry has apparently put him off balance and impelled him look for other issues to bring to the voters' attention.

title: 2 FOR ROGERS
description: George Rogers, the first player chosen in this year's National Football League draft, scored two touchdowns tonight to lead the New Orleans Saints to a 27-7 victory over the Houston Oilers in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: A ROADMAP TO REAPPORTIONMENT
description: HARTFORD THE key battles in a state commission's fall offensive to try to redraw Connecticut's six Congressional districts will be fought over such towns as New Canaan, Trumbull, Southbury, Enfield, Windsor Locks, East Windsor, Berlin, Newington, Bloomfield and East Hampton.

title: ARCHEOLOGISTS SIFT FRAGMENTS OF OLD SAYBROOK'S PAST
description: OLD SAYBROOK A TEAM of archeologists has been digging in an 18-acre site in Old Saybrook this summer, hoping to learn about the early development of what was Connecticut's first coastal settlement.

title: COSMOS' CABANAS FILLS A VOID
description: Roberto Cabanas proved again last week how valuable he is to the Cosmos. Cabanas continuously moves fast, constantly creates problems for the opposition and often does the unexpected, an aspect of the game missed by Cosmos' fans since the departure of Franz Beckenbauer and Carlos Alberto at the end of last season.

title: Gottfried Gains Final In Grand Prix Tennis
description: Brian Gottfried defeated unseeded Marko Ostoja of Yugoslavia, 4-6, 6-0, 7-6, today and reached the final of the $75,000 Stowe Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: SELECTMAN PAID LEAST
description: LOOKING for a better job in the fast-paced, high-paying world of municipal government? Head for Hartford or Newington, and whatever you do, stay away from anyone who wants to make you a first selectman.

title: Christena C. Luce Is Married
description: The marriage of Christena Charlotte Luce to Paul Mansfield Mc Nicol took place yesterday at the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I. The Rev. William W. Rogers performed the ceremony.

title: TROUBLES PLAGUE U.S.-CHINA EXCHANGE PROGRAM
description: Three years after scientific and educational exchanges between the United States and China began amid expressions of good will, they are running into difficulty.

title: The Region in Summary;
description: Deregulation may be the watchword in Washington, but no such trend is in evidence in New York, at least as far as owners of the city's 2,000 horses are concerned.

title: The Nation in Summary; Detroit Bail-Out, For a While
description: Ever since New York City wobbled back from bankruptcy on an artfully constructed save involving in part the sale of city bonds to municipal pension funds, similar plans have been a key part of many urban rescue packages. Now it is Detroit's turn to teeter on the brink and offer its municipal unions bonds.

title: Around the Nation; Bubonic Plague Found In Fleas in New Mexico
description: The Forest Service yesterday warned campers and picnickers in the Sandia Mountains east of Albuquerque that a large number of fleas carrying bubonic plague had been found in the Las Huertas Canyon area.

title: Around the Nation; Five Killed in Crash Of a Hot-Air Balloon
description: Five persons were killed and a sixth was seriously injured when a hot-air balloon caught fire tonight and crashed in a residential area in this northwest Chicago suburb, the authorities said.

title: HOMEOWNER FIGHTS ESSEX DEVELOPMENT
description: ESSEX KIMBALL S. NICKERSON'S home is one of several 18th-century sea captains' houses along this small riverfront town's Main Street, a largely one-way street that has thriving specialty shops side-by-side with the historic residences.

title: POPE GIVES 25-MINUTE TALK TO VATICAN CROWD
description: In a strong, clear voice, Pope John Paul II today made his first public address at the Vatican since his release from a Rome hospital yesterday.

title: PLAN FOR NIXON LIBRARY STIRS DUKE U. DISPUTE
description: Duke University is negotiating with Richard M. Nixon to have his Presidential library on its campus, but opposition to the project is being expressed by faculty members in the history department.

title: Q.&Q.
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE county has added up the costs for all the broken cell doors, water pipes ripped off walls, shattered windows and torn grill work at the Valhalla jail and come up with a total of $470,585. With a built-in $20,000 to cover odds and ends, that is the estimated cost of the riots that occurred there over the July 11 weekend.

title: ALL'S FAIR
description: With its mixed ethnic background and deep Colonial roots, Huntington has a variety of cultures to acknowledge when it celebrates its past. And today from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the Heckscher Ball Park on Route 25A, the Historical Society's annual Heritage Festival and Antiques Show will do just that. Featured will be its noted militia in Colonial garb, Irish pipers and step-toe dances, Swedish folk dances and singers, square dancers and even a Matinecock Indian dance by the local Boy Scouts. The evening will be capped with a free Long Island Philharmonic concert at 8:30 P.M. at nearby Heckscher Park. All this is in addition to the usual children's games, arts and crafts exhibitions and sales, and a variety of foods. Admission is $2; for children 5 to 12, 50 cents.

title: RIVER LOG: TRAVELS OF A MODERN HUCK
description: Copyright c 1981 by Jonathan Raban This article is an excerpt from ''Old Glory,'' by Jonathan Raban, to be published next month by Simon and Schuster. By Jonathan Raban t is as big and depthless as the sky itself. You can see the curve of the earth on its surface as it stretches away for miles to the far shore. Sunset has turned the water to the color of unripe peaches. There's no wind. Sand bars and wooded islands stand on their exact reflections. The only signs of movement on the water are the lightly scratched lines which run in parallels across it like the scores of a diamond on a windowpane. In the middle distance, the river smokes with toppling pillars of mist which soften the light so that one can almost reach out and take in handfuls of that thickened air.

title: The Region; A Strike-Free System?
description: Goodness knows the New York transit system provides few enough joys, but last week the president of the Transport Workers Union threatened to deprive New Yorkers of yet another one - the thrill of surviving transit strikes.

title: New Jersey Housing; THE PITFALLS OF HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CARPENTERS around the state are raising high the roof beams on many a house whose owners have decided to extend, add to or otherwise improve what they have rather than move.

title: The Baker's Bread
description: To the Business Editor: Jude Wanniski's article, ''The Burden of Friedman's Monetarism'' (July 26) may seem confusing to some readers. Although the example of barter exchange is lucid, the exposition on money seems fragmented and indirect.

title: TRAINING AND TECHNOLOGY
description: We are lagging in technology because almost half our labs and research personnel are tied up in high-technology work which produces the most sophisticated weaponry in the world but which saps the economy of vital components for productivity.

title: C.A. Taylor Weds Lynn M. Tappan
description: The marriage of Lynn Merrill Tappan to Christopher Alan Taylor took place yesterday in the Episcopal Church of St. Ann's-by-the-Sea in Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Laman Harmon Bruner Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Billy Graham's Mother Dies
description: Morrow Coffey Graham, the mother of the evangelist Billy Graham, died yesterday at her home here.

title: The Region in Summary; Million-Dollar Ride in Store For Straphangers
description: It sometimes seems that the cost of New York City's subway and bus equipment is underestimated as much as its reliability is overrated.

title: EYE BANK MARKS 20 YEARS OF SERVICE
description: THE Connecticut Eye Bank and Visual Research Foundation Inc., which is based at New Britain General Hospital and recently marked its 20th anniversary, has since its founding helped to give renewed sight through corneal transplants to about 3,000 people, primarily Connecticut residents.

title: Realty News
description: The Prudential Life Insurance Company, the nation's largest and most active insurance company in real estate development, is planning to build a $65 million office complex in Newark, where it has its headquarters.

title: MILLER: THE UNION'S STRENGTH IS ESTABLISHED
description: How does an industry insure against a strike? The recent baseball experience does not provide a positive answer. It does suggest, however, that an insurance policy providing management with some payments against strike losses is ineffective and likely counter-productive.

title: Elizabeth Nolin Wed To Peter R.D. Tagge
description: Elizabeth Payson Nolin and Peter Russell Deupree Tagge were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn. The Rev. Andrew Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Music View; A HEARTY MIX OF OPERA AND GREEN CHILIES
description: Santa Fe doesn't look like Bayreuth or Salzburg, true. Nowhere in the Bavarian temple city of Wagnerism, for instance, can you get a quiche stuffed with the fearsome green chile, one of the hottest uncontrolled substances known to culinary man. Nor are you be likely to find at Austria's shrine to Mozart a plaza filled with picturesquely squatting Indian women who are not only eager to sell you handcrafted silver jewelry but prepared to accept your major credit card and run it through their portable machines. And yet, despite such local peculiarities, or maybe in part because of them, Santa Fe comes closer to being a genuine international festival than any summer music series in America, thanks to the continued presence and continued brilliance of the Santa Fe Opera, which this season is celebrating its 25th anniversary.

title: AND SHADOWS THAT STAY EVEN WHEN THE SUN GOES IN
description: IT was a lovely day at the beach with the same hot sun and cool breeze I had dreamed about last February. I lay on a towel on the warm sand with a hat slanted over my face. Nearby, two young boys were building a sand castle.

title: SEEKING VICTORY WITH A VIOLINIST AT SHORTSTOP
description: ''COACH, coach.'' Lee, my 6-year-old center fielder, was urgently beckoning to me. There were men on base in a close game, and I thought he had to know what to do if the ball came to him. I ran over to where he was standing in the outfield.

title: Lisa Preston, James Bertles Are Married
description: Lisa Conger Preston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest R. Preston Jr. of Akron, Ohio, was married in St. Paul's Episcopal Church there yesterday to James Billet Bertles, son of Mrs. William Bertles Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Bertles. The Rev. George Ross performed the ceremony.

title: Taiwan Jailing 27 Fishermen For Trade With the Mainland
description: The Taiwan High Court overruled a lower court's verdict today and sentenced 27 fishermen to prison terms ranging from five months to a year on charges of trading with Chinese Communists in the Taiwan Straits.

title: Topics; LIFE FORMS; Life, Plus
description: The threat of being sentenced to ''life, plus 99 years'' may have genuine deterrent power. But when a judge hands down sentences of 1,940 and 1,620 years all that's being deterred is common sense.

title: MANCHESTER SETS HIRING GOAL
description: PARTLY as a result of a stepped-up affirmative action effort, more than twice as many blacks and Hispanic people have applied for openings at the Manchester Police Department than have ever applied before.

title: QUARANTINE ON CROPS EXTENDED IN CALIFORNIA
description: Officials ordered a quarantine covering more than 264 square miles of the nation's lushest farmland today after at least 56 crop-threatening fruit flies were found in California's San Joaquin Valley.

title: Alison Brown Wed to Stephen White
description: Alison Graham Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond David Brown of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Aden White, son of Mrs. Peter Gillette White of New York and the late Mr. White. The Episcopal ceremony was performed at home of the bridegroom's cousin, Lucy White, in Hulett's Landing, N.Y., by the Rev. Robert Condit.

title: Advisers Said to Prefer Land-Based MX Plan
description: Members of the Defense Science Board have recommended that the Reagan Administration go ahead with the land-based shelter plan for deploying the MX missile, Administration sources said today.

title: CONTROLLER CALLED TYPICAL OF NEW BREED OF WORKER
description: The striking air traffic controllers are representative, experts say, of a new kind of American worker in the rapidly growing fields of communications and other technical work who will increasingly demand the respect and status traditionally accorded white-collar workers.

title: Charles Chapler, Industrialist And Developer of Real Estate
description: Charles Chapler, a retired industrialist and real estate developer, died Tuesday at Community Hospital in Montclair, N.J., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Hackensack, N.J.

title: BASEBALL RETHINKS PLAYOFF FORMAT
description: Since the split-season divisional playoff format has drawn criticism, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday that he and the presidents of the American League and National League will meet this week to decide whether another postseason plan would be feasible.

title: GAMING INDUSTRY GROWTH DOUBTFUL
description: FROM modest beginnings a decade ago, legalized gambling has grown into a major industry in this state with revenues of almost twothirds of a billion dollars a year. But continued growth of gaming and of the income it provides the state - $91 million last year - is in doubt.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: GARDEN CITY BEHIND the scenes, the scenario was full of promise and suspense. A theater that's trying to make a name for itself (Actors Conservatory Theater at Adelphi) engaged a pair of accomplished ''artistic directors'' (Jean Marsh and Philip Minor), who, in turn, persuaded an illustrious star (Geraldine Page) to appear in the summer season's second play.

title: KAFKA'S HEBREW TEACHER
description: IN ''Looking at Kafka,'' Philip Roth resurrects the Prague novelist as a Hebrew teacher in postwar Newark. Kafka's own fantasies ran toward more exotic ambitions - he wanted to be a waiter in Tel-Aviv. As for Hebrew, nothing in his background would have qualified him to teach it; but toward the end of his life he did study it, with grim determination and creditable success. In fact, it was a little-known letter of his, written in quite idiomatic Hebrew, that first led me to wonder what had become of his friend and teacher, Puah Ben-Tovim, to whom it was addressed.

title: LAW OF SEA PARLEY IN A WAITING GAME
description: The United States and third world countries are engaged in a high-stakes poker game at the United Nations' longrunning Conference on the Law of the Sea, with each side holding its cards close to the vest.

title: Oct. 10 Bridal Set By Margaret Gow
description: The engagement of Margaret Gow to Dean Cole Trautmann has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Frederic H. Williams Jr. of Glen Cove, L.I., stepfather and mother of the future bride.Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Trautmann Jr. of Manhasset, L.I.

title: GARBAGE CONTRACT TROUBLING TOWNS
description: MONTCLAIR THE recent generous settlement of the seven-day strike by 1,400 trash collectors employed by private garbage companies, which gives the workers a 50 percent raise within three years, is causing great concern among municipalities that still have their own sanitation departments.

title: TROUBLED VIETNAM VETERANS ACQUIRING STATUS
description: It was last Thursday afternoon when Bobby Muller lifted the phone in the office of the Vietnam Veterans of America and dialed the number of Robert P. Nimmo, head of the Veterans Administration.

title: DEATH OF BLACK MAN IN POLICE CUSTODY LEADS TO BITTER PROTESTS IN MILWAUKEE
description: It was much too hot and humid during the day, so Ernest R. Lacy and his cousin, Jeff Garland, waited for the relief that darkness brought before they began painting at an apartment building at 20th Street and Wisconsin Avenue last July 9.

title: HOTEL WEIGHED AS 'LANDMARK'
description: Before wreckers went to work inside the Biltmore Hotel, New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission had been reviewing some of the hotel's spaces for possible designation as ''interior landmarks,'' a top city preservation official said yesterday.

title: DEARIE FILED TAX RETURNS LATE IN 4 OF LAST 6 YEARS
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for City Comptroller, filed four of his last six income tax returns from eight months to two years late.

title: FRESH AIR FUND BENEFITING HOST FAMILY
description: Eight-year-old Sara Carroll of the Bronx has never been to the ocean. She finds it hard to imagine the sounds of breaking waves or the feel of warm sand between her bare toes.

title: SOMEDAY, AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS MAY HIT THE TARGET
description: Elsie Sekanka, a black domestic servant on a military base just outside Pretoria, received a message last week that was meant for white South Africa. It was a 122-millimeter Soviet-made rocket and it came crashing through the roof of her room in the servants quarters behind an officer's house, exploding near her bed without causing her any injury.

title: Millstone 3: 'At What Cost?'
description: The article ''Nuclear Plant's Impact Debated'' (Aug. 2) provided an excellent background of the escalation in the cost estimates of the Millstone 3 nuclear unit between 1975 and 1981. The original cost estimates of Millstone 3, however, go back to 1971.

title: Woman Sets Herself on Fire
description: A woman was badly burned when she set herself afire on a sidewalk on Fifth Avenue near 60th Street. The police, who tentatively identified the woman as Elsie Olovich, said she used insect spray to start the flames. A witness said she had marched up and down the street saying ''the government doesn't care'' before the incident on Friday.

title: UNRELIABLE SAMPLINGS OF THE NATION'S PULSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Leader Assails Reagan Over 'Union-Busting' Tactics
description: A regional director of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations told the group's Nevada state convention today that what he termed President Reagan's ''union-busting'' efforts aimed at the striking air controllers would result in a confrontation between the President and organized labor.

title: Caren Utzig Married to Walter Forbes
description: Caren Suzanne Utzig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Utzig of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Walter Alexander Forbes of New Canaan, Conn. Judge Nicholas Cioffi of the State Superior Court performed the ceremony at the Silvermine Inn in Norwalk, Conn.

title: CRUSTACEANS VERSUS CONTROLLERS
description: Some travelers seethe at flight delays. Others stay admirably cool. Maine's lobsters are in the latter catagory. Maine's lobster shippers are in the former.

title: OUR DOLLAR, THEIR PROBLEM-AGAIN?
description: LONDON Once again, the system by which the world prices its money is under fire. For a decade now, the international financial order has evolved a system that largely leaves the price of yen, marks, francs, pounds, guilders, lire, pesos and cruzeiros to the ebb and flow of supply and demand. In many quarters, of course, this system is still heartily applauded; but increasingly there are calls for reconsideration and for a return to what in any other market would be known as price controls.

title: RIMSKY-KORSAKOV'S 'MOZART AND SALIERI'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Harlow Robinson writes frequently on Russian society and culture. By HARLOW ROBINSON

title: Edward Culhane, Miss McCormack To Marry Oct. 10
description: Mrs. Buren H. McCormack of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., has made known the engagement of her stepdaughter, Judith McCormack, to Edward Carroll Culhane, son of Mrs. M. Carroll Culhane of Waterbury, Conn., and the late Dr. Culhane.

title: Elizabeth Parr Wed To William Newman
description: Elizabeth Alvord Parr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Preston Parr of Bethlehem, Pa., was married yesterday to William Harley Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kincaid Newman of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Alvord Miner Beardslee, the bride's uncle, a minister with the United Church of Christ and the chaplain of Hollins College, performed the ceremony in the garden of the Parr home.

title: S.F. Owen Weds Shelby L. Ochs
description: The marriage of Shelby Latimer Ochs to Stephen Frazier Owen took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Ivy, Va. The Rev. George W. Wyer, assisted by Canon Hunsdon Cary Jr., performed the ceremony.

title: MELANIE SZE WILL BE BRIDE OF DR. RANDOLPH E. HOCK
description: The engagement of Melanie Chia-Yu Sze to Dr. Randolph Edward Hock has been announced by the future bride's father, Dr. Palmer Ch-Yuan Sze of Chatham, N.J. Dr. Hock is a son of Anna S. Hock of Chestertown, Md., and the late Arthur S. Hock. The wedding will take place next month.

title: LONG ISLANDERS REPEATS SWEEP IN WALKS
description: Rain made the third day of the Empire State Games competition a sloppy affair today, but it did not prevent Susan Liers-Westerfield, a Long Islander, from winning again.

title: MODIGLIANI--THE BOHEMIAN
description: Modigliani is one of the most familiar 20th-century artists. His melancholy faces and languid nudes occupy an entire corridor in the museum without walls. His works have been reproduced so often, in so many places, that they were part of us before we knew his name.

title: Cold War Family
description: What's to be done with young Walter Polovchak? In January, 1980, Walter's father, a Ukrainian bus driver, emigrated to the United States with his wife and three children. He soon grew disillusioned: he couldn't find a job he liked; he didn't get along in Chicago's Ukrainian-American community.

title: MAINTAINING AN AIRY AND MOIST SOIL
description: WHEN one observes a healthy plant in the garden, one sees only half of that plant. The other half is hidden beneath the soil. Half of any healthy, well-balanced plant is made up of roots and lies buried in the soil.

title: LOCAL MELONS AT PEAK
description: THANKS to a couple of seasons of nearly ideal weather, one Long Island crop is attracting the attention of those who make it a point of enjoying local delicacies. Muskmelons, in season from now through roughly the end of this month, have been sweet and juicily flavorful.

title: CLEVELAND BOND RATING RAISED
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation has upgraded Cleveland's bond rating to allow it to re-enter the municipal bond market, but the city's finance director has said the re-entry will not come soon.

title: Lucy G. Robinson Is Wed in Seattle
description: Lucy Grosvenor Robinson, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Dwight Edwards Robinson of Seattle, was married there yesterday to Charles Parsons Cooley 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Porter Cooley of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. John Gorsuch performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany.

title: Union Refuses to Halt Strike in Sierra Leone
description: Leaders of Sierra Leone's first general strike met with the Government today and vowed to continue the walkout despite a promise by authorities to stabilize rice prices.

title: SUBSTANCE MARKS 'PRETENDERS II'
description: The Pretenders, whose second album, ''Pretenders II'' (Sire/Warner Brothers), was released this week, are unusual for at least two reasons. Their guitarist, bassist and drummer are British, but their principal songwriter, lead vocalist and rhythm guitarist is an American woman, Ohio-born Chrissie Hynde. And at a time when seasoned performers dominate rock as never before, the Pretenders, none of whom had enjoyed a previous recording career, have been an overnight success, with a string of hit singles and a debut album that went platinum in the United States and entered the British best seller charts at number one.

title: WOMEN IN ARTS BRIGHTEN A BLANK WALL
description: ''IS that graffiti?'' asked a youngster riding his bike near the railroad station on Marmaroneck Avenue. ''No, but it's a good question,'' said Barbara Chen, one of the women who was standing on a metal-and-wood scaffold painting the wall near the station's underpass in broad daylight.

title: ST. BENEDICT'S PREP: AN URBAN SUCCESS STORY
description: NEWARK ONE of the first things Abbot Melvin Valvano did after St. Benedict's Prep reopened here in 1973 was to have the exterior of the old school and monastery buildings sandblasted and repointed, an uplifting that represented an investment of more than just mortar and brick.

title: PART 2 OF REAGAN AGENDA SOMEHOW LOOKS FAMILIAR
description: For months now, Ronald Reagan's White House has had its mind fastened on the President's economic program. In fact, Mr. Reagan's ceremonial signing of his package of budget cuts and tax cuts was billed as the occasion for a long-awaited shift of focus.

title: SPACECRAFT NEAR SATURN STILL GETS JUPITER DATA
description: Although Voyager 2 flew by Jupiter two years ago and is now approaching Saturn, several times in recent months the American spacecraft has reported data coinciding with those on the environment of Jupiter, an occurrence that project scientists said last week was giving them a new appreciation of the vast interplanetary reach of Jupiter's magnetic influence.

title: Westchester Guide; FIVE TO VIE FOR PODIUM
description: Five young conductors will take turns leading the Westchester Symphony Orchestra's 1981-82 concert series. At the end of the season one of them will be chosen to head the orchestra.

title: BLAZE IN WEST SIDE TOWER SENDS FIERY DEBRIS BELOW
description: A three-alarm fire last evening spewed flaming lumber and metal debris from the top of an unfinished apartment tower onto the roofs and balconies of adjacent buildings and into the streets some 40 stories below.

title: MONEY PLAYING A BIGGER ROLE IN JAPANESE POLITICS
description: Government figures released last week indicate that money is playing an increasingly major role in Japanese politics.

title: MRS. INKSTER KEEPS GOLF TITLE
description: Juli Inkster sank putts for birdies on the final two holes today to defeat Lindy Goggin of Australia and win the United States Women's Amateur golf championship for the second consecutive year.

title: POLICE USE DOLLS IN CHILD SEX CASES
description: The police officers, shifting nervously in their chairs at the beginning of the four-hour training session on sexual abuse of children, were caught off guard when the speaker started undressing anatomically complete rag dolls and tossing them at the audience.

title: JAPANESE BEETLE BEGINS YEARLY ONSLAUGHT
description: THE suburban homeowner, scarcely recovered from this summer's gypsy moth onslaught of trees, now can find the garden besieged by yet another uninvited guest, the Japanese beetle. Lacy skeleton-like plants, chewed flower petals and half-eaten berries and fruits are signs that this pest is at work. The adult beetles emerged from their larval or grub stage about the middle of last month in our area, and are at their peak activity. Since both vegetables and flowering annuals are also in their prime, it is small comfort to learn that the chewing stage lasts from four to six weeks.

title: Fashion; NEW ARCHITECTS OF FASHION
description: Sometimes fashion happens when no one is watching. While in the past five years, for example, an enormous amount of attention has been lavished on pumps and ruffles, two new designers have quietly emerged on the scene so conceptually full-grown and markedly different from their brethren that even the stodgier members of the fashion establishment have been forced to sit up in the collective club chair and pay attention. And if two is a trend, then Ronaldus Shamask and Gianfranco Ferre may signal that a new kind of fashion designer is afoot, one who finds design solutions considerably more attractive than furbelows.

title: Amber Pass, $8.40, Wins
description: Amber Pass pulled ahead in the stretch and captured the $284,300 Monmouth Handicap by two lengths at Monmouth Park today.

title: M. R. Werner Is Dead; Biographer and Editor
description: M. R. Werner, a biographer and historian, died at Lenox Hill Hospital on Aug. 5. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan. Mr. Werner was probably best known for his biographies of Horace Greeley, William Jennings Bryan, P. T. Barnum and Julius Rosenwald, the philantropist.

title: IRAN SAYS THE C.I.A. ARRANGED EXILES' HIJACKING OF GUNBOAT
description: Iran today accused the Central Intelligence Agency of arranging the hijacking of an Iranian patrol boat by Iranian exiles.

title: BRITONS BRISTLE AT BBC'S PLANNED BUDGET CUTS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic policies have inflamed passions across the land, but rarely has so much heat, drama and political intrigue been generated over so little money as in the case of a proposed cutback involving the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: TV PRODUCERS HAVE THEIR EYE ON THE BIG APPLE
description: Early in 1980, Mayor Edward Koch wrote a letter to Nancy Littlefield, who as director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting has had conspicuous success in luring movie production, with all its jobs and tax revenues, to the city. ''Dear Nancy,'' he wrote. ''You're doing a tremendous job bringing feature films back to New York ...but what about television?''

title: MALTBIE SHOOTS A 64 FOR 2-STROKE LEAD
description: Roger Maltbie, four strokes off the pace at the start of the third round today, shot a seven-under 64 and took a two-stroke lead in the $300,000 Greater Hartford Open golf tournament.

title: STRONG MET HURLING SUBDUES PHILS, 3-1
description: Terry Leach, making his first major league start, held the Phillies to three hits, only one of them solid, and no earned runs in five innings last night as the Mets scored a 3-1 victory over Philadelphia at Shea Stadium.

title: WHICH AGENCIES SERVE CHILDREN
description: The Division of Youth and Family Services is the children's protective services agency of the state's Department of Human Services.

title: ARMY DOMINATES SALVADOR'S 'MARRIAGE'
description: ''It's a marriage of convenience,'' United States Ambassador Deane R. Hinton said during a recent interview in San Salvador. ''An unnatural alliance,'' was a business leader's description.

title: Rodgers Finishes First In Stockholm Marathon
description: Bill Rodgers wore down Dick Beardsley wih a grueling pace after the midway point and went on to win his first Stockholm Marathon today in record time.

title: 'NEW FEDERALISM' GETS DOWN TO CASES
description: When the nation's governors gathered last weekend in Atlantic City, no one expected much talk about anything other than the coming cuts in Federal aid. That had been the case this summer whenever city, county and state officials had gathered, and there was no reason to think the annual meeting of the National Governors' Association would be any different.

title: Sports of The Times; Chinaglia, Most Valuable
description: IT is time to end the injustice against Giorgio Chinaglia. For the last six seasons Chinaglia has been the highest scorer for the most successful team in the North American Soccer League, but he has never won the most valuable player award.

title: Roth Article Called Unfair to Brittain
description: Perhaps Sondra G.S. Bleich is right (Opinion page, July 26) about Philip Roth and what has happened to the Weequahic girls, cheated by the 1950's of their due.

title: A WEEK OF TOUGH CHOICES IN DEFENSE AND DIPLOMACY
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT Reagan's decision to order assembling and stockpiling of neutron weapons - overruling arguments for delay by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. - had many members of Washington's diplomatic community asking last week, ''Who's in charge of foreign policy here?'' The President's action had the effect, at least for the present, of diminishing Mr. Haig's standing and elevating Secretary of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, who had successfully argued for going ahead with the neutron bomb.

title: CHINA'S SONGBIRDS AND PEOPLE HAVE NEW REASONS TO SING
description: It is 5 o'clock on a misty, dewy and unusually placid August morning. Old men in shorts are filtering into city parks to walk their birds and young boys are crouching in the first high grass in decades in search of crickets.

title: Antiques; BILLIARD TABLES FOR LOVERS OF FINE WOODWORKING
description: even in the workshop, warehouse and salesroom of a home for old pool tables.

title: Eye to Eye
description: As a ''blooded veteran of New York's guerrilla life,'' I must take issue with Russell Baker's belief that ''the rule of survival is never look anyone in the eye'' (''Instinct for Survival,'' July 26). I was a resident of New York City for 25 years and am still employed there; direct eye contact with a suspicious-looking individual definitely has its place.

title: THE NEWS AT NEWPORT: JAZZ IS BACK IN TOWN
description: Jazz in Newport struck a sour note 10 years ago, and it has taken until now to ease the ill feeling that drove America's first great outdoor music event out of town.

title: IN WHITE PLAINS, SOFTBALL IS QUEEN
description: WHITE PLAINS IN the last few years, interest in women's softball has grown to such an extent that there are now 40 teams competing in this city. ''The recent surge in softball among the women has given us a lot of satisfaction,'' said Dan Miller, a recreation supervisor with the city's Department of Recreation. ''The sport has really taken off. It's gone from almost nonexistant four years ago to a level in which we find ourselves hard-pressed to provide enough playing fields.''

title: ARMY PLANS TWO DIVISIONS TO CARRY OUT NEW STRATEGY
description: The Army's Chief of Staff, General Edward C. Meyer, says that the Army expects to add two divisions to its active force and two divisions to the National Guard by the end of the fiveyear plan being drawn up in the Pentagon.

title: The World in Summary; French Allowed To Leave Iran
description: France, Iranian President Mohammed Ali Rajai said last week, is turning into ''a second America.'' Demanding the extradition of ousted President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, Iranian spokesmen pointedly reminded Paris of Washington's hostage ordeal when it extended hospitality to the Shah.

title: The World in Summary; Burned Out but Not Moved Out
description: The laws of economics and of human relations keep defeating South African attempts to limit migration by black laborers and their families from impoverished tribal ''homelands'' to the cities. Last week, the police again destroyed a shanty town outside Cape Town that has been home to several hundred of the thousands of ''illegal'' migrants in the area.

title: Sundays at the Bronx Zoo
description: I agree with Michael Wright's article about the Bronx Zoo (''Zoo to the World,'' July 19).

title: Hardy Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookshelf; PILGRIMAGES AND NOSTALGIA
description: In February 1858, a 14-year-old girl named Bernadette Soubirous was out collecting firewood when, she reported, the Virgin Mary appeared to her in a grotto above a rose bush. It was the first of 18 such apparitions; by the time they ended, in July of the same year, crowds were accompanying the girl to the grotto, and souvenir hawkers were working the crowds. In the course of her visions, Bernadette unearthed a spring; a popular cult arose, based upon the belief in the healing powers of the Lourdes waters. In 1862 the bishop of Tarbes authorized the formal veneration of Our Lady of Lourdes, and what had been an obscure provincial town was on its way to becoming the greatest pilgrimage site of western Europe.

title: The Madeleine
description: To the Editor:

title: NJ TRANSIT CAUTIOUS ON TESTS
description: PROBLEMS surrounding the controversial purchase of 271 Grumman Flxible buses by NJ Transit, New Jersey's mass transit corporation, have made the public a bit jittery about the $38 million being spent on the buses.

title: I.R.A. MEMBER WINS EXTRADITION CASE IN U.S.
description: An effort to extradite a member of the Irish Republican Army accused of shooting a British soldier has been rejected by a Federal magistrate who ruled that the case involved ''a relatively political offense.''

title: Mary Margaret Van Buren Married To Michael Wilkinson in Greenwich
description: Mary Margaret Van Buren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin E. Van Buren of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Michael Wilkinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wilkinson Jr. of Quaker Hill, Conn.

title: About Westchester
description: PORT CHESTER FEW of the activities that call to mind small-town America are as evocative as the band concert. Whether a few musicians in a latticework gazabo, or a big brass orchestra stretched across the village green, it is an image rooted in an idealized view of an earlier time.

title: SEAFOOD DELIGHTS ON THE NORTH FORK
description: ONE of the most appealing waterfront settings on the Island is at the Oyster Factory restaurant in Greenport. The weathered, rustic barnlike structure, once the site of an oyster processing plant, overlooks the docks and harbor, busy with the regular activity of the Shelter Island ferry. Tables covered with flower-sprigged cloths have a view of the bay and not of the parking lot, as at many other restaurants situated on the water.

title: JUDGE ASSAILS LAW IN THROWING OUT GUN CASE
description: The case against two women charged with illegally carrying a firearm has been thrown out by a judge who determined that their 26 3/8-inch-long sawed-off shotgun was too long to be considered ''concealable.''

title: TASK FORCE AWAITS INDIAN POINT PLAN
description: ALTHOUGH emergency warning sirens are now being mounted on 60-foot poles throughout a 10-mile area surrounding the Indian Point nuclear-power facilities, the approved emergency-notification and evacuation plan mandated by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is still lacking.

title: ELAINE BENSON: DOYENNE OF ART
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON HER full name is Elaine Klebanoff Goff Benson Kaufman. Her pen name is Elaine K.G. Benson. But to most people who know her - and to a lot of name droppers who wish they did - she is simply Elaine, owner of the leading art gallery in the Hamptons, as well as a widely read weekly newspaper columnist and a fund-raising force at Southampton Hospital.

title: Theater; HE CAN'T STOP PLAYING 'ENRY 'IGGINS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Patricia Bosworth is the author of ''Montgomery Clift, a Biography.'' By PATRICIA BOSWORTH BOSTON

title: Cecile Joan Cooke Bride Of Anthony Thompson
description: Cecile Joan Cooke, daughter of Dr. Edwin B. Cooke of Richmond and the late Poppy Bontemps Booker, was married yesterday to Anthony DeCarselle Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francois DeCarselle Thompson of Washington. The Rev. James Joy performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Washington.

title: ENERGETIC QUESTIONS AND
description: ANSWERS ENERGY AND SECURITY Edited by David A. Deese and Joseph S. Nye. 489 pp. Cambridge: Ballinger Publishing Co. $16.50. ARAMCO, THE UNITED STATES, AND SAUDI ARABIA A Study of the Dynanmics of Foreign Oil Policy, 1933-1950. By Irvine H. Anderson. 259 pp. Princeton: Princeton University Press. $18.50. OUR ENERGY: REGAINING CONTROL A Strategy for Economic Revival Through Redesign in Energy Use. By Marc H. Ross and Robert H. Williams. 354 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill. $16.95.

title: Stuart Guy Tipton, 70; Air Transport Official
description: Stuart Guy Tipton, former president and chairman of the Air Transport Association and a senior vice president of Pan American World Airways, died yesterday at George Washington University Hospital here. He was 70 years old.

title: ERIC GUTTERSON FIANCE OF ELIZABETH M. BOLES
description: Dr. and Mrs. Russell Sage Boles Jr. of Osterville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Middleton Boles, to Eric Norman Gutterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lindsley Gutterson Jr. of Siasconset, Mass.

title: ISRAEL'S ULTRA- ORTHODOX ARE BATTLING ARCHEOLIGISTS DIGGING FOR CITY OF DAVID
description: A violent dispute has broken out between archeologists and ultra-Orthodox Jews over an excavation south of the walled Old City of Jerusalem.

title: U.S. TRANSFER OF NERVE GAS IS PRAISED BY UTAH AIDE
description: The director of the State Health Department has praised the Army for safety precautions taken in moving a cache of nerve gas bombs, among the deadliest in the nation's arsenal, to this depot.

title: 11 COUNTIES WIN BATTLE FOR LOWER ELECTRIC BILLS
description: NEWARK AN agreement that will shift part of the next Public Service Electric and Gas rate increase away from counties and municipalities and onto large industries will be signed next week by the participating parties in the utility's current rate case.

title: Mary S. McGoldrick Wed To Stephen Michael Grant
description: Mary Stuart McGoldrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McGoldrick of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Stephen Michael Grant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Grant of Paramus, N.J. The Rev. Henry A. Albeke performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Embattled Press
description: ''To the I.R.S. - 'Nuts!!!' '' With this front-page headline, the Rev. Brian Wallace, editor of Today's Catholic, the official weekly newspaper of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of San Antonio, flung down the gauntlet before the Internal Revenue Service in June 1980.

title: Horowitz Fabrics Offers a Wide Mixture
description: Since 1913, Horowitz Brothers Fabrics has been supplying those who sew at home and offering home-decorating choices for custom-made draperies and upholstery. All this happens from a building opened in 1891 on Chapel Street with the first Otis electrical safety elevator in New Haven. The elevator still works and so does the Horowitz mixture of fabrics, notions, patterns, placemats and men's clothing, including irregular shirts with labels removed - still at $4 and regularly supplied by a former New Haven manufacturer who moved to Pennsylvania six months ago. Other Horowitz fabric shops are in Milford, Guilford and Hamden, but they do not carry clothing.

title: CONTROLLERS IN AZORES SET BOYCOTT BUT ATLANTIC FLIGHTS ARE REROUTED
description: Portugal's 300 air traffic controllers planned to begin a 48-hour boycott tonight of flights to and from the United States, but the action in support of their striking American colleagues was not expected to disrupt trans-Atlantic air travel seriously.

title: Paperback Talk
description: The movie tie-in game. If you study the large display ads and posters touting the new movies these days, you're apt to find, at the bottom in tiny type, a legend reading ''Novelization from Ballantine Books,'' or ''Based on the Avon Book'' or the like. Every summer and at Christmas time, many publishers get involved in the movie tie-in game, issuing books that are associated in some way with current films.

title: 'Managing Wildlife' Termed Not Natural
description: The article ''Wildlife Havens in the Yard,'' (July 26) by Suzanne DeChillo was a dichotomy and a paradox, and mirrored the misconceptions instilled by so called authorities.

title: Cables' Failure Delays Conrail Trains 2 Hours
description: A power failure in three feeder cables in the Bronx halted train service yesterday morning on Conrail's New Haven Division, stranding 1,400 passengers for more than two hours.

title: Jennifer Geer Wed To William Bilbao
description: Jennifer Clayton Geer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Farr Geer of Manhattan, was married yesterday to William Eugenio Bilbao, son of Mr. and Mrs. Santiago P. Bilbao of Silver Lake, S.I. The Rev. Paul F.M. Zahl performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: TV View; CABLE TV--WHO'S MINDING THE CHILDREN?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kate Moody is the author of ''Growing Up on Television.'' John J. O'Connor is on vacation. By KATE MOODY

title: John Pickering 2d Weds Miss Bagoly
description: Emily J. Bagoly, daughter of Lewis Bagoly of Valley Forge, Pa., and Mrs. Wallace Chambers of Charlestown, Pa., was married in Waldoboro, Me., yesterday to John Pickering 2d, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Timothy Pickering of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Friendship, Me. The bridegroom's father, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, performed the ceremony at the Old German Church.

title: Headliners; And Good Luck
description: If past is prologue, Robin H.H. Wilson would do well to brace for a rough and possibly brief ride.

title: Essay; THE SACKING BOMB
description: ''I have bad news for you,'' the pilot of a Pan Am flight told his passengers awaiting takeoff in Washington. ''This plane is going nowhere.''

title: CAPSULE HOTELS CATCH ON WITH THE JAPANESE
description: In some of Japan's most up-to-date hotels, a guest turns off his color television set, switches on the radio for bedtime music, sets his built-in digital alarm clock for the morning, folds his arms behind his head and looks at the ceiling waiting for sleep.

title: Cup Sailing Plans Take Shape
description: The Independence Syndicate has announced a series of ambitious plans, including the first large-scale model tank testing for 12-Meter yachts and the building of at least one new boat for the next America's Cup defense in 1983 off Newport, R.I.

title: New Jersey Guide; AN ELIZABETHAN FAIR
description: For the last few years, as the summer has peaked, an enclave from Elizabethan England has appeared amid the 65 acres of hills, lakes, meadows and gardens of Sterling Forest, just over the state line in Rockland County.

title: REAGAN LEANING TO EASING RULES FOR ATOM POWER
description: The Reagan Administration's long-awaited policy on nuclear power, to be announced next month, will specify the President's intention to ''move expeditiously but wisely'' to remove governmental barriers to the wider use of nuclear energy, according to a draft of his statement.

title: PRODUCER PRICES: CONTINUED EASING OF INFLATION
description: When I.B.M. announced last week that it was entering the personal computer market, many already in the market welcomed the move, saying it put the stamp of legitimacy on the young industry and that sales would improve.

title: THE OPTIONS ON STOCK OPTIONS: A PRIMER
description: Of all the ways investors have of losing money in the stock market, none is as common as ''lost opportunity.'' This is how professional money managers describe investments that are not earning the current available rate of interest. Today, this rate, based on money market funds, is nearly 18 percent on an annual basis.

title: BONN NEEDS THE BUSINESS EVEN MORE THAN THE GAS
description: Under conflicting international and economic pressures made more acute by record unemployment, West Germany appears determined to go ahead with the projected $10 billion pipeline to bring Siberian natural gas to Europe.

title: SLIDE SHOW
description: MIRACLE PLAY By Susan Richards Shreve. 321 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.95.

title: The World in Summary; Israel Getting Out Of Penalty Box
description: The diplomatic distance opened by Israel's raid on an Iraqi nuclear reactor and bombing of civilians in Beirut should narrow early this week when President Reagan is expected to lift his suspension on the delivery to Israel of 16 jet fighters.

title: Antiques; A BOGART LETTER RIVALS A LINCOLN NOTE
description: Is a Humphrey Bogart letter worth more than one from Abraham Lincoln? Charles Hamilton, the autograph dealer and auctioneer, thinks it is - or soon will be. In fact, he says, the time is coming when the autographs of many of the top movie stars will command more than those of United States presidents.

title: TV's Ed Asner Joins Picketing Controllers
description: Ed Asner, the Emmy Award-winning actor, joined picketing air traffic controllers yesterday at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: 8-CONCERT SERIES FOR THE NEW HAVEN
description: WITH the downbeat on Oct. 6, Murry Sidlin begins his fifth season as music director of the New Haven Symphony. But for many more years than that, the maestro has been summering at the Aspen, Colo., Music Festival, first as a student, later as a teacher, and now as resident faculty conductor. Since I have also been spending a couple of weeks in Aspen these last few years, moderating panels at the festival, I like to track down the maestro in reasonably relaxed circumstances and get an early view of the forthcoming orchestral year in New Haven.

title: AIR STRIKE: EFFECTS CUT ALONG L.I.
description: ON the Island, the home of more air traffic controllers than anywhere else in the nation, the controllers' strike was greeted with the fury of a feud between the McCoys and the Hatfields. Air freight executives and commercial pilots in summer homes on the North Fork applauded the Reagan Administration's efforts to dismiss the controllers for taking part in an illegal strike. Elsewhere on the Island, would-be passengers said that the controllers deserved better working conditions.

title: Zimbabweans to Change Capital's Name to Harare
description: The name of this capital city will soon be changed to Harare, the name of a Shona tribal chief who was living here when white settlers arrived in 1890.

title: Article 234770 -- No Title
description: Legal fees and court expenses have mounted to at least $4.3 million in the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League, in which a mistrial was declared last week, parties to the suit have estimated.

title: RELIGIOUS AND CHARITY GROUPS SEE GOOD AND BAD IN TAX LAW
description: The budget and tax-cutting measures signed into law this week by President Reagan will have contradictory effects on churches and other nonprofit groups, according officials of religious and charitable organizations.

title: The Region in Summary; Deciding Where To Draw the Lines
description: Even a ''live-and-let-live'' redistricting plan can be fatally flawed, groups challenging New York's new City Council district map have said. The Justice Department showed interest in the complaint of racial gerrymandering and last week asked those responsible for the plan to defend their cartography.

title: A RESURGENCE IN WALLEYE POPULATION
description: The walleye fishery in Lake Ontario and the nearby St. Lawrence River is on the mend. And on Lake Erie, where a decade ago walleye populations had plummeted to incredibly low levels, the sport and commercial fishery for the species in the lake's western basin, or end, is probably the most productive in the world.

title: A DAY WITH A SOVIET DISSIDENT ARTIST
description: IAM sitting in the apartment of one of the world's foremost collectors and exhibitors of Soviet dissident (nonofficial) art. He is teaching me Russian. On the record player is Russian gypsy music.

title: APPLAUSE FOR THE 'INCENTIVE' STOCK OPTION
description: FOR business executives, one of the most far-reaching provisions of the tax legislation just enacted is the creation of a new compensation tool, the ''incentive'' stock option. It is being welcomed as the reincarnation of a familiar friend.

title: Officer Weds Helen Pirtle
description: The marriage of Helen Louise Pirtle to Second Lieut. Rex Alan Russell, U.S.A., took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: Gallery View; LEGER'S CONTAGIOUS ENTHUSIASM
description: This year's unsung centenarian is the great French painter Fernand Leger, who was born on a farm in Argentan, in Normandy, in February 1881 and died near Paris in August 1955. Neither in France nor anywhere else - except perhaps at the Leger Museum in Biot, near Antibes - has the anniversary aroused much attention. The big, fat, decisive book has yet to appear, and it is a little too early for the big, fat, decisive exhibition. But the scale and the variety of Leger's activity were such that it would be outrageous for the centenary to pass unnoticed.

title: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Producer prices rose at a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in July, indicating a continued easing in inflation. The Government said the increase would have been the lowest since last fall save for a surge in prices for pork.

title: FOR JOHN KENNEDY JR., A SEASON IN THE CAPITAL ENDS
description: Toward the end of summer, scores of university students who annually flood the nation's capital for three months of work in Congressional offices, law firms and policyresearch organizations begin heading back to their campuses. Among them this year is John F. Kennedy Jr., who left this week after his first season here in 17 years.

title: HARDY COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Flournoy Bride of a Lawyer
description: Victoria Fox Flournoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Flournoy, was married yesterday in the Princeton University Chapel to Kevin Edward McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McCarthy Jr. Both families are of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Charles B. Weiser, Roman Catholic chaplain at the university, performed the ceremony.

title: THE COUNTY AIRPORT 'SETTLED DOWN NOW'
description: The volume of air traffic at the County Airport has dipped about 20 percent below normal levels since the air traffic controllers went on strike Aug. 3, the airport's assistant manager reported last week.

title: LONG ISLAND RESORTS FOR SALE--BY THE WEEK
description: Two resorts on Long Island - Gurney's Inn in Montauk and East Hampton House in East Hampton - are testing the market to see how many vacationers might be willing to pay as much as $19,800 to have the exclusive right to use the same room, the same week, every year.

title: RING IN COLUMBIA KIDNAPS CHILDREN FOR SALE ABROAD
description: The authorities have uncovered a multimillion dollar international ring in which hundreds of poor Andean children were kidnapped or bought from their mothers and sold under forged birth certificates and adoption papers to childless couples from the United States and Europe.

title: Fallout From the Air
description: The first tangible benefit from President Reagan's hard line on the air controllers' walkout may be felt in an unexpected place - underground.

title: 15 Food Outlets Cited For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 15 food establishments it said had violated the health code. The department also released the names of two establishments that reopened after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for failing to do so.

title: THE FLOATING HAYSTACK
description: THE TIGRIS EXPEDITION In Search of Our Beginnings. By Thor Heyerdahl. Illustrated. 349 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95. By EVAN CONNELL

title: 150 NEW ZEALANDERS SEIZED IN RUGBY PROTEST
description: The police arrested 150 people in antiapartheid protests in three cities today as South Africa and New Zealand played their first international rugby match.

title: Widow of Joe Louis Assists Boxing Figure in Making Bail
description: Harold Rossfields Smith, a former boxing promoter who is under indictment in a $21.3 million embezzlement from the Wells Fargo Bank, was released from jail last night.

title: Pakistan Said to Free 8 Political Leaders
description: Pakistan's military authorities have released eight imprisoned political leaders, including three who served as Cabinet ministers under Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, official sources said here today.

title: Javelin Record Broken
description: Antoaneta Todorova of Bulgaria set a world record in the women's javelin with a throw of 235 feet 10 inches today at the European Track and Field Cup finals. Miss Todorova made the record throw in her third series.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ There have been very few bandleader-composers in jazz who have created a big band style and sound that is so idiomatically their own that it is immediately recognizable. The most eminent have been Duke Ellington, Gil Evans, the team of Eddie Sauter and Bill Finegan, and, most recently, Carla Bley.

title: Golda Meir Landmark Urged
description: The Denver Landmark Preservation Commission has passed a resolution urging that the former home of Golda Meir be designated a historical landmark. The commission said Monday that a house where the late Israeli Prime Minister lived from 1913 to 1915 was likely to qualify as a landmark.

title: Rice Crop Cut in China Area
description: Rain, typhoons, hail and insects have cut early rice production by 400,000 to 450,000 tons in Guangdong Province, the New China News Agency reported. But production of other crops has increased from last year, the agency said, with increases of 8.7 percent in peanuts, 8.6 percent in jute and 37.6 percent in tobacco. Tea and soybeans also increased, and a bumper harvest of sugar cane is expected.

title: HARBISON'S CONTINUING ASCENT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joan Peyser is the editor of Musical Quarterly and the author of two books on contemporary music. By JOAN PEYSER

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; The Daily News Says Goodbye To Tonight
description: The sound of afternoon newspapers falling is being heard in the land. Dust is settling on The Washington Star. The foundations of The Philadelphia Bulletin are rocking. And last week, New York's The Daily News, once the nation's largest newspaper, said it would abandon its year-old afternoon edition, Tonight, and lay off up to 10 percent of its 4,000-member staff.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE This week there will be a chance to catch up on dance that isn't seen all that often in and around New York. U.S. Terpsichore will be seen Monday in the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival at Damrosch Park. The young chamber ballet company's varied program includes the second act of ''Swan Lake,'' a new ballet by Broadway's Debbie Allen, and two works by company-choreographer Daniel Levans.

title: GOODBYE COLT .45, HELLO METRIC AT THE PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON When the biggest single buyer of handguns on this side of the Atlantic goes shopping for a new model, it is bound to arouse considerable interest. Also controversy, especially when it involves what American companies view as giving an unfair edge to their foreign competitors.

title: THE REAGAN PRESIDENCY IS 'RIGHT ON THE MARK'
description: To the Editor:

title: Interstate Highways
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 RIDERS HURT IN SPILL
description: One jockey was in critical condition today and two others suffered minor injuries after a three-horse spill at Playfair Race Course. Charlie Tohill was hospitalized with critical head and spinal injuries, according to a spokesman at Sacred Heart Medical Center. Connie Doll was in satisfactory condition with possible fractured ribs and Ricky Obrist was held for observation of minor injuries, officials said.

title: PUSHING THE MAXWELL PRODUCT AT GENERAL FOODS
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. JOHN SUSKO, as the photographs papering his office attest, has played on the Maxwell House football team. Also the softball team, the tennis team, the basketball team and the baseball team. At one time or another, he has captained them all.

title: WHAT FUTURE FOR THE P.M. PAPERS?
description: Between traffic problems and television, nobody can make any money with an afternoon newspaper any more. If you happen to own one, you can either wait until it goes bankrupt or cross your fingers and hope it survives being converted to a morning paper.

title: HOME FINANCE BECOMES AN ART
description: THE persistence of high interest rates has prompted home buyers and sellers to develop ever more imaginative ways to finance real-estate transactions.

title: Barbara Butler, Richard Devor Jr.  Have Nuptials
description: Barbara Allyn Butler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Butler Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Marion, Mass., was married at the Unitarian Memorial Church in Fairhaven, Mass., yesterday to Richard Campbell Devor Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Devor of East Lansing, Mich. The bridegroom's father, a Methodist clergyman and senior minister of the People's Church in East Lansing, performed the ceremony.

title: Realty News; Madison Avenue
description: Both the law firm of Seyfarth, Shaw, Fairweather & Geraldson and Credit Industriel et Commercial, a French bank, have leased two floors in the office tower under construction at 520 Madison Avenue.

title: Article 234874 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TROUBLES OF TIP O'NEILL
description: Martin Tolchin reports on the Congress for The New York Times. By Martin Tolchin The afternoon was cool and brilliantly clear for a summer day in Washington, but inside the House of Representatives, at the seat where Speaker Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr. sat in rumpled solitude, gloom was heavy in the air. On the floor, where members chatted or paced in the aisles, tension was palpable. When the Speaker finally rose and moved to the rostrum - a large familiar figure with a hank of off-white hair spilling across his forehead - Congressmen on both sides of the aisle stood to applaud him.

title: Loss Put at $4 Million In Riviera Jewel Theft
description: Jewels estimated by the police to be worth $4 million were stolen from the seaside villa of a Spanish princess in this year's biggest burglary on the Riviera, the police said today.

title: HASIDIC SUMMER CAMP, AT 25, TO DEDICATE OWN POST OFFICE
description: Rabbi Abraham Shemtov stood on a ladder leaning against the wall of a one-story, one-room wooden building here the other day, stapling to it a sign that read, ''Kiryat Gan Israel 12768.'' The Hebrew words mean, ''the village of Israel.''

title: WINCING NOW AT WAGE PRICE CONTROLS
description: Remembrance of the occasion is stirred by anniversary dates or chance meetings with individual participants. On the afternoon of Aug. 15, 1971, we all filed into Aspen Lodge, the Presidential living quarters at Camp David. The policy decisions had been confirmed, the necessary executive orders drafted, and the lyrics composed for the President's speech to the nation that night. All the elements of the New Economic Policy were in place - a comprehensive wage-price freeze, the suspension of the convertibility of the dollar for gold, the levying of a surcharge on imports, and various tax measures.

title: A BUSH LEAGUE PLAN, YES, BUT NOT SHAUGHNESSY'S
description: To the Sports Editor: I heartily agree with Red Smith ("1981-II*," The New York Times, Aug. 9) that the playoff system adopted for this season is bush league. But it is not a Shaughnessy playoff.

title: The Nation in Summary; Teamster Inquiry A Textbook Botch
description: Law officers and Congressional investigators have long regarded the teamsters' Central States Pension Fund as a $2.2 billion, poorly administered reservoir into which the hand of organized crime has been allowed to dip freely and deeply. The Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations charged last week that the Labor Department botched a ''historic opportunity'' to change all that.

title: On Language
description: Boll Weevils Whomp Gypsy Moths

title: THE AIR STRIKE IS OMINOUS FOR LABOR
description: I N every national administration, Republican as well as Democratic, since the Roosevelt New Deal, organized labor has been able to count on a White House insider high in the President's confidence to whom union leaders could turn as a trusted go-between whenever confrontations over breakdowns in collective bargaining threatened grave damage to nation and labor alike.

title: Television Week
description: The Monastic Life ABC's News Closeup unit has explored a subject it regards as unusual for network news, and is devoting 90 minutes to the result. The documentary is called ''The Monastery'' - scheduled Thursday at 9:30 P.M. - and it goes behind the cloistered walls of St. Joseph's Abbey in Spencer, Mass.

title: WOMEN WHO PLAY POOL PONDER THEIR PLACE IN THE GAME
description: Vicki Frechen is a college graduate who manages an insurance office, but she'd rather shoot pool. Gloria Walker wouldn't dream of missing a game of pool and so she brings her 6-month-old daughter on tour with her. Billie Clark is a grandmother who confides that occasionally she prefers her Buffalo pool hall to her grandchildren.

title: Film View; REELING WITH SURPRISE
description: Little surprises - breathes there a filmgoer who hasn't had his or her share? It might be that the well-publicized, well-paid star you came to see has received top billing for a nine-minute appearance (including three minutes' worth of shots of his back, which were done by a double). Or that the hilarious coming attractions for soand-so's new comedy have packed all the good jokes of an otherwise witless two hours into 30 seconds' time. Or maybe the reviews have made a film sound serious and important, while in reality the piefight sequence marks its most contemplative scene.

title: A BANNER SEASON FOR FLAGMAKERS, NOT FOR FANS
description: GOOD news for the hardworking men and women who make America's banners. With the decision of major league baseball owners to adopt a split season format for 1981, nearly a third of the 26 teams may have something besides the manager to hoist up their flagpoles next Opening Day. And while they may already be breaking out the champagne (splits, of course) in demi-pennant-winning New York and Oakland, Philadelphia and Los Angeles, I find myself less than thrilled by the change.

title: Dana G. Galbraith Marries Ginnie L. Schroth, Student
description: At Zion Lutheran Church in Oldwick, N.J., yesterday, Ginnie Lee Schroth, a student at San Diego State University, was married to Dana Gage Galbraith, a graduate of James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va. The Rev. Dennis Carroll performed the ceremony.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: It is a time-tested tale: Headstrong girl from small town bucks tradition, marries boss and uses wits and energy to get rich and famous. But Janet Dailey is very real indeed. Since the publication of her first book 60 titles and over 80 million copies ago, she has reportedly become America's best-selling romance novelist and the fifth best-selling author in the world. She is published in 17 languages and 90 countries, and ''This Calder Sky'' - a romantic adventure set in a larger-than-life American West - moves up this week to No. 1 on the trade paperback best-seller list less than four weeks after being shipped.

title: BUDGET GAP FOR U.S. EXPECTED TO TOP $60 BILLION IN '82
description: Less than a month after Congress approved his fiscal program of cuts in both spending and taxes, President Reagan is being told by budget advisers that the Federal deficit next year is likely to be as much as $20 billion over his original estimates. Administration officials said today that the increase is expected because of lagging economic conditions, high interest rates and other factors.

title: Television Week
description: Up in the Air ''It's not timely at all, really,'' said a spokesman for WNEW, which is not the sort of report a station usually gives about a documentary. He was explaining that a special scheduled on Channel 5 Sunday at 8 P.M., looking at the history of commercial air flight and its impact on people's lives, had no connection whatsoever with the air controllers' strike that has been having considerable impact of its own.

title: HARDY COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAINING AND TECHNOLOGY
description: William Stockton named the disease, but what is the fundamental cause? Armies of B.S. degree holders are indeed spurning the technical graduate schools and flocking to the business schools! They emerge clutching an engineering degree in one hand, an M.B.A. in the other and a copy of ''How to Dress for Success'' clamped between their teeth.

title: On Rezoning In Southampton
description: I must comment on the report prepared for the Southampton Town Planning Board by Mr. Van de Kieft and his planning staff (''Teamster Housing Plan Facing Rejection'').

title: Television Week
description: Prime-Time Captain An anniversary celebration seemed in order. For 25 years, the man with the blond bangs and sideburns and gentle manner - television's Captain Kangaroo - had appeared on the screen from 8 to 9 each weekday morning on CBS, reading a story to his young fans, telling how to make a boat from a shoebox or suffering a barrage of Ping-Pong balls dropped on him by Mr. Moose.
