title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: ''WATCH OUT FOR THE FOREIGN GUESTS!'' by Orville Schell. (Pantheon, $3.95.) Through a collage of verbal snapshots of encounters he had with people in Peking, Shanghai and other major Chinese cities during visits in the past half-dozen years, an American journalist records the cultural shock that contact with Westerners is having on citizens of the People's Republic. Our reviewer Allen S. Whiting called this ''a suggestive introduction to the difficulties that will face foreigners as well as Chinese if the next decade of transition is not to end in bitter retreat on both sides.''

title: U.S. DEAL EMBROILS TINY ISLAND NATION
description: With an election scheduled for Sept. 8, the Prime Minister of this tiny, impoverished South Pacific island nation is in serious political trouble over an investment deal with a California businessman involving more than $640,000 in Government funds.

title: Passwords
description: To the Business Editor: The article concerning computer security, ''Case of the Purloined Password'' (July 26), may have been a good piece of investigative reporting about the specific problems of one company, but it came across inaccurately as an indictment against the entire computerservices industry.

title: Ancient Wood Object Is Discoverd on Coast
description: Part of a tool that may be the oldest man-made wooden object in the world has been found by archeologists at a 10,000-year-old site on Olympic Peninsula in this state.

title: FOREIGNERS VITAL TO ZAIRE'S FORCES
description: The Belgians are here, training the 2,500 men of the 21st Brigade of Zaire's army. The French are doing something similar in Kinshasa, the capital, with the 31st Brigade.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: STEPPIN' OUT New York Nightlife and the Transformation of American Culture, 1890-1930. By Lewis A. Erenberg. 29l pp. Westport, Conn: Greenwood Press. $23.95.

title: Nine Policemen Injured In Liverpool Violence
description: Nine policemen were injured today as violence erupted in Liverpool's troubled Toxteth district during a march to protest ''police harassment,'' the authorities said.

title: THE MYSTERY OF A MISSING NATURALIST MAY LEAD TO LEGAL TEST OF DISMISSAL
description: The disappearance of a National Parks Service naturalist 19 months ago has become a mystery to Park Service officials, investigators and friends and relatives of the missing man. And what began as a search for him has evolved into a controversy over Government handling of the case.

title: WALTER MATTHAU: 'I'M SERIOUS WHEN I DO COMEDY'
description: Everyone in the 20th Century-Fox executive dining room seems to gravitate toward Walter Matthau. First Joseph Sargent, who directed him in ''The Taking of Pelham One Two Three,'' comes over, and they spend a few minutes comparing notes on their coronary bypass operations. Stanley Jaffe, the producer of ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' stops at the table to introduce Timothy Hutton, who played the troubled son in ''Ordinary People.'' ''The next time you do a picture with Hutton,'' Mr. Matthau instructs Mr. Jaffe, ''I want to be in it; I'll play his grandfather.'' A few minutes later producer Daniel Melnick and writer-director Buck Henry approach the actor. ''Am I in your next picture?'' Mr. Matthau asks the pair. Mr. Melnick jokes, ''First you have to lose the beard.'' ''No,'' Mr. Matthau replies. ''The beard makes me look less clownish, more heroic. Besides, I want Pauline Kael to see that my hair is real. She once accused me of having a bad toupee like John Wayne.'' Finally Marvin Davis, the new owner of the studio greets Mr. Matthau warmly before taking his own seat in the inner sanctum.

title: ORIGINALITY AT NEW EAST END GALLERIES
description: EAST HAMPTON AMONG the several new galleries that have opened in the Hamptons this season, three stand out for their special contribution to the local art scene. Two are outposts of Manhattan galleries and the third is not really a gallery at all, but rather an outdoor sculpture center of very special appeal.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 16, 1981
description: International Moscow took a conciliatory tone toward the Polish Communist Party's efforts to end months of turmoil in a communique that followed a meeting in the Crimea of Polish leaders with Leonid I. Brezhnev and other Soviet officials. The communique represented the Soviet Union as backing the Polish party's efforts to gain control of the domestic situation, and described the 24-hour meeting as having ''passed in an atmosphere of fraternal friendship and comradely mutual understanding.'' (Page 1, Column 1.) Full rapport with Chinese scholars that had been expected by American scientists and educators after the promises of good will and exchange of ideas made three years ago has not occurred. China is not cooperating, according to Americans, who say they are not being given access to the Chinese people and China's archives. American college leaders are talking about reconsidering their willingness to cooperate in the exchanges. (1:2.)

title: The World in Summary; U.S. Vetoes Loan for Guyana
description: In ideological as well as economic terms, the Reagan Administration aims to get its money's worth from foreign aid. It put its philosophy into practice last week by vetoing a $20 million loan from the Inter-American Development Bank to promote Guyanese rice production.

title: Three Youths Are Hurt In El Salvador Bombing
description: Four bombs exploded around the capital of San Salvador last night, and one of them seriously injured three young bystanders, residents said. Two shootouts between leftist guerrillas and army troops followed the blasts.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Good News on Grain

title: Topics; LIFE FORMS; An Ox Is Gaured
description: We had no sooner read the last page of a paperback bestseller titled ''The Cradle Will Fall''(evil doctor does big business in fetus transplants) than we read the story on the front page of The Times. There they were: Manhar, the transplanted embryo, and his ''mother,'' Flossie.

title: MOSTLY MOZART: PIANO AND CLARINET CONCERTOS
description: With three of New York's most respected and popular musicians in charge of the proceedings, the Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night could scarcely fail to give pleasure. Alexander Schneider conducted the orchestra, and, featured in a pair of Mozart concertos, the soloists for the evening were Richard Goode, pianist, and Richard Stoltzman, clarinetist - a sure guarantee of musical excellence.

title: Julia Loretta Egan Married
description: Julia Loretta Egan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Egan 3d of Weston, Conn., and Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday to John Harding Bishop Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bishop of Annisquam. The Rev. Myron F. Bullock performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Lanesville, Mass. The bride's father is vice president, institutional sales, with Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. in New York.

title: DIVORCE REFORM'S WARNING TO 'UPPITY' WOMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH RADIUM LEVELS FOUND IN 45 CAROLINA WATER SYSTEMS
description: Officials say that drinking water in 45 communities in North Carolina is contaminated with radioactivity, and one woman who bore a deformed child after drinking the water says she was warned too late.

title: Recordings; NEW DISKS PAY TRIBUTE TO SENIOR SINGERS
description: Bcause of the individuality, communicative immediacy and fragility of the human voice, great singers seem to inspire fiercer audience loyalties than other musicians, even when they are no longer in their youthful prime and more vulnerable to criticism. A number of recent recordings pay tribute to greatly admired senior singers, most of them lately retired. These homages to their special vocal talents give ample evidence of why they were held in such high esteem during the high noon of their careers.

title: DANNY KAYE: 'I'VE NEVER STUDIED CONDUCTING'
description: ''There was this pregnant woman once with the St. Louis Symphony.'' That's how the story began anyway. For the longest time, it wasn't clear how it ended or even if it ended, because Danny Kaye's sentences have a way of often not making it to the finish. Somewhere in the middle they stumble upon a series of pauses and ellipses, and before they can get going again they tend to reshape into something else entirely.

title: A LOYALIST REFLECTS ON THE REAGAN PLAN
description: President Reagan has been more successful in curbing growth of the Federal Government than anyone could possibly have expected six months ago. Having inherited a situation in which both Government spending and tax burdens were rising rapidly relative to the gross national product, he has achieved legislative successes in cutting spending and taxes that insure -absent any highly improbable event - that the ratio of both outlays and receipts to G.N.P. will be lower in 1984 than they are today.

title: SCHOOLBOY CRUELTY
description: SAKI A Life of Hector Hugh Munro. With Six Short Stories Never Before Collected. By A.J. Langguth. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. By VICTORIA GLENDINNING No anthology of 20th-century short stories seems complete without a piece by Saki, who in 1870 was born in Burma (where his father was Inspector General of Police) as Hector Hugh Munro. Although he wrote for adults, his stories used to be considered ideal reading for schoolboys; knowing a little about his life and personality - you only learn a little from this book, but it is enough -one wonders why.

title: Headliners; Parting Words
description: Custody battles, while never very pleasant, are even less so when nations join parents in the proceedings. So it was for Michael and Anna Polovchak, who returned to the Soviet Union last week, and their 13-year-old son, Walter Polovchak, who chose to remain in Chicago.

title: Previous Works
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MAYOR Fred Lager of Atlantic Beach is supporting the retention of the toll on the Atlantic Beach Bridge. The bridge is the only one in Nassau County that has a toll and is operated by the Nassau County Bridge Authority.

title: CLASSES FOR GIFTED STIR CONTROVERSY
description: A PROGRAM in the Three Village School District for children who have been designated as gifted and talented has become the focus of controversy. Some parents are calling the program elitist, and others are charging that it is funneling money away from the majority of students.

title: PROTEST OVER NUCLEAR PLANT NEAR OFFSHORE FAULT PLANNED
description: In a valley with a view of long-dead volcanic peaks, rows of tents and bare wooden lean-to frames await the ''troops'' in the next major battle against atomic power.

title: 6 Die at German Carnival
description: Several cars of a carnival ride slammed into a mobile crane early today, spilling riders to the ground. Six people were killed and 15 injured, the police said. The cars, which resembled space capsules and were part of a ride called "Skylab," collided with the arm of a crane that had been used to repair another ride.

title: DEPORTATION HEARING IS SET FOR JAILED IRANIANS
description: A tentative agreement that would have allowed 59 jailed Iranians to be released from a Federal prison here fell through yesterday, and deportation hearings were scheduled for Monday.

title: POLISH ARCHBISHOP VOWS TO CONTINUE HIS KEY ROLE
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, offering his first public sermon since he succeeded the late Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski as Primate of Poland, said today that he was confident that the church would continue to mediate confrontations between the state and its citizens.

title: Dining Out; SINGULARITY AMONG THE ANTIQUES
description: IN a bosky section of Rye, Milton Harbor Inn now occupies the roomy white Colonial that once housed the White Elephant. Studded with old sprawling mansions, many built as fashionable summer residences for the wealthy, this area enjoys a renewed popularity not unrelated to the recent refurbishing of nearby Playland and its increasing attractiveness as a family park. Thus encouraged, a number of restaurants opened a bit too soon over the last two years and failed. But given half a chance, a decent restaurant can usually hold its own through the whimsical calms and tempests of the economy. Milton Harbor Inn looks very much like a survivor.

title: PLAN WOULD TRIM PARKING SPACES
description: The parking industry, environmental groups and the Koch administration have reached a compromise on proposed rules for off-street parking in Manhattan south of 96th Street, sharply limiting the amount of new off-street parking that can be developed and calling for more exclusive use of that parking.

title: SUSPECT IN BRINK'S ROBBERY MISSING FULL YEAR
description: George Manuel Bosque, who wanted a career as policeman but became a security guard, marked an anniversary as a fugitive today. He is sought in one of the largest Brink's robberies in history.

title: Critics' Choices
description: MUSIC ''Ruddigore'' is Gilbert and Sullivan's venture into the Victorian world of witchcraft and the supernatural. The Light Opera of Manhattan will be presenting this nicely calculated combination of the eerie and the ridiculous beginning Wednesday and running through August 30.

title: PARTIES' WOES MARK PRIMARY DRIVE
description: CONTINUING turmoil in the Suffolk Republican Party and a lack of campaign finances in the Nassau Democratic Party were evident last week as the boards of elections in the two counties processed designating petitions and campaign financial reports for the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A Bundle of Joy At the Bronx Zoo
description: Flossie, a black and white Holstein resident at the Bronx Zoo, must have been one very surprised cow. Last week, after a gestation of 308 days, she gave birth to a 73-pound baby gaur - a wild ox native to India -and wildlife specialists everywhere cheered.

title: Around the Nation; Airmen in Vital Posts Linked to Sales of Drugs
description: Thirty-nine airmen, including 14 security policemen and nine who had access to sensitive information, are suspected of using or selling drugs at Offutt Air Force Base, the Air Force says.

title: CHURCH COUNCIL LIKELY TO REJECT AN APPLICANT
description: Top staff members at the National Council of Churches, the nation's largest ecumenical organization, say they expect the council to reject a membership application by the Universal Fellowship of Metropolitan Community Churches, a denomination that endorses homosexuality.

title: TAX ISSUE SPARKS DEMOCRAT DISUNITY
description: HARTFORD THE Democrats, who control the State Capitol, are now so divided over tax policy that the special legislative session scheduled for October appears destined to be the scene of protracted intra-party debate.

title: Topics; LIFE FORMS; Horse Power
description: After the City Council passed a bill requiring the licensing of horses and setting new regulations for their humane treatment, stable owners screamed that the $25 fee is too high and the protections too elaborate. ''What are they going to do for the horse?'' one asked.

title: THE BAR WEIGHS IN AS A FRIEND OF COURTS
description: When legislators return to Washington next month, they will face one of the most momentous constitutional issues to come before Congress in years. The question they will be weighing, through a series of bills, is whether Congress can - or should attempt to - restrict the Supreme Court and lower Federal courts from enforcing constitutional precedents with which a majority in Congress and the President disagree. Last week, in anticipation of the undoubtedly heated debates to come, the American Bar Association, meeting for its annual convention in New Orleans, offered some strong advice.

title: MOSCOW ADOPTING CONCILIATORY TONE IN TALK WITH POLES
description: Talks between Polish and Soviet leaders in the Crimea ended today with the publication of a strikingly conciliatory communique.

title: STRIKING CONTROLLERS LOSE SUPPORT
description: For a while last week, it appeared that the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization might pull out of its nose dive. In a show of support, Canadian controllers responsible for a band of busy airways over the North Atlantic refused to handle flights that were bound for or had originated in the United States. The results were long delays for thousands of travelers - a KLM airliner, for instance, took off from Amsterdam 30 hours late - and scores of canceled international flights. There was also speculation that the disruptions might force the Reagan Administration to moderate the tough, no-talks stance it has maintained from the start of the controllers' strike earlier this month.

title: Day Old Bread
description: To the Business Editor: I read the Personal Finance column, ''Reagan's Boon to Retirement Savings'' (Aug. 2), several times to no avail, hoping to find the little niche I fit into with the recent tax benefits. I am a retiree, single, living on a fixed civil service pension.

title: ROCK 'N' RETAIL: STYX ON TOUR Sutton
description: Tony Scherman is a reporter for The Record in Hackensack, N.J. By Tony Scherman igh above the ocean in Hollywood, Fla., Derek Sutton paced his hotel room, energetically criticizing the members of his profession. ''The music industry,'' he said, ''has traditionally been a bunch of whores, amateurs and egomaniacs. That must change. The fat years are gone. In order to survive as an industry, we've got to professionalize. I, for instance, am growing accustomed to seeing myself not merely as the manager of a rock band, but as executive vice president of a large-volume retail operation.'' The retail outfit to which Sutton was referring is Styx, a rock band he manages which is scheduled to appear this week at Madison Square Garden as part of a world tour. The ''Paradise Theater'' tour, billed as the largest in rock-music history, could bring the group $15 million in ticket sales. Their current ''Paradise Theater'' album on A&M Records has sold almost three million copies, and if it tops that mark, as it is expected to, the record will be Styx's fourth consecutive ''triple platinum'' album - something not even the Beatles or the Bee Gees ever accomplished. With assorted merchandise tie-ins, such as T-shirts and hats, the tour and album will gross $60 million worldwide this year, at a time when the industry as a whole is suffering a prolonged slump.

title: Rezoning Mitchel Field: The Effect on Water
description: The proposed rezoning of Mitchel Field (''Mall Plan Stirs Up a Storm'') to accommodate developers deserves the intense scrutiny of all residents of Nassau County since this proposed rezoning from lowdensity residential to office and commercial may affect their drinking habits.

title: WATT ACTS TO ASSURE SURVIVAL OF ALASKA'S HUMPBACK WHALES
description: James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, has disclosed plans to help assure survival of the badly depleted humpback whale population.

title: GIRL MOTHERS
description: BABY LOVE By Joyce Maynard. 244 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. By ANNE TYLER

title: BASIC SKILLS DE-EMPHASIZED
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH public education in New Jersey will be changing its focus from basic skills to school leadership and social programs, state officials say, basic skills programs and testing will remain intact this year,

title: Diane Fraher, Teacher, Wed to B.M. Grobman
description: The marriage of Diane Fraher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Fraher of Oklahoma City, to Bernard Michael Grobman, son of Morris Grobman of New York and the late Sylvia Grobman, took place yesterday. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher performed the Roman Catholic cermony in the chapel at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York.

title: SUNDAYS AT THE BRONX ZOO
description: I wonder whether it is lack of access rather than lack of interest that is responsible for the drop in attendance at the Bronx Zoo? When I was a child, the treat of the week was to go, with my sister and parents, to the Bronx Zoo on Sunday afternoons and have an ice-cream cone afterward. In those days, admission to the zoo was free (the three days when no admission is charged at the zoo now do not include Sunday, when more working people can go on such outings), subway and bus fare were a nickel a ride, and ice-cream cones were 10 cents.

title: A LITTLE GOOD NEWS IN WAGES
description: While the recent deceleration in price inflation has been welcome news, economists have said that they doubted the downturn would continue unless wage gains began to slow, too. Now there is evidence of a slowing in wage growth.

title: Lusyd Wright Doolittle Is Married To P. Nicholas Kourides, a Lawyer
description: At the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Buffalo yesterday, Lusyd Wright Doolittle, a June graduate of Yeshiva University's Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, was married to P. Nicholas Kourides, an associate with the New York law firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates. The Rev. Thomas P. Stewart performed the ceremony.

title: ATHLETES' SALERIES: HOW HIGH WILL THE BIDDING GO?
description: C RAIG SWAN is paid more than twice as much as Ron Guidry. The Milwaukee Brewers are lending Robin Yount between $400,000 and $700,000 - at 3.5 percent interest. Gary Matthews's agent got a direct payment of $116,750. Steve Stone gets a private room on the road. And Barry Foote's wife got $10,000 for school.

title: Wine; A PREMIUM RED FROM THE WEST
description: The words beau lieu in French mean beautiful place, and that is what it is, this oasis amid the vines in the heart of the Napa Valley, a place where some extraordinary American wines are made.

title: THE UNSEEN BURDEN
description: The conclusions reached in your article, ''The Quiet Repeal of the Corporate Income Tax'' (Aug. 2), are dangerously misleading. The article falls into the familiar trap of failing to recognize that the reporting of corporate profits has been severely distorted by inflation.

title: E.F. HUTTON'S ENTRY INTO GENETIC ENGINEERING
description: Just two weeks ago, E. Russell Eggers was on top of the world. Mr. Eggers, a seasoned corporate executive with impressive credentials, was chief executive of a company that hoped to bring a new management concept and sound financing to the aborning world of biogenetics.

title: FOR PETE ROSE, THE BIG THING IS TO PLAY THE GAME
description: Pete Rose was waiting his turn beside the batting cage at Shea Stadium Friday night when he was asked, ''Now that you finally got the hit that makes you the most prolific batter in National League history, do you think you can still maintain the same intensity the rest of the season?''

title: Roberta Hornig Married
description: Roberta Hornig, a former member of the national staff of The Washington Star, was married in Washington yesterday to Morris Draper, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs.

title: BARGAINERS MEET ON SAVING PAPER
description: As they have for 134 years, newsroom employees sat down at their desks and others staffed the presses at The Bulletin today. But this time just about everyone had an ear cocked for news to stimulate rising hopes that their newspaper would survive beyond the Sunday edition they were preparing to publish.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BERLIN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ELLEN LENTZ contributes to The Times from Berlin. By ELLEN LENTZ

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Poland is like a boat on a rough sea, tossed up and down and sideways. So now the rudder is being grabbed, and some are pulling one way and others are pulling it in another.'' -Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate. (8:2.)

title: Oil Workers' School to Open
description: A school for oilfield roustabouts, in big demand because of the drilling boom set off by the decontrol of petroleum prices, is scheduled to open this fall and is guaranteeing jobs for all successful graduates.

title: DANELO'S FIELD GOAL DEFEATS COLTS, 20-17
description: The Giants won their second straight National Football League exhibition game tonight, but they took their time doing it. They beat the Baltimore Colts, 20-17, on Joe Danelo's 29-yard field goal with three seconds left.

title: MICKEY SHULER HURT
description: In an exhibition game that took on ominous overtones for the Jets, the Falcons scored a 21-20 victory tonight. Beyond the score was the potentially serious weakening of the Jets' offense with the loss, for perhaps as long as two months, of the tight end Mickey Shuler, who suffered a separated shoulder.

title: Sound; NEW INDOOR ANTENNAS AID FM
description: Everyone knows about the unsuitability of sows' ears for making silk purses. Similarly, you can't get clean sound from a dirty signal. That's why some audio experts flatly declare that no FM receiver can be any better than the antenna to which it is connected.

title: 400 JOIN IN A RALLY AT KENNEDY FOR CONTROLLERS
description: Four hundred unionists, most of them air traffic controllers, marched in picket lines at Kennedy International Airport yesterday to show their support for the nationwide strike by the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization.

title: A MODEST U.S. DEFICIT
description: Although traders in financial markets, monetary economists and some members of the Reagan Administration seem worried about the inflationary impact of further Government deficits, that prospect has not seemed to upset foreign exchange markets, where the dollar remains strong. Part of the reason, according to economists at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, is an awareness that many other countries face more serious fiscal problems than the United States.

title: AUTHORS AND PARENTS: 'BE MORE LIKE GRAHAM GREENE, DEAR'
description: ''IT is quite natural for you not to like the book, and I regret your reading any book that causes you pain or disgust,'' Ernest Hemingway wrote his mother of ''The Sun Also Rises.'' ''We have different ideas about what constitutes good writing - that is simply a fundamental disagreement - but you really are deceiving yourself if you allow any Fanny Butchers (a Chicago book reviewer) to tell you that I am pandering to sensationalism etc. etc. ... You may never like any thing I write - and then suddenly you might like something very much. But you must believe that I am sincere in what I write.''

title: Willow Hour's Finest Hour
description: goggle day, Angel Cordero said, meaning the slop on Saratoga's old bridle path was so gooey that, before he mounted Pleasant Colony for the 112th Travers, he put on seven pair of goggles so whenever one got coated he could flip it down and see again. Even so, he said, ''I couldn't see for an eighth of a mile.''

title: A LIMITED GUIDE TO ALL THOSE MORTGAGE OPTIONS
description: If it is any consolation for prospective home buyers, even bankers are having trouble deciphering the complex world of adjustable mortgages, flexible mortgages, renegotiable mortgages, rollover mortgages, variable mortgages and so on.

title: Miss Hoimes Is Betrothed To a Lawyer
description: Margaret C. Hoimes and John D. Hirschfeld, 1979 graduates of the Fordham Law School, plan to be married Sept. 19.

title: GOVERNMENT SHOULD ASSUME HOUSING ROLE
description: RESPONSES to a recent health survey indicated that a lack of decent housing is, interestingly enough, considered to be a major health concern. If the present trend in housing continues, that concern will become even more acute.

title: YOUNG PICARO
description: Noel Perrin teaches the American novel at Dartmouth. WILL'S BOY A Memoir. By Wright Morris. 200 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. By NOEL PERRIN Few people in the 20th century can have had a more adventurous or a less studious childhood than the novelist Wright Morris. It's one thing for Gil Blas or Lazarillo de Tormes to grow up like characters in picaresque novels -after all, they are characters in picaresque novels. But for a nice American boy, born in Central City, Neb., as recently as 1910, such a childhood is remarkable.

title: FOCUS IS INTENSITY IN PHOTO WORKSHOP
description: MONTAUK THIS winter, when the folks from Levittown gather to swap summer vacation yarns, Joe Gsell may have the most unusual tale of all to tell. The high school teacher spent his vacation focusing his camera on pieces of broken glass on a beach here.

title: Teacher's Opinion Piece Draws Appreciation
description: After I picked myself up from the carpet, having suffered a nearheart attack over The Times's actually printing an article by a real honest-to-God classroom teacher (Opinon page, Aug. 2), I promptly fell on the floor again - this time laughing. Oh, how I savored every one of the lovely digs at those or foolish (maybe both) theorists who fill newspapers with all manner of drivel. As a satirist, Mr. Steckline deserves a place somewhere near Dean Swift. E.J. SHELLY

title: Fish-Processing Plant In Brooklyn Proposed
description: The Port Authority has retained three consultants to prepare marketing strategies for the possible development of a commercial fishing industry complex in Brooklyn.

title: THE REAGAN PRESIDENCY IS 'RIGHT ON THE MARK'
description: To the Editor:

title: EMILY DEWITT DALSEMER
description: Emily DeWitt Dalsemer, who was active in charities and organizations concerned with the physically handicapped in New York, died Wednesday at the Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital, Santa Barbara, Calif., after a long illness. She was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan, the Bahamas and Montecito, Calif.

title: A FLOATING ENVIRONMENTAL SCHOOL GETS HER BAPTISM OF CHAMPAGNE
description: IT RAINED, on and off, all day, sometimes gently, sometimes in a drenching downpour, and the sun never had a chance. But for the dozens of volunteers who turned out, the day could not have been brighter.

title: Photography View; LANDMARKS OF 19TH-CENTURY HISTORY AND ART
description: In 1888, Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Peabody of Boston spent six months traveling through Europe, the Near East and North Africa. In Paris, the Eiffel Tower was under construction that year, and the Oliver Peabodys bought two photographs of it, albumen prints that showed the truncated tower as it looked when the workmen had barely reached the second stage.

title: Barbara Fischer Wed To W.H. Davisson Jr.
description: Barbara Ann Fischer, daughter of Ann Buckle Fischer of Plainfield, N.J., and Arthur Louis Fischer of Oldwick, N.J., was married yesterday to William Howard Davisson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Davisson of Shirley, Ind. The Rev. Fredrick Schulz performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in East Hampton, L.I.

title: AN ICE CREAM SPLIT
description: EAST HAMPTON THE tradition of patronizing a soda shop after a movie may be an impossibility here if the Zoning Board decides against a Haagen-Dazs franchise.

title: JOBS EASIER FOR COUPLES IN SCIENCE
description: IN 1950, after years of marriage and unsuccessful attempts at finding dual careers, Maurice and Gertrude Goldhaber became the first physicists hired as a couple at the Brookhaven National Laboratory. Now members of the National Academy of Sciences, the Goldhabers work in separate laboratories in Brookhaven's physics department, where a nuclear reactor looms overhead. He specializes in high-energy physics and she does research in nuclear physics.

title: TRAINING AND TECHNOLOGY
description: William Stockton's article condemns America for an essential technology lag. Perhaps we are being too impatient.

title: MODEL SKILLS SHOWN AT PARK REGATTA
description: Skippers came with their 50-inch Marblehead-class sloops from eight states yesterday for the Sixth Annual Cutty Sark Regatta at Conservatory Pond in Central Park, and from 10 in the morning until 3 in the afternoon they raced and raced.

title: Stamps; AN ARMCHAIR WORLD TOUR OF PHILATELISTS
description: This is the peak season for armchair travelers, those collectors who visit beauty spots, historic spots and the still pristine spots of the world by means of stamps. MOreover, those travelers are not only economical and free of the inevitable hassies and delays, but often lead to places the tourist never even know existed.

title: DEVELOPER OF MODERN ART MUSEUM
description: Alfred Hamilton Barr Jr., who shaped the Museum of Modern Art from its beginning in 1929, died yesterday at a nursing home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 79 years old and had lived for many years on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Miss Cartmell Bride in Rumson
description: Elizabeth B. Cartmell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Cartmell of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Paul Henry Zoubek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Zoubek of Holmdel, N.J. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. performed the ceremony in St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church.

title: FIO RITO WINS BY NOSE IN MICHIGAN HANDICAP
description: Fio Rito came from off the pace to win the $161,900 Michigan Mile by a nose from Laddie Dancer today at the Detroit Race Course.

title: CORPORATE MERGERS AFFECT 'SCOREBOARD'
description: FOUR large corporations based across the border in lower Fairfield County were among those affected by the wave of mergers that has recently hit the business world. But though it appears that none of the acquistions will mean a loss of jobs, the change in ownership has produced some touchiness among corporate scorekeepers.

title: The Nation in Summary; Gearing Up for Budget Battle's Second Round
description: David A. Stockman has a way with words. This Administration's program, the White House budget director said recently, will not be ''a captive of deteriorating economic conditions rather than a catalyst for economic improvement.'' Last week, a bouyant President Reagan took 24 pens to his budget and tax bills, and, in the course a chatty press conference after the signing, told the nation that Mr. Stockman will have to ratchet up his determination.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART As of Wednesday next the Museum of Modern Art will have on view an exhibition called ''Words and Pictures'' that has been devised and directed by Bernice Rose, curator of drawings. It is a very good subject, on every count.

title: Miss Caulkins Wins 3d Title In Swimming
description: Tracy Caulkins won another national swimming event tonight, giving her a career total of 34 and pulling her to within two of the record set by Johnny Weissmuller from 1921-28.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Networks Segue Into Cable TV
description: Cable television, which some saw as a threat to the national television networks a few years ago, is rapidly turning into an opportunity. Last week, ABC and Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, two of the nation's largest broadcasting entities, announced plans to create a 24-hour news network for cable television.

title: SIX NATIONS MEETING ON SHARED PROBLEMS IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Representatives of six Central American nations opened talks here today on social, economic and political problems plaguing the region.

title: HEARINGS DELAYED
description: A SPECIAL subcommittee of the Assembly will require a bit more time to organize its hearings on the relationship between organized crime and the garbage industry.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN IDON'T remember just what Thomas James McMorrow's rating had been in the Navy, but, if he was any kind of overseer, I would have been proud to have him on my ship if I were a captain and horrified if I were an ordinary seaman. So I concluded after helping to rebuild our stand-up backyard pool, with Tom in charge and our other resident son, Robert Frederick McMorrow, and I as his crew.

title: Ideas & Trends; SCIENCE-ADVISING THE KEYWORTH WAY
description: THREE months ago, George A. Keyworth 2d left the relative obscurity of heading the physics division at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico to become President Reagan's science adviser. Since then, the 41-year-old nuclear physicist and atomic weapons expert has had to begin correcting his admitted weaknesses, including ignorance of Washington policymaking. In one recent week, his duties touched on matters as diverse as nuclear reactor waste disposal, dissidence among Soviet scientists and the ''deteriorating quality of life'' in academia. The importance of scientific and technical considerations in national policy was underscored last week when the Reagan Administration confirmed its decision to produce and stockpile neutron, or enhanced-radiation, weapons. Robert Reinhold, a reporter for The New York Times in Washington, discussed with Dr. Keyworth his role in that and other White House decisions and in the scientific community. Excerpts follow.

title: A World to Feed:; First article of a series appearing from time to time.
description: The world food situation is like a basket half empty, half full. On the bountiful side, for the last three decades global food production has steadily increased, slightly outstripping population growth and enabling more people to eat better than at any time in history.

title: No Headline
description: An item in this column on Aug. 2 stated that the land portion of a seven-night package at the Aruba Concorde Hotel-Casino cost $169 a person, double occupancy, including meals. The meals cost $154 extra.

title: Susan Gary Bride Of A.B. Murphy
description: Susan Nannette Gary and Alexander Bailey Murphy, who graduated with the class of '81 from the Columbia University School of Law, were married in New Haven yesterday. The Rev. Daniel D. Allen, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the Dwight Chapel at Yale University.

title: Stage View; WHY ARE THESE PEOPLE TALKING TO EACH OTHER?
description: Idon't want to burden you with too much information about George Furth's ''The Supporting Cast'' because ''The Supporting Cast'' struck me as bearing - all too seasonably - a great resemblance to the last rose of summer, fading away. But if enough aspiring playwrights dropped in to see it, I thought the occasion might yet serve a sort of purpose. In fact, every time I heard the sound of a helicopter, making a noise like a great drunken buzzard, hovering over Hope Lange's Malibu beach house to warn Miss Lange's assorted guests that both a brush fire and a landslide were about to wreak havoc on the area (no mention of earthquakes, though two tremors turned up), I felt that the helicopter's bullhorns might well be used to issue a few safety instructions for playwrights as well. Safety instructions derived directly from ''The Supporting Cast.'' Like:

title: ART SETS TONE OF FARMINGTON MANOR
description: WITH its generous six-column portico, Hill-Stead looks at first more like a Southern mansion than a Connecticut manor (it was inspired by Mount Vernon). That this impression quickly fades has much to do with the house's white clapboard exterior and the unexpectedly low ceilings within. Besides, the estate - about 150 acres and rich in trees that include a couple of elms - is unmistakably New England.

title: CHILDREN IN NEED: FOSTERING
description: THE deinstitutionalizing of homeless children - removing them from temporary and long-term institutions throughout the state - is relying heavily on foster homes. But although many professionals feel this is a more humane alternative, the foster-care system itself has been plagued with problems. Among them:

title: Topics; LIFE FORMS; Bottom Line
description: Compulsive readers are in constant need of a fix: witness their preoccupation with soup cans, classified ads and package directions. They are also assiduous readers of jeans.

title: A Change Of Strips
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLANDERS
description: ''IT'S always a matter of luck,'' said Peter Spier of Shoreham. ''Being in the right place at the right time.'' These days, the 54-year-old, Netherlands-born Mr. Spier is known to myriad youngsters and their parents as a prize-winning illustrator and author of children's literature - recipient, among other awards, of the prestigious Caldecott Medal in 1978 for ''Noah's Ark'' and winner of the Mass Media Award from the National Conference of Christians and Jews, the 1980 Christopher Medal and a National Book Award nomination for his most recent book, ''People.''

title: Hirohito Marks Anniversary Of War's End at Tokyo Rites
description: Emperor Hirohito marked the 36th anniversary today of the end of World War II with a ''prayer for world peace'' in ceremonies before 6,600 people at Tokyo's Martial Arts Hall.

title: Hunger Striker in Belfast Gives Up His Prison Fast
description: Patrick Quinn, the Irish Republican Army hunger striker whose life was saved at the request of his family, has given up his fast, Irish nationalist sources reported today.

title: PRINCESS WITH A MISSION
description: THE target that overcast day in 1944 was the Ploesti oilfield in southeastern Rumania. James Miceli, a 23-year-old second lieutenant from Woodcliff Lake, Bergen County, was navigator in the lead B-24 that bombed the refineries, hoping to destroy the Axis oil pipeline.

title: HERB-HARVEST EXHIBITORS
description: NEW LONDON MORE than 200 antiques dealers from a dozen states will convene early Saturday morning to set up displays for the 18th annual New London Outdoor Antiques Festival, produced each year on the campus of Connecticut College for the benefit of the school's Lyman Allyn Museum.

title: NEW YORK CITY SUFFERS FIRST DROP IN TOURISM IN 5 YEARS
description: Tourism in New York City is going through its first serious slump since its revival five years ago during the Bicentennial. While tourism is still stronger than it was a decade ago, economists and industry experts concede that there is a problem, one that is beginning to affect individual businesses and the city's treasury.

title: U.S. BUDGET TO FORCE FISCAL SHIFTS IN NEW YORK
description: State officials are grappling with a series of broad changes in the way the state organizes its finances. The changes are a result of the revisions in Federal programs introduced by President Reagan and also a result of a new state budget law, which for the first time gives the Legislature control over some $7 billion in Federal money that comes into the state.

title: DETROIT OUSTS 252 IN A UNION DISPUTE
description: The City of Detroit laid off 252 workers today after their unions refused to accept wage freezes and other concessions linked to a financial rescue package for the nation's sixth-largest city.

title: Topics; LIFE FORMS; Life Defined
description: Can Congress define life? Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and others want to pass a law declaring that life begins at conception. The idea is to undermine Supreme Court abortion decisions by declaring that the Constitution doesn't mean what the Court said it meant.

title: NABOB OF NOSTALGIA KEEPS OLDIES NEW
description: LIVINGSTON FOR some people, a job change happens only when there is a big push. And for Danny Stiles the big push came last spring. For 11 years Mr. Stiles had been host of the Nostalgia Show on WEVD-FM, New York, which featured the ''golden oldies'' music of the 20's through the 50's, from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. Monday through Friday. Then the station decided to put the show in the 3 P.M.-to-5 P.M. slot.

title: Strike Punishment
description: After the settlement of New York City's transit strike in April 1980 - a dispute that halted all subways and public buses for 11 days - the Transit Authority began exacting the penalty from the transit workers: loss of a day's pay for every day on strike, in addition to wages lost while out. This is authorized by the state's Taylor Law, which bans strikes by public employees.

title: Politics; ATLANTIC CITY: IMAGES OF '64 MADE BLURRY
description: ATLANTIC CITY LIKE a lady caught in the act of dressing, this resort city played host last week to the nation's governors. Governor Byrne, the outgoing chairman of the 27-member Democratic Governors Association, won the praise of his colleagues for the efforts that obviously went into making the visitors comfortable and keeping them entertained.

title: MAYBE IT'S TIME TO DISMISS THE F.A.A.
description: It could take as long as 21 months to rebuild the nation's air traffic control system since the dismissal of striking controllers. That's the word from J. Lynn Helms, administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration. Yet what he has in mind is simply replicating the patched-together collection of radar scopes, computers and personnel with which the F.A.A. has muddled through for the past decade. Unfortunately, that simply will not do.

title: Jeffrey Shapiro Weds Catharine Lynch
description: The marriage of Catharine Anne Lynch to Jeffrey Alan Shapiro took place yesterday at the Greenville Community Reformed Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Klausner performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr.

title: AIR STRIKE: LITTLE IMPACT IN THE STATE
description: WHILE air traffic at Newark International Airport has dropped since the strike by air-traffic controllers began two weeks ago, business at the airport's seven instant-insurance counters has been slightly better than normal. Although fewer passengers are flying, said a saleswoman for Tele-Trip Insurance, those who do fly are buying larger policies and more of them.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Incentive Plan For New Recruits
description: Problem: how to get large numbers of young men to join the armed forces, especially the less glamorous units, without a draft. Possible solution: give them a college education.

title: SAN FRANCISCO DANCERS LOOK TO THE EAST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barry Laine wwrites frequently about dance and dancers. By BARRY LAINE

title: Westchester Housing; BENEFITS OF COMMUNITY HOUSING
description: IT'S a long way from the family vegetable garden to the family kitchen for several hundred Westchester families, who for lack of space at home do their gardening in community plots.

title: Exception to Bates On Social Aid
description: Those of us who are public employees on the ''front lines'' wish to take exception to statements recently made by Commissioner Charles W. Bates (''Assessing Social Aid Priorities,'' July 5).

title: THE INVIDIOUS TASK OF DINNER
description: OF the common delights to fall victim to changes in the relationship between men and women during the last decade, none will I mourn more than the friendly dinner party.

title: THE 2 SIDES OF THE BASEBALL STRIKE
description: Collective bargaining and labor disputes are no stranger to America's game of baseball. In the just-concluded negotiations, the issue was compensation - player selection rights - for clubs losing ranking free agents.

title: Valerie Brown Is Bride Of Alan Kirk Banks
description: At the Old Lyme (Conn.) Congregational Church yesterday, Valerie Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pelham W. Brown of Old Lyme, was married to Alan Kirk Banks, son of Stella Goulding and David Banks, both of Hamilton, Mass.

title: No Headline
description: In last week's Arts and Leisure section, W. Barnabas McHenry was identified as chairman of New York City's Advisory Commission on Cultural Affairs. In fact, Mr. McHenry resigned from that post in May, 1980, and was replaced by John C. Lankenau. In the same article, which concerned government support of the arts, Alvin Ailey was identified as a black member of President Reagan's task force; whereas, the reference should have been to Arthur Mitchell, head of the Dance Theater of Harlem.

title: SANDANISTS ASK PRIVATE SECTOR TO BE A QUIET ONE
description: In the days when Nicaragua's private sector tipped the balance in the struggle against the Somoza regime by organizing crippling strikes and helping to persuade the Carter Administration of the popularity and justice of the rebel cause, Sandinist guerrillas considered business's political role a patriotic one.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Grimes Is Bride of Gene A. Triggs Jr.
description: Dr. Elizabeth Mosby Grimes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Andrew Grimes of Rocky Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to Gene Austin Triggs Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Triggs of Yazoo City, Miss. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jerry McBride at St. James Episcopal Church in Jackson, Miss.

title: EXCERPTS FROM POLISH-SOVIET COMMUNIQUE
description: Following are excerpts from a communique carried in English by the official Soviet press agency Tass after talks between the Soviet and Polish leaders:

title: A FABLED GUESTHOUSE IN INDIA
description: For a generation of travelers in India -writers, diplomats, adventurers and the occasional prince - No. 10 Cantonment, Amritsar, has been an address to remember and to pass on to kindred vagabond souls. The place is Mrs. Bhandari's Guesthouse, an oasis of serenity, good food and lively conversation in a sprawling, teeming, unkempt border town along the Grand Trunk Road from Delhi to Kabul and points west.

title: Silence for Pupils Is Also Golden
description: I share with Sister Lilla Hull of the Maryknoll Sisters in Ossining the opinion that silence can play an important role in the complex life of an individual (''The Sounds of Silence in the Suburbs,'' Aug. 2).

title: YONKERS BUDGET STILL AWAITS A DECISION
description: IT took two meetings of the Yonkers City Council and a lot of political maneuvering this month to pass a budget of $192.7 million, and now it appears that it will take more of the same to complete the job.

title: Music; SCARSDALE FESTIVAL ENDING IN SUCCESS
description: ABOUT a month ago, this column noted with pleasure the arrival of a new series of summer concerts in Westchester: the Twilight Music Festival, with an initial season of four 5 P.M. concerts at the Apple Tree Barn Gardens, on Richbell Road in Scarsdale.

title: Andrea Hulnick Wed to Paul Ciminello, Teacher
description: Andrea Ellen Hulnick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hulnick of Irvington, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Matthew Ciminello, son of Dr. and Mrs. Vito Ciminello of South Dartmouth, Mass. Rabbi Burton Siegel of New York performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's parents in Tupper Lake, N.Y.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 15 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 19 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 5 3 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 4 3 8 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood. 5 1 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 6 4 10 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 7 11 4 TRADE WIND, by M.M. Kaye. (St. Martin's, $15.) Love and death in exotic 19th-century Zanzibar.

title: Lynn E. MacAusland Bride of A. A. Huegel
description: Lynn Everett MacAusland and Anthony Allan Huegel were married yesterday in Calpella, Calif.

title: INDIA DAY JOINS CITY'S ETHNIC PARADE
description: When the New York area's growing number of Indian-Americans decided this year that it was time for a public celebration of their ethnicity, they fell right in with an old New York tradition: they had a parade.

title: Lisa Ann Diamond Is Wed In Yonkers to Erik Lindauer
description: Lisa Ann Diamond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Diamond of Yonkers, was married there yesterday to Erik Lindauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lindauer of Merrick, L.I. The ceremony was performed at Temple Emanuel-El by Rabbi Sanford Saperstein.

title: EVEN MORE THAN YOUR BEST FRIEND
description: Most of the 56 million pet owners in the United States will attest to the fact that a pet can be a good companion. But there may be more to it than that. An International Conference on the Human/Companion Animal Bond will be held at the University of Pennsylvania in October, suggesting that science is beginning to take a closer look at the age-old connection between man and his dog.

title: Inquiry Begins in Crash Of Balloon That Killed 5
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today began an investigation into last night's fiery crash of a hot-air balloon in which five persons died and a sixth was critically injured.

title: Borgnine a Believer
description: Ernest Borgnine, who is coming to Broadway next spring in ''An Offer You Can't Refuse,'' which traces three generations of a crime family from the 1890's to the present, has set up his own company to help back the enterprise.

title: Steel Import Trigger Price
description: The ''steel trigger prices'' designed to fight unfair competition in United States imports will remain at the same basic level in the October-December quarter, according to the United States Commerce Department.

title: Recoveries Indicated In 7 Nations
description: The world's seven leading industrial nations appear to be on their way to recovery from the 1980 recession, even though the United States and France showed some slackening of economic activity, according to the Conference Board, a business research group,

title: ARAFAT SAYS SAUDI PLAN COULD LEAD TO LASTING MIDEAST PEACE
description: Yasir Arafat said today that a Saudi Arabian proposal calling for Israel to withdraw to its 1967 borders offered ''a good beginning for a lasting peace in the Middle East.''

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: AT HOME ON THE RANCHO...
description: For 10 days now, President Reagan has been in seclusion in the Santa Ynez Mountains north of this seaside community. He has made only one public appearance, to sign his economic package into law Thursday, a day when Rancho del Cielo was cloaked in fog.

title: Code Makers, and Breakers
description: Did one branch of the Government deliberately try to weaken a coding system devised by another to protect data stored in computers? Some experts believe that's what happened a few years ago. They allege that the National Security Agency, the Government's chief code maker and breaker, leaned on the manufacturer and the Bureau of Standards to keep a new civilian computer code system vulnerable to military cryptographers. Intelligence agencies feared the spread of powerful commercial encryption devices might lead to development of codes they couldn't decipher.

title: Miss Meagher Breaks Record
description: Mary T. Meagher broke her world record in winning the 100-meter butterfly tonight, highlighting the final day of the U.S. Long Course Swimming Championships.

title: FEEBLE 'WAGNER ACT' FOR THE HORSES OF NEW YORK CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: About two years ago, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company restructured its management to create two presidencies instead of one, and John M. Pitblado was elected president for United States operations. Now the giant company, based in St. Paul, says that it will restructure again next Jan. 1 when Mr. Pitblado, 63, retires and no one is appointed to fill his position.

title: A POWER LINE ACROSS ZAIRE NEARLY READY
description: After seven years and many delays, the construction of the Inga-Shaba power line, the longest and most powerful in the world, will be completed this month.

title: Owners Build A Monster
description: IN the seven weeks baseball was shut down, the club owners had considerable time on their hands in airports and hotel lobbies and offices. Given all that time to plan for the resumption of the season, they botched the job. Like Dagwood Bumstead slapping paint on the floor every week in the Sunday comics, they painted themselves into a corner, creating an Orwellian situation in which losing is winning and winning is losing.

title: 3 Gold Medals to City Fives
description: A New York City basketball team, led by Tony Bruin of Syracuse University and Sidney Green of Nevada-Las Vegas, captured the gold medal today in the men's open division on the final day of the Empire State Games.

title: A 3-Alarm Blaze Damages Junior's
description: Junior's Restaurant, one of Brooklyn's best known eating establishments, was badly damaged by a three-alarm fire early this morning. The upper floor of the two-story restaurant, at 386 Flatbush Avenue Extension, was almost completely destroyed and other parts suffered heat and smoke damage, according to Fred Matthews, a manager.

title: Brabham Takes Alberta Can-Am
description: Geoff Brabham of Australia took the lead with 11 laps remaining and went on to score an easy victory today in an $85,000 Can-Am race at Edmonton International Speedway.

title: GARFINCKEL REJECTS BID BY ALLIED STORES
description: Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc. said yesterday that its board had rejected as inadequate a $210 million takeover bid by the Allied Stores Corporation.

title: An Ammunition Dump Explodes in Zimbabwe
description: A Zimbabawe army ammunition dump caught fire today, setting off six hours of explosions.

title: CHALLENGE OF THE BOW AND ARROW
description: NOSTALGIA and the challenge of what is difficult have created a rapidly growing interest in bowhunting in this country.

title: Washington Watch; Bringing Gas From Alaska
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Administration is taking a pretty hard-nosed approach to the Alaska natural gas pipeline. It has been four years since plans were established for the huge project to transport gas from the north shore of Alaska to the West Coast and Middle West, but the problem today is the same as it was in 1977: How do you raise the money?

title: MISS PIATEK TRIUMPHS AS PRO
description: Mary Lou Piatek won her first professional tennis tournament today with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over an injured Sue Barker of Britain in the final of a $100,000 international event.

title: ECONOMIC WORRIES PERSIST
description: Leading economists echo President Reagan's assessment that the economy will remain ''soggy'' in the coming months, but they also warn that continuing high interest rates and the specter of inflationary Government deficits will hamper the President's recovery program well beyond the near-term.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 17, 1981
description: Controllers' Strike About one-fifth of Atlantic flights normally controlled by Portuguese air controllers were rerouted by the Federal Aviation Administration in response to the controllers' 48-hour boycott imposed in support of the American strikers. The boycott began at 8 last night and was to continue through 8 Tuesday evening. The F.A.A. established two new flight routes that will affect about 20 percent of trans-Atlantic originating in Southern Europe and North Africa. (Page A1, Column 6.) International Polish students postponed marches they had planned to call for the release of five men they said were political prisoners. The demonstrations had been opposed by the Government, the Solidarity union and the Roman Catholic Church. A final decision on whether to hold the marches will be made Saturday, an organizer said. (A1:4.) ''A wrong was done to Israel'' when the Reagan Administration suspended delivery of 16 fighter planes after the Israeli attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor last month, Prime Minister Menachem Begin told reporters in English and Hebrew. Speaking after the first meeting held by the Cabinet of his coalition Government, he said that President Reagan had ''decided to right that wrong'' and that he expected the suspension to be lifted in the next few days. (A1:5.)

title: Green, on Final 64, Winner by Stroke
description: Hubie Green, a former United States Open champion, finished spectacularly with a seven-under-par 64 today and won the $300,000 Greater Hartford Open golf tournament by one stroke. It was his first victory in two years.

title: De La Rose Scores With Maple Riding
description: De La Rose, the 3-year-old filly who has regularly been beating males of her own age on the grass this year, outran a field of seven older fillies and mares today to win the $60,700 Diana Handicap at Saratoga race track.

title: ...AND MEANTIME, BACK IN THE CAPITAL
description: The West Wing lobby is normally the crossroads of the White House, bustling with important visitors, Presidential aides and security guards, all moving to the rhythm of the steady, insistent ringing of a telephone.

title: IN DEFENSE OF CUTTING ESTATE TAX
description: In the critically important debate on tax reductions, there has been understandable criticism of benefits for those who do not need them.

title: RISK OF DISASTER OR A CERTAINTY
description: ,165.6,0,257.6,2Scientists know certain things in a fashion more immediate and more certain than those who don't know what science is. Unless we are abnormally weak or abnormally wicked men, this knowledge is bound to shape our actions. Most of us are timid, but to an extent, knowledge gives us guts. Perhaps it can give us guts strong enough for the jobs in hand.

title: Canada Mail Vans Attacked
description: Vandals destroyed three post office vans today and damaged 40 others, the police said.

title: Julie Bernstein Wed To David Borhani
description: Julie Bernstein, daughter of Richard Bernstein and Dr. Anne Bernstein of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Borhani, son of Dr. and Mrs. Nemat Borhani of Davis and Lake Tahoe, Calif. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony at the Bernstein home.

title: Paul Weinstein Weds Margery Nathanson
description: At Temple B'nai-Israel in Millburn, N.J., yesterday, Margery Nathanson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack S. Nathanson of Millburn, was married to Paul David Weinstein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Weinstein of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Victor Mirelman, assisted by Cantor Joshua Steele, performed the ceremony.

title: News Analysis
description: Behind the latest polemics between the Polish Government and Solidarity, the independent union, a struggle for power is being played out.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will publish a Monday newspaper and hopefully forevermore.'' -Craig Ammerman, executive editor of The Bulletin in Philadelphia. (A1:1.)

title: JETS' BUTTLE GETS GIFT AND A POLICE GUARD
description: An apparently ominous gift of red orchids, tied with a black ribbon, that Greg Buttle received last week prompted the unusual security that surrounded Buttle during the Jets' exhibition game at Atlanta last night.

title: SELF: A SURPRISING SUCCESS
description: Back in 1976, when Phyllis Starr Wilson was managing editor of Glamour magazine, one of Conde Nast's imposing stable of women's publications, she felt that women's magazines were not doing enough for the over-30 set. So she whipped up a prospectus for a magazine geared for women of all ages. She thought of calling it Woman or Self.

title: S.W. MEEK, LEADER IN GROWTH OF J. WALTER THOMPSON, DIES
description: Samuel Williams Meek, who helped build a worldwide advertising organization for the J. Walter Thompson Company, died Saturday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Dith Pran
description: NEW YORK'S FIRST INDIA DAY PARADE: Dancers performing on a float bearing the portrait of Mohandas K. Gandhi yesterday during the India Day Parade on Madison Avenue. This weekend was chosen for the parade because Saturday marked the anniversary of India's independence from Britain in 1947. Page B3.

title: RURAL WOMEN: A CHANGED LANDSCAPE
description: A teen-ager rocked her baby, a comely young woman patted the dog on her lap, several industrious souls sewed and quilted as they listened and an older woman puffed on her pipe as she took notes. It was a picture of bucolic charm, but as the seminars progressed it was evident that the canvas was cracking.

title: Addendum
description: * Capelin, Carton & Landreth Inc., a new public relations company at 229 East 60th Street.

title: FREEDOM FOR CONVICT-AUTHOR: COMPLEX AND CONFLICTING TALE
description: In the manuscript of his book on life in prison, Jack Henry Abbott wrote that he was tortured, along with six or seven other inmates, at the Federal Penitentiary in Marion, Ill., on April 28, 1980.

title: BRITON'S WAR REPORTS ON U.S. FORESAW THE FUTURE
description: Thirty-six years ago on Aug. 11, after the United States dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki and the Soviet Union declared war on Japan, the weekly political report from the British Embassy in Washington to the Foreign Office in London said:

title: AS PRAGUE STEPS UP ITS WAR ON DISSIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: VALENTINE STAR AS METS WIN
description: ''I'd rather be lucky than good,'' Lefty Gomez said when he was pitching for the Yankees more than 40 years ago. Yesterday at Shea Stadium, Ellis Valentine lent some validity to that philosophy as he led the Mets to a 5-2 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies and back into a first-place tie in the National League East.

title: PLAYBOY TO PRODUCE A CABLE VERSION OF MAGAZINE
description: FOR all the talk about wholesale sex and nudity on cable television, the area has been treated very cautiously - or avoided altogether - by large, image-conscious cable companies wary of controversy.

title: STEEL INDUSTRY: SIGNS OF HOPE
description: The steel business, a sampler of all that ails basic American industry, is showing signs of faint recovery. Profits are improving, and in recent months steel companies have announced investment projects totaling more than $5 billion, spurred by recent changes in Government policy, including the new tax law.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York has named Martha L. Dinerstein a vice president.

title: Marshall Eyed
description: There is a good chance that Mike Marshall will sign with the Mets during their coming road trip, Manager Joe Torre indicated yesterday. Marshall, out of baseball since early last season, pitched batting practice Saturday and yesterday, and will accompany the team to Atlanta.

title: UNWANTED PENNIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Times Price
description: The newsstand price of The Financial Times, London's daily business newspaper, rise tomorrow to 30 pence, or about 54 cents in United States currency, from 25 pence.

title: Playoffs Will Be Revised
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday that baseball's second-season playoff format would be revised in an effort to close loopholes and ''preclude any possibility of a team losing a game to get ahead.''

title: JOHN PAUL ARRIVES AT SUMMER HOME
description: Pope John Paul II, greeted by a cheering crowd of 3,000, arrived at his country residence today to continue his convalescence from a May 13 assassination attempt.

title: 32 on a Chartered Boat Are Rescued Off Jersey
description: Coast Guard cutters sped through rough seas off the New Jersey coast last night to rescue a foundering chartered fishing boat with 32 people aboard, authorities said.

title: INCOMING MUSICALS FACE A SHORTAGE OF THEATERS
description: At the start of each season, inevitably, there is a theater shortage. By midseason, inevitably, plays or musicals have closed or been postponed, and the shortage has been alleviated. It is possible, however, that this season will be different. This season, there truly may be a shortage of theaters, particularly for musicals.

title: Brian Friedman, Lawyer, Marries Barbara Shulman
description: Barbara Shulman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Shulman of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Friedman of Passaic, N.J. Rabbis Alexander Shapiro and David Panitz officiated at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: BILTMORE DISMANTLING STOPPED AGAIN: FOR HOTEL, CLOCK RUNS OUT
description: Somewhere, F. Scott Fitzgerald and James A. Farley must be sorry. The 68-year-old Biltmore Hotel -long the traditional New York headquarters for the Ivy League and preppy set as well as for Democratic politicians - is about to become a bank's headquarters.

title: CAN THE STEELERS REVIVE?
description: LATROBE, Pa. ASIGN startles the visitor coming here to St. Vincent College, where the Pittsburgh Steelers have trained for 13 years. The sign with the arrow on the campus road says ''St. Vincent Cemetery'' and it has its symbolism.

title: WHEN THE THERAPIST IS AWAY, PATIENTS DO NOT PLAY
description: A great many neuroses are still here, but the therapists are mostly away. It is, after all, August. Why do they all seem to leave in August? ''Probably because many New York City analysts began following the European tradition of leaving the city in the most uncomfortable time of the year when they themselves were in analysis with first-generation Americans,'' according to Howard Kogan, a psychoanalyst and a director of the Training Institute for Mental Health Practioneers.

title: Doctors Get New Job Offers Under Budget Cuts
description: Reagan Adminisration budget cuts will have a particularly odd effect in the case of three physicians employed by the Railroad Retirement Board in Chicago.

title: Getting Rarer
description: On the theory that there's usually more to a trend (in this case, the drop in beef consumption) than meets the facts, we often consult a friend who operates on instinct about the way the world's turning. ''What's all this stuff,'' we asked her, ''about nobody wanting a nice juicy steak anymore?''

title: Broodmare Brings $149,000 at Sale
description: A broodmare in foal to Niatross sold for $149,000 today as the Garden State Standardbred Sales opened at The Meadowlands.

title: Who Complains About Audiences? Not Ira Levin
description: The audiences aren't as sophisticated as they once were, there are more children and out-of-towners these days, and the acting is broader than it was three and a half years ago.

title: Former Manager of Presley Denies Cheating Entertainer
description: Elvis Presley's longtime manager broke his silence yesterday, the eve of the fourth anniversary of the singer's death, to deny allegations that he cheated his client.

title: A SOCIALIST FOREIGN POLICY?
description: Paris, Aug. 14 - France's Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, has begun a dizzying series of trips around the world to introduce the new Government's foreign policy. He is a sharp-tongued man, particularly bright, with convictions as rocky as his chin, and too much concern for candor and clarity to bother with diplomatic mumbles.

title: The Economy
description: The sluggishness of the economy may last longer than the few months that President Reagan has forecast, according to leading economists. They warn that sustained high interest rates and the specter of continuing deficits in the Federal budget could retard economic recovery for a much longer period. They also say that currently economic indicators might be decewptive. (D1.)

title: ARS/NCK Wins Paper Account
description: Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin/NCK has been named the agency for the consumer paper products division of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation.

title: Index; International
description: For many Vietnamese, refuge in Macao is a Catch-22 A2 Portugal's former Prime Minis- ter is asked to return A3 Iran's President assails leftist Mujahedeen A6 After many delays, Zaire com- pletes giant power line A7 Enriched uranium from Soviet figures in trade with U.S. A8 Around the World A9 Government/Politics Democratic Comptroller candi- dates trade barbs in debate B3 Medicaid payments are going to the dead, Goldin charges B3 General Jazz festival is a symbol for a black community in Chicago A10 Ad by Denver resident highlights debate on court-order busing A10 Around the Nation A10 Radioactive cleanup to begin at Three Mile Island A13 Juveniles tied to 23% of violent crimes against individuals A13 For the Biltmore Hotel, the fa- mous clock has run out B1 A modern Hudson Valley farmer faces melon season B1 The City B3 India Day parade brightens Madison Avenue B3 A melange of old and new buses greets New Yorkers B3 A water main break affects resi- dents of Jersey City B3 Style Relationships: More than your best friend B12 For rural women, a changing landscape B12 When the therapist is away, pa- tients do not play B12 Child care in United States is criticized B12 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Laffite captures Austrian Grand Prix C9 Baseball: Tigers beat Yankees on Gibson's three-run homer C1

title: Six in OPEC Meet Today
description: Oil ministers from six key producer states are to meet tomorrow to iron out production and pricing disputes before the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets Wednesday, Arab sources said today.

title: Arraignment Set Today For Atlanta Suspect
description: Wayne B. Williams, charged with murder in the deaths of two young blacks in a recent string of slayings here, is scheduled to be arraigned tomorrow. His attorney said he will plead not guilty.

title: Petty Triumphs
description: Richard Petty wrested the lead from Bobby Allison with five laps remaining and went on to win the Champion Spark Plug 400 Grand National stock car race today at Michigan International Speedway. Petty led 17 times for a total of 65 laps.

title: Laurie Owitz Is Bride Of Kenneth Freeman
description: Laurie E. Owitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Owitz of Marlboro, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth D. Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton M. Freeman of New York. Rabbi Philip E. Schechter performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Rights Group Will List Its Corporation Targets
description: After a successful bout with the Coca-Cola Company, Operation PUSH, the Chicago-based civil rights organization, is drawing up list of companies group says lack adequate affirmative action policies.

title: DODGERS RALLY IN 7TH, DEFEAT BRAVES, 6-5
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the Dodgers' 20-year-old rookie left-hander, looked both good and bad yesterday. He struck out nine batters in five innings but gave up eight hits, three of them home runs. Still, Los Angeles managed to please a home crowd of 49,053 by rallying from a 5-1 deficit and overtaking the Atlanta Braves for a 6-5 victory.

title: GOLDIN FINDS WASTE IN FAILURE TO UPDATE THE MEDICAID ROLLS
description: Federal and local officials are wasting up to $11 million a year providing Medicaid and other social-program benefits to New Yorkers who have been dead for as long as 20 months, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged in an audit yesterday.

title: PORTUGUESE BEGIN 48-HOUR BOYCOTT OF OCEAN FLIGHTS
description: Portuguese controllers began a two-day boycott of flights to and from the United States tonight, but its effects were limited because the Federal Aviation Administration began to reroute about one-fifth of trans-Atlantic flights hours earlier.

title: FAILURE TO SUBDUE DISSIDENTS SEEN
description: President Mohammed Ali Rajai of Iran has denounced the leftist Mujahedeen Khalq movement as a continuing threat to the Government.

title: Surgery on Twins Ruled Out
description: Doctors at Children's Hospital here said yesterday that Siamese twin girls born last week have serious heart defects which threaten their lives and virtually rule out surgical separation. The twins, born Wednesday to an unnamed 29-year-old woman, remained in critical condition, kept alive with respiratory assistance.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS' STRIKE HURTS COMMUTER LINES
description: The small air carriers known as commuter airlines have been in some ways even harder hit by the air traffic controllers' walkout than the larger airlines, aviation experts say, and some commuter carriers are expected to go out of business.

title: TULANE'S BUSINESS DEAN
description: According to Meyer Feldberg, the ''great business schools tend to be on the East Coast, in the Midwest and on the West Coast.'' He believes there is ''a need to develop a great management school in the South.''

title: Commodities; Currency Futures At Age 10
description: WHILE the 10th anniversary of the start of trading in foreign currency futures will not be marked until next May 16, its birth took place a decade ago last Saturday. On Aug. 15, 1971, President Nixon acted to defend the dollar, then flooding the world in everincreasing volume, by imposing a 10 percent surcharge on imports, suspending the convertibility of the dollar into American gold by foreign central banks and instituting wage and price controls to combat domestic inflation.

title: New Ballot Listing Sought for Barbaro
description: Supporters of Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro's mayoral candidacy have begun circulating petitions to put him on the ballot in the November election even if he loses the Democratic primary next month to Mayor Koch.

title: 'Maggie and Pierre' To Open Phoenix
description: The Phoenix Theater will open its new season Sept. 17 with ''Maggie and Pierre'' by Linda Griffiths and Paul Thompson. Mr. Thompson, artistic director of Toronto's Theatre Passe Muraille, will direct the play, which was first staged at Toronto's 1981 International Theater Festival. The story concerns the marriage of Margaret and Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the Canadian Prime Minister.

title: KOCH'S BATTLE WITH UNIONS GOES TO ARBITRATOR
description: A politically sensitive dispute over whether New York City employees should be allowed to authorize payroll checkoffs for contributions to union political committees will be taken up tomorrow by a labor arbitrator sitting as a one-man impasse panel.

title: Lesley Zankel Is Bride
description: At Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J., yesterday, Lesley Susan Zankel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Zankel of Clifton, N.J., was married to Daniel Harold Glowinsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Glowinsky of Brooklyn.

title: STEPHEN CZUFIN
description: Stephen Czufin, a retired advertising executive, died Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Angela Pochert Is Wed
description: Angela Pochert, daughter of Ursula Pochert of Speyer, West Germany, and Karl Pochert of Landau, West Germany, was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Frederick David Weil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Weil of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbi Herman Blumberg performed the ceremony in the Winthrop House courtyard at Harvard University. The bridegroom is a lecturer in social studies and a doctoral candidate in sociology at Harvard.

title: ARTS TASK FORCE BACKS CONTINUED U.S. SUPPORT
description: The Presidential task force on the arts and humanities announced today that it would recommend continued Federal financing of the arts, but also called for an increase in private endowments. Charlton Heston, task force co-chairman, assured representatives from arts and humanities organizations at a public hearing that his group was committed to recommending Government support of their projects.

title: FARMER USES TECHNOLOGY AND LORE
description: It is melon season in Washington County and Aaron Allen Hand was on the prowl in his cantaloupe fields, his green eyes squinting in the morning sun.

title: Shooting Ruled Self-Defense
description: A wife who testified that her husband of 39 years bound and tortured her before she shot him has been acquitted of murder charges. The jury ruled, late Friday, that Nancy M.
