Zeller, 58 years old, acted in self-defense when she shot Clarence Zeller, 66, five times in the head in November 1980.

title: Miss Landau Wed To Bobby Minter
description: Maggi Landau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Landau of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Bobby Minter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Minter of Providence, R.I. The ceremony was performed jointly by Carol Bellamy, president of the New York City Council, and Judge Matthew F. Coppola of the State Supreme Court, Westchester County.

title: Storm Spreads Rains Over Southern Florida
description: Tropical storm Dennis, with its top wind gusts at 55 miles an hour, spread gale-force winds and torrential rains over the Florida Keys and the state's southern peninsula today, giving residents a scare but causing little immediate damage.

title: CHICAGO BLACKS USE JAZZ TO SAVE SYMBOL OF NEIGHBORHOOD'S PAST AND FUTURE
description: The lake was choppy, and a brisk breeze whipped around the beach, carrying the peppery smell of barbecue and the soft sounds of the Morriss Ellis big band.

title: Mesta Machine To Shut Facility
description: The Mesta Machine Company, a supplier of steel components, said it would shut its foundry and forge shops at nearby West Homestead in an economy move and idle 300 hourly employees.

title: PHILADELPHIA BULLETIN IS RESCUED AS 8 UNIONS AGREE TO CONCESSIONS
description: The Bulletin, one of the country's largest afternoon newspapers, was given a reprieve by its unions this evening, and a threat that it would stop publishing was lifted.

title: ROBERT HERRIDGE, TV PRODUCER
description: Robert Herridge, who created the CBS-TV program, ''Camera Three'' and wrote and produced more than 1,700 hours of television programs since 1950, died of a heart attack Friday in his Woodstock, N.Y., home. He was 67 years old.

title: BILTMORE DISMANTLING STOPPED AGAIN: A 2D STAY IS GAINED PENDING
description: HEARING THIS MORNING By DAVID W. DUNLAP

title: Chrysler Plans Employee Recall
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would begin calling back 1,500 employees of its St. Louis assembly plant this week after extensive modifications were completed on the factory.

title: Technology Sales by U.S.
description: The United States would probably pay a higher financial and political price than the Soviet Union if plans to broaden the ban on advanced technology exports to Russia were adopted, according to a Rand Corporation study published today.

title: TRADERS CONFUSED ON RATE OUTLOOK
description: On the eve of tomorrow's meeting of monetary policy makers, the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, the credit markets are still bewildered by an array of contrasting interest rate forecasts.

title: JAMES R. RILEY
description: James Ralph Riley, who rose from hauling milk to become an executive of one of Ohio's largest trucking companies, died yesterday at his home in Worthington, Ohio.

title: 9 of 14 Complaints Resolved in July
description: During July, nine of the 14 national advertising claims investigations conducted by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus were resolved with the withdrawal or modification of the disputed advertising.

title: Trying Times In Fiji Soccer
description: The New Zealand team set a World Cup scoring record last night when it beat Fiji, 13-0, to qualify for the final pool of the Asian elimination rounds for next year's World Cup soccer final in Spain.

title: EAST GERMANS SWEEP TRACK
description: East Germany won the men's and women's titles, and Sebastian Coe of Britain, the world-record holder, easily won the 800-meter run on the final day of the European Track and Field Cup championships today.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 17, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HOUSING BOOM GOES BUST IN LOS ANGELES
description: A word to the wise: The great Los Angeles housing boom is over. The real estate price explosion in southern California, which sparked a national boom still continuing elsewhere, has stopped. The bubble that everyone said could never burst has burst. All over Los Angeles and Orange County, home buyers can buy a property for less than it would have cost a year ago, although there are exceptions. Buyers who can pay cash can almost steal houses and real estate. The days when ordinary citizens got rich from buying houses are gone, at least for the time being and at least in southern California.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Grain
description: The Soviet Union has purchased 700,000 metric tons of American grain, half corn and half wheat, for delivery before Sept. 30, the Agriculture Department announced Friday.

title: East St. Louis Lays Off A Fourth of Its Workers
description: Nearly a fourth of this city's 402 municipal employees will be laid off by Sept. 1 as the St. Louis suburb attempts to avert a severe budget deficit, the Mayor said yesterday.

title: LISBON'S EX-PREMIER URGED TO RETURN
description: Francisco Pinto Balsemao, who resigned last week as Portugal's Prime Minister, was given an overwhelming vote of confidence by the Social Democratic Party's leadership today and invited to resume the post.

title: A Chicken, a Goat and Other Tests of an Actor
description: It's not every actor who gets to portray five characters in a single play, but for Scott Sparks, who does just that in the Off Broadway production of ''My Blue Heaven,'' the challenge is even more unusual.

title: Jockey, After Spill, Still Unconscious
description: The jockey Charlie Tohill remained unconscious and in critical condition today with severe head injuries sustained Friday in a three-horse collision at Playfair Race Course.

title: GERMANS COVET GENE TECHNOLOGY
description: Alert to American advances in genetic engineering, West Germany's chemical giants are scrambling for access to United States expertise in an effort some industry analysts say could parallel Europe's drive in the 1970's for American computer technology.

title: U.S. CHILD CARE CRITICIZED IN REPORT
description: A report issued by the United States Commission on Civil Rights concludes that the nation's child care policy is inadequate to meet current and projected needs.

title: Sierra Leone Union Leaders Call a Rally on General Strike
description: Union leaders have called a rally for tomorrow, the fourth day of Sierra Leone's first general strike.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SALUTE TO A JAZZMAN

title: America at Play
description: Among Americans who like physical activity, soccer seems to be still rising in popularity, but jogging may be losing wind. These are the findings of Dick Kazmaier, probably the best football player Princeton ever had, who is now something of an expert on American leisure.

title: Ellen Ruth Dunkin Is Married to Joseph Michaeli
description: Ellen Ruth Dunkin, daughter of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Sol R. Dunkin of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday to Joseph Michaeli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Amnon Michaeli of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Israel Moshowitz performed the ceremony at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens.

title: Situation Wanted
description: As the National Football League's regular season approaches, Chuck Foreman, once one of the game's best running backs and pass-catchers, says he still hopes to play this year.

title: Rare Breed of Pro
description: Most professional athletes have the public image of ''hired Hessians who skim the cream off the communities they play in, then don't come back,'' according to Leigh Steinberg, a lawyer who has 70 pro players as clients.

title: H. M. Denson Weds Ann Lemelson, Psychologist
description: The marriage of Ann Lemelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lemelson of Ridgewood, N.J., to H. Mark Denson, son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Bruce Denson of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., took place yesterday at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Rudavsky officiated.

title: REAGAN'S ERRORS IN THE CONTROLLERS' STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Report Criticizes U.S. Bridge Repairs Program
description: Nearly 40 percent of the nation's 514,000 highway bridges are deficient, and the federally aided program to detect and correct those faults suffers from a lack of consistent policy, the General Accounting Office said Sunday.

title: FOR DEARIE AND GOLDIN, THE ANIMOSITY'S MUTUAL
description: Accusations of criminal activity were met with charges of ineptitude as the two Democratic candidates for New York City Comptroller met in debate yesterday.

title: RUSSIAN URANIUM EXPORTED TO U.S.
description: Soviet-American trade, which has been limping along since Moscow's military intervention in Afghanistan, was given impetus from an unusual source last year - the transfer of enriched uranium from the Soviet Union.

title: COSMOS BEAT MANIC, 2-1, AND GAIN BYE
description: The Cosmos clinched first place in the overall standing of the North American Soccer League by defeating the Montreal Manic, 2-1, at Giants Stadium tonight.

title: Weather Service Plans Flood-Warning System
description: This fall 14 counties in Kentucky, West Virginia, Virginia and Pennsylvania are to get a National Weather Service program to give them early warning of destructive flash floods, with eventual expansion planned in more than 80 flood-prone counties.

title: People
description: * Peggy Bell Masterson, John R. Spencer, Donald B. Weir, Norman M. Sherman, Richard P. Kassof, John T. Jennings and Joseph R. Toto have been elected senior vice presidents of Benton & Bowles Inc.

title: FOR REFUGEES FROM VIETNAM, A CATCH-22 IN MACAO
description: The continuing arrival of large numbers of Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong and in this Portuguese colony is not limited to people from the south of Vietnam.

title: ARMY'S CHIEF OF STAFF REORGANIZES TOP LEVEL WITH 20 APPOINTMENTS
description: It has been a summer of turbulence for the Army's senior generals as the Chief of Staff, Gen. Edward C. Meyer, has named an almost entirely new cast of combat commanders and resource managers to positions of top leadership.

title: PERKINS SEES GIANTS MAKING PROGRESS
description: What football coaches see in a game and what they see later in the game films are often different. Coach Ray Perkins of the Giants is happy about the distinction.

title: Susan P. Zaccari Bride Of Alan Winick, Editor
description: Susan P. Zaccari, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Zaccari of Utica, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alan Winick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Winick of Brooklyn. Judge James D. Massenek of the Port Jefferson (L.I.) Justice Court performed the ceremony in the garden of the Three Village Inn in Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Advertising; Scanners Monitor Buying
description: THOSE supermarket scanner-cable television networks are growing rapidly, with implications for just about everybody who has anything to do with advertising.

title: MUIR ENDS BUSINESS TODAY
description: John Muir & Company, the controversial Wall Street brokerage firm, is ''ceasing to do business'' this morning. In an announcement late last night, the company said that it had agreed with the New York Stock Exchange to take the move and had also ''voluntarily consented'' to the appointment of a trustee to wrap up Muir's affairs. An official of the exchange confirmed Muir's statement.

title: ROCK: ALICE COOPER LOOKS BACK ON A DECADE
description: ALICE COOPER'S brand of shock-rock has been a part of the pop scene for so many years that it now seems well on its way toward becoming a new form of show-business nostalgia. At least that's the way it looked Friday at the Savoy, where Mr. Cooper and a five-piece band ran through 10 years of hits and show-business razzmatazz.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Kenneth A. Briggs HOLY COMPANY. Christian Heroes and Heroines. By Elliott Wright. 272 pages. Macmillan. $11.95.

title: BUS TALE: SOME OLD, SOME NEW, SOME TO BE TRIED, SOME TRUE
description: There was a time in New York City, and it wasn't long ago, when a person waiting at a bus stop had a pretty good idea of what was coming. But today there is such a mix of buses on the city streets, that a new dash of excitement has been added to commuting.

title: NEW HAVEN RIDERS WARNED OF DELAYS
description: Conrail said yesterday that many of the 40,000 daily riders on its New Haven commuter trains would be delayed today because of a power shortage that began with a failure in electric lines on Saturday.

title: West German Criticizes U.S. Over Neutron Arms
description: Egon Bahr, foreign policy expert of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Party, criticized the United States today for failing to consult fully with West Germany before beginning full production of neutron weapons.

title: Bruce Zik, Medical Student, Marries Jessica E. Schwarz
description: Jessica Ellen Schwarz, who will graduate next May from the Columbia University School of Law, was married yesterday to Bruce D. Zik, a fourth-year student at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: 4 Die as Train Strikes Auto
description: A train struck an automobile at a crossing last night and dragged it for a quarter of a mile, killing four persons. The dead were identified as James E. Laque, 57 years old, the driver; his wife, Jeanne, 46; Warren C. Madere, 40, and his wife, Carol, 38.

title: Ex-Skating Star Wins Cycling Title
description: Sheila Young-Ochowicz of Pewaukee, Wis., won the senior women's sprint gold medal today in the national track cycling championship, her fourth national sprint championship since 1971.

title: Rain at Montreal
description: The Canadian Open championship continued to be plagued by bad weather, and was rained out today for the second straight day. Tournament officials rescheduled the semifinals and final to tomorrow.

title: FOLK FESTIVAL: PROTEST SINGERS OF 60'S ARE REUNITED
description: NEW YORK'S first annual Folk Festival drew many of its biggest names from the 1960's folk boom, and so its major events at Town Hall, featuring Buffy Sainte-Marie, Odetta, Richie Havens and Tom Paxton, suggested a class reunion rather than a folk revival. Where were the Roches, Steve Forbert, Loudon Wainwright, and Willie Nile, young performers who all reached maturity on the New York folk circuit during the 70's? Even though a few younger performers did appear, their presence wasn't strong enough to provide a feeling of generational continuity.

title: CLEANUP TO BEGIN AT NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Decontamination of the most potent radioactive wastes produced by the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in 1979 will begin next week, according to a senior official of the company that operates the power plant.

title: Accounts
description: * Jenson Sound Laboratories division of Esmark Inc., to Cunningham & Walsh, Chicago.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times on Wednesday misidentified the court that recently upheld a District of Columbia law providing for detention of dangerous defendants before trial. It was the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.

title: WHEN A SMALL TOWN TURNS 'METROPOLITAN'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheppard Pace To Icarus Lobell
description: Herve Filion drove Icarus Lobell to a 1 1/4-length victory tonight in the $463,000 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: JAN STEPHENSON WINS ON 54-HOLE RECORD
description: Jan Stephenson posted the lowest 54-hole score ever in women's professional golf today and won her second tournament this year and sixth of her career.

title: A Booklist For Hunters
description: The literature dealing with archery and bowhunting is voluminous and one first-class book is ''Fred Bear's World of Archery'' (Doubleday). Fred Bear is one of the undisputed giants of the modernday world of these pursuits.

title: BERNAZARD LIFTS WHITE SOX OVER ORIOLES
description: Eddie Murray cannot seem to do enough to help the Baltimore Orioles win, and Tony Bernazard of the Chicago White Sox keeps beating them. Last year, Murray, the Orioles' first baseman, had the best season of his four years in the majors, batting .300, hitting 32 home runs, 36 doubles, and knocking in 116 runs, all career highs. But the Orioles, who won the American League pennant the year before, did not make the playoffs.

title: Reagan May Nominate Adviser as Paris Envoy
description: President Reagan was reported today to be considering Evan G. Galbraith, a 53-year-old investment banker, for the post of Ambassador to France. The White House indicated that an announcement might come tomorrow in Santa Barbara, Calif., where the President is vacationing.

title: SOUTH OF THE BORDER
description: In the first week of July, after 10 years playing minor league baseball, Jim Buckner said he was through. He had just been sent down to the Jacksonville, Fla., Class AA team by the Omaha Royals, a Class AAA farm team of the Kansas City Royals. ''I just can't motivate myself anymore,'' said Buckner, whose older brother, Bill, a first baseman-outfielder with the Chicago Cubs, was the National League batting champion last year and has been in the majors for 12 years.

title: MANY IN JERSEY CITY ARE LEFT WATERLESS AFTER A MAIN BREAK
description: About a quarter of the population of Jersey City was left without water or had sharply reduced water pressure yesterday morning after a main broke in a residential section of New Jersey's third largest city, local authorities reported.

title: U.S. SET TO START HEARINGS FOR 1,800 JAILED CUBANS
description: Federal District Judge Marvin Shoob has scheduled a series of hearings, the first tomorrow morning, for hundreds of Cuban refugees held in United States prisons since they came to this country more than a year ago with the ''freedom flotilla.''

title: Nicaragua's Answer to Its Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Florence Hutner Is Wed
description: Florence Anne Hutner, daughter of Mrs. Arthur I. Hutner of New York and the late Dr. Hutner, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Jonathan Mark Fredman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Jay Fredman of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Fredric Kazan performed the ceremony in Prospect Gardens at Princeton University, of which the couple are graduates.

title: Bridge: Popular New York Player Managed to Move Around
description: Some bridge trivia questions are merely difficult, while others test one's knowledge beyond ordinary limits. As an example of the latter category, try this: What American player represented Germany in a world championship?

title: AUSTRIAN GRAND PRIX TO LAFFITE
description: Jacques Laffite of France, in a Talbot-Ligier Matra V-12, outraced the favored Renault turbos today to win the Austrian Grand Prix, his first grand prix triumph this season and fifth career victory.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Science Times on July 28 about the poetry of E.E. Cummings inadvertently omitted a copyright notice. The poetry should have carried the notation ''c 1949 by E.E. Cummings, renewed 1977 by Nancy T. Andrews.''

title: Crime and Punishment - and Crime
description: Is a political assassin just another murderer? Yes, California's parole authorities have said of Sirhan Sirhan, the man who killed Robert Kennedy during the 1968 Presidential campaign. Other murderers commonly are paroled after about 15 years in prison and the state Board of Prison Terms has said it will let him out after a like period, and in any case not later than Sept. 1, 1984.

title: Jockey Sets Marks In Stakes Victories
description: Larry Snyder set several records today by riding five winners, three in each of the divisions of the Myrtlewood Stakes.

title: WORLD HUNGER IS EXACTING HIGH HUMAN TOLL
description: Widespread hunger remains intractable throughout the world and is exacting a high human toll. About half a billion individuals are still crippled by hunger, and a billion or more others should have a more varied diet, according to nutritionists. The great majority of the undernourished - some 80 percent, by World Bank estimates - are women and children. In recent testimony before Congress, Jean Meyer, the president of Tufts University and a noted nutritionist, said the human toll of hunger took the following forms:

title: NEW SABINE PRESIDENT
description: William R. Goff, 45, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Sabine Corporation, an oil and gas exploration and production company. He succeeds Ashley Priddy, 58, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Dallasbased energy corporation, which also has investments in coal and uranium resources.

title: Michael Ashkin Weds Jamie Kreitman
description: Jamie Lauren Kreitman, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Benjamin Z. Kreitman of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Michael Ashkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ashkin of Rumson, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the Reale-Frojd Gallery in New York by the bride's father. He was assisted by Rabbi Leon B. Fink, president of the Brooklyn Jewish Community Council.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A hard ground ball bounces off the pitcher's leg and is fielded by the first baseman. He tosses the ball to the pitcher, who has run over to cover first, and the batter is out. Does the pitcher get credit for an assist and a putout?

title: Salazar Takes Falmouth Race
description: Alberto Salazar, the New York City Marathon champion, won the ninth annual Falmouth Road Race today and set a course record.

title: GIBSON'S HOMER BEATS YANKS
description: Kirk Gibson, who replaced Rick Peters in the Tiger outfield in the top of the ninth after Peters had been ejected, rocked Ron Davis of the Yankees for a three-run homer with one out in the bottom of the ninth today to give Detroit a 5-4 victory, its third in a row over New York.

title: PREPARING FOR FLOOD OF DATA
description: Cambridge, Mass. - The emergence of a host of new communication technologies and services - among them cable televison, videodisks and videotext systems that link computer data bases to televison sets - has moved rapidly this year from the pages of the trade press to prominent coverage in newspapers and magazines.

title: MAINE'S OPERA: 'FIDELIO'
description: Maine is trying to grow an opera company in the sandy soil of Biddeford. On one side of this gritty mill town near the sea are textile mills; on the other, they make the M-16 rifle.

title: ERVIL LEBARON, UTAH POLYGAMIST, IS FOUND DEAD IN HIS PRISON CELL
description: Ervil LeBaron, a leader of a sect based on polygamy and several times a suspect in attempts to kill rival religious leaders, was found dead in his cell in Utah State Prison yesterday. A note said, ''I've gone to meet my maker.''

title: Judge Challenged In Petition Case
description: A state justice who signed a nominating petition for Councilman at Large Steven S. Orlow of Queens and is the presiding judge in a court challenge to the petition of Mr. Orlow's opponent has been ordered to appear this morning in Federal District Court.

title: ARRESTS REPORTED IN CASINO BOMBING
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has arrested five persons in the Fresno, Calif., area in connection with the planting of a bomb at Harvey's Resort Hotel-Casino in Nevada a year ago, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: A FEDERAL INSTITUTION RESPONSIBLE TO NO ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaders of Airline Union Arrested in Pakistan
description: Military authorities arrested union officials and raided airport offices today in a crackdown that they said was aimed at saving the state-run Pakistan International Airlines from collapsing in debt.

title: THE DANCE: JOHN GOODWIN
description: THERE aren't many choreographers around who can be funny. But John Goodwin, whose Dime-a-Dance Company performed on Saturday at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio, is a very funny man.

title: AYDIN MAY FIND LAST YEAR'S ACT TOUGH TO FOLLOW
description: Last year was something special for the Aydin Corporation, an electronics concern that specializes in manufacturing equipment for telecommunications via satellite.

title: Patricia Ann Murphy Bride of John W. Kennelly
description: Patricia Ann Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Murphy of Mahwah, N.J., was married yesterday to John William Kennelly, son of Mrs. John J. Kennelly of Wyckoff, N.J., and the late Mr. Kennelly. Rev. John McDermott and the Rev. Thomas Burke officiated at the nuptial mass at the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J.

title: TAX-EXEMPT CALENDER FULL AMID HIGH YIELDS
description: While industrial companies continue to delay long-term financings, utilities and state and local governments tend to go ahead and borrow despite high interest rates.

title: POLISH STUDENTS HEEDING APPEALS, PUT OFF MARCHES
description: A group of students today reversed a decision to go ahead with a series of protest marches scheduled for tomorrow. The marches had been opposed by the Government, the Solidarity union and the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Jayne S. Erger Married
description: Jayne S. Erger, training manager for the Loews Corporation, was married yesterday to John A. McGlynn, a corporate vice president and director of personnel with Paine Webber Inc. Rabbi Irwin C. Lowenheim performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Erger, parents of the bride, in Roslyn Heights, L.I. Mr. McGlynn is the son of Alice C. McGlynn of Highlands, N.J., and the late John McGlynn. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: JUVENILES TIED TO 23% OF VIOLENT CRIME
description: Juveniles committed 23 percent of the violent crimes against individuals in the United States from 1973 through 1977, the Justice Department said today.

title: China Reports Repelling Vietnamese 'Invaders'
description: Chinese soldiers repelled three border attacks by Vietnamese troops and killed a number of the ''invaders,'' the official New China News Agency said today.

title: Market Place; Inferences And Investing
description: IN recent years, Wall Street brokerage houses have employed such specialists as meteorologists and language experts. After the stock market crash in 1929, the firm of A.M. Kidder & Company even used the services of an astrologer for a brief period.

title: POLYCHROMATIC CANOE
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. MINUTES after Willow Hour panted under the wire in the 112th Travers Stakes, the canoe that rides the infield lake was hauled out of the water and carted away to the paint shop. Since last August, it had been painted yellow and black, approximating the racing silks of Loblolly Stable, whose Temperence Hill won the 111th Travers. It would be back in the morning wearing the colors of Marcia W. Schott of New York, whose colors consist of a royal blue blouse with white braces, red sleeves with a white hoop, red, white and blue cap.

title: Boy Detained in East Berlin
description: A 14-year-old boy has been arrested by East German border guards after crossing the Berlin wall to retrieve a pack of cigarettes, the West Berlin police reported today. They said the boy climbed the wall out of high spirits last night and was led away by guards after jumping into East German territory to pick up the cigarettes he had dropped.

title: BEGIN SAYS U.S. IS ABOUT TO LIFT PLANE EMBARGO
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin criticized the Reagan Administration today for suspending the delivery of 16 sophisticated American fighter planes to Israel and said he understood that the embargo would be lifted in the next few days.

title: Controllers in Midwest Seeking to Be Rehired
description: Nearly one-third of the dismissed air traffic controllers in the Great Lakes region have asked the Federal Aviation Administration to rehire them, an agency spokesman said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Ives Laboratories Inc. to Lally, McFarland & Pantello Inc. for two ethical pharmaceutical products.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amana Refrigeration Inc., Amana, Iowa., has named Jack F. Peppers vice president, sales-major appliances, and Richard H. Pendergast vice president, sales-central air-conditioning and heating products.

title: INDIANAPOLIS PUPILS BUSED TO SUBURBS
description: Desegregation moved peacefully to the white suburbs here today with the first of 5,500 black children from the inner city riding buses to Franklin Township schools.

title: Football Coaches Said To Get Cars for Tickets
description: Elroy Hirsch, the athletic director at Wisconsin, said today that car dealers in this area have donated about a dozen cars to university coaches in return for prime tickets at Badger football games.

title: MOBUTU ENDURES AS SYMBOL AND PERVASIVE FORCE
description: The newspapers usually carry a frontpage picture of him and an item about what the Guide is doing. His portrait hangs in every office, invariably depicting him wearing a leopardskin cap and holding a carved swagger stick - two articles that have become the symbols of his power.

title: U.S. LAWYERS PRESS BREAKUP OF A.T.&T.
description: Justice Department lawyers prosecuting the antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company renewed their request today that A.T.& T. be broken up.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BARD AT ST. BART'S

title: U.S. TO AID SAVINGS INDUSTRY
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation today announced a program to acquire low-interest, long-term mortgages now held by the nation's thrift industry and convert them into securities that the thrifts could use to raise cash more easily.

title: SLOPPY MORTALS, GUCCI BAGS AND NEUTRON BOMBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Viola Farber to Head French Troupe
description: Viola Farber will succeed Alwin Nikolais as artistic director of the Centre Nationale de Danse Contemporaine, in Angers, France. ''She is a great dancer and well-known in France as a dancer, choreographer French Ministry of Culture said in announcing the appointment.

title: Army Continues to Move Nerve Gas to Utah
description: The Army today moved 127 nerve gas bombs from Colorado to Utah in the second phase of the Weteye operation.

title: FORMER TIME INC. EXECUTIVE
description: Arthur W. Keylor, a former vice president in charge of Time Inc.'s magazine group, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Ekwanok Country Club near his summer home outside Manchester, Vt. He was 61 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Aid Asked for Refugees
description: Officials of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York have issued an appeal for volunteers to help 100 Cambodian refugees adjust to life in New York City when they arrive from Asian camps. The refugees are to arrive by mid-September, according to Paul Martin, director of the archdiocesan Indochinese resettlement office. The volunteers, who would be short-term sponsors, would welcome the refugees at an airport, provide temporary housing, aid in day-to-day living situations and help find more permanent housing. Mr. Martin said his office would provide financial and employment aid, English classes, counseling and access to interpreting.

title: Montreal Shuttle Off
description: Eastern Airlines yesterday announced a temporary postponement of a Montreal-New York air shuttle service that had been scheduled to start Aug. 31, citing the air controllers' strike. No new starting date was announced. Russell L. Ray, the airline's senior vice president of marketing, said that ''we must defer the start of this service pending resumption of a level of airline operations akin to that prior to the controller strike.''

title: People
description: * Richard Chrampanis named advertising director of Co-Ed and Forecast magazines.

title: PLAY: 'LIGHT UP THE SKY' IN LONG ISLAND REVIVAL
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. MOSS HART'S ''Light Up the Sky'' is imbued with a healthy cynicism about the inanities of the Broadway theater. In revival at the John Drew Theater, 32 years after it first entertained New York audiences, this summer theater perennial retains its impertinence. The cast of conniving Broadway characters is still recognizable and laughable.

title: Pitney Bowes Study Ended
description: The Justice Department has ended a five-year antitrust investigation of Pitney Bowes Inc. and decided to take no action against the company, department officials said today.

title: CONTROLLERS' STRIKE STIRS RESTUDY OF ARBITRATION
description: The air traffic controllers' walkout has spurred renewed discussion among labor leaders of alternative procedures for bargaining with public employees who are prohibited by law from striking.

title: Voting Rights North
description: Some say that the national Voting Rights Act discriminates against the South. New York City is learning that it is binding in all respects in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. The City Council has made such a mess of its 1981 redistricting that its plan probably violates the Federal law. So the Sept. 10 primary will be held under a legal cloud; even the November general election could be invalidated.

title: HAIG'S ANNOUNCEMENT ON JETS
description: Following is Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s announcement of President Reagan's decision to lift the embargo on shipments of F-15 and F-16 planes to Israel:

title: 'EFFORT IS HALF THE BATTLE,' SAYS U.N.'S PEACEKEEPER
description: When he was United States chief delegate here, Donald F. McHenry was once asked what he would do if faced with a peculiarly tangled problem. ''What we always do,'' was the prompt reply, ''go to Brian.''

title: FAYE L. SCHENK, 72, HADASSAH PRESIDENT FROM 1968 TO 1972
description: Faye L. Schenk, national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, from 1968 to 1972, died in Jerusalem today on her 72d birthday.

title: Volkswagen Van Output to Be Cut
description: Volkswagenwerk said 8,000 to 9,000 workers at its Hanover van production plant will be put on reduced work schedules for 15 days beginning at the end of August.

title: 3,000 Salvadoran Troops Said to Head for Battle
description: Witnesses estimated today that 3,000 Government troops, backed by fighter planes and helicopters, were advancing on the town of Perquin in the northeastern province of Morazan, where rebels say they have begun a major offensive.

title: Bill May Aid Continental
description: An attempt by employees of Continental Air Lines to buy a controlling interest in the carrier and thwart a takeover by Texas International Airlines received some help today from a legislative committee.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why does hot water clean better than cold water?

title: TREAT WILLIAMS: FOR THE MOMENT, PRINCE OF THE CITY
description: TREAT WILLIAMS is opening tomorrow as the star of one of the summer's most ambitious new films, ''Prince of the City.'' He plays a police officer on the narcotics squad who turns informer on his colleagues - and finally admits to his own misdeeds - in this true, complex story of police corruption in New York City. The film has already generated a great deal of interest, for it was directed by Sidney Lumet (''Serpico,'' ''Dog Day Afternoon,'' ''Network'') and is based on the publicized exploits of former Detective Robert Leuci, whose cooperation with Government investigators led to the indictments of 52 detectives who used to roam New York at will as members of the elite Special Investigating Unit in the Narcotics Division.

title: VETERANS ASSAIL COMMENTS BY DOCTOR HEADING DEFOLIANT STUDY
description: A University of California physician, hired by the Government to design a study on the effects of Agent Orange on American troops in Vietnam, was accused of bias today by several veterans' groups because he has made statements that there was ''little evidence'' that the defoliant had had any effect on the soldiers.

title: Holders Buy More Of Gulf Resources
description: Bel-Fran Investments Ltd. and H.C.I. Holdings Ltd. said they had acquired a 6.3 percent stake in the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, or 663,500 shares.

title: ATLANTA SUSPECT PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: Wayne B. Williams pleaded not guilty today to murder charges in the deaths of two of 28 young blacks, and a Superior Court judge set a tentative trial date of Oct. 5.

title: Deduction of Dues For Bus Unit Ends
description: The right of Local 252 of the Transport Workers Union to have its members' dues deducted by the Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority has been suspended indefinitely by the New York State Public Employment Relations Board because of a strike in January 1980.

title: F.B.I. SAYS CASINO BOMBING FIGURE CONSIDERED COAST BANK EXTORTION
description: A Hungarian immigrant charged with constructing the sophisticated 1,100-pound bomb that exploded at a Lake Tahoe hotel-casino a year ago planned a second extortion attempt at either the same resort or at the Bank of America headquarters here, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: PSYCHOLOGIST SEES A KEY TO LEARNING IN MANAGING 'UNSOLVABLE'
description: PROBLEMS By FRED M. HECHINGER ASPEN, Colo. ''IWANT the schools, like life, to bring into the light the tough predicaments that pupils are already beginning to recognize and make them part of the coin of discussion,'' said Jerome S. Bruner. ''Do not ask whether children are ready. Nobody is ever ready until given a chance.''

title: MINNESOTA WORKERS VOTE PACT
description: State clerical, maintenance and technical workers overwhelmingly approved a two-year contract negotiated in the settlement last week of their 22-day strike, union officials said today.

title: Actress to Be a Guest on Her Former Series
description: Mackenzie Phillips, the 21-year-old actress who was dropped from the ''One Day at a Time'' television series last year because of her problems with drug addiction, will return to the CBS program for two guest appearances Nov. 1 and 8.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE more threadbare the English economy becomes, the more fashionable everyone in London looks. A good place to see fashion ideas is King's Road, once again the center of a youthful fashion boom, where, it seems, one can find more tattoos and pierced ears and noses per square foot than in any other place on earth. For many, the New Romantics trend of six months ago, the Pirate look, has become passe. Now the most fashionable young people, those who listen to the music of the Spandau Ballet and Steve Strange, say the trend is yet another revival, the zoot suits of the World War II years, and listening to the salsa beat of Blue Rondo A La Turk.

title: BUSH REJECTS VIEWS OF SOVIET
description: Vice President Bush, borrowing a word from a World War II general who refused to surrender to the Germans, said ''nuts'' to the Soviet Union today for criticizing President Reagan's decision to produce the neutron bomb.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loan

title: NICARAGUAN GRIEVANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors' Strike Spreads To Miners in Peru
description: Copper miners and bank employees went on strike today, joining 13,000 physicians in a campaign for higher pay.

title: U.S. MOVES TO HIRE NEW CONTROLLERS
description: The Government began officially accepting applications for air traffic controller jobs today. It thus moved ahead with a complicated two-year plan to replace striking union workers by resorting to round-the-clock classes at the controller training academy in Oklahoma City.

title: Bridge: A Question of Ethics Rises When Losing Is Attractive
description: A controversy that comes up frequently in bridge events and occasionally in other sports and recreations concerns this question: If it is in your best long-term interests to lose, is it ethical to play badly on purpose?

title: Victor Disk Delay
description: The Victor Company of Japan said it will delay its planned domestic sales of videodisks and players until next April. Victor Japan, which uses the visual-audio high-density disk system, originally intended to sell the equipment beginning in October. It said the delay had been caused by a lack of choice of materials used for disks.

title: Ludlow Agrees To Bairnco Bid
description: The Ludlow Corporation, after spending two years fighting an on-and-off takeover attempt by Tyco Laboratories Inc., said that it had agreed to merge with the Bairnco Corporation in a takeover valued at about $90 million.

title: Police Charged in Burglary
description: Two police officers were charged yesterday with burglarizing a home while on duty and in uniform. Officers Stephen W. Webster, 33 years old, and Tyrone L. Pickens, 32, were charged with burglarizing the South Side home of Terry Johnson. Both were suspended.

title: SLOPPY MORTALS, GUCCI BAGS AND NEUTRON BOMBS
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 18, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FOLK MUSIC: WOOODSTOCK
description: THE Woodstock Mountains Revue, an informal grouping of nine reputable East Coast-based folk musicians, closed the third and last Town Hall concert of the New York Folk Festival on a decidedly pleasant note. The current edition of the revue, which has toured on and off for nearly a decade, includes the brothers Happy and Artie Traum, the pedal-steel guitarist Larry Campbell, the New York-bred folk-blues singer John Herald and the country singer Jim Rooney, among others.

title: MRS. SOLIMAN TO SIMON & SCHUSTER
description: Patricia B. Soliman, who resigned last June as president and publisher of Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, was appointed associate publisher of the trade division of Simon & Schuster yesterday. The appointment was made one week after the announcement that Herman Gollob, editorial director of the Doubleday book clubs and editor in chief of the Literary Guild, will join Simon & Schuster as senior editor.

title: Bucks' Staff to Discuss Johnson Trade Request
description: James F. Fitzgerald, owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, plans to meet with members of the team's front office staff this week to discuss Marques Johnson's request that he be traded.

title: LONG A FOOTBALL COACH
description: Lynn O. (Pappy) Waldorf, former football coach at Northwestern University and the University of California, died of an apparent heart attack while walking in the hills Saturday night. He was 78 years old.

title: Service for Raine E. Bennett
description: A memorial service for Raine E. Bennett, a former newspaperman, radio commentator and historian of the islands of the world, will be held at 5 P.M. today at the Overseas Press Club, 52 East 41st Street. Mr. Bennett, who lived in Manhattan, died July 5 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center at the age of 89. He established the Islands Research Foundation in 1950 and had been a reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle, a radio commentator in Los Angeles and radio editor of The Los Angeles Evening Express. He is survived by a daughter, Nola, who lives in Phoenix.

title: Cards May Get Porter Into Lineup This Week
description: Darrell Porter, the catcher who has been out of action since early in May with a shoulder injury, may return to the St. Louis Cardinals' lineup as early as Wednesday, Manager Whitey Herzog said today.

title: Festival's Organizers Accuse West Berlin Police of Brutality
description: The organizers of a West Berlin street festival that ended in an uproar Saturday accused the police today of brutality against innocent bystanders.

title: 4-DAY LOSS IS 22
description: The stock market dropped sharply yesterday as the concern of investors over interest rates continued to weaken prices. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a decline of 10.18 points, to 926.75.

title: Anheuser-Busch Takes Full Control of Stadium
description: Anheuser-Busch completed today its takeover of the Civic Center Redevelopment Corporation, and thus control of Busch Memorial Stadium, by electing a six-member board of directors at a shareholder meeting.

title: The first of two articles.
description: SIGMUND FREUD is undergoing re-analysis. Nearly a century after the Viennese master produced a key to the secrets of the human psyche, scholars are focusing growing attention on some of the enigmas that still obscure the personal and professional life of the founder of psychoanalysis. These include the evolution of his critical theory of infantile sexuality, his long ''bondage'' to a quixotic visionary who became his closest confidant and his relationship to his parents and other family members.

title: TV TUBE'S PATERNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: BROOKLYN BLAZE CLOSES LANDMARK RESTAURANT
description: Junior's Restaurant, a landmark in downtown Brooklyn that for 30 years had been a magnet for hurrying office workers, relaxing families and deal-making politicians, was a scarred ruin yesterday as a result of a three-alarm fire.

title: Report Clears Hospitals In Veteran's Death
description: Two medical centers run by the Veterans Administration were exonerated today after an investigation of the suicide of a Vietnam veteran who crashed his jeep into the glass doors of one of the medical centers last spring.

title: 5,853 PASS 'LAST CHANCE' EXAM
description: Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola announced yesterday that 38 percent of the students who last Friday were given one more chance to show that they had caught up sufficiently in reading and mathematics would be promoted.

title: BROOKS DEFYING 3D-BASE JINX
description: Everything seems to be falling into place for the Mets as they begin a one-week trip tonight with a game against the Atlanta Braves. Despite having three starters on the disabled list, the pitching staff is holding up. And there is the luxury of four solid outfielders, each of whom is hitting well. The Mets are only a half game behind the first-place St. Louis Cardinals in the National League East after the Cardinals' victory over San Diego last night. But most significantly, perhaps, in Hubie Brooks the Mets appear to have found the solution to the old problem at third base.

title: FUQUA BOARD REJECTS FORSTMANN BID
description: Fuqua Industries' board of directors rejected yesterday an offer made by Forstmann Little & Company to acquire the Atlanta-based conglomerate for $25 a share, or a total of $322.5 million.

title: Nassau Board Sets Expansion of Jail
description: Plans to expand the overcrowded Nassau County jail were formally approved by the county's Board of Supervisors. The board also approved advertising for bids on the $1 million project.

title: Index; International
description: Mobutu's presence and power are pervasive in Zaire A2 Colombia is racked by a resurgence of guerrilla warfare A3 U.N.'s chief peacekeeper says effort is half the battle A4 Haig's announcement on ending embargo on jets for Israel A6 Syrians try to quell Moslem-Communist clashes in Beirut A7 Sri Lanka declares emergency to combat ethnic rioting A8 Around the World A9 General Around the Nation A12 Indianapolis begins cross-district school desegration A12 Doctor heading defoliant study assailed by veterans A12 Judge rules Guayana ''confession'' by Layton admissible A16 Over 5,000 pass ''last chance'' reading and math tests B4 Jerseyan seized in South in slaying of officer in Queens B5 California farmers conduct own fruit-fly spraying B8 Industry/Labor Labor leaders ponder ways to settle public employee disputes B6 Portugues boycott has slight effect in delaying flights B7 Obituaries Arthur W. Burns on Moscow's approach to Polish problem A1 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A20

title: Advertising; Reaching Moneyed Markets
description: HOW do you get the nicest people to talk about your product? You pay them, that's how. That is the strategy at the Canada Dry Corporation (for Club Soda) and Somerset Importers (for Wyborowa Vodka), both Norton Simon Inc. companies. The idea comes from Letitia Baldrige Enterprises, a public relations firm founded in 1965 by the woman who was the social director of the Kennedy White House.

title: REGENTS FAILURES GET SECOND CHANCE
description: The Regents Competency Test, an examination measuring reading, writing and mathematics skills, will be administered again today in high schools throughout New York City to 716 students who were denied diplomas because they were found deficient in those three areas.

title: THE GOING GETS ROUGH
description: The Reagan Administration has rewritten regulations for administration of the Davis-Bacon Act in order to give the construction industry most of what it wants - but in hopes that Republicans in Congress will not now outrage organized labor by repealing the act.

title: F.W. Woolworth
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company announced that two nonrecurring credits totaling $29 million, or 96 cents a share, caused net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1981 ended July 31 to rise to $15 million, or 49 cents a share, from $1 million, or one cent a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The company had sales of $1.75 billion in the latest quarter, compared with $1.68 billion in the period a year ago.

title: Oil Nationalization
description: India has agreed to pay $24 million to the Burmah Oil Company of Britain for the nationalization of three of its subsidiaries, local press reports said. Burmah owns all the shares in the Assam Oil Company and the Burmah Oil Company and jointly controls Oil India Ltd. with the Indian Government on a 50-50 equity basis. The agreement for the nationalization, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1977, came after protracted negotiations between Burmah and the Indian Government over the past year, the press reports said.

title: July Electric Costs 23% Higher in City
description: The cost of electricity was 23 percent higher last month than in July of last year for a theoretical, composite household in New York City, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs says.

title: TAKEOVER OF CONOCO BACKED BY DU PONT'S SHAREHOLDERS
description: In a meeting punctuated alternately by sharp exchanges and warm applause, the largest corporate takeover battle in history became final today.

title: I. Milton Sacks, 62, Professor And an Authority on Vietnam
description: Dr. I. Milton Sacks, a professor of political science at Brandeis University and an authority on Vietnam and Southeast Asia, died Friday at Park Hill Hospital in Boston. He was 62 years old.

title: CASEY AMMENDING ETHICS FILE TO LIST 10 MORE ASSETS
description: The Federal Office of Government Ethics today released documents showing that William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, intended to amend his personal financial disclosure to include additional assets worth more than $250,000.

title: HEAD OF INTERNATIONAL COURT
description: Sir Humphrey Waldock, president of the International Court of Justice, has died here of a heart attack, the court announced today. He was 77 years old.

title: Rate Raised On Certificate
description: The maximum interest rate for new 30-month savings certificates increases today to 15.9 percent, up from 15.8 percent during the last two weeks.

title: Market Place; Municipal Bond Swaps
description: THE municipal bond market, once the happy tax-sheltered preserve for millionaires and certain lesser folk, has fallen upon rocky times. This vast sector of revenue and general obligation bonds totals more than $300 billion - in face value - of outstanding securities.

title: Ex-Quarterback Is Safetyman
description: It was typical of the coaching staff of the Pittsburgh Steelers - a crew merciless at testing rookies. Bill Hurley, who was starting his first game in professional football, was assigned to the Steeler kickoff unit with the job of running down field and breaking the blocking wedge of the Giants' receiving team. It was a task better suited for a sacrificial lamb than a quarterback from Syracuse who had never before performed on a kickoff team. Welcome, indeed, to the National Football League.

title: Norton Simon
description: Norton Simon Inc. said that it planned to acquire up to 5 million shares of the company's common stock through occasional market or private purchases in accordance with Securities and Exchange Commission regulations.

title: PORTUGUESE ACTION SHOWS MILD IMPACT ON ATLANTIC ROUTE
description: Only a few of the trans-Atlantic flights using the ''southern track'' were reported late yesterday because of the refusal of Portuguese air traffic controllers in the Azores to guide planes to and from the United States.

title: Venezuelan Oil Output
description: Production of crude oil in Venezuela in the week ended last Wednesday averaged 1,930,000 barrels daily, an increase of 106,000 barrels from the previous week's average but below the year's goal of 2,200,000 barrels a day, the Ministry of Energy and Mines reported today. Daily production for the year through Aug. 12 is 2,093,000 barrels. Crude exports through Aug. 5 have averaged 1,711,000 barrels a day, less than the goal of 1,895,000 barrels.

title: JAPAN SEEKING CURBS ON FRUIT SHIPMENTS FROM INFESTED AREA
description: Japan today asked the United States to restrict shipments of some Calilfornia fruits starting tomorrow to prevent the spread of the Mediterranean fruit fly, according to the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries.

title: BALTIMORE AQUARIUM: BIRDS, FISH, REPTILES ADAPT TO NEW LIFE
description: BALTIMORE IN the simulated rain forest on top of Baltimore's new $21 million aquarium, a rooster-sized tropical bird flew from a tree and landed alongside a startled visitor. The bird was a piping guan, a red, white and black native of Brazil.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 18, 1981
description: International Jet shipments to Israel are resuming under a decision by President Reagan. A State Department spokesman said that 16 F-16 and F-15 fighters that had been held up for 10 weeks would be shipped within a few days. During the suspension, the United States voted for a resolution in the United Nations Security Council condemning Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor in June. (Page A1, Column 6.) An accord on oil pricing among the OPEC producers seemed more likely as Libya indicated it was willing to reduce its official charge. Libya, together with Nigeria and Algeria, has insisted on charging $40 a barrel at a time when world oil markets have been glutted and buyers have balked at the high prices. (A1:5.)

title: U.S. Coast Guard Aids Anti-Castro 'Invaders'
description: The Coast Guard today came to the aid of anti-Castro Cubans sailing to the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba. Taken aboard were 16 men who said they feared for their lives in the seas churned up by the tropical storm Dennis.

title: SLOPPY MORTALS, GUCCI BAGS AND NEUTRON BOMBS
description: To the Editor:

title: REVOLUTIONARY CHANGES FOR SOLAR FIELD
description: President Reagan's decisions to slash the budget for the development of solar energy, to decontrol oil prices and to force solar resources to compete on a free-market basis with other fuels have combined to revolutionize the infant solar energy industry in this country.

title: A NEW MOVIE SPOOFS THE DESIGNER JEANS CRAZE
description: Jeans, jeans, jeans. They come at you from television commercials, from billboards high atop Times Square, from the pages of glossy fashion magazines, from the bodies of almost everyone under 65.

title: Health Effects of Meat
description: Meat-eating societies, such as the United States, tend to have higher levels of cholesterol in their blood, and higher rates of coronary heart disease, than societies where people depend more heavily on plant foods.

title: China to Sell Bonds in Japan
description: China is going ahead with plans to place its first bonds on the Japanese market and later wants to issue bonds in other currencies to raise money, the director of the China International Trust and Investment Corporation said today.

title: FILM FESTIVAL STARTS SEPT. 25 IN FISHER HALL
description: ''Chariots of Fire,'' an English film based on the true story of two British runners at the 1924 Olympic Games in Paris, will open the 19th New York Film Festival at Avery Fisher Hall on Sept. 25.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday incorrectly described the status of the United States Ambassador's post in France. Arthur A. Hartman, appointed in 1977, remains in the post.

title: Oil and Gas Drilling Rises
description: Oil and natural gas drilling activity in the United States has increased rapidly since 1979 despite concerns raised about potential shortages of drilling equipment and personnel, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AM General Corp., a unit of the American Motors Corp., said it had been awarded a $100 million contract to supply delivery vehicles for the United States Postal Service.

title: IN BOGOTA, REBEL DARING VS. THE CLUB
description: Only months after being pronounced ''virtually annihilated'' by Colombia's Defense Minister, guerrillas have rejected an amnesty offer and renewed fighting with such ferocity that the country's army commander warned that the conflict could reach a ''point of no return.''

title: ARSON AND ANARCHY
description: 4,0,3100,2Democracy is a Greek word. So is anarchy. So is pyromania. From industrialized Salonika in the north to olive-growing Kalamata in the south, man-made fires have been raging throughout Greece. Virtually every summer, one mountainside or another has been burning but nothing like what happened this month has occurred before.

title: Official Says U.S. Can Take On Bigger Role in Asian Defense
description: The United States is willing to play a greater role in helping Southeast Asian countries face external threats, a senior State Department official said today.

title: OPEC APPEARS READY TO LIMIT PRICING SPREAD
description: In what might be a major breakthrough in the bitter OPEC dispute over oil pricing, Libya indicated today a willingness to reduce its official oil price of $40 a barrel and Saudi Arabia said it might raise its price from $32 a barrel.

title: UNSTABLE EMOTIONS OF CHILDREN TIED TO POOR DIET
description: AN international team of investigators reports that even mild caloric deficiencies in the diet of an infant or a pregnant woman can disrupt a youngster's emotional stability by the time he reaches school age. At the same time, the researchers have found, such ''mild-to-moderate undernutrition'' does not appear to affect the higher intellectual and learning abilities significantly.

title: U.N. COMMITTEE DEBATES PUERTO RICO'S STATUS
description: A United Nations committee began hearings today that could force the United States to submit to a yearly examination of its treatment of Puerto Rico.

title: UNSKILLED NORTHERNERS FIND SUN BELT JOB CLIMATE COOLING
description: At 5 A.M., long before executives arrive at the skyscrapers overhead, before even the early-bird construction workers climb into nearby girders, part of what may be the last chapter in the migration of Americans from North to South is being written at Labor Force Inc.

title: Fire Damages Carrier
description: A weekend fire aboard the aircraft carrier Independence damaged the air operations room and carrier control approach room, the Navy said today. There were no injuries, and damage was still being assessed. The 22-year-old carrier has been at the Naval Shipyard here since Aug. 7 for a four-month overhaul.

title: Hijacked Iranian Missile Craft Is Said to Have Left Morocco
description: A hijacked Iranian missile patrol boat arrived at the Moroccan port of Casablanca and sailed off again after the hijackers forced harbor authorities to provide fuel, food and water, Moroccan sources said today.

title: A MIDEAST ANALOGY GONE AWRY
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right Place for Education
description: Is an independent Department of Education the answer to what ails public education? The National Education Association thought so fervently and got Jimmy Carter to agree, in 1976. As a result, thousands of teachers supported him - and the department opened for business last summer.

title: ORNITHOLOGISTS DEBATE WAYS TO SAVE THE DUSKY SPARROW
description: MIAMI THE five birds, all of them male and believed to be the last dusky sparrows on the earth, are growing older. As they age, the Government and conservation groups have been arguing over whether the males ought to be crossed with females of similar species so as to preserve at least something like the original bird.

title: JERSEYAN SEIZED IN KILLING OF OFFICER IN QUEENS
description: A New Jersey man wanted in the murder of a New York City policeman in Queens last spring was arrested yesterday afternoon in Sumter, S.C., New York authorities said.

title: ALBERTA HUNTER TO SING BLUES AT THE COOKERY
description: Alberta Hunter, the 86-year-old blues singer, will bring her songs to the Cookery, 21 University Place, next Wednesday for a two-week engagement.

title: Cambodian Refugees To Dance at Benefit
description: Refugee Cambodian dancers will perform on Sunday at the Ted Shawn Dance Theater at Jacob's Pillow, in Becket, Mass., in ''An Evening of Cambodian Dance and Music Featuring the First U.S. Performance of Former Members of the Royal Ballet of Cambodia.''

title: LAYTON GUYANA 'CONFESSION' IS RULED ADMISSIBLE BY JUDGE
description: A Federal District judge ruled today that a disputed confession by Larry Layton, a former member of the People's Temple, can be used in Mr. Layton's trial for murder and conspiracy.

title: Cleveland Policeman Dies in Siege at Home
description: A police officer died yesterday in his burning apartment after holding 40 officers at bay for 14 hours while he shot at them and threw objects from the window, including his burning uniform.

title: Poetry Prize to Miss Urdang
description: The poet Constance Urdang, author of ''The Lone Woman and Others,'' is the recipient of the Delmore Schwartz Memorial Poetry Award, given by the New York University College of Arts and Science to ''a young poet of exceptional promise or to a more mature poet who has received insufficient national acclaim.'' The award, a $1,000 cash prize, will be presented at a ceremony on Sept. 30 at La Maison Fran,caise, 16 Washington Mews.

title: Woman Is Sought In Lost Girl Case
description: The police issued an appeal yesterday for a woman who they said might be able to help in their search for a 7-year-old girl who disappeared on Staten Island last month.

title: N.A.S.L. STUDYING FATE OF TEAMS
description: The board of directors of the financially troubled North American Soccer League opened a two-day meeting in Chicago yesterday to discuss, among other matters, the status of the Washington Diplomats and the fate of several other franchises.

title: Sports of The Times; Mazzilli's Rude Awakening
description: THERE used to be squeals when Lee Mazzilli emerged from the Met dugout - the sounds of young girls who liked the way his uniform fit him, who liked his dark, handsome appearance. Other fans liked the way he hit .303 in 1979.

title: Research Concern Names New Chief
description: Norman M. Wellen, 50 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Business International Corporation, a business research and information company with headquarters in New York. He succeeds Orville L. Freeman, the 62-year-old former Secretary of Agriculture, who was elected chairman.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE;
description: It's been 10 years in the works and it isn't finished yet, but Macmillan London Limited is not taking any chances that another publisher might win the British rights to Norman Mailer's new novel, tentatively titled ''The Egyptian.''

title: CITICORP TO SELL KEY SITE TO CANADIAN DEVELOPER
description: Citicorp announced yesterday that it was selling a prime piece of Manhattan real estate to Cadillac Fairview, a large Canadian development company.

title: The Talk of East Rutherford
description: All around this friendly, perennially faded, mostly blue-collar town of 8,800 people, the Meadowlands Sports Complex has become a conversational staple of moralists and handicappers, politicians and homeowners.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an item in Notes on People on July 10 about Andrew Hamilton, the ''first Philadelphia lawyer,'' who defended John Peter Zenger 246 years ago, cited the cause of his death incorrectly. Hamilton died at his estate in Philadelphia after a long illness.

title: A PARABLE FOR BAD TIMES
description: 2,386.4,0,3100,2Once upon a time there was a small town that had a beach protected by 18 lifeguards, who were paid by the town government from taxes.

title: SRI LANKA DECLARES AN EMERGENCY IN ATTEMPT TO HALT ETHNIC RIOTING
description: Sri Lanka's President declared a nationwide state of emergency today in an attempt to halt rioting between the two major ethnic groups in the country. At least seven deaths have been reported in the last 10 days.

title: No Headline
description: Talking Business with Vincent of Columbia Pictures A New Image At Columbia

title: Girl's Body Found In L.I. Boat Crash
description: The body of a girl washed up on Plum Island yesterday morning and was tentatively identified as 10-year-old Karen Elizabeth Lublin, missing along with three others since a boating accident in the Long Island Sound a week ago.

title: BID TO PRESERVE WHAT IS LEFT OF BILTMORE IS SET BACK
description: City and private preservationists were set back yesterday in their attempts to save any remnant of the Biltmore Hotel, which is scheduled to be converted into an office building to house the Eastern headquarters of the Bank of America.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think one in a subjective way can argue to eternity as to whether or not a military action may be defensive or offensive in character.'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. (A6:2.)

title: Bucyrus-Erie Bids For Western Gear
description: The Bucyrus-Erie Company has made a cash offer of $171.2 million for all the shares of the Western Gear Corporation, the two companies said today.

title: Steel Production Rises
description: Steel production rose to 2.274 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.27 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 76.9 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 76.8 percent in the previous week.

title: Applied Solar President
description: The growth of the solar energy business in general and that of the Applied Solar Energy Corporation in particular has led the company, based in City of Industry, Calif., to bring in a new president and chief operating officer. He is William L. Thompson, who succeeds Daniel Josylin, president of Optical Coating Laboratories, which holds a majority interest in Applied Solar. Mr. Josylin held the post on an interim basis.

title: AIRLINE PILOT REPORTS 'NEAR MISS' OVER JERSEY
description: An airliner carrying 118 passengers and a private light plane were reported to have come close to each other over New Jersey Sunday evening, but just how close was in dispute yesterday between the pilots.

title: A JUDGE WHO FORGES AHEAD
description: When Marvin H. Shoob, the World War II soldier fighting in West Germany, became lost behind enemy lines, he gave his family and friends here a scare, since he was missing in action for more than a month. However, after the relief of knowing he was alive and back in the ranks of American friends, he was jokingly characterized by a woman who is now his wife of ''being very bright, but having no sense of direction.''

title: Net Off 5.2% At Winn-Dixie
description: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended June 24 dipped 5.2 percent, to $22.1 million, or 86 cents a share, from $23.3 million, or 88 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: YANKEES DEFEATED BY White SOX 4-1; LOSE 4TH IN ROW
description: The Yankees brought their second-half woes home last night and encountered even more trouble as they suffered a 4-1 loss to the Chicago White Sox for their fourth straight defeat.

title: SEAMAN SEIZED IN CALLS TO 911 FAKING DISASTER
description: A 20-year-old Coast Guardsman stationed on Governors Island was arrested by the New York City police yesterday and charged with making scores of calls to the 911 emergency number to report fake incidents of vessels and aircraft in distress in New York Harbor.

title: THE $4 MILLION TAX THAT GOT AWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Athlone Industries said it had repurchased 20,000 shares of its common stock in the open market for $572,500.

title: Savemart Awards $1 Million Account
description: Shapiro/Budrow & Associates has won the $1 million account of Savemart, New York's leading dealer of Zenith television, video and audio products.

title: G.M. Seeks New Policy For Pricing
description: The General Motors Corporation wants to end its policy of raising prices every three months, F. James McDonald, the company's president, said today.

title: Ground War at Newark Airport
description: Cab drivers on both sides of the Hudson are fuming over New Jersey Governor Byrne's plan to steer more passengers to the under-used Newark International Airport. Their outrage is misguided, since the plan would increase use of the airport, and thus increase demand for cab service in both New York and New Jersey.

title: ESTELLE GRISWALD, ACTIVIST, 81
description: Estelle T. Griswold, former executive director of the Planned Parenthood League of Connecticut, died last Thursday at her home in Fort Myers, Fla. She was 81 years old and had lived in Essex, Conn.

title: 7,000 Goats Die on Ship
description: A cargo of 7,000 goats suffocated aboard a freigher after the vessel's ventilation system broke down, port authorities said today. The Panamanian-flag ship, which had picked up the goats in Bulgaria and was en route to a North African port, put into Catania after the livestock died.

title: A FESTIVAL OF STRAVINSKY AND HAYDN
description: A weeklong celebration of the music of Haydn and Stravinsky is planned for next month at Alice Tully Hall by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Among the guest artists will be Leonard Bernstein and Michael Tilson Thomas.

title: DODGERS BOW, 3-1, TO BIRD OF CUBS
description: Doug Bird pitched a six-hitter, leading the Chicago Cubs to a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today. Bird (2-0) struck out five and walked two in pitching only the third complete game by the Cub staff. It was his first since 1976, when he was with Kansas City. ''I know our bullpen is tired and the plan was for me to go seven innings, but if could go more, I would,'' he said. ''The wind was blowing in, and that helped.''

title: TONY LARUSSA IS LOOKING AT THE PLAYOFFS' FINE PRINT
description: Tony LaRussa of the Chicago White Sox said yesterday that he was neither a loser nor a martyr, and to him the question was still clear: Under baseball's split-season rules, couldn't a team win by making certain that it lost?

title: CAN AFRICA AFFORD NOT TO SELL MINERALS?
description: In September 1980, Alexander M. Haig Jr., now Secretary of State, told a House subcommittee that the United States was entering ''an era of resources war'' and that southern Africa was its primary theater.

title: BUFFALO SAVINGS, WESTERN TO MERGE
description: Reinforcing the trend toward consolidation of the nation's thrift industry, trustees of the Buffalo Savings Bank and the Western New York Savings Bank yesterday announced an agreement to merge their institutions.

title: FUND RAISER'S LURES
description: Vernon Steinhert, a Wyoming prospector, has created a flap of sorts by fulfilling a contractual obligation to pay the state a 5 percent royalty on any gold he takes from state-owned land.

title: REAGAN PANEL ASKS AID TO STATE JAILS AND STERNER LAWS
description: An advisory committee appointed by the Reagan Administration recommended today that the Federal Government spend $2 billion to help the states build prisons. It proposed the abolition of parole in Federal cases, a tightening of bail laws and many other changes designed to insure punishment of violent offenders.

title: T.V.A. Faulted
description: A General Accounting Office report concluded today that the Tennessee Valley Authority, a Government-run utility, was paying too much for its coal as a result of unfavorable long-term contracts signed in the 1970's. The report by the Congressional agency faulted T.V.A. managers for choosing the two least favorable periods for coal purchases in the last decade as a time to contract for almost three-quarters of the coal the T.V.A. purchased in the 10-year period.

title: Ayer Buys Interest In 3 Overseas Agencies
description: N.W. Ayer Inc. has purchased for cash a substantial minority interest in advertising agencies in Argentina, Spain and West Germany, giving Ayer a total of 12 partners overseas.

title: SOLIDARITY PLANS NEWSPAPER STRIKE IN POLAND
description: Polish newspaper workers today made strike preparations for a two-day shutdown of the country's presses over the issue of the Solidarity independent labor union's access to the state-run media.

title: Georgia-Pacific To Buy 8 Plants
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire eight corrugated container plants from the Johns-Manville Corporation.

title: Canada Willing to Sell Strategic Goods to China
description: Canada is willing to supply China with ''some kinds of strategic goods,'' External Affairs Minister Mark MacGuigan said today. He did not specify what kinds of strategic goods he had in mind.

title: Ride in Jersey Park Opens After Death
description: Officials at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park reopened a roller coaster yesterday afternoon after investigators concluded that a man who plunged to his death from the ride might not have used a safety bar.

title: RIKERS PRISONERS ARE BOYCOTTING MEALS AS A PROTEST
description: A large number of inmates at the major adult facility on Rikers Island began a meal boycott yesterday to protest conditions, including visiting rights, food service and the cost of bail.

title: Precinct in Queens Gets New Building
description: Construction has begun on the first police station house to be built in New York City in 10 years. The building, at Northern Boulevard and 91st Street in Queens, will serve the 115th Precinct, which includes Jackson Heights, East Elmhurst and North Corona.

title: Ribicoff Slaying Suspect Agrees to Plead Guilty
description: Anthony La Quin McAdoo pleaded guilty today to first-degree murder in the slaying of Sarai Ribicoff, a niece of Abraham Ribicoff, the former Senator from Connecticut.

title: Dancer Agency Wins Parker Canada Account
description: Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample has been named the agency for the toy, game and doll products of Parker Brothers Canada, a division of General Mills Inc., Canada.

title: COAST FARMERS SPRAY PLANES
description: Anxious produce growers in the northern part of the San Joaquin Valley, the heart of the nation's richest agricultural region, have joined the battle against the Mediterranean fruit fly with their own aerial pesticide spraying.

title: World Bank's Energy Loans
description: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today that it will lend nearly $3 billion this year for energy projects in developing countries, and promised to give high priority to energy projects in the years ahead.

title: Lawyer Says Sect Leader Wouldn't Kill Himself
description: Ervil LeBaron, who died yesterday in a Utah State Prison cell, was described by his lawyer today as a deeply religious man who believed suicide would result in eternal damnation.

title: India Buying U.S. Wheat
description: Agriculture Minister Rao Birendra Singh announced today that India would pay $293 million for wheat imported from the United States this year.

title: Soviet Adds U.S. Grain
description: The Soviet Union has added another 300,000 metric tons of American grain to its orders for delivery during the next six weeks, officials at the Agriculture Department said today.

title: MAGNETIC SCANNER MAY SUPPLANT SOME X-RAYS
description: LONDON EARLIER this year, the first images of abnormal human tissue taken with a nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) scanner appeared in British medical journals. At a glance, the scanner's pictures resemble those produced by computerized axial tomography X-rays, the so-called CAT scanners, which deliver cross-section images of the body or its parts. But because the NMR scanner does not use X-rays, it may be safer than CAT scanners -provided the images can be brought up to the same quality as the CAT scanner produces.

title: Arizona Caterpillars Making
description: Roads Slippery for Drivers

title: PROLIFIC TRANSLATOR AND GHOST WRITER
description: Herma Briffault, a prolific translator of French and Spanish books into English, died on Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 137 West 12th Street.

title: ONE PILOT KILLED IN MIDAIR COLLISION
description: Two light planes on approach to the San Jose airport collided in the air two miles short of the runway this afternoon, killing one person and injuring two as they crashed in a residential area in the middle of town.

title: DRESSER GAINS 45.7% IN QUARTER
description: Dresser Industries, one of the world's leading suppliers of services and products to the energy and natural resources industries, reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter of the 1981 fiscal year ended July 31 rose 45.7 percent as revenues advanced 17 percent.

title: FACTORIES' USE IN JULY DOWN A BIT
description: The operating rate of the nation's factories fell one-tenth of one percentage point in July, to 79.6 percent, the lowest level since last November, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Industry Honor Is Voted for 2
description: Loet A. Velmans, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Hill & Knowlton, and Ronald E. Rhody, corporate vice president for public relations and advertising at the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, have been voted the ''public relations professionals'' of 1981 by the subscribers of Public Relations News.

title: 20 DIE IN COMMUNIST- MOSLEM BATTLE IN BEIRUT
description: Pro-Soviet and pro-Iranian Lebanese militiamen exchanged mortar and rocket fire today for the second day. The police said at least 20 people were killed and 68 wounded. Most of the casualties were reportedly caught in the crossfire.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Caring for the 'Crown Jewels'
description: It's the season for touring national parks - and for park managers and conservationists to decry the neglect of the ''crown jewels'' like Yellowstone. On the strength of a tour of Mesa Verde, Zion and Bryce and the north rim of the Grand Canyon, let me file a brief for protecting the parks at all reasonable cost.

title: Leaders of 3 Nations Confer On Cooperation Against West
description: The leaders of Libya, Ethiopia and Southern Yemen began talks in Aden today aimed at forging a closer alliance against Western policy in the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL DETROIT (AL) - Placed Champ Sum- mers, outfielder, on 15-day disabled list; recalled Monte Castillo, catcher-third baseman, from Evansville farm club in American Association.
