LOS ANGELES (NL) Placed Davey Lopes, second baseman, on 15-day dis- abled list after he suffered groin injury in game with Cubs yesterday. To replace him recalled Steve Sax, second baseman, from San Antonio, where he was leading Texas League in batting with average of .346.  ST. LOUIS (NL) - An
description: Rudnay, 11-year center, to two one-year contracts. He had missed 25 days of train- ing camp and two exhibition games. Waived six free agents: Mike Solomon, quarterback, Wayne Washington, guard, Wayne Anderson, kicker, Ed Baxley, line- backer, Terry Love, safety, and Gerald Scott, offensive lineman. MIAMI (AFC) - Assigned Delvin Wil- liams, running back, to reserve-did not re- port list because of holdout. Waived Steve Fulson, tight end, Jerrold McRae, wide re- ceiver, Nate Henderson, offensive tackle, Mike Murphy and Paul Piurowski, line- backers, and Bill Searcy, offensive tackle. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Offered con- tract to Garry White, rookie running back from University of Minnesota, who was cut last week by San Francisco 49ers. Cut nine players: Ron McCall and Kevin Mill- er, a four-year pro, wide receivers, Ken Harris, running back, Brian Williams, tight end, Mike Guzzo, kicker, Bob Farra, quarterback, Ricky Robinson, defensive tackle, Marcus Fisher, cornerback, and Larry Brune, second-year safety. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Placed three players who underwent surgery re- cently on injured reserve list: Allan Clark and Rich Villela, running backs, and Gary Wright, tight end. Placed Steve Schindler, guard, and Barry Burget, linebacker, on reserve-did not report list. Announced loss of Ray Hamilton, nose tackle, for at least two weeks with sprained right ankle and further testing of Larry McGrew, line- backer, for knee problems. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Waived four players: Earnest Adams and Ken Sheets, linebackers, Artis Carhee, running back, and Mike Lush, defensive back. Placed eight players on the injured re- serve list: Terrell Ward, cornerback, Gail Davis, nose guard, Ray Sydnor, wide re- ceiver, Kelton Dansler, linebacker, Ken Blair, wide receiver, Bill Gower, fullback, Chris Kelly, guard-center, and Buddy Moor, defensive tackle.

title: Returning to the Source
description: He has 10 plays, four musicals, nine operas and an assortment of television productions and centennial celebrations to his credit, so it should come as no surprise that Arnold Sundgaard is at it again and on familiar ground.

title: 2,000 in 'People's Strike'
description: Doug Prichard, owner of the Pritchard Fence Company, organized a ''multipurpose strike'' Saturday to protest what he felt were the devastating economic effects in recent months of strikes, one against his company. Nearly 2,000 people visited his office or telephoned their support during the four-hour event, which he billed as a ''people's strike.''

title: No Headline
description: The proposal by a key aide to President Reagan that the tax laws be changed to encourage more contributions by middle- and higher-income donors to the arts and humanities was approved in principle today by a Presidential task force but not before the idea had been challenged as a benefit to the rich.

title: Connecticut Opera Gets A $27,300 Donation
description: The Connecticut Opera has received $27,300, the largest single gift ever received from an individual donor, from one of its past presidents.

title: U.S. to Transfer Iran Funds
description: The United States will transfer more than $2 billion of once-frozen Iranian funds to a Government bank in the Netherlands tomorrow under banking agreements signed in Amsterdam today, the Treasury Department announced.

title: No Headline
description: Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan is outspending his challenger in the Democratic primary, City Clerk David N. Dinkins, by better than 2 to 1.

title: LED RANGERS' HOCKEY TEAM
description: William M. Jennings, the president of the New York Rangers and a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame, died yesterday at his home in Byram, Conn. He was 60 years old and had been undergoing treatment for cancer the last five months.

title: Chess: Timman (the Giant-Killer) Adds Korchnoi to His List
description: Jan Timman, a Dutch grandmaster, notched his second straight triumph in the Las Palmas International Tournament, winning with an 8 1/2-1 1/2 score. Among others, Timman surpassed Viktor Korchnoi, challenger for the world championship this fall, to go with his victory over the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov, in the I.B.M. tournament in Amsterdam a month earlier.

title: World Church Council Meets in East Germany
description: The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches today opened its first meeting in 25 years in Eastern Europe and heard a strong attack on racism and a defense of the organization's policies in Africa.

title: DAY'S 'SIMIAN WORLD' IS BACK AGAIN
description: SIXTY years after its initial appearance, Clarence Day's first book, ''This Simian World,'' is being issued for the third time because Alfred A. Knopf, the patriarch of American book publishing who will be 89 years old on Sept. 12, thinks it's the cat's pajamas; or, as he put it the other day, ''still relevant to an understanding of the human animal in New York, Washington or anywhere else.''

title: 'FAIR LADY' UNDERSTUDY IS GOING ON
description: It was a year ago this month that the musical ''42d Street'' opened, bringing to Broadway yet another version of that familiar show-business story of the ingenue who is suddenly called upon to step in for the ailing star. Now, in a case of life imitating art, that very tale is being played out backstage at ''My Fair Lady,'' which opens tonight at the Uris Theater.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc., the subsidiary of Merrill Lynch & Company that deals in money market instruments, has been booming recently because of the growing investor interest in commercial paper, certificates of deposit and bankers acceptances. Now it has a new chairman and chief executive officer, Roger M. Vasey, 45, who also continues as president.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Nona Balakian SHAKESPEARE AND TRAGEDY. By John Bayley. 228 pages. Boston: Rout- ledge & Kegan Paul. Cloth, $25. Paper, $10.95.

title: Laker Asks Delay On Debt Payments
description: Sir Freddie Laker, who pioneered the cheap, nofrills trans-Atlantic fare, has found himself short of cash. Faced with large interest payments on recently purchased airplanes, Sir Freddie today confirmed reports that he had asked his bankers to postpone the payment of $234 million on long-term debts.

title: Thunderstorm Cited in Crash That Killed Five on a Balloon
description: The authorities said today that a sudden thunderstorm that swept a hot-air balloon into utility wires was the cause of a fiery crash that killed five persons, including one of the world's top-ranked free-fall parachutists.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
description: Interest rates soared yesterday at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills. The average rate realized on the three-month issue was 15.705 percent, up from 15.24 percent the week before, while the six-month rate climbed to 15.644 percent from 15.122.

title: Lendl Turns Back Teltscher in Final
description: Ivan Lendl defeated Eliot Teltscher, 6-3, 6-2, tonight and won the Canadian Open tennis title for the second straight year.

title: MARY FRANCES BARNARD
description: Mary Frances Barnard, the last survivor of an oil, ranching, banking and investments empire that donated an estimated $750 million to charity, died yesterday.

title: TOWARD MINORITY RULE?
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: For a year now the Soviet Union has been faced in Poland with a a series of challenges to Communist Party leadership unlike any in Eastern Europe since World War II.

title: IRAN REPORTS EXECUTION OF 23 LEFTISTS
description: The Iranian state radio reported today that 23 more leftists had been put to death as the Islamic leaders of Iran continued a crackdown against those they described as activists opposed to their rule.

title: TUESDAY, AUGUST 18, 1981; International
description: Libya indicated it was willing to reduce its official oil price of $40 a barrel, a concession that would help resolve a bitter OPEC price dispute. Saudi Arabia said it might also make a concession and raise its official price of $32. If OPEC manages to work out a unified price at a level below the current $36, analysts said, it would be the first time the 20-year-old group had ever voted to cut official prices. (Page A1.)

title: THE LIQUIDATION OF JOHN MUIR
description: Armed Federal marshals stood outside the offices of John Muir & Company yesterday to prevent employees from entering as the courtordered liquidation of the controversial Wall Street brokerage house was begun.

title: NEW HAVEN LINE DISRUPTED ANEW BY COS COB UNIT
description: Between 7,000 and 8,000 homeward-bound commuters were delayed for up to 53 minutes last night on Conrail's New Haven line when a generator at the Cos Cob power plant broke down.

title: Jets' Barber Seems Out for the Season
description: The Jets placed their second-round draft choice, Marion Barber, a fullback from the University of Minnesota, on the injured-reserve list today and pared their roster to 59, one below the National Football League limit they would have had to reach tomorrow.

title: REAGAN ENDS BAN ON SENDING ISRAEL 16 JET WARPLANE
description: President Reagan today lifted a 10-week-old suspension in the shipment of F-15 and F-16 jet fighters to Israel without reaching a conclusion on whether Israel had violated an agreement in using its American-made F-16's to bomb an Iraqi nuclear reactor in June.

title: CALLS HANDLING OF EXILES 'DISGRACE'
description: A Federal judge ordered the Government today to free 322 Cuban refugees who have spent more than a year in a Federal prison here unless it can give compelling reasons not to.

title: Conrail Agreements Reduce 285 Bargaining Pacts to 26
description: After more than five years of negotiations, Consolidated Rail Corporation announced today that it has consolidated what were 285 separate labor agreements into 26.

title: AFTER 15 YEARS, A HARLEM EXPERIMENT IS REAPPRAISED
description: MORE than 15 years ago a group of poor black children in Harlem started out in a preschool project that turned out to be an influential forerunner of the nation's Headstart program. For those youngsters, their teachers and their families, it was a time of great promise, an experiment that, if it worked, would give them an edge that would last all their lives. Did it fulfill that promise?

title: LATEST SWIMSUITS DEMAND SLEEKNESS IN THE WEARER
description: There is no panacea for bumps and bulges. Not in swimsuits. Not through 1982. So lollers in the sand this summer nibbling on bonbons, dreaming of camouflage to be provided next year by the growing ranks of fashion designers who have turned to swimsuits - as in other years they put their names to sunglasses, scarfs and shoes - be advised that there is no hope in sight. Spend the winter pushing away pie and pasta.Keep up the jogging, the indoor tennis, even the swimming.

title: TIME FOR A REAGAN DOCTRINE ON LABOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Groups Ask Exemption From F.T.C. Prize Rule
description: The American Advertising Federation and the National Association of Broadcasters and Telecom Productions have petitioned the Federal Trade Commission to exempt broadcast advertising from that part of the 1969 Games-of-Chance Rule that requires food retailers and gasoline companies to disclose information about the number of prizes and the odds of winning them.

title: Giants' King Looks for Corner
description: Like all other players in the Giants' training camp here, Jerome King knows that tomorrow is a special day but not necessarily a happy one.

title: Ofrex Bid Raised By Gallaher Ltd.
description: A unit of New York-based American Brands Inc. has raised its offer to acquire Ofrex Group Ltd. to about $64.4 million.

title: Soviet Revives Call To Ban Neutron Weapon
description: Reacting to Washington's decision to manufacture and stockpile neutron weapons, the Soviet Union today revived its three-year-old call for an international treaty to outlaw them.

title: Boycott of Meals Eases at Rikers
description: A majority of the inmates involved in a two-day boycott of meals on Rikers Island turned out for supper last night, the Correction Department said. Their return followed a promise by the warden to investigate inmates' complaints about food and visiting policies.

title: A SYNTHESIZER BAND WHOSE MUSICIANS OUTSMART MACHINES
description: PEOPLE who like synthesizers will tell you that they can do just about anything. Why hire a studio full of violinists when one musician can duplicate their sound with an Arp String Ensemble synthesizer? Why use a drummer on your rock-and-roll record when you can program a Moog to play any percussion pattern you want? For that matter, why bother with guitars, bass, brass, saxophones? Synthesizers can reproduce the sound of virtually any instrument, and they can create sounds that have never been heard before.

title: VETA GRANDE COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Yr-ago results are not available since the company was in the development stage...C-Includes tax credits of $227,127 for qr and $276,673 for 6 mos

title: U.S. STEEL CANCELS RISE IN TIN PRICE
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was withdrawing its price increase on tin mill products, which was to have gone into effect on Sept. 20, after the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation announced Monday night that it would not increase its prices until January.

title: Arco Says F.T.C.  Approves Sale
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said that it had won Federal Trade Commission permission to sell some copper properties in Montana to Asarco Inc.

title: OUTLOOK BRIGHTER FOR PAKISTANI-AFGHAN TALKS
description: Pakistan and Afghanistan have moved closer to talks aimed at the removal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, United Nations officials said today.

title: U.S. ACTS TO AVERT JAPAN ACTION
description: Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark met today with Japanese officials in an attempt to head off threatened restrictions on California farm produce because Japan fears it might harbor Mediterranean fruit flies.

title: PROF. LONGHAIR LIVES AS HIS MUSIC PLAYS ON
description: and-roll, died of a heart attack in January 1980, but his music lives on. Last week, both Dr. John at the Lone Star Cafe and the Neville Brothers at the Savoy performed Professor Longhair medleys, and the excitement they generated indicated just how potent Longhair's distinctive rumba-blues rhythms remain.

title: STOCK DROPS 37 1 4
description: A yearlong auction for the Delhi International Oil Corporation ended yesterday without a bidder and shareholders quickly registered their disappointment with a flurry of sell orders that pushed the stock down 37 1/4 points in one day, to 77 1/4, on the American Stock Exchange on a volume of 455,200 shares.

title: P.& G. to Buy Fruit Processor
description: Ben Hill Griffin Inc., a leading Florida citrus processor and grower, will sell its processing facilities to the Procter & Gamble Company for an undisclosed price, it was announced today.

title: Hague Coalition Postponed
description: The Christian Democratic Party postponed a decision on forming a three-party coalition today after the Prime Minister-designate, Dries van Agt, threatened to step down if the party joined the coalition without an agreement to cut $1.6 billion from the 1982 budget, a party spokesman said.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $6,920 investment gain for qr and $126,632 investment gain for 6 mos...C-Includes capital gains of $36,627 for qr and $59,208 for 6 mos

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUPERIOR ALTERNATIVES TO A STATEN ISLAND POWER PLANT
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Black Nationalists Convicted in South Africa
description: South Africa's Supreme Court convicted three black nationalists of high treason today for bombing an oil refinery and attacking a police station last year.

title: THE WORLD NEEDS A SECOND LANGUAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split effective Mar 16, 1981

title: South African Donated $25,000 to Rugby Unit
description: A businessman from South Africa with reported ties to that country's Government gave $25,000 last December to the Eastern Rugby Union, which then invited a South African rugby team to play in this country.

title: Freddie Mac To Sell Notes
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell short- and long-term debt issues backed by its own creditworthiness.

title: 6 BUILDERS CHOSEN FOR HOUSING AT BATTERY PARK CITY
description: Six real-estate companies were named yesterday to develop housing in Battery Park City that would reject the uniformity of other large projects and reflect the diversity of Manhattan neighborhoods.

title: REPUBLIC GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $364,000 for qr and $1,151,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $231,000 for qr and $833,000 for yr

title: SIPPICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 5
description: B-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $287,000 for qr and $469,000 for 6 mos

title: REAGAN IS SEEKING MORE BUDGET CUTS WORTH $75 BILLION
description: President Reagan today began a review of proposals aimed at achieving at least the $75 billion in additional budget cuts that his advisers said would be necessary to eliminate the Federal budget deficit by 1984.

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PARAMOUNT PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: The 1980 figures restated to reflect final effective income tax rate for fiscal yr 1980

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard FISTFUL OF SUGAR. By Alan Goldstein.Illustrated. 299 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $12.95.

title: News Analysis
description: In refusing to say whether Israel's bombing of Iraq's nuclear reactor did or did not violate its arms agreement with the United States, Washington has signaled a decision of another kind - to avoid a confrontation with Israel at a time when the Administration's Middle East diplomacy is still being formulated and Israeli cooperation will be vital for success.

title: CLAIBORNE LEAVES DELL TO JOIN WARNER BOOKS
description: To carry out its plans to ''increase, expand and diversify,'' Warner Books has named Ross H. Claiborne as vice president and publisher of its hardcover division.

title: SOVIET GIVES 'TARZAN' A 'NYET' RATING
description: The new Bo Derek movie, ''Tarzan the Ape Man,'' has earned a loud ''nyet'' from Soviet critics, one of whom complained that the film ''delivered less than it promised, even in terms of hard-core pornography.''

title: PSYCHOTHERAPY AND THE PROBLEM OF PRIVACY
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Plead Guilty In Stock Fraud
description: ALBANY (UPI) - The head of a New York City investment company and two members of his family pleaded guilty to charges of defrauding elderly New Yorkers of more than $2.4 million, the State Attorney General's office said.

title: SCREENWRITER, NOVELIST
description: Anita Loos, the screenwriter, playwright and novelist whose name was indissolubly linked with her book ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,'' died last night at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. She was 93 years old.

title: Pemex Eurocredit
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia said today that the Mexican state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, had given it verbal authority to raise a $200 million, six-year Eurocredit. The Eurocredit would be a club deal, with eight banks contributing $25 million each, the bank said. Interest would be at either one-half of a percentage point above London interbank offered rates, or three-eighths of a percentage point above the United States prime rate.

title: GUIDRY AND FRAZIER STOP WHITE SOX FOR YANKS, 4-0
description: Just when people were wondering, the Yankees broke their four-game losing streak last night by beating the Chicago White Sox, 4-0, and the revival was led by Ron Guidry.

title: Detectives Who Dine
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Will the article ''From Super Sleuths, Great Meals to Die By'' (Living Section, Aug. 5) temper the public's fondness for a good detective story as an acceptable substitute for excessive eating? Dilys Winn cites the obsession of fictional investigators with food - usually the fancier, the better.

title: CANADIANS ATTACK PRESS MONOPOLIES
description: A Canadian Government commission, born out of the ''shock and trauma'' of two major newspaper closings in a single day a year ago, urged tough measures today to limit concentration of ownership and enhance the quality and independence of Canadian newspapers.

title: Killer of 2 Girls Gets Added Term
description: A 27-year-old Johnstown man convicted of the murders of two teen-aged girls and serving two terms of 25 years to life, was sentenced again - to eight and a third to 25 years for the attempted murder of a 15-year-old Northville girl.

title: 2 UNITS TO STUDY EFFECTS OF STRIKE ON SAFETY IN AIR
description: Two Federal agencies said today that they had begun studies of whether the air controllers' strike had impaired safety.

title: TRUDEAU'S LIBERALS UPSET IN 2 CANADIAN ELECTIONS
description: Canadian voters in two special by-elections have handed Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal Party two defeats, one of them a stunning upset of Mr. Trudeau's chief political aide in what had been the Liberal Party's safest district in Canada.

title: Hunt Oil Planning To Buy Union Life
description: The Hunt Oil Company, the cornerstone holding of the wealthy Hunt family of Dallas, said that it had agreed to acquire the Union Life Insurance Company of Little Rock, Ark., for about $68.7 million.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SEEGER SALUTES HUDSON

title: Headquarters Sale Urged on M.T.A.
description: Richard Bernstein, the Republican candidate for City Comptroller, urged that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority sell its headquarters at 347 Madison Avenue.

title: BERVEN CARPETS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
King Presses Cooney To Sign for Title Bout
description: Don King, the boxing promoter, said today that Gerry Cooney must sign for a title fight with Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, by the end of this week or risk becoming ''just another contender.''

title: MORE WORKERS GET TAX BREAK AS THEY SAVE FOR RETIREMENT
description: Saving for retirement will be more attractive financially for many individuals under the new tax law. The rules are so beneficial, tax experts say, that virtually everyone with any kind of wage or salary income should be thinking of establishing a tax-exempt retirement account, even though the new provisions do not take effect until Jan. 1. ''Here you've got the simplest, safest tax shelter you could have,'' Herbert Paul, associate national tax director for Touche Ross & Company, said in an interview recently. ''This is a gift that everybody ought to take advantage of.''

title: CURTICE-BURNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
BOLT BERANEK & NEWMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $1.2 million gain from the sale of investment in General Telephone & Electronics Corp

title: FEDERAL GRAND JURY INDICTS 6 IN BOMBING OF CASINO AT TAHOE
description: A Federal grand jury indicted six persons today in the extortion bombing of a Lake Tahoe casino nearly a year ago.

title: RULING REVERSED ON HEAD SHOPS IN WESTCHESTER
description: A ruling that barred enforcement of a Westchester County law against the sale of ''drug paraphernalia'' was overturned yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: UNITED CANSO OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After special gains of $391,000 for the qr and $335,000 in the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: UNILEVER LTD AND UNILEVER NV reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIR FLORIDA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $7,962,055 gain on redemption of Series A preferred stock of Westgate-California Corp and on the disposition of Boeing 737 100 aircraft...C-Including $42,888 extraordinary gain

title: ATOMIC AGENCY FINDS ITS RULES ARE A PROBLEM
description: The operators of the nation's nuclear power plants have become so swamped by safety directives from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that a new ''potential safety problem of unknown dimensions'' has arisen, according to a commission staff report published today.

title: EXTRADITION IS SET IN OFFICER'S SLAYING
description: James Dixon York, accused of fatally shooting one New York City police officer and wounding another, waived extradition yesterday in Sumter, S.C. He was captured there Monday evening a week after the New York police received a tip on his whereabouts.

title: ICE CREAM SCOOPS
description: LIKE most kitchen tools, the ice-cream scoop has its secrets. The novice will take one or another of these utensils and, not quite knowing the rules that apply, will make the kind of small mistake that is hard to pinpoint in retrospect.

title: GREEK STORM BREWING
description: Ever since the fall of the military junta in Greece in August 1974 the country has had an unparalleled, almost uncharacteristic, political calm. Elections in 1974 and 1977 brought the same center-right majority to office. The strongman of Greek politics, Constantine Caramanlis, moved to the presidency after serving as Prime Minister for six years and was replaced by one of his lieutenants, George Rallis. This Jan. 1, Greece formally became a member of the European Economic Community and, despite the lack of an agreement on American bases, joined the integrated NATO command.

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CARTER RE-ELECTION GROUP GETS BILL FROM TREASURY
description: The Federal Election Commission today ordered the Carter-Mondale Re-election Committee of 1980 to pay the Treasury slighly more than $105,400, almost all of it interest that the Democrats earned on the Federal subsidy that financed their losing effort.

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PAUL BRUNTON
description: Paul Brunton, the author of 13 books on Oriental philosophy, died in the Good Samaritan Hospital in Vevey, Switzerland, on July 27.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: McG. Thomas Jr. Village People's Policeman Runs Afoul of Law

title: N.A.S.L.  Continues Indoor Play
description: The board of directors of the North American Soccer League, ending a two-day meeting in Chicago yesterday on the league's growing financial problems, put off most decisions until the annual meeting two months from now in Seattle.

title: Index; International
description: Costa Ricans up in arms over Mrs. Kirkpatrick A2 Israeli policy toward West Bank to ease, but doubts remain A3 Around the World A5 Pakistan and Afghanistan said to move closer to negotiations A7 Arthur A. Hartman is named U.S. Ambassador to Soviet Union A8 Canadian commission proposes curbs on press monopolies A11 Portuguese air traffic controllers seek to widen boycott A14 Government/Politics G.A.O. report urges stringent in- spection of slaughter plants A12 Atomic agency finds plant opera- tors swamped by its rules A13 Court overturns ruling against ''head shop'' law B2 7 hospital officials transferred or dismissed in New York B8 General Around the Nation A12 Atlanta's businesswomen finally have a home A12 Glacier park getting tougher with grizzly bears A12 Air traffic controller backed in collision A14 Indian family wins delay on deportation A16 Passersby save unborn baby's life after crash A18 The Region B2 Coast Guard recommendations on boating safety B3 Coast Guard hearing into L.I. cabin cruiser sinking begins B3 The City B4 27 persons are charged with fraudulent sales of a rare metal B4 Belmore Cafeteria being sold to make way for condominium B4 Living Section Food Time is ripe for tomatoes C1

title: Tear Gas Halts Melee At Nonunion Mine Site
description: The state police dropped tear gas from helicopters today to disperse 2,000 demonstrators who set fires and tore down fences at the construction site of a nonunion coal mine, officials said.

title: NATIONAL PARK GETTING TOUGH WITH GRIZZLY BEARS
description: Since three campers died of maulings by grizzly bears at Glacier National Park last summer, a new plan for controlling bears has been forged.

title: TRACY AUSTIN 2-SET WINNER
description: Tracy Austin, untroubled by Pam Casale's unusual backhand, scored a 6-3, 6-1 victory tonight in the second round of the $200,000 Canadian Open for women.

title: POLES SHUT DOWN THE OFFICIAL PRESS IN UNUSUAL STRIKE
description: A printers' strike called by the Solidarity labor union closed or disrupted most Polish newspapers today, an extraordinary action against the state-controlled press in the Soviet bloc.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Could you explain to me the difference between fish, shellfish and seafood? I had always thought that seafood included shellfish only. Friends tell me that seafood includes both fish and shellfish.

title: AMULEX CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 28
QUIXOTE IS SEEKING KOCH'S JOB
description: The subway car was packed and steamy, and the straphangers seemed about to slip into stupor. Suddenly a loud voice shattered the general torpor.

title: NBC Agrees to Share Legal Fees, C.F.A. Says
description: The College Football Association said today that NBC had agreed to pay half the costs of any legal fight the association might have with the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
K MART SLIPS 4.1%
description: The J.C. Penney Company, the nation's largest retailer after Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K mart Corporation, reported yesterday that earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended Aug. 1 had quadrupled as sales increased 8.2 percent. It cited better price margins and lower interest expense.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PASSERSBY SAVE UNBORN CHILD AS CAR ACCIDENT KILLS MOTHER
description: Passersby who administered cardiopulmonary resuscitation to a mother fatally injured in an automobile accident saved the life of her unborn child, the police say.

title: PENNCORP FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $4.4 million loss from discontinued operations and $117,000 capital gains...C-Net income including gains from discontinued operations of $306,000 and $683,000 and capital gains of $503,000 and $842,000 for qr and 6 mos, respectively...D-After $4.4 million loss from discontinued operations and capital gains of $603,000

title: A SOCIETY DEAD SET AGAINST ITS ELDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: PARKER-HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $4,856,000 gain from the sale of land

title: 27 CHARGED IN FALSE SALE OF VALUABLE, RARE METAL
description: Twenty-seven persons were arraigned in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday on charges of conspiring to defraud 144 investors of $1.3 million by pretending to sell them tantalum, a rare metal, while actually selling them scrap metal at four times its worth.

title: New Mexico Aide Tried In Expense Fraud Case
description: The prosecuting attorney said today that witnesses and documents introduced in the trial of Manny Goldstein, former assistant basketball coach at the University of New Mexico, would be like the pieces of a puzzle.

title: NO WRONGDOING FOUND IN AGENCY'S CONTROVERSIAL S.I. PIER PURCHASE
description: In 1977, under pressure from the courts and the residents of Staten Island, the Transit Authority began looking for a place to garage 250 buses used on the island. It located an unused pier on the borough's northeastern shore, which it bought for $1.8 million.

title: QUENCHING THE VARIED THIRSTS OF SUMMER
description: Whether conjured by innumerable sets of fervent tennis, or a hard time sprawled beneath the sun's rays, the thirst of summer demands quenching anew each day, with something more satisfying than water, and more original than plain iced tea or coffee. It often arises in midafternoon, a bit early to begin a round of gin and tonics, and there are inevitably parched children to contend with, then, whom one in good conscience refuses to refuel with yet another soda.

title: BELMORE CAFETERIA BEING SOLD TO CONDOMINIUM DEVELOPERS
description: There is perhaps no stereotype in this city as widespread, as enduring and, at base, as accurate, as the stereotype of the veteran New York cabdriver: raconteur, tour guide, inveterate kvetch, bon vivant, complainer and explainer, defender and reviler, the Renaissance New Yorker, part common man, part Catskills comic.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 19, 1981
description: International A printers' strike swept Poland, closing or disrupting the publication of most newspapers in the first labor action of its kind in the Soviet bloc. The walkout, which the independent union said would last two days, was called to protest what it says is a press offensive against it and to demand increased access for the union to the state-run media. (Page A1, Column 1.) Canada's Liberals were rebuffed in two by-elections. In one, the chief political aide of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau was trounced in what had been regarded as the Liberals' safest district in the country. (A10:1-3.)

title: THE NEED TO UNDERSTAND LAB AND OTHER TESTS AND TO ASSESS WHAT THEY FIND CORRECTLY
description: A 45-year-old friend proudly announced that he had just had a complete checkup and had been told that his cholesterol level and blood pressure were ''normal.'' When I asked what the readings were, he responded: ''Well, I don't know. The doctor didn't tell me, and anyway they wouldn't mean anything to me.''

title: FOOD PRICES DECLINE A LITTLE, BUT IT MAY BE JUST TEMPORARY
description: FOOD costs have declined in the last two weeks. The average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped 62 cents, from $107.20 to $106.58, during the period Aug. 3 to 14. But shoppers paid $8.49 more for food than during the same period last year.

title: SIBONEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes gain from discontinued operations of $89,804 for qr $66,765 loss for 6 mos and gains on sale of discontinued operations of $3,276,528 for qr and $3,559,675 for 6 mos... C-Includes $577,927 gain from discontinued operations... D-Net loss including $326,455 gain from discontinued operations

title: Herschel Walker Insured for $1 Million
description: Herschel Walker, the University of Georgia running back, has taken out an insurance policy worth a reported $1 million against injuries that would end his football career.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: RECENTLY in this space, William Cole first announced his great poetic invention, a new verse form for New York City: ''Poipetrator Voises.'' His inspiration, of course, was the full, authentic pronunciation of the word ''perpetrator'' by Gotham officialdom. Noting that a large number of words rhyme with ''poipetrator'' - ''such as incubator, respirator and, um, potater,'' as he wrote - Mr. Cole offered a host of examples of the new verse form, like this: Once there was a poipetrator Did away with old Judge Crater, He disappeared, like the equator Such a prestidigitator!

title: UNITED STATES REALTY INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $175,000 gain on the sale of property and $99,000 tax debt...C-Net income...D-Includes $3,809,000 on the sale of property and $1,512,000 tax credit...D-Net loss

title: Addenda
description: * Effective January, Tennis magazine is increasing advertising rates 14.1 percent. Golf Digest increases its advertising rates 11.9 percent and its circulation rate base by 1.5 percent, to 1,025,000, effective the same date.

title: Defector From Taiwan Joins Chinese Air Force in Peking
description: Huang Zhicheng, a former member of the Taiwan air force who defected to China in a United States-built F-5 jet 11 days ago, today joined the Chinese air force.

title: Beating the Clock at the Biltmore
description: ''Like everyone else I wore a camel's hair polo coat - it was the 50's after all - and a long wool scarf. And a dab of Arpege behind each ear, or maybe Chanel No. 5. We'd go there for something innocuous like a sherry before we got the Sunday night trains back to New Haven or Providence or Boston ... I remember coming in from cold autumn afternoons to a hum of conversation and an occasional 'Hey Bob, over here!' or 'B.J., for heaven's sake!' And I remember feeling excited even if I wasn't meeting anyone under the clock. It was like a club, an enormous, noisy, cozy club. Then someone would say 'It's getting close to 7' and we'd dash for Grand Central, lugging our souvenirs. A theater program, maybe, or a few swizzle sticks.''

title: Conrail Faces Layoffs of 195
description: More than half of the employees at the Consolidated Rail Corporation's car shop in Reading, Pa., will be laid off, a move expected to result in savings of about $12 million a year, the federally subsidized railroad said today.

title: CITY HOSPITAL OFFICIALS OUSTED IN INQUIRY ON MICROFILM COMPANY
description: The executive directors of two New York City hospitals have been transferred from their posts and five other officials at the same hospitals have been dismissed following charges that a microfilm company stole $853,000 from the municipal hospital system.

title: TWIN FAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $117,000 for qr and $100,000 for 6 mos and 1981 results include $1,820,000 gain from sale of Ohio Discount Dept Store division completed in May...C-Includes tax credits of $802,000 and $2,366,000 and gains from discontinued operations of $360,000 and $541,000 for qr and 6 mos respectively

title: NUMEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELI SHIFT ON ARABS: REAL OR MIRAGE
description: A week ago, a select group of Israeli political reporters were summoned to Defense Ministry headquarters in Tel Aviv for a closed briefing.

title: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jersey City Section Gets Water Again
description: JERSEY CITY (UPI) - Water started flowing again to two apartment complexes that had been without service since a 100-year-old main ruptured over the weekend, the Jersey City Water Department reported.

title: New Zealand Rail Car Kills 4
description: Four people died when a diesel rail car carrying about 70 passengers from Wellington to Auckland jumped the tracks and rolled down an embankment in this remote part of New Zealand's North Island today, the police said. The number of people injured in the accident was not immediately known.

title: Portugal's Social Democrats Ask Backing for Government
description: Portugal's Social Democratic Party has called on its Christian Democratic coalition partners to give full backing to a new government led by Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao.

title: Tax-Exempt Bonds Decline
description: The tax-exempt market, totaling more than $300 billion in face value of bonds, fell sharply yesterday as a result of the Federal Reserve's continuing tight clamp on credit conditions and other worrisome factors.

title: UNITED ASBESTOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HEWLETT-PACKARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings amounts reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June

title: Nelson Changes Mind About Trading Johnson
description: Coach Don Nelson of the Milwaukee Bucks today reversed his contention that he would never trade Marques Johnson.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Westinghouse Cable Acquisition
description: The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company said that it had completed the acquisition of the Teleprompter Corporation, a leading cable television company, for about $650 million.

title: Real Estate; An Atrium For Public In Midtown
description: THE proposed revision of midtown zoning in Manhattan removes many of the bonuses for urban design amenities such as ''covered pedestrian spaces'' with which city planners had sought in recent years to encourage more lively office building design.

title: NETWORKS ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in July 1981

title: The Nose Knows When Skunk Trappers Fail
description: How do you trap a skunk? Very carefully, says George Schavlay, game warden of Little Egg Harbor Township, N.J. Mr. Schavlay advised the other day that in the case of skunks, ''You really have to have a way with them, you have to charm them.'' The 47-year-old game warden, whose job virtually foreordains that he work alone, said his main concern was that skunks were capable of spraying their nauseating vapors up to 25 feet.

title: Careers; Outsiders Sought as Directors
description: AFTER the furor over Du Pont's acquisition of Conoco had died down, Du Pont said that at least four top officials of Conoco would join its board of directors.

title: PERMITS OFF
description: The sagging United States housing industry revived slightly in July, with housing starts rising 3.3 percent, to 1.06 million units, after falling more than 10 percent in each of the previous two months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PSYCHOTHERAPY AND THE PROBLEM OF PRIVACY To the Editor:     You are to be commended for the publication of Dava Sobel's news article ''Thousands With Mental Health Insurance Choose to Pay Own Bill'' (Science Times, Aug. 4).
description: Armed forces personnel, civil servants, politicians, teachers, students and corporate executives are particularly vulnerable to the problem of jeopardized careers or privacy. A senior insurance executive, sophisticated in the methods of handling sensitive client information, confirmed the reality of the problem when it came to paying for his own psychotherapy.

title: HOW FAR CAN A MEDFLY FLY?
description: Every time California bug killers think they have the pesky Mediterranean fruit fly cornered, it escapes to infect a new area. New infestations have been found outside the zone of aerial spraying near San Francisco, and now more have been found across the mountains in the lush San Joaquin Valley. No natural barriers remain to impede the Medfly's ruinous progress.

title: 500 Flee as Man Threatens Suicide
description: A man dissatisfied with the processing of a Federal workers' compensation claim pulled out a flare gun yesterday afternoon and, threatening to kill himself, forced the removal of 500 people from five floors of Labor Department offices on Times Square.

title: United Airlines To Add Flights
description: United Airlines said that, subject to approval by the Federal Aviation Administration, it plans to initiate service on Oct.1 to four cities, expand service to four others and offer low-cost flights in the West.

title: SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPANY NEWS; Moody's Lowers Du Pont's Rating
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, burdened with billions of dollars in debt from its acquisition of Conoco Inc., lost its bluechip credit rating yesterday.

title: MOSTLY MOZART: RAMPAL PLAYS AND LEADS
description: WHEN Jean-Pierre Rampal played the flute in Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night, he demonstrated why he is so popular that he is featured in five Mostly Mozart Festival concerts this summer - he had, as usual, versatile fingers, a lovely tone and seamless legato.

title: VILLAGE VIEW OF THE WORLD
description: SEIS, Italy - Far from the headlines, how do people of this tiny village in the Dolomite Alps - about 1,500 inhabitants - think of the events behind the news?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * First Interstate Bancorp, Los Angeles, has elected to its board Warren Christopher, a former United States Deputy Secretary of State.

title: 2 Children Killed In a Camden Fire
description: A young brother and sister were killed in a fire that trapped them in a bedroom closet on the second floor of their home, authorities said.

title: Playoff Decision Put Off
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn yesterday delayed his decision on a change in the format for the major league's split-season playoffs. Kuhn met with the league presidents, Lee MacPhail of the American and Charles Feeney of the National, but no announcement was made regarding the split-season and playoff systems adopted by the owners after the 50-day players strike.

title: Hinckley's Jail Changed As Psychiatric Tests End
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., accused of trying to kill President Reagan, was transferred today to the Marine base at Quantico, Va., from his Federal prison cell in Butner, N.C., after extensive psychiatric tests.

title: New Haven Line Has Few Delays
description: There were no major delays on Conrail's New Haven line, although several trains were 10 to 15 minutes late in the morning rush, Conrail officials said.

title: REAGAN'S NEW DEAL
description: On every side we are told that President Reagan and Congress have repealed the New Deal and that the Democrats have no ideas. The President and Congress have done no such thing, and the Democrats' New Deal forebears might have said, rather, that the Democrats have short memories or know little history. The Democrats' present confusion set in with President Johnson's radical departure from New Deal principles to construct what he called the Great Society. Consider the history.

title: Hewlett Net Up by 15.7%
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the giant electronic instrument producer, reported a 15.7 percent increase in earnings today on a 15.6 percent rise in sales for the third quarter of its fiscal year.

title: ANIMALS AS ANIMALS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: For every monkey, snake and exotic bird that clings to a strolling New Yorker, many more die in transit. Those who claim to be animal lovers, yet provide the market for this bloody trade that is depopulating jungles, should think again about the consequences of their purchase. ANITRA BROWN

title: I.M.F. ROLE IN POLAND TLAKS SET
description: The International Monetary Fund will send a representative to a meeting in Paris next month between the Polish Government and its Western creditors, heightening speculation that Poland will seek membership in the 141-nation lending agency as a means of dealing with its mounting financial problems.

title: BONANZA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nuclear Fuel in Japan
description: Japan's Atomic Energy Commission gave the goahead today to build the country's first prototype commercial uranium-enrichment plant for providing fuel to the domestic nuclear power industry. The $304 million plant, which still needs final Government approval, would begin partial operation in 1986 and produce enough enriched uranium to fuel two one-million-kilowatt atomic power plants for a year.

title: Jets Interested In Sam Bowers
description: While every other team in the National Football League was paring its roster to 60 players by the 4 P.M. deadline today, the Jets, who had trimmed to one under the limit yesterday, were trying to fill a spot. They did so by listing Sam Bowers, a tight end from White Plains High School and Fordham who was placed on waivers by the Giants a week ago.

title: Suspect Killed In Drug Seizure
description: ROCHESTER (AP) - A suspected drug dealer was killed and three policemen were wounded yesterday in an airport parking lot as detectives were trying to arrest two men carrying several million dollars' worth of heroin, the police said.

title: HYSTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After foreign currency losses of $4.4 million for qr and $5.8 million for 6 mos...C-After foreign currency losses of $2.3 million for qr and $1.9 million for 6 mos and tax credit of $2 million

title: 'ABUSE' VS. 'CONTACT'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: A story about the fifth National Conference on Child Abuse and Neglect (''Child-Abuse Parley Deplores Fund Cuts,'' Living Section, April 8) carried the misstatement that one of every four American girls is sexually abused. This is a preposterous proposition advanced by the child-abuse lobby, which like most pressure groups, bends statistics to advance its cause.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE are specialized forms of cookery or cooking techniques that have always fascinated me, and one of these is the technique of cooking foods in paper, or, as it is known in French, en papillote. As most Southerners can tell you, this means wrapping and sealing foods with a sauce or seasonings in parchment and baking until done. The foods generally remain notably moist, and the ''bag'' in which the foods are cooked puffs up. There are, generally speaking, two ways to serve such foods: Either cut a circle from the top of the puffed paper to expose the dish, or open the package and transfer the foods to individual dishes.

title: BROWN HINTS RETALIATION ON TRADE IF JAPAN BARS CALIFORNIA PRODUCE
description: Threatened with a Japanese embargo that could cost California farmers millions of dollars, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. warned the Japanese Ambassador today that such a ban could result in retaliation by the State Legislature against Japanese imports.

title: COSTA RICA UP IN ARMS OVER MRS. KIRKPATRICK
description: Government and opposition leaders here have angrily disputed a charge by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate to the United Nations, that Costa Rican democracy is being undermined by Communist subversion.

title: Selma Stern-Taubler Is Dead; A Specialist on German Jews
description: Dr. Selma Stern-Taubler, a scholar in German Jewish history, died on Monday in Basel, Switzerland.

title: Sailor Sentenced to 30 Years In Fatal Stabbing of Shipmate
description: A 20-year-old sailor who said he was under the influence of drugs when he stabbed a sleeping shipmate to death aboard the amphibious assault ship Saipan was sentenced today to 30 years in Federal prison.

title: Stolen Audubon Birds Book Returned to Peabody Library
description: A $250,000, 90-pound volume of Audubon's ''The Birds of America'' that was stolen in June from a locked glass case at the Peabody Institute Library has been recovered, District Attorney Kevin M. Burke of Essex County said today.

title: UNILEVER PLC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: On June 1 Unilever Ltd changed its name to Unilever PLC in compliance with the Companies Act 1980 of Britain; Unilever NV and Unilever PLC form the Unilever Group

title: UNISERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Public Housing and the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: SINKING PROMPTS COAST GUARD TO RENEW BOATING SAFETY SUGGESTIONS
description: Coast Guard safety specialists say the events that occurred before the 36-foot cabin cruiser Karen E was hit by a barge towed by a tugboat in Long Island Sound 10 days ago exemplify a host of problems that can suddenly confront amateur boaters.

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boarding Woman Resident Says Operator Tricked Her
description: One of five elderly women who turned up in Detroit after disappearing from a Miami boarding home says she was tricked from the start by the boarding home operator.

title: Olympia & York Buys Hiram Stake
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd., a development and natural resources concern, reported in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that three of its subsidiaries now owned 4,024,300 common shares, or 5.9 percent, of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.

title: Bombs Explode in West Berlin At Allied Military Installations
description: Two bombs exploded early today at American and British Army installations, but did no damage, the authorities said.

title: ORCHESTRATED TOP MUSICALS
description: Robert Russell Bennett, the American composer and conductor celebrated mostly for the orchestration of such wildly successful Broadway hits as ''Show Boat,'' ''Oklahoma!'' and ''My Fair Lady,'' died yesterday in his suite at the Warwick Hotel on West 54th Street. He was 87 years old.

title: Lerner Weds Actress He Directed as Eliza
description: Alan Jay Lerner, lyricist and librettist of ''My Fair Lady,'' was married last Thursday in Billingshurst, England, to Liz Robertson, whom he met when he directed her in the role of Eliza Doolittle in a recent London revival of his musical.

title: SERVICES REPORT MANPOWER GAINS
description: The Defense Department reported today that higher pay and growing public support for the armed forces had pushed the services to nearly 100 percent of their manpower objectives for the nine months ended June 30.

title: Decline in Brazil Wheat Crop
description: The United States agricultural attache in Brasilia yesterday lowered the estimate of Brazil's 1981-82 wheat crop to 1.5 million tons from 1.95 million because of frost and drought damage in the province of Parana.

title: PAN AM SEEKS SALE OF HOTELS
description: Pan American World Airways, struggling to raise cash for its money-losing airline operation, said yesterday that it was in ''active negotiations'' for the sale of its most profitable subsidiary, the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation.

title: G.M. to Delay Land Purchase
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would delay indefinitely the purchase of land for a new $500 million car assembly plant in Wyandotte County, Kan., because of a continued slump in car sales.

title: F.A.A. Issues Subpoenas
description: A regional official of the Federal Aviation Administration said today that the agency had subpoenaed about 75 news organizations in Washington, Idaho and Oregon for records, film and photographs of striking air traffic controllers.

title: TV: 'IRENE,' A SITUATION-COMEDY PILOT
description: IF nothing else, summer's spate of one-shot airings of pilots that never made it should convince cynics that someone out there in televisionland does draw the line somewhere. ''Irene,'' to be shown tonight at 9:30 on NBC-TV, doesn't weigh in at the lowest common sitcom denominator.

title: BUSINESSWOMEN OF ATLANTA FINALLY HAVE A HOME
description: The idea has raised some eyebrows, generated some frowns and touched off some broad smiles. But its real test begins tomorrow. That is when the doors of a new private dining club for businesswomen open here.

title: Eastern Joins Refund Effort
description: Eastern Airlines said today that it had joined Delta Air Lines in an effort to collect millions of dollars in taxes the airlines assert the City of Atlanta collected illegally.

title: TROPICAL STORM CROSSES FLORIDA, TRAVELING NORTH
description: Tropical storm Dennis, which dumped flooding rains on south Florida for three days, moved off the state's east coast last night. Forecasters warned that it could grow into a hurricane and threaten the Carolinas.

title: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ayala and McCrory On Hearns Undercard
description: Tony Ayala and Milton McCrory, unbeaten teen-agers, and Marvis Frazier, son of the former heavyweight champion Joe Frazier, were named yesterday to head the undercard for the Sept. 16 welterweight title fight between Thomas Hearns and Sugar Ray Leonard at Las Vegas, Nev.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: FORGET that tipping was once a reward for good service, and accept that it has now become an expected subsidy for something that should have been done anyway. Still, there is a difference between being a peasant and a patsy.

title: Market Place; Callon's Gas Royalties
description: THE Callon Petroleum Company, a corporation that acts as general partner in gas royalty plans, has been offering its limited partners a premium rate of return while building gas reserves for its shareholders.

title: Movie Ads on TV Up by 61% in 1980
description: Motion picture advertising on network television increased last year by 61 percent, to an estimated $103.3 million, making it the fastest-growing major category of advertising on network, according to Broadcast Advertisers Reports.

title: JACOB'S PILLOW PIONEER COMES HOME
description: BARTON MUMAW comes home to Jacob's Pillow this week. Mr. Mumaw, a longtime associate of the late Ted Shawn, the pioneering modern-dance figure who founded the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival 48 years ago, appears through Saturday at the festival in Becket, Mass. He will perform solos choreographed by himself and by Mr. Shawn as part of the festival's ''American Sampler'' program, which also includes dances by Isadora Duncan, performed by Annabelle Gamson, and performances by Clive Thompson, the folk-dancing Vanaver Caravan and the Berkshire Ballet.

title: IS UNESCO TO BLAME?
description: Unesco is being used, it appears, as the scapegoat for America's failure to awake to the development and challenges of the free flow of information in the world, locally and internationally, and of our failure to develop an effective response.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONFRONTING A TABOO SUBJECT IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO ON the morning before Christmas, Atsuko Chiba woke up and discovered a lump in her breast. ''I was sure it must be cancer,'' she said, citing a history of cancer in her family. She was right. Like a growing number of Japanese women, she underwent surgery to remove a breast. But unlike other Japanese women, for whom cancer is largely a taboo subject, Miss Chiba wrote about her experience.

title: AT SARATOGA, THE BETS ARE ON THE NOSE
description: At 10:29 each night, about 20 men standing behind the Spa City Diner, an all-night eatery also known for its cheesecake, begin to shift nervously under a Greyhound bus sign. The 6:30 from New York is due. The men are not expecting a friend or a relative or an early edition of a newspaper. They are waiting for a messenger who will step off the bus and hand them envelopes containing a set of numbers. They say those numbers can help them beat the races.

title: BLOUNT IS AMONG 10 DROPPED BY GIANTS
description: A year ago, Tony Blount excited people at the Giants' training camp. A third-round draft choice from Virginia, he was a hard tackler who leveled his workout opponents from his safety position.

title: NEWARK OFFICIAL IS FACING CHARGES
description: NEWARK Aug. 18 - The president of Newark's Board of Education was arraigned today on charges of attempted murder, illegal possession of weapons and aggravated assault in connection with attacks on two men last month.

title: Thank You, Mr.  LaRussa, for Your Counsel
description: THE towering intellects of baseball are clanking and groaning and sending up blue curls of smoke as they ponder how to putty up the holes in the split season and playoff plan they swiped so hastily from the bush leagues. It is hoped that if they accomplish it, they adopt by acclamation a resolution of thanks to Counselor Tony LaRussa, the White Sox manager, for calling attention to their bungling.

title: LICENSES FOR GENE-SPLICING
description: Gene-splicing recently passed a major milestone on its journey from the laboratory to the marketplace with Stanford University's issuance of a nonexclusive licensing agreement covering the use of patented splicing techniques invented by researchers at Stanford and the University of California.

title: INDIANS GRANTED DELAY ON OUSTER
description: Shailesh K. Patel seemed stunned. He had just learned that, instead of facing deportation Sunday, he and his family had 60 more days before an expulsion order issued by the Immigration and Naturalization Service would go into effect.

title: HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Steffen Leads by Shot With 68 in Met. Golf
description: Doug Steffen, the head pro at Middle Bay of Oceanside, L.I., scored a three-under par 68 today to take the lead in the first round of the Metropolitan Golf Association Open.

title: Death of 3 Texas Youths Brings 3 Indictments
description: A deputy sheriff, a reserve deputy and a county probation officer were indicted today on misdemeanor charges of criminally negligent homicide in the deaths of three youths who drowned while in their custody.

title: Unilever Earnings Rise 42.7%
description: The Unilever Group, the mammoth British-Dutch food and industrial products company, reported yesterday that combined earnings in the second quarter of 1981 increased 42.7 percent, while combined sales advanced 12.9 percent.

title: JULY INCOME SURGED 1.6% AND SPENDING ROSE 1.2%
description: Americans' personal income surged 1.6 percent in July, the largest gain in a year, the Commerce Department reported today. It cited rising employment and a midyear increase in Social Security payments.

title: Bozell Selects New Executive
description: Hailing it as the ''greatest partnership since Max Dane met Bill Bernbach,'' G. Bruce McLaren, who has been president of Bozell & Jacobs's Atlantic division for all of seven weeks, has chosen Neal Dearling as executive vice president and executive creative director.

title: HARVEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RELEASING PLANES IS NO MIDEAST POLICY
description: There was never much doubt that Israel would get its 16 new warplanes from the United States, no matter how great American distress over its attacks on the Iraqi reactor and Lebanese civilians. President Reagan was not condoning those raids in lifting the two-month embargo. But implicitly, his action shows how flimsy are the strings attached to American arms sales.

title: 4 POLICE OFFICERS LOSE THEIR JOBS IN BURGLARY CASE
description: Four police officers, including an eight-year veteran with 32 citations for excellence, were dismissed from the force yesterday after a departmental trial found that they had sought to commit a burglary at a bakery-supply company's offices in the Bronx.

title: STRUGGLE TO RECCOVER AT B.P.
description: For the past two years or so, the British Petroleum Company has been running advertisements on television, in newspapers and on billboards here trumpeting itself as ''Britain at its best.'' The ads are now in suspension, just for the summer, and, coincidentally, so is B.P.'s once-outstanding performance - but perhaps for quite a bit longer.

title: HEIST, C H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
43 Death Penalties Asked In 3 Trials in Turkey
description: Military prosecutors demanded the death penalty today for 43 suspected terrorists being tried on charges of insurrection in three cases in Istanbul and Ankara.

title: Animals as Animals; 07TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: Your recent photo essay, ''Pets Join the Summer Street Circus'' (Living Section, Aug. 5) exacerbates a serious problem in New York City and across the nation - the victimization of exotic animals by amateur owners. It is one thing to own a cat, dog or some goldfish - but it's an entirely different and often dangerous matter to be the owner of a pet python, raccoon or monkey.

title: VENDO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After gains of $870,000 from proceeds of a lawsuit and $725,000 from sales of a warehouse...C-Net loss

title: HARTMAN, VETERAN DIPLOMAT, IS NAMED ENVOY TO MOSCOW
description: Arthur A. Hartman, a veteran of more than 30 years of Government service who has urged America's West European allies to take a strong stand against Moscow, was named United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union today.

title: IRANIAN HIJACKERS SAIL TO MARSEILLES
description: Iranian exiles who hijacked an Iranian gunboat off the Spanish coast last week sailed into Marseilles today, let crew members debark and demanded permission to refuel. The French refused, and the hijackers threatened to blow up the vessel. (But negotiations continued, and the French offered political asylum if the exiles agreed to go ashore peacefully, Reuters reported. Later the hijackers, who were said to number about 20, agreed, according to The Associated Press, to let the French tow their vessel out of the busy Marseilles harbor eastward toward Toulon, but it was not clear if the standoff had been resolved.)

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After gains from discontinued operations of $50,166 for the qr and $88,183 for the 6 mos...C-After gains from discontinued operations of $75,072 for the qr and $74,913 for the 6 mos

title: THE STAGE: 'MY FAIR LADY' RETURNS
description: Rex Harrison returned triumphantly last night to his role as Henry Higgins in ''My Fair Lady,'' 25 years after he first electrified audiences in Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe's masterful musical transformation of Shaw's ''Pygmalion.'' The revival at the Uris Theater should attract a new generation of theatergoers and should also disarm skeptics who believe that Broadway history cannot repeat itself. Mr. Harrison is older, but he is still the quintessential Higgins, who, after all, could never be considered youthful.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Norman B. Levy, a longtime film industry sales executive, has in recent years been closely associated with Alan J. Hirschfield, first at Columbia Pictures Industries and since January 1980, at the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation. Now, a month after Mr. Hirschfield was promoted to chairman and chief executive officer of Fox by Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman who purchased the company last spring, Mr. Levy has been appointed to Mr. Hirschfield's former post of vice chairman. The changes follow the resignation of Dennis C. Stanfill as chairman and chief executive officer late in June after a dispute with Mr. Davis. C. Joseph LaBonte continues as president.

title: Companies
description: Pan Am is negotiating the sale of Intercontinental Hotels, a highly profitable subsidiary, to raise cash for its money-losing airline operation. Other measures to shore up its finances include a delay in the delivery of new jetliners and an agreement for a $200 million revolving credit conditional on union wage cuts. (Page D1.)

title: President for Filmways
description: After less than a year with the company, Gerald S. Armstrong has been promoted to president and chief operating officer of Filmways Inc. Mr. Armstrong, 38, succeeds Richard L. Bloch as president. Mr. Bloch remains chairman and chief executive officer of the Los Angeles-based entertainment and publishing company.

title: Hearing on Atlanta Trial Set
description: Judge Clarence Cooper of the Superior Court said yesterday that he would hear arguments Friday on an Atlanta Press Club request for live television and still camera coverage of the Wayne B. Williams trial. Judge Cooper received the petition Monday after Mr. Williams pleaded not guilty to charges that he murdered two of the 28 young blacks whose slayings terrorized the city for almost two years.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for Bellwether issues

title: Seaver Outduels Carlton
description: Tom Seaver outpitched Steve Carlton tonight as the Cincinnati Reds scored a 3-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: CAPTAIN OF TUG TELLS HEARING BARGE COULD NOT HAVE HIT CRUISER
description: A tugboat captain testified yesterday that there was no way that a barge he was towing could have been involved in a cabin cruiser's sinking, in which five persons drowned, on Long Island Sound 10 days ago.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Maria Martin was back with her parents today after a 10-day kidnapping that ended when a police chief tricked a kidnapping suspect.

title: WHEN DINING OUT WAS HARDLY SUMPTUOUS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The latest novel by Avery Corman, author of ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' is ''The Old Neighborhood,'' just published in paperback by Bantam Books. By AVERY CORMAN

title: Plaque in Harlem a Memorial to Fats Waller
description: The house on West 134th Street is gone now, torn down to make way for a school, but the man who grew up there became one of Harlem's most famous sons, and today his own son will join Harlem leaders in dedicating a commemorative plaque at the site where Fats Waller spent his boyhood years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have no reason to believe that the system has deteriorated in safety in any way.'' - J. Lynn Helms, Federal Aviation Administration director. (A1:2)

title: KLEINDIENST'S PERJURY TRIAL BEGINS IN PHOENIX
description: Richard G. Kleindienst, who was Attorney General in the Nixon Administration, went on trial today on charges that he lied in an Arizona Bar Association investigation into his role in an insurance fraud.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Baltimore Gas and Electric Company said it had filed an offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission of $100 million of 30-year mortgage bonds to be sold by an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Salomon Brothers. * Carl Karcher Company filed an issue of 1.4 million common shares.

title: POLI'S MISCALCULATION
description: Tothe Editor: The saddest thing about the air traffic controllers' strike is that it is so unnecessary. Most air travelers who have experienced them would agree that a slowdown, the usual trump card of the controllers' union, is far more effective than a strike, at least at causing economic discomfort and forcing the Federal Government closer to union demands.

title: A PROMISING NEW YORK STATE WINERY IS STRUGGLING BACK FROM A BAD WINTER
description: Ben Feder stood in his vineyard and pointed to a row of vines. ''These are usually jammed,'' he said. ''Now there's almost nothing.'' A cluster of grapes is evident here, another cluster there, but they are far apart and stunted. They are called bullets, Mr. Feder said, because they are stunted and taste of acid, a result of secondary growth after the lethal frost last December that New York wine makers call the Christmas massacre.

title: An Echo of the Oscar Wilde Affair
description: It took him 36 years to do it, but yesterday Edward Colman, executor of the estate of Lord Alfred Douglas, proved in London Bankruptcy Court that the writer and figure in the scandalous Oscar Wilde libel trial, could no longer be considered a bankrupt.

title: 1.Rustic Wares
description: Cat pillows made from antique quilts, handmade copper colanders, tritoned laminated wood rolling pins and off-white rag rugs are among the rustic wares in a new department called A Country Craft that just opened in Macy's Cellar. Just about everything in the shop would make an appropriate gift for the weekend host or hostess. Practicality is combined with handsomeness in many of the offerings such as the rag rugs ($18) and the rolling pins ($24). Potholders ($5) come in calico prints or patchwork. Oversize ceramic hot plates, with a hole for hanging on a wall, are decorated with animal motifs such as a rabbit, duck or fish ($28). There's more than a touch of whimsy in many of the items, which seem to be intended for a child's room. These include clothing hooks shaped like pigs, cows, horses and teddy bears ($18), and napkin rings that are painted wooden cats with curled tails forming the opening ($5.50). Not only for children are the catshaped pillows ($32), which are one of a kind and should be appreciated by anyone who collects old quilts.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Nuclear Corp. said it had engaged Kidder, Peabody & Co. to seek a buyer for its uranium assets.

title: Bridge: Rare Comeback Succeeds In Double Knockout Play
description: When a strong team loses in the first round of a knockout event, the players can do no more than moan about the blows dealt them by the fates and wait for a better day. But if the event is a Swiss teams or a double knockout event, the losers are still in business, although the odds against victory are substantial.

title: NU-WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LUMET'S 'PRINCE OF THE CITY'
description: Although Sidney Lumet's ''Prince of the City'' has an atmosphere deeply redolent of crime and corruption, very few specific misdeeds are ever shown on the screen. They don't have to be. Mr. Lumet's film offers such a sharply detailed landscape, such a rich and crowded portrait, that his characters reveal themselves fully by the ways they move, eat, speak, listen or lie.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shrs adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split paid in Feb

title: RETAINING ORDER TO BLOCK BILTMORE DEMOLITION EXPIRE
description: New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission tried yesterday to devise a way to stop demolition work in the Biltmore Hotel as the last of the restraining orders sought by private preservation groups expired.

title: Bergey Is Placed by Eagles on Injured-Reserve List
description: Bill Bergey, the linebacker who had been a Pro Bowl player five times in 12 seasons, was placed on the injured-reserve list by the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday, an action suggesting that his career might be near an end.

title: PORTUGUESE SEEKING WIDE BOYCOTT
description: Portuguese air traffic controllers ended a two-day boycott of flights to and from the United States early today, but said they would promote a worldwide action in support of striking American colleagues.

title: Canada Diesel Sale
description: Canada and the Egyptian national railway today signed financing arrangements for a $155 million sale of another 51 diesel locomotives to Egypt.

title: SEABOARD ALLIED MILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
AMERICAN ART GOING TO CHINA
description: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston is sending an exhibition of 200 years of American art to China next month, the first under a cultural agreement signed in January 1979.

title: SAUDI PRICE PLAN ARGUED BY OPEC
description: Saudi Arabia's bid to establish a unified pricing structure for OPEC oil that would involve big rollbacks for some major producers appeared to be running into difficulties tonight.

title: Credit-Card Fraud Curb
description: A computerized system to reduce the credit card industry's fraud and credit losses was announced yesterday by Visa USA. David A. Huemer, vice president for operations of Visa International's United States subsidiary, said that in 1980 Visa USA members alone recorded nearly $400 million in such losses, while the card industry as a whole ''was staggering under a $1 billion loss burden.''

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Assigned Rawly Eastwick, right-handed relief pitcher, to 21-day disabled list retroactive to Aug. 12.; COLLEGE FRANKLIN (Ind.) - Robert Lovell re- signed as basketball coach.  LONG ISLAND UNIVERSITY - Ex- tended contract of Paul Lizzo, basketball coach, through 1983. Appointed LaVozier LaMar head coach of women's basketball.  SOUTHERN ILLINOIS - Named Lew Hartzog, track coach, acting director of athletics effective Sept. 1. He replaces Gale Sayers, former all-pro running back
description: Lawrence Savage, linebackers, Hubie Bond, John Puhalski and Bob Lisowski, tight ends, David Booze, Lee Haynes, and Ken Robinson, wide receivers, Bruce Byrom and Dennis McKnight, centers, Henry Foster, running back, Steve Sybel- don, guard, Doug Woodward, quarter- back, DENVER (AFC) - Signed Fred Stein- fort, free-agent kicker who was a holdout, to new contract. Placed three players on the injured reserve list: Keith Bishop, guard, Matt Braswell, tackle, and An- thony Arnold, wide receiver. Cut I.M. Hipp, Mandel Robinson, and Ron Greene, running backs, John Smith and David Scott, wide receivers, Roy White, Mel Land, and Perry Drake, linebackers, Mike Nolan, defensive back, Carl Allen, center, Rusty Olsen, defensive lineman, and Roy Geirger, kicker. DETROIT (NFC) - Assigned four players to injured reserve list: Jesse Thompson, wide receiver, Willie Jackson, defensive back, Dennis Hartman, running back, and Robert Barnes, defensive line- man. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Cut seven players: Frank Reed, strong safety and a six-year pro, Bill Larson, five-year tight end, Charles Cornelius, five-year corner- back, Rick Kehr, offensive tackle, Rich Mohr, defensive end, Frank Garcia, punt- er, and Pete Thompson, wide receiver. HOUSTON (AFC) - Released four rookie free agents: Joe Campbell, defen- sive lineman, Randy Rich, defensive back, Press Theriot, punter, and Greg Tyler, running back. LOS ANGELES (NFC) - Waived Eddie Hare, punter, Randy Gill, linebacker, Wil- liam Daniels, defensive lineman, Richard Hersey, running back, Rick Parma, wide receiver, Billy Yancy and Elbert Roberts, cornerbacks. Placed on the injured re- serve list George Farmer, first-year wide receiver.

title: THE TRUE CONFESSIONS OF A VINCOMPOOP
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Patricia O'Toole is a writer and a consulting editor of Savvy magazine. By PATRICIA O'TOOLE

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $234,000 on exchange of debentures...C-Net loss

title: Accounts
description: * Home Products division of Rubbermaid Inc. to Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, for a new product.

title: DOW AT 8-MONTH LOW OF 924.37
description: The stock market declined broadly yesterday with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level in eight months. At the final bell the Dow average was down 2.38 points, to 924.37, its lowest closing price since Dec. 16, 1980, when it finished at 918.09.

title: SPARKMAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Violence Subsides In South of Sri Lanka
description: Sri Lanka was calm today after the Government imposed a nationwide state of emergency to quell violence between the Sinhalese and Tamils, but some people were reported to be collecting weapons, a Government spokesman said.

title: CALIFORNIA GROUP TRYING TO REVIVE CIVILITY AND CONSIDERATION
description: Thomas Danaher's society attracts old women who have been shoved out of movie lines, middle-age businessmen who find their assigned parking space lined with Honda motorcycles and people who pepper their speech with ''dear,'' ''please'' and ''thank you.''

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Carson, British Jockey, Fractures Skull in Race
description: Willie Carson, Britain's champion jockey, fractured the base of his skull in a racing accident today and will not ride again this season.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; 1981 results include results from Western Kentucky Gas Co which was acquired on Dec 1, 1980

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 19, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Pact Reached In Allied Case
