description: The Allied Stores Corporation said yesterday that it had reached agreement with Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc. to postpone indefinitely a court hearing in connection with Allied's efforts to take over Garfinckel.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Frank E. Grzelecki, 44 years old, will join Lenox Inc., a major producer of china, crystal and other dinnerware, as president and chief operating officer, effective Aug. 31. He will succeed John S. Chamberlin, 53, who was named to the vacant post of chairman and who will continue as chief executive officer of the Lawrenceville, N.J., company.

title: Ex-Bank Aide Pleads Guilty
description: A former vice president of the Allied Bank of Texas who is charged with 30 counts of bank fraud and embezzlement has pleaded guilty to charges that he embezzled $17 million. W.Darrell Wiggins pleaded guilty to six of the 30 charges.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
G.A.O. CRITICIZES MEAT PLANTS AND SEEKS STRICTER INSPECTIONS
description: Surprise visits to meat and poultry slaughter plants that found one-fourth of them in violation of Federal standards have led the General Accounting Office to recommend tougher Federal inspections of plants.

title: A NEW RESTAURANT AT SCHOOL FOR CHEFS
description: A restaurant to be called American Bounty and to feature regional American cuisines will be opened in the middle of next year by the Culinary Institute of America, the country's leading school for professional chefs, in Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: Economic Scene; Investment And Inflation
description: INFLATION in the United States has slowed markedly in recent months. In July, seasonally adjusted producer prices of finished goods rose only 5.5 percent at an annual rate from June and were up only 8.8 percent from a year earlier. This was in marked contrast to the 15 to 20 percent rates of increase seen in early 1980. A large part of the improved price performance reflects the worldwide oil glut and its impact on oil-related prices as well as the better-than-expected world agricultural outlook for 1981.

title: STEPFATHER OF LECH WALESA DIES IN JERSEY CITY
description: Stanislaw Walesa, stepfather of Lech Walesa, the leader of Poland's Solidarity union, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Jersey City. He was 64 years old.

title: Advertising; Answering The 'Calls To Action'
description: CHARLES RUPPMAN hates those advertisements with big, splashy graphics and eye-catching photographs. What he likes are ''800'' WATS-line numbers and coupons.

title: BRITON'S GUIDE TO OUT-OF-WAY FRENCH DINING
description: One of the most interesting recent publishing ventures in England is a small, comprehensive guide to dining in France titled ''French Leave.'' It is singular among guides in English devoted to the pleasures of the French table and offers as a casual bonus the finest, most concise glossary of food terms to be found on French menus - whether at home or abroad - that I have encountered.

title: News Anaylsis
description: The Reagan Administration's legal offensive to put the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization permanently out of the business of representing Federal employees opens a new chapter to

title: U.S., IN SWITCH, AGREES THE U.N. CAN SUBSIDIZE PRESS SUPPLEMENTS
description: The United States, in a change of position, has agreed that the United Nations ccn continue subsidizing newspapers promoting its views on aid to the third world.

title: 2 KINGMAN HOMERS HELP METS WIN, 4-0
description: The New York Mets continued their strong second-half play tonight, defeating the Atlanta Braves, 4-0, and moving into first place in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Advertising; Citibank Campaign
description: Citibank has announced a major advertising campaign, to begin next month, for its electronic banking and cash management services for corporations and financial institutions. Advertising, which is being handled by Foote, Cone & Belding, will run in 22 national newspapers and magazines.

title: CITY RUNS A SCAM ON RENOVATION DEALS
description: JONATHAN BELKIN'S house in Queens needed major repairs, including a new heating system, new kitchen and bathroom, electric wiring, windows and exterior siding. Like many consumers, he knew nothing about construction. He simply threw himself at the contractors' mercy, asking for the ''best price'' for the ''highest quality material and workmanship.''

title: PAN AM UNIT IS PROFITABLE, AND FOR SALE
description: Bullets ricocheted around the Amman Intercontinental during Jordan's 1970 civil war. Revolutionaries smashed windows at the Teheran Intercontinental while the Shah's regime was being overthrown. Sheiks have been sauntering through the Riyadh Intercontinental since well before the 1970's oil boom.

title: FOE OF COMMUNISTS IN POSTWAR HUNGARY
description: Zoltan Pfeiffer, who led opposition to the 1947 Communist takeover of Hungary, died Sunday in St. Luke's Hospital, one day after his 81st birthday. He lived at 420 West 119th Street.

title: YOUNGBLOOD OUT
description: After 15 innings of shutout pitching, the New York Mets' spell over the Atlanta Braves ended tonight on one swing by Brian Asselstine. Pinch-hitting with two out and two on in the seventh, Asselstine hit a homer that propelled the Braves to a 5-2 victory at Atlanta Stadium.

title: Weinberger on London Trip
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will fly to London tonight for another in a series of private talks with the British Defense Minister, John Nott, Pentagon officials said. They said Mr. Weinberger would arrive in London tomorrow morning and meet Mr. Nott in the afternoon. He plans to return to Washington Sunday.

title: U.S. Steel Joins Price Increases
description: The United States Steel Corporation said today that it would raise prices on steel plate and structural beams, matching increases announced earlier by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

title: Around the Nation; False Alarm Sounds Aboard Nerve Gas Plane
description: A 10th planeload of Weteye nerve gas bombs arrived safely today at Utah's Dugway Proving Ground after a false alarm of a leak aboard an Air Force C-141 cargo jet.

title: DESPITE PROBLEMS, GIANTS TAKE TO THE 3-4
description: One theory about pro football's 3-4 defense is that it makes things tough for the defensive linemen because only three rush the quarterback, giving him more time to pass. That, in turn, makes the job of the secondary more difficult, the theory goes.

title: Business People; Citicorp International Appoints Two Officers
description: John C. Botts, 40, has been named managing director and chief executive officer of the Citicorp International Bank Ltd., a unit of Citicorp with headquarters in London. James W. Stevens, 44, has been appointed chairman.

title: Around the World; Key Dutch Party Rejects A Proposed Coalition
description: The Christian Democratic Party today rejected a proposed three-party coalition that was accepted by the Labor and Democrats '66 parties yesterday after almost three months of talks, a party spokesman said.

title: No Headline
description: The F-14 and SU-22 AT A GLANCE F-14 Tomcat History

title: TEMPERENCE HILL IS FIFTH ON THE GRASS
description: Temperence Hill has won almost $1.5 million in fast and sloppy going, under heavy weight and on tracks from here to Louisiana. But today he convinced even his most ardent supporters that he can't run on the grass.

title: PROTEST NOTE BY THE U.S.
description: Following is the text of the protest to the Libyan Government issued by the State Department today: Special to the New York Times

title: U.S. REPORTS SHOOTING DOWN 2 LIBYA JETS THAT ATTACKED F-14'S OVER MEDITERRANE
description: The United States said today that two Navy F-14 jets shot down two Soviet-built Libyan SU-22's about 60 miles from the Libyan coast after being fired on by one of the Libyan aircraft.

title: Calendar of Events
description: ''Potpourri: Scents and Spices,'' the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: Yr-ago revs figures have been restated

title: Home Beat
description: THERE were a lot of ''older typewriters -relics that still work,'' said Paul Weingarten of KBM, a typewriter rental and sales concern, ''so we decided to spruce them up.'' That meant having Caren Shapiro paint the machines.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Under these conditions of operations such as this, that if an enemy aircraft conducts a hostile act, in this case did take on fire of our two aircraft, the aircraft flight commander has the authority to defend himself; in this case, that's exactly what he did.'' - Lieut. Gen. Philip J. Gast, director of operations of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. (A8:1.)

title: COE, WITH A 3:48.53 MILE, AND NEHEMIAH SET MARKS
description: ZURICH Aug. 19 (AP) - Sebastian Coe of Britain set a world record for the mile tonight with a time of 3 minutes 48.53 seconds at an invitation track and field meet.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, AUGUST 20, 1981; The Economy
description: The economy contracted at a revised annual rate of 2.4 percent in the second quarter, more than previously estimated, after a robust 8.6 percent growth rate in the first quarter. Corporate profits also fell after a first-quarter rise, the Commerce Department reported, with after-tax profits down 11.3 percent to an annual rate of $150.1 billion. But economists declined to forecast a recession. (Page D1.)

title: SEPARATED SIAMESE TWINS IN COUNTY'S CUSTODY
description: A District Court judge turned over to the county today the legal custody of Siamese twins whose parents were charged with neglecting them.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $86,000 for the qr and $13,317,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $913,000 for the qr and $4,424,000 for the 6 mos; results for the latest periods include operations of the company's Ayr-Way Stores

title: TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Around the Nation; Police Chief in Nashville Faults Rookie's Partner
description: Failure by her partner to take appropriate action was the reason a rookie policewoman shot three innocent persons fleeing a grocery robbery, Police Chief Joe Casey said today.

title: BROWN SLIPS IN POLLS ON ISSUE OF FLIES
description: Polls and the talk among politicians would indicate that the Mediterranean fruit fly has given a fatal sting to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s political career. But Governor Brown not only defended his handling of the fruit fly problem but also said in an interview today, ''I'm happy to be the underdog'' in next year's race for the United States Senate.

title: BONN EXPECTS TALKS WITH U.S. ON FUEL PLANS
description: American officials are expected to visit Bonn in mid-September to present Reagan Administration proposals for more energy cooperation, according to West German Government sources.

title: 'STREAK' BIDS FOR JETS' JOB
description: They call Kenny Lewis The Streak these days at the Jets' camp. An 80-yard touchdown run against Atlanta in an exhibition game Saturday gave him the new nickname and celebrity status, but Lewis knows that the Jets usually keep three halfbacks - and he is listed as No.4.

title: JERSEY CITY COMPANY HONORS MEMORY OF STANISLAW WALESA
description: The Henderson Lumber Company was closed from 2 P.M. until 5 P.M. today because of the death of one of its employees, Stanislaw Walesa.

title: No Headline
description: A listing of airline profits in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly labeled the period covered. The results were for the second quarter of 1981.

title: COMMISSARY SUBSIDY CUT WEIGHED
description: Reagan Administration economic officials are considering reducing the public subsidy for military commissaries and post exchanges and setting up a system of user fees by which foreign travelers would finance the Customs Service, a high-ranking Reagan official said today.

title: Stocks of Oil Rise in Week
description: Inventories of gasoline and crude oil rose last week as refineries stepped up production and more oil was imported, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.

title: NEW STATE GAMING PLAN RUNS INTO LEGAL TANGLE
description: After disclosing late Tuesday that New York State would start cardgame gambling on computer video screens in the fall, the director of the Lottery Division postponed the plan yesterday when the State Attorney General said that such betting might be illegal.

title: TOWNSHIP EVICTS AN INDIAN MUSEUM
description: The dream was to recreate an authentic village to perpetuate the ways, the lore and the legends of a vanishing tribe of native Americans. A museum crowded into the basement of a recreation center here was to be the nucleus.

title: BASEBALL REVISES PLAYOFF PLAN IN ATTEMPT TO CLOSE LOOPHOLES
description: Baseball officials have proposed a revised plan for the intradivision playoffs, and they expected the players to add their necessary approval today.

title: Over the Gulf of Sidra
description: That was no idle decision to order the United States Sixth Fleet to conduct maneuvers in the Gulf of Sidra, some 60 miles from the shores of Tripoli. The aim, clearly deliberate, was to test Colonel Qaddafi, whose radical Libyan regime lays sovereign claim to those waters. And two Libyan jets were downed by American fighters, but only after those Soviet-built planes fired first. So runs the Reagan Administration version of the episode, and what is wrong with that?

title: Cosmos Lose, 2-1, In Finale
description: Colin Franks, Duncan Davidson and Azex Cropley scored in a shootout tonight to lift the Toronto Blizzard to a 2-1 triumph over the Cosmos in their North American Soccer League regular-season finale. It was Toronto's first victory over the Cosmos since 1975.

title: G.N.P. DIP REVISED TO 2.4% RATE
description: The United States economy suffered an even sharper downswing during the second quarter than originally estimated, while corporate profits posted a steep decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: LUNDY ELECTRONICS & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Including $1,608,298 or $1.06 a shr nonrecurring gain

title: 31 SUSPECTS ARRESTED IN OPERATION SELLING NARCOTICS IN LOCKUPS
description: Thirty-one persons were arrested yesterday in connection with a drug-selling ring that succeeded in smuggling narcotics into the Rikers Island jail complex and the Bronx House of Detention. Five other accused members of the ring, who have been indicted, were still at large.

title: SECRET SERVICE IS PRAISED IN REPORT BUT SOME SECURITY GAPS ARE CITED
description: A management review team at the Treasury Department said in a report released today that the Secret Service and other agencies within the department had ''performed well'' during and after the attempt on President Reagan's life last March 30.

title: NEW RISKS LINKED TO BIRTH PILL USE
description: Women who were longtime users of birth control pills still face double or triple the usual risk of heart attack up to nine years after they stop taking the pill, a study shows.

title: REALTY REFUND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BIG CONTRAST IN PAY IN N.B.A. AND N.F.L.
description: Rory Sparrow, traded last week to Atlanta, was a rookie guard last season with the Nets, who paid him $37,500, the league minimum in 1980-81. Toward the other end of the National Basketball Association's pay scale is Marvin Webster, the Knicks' veteran center, who got $600,000. In the middle range lies the average N.B.A. player, who received $193,000.

title: Dennison Ends Bid for Ofrex
description: The Dennison Manufacturing Company said it would bow out of a bidding contest with Gallaher Ltd. for control of the Ofrex Group Ltd. of England, but that it expected to make a profit from the effort.

title: CABARET: 'JERRY'S GIRLS'
description: IT just happens that some of the best songs Jerry Herman has written for his musicals - ''Milk and Honey,'' ''Hello, Dolly!,'' ''Mame,'' ''Dear World,'' ''Mack and Mabel'' and ''The Grand Tour'' are his major shows - were written for women or about women. So it is no coincidence that the cast for a cabaret revue made up of Mr. Herman's songs at Onstage, 349 West 46th Street, consists of four women. Even the instrumental group that accompanied them is a female trio, underscoring the fact that the production is called ''Jerry's Girls.'' But it is more than that. These are really ''Jerry's Pearls.''

title: BRIDGEPORT TURNS THE TABLES ON F.B.I.'S UNDERCOVER MAN
description: A Federal investigation to see whether Bridgeport's Superintendent of Police would accept a bribe took an unexpected twist last night: the local police arrested an undercover operative as he passed the money.

title: HANDICAPPED YOUTH IN GARDEN PROJECT
description: AMID the roses, herbs and wooded knolls at the Queens Botanical Garden, a new concept in teamwork is under way. Since June, 27 young people from the ages of 14 to 20 have been working with 25 adult volunteers in a variety of jobs at the garden.

title: Going Out Guide
description: MOSTLY NOT MOZART

title: Q.
description: We have recently purchased a very old house (circa 1730) and all the wood floors in this house are painted. These are the original floors, made of wide-plank pine, and we would like to retain the painted floors throughout the house because we understand that this type of floor is authentic to a house of this type and age. Because of the age of these floors we do not plan to strip or sand them down to the bare wood. However, the boards have numerous layers of paint on them and some of this paint looks as though it was walked on before it was fully dry. How should these floors be prepared for painting, and how should the floors be maintained after they are painted? - L.W., Newton, Mass.

title: A BILLION-ACRE GAME TAXPAYERS WILL LOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Afghans decide to modify land program to gain support A3 Canadian press attacks plan to curb newspaper chains A4 3 blacks in South Africa sentenced to death for sabotage A6 I.R.A. hunger strike is issue in Ul- ster by-election A7 Text of U.S. protest to Libya A8 Transcript of news conference held by Weinberger and aide A8 Libya criticized U.S. maneuvers before air battle took place A11 U.S. officials to visit Bonn in Fall to plan energy cooperation A13 Israel stands on previous position for West Bank autonomy A15 Soviet delaying development of a new Siberian natural-gas field A17 Government/Politics City to open accounts again in mi- nority-owned banks B6 Barbaro and Esposito give views on travel in New York City B8 General Company closes in honor of Lech Walesa's stepfather A2 Hijackers return Iranian gunboat to France A3 Oil companies not concerned by possible Libyan crude cutoff A9 Around the Nation A18 Pennsylvania township forcing out Indian artifacts exhibit A18 Tropical storm Dennis heads to- ward Charleston A18 Four charged with selling techno- logical equipment to Soviet A19 Historians find evidence of a black Pilgrim at Plymouth A28 North Carolina county gets cus- tody of twins A32 Norwalk police grow beards as contract talks stretch out B2 Tug captain's charting of cruiser questioned at hearing B3 Defendants in attempted helicop- ter escape go on trial B4 Home Section Home No space, but ingenuity adds room for a child C1

title: E.N.I.-Brazilian Deal
description: The Italian state energy group, E.N.I., said today that it had signed a deal valued at more than $100 million to take over all the Brazilian operations of Liquigas S.p.A. E.N.I. said in a statement that the contract was signed in Zurich last Friday.

title: ISRAEL AFFIRMS CONDITIONS ON WEST BANK TALKS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin and some of his ministers met today to discuss reviving the talks on autonomy for the Arabs of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: BUSH AND THE FOURTH AMENDMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Arabs Quit U.N. Parley As Israeli Starts to Speak
description: Arab and some African delegates walked out of a United Nations energy conference here today when an Israeli delegate rose to speak.

title: EDWARDS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PSYCHOLOGISTS LOOK AT CHILD'S DOMAIN
description: HAS behavioral science shown that there is some ideal design for children's rooms, some configuration of space, color and setting that will most perfectly shape a youngster's development?

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: KIDNAPPING SUSPECT KILLED: Miami police giving first aid Tuesday night to a man they shot during a raid on one of four homes.

title: REEVES BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
O'Grady Seeks Inquiry On Loss of W.B.A. Title
description: Pat O'Grady, father and trainer of Sean O'Grady, former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, wants an investigation into the judicial proceedings that resulted in his son's loss of the title.

title: AMERICAN QUASAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the consolidated of limited partnership interests

title: BRONSTON LOSES BID TO OVERTURN HIS CONVICTION
description: Former State Senator Jack E. Bronston of Queens has lost the appeal of his conviction on fraud charges in the only criminal case to grow out of an investigation involving bus-stop shelters in New York City.

title: RICHARD GIBIAN
description: Richard Gibian, a retired businessman, died Sunday in the Harkness Pavilion of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Earnings; SEARS, FEDERATED LEAD RETAIL GAINS
description: Several of the nation's leading retail store chains reported broadly higher earnings yesterday for the second fiscal quarter. They included: Sears, Roebuck & Company, up 26.3 percent; Federated Department Stores, 51.5 percent; May Department Stores, 32.7 percent; the Dayton-Hudson Corporation, 19.1 percent, and the Allied Stores Corporation, 56.5 percent.

title: Bridge: For High-Level Decisions, Experience Is Unbeatable
description: Making the right decision at a high level in a competitive auction is not easy, and can be learned only by experience. Most players are too inclined to decide matters unilaterally. The expert will often look for a way to give his partner a voice in the proceedings.

title: OPEC REMAINS DIVIDED ON UNIFYING BASE PRICES
description: Oil ministers representing the 13 OPEC nations broke up an informal meeting in disagreement tonight over a Saudi Arabian plan for a new range of oil prices that would raise the cost of Saudi Arabian crude but roll back prices charged by several other producers.

title: Critic's Notebook; BRIBING CRITICS: AN IMMODEST PROPOSAL
description: IJUST want you to know that, as a reviewer, I do not feel debased by the arrival of gifts from those whom it is my duty to criticize. Of course I don't get any such gifts - I can't recall receiving so much as an art calendar at any time during the last 15 or 20 years - but I thought I should declare myself in principle, just in case anything is going.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Ads for Parker Pens Are Returning to TV
description: The Parker Pen Company is returning to television advertising for the first time since 1969, as part of a four-month, $2 million campaign to introduce its new Arrow gift line of writing instruments.

title: News Analysis
description: ''It was absolutely a shot in the dark,'' an aide to City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said in explaining why the Comptroller had asked his Democratic primary rival, Assemblyman John C. Dearie, to disclose his income-tax returns.

title: WHAT MOTIVATES WRITERS?
description: CERTAINLY the genesis of any novel is as singular as its author's apprehension of his craft: some writers start with an idea, a calculated theory that they hope to illustrate; others find their book in an epiphany, a character or incident glimpsed with sudden recognition. In the case of Francine du Plessix Gray's new novel ''World Without End,'' it was a bit of both. The sight of a fellow Intourist traveler - ''a sort of forlorn, middle-aged bachelor with melancholy blue eyes'' - during a 1976 trip to the Soviet Union gave Mrs. Gray her central character, Edmund, and it also gave her a theme, that of ''the solitude of middle age.''

title: SHARK ATTACKS ARE INCREASING
description: The cry ''Shark!'' is being heard with alarmingly increasing frequency in the waters off Florida and the Bahamas these days, puzzling experts and experienced divers.

title: Du Pont Planning Factory in Japan
description: Du Pont K.K., the Japanese unit of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said that its parent planned to build a factory in Utsunomiya, Japan, to produce engineering plastic. The plant will process raw material from the United States into engineering plastic mainly for use in automotive parts, a Du Pont spokesman said.

title: TRIPOLI, IN A PROTEST NOTE, ACCUSES U.S. OF 'INTERNATIONAL TERRORISM'
description: Libya accused the United States tonight of ''international terrorism.'' The charge came in a note of protest delivered to the Belgian Embassy, which looks after American interests here in the absence of direct Libyan-American diplomatic relations.

title: Sports of the Times; FRENCHY IS ALIVE AND STILL DOING SWELL
description: DETROIT WHATEVER happened to Frenchy Fuqua's glass shoes with goldfish in them? Whatever happened to Frenchy Fuqua's white musketeer hat with red, white and purple ostrich plumes? Whatever happened to Frenchy Fuqua? ''The mad Frenchman!'' said John (Count Frenchy) Fuqua. ''The true and only and original black count! He's alive and still doin' swell.''

title: News of Music; CONCERT-PROGRAM MAGAZINES GETTING NEW FACES
description: THE normally placid and secure world of Stagebill, the free concert-program magazine distributed at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center, is being disturbed by the former editor of the magazine, Karl Leabo.

title: Companies Study Coal Power Plant
description: The Celanese Chemical Company, a unit of the Celanese Corporation, and Big Three Industries said they were studying the feasibility of constructing a coal-fired steam and electric power co-generation plant in the Bayport Industrial Complex southeast of Houston.

title: BEFORE PLANE BATTLE, LIBYA ASSAILED U.S. OVER ITS MANEUVERS
description: The Libyan press agency said Tuesday that American naval maneuvers in the Gulf of Sidra had exposed ''the nature and reality of American aggressive intentions'' against Libya.

title: The City; Teachers Fund To Buy Mortgages
description: The New York City Teachers Retirement System plans to issue a $1.9 million check today for the purchase of a pool of 46 federally insured mortgages, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said.

title: Essay; THE NEW CAPABILITY
description: Lancelot ''Capability'' Brown was the great English landscape architect of the 18th century, rescuing English gardening from the hedged-in formality of French estates. This believer in the freedom of long-term growth created lakes and planted trees to set nature on its centuries-long course, and earned his nickname from his recurring remark to royal clients: ''This place has great capabilities.''

title: POWER VS. PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Tied to German Neo-Nazis Are Suspects in Jew's Murder
description: A judge today ordered the founder of West Germany's largest neo-Nazi group and a friend to be held in custody for suspected murder, the public prosecutor's office here said.

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Advertising; People
description: * Bernard R. Cammarata, Michael M. Marsak and Hadassa Gerber have been elected senior vice presidents of McCann-Erickson Worldwide.

title: Company Seeking More Phibro Seats
description: The Minerals and Resources Corporation, a Bermuda-based holding company, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it wanted to increase its representation on the Phibro Corporation's board.

title: FOUR ARE INDICTED IN SELLING OF TECHNOLOGY TO SOVIET
description: Four persons were charged today with selling restricted high-technology communications and computer equipment valued at $2 million to the Soviet Union through a West German middleman.

title: Court Orders Nashville To Delay School Plan
description: A Federal appeals court today barred schools in Nashville and Davidson County, Tenn., from implementing a desegregation plan. Unless the stay is lifted, officials said, students will not report Friday for the new school year.

title: Bear Terrorizes Woman
description: A 220-pound black bear ripped off a screen door and attempted to break into the home of 85-year-old Thelma Kouba.

title: FLOURISHING IN THE CAPITAL: THOSE SPECIAL ASSISTANTS
description: The special assistant put on a brown pants suit at her home in Annandale, Va., at 6:30 A.M. She picked up her car pool members near Route 395, drove to the great gray concrete-block Federal building where she works and took the elevator to the seventh floor, where she bought a Pepsi from a machine.

title: NO CONCERN IS SEEN OVER OIL SUPPLIES
description: Officials of American oil companies seemed nonchalant yesterday about the possibility that Libya might cut off supplies to them in retaliation for the United States' downing of two Libyan planes. But they expressed guarded concern over the welfare of the more than 1,000 United States citizens believed to be working in the Libyan oilfields.

title: American Jailed in Thailand
description: A 31-year-old American was sentenced today to 25 years in prison for possessing heroin for sale. John Hamilton Fuller, of Washington, D.C., was arrested in January as he boarded a flight to Paris with eight ounces of heroin, the prosecution said.

title: PAUL BRUNTON
description: Paul Bronton, the author of 13 books on Oriental philosophy, died in the Good Samaritan Hospital in Vevey, Switzerland, on July 27.

title: PLYMOUTH HISTORIAN SAYS A BLACK SETTLED AT PILGRIMS' COLONY
description: Historians said today they had enough evidence to suggest that one of the early settlers of the Plymouth colony in New England was a black man.

title: The City; Suspect Extradite- d In Officer's Slaying
description: The man accused of killing a New York City police officer and seriously wounding another last April was returned to New York from South Carolina and jailed without bail.

title: Judge Delays New Rule On NOW Account Use
description: A Federal judge, acting on a request by commercial banks, temporarily blocked savings and loan associations today from offering interest-bearing checking accounts to nonprofit organizations and state and local governments.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 20, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Decoloniza- tion - 10:30 A.M.

title: Advertising; And Now It's Designer Ads
description: See Jean Cacharel drive his Rolls-Royce through Paris. See Donna Karan walk across Central Park. See Steve Davis (for Christian Dior sportswear) stroll past the Guggenheim.

title: PARTNERS OIL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TURNER STARTS 2D NEWS REPORT
description: Ted Turner, the Atlanta entrepreneur who last year launched the Cable News Network, a 24-hour news service for cable systems, is planning a second news network aimed at competing with a similar service announced last week by Westinghouse and ABC.

title: Home Improvement; NEW PRODUCTS FOR AROUND THE HOUSE
description: DESIGNED to provide the luxury of a pulsating, massage-type shower without wasting a lot of water, a new shower massage handset includes a built-in control that restricts water flow to a maximum of 2.75 gallons a minute without affecting the force of the pulsating spray.

title: CORE'S LEADER HELD ON CHARGE OF BEATING MAN
description: Roy Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, was arrested yesterday and charged with severely beating a man his aides said they saw stealing a radio from one of the civilrights organization's cars last Friday night.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Wall Street appears convinced that the nation's budget deficits are going to be higher than the President has predicted, thus preventing or delaying the long-awaited decline in interest rates.

title: 2.5% STAKE IN HUTTON PURCHASED
description: The E.F. Hutton Group said yesterday that during April and May the Transamerica Corporation, which owns one of the nation's largest insurance companies, bought 2.5 percent, or 400,000, of its outstanding shares.

title: MESA RAISES STAKE IN CITIES SERVICE
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company has increased its holdings in the Cities Service Company to a 4 percent share, it disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mesa, an oil and gas exploration company that is much smaller than Cities Service, said it had acquired 3,244,800 shares in Cities Service before June 30.

title: BARTON BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TV: HOW TRAPPIST MONKS ADJUST TO CHANGING TIMES
description: TRAPPIST monks were forbidden to speak even to each other 20 years ago. But the Second Vatican Council ended the rule of silence and now, as ABC News will document tonight at 9:30 in a 90-minute ''Closeup'' special, ''The Monastery,'' they talk not just among themselves but also join the procession bent on going public with the innermost secrets of their hearts.

title: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWSPAPERS RARE IN WARSAW KIOSKS
description: The Polish authorities attempted to publish skeleton editions of a number of newspapers today, but distributors and vendors refused to handle them.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $745,000 for the qr and $2,111,000 for the yr and $2,354,000 extraordinary gain for the yr on the sale of land...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $648,000 for the qr and $1,412,000 for the yr $6,662,000 loss for the qr and yr on the disposal of discontinued operations and $300,000 approximate nonrecurring charge for the qr relating to the discontinuance of certain operatons, principally start-up operations

title: Around the World; France to Help Iraqis Rebuild Nuclear Center
description: France agreed in principle today to help Iraq rebuild the nuclear reactor complex destroyed by Israeli bombers in June, a French Government source said.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, AUGUST 20, 1981
description: International Two Navy jets downed two Libyan jets about 60 miles from the Libyan coast after being fired on by one of the Soviet-built Libyan SU-22's, the United States announced. Officials said that the one-minute dog fight occurred in the final hours of a two-day United States Navy exercise in the southern Mediterranean and the northern part of the Gulf of Sidra. The gulf is a broad body of water claimed by Libya as part of its terroritial waters but regarded by the United States as international waters. (Page A1, Column 6.) Libya accused the United States of ''international terrorism'' as a result of the air clash over the Mediterranean, which it described as ''aggression.'' Libya's official press agency asserted that one United States jet had been shot down, a statement that Washington denied. (A1:4-5.)

title: KABUL, IN OVERTURE TO REBELS, MODIFIES LAND POLICY
description: The Soviet-backed Government of Afghanistan has virtually reversed a land redistribution program that aroused feudally organized tribesmen into rebellion some three years ago.

title: AS AMERICA'S RICH GET RICHER...
description: To the Editor:

title: DEPORTING OF OTHERS BARRED
description: The Federal Government was temporarily barred today from deporting any of the 1,800 Cuban refugees who have been imprisoned here more than a year.

title: Italians Seek Coast Bank
description: The First Los Angeles Bank said today that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by a major Italian bank in a cash transaction valued at up to $68 million.

title: BIZARRE CASES MAR RELATIONS WITH LIBYA
description: Today's clash over the Mediterranean was only the latest in a series of bizarre events that have marked Libyan-American relations since Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a leader with grand notions of forging a single Arab nation, overthrew King Idris I in 1969.

title: WILLIAMHOUSE-REGENCY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-After a $314,000 gain from discontinued operations; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in Feb 1981

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Finance Briefs
description: * American Microsystems signed a previously announced financing and joint venture agreement with Voest-Alpine of Austria and has received about $15 million as part of the deal.

title: NUCLEAR MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Reflects company's equity in net loss of affiliated companies totalling $41,590

title: Executive Changes
description: * Castle & Cooke Inc., Honolulu, has elected Robert W. Fisher, Ronald R. Jensen, Charles J. Bauman and William S. Kamin corporate vice presidents.

title: DANCE FESTIVAL: 'AMERICAN SAMPLER'
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival celebrated the past, present and future yesterday with ''American Sampler,'' a program of dances that spanned 60 years of American dance. It was an unforgettable evening of theater.

title: Coffee Frost Damage Gauged
description: The Brazilian frost of last month will probably reduce next year's coffee harvest in the state of Sao Paulo by about 50 percent, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Chile Deficit Widens
description: Chile's trade deficit widened to $1.53 billion in the first half of this year from $129.4 million in the same period of 1980, the central bank said today. Imports rose to $3.56 billion from $2.52 billion, while exports fell to $2.03 billion from $2.39 billion, mainly because of a 23 percent drop in copper earnings, the bank said. The rise in imports was a result of an increase in purchases of consumer goods, particularly cars, the bank added.

title: MISGUIDED OPPOSITION TO NEUTRON WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region;
description: A final review of Federal budget cuts has put the loss of funds in New Jersey at $788 million for the 1981 and 1982 fiscal years.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a gan of $30 million from the sale of a Texas shopping center and foreign currency translation loss of $7 million...C-Includes foreign currency translation gain of $6.2 million

title: CANADIAN NEWSPAPERS ATTACK PROPOSAL TO CURB MONOPOLIES
description: A confrontation between the Canadian Government and the nation's press appeared likely today following proposals for official action to curb press monopolies in Canada and raise the quality of newspapers.

title: THE NEWS LETS UNIONS ORDER AN OUTSIDE AUDIT
description: The Daily News said yesterday that it would open its financial records to an accounting concern selected by its unions and would form an advisory committee of union and management representatives to look at some of the problems facing the tabloid.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 15 percent stock divd paid in Mar 1981

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Including gains of $152,000 for the qr and $223,000 for 4 percent estimated change of subordinated debentures for common stock and five-yr warrants.. C-Net loss including gains of $161,000 for the qr and $518,000 for the 6 mos from the acquisition of debentures

title: Notes on People; Miss Hearst to Disclose Some Secrets
description: Several books have been written about the Patricia Hearst case, but the heiress to the newspaper-chain fortune has mostly kept silent about her ordeal. Now, however, she is writing a book that will give a first-person account that begins with her kidnapping in 1974 and ends with her release from prison in 1979.

title: Japanese Bond Issue
description: The Murata Manufacturing Company, a leading Japanese maker of ceramic condensers, said today that it would issue industrial revenue bonds worth about $6 million in the United States to raise funds for construction of production facilities. A Murata spokesman said that the State of Pennsylvania would issue the bonds on behalf of the company's wholly owned subsidiary, Erie Technology Products Ltd., based in Toronto. Another Japanese company, the Fujitec Company, an elevator maker, is reportedly negotiating with state government authorities in Ohio on the possible issuance of industrial revenue bonds.

title: ...AND THE SOCIAL SECURITY POOR GET POORER
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Talon Inc., a division of Textron, to the Chester Gore Company.

title: STOCKS END FIVE-END RETREAT
description: The stock market showed signs of stabilizing yesterday after its recent weakness and finished slightly higher in slower trading. There were few major price changes in the list, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 2.09 points, to 926.46. In the previous five sessions the Dow had dropped about 25 points, mostly because of investors' concern that interest rates would remain high over the near term.

title: A CHECKLIST FOR SIGNING CONTRACTS
description: The following checklist on hiring a contractor was provided by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs: Before choosing:

title: The Region; Hostage Released At New Haven Jail
description: NEW HAVEN (UPI) - Several inmates held a guard hostage yesterday at the New Haven Correctional Center in an apparent attempt to escape, but they released him unharmed about two hours later and surrendered, corrections officials said.

title: OFFICERS GROW BEARDS IN A CONTRACT PROTEST
description: As the beards on more than half of the city's police officers grow longer in a protest over stalled contract talks, the Police Chief's patience with what he considers a sign of slackening professionalism grows shorter.

title: Reports Predict BL Ltd. Losses
description: BL Ltd., the British state-owned auto maker, is expected to announce next week a loss of more than $457.5 million for the first half of 1981, British press reports said. The amount compares with a loss of $421.7 million in the comparable 1980 period.

title: 2 Killed in Hong Kong Crash
description: At least 2 people were killed and 61 injured today in a head-on collision between two buses on an outlying Hong Kong island, the police said. The buses were carrying construction workers home from work.

title: Cardinals 7, Padres 6
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Gene Tenace, a pinch-hitter, singled home a run with two out in the bottom of the ninth inning to beat San Diego.

title: What If There Is No Free Lunch?
description: It's the worst-kept secret in Washington. Next year's Federal budget deficit, officially estimated by the White House at $42 billion, is almost certain to exceed $60 billion. That's hardly cause for panic. By historical standards, a deficit equal to about 2 percent of national income is quite modest. But it does make clear that the President's program is no free lunch. After gorging on all those tasty tax cuts, the Administration, and the public, may pay dearly for the main course.

title: WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Design Notebook; OUTDOORS IS A DESIGN FORCE IN CALIFORNIA
description: LOS ANGELES TO observe that Californians live an outdoor kind of life was one of the constant themes of the so-called shelter magazines of the 1950's. Their pages were filled with illustrations of wide-open glass-enclosed houses, full of people who swam in the winter and ate breakfast outdoors in the summer, smiling all the while.

title: Around the World; Turks Put 674 Rightists On Trial in Ankara
description: Some 674 members of Turkey's extreme right-wing Nationalist Action Party were put on trial today in an Ankara military court for actions that the ruling military junta says were directly linked to the wave of terrorism that has afflicted Turkey in the past two years.

title: Notes on People; An Actor, a Sculptor and Now a Playwright
description: When Gardner McKay made his acting debut, back in 1959, as star of the television series ''Adventures in Paradise,'' a major TV critic noted that he ''played in one emotion.''

title: British to End Use of M.L.R.
description: The Bank of England's minimum lending rate, the benchmark of British interest rates since 1971, will be formally suspended tomorrow, the bank said today.

title: YANKS ARE BEATEN BY WHITE SOX, 6-5
description: Tommy John interrupted the vigil at the bedside of his 2 1/2-yearold son last night, returned to work with the Yankees for the first time in 10 days and pitched three and a third innings against the Chicago White Sox in Yankee Stadium.

title: PUREX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.5 million for the qr and $1.7 million for the yr...C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $1.4 million for the qr and $3.3 million for the yr

title: Insurance Computation
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The important information that you have presented (''The Right Kind of Home Insurance: A Guide to the Maze,'' Aug. 6), along with the suggestions, caveats and admonitions will be very helpful to the consumer.

title: Around the World; Moscow, in Retaliation, Expels British Diplomat
description: The Soviet Union has asked a British diplomat to leave Moscow in retaliation for the expulsion from Britain of a second secretary at the Soviet Embassy in London, the British Foreign Office said today.

title: WORKING MOTHERS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I was very surprised to find no mention of the largest single group of working mothers, i.e., divorced women raising children alone.

title: CRASH OF TEXASGULF'S JET TIED TO CREW DISTRACTION
description: WHITE PLAINS Aug. 19 - The crash of a corporate jet near the Westchester County Airport that killed six Texasgulf executives was probably caused by the crew's preoccupation with an electrical failure, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
NATURE GROUPS ACCUSING WATT OF 'COLLUSION'
description: Lawyers for environmental groups said today they had notified a Federal district judge in Montana that they would seek to prove that Interior Secretary James G. Watt had engaged in ''collusion'' with his former law firm. In June, the firm sued the Secretary in an effort to lift a Congressional ban on oil and gas leasing imposed to protect the environment of a Montana wilderness area.

title: Candidate Will Return Gift to Realty Concern
description: Norman Rosen, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn District Attorney, said yesterday that he would return a campaign contribution of $100 from the Cantalupo Realty Company.

title: FUNDS REPORTED ASKED FOR SPRINGBOKS' TOUR
description: The head of the Eastern Rugby Union, which is based in Schenectady, N.Y., is reported to have solicited companies that do business in South Africa for funds in support of the Springboks' rugby tour in this country.

title: SAVINGS AT A PRICE
description: The Reagan Administration wants to decontrol fuel prices at the same time that it inhibits the Department of Energy from advising us on how to burn less oil and gas. It is a peculiar double whammy.

title: NO PITY IN THE PIT
description: In many large cities of the world, subways are enjoyed by an appreciative public to a degree beleaguered New Yorkers might find hard to believe. From Moscow to Mexico City, Paris to Montreal, millions of people every day travel underground in comfort, security and occasionally even opulent style. Fast, quiet, reliable trains, stations that are clean and imaginatively adorned, are customary features of many systems. But for the New Yorker the subway is quite literally a hell.

title: U.S. AIDES CALL A MIDAIR COLLISION UNCONNECTED TO CONTROLLER STRIKE
description: Federal officials said today that they are convinced that the midair collision of two light aircraft here Monday was not caused in any way by the strike by members of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, despite assertions by Patco members that fatigue and lack of recent experience by replacement controllers had contributed to the collision.

title: THE PENTAGON'S HELPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN DROPS BAN ON FOOD PRODUCTS FROM CALIFORNIA
description: Japan at the last minute reversed its decision to restrict shipments of California produce, leaving California citrus growers and state and Federal officials pleased and relieved today.

title: EXECUTIVE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Including $4,746,000 gain on the sale of real estate

title: A FOUR-POSTER BINGE: SLEEPING IT OFF
description: IT began, I suppose, with Scarlett IT began, I suppose, with Scarlett O'Hara. There she was, lingering and languishing in a four-poster bed in Atlanta, a bed gracefully draped, outlined in ruffles, with a mattress so deep that she sank into it rather than rested upon it. Subsequently, however, thoughts of Miss sequently, however, thoughts of Miss O'Hara in a four-poster were sublimated and eventually I found myself bedperson and how it must have been, must be, to sleep in a four-poster. I wanted, in short, to sleep in one, too.

title: Technology; War on Waste With Microbes
description: CERTAIN bacteria can reduce an industrialist's hazardous waste nightmare to a manageable pile of sludge and a potentially valuable supply of methane-rich gas. The bacteria, known as anaerobic microbes, live in oxygen-less environments and feed by breaking down organic compounds like formaldehyde and acetic acid.

title: G.M. Ties Cuts to Eased Rules
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Roger B. Smith, said today that the No.1 auto maker would reduce sticker prices on some car models by as much as $300 if Congress relaxes tailpipe emission standards.

title: The City; 55 Agents Joining Sanitation Force
description: Fifty-five new civilian Sanitation Enforcement Agents, the first civilian agents in the Sanitation Department's 100-year history, were sworn in by Commissioner Norman Steisel during a ceremony at City Hall.

title: Advertising; Selling Via the Movies
description: AMONG the performers in ''Honky Tonk Freeway,'' which opens at movie theaters tomorrow, will be Cheerios, Budweiser and Quaker State Motor Oil. Those are some of the placements made by Associated Film Promotions, a Los Angeles-based company that says it is the leader in the business of getting clients' products on the big screen.

title: Ohio Can't Trace $1.3 Million; Former Cashier Has Amnesia
description: Ohio may have to write off $1.3 million in missing state funds because the former cashier has amnesia and her records have disappeared, officials said today.

title: CYCLOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'ANNIE' PREMIERES TO AID PBS
description: The film version of the hit Broadway musical ''Annie'' will have its premiere as a benefit for public television stations around the country in more than 100 movie theaters next May.

title: Massey Completes Engine Plant Sale
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian farm equipment maker, said it had completed the sale of its Canton, Ohio, diesel engine plant that has been closed since December 1979.

title: RAMADA'S CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
description: M. William Isbell resigned yesterday as chairman of the troubled Ramada Inns Inc., but company officals insisted that his departure was not tied to major cost overruns at Ramada's Atlantic City Casino hotel, now under development, and a published report of serious losses at its Las Vegas, Nev., casino-hotel.

title: NO SPACE, BUT INGENUITY ADDS A ROOM FOR A CHILD
No Mohasco Dividend
description: Mohasco, a home furnishings manufacturer seriously affected by the slump in the housing industry, said today that it would not pay the regular quarterly dividend of 22.5 cents a share in the third quarter, which will save the company about $1.5 million. Mohasco, which also omitted a dividend payment in the second quarter of 1980, lost more than $2 million last year. It had a small profit in the first quarter of 1981 and profits totaling just over $5 million for the first half of 1981.

title: Two Brazilian Pianists To Play Bach, Chopin
description: Joao Carlos Martins will join another Brazilian pianist, Arthur Lima, for three concerts of music by Bach and Chopin next month.

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VALLEYLAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AN APOLOGY CAN'T CURE A 40-YEAR OLD WRONG
description: To the Editor:

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $1,960,000 extraordinary charge from an out-of- court settlement of litigation still subject to certain conditions; results for the latest yr have been restated to reflect an increase in the amortization of magazine subscription list value

title: Notes on People; The Gallipoli Campaign and Casualty Capote
description: When Allan Carr, the Hollywood and soon-to-be Broadway producer, gives a party, people from what is known as ''the A-list'' invariably show up, and that was the case when Mr. Carr held a cocktail party Tuesday in honor of Peter Weir, director of the new Australian movie ''Gallipoli,'' about the famous World War I battle.

title: Advertising; Squibb's Clearaid
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc., has been named the agency for Clearaid, a Squibb skin product introduced last year. Billings might reach $5 million, according to industry sources. The account will be Scali, McCabe's first proprietary drug assignment. The previous agency was Gross Townsend Frank Inc.

title: Bricks and Bars Against Crime
description: What's the Reagan Administration's answer to violent crime? More prisons, if you take as your guide the report of the Attorney General's Task Force on Violent Crime.

title: SUPRADUR MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 5
QUALITY OF AIR TRAVEL SAID TO BE UNEVEN
description: A man flying to La Guardia Airport from Chicago the other day complained that his plane was so full that ''we only got drink service once.''

title: IN JAPAN, 3 CENTURIES OF POTTERY TRADITION
description: ONTA, Japan HARUZO SAKAMOTO gently lifted a large vase from his potter's wheel and turned it, deftly, scraping away the excess clay around the neck. The form complete, he placed it back on the wheel. With a small wooden knife he pressed against the revolving vase, making the incisions in the clay that are one of the trademarks of his pottery. The only sound was the soft thud of his foot turning the wheel.

title: Around the Nation; Colorado Shooting Trial Set for Former Soldier
description: A former Green Beret who is said to have been hired by the Libyan Government to kill a dissident was held today for trial on charges of attempted first-degree murder and conspiracy.

title: BANKERS TRUST TO SELL VISA CARD UNIT
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation announced yesterday that it would sell its credit card business, which is part of the Visa system and is one of the 10 largest in the nation. The bank holding company also plans to sell four upstate New York commercial banking subsidiaries.

title: I.R.A. FAST IS ISSUE IN ULSTER ELECTION
description: This green and gentle farmland, which looks as peaceful as any place can be, has come to the end of a hard-fought by-election campaign tinged with sectarian hatred.

title: Study Says 510,528 Israelis Emigrated in 10-Year Period
description: More than a half million Israelis emigrated during the 10 years between 1969 and 1979, and dwindling Jewish immigration failed to fill the gap, according to an official study quoted today by the Israeli press.

title: Hers
description: IBEGAN my life waiting for him. When other children asked, ''Where is your father?'' I had my mother's answer: ''He's fighting in the war.'' For the first four years of my childhood, I grew into the anticipation: My father would come home when the war ended. In the interim, my mother and I moved in a holding pattern - from one relative's apartment to another, sleeping on sofas and collapsible cots. In the dark of different living rooms, we traded questions and answers that were always the same: ''Did he see me before he left?'' ''Once. You were in your crib, sleeping.''

title: Notes on People; A Note Cast Upon the Waters Brings Results
description: A follow-up: A month ago Billy Graham had some bad news for his supporters. His Minneapolis-based Evangelistic Association, he said, was running a $2.5 million deficit that could reach $6 million by the end of the year.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN ARRESTS 2,000 SQUATTERS IN DAWN RAID
description: About 2,000 men, women and children were arrested at dawn today at a black squatter camp near Nyanga township in Cape Town and carried off to prison in a convoy of trucks, apparently to await expulsion to a rural black homeland.

title: Market Place; A Bullish Sony Forecast
description: THE Sony Corporation, a solid contributor to the quality image enjoyed by Japanese products, has made striking gains in the equity market here. The American depositary receipts -the trading vehicles in the United States market that are known as A.D.R.'s - are holding at a level three times as high as in February 1980, although currency fluctuations are crimping earnings somewhat for the fiscal year ending in October.

title: WORKING MOTHERS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The notion that a full-time ''competent housekeeper who takes total charge of household maintenance'' is essential to enable working mothers to provide quality time for their children (''Children, a Job and No Time,'' Aug. 13) is an elitist point of view that seems designed to engender guilt and despair among the vast majority of working parents, who cannot afford even minimal household help.

title: Cauthen in Rich Race
description: Steve Cauthen, who has been riding in Europe since 1979, will ride Fingal's Cave in the Arlington Million Aug. 30, track officials said today. Cauthen replaced Willie Carson, who suffered a head injury in a race accident yesterday.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $87,000 in the qr and 6 mos periods; the shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 17

title: Soviet Says Flood in Far East Left 8,000 Homeless Aug. 3-6
description: The Government newspaper Izvestia said today that floods in the Far East earlier this month had caused extensive property damage and left 8,000 people homeless.

title: CHARTING BY TUG CAPTAIN QUESTIONED
description: A tugboat captain, during his testimony yesterday at a Coast Guard hearing, incorrectly plotted the position of his vessel in relation to a cabin cruiser that sank in Long Island Sound 11 days ago with the loss of five lives, the hearing officer said. A barge that the tug was towing is suspected of having crashed into the pleasure boat.

title: Kuwait Oil Price Offer
description: Kuwait has told Japanese oil importers that it would lower its sales premiums if Japan continued to import Kuwaiti crude on the same basis as the present one-year deal, which expires at the end of 1981, industry sources said here today. The sources said that Kuwait had offered to reduce premiums here by $1.75 a barrel from the current premiums ranging from $5.50 to $6 a barrel, retroactive to Aug. 1. Kuwait made the proposal at pricing negotiations with four Japanese oil refiners that now import a total of 125,000 barrels of Kuwaiti oil a day, they said.

title: SIBERIAN GAS FIELD DELAYED BY SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union, in a shift of its @natural-gas strategy, has disclosed that it is delaying the development of a new Siberian field that was to be a major supplier of gas to West Germany and other European countries.

title: The Region; Jersey Will Close Abandoned Mine
description: TRENTON (UPI) - State officials said they would seal an abandoned uranium mine in Sussex County because of potential safety problems. The mine, which ceased operations in the 1960's, is on state-owned land near Cranbury Lake, within the proposed boundries of the Allamuchy Mountain State Park.

title: United Telecom Purchases ISA
description: United Telecommunications Inc. and Insurance Systems of America said they had signed an agreement for United Telecom to acquire ISA for $41.5 million in a stock transaction.

title: The Talk of Rosedale Park
description: At about 6 A.M. each morning during the summer, two roosters crow somewhere along Fteley Avenue. To an elderly West Indian man who lives nearby, it brings back memories of another time and another place, far from the Rosedale Park neighborhood.

title: CFS CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
AT BUSIEST CONTROL TOWER, WEARY DETERMINATION
description: The morning shift is leaving the Chicago Air Traffic Control Center and the afternoon shift is arriving. Pickets with effigies of chickens hanging from sticks taunt those going through the gates with epithets like ''scab'' and ''slime.'' Five Federal marshals patrol the gate.

title: HERMAN M. DENBURG
description: Herman M. Denburg, founder of Barton Press Inc., died Tuesday at his apartment in East Orange, N.J., after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: PILOT UNION CHIEF CALLS FLYING SAFE IN SPITE OF STRIKE
description: The president of a union representing 33,000 airline pilots said today that the nation's air lanes were safe despite the strike by 12,000 air traffic controllers.

title: BARBARO AND ESPOSITO EXAMINE TRAVEL IN THE CITY
description: Assemblymen Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and John A. Esposito of Queens, candidate for the Republican nomination, were asked by The New York Times for their views on major issues confronting New York City. Following are their replies on transportation: Barbaro: 'Westway Trade-In'

title: Subpoenas to Press and TV Withdrawn by Flight Agency
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today suddenly withdrew subpoenas issued to 74 Northwestern newspapers and television stations requesting pictures of striking air traffic controllers.

title: Advertising; Vanity Fair Names Its New Publisher
description: Joseph E. Corr Jr., has been named publisher of Vanity Fair, the Conde Nast magazine that resumes publication as a monthly in January 1983.

title: FOUNDATION SELLING ASSETS WORTH OVER $1 BILLION
description: The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago, one of the country's wealthiest foundations, is selling its considerable assets in insurance companies and real estate. Its aim is to comply with Federal laws limiting the tax-free business ownership that is permitted private foundations.

title: BASEBALL SALARIES RANGE WIDELY
description: The Minnesota Twins were so eager to sign the free agent Mike Marshall for their bullpen three years ago that they guaranteed to pay him $300,000 a year through 1981, even if they dropped him in the meantime. A year ago they did drop him, and now they will continue to pay him for this season, even though he signed with the Mets last night and will be drawing a salary from them for the rest of the year.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED TO FREE IRANIANS FROM UPSTATE PRISON
description: Federal officials agreed to an arrangement late today under which 58 Iranians who have been held in Federal prison here since Aug. 7 could be released.

title: NAVY'S SECRETARY CHARGES SUPPLIER 'RIP-OFFS'
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. today accused such major military contractors as the Electric Boat Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of contriving ''rip-off'' and ''preposterous'' claims as compensation for their own contract failures.

title: TRAVELERS FLEE AS TROPICAL STORM SKIRTS SOUTH CAROLINA COAST
description: After whipping Florida with high winds and heavy rain and claiming two lives in South Carolina, tropical storm Dennis crept up the East Coast toward North Carolina resorts early today.

title: LEISURE CONCEPTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $79,600 tax credit...C-Including tax credits of $84,358 for the qr and $175,350 for the 6 mos

title: Briefs
description: * Allied Corp. said it had complied with a request from the Federal Trade Commission for additional information in connection with Allied's $330 million tender offer for shares of the Fisher Scientific Co.

title: Joy Adamson Case Put Off
description: Judgment in the murder trial of Joy Adamson, the naturalist and author of ''Born Free,'' has been postponed until Aug. 28, legal sources said today. They said Judge Mathew Muli was still considering 800 pages of evidence. A teenage herder from the nomadic Turkana tribe is said by the police to have confessed to the killing.

title: Around the Nation; Illinois Town Is Quiet After Uproar at Mine Site
description: A dozen state troopers today patrolled a quiet wreckage-strewn coal mine construction site where hundreds of demonstrators had set fires and trampled fences in apparent protest over nonunion hiring, officials reported.

title: ENERGY METHODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Israel's Two Top Rabbis Rule Against the David Excavation
description: Israel's two chief rabbis, Shlomo Goren and Ovadia Yosef, ruled today that excavations of a biblical city built by King David violated Jewish law because they desecrated graves.

title: PUBLIC BROADCASTING IN QUEST FOR CHIEF
description: The board of directors of the embattled Corporation for Public Broadcasting will begin choosing a new president tomorrow, amid disagreement over what the job should entail.

title: 2 POLYGAMIST RIVALS DIED ON THE SAME DAY
description: Ervil and Verlan LeBaron, brothers who were bitter rivals for leadership among polygamists, died the same day, one in a Utah prison and the other in a Mexican automobile crash.

title: Division Sale Helps Harvester
description: Helped by the sale of one of its divisions, the International Harvester Company, the nation's leading manufacturer of farm and construction equipment, yesterday reported net income of $101.4 million, or $2.97 a share, in its third fiscal quarter. That was up from $61.9 million, or $2.01 a share, in the similar 1980 period.

title: ETZ LAVUD LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $988,000 income from shr in profit of affiliated companies...C-Net loss includes $105,000 income from shr in profit of affiliated companies; results have been translated at the rate of 10.21 Israeli shakeis per $1 for the latest qr and 6.38 Israeli shakeis per $1 for the previous qr

title: 7 Senators Urged to Return Companies' Campaign Gifts
description: An environmental group said today that seven senators and a potential candidate should return more than $30,000 in campaign donations from the political action committees of five companies.

title: Paper Says Egypt and Britain Will Build Heavy Arms in '82
description: Egypt is to start producing heavy weapons in January as a result of an agreement with Britain for the joint manufacture of 105-millimeter and 122-millimeter artillery, the authoritative newspaper, Al Ahram, said today.

title: Business People; C.A.B. Chief Plans To Resign Sept. 15
description: Marvin S. Cohen, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board since the Airline Deregulation Act was passed in 1978, formally announced yesterday that he would resign, effective Sept. 15. He will become a Washington-based partner of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, a New York law firm.

title: Texas Officers Are Suspended From Duty in Youths' Deaths
description: A deputy sheriff, a reserve deputy and a county probation officer were suspended today in the deaths of three black teen-agers who drowned while in their custody June 19.

title: BOLIVIA'S WANING TIN MINES
description: The scoop rumbles down the narrow mine shaft like an angry monster, its blinding headlight piercing the rock dust. The miners hug the cold, damp walls as the long, low-slung machine on wheels grumbles by, drops its front-end scoop, and powerfully plows into the pile of crunched rock lying at the face of the tunnel wall. One time, two times, three times - then, loaded, it rumbles off as it came. Suddenly, it is dark and quiet again.

title: HIGH TIME TO OUTLAW VIOLENCE BY UNIONS
description: At first blush, it is startling to realize that right now in the United States one small, specially privileged group terrorizes with impunity anyone standing in the way of its objectives.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS KEEPS UNIT
description: The American Express Company, which had been considering the sale of its American Express International Banking Corporation subisidary, said yesterday that it had decided against such a sale and had accepted the resignation of the head of the subsidiary, who opposed the decision.

title: Conrail to Cut Some Rates
description: Conrail, the federally owned railroad, said today that it would reduce shipping rates for furniture, games, toys, bicycles and sporting goods from most points on its lines to the Western United States, except the West Coast.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ADD A WALL AND GET ANOTHER BEDROOM
description: AT today's stratospheric rents, the Manhattan studio is virtually crying out to be walled off into a makeshift one-bedroom apartment, a one-bedroom with dining ''L'' into a two-bedroom and a two-bedroom with large living room into a three-bedroom.

title: McDonnell Layoff
description: McDonnell Douglas Canada Ltd., a unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, said it would lay off about 850 workers as a result of declining commercial aircraft orders. About 350 workers will be given notice this week and the remainder will be released over the next three months, the company said. McDonnell Douglas Canada said employment at its Toronto plant, where wings and other components for the parent company's DC-10 airliners are built, is more than 3,800.

title: Oil Project Loan to Sudan
description: The International Finance Corporation said today that it would provide $300,000 to help form and finance the White Nile Petroleum Company to promote a pipeline and refinery project in the Sudan.

title: CITY TO OPEN ACCOUNTS AGAIN AT BANKS OF MINORITY GROUPS
description: For the first time since 1974, New York City plans to deposit some of its money in minority-owned banks, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's office said yesterday.

title: OUTLET STORES OFFER ROCK-BOTTOM PRICES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Mel Novit is a freelance writer living in Skokie, Ill. By MEL NOVIT

title: Boston School Board Votes To Drop 960 Teaching Jobs
description: The Boston School Committee has voted unanimously to eliminate 960 teaching jobs, including 710 held by permanent teachers, in the city's public school system.

title: Player's Suit Cites Failure To Teach
description: A former Detroit high school basketball star is suing his former junior college, high school and several coaches and officials for $15 million, claiming that he was pushed through school despite being unqualified for higher education.

title: POLISH REFUGEES REACH NEW YORK
description: The first in a series of special flights bringing East European refugees to the United States arrived at Kennedy International Airport yesterday with 252 passengers on board, two-thirds of them from Poland.

title: INTERNATIONAL DISPUTE IS CENTERED ON STATUS OF MEDITERRANEAN GULF
description: The legal issue raised by the reported downing of two Libyan fighter planes over the Gulf of Sidra centers on whether the site was part of the high seas or within Libyan internal waters.

title: DANCE: U.S. TERPSICHORE PERFORMS IN DAMROSCH PARK
description: THE Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival at Damrosch Park is getting to be the place to go for dance this summer. Last week it was Limbs, a zippy young troupe from New Zealand. And the performance on Monday of U.S. Terpsichore, a young, New York-based chamber dance company, provided one of the happiest and most varied evenings of dance entertainment this summer.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS ADVOCATES UPSET AT RISE IN KLAN-STYLE HARASSMENT
description: After four months of hate letters, cross burnings and shotgun blasts into houses and automobiles, one of the targets of harassment here has fled this tiny village in southeast Georgia. But no one has been arrested and the Federal Bureau of Investigation began an inquiry only three weeks ago.

title: NATIONAL RAILWAY UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $2,523,000 for the qr and $5,646,000 for the 6 mos from the extinguishment of debt...C-Including extraordinary credits of $2,461,000 for the qr and $2,390,000 for the 6 mos from the extinguishment of debt

title: Business People; Senior Vice President At Fuqua Adds 2 Posts
description: Lawrence P. Klamon, 44-year-old senior vice president for finance and administration of Fuqua Industries, a diversified Atlanta based company, has taken on the responsibilities of two other officers who resigned recently. These assignments were assumed ''for the time being,'' according to a Fuqua spokesman.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF NEWS CONFERENCE AT PENTAGON ON THE DOGFIGHT WITH LIBYANS
description: Following is a transcript, provided by the Defense Department, of the news conference held today by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Lieut. Gen. Philip J. Gast, director of operations of the Joint Chiefs of Staff:

title: RICHMOND WHITES SEEK HELP UNDER THE VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: A group of whites involved in a redistricting dispute, seeking to take advantage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, are asking the Federal Government to disapprove a plan that they say would discriminate against whites.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OTTO PLUME, 80, PROPRIETOR OF COPENHAGEN RESTAURANT
description: Otto Plume, the owner of Copenhagen Restaurant, died Tuesday at New York Hospital.

title: V.A. FINDS 16 CASES
description: A doctor at the Veterans Administration Medical Center said today that 16 cases of legionnaires' disease had been found in the Buffalo area this year.

title: SAVING BLOOMSBURY SET'S SUSSEX HAVEN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan Goodman is a freelance writer living in London. By SUSAN GOODMAN LEWES, England THE painted signboard indicates Charleston, its arrow pointing away from the winding country road up a narrow lane. It was up this same lane, deep in the Sussex countryside, that the artist Vanessa Bell first rode in September 1916, pedaling her bike to view an isolated farmhouse 56 miles from London. Her sister, Virginia Woolf, who lived nearby, had described it in a letter as ''a most delightful house and strongly advise you to take it.''

title: Soviet Pipeline Deal in Japan
description: The Japanese Government has approved a $152 million export credit for the Soviet Union to finance the purchase of pipelayers and bulldozers for a pipeline in Siberia, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Steve Lohr TEXAS RICH. The Hunt Dynasty From the Early Oil Days Through the Silver Crash. By Harry Hurt 3d. 446 pages. W.W. Norton. $16.95.

title: Nuclear Accident in India
description: Two to three tons of heavy water leaked out of an atomic reactor in western India on Aug. 5 and one of the power plant's units was shut down, the Press Trust of India news agency reported today. No damage or injuries were reported.

title: De Beers Posts Drop in Profits
description: The world's leading diamond mining concern, the De Beers Mining Company, today announced a sharp drop in net profits for the first six months of this year, reflecting a slump in sales of precious stones in the United States and Europe.

title: HORSE-CARE BILL SIGNED BY KOCH AMID CLAMOR
description: Shouting, stamping, cheering and booing, horse owners and horse lovers packed the Blue Room of City Hall yesterday as Mayor Koch signed a bill that requires $25-a-year license tags for the 2,000 horses in the city and sets standards of care for horses.

title: 3 IN SOUTH AFRICA DOOMED BY COURT
description: Three members of the outlawed African National Congress, the main underground movement opposing white rule, were sentenced today to hang for their role in a series of sabotage attempts.

title: CONTRACTORS RATED BY CITY
description: Companies that were rated ''good to excellent'' in their presentations by the Department of Consumer Affairs:

title: Michigan Guards Attacked
description: Two prisoners attacked two guards today at the Michigan Reformatory, the scene of rioting this spring, officials reported.

title: POP: THE JACKSONS PERFORM AT GARDEN
description: THE Jacksons, who sold out Madison Square Garden for the first of two shows Tuesday night, are still five young men who perform contemporary black music. They still are led by Michael Jackson, and they still spice their music with various flashy moves and other bits of road-show spectacle. But these Jacksons are vastly different from the Jackson 5 who broke into American consciousness with four No. 1 singles in 1970.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Applies Herbicide To Oklahoma Reservoir
description: The Federal Government began sprinkling the herbicide 2,4-D today into the weed-infested Fort Cobb Reservoir, the source of drinking water for several southwestern Oklahoma towns.

title: PAPI'S HOMER HELPS TIGERS DEFEAT TWINS, 4-0, FOR 6TH STRAIGHT
description: Stan Papi, a last-minute replacement for the outfielder Kirk Gibson, who had a sore foot, hit a two-run homer tonight as Detroit beat the Minnesota Twins, 4-0. Papi's home run sparked a three-run fourth inning that helped the Tigers win their sixth straight game.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 common stock split on July 10, 1981; certain yr-ago results have been reclassified to conform to the 1981 presentation

title: ONASSIS EMPIRE STRUGGLES TO ADAPT
description: The empire Aristotle Onassis built remains, six years after his death, a major force in world shipping. But oil price increases and a depressed market for large tankers have complicated efforts by his daughter and the men he chose as assistants to make the holdings less vulnerable to sharp declines in the industry.

title: CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
