description: B-Including tax credits of $630,000 for the qr and $835,000 for the yr...C-Including $285,000 tax credit for the qr and $2,146,643 gain for the yr from a tax credit and the early extinguishment of debt; the company was formerly called Midland Mortgage Investors Trust

title: Rangers Talking With Hull
description: Bobby Hull, the seven-time goal-scoring champion of the National Hockey League, may be returning at the age of 42 to play for the Rangers. Hull has had several discussions with Craig Patrick, the vice president, about coming out of retirement.

title: Credit Markets; Oregon Issue at Record Yield
description: Record yields were set for double-A rated state bonds yesterday when Oregon brought a $180 million issue to the municipal market. The most-distant maturities fetched a tax-exempt return of 12.60 percent.

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * New West magazine changing its name to California magazine, effective with the October issue.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the Transit Authority's purchase of a Staten Island pier incorrectly described the relationship of John G. deRoos to Pouch Terminal Inc., owner of the pier, in the 1960's. Mr. deRoos was counsel to the Barber Steamship Lines, a tenant of Pouch.

title: IRANIAN EXILES SURRENDER BOAT TO FRANCE
description: After more than 24 hours of negotiations, Iranian hijackers agreed today to surrender to the French the Iranian gunboat they seized off the Spanish port of Cadiz last Thursday.

title: Helpful Hardware blocks; RESTORATION HARDWARE: CATALOGUES FOR BUYERS
description: IN the last year several catalogues from companies that specialize in restoration hardware supplies have come to our attention. They are a real boon to those renovating - or even building -houses in areas where a wide range of decorative hardware is not available. Even in large cities such catalogues can save trips to hardware sources.

title: Pop Jazz; ART HODES IS BACK PLAYING THE BLUES
description: CAN a white musician play the blues? In the 1960's, this seemed a burning question as young musicians like John Mayall and Eric Clapton in Britain, John Hammond Jr. in New York and Paul Butterfield and the late Michael Bloomfield in Chicago began to emulate older black blues artists. It was not the first time the question had been raised.

title: BATTLE OF BIGHORN: INDIANS VS. FISHERMAN
description: For six years the battle had been joined, in court and out. The Crow Indians on the reservation near here argued that a 52-mile stretch of the Bighorn River that crosses their land belonged to them, and they closed it to non-Indian fishermen.

title: Advertising; Sawdon & Bess Names Co-Op Ad Director
description: Sawdon & Bess has named Thomas J. McGoldrick, formerly a vice president in charge of retail sales for the Television Bureau of Advertising, to the new position of director of co-op advertising.

title: Philharmonic Embarks On a Tour of 10 Cities
description: The New York Philharmonic opened a 10-city, 14-concert transcontinental tour Wednesday night at the Wolf Trap Farm Park, near Washington. This is the first cross-country tour by the orchestra with Zubin Mehta, its music director.

title: Disney to Issue Its First Debt
description: Walt Disney Productions, the California-based entertainment concern and theme park operator, is raising $100 million with a five-year Eurobond, its first public debt issue anywhere, the lead manager, Morgan Stanley International, said today.

title: In the Nation; HOW TO 'REVULSE' THE PUBLIC
description: ''Reagan Panel Urges $2 Billion to Build Prisons,'' said one day's headline. ''Reagan Seeks More Budget Cuts Worth $75 Billion,'' said the next day's.

title: STRIKE IN POLAND AGAINST THE PRESS ENDS ON SOUR NOTE
description: A two-day printers' strike that effectively silenced most of Poland's major newspapers, ended today on an angry note. Solidarity, the independent trade union, threatened an even wider shutdown that might include television and radio.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
VW Seeks Ottawa Pact
description: Volkswagenwerk, the West German auto maker, said today that it would transfer some high-technology operations to a proposed Canadian parts plant in return for duty-free privileges from the Canadian Government.

title: EXPERIENCE, OR LACK OF IT, IS THE ISSUE IN BROOKLYN'S DISTRICT ATTORNEY RACE
description: Norman J. Rosen says he has lived in the shadow of District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn for 12 years. He worked in a spacious office adjoining Mr. Gold's, preparing grant applications, drawing up a budget and, in his words, ''sitting in on'' the policy decisions.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Per Series A common stock...C-Per Series B common stock; yr-ago shr earnings for Series A common stock have been adjusted for subsequent stock divds

title: BALCO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Including $103,000 tax credit

title: Around the Nation; Cult Defector Testifies In 1978 Guyana Ambush
description: A defector from the Peoples' Temple cult testified today that his suspicions were aroused when Larry Layton, on trial for conspiracy to commit murder, joined a party leaving the cult's settlement in Jonestown, Guyana.

title: FORD SELLING FACTORY RICH WITH HISTORY
description: Henry Ford's Highland Park factory, the birthplace of mass production and the spiritual cradle of the American automobile industry, will be sold to a group of land developers, the company announced late today.

title: STARRED IN MUSICAL COMEDIES
description: Jessie Matthews, a star of Britain's musical-comedy stage, died of cancer today. She was 74 years old. Miss Matthews won fame on three continents before World War II as a singer and as one of the most graceful and athletic dancers of stage and screen. She was best known to American audiences as the star of such British film musicals of the mid-1930's as ''Evergreen,'' ''First a Girl'' and ''It's Love Again.''

title: Harris Poll Finds Most Oppose the Air Strike
description: A majority of Americans side with the Reagan Administration in opposing the air traffic controllers' strike, despite their sympathy for the controllers' personal and financial plight, according to a Louis Harris survey made public today.

title: Pirates Trade Milner To Expos for Montanez
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates announced today that John Milner, an outfielder and first baseman, has been traded to the Montreal Expos for the first baseman Willie Montanez.

title: Aoki and Irwin Tie For Lead With 65's
description: Isao Aoki, who got into the tournament because Mike Souchak stepped aside for him, and Hale Irwin each shot seven-under 65 today to share the first-round lead by one stroke in the $350,000 Buick Open.

title: Sports News Briefs; Coroner Begins Inquiry Into Death of Settles
description: A coroner's inquest began today into the death of Ron Settles, a Long Beach State football star who was found hanged in his jail cell in June.

title: Hearings on Court Nominee
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has tentatively set hearings for Sept. 9 to 11 on the nomination of Sandra Day O'Connor to the Supreme Court, a committee aide said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co. said the independent French airline Union de Transports Aeriens had ordered two extra-capacity Boeing 747 airplanes, valued at about $140 million, with delivery scheduled for March 1983 and May 1984.

title: POORLY CHOSEN LABEL FOR OLDER AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: D'AMATO, IN TESTIMONY, DENIES PLANT KICKBACKS
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, testifying in Federal District Court here, denied today that he had received kickbacks in exchange for the awarding of construction contracts at the Town of Hempstead's recycling plant in Westbury.

title: JETS FILL SPOT IN DEFENSIVE LIVE
description: When Paul (Bear) Bryant showed up at the Jets' camp a couple of weeks ago to pose with some of his former Alabama players - like Joe Namath, Richard Todd and Marty Lyons - Ben Rudolph was not in the picture.

title: Canadian Bill Rate
description: The average yield on this week's issue of 91-day Canadian Treasury bills declined to 20.78 percent from 20.82 percent last week, the Bank of Canada said today. Another rate, the key bank rate, fell slightly to 21.03 percent from 21.07 percent the week before and from a record 21.24 percent two weeks ago.

title: Business People; OPERATIONS SPECIALIST TO PAINE, WEBBER POST
description: Leland H. Amaya, a Wall Street operations expert, has been appointed vice chairman of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, the big securities firm, effective Oct. 1. The post had been vacant.

title: Temperence Hill Out Of Arlington Million
description: Temperence Hill will not run in the Arlington Million Aug. 30, Arlington Park officials announced today.

title: Advertising; Weekend Watching Of TV Shows Rises
description: More homes are watching weekend television than ever before, according a study by the Television Bureau of Advertising. In the last five years, the study found, weekend viewing in every time period was up by at least 10 percent, with a 27 percent increase in Sunday morning viewing and 21 percent increase in Saturday afternoon.

title: Angels 6, Orioles 2
description: Don Baylor slammed a two-run homer and a pair of doubles, and Geoff Zahn completed a nine-hitter for his first career victory over Baltimore after seven losses. The Orioles stopped Bobby Grich's hitting streak at 21 games, one short of the Angel record set by Sandy Alomar in 1970. Steve Stone, the 1980 Cy Young Award winner, pitched a perfect inning for Baltimore in relief, his first appearance since May 16.

title: BOND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $925,000 for the qr and $1,940,000 for the 9 mos

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, AUGUST 21, 1981; The Economy
description: The Federal Reserve Board moved to provide emergency credit for financial institutions at rates as low as 14 percent. The action, welcomed by the troubled thrift industry, is meant to offer longer-term credits than the two- to three-day loans now available. (Page D1.)

title: American Beaten in Somalia
description: A 25-year-old American relief worker was attacked and beaten in his tent at a refugee camp near the Ethiopian border, officials said today.

title: CONVERSATION IN BRIDGEPORT
description: A conversation between Police Superintendent Joseph A. Walsh of Bridgeport and Thomas Marra Jr., an undercover operative for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, that led to Mr. Marra's arrest for attempting to bribe Mr. Walsh took place in a parked car in Bridgeport Tuesday night. Here are excerpts from a transcript of that conversation, as released by the Bridgeport police.

title: Mount Everest Attempt Due
description: A United States expedition has set out from Lhasa for an attempt on the previously unconquered eastern face of Mount Everest, an official of the Chinese Mountaineering Association said today. Richard Blum, the husband of Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco, is leading the 15-member expedition. The Americans hope to reach the top, an elevation of 29,028 feet, by Oct. 4.

title: AT ZAIRE MASSACRE SITE, THE SCARS AND FEAR LIVE ON
description: Some people did not claim their dead, and the bodies lie in paupers' graves, where crab grass curls around stenciled name boards and numbered pegs that are their only memorial.

title: Family Abducted in Alabama
description: A bank executive and his wife and two children were held hostage yesterday by two gunmen who demanded money from the bank where he worked, the authorities said. Edward Hilliard, a 32-year-old vice president at a First National Bank branch office, and his wife and children, who were not identified, were released unharmed after the money was delivered. The amount taken was not immediately determined.

title: RABBIS' STAND ON EXCAVATION SPLITS ISRAEL
description: Condemnation by Israel's two Chief Rabbis of a major archeological excavation near the Old City of Jerusalem has created a further division between secular and religious Jews in Israel.

title: IT'S A BUSY SEASON ON THE SUMMER-THEATER CIRCUIT
description: IT is getting chilly on the Hampton beaches early in the morning; it is cool in the Berkshires late at night. The summer is waning, although some of its entertainments are still intact. One of them is summer theater, which this season is rich, as always, in comedies, musicals and classics, and short, as always, in straight plays, especially somber ones. Somberness in summer theaters is sanctioned only in classics, preferably Elizabethan. The names in summer theater this year are Hart, Gershwin and Shakespeare, not O'Neill, Williams and Miller, although many of the summer productions are uncommonly ambitious. Once, the strawhat circuit was just a poor cousin of Broadway; now it is more like an adjunct.

title: U.S. REBUFFS A PROPOSAL TO RENEW NEGOTIATIONS WITH AIR CONTROLLERS
description: Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis today rejected a call from the international air traffic controllers' group to resume negotiations with the president of the striking American controllers' union.

title: Around the Nation; Storm Grows Stronger But Heads Into Atlantic
description: Tropical Storm Dennis routed thousands of tourists from the Carolina vacation islands today, then moved out into the warm waters of the Atlantic and became the first hurricane of the year.

title: Sports News Briefs; Receipts in Evidence At Ex-Coach's Trial
description: Prosecutors introduced ticket receipts today as they attempted to prove their contention that Manny Goldstein, a former University of New Mexico assistant basketball coach, had a history of trying to defraud the school.

title: Around the World; U.N. Energy Parley Seeks a Compromise
description: Delegates to the United Nations energy conference here were meeting today to try to reach a compromise on how to finance and promote the development of fuels to replace expensive and dwindling hydrocarbons. With the 11-day conference set to end tomorrow, the outcome appeared in doubt.

title: QADDAFI ATTACKS U.S. 'PROVOCATIONS'
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has accused the United States of ''persisting in its provocations and terror'' but has remained silent on what action he might take as a result of the air battle Wednesday between American and Libyan jets.

title: Stephen Salyer Heads WNET Education Unit
description: Stephen L. Salyer has been named vice president and director of WNET-TV's educational division, filling a position that had been open since the division was expanded last fall.

title: 'FIRST MONDAY IN OCTOBER'
description: WHAT if the latest Supreme Court Justice were a woman? And what if that woman were a terrible pill? ''First Monday in October'' manages to ask both of these questions, only the first one intentionally. But Justice Ruth Loomis, as played by Jill Clayburgh, is both a belligerent, tough-minded careerist and the kind of woman who, when left alone in her office, will surreptitiously repot a begonia. She combines the worst of both worlds.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GRAY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Net loss after $485,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: BLUE SKY OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
description: B-Including gans of $5,449,015 for the latest yr and $691,175 for the previous yr from securities transactions

title: Record Cotton Use Expected
description: Worldwide consumption of cotton is expected to set a record of 67.5 million bales this season, the Agriculture Department reported today, with increases forecast in both American and foreign use. Last season's total consumption amounted to 65.9 million bales, the department said.

title: 2 Flee From East Germany
description: The West German border police said today that two youths, aged 17 and 18, had fled from East Germany by digging a tunnel under the boundary fence. The youths managed to avoid the notice of East German border guards because the area was mainly woodland.

title: OPTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: The shr earnings reflect an 8-for-1 reverse stock split effective Nov 30, 1980; the results do not reflect the July 27, 1981 disposition of a retail divisin

title: BOARDWALK BLAZE DESTROYS 12 STORES IN WILDWOOD
description: A wind-whipped fire burned through a row of stores on a sprawling amusement pier in the business center of this oceanfront resort early today, causing millions of dollars in damage as it destroyed the site of a historic dance hall.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes 40 cents a shr gain on sale of interest in a business

title: Around the Nation; Delay Sought in Freeing Cubans in Federal Prison
description: The Government asked a Federal District judge tonight to postpone the effective date of an order freeing several hundred Cuban refugees from the Federal penitentiary here. The request was made moments after the judge, Marvin H. Shoob, formally filed a decision he announced earlier freeing 365 Cubans as soon as sponsors could be found for them.

title: KNOTTING, A FINE ART OF CHINA, ON 65TH ST.
description: To most New Yorkers, knots are for shoelaces and neckties. But to the Chinese, knots are an art form. There are cloverleaf knots and button knots, knots that tell a story and knots used for religious purposes. And, of course, there are lovers' knots.

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1980 figures restated to reflect accounting change

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
News Analysis
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that their decision to hold naval exercises in waters claimed by Libya was intended to affirm the right of free passage in international waters and not continue to allow even the appearance of letting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi set the rules.

title: Sports of The Times; Boxing's Best-Kept Secret
description: THE first time Wilfredo Gomez pulled on padded mittens to punch another fellow for money was in Panama City Nov. 16, 1974. He boxed a six-round draw with one Jacinto Fuentes. Since that evening, Wilfredo has had 32 matches and knocked out 32 opponents, including Jacinto Fuentes. Thirty-two bouts and 32 knockouts, no decisions, no draws, no defeats.

title: SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a charge of $1.7 million or 18 cents a shr for the writeoff of certain typewriter patents and production rights

title: SOARING FROM HARD ROCK TO 'PENZANCE' STARDOM
description: AT night she is Mabel, the demure Victorian maiden who gives her heart to a young pirate attempting a career change. During the day she is a rock-and-roller recording songs with titles like ''Dance in My Pants'' and ''Bloody Bess.'' ''It's a little schizoid,'' says Karla DeVito cheerfully. ''Sometimes I get kind of confused.''

title: ROLFITE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEAR CREEK LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POP: MELISSA MANCHESTER
description: ALTHOUGH Melissa Manchester's big, chesty voice and operatic style of declamation make her one of the most commanding theatrical singers in America, her punchy, larger-than-life approach to pop is difficult to record without its seeming somewhat overblown. In a concert setting, however, Miss Manchester is completely in her element, and at the Savoy, where she appeared on Tuesday, Wednesday and last night, backed by a 30-piece orchestra, she put on a very impressive show.

title: MATE SAYS BARGE MAY HAVE HIT BOAT
description: A tugboat's first mate testified yesterday that a barge his vessel was towing ''might have'' hit a cabin cruiser that sank in Long Island Sound 12 days ago.

title: Talking Business; A NEW EXECUTIVE'S PLANS AT WOOLWORTH
description: Given high interest rates and continuing inflation, the nation's biggest retailers are pursuing a cautious operating policy while looking ahead to ways of expanding their growth. This reduces itself to seeking ways of improving current productivity and trying to determine whether to diversify further or narrow their scope. On June 15, Allan L. Pennington left his post as vice president for corporate development at the Dayton Hudson Corporation, Minneapolis, to become executive vice president for marketing at the F. W. Woolworth Company. Recently, the 41-year old executive participated in the following interview.

title: ONE-TRACK MIND ON U.S. SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S A BOY! 180 POUNDS - FOR NOW
description: An 11-year-old Indian elephant named Patty filled the early-morning darkness at the Bronx Zoo yesterday with a trumpeting scream and, within seconds, gave birth to a pink-skinned, white-haired, 180-pound bull calf.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BELL ASKS TRUST-SUI DISMISSAL
description: A lawyer for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company urged a judge today to dismiss the Government's antitrust suit against the world's largest corporation, describing it as a ''fraud'' and an ''outrage.''

title: 5 on Rikers I. Stabbed Over a Lunch Boycott
description: Five inmates of the Men's House of Detention at Rikers Island suffered minor stab wounds yesterday, according to the city's Department of Correction.

title: CANCER UNIT ACCUSED OF IRRADIATING UNWITTING PATIENTS IN NASA TEST
description: Scientists at a Federal cancer center exposed 194 unsuspecting patients to large doses of radiation to determine the limits of human tolerance to radiation for the space program, it was charged today.

title: Notes on People; Justice for Clerks
description: When Potter Stewart left the Supreme Court last month, he left his three young law clerks in the lurch. The three, Deborah A. Jones, John P. Dwyer and Brian G. Cartwright, had just been hired after clerking for the Court of Appeals in Washington, but Mr. Stewart's departure seemed to end their chance to serve the high court.

title: News Analysis
description: When the Battery Park City Authority announced plans this week for the latest phase of housing construction on its 92-acre landfill site in the Hudson River, it took pains to describe the complex it would build as something apart from conventional housing projects.

title: Market Place; Fast Growth For Air Cargo
description: FOR years, some in Wall Street have been saying that the Federal Express Corporation's rapid growth would soon peak. Yet the 10-yearold air express company keeps growing.

title: The Joint Chiefs of Staff had just returned from lunch and were feeling bloated. The generals and I were sitting in the Pentagon's war room playing Space Invaders on the giant radar screens.
description: ''We're really taking a lot of flak from the press these days about military spending,'' began the General of the Army, feeding the radar screen another quarter. ''Did you see what they said about our cost overruns in Time? I'll tell you, we're really getting killed out there.''

title: NORBERT MUHLEN, 72, A WRITER
description: Norbert Muhlen, a staunch opponent of Nazism who wrote many books on postwar Germany, died Thursday of leukemia at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Braves Defeat Mets, 6-4; Sharp Outing for Niekro
description: Six Mets pitchers, four of them rookies, could not match the 42-year-old knuckleballer Phil Niekro tonight. Niekro, a right-hander in his 18th season, held the Mets to six hits for seven innings and led the Braves to a 6-4 victory.

title: Connecticut Opera Gets A $27,300 Donation
description: The Connecticut Opera has received $27,300, the largest single gift ever received from an individual donor, from one of its past presidents.

title: TV Weekend; A REAL COURTROOM, A FUNNY PILOT AND MRS. CAREY
description: TELEVISION has long drawn on the courtroom as a setting for primetime entertainment shows, ranging from the classic Perry Mason series, in which countless episodes were capped with a dramatic confession from the witness stand, to the sepulchral, simulated trials of ''Divorce Court.'' But just how gripping are real-life cases in average courtrooms around the country?

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OPEC FAILS TO NARROW PRICE GAP
description: The oil ministers of the 13 OPEC nations, unable to resolve their price dispute, announced tonight that their heads of state were appealing directly to King Khalid of Saudi Arabia to raise that country's oil price by more than $2 a barrel.

title: GROUP PRESSES U.S. TO MARK FOOD DAY
description: ''Only they who attempt the absurd can achieve the impossible,'' reads the poster behind the desk of Patricia Young, coordinator of the National Committee for World Food Day.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Tin Price Rollback At National Steel
description: The National Steel Corporation said it was withdrawing an earlier announced 6 percent increase in the base price of tin mill products, virtually completing the industry's rollback of a price increase announced only two weeks ago. The United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest steel producer, made a similar move on Tuesday.

title: Topics; BOOKS, BLONDES, BOMBS, BROOKLYN; Gates
description: Merit promotion is now a fact of life for New York City schoolchildren. Last June, 24,000 fourth- and seventh-graders failed to get through the school system's promotional gates because they lagged a year or more in reading.

title: TOWN RETAKEN, EL SALVADOR SAYS
description: Salvadoran Army officials said today that their troops had recaptured the strategic town of Perquin from rebel forces.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $12.2 million gain from the sale of an investment

title: IN SEARCH OF A MONSTER
description: A strange sense of anticlimax has set in here since the arrest of Wayne B. Williams, who is charged in 2 of the 28 murders that terrorized the city for two years.

title: RETIREMENT ACCOUNT: IT'S EASY
description: Most tax matters are complicated. But for those wishing to take advantage of the new rules governing tax-free retirement accounts, setting up such an account can be as easy as opening a bank account or investing in a money market fund.

title: FOR COMRADE HUANG, A NEW NAME, A NEW UNIFORM
description: A former Taiwan Air Force flight instructor said here today that he had willingly defected on Aug. 8 in his F-5 jet fighter in order to demonstrate his desire to see Taiwan and China peacefully reunified.

title: A 10TH HUNGER STRIKER DIES IN ULSTER
description: Michael Devine, a 27-year-old Irish nationalist, died in the Maze Prison here this morning at the beginning of his 60th day without food.

title: THE TITLE X BATTLE IS WON--FOR NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: PICTURES THAT TELL STORIES AT THE MODERN
description: IN the beginning was the word, the Bible says. But it's a safe bet that the picture came close behind. We long ago lost count of how soon after publication day the old masters - and sometimes the more recent masters, too - hightailed it into the studio with the new poem, the new novel or the latest play.

title: NEW CHIEF NAMED BY GREYHOUND
description: The Greyhound Corporation announced yesterday that it had named John W. Teets, a vice chairman, as chief executive officer. The promotion put the 48-year-old executive in line to succeed Gerald H. Trautman as chairman of the diversified company when Mr. Trautman retires next August.

title: COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Funds' Assets Rise $2.5 Billion
description: The assets of the nation's money-market mutual funds climbed $2.5 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 12th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Advertising; Black Shoppers Guide To Aid Fund-Raising
description: A Black Shoppers Guide linking cents-off coupons to fund-raising is being introduced in New York this November by the Black Gospel Collection, a marketing company formed to distribute goods and services to black consumers through their churches.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-After $9.5 million extraordinary charge resulting from a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission...C-Net income

title: 2-Year Notes at Record 16.26%; Other Rates Fairly Stable
description: Reflecting the heavy supply of new Government issues coming to market, the Treasury yesterday sold two-year notes carrying a record coupon of 16 1/4 percent. The previous sale of notes in this maturity bore a 15 7/8 percent coupon only one month earlier.

title: The Evening Hours
description: I T'S a moot point as to whether blondes have more fun, but millionaires certainly do, especially Malcolm S. Forbes, who is the chairman of Forbes magazine. Mr. Forbes is not what one would call a reticent type. He enjoys himself smack in the public eye, and balances such unmillionaire-like activities as ballooning and motorcycling with the more genteel pursuits of collecting Faberge and yachting.

title: Cities Service Discovery Well
description: The Cities Service Company, the nation's 18th-largest oil company and a frequent target of takeover speculation, reported a new oil discovery in a wildcat well off Palawan Island in the Philippines.

title: C.A.B. Chief to Resign
description: Marvin S. Cohen announced yesterday that he would resign as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board effective Sept. 15. The announcement had been expected.

title: Nuclear Submarines' Builder Says Rickover Imperiled Two
description: The manufacturer of two nuclear submarines said that they went out of control and their crews were endangered because Adm.

title: Paper Goods' Trade Surplus
description: The United States exported about $200 million more in paper and related products last year than it imported, the Commerce Department said today. It was the first time exports topped imports since World War II.

title: RED SOX 6, A'S 4
description: Dwight Evans drove in the deciding run when he singled with the bases loaded in the eighth to help Boston snap Oakland's five-game winning streak.

title: OBOTE VOWS TO END UGANDAN 'CULT OF KILLINGS'
description: Faced with violence and a state approaching anarchy, President Milton Obote vowed today to end ''the cult of rampant killings'' in Uganda.

title: United to Cut Fares
description: United Airlines announced today it would reduce its normal transcontinental fares by as much as 45 percent on Oct.1.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
No Headline
description: Books: Bomb Watchers By Herbert Mitgang UNFORGETTABLE FIRE: Pictures Drawn by Atomic Bomb Survivors. Edited by the Japan Broadcasting Cor- poration. 111 pages. Pantheon. Hard cover, $15.95, paperback $7.95.

title: PUBLISHING: CHICAGO'S R.K. NARAYAN
description: THIS fall, the University of Chicago Press plans to publish ''Waiting for the Mahatma'' and ''The Financial Expert,'' bringing to seven the number of novels it will have published by R.K. Narayan. That represents a sizable portion of the 25 novels and stories in English written by the acclaimed Indian author during the last 46 years, and is all the more unusual because Chicago rarely publishes fiction.

title: Samuel Nass, 72, Dies; Former Gimbel Official
description: Samuel Nass, who served for more than 40 years as an executive of Gimbel Brothers Inc., died last Friday at New York Hospital of heart disease. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: VALEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TWO-DAY PARTY IN CELEBRATION OF ELEPHANTS AT BRONX ZOO
description: a workout on the tambourine, a run-through on the waltz, some salutes and bows. Being elephants, they haven't seen the press release, and so they don't know that they are the stars of a festival, the Bronx Zoo's ''Elephant Weekend: Elephants Galore.''

title: Auto Layoffs Up in Week
description: The number of open-ended layoffs in the United States auto industry rose slightly this week, despite a 20 percent increase in car production, according to industry reports released today.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SHE FOLLOWS THE PARTY LINE
description: It was bewildering. Should one go at the small mountain of cold lobsters heaped on a sideboard? Or the platters of smoked trout or poached salmon? A dip into the rattan cornucopias of crudites or fresh melon and berries?

title: Notes on People; Roy Wilkins in Hospital
description: Roy Wilkins, the 79-year-old civil-rights leader, was being treated for a heart ailment yesterday at New York University Medical Center. Mr. Wilkins, who headed the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for 21 years, until his retirement in 1976, entered the hospital Tuesday night. His condition was listed as serious but not critical, according to a hospital spokesman, who said the Wilkins family had asked that details of his ailment and treatment not be released. On Wednesday, his physician, Dr. Lawrence Meyers, said that the outlook for his patient was ''favorable.''

title: REAL INCOME DOWN 5.5% IN 1980 IN A RECORD DROP
description: Persistent double-digit inflation and the 1980 recession combined to depress the real income of American families by 5.5 percent last year, the biggest drop since 1947, when the Government began keeping records, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: SOME COLLEGES TURNING TO CLASSES FOR THE YOUNG
description: The chairs at Mohawk Valley Community College here are too large for some students, the slot for the soda machine is too high, and even the most well-adjusted students have been known, occasionally, to cry for their mothers.

title: Notes on People; Biggest Art Crime
description: Seventy years ago today two Italian carpenters walked out of the Louvre in Paris, committing what Seymour V. Reit, who is passionately interested in the case, yesterday called ''the most incredible art crime of this century.''

title: SHELL OIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Represents Royal Dutch Petroleum's portion of shr earnings... C-Represents Shell Transport & Trading's portion of shr earning both Royal Dutch Petroleum which has a 60 percent shr of the group ad Shell Transport & Trading, which has a 40 percent shr are listed on the New York Stock Exchange

title: NOISE PROTECTION RULES ISSUED
description: The Reagan Administration issued a modified version of Federal noise protection rules today, eliminating many details from a plan originally proposed by the Carter Administration to conserve the hearing of 5.1 million workers.

title: Zimbabwe Backs Move To Bar New Zealanders
description: Zimbabwe today declared its support for moves to bar New Zealand from competing in the 1982 Commonwealth Games in Australia because it has allowed the Springboks rugby team from South Africa to tour the country.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AIDE CRITICIZES FIRM SUING WATT
description: Alfred S. Regnery, a Justice Department lawyer defending Interior Secretary James G. Watt, today accused one of two conservative legal groups that have sued Mr. Watt of ''improper'' suggestions in letters to the department.

title: N.C.A.A. Official Issues A Warning on TV Plan
description: A committee chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association said today that the College Football Association's television plan might result in the distintegration of the Southwest Conference.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, AUGUST 21, 1981
description: International The Navy maneuvers off Libya this week were planned to show that the United States was not honoring Libya's territorial claim to the Gulf of Sidra in the southern Mediterranean, President Reagan said. The maneuvers preceded an incident in which the United States said it had shot down two Libyan fighters that had fired on American jets. But Mr. Reagan denied that the exercises about 60 miles from the Libyan coast had been designed to provoke an incident or to threaten the Libyan regime. (Page A1, Column 6.) Oil company executives discounted the possibility that Libya would retaliate for the downing of the two jets. However, the officials expressed concern about the safety of the 1,500 American citizens living in Libya, and Exxon announced that all dependents of its employees there were being evacuated. (A11:1-2.)

title: HAZELTON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Homemade Music
description: A free outdoor concert of original music on instruments made of organic material will be presented by the Boneworks New Music Ensemble on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue.

title: Mexico to Sell Crude Oil To U.S. for Its Stockpile
description: Mexico signed a five-year contract to sell crude oil directly to the United States Energy Department for its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, officials said today.

title: 'Ballo' in Madison
description: Dana Talley, a tenor with the Metropolitan Opera, will join the Jersey Lyric Opera Company for a performance of Verdi's ''A Masked Ball,'' tomorrow night at 8 at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison, N.J. The cast, directed by James Millar, also features Paul Aquino, Alice Helgeson, Karen Beardsley, Sonia Lewis, Sal Cavallero and Charles Ward. Tickets are $10. Information: (201)464-4341 or (201) 654-5092.

title: HERMAN O. WEST
description: Herman O. West, who dropped out of college for lack of money and went on to build a multimillion-dollar department store chain, died today in the Minden Medical Center.

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fed to Keep Credit Curbs
description: The Federal Reserve will continue to follow ''a policy of restraining the growth of money and credit,'' its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said in an interview broadcast yesterday.

title: Country-Music Concert At Shea Is Canceled
description: ''A Day in the Country,'' an all-day country-music concert that was scheduled to take place in Shea Stadium tomorrow, has been canceled. According to Gordon Davis, New York City's Commissioner of Parks, ''the promoters were not able to meet the financial obligations they had in a timely and reasonable fashion.''

title: ISRAEL TIGHTENS EMIGRE POLICY
description: Israel has moved to make it more difficult for Jewish emigrants arriving in Vienna from the Soviet Union to go anywhere else but Israel.

title: FEDERAL RIGHTS CHIEF FAVORS MODERATE TACK
description: William Bradford Reynolds, the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, said today that he would not favor a wholesale review of Federal court decrees that pertained to school desegregation and other civil rights matters.

title: IN DEFENSE OF 'INTREPID'S' RECOLLECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; BOOKS BLONDES, BOMBS, BROOKLYN
description: The fire at Junior's Restaurant on Flatbush Avenue destroyed no ordinary eatery.

title: HARSH VIEW OF AMERICA IN 'HONKY TONK FREEWAY'
description: SYLVIA MILES'S poodle is alive and well, the one that appeared in ''Midnight Cowboy'' wearing false eyelashes and yapping nastily at everything in sight. Not that particular dog, perhaps, but certainly its attitude. John Schlesinger, who directed that film and has now made ''Honky Tonk Freeway,'' still thinks America is a crass, foolish, disagreeable place, and he has nothing to say about it that's new. However, Mr. Schlesinger has dusted off some old gags, shamelessly borrowed some more recent ones and put together a movie that's almost as surprisingly funny as it is silly.

title: New Battles Flare in Beirut
description: Fighting erupted along the dividing line between east and west Beirut today, and the radio of the right-wing Phalangist Party said two people were killed and 12 wounded.

title: About Real Estate; HOUSING ADVISERS HELPED LEFRAK CITY MEET ITS CRISIS
description: Because of the grafitti-scarred walls, the crime in the elevators and the resulting ''white flight'' at Lefrak City, many of its middle-class tenants had come to expect the worst: that the huge, middle-class Queens housing complex would suddenly decline into a slum.

title: The Wrong Defense Argument
description: Fitting the armed services' annual wish-lists into overall Pentagon and Administration budgets has been compared with trying to stuff a quilt into a pillowcase. But the Reagan Administration's initiation into this process is producing a misleading debate.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alabama Power Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $100 million of first-mortgage bonds to be sold through public bidding.

title: CORRECTION
description: As a result of a mechanical error yesterday, a dancer's name was omitted from a review of the ''American Sampler'' program at Jacob's Pillow. The sentence should have read: ''Clive Thompson, a former member of the Martha Graham and Alvin Ailey companies, danced the 'Ready' solo from Mr. Ailey's 'Revelations' with stunning intensity.''

title: O'Grady's W.B.A. Title Will Be Removed Soon
description: Rodrigo Sanchez, the World Boxing Association president, said today that the association would soon remove Sean O'Grady's lightweight title but has not done so already.

title: Topics; BOOKS, BLONDES, BOMBS, BROOKLYN; Reprise Surprise
description: In his classic study, ''Aspects of the Novel,'' E.M. Forster writes that man's fascination with suspenseful stories, ''goes back to neolithic times, perhaps to paleolithic.... The primitive audience was an audience of shock-heads, gaping round the camp-fire, fatigued with contending against the mammoth or the woolly rhinoceros, and only kept awake by suspense. What would happen next?''

title: Texas International May Get Stock Vote
description: Texas International Airlines, awaiting President Reagan's approval of its bid to take over Continental Air Lines, was given more flexibility today to exercise voting rights on its 48.5 percent interest in Continental.

title: JAZZ: GEORGE SHEARING
description: GEORGE SHEARING, whose New York appearances in recent years have been at the Cafe Carlyle, has moved from that supper club atmosphere to a genuine jazz room this week, Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue and 17th Street, where he is playing through Sunday.

title: Restaurants; Distinctive kitchen; convivial trattoria.
description: A CONSISTENT problem with many of the self-taught young cooks who are in a hurry to open their own restaurants without working enough for experienced chefs is that they get little opportunity to develop their palates. With apprenticeship to a master, their own natural talents would be honed against the classics, and gradually they would achieve the best sort of creativity - an individual style rooted in tradition. It is unusual for a self-taught chef who is not drawing from a family or ethnic-food background to achieve a dependably sure hand in an idiom not basically his or her own.

title: WESTERN EUROPEANS EXPRESSING FAVOR AND UNEASE
description: Western Europe reacted today to the reported American downing of two Libyan fighter planes with a mixture of support for the United States view of the legality and the appropriateness of the action and concern about increasing signs from Washington of an aggressive foreign policy.

title: Free Jazz and Puppets at the Atrium
description: Free entertainment continues this weekend in the Atrium at the Citicorp Center, with jazz and classical concerts today through Sunday and a puppet show for children tomorrow.

title: POORLY CHOSEN LABEL FOR OLDER AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSER CAPTURES MET GOLF
description: Kelley Moser of Shorehaven, winner of the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association earlier this year, added the Metropolitan Golf Association Open championship today.

title: Guerrillas Warn South Africa
description: The African National Congress threatened reprisals today if the South African Government carries out death sentences imposed on three of its guerrillas. A Pretoria court convicted the men of high treason for attacks on a refinery and a police station.

title: DIRECTOR RESIGNS AS BROOKHAVEN FACES A PROBLEM
description: The director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island has resigned. His decision comes at a time when budget cuts and developmental difficulties could threaten completion of a $500 million physics project there.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Japan Cuts Oil Imports
description: Japan, with oil storage tanks filled to capacity and domestic demand declining, is cutting its crude oil import target for the 1981-82 financial year by 4.9 percent, to 4.65 million barrels a day, the Ministry for International Trade and Industry said today. The new target compares with 4.89 million barrels daily of crude oil imports in the year ended March 31, and an original goal of 4.98 million for the current year, the ministry said.

title: TRECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chrysler Canada Offers Incentives
description: Chrysler Canada Ltd. said it was offering its dealers an incentive program that includes factory discounts of $200 to $1,000 on most 1981 Chrysler-built passenger cars and trucks.

title: INQUIRIES STARTED IN PATIENT'S DEATH
description: Two state agencies and New York City's Medical Examiner have begun investigations into the unexplained death of a 17-year-old patient at the South Beach Psychiatric Center on Staten Island last Monday, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: CALIFORNIA FINDS NEW FLIES AND EXPANDS SPRAYING
description: As two more fertile Mediterranean fruit flies were discovered, the California Attorney General asked the United States Supreme Court today to prevent Georgia from banning produce grown on farms outside four counties battling the destructive insect.

title: energywatch
description: AUG. 14, 1981 Crude oil stocks rose to 387.5 million barrels as imports increased to 4.3 million barrels a day.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE IMPOTENCE OF EUROPE
description: Gaston Thorn, the new President of the Common Market's Commission, is from Luxembourg. Like many Europeans, he has a vacation house in Spain, near the Costa Brava, and it is a good place to reflect on the continuing quarrels and frictions which prevent consolidation of the European Community.

title: Sale by Crompton
description: The Crompton & Knowles Corporation said it had reached an agreement in principle with the Leesona Corporation of Warwick, R.I., for the purchase by Leesona of virtually all the remaining textile machinery business of Crompton & Knowles for an undisclosed amount of cash. Under the agreement, Leesona would acquire Crompton & Knowles plants in Burlington and Mooresville, N.C., that produce textile weaving equipment and replacement parts. It would also receive patent rights to the equipment, marketing information and all inventory at the plants.

title: Around the World; Former Premier to Form New Cabinet in Lisbon
description: Francisco Pinto Balsemao, who resigned as Prime Minister Aug. 10, agreed today to form a new government of the Democratic Alliance coalition, a spokesman for the Social Democratic Party said.

title: Poles Agree To Debt Plan
description: Poland has broadly accepted proposals by Western banks allowing it to defer repayment of some $2.8 billion of debt falling due this year, Western bankers said here today.

title: Playoffs Beginning For N.A.S.L. Clubs
description: The North American Soccer League playoffs will get under way tomorrow with 14 teams participating and one team, the Cosmos, waiting as a result of a bye in the first round.

title: PREVOR-MAYRSOHN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $37,847 extraordinary net loss on the sale of an investment

title: 'HENRY IV, PART 1,' IN THE PARK
description: IN John Vickery's performance as Prince Hal in ''The First Part of King Henry the Fourth,'' which opened Wednesday at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, there is a feeling of personal and historical inevitability. More than most actors I have seen in the role, Mr. Vickery makes it clear that Hal's quick maturing is deeply imbedded in his character. His true purpose has been dammed up behind his ''truant youth,'' and as he vows to his father that he will conquer Hotspur, he floods the stage with determination. In this intelligent and impassioned performance, we can see the seeds of the martial glory that will be the heritage of Henry V.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
APPLICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: Results reflect a $360,000 pretax decrease in net income for th latest qr and a $52,000 pretax increase in net income for the previous qr

title: GROW GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
1,000 Protest in Cape Town Over the Arrest of Squatters
description: About 1,000 people, most of them whites, marched to the center of Cape Town today to protest the South African Government's treatment of black squatters.

title: Convict Ordered Extradited
description: A escaped prisoner charged with murdering a San Diego woman in the South Pacific seven years ago has been ordered extradited to Hawaii to stand trial. The 43-year-old convict, Buck Duane Walker, is charged with the slaying of Eleanor Graham, who, along with her husband, Malcolm, were last heard from Aug. 8, 1974, on Palmyra Island, 1,200 miles south of Honolulu. Mr. Walker and his companion, Stephanie K. Stearns, 35, were convicted in 1975 on charges of stealing the Grahams' yacht, which was found in Honolulu.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 21, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Special Committee on Decolonization, subcommittee on petitions, information and assistance - 10:30 A.M. Special Committee on Decolonization - 11 A.M.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: The stock market posted its second small consecutive advance yesterday in lackluster trading. Analysts continued to attribute the indifferent performance to investors' apprehension that interest rates would remain high over the near term. When interest rates are high, stock prices generally decline.

title: THE S.E.C. STAYS FIRM ON FIRMS' DISCLOSURES
description: To the Editor:

title: SANDAR RADO, CARTOGRAPHER, 81
description: Sandor Rado, a Hungarian cartographer who served as a Soviet intelligence agent in World War II, died Wednesday in Budapest. He was 81 years old.

title: Dutch Shell Off 75.9%; Currency Factors Cited
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of oil companies, the world's thirdlargest industrial corporation after the Exxon Corporation and the General Motors Corporation, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1981 plunged 75.9 percent, as revenues advanced 12.7 percent.

title: ELDERLY FIND SECOND CAREERS ON CANVAS
description: At one time, when she was 18 and excited by courses she had taken in applied design, Ivy Wood wanted to be an art teacher, but the Depression came and, she said, ''I couldn't, I had to go out and work.''

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $745,000 for the qr and $2,111,000 for the yr and $322,000 extraordinary gain for the yr on the sale of land...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $668,000 for the qr and $1,412, for the yr $6,662,000 loss for the qr and yr on the disposal of discontinued operations and $3.3 million approximate nonrecurri charge for the qr and yr relating to the discontinuance of cert operations, principally start-up operations

title: Auctions; Photography levels off.
description: auction houses - Sotheby Parke Bernet, Christie's and Phillips, Son & Neale. Photography figures from Sotheby's and Christie's showed decreases in total sales. Both houses attributed the decline to the withdrawal of many investors from the auction scene.

title: Advertising; Newsweek Consolidates Ad Sales Functions
description: Newsweek has consolidated all advertising sales functions and operations in a single new department, Advertising Services, headed by Arthur E. Karlan, vice president. Mr. Karlan, who most recently was vice president, marketing/domestic, has held a number of positions in advertising at Newsweek since 1962.

title: Suspect in Slaying of Officer In Queens Pleads Not Guilty
description: The man accused of killing a police officer and seriously wounding another in Queens last April 16 pleaded not guilty to charges of first- and second-degree murder, attempted murder and first-degree assault in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday.

title: DISPUTE SETTLED BY MOON GROUP AND TARRYTOWN
description: The case of the boats on the lawn of the estate of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church was closed today as the Village of Tarrytown determined that the boats were finally gone and got an assurance that they would not return.

title: EX-NBC OFFICIAL PLEADS GUILTY IN KICKBACK CASE
description: Stephen Weston, a former vice president of NBC, has pleaded guilty in Manhattan to a Federal fraud charge involving cash kickbacks on services and equipment used for televising events.

title: EDWIN BOOTH JOINS SHAKESPEAREAN SUMMERFEST
description: When Dorothy Swerdlove was asked to prepare a display on the actor Edwin Booth's Shakespearean roles for the New York Public Library's part in Shakespeare Summerfest, her biggest problem was how to limit herself to the one big round case set aside for the exhibition.

title: Notes on People; Father Gets a Street Named After His Daughter
description: This has been no ordinary, run-of-the-mill week for Leona Mitchell, the soprano who has starred in productions at the Metropolitan Opera, the San Francisco Opera and Covent Garden.

title: Perkins Cautious, Pleased
description: In May, during the Giants' threeday minicamp, Coach Ray Perkins promised to predict before the season how well the team would do this year.

title: Bennett Memorial Today
description: A memorial service for Robert Russell Bennett, the arranger, composer and conductor, will be held today at 2:30 P.M. at the Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. Mr. Bennett died Tuesday at the age of 87.

title: DOING THEIR OWN THING ON A RENAISSANCE STAGE
description: The Renaissance Festival, now in its fourth summer at Sterling Forest Gardens in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., has several new attractions this year, but perhaps none more appropriate than Everyman's Stage, which is devoted entirely to the increasing number of people who want to offer their own performances.

title: A STRAWHAT-CIRCUIT GUIDE
description: A guide to what's doing on the straw-hat circuit in New York and neighboring states: Long Island Bellport: Gateway Playhouse, (516) 286-1133. ''The Pirates of Penzance.'' Today, tomorrow and Sunday. East Farmingdale: Arena Players Repertory Theater, (516) 293-0674. ''Love's Comedy.'' Today, tomorrow and Sunday. East Hampton: John Drew Theater-Guild Hall, (516) 324-4050. ''Light Up the Sky.'' Today and tomorrow. Garden City: Actors Conservatory Theater at Adelphi University, (516) 741-2313. ''A Woman of Paris.'' Today, tomorrow and Sunday. Wantagh: Jones Beach Theater, (516) 221-1000. ''Damn Yankees.'' Today, tomorrow and Sunday.

title: Ozark Air Lines Says Layoffs Are Being Doubled by Strike
description: Ozark Air Lines says the air traffic controllers' strike will force it to lay off more than 200 employees Sept. 1, double the normal layoff in autumn.

title: Puccini on Fire Island
description: Puccini's comic opera, ''Gianni Schicchi,'' will be sung by the Opera Ensemble of New York this weekend in the Community House at Cherry Grove on Fire Island.

title: Norway Oil Licenses
description: Norway issued eight licenses today for oil exploration in nine sections of the North Sea field. The Norwegian affiliates of Conoco, Elf Aquitaine, Exxon and the Shell group were assigned as operators on four of the sections, and three Norwegian companies, Norsk Hydro, Saga Petroleum and Statoil, on five others. Other foreign companies that will participate in the licenses include Texaco, Total, Mobil, Atlantic Richfield, Phillips Petroleum, Agip, British Petroleum, Deminex, Petroswede and Volvo Petroleum.

title: ONE-TRACK MIND ON U.S. SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Stowaways Feared Drowned
description: Two Colombian stowaways who jumped from the Ecuadorean cargo vessel Isla Puna into the Houston Ship Channel today apparently drowned and four others were missing and feared dead, sheriff's deputies said.

title: British Bank Ends Base Rate
description: A tradition of more than 130 years ended in Britain today with the disappearance of the Bank of England's official interest rate.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's the first elephant born in the New York area in about 9,500 years, although I guess that was a mammoth.'' - William G. Conway of the New York Zoological Society. (B1:3.)

title: Ward Plans to Cut Aides
description: Montgomery Ward, the troubled retailer owned by the Mobil Corporation, said today that it would pay up to 18 months' salary to some of its top executives if they would leave so the company's management could be streamlined.

title: PAN AM IN PACT TO SELL HOTELS
description: Pan American World Airways announced early this morning the sale of its Intercontinental Hotels subsidiary to Grand Metropolitan Ltd., the British conglomerate, for $500 million in cash. The sale is to be completed by Sept. 30.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Including $204,000 income from the sale of retail stores

title: VERIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Nicklaus's Son Steven Fined on Traffic Charge
description: Steven Nicklaus, Jack Nicklaus's 18-year-old son, was fined $35 on one traffic charge yesterday and forfeited a $100 bond on another.

title: Mike-Mayer, a Kicker, Is Dropped by the Colts
description: Steve Mike-Mayer, a veteran placekicker, was released today by the Baltimore Colts.

title: AFTER LONG SEARCH, MAYOR OF STAMFORD SELECTS POLICE CHIEF
description: A nine-month search for a new police chief that had become a political liability to the Mayor ended today when he selected the Acting Chief, Joseph Considine, to head the department.

title: Johnson & Johnson Expects Lower Net
description: Johnson & Johnson said it expects earnings for the third quarter of 1981 to be below last year because of the strength of the dollar and that earnings for the full year may also fall below last year's $400.7 million.

title: IRANIAN WARNS FRANCE TO EXTRADITE BOAT HIJACKERS
description: Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, hinted today that French ships and planes might be hijacked in the Persian Gulf unless France extradited the Iranian exiles who seized an Iranian gunboat.

title: Patino Mining Terms Reached
description: Northgate Exploration Ltd. said it had agreed to buy from Patino of the Netherlands all outstanding shares of Patino Mining Investments Ltd. for $120 million (Canadian), a move that would give it indirect access to a 6 percent interest in Brascan Ltd., the big Canadian minerals and natural resources concern controlled by the Bronfman family.

title: Topics; BOOKS, BLONDES, BOMBS, BROOKLYN; Blithe Spirit
description: ''Anita Loos,'' said a friend of hers this week, ''was the best laugher in the world.

title: ROBINSON NUGENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Results reflect a change in accounting methods which reduced net income by about $359,000 or 14 cents a shr

title: Boiler Contract
description: Combustion Engineering Inc., based in Stamford, Conn., said it had received a contract from South Africa's Electricity Supply Commission to help design and build six 600,000-kilowatt coal-fired boilers for installation in South Africa.

title: KOCH TELEVISION ADS CITE DEFICIENCIES
description: Mayor Koch began a $200,000 television advertising campaign yesterday that included a commercial in which he conceded that ''crime went up'' and ''the streets got dirtier'' during his administration for the sake of a balanced budget.

title: Business People; FROM DART TO OLGA IN PURSUIT OF GOALS
description: When Thomas P. Mullaney announced his resignation in July 1980 as president and chief operating officer of Dart Industries shortly before it merged with Kraft Inc., he said that the amalgamation - which resulted in Dart & Kraft Inc. - ''makes achievement of some of my personal goals difficult.'' Now Mr. Mullaney, who is 48 years old, is setting off toward a new personal goal. Effective Sept. 28, he will become president and chief executive officer of the Olga Company in Van Nuys, Calif.

title: BRIBE CASE TO BE PRESSED IN F.B.I. BRIDGEPORT SCAM
description: The state prosecutor for the Bridgeport area said today that he planned to press charges against a man assigned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to offer a $30,000 bribe to the Bridgeport Police Superintendent.

title: False Alarm Against Gun Control
description: In the eyes of the National Rifle Association, David Moorehead, a gunsmith and disabled Vietnam veteran, is a hero for his service at home as well. Agents of the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms spent a lot of time and money in 1976 prosecuting Mr. Moorehead for owning a machine gun. But the weapon turned out to be an M-14 rifle, which he kept as a souvenir. And at his acquittal, a Federal District Judge apologized for the shoddy treatment he received at the hands of his Government.

title: Advertising; P.J. Agency: Is It Fact Or Fiction?
description: THE Potter Jackson Company, a leading advertising agency with exquisitely decorated midtown offices, is run by super-WASP males who close the executive dining room to women, keep women off the board of directors and don't even like to recognize their existence by identifying the bathroom doors. The personnel director conducts bedroom interviews with would-be female copywriters and assistant art directors.

title: Revised Playoff Plan Detailed
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn formally announced yesterday a revision in major league baseball's plan for the intradivisional playoffs, and he said that the new approach ''still has some warts, but no integrity warts.''

title: 150 European Writers Appeal For an End to the Arms Race
description: About 150 East and West European writers called today for disarmament negotiations and an end to the arms race.

title: Around the World; U.N. Group Asks Review Of Puerto Rico's Status
description: Third world countries today took a step toward labeling Puerto Rico an American colony when a United Nations Committee voted for a General Assembly review next year of United States conduct on the island. The vote was 11 to 2, with 11 abstentions.

title: NEW ADVENTURES IN EDIBLE ICE CREAM HOLDERS
description: CONSIDERING that we are surely in the grip of ice cream madness, it is not surprising that just about everything that can be put into ice cream to flavor it has been put in. The only way to gain a competitive edge now, apparently, is to vary what the ice cream is put into - in other words, edible take-away containers. The biggest ''news'' in cones is, in fact, something very old that goes back to the origin of the ice cream cone as such.

title: 'AMERICAN WEREWOLF,' HORROR PLUS LAUGHS
description: IMAGINE a college boy from Great Neck, L.I., carrying a knapsack and wearing a down parka, wandering very, very incongruously across the English moors. Now imagine two such innocents abroad, to the musical accompaniment of ''Blue Moon.'' As the song suggests, the sun will be going down soon, and the moon will be coming up, and those deserted moors will prove to be not so empty aftr all. ''An American Werewolf in London'' begins on a note that's equally balanced between comedy and horror, and that also has a fine touch of restraint. It gets off to a wonderful start.

title: Yankees Practice on a Day Off
description: Except for Willie Randolph, who was absent and may be fined, the Yankees held a two-hour workout on their day off yesterday after George Steinbrenner had criticized the team and complained: ''I'm not getting my money's worth.''

title: Sports News Briefs; Jockey Injured in Spill Leaves Intensive Care
description: The jockey Charlie Tohill, who was critically injured last Friday in a three-horse accident last week at Playfair Race Course, was transferred from the intensive care unit today, officials at Sacred Heart Medical Center said. Tohill, 43 years old, was still unconscious, but reported breathing on his own for the first time since the accident, in which the base of his skull was fractured.

title: OUR VULNERABLE TRANSPORT SYSTEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSIT AGENCY IS VOTED MONEY FOR MORE POLICE
description: The City Council yesterday shifted $7.9 million from the Police Department to the Transit Authority for 500 new transit police officers, but an authority spokesman said no new officers could be hired until a Federal ruling on a lawsuit challenging an examination given to applicants.

title: Jazz Gets Robinzine
description: he Utah Jazz traded Allan Bristow and Wayne Cooper to the Dallas Mavericks today for Bill Robinzine. Robinzine, 6 foot 7 inches, was a first-round draft choice of the Kansas City Kings in 1975.

title: TRIPOLI STILL SAYS IT DOWNED U.S. JET
description: Libya broadcast today what it said were interviews with the pilots of the two Libyan planes involved in yesterday's air clash, while continuing to insist that one American jet was shot down.

title: INNIS RELEASED FROM JAIL AFTER HE DENIES ASSAULT
description: Roy Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, was released from jail without bail yesterday after pleading not guilty to a charge that he had severely beaten a man whom his aides said they had seen stealing a radio from one of the organization's cars in Harlem last Friday night.

title: PIZZA INN (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
No Headline
description: Deposits at Record Strong loan demand helped increase deposits at the nation's 300 largest commercial banks by $84.5 billion in the year ended June 30, to a record $954.6 billion, The American Banker's annual survey shows. Increased merger activity contributed to the gain in deposits, the newspaper said.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Anna Kisselgoff BUCKLE AT THE BALLET. Selected criti- cism by Richard Buckle. Illustrated. 416 pages. Atheneum. $19.95.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Company has elected Robert F. Smith vice chairman of its subsidiary, the American Express International Banking Corporation.

title: Brown Rules Out 1984 Race
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. says he has assured key Democrats that he will not run for President in 1984, according to The San Francisco Chronicle. The newspaper said today that the Governor made those assurances to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. By making them aware of his plans now, The Chronicle said, Mr. Brown hopes both will support him in a bid for the United States Senate next year.

title: U.S. OIL EXECUTIVES IN LIBYA DISCOUNT RETALIATION THREAT
description: Representatives of American oil companies operating in Libya said yesterday that they had received assurances from top Libyan leaders that Libya would not retaliate against United States oil interests for the downing of two Libyan planes by American Navy fighters. Some company officials criticized the United States Government for the action.

title: Coffee Margin Change
description: The New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange reduced the original margin requirements on coffee ''C'' contracts yesterday by $500 a contract, effective immediately. The exchange said margins for a 37,500-pound contract of coffee would be reduced to $6,500 for 500 contracts or less, $7,500 for 501 to 1,000 contracts and $8,500 for 1,000 or more contracts. The exchange said there would be no margin changes made for straddle transactions and the additional $1,000 margin on the spot contract month of September coffee contracts would remain in force.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS LIBYAN ENCOUNTER AS 'IMPRESSIVE' ACT
description: President Reagan today defended the reported downing of two Libyan jets and vowed to continue the policy of prompt retaliation to make American power ''impressive to the enemies of freedom.''

title: Miss Shriver Gains in Canada
description: Bettina Bunge, angered by two disputed line calls, withdrew in the third set of her second-round match with Pam Shriver today at the $200,000 Canadian Open women's tennis championships.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a change from FIFO to LIFO accounting

title: CANADIAN FLAVOR IN DENVER'S BOOM
description: When Michael J. Brenneman looks out the windows of his office suite on the 23d floor of a downtown Denver skyscraper, the view makes him feel right at home.

title: BRADY STABLE AFTER OPERATION TO HALT LEAK OF SPINAL FLUID
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, was reported coherent and ''chattering away'' today after nearly three hours of surgery in which doctors found and patched a leak that was letting spinal fluid escape from his braincavity, which had been damaged by a bullet.

title: Business People; CHASE NAMES EDUCATOR AS ECONOMIST
description: J. Richard Zecher, a monetarist who formerly taught at the University of Chicago and now is dean of the College of Business Administration at the University of Iowa, has been named chief economist of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Mr. Zecher, 41, who is also expected to be elected a senior vice president when he joins the big New York bank before Nov. 1, succeeds John D. Wilson, 66, who retired last April.

title: Notes on People; Family Tree Balanced
description: When he joined the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center earlier this month as executive director for development and public affairs, Frank Markoe Jr. didn't realize he was following a family tradition.

title: Court-Martial Delay Granted
description: Initial proceedings in the court-martial of Second Lieut. Christopher Cooke have been delayed by a military judge at the request of Lieutenant Cooke's attorney, F. Lee Bailey, an Air Force spokesman said today.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; CATSKILLS CELTIC FLING
description: The International Celtic Festival, a melange of Irish, Scottish and Welsh music, dance, handicrafts and entertainments - the tossing of the caber, for one - is under way this weekend at Hunter Mountain in the Catskills. It will continue through Sunday, when the big attraction will be 18 pipe bands, including the one sponsored by the New York Police Department's Emerald Society. There will also be food - corned beef and cabbage, sausages, haggis, Celtic delicatessen -and a couple of enormous tents under which much of the festivities will take place. Hunter Mountain is on Route 23A, about a half-hour drive from Exit 20 on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. Rain or shine, the gates open at 10 A.M. Admission is $3.50 for adults, and $1 for children. Parking is $1.50. Information: (518) 263-4141. HARLEM ON 57TH ST. STAGE

title: Economic Scene; Risk of a Drop In Inventory
description: IN book value terms, manufacturing and trade inventories rose $3.3 billion in June to $493.5 billion, according to data released by the Bureau of the Census. After adjustment for inflation, this represented an increase of $1.6 billion, the third consecutive month of accumulation this year.

title: Bridge: Weakness of Artifical Bids Useful to Alert Opponents
description: Nearly all the conventions that call for an artificial bid in a suit have a weakness that can occasionally be exploited by alert opponents: A double will represent a safe way to indicate a good lead, and even the absence of a double will carry a negative message.

title: TRANS-WESTERN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MADISON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Unfair Treatment Attributed To Reagan in a Gallup Poll
description: Even though public approval of the President is holding steady, 70 percent of Americans believe that one or another major population group is ''being unfairly treated by the Reagan Administration,'' according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
Donizetti on S.I.
description: A free, fully staged production of Donizetti's ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' will be presented outdoors by the New York Grand Opera on Sunday at 5:30 P.M. at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Snug Harbor Road in the West Brighton section of Staten Island.

title: Delay in Desegregation Is Upheld for Nashville
description: Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court today let stand a court-ordered delay of a desegregation plan for the Nashville, Tenn., public schools.

title: Advertising; Geers Gross to Handle Light 'n Lively Account
description: Geers Gross Advertising, which has been handling the advertising for Breakstone's, has been named as the agency for Light 'n Lively, another Kraft Dairy Group product line. Billings are estimated at approximately $7 million, nearly double those for Breakstone's.

title: A.T.&T., LIKE A LION, INSISTS ON ITS SHARE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is bidding for the 1981 Triple Crown. The world's richest corporation, A.T.&T. hopes that in 1981 the Justice Department will drop its antitrust suit and Congress will pass two bills that would give the company even greater power and scope. HR 1524 would guarantee the Bell System a annual subsidy of more than $3 billion, and the telecommunications deregulation bill that would allow A.T.&T. into every market from which it has been barred.

title: Treasury Will Review Policy on Cuban Books
description: The Treasury Department said today that it had agreed to review the policy on importing of books and publications from Cuba.

title: Broadway; A drama of power, Napoleon vs. Pope, due in December.
description: ''IN 1809 Napoleon kidnapped the Pope.'' Those are the words that leaped out at Edward Sheehan from a history book, caught his imagination and inspired him to write a play. His drama is called ''Kingdoms,'' and it will open on Broadway early in December. Roy Dotrice, seen on Broadway last season in ''A Life,'' will play Pope Pius VII. Armand Assante, who attracted attention as Goldie Hawn's French lover in the film ''Private Benjamin,'' will play Napoleon. The director is Tony Giordano, who staged ''G.R. Point'' and ''Ladyhouse Blues'' in New York. The producer is Elliot Martin.

title: Hammermill Plans Expansion of Mill
description: The Hammermill Paper Company said it would expand its Riverdale pulp mill, near Selma, Ala., at a cost of $127 million.

title: SAVINGS UNITS GET LOAN AID
description: The Federal Reserve Board put into effect today a program of emergency loans from its discount window to help financially squeezed savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks.

title: Index; International
description: At Zaire massacre site, the scars and fear endure A2 Israelis divided in archeological dispute A3 South Korea dismisses command- ing general of Seoul city A3 El Salvador reports key town is retaken A4 Around the World A5 Volunteer unit preses U.S. to join in World Food Day A6 Taiwanese pilot says he defected to back reunification of China A7 Western Europe reacts to U.S. ac- tion with support and concern A10 Libya continues to insist it downed U.S. jet A11 Libyan leader silent on any action against U.S. A11 Government/Politics Koch begins a $200,000 TV cam- paign B3 City Council allots $7.9 million to hire 500 new transit officers B3 D'Amato denies receiving kick- backs in Hempstead project B4 General Around the Nation A12 California asks High Court to ban Georgia's quarantine A12 Brady undergoes fourth operation since shooting A14 Modified noise protection rules issued by OSHA A18 First mate testifies barge''might have'' hit cabin cruiser B2 Health/Science Cancer center accused of irradi- ating unknowing patients A12 Education/Welfare Community colleges starting to offer courses for youngsters B1 Style The Evening Hours A20 Elderly find second careers on canvas A20 She follows the party line A20 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Elephant weekend at the Bronx Zoo C1 Renaissance Festival is back at Tuxedo Park C19 Theater: Busy season on the strawhat circuit C1

title: MILK TOASTS?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Weekend of Finales For Seuffert Band
description: The Seuffert Band closes its 83d season of free outdoor concerts this weekend with two performances in Queens. Led by George F. Seuffert, son of the founder, the band makes a stop tomorrow night at 8 at Francis Lewis Park on Third Avenue (under the Whitestone Bridge) in the Whitestone section.

title: At the Movies; William Hurt and the roles he leans to.
description: smoked as he kept repeating sotto voce that he didn't want his life examined, that his ''personal sharing'' was in his work.

title: DISMISSAL OF A SOUTH KOREAN GENERAL CATCHES AMERICANS OFF GUARD
description: Maj. Gen. Pak Se Jik was the commanding general of Seoul. A tall, powerfully built man in his late 40's, General Pak controlled with his armored forces this city of over eight million, 25 miles south of the demilitarized zone that divides the peninsula from North Korea.

title: Around the World; Soviet Proposal on Arms Rejected at Geneva Talks
description: The West today rejected a Soviet proposal to have the 40-nation disarmament conference here discuss a possible ban on neutron weapons.

title: Official in Oklahoma Resigns In State Inquiry on Kickbacks
description: Carl White, a Pittsburg County Commissioner, resigned yesterday after admitting he had accepted kickbacks.

title: Singapore Parts Deal
description: Singapore signed an agreement today enabling it to export locally made aircraft components to the United States. Under the agreement, Singapore-made aircraft parts certified by the director of civil aviation here will be accepted by the United States Federal Aviation Administration, the Trade and Industry Minister, Tony Tan, said at the signing ceremony.

title: FISHERMEN GET THEIR DAY IN BIGHORN
description: Like the hundreds of other fishermen who converged on the Bighorn River here this week to test their skill against its trophy trout, Richard Rosolek thought the fishing today was worth the wait.

title: Former Aide Guilty of Fraud
description: Manny Goldstein, a former University of New Mexico assistant basketball coach, was convicted today on one count of fraud and one count of filing a false public voucher.

title: OPHULS FILM ON FRENCH TV
