description: A controversial 12-year-old documentary film decpicting French attitudes during the 1940-44 German occupation in an unflattering light will finally be shown on French television, a Government official said today.

title: CAREY, ENDING HEDGING, ASSAILS CASINO GAMING
description: Governor Carey, who has frequently hedged his position on casino gambling, said today that he opposed it. In his strongest statement on the subject to date, Mr. Carey declared that ''after a visit to Atlantic City for the Governors' conference, I don't want that kind of casino gambling in New York State - or any kind.''

title: DOW FALLS TO LOWEST 1981 LEVEL
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.80 points yesterday to 920.57, its lowest closing level this year, as the technology and energy issues led a broad market decline.

title: MISDIRECTED BLAME FOR READING FAILURES
description: To the Editor:

title: IF PEDESTRIANS AND CABS ARE TO COEXIST
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINESE SAY DEFORESTATION CAUSED FLOOD DAMAGE IN SICHUAN
description: As waters from the second major flood in a month receded in Sichuan Province this week, Chinese officials and scientists disclosed that deforestation in China's most populous province was a major cause of flood devastation there.

title: CALIFORNIA AGAIN EXPANDS FRUIT FLY SPRAYING AREA
description: California officials began pesticide spraying today to control Mediterranean fruit flies found in a new San Francisco Bay area.

title: Amax Ending Bid For U.S. Steel Site
description: Amax Inc. said it had decided not to renew its option to buy a United States Steel Corporation site in Duluth on which it had considered building a plant to convert coal to methanol gas and alcohol.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Consumer Saturday; CHEATING IN GASOLINE BY LITER
description: T EN percent of the approximately 2,000 to 2,300 gasoline stations in New York City have converted to metric measure and are now pumping gas in liters. Which is fine for those who enjoy fantasizing that Bruckner Boulevard is really the Rue de la Paix but could be costly to anyone without a pocket calculator or a mathematically inclined mind.

title: SLAPSTICK DRAWS LUCKY 3-POST
description: Slapstick has had a lot of racing luck this season, Bob Lipman says, but it has been almost all bad. Lipman is an owner of Slapstick, the Meadow Skipper colt whom the United States Trotting Association rated the second-best 2-year-old pacer of 1980, so he can readily tick off examples: ''He drew the 8-post in two 8-horse fields, the 6-post in a 6-horse field, the 9-post in a 9-horse field and the 10-post in a 10-horse field.''

title: Religious Exceptions In Army Uniform End
description: The Army's 23-year-old policy of granting religious exceptions to its standards on appearance, which had allowed wearing of beards, ''unshorn hair,'' turbans and bracelets, was ended today.

title: Winning Is Not the Only Thing
description: Embarrassed by a clubhouse lawyer who really is a lawyer, the lords of baseball have patched up some of the damage done to the striketorn 1981 season. Having erased a minor error by revising the method of picking teams for the split-season playoffs, let's hope baseball avoids making a major one by installing this playoff system permanently.

title: OFFICIALS CLEARED OF TAKING GIFTS BY NEWARK JURY
description: A Federal Court jury here tonight acquitted the former regional director of the United States Customs Service in the New York area, who had been accused of soliciting and accepting illegal gifts of liquor from subordinates.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSESS NOMINATING RULES
description: A special commission of Democrats took a close look today at the party's Presidential nominating procedures. Some members seemed to suggest that perhaps there was a bit too much democracy in the process for it to be effective in the cold, practical world of high-stakes politics.

title: MOZART: FIVE VIRTUOSOS OFFER SOME CONFECTIONS
description: Viewed in a purely historical perspective, the Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night was a topsy-turvy affair indeed. Here was a huge auditorium packed to capacity, everyone listening intently to five virtuosos play mid-18th-century chamber music written primarily for the use of amateur musicians in an intimate salon atmosphere.

title: First Lady to Write on Foster Grandparents
description: The White House said yesterday that Nancy Reagan would write a book about a foster grandparents program in which she has had a longtime interest.

title: ANTI-ISRAEL FEELING IS HIGH IN EGYPT BEFORE SADAT-BEGIN TALKS
description: When the wife of a doctor here heard about the meeting between Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Anwar el-Sadat in Alexandria next week, she asked, ''Are they still making fun of us?''

title: AMOCO MINERALS BUYS HARBERT UNIT
description: The Amoco Minerals Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), and the Harbert Corporation announced today that Amoco had agreed to acquire Harbert's mining operations in exchange for approximately 5 million shares of Indiana Standard's common stock.

title: Option Cash Set On Conoco
description: The Options Clearing Corporation, a private company that guarantees the payment of stock option transactions, is ordering that an estimated $50 million in Conoco stock options be settled in cash rather than in stock.

title: Another Round For Smokin' Joe
description: There was never anything subtle about Smokin' Joe Frazier. With that happy gleam in his eye, the swagger of his shoulders, he moved straight forward, always willing to fight. He was more than an honest laborer; he was a man who enjoyed his work.

title: The Careys Get Help On Cost of Their Trip
description: Governor Carey and his wife, Evangeline, will leave tomorrow on a trip to Greece and Ireland, and a statement by the Governor's press office today said that the Greek National Office of Tourism would pay their travel and hotel expenses while in Greece.

title: G.M. MIGHT CLOSE ENGINEERING SCHOOL
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it might close its private training facility, the General Motors Institute, in Flint, Mich., as a part of its program of cost containment.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect closing date for the annual series of free concerts given by the Seuffert Band in Queens parks. The concerts will continue through early October.

title: Pakistan Official Meets With Haig About Aid
description: Foreign Minister Agha Shahi of Pakistan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met today to discuss details of a military sales and economic aid package for Pakistan.

title: WHERE THE SOUND SITUATION IS GETTING SOUNDER
description: Work has already started on the acoustic renovation of the New York State Theater: even though the theater has been used for most of the summer for the ''Fiddler on the Roof'' revival - which closes tomorrow - intensive work is being done on the ceiling of the auditorium. A large crew is preparing for the day, not long in the future, when plaster will be poured to provide an airtight ceiling over the handsome metal mesh that is one of the adornments of the theater.

title: De Gustibus; GUESTS ARE JUDGED BY HOW THEY JUDGE THE FOOD
description: ''Love me, love my food'' is hardly a classic adage, but it is a truism worth embroidering on a cross-stitched sampler to be hung on a kitchen or dining-room wall. Few gestures are taken as personally as the acceptance or rejection of food, most especially if it has been prepared by the giver. By overtly or tacitly registering dislike for food served in a home, one invariably, if unintentionally, expresses at least a certain amount of disapproval of the cook and often of an entire family and its way of life.

title: Communique From OPEC
description: Following is the text of the communique issued today in English by OPEC at the conclusion of its three-day ministerial meeting here:

title: DURABLES ORDERS UP 0.9% IN JULY
description: Factory orders for durable goods rose for a sixth consecutive month in July, the Government reported today, and the figures challenged other signs that the national economy was weakening.

title: GRAND MET'S DEAL FOR QUALITY
description: Last Saturday, Stanley Grinstead, the vice chairman of Grand Metropolitan Ltd., flew to New York to spend two days exploring the possibility of purchasing the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation from Pan American World Airways. Six days later, he arrived back in London, a signed contract in hand.

title: U.S. Leading Soviet in Dual Swim Meet
description: Jeff Float upset the Soviet Olympic star Vladimir Salnikov in the men's 400-meter freestyle today as the United States swimming team took a 79-41 lead over the Soviet Union in the opening round of a three-day dual meet.

title: Around the Nation; Libyan Charged in Death Under Terrorism Inquiry
description: A Libyan national was arraigned today on a charge of second-degree murder in the fatal shooting of a countryman who was resisting going back to Libya.

title: LOSS OF HOPE LEADS VIETNAMESE TO BRAVE THE SEA
description: Tran Thi Yen, her husband and their three young children fled from Vietnam because, she said, ''we wanted to have a future for the children.'' Three other young women from southern Vietnam nodded sympathetically, as if to say that they had escaped for the same reason.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: STAGE: PLUMMER, JONES STAR IN NEW 'OTHELLO'
description: STRATFORD, Conn. The matching of James Earl Jones and Christopher Plummer in ''Othello'' at the American Shakespeare Theater brings to mind other historical pairings. Mr. Jones and Mr. Plummer are major classical actors, and their ''Othello'' is clearly a contest of equals.

title: G.M. Changing Preview Policy
description: Frustration on the part of dealers and customers has caused the General Motors Corporation to consider dramatic changes in its new-car introduction policies for 1982 models.

title: A SPORTS STORE FOR WOMEN
description: Women who run, swim, sail, lift weights, swing a tennis racket, or simply do stretching and bending exercises, usually like to dress the part. You can wear a swimsuit to play tennis or jeans to play golf, but who does? Certainly not the New York women who shopped for their sport shoes at the Athlete's Foot. They kept asking about apparel, said the co-owners, Matt Zale and Ron Greenberg. So the two young men decided to open Sporting Woman.

title: ZAIRE'S EFFORTS AT RECOVERY
description: The Westerners who monitor Zaire's broken economy are, for the first time in years, displaying a glimmer of satisfaction about this vast and turbulent nation's handling of its economic affairs.

title: Around the Nation; Panel Vote May Speed Nuclear Plant Reopening
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission issued an order today that could lead to reopening the undamaged reactor at the Three Mile Island power plant in November even as challenges to the reopening continue before a subsidiary board of the commission.

title: 17 CUBANS LACKING PAPERS RELEASED AFTER YEAR IN JAIL
description: Freedom became a reality today for 17 Cuban refugees who were detained at the Federal prison here for more than a year because they did not have proper entry papers when they came to the United States by sea with more than 124,000 Cuban refugees.

title: Kleindienst Case Jury Hears Initial Remarks
description: The prosecution opened its perjury case today against Richard G. Kleindienst, a former United States Attorney General, by telling the jury the charges were ''rather simple,'' but the defense said that was oversimplifying.

title: RETIRED SALES EXECUTIVE
description: John S. Hewitt, retired president of the family products division of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company and the Anahist Company, died Wednesday at the New London (N.H.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in West Springfield, N.H., and Lyford Cays, Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: Giants to Start Dennis Again
description: If the Giants' three best cornerbacks - Terry Jackson, Mark Haynes and Mike Dennis - were healthy, Coach Ray Perkins says Dennis would be No. 3. Ask Dennis if he is one of the team's two best cornerbacks, and he will say he is one of the top three.

title: 'COMIN' AT YA'
description: When 3-D movies went out of style 25 years ago, they went out of style for a reason. 3-D is fun in small doses, but it wears out its welcome in a hurry. The glasses need to be fiddled with constantly, and they tend to induce double vision. Also, the thrill of imagining that a rifle, hot poker or angry bat is flying right into your face is a thrill that wears thin.

title: Australians Say Beef For U.S. Was Impure
description: Part of a shipment of boneless beef destined for the United States was adulterated with kangaroo meat, the Australian Government said today.

title: All in a Day's Work
description: He was, of course, very pleased with the highly successful American premiere last month of Philip Glass's opera ''Satyagraha,'' which he conducted, but that success means that Christopher Keene will put in a musically schizophrenic day's work on one November day.

title: AT AUDUBON CAMP: ADULTS REDISCOVER THE WILDS
description: At 6:30 A.M., a harmonica serenade roused the 33 sleeping campers of the Audubon Ecology Workshop for the season's last pre-breakfast nature walk.

title: REVENUE DROP CITED
description: Eastern Airlines announced today that it was eliminating 3,000 jobs because revenues were dwindling in the air traffic controllers' strike.

title: Donna Caponi's 69-134 Leads Sally Little by 4
description: Donna Caponi shot a threeunder-par 69 for 139 today and took a four-shot lead after two rounds of the $150,000 World Championship of Women's Golf.

title: NOT-SO-DISPENSABLE PRIVATE FLIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Pays Family of Japanese Killed in Crash Caused by Sub
description: The family of a Japanese seaman killed in an accident caused by an American Polaris submarine four months ago accepted a compensation payment of $374,000 in an out-ofcourt settlement reached here today.

title: SHORTCUT TO A CAREER
description: To the Editor:

title: BOAT OWNER TELLS OF FATAL CRASH OFF L.I.
description: Testifying for the first time about a boating accident that killed his wife, daughter and three friends, the operator of a 36-foot cabin cruiser said yesterday that his vessel had been sucked into the wake of a passing tugboat, got caught on the tugboat's 1,200-foot-long towing cable and then was run over by the barge that followed.

title: IMMIGRATION WORKERS PICKET TO URGE MORE AID AND STAFF
description: Several hundred employees of the Immigration and Naturalization Service held protests across the nation today, distributing leaflets or picketing outside their offices to urge more money and manpower for the agency.

title: OPERA: MOZART-SALIERI
description: Curious are the ways of fashion. Forgotten for 150 years, Antonio Salieri has become the toast of New York this year, what with the interest aroused in him by Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus'' on Broadway. The latest and perhaps grandest testimony to his momentary vogue came Thursday night, with the first in a run of a conceptually clever triple bill by the Chamber Opera Theater of New York.

title: HERMAN O. WEST
description: Herman O. West, who dropped out of college for lack of money and went on to build a multimillion-dollar department store chain, died Thursday in the Minden Medical Center.

title: Bairnco Ends Bid for Ludlow
description: The Bairnco Corporation dropped its $90 million bid for the Ludlow Corporation after Tyco Laboratories Inc., which owns nearly 30 percent of Ludlow, increased its offer for the rest of the company.

title: STORM FALLS APART IN ATLANTIC
description: Tropical Storm Dennis was falling apart in the North Atlantic today while a possible successor storm was forming near the Windward Islands.

title: STUDY FINDS WARMING TREND THAT COULD RAISE SEA LEVELS
description: A team of Federal scientists says it has detected an overall warming trend in the earth's atmosphere extending back to the year 1880. They regard this as evidence of the validity of the ''greenhouse'' effect, in which increasing amounts of carbon dioxide cause steady temperature increases.

title: IN LIEU OF LICENSING APARTMENT MANAGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Reds Hand Mets 3d Straight Defeat, 2-0
description: The Mets have never had much luck against the Cincinnati Reds in Riverfront Stadium. In the 134 previous games here, the Mets had lost 96, usually because they were overpowered or outclassed.

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick, Loudly
description: Jeane Kirkpatrick surprised a lot of people by keeping her footing in that most treacherous of sandpits, the Arab-Israeli quarrel. Her belief in quiet diplomacy paid off at the United Nations when she negotiated a unanimous Security Council resolution on the Israeli assault on Iraq's nuclear reactor. But fresh from that triumph, Mrs. Kirkpatrick, the American representative at the U.N., started sounding off in Latin America in the very manner she used to deplore.

title: NOT-SO-DISPENSABLE PRIVATE FLIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: REGINALD KELL
description: Reginald Kell, a concert clarinetist, died on Aug. 5 at his home in Frankfort, Ky., after a long illness.

title: WHEN BUYING A VIDEO CASSETTE RECORDER
description: Judging by their rising sales, video cassette recorders - VCR's for short - are the hottest item in home entertainment. Despite their hefty price tag of anywhere from $600 to more than twice that amount, they are selling twice as fast as they did last year, and it's easy to see why.

title: 21 Finish Astronaut Training
description: Nineteen Americans and two Europeans became the newest astronauts, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced here today. Eight are to become pilots and 13 are to be mission specialists operating equipment and scientific experiments during flights of the space shuttle.

title: Spilled Coins Snarl Traffic
description: The police and security guards had to scramble to recover thousands of coins that spilled from an armored truck near the Walt Whitman Bridge, tying up evening rush-hour traffic. The Delaware River Port Authority police said that about $2,000 in quarters had rolled out of two bags that fell yesterday from the back of a Purolator Armored Inc. truck.

title: Strawberry Fields Is in for a Restoration
description: Mayor Koch and Gordon J. Davis, the Parks Commissioner, said yesterday that Strawberry Fields, a triangular area of Central Park named in honor of the late John Lennon, would undergo landscape restoration.

title: Presidential Vacations
description: It's vacation time for two former Presidents, Jimmy Carter and Richard M. Nixon.

title: Your Money; Annuity Funds And Taxes
description: WITH money market funds continuing to pay a hefty 17 percent or more, the main complaint from the small savers who have flocked to the funds is that the Federal tax bite can spoil the party.

title: EVIDENCE DELAYS COULD BE SET BACK S.I. MURDER CASE
description: A nine-month delay by the Staten Island District Attorney's office in ordering blood tests has apparently further weakened the prosecution's case in the slaying of a young woman in Wolfe's Pond Park last August.

title: ELECTRONIC PEST CONTROL COMES UNDER SCRUTINY
description: There are many electronic products on the market that promise to do away with mosquitoes, roaches and rodents. Despite the attraction of products that contain no chemicals, the evidence is that many of these devices simply do not work.

title: Patents; Reflectors Help Night Driving
description: WASHINGTON JACOB RABINOW of Bethesda, Md., who has been an inventor for 40 years, got his 217th patent this week, on lane markers that reflect light back from car headlights, showing drivers where to steer at night. The little reflectors will be flush with the road surface and so will not hamper snowplows.

title: NU-WEST IN TALKS ON CITIES SERVICE
description: Nu-West Group Ltd. of Canada, the owner of a 7.2 percent block of stock in the Cities Service Company, disclosed yesterday that it was discussing the ''possible acquisition'' of all or part of its Cities Service stake by the Mesa Petroleum Company or by other companies, including Cities Service itself.

title: PIONEER IN CHINESE RAILROADS
description: Hung-hsun Ling, a writer, educator and engineer who played a major role in the construction of Nationalist China's railroads, has died in Taipei, Taiwan. He was 87 years old.

title: Around the World; Sri Lanka Censors Press In Bid to Curb Rioting
description: Sri Lanka imposed press censorship today in what it said was a move to curb clashes between the majority Sinhalese and minority Tamils.

title: LOS ANGELES EXECUTIVE HELPS A FRENCH FAMILY AFTER THEFT
description: A French family who had been mugged and robbed of their money by two youths continued their tour of the United States today, thanks to a $900 gift from a businessman.

title: Hitachi Metals Adds U.S. Unit
description: Hitachi Metals Ltd. said it had acquired the Concise Casting Corporation, an aluminum castings manufacturer based in Hayward, Calif.

title: ISRAEL IS SAID TO HAVE SOLD IRAN F-4 TIRES
description: Israel secretly sold Iran 250 spare tires for American-built F-4 fighters in October to help Iran in its war with Iraq, Carter Administration officials and diplomatic sources said today.

title: Halldorson Ahead by 2
description: Dan Halldorson, a Canadian pro, shot a 68 today and took a two-stroke lead into the third round of the $350,000 Buick Open.

title: Index; International
description: Mid-air explosion of Taiwan jet reportely kills all 110 aboard 1 Polish press eases attacks on union, but tensions persist 3 ''Boat people'' are still fleeing Vietnam, and for same reasons 3 Qaddafi, condemning U.S., vows to defend Gulf of Sidra 4 Egyptians view Israel with in- creasing skepticism 4 Students in Israel get arms training in immigration program 5 Iranian exiles plan new military actions against Islamic regime 5 Around the World 5 Government/Politics Young Americans for Freedom enjoy an awaited rise to power 7 F.B.I. in agreement to limit political spying of groups in Chicago 7 Commission of Democrats examines nominating procedures 7 Miss Holtzman and Rosen meet in their first debate 26 Nassau official is convicted of perjury and obstructing justice 26 Koch begins campaigning, says Carey is vulnerable 27 Carey says he opposes casino gambling 27 General Black businessman aids French family robbed in Los Angeles 5 Around the Nation 6 Fishermen try out Bighorn River, site of Crow protest 6 California expands spraying while talks open in Japan 6 Atlanta judge opened Williams' trial to camera coverage 8 Indianapolis man kills his children, his wife and her mother 8 City Hall basks in the summer doldrums 25 Deliberations begin in the trial of a former Customs official 26 At an Audubon camp in Connecticut, 33 adults soak up nature 26 Boy, 14, shot to death in dispute involving bicycle 27 Arts/Entertainment Jones and Plummer in ''Othello'' at Stratford, Conn. 9 Progress made on improving N.Y.S. Theater's acoustics 9 Jean Fineberg quartet plays at Citicorp Atrium 9 Chamber Opera triple bill focuses on Salieri 11 ''Souvenirs'' by W.D. Wetherell reviewed 12 Mostly Mozart features a mid- 18th-century chamber concert 12 ''Comin'' At Ya,' a movie in 3-D 12 Christopher Cross concert at Radio City Music Hall 12 Industry/Labor The White House denied a ''possible'' plan to end the air strike 8 Ford Motor Company will announce safety-related recalls 8 Eastern is cutting 3,000 jobs as revenues decline 8 Education/Welfare Education Department revoking 30 ''unnecessary'' rules 8 Nashville School Board loses bid to press ahead on integration 24 Style Consumer Saturday 21 When buying a video cassette recorder 21 De Gustibus: Guests are judged by how they judge the food 21 Electronic pest control comes under scrutiny 21 A sports store for women 21 Sports George Vecsey on the worries of a wildlife group 16 Giants to start Dennis again in place of Haynes 16 Baird and Baker recall first Jets-Giants exhibition game 16 Sanchez stops Gomez in eighth, keeps featherweight title 17 Another round for Smokin' Joe Frazier 17 Royals defeat Yankees, 4-0 17 Mets lose third 3d straight, 2-0 17 College Football Association approves rival television pact 17 14 entered in tonight's Cane Pace at Yonkers 18 Seedings continue to cause problems in women's tennis 19 Tigers beat Rangers for 7th straight victory 19 U.S. leads Soviet in dual swim meet 20 Obituaries Hung-hsun Ling, figured in building of China's railroads 14 Features/Notes Man in the News: Arthur A. Hartman, outgoing envoy in Paris 2 Going Out Guide 10 Saturday News Quiz 12 About New York 27 Notes on People 48 News Analysis Douglas Martin discusses impact of OPEC meeting 1 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: Carter Hawley Net Drops 13%
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores, whose department stores include Neiman-Marcus, John Wanamaker and Bergdorf Goodman, reported today that earnings in the second quarter fell 13 percent despite a 13 percent rise in sales over the same period last year.

title: Around the World; Weinberger Said to Bar Neutron Issue in London
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and his British counterpart, John Nott, discussed North Atlantic Treaty Organization military matters today, but United States officials said there had been no attempt to persuade Britain to arm its missiles with neutron weapons.

title: TIGERS WIN 7TH IN A ROW
description: Richie Hebner, Steve Kemp and Lou Whitaker hit home runs tonight to help the Detroit Tigers beat the Texas Rangers, 7-4, for a seventh straight victory.

title: Chronology of Prices
description: Following is a chronology of the major pricing decisions taken by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its individual members over the past three years that have led to the current wide range of OPEC prices. All prices are for 42-gallon barrels.

title: Merl Young of R.F.C.; Was Named in Scandal
description: E. Merl Young, a former official of the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation who went to prison in a Truman Administration scandal involving a mink coat, died Wednesday in St. Louis, where he was visiting his son. He was 67 years old.

title: Pirates Accuse Cubs Of Tampering Violation
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates said today they had filed a tampering complaint with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn over remarks reportedly made by an official of the Chicago Cubs.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: It can only have been her unwavering faith in the beauty of charity that led Sister Angeline to call her shelter for homeless women Star of the Sea.

title: POP: CHRISTOPHER CROSS
description: Although Christopher Cross, the Austin-based singer-songwriter who walked off with five Grammy Awards this year, calls his music Texan pop, he has almost nothing in common with the honky-tonk tradition of Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings and other so-called outlaws who dominate the Texan scene. The debut album that won Mr. Cross his awards is actually a distillation of several related styles of Los Angeles pop-rock, with its echoes of Steely Dan, Fleetwood Mac, the Eagles, and especially the Doobie Brothers.

title: MOTHER RESISTS USE OF CAMERAS TO COVER ATLANTA MURDER TRIAL
description: News officials testified today that television could provide an accurate account of Wayne B. Williams's trial in the slayings of two young blacks, but other witnesses said it would create a ''circus-like'' atmosphere and cause trauma for local children.

title: WILLIAMS REPORTS MOVE TO OUST HIM FROM SENATE
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today that he had learned that the special counsel for the Senate Select Committee on Ethics had recommended his expulsion from the Senate for his activities during the Abscam undercover investigation.

title: 'Romeo' Ending Run At Festival in Jersey
description: ''Romeo and Juliet'' will complete its performances at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival on Tuesday night.

title: BRIEFS
description: * First City Financial Corp., an investment concern controlled by the Belzberg family of Vancouver, British Columbia, said it had acquired a 5.1 percent interest, or 692,400 shares, of the Masonite Corp. at a price of $22.2 million (United States currency). It said the purchases were for investment only.

title: Inflation Rate Dips in Britain
description: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 10.9 percent in July, the lowest rate since shortly after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government took office, the Department of Employment reported today. The annual rate was 11.3 percent in June.

title: Patents; Silicon Film Improves Solar Cell Performance
description: Staff members at Bell Telephone Laboratories in Holmdel, N.J., have discovered material that absorbs 90 percent of sunlight and converts it to heat, promising great improvement in solar cells.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You know, it's just not right. I made foolish, meaningless mistakes, but I did not violate my trust or the law.'' - Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. (1:4.)

title: NASHVILLE LOSES SECOND PLEA ON SCHOOLS PLAN
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist refused to intervene today in a dispute over a desegregation plan for the Nashville schools and referred the case to the full Supreme Court.

title: News Analysis
description: Gasoline prices in the United States are expected to remain generally stable and possibly dip slightly over the next few months because of the failure yesterday of the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on a uniform pricing policy.

title: Rival Football Unit Approves TV Pact
description: Despite a threat of reprisals from the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the College Football Association voted tentative approval today of a $180 million four-year television contract with NBC Sports.

title: ATTACKERS MAY HAVE WANTED BIKE
description: A 14-year-old boy who liked to build bicycles from spare parts and had lost two of his bicycles to thieves recently was shot and killed near his Brooklyn home early yesterday by one of two or three young thugs, the police said.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 14.

title: Sports of The Times; Wildlife Group Fights U.S. Policy
description: HIS daughters are 6 and 5 years old, not quite ready to handle fishing poles, and Jay D. Hair is afraid there won't be enough fish left when his daughters are old enough to catch them.

title: PAN AM'S HOTEL DEAL DRAWS QUESTIONS
description: Pan American World Airways might have received more than the $500 million for its Intercontinental Hotels Corporation that Grand Metropolitan Ltd., a London-based conglomerate, agreed to pay, if it had invited more bids for the chain, financial analysts said yesterday.

title: Donald Lee Dunphy Weds Debra Lynn Rolquin on L.I.
description: Debra Lynn Rolquin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Rolquin of Naples, Fla., was married at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., last evening to Donald Lee Dunphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barton Dunphy of Baltimore. The Rev. William Rodgers of the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: Suzuki Planning Tie to U.S. Isuzu
description: Isuzu Motors Ltd. officials said that the Suzuki Motor Company, a leading Japanese manufacturer of subcompact cars and motorcycles, was planning to acquire about 20 percent of Isuzu's United States unit.

title: Japan Cited On Dumping
description: The United States is investigating charges that high-powered microwave amplifiers and components from Japan are being ''dumped'' on the United States market, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CANADA IS STILL GOOD TO U.S. INVESTORS Letter: On Trudeau's Energy Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Presley Promise Enforced
description: Elvis Presley's estate must honor a promise the singer made to pay off a $40,000 mortgage on the home of his girlfriend's mother, the Tennessee Court of Appeals has ruled. The ruling yesterday reversed a Shelby County Chancery Court decision against Jo Laverne Alden, mother of Ginger Alden.

title: OPEC NATIONS FAIL TO HEAL THEIR RIFT OVER PRICE OF OIL
description: A three-day meeting of OPEC oil ministers ended today in failure to reach agreement on a new, lower range of prices.But Saudi Arabia, which accounts for one-fifth of the West's oil production, said it would maintain its price of $32 a barrel through 1982.

title: PRESS IN POLAND SOFTENS ITS ATTACKS ON SOLIDARITY
description: Polish news organizations eased their attacks today on the independent union Solidarity, but tensions persisted between the two sides in the wake of a nationwide printers' strike.

title: Jersey Boardwalk Fire Still Being Investigated
description: The state police and local authorities today were investigating the cause of the fire last night that destroyed or damaged more than a block of boardwalk businesses and part of the popular Mariner's Landing amusement pier.

title: WILL CUTS IN TAXES FOSTER MERGERS OR JOBS?
description: 294.4,0,3100,2BROOKLINE, Mass. - A close look at the possible consequences of the most feverish corporate merger wave in American business history, which is now under way, casts serious doubt on the Reagan Administration's assumptions about how the economy works.

title: FORD IS CHANGING POLICY ON RECALLS
description: In an effort to ''avoid any misunderstandings,'' the Ford Motor Company said today that it would make public announcement of safety recalls of vehicles as it notified the owners.

title: AFTER 20 YEARS, YOUNG CONSERVATIVES ENJOY A LONG-AWAITED RISE TO POWER
description: Nothing fuels the happiness of reunion like a common triumph, and in the Presidential suite of the Park Plaza Hotel at midnight Wednesday, after the opening of the Young Americans for Freedom convention here, the beer flowed like wine and the jubilant young voices of the conservative right wing were raised in song.

title: Patents; New Process Removes PCB's From Liquid
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, received a patent this week for its method of dealing with PCB's, the hazardous chemical compounds widely encountered by industry. Patent 4,284,516 was granted Dane K. Parker and Richard J. Steichen of the company's research staff.

title: VOYAGER 2 SEND PHOTOS OF BIG '6' ON SATURN FACE
description: Voyager 2, racing in for its rendezvous with Saturn, is returning sharp photographs of the huge planet's turbulent atmosphere that reveal features never before seen. Among the features are a jet stream with 1,000-mile-an-hour winds, bluish storm clouds and a curious cloud system that curls into a figure 6.

title: IRAN EXILES PLAN NEW MILITARY ACTS
description: The leader of the Iranian exiles who hijacked an Iranian Navy gunboat last week said today that his group was planning new military actions aimed at overthrowing Iran's Islamic Government.

title: Two Arrested in Kidnapping Of Boarding Home Residents
description: Two women believed to have been involved in taking five residents of a Florida boarding home to Michigan were arrested today and charged with kidnapping, a spokesman for the Oakland County prosecutor's office said.

title: THE 'YELLOW-DOG' DAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Salvadorans Say Rebels Killed Four in Siege
description: Residents of this northeastern town said today that guerrillas executed two civilians and two National Guardsmen, forced youngsters to join their ranks and raided homes for food in a weeklong occupation.

title: W.S. Moorhead 3d Weds Erica Schmidt
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd in Beverly Hills, Calif., yesterday Erica Etheridge Schmidt was married to William Singer Moorhead 3d by the Rev. Michael Bunny.

title: SANCHEZ RETAINS HIS TITLE BY STOPPING GOMEZ IN 8TH
description: Wilfredo Gomez, who almost lost the battle of the bulge this morning, was routed in the ''Battle of the Little Giants'' tonight when Salvador Sanchez of Mexico stopped the previously undefeated Puerto Rican at 2:09 of the eighth round of their long-awaited World Boxing Council featherweight title fight.

title: Bridge; LUCK CANNOT BE NEGLECTED BUT ISN'T ALWAYS TO BLAME
description: Broadway-musical buffs will recall the oldest-established permanent floating crap game in New York and Sky Masterson's plea: ''Luck be a lady tonight.'' One might think that had little to do with bridge, but it does. Those who wish to avoid the element of luck should stick to simpler games.

title: U.S. LAUDS OIL SALE BY MEXICO
description: Government planners today hailed the United States agreement to purchase some 110 million barrels of oil from Mexico for its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, saying it would mean a reliable supply at prices that were likely to be below those of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Conoco Expands
description: Conoco Inc. announced that it will begin construction late this summer on a natural gas processing facility near Clinton, Okla., costing more than $10 million. The plant will have initial processing capacity of 50 million cubic feet of gas a day and is expected to produce more than 4,000 barrels of liquids a day, the company said. Completion is scheduled for early next year.

title: NASSAU OFFICIAL FOUND GUILTY OF PERJURY IN A KICKBACK CASE
description: A Federal court jury today convicted Nassau County's Commissioner of General Services of perjury and obstruction of justice involving an investigation into charges of payoffs for contracts at the county's recycling center.

title: Haitians Land in Puerto Rico As Expulsion Hearings Start
description: A fifth planeload of Haitian refugees, including three children, arrived from Miami today as immigration officials began hearings that may send the refugees back to their impoverished homeland.

title: Nissan, Toyota Sales Off
description: Japan's two largest auto makers said today that exports and domestic sales fell in July from a year earlier, because of the sluggish Japanese economy and restraints on shipments to the United States and other countries.

title: INDIANAPOLIS MAN KILLS HIS WIFE, THEIR 4 CHILDREN AND HER MOTHER
description: A man who was worried about raising his four children because his wife had left him killed the children, his wife and her mother and tried to kill a friend of his wife early today, the police said.

title: Money Market Shifts Margins
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange today lowered the margin requirements on its International Monetary Market gold futures and changed the margin requirements on the Swiss franc, West German mark and Mexican peso.

title: Nehemiah Leads U.S.  In Sweep of Hurdles
description: Renaldo Nehemiah, fresh off a worldrecord setting performance, streaked to victory in a United States sweep of the 110-meter hurdles tonight at the Olympic Stadium.

title: CONVICTED SPY FOR RUSSIANS CAUGHT AT COAST RESTAURANT
description: Federal agents tonight arrested Christopher John Boyce, the convicted Soviet spy who has been missing for one and a half years since his escape from a maximum security prison, at a fishing village in Washington State, the United States Marshal's Service said.

title: U.S. ASSERTS TAPE FROM DOGFIGHT HAS LIBYAN SAYING: 'I HAVE FIRED'
description: Pentagon officials gave a detailed report today on Wednesday's dogfight over the Gulf of Sidra to support the United States contention that American pilots shot down two Libyan planes only after being fired at first.

title: 2 KEY CONGRESSMEN RESIST WEINBERGER ON 2 MISSILE PLANS
description: Leaders of two key Congressional military committees told President Reagan today that they opposed Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's proposals for an air-based MX missile and for a more advanced ''common missile'' to be used by both the Air Force and Navy.

title: Helen Simpson Bride Of Neil Kimmselfield
description: The marriage of Helen Simpson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Simpson of Usk, Wales, to Neil David Kimmelfield took place in New York yesterday. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony at the home of Arthur L. Kimmelfield and Marilyn Braveman, father and stepmother of the bridegroom.

title: White Motor Link To Volvo Cleared
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge said he would permit the Swedish auto maker, Volvo, to acquire the truck-making assets of the White Motor Corporation, a move he said was necessary to keep White alive.

title: Toxic Olive Oil Sold in Spain Kills 100th Victim Since May
description: A toxic cooking oil sold illegally by doorto-door salesmen claimed its 100th victim today, authorities said. The olive oil, mixed with rapeseed oil that had been treated for industrial use, killed its first victim in early May. Twenty-five people have been arrested for producing and selling the mixture, and officials said 11 of them would be prosecuted.

title: Gold Stake Increased
description: Consolidated Goldfields Ltd. said today that it had acquired an additional 291,100 shares, or 1.58 percent, in Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd., increasing its share to 48 percent. Consolidated said in a statement that it had no intention of increasing its holding beyond 48 percent. A Consolidated spokesman said the shares had been purchased on the open market, at an indicated value of $222,691.

title: JETS-GIANTS RECALLED
description: The first Jets-Giants game wasn't even staged in New York or New Jersey. But few players on the Jets know that. After all, 1969, when measured in football time, is two generations away.

title: FROM OPERA TO BOLSHOI: ARTHUR A HARTMAN
description: Each week, Le Nouvel Observateur chooses a luminary of the Parisian intellectual or artistic world to set out his or her choices among the cultural events of the succeeding week. One week last

title: FALCONS: STOOPING AND PREYING
description: There are no more typical city birds than domestic pigeons, the somewhat tatty form of the rock dove of Europe. They manage to make a living in the concrete cityscape, enjoying but not depending on occasional handouts of crusts. Any ledge will do for their nests and, if concentrated in one place, their guano would collect in quantities sufficient for New York to rival the famous islands of Peru.

title: Around the Nation; Louisiana in Agreement On College Integration
description: A tentative settlement has been reached in the Justice Department's suit to desegregate Louisiana's colleges further, Gov. David C. Treen said today.

title: STORMY MATCHES IN TORONTO
description: Pam Shriver insulted Tracy Austin after a stormy 6-2, 7-5 loss today, and Hana Mandlikova made an obscene gesture to a base linesman during a 6-3, 7-6 defeat to Chris Evert Lloyd in the quarter finals of the Canadian Open women's tennis championships.

title: Patents; New Material Enhances Dental Restoration
description: An improved restorative dental material has been devised by Harold Argentar, a chemist for the American Dental Association Health Foundation, Washington. Patent 4,284,551, granted him this week, covers ingredients that harden fillings at room temperature, and offer more strength and less toxicity than present materials.

title: The Power of the Prosecutor
description: Political campaigns ought to educate the public as well as select candidates. That's why we look with special interest at the contests for District Attorney in New York City's primary next month.

title: No Headline
description: QADDAFI, CONDEMNING U.S., VOWS TO DEFEND SIDRA GULF

title: Patents; Static Metering Pump For Measuring Liquids
description: A static metering pump was patented this week by Vladimir Horak of Closter, N.J., who specializes in automated systems for liquid measurement.

title: IF PEDESTRIANS AND CABS ARE TO COEXIST
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON ROULETTE FOR SMALL BUSINESS
description: Over the last several years, a new kind of Government game has gained popularity in Washington. I call it ''the small business game.''

title: WEST LINN, Oregon - We should have known what would happen when behaviorists crept into the management-consultant business. Their target on the corporate hit list these days is the office troublemaker, that 10th of the work force making life miserable for the 70 percent who are super serious about jobs. Never mind that Moses, Samuel Adams, Hyman Rickover or Sister Elizabeth Kenny productively disturbed the world's tranquillity. Today they would be called ''Sherman tanks,'' ''complainers,'' ''unresponsives,'' ''indecisives'' or ''know-it-alls'' in this new office game.
description: It's bad enough to have Muzak soothing any beast savaging an office. Or a self-styled fashion expert trying to intimidate us into uniform dress codes the way no office manager could (shades of China's blue-quilted masses!). Now we're being pressed to be quiet fixtures in a tranquil office.

title: KOCH SAYS CAREY WOULD BE VULNERABLE IN PRIMARY
description: With some casual, but pointed, criticism of Governor Carey and a smile at the flutter of hands when he asked street crowds to signal if they intended to vote for him, Mayor Koch campaigned yesterday for a second term.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY UP $80 MILLION
description: In what the financial markets regarded as an unpleasant surprise, a key measure of the nation's money supply rose $800 million in the week ended Aug. 15, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: ISRAEL VISITORS GIVEN A TASTE OF ARMY LIFE
description: The Israeli Army has begun training students from outside Israel to use light weapons as part of a program that is intended to persuade them to remain in the country.

title: CAREY APPOINTS INTRONE AS HIS 2D-HIGHEST AIDE
description: Governor Carey today announced the appointment of James E. Introne, who is currently the Commissioner in charge of programs for the mentally retarded, as Director of State Operations.

title: Brazilians Riot Over Fares
description: Demonstrators rioted in the northeast city of Salvador last night during a protest over a 60 percent increase in local transportation fares, a police spokesman said today. Thirty people were arrested and 27 people were injured.

title: CITY HALL TRUDGES TO A TATTOO OF SUMMER
description: The Birdman, as always, showed up outside City Hall at 3:30 yesterday afternoon. Every weekday afternoon for months, he has stood on a plaque that commemorates the beginning of subway excavation on the spot on March 24, 1900. They call him the Birdman because of his whistle, a little bird made of blue plastic. When he blows it, it sounds as if a canary has gotten loose.

title: Northwest Air
description: In a move to cut unit costs and sharpen competitiveness, Northwest Airlines said it would increase the capacity of its 52 Boeing 727-200 aircraft to 146 passenger seats, from their present 128-seat capacity. The addition of 18 seats to each aircraft will provide a capacity gain equal to the addition of seven new aircraft to the fleet, the airline noted. The airline also said that the increased capacity would make its fleet more competitive in today's deregulated environment and more profitable in the years ahead.

title: WHO WILL TAKE NEW YORK'S 36,000 OUTCASTS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Music on Exhibit At Historical Society
description: The New-York Historical Society will present an exhibition from its music collection, ''Anacreon Revisited,'' from Sept. 29 to Dec. 6. The exhibition will include manuscripts of early American music, some of them shown to the public for the first time.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOUVENIRS. By W.D. Wetherell. 196 pages. Random House. $10.95.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 22, 1981 Energy A worldwide reduction in oil prices at least for the remainder of this year will be encouraged by Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter of oil, to help bring about a general recovery from the recession, the Saudi oil minister, Sheik Amed Zaki Yamani, announced in Geneva, where the oil ministers of the OPEC nations had been meeting. The meeting, according to many participants, was one of the most divisive and difficult ever held by the cartel. The world's major oil exporters failed to reach an agreement on a new strategy for preventing a further decline in oil prices in a glutted market. Saudi Arabia did not support the strategy effort. It is expected to continue to insist on its pricing policy, forcing OPEC members to reduce their prices by deliberately underselling them. (Page 1, Column 6.) International The price of arms Saudi Arabia wants to buy from the United States has risen to $8.5 billion, nearly $4 billion more than the rough estimate Administration officials gave to Congressmen this spring. The increase brings the price of the arms considerably closer to the $12 billion the United States paid to import crude oil from Saudi Arabia last year. (1:6.)

title: Financier Gains Trans-Lux Stake
description: J. Morton Davis, a New York financier, said two companies he controls had acquired a 9 percent interest, or 91,100 shares, of the Trans-Lux Corporation, a diversified media and information concern based in Norwalk, Conn. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Davis said the two companies, D.H. Blair & Company and the Rivkalex Corporation, had together paid an aggregate price of $839,185 for their shares. Mr. Davis is the sole shareholder and president of Blair, a New York investment banking firm. Rivkalex is a private company whose shares are wholly owned by Blair.

title: BILTMORE CLOCK GETS HOME
description: Incurable romantics who long to rendezvous under the Biltmore clock will find it again in a matter of months - but they will have to go to Eighth Avenue.

title: Navy Surgeon Convicted
description: A military court today convicted a Navy surgeon, Lieut. Comdr. Muhammad Ansari, of involuntary manslaughter in the death of an Army sergeant who died after surgery for a varicose vein. Colonel Ansari was given a letter of reprimand and a $2,000 fine for negligence in the death of Sgt. Robert H. Stege, 31 years old, of Crete.

title: DONOVAN COMMENT TIED TO AIR STRIKE
description: Labor Secretary Ray Donovan said yesterday that the Administration was considering a proposal for a ''grace period'' for striking air traffic controllers to appeal their dismissals, but the White House said its position on not rehiring the controllers was unchanged.

title: Jury in 'Town Bully' Shooting Returns a Closed Indictment
description: A grand jury investigating the slaying of a man described as a town troublemaker returned an indictment today, but officials kept it closed.

title: WITH EYE ON COSTS, AGENCY APPROVES CUTBACKS IN CITY'S CONVENTION CENTER
description: The agency that will operate the New York City Convention Center yesterday eliminated portions of the project costing $17 million to insure that the $375 million structure stays within its budget.

title: Royals' Gura Halts Yanks on 4 Hits, 4-0
description: Larry Gura, who has not lost to the Yankees in more than three years, won his seventh straight against New York last night with a 4-0 complete game. Gura needed only 94 pitches to finish off the Yankees, who lost their sixth game in the last seven and their first this year to the Kansas City Royals.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: 1. 1,000. 2. Ten Weeks. 3. The new-found strength of the dollar has meant fewer tourists and less buying power for tourists who do come to the city. 4. The New York Yankees have the highest and the Oakland A's the lowest. 5. Researchers have found that the program has improved the lot of the boys who took part but, for reasons still uncertain, not that of the girls. 6. The gross national product, the combined value of all goods and services in a given period. 7. a. 8. Sir Isaiah, a British philosopher, worked in the British Embassy in Washington in World War II, writing what were considered astute and farsighted dispatches on the American scene for the Foreign Office. Some of them have been published in "Washington Despatches, 1954-1945. 9. The handling of the cases of imprisoned Cuban refugees. 10. "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes." 11. The Belmore Cafeteris, a popular gathering place for taxi drivers, is being demolished to be replaced by a condominium complex. The Biltmore Hotel is being converted into an office building. 12. In 1975, when the crew of the freighter Mayaguez was rescued off Cambodia by United States Marines. 13. Sebastian Coe of Britain set a world record for the mile with a time of 3 minutes 48.53 seconds. Renaldo Nehemiah of the United States bettered his world record in the 110-meter hurdles with a time of 12.93 seconds. 14. The doors to the company's office were locked and guarded by Federal marshals as a court-ordered liquidation of the concern began. 15.

title: Going Out Guide
description: HAMLET ET SES AMIS

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, AUGUST 22, 1981; Energy
description: OPEC failed to agree on narrowing oil price discrepancies among its members. Saudi Arabia said it intended to continue selling its oil at a relatively low $32 a barrel, but would reduce production in September, and possible on a month-by-month basis thereafter. Nigeria said it might cut prices to retain customers. (Page 1.)

title: Venezuela Oil Output
description: Crude oil production in Venezuela for the week ended Wednesday averaged 2.09 million barrels daily, the Ministry of Energy and Mines reported today.

title: Around the World; Gambia and Senegal Plan To Join in Confederation
description: Three weeks after a left-wing revolt in Gambia that was crushed by troops from neighboring Senegal, the two West African nations have announced plans for joining in a confederation.

title: Gulf Plans Cuts In Philadelphia
description: The Gulf Oil Company said it will trim its Philadelphia refinery work force and maintain production at 65 percent of capacity over the next five years.

title: SAUDI AWACS DEAL PASSES $8 BILLION
description: The price of military equipment, including Awacs planes, that Saudi Arabia wants to buy from the United States has risen to $8.5 billion, Administration officials said today.

title: I.R.A. BACKER WINS ELECTION IN ULSTER
description: In a defeat for the Protestant establishment of Northern Ireland, another hard-line supporter of the Irish Republican Army has been elected to the British Parliament.

title: F.B.I. AGREES TO RESTRICT SPYING ON POLITICAL GROUPS IN CHICAGO
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, in settling a lawsuit, has agreed to restrict its surveillance of lawful political activities of orgainzations and individuals, but the new guidelines may be applicable only in Chicago.

title: JAZZ: FINEBERG QUARTET
description: Jean Fineberg says that Sonny Rollins is one of her favorite saxophone players. But that may be an understatement. Miss Fineberg, who, like Mr. Rollins, plays tenor saxophone, led her quartet in a program in the Atrium of the Citicorp Center on Thursday evening that featured a pair of Mr. Rollins's compositions, ''Playin' in the Yard'' and ''Doxy,'' and also showed Miss Fineberg as a saxophonist whose playing was constantly colored by the influence of Mr. Rollins not only when she was playing his compositions but also on such standard pieces as ''The Lady Is a Tramp.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alexander Energy Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 1.5 million common shares.

title: TWO CANDIDATES FOR PROSECUTOR IN FIRST DEBATE
description: Elizabeth Holtzman, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Brookyn District Attorney, said last night that the office she was seeking had become more ''politicized'' during the campaign of her opponent, Norman J. Rosen.

title: U.S. GETS 4TH ENTRY FOR CUP
description: By JOANNE A. FISHMAN

title: KILLINGS IN GUYANA RECALLED IN COURT
description: In the staid formality of a Federal courtroom here, four witnesses have been recreating the horrors of the jungle airstrip in Guyana where Representative Leo J. Ryan and four other persons were slain by members of the Peoples' Temple almost three years ago.

title: Home Clinic; REPLACING GLASS DOESN'T HAVE TO BE A PAIN
description: REPLACING a pane of broken glass in a window or door is one of those nuisance jobs that generally has to be done promptly, especially if rain is expected. Fortunately, it is a fairly simple job that anyone can safely tackle, and it requires no special tools or unusual skills.

title: CHINA GETS A LESSON FROM BEVERLY SILLS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Schuyler Chapin, former general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, is presently Dean of the School of the Arts at Columbia University. By SCHUYLER CHAPIN

title: LIMITLESS BOUNTY
description: BREAD UPON THE WATERS By Irwin Shaw. 438 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. By EVAN HUNTER

title: New Jersey Guide; BIG BLUEGRASS BASH
description: The annual bluegrass festival at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, now in its fifth year, has grown into one of the best in the East, with a lineup including such luminaries of the traditional genre as Bill Monroe - the father of bluegrass, who named the four-part harmonies for his native Kentucky -and Ralph Stanley, and a selection of younger musicians.

title: Foothills Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Iran Reports Attacking Leftist Guerrillas
description: Iran's revolutionary guards attacked a hide-out of the leftist Mujahedeen guerrillas in suburban Teheran early today, the Teheran radio reported.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Snake and Eggs
description: While making an omelet, Ursula Beckley said, she cracked open an egg and out came a snake. That's right -about six inches long, the Seaford, L.I., woman asserted.

title: Dining Out; FRIENDLY INN WITH A FINE VIEW
description: NEW PRESTON HILLTOP views of Lake Waramaug from the wide glass windows of the Boulder Inn vary pleasingly from season to season. But if you like outdoor dining, you'll opt for summer. During this season you can sit outside on an upper or lower terrace, sheltered from direct sunlight by branches of a large spruce tree. By day you can watch the various lake-side activities as you lunch; by night, if you're lucky, you'll enjoy the sight of the moon through the branches.

title: No Headline
description: Many of my women friends cannot understand my own commitment to my career, and there is always the undercurrent that women with a career and family are pursuing that career at the expense and welfare of their families. I believe Betty Friedan's article will cause such women to think beyond the confines of their own backyards and come to the realization that the day just might dawn when circumstances might put them in the role of breadwinner, and they will understand the frustration of being paid wages below those of a man for performing the same job. CAROL RENZA, Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Around the World; 6 Persian Gulf Nations Assail U.S. on Dogfight
description: Six conservative Persian Gulf nations, including Saudi Arabia, accused the United States today of engaging in ''cowboy politics'' in the incident in which two Libyan planes were reportedly shot down over the Gulf of Sidra.

title: KINSEY STUDY FINDS HOMOSEXUALS SHOW EARLY PREDISPOSITION
description: A major new study of homosexual men and women by the Kinsey Institute for Sex Research has found little or no support for most of the traditional theories about the origins of homosexuality.

title: NICARAGUANS FEEL THE PINCH OF FAILED EXPECTATIONS
description: Two years after ousting the Somoza regime, Nicaragua's Sandinist rulers are beginning to feel the backlash of the expectations raised - and now disappointed - by their revolution.

title: Stacey Jackson, Lawyer, Married
description: Stacey R. Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Jackson of Sands Point, L.I., was married there yesterday to Harry Arthur Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Perkins of Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Martin R. Rozenberg, assisted by Cantor Jacob Yaron, performed the ceremony at the Community Synagogue.

title: STATE PLANS CHALLENGE TO RULING ON BEACHES
description: THE state's Public Advocate is planning to challenge a court decision that allows oceanfront property owners to bar the public from their beaches.

title: FRESH AIR FUND CAMPERS GET HAYRIDE TO FARM FAIR
description: A camper had wriggled through the fence reaching for one of the squealing piglets, and now he was stuck at the waist with his bare legs and sneakers kicking in the air. Shelley Stoughton, the 20-year-old farm manager, calmly walked over farm manager, calmly walked over and pulled his feet back to the ground.

title: About Long Island
description: BALDWIN SILVER Lake is a misnomer for the broad pond from which the district of Baldwin just south of Merrick Road, off Grand Avenue and Foxhurst Road, takes its name. Its water is as dark as the most forbidding flux of New York Harbor, though hardly as toxic: Its only pollution is caused by the wild and tamed water birds that frequent it and, in good weather, by beer cans and bottles left by human night visitors who cannot resist the lure of a darkened park.

title: An 'Outraged Citizen' On the Byrne Arena
description: The article by R.J. Codey (Aug. 9) supporting the naming of the Meadowlands arena after our Governor does not reflect my viewpoint, even though, according to that article, I risk being petty and political.

title: Two More Scratched From Arlington Million
description: Two more of the original 14 horses chosen to run in the Arlington Million on Aug. 30 have dropped out, track officials announced.

title: REAGAN WRAPS UP A WEEK MARKED BY BUOYANCY
description: President Reagan returned to the seclusion of his mountain ranch near here today after a busy week in Los Angeles that came to a dramatic end with his series of impromptu statements in which he claimed the key role in the decision that led to the confrontation with Libya.

title: DANCE: VERNON'S 'SEASONS'
description: Charlie Vernon is a lot of laughs. Mr. Vernon, whose engaging young Chicago-based modern dance company is appearing in Dance Theater Workshop's Out-of-Towners series through Sunday at the American Theater Laboratory, is also a choreographer with an appealingly easy, athletic style of movement, and a witty, perceptively humane scenarist.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE NINE NATIONS OF NORTH AMERICA By Joel Garreau. 427 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $14.95.

title: Second-Guessing at the Helm
description: Perhaps because he is not a soldier, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, now a feisty 81, has refused to fade gracefully away.

title: Victoria J. Abels, Tennis Pro, Wed
description: Victoria Jean Abels, daughter of Mrs. Gerald Abels of Locust Valley, L.I., and New York, and the late Mr. Abels, was married at her mother's Abels, was married at her mother's Long Island home yesterday to Long Island home yesterday to Garold Spindler Jr. He is the son of Elizabeth Spindler of Morgantown, W. Va., and the late Mr. Spindler.

title: Trudeau's Party Loses a Couple
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, after more than a dozen years as Prime Minister, has often indicated that he finds political duties boring. Last week, at least some of Canada's voters seemed to be returning his disaffection.

title: EX-TOWN TREASURER IN VERMONT IS JAILED FOR EMBEZZLEMENT
description: Harold Wisell, the former treasurer of Manchester who stunned townspeople when he said he had been taking money from town accounts for years, has been sentenced to two to five years in jail.

title: Two Nuns Die in Car Crash
description: Two Roman Catholic nuns from New York were killed in an automobile-truck collision yesterday in Mercer County, W.Va., the police say. The victims were identified as Sister Jean Makowski, 34 years old, of Buffalo, and Sister Mary Forde, 50, of Lockport, N.Y.

title: FILMING A DOCUMENTARY STARRING THE TEXAS LEGISLATURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Larry L. King is co-author of the Broadway musical ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.'' By LARRY L. KING

title: RADIATION REPORT FAILS TO EASE FEARS
description: MAYWOOD WHEN the word ''radiation'' is used in conversation in this middleclass Bergen County community of 12,000, it evokes a little apprehension in some people, even though the Federal Government says there's no reason for it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''California has become the Ellis Island of the 1980's.'' - Dr. Bertram Brown of the Rand Corporation. (1:3.)

title: 48 INJURED IN ULSTER RIOTING AND BOMB BLASTS
description: At least 48 people were wounded today in bombings and rioting in northern Ireland. The violence came as Michael Devine, the 10th nationalist hunger striker to die at the Maze Prison, was buried in Londonderry.

title: Photography View; POSTWAR FRENCH PRACTITIONERS
description: Photographs in the lyric mode - anecdotal, serendipitous depictions of human behavior that speak to a belief in the essential sweetness of life - are easily appreciated, as Edward Steichen's ''Family of Man'' once demonstrated. Indeed, to dislike them is tantamount to curmudgeonly cynicism. When generated by a unique and personally expressive style, as in the work of Andre Kertesz and Henri Cartier-Bresson, photographs of this persuasion can convey a vision of the world that is singularly moving.

title: OUR SPECTACULAR FAILURES
description: LITERARY DEMOCRACY The Declaration of Cultural Independence in America. By Larzer Ziff. 333 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $20. By PAUL ZWEIG

title: Restrooms on Planes
description: To the Editor:

title: GENE AMDAHL'S NEW COMPUTER VENTURE
description: I T would seem enough to scare off all but the most venturesome of investors. ''These securities are speculative and involve a very high degree of risk,'' the hefty prospectus warns in bold black letters. The investment, it says, is suitable only for those ''who have no need for liquidity'' and who have ''adequate means of providing for their current needs and contingencies, even if the investment results in a total loss.''

title: EZRA POUND SAID BE A PUBLISHER
description: THIS fall, ''New Directions 43'' will appear. In 1936, the first of these annuals included poets named Williams, Pounds, Moore, Stein, Stevens and Cummings - none of them yet the cynosures of English departments. It also published the very new: three early poems by Elizabeth Bishop and a short story by Henry Miller, whose ''Tropic of Cancer'' had appeared only two years earlier in Paris. At the time, the 22-year-old editor-publisher, James Laughlin, loaded his Buick with 600 unpaginated copies, became a traveling salesman and persuaded bookstores to stock a few volumes - out of pity, he believes.

title: RISK OF SUCCESS GIVES PAUSE IN POLAND
description: The Polish independent union movement notched up another first last week. For two days, printers loyal to Solidarity idled newspaper presses across the country, effectively silencing the written word of the Communist Party. The strike would have been dramatic in any nation, but in Eastern Europe it was astonishing and, viewed from the Kremlin, heretical.

title: Food; THOSE EARTHLY DESSERTS
description: A short while ago we were asked if there was such a thing as a mud pie, and we offered a vague definition from a book that spoke of a creation from Mississippi: a chocolate-cookie crust filled with chocolate or coffee-brandy ice cream. To our enormous surprise, the printed question and answer elicited scores of recipes from all over the nation not only for Mississippi mud pies but for mud cakes as well. Both of them, as readers warned us, are sinfully rich.

title: REUSCHEL IS WINNER
description: Rick Reuschel, the portly starter who looked like one of the oldtimers in the New York clubhouse, and George Frazier, the gangly reliever who has not allowed a run since joining the Yankees, teamed up yesterday in a 5-0 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Eagles Short at Two Positions
description: The Philadelphia Eagles opened their training camp five weeks ago with 128 players on their roster, which seemed enough. But the team has come up short on manpower at two positions, guard and fullback, for its third pre-season game. That one will be played tomorrow against the New Orleans Saints and televised nationally by NBC from the Carrier Dome here beginning at 1 P.M.

title: CANE PACE PROVIDES TEST OF THE FITTEST
description: When Bill Popfinger called Long Island Jewish Hospital today - as he does every day - the cheery voice of the telephone operator gave him the good news.

title: Miss Early, Lawyer, Wed
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Amarillo, Tex., yesterday, Patricia McIntire Early, an associate with Webster & Sheffield, lawyers in New York, was married to George Howard White 3d, who will join the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell as an associate next month. The Rev. James Carroll performed the ceremony.

title: Those Who First Didn't Succeed
description: Second chances are not guaranteed in life, but they are in the preparation for it, at least in the New York City school system. Having failed in June to demonstrate sufficient competence in reading, writing or mathmatics to merit a diploma, 716 high school pupils last week tried again.

title: NABOKOV ON DOSTOYEVSKY
description: Copyright c 1981 by the Estate of Vladimir Nabokov PRECEDE FOLLOWS: Vladimir Nabokov, who died in 1977, left a mass of notes he had used for his lectures on literature at Wellesley and Cornell. This treasure trove of the novelist's often unconventional ideas has been the object of an editing project undertaken by the eminent textual scholar Fredson Bowers. The project produced, first, a collection of Nabokov's lectures on English, French and German writers, published last year, and, now, a companion volume on Russian writers, to come out in the fall.

title: Around the Nation; Six Die in Plane Crash In Grand Canyon Park
description: A single-engine plane crashed and exploded last night in Grand Canyon National Park, killing all six persons aboard, officials said today.

title: MISS DANIEL SHARES ONE-SHOT GOLF LEAD
description: Beth Daniel shot a recordtying three-under-par 69 today and shared a one-stroke lead with a faltering Donna Caponi at 213 after three rounds of the $150,000 World Championship of Women's Golf.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF A TEACHER
description: WHEN Debbie (she prefers not to have her surname mentioned) was a student in junior high school, she made an important decision concerning her future. A review of her educational background prompted her to prepare for a career as a teacher.

title: TELL IT TO THE POLES
description: Statisticians who know their business are always suspicious, keeping one eye on the calculator and the other on the lookout for inconsistencies inherent in manipulating layer on layer of mass numbers.

title: DEATH IN THE PHOTOGRAPH
description: CAMERA LUCIDA Reflections on Photography. By Roland Barthes. Translated by Richard Howard. Illustrated. 119 pp. New York: Hill and Wang/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. By ANDY GRUNDBERG

title: BENEFIT ROAD RACE IS FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: THE controversial 10-kilometer run through the Village of Buchanan, sponsored by Consolidated Edison for the benefit of the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, has been rescheduled for 9 A.M. next Sunday. But as the day of the race approaches, the arguments that had caused postponement of the road-running event, originally set for March 15, have flared up again and made the race a forum for political dispute.

title: Miss Reimer Has Nuptials
description: Donna Alice Reimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Squier Reimer of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Alexander Spotswood Hoes, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Spotswood Hoes of Rome and Cooperstown, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Miner, assisted by the Rev. Arthur Hargate, performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: CONFLICT IN REAGAN'S FAVORITE GOALS
description: There are very few general rules of politics that hold true almost all the time. One that never fails is: Hold onto your wallets when they start talking about future deficits and military spending. This year, you may need both hands.

title: Art; SCULPTURE ENHANCED BY A DRAMATIC SETTING
description: MOUNTAINVILLE SOUNDING as if it should have figured in Walt Disney's movie, ''Fantasia,'' Storm King Mountain shares its name with a sculpture preserve that itself is not short on fantastic moments. Just for openers, there's the estate -200 acres, beautifully landscaped by William Rutherford - where most of the sculpture is on view daily from mid-May to the end of October; then there's the ''Normandy chateau'' that presides over it. Structures and setting combine into a spectacle that would move even a Philistine; one which, according to the director of Washington's National Gallery, Carter Brown, has no equal in this country.

title: EQUAL RIGHTS BACKERS MARCH FOR AMENDMENT
description: More than 6,000 supporters of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment turned out here today at the largest of more than 100 rallies held across the nation under the name of ''The Last Walk.''

title: CHEMICAL SPILL ON COAST RESULTS IN 28 INJURIES
description: A toxic cloud from a chemical plant spill today injured 28 persons today and forced the evacuation of 10,000 people from the area. Later the cloud dissipated, and officials reopened the industrial area.

title: Dr. Peter Schiff Weds Alice Clark
description: Alice Marcia Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Harold Clark of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Bernard Schiff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Ira Schiff of Larchmont, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Helmsley Palace by Rabbi Martin J. Zion of Temple Israel.

title: F.V. Schoch, Miss Billings Are Married
description: Beatrice Anne Billings, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Clarke Billings of Old Saybrook, Conn., was married in Branford, Conn., yesterday to Frederick Vaughn Schoch, son of Mrs. Delos Clifton Schoch of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Schoch. The Rev. William Shiflet performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Around the Nation; Fights Break Up a Rally Of Nazis in Detroit
description: Nazis gathering for a rally in a downtown plaza were forced to retreat today by counterdemonstrators hurling stones and bottles.

title: Long Island Journal
description: ALTHOUGH its recent efforts to establish a group home in Cedarhurst for the mentally retarded were rejected when the house selected by the State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities was taken off the market, the agency is once again trying to purchase a home in the Five Towns area, this time in neighboring Woodmere, an unincorporated village.

title: India Forbids Most Tourists To Pay Hotel Bills in Rupees
description: The Government announced today that most foreign tourists would now have to pay their hotel bills in foreign currencies.

title: Design; SOMETHING SPECIAL FOR A CHILD
description: Photographs by Arnold T. Rosenberg Photographs by Arnold T. Rosenberg SOMETHING SPECIAL FOR A CHILD ifts for children tend to be like Fourth of July sparklers - dazzling one moment, fizzled the next. Yet, some childhood treasures strike chords so strong that they endure for a lifetime in their owners' hearts. Giving such a present can be deeply satisfying. Selecting one takes sensitivity and luck.

title: Peter Frew Weds Elizabeth Ashby
description: Elizabeth Roberts Ashby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Linden Garnett Ashby Jr. of Atlantic Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Allan Frew. The Rev. James Cooper performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

title: Whales Die in South Africa
description: Fifty-seven whales were found dead on a stretch of beach between St. Helena Bay and the Great Berg River estuary on the west coast.

title: Chess; THE UNRAVELING OF RESHEVSKY IS NO MEAN TRICK
description: By ROBERT BYRNE

title: TIMELY WRITER WINS HOPEFUL
description: The search for a champion 2-yearold hit another dead end today. Timely Writer, a former claiming horse whose home base is Suffolk Downs in Boston, took advantage of a fast early pace to pass previously undefeated Out of Hock in midstretch and win the $86,650 Hopeful at Saratoga by 4 1/4 lengths.

title: Westchester Guide; BRONX ENSEMBLE CONCERT
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble winds up its seventh year of chamber music concerts with performances at 2 and 4 P.M. today and next Sunday. The 2 P.M. performances are to be held at Van Cortlandt Mansion, Broadway and 246th Street, and repeated at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall, Fordham University, Southern Boulevard entrance to the Rose Hill Campus in the Bronx. All are free.

title: Ann C. Kuhn Is Of Stephen R. Levitan
description: Ann Cecelia Kuhn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Kuhn of West Nyack, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Richard Levitan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Levitan of New City, N.Y. Msgr. Hugh Curran performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: Television Week
description: Looking Back In the pre-videotape/instant-replay television age, programs seen live in the east were kinescoped and rebroadcast for the West Coast audience. Kinescopes were films made by pointing a 16-millimeter camera at the screen of a television set and shooting.

title: PODUNK REVISITED
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out; CHARM--AND FINE FOOD, TOO
description: PERCHED on a bend in the road just north of New Hope stands a charming stone converted barn, circa 1750, called The Inn at Phillips Mill. The cozy little inn, set in a cluster of cottages and outbuildings, is reminiscent of a European auberge.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Pets in Retirement
description: The founding director of the Kent Animal Shelter in Calverton, L.I., had a vision in May 1978: a retirement home for dogs and cats. In describing the plan, the 65-year-old director, Gretchen Scanlan, explained: ''Older people worry about what will happen to their pets after they're gone, and we've decided to help give them peace of mind.''

title: Long Ellis Jr. Weds Catherine Buckley
description: Catherine Mary Buckley and Long Ellis Jr. were married yesterday at the Thompson Memorial Chapel of Williams College. The Rev. Ralph Metts, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Whitman Dennison, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Around the Nation; New Director Reported For Teamsters' Fund
description: George Lehr, a longtime political leader, will become executive director of the $3.5 billion Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, a newspaper reported today.

title: U.S. Reports Far West Now Leads in Incomes
