description: In another sign of the shift of the nation's resources to the Sun Belt, the Far West replaced the Middle Atlantic states in the late 1970's as the region with the highest income per person, the Government reported today.

title: On the Isle; MOVIES IN THE PARK
description: When they were first getting started, Martin Scorsese, director of ''Raging Bull,'' and Terence Malick of ''Days of Heaven'' had their early efforts showcased by Movies in the Park, a free outdoor festival designed to show a varied audience the works of young film makers. Tonight, the festival - the touring program has been up in Central Park and upstate New York in this, its 12th season - comes to Sag Harbor.

title: MORAL MAJORITY'S DEBT TO THE 'MONEY-CHANGERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: RED SMITH Sports of The Times
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. ''JUDGES ready?'' Ken Goldberg asked through a microphone. ''Shuckers ready? Would you folks step back six inches or so to give them room? All right, on your marks, get set, go! Whee! Nice form there. Five fingers to each hand so you can see they're amateurs. Oops! Freddie's on four. How is it, Justin?''

title: Environews; ILLEGAL DUMPING
description: THREE garbage-hauling corporations awaiting trial on state charges of conspiring to manipulate the garbage industry in northern New Jersey also are among those accused last week by the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission of illegally dumping refuse there.

title: Knowles Grades Today's Preppies
description: Southampton, N.Y. -- At the same time that ''The Official Preppy Handbook'' is selling well in the bookstore here, John Knowles, the dean of writers about prep school life, is living in the woods nearby. And if he were graded according to the handbook by a recent visitor, he would not make the honors list.

title: Susan S. Stant Bride Of Stewart Brownlee
description: Susan Shaker Stant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Shaker of Darien, Conn., and Stewart French Brownlee, son of Mr. and Mrs. William French Brownlee of West Hartford, Conn., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Claude L. Peters of the Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Antiques; RARE SURVIVORS OF GLASSMAKING
description: HARTFORD MUCH of what is known - if history can be recounted in the form of material examples - of the kind of glass first manufactured in this state is now on display in a small case at the Connecticut Historical Society, 1 Elizabeth Street.

title: BY MARY CANTWELL
description: DOROTHY L. SAYERS A Biography. By James Brabazon. 308 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $14.95. SHADOW MAN The Life of Dashiell Hammett. By Richard Layman. 285 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovitch/Bruccoli Clark. $14.95.

title: Balsemao Steps Down, Then Up
description: For months, rightists in Portugal's ruling center-right coalition had urged Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao to get tough with President Antonio Ramalho Eanes and other left-leaning military men. Last month, they said he should resign rather than allow the leftists to block further denationalization of the Portuguese economy.

title: LEGAL TANGLE DELAYS TIDAL GATE REPAIR
description: CENTERPORT IN April of 1980, the concrete structural supports for the mill dam tidal gate system here were found to be deteriorating. As administrators from the Town of Huntington and Suffolk County move closer to resolving their differences over the projected refurbishment of the area, local residents, businessmen and town offigials are expressing concern over the delay of the repair.

title: Enough Said To Libya
description: In downing two Libyan jets over international waters the United States has accomplished both a successful military operation and a likely salutary political demonstration. The Reagan Administration has made it a top policy objective to restore the credibility and integrity of American power and influence abroad. This is based on the sound judgement that a world in which American power is respected will be a more peaceful world in the long run. It is within this context that the response to the Libyan air attack should be judged.

title: Wings Obtain Murdoch And Smith From Stars
description: The Detroit Red Wings have obtained Don Murdoch, a right wing, and Greg Smith, a defenseman, from the Minnesota North Stars in exchange for Detroit's 1982 first-round draft choice.

title: FOLK DANCERS GIVE THE PARK A GLOBAL GLINT
description: Constantinos Patukas wandered into Central Park one day and ended up dancing. Mr. Patukas was a bit surprised to see a hundred or so people dancing, but recognized some of the steps, which reminded him of the Greek folk dances his family does on holidays, and he joined in.

title: EXTREMIST SOUTH AFRICAN GROUP AROUSES CONCERN
description: Mainstream Afrikaner politicians, and even some on the far right wing, have begun to express concern about the influence of an extremist group that holds that all political parties must be abolished if South Africa is to be saved as a white, Christian nation from the forces of the Antichrist.

title: Catherine A. de Bary, Sales Manager, Bride of Gregory Knox in New Jersey
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Anthony in Northvale, N.J., yesterday, Catherine Anne de Bary, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Theodore de Bary of Tappan, N.Y., was married to Gregory Knox, son of Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Aylward Knox of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Realty News; Park Avenue
description: The law firm of Morgan Lewis & Bockius has leased about 100,000 square feet of office space on the 43d through the 46th floors at 101 Park Avenue for 20 years.

title: A PERIPATETIC ADMAN PUTS DOWN ROOTS
description: David Ogilvy, for 25 years the high-powered head of Ogilvy & Mather, one of the largest advertising agencies in the world, has made the transition from rat race to semiretirement by striking a judicious balance between country squire and peripatetic elder statesman.

title: Food; FILLING A NEED: THE FOOD BUSINESS
description: AS she lifted a tray of fragrant lemon squares from the large commercial oven, Deborah Davidson, commented, ''this is the most creative thing I've ever done.'' And it's not as if she's been sitting home idly for the last 10 years.

title: TV ISSUE DIVIDING FOOTBALL COLLEGES
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, which has easily withstood challenges to its power from many outside organizations, including Congress, over the last 30 years, is preparing to do battle again. This time the challenge comes from within, and the stakes are higher than ever - hundreds of millions of dollars in television revenues and possibly the survival of the N.C.A.A. as well as the survival of major college athletic conferences.

title: Kelly H. McCormick Wed To Michael John Delaney
description: Kelly Hartt McCormick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Peter McCormick of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael John Delaney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Delaney 3d of Boonton Township, N.J.

title: Lisa Whitman, Reporter, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Thorne Whitman of New York to Scott Ricketson of Needham, Mass., took place yesterday at the Nantucket (Mass.) Unitarian Church.

title: AS 3D NUCLEAR PLANT ATTAINS CAPACITY, JERSEY SEES FEWER POWER RATE RISES
description: New Jersey's third nuclear power plant has now reached full generating capacity, and officials say the result should be a sharp reduction in fuel-related increases in electric bills.

title: THE NEW FEDERALISM MAY BE BAD FOR THE OLD DRUG PROBLEM
description: Uncertainty about the future of Federal drug enforcement, combined with a major change in funding of treatment programs under the Reagan block grant plan, has raised fear among New York State officials that epidemic drug abuse in the region will continue unabated.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Prisoner' of TB
description: For months, Louis Semerano was treated for tuberculosis at a Denver hospital. Finally doctors gave up. Mr. Semerano, they said, had drug-resistdrug-resistant tuberculosis, the latest manifestation of an old disease.

title: 'ACTING GAVE ME THE SELF-CONFIDENCE TO WRITE DIALOGUE'
description: Even accounting for lucky breaks, it is something of a puzzle how Kevin Wade managed to write ''Key Exchange,'' the Off Broadway hit that many critics have called the debut of a promising young American playwright.

title: CELTS PRESSING BID TO RETAIN THEIR CULTURE
description: Here on the rocky north coast of Brittany, where Celts arrived around A.D. 350, about 200 of their descendants gathered recently for a week to honor their heritage.

title: Critics' Choices
description: LATIN JAZZ The ''1981 Latin American Jazz Festival'' that begins on Thursday night at the Beacon Theater looks too good to be true. Thursday's concert, ''Salute to the Masters,'' begins at 8 P.M. and is to present the celebrated Latin percussionists Mongo Santamaria and Ray Barretto, the great jazz drummer Max Roach, and the Machito orchestra featuring another outstanding percussionist, Patato Valdez. On Friday, again at 8 P.M. at the Beacon Theater, ''Salute to New Music'' presents an even more star-studded array: Ornette Coleman and his Prime Time band in their first appearance since four sold-out shows at the Public Theater in July, plus the saxophonist Jackie McLean (soloing with the city's most adventurous Latin-jazz ensemble, Libre), the saxophonist Paquito D'Rivera and his spectacular, half-Cuban New York/Havana group, and the saxophonist Chico Freeman's ensemble.

title: THE MAKING OF A CABLE TELECOMMUNICATIONS MONOPOLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Realty News; Madison Avenue
description: Andrew Geller Industries, a shoe company, has leased about 11,000 square feet of office space on the 14th floor at 660 Madison avenue for 10 years at an aggregate rent of more than $3.1 million.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Reagan's Taxing Problem

title: AVON'S CALLING A FAMILIAR TUNE
description: A ON'S calling, and those Avon chimes keep sounding the same old tune. A little over two years ago, when Avon made headlines by buying Tiffany & Company for $104 million in stock, David W. Mitchell, chairman and chief executive of Avon Products Inc., called the Fifth Avenue retailer ''a unique and rare merchandising situation.'' Two management upsets later, Tiffany remains pretty much as it was - a potential sparkler, as yet unset in the Avon empire.

title: SETON HALL, MARKING 125 YEARS, CONFRONTS CONTROVERSY
description: SOUTH ORANGE TWO months after being appointed president of Seton Hall University, Dr. Edward R. D'Alessio is busy planning ''an active involvement for every segment of this university - the eighth-largest Catholic university in the country - in the celebration of its 125th year, which begins in September.''

title: IRISH PLAN CULTURAL CENTER
description: SPRING is usually the season most closely associated with the Irish, with St. Patrick's Day parades part of the greening of America or at least the wearing of the green.

title: BROADER SCHOOL TALKS SOUGHT
description: WITH the new school year and another round of school board-teacher negotiations about to begin, teachers unions are pinning their hopes on two bills introduced in the Legislature that would expand the scope of such negotiations.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: LYNDON: An Oral Biography, by Merle Miller. (Ballantine, $9.95.) An account of the career of President Lyndon B. Johnson, pieced together from hundreds of tape-recorded interviews with persons who knew him well and connected by lengthy passages of background material. Our reviewer Anthony Lewis called it ''a sensitive, fascinating and often uproariously funny biography of a legislative genius, a manipulator of men, a performer'' that is best when it pictures L.B.J. at work in behalf of liberal causes, but is lacking, perhaps inevitably, when it comes to explaining what lay behind the tragedy of Vietnam.

title: STUNG, BITTEN, BEMUSED; Bears in Love
description: The eastern black bear, say New Jersey wildlife officials, is a gentle, lovable creature, shy of humans, who would not pose a threat to anyone if reintroduced into the pine barrens from which he was driven by development decades ago. But farmers and some other local residents are dubious, and a recent report in The Washington Post lends some support to their fears.

title: MINERS STILL UNCERTAIN ON SELF-RESCUE DEVICE
description: The courts have finally spoken, but 10 years of uncertainty about an aqualung-like device to save the lives of coal miners trapped underground by fires or explosions still cloud the future of the ''self-rescuer.''

title: Uniondale Fire Under Inquiry
description: Some 200 members of six fire companies fought a suspicious blaze at a lumberyard here for more than two and a half hours before extinguishing it early today, the police said. There were no injuries in the blaze, which destroyed most of Woody's Lumberyard, at 1000 Front Street, as well as two adjacent buildings and six mail trucks in a Postal Service parking lot next door, according to the Nassau County police.

title: Wood Fuel Gains in Vermont
description: Wood has edged out oil as Vermonters' first choice for winter warmth, according to a state survey. Of the sample group, 41 percent said they heated their homes primarily with wood.

title: The Rush is On To Fill Jobs of Air Controllers
description: As the air controllers strike lurched on last week, the Government showed no sign of deviating from its flight plan. Maintaining that the 12,000 or so controllers who've refused to work since Aug. 3 will never again be on its payroll, the Federal Aviation Administration formally began accepting applications from prospective replacements. It got more than 59,000.

title: Third Avenue
description: To the Editor:

title: Alfa Presents a Classy Beast
description: UP ahead, five tractor-trailers have tangled and the accident is sprawling across most of the Long Island Expressway. Ahead, too, are maybe three or four thousand cars, and the helicopter traffic report says the jam is six miles long. But through it all, even in 85-degree temperatures and with the air-conditioner going full blast, the new Alfa engine keeps its cool.

title: About Westchester
description: TARRYTOWN

title: End of the Cruise
description: One phase of the Iranian counterrevolution ran out of gas last week, literally. Iranian monarchists who hijacked an Iran-bound gunboat off the coast of Spain Aug. 13 surrendered off Marseille when the French authorities refused to give them food or fuel.

title: Politics; REDISTRICTING: WHO'LL BE LEFT OUT IN THE COLD?
description: AFTER the voters pick a Governor this year, they will be asked to elect a United States Senator and 14 members of Congress in 1982. Since there are now 15 members of the state's Congressional delegation, somebody has to go.

title: DISASTER AT HYATT HAUNTS SURVIVORS
description: It has been more than a month since this city's most elegant hotel became a 40-story memorial to 112 people.

title: Lauren J. MacMannis Wed to W.I. Huyett Jr.
description: At the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday, Lauren Jean MacMannis was married to William I. Huyett Jr. The Rev. Michael A. Drake performed the ceremony.

title: BOXING PROGRAMS HELD IN PRISONS ARE HALTED
description: SHORTLY after the eight-year ban against professional boxing was lifted in 1973, Peachy Davis, a middleweight fighter, and Bobby Guthridge, a welterweight, appeared in a boxing match at the Waterbury Armory. Few of the spectators were aware that Mr. Davis and Mr. Guthridge were convicts, participating in a new furlough program that permitted inmates of the state prisons in Enfield and Somers to box on the ''outside.''

title: FILM: PLUCKY PIONEERS IN 'HEARTLAND'
description: ''Heartland'' was shown as part of the 1979 Festival of American Independent Feature Films at the Paramount Theater. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Sept. 22, 1979. The film opens today at the Paris Theater, 58th Street west of Fifth Avenue.

title: August 23, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE AGE OF THE CATHEDRALS: Art and Society, 980-1420 By Georges Duby. ............................................ 3 CAMERA LUCIDA: Reflections on Photography. By Roland Barthes. 11 DOROTHY L. SAYERS.

title: WHY EUROPEANS WANT NO NEUTRON WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC-COLLEGE STUDENTS TO BEAR MOST OF CUTS IN GUARANTEED LOAN PROGRAM
description: Students in public colleges and universities whose families earn $30,000 to $45,000 a year will bear the brunt of the cuts in the Federal Guaranteed Loan Program that President Reagan signed into law this month, according to student-aid experts.

title: LAND TIDES MAY AFFECT EARTH'S CORE AND ROTATION
description: Twice a day the twin towers of New York's World Trade Center rise and fall about 14 inches. They also tilt about two inches, first to the west and then to the east.

title: Party Lines In New Haven
description: In response to ''A Halfhearted Two-Party System'' (July 12), Jonathan J. Einhorn's reflections about being New Haven's sole Republican alderman on a Democrat-controlled board are all too true. I have lived in New Haven for the greater part of my life, as have my parents and their parents. Consequently, we have experienced many of Mr. Einhorn's frustrations.

title: Jane M. Hewson Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Beresford Hewson of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Mabbett Hewson, to Henry Gregor Mueller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Muth Mueller of New York and Nantucket.tucket.

title: Relatives of Slain Girl Suing, Saying Store Faked Security
description: The husband and parents of a girl killed in a holdup at a convenience store filed a $16@.5 million damages suit, saying that the Stop-N-Go store failed to provide adequate protection.

title: FOOD POISONING CASES TRACED TO ROAST BEEF
description: Three outbreaks of food poisoning that struck more than 100 people last month were traced to roast beef from a Philadelphia meat processing plant, the National Centers for Disease Control said.

title: Alexander Greendale, Headed Jewish Council
description: Alexander Greendale, a playwright and the executive director of the West Side Jewish Community Council, died of cancer Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: PARKING PLAN STIRS ATLANTIC CITY
description: OF-TOWNERS, especially casino-hotel workers and, to some extent, tourists, would be barred from parking on nonmetered streets during early-morning and late-night hours if a recently adopted city ordinance wins the approval, which is expected, of the State Department of Transportation.

title: Lisa Lyons Bride Of Robert Durkin
description: Lisa L. Lyons, daughter of Mrs. Victor K. Kiam 2d of New York and Stamford, Conn., and Richard E. Lyons of Los Angeles, was married in Stamford yesterday to Robert Leonard He is the son of Mrs. James E. Durkin of San Francisco and the late Mr. Durkin. The Rev. Roger O. Douglas, uncle of the bride and an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Kiam home.

title: ENDANGERED SPECIES IS NOW INCARCERATED AT THE END OF THE BOOK
description: 6,2,266.8,0,3100,2AMHERST, Mass. - The footnote is an endangered species. I mean the real footnote, the one found at the foot of the page instead of at the end of the chapter or the back of the book. The threat to the footnote comes from publishers and book sellers who find them unsightly, costly, forbidding.

title: TOURISM STILL BOUNCY
description: Rising energy prices and economic stagnation or recession are not generally associated with a healthy tourist trade. In spite of those conditions in many industrialized countries last year, international tourism receipts nevertheless rose by 15 percent in 1980, to $72 billion, according to a study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: STING VIEWED AS A THREAT TO COSMOS' HOPES FOR ANOTHER TITLE
description: Willy Roy of the Chicago Sting may very well be the only coach in the North American Soccer League who is not picking Chicago to reach the Soccer Bowl, the league's championship game in Toronto on Sept. 26.

title: URBAN TROOP GIVES SCOUTS A NEW 'HIGH'
description: ORANGE FOR most of the members of Eagle Flight Post 290, ''getting high'' used to mean drugs - if not for them, then for many of their friends and neighbors in this Essex County city. But the word has a different meaning for them now. The post, an Explorer Scout troop, offers them a chance to fly, literally, and a good shot at someday finding a career in aviation.

title: A LIBERAL LOOK AT INCOME DISTRIBUTION
description: T HE distribution of income lies at the heart of the difference between liberals and conservatives, Democrats and Republicans. Liberals believe that there is a social obligation to narrow market income differentials. In theory, conservatives are agnostics with respect to the distribution of income. Whatever the market produces is all right with them so long as the Government keeps out of the way. In practice, conservatives adopt government policies that make the market distribution of income more unequal.

title: LEWIS ELIMINATES SMITH
description: Unseeded Chris Lewis outlasted 16th-seeded Stan Smith today for a 6-7, 7-6, 6-3 semifinal victory in the $200,000 Association of Tennis Professionals tournament.

title: Around the World; Lisbon Leader Confers On Next Government
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes began consultations today on whether to reappoint the Social Democratic Party leader, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, as Prime Minister. Mr. Pinto Balsemao, who resigned Aug. 10 under heavy criticism from the right wing of his Democratic Alliance, said Thursday that he was ready to form a new government.

title: Besides Infesting Produce, Medfly Packs a Sting
description: The Mediterranean fruit fly has been a tough pest to crack. Since its infestation first threatened California some 14 months ago, the state has fought back with tree stripping, ground spraying and importation of sterile flies.

title: Art; GATCH: A SYMBIOSIS OF BEAUTY AND EXPERIMENTATION
description: NEWARK LEE GATCH, whose paintings and collages are on view at the Newark Museum, is one of those artists whose talents far exceed their reputations. Although by no means unknown to the art public, Mr. Gatch's esthetic accomplishment has decisively not received the claim it deserves.

title: SLIM DESIGNS MAKE SLIM SPACES WORK
description: Tall, thin towers, often with only one apartment on a floor, are going up in many residential neighborhoods in Manhattan. Some of the sliver-like buildings are being squeezed into slots between high-rise apartment buildings on major cross streets; others loom over their low-rise neighbors on side streets.

title: Invidious Comparison
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques; A RECIPE FOR COOKBOOK COLLECTORS
description: ''Having got the flowers of a peck of cowslips'' begins a recipe for cowslip pudding in Hannah Glasse's 1747 edition of ''The Art of Cookery, Made Plain and Easy, Which far exceeds any Thing of the Kind ever yet Published'' - just the sort of quaintness that appeals to collectors of old cookbooks. Not only is the irregular grammar and flamboyant title (old cookbook titles tend to wax wordy) captivating, but so is the notion of whiling away a morning gathering a quarterbushel of cowslips.

title: No Headline
description: I applaud Betty Friedan's article, but I feel that she left out a half step between the first and second stages of the women's movement. Mrs. Friedan is more sanguine than I am about the readiness of men, and growth in men, to join with women for the second stage of the work of feminism. While I am in agreement with Mrs. Friedan's understanding of the promise of feminism to be ''a new human wholeness,'' and am myself working at this, I am concerned that men have not acted on their need to be together, to share struggles, to rejoice in living the life of a feminist and to support one another when it gets more than tough. R. ALAN JOHNSON Secretary of Evangelism United Church Board for Homeland Ministries New York City

title: 120 Florida Alligators to Get 'First Class' Flight To Israel
description: More than 100 Florida alligators will be flown to Israel this week to populate a swamp where crocodiles used to roam wild, officials say. They gators will be turned loose in a 10-acre tourist park near an ancient Roman spa in Israel, the hot springs of Gader.

title: THE SOUR CREAM SENSIBILITY
description: SOCIAL STUDIES By Fran Lebowitz. 147 pages. New York: Random House. $9.95. By GLENN COLLINS

title: Lee Montross Will Be Bride Of a Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Montross 3d of Bedford Hills, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lee Chamberlin Montross, to David Perrin Wheeler, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Wheeler Jr. of New Vernon, N.J.

title: Fashion; ELEGANCE FOR KIDS
description: ELEGANCE FOR KIDS This fall, children happily will discover that they need not pillage their folks' closets to find clothes that make them feel all dressed up. Here and on the following pages are new fashions for children which prove the elegant look is au courant for children, too. Above left: Cotton corduroy dress by Nicolle for Dorissa of Miami. Maggie Vail. $52. At Macy's. Above: Cotton velveteen dress with

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 5 2 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 2 1 16 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 3 3 4 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 4 2 20 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 5 4 9 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood. 6 6 11 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 7 7 5 TRADE WIND, by M.M. Kaye. (St. Martin's, $15.) Love and death in exotic 19th-century Zanzibar.

title: Dogged by Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: METS RALLY TO BEAT REDS, 7-4, ON GRAND SLAM BY KINGMAN
description: Dave Kingman hit a grand slam tonight to propel the Mets to a 7-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds at Riverfront Stadium.

title: NAUGATUCK VALLEY PROGRESS
description: WATERBURY DEVASTED by the collapse of the brass industry, the Naugatuck Valley has long been one of Connecticut's most economically blighted areas. The strike this month at Century Brass Products Inc. in Waterbury, which threatened 2,000 jobs at the city's last remaining large mill, showed anew how vulnerable the area is to further erosion of its industial base.

title: No Headline
description: FIRST FLIGHT: Dushenka, the first Siberian crane bred in captivity, takes a running start before flying for the first time. Susan Rogers, left, and Lisa

title: Lost - and Found
description: To the Editor:

title: Realty News; Broadway
description: Charles of the Ritz Group Ltd., a subsidiary of the Squibb Corporation, has leased the 13th floor with 55,221 square feet at 770 Broadway for its executive offices.

title: EDWARD H. STROM
description: Edward H. Strom, who had been a newspaper artist in New York City, died Wednesday at Bozeman Deaconess Hospital in Bozeman, Mont.

title: Street Justice?
description: As chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, Roy Innis has frequently reviled police for what he called intentionally lax law enforcement in Harlem.

title: 2d Victim Of Shooting Dies
description: A second staff member shot when a gunman opened fire at the Stony Brook Counseling Center last week died early today. The latest victim was Deane Fritz Coombs, 32 years old, of Somerville, a psychologist who had been shot in the head.

title: Karen Andresen, David J. Williams Wed in Vermont
description: Karen Elizabeth Andresen, daughter of Dr. Donald C. Andresen of NorNorwich, Vt., and Margaret W. Redden of South Strafford, Vt., was married yesterday to David Joseph Williams, of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Williams of Hamden, Conn. The Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Herman Redden, was performed by Canon Preston T. Kelsey of San Mateo, Calif.

title: Bomb Conditions
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt last week reached back to his difficulties with the Carter Administration over the neutron bomb and produced three conditions that he said still obtained for permitting the weapon on West German soil. The conditions were that other European countries must also accept the weapons, that their deployment be made a North Atlantic Treaty Organization decision and that the weapons be withheld unless arms control talks with the Soviet Union ''remain without results.''

title: Jets' Kensil Works At Cultivating Fans
description: When the Jets and Giants renewed their rivalry last night at Giants Stadium, Jim Kensil looked for a cozy place to root for his team without losing too much dignity.

title: Around the Nation; Suit Ends in Case of Boy Who Killed His Teacher
description: An out-of-court settlement has been reached in a suit filed against George Christian, the White House press secretary under President Johnson, by the widow of a teacher who was shot by Mr. Christian's son.

title: Connecticut Guide; PREMIERE IN WESTPORT
description: As the next-to-final attraction of the season, the Westport Country Playhouse will present Lucie Arnaz and her husband, Laurence Luckinbill, in the American premiere of ''Educating Rita,'' by Willy Russell.

title: Politics; REPUBLICANS REFINE ELECTION STRATEGIES
description: MERIDEN IN the Town Crier room of the Yale Motor Inn, before an audience of about 300 men and women from around the state, Michael McGarry, a Hartford businessman, was giving an unusual lesson in marketing.

title: NEW PLAN, OLD FLAWS
description: 4,2,358.8,0,3100,2For those who remember unpleasant things, President Reagan's call for a two-year experimental guest worker program, which would bring in 50,000 Mexicans a year, triggered memories of the infamous bracero program.

title: Priscilla Ripley, R.H. Lichty Wed
description: Priscilla B. Ripley, daughter of Henry B.H. Ripley Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and Priscilla Bradford Ripley of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Roger H. Lichty, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Alden Lichty of Denver. The Rev. Dr. Clarence Ammons performed the ceremony at the Wellshire Presbyterian Church in Denver.

title: IN VIRGINIA, 'CONSERVATIVE' DOESN'T MEAN WHAT IT USED TO
description: Like a Kabuki dance, the ornately choreographed gubernatorial campaign here this year contains more than the strange gestures that meet the eye. A win here in November would be important to the Democrats, locally and nationally, who seem so eager to turn the tide that they appear willing to do almost anything - even look and sound like Republicans.

title: Recycling Held to Be Profitable Operation
description: In response to the article entitled ''Recycling: Its Future Is Cloudy'' (Aug. 2), I take exception to the statement that ''there is some disagreement about whether this is an actual saving ...''

title: The Lively Arts; STARS GATHER FOR 'LIGHT UP THE SKY'
description: EAST HAMPTON THEATER people carry on in every sense. They have fits and they survive. That's what the late Moss Hart's comedy, ''Light Up the Sky,'' is about. The star of a Broadway-bound play threatens to walk out, the producer wants to sell out, and the playwright, in despair, disappears. Everything portends disaster.

title: THE HARDY BOYS AND THE MICROKIDS MAKE A COMPUTER
description: THE SOUL OF A NEW MACHINE By Tracy Kidder. 293 pp. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown. $13.95.

title: VALENZUELA TOPS CARDS FOR 10TH VICTORY, 3-2
description: Fernando Valenzuela pitched a fourhitter over eight and two-thirds innings tonight and became the first National League 10-game winner this season as the Los Angles Dodgers beat the Cardinals, 3-2.

title: KLEINDIENST JURY FACES MAZE OF PAYOFF ISSUES
description: It took the state six months to get a perjury indictment against Richard G. Kleindienst, a former United States Attorney General, but prosecutors believe they can win a conviction.

title: ECONOMISTS AND THEIR (OWN) MONEY
description: ''A FORMER treasurer of Harvard once told me that he had two golden rules for managing the Harvard portfolio,'' Paul A. Samuelson, Institute Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said. ''One: Never consult the Economics Department. Two: Never consult the business school.''

title: IN EUROPE, IRONIC REACTION TO NEUTRON MOVE
description: While European leaders expressed dismay and anger about President Reagan's decision to produce neutron weapons, some other Europeans were neither surprised nor entirely displeased by the move.

title: Jovi Tenev Weds Nancy Hingston
description: Nancy Burgess Hingston, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Hingston of Doylestown, Pa., was married yesterday to Jovi Tenev, son of George and Helena Tenev of New York, at Holy Innocents' Episcopal Church in Beach Haven, N.J. Canon Gilbert D. Martin performed the ceremony.

title: Edith Ainsworth Wed To William F. Quinn
description: Edith De Nyse Ainsworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram J.L. Ainsworth of Fairfield, Conn., and William Francis Quinn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Quinn, also of Fairfield, were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph A. Racioppi performed the ceremony at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Fairfield.

title: Gardening; THE COOL AND VERSATILE VINE
description: THERE are many similarities between the autostrada in Italy and our own interstate highways. The traffic lanes are separated by a median strip that, more often than not, is planted with oleanders, as are the freeways of southern California. One has to pay at toll booths that would not be out of place on many turnpikes. There are rest stops and service areas at regular intervals, and it is here, however, that an interesting difference may be seen.

title: TOKYO CAUTIOUS ON SEOUL BID FOR $6 BILLION AID
description: South Korea has asked Japan for $6 billion in economic aid, but officials here say that, while they plan to increase their assistance to the Seoul Government, it will be nothing like the amount requested.

title: DONNA CAPONI: STARTING OVER
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio

title: U.S. Landlords
description: To the Editor:$

title: Christine Y. Jones, TV Actress, Wed
description: Christine Young Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Terry Jones of Elmira, N.Y., was married in Williamsburg, Va., yesterday to Thomas Heber Libscomb 3rd, son of Maj. Gen. Thomas H. Lipscomb 2d, U.S.A., reThomas H. Lipscomb 2d, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Lipscomb of Haddonfield, N.J. The Rev. John Gregory Tweed of the Marble Collegiate Church in New York performed the Dutch Reformed ceremony at the Wren Chapel of the College of William and Mary.

title: AN IRISH IDYLL BY CARAVAN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ERIC W. JOHNSON is a writer who lives in Philadelphia. By ERIC W. JOHNSON

title: THE ZANY NEW WORLD OF MICKEY ROONEY
ITALY'S '100 CITIES': A TIME MACHINE TO A GENTLER ERA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN, a retired Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: TIP BRINGS ARREST OF SPY FOR SOVIET
description: Christopher John Boyce was arrested near here last night after a 19-month international manhunt, and investigators said today that the escaped spy for the Soviet Union might have committed up to 16 bank robberies in recent months.

title: New York Political Notes
description: A State Supreme Court referee is likely to rule tomorrow on whether Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro will be the only challenger to face Mayor Koch on the Democratic primary ballot.

title: Risky Effort to Save Par
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany played an amazing shot from 20 feet up in a tree today in the third round of the $180,000 International Open.

title: Gminski Shows Improvement
description: Doctors have told officials of the New Jersey Nets that Mike Gminski, their No.1 center, who is hospitalized with a viral blood infection, is responding to antibiotics so well that he is scheduled to be released next Saturday from the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry in Newark.

title: No Headline
description: As a woman seeking ordination at midlife in the church, I second Betty Friedan's motion: We must work together as human beings. I want to be ordained because I am a woman and see that as essential for the survival of the church itself.

title: Miss Ahlgren of Sweden Wins World Pentathlon
description: Ann Ahlgren of Sweden won the world women's modern pentathlon title today, despite finishing 13th in the 2,000-meter cross-country event. Sabine Krapf of West Germany took the silver medal and Wendy Norman of Britain the bronze.

title: SUBSCRIBING IS BIG BUSINESS
description: PORT WASHINGTON IT will be business as usual on Sept. 9 for Publishers Clearing House when it begins to award over $175,000 in money and prizes to more than 4,000 people throughout the United States and Canada. For the third time this year, the privately owned company will determine the winners of its current sweepstakes, and it hopes that the awards it makes will inspire others to purchase magazine subcriptions through its mail-order service.

title: EXCELLENCE IN AMATEUR PHOTOS
description: FAIR LAWN SOME professional photographers arch their eyebrows, stiffen their necks and walk away when they hear the words ''camera club.'' To them, such an association denotes awkward amateurism, stifling organized artistry and too many cameras trained on sunsets and vistas.

title: SINKERS ON SUNDAY: SUBURBAN RITUAL
description: THE Sunday morning bakery run may well be a universal ritual. I've gone out for beignets in New Orleans, croissants in Tours, even firi-firi (a rubbery figure-eight doughnut) in Bora Bora on a Sunday morning.

title: Handcuffs of Gold
description: The Gold Standard: the term conjures images of clipper ships, William Jennings Bryan and confusing afternoons in the college library.

title: Storm Off Alaska Kills Fishery Ship Crewman
description: One crewman died and another was missing after sailors abandoned the foundering Northern King, a fish processing ship, in a raging storm on Bristol Bay, the Coast Guard said.

title: SUICIDE SPARKS UNION COUNTY JAIL INQUIRY
description: ELIZABETH THE recent suicide of a 19-year-old woman at the Union County Jail has sparked controversy over the jail's management and operation, both under the control of Sheriff Ralph Froehlich.

title: Headliners Kleindienst Trial Opens
description: When indicted some months ago on charges of perjury, former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst announced, after a fashion, that he had accepted a new position. ''My job now,'' he said, ''is to prove that I'm a truthful man.''

title: IF IT'S MILEAGE YOU WANT IT'S STILL DIESEL YOU'LL GET
description: Time was when only truckers, farmers and boat-owners talked about diesel fuel. All the average motorist knew was that the stuff on which tractors, trailers and becalmed trimarans ran was cheaper than gasoline and ranked with the camel in mileage per gallon. The fuel that powered Rudolph Diesel's new engine in 1885 still goes a long way. But ''cheap'' is an adjective no longer heard around the diesel pump, where owners of Oldsmobiles and Volkswagens have joined truckers. Diesel fuel prices rival and sometimes surpass those of regular gasoline, to the chagrin of thousands of people who thought they could escape the oil crunch by purchasing diesel-powered cars. The following explores the relationship between crude oil prices and supplies - which the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was reshuffling last week - and motor fuel costs, and examines what happened to the diesel ''bargain.''

title: Art; MARRIED ARTISTS' OWN STYLE
description: WATER MILL EXHIBITIONS of works by husband and wife artists are a feature of the Hamptons gallery scene this month. The comparative exhibition on Jackson Pollock and Lee Krasner at Guild Hall in East Hampton is one example, but there is also an engaging show of recent works by Charlotte Park and James Brooks at the Louise Himelfarb Gallery, one of several in the area that are participating in a salute to Guild Hall on its 50th anniversary.

title: INSURANCE INDUSTRY SUPPORTS ITS OWN COLLEGE IN MANHATTANMANHATTAN
description: When the Insurance Society of New York was founded in 1901, its members began meeting in a small office at 75 William Street, just four blocks north of Wall Street, to see what they could learn from each other.

title: Margaret Sweeney Wed
description: Margaret Mary Sweeney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Sweeney of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Lawrence Daniel Muldoon Jr., son of Dr. Alyce R. O'Neil of Bridgeport, Conn., and the late Mr. Muldoon. The Rev. Thomas Halkovic performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church. The bride attends Northwestern University, where Mr. Muldoon is a medical student.

title: 2 GIVE UP CAMERA FOR EMPANADAS
description: SALISBURY ''IF this story ends happily, maybe we'll turn it into a wonderful Frank Capra-type movie,'' said Sherry LaFollette Zabriskie of her family's newest venture, baking and selling empanadas. Film makers for 18 years, Sherry and her husband, George, switched from cutting celluloid to rolling pastry dough because, they said, ''at least we can eat the out-takes.''

title: REAGAN MAY TURN TO MX MISSILE PLAN BASED ON CARTER'S
description: President Reagan is moving toward approval of a smaller version of the Carter Administration's proposal for basing the MX missile, despite his strong past criticism of that plan, according to Administration officials.

title: WINNING A RACE AGAINST CANCER
description: IN the summer of 1976, at age 31, I lay in a hospital room at Harvard, recovering from surgery of an apparent cyst. My surgeon entered the room and walked hesitatingly to the foot of my bed.

title: New Jersey Housing; HOW TO CONVERT AN IDEA INTO REALTY
description: OFTEN, what distinguishes a developer from the rest of us is vision: seeing possibilities for land use that would leave others shaking their heads in skepticism and disbelief.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSIC JAZZ At the age of 75, Earl ''Fatha'' Hines is the last of the great jazz pioneers of the 1920's who is still actively playing. Almost all of his peers have passed on - Louis Armstrong, Fats Waller, Duke Ellington, Fletcher Henderson, Coleman Hawkins, Art Tatum, Jack Teagarden, Bix Beiderbecke.

title: U.N. ENERGY TALKS END WITH PLEA FOR MONEY
description: The first United Nations Conference on New and Renewable Energy Sources ended last night with agreement on a billion-dollar plan to end dependence on fossil fuels but no money to carry it out.

title: ON LOCATION WITH 'KING OF COMEDY'
description: Making a movie in New York: Scene 1. The seventh floor of a midtown office building, a headquarters of Murjani, which makes those jeans Gloria Vanderbilt tells us about. The reception area has been repainted, deep blue and silver-white. Another wall, bright red, has a silver caricature of Jerry Lewis glued to it and the name, ''Jerry,'' underneath it. It is meant to be the reception area for ''The Jerry Langford Show,'' a television talk show.

title: Stung, Bitten, Bemused; Poetic Justice
description: Has the Sting show, which opened with Abscam in Washington, closed in Connecticut? Federal law enforcers, fresh from the triumphant performances that produced convictions of seven Congressmen, were trying to extend their use of simulated criminals. The other night in Bridgeport, it turned into bad street theater.

title: Chrisanne Peepas Is Bride
description: Chrisanne Peepas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Z. Peepas of Smoke Rise, N.J., was married in Orange, N.J., yesterday to Russell Lee Hensley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert P. Hensley of Cincinnati. The Rev. George Mamangakis performed the ceremony at SS. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church.

title: No Headline
description: It is my belief that the time is not now to preach conciliation to women.

title: Debate Over Rank
description: One of Chairman Mao's not-so-great thoughts, in 1965, had it that military ranks were uncomradely.

title: PLAYLAND ACTS TO COUNTER DROP IN ATTENDANCE
description: RYE AN expansive $90,000 promotional campaign, implemented earlier this month by Playland officials to boost attendance, has apparently encouraged more people to visit the 53-year-old amusement park here. But officials of the Marriott Corporation, which manages Playland, expressed doubts that the park would produce sufficient revenues this year to offset the more than $800,000 spent by Westchester County in capital improvements.

title: EFFORT TO SAVE 95-YEAR-OLD SCHOOL MEETS GOAL
description: A community fund-raising effort appears to have won a reprieve for the 95-year-old Woods Hole School, which was scheduled to be closed this fall in an economy move.

title: Friedan on Feminism's Next Step
description: Betty Friedan wonders whether a second stage of the women's movement ''may be evolving'' (''Feminism's Next Step,'' July 5). I can assure her that it is.

title: THREE AMERICAN POETS
description: THE REVISIONIST By Douglas Crase. 85 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $5.95. THE DOLLMAKER'S GHOST By Larry Levis. 71 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $10.25. Paper, $6.25. SWIMMER IN THE SPREADING DAWN By Kathleen Spivack. 96 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Apple-wood Books. Paper, $4.95. By CHARLES MOLESWORTH

title: Long Islanders; THE HOW AND WHY OF ALL HE SURVEYS
description: THERE are some people in show business who wish that Steve Levitt and his TvQ and Performer Q ratings, which rate the appeal of television programs and personalities as the Nielsen ratings assess the popularity of programs, would go away.

title: SCARSDALE VOYAGER CIRCLES THE GLOBE TO WATCH ECLIPSES
description: SCARSDALE BEFORE he left for Siberia, Philip L. Carret said: ''I don't think you can explain it to any rational person. Some like antique chairs, some like classical music, some like no music at all. I like eclipses.''

title: Connecticut Journal
description: CITIES with high tax burdens often complain about having to bear the full financial burden of providing services to tax-exempt institutions within their boundaries, even though those institutions may serve whole regions.

title: SAVING A WILDERNESS WHERE DWARF OAKS DWELL
description: BRENTWOOD STATE and county officials are near agreement on the creation of an oak-brush plains preserve on state-owned land around Edgewood State Hospital and adjacent to the proposed site of the Multi-Town Solid Waste Management Authority treatment plant.

title: Tougher Line Toward Crime
description: Statistics on serious crime in the United States are invariably debated but public sentiment on the issue has been increasingly clear, as Attorney General William French Smith noted when appointing the Task Force on Violent Crime. Last week, the bipartisan group, headed by former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell and Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois, presented its final recommendations as to how the Justice Department might strengthen law enforcement at Federal, state and local levels.

title: No Headline
description: In her silence and innuendoes about radical feminism, Betty Friedan makes her strongest appeal to the forces of reaction. All feminists are no more alike than all women are alike, and many feminists, both straight and gay, are committed to evolving new forms of intimacy and kinship outside the conventional family.

title: Yielding at The Bulletin
description: In the United States, a newspaper monopoly-by-survival was narrowly averted in Philadelphia last week when unions at The Bulletin agreed to $4.9 million in job and wage concessions demanded by the publisher, N.S. Hayden.

title: GAS HEATING COSTS UP IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The cost of gas heating is 14 to 23 percent higher than a year ago in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan area, and both producers and energy officials expect supplies to be adequate this winter.

title: STUDENTS HURRY TO GET LOANS BEFORE U.S. LIMITS ELIGIBILITY
description: College and graduate students are applying for federally guaranteed student loans in record numbers, spurred by publicity about cuts in the loan program and uncertainty about its future.

title: Dining Out; LIGHT MEALS IN UNUSUAL SETTINGS
description: Akaffeehaus, an institution attributed to Viennese genius, has found a home in Armonk. For three months now, Karl Ausserlechner, schooled in Vienna in both cooking and pastry-making, has been overseeing the accomplished kitchen and homey dining room of the singular Kaffee Bazar. The restaurant conveys the feel of European coffee houses; patrons sense that they are welcome to linger over coffee or brandy.

title: Bridge; TAKING A PLUNGE
description: In quantitative terms, the recent Summer National Championships in Boston fell far short of the record: 14,079 tables in play compared to l8,517 in Las Vegas in 1979. Qualitatively, there were some most interesting contestants. Pride of place must go to Benito Garozzo, a key member of the great Italian Blue Team. He had come directly from Birmingham, England, where his team had finished fourth in the European Championship behind Poland, Britain and France.

title: THE STONE ENCYCLOPEDIAS
description: THE AGE OF THE CATHEDRALS Art and Society, 980-1420. By Georges Duby. Translated by Eleanor Levieux and Barbara Thompson. Illustrated. 312 pp. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. $22.50. By JOHN RUSSELL

title: POLICE REPORT TIPS IN SLAYING OF BOY
description: Detectives investigating the slaying of a 14-year-old Brooklyn boy during a bicycle ride Friday morning canvassed an East Flatbush neighborhood yesterday in search of witnesses and clues. They made no arrests, but received some telephone tips and reported several new leads.

title: BEIRUT, LEBANON
description: COL. Muammar el-Qaddafi was struck uncharacteristically speechless for a time last week after American F-14's, in one minute flat, shot down two Libyan jets - and with them, some of the colonel's claim to be the champion of the Arab nation and defier of the West.

title: TRACY AUSTIN AND MRS. LLOYD GAIN FINAL
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Tracy Austin, who have not met in almost a year, will play for the $34,000 first prize in the Canadian Open tennis championships tomorrow.

title: UNCOVERING ARABIA'S PAST
description: At dawn, the sun over the Arabian Hejaz paints the stark craggy buttes and mesas jutting from the golden sand with delicate hues of rust and amber. Crossing this parched land of stunning, pristine vistas, the newly laid ribbon of asphalt leading north from the Saudi Arabian city of Medina follows the old camel caravan route to Damascus. Alongside it runs the twisted remains of the famed Hejaz railway built by the Turks for the pilgrimage to Mecca and sabotaged by the Arab followers of Lawrence of Arabia. The highway passes countless tiny oases and villages strung close by the wadis, or river beds, that today, as in ancient times, form the loci of Arab life. Loping along the undulating sands are the ubiquitous camels, which, after millenniums of faithful service as the vehicles of the desert, are fast being replaced by the white Toyota and Datsun pickups that now bounce over the sands.

title: MILFORD DEFERS SEX EDUCATION
description: THE Milford Board of Education last week moved to conclude, at least for the moment, debate on whether the sex education program in its elementary and secondary schools is adequate.

title: MAKING STRIDES THROUGH RUGBY
description: To the Sport Editor: Richard Lapchick and Franklin Williams claim the South African Springboks represnet their government's apartheid system and compare them to a group of Klu Klux Klansmen. They also dismiss the touring party's two "coloreds" as tokens. What Mr. Lapchick and Mr. Williams choose to ignore is that neither the Klan nor the South African Government have any room for tokenism.

title: Westchester Journal
description: CALDOR'S has been saying that its newest store, in Port Chester, represents a homecoming. And that is not advertising hyperbole. Caldor's began in Port Chester, opening it first store there in 1951. Caldor's eventually moved out of Port Chester. But now it is coming back, with its 70th store.

title: CORONARY PATIENTS CAUTIONED
description: Urging patients out of bed to exercise just days after a coronary does not improve the health of their hearts, a study shows.

title: Sound; SUBTLETY POWERS A BIG SPEAKER
description: Judging a speaker by its ''specs'' is like judging a wine by its label. You get some pertinent data, but they don't really tell the story. By contrast, discursive description can occasionally suggest something about the character of either a wine or a loudspeaker and give you some inkling whether you might be interested in a closer acquaintnce. From time to time we therefore relate our subjective impressions of noteworthy speakers, focusing today on one of the largest and sonically most potent among current bookshelf models.

title: SIX MEMBERS OF A BROOKLYN GANG ARE ARRESTED IN SUBWAY ROBBERIES
description: Six members of a gang that the police said terrorized and robbed at knifepoint several young subway passengers in Brooklyn early yesterday were arrested by Transit Authority police after the victims identified them as their assailants.

title: TIGERS 2, RANGERS 0
description: Dan Petry, Dave Rozema and Kevin Saucier combined on a four-hit shutout today as the Detroit Tigers extended their winning streak to eight games by beating the Texas Rangers, 2-0.

title: AUTO DEALER BLUES
description: With the auto industry well into its second year of slump, the new car dealerships continues to dwindle. In conjunction with a narrowing of price differentials between models, the reduction has meant changes in dealer market share.

title: CALIFORNIA BECOMES MELTING POT OF 1980'S
description: Over the last decade, California has all but supplanted New York as the principal ethnic melting pot of America, according to data from the 1980 census.

title: SRI LANKA CALM, BUT ETHNIC PROBLEMS REMAIN
description: Soldiers with fixed bayonets and steel helmets are mingling with tourists in the streets of this bustling capital.

title: Lunch-Hour Events At Galleria Building
description: A series of free lunch-hour concerts, lectures and multimedia events are being given Fridays at noon in the atrium of the Galleria Building, at Park Avenue and 57th Street. The concerts feature musicians and performing artists from Queens College.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BUENOS AIRES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- EDWARD SCHUMACHER is the Times bureau chief in Buenos Aires. By EDWARD SCHUMACHER

title: COUNTY TO BE HOST TO 2 TENNIS EVENTS
description: IN an era when interest in recreational tennis continues to grow nationwide, it comes as no suprise that two small but high-quality tournaments with international overtones have been scheduled for courts in the county.

title: Theater; A TUNEFUL PACKAGE AT THE COACHLIGHT
description: DAVID GUTHRIE surely is one of the most talented men working the dinner theater circuit. Not only does he stage almost every show at the Coachlight Dinner Theater, he also designs and costumes them, and every summer he creates one from scratch.

title: OF LANCES, LIBRARIES AND HONORABLE MEN
description: ''BURY ME on my face,'' the Greek philosopher Diogenes instructed before he died in 323 B.C., ''because in a little while everything will be turned upside down.''

title: POP: ERNESTINE JACKSON
description: Ernestine Jackson, a stimulating and striking-looking woman with brightly sparkling brown eyes, gorgeous facial planes and a strong, soaring singing voice was at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, last week, performing with a confidence that belies the the emptiness of her act.

title: AMERICA'S NEW FOREIGN POLICY
description: Frank Church, former Democratic chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, now practices law in Washington. By Frank Church At his first White House press conference, Ronald Reagan lambasted the Soviet Union. He said the Russian leadership reserved ''the right to commit any crime, to lie, to cheat,'' in order to attain their goal of a one-world Communist state. His words, in one sense, were right on target. He understood that most Americans would welcome his indictment as reassurance that their tough-talking new President had no intention of letting the Russianspush him around.

title: ORIENT MOSQUITOES MEET THEIR MATCH
description: ORIENT THE residents of this village are sleeping soundly at night nowadays, unbothered by any hum of mosquitoes about their heads, because Jim Bogden does his job.

title: INNOVATIVE BRAZILIAN DIRECTOR
description: Glauber Rocha, a film director who was a leading exponent of Brazil's ''new cinema,'' died in a Rio de Janeiro hospital yesterday from complications of a lung infection. He was 42 years old.

title: SAVORING MORE THAN SHERRY IN JEREZ
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ROBERT PACKARD is professor of humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology. By ROBERT PACKARD

title: WHERE THE SUPPLY-SIDE PATH IS OLD HAT
description: E NCOURAGED by their popularity with an American public weary of high taxes and sluggish growth, supply-side economists are now turning their attention to the third world with almost missionary zeal.

title: Polish Flight Hijacked
description: A man hijacked a Polish airliner on a domestic flight today and forced the pilot to land at a United States air base in West Berlin. The hijacker then surrendered and let the 38 other passengers and four crew members off. Officials said the passengers and crew would be fed and questioned before returning to Poland aboard the AN-20 turboprop of the Polish airline, LOT.

title: FROM APPALACHIA, HANDMADE OBJECTS
description: EAST HAMPTON THE names of the hamlets sound like the charmed, fictional appellations of towns in a book of fairy tales - Bear Wallow Hollow, Chloe, Shock and Nitro, Alum Creek, and Sam Black Church. These tiny villages, however, actually have zip codes and are nestled in pockets of the rippling mountains of North Carolina, Virginia, Kentucky, West Virginia and Georgia. They are the homes of some of the three dozen artisans whose handmade products are for sale in a newly opened East Hampton gallery called Appalachian Art.

title: Smallpox Suspected in Italy
description: A sailor aboard the oil tanker Neptune Aires, which is registered in Singapore, is suspected of having smallpox, port officials said today. The doctor on the ship, which came from Kuwait carrying diesel fuel, identified the crew member as Selwyn Gerard Galistan, 25 years old.

title: WHAT'S BETTER THAN FRIDAY? WHY, IT'S MONDAY
description: EVERYONE is familiar with the ''Thank God, it's Friday'' club. Not just the weary toilers wending their summery way to the farther, cooler reaches of our watery Island at the thankful end of a work week in the withered Apple, but their families and other loved ones, too.

title: NOW, DIAL A RENT GUIDELINES QUERY
description: Anybody who called the Rent Stabilization Association before this summer to find out about new rent guidelines or fuel surcharges or renewing a lease, probably could not get through.

title: Raid Nets 51 Stolen Guns
description: Four persons were arrested and 51 guns were seized in a raid at a Charleston motel today, the authorities said.

title: NO EASING AHEAD IN CREDIT
description: With interest rates remaining at near-record heights, and the economy showing few signs, if any, of growth, some economists have expected private demand for credit to weaken, a prerequisite for sustained reduction in interest rates. Thus far, however, such a downturn has not occured.

title: Kuwait Refinery Still Closed
description: One of three oil refineries in Kuwait, a Persian Gulf petroleum exporter, remained closed today as firemen fought the last of five oil tank fires that began early Thursday. The fire broke out at the Kuwait National Petroleum Company, killing one worker.

title: GLOBAL GROUP PONDERING AID TO CONTROLLERS
description: A global organization of air traffic controllers began a two-day meeting near Amsterdam today to discuss possible measures to support the American air traffic controllers' strike.

title: A Lighter Touch; On Civil Rights
description: It remains to be seen, of course, what the civil rights record of the Reagan Administration will be. But last week there were further signs that, when it comes to matters of race and sex, the Justice Department's rule of thumb will be an increasingly familiar one: the less regulation and interference the better.

title: Man Seized in Casino Threat
description: A man who threatened to blow up the Caesars Boardwalk Regency hotel-casino was arrested today at a bus terminal as he tried to pick up the $50,000 he had demanded, authorities said. The suspect was identified as 47-year-old William Vincent Spencer, of Kings Beach, Calif. Authorities said he had made his threats by telephone.

title: No Headline
description: The article on Caesarean births left out any mention of the most important side effect - the debilitated condition of the mother after what is considered to be major surgery. Most surgical patients are given a six-week recuperation period during which they are told to rest and take it easy.

title: TV View; WHEN THE WHITE HOUSE COZIES UP TO THE HOME SCREEN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard S. Salant is vice chairman of NBC and the former president of CBS News. John J. O'Connor is on vacation.

title: Peggy Daniel Is Married to Michael Denis Murphy
description: Margaret Peyton Daniel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Peyton Daniel Jr. of Ladue, Mo., was married yesterday to Michael Denis Murphy, son of Timothy F. Murphy of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Patricia Murphy. The ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in St. Louis was performed by the Rev. Richard Baker, assisted by the Rev. Timothy Scannell.

title: Antiques; SPENDING A WEEKEND DIPPING INTO THE PAST
description: STOCKTON A DIP into the past with antiques as the lure can provide an interesting weekend next Friday and Saturday. The First Annual Prallsville Mills Antiques Show and Sale will take place here on the banks of the Delaware River, just north of the center of town on Route 29.

title: Notes; A SMORGASBORD OF FESTIVALS
description: With the dog days of August nearing their end, the calendar of coming tourist events remains crowded. The weeks ahead will see foliage displays, balloon ascensions, fairs of all descriptions and a number of special musical and cultural programs. A brief sampling follows:

title: HAMILTON VS. JEFFERSON THIS TIME IT'S ENERGY
description: 2,2,294.4,0,3100,2RESEARCH TRIANGLE PARK, N.C. - On a recent trip I was stopped by one of those irritating young men who seem to spend their lives in shifts at the airports. ''Are you for nuclear power - or are you for solar?'' Everyone who walked by was asked the same question. It is, of course, a dumb question. Conceivably one could be for both or neither. Nuclear and solar energy hardly exhaust all the possibilities - oil, gas, coal, water, sun fuels. It's not an endless list by any means, but it's long enough and slowly getting longer. Foolish question. ''Nuclear or solar?'' Why should I even think twice about it?

title: LONDON THIS year, Britain will finally achieve what all nations desire - self-sufficiency in oil. Twelve years after the North Sea discoveries, the economically troubled island nation can boast of petroleum reserves roughly equivalent to Kuwait's. Unlike most of the industrial West, no longer must Britain depend on other countries for any part of the basic fuel to run its economy.
description: But, for all that, Britain is no Kuwait. Self-sufficiency hasn't made a lord of the average man, nor will it. Rolls-Royce hasn't experienced a sudden surge in sales at home, nor is there any ostentatious display of wealth. With a population of 54 million, the value of a year's oil production amounts to just $450 per Briton.

title: By PETER G. DAVIS
description: Sometimes it seems that all instrumentalists want to become conductors conductors these days, even while simultaneously playing in a solo capacity. Jean-Pierre Rampal is only one member of this breed, and he appeared in Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night conducting a Mostly Mozart Festival concert. He also performed Mozart's Flute Concerto in D (K. 314), leading the orchestra at the same time, and it was a sight to behold.

title: BONN PARTIES SPLIT ON AUSTERITY PLAN
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's coalition parties are deeply divided on the details of an austerity program for 1982 that was authorized by the Cabinet last month.

title: AMID STORM OVER HUNGER STRIKERS, ALL IS CALM IN MAZE PRISON HOSPITAL
description: The gaunt young hunger striker, wearing striped pyjamas, sat on a gray steel bed reading a newspaper, a blue blanket pulled close around him because he now feels chilly most of the time. His tidy hospital room, with yellow walls, shiny gray linoleum and a square of bright orange carpet, looks like any other modern hospital room except that there is always a tray of food sitting on the table. When the attendant brings in lunch, he takes away the untouched breakfast; when he brings in dinner, he takes away the lunch.

title: Henry Lucander Weds Miss Olson
description: Karen Jean Olson, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Paul Heiberg Olson of New Brighton, Minn., was married there yesterday to Henry Lucander, son of Bjorn-Erik Lucander of Helsinki, Finland, and the late Doris Maria Helin Lucander. The bride's father performed the ceremony at Christ the King Lutheran Church.

title: Sports of The Times; At Stadium, a Spoiling of Sorts
description: TWENTY-FIVE years later, the Dodgers finally got to Don Larsen, when Pee Wee Reese stroked a ground-rule double to left field yesterday.

title: DR. MARTIN KASSAN
description: Dr. Martin Kassan, a former president of the Council of Psychoanalytic Psychotherapists, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home at 115 East Ninth Street.

title: THE GAME PILOTS PLAY OVER THE MEDITERRANEAN
description: The reported destruction of two Soviet-made SU-22 Libyan fighters by carrier-based American F-14's over the Gulf of Sidra last week was the first publicly acknowledged incident in which American aircraft fired on and brought down foreign planes in the Mediterranean since World War II. However, in that theater there have been more than 100 ''hairy situations,'' in the parlance of American pilots, and more than a dozen Soviet and American airmen have lost their lives. Most of these actions have been part of a Soviet-American game of confrontation, surveillance and occasional brinkmanship - the pilots wryly call it ''chicken of the sea'' - that has been in progress in the Mediterranean since at least 1966.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: WEIGHING THE COST OF COUNTY'S MEDICAL CENTER
description: THE Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla has been the subject of extensive discussion in recent time, and I suspect it will occupy our thoughts more in the next few months. The taxpaying public who subsidize this institution have an absolute right to weigh the relative costs of their subsidy versus the benefits that are gained by the presence of this ''tertiary'' care institution. To make an informed judgment, however, requires a fundamental appreciation of the facts free of political rhetoric.

title: MALAYSIANS DEPICT CHINA AS A THREAT
description: Malaysia's month-old Government is emphasizing the theme that China remains a major threat to the non-Communist nations of Southeast Asia, and it is urging the United States to bear this in mind.

title: LOUISIANA PLAN WOULD IMPROVE BLACK UNIVERSITIES
description: The State of Louisiana will spend millions of dollars over the next six years to improve its predominately black state universities under a proposed settlement of a Federal desegregation lawsuit that has been pending since 1974.

title: Another Fly Is Found Outside of Quarantine
description: A Mediterranean fruit fly has been found in a small walnut orchard outside a Santa Clara Valley quarantine area in California, and eradication project directors yesterday ordered an immediate aerial spray of the area.

title: Saving Energy
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Reagan's Energy Plan: Paper Promises'' (Aug. 2), the Administration's drastic cut of the Energy Department's conservation budget is a strong signal that the White House does not comprehend conservation's tremendous potential.

title: Station in Albany Scheduled For $100 Million Renovation
description: The 81-year-old Union Station here is scheduled for a $100 million renovation that will include a 500,000-square-foot office building, a 300-room hotel and a shopping complex, Governor Carey announced yesterday.

title: AS BYRNE WINDS DOWN, HIS FOES WIND UP
description: Though he is nearing the end of his eight years in office and not running for anything this year, Governor Byrne will nevertheless see his name on the ballot in November, if only in Bergen County. The county Board of Chosen Freeholders decided last week to ask the voters whether they approve of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority naming its new arena in the Meadowlands after the Governor, and not telling anyone about it until the letters were affixed to the building.

title: POLISH PRINTERS PERSIST IN STRIKE IN ONE TOWN
description: Printers refused to publish the Communist Party paper in the northern city of Olsz@tyn for the fourth consecutive day today amid continuing unrest among industrial workers around Poland.

title: EASTERN SHUTTLE KEEPS NO-RESERVATION POLICY
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that the company had decided to continue operating its Air Shuttle service without requiring reservations, although it had considered last week ''going to a reservation system'' because of the difficulties of guaranteeing extra flights for passengers during the air traffic controllers' strike.

title: LEARNING THE 'IMPOSSIBLE' ART OF CONDUCTING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Helen Epstein writes and teaches at New York University. By HELEN EPSTEIN

title: THE TAXMAN RUSHETH TO FILE ON TIME
description: Nelson A. Brooke's publications don't have fancy titles but then again, with a guaranteed press run of anywhere from 3.5 million to 92 million copies, there isn't much need for a snappy lead.

title: WHEN NEW RESIDENTS BECOME THE 'INS'
description: NORTH HILLS THIS small village adjoining Manhasset has been converted in less than a decade from an area of patrician country estates into a scattered series of attached town-house condominium developments. The same speed-up has affected North Hills politics.

title: CAN A CRASH DIET TRIM BILLIONS IN JUST MONTHS?
description: In the elephantine interstices of Federal bureaucracy, it is alleged, billions of dollars a year disappear through waste, fraud, abuse and mismanagement, evils which prior Administrations have striven to extirpate. Now it is President Reagan's turn to promise a spirited campaign to ''follow every lead, root out every incompetent, and prosecute any crook we find who is cheating the people of this nation.'' The man in charge is Deputy Budget Director Edwin L. Harper, a former vice president of the Emerson Electric Company and in 1980 a member of the Reagan campaign's spending control task force. As director of the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency, Mr. Harper oversees what is described as a broad, high-visibility effort to get the efficiency and savings that could reduce future-year budget deficits. Recently, he talked with Clyde H. Farnsworth, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, about his work. Excerpts of their discussion follow.

title: Turkish Right Goes On Trial
description: Alpaslan Turkes, a retired colonel and former Deputy Prime Minister of Turkey, is known by his Nationalist Action Party followers as the ''basbug,'' a Turkish title that has been compared to Adolf Hitler's ''fuehrer'' and Benito Mussolini's ''il duce.''

title: Ferry Runs Aground in Crete
description: All 300 passengers were taken off the 4,500-ton Egyptian ferry Syria, stranded when it ran aground on the northeastern coast of Crete yesterday, a harbor authority spokesman said here today.

title: Gabriel Sets Pro Mark
description: Tony Gabriel of the Canadian Football League's Ottawa Rough Riders set a professional record last night when he caught a pass in his 128th consecutive game. Gabriel's total broke the record he shared with Harold Carmichael of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League. Despite Gabriel's record, the Calgary Stampeders defeated Ottawa, 30-18.

title: Hasty Words; On Agent Orange
description: Agent Orange, like the war in which it was used extensively, has left behind a long-lasting residue. Last month, an epidemiologist who has been hired by the Veterans Administration to design a study of the effects of Agent Orange - a defoliant sprayed over broad swatches of Vietnam - on American troops told a state legislative committee in California there was ''little evidence'' that they were harmful or widespread.

title: Veteran Acquitted in Assault
description: McKINNEY, Tex., Aug. 22 (UPI) - A 33-year-old Vietnam veteran who blamed a combat flashback for a standoff with the police in which he fired a shotgun from a window of his home has been found not guilty of aggravated assault by reason of insanity. Michael Ashley, who served in the Air Force, said the verdict yesterday was a victory for Vietnam veterans who suffered from trauma caused by the war. His five-hour standoff with the police occurred Oct. 17, 1980.

title: BIOPOLITICS: ODD HYBRID OR A SYNTHESIS?
description: The formation of new disciplines through the marriage of old ones occurs regularly in science. Some of these academic hybrids - biophysics and biochemistry, for example - make widely recognized contributions to knowledge and become respectable rather quickly. Others, such as psychohistory or sociobiology, seem perpetually embroiled in controversy and doubt. One of the most recent mergers occurred when political scientists began to use the concepts and techniques of modern biology.

title: ABOUT THOSE NEW FOLKS IN TOWN
description: SOCIETY editors are scrambling - or soon will be - for the first ''inside'' photos and stories about the Nixons' new home in Saddle River. There will be the usual notations about the cost of the house and the size of the swimming pool. There will be descriptions of the new decor, mixed tastefully with Presidential memorabilia and the neighbors' reverential comments.

title: FOR BEAUFORT CASTLE, A RESPITE FROM VIOLENCE
description: For 900 years it has withstood siege after siege with weapons ranging from crossbows and catapults to bombs and artillery shells. Now, with a cease-fire between Israeli and Palestinian forces still in effect across the Lebanese border, a certain calm has returned to the countryside around Beaufort Castle.

title: PAGE KEEPS TITLE ON DECISION
description: Undefeated Greg Page retained his United States Boxing Association heavyweight title tonight by winning a 12-round split decision from George Chaplin.

title: CO-MANAGERS OF AMERICA'S NUCLEAR WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: STUNG, BITTEN, BEMUSED; Top Hat
description: During the Depression, when people were selling apples and factories were still and guys were jumping out windows because they lost everything, people would go to the movies. They loved those glamorous pictures showing people driving beautiful cars and women in beautiful gowns, showing that people were loving the glamorous good life.

title: SCHOOL TO MONITOR SATURN OVER TV SATELLITES
description: The radar dish and Army surplus radio shack occupy a fenced-in 40-by-40-foot patch of lawn behind the high school, between a football field and a soybean field. And with the four-gigahertz television receiver in the shack, the school can pick up transmissions from five American and three Canadian satellites.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; JUDY MAZEL
description: During the past few months no fewer than six books on diet or nutrition have appeared on the best seller list, outperforming even such perennial big-sellers as how-to and get-rich books. The current leader, ''The Beverly Hills Diet'' by Judy Mazel, sits in the No. 1 position after 10 printings and with more than 800,000 copies in print, followed in third place by Hollywood television personality Richard Simmons' ''Never-Say-Diet Book.''

title: CATALOGUE MARKS 75TH SWEET YEAR
description: To the catalogue-conscious construction industry, the publication in 1906 of a one-volume compilation of building product information entitled ''Sweet's Indexed Catalogue of Building Construction'' was a deliverance from a dim past. Prior to its publication, architects had to consult scores of catalogues from different manufacturers in order to select needed products.

title: IRWIN'S 67-205 LEADS BUICK OPEN BY SHOT
description: Hale Irwin, the two-time United States Open champion, shot a five-under-par 67 today to take a onestroke lead into the final round of the $350,000 Buick Open.

title: New Storm in the Caribbean
description: As Tropical Storm Dennis dissipated over the North Atlantic, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center here were watching a tropical depression off northeastern Venezuela today. The depression was centered at daybreak about 20 miles north of Isla Margarita, in the southeastern Caribbean Sea.

title: Reagan Seen Certain To Keep Union Card
description: Ronald Reagan's union card is secure at the Screen Actors Guild and there is little chance he will be stripped of his lifetime membership because of the air traffic controllers' strike, a union official says.

title: 20 Food Places Called Health-Code Violators
