description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 20 food establishments that it said had violated the health code. The department also named three restaurants that had reopened after correcting earlier violations.

title: Sentenced to; The Gallows
description: Without blinking, the same legal system that regards Bobby Tsotsobe as a citizen of the black ''homeland'' of Transkei found him guilty of treason to white South Africa. He was sentenced last week to hang, along with two other members of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: No Headline
description: With all due respect to Betty Friedan's past contributions to feminism, she has long since become hopelessly confused about whose side she's on. The following is, I think, a fair summary of her argument.

title: WHATEVER BECAME OF SPANISH DANCE?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Walter Terry, a dance critic for 45 years, is dance critic for Saturday Review and author of ''Alicia: Alicia Alonso and her Ballet Nacional de Cuba,'' his 20th dance book. By WALTER TERRY

title: BEARS TRIUMPH BY 24-21
description: Vince Evans threw for two touchdowns and set up another in the first half to give the Chicago Bears a 24-21 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals tonight in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: Lisa Kunstadter Wed to N.A. Stephens
description: Lisa Jan Kunstadter, a financial analyst with Home Box Office, a subsidiary of Time Inc. in New York, was married there yesterday to Nicholas Andrew Stephens, a consultant with the New York accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand. The ceremony was performed at St. Thomas Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Andrew.

title: Peggy Strimple Is Wed to Frederick T. Scruggs Jr.
description: Margaret Ellen Strimple, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Hoyt Strimple of Milltown, N.J., was married there yesterday to Frederick Thornton Scruggs Jr., son of Mrs. Scruggs of Lynchburg, Va., and the late Mr. Scruggs. The Rev. James W. Marshall performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church.

title: IMPORTING VIOLENCE IS A SHADOW INDUSTRY
description: Do foreign government agents spy on foreign citizens in the United States? And if they do, is it illegal? These questions, which have bedeviled lawyers and diplomats here for years, arose again this summer with the disclosure that a 31-year-old instructor from Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, a Taiwan national, had died in his homeland after being interrogated by the Taiwan security police.

title: Leisure; IT'S EASY TO SOW HARDY FLOWERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Carolyn Jabs, a writer, lives on a farm in upstate New York. By CAROLYN JABS

title: HARASSMENT RULING APPEALED
description: ARULING in the first sexual-harassment case in the state to get a hearing before an administrative law judge is being appealed by an East Orange company, which was ordered to pay the complainant $7,000 and to develop a comprehensive policy to do away with such harassment.

title: PAN AM: WHAT'S LEFT
description: Pan Am, fighting for its financial life, continued last week to sell off the company jewels.

title: William S. Schwoebel, at 69; Ex-Steel Company Executive
description: William S. Schwoebel, a former steel company executive, died Friday at Mercy Hospital in Pittsburgh after a brief illness.

title: Ministers Use Putter On Golf Course Thug
description: Three ministers confronted on a golf course by a would-be robber used a putter to smote their assailant. The Rev. W.J. Millard, the Rev. Vince O'Leary and the Rev. Jim Breytspraak said they were on the eighth green at Overton Park golf course yesterday morning when a man appeared and demanded their wallets.

title: Music View; THE RIDDLE OF JOHN CAGE
description: At some point, John Cage must have decided he was not going to be one of the world's great composers so he invented a fallback career for himself. Perhaps it was after Arnold Schoenberg, his teacher, said he was ''not a composer, but an inventor - of genius.'' Mr. Cage became, instead, one of the leading philosophers and wits in 20thcentury music, a man whose influence went on expanding even while his composing pretensions seemed to shrink. Especially in his early years, Mr. Cage produced some original and captivating works, such as the Sonatas and Interludes for Prepared Piano (1946-48). However, if I were to be asked to name the Cage works that might still have an audience in 2001, I would restrict my list to four: ''Silence'' (1961), ''A Year from Monday'' (1967), ''M'' (1973), and ''For the Birds'' (1981).

title: THE DOYENNE OF THE DRAWING ROOM
description: MRS.L. Conversations with Alice Roosevelt Longworth. By Michael Teague. Illustrated. 203 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. 9.95. By CHARLOTTE CURTIS

title: Barbara Sullivan Wed to F.A. Yonkman
description: Barbara Anne Sullivan, a public-affairs consultant in New York, was married yesterday to Fredrick Albers Yonkman, chairman of Outward Bound Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., at St. James Episcopal Church in North Salem, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert H. MacArthur of Hanover, N.H., who is associate director of the Hurricane Island Outward Bound School.

title: THE $138 MILLION MISTAKE
description: Sunday ObserverBy Russell Baker

title: ORGANIZED CRIME SAID TO RULE FULTON FISH MARKET
description: A Federal prosecutor has charged that organized crime dominates the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan, terrorizing legitimate businessmen and threatening them with death if they testify in a continuing investigation.

title: Art View; ALFRED BARR: 'MUSEUM MAN OF THE CENTURY'
description: Without Alfred H. Barr Jr., who died in Salisbury, Connecticut, on Aug. l5, there quite possibly would never have been a Museum of Modern Art on West 53rd Street in New York. There might be an institution of that name somewhere in the city, but it would not be the museum that Barr left on his retirement in 1967 - a walk-through encyclopedia, that is to say, of art, architecture, design, photography and film as they had developed during the first twothirds of this century. That encyclopedia was his dream, and to a considerable extent his creation.

title: Amy L. Hornsby Bride of Edwin J. Fitzpatrick Jr.
description: The marriage of Amy Louise Hornsby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. William Hornsby of Concord, Calif., to Edwin J. Fitzpatrick Jr. took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Fitzpatrick, in Plainfield, N.J. The Rev. Richard L. Van Deusen performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: Careful Shopper; Summer Sales In Scarsdale
description: In the village of Scarsdale, summer sales continue along Spencer Place even after the sidewalk sales are over. Mary Rothman's women's wear specialty shop, 30 years old next February, has most summer items reduced by half, and sometimes 60 to 70 percent, and still provides individual try-on rooms and knowledgeable sales help. Sizes are 3 to 13 for juniors and 6 to 20. All red-ticketed items are final cash sale and merchandise not sold after the progressive reductions will be given away to charities after Labor Day. Nonsale merchandise may be returned for refund or exchange within 10 days, with sales slip and price @ticket.

title: GROWTH REPORTED IN TOURISM
description: THE state's billion-dollar tourist industry is continuing its steady growth, according to figures released last week by the Department of Economic Development.

title: Camera View; THE TECHNIQUE OF COMPOSING PHOTOGRAPHS IN A FLASH
Audrey Elstner Noyes Wed
description: Audrey Elstner Noyes, daughter of Mrs. Blancke Noyes of Darien, Conn., and the late Mr. Noyes, was married yesterday to Richard Michael Ludemann, son of Mrs. Herbert Joseph Ludemann of Bellerose, Queens, and the late Mr. Ludemann. The Rev. Douglas Ray performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: Mary Wade Is Married
description: Mary Jennifer Wade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Wade of Pawling, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joseph Paul Garrity, son of Mrs. Paul F. Garrity of New Hyde Mrs. Paul F. Garrity of New Hyde Park, L.I., and the late Mr. Garrity. The Rev. Kilian Brennan performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. James Moriarty, the pastor.

title: Multi-Town Project Is Challenged
description: In reference to the recent article concerning the Multi-Town Solid Waste Management Authority, I would like to point out that our community finds fault not only with the management of this authority, but also with its location, its size and the manner in which its recent enabling legislation was passed.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 23, 1981
description: International If the U.S. sells surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia it could not prevent them from being used against Israel, according to American officials. They said that under the proposal by President Reagan to sell the Airborne Warning and Control System planes, known as Awacs, there would be no future American control over the planes. In addition, they said, the Saudi Government has not agreed to operational restrictions on the planes or on the high-performance fighter planes that are also being sold to the Saudi Air Force. (Page 1, Column 4.)

title: Art; SEEKING DANCE'S FLUIDITY
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE camera is often its most agile, its most expressive when taking motionless subjects like landscapes, portraits and still lifes. It frequently reveals, though, its greatest ineptitudes when attempting to capture a subject in motion. It can simply pluck the life from something on the move, immobilizing it into a fixed frame.

title: Briton Utilizes Solar Energy To Cross Channel by Balloon
description: A 37-year-old London engineer crossed the English Channel to France in less than two hours today in a hot air balloon kept aloft by solar energy.

title: The Careful Shopper; Back-to-School Sale At Trudy Gary's
description: Trudy Gary, in business 30 years in Westport with better children's clothing, has a back-to-school storewide inventory clearance with prices half-off or below for both innerwear and outerwear and from head to toe. Sizes are infants, toddlers and through preteen for girls and through toddler for boys. All sales are final and there is a 4 percent charge for the use of MasterCard and Visa. There are individual try-on rooms.

title: MARBLED SALAMANDER; Ambystoma opacum
description: Size: Averages four inches. Color: Black with brownish tint on legs, toes and underside of head.

title: On Language
description: Time once again for The Bloopies, those coveted awards to the advertising industry, bestowed annually on the most creative copywriters and laid-back layouters by the Academy of Academic Academicians. (''What do you mean, 'Once again'?'' a member of the redundancy-spotting Squad Squad is bound to write. ''Why not just 'again'?'' Because sometimes I like to use yet another intensifier, that's why.) The envelopes, please:

title: Addendum on Jai Alai And Problems of Crime
description: John S. Rosenberg's article last Sunday on Connecticut's gaming industry (''Gaming Industry Growth Doubtful'') was excellent and serves the public well.

title: Around the World; 5 Civilians Killed In Shelling in Beirut
description: Artillery and rocket barrages between Syrian and Christian forces killed 5 civilians and wounded 47 during the night, the police said today.

title: The Supply Side; On the Down Side
description: Having successfully slid the growth of Federal spending into reverse with barely the clanging of a Congressional gear, the Reagan White House last week started grappling with how to put a heavier foot on the accelerator. As the President's denials that his economic revitalization program is not up to speed made clear, it is not a comfortable exercise.

title: A DEBT TO SOCIETY IS RECOUPED IN PART
description: The United States Courthouse in Brooklyn is normally in the business of dispensing justice. The other day, however, its wares included used television sets and such bric-a-brac as porcelain figurines of prancing elephants, dancing ballerinas and kissing couples.

title: CAN 1944-STYLE SENTIMENT MAKE IT TODAY?
description: The sounds of ''Strange Music'' will shortly be heard rising from the stage of the City Opera. No, not the rude cacophony of a contemporary opera - far from it. ''Strange Music'' is the hit love ballad from ''Song of Norway,'' a musical that triumphed on Broadway in 1944 and receives its first New York City production since that date at the City Opera on Sept. 3. This will be the second offering in the company's now traditional pre-season series of operetta revivals, which opens on Thursday night with ''The Student Prince'' with Elizabeth Hynes, Henry Price and Dominic Cossa. A sigh of recognition will undoubtedly greet the lulling strains of ''Strange Music'' for it was a popular juke-box staple during the last days of World War II, right up there with ''Ac-cent-tchu-ate the Positive,'' ''Rum and Coca Cola'' and ''Irresistible You.''

title: A SECOND CITY VIEW OF SPORTS' FIRST CITY
description: There is a widely circulated opinion found in this town's sports columns and bar booths that ''It's good for ----- (fill in your favorite sport) if there's a successful franchise in New York.'' This is a myth, a petty, parochial myth. I know. I'm from Chicago.

title: AIRLINER THAT CRASHED IN TAIWAN, KILLING 110, HAD PRESSURE SNAGS
description: A Taiwanese jetliner that exploded and crashed near here, killing all 110 people aboard, had been delayed for two hours on the ground because of a pressurization problem in the cockpit, airline officials said today.

title: Fundless Energy Fund
description: The World Bank said that developing countries, faced with oil bills that take up to 60 percent of their foreign exchange, would need $54 billion in the next five years for energy.

title: DISCIPLINE LEADS CONCERNS IN POLL ON SCHOOLS
description: Pupil discipline continues to be perceived as the major problem facing the nation's public schools, but the public's opinion of the schools is no longer declining, according to the 13th annual Gallup Poll on attitudes toward the public schools.

title: OPEC'S SEARCH FOR UNITY ENDS IN DISARRAY
description: Saudia Arabia's drive for a unified oil price failed last week, leaving OPEC in disarray. The Saudis stood firm on their proposal to raise their price by $2 to $34 a barrel if the 12 other OPEC nations would drop their price $2 from their benchmark quote of $36. A compromise to peg the price at $35 failed. The West is hoping that the discord will produce discounts and further crack the OPEC facade. The Saudis, meanwhile, announced plans to cut output 10 percent.

title: WALTER POLOVCHAK'S CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Joyce M. Barrea Wed To Donald Rosenthal
description: Joyce Marie Barrea, daughter of Thomas A. Barrea of Upper Brookville, L.I., and Mary Ann Barrea of Plainview, L.I., was married at ther's home yesterday to Donald J. Rosenthal. Mayor Alfred J. Seaman of Upper Brookville performed the ceremony.

title: Stage View; A THOROUGHLY DELIGHTFUL 'MISALLIANCE'
description: Whenever you go to a revival of a play you truly like, it's always wise to take with you someone - preferably someone younger -who's never seen the play before. Given a good production, as Bernard Shaw's ''Misalliance'' is now being given a good production at the Roundabout Theater's Stage One, a most satisfactory thing is bound to happen. Your companion will of course gratify you by laughing in all the right places and by sitting back in his seat with a contented purr whenever he hears something so deeply agreeable to him that a laugh simply wouldn't be enough. He'll confirm your taste, and that is always pleasing.

title: WOMEN GAINING IN JOURNALISM
description: DURING the late 1960's and early 70's New Jersey newspapers were filled with ''first woman'' stories: the first woman to join a fire company, the first woman executive of a major company, the first woman state trooper.

title: LAPORTE SETS BACK LOCKRIDGE IN FEATHERWEIGHT TITLE FIGHT
description: Juan LaPorte scored the second major upset in the exciting featherweight division within 18 hours when, coming off the ropes with a right hand, he knocked out Rocky Lockridge at 2:52 of the second round and won the United States Boxing Association's 126-pound title.

title: AN ANCIENT FEAR COLORS INDIA-PAKISTAN RELATIONS
description: A senior Indian diplomat was assailing the ''naivete'' of a foreign visitor. ''You simply do not understand the Pakistanis,'' he said. ''I tell you, when I was interviewing the officers we captured in the 1971 war, one after another said they would be back to plant the Pakistan flag on the Red Fort in Delhi.''

title: GIANTS 2, CUBS 1
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Larry Herndon singled to drive in the go-ahead run, and Jack Clark homered and scored twice for San Francisco.

title: New York Times Magazine August 23, 1981
description: William Safire 8 On Language The Bloopie Awards Russell Baker 13 Sunday Observer The $138 Million Mistake Robert Reinhold 16 Uncovering Arabia's Past Frank Church 30 America's New Foreign Policy A Democratic critic argues that the Reagan Administration's rigid anti-Soviet ideology puts it on a collision course with political reality. Vladimir Nabokov 35 Nabokov on Dostoyevsky FOR KIDS Andrea Skinner38 Fashion Elegance for Kids Marilyn Bethany72 Design Something Special for a Child Craig Claiborne 70 Food with Pierre Franey Those Earthy Desserts 81 Puzzles Answers, Page 82 86 Letters Cover: Photograph by Robert Azzi/Woodfin Camp and Associates Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: No Headline
description: Men do not wield power so much as power rides men. Even those most successful individuals in the executive suite bear the scars of battles which are the fodder of their economic success.

title: Around the Garden
description: THIS WEEK: Lawn care should be first on the list, either bringing back estabished turf with weed control, feeding, dethatching and reseeding or planting new ones with top quality seed or sod. Results will depend on the degree of good soil preparation, planting care and proper watering of seed/sod to hasten germination and rooting.

title: MIXING BUSINESS WITH BREAKFAST
description: IN Stamford, it's Danish pastry at the Landmark Club. In Fairfield, it's frequently toast at the Post Road Howard Johnson's. In Stratford, it's more often English muffins at another Howard Johnson's, on Honeyspot Road.

title: Podunk Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: VOYAGER CAMERAS SEND SATURN DATA
description: Voyager 2 sped into the environs of Saturn today, photographing the giant planet's carrousel of bright icy particles, searching for undiscovered satellites and observing in new detail the strange two-toned moon Iapetus.

title: Around the Nation; Kentucky Fair Manager Will Keep Chapel Tent
description: The 1981 Kentucky State Fair ended today with the fair manager determined to bring back a chapel tent next year despite a complaint that the chapel violated the principle of the separation of church and state.

title: Food; A BOARDWALK'S WORLD OF FOOD
description: LONG BEACH IF you forget to pack lunch, a cold, tasteless frankfurter, mealy french fries and weak coffee may be the only sustenance available by the ocean. Catering to impulse buyers taking a break from the summer's heat, beachfront food concessions often fall short on variety and quality.

title: Cable Rights
description: To the Business Editor: Your article on the Copyright Royalty Tribunal, ''Cable TV's Benefactor Comes Under Fire'' (Aug. 9), did not discuss the effect of the compulsory license on consumers.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART The New-York Historical Society - and don't you dare drop that hyphen - is one of the great consistent treasures of our city. It doesn't have jazzy openings or employ a public-relations firm to get itself talked up.

title: Asian Astonomers to Meet
description: About 100 astronomers from 23 countries will attend a five-day international conference, beginning Monday in the resort city of Bandung, 160 miles east of Jakarta, on the development of astronomy in the Asia-Pacific region, a spokesman said today.

title: JOHN STANTON
description: John Stanton, a former writer for Time-Life, died Wednesday at a Manhattan hospital. He was 73 years old. Mr. Stanton began his journalistic career in 1929 on the nowdefunct Long Island Press.

title: UNIVERSITIES JOIN PURSUIT OF FITNESS
description: UNIONDALE IN a departure from the traditional curriculum, a number of Long Island universities have entered the field of preventive sports medicine, offering sports fitness programs to the public on the premise that emphasis on cardiovascular conditioning may not only reduce the risk of heart attack but also lead to physiological rejuvenation.

title: Kathleen S. Sterk Bride in Chicago
description: Kathleen Sue Sterk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dick J. Sterk of Munster, Ind., was married yesterday to Andrew Frederick Brenner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Brenner of New York and Weston, Conn. The Rev. David N. Harris performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. James in Chicago.

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER ''Deathtrap'' has proved to be a most durable comedy thriller. Threeand-a-half years after Ira Levin's play first chilled Broadway audiences, it is still provoking shrieks of fright and laughter.

title: A 10-YEAR EFFORT TO CHRONICLE A FORMIDABLE FAMILY
description: MILTON RUGOFF talks about the Beecher family as easily and familiarly as if it were his own. After almost 10 years of research and writing about their lives and achievements, his collective biography, ''The Beechers: An American Family in the 19th Century,'' was published last week by Harper & Row. It is the story of Lyman Beecher, the Congregationalist minister, and his 11 children, the most famous of whom was the author Harriet Beecher Stowe. And it is the story of changing ideas in a changing century.

title: TAX REFORM LIVES!
description: I N his assessment of the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, ''Reagan's dubious tax revolution'' (Aug. 9), William Nordhaus wrote: ''... the tax reform movement is utterly dead. Compared with earlier major bills - 1964, 1969 or 1976 - the current bill makes no pretense about closing the loopholes.'' Might a participant take another view?

title: Numismatics; GOOD BOOKS AND LEARNING GO HAND IN HAND
description: Good books deserve a large share of the credit for the coin hobby's dizzying growth in recent decades. Two of the hobby's best and most important books have both reached major milestones this summer.

title: Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim; For Two Days, Poland Doesn't Read All About It
description: Solidarity would be the first to agree with Lenin that a newspaper ''is not merely a collective propagandist and collective agitator; it is also a collective organizer.'' Poland's independent union is demanding regular access to state-run newspapers, radio and television and an end to their anti-Solidarity commentary. Newspaper printers struck for two days last week to back up those demands.

title: SOFTBALL VERSUS LAW OF GRAVITY
description: To the Sports Editor: Robert Geake (The New York Times, Mailbox, Aug. 9), who argues that Kathy Arendsen's fastball cannot defy gravity by jumping upwards as perceived by an opposing batter, is right about gravity but forgets about aerodynamics.

title: NEXT, A COMPUTER ON EVERY DESK
description: I T used to be that a little money and a little inventiveness would go a long way in the personal computer business. Apple Computer, it is now legend, was started by two college dropouts working in a garage. The Tandy Corporation, now one of the industry's leaders, invested just $150,000 to develop its first computer.

title: MUSICAL FREEDOM AND WHY DICTATORS FEAR IT
description: In the mid-1930's, according to Dmitri Shostakovich's memoirs, a convention was called in the Soviet Union for Ukrainian folk poets - blind musicians who wandered around the countryside singing of the past. From tiny villages all over the Ukraine, these Lirniki and Banduristy, as they were called, gathered at the First All-Ukrainian Congress to discuss their future in the Soviet Union under Stalin's guidance. ''It was a living museum,'' Shostakovich says, ''the country's living history. All its songs, all its music and poetry.'' There, at the Congress, the blind poets were subjected to ''highest measure of punishment'' for their singing -they were executed.

title: A TOWN IS TROUBLED BY TOXIC WELLS AND PITS
description: With its steepled churches and houses dating to the Revolutionary War, Hudson seems like a typically quaint New England village.

title: URBAN PROBLEMS PUSH DANBURY'S NEW PLANNING
description: DANBURY THE field is still ringed with flying white reindeer, a blue polar bear, a green dinousaur, hippos and penguins and gorillas and elves. Mickey and Minnie Mouse still grin their silent, frozen grins; tall as buildings, Wild Bill Hickok and Paul Bunyon and Uncle Sam still tower over the well-tended but deserted lawns, where only the occasional bird or squirrel treads these days.

title: News Monopoly; Curbs Proposed
description: In Canada, cries for freeing the press are coming from an unusual quarter - the Government. In a report issued last week, a special Government commission condemned a ''monstrous'' concentration of newspaper ownership in Canada which it said sacrificed quality and independence for profits.

title: Alternatives In Childbirth
description: Regarding ''Caesarean Births Rise on L.I.'': As the Caesarean rate climbs, we realize how vital it is that parents receive consumeroriented education for childbirth. It is no longer enough to ''leave everything to the doctor.''

title: AEROBATIC CHAMPIONS TO MEET
description: SUSSEX AEROBATIC pilots, skydivers, wing walkers, parachutists and barnstorming aviators will cut capers above this rural North Jersey region next Saturday and Sunday in the ninth annual Air Show at the Sussex Airport.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Wobbly Baskets
description: Every year the City of New York loses perhaps 2,000 litter baskets to thieves. The 35-gallon wire mesh receptacles have been converted to leaf burners, barbecue grills, basketball hoops and even a coffee table base, the Department of Sanitation reports.

title: Mary Grant Married To Patrick Crawford
description: Mary Catherine Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Grant of New Providence, N.J., was married yesterday to Patrick Gerard Crawford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Crawford of Ballylanders, Ireland.

title: Stamps; RECOGNITION FOR AMERICAN ARCHITECTURE, PART III
description: A block of four stamps, the third segment in a four-part series delineating American architecture from Colonial times to the present, is being issued this Friday in Washington, D.C.

title: PRINCETON MIDDLE SCHOOL GETS A WALL-SIZED GIFT
description: PRINCETON THERE'LL be something new on the wall outside the gymnasium in the John Witherspoon Middle School here this fall - a 17-by-55-foot mural, a gift from the artist, Michael Graves.

title: Carl Lankowski, Mary O'Meara, Teachers, Marry
description: Mary Elizabeth O'Meara, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward S. O'Meara of Waterville, Me., was married yesterday at her parents' home in Hancock Point, Me., to Carl Francis Lankowski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Lankowski of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Susan Clague-Davies, a United of Christ minister, performed the cere- The bride, who is a doctoral candidate in anthropology at Columbia U niversity, teaches at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N .Y., where her husband is on the economics faculty.

title: Gail Smith Weds Dr. Frances Chalmers
description: Dr. Frances Talcott Chalmers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Chalmers of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gail Raymond Smith, son of Mrs. Alexander E. Smith of Annandale, Va., and the late Mr. Smith. The Rev. Sydney Lovett performed the Protestant ceremony on Church Island, Squam Lake, N.H.

title: JUST WHAT YOU NEED FOR THE BEACH
description: Speedy Bikini Repair Kit: In case of accident at the beach. Designed to rectify, on the spot, any rips, tears or broken clasps. Contains string, glue, needle and thread, tape and patches. $2.50.

title: Soviet Politburo Warns Poland on Debt to West
description: The Soviet leadership called on the Polish Communist Party today to adhere to the principles of Marxism as it is practiced in Moscow and act to revive the economy ''without running into excessive debt with the capitalist states.''

title: Politics; SUFFOLK LIBERALS IN LIMBO
description: THE moribund condition of the Liberal Party in Suffolk County was evident with the filing of candidate petitions recently. The party was able to field only nine candidates for some 60 town and county public offices to be filled in the November election.

title: Anne Weisman
description: Anne Waters Weisman and Andrew Spence Hogeland were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in North Pomfret, Vt. The Rev. Dr. H. Ganse Little Jr., chairman of the Williams College religion department, performed the ceremony.

title: Missouri French Fete
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Journal
description: NEW JERSEY'S bookies, who are not subject to government regulation, will nevertheless continue to have a monopoly on betting by phone, even if it is illegal. That's because Attorney General James R. Zazzali has ruled that the State Racing Commission cannot establish a Dial-a-Bet program without an act of the Legislature. That means the plan is dead, at least for now, because Governor Byrne is against it.

title: A 'Panacea' Program That Really Worked
description: Although Vincent S. Steckline presented his ''educational panacea proposal'' with tongue in cheek (Aug. 2), in actual fact a philosophy very similar to that underlying his idea provided the basis for developing a unique educational program that resulted in literally saving the lives of most of the students who participated.

title: WHO'S IN THE KITCHEN WITH DINAH? GARLAND, AMONG OTHERS
description: After taking lessons in Chinese cuisine, where she learned that good cooking is easier on a good stove, Beverly Savage, a reporter for the Newark Star Ledger and an avid amateur cook, went for broke. Remodeling her Hoboken kitchen, she bought a three-foot-wide, sixburner Garland range, a model more usually seen in a restaurant kitchen.

title: INSECT THREATENS RED PINES
description: A NEWLY discovered insect pest, Pineus boerneri, is threatening red pine trees. Believed to have been introduced from Japan, the insect feeds beneath the trees' loose bark flakes and eventually kills them.

title: FOR EGYPT, U.S., BEGIN IS NOT EXACTLY A FUN GUEST
description: Embarked on a second term with the narrowest of margins, Menachem Begin is preparing for two meetings in the next three weeks that could well determine what course his administration will take.

title: NO DEFENSE FOR RUGBY TOUR
description: To the Sports Editor: Tom Selfridge's defense of the upcoming South African Springbok rugby tour rests on false premises ("The South African Rugby Tour," The New York Times, Aug. 2). He clings to the notion that international sports can somehow remain separate from the political climate that surrounds them, but even a cursory glance at the role of sports in society would prove otherwise.

title: Presley's Promise
description: With the money he made giving the world hit records, Elvis Presley gave his friends cars, cash and, it appears, at least one commitment to pay off a friend's mother's mortgage. But he died before he could live up to such a promise to Jo Laverne Alden, mother of Ginger Alden, and his heirs said the promise went with him. Not so, said the Tennesee Court of Appeals last week in ordering the Presley estate to pay off the $40,000 note.

title: QADDAFI'S SHREWD GAMBIT
description: The significance of the aerial combat off Libya last week was not merely that Mr. Reagan showed himself ready to maintain access to air space over the high seas, or that he directed our forces to shoot back - the central fact of the incident was dictator Muammar el-Qaddafi's decision to select this as the moment to assume the role of victim.

title: KNOWLES GRADES TODAY'S PREPPIES
description: SOUTHAMPTON AT the same time that ''The Official Preppy Handbook'' is selling well in the bookstore here, John Knowles, the dean of writers about prep school life, is living in the woods nearby. And if he were graded according to the handbook by a recent visitor, he would not make the honors list.

title: Reading and Writing; WASTEFUL ECONOMIES
description: It might be instructive to take a closer look at the word economy as it is used by critics to praise novels and short stories. While we all understand the ordinary sense of the word - nothing exaggerated, irrelevant or superfluous - it seems to me that its current use contains a number of implicit assumptions that are not so well understood.

title: Footnotes
description: Stephen King has taken complete charge of the fiction possibilities this week. His ''Cujo'' has moved up from fifth to first place on the hardcover list, and his ''Firestarter'' continues in the top mass paperback spot.

title: PRESSURES FOR TAX CHANGE
description: GOVERNMENT in the 1980's seems limited to two painful alternatives: to live with small tax increases so that present programs can be maintained or to massively cut government services in order to hold taxes at their present level. In Connecticut, there is a third, which to some may be the most painful: tax reform.

title: ULSTER: THE LIVING, THE DEAD AND THE ELECTED
description: Late Thursday night, in an antiseptic corridor of a one-story prison hospital outside Belfast, two anguished women made a hard decision. Tortured by the sight of Patrick McGeown going through the agony of starvation, his wife and his mother ordered that he be fed, abruptly ending his political hunger strike at the end of its 42d day. Their decision to save the life of Mr. McGeown, an Irish Republican Army bomber, could have important repercussions in London and Dublin and beyond. The prisoners' hunger strike has dominated the affairs of this troubled province for months.

title: CITY SEEKS PLANS FOR USE OF EAST RIVER ISLAND
description: North Brother Island, 20 acres of forest and pheasants in the East River, may go up for sale to anyone who can suggest a use that meets the city's approval. The Board of Estimate voted Thursday to request proposals to develop the island.

title: FAMILY AND FRIENDS
description: OH! By Mary Robison. 209 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. ADULT EDUCATION By Annette Williams Jaffee. 230 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Ontario Review Press. Distributed by Persea Books, New York. $12.95. By KATHA POLLITT

title: Paperback Talk
description: Cat craze. Back in the spring of 1975, a small Manhattan publisher quietly issued a small paperbound album of cartoons depicting the capers of fat, furry felines. The collection had previously been turned down by editors at the larger houses (''personally, I love them, but I don't think they'd go as a book''). Within a few months, word-of-mouth enthusiasm among America's 50 million cat lovers had enabled B. Kliban's ''Cat'' (Workman Publishing Co.) to claim a place on the trade-paperback best-seller list. To date, it has sold more than 800,000 copies.

title: Recordings; ARE TEEN-AGE SINGERS EXPLOITED?
description: Call it the Brooke Shields Syndrome. Among the most popular records in the United States are a revival of the Moments' hit ''Love on a Two Way Street'' by 14-year-old Stacy Lattislaw, ''Everlasting Love'' by 19-year-old Rachel Sweet and the teen idol Rex Smith, and ''I'm In Love'' by the teen-age singer Evelyn King. For the most part, the lyrics to these hit singles are of the moon-June-spoon variety. But on their albums, these teen-agers and other, less successful young hopefuls are singing decidedly adult fare.

title: THAT STAGE IN LIFE WHEN WE ALL MOVE ON
description: IT took me about three months to identify that ''funny feeling'' (as I came to call it) that began the day my oldest son received the first of several college applications. In the midst of writing my own college papers (a late-blooming academic was I) and juggling the daily businesses that a home with three teen-agers inspires, I was too busy to take stock of that sensation which hovered like a bat around my smiling moments and stuck in my gut like a spur during quieter times.

title: DVORAK'S CHARMING 'JACOBIN'
description: Charm is not a highly salable commodity on American opera stages, where strong passions or sparkling comedy dominate. Many French or Central European works never make it into the repertory, either permanently or at all because they are merely graceful or genial. Czech operas in general fall into this category. Delightful as Smetana's ''The Bartered Bride'' is, it does not seem to hold the stage the way Donizetti's comedies do. Despite a few productions, Dvorak's lovely ''Rusalka'' has never gained a foothold here.

title: THERE'S MORE SHELTER NOW IN REAL ESTATE
description: T HE new tax law has been dubbed a Christmas-in-July gift to investors, and nowhere is its salutary effect clearer than in tax shelters. Tax experts predict that real estate shelters, especially those dealing with rehabilitated property, will particularly benefit because of the dramatic shortening of the depreciation period on real property such as apartments, office buildings and shopping centers.

title: STATE JUSTICE LEFF TO FACE JUDGEMENT
description: James J. Leff has been a justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan since Jan. 1, 1969, and during most of his tenure has been - by his own account -a harsh critic of how the court has been run.

title: Nixon's 1974 Papers Drawing Few Buyers
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon's official papers for his final seven months in the White House - from Jan. 1 to Aug. 9, 1974 - are the slowest-selling volume for any President since the compilation and publication of Presidential papers began.

title: Music; MUSEUM BLENDS JAZZ INTO SERIES
description: FOR many years the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers has played host to fine classical artists, but earlier this month, at the premiere of the museum's Summertime Jazz Series, congo drums and Afro-Latin jazz echoed across the courtyard.

title: Aerial Antics in Central Park
description: No, those were not flying saucers over Central Park. They were Frisbees, being tossed in the 1981 World Junior Contest.

title: 11 CARS DERAILED ON A FREIGHT LINE
description: Eleven cars of a southbound Conrail freight train jumped the track near Wallingford, Conn., early yesterday, knocking down power lines and briefly cutting electrical service to part of the town.

title: No Headline
description: Women who are the victims of rape, violence and unpaid domestic labor will take little consolation from idealistic notions of coparenting and corporate flexitime. A feminism which transcends sexual politics represents a profound betrayal of women. MIDGE QUANDT, New York City

title: Biking in China
description: To the Editor:

title: SMOKE DETECTORS: A DEADLINE
description: Facing an end-of-the year deadline, owners and builders of New York City's residential buildings are gearing up to install smoke detectors required in more than two million apartments.

title: Judge Orders; Cubans Freed
description: The fate of Cuban refugees last week came down to the case of a Federal district judge vs. the Immigration and Naturalization Service. It has been holding 1,800 Cubans in Atlanta's Federal prison for more than a year, during which Carter policy became Reagan policy and Reagan policy was delayed pending review.

title: Speaking Personally; COGITO, ERGO...OH, FORGET IT!
description: CAVEMAN invented fire. But where did he go to think that one up? Did the inspiration occur as he was clubbing some cavewoman over the head and dragging her back to his cavepad? Or did he have a special spot to ponder?

title: No Headline
description: What Betty Friedan has failed to recognize is not only the need ''to free ourselves from the male power traps,'' but from the female power traps as well. Many feminists have become so fanatical in maintaining or furthering their already hard-earned positions that they've discouraged the ambitions and perseverance of other women, seeing them not as co-feminists, but as a collective threat to their power.

title: All That's Missing; Is the Mounties
description: With more and more investigators setting electronic traps for public officials, it was perhaps inevitable that officials would begin using similar means to thwart them. Such a case of crossed wires occurred last week in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: CAMP IN GREECE A HALFWAY POINT FOR REFUGEES
description: Twenty-year-old Teresa, from Gdansk, Poland, has been waiting here for seven months to get clearance to begin a new life in Toronto.

title: Kathleen Horan Is Married
description: At St. Martin of Tours Roman Catholic Church in Bethpage, L.I., yesterday, Kathleen Marie Horan, an operations officer with Citibank, was married to Mark Kenville, a writer for The Associated Press. The Rev. Patrick A. A. Hanley performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Horan of Bethpage, was graduated from St. Bonaventure University, as was Mr. Kenville. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William McGill Kenville of Binghamton, N.Y.

title: WRITER-ACTRESS RUNNING HARD
description: Broadway hit musical ''I Can't Keep Running in Place,'' has been off and running -hard - on stage, ever since her first ''leading role,'' at age 6, in South Orange.

title: CHARGE OF FIRE DEPT. 'SEXISM' STIRS UP CROTON
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 20 - Four 15-year-old girls who say they want to be firefighters when they are older have charged the Croton Volunteer Fire Department with ''sexism'' for ejecting them from a youth fire-training program.

title: The Last of Castro's Castoffs
description: No problem arising from last year's ''boatlift'' of 125,000 Cuban refugees is more vexing than that created by the 1,900 ruled excludable by United States immigration officials. Normally, aliens with criminal records are promptly shipped back home, but in this case Cuban President Fidel Castro won't hear of it. So for more than a year, the 1,900 have remained in a strange limbo. In law, they have not yet been admitted to the United States. In fact, they are doing time, hard time, at the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta.

title: DATA SERVICES MAP THE WAY IN LABYRINTHS OF INFORMATION
description: A prestigious scientific journal, Physics Today, recently published a letter from a New Zealand scientist deploring the introduction of ''yet another journal'' - Solid State Ionics -by a profit-seeking publisher. ''The establishment of these journals deals a blow to all scientists attempting to keep abreast with developments,'' the correspondent wrote. ''It is time physicists took positive action to eliminate this scourge.''

title: Phoning From Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Housing; NORWALK FACILITATES HOME-BUYING
description: NO one seem really sure how long the large Victorian house on Elizabeth Street in South Norwalk had been boarded up and empty, its frame rotting.

title: MICRONESIAN ISLES FIND SELF-RULE WORKS BEST
description: As a kind of farewell gift, the United States is providing money for a five-year program of road improvements and other long-needed projects on the beautiful Pacific island of Ponape.

title: U.S. AND KREMLIN COMPETE IN PACIFIC
description: South Pacific islands that figured prominently in World War II as American military bases have again become a battleground, this time in a competition between the United States and the Soviet Union for influence among the newly independent nations of the region.

title: Dining Out; DIM SUM ON THE EAST END
description: MING'S HSF, the newest branch of HSF, the well-known Chinatown dim sum restaurant, opened this summer in Bridgehampton. The large, rectangular dining room has been done in cool, subtle gray and lavender that deepens to midnight black at the bar. A shiny, silvertoned ceiling adds a slick, sophisticated touch.

title: Beardsley's Record Paces U.S. Victory
description: Craig Beardsley of Harrington Park, N.J., bettered his world record in the 200-meter butterfly today to pace the United States swim team to an insurmountable 139-85 lead over the Soviet Union after the second day of a three-day dual meet.

title: Much Ado About; Secretary Watt
description: James G. Watt, it seems, attracts controversy the way public land attracts mineral prospectors. Last week, Mr. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, not known as a man who kids around, reportedly boasted in an interview that he had pretty well gotten the House Interior Committee under control. He had done that, he said, by in effect telling its chairman, Morris K. Udall, that a pet water project back home in Arizona wouldnot have a top priority until the committee eased up on him.

title: Strife in Sri Lanka
description: For two weeks, some of Sri Lanka's 10 million Sinhalese and 1.4 million Tamil-speaking people have been battling.

title: GREENWICH SCALES DOWN FLEET
description: LAST year, fuel for the Greenwich Police Department's 40 vehicles cost the town about $150,000. This year, with 40 tanks to fill and prices constantly climbing, Chief Raymond Grant decided the problem was big enough to call for a small solution.

title: Oppenheimer Drama Opens Season at the Y
description: The American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y will open its new season of five plays on Sept. 19 with a revival of Heinar Kipphardt's ''In the Matter of J. Robert Oppenheimer,'' directed by Robert Brink. The play, set at the height of the cold war, examines the loyalty of Dr. Oppenheimer, known as the father of the atomic bomb, to the United States Government, and also explores the relationship between scientific research and its eventual use for destructive purposes.

title: Dianne Lee Miller Is Bride Of Garry Hager, Salesman
description: At the Wyckoff (N.J.) Reformed Church yesterday, Dianne Lee Miller was married to Garry Frank Hager by the Rev. David Bach. The bride is a daughter of Frank Miller Jr. of New York, vice president-programs for the CBS Radio Network, and Sonya H. Huhn of Mahwah, N.J. Mr. Hager's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Hager of Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: City Primary Not One For the Meek
description: They may be running for New York City Comptroller, but personal finances, not public ones, dominated the campaign last week between incumbent Harrison J. Goldin and his challenger in the Democratic primary, Assemblyman John C. Dearie.

title: OPEC Gives Up; On Price Accord
description: All during the world economic slump that their precipitous price increases helped bring about, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia has been trying to teach his oil-exporting colleagues about market economics. Last week at Geneva, OPEC came close - within $1 per barrel -to getting the message, but other views prevailed and after five days of stormy debate, the oil ministers dispersed as they had come, in disarray.

title: Film View; WEIGHING THE FACTUAL CONTENT OF MOVIES
description: In recent weeks, a typically broad spectrum of new film releases has touched all bases: we've seen glimpses of political unrest in El Salvador, more upheaval in Nicaragua, the history of Northern Ireland, life in contemporary Poland, police procedures in New York City and punk rock. In each of these cases, whether the film in question is a documentary or drama, its success has depended largely upon the fashion in which it conveys its technical information.

title: U.S. AIDES CONCEDE SAUDIS BAR LIMITS ON USE OF AWACS
description: If the United States sells five advanced radar monitoring planes to Saudi Arabia, it will have no power to prevent them from being used against Israel, American officials say.

title: Westchester Housing; REAL COST OF SOLAR-HEATED WATER
description: ASOLAR hot-water system became cheaper last month, when Governor Cary approved a state income tax credit of 15 percent of its cost for homeowners who install one - but many Westchester residents are still trying to determine the actual dollar saving of switching to solar.

title: TROUPE AIMS PROVINCIAL JOKES AT ALL CANADA
description: Question: What has 10 legs, five mouths and a hundred different voices? Answer: The Royal Canadian Air Farce, an eclectic collection of comedians that has managed to survive for eight years by poking fun at just about everything a Canadian could possibly hold dear.

title: Realty News; Fort Lee, N.J.
description: Kwasha Lipton, an employee benefits consulting firm, has leased 60,000 square feet of office space at the Bridge Plaza North office building in Fort Lee, N.J. It will lease an additional 20,000 square feet in 10 years.

title: U.S. Sends Libya And the World a Forceful Message
description: Although aides allowed him a full night's rest before telling him that American planes had shot down two Libyan jet fighters, President Reagan probably would not have regretted the lost sleep. Last week's dogfight over the Mediterranean was a far less complicated and much more successful show of force than the last acknowledged combat incident involving American forces, the rescue of the Mayaguez from Cambodian pirates in 1975.

title: No Headline
description: The recent articles on Caesarean sections were important, informative and newsworthy.

title: A CHANCE TO LIVE RIGHT ON THE RUNWAY
description: Living next to an airstrip may not be everybody's idea of paradise, but it had been Davidson Smith's dream for years and he did not think he was alone.

title: Lord Avie Is Retired
description: Lord Avie, the Eclipse Award winner as the top 2-year-old last year and a leading 3-year-old contender this season, was retired today. He will be flown to Spendthrift Farm in Kentucky tomorrow to begin his stud career next year.

title: COURT WEIGHS CASINO DISPUTE
description: CAMDEN THE fate of Atlantic City's largest union may be decided by a Federal Court rather than by the state's Casino Control Commission. On Aug. 5 the commission ruled that it had authority under the state's Casino Control Act to regulate unions representing casino hotel employees. It ordered Local 54 of the Hotel, Motel, Restaurant Employees and Bartenders Union to appear for a hearing Sept. 9 on whether it should be decertified as representative of some 10,000 workers at Atlantic City's eight casino hotels.

title: INVESTIGATORS SAY THAT EVIDENCE IN ATTACK ON LIBYAN GOES UNUSED
description: Federal and local prosecutors have not actively pursued a large body of evidence that investigators believe links the suspect in the attempted assassination of a Libyan student here last year to a former agent for the Central Intelligence Agency, according to officials here and in Washington.

title: TOWNS STUDY RULES TO SAVE FARMS
description: WHATEVER the fate of Suffolk's Farmlands Preservation Program in the County Legislature on Tuesday, officials in three of the four East End towns believe local land-use measures are essential to preserve large amounts of farmlands and open space in the face of increased pressure for development.

title: Humor in the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Art; ART: BRITISH PAINT ITALY, 7140-1830
description: NEW HAVEN ''CLASSIC GROUND: British Artists and the Landscape of Italy, 1740-1830'' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven through Sept. 20 is a puzzling, distressing show that yet contains some rarely seen and quite wonderful works of art. The first question it raises is to what extent art museums should be devoted to the exhibition of beautiful things. For this writer the answer has for years seemed clear: almost entirely. There is, of course, a place for the occasional oddity, especially if it is amusing, but by and large the public, at least, expects to see beautiful things when it goes to art museums. There are a good many of these in this show at Yale, but there are also undeniably a number of what are usually called dogs, some of them barking all too audibly.

title: DELAYS PLAGUE MOTOR VEHICLE OFFICES
description: WESTBURY LONG ISLAND motorists have been standing on line long hours at their state motor vehicle offices, primarily because of frequent breakdowns in the recently installed computer system. But they may have to endure even greater delays, if additional changes now being contemplated by state and county officials are instituted.

title: DRUG AGENCY CHIEF WEIGHS CURBING UNDERCOVER AGENTS
description: The acting chief of the Drug Enforcement Administration says he may impose new controls on undercover operations by Federal narcotics agents.

title: SCHOOL DAYS: HOW TO SURVIVE
description: SEPT. 2 will be like no other day. On that Wednesday my son will start school. But unlike other mothers who are about to lose their first-born to the public-school system, I will not anguish over his leaving. I will not fret over his safety and well-being. I will not worry about his adjusting.

title: King Hussein Visits Spain
description: King Hussein of Jordan and Queen Noor, his American-born wife, left today for Spain on a brief private visit during which the King was expected to meet King Juan Carlos, the official Jordanian press agency reported.

title: Realty News; ABRAMS REJECTS PLAN AS UNCONSCIONABLE
description: New York Attorney General Robert Abrams has rejected a Manhattan building owner's $11.6 million plan to convert 78 rental apartments at 1230 Park Avenue into a cooperative. Mr. Abrams called the proposal ''unconscionable.''

title: Denver Library Adopts A $10 Nonresident Fee
description: The Library Commission here, over the opposition of its chairman, has voted to charge nonresidents $10 a day or $100 a year to use Denver's public library.

title: Deborah Cofield Is Bride
description: Deborah Lou Cofield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winfred R. Cofield of Ranburne, Ala., was married yesterday to James W. Davidson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alton W. Davidson of Bessemer, Ala.

title: No Headline
description: An obituary of Charles Chapler last Sunday omitted the name of one survivor. His wife was the former Ruth Klein.

title: A Profitable; Slice of Life
description: In December came the first patent on recombinant DNA, or ''gene splicing,'' processes in which scientists manipulate the genetic material of living cells. Now, Stanford University and the University of California at San Francisco are preparing to enjoy projected profits from their patented gene-splicing techniques, offering the first major licensing agreement covering their use.

title: Springboks Win; Marches Continue
description: The Springboks rugby team of South Africa posted an 83-0 victory today over a local team in the eighth match of its New Zealand tour as street protests continued throughout the nation.

title: Editors' Choice
description: ANGEL OF LIGHT, by Joyce Carol Oates. (E.P. Dutton, $15.50.) A modern retelling of the Atreus story. ETHNIC AMERICA, by Thomas Sowell.

title: STANFORD DENIES COVER-UP OF RESEARCH FRAUD
description: Stanford University has denied charges that it covered up possible fraud in federally financed medical research.

title: TELETHON ASKS JOBS FOR YOUTH
description: THE Yonkers Summer Youth Employment Program is entering the final week of its Job Telethon and last week Frank Centeno, who is coordinating the project, discussed the response so far. ''We would like to see more participation,'' he said, ''in a program that gives an opportunity to economically disadvantaged youth.''

title: Surgeon General Rules Changed in Budget Bill
description: A little-noticed provision in the 1982 budget bill has opened the way for President Reagan to nominate Dr. Everett Koop, a noted opponent of abortion, to be the Surgeon General of the United States.

title: WHAT INDEXING INCOME TAXES PRODUCED FOR CANADA
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia I N 1973, when Canada's then Minister of Finance, the honorable John N. Turner, announced a plan to index the country's personal income tax rates to inflation, he proclaimed that ''Canada will join a very select group of countries which have eliminated the hidden revenues accruing to governments through the effect of inflation on a progressive tax system.'' Now, as President Reagan and the United States prepare to join this exclusive club, an increasing number of Canadian Government officials and others wish that Canada could get out.

title: Dance View; EXTRAORDINARY DANCES FOR NON-DANCERS
description: Johanna Boyce, one of the young choreographers chosen for the ''Emerging Generation'' programs of this year's American Dance Festival in North Carolina, is a choreographer whose works look back to the 60's. Yet they are very much at home in these early days of the 80's. One could even argue that, though they derive from the 60's, the ideals they uphold are ones that some people may find increasingly important as the 80's roll onward.

title: JETS' PASSES SET BACK GIANTS, 37-24
description: Richard Todd, seldom bothered by the Giants' ineffective pass rush, passed the Jets to a 37-24 victory over the Giants tonight in a National Football League exhibition game before a crowd of 74,962 at Giants Stadium.

title: Practical Traveler; CLEARING CUSTOMS: STILL A HURDLE
description: If, when international flights are operating normally, you enter the United States at Kennedy International Airport in New York, you may be walking out of the arrivals terminal less than half an hour after your plane parks at the arrival gate. But you stand an equal chance of being delayed two hours or longer. You may spend perhaps 45 minutes of that time in the parked plane because a lot of wide-bodied jetliners have landed within a few minutes of each other and the terminal facilities are jammed.

title: Pirates Accuse Cubs Of Tampering Violation
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have filed a tampering complaint over remarks reportedly made by an unidentified official of the Chicago Cubs.

title: Checkout Time; At the Biltmore
description: Like many who have had appointments under the gilded clock in the Biltmore Hotel's Palm Court, private groups seeking to preserve the hotel's grand salons arrived late. Having failed with last-ditch legal action to halt the destruction of three of those rooms, the preservationists last week shifted their attention to saving what they could of what remained.

title: Battery Park - Less Awesome, More Feasible
description: With its 92 acres nearly as empty as the promises that heralded its coming, it might have been more accurately called Battery Park Beach. But last week, as the New York State Urban Development Corporation announced its latest housing plans for the mile-long landfill along the Hudson, it seemed that Battery Park was destined to become a City after all.

title: FILLY BREAKS AND TIES MARKS
description: Sugar Move, a 2-year-old pacer, shattered the track record and equaled a world record yesterday as she won the $45,000 New York Sire Stakes at the Syracuse Mile.

title: TIME KEEPS A FAMILY STRONG
description: NEW HAVEN EVERYONE knows all about the Mayflower, the ship that brought the Pilgrims to the New World in 1620, but for the Strong family, whose numbers are legion, the trans-Atlantic voyage made 10 years later by the Mary and John is more significant. For it was aboard this vessel that their ancestor, Elder John Strong, made his trip from England to the shores of Massachusetts.

title: Lahore
description: To the Editor:

title: ESPOSITO AND BARBARO ASSESS CITY'S FISCAL AFFAIRS BARBARO: 'MORE MONEY FOR SERVICES'
description: Managing the fiscal affairs of a city with a $15 billion budget is a complex task. Much more is needed to do this job well than a blind determination to meet the legal requirement of a balanced budget. That alone does not produce a healthy economy.

title: TO HIT A SOVIET TANK - COST-EFFECTIVELY
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY TOY STORE BOWS TO CHANGE
description: Rappaport's Toy Bazaar, a large and venerable store at 1381 Third Avenue near 79th Street, has long been famed for its polka-dotted wrapping paper, for its polka-dotted delivery trucks and for staying open until midnight on Christmas Eve in case parents had problems.

title: Settlement by Gas Company
description: A New York industrial gas company accused of rigging bids and overcharging Virginia more than $30,000 has agreed to an out-of-court settlement with the state. The $19,000 settlement with the Refrigeration Sales Company of Long Island City, Queens, was a result of recommendations by a special grand jury here that investigated bribery, bid-rigging and corruption in Virginia's purchasing programs.

title: CITY IS PRESSING STATE TO OBTAIN U.S. SEWAGE AID
description: Facing a loss of $100 million in Federal aid to the state for water pollution control and sewage disposal plants next year, New York City officials are pressing the state to apply for a transfer of other Federal funds to complete local projects.

title: NEW ROLE IN INVESTING FOR QUEBEC
description: When the shareholders of Domtar Inc., Canada's second-largest forest products company, picked up their morning newspapers last Wednesday, they discovered that the Province of Quebec owned nearly half of the company's common shares.

title: Dani Shapiro Is Married to Dan Mitchell Storper
description: Daneile Joyce Shapiro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Shapiro of Hillside, N.J., was married yesterday to Dan Mitchell Storper, son of David Harrison Storper of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Mrs. Storper.

title: Daniel & Charles Gains Safety Razor Billings
description: Daniel & Charles has been named to handle more advertising for the American Safety Razor Company's razor brands, with billings estimated at $4 million, according to trade sources.

title: HERNANDEZ SPARKS CARDS' 11-7 TRIUMPH
description: A sprained right ankle and a pulled muscle in the same leg failed to slow Keith Hernandez yesterday. Hernandez, the St. Louis Cardinals' 27-year-old first baseman, hit his seventh home run of the season, added a double and two singles in five times at bat and drove in two runs in an 11-7 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers in St. Louis.

title: Miss Casale Wins
description: Pam Casale of Fairfield, a 17-year-old rookie on the professional tour, routed Marjorie Blackwood of Canada, 6-0, 6-1, today in the first round of the $100,000 Volvo Cup at Ramapo College.

title: Mayor Gibson's Odd Lesson
description: Surely citizens of Newark deserved a better response from Mayor Kenneth Gibson to the indictment of Carl Sharif, the city's school board president, for attempted murder.

title: Foreign Affairs; SPAIN: A NERVOUS NEW ALLY?
description: Despite the harrowing attempted putsch last Feb. 23, King Juan Carlos of Spain remains the calm, direct, basically confident monarch he was before.

title: Around the World; Bani-Sadr's Wife Says She Was Jailed in Iran
description: The wife of the ousted Iranian President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, said today that she was jailed and her life threatened in Iran before she and her 8-year-old son were able to flee the country.

title: ROCK: STYX FROM CHICAGO AT THE GARDEN
description: STYX, the Chicago rock quintet that appeared at Madison Square Garden on Friday, brought the arena to an emotional peak that this observer hasn't seen since Bruce Springsteen appeared there last December. The band's accomplishment was unexpected, because, to judge from its records, the only thing special about it is its puritanism.

title: SEISCOM DELTA CHANGE
description: Thomas B. Portwood Jr., 56, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Seiscom Delta Inc., a seismic surveying and energy search company. He succeeds D. Gale Reese, 47, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Houston-based corporation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Corp. and the Chase Manhattan Bank have elected to their boards Donald H. Trautlein, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

title: U.S. PREVAILS IN SWIMMING
description: The United States national swim team completed a 203-141 rout of the Soviet Union today by splitting the final 10 events of their three-day dual meet.

title: AFTER A DECADE, PROPERING NEWPORT CELEBRATES THE JAZZ FESTIVAL'S RETURN
description: Several thousand miles west in Vancouver, British Columbia, last May, Stewart Jeans turned the page of the local newspaper, The Province, and saw an article that said George Wein was going to bring his jazz festival back to Newport.

title: YOUNG PITCHERS GIVE METS SOME HOPE
description: CINCINNATI THEY'RE not young kids anymore, but they're not exactly veteran pitchers, either. They've knocked around the minors long enough to appreciate what it means to be in the big leagues. And with three of the Mets' top starters disabled, they realize that this may be the best chance they'll have to prove what they can do.

title: BLACKS IN U.S. ARE BECOMING MORE PESSIMISTIC, POLLS HINT
description: Black Americans are growing increasingly gloomy about the present condition of the nation and pessimistic about its future, according to analyses of several national polls and interviews with leading students of black opinion.

title: PRUSSIA REDISCOVERED IN WEST GERMAN DISPLAY
description: WEST BERLIN ''PRUSSIA is part of our history,'' Ingrid Mittenzwei, an East German historian, said in a study on Frederick the Great not long ago. ''People cannot choose their national traditions,'' she added. ''They must acknowledge them and then take a stand.''

title: Washington Watch; Iran Rebuilds Its Oil Market
description: WASHINGTON IRAN, which cannot sell all the oil it produces even at today's sharply reduced rates of output, is trying to repair its bridges with American oil companies, apparently in efforts to recover some of its lost markets, according to Treasury Department monitors.

title: WOMEN'S TENNIS: TANTRUMS, PROTESTS
description: TORONTO BETTINA BUNGE stalked off the court at 0-5 in the third set, Pam Shriver verbally insulted Tracy Austin, Hana Mandlikova fired an obscene gesture at a linesman, and almost everyone criticized the computer.

title: Siran Hovnanian Is a Bride
description: Siran H. Hovnanian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hirair S. Hovnanian of Deal, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Douglas Mardigian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mardigian of Birmingham, Mich. The Armenian Apostolic ceremony was performed by Archbishop Shahe Ajamian, Armenian Patriarchate of Jerusalem and cousin of the bride's mother, at St. Vartan's Armenian Cathedral in New York.

title: TRANSACTIONS;
description: BASKETBALL

title: A Hospital Complaint Plan
description: Patients at two Atlanta area hospitals will not have to pay for unsatisfactory nursing care, bad food and unclean rooms. Parkway Regional Hospital at Lithia Springs, an Atlanta suburb, and West Paces Ferry Hospital in Atlanta, both owned by the Hospital Corporation of America, have begun this program to improve hospital service. Solon Boggus, the administrator at Parkway Regional, said, ''We guarantee that all call lights will be answered within five minutes.''

title: J. T. Rosenblum Weds Dr. Marcia R. Taylor
description: At Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers yesterday, Dr. Marcia R. Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aron Taylor of Yonkers, became the bride of Jeremy T. Rosenblum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rosenblum of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbis Samuel Scolnic and Abraham Klausner officiated.

title: U.S. ISSUES DOMINATE THE SCHEDULE
description: Treasury and Federal agency issues promise to dominate new financing activity this week in the fixed-income market. Corporate financing, meanwhile, will remain light for the fourth consecutive week, reflecting the high cost of borrowing. Market participants estimate that the corporate calendar for August probably will total less than $1 billion, compared to nearly $3 billion in new issues for the same month in 1980.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A player in the National Basketball Association goes up for a jump shot. While he is in the air, the ball pops out of his hands, but he catches it immediately and makes the basket before his feet touch the floor. Is this considered a legal play?

title: Index; International
description: Nicaragua hopes the next U.S. Ambassador matches the last A2 Israel is a large supplier of arms but keeps details secret A3 Around the World A5 South African woman, banned 17 years, regains political voice A6 Haig says Reagan is ready to meet Soviet Union halfway A8 Conservative leader to join Portu- guese government A10 Government/Politics Barbaro and Esposito give views on city's fiscal affairs B6 General Around the Nation A12 A jazz festival returns to a differ- ent Newport, R. I. A12 Proponents of organic farming meet in Vermont A13 After a weekend away, all roads lead to home - unfortunately B1 Study finds New Jersey dams need repair B1 New Rochelle opens park on Oak- wood Island B1 The City B3 Kite fliers, angry at copter sum- mons, take protest to the skies B3 The Region B5 Hawaii battles old foe, the fruit fly B8 37 Atlanta children leave New York after a vacation D15 Health/Science Voyager searches for moons among Saturn's rings B9 Laboratory to study Reye's syn- drome officially opens B15 Style Relationships: Familial stresses of the disabled B14 A family toy store bows to change B14 Newport celebrates a tennis cen- tenary B14 SportsMonday Baseball: Yankees, Guidry de- feat Royals, 8-0 C1

title: Rose's Lucky Number
description: The career record that Pete Rose set for hits in the National League was 3,631. As quickly as possible the people who play hunches in state lotteries bought that number and variations of its digits. Sure enough, the number 3613 came up not in one state, but in Delaware and New Jersey.

title: Carter to Visit China Today
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, who normalized relations with China in 1979, is scheduled to arrive in Peking tomorrow on his first visit. Mr. Carter, who presided over the re-establishment of full diplomatic relations with Peking, was invited to come by Deng Xiaoping, China's principal leader, when he toured the United States in 1979.

title: UTILITIES' PLANNED DIVESTITURES IN MIDWEST STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: Two Middle West gas companies are planning spinoffs that could send shock waves through the industry. Faced with the twin effects of rising costs and regulated rates, the Chicago-based Peoples Energy Corporation and the Detroit-based American Natural Resources Company are attempting to raise their return on investment by divesting their more profitable gas production and transmission operations from the heavily regulated and less profitable utility operations.

title: WORLD CONTROLLERS SAY THEY BACK STRIKE BUT AVOID IMMEDIATE MOVE
description: The global organization of air traffic controllers agreed today to back the striking United States controllers with labor action, if necessary.

title: Around the World; One Body Still Missing In Taiwan Air Disaster
description: Two more bodies were recovered late yesterday in the wreckage of a Taiwanese jetliner. A search continued this morning for the body of the last of the 110 people killed in Taiwan's worst air disaster.

title: Gminski to Leave Hospital
description: Mike Gminski, the New Jersey Nets' No.1 center who has been hospitalized since Aug. 1 with a viral infection, is scheduled to be released later this week from the New Jersey College of Medicine in Newark. He injured his lower back while playing for the Nets' entry in the Southern California Pro Basketball League.

title: The Region; L.I. Couple Held In Child Abuse
description: A man and a woman he lived with were ordered held on $175,000 bail on charges that they beat and tortured the man's two teen-age daughters.

title: NICARAGUA HOPES NEXT U.S. ENVOY EQUALS THE LAST
description: Just days before winding up an assignment here, a popular foreign Ambassador was honored recently at a private luncheon given by the junta and top Sandinist commanders. They wanted to show their appreciation for his efforts to improve relations between his Government and Nicaragua's revolutionary regime.

title: PATCO'S WRONG MOVE
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPTROLLER CANDIDATE
description: C. Todd Conover, a 41-year-old partner in a San Francisco consulting company, is a candidate to become the United States Comptroller of the Currency, the Treasury Department official with oversight of more than 4,000 Federally chartered banks. The post has been filled on an acting basis since May by Charles Lord, 53, who, the White House said, will be nominated as vice chairman and first vice president of the Export-Import Bank. John D. Heimann, 52, who stepped down as Comptroller May 15, became chairman of the executive committee of Warburg Paribas Becker, an international securities firm, last month.

title: IRWIN WINS IN 4-WAY PLAYOFF
description: Hale Irwin faltered on the last nine holes but made a 20-foot putt for a birdie on the second playoff hole today and won the $350,000 Buick Open.

title: The Region; Man Is Charged In Brother's Death
description: A kitchen worker has been charged with murder after he reportedly slit his brother's throat in the dining room of the Hackensack Golf Club, carried the body across a patio and then left it in the pro shop, the police said.

title: Compton Group Names Klemtner Chief to Post
description: Albert P. Molinaro Jr., president and chief executive officer of Klemtner Advertising, an ethical-pharmaceutical specialty shop acquired by Compton Advertising two years ago, has been named director of Compton Group Operations.

title: U.S. Designates Four To Get Youth Medals
description: Four young people from Wisconsin, Arkansas, Maryland and Puerto Rico were named winners of the Young American Medals for Bravery and Service today by Attorney General William French Smith.

title: Gail Gold, A Nurse, Is Bride of James N. Ellowitch
description: Gail Gold, daughter of Shirley Fox of Springfield, N.J., and the late David Fox, was married yesterday to James N. Ellowitch. Rabbi Morrison Bial performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Summit, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon H. Ellowitch of Springfield, N.J., and Lake Worth, Fla.

title: The U.N. Today; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10?30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ------------ Tickets are available at the Public desk in the main lobby, United Nations headquarters. Tours: 9 A.M. - 4:45 P.M.

title: Notes on People; 2 Navy Vice Admirals in a Ceremonious Job Swap
description: It was a simple job swap, but since it was the Navy that was doing the swapping, there was a colorful ceremony Saturday as Vice Adm. Edward C. Waller was formally installed as the 50th Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md.

title: John Koppel, Lawyer, Weds Rosa M. Gottlieb
description: The marriage of Rosa M. Gottlieb and John S. Koppel, 1981 graduates of the New York University School of Law, took place yesterday at the Kittle House Inn in Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Chaim Stern performed the ceremony.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, AUGUST 24, 1981
description: International Support of Soviet-style Communism was demanded by Moscow in a warning to its Eastern bloc allies that they must strictly maintain orthodoxy to prevent another upheaval similar to Poland's. The message was published on the front pages of Soviet newspapers. Western diplomats said that the warning was the clearest indication yet of Moscow's concern that the disorder in Poland could spill over into other Eastern bloc countries and undermine Soviet domination. (Page A1, Column 6.) Civil war has resumed in Lebanon between the country's political factions since the recent Israeli-Palestinian truce. Nearly 100 people have been killed in the past month in sporadic political fighting, most of it between leftists groups. (A1:5-6.)

title: THE FAVORITES ARE COMING UP SHORT AT SARATOGA
description: usually the most formful events with the highest percentage of winning favorites.

title: TITLE-FIGHT BIDDING ON RISE, KING SAYS
description: The bidding for the Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney heavyweight title fight, with one offer of $23.75 million already having been made, has only started, Don King, one of the promoters, said yesterday.

title: Advertising; JWT's Spreading Umbrella
description: WORKERS are putting the finishing touches on the stainless-steel sculpture suspended in the Park Avenue Atrium, the glittering new headquarters of the JWT Group, come October. Hill & Knowlton, which JWT aquired 14 months ago, inherits the hacienda-style offices in the Graybar Building, and its attractively priced lease.

title: KITE FLIERS, IN A PROTEST, TAKE BATTLE TO THE SKIES
description: In the case of the kite v. the police helicopter, the precourt motion was upward yesterday as more than a hundred kite fliers joined near Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn to send an airborne protest to city authorities.

title: A SOWETO WOMAN REGAINS HER POLITICAL VOICE
description: Albertina Sisulu has just recovered her voice. Her problem was not medical but political, in the form of what are known in South Africa as banning orders.

title: ARMS ARE A CRUCIAL EXPORT FOR ISRAEL
description: Last week's statement by Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the deposed President of Iran, that Islamic leaders decided to buy arms from Israel during the American hostage crisis has focused fresh attention on the Israelis' role in the world arms market.

title: Nancy Conz First
description: Nancy Conz of East Hampton, Mass., won the fourth annual Avon International Marathon Championship for women today in an unofficial time of 2 hours 36 minutes 44 seconds. Second place went to favored Joan Benoit of Cape Elizabeth, Me., who finished in 2:37:23. Julie Isphording of Cincinnati was third in 2:38:24, and Kiki Sweigart of Darien, Conn., was fourth.

title: Market Place; Storage's Computer Gain
description: THE Storage Technology Corporation, often perceived as a high-risk holding, could be selling in the stock market at an unduly low price. That's the argument in two research reports issued last week. Selling at roughly 13 times the earnings expected for the current year, Storage is believed by the analysts to carry an unusually low multiple for an important technology company with an advanced product line. The shares closed Friday at 30 1/2, down 5/8.

title: PECULIAR PERCEPTIONS BY MICHAEL MANLEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal of $15 Million For Quarter Horse
description: Special Effort, an undefeated colt striving to win the triple crown for quarter horses, has been syndicated at a record $15 million for horses in training.

title: JERSEY TOWN USES CURFEW TO KEEP ITS QUIET IMAGE
description: Every evening at 8:45 in this small riverside town, a siren sounds, warning youths under 18 that they must be off the streets in 15 minutes.

title: Elin Spring Bride of Nathan Kaufman
description: Elin Felice Spring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard P.
