Spring of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday in the garden at her parents' home to Nathan Evan Kaufman, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Kaufman of Chevy Chase, Md. The nondenomination ceremony was performed by the Rev. Peter Samsom of the Community Unitarian Church of White Plains.

title: The City; Hostage Unit Aide Is Shifted by Police
description: Capt. Francis A. Bolz Jr., who has coordinated the New York City Police Department's hostage negotiating team since its establishment eight years ago, is being given additional duties as commander of one of the department's five detective zones in Manhattan.

title: Value of U.S. Farm Exports Could Fall in '82
description: The value of United States farm exports could slip next year, ending a 12-year string of record highs, unless the situation improved greatly in the coming months, the Agriculture Department said in a report issued Friday.

title: CRIME AND CONTRIBUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On New York City Schools Wrong Way to Choose Principals
description: To the Editor:

title: Weiskopf Winner
description: Tom Weiskopf of the United States won his first tournament in two years today, shooting a three-under-par 69 to capture an international open golf tournament by one stroke.

title: Schlichter Cases Draw Complaints
description: Several Franklin County Municipal Court judges have received complaints about the handling of traffic cases against Art Schlichter, the Ohio State University quarterback.

title: ON WEEKENDS, ALAS, ALL ROADS LEAD HOME
description: The summer weekend in the country is a splendid thing: fresh air and vegetables, beaches and concerts, barbecues and bare feet. There is only one tiny flaw, and its name is Sunday night, otherwise known as coming back to the city.

title: Australian Film Festival at the Griffith; Australian Film Festival At the D.W. Griffith
description: Begining Sept. 11 with ''My Brilliant Career,'' the D.W. Griffith Theater, on East 59th Street, will show past and new films from Australia and New Zealand. The theater's new policy is a joint venture between Cinema 5 Theaters, its owner, and Satori Productions, an entertainment concern based in the city.

title: Miss Orzack Wed To Daniel Moore
description: Karen Orzack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett D. Orzack of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday in a garden ceremony at the Bee and Thistle Inn in Old Lyme, Conn., to Daniel C. Moore. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Burness E. Moore of Atlanta, formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. B. Davie Napier, a Protestant minister and master of Calhoun College at Yale University, performed the ecumenical ceremony.

title: Harriet Schwartz Wed to G.B. Crew
description: Harriet Sue Schwartz was married yesterday in Philadelphia to Geoffrey Bennett Crew. The ceremony was performed at the Barclay Hotel by Rabbi Seymour Rosen.

title: FOR HAWAII, CROP PEST IS AN OLD FOE
description: Hawaiians, who have lived with various types of fruit and melon flies for nearly 100 years, are worried about losing world markets for tropical fruit as a result of growing concern over the spread of the crop-damaging insects.

title: Feeling Like a Million
description: Kathy Whitworth, a golfer who has won 80 tournaments in her 23 years on the professional circuit, laughs as she says it: ''When you joined the tour you never thought you were going to make a million dollars. Now, of course, it's feasible.''

title: Notes on People; Ultimate in Authenticity
description: The way Muriel Harris explained it the other day, the Golden Nugget hotel-casino in Atlantic City has no use for six tropical birds that refuse to chirp and sing, so they're being shipped off to the Philadelphia Zoo.

title: 22 MORE FILMS IN NEW YORK FESTIVAL LISTED
description: Besides the five films already announced for showing at the 19th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, 22 more were announced yesterday by Richard Roud, director of the festival and chairman of the program comittee.

title: PHILIP AGEE'S SOURCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Gail Susan Rickman Wed To David Nathan on L. I.
description: Gail Susan Rickman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rickman of Hollywood, Fla., formerly of Freehold, N.J., was married yesterday to David Nathan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Nathan of Flushing, Queens.

title: TIGERS' STREAK, EXTENDED TO 9, IS CREDITED TO PITCHING COACH
description: Dave Tobik has traded in his slider for a curve. Milt Wilcox has been taught to throw the fork ball. Every pitch that Kevin Saucier, Dave Rozema, Tobik or George Cappuzzello throws for the Detroit Tigers has been selected by Roger Craig.

title: HOW SHOULD HUMANS PAY THEIR WAY
description: We like to think of ourselves as the most special things on earth, uniquely endowed with intelligence and awareness, the owners and operators in charge of the place, but this is a notion we will probably have to outgrow. If we try to hang onto the view too long we run the risk of not outliving it. We cannot survive indefinitely thinking of the earth as a kind of combination domestic animal and kitchen-garden placed at our disposal for consumption, by luck or providence. We are obliged, like all other living beings, to pay our way.

title: 2 Monsanto Holdings Sold
description: The Monsanto Company said it had completed the $275 million sale to Conoco Inc. of its interests in their joint ventures in Louisiana and Texas.

title: Around the Nation; Study Links Deaths To Crowding in Prisons
description: Long-term inmates of overcrowded prisons die, commit suicide, become ill and create disciplinary problems more frequently than those confined in private cells of at least 50 square feet, according to a federally financed study released today.

title: STING WINS OPENER IN N.A.S.L. PLAYOFFS
description: While the Cosmos, who have a bye in the first round of the North American Soccer League playoffs, had a cross-country run as part of a workout in New Jersey yesterday, the Chicago Sting, the team seen as the biggest threat to replace the Cosmos as champions, scored a 3-2 victory over the Seattle Sounders in Chicago in their playoff opener.

title: Relationships; FAMILIAL STRESS OF DISABLED
description: T HE jet carrying Frances Barish to the Caribbean had just landed, and the cheerful flight attendant walked over to Mrs. Barish's seat to see if her passenger needed help moving to her wheelchair. The flight attendant looked brightly at Mrs. Barish's husband. ''Can she walk?'' she asked him.

title: Brazil Studies 12-Mile Limit
description: Brazil is considering dropping its 11-year claim to a 200-mile coastal territorial limit in favor of a possible 12-mile limit, the Jornal do Brasil newspaper reported today.

title: Around the Nation; Notre Dame's President Offers Solution on Aliens
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, the president of the University of Notre Dame, who served on a Federal commission studying refugee problems, said today that the only way to solve the problem of illegal aliens was to open the legal ''front door'' to refugees.

title: Stabler Was Close To Coming Back
description: Ken Stabler, the former quarterback of the Houston Oilers who recently retired, said he almost asked to rejoin the team but that comments by the Oiler coach, Ed Biles, caused him to change his mind, a newspaper reported yesterday.

title: ISRAELI CABINET AFFIRMS STAND ON AUTONOMY TALKS
description: The Israeli Cabinet, signaling an interest in reviving the talks on Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, today reaffirmed its longstanding proposals on the issue.

title: What Federal Bail Problem?
description: A proposed change in the Federal bail law that would imprison assertedly dangerous defendants before they come to trial is a solution in search of a problem.

title: VOYAGER SEARCHES RINGS OF SATURN FOR NEW MOONS
description: The cameras of Voyager 2 searched the rings of Saturn today for evidence of small moons that could, in theory, account for many of the wide gaps in the blizzard of icy material forming the hundreds of bright rings around the planet.

title: Waltrip Captures Busch 500 Race
description: It's tough to beat the combination of Junior Johnson and Darrell Waltrip at Bristol International Raceway. ''The car was just that much better than everybody else's,'' Waltrip said after he coasted to a one-lap victory over Ricky Rudd in the Busch 500 Grand National stock car race last night in his Johnson-prepared Buick.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Jane E. Brody THE STARR-WEINER REPORT ON SEX & SEXUALITY IN THE MATURE YEARS. By Drs. Bernard D. Starr and Marcella Bakur Weiner. 302 pages. Stein & Day. $14.95.

title: TORRE'S MOVES WORK AS METS BEAT REDS, 3-2, IN 10
description: Manager Joe Torre went six for six today against the Cincinnati Reds, and the Mets won, 3-2, in 10 innings. Torre made six strategic moves that all worked to perfection. His day of maneuvering was culminated when Bob Bailor, a defensive replacement for Dave Kingman in left field, leaped against the wall and snared a drive by George Foster for the final out.

title: Pipeline Cost Estimate
description: Construction costs for the 745-mile Alaskan segment of the Alaska Natural Gas Pipeline have been estimated at $8.08 billion, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said Friday. The pipeline is expected to be completed by late 1986 to bring about two billion cubic feet of natural gas a day from Prudhoe Bay in Alaska to Canada and the lower 48 states.

title: Bolivian Tin Miners End Strike As Officials Pledge an Inquiry
description: Workers at Bolivia's major tin mines have temporarily ended an indefinite strike after the Government pledged to investigate the events that touched it off.

title: Retiree Publications Plan Merger in 1982
description: Modern Maturity and NRTA Journal, two publications catering to the 50-years-and-up age group, have announced plans to consolidate, effective February 1982. The combined magazine, which will be called Modern Maturity, will increase its circulation by 400,000, to 7.5 million.

title: DAMS IN JERSEY FOUND IN NEED OF MAJOR REPAIR
description: A four-year study of 1,000 of New Jersey's aging and long-neglected dams has uncovered erosion damage, leaks, excessively high water levels and other problems needing major repairs to prevent serious flooding, the state's Department of Environmental Protection reported yesterday.

title: Notes on People; The Careys Take a Belated Greek Honeymoon
description: There were receptions in New York City and Albany and any number of little jaunts around the state, but Governor Carey and his wife, Evangeline Gouletas-Carey, didn't have a chance for a proper wedding trip following their marriage in April.

title: The City; New Funeral Code Effective Today
description: A new New York City law designed to protect and inform consumers in their dealings with funeral homes takes effect today ''Aside from a house and a car, a funeral is the single most expensive purchase that many people make,'' said Henry J. Stern, the City Councilman who sponsored the bill creating the law.

title: TODD AVOIDING INTERCEPTIONS
description: Richard Todd, whose passes were intercepted a combined total of 52 times the last two seasons, is nonplussed by what he has accomplished in the Jets' three exhibition games: 63 passes without an interception.

title: Poker Machines Offer a Raw Deal
description: Round and round she goes, and where she stops, nobody knows: that was the old carnival barker's specious pitch. Now John Quinn, the Director of the New York State Lottery Division, seems to find it alluring.

title: Commodities; A Strong Comeback For Silver
description: WHATEVER fundamental or technical factors may have provoked the remarkable rebound in silver prices this month, they have sent the metal soaring from a two-year low of $8.52 an ounce last July 31 to $9.60 at last Friday's spot (cash) quote in New York.

title: Around the Nation; Gunmen in Philadelphia Wound 7 at Block Party
description: Seven persons were wounded and hundreds were sent running for cover when a gunman fired on a crowded block party last night.

title: Around the World; Pope, at Summer Home, Appeals for World Peace
description: Pope John Paul II made an appeal today for world peace. The Pope, 61 years old, arrived here last Sunday for a period of convalescence after his discharge from the hospital where he was treated for wounds suffered when he was shot and wounded by a Turkish gunman.

title: Susan Burns Is a Bride
description: At the Union Baptist Church in Orange, N.J., yesterday, Susan Jane Burns and Albert Benjamin Miles Jr., graduates of Wesleyan University, were married by the Rev. J. Vance McIver. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Burns of Montclair, N.J., is a systems engineer with I.B.M. in New Haven. She will enter the Yale School of Organization and Management next month to study for a master's degree. Mr. Miles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miles of Brooklyn, is an analyst programmer with the data systems group at the Southern New England Telephone Company in New Haven.

title: Israel Repeats Its Opposition To Radar-Plane Sale to Saudis
description: Israel remains opposed to the American sale of the advanced radar planes to Saudi Arabia since it represents a threat to Israeli security, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today.

title: GUIDRY EXTENDS STREAK
description: The Yankees got more strong pitching from Ron Guidry, who has not allowed a run since the second half of the split season began, scored eight runs in the first two innings, then coasted to an 8-0 victory over the Kansas City Royals yesterday before 40,258 at Yankee Stadium.

title: The Region; Wildwood Stores Lacked Insurance
description: Some store owners whose businesses were destroyed in a boardwalk fire last week did not have enough insurance to cover their losses, according to city officials.

title: GIANT SHORTCOMINGS DON'T UPSET PERKINS
description: When the Giants won their first two exhibition games, Coach Ray Perkins saw good things and said that many of the bad things could be corrected. Now, after their first defeat, that view has not changed.

title: Inquirer Raises Price
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer is to raise the price of its Sunday edition to 75 cents from 60 cents, beginning Aug. 30, the newspaper announced today. The price of the daily Inquirer will remain at 20 cents.

title: SPENDING REPORT DUE ON MILITARY
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and David A. Stockman, the budget director, are scheduled to arrive here Wednesday to report on their efforts to reduce military spending below the levels favored by Mr. Weinberger, according to a White House official.

title: CONSERVATIVE CHIEF ACCEPTS OFFER TO ENTER PORTUGUESE GOVERNMENT
description: The leader of one of Portugal's three coalition parties, Diogo Freitas do Amaral of the conservative Christian Democrats, has accepted an invitation to join a new government being formed by Francisco Pinto Balsemao.

title: PILLSBURY'S CONTROVERSIAL CHIEF
description: The weary soldier, barely alive, is slumped forward on his mount, his bloody left shoulder pierced by a long arrow. Billows of bluish-gray smoke rise beyond the ridge along a distant horizon.

title: BETH DANIEL TAKES TOP L.P.G.A. PRIZE
description: Beth Daniel knocked in a twofoot birdie putt on the 17th hole today to win the richest first prize ever in women's golf, $50,000, and capture her second consecutive World Championship of Women's Golf title.

title: CONTINENTAL EMPLOYEES GET REPRIEVE
description: Continental Air Lines' plan to thwart a takeover by Texas International Airlines by becoming the nation's largest employee-owned company has been pulled from the ashes.

title: ESPOSITO AND BARBARO ASSESS CITY'S FISCAL AFFAIRS ESPOSITO: 'CITY STILL IN A FISCAL CRISIS'
description: As I sit at my Queens Village kitchen table scribbling out this position paper on the city's fiscal affairs, many thoughts go through my mind while listening to the splash of a heavy rain on a hot humid summer evening.

title: A COLONY FOR ARTISTS IN VIRGINIA
description: SWEET BRIAR, Va. THE sign is so inconspicuous as almost to melt into the lush, hilly landscape. ''Virginia Center for the Creative Arts,'' it says, and then, after a drive up a steep, winding road over the cattle guards to the top of Mount San Angelo, the visitor finds one of those retreats for writers, artists and composers that can be heaven on earth.

title: New Education Weekly To Start Sept. 8
description: Education Week, a weekly newspaper aimed at policymakers in the elementary and secondary education field, will be started Sept. 8 by Editorial Projects in Education, founder of The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: News Analysis
description: In its seven months, the Reagan Administration has sought with some success to give the impression that it knows what it wants to do about an issue and moves swiftly to get the job done. It has not been able to sustain that image in the legal wrestling match over a group of Cuban refugees here.

title: People
description: * George Bragg has joined Compton Advertising as senior vice president, director of television production and broadcast services.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM MAKES KEY SHIFT
description: At First Bank System Inc., a $13.9 billion bank holding company based in Minneapolis, a change will take place Sept. 1. George H. Dixon, 60, president, will assume the additional title of chief executive officer from Donald R. Grangaard, 63, who will continue as chairman.

title: Dr. D.S. Poll, Internist, Marries Rebecca Bien
description: Rebecca Leah Bien, daughter of Lia C. Freedman of Freeport, L.I., and the late Dr. Edward J. Bien, was married yesterday to Dr. David S. Poll, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Poll of New York. The ceremony was performed at the Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., by Rabbi Arthur Schneier.

title: HOSPITAL SUPPLY BIDS FOR BENTLEY
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation has agreed to buy Bentley Laboratories Inc., a maker of medical equipment, in an exchange of stock valued at about $245 million, the two companies announced jointly yesterday.

title: Reverse Play
description: Jon Turner is no longer a run-off, the term used openly in college sports to refer to a method of forcing off a team those athletes on scholarship who fail to produce.

title: Richard Lustiger Marries Rachel Shapiro in Jersey
description: Rachel Shapiro, daughter of Dean and Mrs. E. Donald Shapiro of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Lustiger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Lustiger of Scottsdale, Ariz. Rabbi Barry Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J.

title: GENE KELLY PUTS STRUT IN 'SATCHMO'
description: FOR years, Gene Kelly has been asked to direct Broadway shows; for years, he has said no. His kids were too young, he said. He couldn't leave California. But here is Gene Kelly in the Alvin Theater, wearing a seersucker jacket and black loafers (footwear he did more to popularize than L.L. Bean) auditioning singers and dancers. This season he will direct and choreograph ''Satchmo,'' a musical about Louis Armstrong, starring Ben Vereen.

title: C.D. FUTURES MARKET GROWING
description: Some call it a three-ring circus; others describe it as three pits. Both refer to trading in new futures contracts for bank certificates of deposit now under way on the New York Futures Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and the International Monetary Market.

title: Around the Nation; Massachusetts Allows Buyers to Taste Wines
description: Wine fanciers in Massachusetts now can let their taste buds decide which vintage to buy under a new state law that allows customers to sample wine in retail liquor stores.

title: The Region; Service Returns After Derailment
description: Freight and passenger train service was almost normal after a weekend derailment that temporarily knocked out service on two lines.

title: All Certificates Are Not Alike
description: Millions of individuals with savings accounts are familiar with the certificates of deposit issued at banks, guaranteeing the depositor a specific interest rate for a specified length of time.

title: THREE JOCKEYS INJURED IN SPILLS
description: A runaway victory in the Spinaway Stakes by the brilliant 2-year-old filly Before Dawn paled a bit after two accidents and injuries to three prominent jockeys earlier today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: SOVIET INTELLIGENCE AND THE WESTERN JOURNALISTS ABOVE SUSPICION
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWPORT CELEBRATES TENNIS CENTENARY IN A PIAZZA
description: Back in 1880, according to legend, James Gordon Bennett Jr., a man of some means and even more eccentricities, decided that certain residents of Newport might be upper crust, but that their sense of humor was half baked.

title: ROGERS RUNNING INTO OBSTACLES
description: Since the Heisman Trophy was first awarded in 1935 to college football's outstanding player of the year, no winner has yet achieved election to the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Bum Phillips, the coach of the New Orleans Saints, has acquired the most recent of those trophy winners, George Rogers of South Carolina, and he wants his rookie running back to tread carefully.

title: A PLAN CALCULATED TO CUT CRIME
description: The Attorney General's Violent Crime Task Force Report is a good prescription for reducing the fever of violent crime consuming this country. Task force reports are old hat; they are reported with fanfare then conveniently shelved. This year should be different. President Reagan wants to reverse years of backsliding on crime control. Congress is already acting on drug legislation and, most important, people are fed up with being prisoners in their homes while criminals appear to roam the streets and the parks at will.

title: Notes on People; Jerry Rubin Takes on Diablo Canyon, But Quietly
description: It took him two weeks to cover 200 miles, but a footsore Jerry Rubin finally made it. He arrived at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant near San Luis Obispo, Calif., on Saturday carrying a sign that read, ''Warning: Diablo Canyon on Shaky Ground.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is a widespread sentiment that if the Reagan Administration comes out on top, it will be open season on controllers.'' - Richard C. W. Weston, an adviser to the International Federation of Air Traffic Controllers. (B13:3.)

title: FEARS, NOT REALITIES, INFLUENCING FRUIT FLY'S IMPACT ON CALIFORNIANS
description: California's vast Central Valley, now threatened by an insect dwarfed by the common housefly, stretches over roughly 50,000 square miles, almost exactly the area of New York State.

title: Bridge: Pros and Cons on Actions When Bidding Is Doubled
description: One of the many areas in which traditional bidders and modern scientists disagree relates to actions by a responder after a takeout double. It used to be standard to redouble with any hand including 10 or more high-card points, so a suit bid would deny 10 points and be nonforcing. A disadvantage is that the opener's side loses time in locating a good suit-fit, and may never find it at all.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF U.S. ESTATE AND GIFT TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: Zelda Rae Tetenbaum Bride of Mark Yoder
description: Zelda Rae Tetenbaum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Tetenbaum of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Mark George Yoder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Yoder of Schuylkill Haven, Pa. State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Slavin performed the ceremony at the Tetenbaum home.

title: SOVIET TELLS BLOC TO ADHERE TIGHTLY TO COMMUNIST LINE
description: In an unusual statement published today on the front pages of Soviet newspapers, the Soviet Union warned its Eastern bloc allies that they must remain faithful to Soviet-style Communism to prevent what happened in Poland from recurring elsewhere.

title: Relaxing a Winner
description: Relaxing was an easy winner today, scoring by 2 3/4 lengths in the $115,250 Delaware Handicap, the event's 44th running. She won $75,075 for her owner, Ogden Phipps, increasing her earnings for the year to $211,401.

title: Elizabeth Meadow, Nurse, Bride of Robert Smoler
description: At the Jewish Community Center in White Plains yesterday, Elizabeth Carol Meadow, daughter of Mrs. Martin Neschis of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Edward Meadow of New York, was married to Robert Mark Smoler, son of Ann Smoler of Scarsdale and Leonard Smoler of Ridgefield, Conn.

title: EVEN LOSERS ENJOY TIMES SQ. SIDEWALK CHESS
description: In the teeming street life of Times Square this summer, the largest growth industry, aside from the sale of chocolate chip ice cream sandwiches, may be an unlikely one - sidewalk chess.

title: Esty Wins Marriott's Great America Account
description: The William Esty Company has been named as the agency for the $8 million advertising account of Marriott's Great America, a division of the Marriott Corporation.

title: Equatorial Guinea Said to Put Curbs on the Foreign Press
description: Equatorial Guinea plans to restrict the activities of foreign journalists and has banned the sale of Spanish newspapers, diplomatic sources said in Madrid today.

title: The City; Hearing on Term In Lennon Slaying
description: A hearing will be held this morning in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to determine what sentence Mark David Chapman will receive for killing John Lennon.

title: NEW HEALTH PLANS FOCUS ON 'WELLNESS'
description: Headache. Backache. ''Job burnout.'' Emotional problems. Whatever ails an employee, his employer is likely to feel worse when the bills have to be paid.

title: Unbeaten Ayala Wins on Decision
description: Tony Ayala Jr. stalked Nicanor Comacho for 10 rounds today and staggered him with bruising right hands to score a unanimous decision in a bout between two previously unbeaten junior middleweights.

title: THE INSTINCT TO SURVIVE
description: IN 10 weeks the Jets and Giants will play the real game, when new players like Kurt Sohn and Ben Rudolph will not be shuffled into the lineup merely for on-the-job training. Even the fans seemed to realize that on a cool Saturday night in New Jersey. They worked on their rivalries - the subtleties that separate Jet fans from Giant fans - but they saved some viciousness for Nov. 1.

title: TRACY AUSTIN WINS
description: One year ago, the last time Chris Evert Lloyd and Tracy Austin met on the tennis court, the eagerness belonged to Mrs. Lloyd. Today, Miss Austin was the more determined player in a 6-1, 6-4 victory for the Canadian Open singles title.

title: ORGANIC FARMERS SEE SOLUTION TO FOOD CRISIS
description: It was 10 years ago that 135 people gathered on a hillside at Samuel Kaymen's farm near Putney, Vt., to discuss organic farming and how they could make it work. That was the beginning of the Natural Organic Farmers Association, and the meeting brought together some representatives of what was then regarded as agriculture's radical fringe.

title: WITH GREAT CIVIC PRIDE, NEW ROCHELLE OPENS A NEW PARK
description: In the late 1960's a real-estate developer proposed turning Oakwood Island here into a complex of luxury apartments. Today, amid considerable merriment, Oakwood Island was opened as a public park.

title: CANE FINISH IS A FLURRY OF CONFUSION
description: It was an unusual scene. Gerald Lawrence, general manager of Yonkers Raceway, stood clutching the Cane Pace trophy in the glare of flashing lights on the tote board.

title: VIRGINIA NEARY'S RACE AGAINST MS
description: VIRGINIA NEARY rides horses, trains horses, rubs horses, breeds horses, races horses, draws and paints horses between paralyzing attacks of multiple sclerosis. On behalf of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, she has been working with the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association at Saratoga, Seattle, San Francisco, Los Angeles and anywhere else she can help arrange ''Race Against MS'' programs.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A WORLD OF FRIENDS

title: Bill Barber to Miss Canada Cup Play
description: Bill Barber told Team Canada officials today the knee injury he suffered in an intrasquad game Wednesday would keep him out of the lineup for the entire Canada Cup tournament.

title: Weinberger Leaves London
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, who ended a three-day visit to London today and departed for Washington, said the question of deploying neutron weapons in Europe had not been discussed in his talks with British officials. Mr.Weinberger said, however, that if the United States decided to deploy the neutron weapon it would seek permission from its allies.

title: NEW CENTER IN OHIO WILL SEEK A CURE FOR REYE'S SYNDROME
description: Later this year, when school is back in session and the weather turns cold, children will start coming down with the usual sniffles, colds, perhaps flu or chicken pox.

title: Nehemiah Leads Hurdles Sweep
description: Renaldo Nehemiah, the worldrecord holder, posted the fourth-best time ever in the 110-meter hurdles at an international track and field meet today.

title: Ellen Stopsky Is Married To Jay Steinberg on L. I.
description: Ellen Stopsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Stopsky of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Jay Steinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Steinberg of Melville, L.I. Rabbi Morris Shapiro performed the ceremony at the South Huntington Jewish Center in Melville.

title: News Analysis
description: At a news conference last week called by the independent trade union, Solidarity, a reporter from the Communist Party daily, Trybuna Ludu, asked the union organizers of a printers' strike why they had failed to ask the population if it approved of the two-day shutdown of Poland's newspapers.

title: Elizabeth Deborah Porter Bride of Russell E. Cooper
description: Elizabeth Deborah Porter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Porter of New York, was married yesterday to Russell Evan Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Cooper of Davie, Fla.

title: HAIG SAYS REAGAN IS READY TO MEET SOVIET HALFWAY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the Reagan Administration was ready to meet the Soviet Union halfway and was ''anxious for an improvement in the dialogue.''

title: SMITHSONIAN SHOWS PLATINUM PRINTS OF PRE-1916 GOLDEN GIRLS
description: At the turn of the century, Evelyn Nesbit was the toast of New York society. A stunning Gibson Girl, Floradora Sextette performer on Broadway and sought-after artists' model, she was only 20 years old when her career was shattered by scandal. She lapsed into a life of poverty, alcohol and drugs. Her fame was recently revived when E.L. Doctorow made her a character in his novel ''Ragtime.''

title: Sloop Infinity First In Regatta on L.I.
description: Infinity, a 46-foot sloop sailed by John Thomson of Sands Point, L.I., and designed by Ron Holland, won the big-boat division for cruising yachts in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 49th annual race week today.

title: RATE FEARS STILL HOLD SWAY
description: The credit market and the stock market begin a new week facing a common foe: high interest rates. Compounding this problem, some analysts say, is the expectation that rates - in some sectors, at least - are likely to move even higher.

title: McEnroe on Top
description: John McEnroe beat Chris Lewis of New Zealand, an unseeded player, 6-3, 6-4, and won the $200,000 Association of Tennis Professionals title today.

title: LEBANON'S BORDERS REMAIN QUIET, BUT LEFTISTS TURN ON EACH OTHER
description: With the Israeli and Palestinian guns stilled for now on the southern border, the violence in Lebanon has returned to what passes for normal here.

title: White Hits Homer
description: Koji Yamamoto hit a bases-loaded home run, and Roy White belted a one-run homer to give the Central Leagueleading Yomiuri Giants a 5-3 comeback victory over the Yokohama Taiyo Whales today. White, formerly with the New York Yankees, singled three times and walked once. He has 11 home runs this season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 24, 1981 Companies

title: Stones Jumps 7-7 For a U.S. Record
description: Dwight Stones of the United States set an American record for the high jump when he cleared 7 feet 7 inches today at an international track and field meet.

title: Sports World Specials; N.H.L. Reunion
description: Many of the best hockey players in the world are preparing to play in the Canada Cup series, which hockey people in North America and Europe seem to be approaching as seriously as they do the Stanley Cup playoffs or the Olympics.

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Visits India
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, arrived here today from Bangladesh on a two-day visit. Mrs. Kirkpatrick is to meet tomorrow with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and P.V. Narasimha Rao, the Minister of External Affairs.

title: PHILADELPHIA'S TEACHERS MAY STRIKE OVER CUTS
description: With classrooms scheduled to reopen here in about two weeks, this city's school district is approaching crises that some officials say are made almost inevitable by the design of its system.

title: Around the World; A Storm Leaves 14 Dead, Many Homeless, in Japan
description: At least 14 people were killed and 19 were reported missing today as a typhoon smashed across central and northern Japan, unleashing gusting winds and dumping heavy rains, the police said.

title: A RICH ERA IN THE STUDY OF PLANETS DRAWS TO A CLOSE
description: PASADENA, Calif. LONG before telescopes or spacecraft, the ancients observed lights in the sky that wandered. They called them wandering stars, the planets. Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn, the visible wandering stars were sources of wonder and speculation, and people reached out to them in their imagination, investing them with life and extraordinary civilizations.

title: Notes on People; ''New York, New York'' Brings In a New Award
description: Fred Ebb and John Kander will be at the top of the heap on Sept. 22 when they receive the first New York Song Award for their composition ''New York, New York.''

title: Around the World; Law of Sea Treaty Is Delayed a Year
description: The Law of the Sea Conference, now in its ninth year, today postponed action on a proposed treaty to give the Reagan Administration time to formulate its policy on the pact.

title: ANDREA DORIA'S CHINA FOUND
description: A set of dinner plates, ''filthy, but in perfect condition,'' has been brought up from the sunken luxury liner Andrea Doria, explorers say.

title: 'LEAVE LOW-KEY PROSTITUTES ALONE'
description: To the Editor:

title: 17 Die in Guatemala Violence
description: At least 17 people, five of them national police, were killed in this nation's continuing political violence, authorities said today. Firemen acting on an a telephone tip found eight bodies beside a highway outside the capital.

title: Ruling on Building In Rye Is Reversed
description: An appeals court reversed a decision by the Rye Town Board to allow the development of 17.8 acres for an office building, saying the board improperly gave its approval without the preparation of an environmental impact statement.

title: Croton to Readmit Girls to Fire Corps
description: ON-HUDSON - The Croton Volunteer Fire Department has agreed to readmit four 15-year-old girls to a Fire Department training program after the Mayor and Village Attorney told the chief that the eviction of the girls was illegal.

title: 'PIRATE' DELIGHTS TV-HUNGRY DANES
description: More than 6,000 citizens of this town in East Jutland have signed a petition supporting a pirate television station that is delighting a growing number of viewers with entertainment taped from West German and Swedish stations.

title: TUBE'S RELIANCE ON BASIC INDUSTRIES HINDERS PROFITS
description: When the TI Raleigh-Creda bicycle team finished a disappointing fourth in the Tour de France bicycle race last month, it was not only the cyclists who were disappointed. The team's sponsors, Tube Investments Ltd., would have liked some cause for celebrating - no matter how small - at a time when the company was preparing to announce record losses.

title: United Brands' Profit Off 16.7%
description: The United Brands Company, a broad-based foods concern, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year ended June 30 dropped 16.7 percent, to $19.4 million, or $1.70 a share, from $23.3 million, or $1.97 a share, in the corresponding quarter of the preceding fiscal year. Sales rose 5.9 percent, to $1.08 billion, from $1.02 billion.

title: Shasta Is Looking For a New Agency
description: Shasta Beverages says it has begun discussions with ''a few leading agencies'' about taking on its account, which, some trade sources say, involves billings of $6 million to $8 million.

title: BEGIN TO SEEK FULL ISRAEL-EGYPT TIES
description: On the eve of talks between Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Anwar el-Sadat, Israeli Foreign ministry officials said today that Mr. Begin would press for full normalization of relations between the two nations.

title: JURY INDICTS HINCKLEY ON 13 COUNTS BASED ON SHOOTING OF PRESIDENT
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of attempting to kill President Reagan March 30 and of assault with intent to kill James S. Brady, the White House press secretary.

title: Talking Business with Dreman of Dreman, Gray & King; What's Good About Stocks
description: The Dow Jones industrial average has fallen steadily in recent months, and yesterday it reached its lowest close in more than a year. Yet some money managers remain enthusiastic about the stock market. One of them is David N. Dreman, managing director of Dreman, Gray & King Inc., an investment counseling concern.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,910,000 for the qr and $1,890,000 for the yr and $1,714,000 tax credit for the qr and yr...C-Including $1,942,000 tax credit; shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May

title: Soviet Pipe Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has contracted to buy, for an undisclosed price, 555,000 tons of large-diameter steel pipes from Mannesmann A.G., a West German steelmaker and fabricator, the official Tass press agency said today.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lebanon Set To Seize Oil
description: Lebanon has requisitioned crude oil in reservoirs of the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company, known as Tapline, in southern Lebanon, following Tapline's decision to stop pumping oil from Saudi Arabia to Lebanon, official sources said today.

title: NEWS CONFERENCE ABOARD THE NIMITZ
description: Following are excerpts from an unofficial transcript of the news conference today by Vice Adm. William H. Rowden, the Sixth Fleet Commander; Rear Adm. James E. Service, task force commander; Cmdr. Henry M. Kleemann, the commander of the fighter squadron that shot down two Libyan planes last week, and other officers, including Lieut. Jay Sumner, a radarman, aboard the Nimitz: OPENING STATEMENTS

title: PRISONS FOR TOMORROW
description: To the Editor:

title: KENTUCKY TOWN SEES DREAM STALLED BY POWER PLANT FIGHT
description: It seems only yesterday that this tiny Ohio River town of just 1,939 residents was dying. Then it became the proud owner of the world's first, fully prefabricated, ready-todrop-in-the-water hydroelectric power plant. And then, still not content, the city lined up five permits and applied for a sixth to build more power plants at existing Government dams stretching from Indiana to Kentucky.

title: About Education; NEW U.S. APPROACH: A FORUM OF IDEAS
description: SECRETARY OF EDUCATION T.H. Bell is planning to establish a national commission on excellence in education to reverse what he describes as a ''nationwide problem of declining college entrance scores'' and to assure high standards of achievement. He also plans to urge tougher requirements for promotion from grade to grade and for graduation from high school.

title: STRONG OPPOSITION CHALLENGE SEEN
description: The Greek Government officially announced tonight that general elections will be held on Oct. 18. The contest is expected to be one of the closest in recent years, with the opposition Panhellenic Socialist Party of Andreas Papandreou saying that it is confident of unseating the ruling New Democracy Party.

title: Mayor Hears Boos And Cheers, Too
description: Twenty-five sign-toting demonstrators from the Richmond Hill Republican Club greeted Mayor Koch as he arrived at the Holy Child Jesus School in Queens last night.

title: Mining Concerns Cite Copper Find
description: Utah International Inc., a subsidiary of the General Electric Company, said it and a unit of the Getty Oil Company had discovered a copper deposit in northern Chile.

title: Nuclear Plant Shut At Indian Point
description: Con Edison announced yesterday that it had temporarily shut down its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in Buchanan to replace a bearing causing vibration in a reactor coolant pump motor.

title: Colombian Pipeline Set
description: Colombia will invest $300 million in the construction of a 156-mile pipeline from its oilfields at Aranca and Casanare to the port of Barrancabemeja, the Mines Minister, Carlos Rodado Noriega, said. He added that oil reserves in the area, close to the Venezuelan border, were estimated at 80 million barrels.

title: SEOUL DISSIDENTS BITTER ABOUT U.S.
description: The 11 women, all wives or mothers of political prisoners, had camped out one afternoon last week in the office of the head of the National Council of Churches in Korea.

title: Head Office Of Hanover Bank Sold
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its headquarters building, at 350 Park Avenue, for $161 million to a newly established partnership of the Republic New York Corporation, holding company of the Republic National Bank of New York, and Salomon Brothers.

title: FILMLESS VIDEO CAMERA IS INTRODUCED BY SONY
description: The Sony Corporation today displayed a new camera for the consumer market that, through the application of advanced electronic and video technology, takes still pictures without the use of traditional photographic film.

title: ELCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International, Los Angeles, has elected J. Lee Ledbetter vice president and controller. * Chemical Bank has named Edward A. Weihman a vice president.

title: SECURITY URGED FOR STATION
description: A task force recommended that operations and security be improved at Newark's Penn Station in addition to the restoration under way there, officials said today. More lighting in and around the station, a train communications center, improved information services and better maintenance were included in a report released by the task force, which includes transit and city officials.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss; results are for the company's third fiscal qr; Energy Management went public on Jan 1, 1980 and 9 mos figures were not provided

title: GREYHOUND LINES OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $4 million or 43 cents a shr gain on the sale of property; the company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: Arco Alaska Plans
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said it planned to spend more than $2 billion, or slightly less than onethird of its total $7 billion oil exploration budget, in Alaska over the next five years. A spokesman said that the oil company planned to drill next winter in the Beaufort Sea, and join with 18 other companies in a $216 million program to put wells in the St. George Basin, the North Aleutian Shelf and the Navarin Basin off the coast of western Alaska. Drilling is expected to begin in 1983 in Arco leases acquired in the eastern Gulf of Alaska, the spokesman said.

title: 'CHOOSE YOUR OWN ADVENTURE' AND MAKE YOUR OWN ENDING
description: ONE evening a dozen years ago, Edward Packard, a Manhattan lawyer, asked his two daughters to help create the plot of their nightly bedtime story.

title: General Mills Chairman
description: H. Brewster Atwater Jr., the 50-year-old chief executive officer of General Mills Inc., has been elected to the additional position of chairman. His previous post of president of the big Minneapolis-based company, which in recent years has diversified from foods into other areas, will not be filled.

title: CHAPMAN GIVEN 20 YEARS IN LENNON'S SLAYING
description: Mark David Chapman, who pleaded guilty to the fatal shooting last December of John Lennon outside the singer's apartment building, was sentenced yesterday to 20 years to life in prison.

title: CONSUMPTION OF MEAT RISING IN THE DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
description: When Lowell Haskins, an American poultry breeder, visited Zambia not long ago, he was invited to lunch at the luxurious home of a Cabinet minister. The official's wife asked if he would like to see her chickens, and then led him outside. There in the back garden were 300 broilers being fattened for the Lusaka market. ''It was like being invited to the home of Alexander Haig and having Mrs. Haig show you her chicken business in the backyard,'' said Mr. Haskins, whose Connecticut company, Arbor Acres, supplies almost one-third of the world's breeding stock for broilers.

title: MIDDLE-CLASS SQUEEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Home of Iranian Prosecutor Gen- eral is attacked A2 Refugees on Malaysian island are in good spirits A5 Workers at Katowice steel mill challenge manager's authority A6 Around the World A7 Greece announces general elec- tions for October A8 South Korean dissidents display anti-American feelings A9 Excerpts from news conference aboard the Nimitz A10 Qaddafi seeks support for Arab meeting on U.S. ''aggression'' A11 Mrs. Kirkpatrick says arms to Pakistan not a threat to India A12 Government/Politics U.S. preparing revisionn of rules on intelligence work A16 New York's police precinct cap- tains turn policy into reality B1 Koch says criticism of judges has brought tougher sentences B3 James Smith, challenger of Mayor Koch, is ruled off ballot B4 City Council group backs bill on student voter forms B19 General Around the Nation A14 New fly forces widening of Cali- fornia quarantine A14 Convicted spy is arraigned on charge of escaping from prison A14 Dispute stalls Kentucky town's dreams of being power baron A14 With one brass mill left, town strives to rebuild economy B2 Judge dismisses kite flier's sum- mons as ''for the birds'' B3 Body of man whose two brothers disappeared will be exhumed B14 Dinner plates are recovered from the sunken liner Andrea Doria D18 Features/Notes Notes on People B8 Going Out Guide C8 Science Times Era of planetary exploration draws Adventure'' books C7 Rosalind Newman's ''Ssandd'' danced at Battery Park C7 Biography of H.H. Munro re- viewed C10 Danish television pirate gains support of citizens C20 ''Nova'' telecast tonight features Voyager II nearing Saturn C20 Style Notes on Fashion B13 Aiding women to seek office B13 The latest from London arrives in SoHo (ours) B13 Sports Twins beat Yanks, 3-2, on rookie's homer in 12th inning B15 Reds' Berenyi strikes out 12 in stopping Mets on 2-hitter, 2-0 B15 Giants put Reed, quarterback, and Heater, on injured reserve B15 The year of Bobby Allison B15 George Vecsey on testing the N.B.A. draft B16 Leslie Allen beaten incontrover- sial Volvo tennis match B16 Oilers, hopeful, keep Stabler on roster B16 Royals end Tigers' winning streak at nine B17 Great Neck and Cordero prevail as Saratoga meet ends B18 News Analysis Bernard Gwertzman on the plane- sale decision A3 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A18

title: Around the World; African Leaders Meet On Western Sahara War
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya opened a two-day meeting of African leaders today on the war between Morocco and guerrillas in Western Sahara.

title: ALMOST A HIT
description: To the Editor:

title: G.& W. Canada Announces Shifts
description: Gulf and Western Canada Ltd., the Canadian branch of the New Yorkbased conglomerate, said it planned to reorganize its recently acquired Famous Players Ltd. unit into theater and real estate divisions and to operate each division through one or more separate wholly owned companies.

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for vacation pay

title: Teamster Aide Denies Account of Kickbacks
description: A lawyer for Jackie Presser, international vice president of the Teamsters Union, today denied reports that the union official took cash kickbacks and acted as a government informer against other union members.

title: Chess: 'Most Interesting' Trophy Replaces Brilliancy Laurel
description: In the recent United States Championship, a prize for the most interesting game was substituted for the traditional brilliancy prize, the idea being to single out an exciting clash in which the issue hung in the balance for many moves.

title: Virginia Aide Seeks Dropping Of Affirmative Action Effort
description: Virginia's personnel chief said today that the state should drop its affirmative action hiring program for women and minorities because it was discriminatory, but the Governor promptly rejected the suggestion.

title: No Headline
description: A news item in Notes on People yesterday incorrectly described the Jerry Rubin who participated in an antinuclear protest in California on Saturday. Mr. Rubin is a student, freelance writer and sculptor's model from Venice Beach, Calif.

title: BILL ON STUDENT VOTER FORMS SPLITS COUNCIL AND EDUCATORS
description: With 15 high school students present, a New York City Council committee and representatives from the Board of Education engaged in a parliamentary tug-of-war yesterday over a bill that would require high schools to provide 18-year-old students with voter registration forms.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: COMMUNICATION WORKERS GIVE $100,000 TO STRIKERS
description: The Communications Workers of America, expressing alarm about the Reagan Administration's handling of the air traffic controllers' strike, announced today that it had committed $100,000 to assist the families of the dismissed controllers.

title: BANI-SADR SAYS KILLING 5 KEY MEN CAN END REGIME
description: SUR-OISE, France, Aug. 24 - In a blue pavilion set up in a riverside garden here, Iran's deposed President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, foretold how his followers might bring down the regime of the Ayatollah.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Science Watch; Pesticides in Tropics
description: Four out of five widely used pesticides tested in Taiwan were found to break down in the soil much faster than they do in cooler climates, a team of researchers has found. Their findings indicated that restrictions based on tests made in temperate Western nations may have to be revised for tropical and subtropical developing countries.

title: DOUBTS CAST ON U.S. FIGURE
description: Congressional budget analysts foresee a 1982 budget deficit $15 billion to $20 billion higher than the $42.5 billion projected by the Reagan Administration in its official forecasts. Their predictions appear in documents expected to be published next month when legislators again take up the budget for the fiscal year 1982, which begins Oct. 1.

title: SAUDI AIR DEAL IS FORMALLY SENT TO THE CONGRESS
description: The Reagan Administration formally notified Congress today that it was proceeding with its intention to sell Saudi Arabia five radar planes and other air defense equipment.

title: TO REFUGEES, MALAYSIAN ISLE NOW GIVES HOPE
description: At the height of the outflow of ''boat people'' from Vietnam, this island off the coast of eastern Malaysia became a symbol of the magnitude of the problem and the depth of the refugees' misery.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The story about one out of every nine people in the world existing on a starvation diet warrants contemplation. At the same time, one must include the truism ''We breed them, you feed them.'' R. C. LESLIE Chicago, Aug. 17, 1981

title: A BAD RAP FOR LAGOS
description: This West African capital may be the most maligned city in the world. Power blackouts, traffic jams, armed robberies and murders occur in all West African cities. Why does Lagos have a reputation for being worse than all the others? Is the reason just that it is bigger, so problems happen more often and are harder to handle? Or is the reason more spiteful than that?

title: GEORGE WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Public Broadcasting Firm Picks Pfister
description: Edward J. Pfister, president and general manager of KERA-TV and KERA-FM in Dallas-Fort Worth, was nominated to be president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting yesterday, succeeding Robben W. Fleming, who retired earlier this year.

title: Manic Defeats Aztecs In Playoff Opener, 5-3
description: Gordon Hill and Thompson Usiyan scored twice each, and Fran O'Brien added a goal tonight to lead the Montreal Manic to a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Aztecs in the opening game of their two-of-three-game North American Soccer League playoff series.

title: ESSENTIAL INGREDIENTS OF A SUCCESSFUL PUBLIC-EMPLOYEE STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Cities Service Also Sues Mesa
description: The Cities Service Company, fighting every takeover sign, yesterday added the Mesa Petroleum Company of Texas to its suit against the Nu-West Group Ltd. of Canada, charging the two with stock manipulation and secretly acting in concert. Nu-West has a 7.2 percent interest in Cities Service and Mesa has nearly 4 percent.

title: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''There was no chance that I was not going to pull the trigger.

title: BY A.O. SULZBERGER Jr.
description: As if the union representing the nation's striking air controllers did not have enough problems, now it must go to court to defend itself against charges from some of its former office employees that the union engaged in unfair labor practices.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TV: VOYAGER'S APPROACH TO SATURN
description: SOMETIMES it seems that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration flies those incredible missions to the planets so that the British Broadcasting Corporation can produce the fascinating one-hour television shows depicting the strange new vistas. And then the Public Broadcasting Service's ''Nova'' brings the show to American audiences just in time to serve as a guide to the next planetary encounter. To the public, this is one of the most rewarding combinations of the space age.

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $646,000 for the qr and $1,284,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including foreign currency translation gains of $297,000 for the qr and $300,000 for the 9 mos; shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec 1, 1980

title: Steel Output Higher
description: Steel production rose to 2.341 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 2.9 percent from the previous week's 2.274 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Club Fights for Iranian Ban
description: The Iowa Supreme Court will review the case of an Ames supper club that was fined $500 for violating a court order by refusing to remove a sign saying ''Iranians Not Welcome Here.'' The club manager, Bruce Russell, put up the sign on Nov. 10, 1979, shortly after Iranians stormed the United States Embassy in Teheran and took hostages.

title: Drug Link Studied in Attack On Gunshot-Wound Patient
description: The police speculated today that revenge for an unsuccessful drug deal might explain why three masked men had held nurses at gunpoint at a hospital and stabbed a gunshotwound patient.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD IN 56 DAYS: Calvin Pitts, right, and Emmett Fry as they arrived yesterday in Manchester, N.H. Mr. Pitts and a series of co-pilots, in-cluding Mr. Fry, made an nine-week, 25,000-mile roundthe-world flight which approximated the 1931 adventure of Wiley Post, the aviation pioneer.

title: Notes on People; Mayoral Fund-Raiser for Andrew Young
description: More than $100,000 was raised in Atlanta for the mayoral candidacy of Andrew Young at Harry Belafonte's benefit performance for the former chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Reed, Heater Are Out
description: The Giants continued the difficult and often painful process of trimming the roster today by placing Mark Reed, Kevin Kurdyla and Larry Heater on the injured-reserve list. The team must cut six more players by 4 P.M. tomorrow and then five more by the following Tuesday to reach the regular-season limit of 45.

title: BRAZILIAN 'NUDITY'
description: ''All Nudity Shall Be Punished'' (''Toda Nudez Sera Castigada'') was shown as part of the 1974 New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of April 1, 1974. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: REDS' BERENYI STOPS METS ON 2-HITTER, 2-0
description: The Mets could not come up with any lateinning heroics tonight, and the result was a two-hit, 2-0 loss to the Cincinnati Reds at Riverfront Stadium.

title: TRADING IN SPOT OIL HAS DWINDLED
description: Few trades were made on the spot oil market yesterday in the apparent expectation that some crude prices will be reduced in the wake of OPEC's failure last week to reach agreement on pricing.

title: London Zoo Says Panda Is Pregnant
description: The London Zoo announced today that its giant panda, Ching Ching, is pregnant and could give birth at any time.

title: Indiana Star Is Moved Out of Intensive Care
description: Landon Turner, the Indiana University basketball player who was severely injured in an automobile accident July 25, has been transferred from the intensive-care unit at Methodist Hospital.

title: VOYAGER 2 SURVEYS ODDLY SHAPED MOON
description: Voyager 2 has discovered that one of Saturn's moons, Hyperion, is an unusually irregular object - from different photographic perspectives it resembles a brick or an Idaho potato or even a hockey puck - that has presumably been shattered and sent reeling in relatively recent times.

title: THE KREMLIN'S FEAR OF NEUTRON BOMBS
description: To the Editor:

title: VENEZUELAN SURPRISES
description: How would the United States react to a Socialist government in Latin America that pursued a truly neutral foreign policy and excluded the pro-Moscow Communist party? Such a hypothetical situation is not an immediate challenge to American policymakers, but it is being discussed among Venezuelan leftists and specifically within the Movement Toward Socialism, that nation's largest party on the left. Just how far and fast a leftist government can proceed without provoking American intervention has always concerned pragmatic Latin American leftist leaders such as those of the Venezuelan movement and has influenced their positions, even though the question has usually not been openly debated.

title: Around the Nation; Witness Says Kleindienst Attended Key Meeting
description: A prosecution witness in the perjury trial of Richard G. Kleindienst said today that the former Attorney General was present when a suggestion was made to place $1.8 million in outof-state banks as part of a scheme.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $2.1 million for the qr and $3 million for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $362,000 for the qr and $638,000 for the 9 mos

title: Education; THINKING AND WRITING, AS ONE
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y. MARK Twain worked in bed. Thornton Wilder required a walk. Ernest Hemingway is said to have needed to sharpen pencils. But here at Bard College no such indulgence about writing is permissible.

title: CENTRAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Around the World; Afghans Offer Terms For Talks on Rebellion
description: Afghanistan announced new terms today for negotiations to end the Moslem guerrilla rebellion that led to Soviet military intervention, the Kabul radio reported.

title: O'Keefe in 'Fifth' for 4 Weeks
description: Michael O'Keefe will replace Richard Thomas in Lanford Wilson's ''The Fifth of July'' at the New Apollo Theater for four weeks, starting Sept. 7. Mr. Thomas will be in Los Angeles, where his wife, Alma, is awaiting the birth of twins.

title: HALSEY SMITH, 60, LED NORTHEAST BANKSHARE
description: Halsey Smith, president of the Northeast Bankshare Association, and former president of the Casco Band and Trust Company, Portland, Me., died Friday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 60 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why does the mockingbird sing so many songs?

title: Space Agency Puts Old Parts to Use
description: The financially pinched National Aeronautics and Space Administration is taking equipment from the old Skylab space station on display at the National Air and Space Museum to help outfit future spacecraft.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Placed Lou Piniella, outfielder, on 15-day disabled list.  PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Recalled Mark Davis, left-handed pitcher, from Oklahoma City of American Association.  Waived John Vukovich, utility infielder.; BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES (NBA) - Signed Dar- rell Allums, forward, to multiyear con- tract.
description: Greene and John Noonan, wide receivers, and Rodell Thomas, linebacker. Placed Doug Beaudoin, safety, on injured re- serve. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Waived Terry Nelson, tight end; Steve McMi- chael, nose tackle; Doug McDougald, de- fensive end; Rich Camarillo and Ken Naber, punters; Kyle Stevens, running back; Craig Johnson, fullback; Jimmy Stewart, fullback; Don Jones, cornerback, and Chy Davidson, kick returner.

title: RECOVERY BID BY PAINT MAKER
description: If the Standard Brands Paint Company, the West's largest home decorating company, were a house, it would be a 42-year-old stucco bungalow, structurally sound, clean, cozy and fully paid for, but in need of renovation.

title: KOCH TAKES CREDIT ON TOUGHER JUDGES
description: Mayor Koch, who has criticized some judges as ''too lenient,'' said yesterday that largely because of that criticism, judges in New York City were now handing down tougher sentences.

title: ALTEX OIL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $68,600 tax credit; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition

title: U.S. Refiners' Capacity Use Rises; U.S. Refinery Use Up
description: United States refineries used 72.6 percent of total capacity, processing an average of 13.3 million barrels of crude oil a day in the week ending Aug. 14, the Energy Department said today in its Weekly Petroleum Status Report. It was the highest capacity level since January. The amount of unused domestic refinery capacity fell to 27.4 percent, it added.

title: A Warning, Again, to Women
description: Many women must have been frightened and angered by the results of a study, recently reported in the New England Journal of Medicine, showing that long-time users of birth control pills still face twice or three times the usual risk of heart attack, even up to nine years after discontinuing them. That may not be as fearsome as first appears.

title: JAZZ ALLIANCE IS FORMED TO RAISE FUNDS, PROMOTE ART
description: The American Jazz Alliance has been formed to provide services for jazz groups and to do for jazz what other organizations have long done for other art forms: serve as a center for raising funds from the Government and private sources.

title: OILERS KEEP STABLER ON ROSTER
description: The Houston Oilers, facing more problems at quarterback with uncertainty over the severity of Gifford Nielsen's shoulder injury, said yesterday that they would keep Ken Stabler on the roster at least another week in the hope that he would reverse his decision to retire.

title: AIDING WOMEN TO SEEK OFFICE
description: A two-year study intended to assist women running for local office in Connecticut has evaluated the experiences of 503 who ran in municipal elections in 1979 and 45 who ran in legislative elections in 1980 - both winners and losers, Republicans and Democrats.

title: Markets
description: The financial markets fell precipitously, shaken by new fears of tight money and bigger Federal deficits. Yields in the bond market surged to record levels. Long-term Treasury bonds changed hands at prices yielding 14.55 percent, and Bell System bonds approached yields of 17 percent. The losses, realized or on paper, were enormous. (Page A1.) The stock market plunged across a broad front. The Dow Jones industrial average registered its biggest one-day drop this year, falling 20.46 points, to 900.11. (D1.)

title: BECKMAN INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Affirms Its Dislike Of Apartheid Policies
description: The State Department affirmed today that it viewed South Africa's apartheid policies as ''repugnant.'' But the department declined comment on a report that the United States refused last week to join a move to have the diplomatic corps in South Africa protest the Government's treatment of black squatters in Cape Town.

title: U.S. EASING RULES ON DISCRIMINATION BY ITS CONTRACTORS
description: The Reagan Administration moved today to relax antidiscrimination rules for Federal contractors and to ease requirements for remedial action.

title: Royals Snap Tiger Streak at 9
description: Amos Otis hit a homer in the second inning and a tie-breaking double in the eighth tonight, enabling the Kansas City Royals to snap the Detroit Tigers' nine-game winning streak with a 4-2 victory.

title: GREAT NECK, CORDERO PREVAIL
description: Great Neck won the $58,400 Seneca Handicap today to give Angel Cordero his sixth consecutive Saratoga riding title on the final day of the busiest season in the history of the track.

title: THE REGION
description: A United Auto Workers local representing more than 900 service and maintenance workers has authorized a strike against Cornell University, just a week before 17,000 students are to return to the Ivy League campus, officials said.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CRITON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After $51,000 loss for the qr from discontinued operations and gains of $4,663,000 for the qr and $4,959,000 for the 6 mos from the sale of discontinued operations

title: S.E.C. Appoints General Counsel
description: Edward F. Greene, 39 years old, has been appointed general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, effective Sept. 1. He succeeds Ralph C. Ferrara, who, as previously announced, resigned to join the New York law firm of Debevois & Plimpton.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK DEFENDS ARMS FOR PAKISTAN
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said here tonight that the Reagan Administration did not believe that contemplated arms sales to Pakistan posed any real threat for India. She said India had the ''fourth largest military establishment in the world.''

title: Chief Takes Job At Sports Complex
description: The Police Chief of New Haven said he was retiring to take charge of the Wackenhut guards at the New Jersey Meadowlands Sports Complex. Chief Edward Morrone is 47 years old and has been with the New Haven police 25 years.

title: Around the Nation; Fishermen on Bighorn Report They're Fired On
description: Three fishermen told the police that a group of Crow Indians shot at them with pistols on the Bighorn River, the National Park Service said today.

title: Bally Acquires Pizza Chain
description: The Bally Manufacturing Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of pinball and electronic games, said it would buy a chain of pizza restaurants and convert the outlets into combination arcade-pizza parlors.

title: AIR-BASED MISSILES MAY BE RULED OUT
description: President Reagan has reached a ''preliminary'' decision on basing the new MX missile system, according to a White House spokesman.

title: Books of the Times
description: By John Leonard SAKI. A Life of Hector Hugh Munro. With six short stories never before collected. by A.J. Langguth. Illustrated. 366 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: In The Nation; RETHINKING THE MX
description: .0,2President Reagan and Budget Director Stockman are looking for $75 billion in additional spending cuts in order to achieve their promised balanced budget by 1984.

title: Carter Warmly Greeted On Arriving in Peking
description: Former President Jimmy Carter got a warm reception today as he arrived on a 10-day trip, reciprocating visits made by Chinese leaders during his Administration.

title: Gubernatorial Honeymooch
description: Governor and Mrs. Carey are off on a trip to their ancestral lands, Ireland and Greece, and are calling it a belated honeymoon. Emily Post says that the groom pays for the honeymoon but in this case, the Greek Tourist Board is paying transportation and hotel bills for the trip to Greece, and Aer Lingus, the Irish national airline, will pay for the transportation to Ireland and back home.

title: FINANCIAL MARKETS SHAKEN
description: Renewed fears of high interest rates and the prospect of growing Federal budget deficits shook the financial markets yesterday. In the bond market, interest rates surged to record levels. On the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.46 points to its lowest level in more than a year.

title: Science Watch; Sparrow Song
description: Young swamp sparrows are more inventive in their singing than one would suspect from listening to the adults of the species, scientists have discovered.

title: Allied to Continue Its Garfinckel Bid
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said that its $207.5 million tender offer for Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc. - bitterly rejected by Garfinckel - still stood.

title: POLICIES ON DOMESTIC SPYING BY U.S. AGENTS TO BE RELAXED
description: The Reagan Administration intends to reduce the number of top-level officials who must approve the use of spying tactics by United States intelligence agents on American citizens and corporations, a top Justice Department official says.

title: Going Out Guide
description: TRUE LOVE

title: FEUDING BY HOSPITAL SUPPLIERS
description: A company develops a new product. A former employee or distributor starts to market an all but indistinguishable copy. Lawsuits fill the air.

title: CONVICTED SPY, ARRAIGNED IN ESCAPE, HAS REJECTED FOOD SINCE ARREST
description: Christopher J. Boyce, the convicted spy for the Soviet Union, was arraigned today on a charge of escaping from a Federal prison. Officials said that he had refused to eat since his arrest Friday night and had indicated that he intended to commit suicide by starving himself.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EXHUMATION IS DUE AS CITY INVESTIGATES C.I.A. LINKS IN CASE
description: The body of Dennis McNell, the brother of two men whose charges of fraud led to the resignation of a top official of the Central Intelligence Agency, today was ordered exhumed from a cemetery in Maine for an autopsy.

title: Fleeing Suspect Shot By a Brooklyn Officer
description: A police officer shot and wounded a fleeing suspect who jumped out of a window of a Brooklyn station house yesterday, a police spokesman said. The officer apparently was in violation of the department's deadly force guidelines, authorities added.

title: More Bad Advice on Crime
description: It will set Federal justice back 67 years if Attorney General William French Smith takes the advice of his Task Force on Violent Crime and succeeds in relaxing the safeguards against illegally seized evidence.

title: A BROOKLYN JUDGE BACKS KITE FLIER'S 'GETTING HIGH'
description: Saying that the case was ''for the birds,'' a Criminal Court judge in Brooklyn yesterday threw out a summons that the police had given a Bay Ridge man for flying a kite in what they said was an illegal and hazardous manner. The police said the kite had been at 1,000 feet.

title: Text of panel's report is on page B7.
description: The Senate Select Committee on Ethics recommended unanimously today that Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. be expelled from the Senate, accusing him of ''ethically repugnant'' conduct in the Abscam undercover investigation into political corruption.

title: Addendum
description: * Trendex Communications International, a new public relations company at 211 East 53d Street.

title: WISDOM OF ANCIENT EGYPT COMES TO LIFE AS LIMERICKS
description: ABOUT 4,450 years ago in Egypt, a powerful vizier named Ptahhotep in the Fifth Dynasty court of Pharaoh Izezi thought he was getting a bit too old for the job and decided he had better prepare his king for the vizier's reduced activity if not his retirement.

title: Israeli Canal Plan Opposed
description: Prime Minister Mudar Badran told Parliament today that Israeli plans for a canal linking the Dead Sea to the Mediterranean through the West Bank represented ''direct aggression on Jordan.''

title: Around the Nation; Financial Plan Rejected For Schools in Chicago
description: The Chicago School Finance Authority voted unanimously today to reject the Board of Education's three-year financial plan, casting doubt on whether classes will open as scheduled Sept. 9.

title: GST LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fire at Restoration Called Suspicious
description: A blaze that destroyed an 18th-century barn at the Philipsburg Manor Restoration in North Tarrytown, N.Y., Sunday night has been labeled suspicious by fire officials.

title: New York; PING-PONG FOR 36,000
description: The city's population of sidewalk people - the homeless, the disoriented, the misfits - is in the tens of thousands and growing. No one wants them.

title: Laker Denies Sale Report
description: Sir Freddie Laker, the low-air fare pioneer, today denied a published report that he planned to sell three widebody A-300B Airbus aircraft to meet loan payments due soon.

title: THE LATEST FROM LONDON ARRIVES IN SOHO (OURS)
description: So what if you can't make it to London for a firsthand look at that city's avant-garde fashions? Now you can simply go downtown to 72 Thompson Street, where a new store with much of the latest from London is set to open Thursday. It is called Susanne Bartsch, after its owner, and there is really nothing quite like it around.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
QADDAFI SAID TO SEEK MEETING ON U.S. 'AGGRESSION'
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, paid a brief visit to Kuwait today and then flew to Syria in a reported attempt to win support for a discussion by Arab leaders on what to do about United States ''aggression.''

title: DID FREUD'S ISOLATION LEAD HIM TO REVERSE THEORY ON NEUROSIS?
description: UNPUBLISHED letters and growing research into the hidden life of Sigmund Freud are providing new insight into a momentous turning point in the history of psychoanalysis -Freud's reversal of his theory attributing neurosis in adults to sexual seduction in childhood.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Diplomat Testifies In Layton Murder Trial
description: Richard Dwyer, an American diplomat, testified today that he had urged Representative Leo J. Ryan to leave the People's Temple cult settlement at Jonestown, Guyana, for his own safety, but that Mr. Ryan wanted to stay another night to encourage others to leave.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OUR LOPSIDED WAR ON HUNGER
description: To the Editor:

title: 350 Flee Fire In Bronx Building
description: About 350 people, many of them elderly, were forced out of a commercial and office building in the Fordham section of the Bronx yesterday morning when a fire suddenly erupted in a ground-floor furniture store.

title: Renaissance Band Concerts
description: The 12-member New York Renaissance Band will return this season to Alice Tully Hall for its sixth series of concerts of early music. There will be three Saturday concerts, all at 8 P.M., with the following titles: Nov. 28, ''Gargantua and Pantagruel''; Jan. 30, ''The Renaissance Band Expos'd''; and April 3, ''A Little Knight Music.''

title: Sports of The Times; Testing the Pro Basketball Draft
description: WHEN Don Cronson and Howard Wood first met on a playground basketball court in East Hampton, L.I., Wood was 13 years old, and Cronson was an admitted ''old jock'' as well as a lawyer.

title: The Doctor'S World; ALCOHOLIC RATS MAY PROVIDE ANSWERS TO A PROBLEM OF MAN
description: WE know that too much alcohol makes us drunk and too much of it over a long period can kill by damaging the liver and other organs. But the scientific reasons for these effects are not clear, such as:

title: Around the Nation; Postal Workers Approve Pact by Large Margin
description: Postal workers overwhelmingly ratified new contracts, union officials said early today, in the first election involving Federal employee unions since the air controllers' strike began Aug. 3.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
No Headline
description: The Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday yesterday incorrectly identified the winner of the 1976 Canada Cup hockey tournament. The winner was Canada.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REEVES COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 50 percent stock divd paid July 10, 1981

title: NORTH AMERICAN ROYALTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Jan 1981

title: News conference excerpts, page A10.
description: The commander of the Sixth Fleet said today that American fighters intercepted Libyan aircraft on 45 occasions during manuevers last week, but had not fired on them until two Libyan SU-22's fired at two Navy F-14's.

title: 20.46 DROP PUTS DOW AT 900.11
description: Stock market prices plunged yesterday as fears of rising interest rates sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 20.46 points, to 900.11, its lowest level in more than a year.

title: SMITH RULED OFF PRIMARY BALLOT IN MAYORAL RACE
description: James A. Smith, one of Mayor Koch's three Democratic opponents, was ruled off the ballot yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Justice Charles G. Tierney ruled that Mr. Smith, the operator of a printing business, had fallen short of the 10,000 signatures of enrolled Democrats necessary to qualify for the Sept. 10 primary.

title: SCHMIDT OPEN TO A NEUTRON ROLE
description: Two weeks after President Reagan's decision to produce the neutron warhead, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has said that ''under certain conditions'' the weapon could be stationed on West German soil.
