title: Market Place; Gain Forecast For Hospitals
description: HEAVY selling by insiders of two hospital management companies might suggest fear in the executive suites that the Reagan Administration's economic policies will cut into Government payments for medical care and thus hurt profits.

title: State of Nature - and Ignorance
description: The fight in Washington over opening a Montana wilderness area to gas and oil drilling has great symbolic importance. If leases are in fact granted, they would be the first ever issued in a wilderness area.

title: THE TEXT OF THE ETHICS COMMITTEE'S STATEMENT ON WILLIAMS EXPULSION AND THE TEXT OF ITS REPORT
description: Following are the text of the Senate Ethics Committee's announcment of its recommendation to expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. and the text of a report adopted by the committee in recommending the expulsion: The Announcement

title: PROGRAM TO USE WELFARE MONEY FOR JOB TRAINING
description: New York State is embarking on a program to use welfare funds to subsidize private employers who provide job training for welfare recipients.

title: LONGTERM JOBLESS WILL LOSE BENEFITS
description: ''I voted for Reagan because I figured he'd be the best one to get me out of this unemployment line,'' Ronald Getz said with a grin while the line he was in inched forward.

title: U.S. ACCUSES A SECT OF TRAINING ROBBERS
description: Eighteen members of a paramilitary Muslim sect conducted a series of armed robberies of banks, liquor stores and automobile dealers, plotting some of the robberies from behind prison bars, according to a Federal indictment announced today.

title: GAP STORES INC, THE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $11,000 for the qr and $66,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $2,000 for the qr and $63,000 for the 9 mos

title: AS LANDMARKS FALL
description: To the Editor:

title: PRECINCT CAPTAINS DECIDE THE WHERE AND WHEN OF POLICE PATROLS
description: When the Police Department commissioners and computers turn out personnel allocations or decide on new emphases in crime fighting, it is in places like the 8 by 10 foot office of Capt. Anthony Cepaglia in the Bronx that the headquarters generalities become specifics.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GOLDIN DEPLORES BASE TACTICS, THEN CITIES FOE'S TAX FORMS
description: Harrison J. Goldin, the incumbent New York City Comptroller, said yesterday that he wanted to ''raise the tone of the campaign'' for Comptroller by discussing the duties of the office. He then contended that his opponent in the Democratic primary had made ''arithmetical mistakes'' on his income-tax forms.

title: Bridge: Bergen and Kamil Capture Men's Pairs in Albany Play
description: Those who organize regional tournaments in New York City are often hard-pressed to find a playing area of sufficient size. The planners of the five-day regional championships that ended Sunday in Albany were particularly fortunate in this respect, for they were able to use the spacious accommodations of the Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller Empire State Plaza Convention Center.

title: Inquest Held in Settles Death
description: A witness to the arrest of Ron Settles, the Long Beach State football star who was found hanging in his jail cell hours after having been booked, told a coroner's inquest today that two police officers put their guns to Settles's head while apprehending him in June for a minor traffic violation.

title: WORKERS AT POLISH STEEL MILL CHALLENGING MANAGEMENT
description: The towers of the iron and steel plant here loom in the morning fog like some unstoppable symbol of the Communist ideal.

title: Notes on People; South Pacific Honeymoon for the Chandlers
description: The board chairman and editor in chief of the Times Mirror Company, Otis Chandler, and his bride were reported honeymooning in Tahiti and Bora-Bora yesterday, and were not expected back in Los Angeles until next week.

title: The Talk of Waterbury
description: ''Waterbury used to be known universally as the brass center of the world,'' said Frank Santaguida, a spokesman for the only surviving big mill here, Century Brass. ''Now it's known as a city between New York and Boston.''

title: News Analysis
description: In officially notifying Congress today of its plans to proceed with the sale of five surveillance aircraft to Saudi Arabia, the Reagan Administration enclosed the deal in a strategic framework designed to persuade Israel and its backers that Israel's security would be enhanced and not diminished by the strengthening of Saudi military forces. Underlying this approach to Middle East policy is Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s belief - first stated last March - that ''it is fundamentally important to begin to develop a consensus of strategic concerns throughout the region among Arab and Jew and to be sure that the overriding danger of Soviet inroads into this area are not overlooked.''

title: TANDY BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Included a partial retirement of debentures of $370,000; 1980 figures included a non-recurring gain of $477,000 from disposal of assets

title: GENERAL REAL ESTATE SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net income figures represent net investment income

title: Little League Teams In World Series Today
description: Eight teams of 11- and 12-yearold boys from five nations are gathering here for the 35th Little League World Series, which begins tomorrow and continues through Saturday.

title: AN AYATOLLAH'S HOME FIRED ON
description: The home of Iran's Prosecutor General was attacked early today by up to 15 armed men as a guerrilla campaign against the Islamic fundamentalist Government continued, the Teheran radio reported.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, AUGUST 25, 1981
description: International American jets intercepted Libyan jets 45 times during maneuvers last week, but had not fired until two Libyan SU-22's fired at two F-14's, according to the commander of the Sixth Fleet. He also said at a news conference that the battle last Wednesday that resulted in the shooting down of the two Libyan planes took place slightly outside a ''designated'' area where the United States had said maneuvers were taking place, but still well within international waters. (Page A1, Column 3.) Arms sales to the Saudis were pressed by the Reagan Administration. It formally notified Congress that it was proceeding with its intention to sell to Riyadh five advanced radar planes and other air defense equipment. The $8.5 billion sale could be vetoed by a joint resolution of disapproval by the two houses of Congress. (A1:2.)

title: Goldstein Fined $1,368 And Put on Probation
description: Manny Goldstein, former New Mexico assistant basketball coach, was given a suspended sentence of one and one-half years, placed on probation and fined $1,368 today for his convictions on one count of fraud and one of filing a false public voucher.

title: THE YEAR OF BOBBY ALLISON
description: The wait has been so long that it doesn't seem logical. For 15 years Bobby Allison has been one of the best drivers in stock car racing, but he has never won the Grand National championship, the premier prize of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing. Three times he has placed second - in 1970, 1972 and 1978.

title: McDonnell, British In Harrier Jet Pact
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and British Aerospace Ltd. have agreed on terms for the joint manufacture of 400 advanced Harrier jump-jet fighters, the state-owned British concern announced today.

title: Salvation Army, in a Protest, Quits World Church Council
description: The Salvation Army has quit the World Council of Churches to protest the ecumenical movement's aid to armed liberation movements, the council said today.

title: INVESTORS PURCHASE STAKE IN SIMPLICITY
description: A group of investors disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that they had acquired an 11.2 percent interest in the Simplicity Pattern Company. The investors also said that they intended to use the holdings in an attempt to block a proposed $85 million merger of Simplicity with NCC Energy Ltd., a British energy and minerals concern.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $50,000 for the latest yr and $24,000 for the previous yr

title: Notes on People; Wanted: Female Comedians for a 'Roast'
description: Since they began in 1950, the luncheon ''roasts'' sponsored by the Friars Club have been exclusively a male preserve. The humor runs not so much to double-entendre as to singular scatology, and that has long been considered unfit for feminine ears.

title: No Headline
description: RETURNS HOME AFTER SWINDLE: Katie Klaasen, 91 years old, being greeted by a social worker as she arrived at Miami airport yesterday. A boarding room operator, Lucille Collins, also known as Lucille Walker, is suspected of kidnapping Miss Klaasen and four other elderly women, bringing them to Detroit and bilking them of their life savings. Mrs. Collins failed to turn herself in yesterday after telling a Michigan prosecutor that she would. The women apparently thought that they were being taken on vacation but were held for 10 days at a home run by relatives of Mrs. Collins, two of whom have been arraigned on five kidnapping counts.

title: Springboks Can Play In Albany, Mayor Says
description: Despite protests stemming from South Africa's racial policies, Mayor Erastus Corning affirmed his stand today that a rugby team from that country could use city-owned Bleeker Stadium for a game against an American team Sept. 22.

title: Around the World; Jailed Irish Nationalist Joins Hunger Strike
description: A jailed Irish nationalist today joined the hunger strike in which 10 prisoners have died.

title: OCELOT INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRUIT FLY QUARANTINE AREA EXTENDED IN CALIFORNIA
description: The area of California where shipment of fruit and vegetables is quarantined because of the Mediterranean fruit fly was expanded by nearly a third today. The change, to more than 3,000 square miles, followed discovery of a fertile fly near a major pepper-growing area.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE fashionable were perplexed. The sign on the door said Odeon was closed until the 31st, which meant there was no place for them to go for a midnight drink of any kind. So they were forced to to try places off their beaten path - like J.S. Vandam, Joanna or Da Silvano, where they dined outside amid the car exhausts and headlamps of Seventh Avenue South.

title: DANCE: STEPS IN THE 'SSANDD' FROM ROSALIND NEWMAN
description: ROSALIND NEWMAN'S ''Ssandd,'' performed on Sunday in the Art on the Beach series at Battery Park City Landfill, lived up to its name with a vengeance. It was a carefully worked-out dance that used almost every aspect of the site - a vast expanse of sand and river and dune framed by skyscrapers - and the kind of dancing that makes the most of that shifting, gritty stage surface. Dressed in white Tshirts and pants, Miss Newman's 15 dancers performed in silence, too, so that the distant cries of children and gulls and the hoots of passing tugs became an indelible element in ''Ssandd.''

title: ENERGY RESOURCES OF NORTH DAKOTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $269,300 tax credit...C-Including $178,422 or 1 cent a shr income from the cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aeronca Inc. said it was forming a new division to develop and market microcomputer software to be distributed through computer stores.

title: ROOKIE'S HOMER IN 12TH FOR TWINS BEATS YANKS, 3-2
description: The Minnesota Twins, contending for a double last-place finish this year, cried for help all the way to the Class A level of the minor leagues yesterday, and Kent Hrbek responded with a 12th-inning home run that beat the Yankees, 3-2, last night.

title: 200-FOOT CRANE INJURES 5 AS IT FALLS OVER 54TH ST.
description: A 200-foot crane collapsed yesterday on the site of a luxury condominium being built midway between First Avenue and Sutton Place, upending its 18-wheel truck on the East 54th Street sidewalk and crashing north to break sidewalk slabs on East 55th Street.

title: BRUNO'S INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to July 4
description: B-Including gains from discontinued operations of $553,000 for the 12 weeks and $1,911,000 for the yr...C-Including gains from discontinued operations of $436,000 for the 12 weeks and $1,445,000 for the yr

title: Science Watch; Trees vs. Hares
description: Can a tree defend itself against an animal that browses on its branches? Scientists are not sure, but in Alaska there appears to be some evidence that has led one researcher to theorize that it may be so.

title: A Look Back at Bentley
description: Seventeen years ago, Donald J. Bentley was vice president and general manager of Edwards Laboratories, where an oxygenator - which functions as a heart and lungs during open heart surgery - was developed. The machine was built under Mr. Bentley's direction and, as he recalled yesterday, he saw enormous potential for the product.

title: MISS ALLEN BOWS AFTER A DISPUTE
description: Leslie Allen of New York became the first seeded player to be ousted in the $100,000 Volvo Women's Cup tennis tournament tonight, when she dropped a controversial first-round match to Mareen Louie of San Francisco, 6-1, 4-6, 7-5.

title: 3D BUBBLE MEMORY EFFORT ENDS
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it was withdrawing from the bubble memory business, becoming the third American electronics company this year to drop out of a market that was once viewed as extremely promising.

title: U.S. Urges Approval Of Pipeline
description: The Reagan Administration is appealing to officials of Washington State to approve the proposed $1.8 billion Northern Tier Project, a pipeline that would carry crude oil from Alaska and California to refineries along a 1,500-mile route from Puget Sound to northern Minnesota.

title: LION COUNTRY SAFARI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AUTO EXHAUST STANDARD IS DISPUTED IN GERMANY
description: West Germany's auto makers are resisting measures sought by the Bonn Government to tighten emissions standards and cut fuel consumption.

title: CORRECTION
description: A list of developers for Battery Park City in Metropolitan Report last Wednesday incorrectly described the Center for Housing Partnerships. It is a nonprofit corporation that retains in- dependent architects and contractors for projects it co-sponsors with com- munity groups and institutions.

title: Team Canada Wins
description: Gilbert Perreault scored the decisive goal at 7 minutes 43 seconds of the third period, and Steve Payne and Ron Duguay added goals late in the game to lead Team Canada to a 5-2 Canada Cup exhibition triumph over the United States tonight.

title: Whirlpool Layoffs
description: The Whirlpool Corporation, the home appliance manufacturer, said it would lay off 280 hourly workers because of lagging sales of automatic washing machines. The layoffs, effective on Wednesday, will cause the temporary closing of one of three automatic washer assembly lines at the company's division in St. Joseph, Mich., a company spokesman said. Whirlpool is based in Benton Harbor and employs more than 1,600 hourly workers at the St. Joseph plant.

title: Notes on People; A Nelson Slowdown
description: Recuperating from a collapsed lung he suffered while swimming, Willie Nelson, the country-music singer, has canceled all his concerts through the end of September.

title: BIG SKY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: HERE'S a cautionary tale of the South - and North - Pacific that has led to a $20,000 problem between Doyle Dane Bernbach and American Airlines, which started flights to the Hawaiian Islands last winter.

title: CAVENHAM USA INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to July 18
The U.N. Today; Aug. 25, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Ontario Hydro Bond
description: Ontario Hydro, the province of Ontario's government-owned electric utility, signed for a $150 million (United States), 10-year Eurobond, with a 16 percent coupon and par pricing, the lead manager, Deutsche Bank, said today. The bond, guaranteed by the province of Ontario, is the largest issue in the Euromarket ever floated for a Canadian utility, Deutsche said.

title: TWINS SET BACK YANKEES, 3-0
description: The Yankees suffered another shutout last night, this time 3-0 to the Minnesota Twins. But there was something different in this shutout - Aurelio Rodriguez batted for Reggie Jackson.

title: Tea Men Defeat Chiefs, Capture Playoff Series
description: Alan Green scored two goals tonight to give Jacksonville a 2-1 victory over the Atlanta Chiefs, advancing the Tea Men to the second round of the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: Advertising; Analyzing 'Irritation Factor'
description: WHAT Rena Bartos, senior vice president at J. Walter Thompson, calls ''the irritation factor'' in today's advertising has left her, if not exactly irritated, at least distinctly worried about its implications for the advertising industry.

title: New Campaigns Set For a Cigar and Wine
description: The Consolidated Cigar Company, a division of the Gulf and Western Corporation, is huffing and puffing in preparation for what it calls ''the biggest ad campaign in cigar history,'' beginning Sept. 21. Nadler & Larimer is the agency for the $5 million, 12-month effort on behalf of Consolidated's new Backwoods Smokes.

title: GUILFORD MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for 5-for-4 stock split paid in Dec 1980

title: BOND TRADER FINDS MARKET FALL 'SCARY'
description: It was slightly after 10 A.M. Monday, with government bond prices skidding and no buyers to be found, that Steven L. Edelson, vice president for government bond trading at Chemical Bank, put in a call to his vacationing boss in Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Loos Memorial Tomorrow
description: A memorial for Anita Loos, the author, who died Aug. 18, will be held tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 80th Street.

title: PRINCETON, N.J. - This month's dramatic hijacking by an Iranian monarchist group of a formerly embargoed Iranian missile boat en route from Cherbourg, France, to Iran was clearly inspired by the spiriting of five embargoed missile boats from Cherbourg to Israel on Christmas Eve 1969. But while the Israeli coup nearly doubled Israel's missile-equipped naval force and contributed materially to its victory over the Egyptian and Syrian navies in October 1973, the Iranian operation was merely a publicity stunt.  Even with the delivery of all three of the missile boats that were in the convoy - and which were handed over by France without their American-made missiles - much of the Iranian Navy may soon be fit only for mothballs.
description: Less than four years ago, such a statement would have been preposterous. The Shah was engaged in a mammoth naval expansion designed to turn Iran's already large navy into one of the most formidable naval fighting forces in the world.

title: Three F-15's Arrive in Israel After U.S. Lifts Suspension
description: The United States today delivered to Israel some of the fighter planes that were held back after the Israeli air raid on an Iraqi nuclear reactor in June, a military spokesman reported.

title: A Book on Setting Up In-House Ad Agencies
description: Now comes the ultimate how-to book: ''How to Be Your Own Advertising Agency'' by Bert Holtje, who heads his own shop, Tek-Mark, Inc. The book (McGraw-Hill, 215 pages, $17.95) is meant partly as a primer for executives of companies outside the advertising industry who are thinking of setting up in-house advertising agencies. It's also written for those who work for in-house shops or head them.

title: Accounts
description: * The Philadelphia Museum of Art to Tyson Ketchum, Philadelphia.

title: The Pop Life; THE ROLLING STONES: ONCE ADOLESCENT, THEY'VE GROWN UP
description: ''TATTOO YOU,'' the new album by the Rolling Stones, is in local record stores today, a week ahead of schedule. Despite extensive security precautions taken by Rolling Stones Records, a copy of the album (probably a tape) made its way to WNMR, a radio station in Philadelphia, and was broadcast at the beginning of last week. Another Philadelphia station, WYST, taped the album off the air and began broadcasting its tape. Within a few days, tapes of the original tape were being broadcast in Buffalo and Chicago, and a copy had reached a disk jockey at WNEW in New York, who called Atlantic Records, the album's distributor. At this point, Rolling Stones Records decided to rush-release the album.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON FRAUD SUIT
description: Did the maker of America's most popular pain-killing pills buy up an innovative electronic pain-killing device in order to stifle the product's development and thereby protect its own drug business?

title: ELY S. RUBIN
description: Ely S. Rubin, motion-picture advertising director of Variety, the entertainment newspaper, died unexpectedly last Saturday at his home in Kearny, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bethlehem Plans To Close Bar Mill
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest producer, said that it would shut a mill in the first stage of a planned phase-out of its tool steel division at its Bethlehem, Pa., plant, a move that will affect about 300 workers.

title: 2 of Gang of 7 Are Sentenced To Life for Rape in Michigan
description: Nearly a year after a Chicago street gang's rape and robbery rampage in southwest Michigan, the remaining two of seven gang members have been sentenced to life in prison.

title: THE CHURCH DINNER: A HARLEM TRADITION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Doris Funnye Innis is a freelance writer and researcher. By DORIS FUNNYE INNIS

title: TEACHERS AT A MAINLY BLACK UNIVERSITY WARNED TO FINISH DOCTORATES
description: In a move by state higher education officials to upgrade predominantly black state universities, scores of junior faculty members at North Carolina Central University here have been told to complete their doctoral degrees by the end of November or face dismissal.

title: Bridge: Undoubled Contracts Vary In Different Parts of World
description: Two interesting trivia questions for the enthusiast are these: What is the rarest undoubled contract? And what is the rarest doubled contract below the level of four no-trump?

title: Around the World; 50 People Are Killed In Salvadoran Violence
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked a bus with dynamite, killing 5 passengers and wounding 14 near San Vicente, the army reported today.

title: First Colony Seeks Business Partner
description: The First Colony Life Insurance Company, one of the nation's 100 largest insurers, said today that it was seeking a business combination with a bigger company to finance its continued expansion.

title: Jail for Ex-Immigration Aide
description: A former Immigration and Naturalization Service official was sentenced today to at least six months in prison for tax evasion and for accepting payoffs to help foreigners, many of them Iranians, file fraudulent immigration papers. Federal Judge Thomas A. Flannery imposed the sentence on Maron Sheehi, 55 years old, of Alexandria, Va.

title: A $161 MILLION BUILDING, ASSESSED AT $30.8 MILLION
description: The Manufacturer's Hanover Trust Company headquarters building on Park Avenue, which has just been sold for $161 million, is assessed by the city at $30.8 million, or 19 percent of its market value, the city's Department of Finance said yesterday.

title: Conscience in the Senate
description: The Senate Ethics Committee's split verdict in the case of Senator Harrison Williams of New Jersey displays all too clearly the inability of Congress to police itself.

title: MODERN MERCHANDISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
WOODWARD & LOTHROP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
WAVES OF CHANGE BUFFET A DREAM OF CITIZENSHIP
description: The rains that ruined much of Franz Leuthardt's strawberry crop this season will not drive the Swiss-born farmer from his 141 acres of bottom land here in rural Missouri. But the obstacles that keep him and his family from becoming American citizens just may.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE PRICE WAR BENEFITS BUYERS BUT THE TRADE IS IN TURMOIL, WITH SMALL SHOPS HARD HIT By Terry Robards

title: JAPAN WILL BAR PRODUCE UNTREATED FOR FRUIT FLY
description: The Japanese Government told United States officials today that it would not permit several types of California produce to be imported unless they have been fumigated or otherwise treated against possible infestation by the Mediterranean fruit fly.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 26, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Going Out Guide
description: REBIRTH OF THE BLUES

title: THOUSANDS EVACUATED AFTER COAST GAS LINE BURSTS
description: A gas main ruptured today, forcing the evacuation of tens of thousands of workers and shoppers from the heart of the financial district.

title: U.S. INVESTMENT ABROAD INCREASED 14.3% IN 1980
description: American investments overseas rose 14.3 percent in 1980, nearly the same increase as in the previous year, the Government said today.

title: The Economy
description: The Consumer Price Index jumped 1.2 percent in July, the fastest inflation pace in 16 months, the Labor Department said. For the three previous months the average advance was six-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts said the surge - 15.2 percent at an annual rate - hurt prospects for lower interest rates. (Page A1.)

title: A SCENARIO
description: To the Editor:

title: LANDMARKS AGENCY URGED TO SAVE 3 BUILDINGS
description: Residents on 63d Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues yesterday urged the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to declare three buildings on the block historic landmarks and thereby prevent a developer from demolishing them for an 11-story apartment building.

title: The Editorial Notebook; TWO YELLOWSTONES
description: At the western exit from Yellowstone Park, the traveler comes upon the village of West Yellowstone; it's like suddenly arriving at Coney Island. Though the park is crowded and some visitors do break some rules, like feeding the deer, bison and moose, the roadways are immaculate and it is wild where it is supposed to be wild. Though not the most beautiful national park, Yellowstone is interesting for its geological phenomena, its wildlife and extraordinary fishing.

title: UNASKED QUESTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Stop Orders As Hedges
description: INVESTORS tempted to snap up bargains in the current disastrous stock market should consider hedging their bets with stop-loss orders. Recent history provides a reason for caution: The market fell harder in 1973 than it has so far this year, but that did not prevent the 1974 collapse.

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including other income of $3,879,000 which consisted of claims income of $4,290,000 and nonoperating expenses of $411,000...C-Including other income of $4,755,000 principally claims income and $11,802,000 extraordinary income; E.C. Ernst Inc has been in Chapter 11 since Dec 1, 1978

title: PUTTING A BETTER FACE ON SQUID
description: THOUSANDS of people crowded into this city along the shores of Monterey Bay in central California last weekend to toast the squid, an ugly mollusk with an identity problem whose friends call it ''the food of the future.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no doubt that the cause of world peace has been advanced by this Sino-American friendship.'' - Jimmy Carter. (A13:5.)

title: MALAYSIA ENDS BAN ON PREMIER'S BOOK
description: Deputy Prime Minister Musa Hitam said he expected no criticism when he decided to lift an 11-year-old ban on a book. ''In fact,'' he said jokingly in an interview, ''I asked the author for a commission.''

title: Shuttle Said to Perform Well In Mock Blastoff and Landing
description: The space shuttle Columbia performed ''like a champ'' today in a mock blastoff and emergency landing before its second flight, scheduled next month.

title: Personal Health; STRESS: WHETHER TO FIGHT OR FLEE
description: IUSED to get headaches all the time: when I was writing on deadline, doing a lot of sewing, preparing for a dinner party, driving in heavy traffic. I attributed them to a variety of causes, including eyestrain and allergic reactions to my colleague's tobacco smoke and to the fumes from my gas stove. But not until I awoke one morning from a bad dream with my teeth tightly clenched did I get a hint of the real reason - a reaction to stress.

title: OILERS' NIELSEN OUT 2-3 WEEKS
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Houston Oilers learned today that their starting quarterback, Gifford Nielsen, who injured his shoulder in an exhibition game over the weekend, would be lost for two to three weeks, into the start of the regular season.

title: VW Still Top Seller at Home
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. remained West Germany's top-selling car maker in the first seven months of this year, with domestic sales totaling 353,700 cars, or 23.2 percent of the market, the Federal Motor Office said today.

title: Careers; Professors May Help Find Jobs
description: LADY LUCK can help a job hunter; so can employment agencies, advertisements in newspapers and trade magazines, college vocational offices and company interviews on campus.

title: Concerns Buy Solar Power
description: A Los Angeles company said today that it had reached an agreement to supply solar power to three United States textile companies in what it called the largest privately financed solar energy project in the United States.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Monday, current passenger volume of commuter airlines was misstated. The correct figure is 6 of every 10 seats filled.

title: Steel Outlook Called Worse
description: Steelmakers who earlier hoped for a strong finish in 1981 are revising their outlook as the traditional late-summer slump shows signs of lingering.

title: CDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Notes On People; An Uncompleat Angler
description: The speedboat was named Fidelity and the cocker spaniel in the cockpit was called Fred, but who was that man at the wheel who sped up to the Maine State Pier in Portland on Monday and fished quietly for an hour before departing as swiftly as he had come?

title: GREEN GETS SUSPENSION FOR JOSTLING AN UMPIRE
description: Dallas Green, the manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, was suspended indefinitely by the National League yesterday for jostling the umpire Steve Fields and then knocking Fields's cap off and kicking it during a game Monday night.

title: Giants Cut Six, All on Defense
description: The Giants trimmed their roster to this week's 50-man limit today by asking waivers on six veteran defensive players. At the same time, they had to begin facing potential problems with defensive backs resulting from player injuries and their own roster moves.

title: FIRESTONE CLIMBS; DEERE UP SHARPLY
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the country's second-largest tire producer after the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, reported yesterday that it had net income in its third fiscal quarter of $18 million, or 31 cents a share, compared with a loss of $32 million a year earlier. Sales, however, slipped 3.6 percent, to $1.08 billion, from $1.12 billion.

title: DOMAN INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: A GUIDE TO THE MAJOR COOKING SCHOOLS IN EUROPE
description: PARIS THE choice of cooking schools in Europe has never been more varied, and, in recent years at least, the prices have never been better. With the dollar having increased sharply against the franc and holding its own against the pound and the lira, the dozens of cooking programs now available take on new appeal.Several new schools have started up in England, including one run by the food writer and restaurateur Robert Carrier, who this summer began a course at his manor house, Hintlesham Hall, in Suffolk. The Horn of Plenty, a Michelin-starred restaurant in Tavistock, opened a school specializing in sauces in March. The chef, Sonia Stevenson, teaches students to prepare sauces in the morning, then the group samples the chef's own preparations in the dining room at lunch and dinner.

title: U.N. GETS A REPORT ON AFRICAN SLAVES
description: As many as l00,000 slaves, probably the world's largest slave population, are laboring in Mauritania, according to a report under study by the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including recoveries from discontinued operations of $45,997 for the qr $122,430 for the yr...C-Including recovery from discontinued operations of $41,693

title: Arlington Entry Is Out; Spread of Flu Is Denied
description: Arlington Park race officials denied today published reports that an influenza virus was spreading through the track's barns and might affect Sunday's running of the Arlington Million.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings for the latest periods reflect 4 million additional common shares sold in Jan 1981

title: PANAMA'S MILITARY TRIES TO PICK UP TORRIJOS REINS
description: Less than a month after the death of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, Panama's military high command has moved quickly to fill the political vacuum left by the death of the strongman who had ruled the country 13 years.

title: No Headline
description: Steve Shutt scored two goals tonight, leading Team Canada to a 6-5 victory over the United States team in an exhibition game.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Joseph B. Pincus, former director of pediatrics at the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn and a biochemist who did research in the pediatric applications of microscopic chemistry, died in the hospital yesterday of heart failure. He was 82 years old and lived in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. Dr. Pincus, who also served as professor of pediatrics at the State University College of Medicine at the Downstate Medical Center, worked with the late Dr. John Howland of Johns Hopkins University, who is regarded as a founder of modern scientific pediatrics. Dr. Pincus's research led to several important advances in characterizing the diseases of childhood and infancy.

title: TV Notebook; ALL THREE NETWORKS' FALL SEASONS TO OPEN LATE
description: ONCE again, the new prime-time television season will stagger to a start. Last fall, it was the actors' strike that delayed the annual September beginning until the late fall. This season, it was the writers who struck. Thus, new episodes of shows won't be ready until the first week in October, and the three networks won't have their fall schedules fully in place before December.

title: Harvester Admits Bill-Paying Delay
description: The International Harvester Corporation, which is in the midst of a $5 billion refinancing program involving 225 banks, confirmed reports that it was taking longer to pay its bills.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A STREETWISE grammarian I know notes the casual disappearance of the Street Apostrophe. The problem: how to pronounce signs that say ''DONT WALK'' or ''DONT CROSS''? A grounding in phonetics suggests DAUNT WALK, DAUNT CROSS.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net loss after $3 million loss for the qr and 9 mos from discontinued operations and tax credits of $1 million for the qr and $4 million for the 9 mos...C-Including $50 million gain from the sale of a plastics company and $6 million extra- ordinary tax credit

title: METS DEFEAT ASTROS BY 2-1 ON WILSON'S HOMER IN 8TH
description: When Mookie Wilson was an outfielder in college, he was known as a right-handed power hitter who could run. After he turned professional, he was converted into a switch-hitter who could occasionally deliver the long ball.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tampa Tops Stamford In Little League Opener
description: Chris Mitchell hit a three-run homer, and Maurice Crum added a two-run shot today to lead Tampa, Fla., to a 6-3 victory over Stamford, Conn., on the opening day of the 35th Little League World Series.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. AND ISRAEL DISAGREE ON GIVING SOVIET CHOICE WHERE TO SETTLE
description: The State Department and a leading American Jewish refugee organization said today that they opposed an Israeli plan to curtail the flow of Soviet Jews to countries other than Israel.

title: JUDGE WON'T ALLOW CAMERAS AT WILLIAMS TRIAL
description: Cameras will not be permitted in the courtroom for Wayne B. Williams's trial on charges of murdering two young blacks, the presiding judge ruled today.

title: CAPITAL GAINS SHIFT: BENEFITS ARE BROAD
description: Speak of capital gains, and an image of wealthy people with expansive portfolios of stocks and other assets generally comes to mind. In fact, that image is not too far off the mark, and the topbracket taxpayers are indeed getting the most substantial reductions in gains taxes under the new tax law. But tax and investment advisers also say that the new law's more favorable treatment of capital gains should prompt nearly everyone to review his investments and financial plans.

title: Around the Nation; Fugitive for 27 Years Seized at Alabama Home
description: A man who escaped from prison 27 years ago is back in custody after being arrested yesterday at his home.

title: ECUADOR'S DEMOCRACY WEATHERS LOSS OF PRESIDENT
description: This small country of traditionally unstable politics has just gone through the national trauma of the sudden death of a popular young President and has emerged with its newly democratic form of Government intact.

title: POP: PETER HAMMILL'S SONGS
description: songwriter who appeared at the Bottom Line on Monday, was a founding member of Van Der Graaf Generator, an art-rock band in the solemn mode of Procol Harum and King Crimson. As a solo recording artist, Mr. Hammill has also earned a minor cult following with heavily synthesized albums in which he plays most of the instruments and sings in an agonized style that recalls the pre-rock David Bowie.

title: THE NEUTRON BOMB MAKES POLITICS, NOT WAR
description: The recent debate on the neutron bomb, sparked b y President Reagan's decision to procure the weapon, is founded on at otal misconception of its military value.

title: Around the World; Ulster M.P.'s Brother Finds House Wrecked
description: An explosion today demolished an unfinished house near here belonging to the brother of Owen Carron, a new member of the British Parliament. No one was injured.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including $15.7 million gain from the sale of patents and know-how...C-Net loss

title: REAGAN'S MESSAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: NEXT to fishing, the thing that I like most about summer is cooking out of doors. I have great recollections of my days over an open fire, one of the greatest of them being at an outdoor camp beside a stream in Wyoming where we hauled trout directly from those cold running waters, fired up a bunch of twigs and logs, cleaned and cooked the still-quivering fish in a bit of fat and butter and practically no other seasonings. It was one of the great feasts of that year.

title: WASHINGTON'S CONSPICUOUS CONSUMERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Buys More U.S. Grain
description: The Soviet Union has purchased another 200,000 tons of American grain, which will be counted toward the sixth year of a recently extended United States-Soviet grain agreement, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

title: When to Sell The Family Business
description: With stock values tumbling anew and fresh evidence yesterday of untamed inflation, corporate merger activities are not likely to abate. That means more families will be deciding, perhaps feuding, over whether to sell their stake or fend off pin-striped suitors with fistfuls of dollars. Ninety-six out of every 100 United States corporations are controlled by families, including 174 of the 500 largest industrial companies.

title: For Airline Boredom, Plastic Slot Machines
description: A new concept for in-flight entertainment was added today when the first jetliner to be fitted with slot machines took off for San Francisco from Singapore.

title: KIM CARNES SINGS AT SAVOY
description: WITH her sweet, husky voice, blond good looks and effervescent stage presence, Kim Carnes, who appeared at the Savoy on Monday and last night, could hardly be a more fitting representative of the shifting sounds and attitudes of mainstream Los Angeles pop. The recent success of ''Bette Davis Eyes,'' the culmination of her sixalbum career, signaled a change in the sound of Los Angeles pop away from traditionally mellow harmonies toward a more brittle, new-waveinfluenced style.

title: NEW YORK POWER SALE
description: New contracts extending until June 30, 2013, the sale of St. Lawrence River hydroelectric power to plants of the Reynolds Metals Company and the Aluminum Company of America in Massena, N.Y., have been signed by the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: N.C.A.A. Gets Backing For 1982-85 TV Football
description: Members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association have overwhelmingly approved key amendments to the 1982-1985 N.C.A.A. football television program.

title: WALL ST. BLAMES REAGAN BUDGET FOR STOCK SLIDE
description: In late April, the stock market reached its highest level in more than eight years. Signs were that the prolonged period of high interest rates was finally easing, and enthusiasm for the Reagan Administration's budget and tax proposals fed a new mood of optimism on Wall Street.

title: Around the Nation; Postal Service Sticking To Plea for 20-Cent Mail
description: The Postal Service said today that the new contracts overwhelmingly ratified by two big unions would not cause increases in postal rates beyond the 20-cent stamp already requested.

title: Notes on People; The Gipper Interpreted
description: She doesn't really think that a remark her father made recently was intended to discourage her, said Maureen Reagan, and so she's thinking ''very seriously'' about running for the United States Senate next year.

title: ANGELS 8, RED SOX 7
description: Bobby Grich looped a broken-bat single to left field with one out and the bases loaded in the bottom of the 10th inning to drive in the tying and winning runs for California.

title: SHORT-TERM PRICES MOVE UP
description: Government securities shrugged off news of a sharp increase in the Consumer Price Index and rallied yesterday in afternoon trading that pushed up prices for short-term issues and lowered their yields slightly.

title: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on July 2, 1981

title: DEARIE PLEDGES 21 SERVICE AUDITS
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie committed himself yesterday to 21 performance audits of police, fire, sanitation and mass-transit services if elected New York City Comptroller.

title: No Headline
description: The Reagan Administration's economic policies served as the springboard today for the first debate between James J. Florio and Thomas H. Kean, the two major party candidates for Governor of New Jersey.

title: Paul Padua, Artist, Is Dead; Known for Portrait of Hitler
description: Paul Mathias Padua, who won fame in Nazi Germany for his portrait of Hitler, died Saturday in a hospital near his home on the Tegernsee, south of Munich.

title: U.S. SAYS TALKS TOUCHED ON AIR CONTROLLERS' STRIKE
description: Reagan Administration officials met privately with the leader of organized labor's public employee unions last week and discussed the air traffic controllers' strike. But Reagan officials denied today that the unannounced session was an attempt to open secret negotiations to settle the three-week-old strike.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Continental Telephone Co. said it had purchased an additional 80,000 shares of Management Assistance Inc., increasing its share of the New York holding company to 6.5 percent.

title: PLANS TO EASE HIRING RULES ATTACKED
description: Civil rights and women's groups reacted angrily yesterday to the Reagan Administration's decision to ease Federal rules that require companies doing business with the Government to file plans for taking affirmative action to hire women and members of minority groups.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE 1.2% IN JULY, MOST IN 16 MONTHS
description: The Consumer Price Index rose by 1.2 percent in July, the fastest pace for inflation in 16 months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Broken Promises on Reading
description: People who favored decentralized control of New York City's schools used to argue that community school boards would respond more sympathetically to the needs of poorer children than a central bureaucracy. Were they right?

title: THE OTHER GULF
description: To the Editor:

title: Philippine Plant
description: Lafarge Coppee said today that a consortium led by its Belgian subsidiary, Coppee-Rust, had signed a $300 million contract to supply a fertilizer plant to Philphos, a Philippines company. The consortium also includes Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, the Spanish company Dragados y Construcciones and the Construction and Development Corporation of the Philippines. The plant is planned for completion by 1984.

title: EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; shr earnings reflect a 3 percent stock divd paid in Feb 1981

title: LIBYAN AND SYRIAN CHIEFS MEET TO FORGE CLOSER TIES
description: The leaders of Libya and Syria met today to discuss ways to strengthen their cooperation in the face of renewed Israeli-Egyptian talks and what Libyan officials denounced as the ''imperialist designs'' of the United States.

title: 2 Teen-Age Brothers Injured In Plunge Down 50-Foot Shaft
description: Two teen-age brothers were critically injured last night when they fell into a construction shaft and tumbled more than 50 feet to site of a new underground subway station in Jamaica, Queens, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Aug. 11 about changes in the Nuclear Regulatory Commis- sion, a word was omitted from a quota- tion attributed to Donald C. Winston of the Atomic Industrial Forum. His full statement, in addressing the difficul- ties faced by the nuclear power indus- try, was, ''The real problem is utility economics.''

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: Bunker Hill Closing
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation said it would shut its Bunker Hill Company operations at Kellogg, Idaho. Bunker is a mining concern and a refiner of lead, zinc and silver. Gulf said the operations had a pretax loss of about $8 million in the first half of 1981, a reflection of continuing depressed lead, zinc and silver prices.

title: UNIVERSAL RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Around the Nation; Bay State Fire Kills 6 In Condemned Building
description: Six persons, including four children and a woman who leaped from her third-floor apartment, died last night when a fast-moving blaze ravaged a condemned four-story tenement, the authorities said.

title: Dow Buys Stake In Genetic Concern
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it had acquired a 5 percent interest in Collaborative Research Inc., a closely held Waltham, Mass., biotechnology concern, for $5 million cash.

title: ELRON ELECTRONIC INDUSTRIES LTD (ISRAEL) reports earnings for Qtr to June
AFTER A FIGHT, BOSTON COUNCIL YIELDS ON MAYOR'S FISCAL PLAN
description: After long debate and bickering, the Boston City Council tonight approved Mayor Kevin H. White's package for alleviating the city's fiscal crisis.

title: HUSBANDING THE BOUNTY OF LAND AND SEA
description: PARSIMONY, or to be more charitable to myself, an urge toward husbandry, has me in its thrall and some of its manifestations are absurd.

title: NEW 'BOXES' FAIL TO END FEAR OF TRAFFIC GRIDLOCK
description: Ten antigridlock ''boxes'' established five months ago at particularly busy midtown crossings to warn motorists aginst blocking intersections are not yet performing as hoped, officials acknowledge.

title: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
KOCH OUTLINES PROBLEMS OF HOUSING FACING CITY
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York City suffered from serious housing problems that affected the lives of most of its residents, but he offered little or no hope that matters would improve much.

title: REAGAN WILL BRING WESTWAY PAYMENT TO NEW YORK CITY
description: President Reagan is planning to visit New York City on Labor Day and will bring a check with him representing the first Federal payment toward the construction of the Westway, Federal and local officials said yesterday.

title: THRIFT UNITS SEEK BROKER ROLE
description: With high interest rates bringing hard times to the thrift industry, two savings and loan institutions yesterday sought Federal regulatory approval to expand into the securities brokerage business.

title: Ludlow Agrees To Tyco Offer
description: The Ludlow Corporation and Tyco Laboratories Inc., which already owns about 30 percent of Ludlow, said they had reached a definitive merger agreement.

title: Tanker Mishap Jams Thruway for 7 Hours
description: Thousands of vehicles were diverted from the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway today after a gasoline tank truck overturned two and a half miles south of here, forcing the state police to close a 16-mile stretch of the four-lane highway from New Paltz to Newburgh for about seven hours.

title: BBC's Ankara Reporter Faces Trial on Unspecified Charges
description: The Ankara correspondent for The Financial Times of London and the British Broadcasting Corporation said today he would be tried in criminal court next month on unspecified charges.

title: Kitchen Equipment; FRENCH-FRY CUTTERS
description: ALMOST every kitchen gadget I have ever tried has captivated me. There is a period of infatuation, and then, usually, the gadget is stored somewhere and I return to the old ways. Some of these little machines stick around, however. The classic egg slicer, to take one example of marvelous gadget design, is always available in my kitchen.

title: DOW UP 1.72 AFTER LATE RALLY
description: Bad news about the inflation rate sent stock market prices sharply lower again in early trading yesterday, but the market recovered later as investors sought to purchase some stocks at bargain prices.

title: Bill Coleman, Jazz Trumpeter With Top Bands, Dead at 77
description: Bill Coleman, a prominent American jazz trumpeter, died yesterday. He was 77 years old. Born in Paris, Ky., Mr. Coleman played with many top bands of the 1920's and with Fats Waller in 1935.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: It all began with opium in China. The yellow smoke curled to the ceiling, and the young men drifted away and dreamed of a land where there were no stones in the soil, where there was money, and women. They rested their heads in one another's laps, and the world dulled and softened.

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENATOR BAKER ENDORSES PROPOSED SAUDI DEAL
description: President Reagan today won the support of Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate Republican leader, for his proposal to sell radar planes to Saudi Arabia, but other members of Congress were critical.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Brown rice is harder to find than white rice. The thing that puzzles me, however, is why it costs more than regular white rice.

title: Marathon Well
description: The Marathon Oil Company said a delineation well off the coast of Indonesia had flowed at a cumulative rate of 11,242 barrels of oil and 6.3 million cubic feet of natural gas a day during tests. Marathon said its Marathon Petroleum Indonesia unit had completed the well about three-quarters of a mile northwest of its successful KH-1X discovery well on the Kakap block. The well was drilled to a total depth of 7,175 feet, Marathon said.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $2 million or 46 cents a shr gain on the sale of a foreign subsidiary

title: AMERICAN NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31

TONY AUDITORE lives in downtown Brooklyn with three cats, an Afghan hound and several hundred thousand honeybees.  "I never expected to get any honey in the city," he said recently, stirring a spoonful of the heavy liquid into his jasmine tea.  "I started bee keeping for the pure pleasure of learning about bees."
description: Now, five years later, he has seven hives in the backyard of his Boerum Hill brownstone. He never buys sugar. And he has more than a hundred pounds of honey left over each year to sell locally.

title: Stevens Sees Earnings Dip
description: J.P. Stevens & Company said yesterday that it expected to report a $41.8 million charge against earnings for the quarter ended Aug. 1, reflecting the cost of restructuring some of its manufacturing operations.

title: HOME SALES DOWN 5.2% IN JULY
description: Sales of existing single-family houses fell 5.2 percent in July, to an annual rate of 2.52 million units, one of the lowest levels this year, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: Around the Nation; Officer Seeks Immunity In Soviet Spying Case
description: The attorney for Second Lieut. Christopher Cooke of the Air Force says that the Lieutenant will press his claim to immunity from prosecution on espionage charges at his court-martial next week.

title: China to Pay Mitsubishi
description: China has agreed to compensate Japan's Mitsubishi industrial group for scrapping a $369 million contract to build a steel rolling mill at Baoshan, near Shanghai, Mitsubishi said today.

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Vilas Beats Frenchman In Opener
description: Play in the $50,000 Head Cup tennis singles tournament opened with an expected result tonight when Guillermo Vilas scored an easy victory over 18-year-old Henri Leconte.

title: BERTRAM A. MAYERS
description: Bertram A. Mayers, a theatrical and communications lawyer, died Monday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center following a brief illness.

title: CENTRAL WISCONSIN BANK SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMID CRITICISM, THE MOUNTIES LOSE SECURITY ROLE
description: The Government announced today that the internal security duties of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police would be given to a separate civilian intelligence agency.

title: HOW PAKISTAN CAN GET U.S. JETS AND BUILD THE 'ILSAMIC BOMB'
description: To the Editor:

title: FED BACKS BRITISH BID ON CROCKER
description: The Federal Reserve Board today announced its approval of a $820 million takeover of the Crocker National Corporation of San Francisco, parent of the 12th-largest bank in the United States, by Midland Bank Ltd. of London. It would be the largest foreign takeover of an American bank.

title: Discoveries; CALCULATORS AND MIRRORS FOR TRAVELING COMFORT; 1. Bracelets From Riviera
description: It started, like so many fads and fashions, in St. Tropez. The chic sun worshipers started wearing gem-studded expansion bracelets along with their expansion-bracelet wristwatches. Parisians brought the trend home with them, and now New Yorkers have returned from their Riviera summers with the bracelets. But there's no need for the rest of us to fly to France. An American company named Eagle & Fox has started making the bracelets in coral, turquoise, ivory or jet. And you don't have to team them with a watch. They look quite fetching alone or in multiples - or with other bracelets. The coral and turquoise together bring a pleasing result. The less adventurous might try the jet and ivory. $80 each in Cul-de-Sac at Bloomingdale's.

title: Around the World; Poland Says Solidarity Is Increasing Tension
description: he Polish Government accused Solidarity of increasing tension in the nation today after union bus drivers in Radom struck for one hour.

title: OFFICES DESIGNED TO SERVE AS AN ENTRY TO STAMFORD
description: In modern buildings it is often difficult to locate the entrance, just as in sprawling modern cities it is often difficult to find the gateway.

title: FEDDERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $312,000 income from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle...C-Including $2,368,000 tax credit

title: Books of the Times
description: By Enid Nemy NANCY ASTOR. A Biography. By Anthony Masters. Illustrated. 237 pages. McGraw-Hill. $10.95. NANCY ASTOR. A Lady Unashamed. By John Grigg. Illustrated. 192 pages. Lit- tle, Brown. $15.

title: Soviet to Buy Vehicles
description: The Soviet Union is expected to buy about 7,000 dump trucks, bulldozers and other types of vehicles from Japan at an undetermined price over the next six years for its third forestry development project in Siberia, trading sources said here today. Autoexport, the Soviet automobile export corporation, recently contracted to buy a total of 1,640 heavy vehicles, worth about $80 million, from Japanese companies for shipment by mid-1982, the sources added.

title: Rumanian Dance Aide Held in Prostitution Case
description: A Rumanian choreographer was arrested today after four young dancers from the Rumanian State Dance Academy said he had forced them into prostitution by promising that they would not have to return home, the police reported.

title: NEW YORK STATE ENERGY PLAN URGES BUILDING FEWER NEW POWER PLANTS
description: New York State's consumption of energy has dropped dramatically in the last three years, according to the state's new energy master plan released today. As a result, the plan calls for the construction of fewer power plants in the state.

title: PRICE INDEX FACING STUDY IN CONGRESS
description: Congress, spurred by economists and by President Reagan's Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, is expected to take a close look at the Consumer Price Index in coming months to see if its accuracy as a barometer of inflation can be improved.

title: L.I. WOMAN DANGLES OVER WATER AFTER VAN HITS RISING DRAW BRIDGE
description: A van crashed into a Long Island drawbridge raised by vandals early yesterday morning, and a passenger was thrown through the windshield onto the still-rising bridge, where she clung for two and a half hours with a broken leg before being rescued.

title: MISSILE STRATEGY DRAWS CHALLENGES
description: Strategic experts inside and outside the Government are beginning to question a fundamental premise of nuclear weapons planning: that American land-based missiles are highly vulnerable to a Soviet strike and that billions of dollars must be spent to protect them.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JUDGE ORDERS INTERDISTRICT INTEGRATION PLAN DRAFTED FOR ST. LOUIS
description: A Federal judge has ordered the drafting of a plan that could result in mandatory school desegregation involving the city system here and 18 suburban districts.

title: The President's Other Constituency
description: Researchers at the University of Michigan claim the nation's consumers are happier with the Government's economic policy than they have been for a decade. But tell that to President Reagan's other constitutency: Wall Street's big-league money managers, investment bankers and brokers. They are in deep gloom.

title: INQUIRIES SOUGHT AS COST OF NUCLEAR PLANT CLIMBS
description: A private audit of Nine Mile 2, a nuclear-power plant on Lake Ontario near Oswego, N.Y., has concluded that the utility companies' previous cost projections for the plant had been ''unrealistically low'' and that major expenses were ''still underestimated'' in the most recent projections.

title: Buljan Is Out Of Playoffs
description: Ivan Buljan and Francois Van der Elst are not in the Cosmos' plans for the playoffs, Coach Hennes Weisweiler indicated strongly today.

title: Indians Recall Charboneau
description: The Cleveland Indians recalled Joe Charboneau from their Charleston, W.Va., farm team today and replaced the pitcher Bob Lacey with Dennis Lewallyn, a minor league pitcher from Wichita.

title: Brown-Forman Net Up
description: The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of the fiscal year 1982 ended July 31 soared by 37.7 percent, to $20.1 million, or 79 cents a share, from $14.6 million, or 57 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of the preceding fiscal year.

title: MACDOWELL HONORS UPDIKE
description: PETERBOROUGH, N.H. THERE was cause for rejoicing at the MacDowell Colony last weekend. John Updike was awarded the 1981 Edward MacDowell Medal for literature on Sunday. Rain that had been predicted did not come to mar the outdoor presentation. And Barbara Grizzuti Harrison, author of three books and a writer in residence, finished her first novel in a burst of energy, to her enormous surprise.

title: TEAM OF EX-GREEN BERETS TRAINED TERRORISTS FOR LIBYAN GOVERNMENT
description: Four years ago, 10 men trained by the Army Special Forces to be America's elite commando troops went to work for the Government of Libya, training terrorists.

title: IN EGYPT, SADAT AND BEGIN DEBATE THE HARD ISSUES
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel met here today to try to resolve snags that have delayed normalization of relations and to resume the Palestinian autonomy talks.

title: Notes on People; 'Kids' Called Miscast
description: Jerry Lewis has raised millions of dollars over the years for the Muscular Dystrophy Association, but not everybody is happy about the way he goes about it in his Labor Day telethons.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ON 'GIVING A BLACK EYE TO COLONEL QADDAFI'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockefeller Grandson Injured in Auto Crash
description: Riding in an automobile on the same road where his grandfather, John D. Rockefeller 3d, was killed three years ago, 19-year-old David H. Spencer was seriously injured in an accident late Monday.

title: THE CITY
description: Mark David Chapman, sentenced Monday to 20 years to life in prison for the murder of John Lennon, began the processing for his imprisonment without any special security arrangements.

title: Best Buys; VEGETABLES STILL A BARGAIN
description: LOCAL vegetables are still priced low as the summer season begins to wind down. Tomatoes, ripe and juicy, are the best buy of all. Among the best places to buy good inexpensive tomatoes, both plum and round, are the sidewalk fruit and vegetable markets on Ninth Avenue between 38th and 40th Streets.

title: TV: 'CBS REPORTS' VIEWS TEXAS LEGISLATURE
description: IN April 1975 there was an unseemly brouhaha in the chaste halls of the Colorado Legislature, about what we forget, which produced some quite unmannerly hollering. Some peace-loving member of that body stepped to the front and said, ''Gentlemen, please, you are behaving like a bunch of Texas legislators!'' Whereat they were all so ashamed that concord was restored instanter. We read this in The Rocky Mountain News and have been convinced ever since that Colorado must be a dreadfully dull place.

title: Italians Flee Forest Fires
description: Police and customs launches today evacuated 150 vacationers and villagers from forest fires in the Mount Argentario peninsula, 100 miles northwest of Rome, the police said. More than 500 firefighters, helped by air force helicopters, were called in to battle the flames. Firemen were also fighting blazes caused by a spell of dry weather on the island of Elba, in the Tuscan hills around Pisa and Livorno and on the tourist island of Ischia in the Bay of Naples.

title: TESSA KOSTA, A STAR OF THE MUSICAL STAGE EARLY IN THE CENTURY
description: Tessa Kosta, a star of the musical stage before and during the 1920's, died of a heart attack at her home in Manhattan on Sunday. She was 83 years old.

title: LOUD AND CLEAR SIGNALS FROM PUERTO RICO
description: To the Editor:

title: CARTER AND CHINESE PREMIER URGE STRONG TIES
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang and former President Jimmy Carter called tonight for a continued strengthening of Chinese-American relations in after-dinner toasts at the Great Hall of the People that were directed more toward the Reagan Administration than toward each other.

title: Slashings Suspect Admits 2 Attacks
description: The man who the police believe was responsible for a series of throat-slashing attacks that left two men dead and 13 wounded pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to attempted murder in connection with two of the attacks.

title: Andrea Jaeger Out On Shoulder Injury
description: Andrea Jaeger, who rose to No. 2 in the world ranking last week, withdrew from the $100,000 Volvo Tennis Cup tournament today because of a shoulder injury that may jeopardize her playing in next week's United States Open.

title: Rollei Sells Optics Unit
description: The Optics division of Rollei Singapore Ltd. has been sold to United Scientific Holdings Ltd. of Britain, Rollei's receivers said today. The purchase price was not disclosed, but the receivers said United Scientific planned to keep the division operating at current levels. Since Rollei Singapore was placed in receivership on July 2 by its two shareholders, Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale and the Development Bank of Singapore Ltd., more than half of its employees have been dismissed, leaving 1,413 workers and 90 executives.

title: The Million's $1,100 Baby
description: FLANKED by two mounted cops, Mayor Jane Byrne of Chicago rode a horse in a parade the other day, which may not tell us a lot about politics in the second city but does suggest that the town is in a tizzy over the upcoming Arlington Million, America's richest race for thoroughbreds.

title: THE PERFECT OUT
description: At least one of the reasons proferred by the air traffic controllers for their strike was that, as a group, they were ''burned out.'' To a psychologist who tries to keep up with the latest fads in psychological infirmities, this increasingly popular phraseology caught my attention. I know that burnout is ravaging medicine, psychology, social work and most of the helping professions but was unaware it had jumped the fire lines into the ranks of the air traffic controllers.

title: Cuban Council Elections Set
description: Nominations have been completed for Cuba's municipal council elections on Oct. 11, the newspaper Granma reported today. It said 22,726 candidates, nominated by neighborhood committees, would run for 10,660 seats on the councils, which have wide powers.

title: RANGERS GIVE HULL A TRYOUT
description: Bobby Hull, one of the most prolific scorers in hockey history, has accepted an invitation to try to win a job as left wing with the Rangers.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Net loss; sales figures exclude sales by leased departments of $3,127,000 and $5,468,000 for the latest qr and 6 mos and $3,067,000 and $5,628,000 for the previous qr and 6 mos; yr-ago results reflect accounting for vacation pay

title: LAMP LOSES NO HIT BID IN 9TH
description: Dennis Lamp, in only his second start of the season, had a no-hitter going into the ninth inning tonight before Robin Yount led off with a double as the Chicago White Sox beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-1.

title: Indian Women March in Delhi To Protest Against Price Rise
description: Thousands of women marched through parts of this city to Parliament today to protest rising prices and lawlessness in India.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 26, 1981
description: International A dispute over Soviet Jewish refugees erupted between Israel and the United States. The State Department and United Hias Service, an immigrant aid group, said they opposed Israel's new plan to curtail the flow of Soviet Jews to countries other than Israel. In recent months, about 85 percent of the refugees have chosen to go from Vienna, the transit stop, to places other than Israel, with most choosing the United States. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) About 100,000 slaves in Mauritania probably make up the world's largest slave population, according to a report under study by the United Nations. The slaveholders, the study said, are predominantly Moors who are victimizing blacks in the poor country in northwestern Africa. (A11:1.)

title: Transactions; BASEBALL NATIONAL LEAGUE - Suspended Dallas Green, Philadelphia manager, in- definitely for an altercation with the Um- pire Steve Fields in Monday night's game.  CHICAGO (NL) - Recalled seven players from minor leagues who will re- port Sept. 1: Jim Tracy, Mel Hall, Ty Waller and Scot Thompson, outfielders; Bill Hayes, catcher; Scott Fletcher, in- fielder, and Dave Geisel, pitcher.  CLEVELAND (AL) - Placed Andre Thornton, first baseman, on 15-day dis- abled list and recalled Joe Charboneau, outfielder, from Cha
description: tackle, on injured reserve. Released Char- lie Hall, linebacker; Ron Simmons, defen- sive tackle; Autry Beamon, safety; Joe Restic, punter and safety; John Mohring, linebacker; Randy Schleusener, guard; Marcus Jackson, defensive tackle; Dean Prater, defensive end, and Sam Mills and Darrie Nelson, free agents. DALLAS (NFC) - Released Terry El- ston, receiver; Angelo King, linebacker; Pat Graham, defensive lineman, and Ken Miller, defensive back. Placed Bill Roe, linebacker, on injured reserve. DENVER (AFC) - Waived Greg Bracelin, linebacker; Larry Brunson and Pat Walker, wide receivers; Axland Thompson, lineman; Laval Short, defen- sive tackle; Steve Trimble, cornerback. Placed Jimmy Robinson, wide receiver, on injured reserve. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Placed Ron Cassidy, wide receiver; Wylie Turner, de- fensive back, and Paul Rudzinski, line- backer, on injured reserve. Waived Dewey McClain, linebacker, and Ray An- derson, running back. HOUSTON (AFC) - Waived Danny Buggs, wide receiver, and Bill Capece, kicker. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Waived Bob Gagliano, quarterback; Phil Cancik, line- backer; Curtis Bledsoe, running back, and Donovan Rose, cornerback. Placed M.L. Carter, cornerback, on injured reserve. LOS ANGELES (NFC) - Placed Victor Hicks, tight end, on injured reserve. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Waived Garry White, Don Shaver and Freddie Smith, running backs; James Murphy wide re- ceiver, and Ron Coccimiglio, defensive back. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Released Joe Federspiel, linebacker; Emanuel Zanders, guard; Mike Fultz, defensive tackle; Don Schwartz, safety; James Marshall, defensive back, and Sammy Green, linebacker. Placed Jeff Harper, center; Gene Gladys, linebacker; Donnie Echols, tight end, and Rich Mauti, wide re- ceiver, on injured reserve.

title: FIRST MITTERRAND LOAN TO PAY A RECORD 16.77%
description: Reflecting concern that French investors will be reluctant to lend to a Socialist Government, the new administration of President Francois Mitterrand announced today that its first borrowing will yield 16.75 percent - more than any other French government has ever paid to borrow from its citizens.

title: TOO MANY PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: ENERGY IN EUROPE
description: There is a growing dispute between the United States and the countries of Western Europe, in particular West Germany, about the sources and supply of energy to those countries.

title: PRICE INDEX JUMPED BY 1.7% IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Consumer prices rose 1.7 percent in July in the New Yorknorthestern New Jersey area, the biggest increase since August 1974, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Stolen Clubs Returned To Aoki and Oosterhuis
description: The stolen clubs of the golfers Isao Aoki of Japan and Peter Oosterhuis of England were returned today to the hotel from which they had been stolen Sunday night.

title: AUSTRALIAN MEAT WILL BE INSPECTED
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, armed with evidence that Australian horse meat has been shipped throughout the United States, announced new efforts today to keep horse and kangaroo meat out of beef imports.

title: ITS PAST SUCCESS MAY HAUNT CORADIAN
description: After several years of expanding sales and profits, the biggest telephone interconnect company in the Northeast and distributor of one of the top equipment lines is feeling pressure on its profits.

title: RIVER ISLANDS OFFER SOLITUDE, FOR A PRICE
description: ''This is heaven,'' Robert Langley said with a sigh as he sat in the glass-enclosed veranda of his new stone-andwood vacation home on the St. Lawrence River. ''I've always wanted to own an island.''

title: Libyans' Harassment Of U.S. Planes Is Cited
description: Without actually firing, Libyan fighter pilots have over the last several years sent a number of radio messages indicating they were preparing to attack American planes, a Pentagon official said today.

title: HINCKLEY'S JUDGE MAY QUERY SANITY
description: Lawyers here say precedents strongly suggest that if John W. Hinckley Jr. refuses to invoke an insanity defense, the judge trying the case would have to consider raising the defense on his own, over Mr. Hinckley's objections.

title: SEGELSTEIN REPLACES SALANT AT NBC
description: Richard S. Salant, who joined NBC two years ago as vice chairman, was replaced yesterday by Irwin S. Segelstein, president of NBC Television. Mr. Salant will become a general adviser to NBC on longrange planning and policy issues.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Minolta Corp., Ramsey, N.J., has elected A.L. Leisey Jr. chairman of Mohawk Marketing Corp., a subsidiary.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings reflect elimination of interest expense 2 percent convertible subordinated

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: During the 1981 period the company adopted Financial Accounting Standards Board number 43 relating to accounting to compensated absences; this change reduced net income in the first 9 mos of 1981 by $750,000 or 3 cents a shr and in addition the restat ment resulted in a reduction of Oct 31, 1979 retained income of $8,700,000 with earnings reduced by no more than 4 cents a shr in any yr; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock divd declared in Mar 1981

title: Minute Amount of Nerve Gas Is Found in Bomb Container
description: A minute amount of nerve gas has been found in the shipping container of a Weteye nerve gas bomb scheduled for shipment from Denver to Utah, according to the chief chemist of the Colorado Health Department.

title: India Takes Delivery Of 'a Few' MIG-25's
description: India said today that it had acquired the Soviet Union's MIG-25, an advanced interceptor-reconnaissance aircraft called the Foxbat by NATO.

title: Index; International
description: Ecuador's democracy weathers loss of popular President A2 Portuguese designate a Prime Minister A4 Around the World A5 Mounties, under criticism, lose internal security duties A6 Senator Baker endorses proposed Saudi plane deal A7 Malaysia ends ban on book by Prime Minister A9 Panama's military moves quickly to assert its power A10 Ex-President Carter, in China, calls for strengthened ties A13 Government/Politics Missouri officials dismayed by in- tegration order A14 Congress may seek ways to im- prove accuracy of price index A20 Dearie pledges 21 performance audits of city services B3 General Around the Nation A14 Block moves to stop horse and kangaroo meat in beef imports A18 Building sold for $161 million, as- sessed at $30.8 million B3 Landmark status is sought to save three 63d St. town houses B3 The City B3 New York City presses campaign against gridlock B3 Features/Notes About New York B7 Notes on People C24 Going Out Guide C24 The Living Section Food The church dinner: A Harlem tradition C1

title: EMBATTLED COPPOLA PLUNGES INTO TV
description: ''Sweat Shop,'' a 16-part newspaper series about the abuse of illegal Mexican aliens in the Los Angeles garment industry, has been purchased by Francis Coppola's Zoetrope studio for that company's first foray into television.

title: Economic Scene; Deficit Finance And Inflation
description: THE question of deficit finance is at the center of public discussion of economic matters today, as it is in any society undergoing serious price inflation, and as it should be, for there is no more basic connection in economic affairs than that linking deficit finance and inflation. Though Milton Friedman's aphorism that ''inflation is always and everywhere a monetary phenomenon'' is true (or as true as economic aphorisms get), it is equally true that sustained monetary expansions are always and everywhere a consequence of printing money to cover the difference between Government expenditures and tax revenues.

title: CLAYTON MEETS A MAN TO AVOID
description: Ralph Clayton, who received a $100,000 signing bonus but never carried the ball in a regular-season game, said he knew his career with the Jets was over when he looked up in the locker room this morning and saw Tim Davey walking toward him.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
VOYAGER SWEEPS CLOSE TO GLISTENING WORLD OF SATURN
description: Sweeping out of the interplanetary darkness and over the sparkling lights of Saturn's rings, Voyager 2 kept its rendezvous tonight with the giant planet and its retinue of moons and sent back data and pictures of worlds as perplexing as they are dazzling.

title: Removal of Body Stirs Violence in Jerusalem
description: Policemen in Jerusalem fired tear gas today to break up a riot of stone-throwing religious militants attempting to prevent the police from removing the body of a suspected murder victim.

title: People
description: * Maxine Paetro has joined Dancer Fitzgerald Sample as senior vice president, director of creative operations.

title: WESTCHESTER RENT PANEL APPROVES A 12% INCREASE
description: Rent increases of 12 percent or more were approved last night for 39,000 apartments in Westchester County. The increases were the largest of any approved this year by rent guideline boards in the New York metropolitan area.

title: HERO- PRISONER IN KOREAN WAR
description: Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, a Korean War hero who spent three years in Communist prisoner-of-war camps in North Korea, died yesterday in Alta Bates Hospital here, the Army said today. He was 82 years old.
