title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug 14

title: DEFENDING THE HONOR OF THE BUBBLE MEMORY
description: Richmond B. Clover has spent most of his career developing the bubble memory, a method of storing computer information. So, when the National Semiconductor Corporation said on Monday that it was quitting the business because it lacked potential, Mr. Clover was less than respectful.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-After $2,385,000 loss from discontinued operations and $2,641,000 provision for loss on disposal of discontinued business...C-After $60,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Blaze Kills Brooklyn Boy, 2, In Home Lit Only by Candles
description: A 2-year-old boy died last night in a fire that raced through a Brooklyn apartment that had been illuminated only by candles, the police said.

title: MID- AUGUST AUTO SALES UP BY 20.3%
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's Big Three auto makers, spurred by industrywide rebate and incentive programs, increased 20.3 percent in mid-August over the comparable 1980 period, the manufacturers reported today.

title: TOYS-R-US CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $534,000 net gain on the sale of property... C-Including $983,000 net gain on the sale of property; Results reflect LIFO charges of 2 cents a shr for the latest and pevious qrs and 4 cents a shr for the latest and previous 6 mos

title: Around the World; Iranian Protesters Seized At Embassies in Europe
description: Dozens of Iranian students opposed to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini were arrested today after occupying the Iranian Embassies in Belgium and the Netherlands.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Net income...C-After $152,299 loss from discontinuance of a meteorlogical services business and a writedown of obsolete inventory

title: Occidental Notes' Rating Is Raised
description: The Standard and Poor's Corporation said it had raised the ratings of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's 11 percent notes due 1982 to BBB+ from BBB. It also said the rating of all outstanding preferred stock had been raised to BBB-from BB.

title: MAJOR SOUTH AFRICAN DRIVE INTO ANGOLA IS REPORTED
description: Angola said today that two South African armored columns had crossed into southern Angola from South-West Africa and were mounting attacks as much as 60 miles inside the country. The Angolan Government announced a general mobilization of its armed forces.

title: U.S. Plans Appeal In Goody Case
description: The Justice Department said it would appeal a judge's ruling throwing out the convictions of Sam Goody Inc. and a company vice president on charges of knowingly dealing in counterfeit popularmusic tapes.

title: PORTUGAL DESIGNATES A PREMIER
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes today designated the Social Democratic Party leader, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, as Portugal's Prime Minister.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. SATIRE AT FILM FESTIVAL
description: A diverse collection of satirical American films, from Charlie Chaplin's 1940 ''The Great Dictator,'' in which he played both Adolf Hitler and a Jewish barber, to Thomas Cohen's ''The hungry i Reunion,'' a 1981 feature about the San Francisco club that gave such comics as Lenny Bruce and Mort Sahl their starts, will be presented at the 19th New York Film Festival in a series called ''Movies for Cynics.''

title: Blue Jays, Celtics in Suit
description: The tug-of-war over Danny Ainge turned into a legal battle today when the Boston Celtics and Toronto Blue Jays sued each other.

title: Man Electrocuted on Pole
description: While more than 100 neighbors looked on, a man who was despondent after arguing with his wife climbed a utility pole yesterday and grabbed a 4,000-volt wire, electrocuting himself, the police said today. The victim was identified as Elton Lee Ward, 29 years old.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 17.887 percent was set at its weekly auction of 91-day commercial paper, up from 17.842 percent last week.

title: Australian Gas Deal
description: The South Australia-based Cooper Basin Producer Group has signed a contract to supply the Idemitsu Kosan Company of Japan with 1.25 million tons of liquid petroleum gas between 1984 and 1988, Santos Ltd., the group's operator and major shareholder, said today. Santos gave no price details but added that the f.o.b. price was competitive with Arabian Gulf prices.

title: 9-Digit ZIP Plan Put Off
description: The Postal Service today withdrew its request for an incentive plan that has been considered vital for success of its nine-digit ZIP code proposal.

title: Gullickson Ousts Fibak
description: Tim Gullickson of LaCrosse, Wis., made two strong comebacks tonight to eliminate Wojtek Fibak of Poland in a first-round match of the $50,000 AMF Head Cup tennis tournament.

title: The Awacs Deal Is No Bargain
description: The Reagan Administration, which prides itself on driving hard bargains abroad, has now formally proposed what looks like a sweetheart deal with the Saudis. They would get Awacs radar planes as part of an $8.5 billion package brimming with the most advanced arms. What would America get in return? On present evidence, too little. It's good that Congress has until Oct. 30 to examine the fine print, for unless Mr. Reagan can make a better case for it, this deal is no bargain.

title: ADIRONDACK SURVIVORS: RUSTIC 'GRAND CAMPS'
description: THEY arrived in private railway cars, sped through the woods in covered surreys and cruised across lakes in mahogany boats before reaching their summer places in the Adirondack Mountains of northern New York. They called their one-or two-thousand-acre estates ''camps'' in the same spirit that they called their marble palaces in Newport, R.I., ''cottages.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We can't decide for the Palestinians behind their backs - President Anwar el-Sadat. (A13:1.)

title: PORTABLE KEROSENE HEATERS ON THE RISE
description: One result of the rising cost of home heating in the United States has been the increasing use of portable kerosene heaters. In the last several months, New York has joined Rhode Island and Delaware in lifting restrictions on the heaters, which had been restricted or outlawed in most states for safety reasons.

title: COLUMBIA PICTURES INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $4,017,000

title: TWO KOCH CHALLENGERS GIVE VIEWS ON HOUSING
description: Assemblymen Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and John A. Esposito of Queens, candidate for the Republican nomination, were asked by The New York Times for their views on major issues confronting New York City. Following are their replies on housing: ESPOSITO: 'TAX BASE HAS ERODED'

title: ARMCO TO RAISE SPENDING ON STEEL MILLS
description: Armco Inc., projecting that the oil and gas drilling boom would continue at least to end of the century, announced yesterday that it would spend $671 million to build new mills and upgrade an old one to increase the production of seamless tubular goods for the industry, which are now in short supply.

title: WHEN DEFENSE HURTS THE PEOPLE DEFENDED
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 IN A RACE FOR COUNCIL STRESS DIFFERENT ISSUES
description: In the West Village, Councilman Edward C. Wallace Jr. shakes hands at a luncheon for the elderly, passing out brochures describing his record as a crusader for tenants' rights and hearing in return a series of diatribes against the sins of landlords.

title: Business People; Ex-Physicist to Head American Express Unit
description: The American Express Company, the credit card and financial services concern, is combining its charge card and traveler's check divisions into a new consumer financial services group, to be headed by William M. McCormick, 41 years old, currently president of the card division and formerly a nuclear physicist.

title: Books of the Times
description: By John Leonard SENTIMENTAL IMPERIALISTS. The American Experience in East Asia. By James C. Tomson Jr., Peter W. Stanley and John Curtis Perry. 323 pages. Harper & Row. $17.50.

title: I.M.F. Loan to Liberia
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a $69 million loan to help support Liberia's economic improvement program. At the same time, the I.M.F. said it was canceling a standby financial arrangement made to Liberia in September 1980 at the request of the country. The monetary fund said that Liberia had been experiencing economic problems for a number of years and that there had been a reduction in demand for its major exports, primarily iron ore.

title: WILLIAM L. TILSON
description: William L. Tilson, a former weather official praised by President Nixon for urging an early evacuation before Hurricane Camille struck in 1969, died today from a selfinflicted gunshot wound, the police said.

title: Storage Program
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a computer maker, said that it was planning a 10-year, $55 million expansion program that would double its work force and expand its facilities here by 1.4 million square feet. The company said that the four-phase expansion, to be completed in October 1992, would increase its work force from 4,300 to 8,946. The company last month introduced a new system designed to reduce the cost of data storage while increasing the speed at which access can be gained to data.

title: The Region; Bridgeport 'Sting' To Undergo Study
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Connecticut's two United States Senators and a Representative will meet with Justice Department officials next month to discuss the Bridgeport ''sting'' operation, Representative Stewart B. McKinney said.

title: PRIVATE AVIATORS CALLING EFFECTS OF STRIKE MINIMAL
description: Pilots who fly the nation's more than 200,000 private aircraft say that, with limited exceptions, the three-week strike by members of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization is having virtually no effect on their flying.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Seagram Deadline
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. said that it would not extend its deadline beyond 5 P.M. yesterday to accept stock it had agreed to purchase under its $92-a-share offer for Conoco Inc. It said earlier that it had been offered some 28 million shares and that it had actually received 27,677,389. It said it would ''review all appropriate actions'' if a significant number of the shares offered were not delivered by deadline.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Esquire magazine increasing its advertising rates 12 percent, effective with the January issue.

title: Burden Convicted In Robbery
description: Luther (Ticky) Burden, a former guard for the Knicks, was convicted today by a Nassau County Court jury of first-degree robbery at a Long Island bank last year. Judge Edward Baker ordered Burden held at the County Jail in East Meadow to await sentencing Oct. 14.

title: CRUSADER FOR CIVIL RIGHTS FOUNDED THE
description: A.C.L.U. Roger Baldwin, who founded the American Civil Liberties Union in 1920 and crusaded for the causes of freedom at home and abroad, died yesterday of heart failure in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 97 years old and lived in Oakland, N.J.

title: Cessna Lifts Prices
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company said today that it was increasing prices on the new editions of its smallest planes by an average of about 13 percent. The price changes apply to the 1982 Model 152, the four-place Skyhawk and the Cutlass RG, a retractable-gear version of the Skyhawk.

title: Notes on People; Selling Big Apple Slices
description: If James F. Capalino, New York City's Commissioner of General Services, sounds like a real-estate salesman, there's a reason.

title: PONDEROSA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
Haitians Given 15-Year Terms For Opposition to President
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 26 (UPI) - A prominent opposition leader, his daughter and 20 of his followers were sentenced to 15 years in jail today for opposing the Government of President Jean-Claude Duvalier.

title: SAFETY PANEL BEGINS INQUIRY ON AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL
description: As a panel of experts for the National Transportation Safety Board began a check of aviation safety today, its chairman said the board had not heard of any serious problems that would make the skies unsafe.

title: EMPLOYEES OF C.I.A. AIDED LIBYAN DEAL
description: The Central Intelligence Agency acknowledged today that some of its employees had supported a former agent, Edwin P. Wilson, in his dealings with the Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, but the agency said those employees had acted without its knowledge.

title: 10,000 Jews Protest Jerusalem Excavation
description: More than 10,000 religious militants rallied in a main city square for several hours today to protest what they described as the desecration of graves by archeologists excavating at a site known as the City of David.

title: U.S. SAYS RAID INTO ANGOLA SHOWS URGENT NEED FOR NAMIBIA ACCORD
description: The United States said today that the South African military moves into Angola underscored the need for ''urgent movement'' toward a negotiated settlement of the problem of South-West Africa.

title: ATTENDANCE INCENTIVE GIVEN
description: Alameda County is giving employees who seldom call in sick a chance to win a Hawaiian vacation or hundreds of dollars in cash. County supervisors approved the incentive program yesterday. The names of workers who have not missed more than one day in the last six months, about 700 of the county's 9,000 employees, will be entered in a drawing for the prizes.

title: PACT REQUIRES CITY TO SHELTER HOMELESS MEN
description: New York City must provide clean and safe shelter to every homeless man who seeks it, according to an agreement signed in State Supreme Court yesterday by city and state officials and a lawyer for six homeless men who sued for that commitment nearly two years ago.

title: Dr. Frank P. Jennings Jr., 65; A Specialist in Dermatology
description: Dr. Frank P. Jennings Jr., the chief of the dermatology department at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home in Manhasset, L. I., after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: INSURER SAYS KLEINDIENST SET UP A SECRET DEAL
description: Richard G. Kleindienst set up a secret deal with a reputed organized-crime figure that helped Joseph Hauser, an insurance executive, win a multimillion-dollar contract with a health and welfare fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the star prosecution witness in the former Attorney General's perjury trial said today.

title: FLIGHT DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-The company said it had no rev base in 1980

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Denies U.S.  Lends Support to Dictators
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, scoffed today at charges that the Reagan Administration ''supports dictatorships in preference to democracies.''

title: CARTER LEAVES THEM PUFFING AT GREAT WALL
description: Jimmy Carter proved yesterday that he is physically fit by striding out along both sections of the Great Wall of China that are open to tourists.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
CORDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $5,000 for qr and $56,000 for yr... C-Net income including tax credits of $304,000 or 12 cents a shr for qr and $395,000 or 16 cents a shr for yr

title: TV: 'GOLDEN AGE' SERIES OPENING WITH 'MARTY'
description: IT'S fitting that ''Marty,'' the opening drama in a public-television retrospective on the ''Golden Age of Television,'' was written by Paddy Chayefsky. Mr. Chayefsky, who died Aug. 1 at the age of 58, was one of the most gifted, popular and prolific of the dramatists who wrote for television during the period in the 1950's when the three networks broadcast as many as a dozen live, original plays each week.

title: EXHUMATION DELAYED IN CASE LINKED TO THE C.I.A.
description: A state judge in Maine yesterday ordered a 24-hour delay in the exhumation of the body of Dennis McNell, the brother of two men whose charges of fraud led to the resignation of a high-ranking official of the Central Intelligence Agency in mid-July.

title: Datapoint's Profit Up 45.7%
description: The Datapoint Corporation, a leading manufacturer of computer systems and peripherals, announced yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended July 31 rose 45.7 percent, to $13.4 million, or 66 cents a share, from $9.2 million, or 52 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: Marshall, 38, Still on Mission
description: The gate of the tall green bullpen fence in right field in Shea Stadium swung open, and Mike Marshall appeared. Marshall, the Mets' 38-year-old relief pitcher took one skipping step, like a boy on a lark, and then trotted forthrightly across the outfield to the mound, like a man on a mission.

title: LIMITED STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Includes $630,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change

title: Around the World; Pakistan Said to Resist Soviet View on Afghans
description: A Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Nikolai P. Firyubin, failed in three days of talks here to persuade Pakistan to soften its stand against the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Allis-Chalmers To Cut Output
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, citing high interest rates and falling demand, announced that it would cut production sharply in all of its agricultural equipment lines, a move that will result in an unspecified number of layoffs.

title: Hussein-Mitterrand Meeting
description: King Hussein of Jordan, here on a private visit, discussed the Middle East situation tonight in dinner talks with President Francois Mitterrand.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split declared in Feb

title: Far, Far Beyond Saturn
description: The jamming of a television platform after Voyager 2 sped past Saturn yesterday disrupted a few experiments but did not detract from a stunning achievement. After a four-year journey covering 1.2 billion miles, the nuclear-powered spacecraft arrived on time and on target. It is already sending back rich new detail on the giant planet and its mysterious rings; more will be transmitted as it speeds on toward the outer planets.

title: Notes on the U.N.
description: The World Newspaper Supplement, the quarterly for which the United Nations gave subsidies to 15 newspapers, appears to be dying for lack of money.

title: ACCORD FILED IN LOUISIANA DESEGREGAGTION SUIT
description: The Reagan Administration today filed a proposed settlement of a desegregation suit against the Louisiana university system that would not require any mergers of black and white institutions.

title: DUKE U. DISPUTE OVER NIXON LIBRARY GROWING
description: As Duke University nears a decision on whether to have Richard M. Nixon's Presidential library built on the edge of its neo-Gothic campus, the controversy over the proposal has escalated. Two prominent alumni have registered strong protests and a faculty council has scheduled an extraordinary session for discussion of the matter.

title: Brazilian Gold Policy
description: The Brazilian Government has adopted a new gold policy aimed at increasing its reserves of the metal, the Finance Ministry said today. A meeting of the National Monetary Council, a top decision making body, decided to give the central bank wide powers to buy and sell the metal on the domestic market at international prices, a ministry spokesman said. Exports would be prohibited; the central bank would be a buyer offering London bullion market prices or above.

title: Around the Nation; Recaptured Spy Refuses Food for a Fifth Day
description: Christopher John Boyce, a spy for the Soviet Union who spent 19 months as a fugitive, spurned food for the fifth day today.

title: Blaze at a Kuwait Oil Refinery Is Extinguished After a Week
description: Firemen today extinguished a Kuwaiti oil tank blaze that had raged for almost a week and closed one of Kuwait's two refineries, a Government spokesman said.

title: U.S.-Peru Drug Fight Set
description: The United States plans to grant Peru $20 million to fight the illicit cocaine trade, the United States Ambassador, Edwin Corr, has announced. He said the grant was part of an antinarcotics agreement to be signed by the two Governments next month.

title: African Leaders Offer a Plan For the West Sahara Dispute
description: A seven-nation committee of the Organization of African Unity today announced a plan for a ceasefire and referendum in Western Sahara.

title: PERSISTENT CAL
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY AND UNION NEAR ACCORD ON ONE-OFFICER PATROL CARS
description: New York City officials and the union representing police officers are nearing an agreement that would give the city the right to send out patrol cars with one officer instead of two, negotiators said yesterday. The officers, in exchange, would get a financial bonus.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ISRAEL AND EGYPT AGREE TO RESUME PALESTINIAN TALKS
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel agreed today to renew the long-stalled talks on self-rule for the Palestinian Arabs of the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip.

title: Sports of the Times; THE MAN AT THE BOTTOM OF THE BATTING ORDER
description: WHEN Bill Almon was a rookie in 1977, he was trying to impress the San Diego Padres, but the person he impressed most was the thirdbase coach for another team.

title: Empire State Suicide Named
description: A naked man who leaped 85 floors to his death from the Empire State Building on Monday has been identified as a 23-year-old Long Island man, the police said yesterday. A police spokesman said the man had been identified as David Klugman of 236 South Park Avenue, Rockville Centre, through fingerprints.

title: CALENDER OF EVENTS: BIRD DECOY EXHIBIT
description: The American Decoy, Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street.

title: Grand Jury to Assess Fatal L.I. Boat Crash
description: A grand jury in Suffolk County, L.I., will be convened next week to consider criminal indictments against the operators of two vessels involved in a crash that killed five passengers in Long Island Sound on Aug. 10.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable Sept 11, 1981

title: A REAGAN PERSPECTIVE ON SEXUAL EQUALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Net Declines 12.9%
description: Columbia Pictures Industries, a leading producer-distributor of motion pictures and television programming, said that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended June 27 slipped 12.9 percent, to $10.1 million, or $1.26 a share, from $11.6 million, or $1.15 a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year earlier. Revenues fell 8.7 percent, to $188.9 million, from $206.8 million.

title: 2 UNIONS THAT ORGANIZE IN HOSPITALS TO MERGE
description: The two labor unions with the country's largest memberships of hospital workers plan to merge next June, union officials said today.

title: Japan Vehicle Output Up
description: Japan's vehicle production last month rose to the second highest on record, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: U.S. CONSIDERING SPECIAL RADIO BROADCASTS TO CUBA
description: The Reagan Administration is giving consideration to creating a radio station that would broadcast to Cuba about its internal developments, Administration officials said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORGANIZATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.4 million for qr and $6.3 million for 6 mos; yr-ago results restated

title: 'Lena' Sunday Matinees To Resume on Sept. 13
description: ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music,'' which will pass the 100-performance mark on Saturday, will resume Sunday matinees at 3 P.M. on Sept. 13.

title: Around the World; Mrs. Thatcher Refuses To See Ulster M.P.
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today refused to meet Owen Carron, the newly elected member of Parliament from Ulster who supports the nationalist hunger strikers in Maze Prison near Belfast.

title: JAPAN CURBS TRADE
description: California's $14.5 billion agriculture industry suffered two severe blows today: Japan decided to require fumigation of produce that it imports from California, and it was confirmed that the infestation of the Mediterranean fruit fly had vaulted 280 miles south, to Los Angeles County.

title: The City; 40 Families Flee East Harlem Fire
description: An explosion of natural gas in a vacant East Harlem building started a three-alarm fire that destroyed four adjacent buildings and drove 40 families from their homes, fire officials said.

title: COURT OVERTURNS AWARD GRANTED IN SEX-BIAS SUIT
description: A state appellate court has overturned an award of $219,172 to a 58-year-old Manhattan woman in a sex-discrimination suit against Burlington Industries.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SUBARU DENIES HAVING UNANNOUNCED RECALL
description: Subaru, the Japanese automobile company, clashed with a consumer group yesterday over whether the company was conducting an unpublicized recall of some of its 1981 cars because of a problem with engine performance.

title: MACRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After tax credits of $41,000 for qr and $1,626,000 for yr...C-After tax credits of $450,000 for qr and $861,000 for yr

title: Design Notebook; COPING WITH THE FOIBLES OF AN OCCASIONAL GUEST ROOM
description: ON the subject of guest rooms there is only limited wisdom to be found by consulting the proper authorities. ''It is by no means idle talk to suggest that every hostess try her guest room by spending a night in it herself,'' ''The New Emily Post's Etiquette'' pronounces, in advice that it explains is to save us all the embarrassment of discovering a guest bath in which the drains are stopped up.

title: DEATH CHILLS A CAMPUS
description: It was this July 18. Wen-chen Chen, a bright 31-yearold Carnegie-Mellon University statistics professor, was being memorialized. It was, mysteriously, a service where the guests wore tattered paper bags with clumsy eye holes over their heads. Remembering our professors who had died and been honored in memorial services at the university before, I was struck dramatically that this service was like no other.

title: Live Bazooka Shell Found in Brooklyn
description: A live shell for a World War II bazooka was detonated by the Police Department's bomb squad after it was found in the basement of a doctor's house in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

title: TEACHER AT EINSTEIN COLLEGE
description: Dr. Samuel Rosen, an associate dean at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, was found dead early yesterday in his office at the college, the police reported.

title: KETCHUM & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $124,000 tax credit...C-Including $2,005,000 or $2.17 a shr net gain on the sale of certain assets of Ketchum's wholly owned subsidiary, Bioproducts Inc consisting primarily of trademarks, trade names and inventory

title: LOST LESSON HELPS A CHILD FIND ANOTHER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Phyllis Theroux is the author of ''Peripheral Visions,'' to be published in January by William R. Morrow. By PHYLLIS THEROUX

title: Funds Lacking, Dance Festival Is Off
description: The New York Dance Festival, the annual presentation at Central Park's Delacorte Theater that traditionally opened the city's dance season, will not take place this year because of a lack of funds. The free two-week festival, known for its eclectic programming of ballet and modern, ethnic, jazz and tap forms on the same evenings, traditionally occurred in early September.

title: Bridge; EXPERTS SPLIT OVER BIDDING WITH TWO FIVE-CARD SUITS
description: The right way to bid as opener with two five-card black suits is a theoretical point that continues to divide the experts. Some always bid one club; some always bid one spade, and some vary their procedure according to the strength of the hand or the quality of the suits.

title: Missing Charter Costs City Council Its Seats
description: A state judge has stripped the three City Council members of their seats here, contending that their three-year terms were illegal because the city secretary could not find the charter bestowing municipal status on the town.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Westphal Breaks Foot,
description: Paul Westphal broke his right foot and will miss at least the first two months of the season, Jim Bennett, a spokesman for the Seattle SuperSonics said today.

title: Advertising; Response Mixed to Postal Plan
description: ADVERTISING executives reacted with cautious and limited approval yesterday to the United States Postal Service's announcement Tuesday that it was considering the sale of commercial advertising space in post offices and on postal trucks, mailboxes and other postal property and materials - but not on the front of postage stamps.

title: U.S. SAYS TERRAIN SHIELDS ISRAEL FROM RADAR-JET PERIL
description: The Administration has prepared a study of Israel's topography and air space that is meant to bolster its arguments that the sale of radar aircraft to Saudi Arabia will not significantly endanger Israel.

title: ALL MOZART: WITH RUDOLF FIRKUSNY
description: THE Mostly Mozart Festival has garnered its annual armful of complaints about its lack of imagination, its slipshod performances and some of its conductors and soloists. But it is a clear popular success, wich must mean something; Tuesday's concert filled Avery Fisher Hall. It deserved to: this was an evening of refined musicmaking, and the music being made was imaginatively chosen for a change.

title: STAMEN STAMENOV
description: Stamen Stamenov, one of Bulgaria's six Deputy Prime Ministers and Minister of Metallurgy and Mineral Resources, died today, the Bulgarian press agency reported. He was 59 years old. A construction engineer by profession, he headed Bulgaria's Construction Research Institute before moving into the Government in the early 1970's.

title: IMMIGRANTS' PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SOLIDARITY PRESSING DEMANDS FOR ACCESS TO NEWS OUTLETS
description: The struggle for control of the Polish press intensified today when the Solidarity union movement threatened a six-day printers strike and the Communist Party leader, Stanislaw Kania, vowed that the press would not be shut down.

title: GANSEVOORT GARBAGE TERMINAL, FOUND DANGEROUSLY RUSTED, IS ORDERED SHUT
description: New York City officials yesterday suddenly shut down a disintegrating sanitation terminal on the Hudson River at which 250 trucks a day had dumped garbage into barges.

title: COURT SUPPORTS ADOPTEE IN HIS SEARCH FOR FATHER
description: The Missouri Court of Appeals says a cancer victim who is looking for his natural parents in an effort to get a life-saving bone marrow transplant may be given the name of his father if it is available and if the father is still alive.

title: News of Music; OPERA STARS IN CONCERT: THE BOOM IS ON
description: GALA concerts featuring celebrated opera stars seem to be a burgeoning phenomenon on the music scene nowadays. At least three such glittering events are scheduled to take place during the coming season, and several others are in the discussion stage. No doubt the great interest stirred up by the concert given in Avery Fisher Hall last March by Joan Sutherland, Marilyn Horne and Luciano Pavarotti has inspired impresarios to devise evenings that might generate equal amounts of vocal glamour and excitement.

title: Advertising; Ship 'n Shore Brings On Star of ''Love Boat''
description: Stanley C. Gillette, skipper of General Mills Inc.'s Ship 'n Shore division, which says it's the ''largest advertiser of branded tops and blouses in America,'' announced that Lauren Tewes is coming on board as Ship 'n Shore's company spokesman, in forthcoming television and print advertising. Ship 'n Shore's advertising agency is Geers Gross Advertising Inc.

title: CAMERA SWIVEL ON VOYAGER STICKS WHILE CRAFT PASSES BEHIND SATURN
description: A malfunction of the camera platform partly crippled Voyager 2 early this morning when the spacecraft was behind Saturn, out of communication with Earth. The malfunction occurred while Voyager was pulling away after its closest approach to the planet.

title: CONTINENTAL COPPER & STEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June
description: B-Includes income from discontinued operations of $507,000 for qr and $3,370,000 for yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $427,000 for qr and $630,000 for yr; shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd

title: WILLIAMS LOOKS BACK AT ABSCAM IN SORROW
description: Convicted by the Government in May and condemned by peers on the Senate Ethics Committee on Monday, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. cast a wary eye on a visitor today and preempted the inevitable questions about Abscam.

title: U.S. Plane Lost in North Sea While on a Training Exercise
description: A jet fighter of the United States Air Force Reserve crashed into the North Sea during a routine training exercise today, and the Danish military began a sea and air search for its pilot, the authorities said.

title: Dome Acts In Hudson's Bay Bid
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., owner of 52.9 percent of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, plans to use an untested legal device to sidestep a law that might prevent it from acquiring the remaining shares of Hudson's Bay.

title: ANTITRUST CHIEF OFFERS REBUTTAL
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - President Reagan's chief antitrust officer today disputed assertions that a wave of mergers has developed in response to the administration's reluctance to challenge mergers.

title: Affirmative Action Revisions Protested by Women's Group
description: Supporters of a women's rights group rallied in front of a Manhattan bank yesterday to protest Federal proposals to revise affirmative action policies for women and minorities.

title: Barnes Freed of Charge; Nets' Offer Still Open
description: A charge of pandering for prostitution against Marvin Barnes was dropped in court today, his former girlfriend having admitted that she fabricated the complaint.

title: Notes on People; Howard Russell Weds
description: The man who married Betty Marshallsee in the New York City Clerk's office yesterday was Harold Russell, and witnesses noticed he placed the ring on the bride's finger effortlessly, even though he did so with prosthetic devices.

title: Around the Nation; Three Accused of Killing Visiting Antiques Dealer
description: Three teen-agers have been charged with murdering a British antiques dealer who was chasing a purse snatcher, the authorities said today.

title: Lester J. Cappon, a Historian And Ex-Archivist, Dead at 80
description: Lester J. Cappon, an editor and historian of early American culture, died here on Monday.

title: The Region; OSHA Cites Park In Coaster Fatality
description: Great Adventure, a large Ocean County amusement park where a 20-year-old ride operator fell to his death from a roller coaster, was cited by Federal safety authorities.

title: DOW FALLS BY 2.57, TO 899.26
description: Investors concern over high interest rates and double-digit inflation sent stock prices down slightly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing below the 900 level for the first time in 13 months.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Home Beat; A ROOFTOP HOT TUB FOR ALL SEASONS
description: IT may be getting to the end of summer, but that doesn't matter much to Barbara Wyckoff and her husband, Peter Siris, shown below with their neighbor, Anne Tischler, right. Since they use their rooftop hot tub all year, the couple pay little attention to the changing seasons, except to regulate the water temperature - ''below body temperature in the summer, 104 degrees in the winter,'' said Miss Wyckoff, a vice president and merchandise manager at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: IN NEW YORK AREA NOV. 9-13
description: The Rolling Stones, whose 1978 American tour was rumored to be their last anywhere, yesterday put an end to those rumors. They announced dates for a 12-week American tour that will begin with a show at Philadelphia's JFK Stadium on Sept. 25. The tour will include performances in some of the nation's largest stadiums and in indoor sports arenas, but there will also be surprise appearances in smaller concert halls and even in night clubs. Dates and sites for the engagements in small halls and clubs have not been divulged, but approximately three-fourths of the group's concerts in large facilities have been set.

title: PRESERVATION IS A PROBLEM
description: For preservationists, the grand camps present a problem because many are adjacent to New York State Adirondack Park. Normally, when such prime lands are put up for sale, the state buys the property for the park and razes or abandons the buildings to conform with a state constitutional requirement that the Adirondack Park ''shall be forever kept as wild forest lands.''

title: Pain Device Lawsuit Filed
description: A $70 million suit has been filed against Johnson & Johnson Inc. by a suburban Minneapolis concern and a doctor who contend that Johnson & Johnson violated antitrust and patent laws in connection with an electronic device for relieving pain.

title: FIRE DEPARTMENT TO SHIFT HEADQUARTERS TO BROOKLYN
description: The New York City Fire Department will move to new headquarters in downtown Brooklyn next spring, officials said yesterday, making it the first mayoral agency to have its central offices outside Manhattan.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: BUT 20.2% GAIN TRAILS '79 RISE
description: Foreign investments in the United States grew 20.2 percent in 1980, a smaller gain than in 1979, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: IT'S TIME FOR FEAR: THE PAINTERS ARE HERE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elaine Dann Goldstein is a freelance writer. By ELAINE DANN GOLDSTEIN

title: 4 LEADING DEMOCRATS ASSAIL KOCH ON HE G.O.P. ALLIANCE
description: Four prominent Democratic officials have sharply criticized Mayor Koch's alliance with the Republican Party because they say it is improving the chances for Republican victories in next year's elections for Governor and the Legislature.

title: Financial Futures Spur Brokers' Net; Financial Futures Gain
description: The rapid growth of financial futures has helped commodity brokerage firms to increase profits this year despite declines in such big-volume areas as soybean, corn, live cattle and gold futures, according to a survey released today by the Commodity News Service.

title: Motorist Is Injured In Crash on Bridge
description: A section of the Williamsburg Bridge was closed for more than an hour after a car accident in which one was man seriously injured.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
N.L. Bars Green for 5 Games
description: Charles Feeney, president of the National League, decided yesterday to suspend Dallas Green, manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, for five games and fine him $1,000 as a result of Green's run-in with an umpire Monday night. Feeney had imposed a suspension on Green Tuesday but had made the duration indefinite, pending the league office's review of game films.

title: The Region; Conrail Reports Performance Drop
description: On-time performance continued to deteriorate and more cars were out of service for repairs on Conrail's three divisions in the second quarter of 1981, the rail line reported.

title: FMC Unsure on Plant
description: The FMC Corporation said today that work on a planned 190,000 square foot plant in Aiken, S.C., to produce components for military vehicles could not go forward if the Federal Government decided to cut procurement of M2 and M3 tank-like vehicles. In response to an inquiry, an FMC spokesman said there had been discussion in Washington of cutting procurement below previously announced plans for about 7,000 vehicles. The company said it planned to make machined aluminum parts for the hulls and propulsion assemblies of the M2 and M3 vehicles at Aiken, where it would employ 700 people.

title: Executive Changes
description: * LSB Industries, Oklahoma City, has elected to its board K. Gordon Greer, president of the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company.

title: MISS WADE, AT 36, COMPETES FOR FUN
description: Her computer ranking keeps slipping, but Virginia Wade says she is ''retired, having fun and playing well.'' And for the second straight day, Miss Wade demonstrated some of the skills that made her a United States Open and Wimbledon champion.

title: Boy, 14, Is Seized In Bank Robbery
description: A 14-year-old boy and two other youths were in Federal custody after their capture in the $4,300 armed robbery of a Citibank branch at Madison Avenue and 91st Street.

title: UNLIKELY HEIR OF THE NEW DEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Supports Topps in Suit
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that Topps Chewing Gum Inc. did not illegally corner the market on baseball trading cards through exclusive contracts with major league players.

title: Fathers' Duties
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Regarding your Aug. 13 article entitled ''Children, a Job and No Time,'' the most appalling omission was mention of the men who have fathered these children. Regardless of whether the father and mother remain married to each other or divorce, the father too has an obligation to worry about spending that minimum quantity and quality time necessary for the health and well-being of his children.

title: BIOFUEL INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Notes on People; 3 Girls for John Boy
description: Richard Thomas, the original John Boy of ''The Waltons'' television series, became a father of three daughters yesterday in a California hospital.

title: Around the Nation; Indians Ordered to Leave Black Hills Encampment
description: United States Forest Service officials told about 40 Indians camped in the Black Hills today that they would have to leave by Sept. 8, but Sioux leaders said they would defy the order.

title: Helpful Hardware; BALANCED WATER VALVES
description: IF you are building a new bathroom or remodeling an old one, you might want to consider an important safety feature and install tub and shower valves that are pressure-balanced.

title: BUILDING SHUTS TROUBLED 43RD ST. PLAZA
description: A midtown office-building plaza designed as a public boon but increasingly populated by Times Square derelicts was fenced off this week.

title: Pratt & Whitney, Rolls Discuss Jet
description: The United Technologies Corporation said that its Pratt & Whitney subsidiary was discussing with Rolls-Royce Ltd., the British engine maker, a possible joint venture to develop and market a new jet engine.

title: To the Trade Only
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Please accept our apologies. Unfortunately on June 4 we misinformed The New York Times regarding our furniture sale at our store called ''ICF, too'' (''Designer Furniture on Permanent Sale'').

title: GARFINCKEL BROOKS BROTHERS, MILLER & RHOAD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug
Business People; Genesco President Will Also Be Chief
description: Richard W. Hanselman, who was elected president of Genesco Inc. only 16 months ago, was tapped yesterday to become chief executive officer of the big footwear and apparel company.

title: CARVING OUT MORE ROOM FROM UNLIKELY SPACES
Fred Meyer Board Accepts Firm's Bid
description: Directors of Fred Meyer Inc. have authorized the sale of the big Northwest retail chain to a New York investment group for $55 a share, or a total of about $420 million, the company announced today.

title: Loan for Peru Concern
description: Representatives of the Chase Manhattan Bank said today that they had received a mandate to raise a $100 million refinancing loan for the Southern Peru Copper Corporation. They said the loan carried a maturity of 10 years, with one year's grace, and interest of 1 1/8 percentage points over the London interbank offered rate. The loan is to refinance a fixed-rate debt taken out by the company in 1964 from commercial banks and the International Finance Corporation to set up a mine, they added.

title: 291,208 at Tanglewood Set Record for a Season
description: A record-breaking total of 291,208 concertgoers attended the 1981 Tanglewood summer music festival, which ended last Sunday afternoon with Seiji Ozawa leading the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Mahler's Symphony No. 8. The previous attendance record was set last summer, when the festival attracted 270,154 persons.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CARTER DRIVES IN 4 AS EXPOS TOP REDS, 6-0
description: Gary Carter drove in four runs with a two-run home run and a two-run single, and Bill Gullickson pitched a four-hitter as the Montreal Expos defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 6-0, tonight. In his last two games, Carter has 10 runs batted in on only six turns at bat.

title: BARBARO CRITICIZES KOCH FOR REFUSING TO HOLD ONE-ON-ONE DEBATES
description: Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro accused Mayor Koch yesterday of trying to blur the choice between them in the Democratic mayoral primary by refusing to hold one-on-one debates.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LABOR DEPT. SAYS WAGE RISE KEPT CLOSE TO INFLATION RATE
description: The earnings of American workers nearly kept pace with inflation over the year ended July 30, a sharp contrast to the slippage found in the previous year, the Labor Department said today.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $895,000 for qr and $6,495,000 for yr and $700,00 loss for yr from discontinued operations and $480,000 provision for yr for future losses... C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,207,000 for qr and $502,000 for yr; yr-ago results have been re- classified to reflect divestiture of the variety and specialty retailing segment of the business and the retroactive adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No 13 regarding accounting for leases

title: A PAINFUL TIME FOR AIRLINES
description: The airline industry, flying 75 percent of its normal schedule and hauling about 80 percent of its expected passengers, is beginning to feel a painful financial pinch from the 22-day slow down in air traffic.

title: Warner-Lambert Selling Candy Unit
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said that it would close its Good & Plenty Manufacturing Company plant in Philadelphia.

title: Fappiano Takes Forego As Belmont Reopens
description: Fappiano set a stakes record yesterday in taking the $83,770 Forego Handicap as Belmont Park reopened for a 42-day season. Carrying 119 pounds, including Angel Cordero, Fappiano, the 4-year-old who had won the Metropolitan Handicap in May, defeated Herb Water by threequarters of a length and paid $3 for $2 to win.

title: DEEP-SEA DIVERS FIND A SAFE IN ANDREA DORIA'S WRECKAGE
description: Divers searching the murky Atlantic for the treasure of the Andrea Doria, the Italian luxury liner that sank 25 years ago, today found one of two safes believed to contain more than $1 million in jewels and valuables.

title: Essay; PEACE THROUGH REALISM
description: In this seaside city, the leaders of two ancient nations met alone for two hours - no aides drawn up in what Churchill derided as ''vast cumbrous array'' -to deal with Middle East realities.

title: The City; 3 in Lundy Case Get Prison Terms
description: Three men were sentenced to prison terms and fined a total of $600,000 in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn for swindling Frederick Lundy, an aging Brooklyn restaurateur, of $11 million shortly before his death in 1977.

title: Around the Nation; Yosemite Staff Accused Of Embezzling for Drugs
description: A Federal grand jury is looking into allegations that young employees of Yosemite National Park's major concessionaire are embezzling millions of dollars, with company officials' knowledge, to buy cocaine and marijuana, it was disclosed today.

title: Briefs
description: * Charles Schwab & Co. said that it had agreed to acquire the Baltimore and Laurel, Md., offices of Brokers Exchange Inc. for an undisclosed price. The move marks Schwab's first entry into Maryland, the company said.

title: REVISED OUTPUT FIGURES SHOW RISE
description: Revised Government figures released today showed that American business productivity actually rose in the second quarter, at an annual rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent, in contrast to the Government's initial report of a nine-tenth of 1 percent annual rate of decline.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, AUGUST 27, 1981
description: International The Palestinian autonomy talks between Egypt and Israel are to resume on Sept. 23. The decision to revive the long-stalled negotiations was the major announcement made by President Anwar el-Sadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin after they ended their 12th meeting in a four-year effort to achieve peace in the Middle East. (Page A1, Column 1.) Nigeria will cut the price of crude oil by $4 a barrel in what may be the first in a series of price reductions by the OPEC exporters in the face of the worldwide oil glut. Industry experts said that if the price reduction - to $36 from $40 a barrel - were matched by other African producers, gasoline prices in this country could drop by two or three cents a gallon. (A1:2.)

title: ROBERT BRAUCHER
description: Associate Justice Robert Braucher of the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts died today at his home in Arlington, Mass.

title: Canadian Dollar Outlook
description: The Canadian dollar will remain below the 83-cent level against its United States counterpart for at least another two or three months, according to a survey of currency traders and economists.

title: YANKS BEAT TWINS
description: Reggie Jackson and the Yankees' front office created yesterday the latest act in the longest running melodrama in New York. First, Cedric Tallis, the club's executive vice president, gave Jackson a letter in which the Yankees asked him to take a complete physical examination today. Then, Jackson asked for and had a meeting with assorted members of the team's hierarchy. George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner and often the producer and director of the five-year-old melodrama, was not present.

title: MEENAN OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock splits distribution in Mar 1981 and Mar 1980 and for pooling of interest

title: SCHOOLS ARE NOT SOCIAL WELFARE INSTITUTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Synthetic Gas Project Ended
description: The three members of a proposed partnership to build and operate an estimated $2.7 billion coal gasification project in Wyoming have ended negotiations on the venture, the Panhandle Eastern Corporation said today.

title: JETS EASE HARPER'S DUTIES
description: For the second time in his four-season career, Bruce Harper of the Jets led the National Football League last year in all-purpose yardage, a feat that owed much to his prowess as a kickoff and punt returner.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, AUGUST 27, 1981; International
description: Nigeria, the No. 2 supplier of oil to the U.S., will cut its price by $4 to $36 a barrel. The cutback may be the first of several by OPEC members in the face of a worldwide oil glut. If other African producers follow Nigeria's lead, analysts said, American gasoline prices might be reduced as much as 3 cents a gallon. (Page A1.)

title: HISPANIC WOMEN: A GRIM REPORT
description: ALANGUAGE barrier, low levels of education and a lack of job experience were cited yesterday as three major reasons for what was termed ''the critical situation'' of Puerto Rican women who head households in New York City.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for 2-for-1 stock splits paid April 11, 1980 and Feb 6, 1981

title: Radial Tires For U.S. Cars
description: All new United States-built cars will have radial tires as standard equipment for the first time in the 1982 model year, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today.

title: LEE HAYS, A CO-FOUNDER OF THE WEAVERS, DIES
description: Lee Hays, who sang bass with the Weavers, the folk-singing quartet that started the folk-music boom of the 1950's, died of a heart attack at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday. He was 67 years old and lived in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: STABLER ABANDONS PLAN TO RETIRE, AGREES TO REJOIN THE OILERS
description: Ken Stabler, the Houston Oiler quarterback, ended his 35-day retirement today by signing a two-year contract and admitting that leaving football was tougher than he thought it would be.

title: 26 DIE IN SALVADOR IN POLITICAL STRIFE
description: At least 26 people died in this country's political violence yesterday and today, judicial authorities reported. Scores of prisoners at San Salvador jails continued a partial hunger strike for a fifth day to demand speedier trials.

title: INTEREST RATE WAR AT SAVINGS UNITS
description: He sports a Hawaiian shirt and a fishing hat, and the sack of money in one hand and the wad of bills in the other have him grinning like the Cheshire cat.

title: Templeton Suspended And Fined
description: Whitey Herzog, the field manager and general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, fined Garry Templeton $5,000 and suspended him indefinitely without pay for making obscene gestures at fans during today's game against the San Francisco Giants.

title: Index; International
description: Notes on the U.N.: Newspaper supplement looks doomed A2 U.S. protests Soviet article link- ing it with attack on Pope A3 Polish union pressing demand for access to media A4 Around the World A5 Canada pledges tight rein on in- ternal security agency A6 26 Salvadorans die in political vio- lence A8 U.S. says South African incursion underscores need for talks A10 Jimmy Carter amazes them in China A11 Government/Politics Safety board begins check of air traffic control system A14 Kleindienst friend testifies in Ari- zona perjury trial A20 Federal commission named to study excellence in education A28 Senator Williams mocks Abscam accusations B1 3 City Council candidates stress varying issues B3 City and P.B.A. near accord on one-officer patrol cars B3 Barbaro and Esposito give their views on housing issue B6 General The SR-71 high-altitude recon- naissance plane at a glance A12 Around the Nation A14 Private pilots say controllers' strike effects now are minimal. A14 Amtrak cuts routes and service to meet budget cuts A17 Survivor testifies about attack at Guyana airstrip A21 Exhumation delayed in case linked to C.I.A. B2 Fire Department plans move to new headquarters in Brooklyn B2 The Home Section Home Carving out more room from unlikely spaces C1

title: MINERALS ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Region; 3 in Bridge Case Ordered to Jail
description: Three young men accused of raising a drawbridge and causing an accident Tuesday that left a 24-year-old woman clinging to the bridge for two hours were jailed when they were unable to post $5,000 bail.

title: Market Place; Tocom's TV Converter
description: TOCOM INC., a major maker of devices that permit consumers to communicate directly with merchants via cable television, has received relatively little publicity. But a number of investment counselors who are fans of Tocom believe that its version of the twoway converter is a leader in the field.

title: IMMUNITY SETS ETHIOPIAN FREE
description: An Ethiopian national was charged with sexually abusing a 19-yearold waitress in her Manhattan apartment building but was released from custody after he claimed diplomatic immunity as the brother-inlaw of a diplomat, the police said.

title: McEnroe No. 1 For U.S. Open
description: John McEnroe and Chris Evert Lloyd, the defending champions and Nos. 1 in the world rankings, were top-seeded yesterday for next week's United States Open.

title: Technology; A TV Station For Business
description: LOBBYISTS for American business interests will soon have a powerful new tool - a satellite television station for their own use. The Business Advocate Satellite Network, or Biznet, is being built by the United States Chamber of Commerce, which represents 180,000 corporations and smaller trade groups. Starting in February, in time for next year's elections, Biznet will transmit programs and news to corporations and local chambers of commerce throughout the nation.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My frame house has a basement with cinder-block walls. When I began to paint the walls last winter I noticed a white crystal-like substance ''growing'' on certain walls. The wall on which this was most noticeable was the one that has no windows. Before painting the walls I treated them with a heavy white sealant that is supposed to prevent moisture from entering; then I used a good oil-base paint throughout the basement. Now I notice that the crystal-like substance is coming back, pushing the paint off in the process. What can it be and how can I get rid of it? - J.G., Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WHERE HOME COSTS GO HALFWAY TO STARS
description: San Francisco is the most expensive metropolitan area in the country in which to buy a home because of its desirable location and limited market, a realty spokesman said this week.

title: Critic's Notebook; PRIVATE PATRON OF NEW MUSIC PLAYS A LONELY ROLE
description: THIS summer's Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood had its ups and its downs, as in every year. There were some good pieces and even more indifferent or overtly poor ones - as in every year. There were complaints, justified as ever, that the festival was slighting experimental originality and was fixated on a narrow view of what contemporary music really is.

title: Taiwan Routs Mexico In Little League Series
description: The Taiwan team of Tai Chung hit four homers today in a 10-0 rout of Monterrey, Mexico, in the final first-round game of the Little League World Series.

title: NATIONALIZATION TARGETS RALLY ON PARIS BOURSE
description: Shares of companies and banks that France's new Socialist-Communist coalition Government plans to nationalize rallied on the Paris stock exchange today, following yesterday's announcement that the Government would pay a record interest rate of 16.75 percent on its first state borrowing.

title: Norway Oil Output Up
description: Norway's oil and gas production in the first seven months of this year rose to the equivalent of 29.6 million tons of oil, or about 231 million barrels, from 28.8 million equivalent tons a year earlier, the Directorate for Petroleum said today.

title: Cape Town Squatters Seized While Sleeping in Churchyard
description: The South African police raided a churchyard before dawn today and rounded up more than 600 black squatters who had been sleeping there.

title: MISSILE IS FIRED BY NORTH KOREANS AT U.S. SPY PLANE NEAR THE DMZ
description: A North Korean surface-to-air missile was fired at an American reconnaissance aircraft near the demilitarized zone of North and South Korea today, Pentagon officials said. The plane was not hit, they added.

title: Advertising; Dairy Group Plans More Milk Commercials
description: The American Dairy Association, which is the advertising and marketing arm of the United Dairy Industry Association, is really taking advantage of the message it introduced last spring, ''Milk: the fresher refresher.'' Its agency is D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/Chicago.

title: SLAUGHTER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MILE RUN BY OVETT IN 3:48.40
description: Steve Ovett of Britain lowered the world record for the mile run today, clocking 3 minutes 48.40 seconds in an international track and field meet only a week after the record had been set at 3:48.53, by Ovett's countryman and long-time rival, Sebastian Coe, at Zurich, Switzerland.

title: COMPACT VIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Tiger Increases Purolator Stake
description: Tiger International Inc., parent of the Flying Tiger Line air cargo carrier, said that it had raised its stake in Purolator Inc. to 13.4 percent.

title: POP: BRITIAN'S SKA-BASED SPECIALS
description: THE Specials, a multiracial ska-based dance band from Coventry, England, have been in existence for four years. At the very least, they have always been a charming dance band. And their concern for social, racial and political issues in England lent them an added weight of interest, an interest that their music alone night not have sustained.

title: CHILDREN'S PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
Cutting More Than Red Tape
description: The Reagan Administration wants, legitimately, to cut down on excess regulatory requirements, simplifying life for businesses and saving everyone money. But that principle shouldn't permit the sacrifice of important policy goals. The Department of Labor's plan to ease up on Government contractors' hiring practices threatens to do just that.

title: NEW DRUG MAY PREVENT HARDENING OF ARTERIES
description: A new drug made from penicillin reduces levels of cholesterol in the blood and may prevent hardening of the arteries, an underlying cause of the heart attacks and strokes that kill 800,000 Americans a year, researchers say.

title: Budget Deficits Cited
description: Henry C. Wallich, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board of the United States, said here today that the battle against inflationary pyschology in the United States was endangered by increasing budget deficits more than anything else.

title: Brazil Devaluation
description: Brazil devalued its currency, the cruzeiro, by 1.682 percent last night, to 102.18 to the United States dollar at the buyers' rate and 102.69 at the sellers' rate, effective today. This was the 23d cruzeiro devaluation of the year.

title: Gardening; FOR CITY GARDENERS, A BOUNTIFUL HARVEST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang is a frequent contributor of gardening articles to The Home Section. By LINDA YANG

title: JAZZ: EARL HINES, HIS QUARTET
description: IN recent years Earl Hines has been carrying less of the load of his quartet's performances than he once did, featuring himself at the piano for two or three numbers and then turning most of the playing over to the other musicians.

title: Ford Foundation Announces Grants to Bolster Math Skills
description: The Ford Foundation yesterday announced $1.1 million in grants to schools to mend what it called ''acute'' problems in mathemathics skills among minority students.

title: Around the World; Iran Executes 26 And Flogs a Monarchist
description: Iran executed 26 more leftist opponents this week and began a crackdown on monarchists by publicly whipping a supporter of the late Shah, the Teheran radio said today.

title: WHIMSICAL CRAFTED ROOM IS COMPLETED
description: TOMMY SIMPSON has built a room without a house, a room of serendipitous, slightly off-center discovery. There are Martha Washington chairs - not quite the Martha Washington straightbacks many people are familiar with - covered with pale blue velvet, with modern cherrywood legs and arms of English oak inlaid with tiny cherrywood hearts.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WICKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-After $133,000 loss from discontinued operations... C-Net loss including gains from discontinued operations of $3,302,000 for qr and $1,862,000 for 6 mos...D-After $364,000 loss from discontinued operations; results for latest periods include the reversal of a $4.5 million reserve

title: Mauritania Denies a Charge That 100,000 Live in Slavery
description: Mauritania denied today that 100,000 of its people, about 10 percent of the population, live in slavery. A report by the London-based Anti-Slavery Society to the United Nations Human Rights Commission, which is meeting here, charged that Mauritanian Government officials kept slaves despite the fact that bondage was outlawed last year.

title: RESTORING GRANDEUR OF NEWPORT'S PAST
description: Jim Rensch does not have a crystal ball or X-ray vision. But he can ''look'' hundreds of years into the past to see people creating fantasies for other people.

title: AMTRAK ALTERS ROUTES, CUTS SERVICE TO MEET BUDGET
description: Amtrak's executive board today voted to rearrange its routes, eliminating several unprofitable trains while keeping most of the nation's rail passenger network intact.

title: CCI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DEFECTIVE ARGUMENTS FOR ESTATE TAX CUTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Noisy Jets Banned at Airport
description: Western Airlines has been told to quit operating at Orange County's John Wayne Airport because the airline's jets are too noisy. County supervisors took the action yesterday.

title: DAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WEINBERGER SAYS HE HAS A PROPOSAL FOR THE MX MISSILE
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he was prepared to make a specific recommendation to President Reagan on deployment of the MX missile.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $11,000 for the qr and $66,000 for the 9 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $2,000 for the qr and $63,000 for the 9 mos

title: A Correction
description: A recipe in Wednesday's Living Section for squid sauteed with green beans and mushrooms gave an incorrect measurement for butter. The correct amount is two tablespoons.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Credit Markets; YIELDS NEAR PEAKS AFTER RALLY ENDS
description: Yields in the fixed-income market rose to near-record levels yesterday as prices eased because of prospects of a bulge in shortterm Treasury financing. That outlook, which helped to end a brief rally, could push up interest rates.

title: Around the Nation; Alcohol Found in Blood Of a Drowned Prisoner
description: An autopsy showed that one of three black teen-agers who drowned while in the custody of police during a local celebration was intoxicated but not under the influence of drugs.

title: OTTAWA PLEDGES TIGHT REIN ON SECURITY FORCE
description: The Canadian Government said today that it would keep a close watch on a new intelligence agency it has proposed to monitor internal and external security.

title: New Guinea Envoy Picked
description: President Reagan will nominate Virginia M. Schafer to be the new ambassador to Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands, the White House announced today. Miss Schafer, 51 years old, entered the Foreign Service in 1964 as a typing clerk and has since served in a variety of posts.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Finance Briefs
description: * M.C.I. Communications Corp.'s $155 million offering of convertible subordinated debentures and preferred stock was raised to a B plus rating by Standard & Poor's, from a B rating.

title: Going Out Guide
description: CHANGE OF ROLES

title: TV: 'MAKING OF WIZARD OF OZ'
description: THOSE who grew up with ''The Wizard of Oz,'' the 1939 film classic starring Judy Garland, tend to plunge back into enthrallment when the film or anything about it surfaces. And so ''The Making of the Wizard of Oz,'' a half-hour documentary to be shown tonight at 8 o'- clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13, will have a guaranteed and uncritical audience of its own. It deserves it.

title: MOZART: ZUKERMAN CONDUCTS
description: AT times, the Mostly Mozart Festival seems like a proving ground for instrumentalists who want to try their hand at conducting. This year we have already seen the pianist Christoph Eschenbach and the flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal on the podium, and on Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall it was Pinchas Zukerman's turn to divide his attention between playing the violin and leading the orchestra.

title: Advertising; People
description: * John Hayter has been appointed senior vice president and general manager of Young & Rubicam, Chicago.

title: MOBOT: NO BELIEF IN PYGMALION
description: When Lawrence Kamm, founder and president of the Mobot Corporation, sets out to sell his industrial robots, he is likely bring up the legend of Pygmalion.

title: MORRISTOWN, N.J. - When President Reagan returns to Washington he will have no choice but to turn the attention of the White House to the abysmal state of the credit markets.
description: Vague hopes that his stunning budget victories would buoy the bond market, bring down interest rates and signal economic recovery have been dashed. There is growing apprehension among the political figures in the White House that the monetarists who control Federal Reserve Board policy will not be able to brake inflationary expectations with high interest rates. The vision Republican candidates for the Senate and House have of trying to defend 20 percent interest rates in 1982 is too awful to contemplate.

title: Hers
description: I SAW them on the street. The boy appeared to be 15, the girl a few years younger. They were kissing - lightly and frequently - as if to punctuate their conversation. How happy and easy they seemed to be, I thought, how unlike myself at that age.

title: Around the World; French Cabinet Backs Ending Death Penalty
description: The French Cabinet today approved a bill to abolish the death penalty and end two centuries of executions by guillotine.

title: FLORIDA GULF REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Mar 1981

title: Business People; Retiring Economist Taking His Own Advice
description: For Walter Hoadley, the Bank of America's chief economist and economic forecaster, the best part of retirement will be having to finally practice all that he has preached.

title: ASTROS SEND METS TO 9-3 DEFEAT
description: The Houston Astros sprayed 11 hits round Shea Stadium last night and easily defeated the Mets, 9-3. Art Howe, the Astros' third baseman, led the attack with two doubles and five runs batted in.

title: Home Improvement
description: DECIDING IF A NEW ROOF IS NECCESSARY, AND HOW TO GET THE JOB DONE By Bernard Gladstone

title: Seasonal Sneezes
description: Your head feels as though a taxidermist has been at it: nothing between your ears but stuffing. Your eyes are small, red and runny; your nose is large, red and runny; and your sneezes rock the room.

title: Gannett Co.  Buys El Diario
description: The Gannett Company, operator of 83 newspapers, seven television stations and 13 radio stations, said yesterday that it had completed its earlier announced acquisition of El Diario-La Prensa, a New York Spanish-language newspaper with an average circulation of 61,000 on weekdays and 63,000 on Sunday.

title: CYNTHIA GREGORY TO PERFORM WITH THARP DANCERS
description: In an unusual use of guest artists who have not previously danced with the company, Twyla Tharp Dance has engaged Cynthia Gregory and Christine Sarry for its Broadway season at the Winter Garden Theater, from Sept. 22 through Oct. 17. Miss Gregory, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will dance the ''ballerina'' role and Miss Sarry a new, composite role in Miss Tharp's ''Deuce Coupe.''

title: U.S. PROTESTS SOVIET INNUENDO ON SHOOTING OF POPE
description: The Vatican, the Italian Government, the office of the American envoy to the Holy See and the Soviet Embassy here have become involved in a four-way diplomatic dispute over an article by a Soviet journalist that implied that the United States was involved in the shooting of Pope John Paul II.

title: SURVIVOR TESTIFIES ABOUT ATTACK AT GUYANA AIRSTRIP
description: An NBC News technician testified today at the murder-conspiracy trial of a former member of the People's Temple cult about surviving an ambush at a jungle airstrip in Guyana.

title: NIGERIA REDUCES CRUDE OIL PRICE BY $4 A BARREL
description: Nigeria, the No.2 exporter of oil to the United States, announced yesterday that it would lower the price of its oil by $4 a barrel in what may be the first in a series of price cuts by OPEC members in the face of a worldwide oil glut.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Chief Sees Trouble Under Reagan
description: Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today that President Reagan could ''end up putting black folks in a worse position than if a racist was in the White House.''

title: CHIEF OF AIR FLORIDA IS APPOINTED AS THE NEW CHAIRMAN OF PAN AM
description: Pan American World Airways, the financially troubled carrier that was a pioneer in international aviation, turned yesterday to a rugged upstart, Air Florida, for its new chairman and chief executive officer.

title: BELL NAMES COMMISSION TO STUDY WAYS TO RAISE SCHOOLS' STANDARDS
description: Education Secretary T.@H. Bell named a commission today to search for ways to raise standards and foster excellence in America's schools and colleges.

title: News Analysis
description: The huge gap in perception between Japan and the United States over the issue of the Mediterranean fruit fly was dramatically illustrated today at the stormy close of the two governments' first round of technical meetings about the cropthreatening pests.

title: Commodity Tie
description: The Gill & Duffus Group Ltd., Britain's biggest commodities trading house, said that it had acquired the Chicago-based commodity futures trading company Agra Trading Inc., and planned to merge it with its own company, Gill & Duffus Services Ltd.

title: U.S. Homes Ends Golden West Bid
description: The U.S. Homes Corporation, the nation's largest on-site builder of single-family homes and a major prefabricated house manufacturer, said that it had broken off merger talks with the California-based Golden West Homes Corporation, another home builder.

title: RECORDS SET IN POSTWAR ART.
description: Auctions of post-World War II art in New York this season set more than 20 records for the works of major artists and 20 more for works by less-known painters and sculptors at Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's. Both houses saw total sales in this area rise, with Sotheby's going from $5.4 million to $6 million and Christie's from $4.9 million to $5.5 million. Both reported many new collectors participating.

title: Around the World; Advisory Council Urges Spain's Entry in NATO
description: The State Advisory Council unanimously recommended today that Spain join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Approval is expected in Parliament.

title: Loss Recorded At J.P. Stevens
description: J.P. Stevens & Company, the nation's second-largest textile manufacturer, said yesterday that an after-tax charge to income left the company with a net loss of $36.6 million for the third quarter.

title: Holly Sugar Says Output Will Rise
description: The Holly Sugar Company will refine 7 percent to 10 percent more sugar this fall than it did last fall because of higher yields and sweeter beets, said John Bunker, the company's president, The company refined 431,000 tons last year, he said.

title: BELL FACING FRESH CHALLENGES
description: To most people in the lower half of Manhattan, Manhattan Cable Television is an entertainment company. But to banks and large companies, Manhattan Cable is also a telephone company.

title: REAGAN RESPONSE TO MARKET UNREST
description: At a point when economists of various leanings are urging President Reagan to take steps to calm the financial markets and thereby bring down interest rates, the Administration contends that the President is already responding with substantial efforts to keep Federal spending in check.

title: Broadway; Plenty of work in new season for the younger set.
description: THE new Broadway season is shaping up as one heavily populated by very young actors, along with nervous stage mothers. ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' the new Hal Prince-Stephen Sondheim musical, has a cast largely made up of teen-agers. ''Broadway Babies,'' a new $3 million revue due to open after the first of the year, has an even younger cast - 40 children in the 6-to-12 age range.

title: PUBLISHING: THE KALBS ON VIETNAM
description: AT the publication party for Marvin and Bernard Kalb's biography, ''Kissinger,'' in 1974, someone asked the Secretary of State what he thought about the book. Mr. Kissinger replied that he had not yet had a chance to read it, but that he loved the title.

title: TRIAL RULE THAT SUPPRESSES TRUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Consolidated Foods Gains
description: The Consolidated Foods Corporation, a major food producer, said today that its profit in the fiscal fourth quarter rose 13 percent from a year earlier.

title: Green Won't Appeal
description: Dallas Green, manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, said today that he would not appeal the fivegame suspension imposed on him by the National League yesterday over his dispute with Umpire Steve Fields.

title: AT SEAPORT, TWILIGHT OF A JAZZ SUMMER
description: The second annual three-month series of free outdoor jazz concerts called Summerpier will end this weekend with concerts tonight and tomorrow night by Melba Liston and Company, a seven-piece group led by Miss Liston, a trombonist. The concerts will start at 8 P.M. on Pier 16 at Fulton Street and the East River.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including $63,000 tax credit...C-Including $105,000 tax credit

title: PUPIL IMPORT SAVES SCHOOL IN TINY TOWN
description: The tiny town of Antler opened its public school today with 21 new pupils who would not have been there if a local farmer had not taken matters into his own hands.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: B-Net loss including $55,000 net income from discontinued operations and $3.3 million extraordinary loss...C-Including $205,000 net income from discontinued operations...D-Including $500,000 net income from discontinued operations and $3.3 million extraordinary loss

title: Bluegrass at Clinton
description: An outdoor bluegrass concert will be given by the Tony Trischka Band tomorrow night at 8 in the Clinton Historical Museum Village, 56 Main Street, Clinton, N.J. Admission is $4 ($3 for the elderly; $2 for children).
