title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
Finance Briefs
description: * Birdview Satellite Communications filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial offering of 35 million common shares, to be offered through underwriters led by Richey Frankel & Co.

title: TRECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $156,000 tax credit...C-Includes $116,000 tax credit

title: Around the Nation; Judge Bans Comments In Atlanta Murder Trial
description: A judge ordered police officers, attorneys and potential witnesses today to stop talking to reporters about the case against Wayne B. Williams, who faces trial Oct. 5 on charges of murdering two young black men.

title: Getting Serious About Drug Enforcement
description: It's odd that the Attorney General's Task Force on Violent Crime should have to call for an ''unequivocal commitment to combating domestic drug traffic.'' A new heroin trade, after all, is sweeping the Eastern Seaboard and drug abuse of all sorts is an increasingly common fact of life in all parts of the country.

title: CHANNELS 2 AND 7 PLAN AFTERNOON NEWSCASTS
description: In moves that reflect the growing audience for news and information programs, WABC-TV, Channel 7, and WCBS-TV, Channel 2, yesterday announced plans to introduce daily afternoon news programs.

title: CITY ARSON RATE IS LEVELING OFF, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: New York City fire officials say that the arson rate in the city seems at least to be staying level, reversing a trend of the last five years. The annual number of determined arson fires in the city rose from 3,878 in 1975 to 8,979 in 1980.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: B-Including $420,000 from life insurance proceeds

title: AMEX PLAN: OPTION TIED TO METALS
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had filed a proposal with the Securities and Exchange Commission to trade put and call options on gold- and silver-denominated notes.

title: WILLIAM HURT AS FALL GUY IN 'BODY HEAT'
description: ''EVERYTHING'S just a little askew. Pretty soon people start thinking the old rules are no longer in effect.'' A character says that in ''Body Heat,'' though in this movie the old rules are the only ones that matter. Those rules - which say the world is a sultry, shadowy place full of characters motivated solely by lust and greed - have little to do with anything lifelike, and everything to do with the 1940's film noir classics from which ''Body Heat'' is skillfully, though slavishly, derived.

title: Pop Jazz; FATHA HINES STOMING AND CHOMPING ON AT 75
description: ''NONE of us knew we were making history,'' said Earl (Fatha) Hines, who was sitting at a corner table in Fat Tuesday's with a substantial cigar clamped securely between his teeth. He was talking about ''West End Blues,'' ''Basin Street Blues'' and the other recordings he made with Louis Armstrong in the late 1920's, recordings that are now recognized as enduring jazz masterpieces. ''To us, every one of those sessions was just one more recording,'' Mr. Hines added, ''and if people liked it, that was fortunate for us. I didn't know those recordings were any good, to tell you the truth.''

title: Business People; KENNECOTT CHIEF NAMED VICE CHAIRMAN OF SOHIO
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) yesterday named Thomas D. Barrow, 56-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Kennecott Corporation, as vice chairman of Sohio.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
The U.N. Today; Aug. 28, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on a complaint by Angola against South Africa at 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Restaurants; East Side French, SoHo Italianate.
description: IT has often been suggested that one should see a play early in its run because with repeated performances the cast loses its freshness and enthusiasm. Apparently that can also be true of a restaurant, judging by recent visits to La Petite Ferme on Lexington Avenue, between 71st and 72d Streets. The bloom certainly seems to be off the performances of kitchen and dining-room staffs, and perhaps even of the management. Started as a pocket-size provincial restaurant in Greenwich Village about 11 years ago, La Petite Ferme moved to this larger location in 1977, still under the close scrutiny of its owner, Charles Chevillot. The same array of brightly fresh and simple dishes was presented on a blackboard menu, and if the enlargement was accomplished at the expense of the original excellence, the food at this newer restaurant was worth two stars when originally reviewed. Simple floral bouquets, checked linen dish towels for napkins and a fresh country setting added to the charm and originality.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, AUGUST 28, 1981
description: International Jimmy Carter praised the policy of the Reagan Administration toward China as ''compatible'' with his own. The former President, who is visiting China, said that, if he were still in the White House, he would also have offered to sell defensive weapons to the Chinese as President Reagan has proposed. (Page A1, Columns 4-5.) Washington warned North Korea of ''serious concern'' over the firing of a North Korean antiaircraft missile at an Air Force high-flying reconnaissance craft Wednesday and vowed that the United States would take all steps necessary to assure the safety of its pilots and planes. (A1:5-6.)

title: UNION OIL CO (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Face: John Vickery; HOW TO BECOME A MADCAP PRINCE
description: A DECADE ago, John Vickery had two passions, abstract mathematics and acting. He was an undergraduate at the University of California at Berkeley then, and thanks to a double major, he was able to indulge both interests. When the time came to make a living, he chose the theater and started thinking mathematically about the problems he faced as an actor.

title: Coca-Cola Bottling Merger Accord
description: Shareholders of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, one of the nation's largest bottlers, approved a merger agreement with the Coca-Cola Company and others that will result in a payment of $10.375 in cash for each share held.

title: White Sox Beat Yankees In Rain-Shortened Game
description: The White Sox, after playing the first 15 games of the second season on the road, returned home to Comiskey Park tonight for the first time since the baseball strike and defeated the Yankees, 3-1, in a rain-shortened game.

title: MCDONALD'S IN A LICENSE FIGHT IN PARIS
description: The McDonald's Corporation, which for years has profited handsomely by selling hamburgers and french fries overseas, is now squabbling over one of its most lucrative foreign fast-food operations.

title: Notes on People; A Message of Love Travels the High Seas
description: The bottle on the beach that Chris Wille found while jogging on the island of Guam had an old-fashioned love note in it. The writer said he was dropping it into the Pacific halfway between Hawaii and Seattle in 1971.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BAN ON U.S. FLIGHTS REFUSED IN CANADA
description: Canadian air traffic controllers asked the Canadian Government today to stop all flights between Canada and the United States, but the Government refused.

title: In the Nation; RETHINKING THE MX (2)
description: Soviet missiles are now so large and so accurate, some defense analysts insist, that in a surprise attack they could wipe out the present American force of 1,052 land-based Minutemen and Titans. And the Russians deploy enough such missiles, these analysts argue, that they could survive a nuclear counterstrike and then destroy most American cities in a second attack.

title: U.S. EXPRESSES 'SERIOUS CONCERN' OVER FIRING OF NORTH KOREA MISSILE
description: The United States expressed ''serious concern'' today over the firing of a North Korean antiaircraft missile at an Air Force reconnaissance plane yesterday. Washington also warned that it would take ''whatever steps are necessary to assure the future safety of our pilots and planes.''

title: MORE CUTS SOUGHT IN EDUCATION AID, DEMOCRAT ASSERTS
description: A Congressional Democrat said today that he had reliable information that the Reagan Administration was preparing to seek additional large cuts in education aid for inner-city children.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON REPORTS A PROFIT
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the financially beleagured manufacturer of farm and industrial equipment, said yesterday that foreign-exchange translations resulted in a small profit in its third quarter.

title: LATIN JAZZ THRIVING AT TWO CITY FESTIVALS
description: THERE are millions of New Yorkers who come from Latin countries - Puerto Rico above all, but also the Dominican Republic, Cuba and the other countries in the Caribbean and Central and South America. These millions make music, and that music has an active subculture life of its own. Latin musicians have their own record companies, clubs and concert circuits. And if they hope lingeringly for a ''cross-over'' hit that will sell in the millions, the best of them do well enough playing almost exclusively for Latin audiences.

title: Legacy of Liberty
description: Roger Baldwin was 97 when he died Wednesday, so a lot of his friends were obviously younger. Many of these were also disciples.

title: News Analysis
description: Japan and South Korea, neighbors that have not been on close terms in recent years, held their first high-level meeting since 1978 last week, but the conference was something less than an outstanding success.

title: ANGOLA ASKS U.N. MEETING ON THE SOUTH AFRICAN RAID
description: Angola called today for an urgent Security Council meeting to demand the immediate withdrawal of South African troops from that country.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: B-Includes $15,689 gain for qr and $34,482 loss for 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: Van der Elst of Cosmos To Be Held for Playoffs
description: Coach Hennes Weisweiler of the Cosmos reversed his position somewhat yesterday and kept Francois Van der Elst available for the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON-PERKINS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
US SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split in June 1981

title: TOWN FEAR OF MOON CHURCH PERSISTS
description: When Mayor Leo Alper talks about the object of his suspicions, it is in a hoarse and scratchy rumble, as if the subject were literally stuck in his craw.

title: Business People; A HOBBYIST FLIER CHOSEN FOR C.A.B.
description: Clinton Dan McKinnon, a California radio and television station owner who flies aircraft as a hobby, has been nominated by President Reagan to be a member of the Civil Aeronautics Board, and would be named as its chairman if the Senate confirms the nomination. He would succeed Marvin S. Cohen, who has announced his resignation, effective Sept. 15, to practice law.

title: PEERLESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Knicks Sign Bradley,
description: Alex Bradley, a forward from Villanova, signed a multiyear contract with the Knicks yesterday. The terms were not disclosed. Bradley was the Knicks' fourth-round selection in the National Basketball Association's draft.

title: Around the World; Qaddafi Returns to Libya After Five-Nation Tour
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, returned to Tripoli today after an 11-day, five-nation tour that was apparently aimed at coordinating opposition to the United States military presence in the Middle East.

title: At the Movies; From song and dance to a tough cop.
description: WHEN the tough narcotics detective named Gus Levy first appears on the screen in Sidney Lumet's ''Prince of the City,'' some unsuspecting members of the audience are likely to do double-takes. Is it? Could it be? Yes, it is Jerry Orbach, the song-and-dance man, star of the current ''42d Street'' and other Broadway musicals.

title: VANDALS SET PACE FOR SUBWAY REPAIRS
description: Like many of the New Yorkers who ride them each day, the city's subway trains got off to another coughing, sputtering, lazy start early the other morning.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings for the latest qr and 9 mos have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split distributed June 30

title: FIERCE CLASHES ARE REPORTED
description: Angola reported fierce fighting today between its forces and South African troops who moved into southern Angola on Monday.

title: 5 CONCERTS-FOR-SINGLES YEARS
description: It was a divorce that started it all for Phyllis Lynd, a divorce and the desire to go back to music school for a master's degree, and next month she will celebrate the fifth anniversary of her Concert Party, which began in her apartment as ''kind of a rent party,'' she recalled the other day.

title: Mrs. Esposito Called By Worker for Koch
description: Mayor Koch's campaign workers have started making an estimated 9,000 telephone calls to enrolled Republicans in an effort to identify potential Koch supporters in the Republican mayoral primary against Assemblyman John A. Esposito.

title: Notes on People; Richard Thomas Names His Triplet Daughters
description: It wasn't long after Richard Thomas, who used to play John Boy Walton on television, became the father of triplet daughters Wednesday that wags started calling the new arrivals John Girl I, John Girl II and John Girl III.

title: SAVINGS ADS CALLED MISLEADING
description: The New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs yesterday charged that some New York savings banks have used ''misleading'' advertisements to sell new savings certificates that will not be available to the consumer until October.

title: The Evening Hours
description: T HERE is one sure-fire way, it seems, to get the trendsetters in this town to go out at night, and that is to ask them to a private film screening. An even better way is to make it a private screening of ''Mommie Dearest,'' the new film about the late Joan Crawford and her love/hate relationship with her adopted daughter, Christina, and follow it up with a light supper.

title: 2 OFFICERS ARE WOUNDED IN RAIDS ON A DRUG RING
description: Two law enforcement officers were shot yesterday morning in a series of raids in Suffolk County and Brooklyn that broke up what authorities said was a major ring supplying narcotics to buyers in eastern Long Island.

title: SWIVEL ON VOYAGER STILL MISBEHAVING
description: Voyager 2's balky camera platform failed to respond correctly to commands today as engineers struggled in vain to diagnose and perhaps fix the spacecraft's problem.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE MALTESE EXAMPLE
description: Malta's feisty Prime Minister Dom Mintoff has his own fight now with Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, after years of mutually rewarding chummery. So he would like the U.S. to come to his aid.

title: Index; International
description: Diplomatic maneuvering under way in Indian subcontinent A2 Sihanouk and Pol Pot leader to meet in Singapore A2 Israeli-Egyptian accord catches U.S. off guard A3 Angola reports heavy fighting with South African force A3 Around the World A5 Bonn's ruling party debates U.S. military influence A8 Salvadoran accused of killing two Americans ordered released A9 British law curbs questioning of jurors D16 Government/Politics Subway inspectors find it tough to keep up with the vandals B1 Members of Congress find summer recess a busman's holiday B2 Casey amends list of law clients submitted to Senate D16 General Around the Nation A10 Long-standing housing dispute in Michigan goes to court A10 Expansion of Unification Church worries Gloucester, Mass A10 Fugitive denies Green Berets trained terrorists in Libya A11 The Region B2 Two officers wounded and 20 suspects seized in drug raids B2 The city B3 The arrest of Roy Innis was another turn in CORE's history B3 The body of a Queens man is exhumed in Maine B3 New York City arson rate seems at least to be staying level B3 Education/Welfare Tiny town saves its school through importing pupils A24 Health/Science Problems persist with a camera platform on Voyager 2 B5 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Concert Parties mark five years C10 The big fair in Dutchess County C13 Art: Museums in the countryside C1

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AUSTRALIAN 'GALLIPOLI'
description: A YOUNG athlete takes a dare. A handsome runner in the first bloom of youth, he agrees to race barefoot against a bully on horseback, even though the odds are stacked hopelessly against him - and even though an important contest he has been training for is only days away. He cuts his feet badly while outrunning the hor e, but not even the bruises can lessen his bravado. So when the day of the major race arrives, he runs triumphantly. And when he decides, on this same day, to enlist in the army, he does so with the same reckless, buoyant self-confidence that induced him to compete with the horse and to court disaster.

title: SIHANOUK AND POL POT LEADER TO MEET IN SINGAPORE
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's deposed chief of state and former King, said today that he would go from France to Singapore next week to meet with Prime Minister Khieu Samphan, the nominal leader of the regime that was ousted by the Vietnamese invasion.

title: SAN FRANCISCO - The roots of the economic crisis in Poland lie in agricultural policies the Government has followed since World War II.
description: An uneven balance of power between urban and rural interests, in the Government and the Communist Party, created policies that undermined the Polish economy and left Poland caught between a rock and a hard place, politically beholden to the Soviet Union and economically beholden to the West. The Soviet Union offers ideological guidance enforceable by troops while Western financial institutions suggest conflicting economic measures backed by capital. The resolution of this dilemna will occur when rural people have a stronger voice in Government and Party decision making.

title: OWNERS ACT TO SAVE COAST NUCLEAR UNITS
description: The owner of two partially built nuclear power plants in Washington State today approved a stopgap measure aimed at preventing the projects from being abandoned for lack of money. The plants, each costing $6 billion, are the most expensive nuclear plants ever undertaken in this country.

title: Topics; TWO STEPS FORWARD...  VIN ORDINAIRE
description: There are Americans still alive who remember when wine meant something that arrived in a straw-swaddled bottle and served as a chaser for spaghetti and meatballs. Such oenological innocence, however, did not long survive the birth of 21-day excursions of Europe, which put a wine basket (used four times and then forgotten) in every other American home.

title: AUDREY MCMAHON OF W.P.A.
description: Audrey McMahon, who administered the Federally financed project that put artists to work during the Depression, died of a heart ailment at her home in Greenwich Village on Aug. 20. She was 87 years old.

title: The Region; Transit Report
description: The Long Island Rail Road reported scattered 45-minute delays on all trains to Babylon last night because of switch trouble in Freeport.

title: ANDREA LEVINE PIROUETTES HER WAY INTO TAP DANCE
description: Inside a small loft in the flower district, a dancer is rehearsing. She dips and turns, her scarlet dress flaring out and a wisp of a ponytail escaping from its rubber band. Looking like a high-spirited waif, she slashes a cane through the air, beating out an intricate counterpoint to her tapping feet. She whirls past the strangled plant groping for light through the barred window, past the mattress on the floor and the rows of tap and street shoes stretched neatly at its foot, past the yellowing newspaper photographs of Fred Astaire and soccer players frozen in precisely the same crooked-leg, flung pose. She slows, then abandons her dance for a moment, clattering purposefully over to the two musicians. A murmured conversation. ''It's hard to tell,'' the pianist says gently of a missed cue, ''because when you walk you click.''

title: POP: AUSTRALIAN LITTLE RIVER BAND
description: LITTLE RIVER BAND, the Australian pop sextet that appeared with a pickup keyboard player at the Savoy on Wednesday, are polished practicioners of a mellow brand of rock that carries the harmonized style of Crosby, Stills and Nash and the Eagles to its glossiest extremes. The group is a highly skilled music machine whose threepart vocal harmonies and triple guitar power are technically impressive, and many of their tunes have a strong melodic stamp.

title: TIME GETS HALF OF CABLE UNIT
description: Time Inc. further solidified its already sizable cable television presence by agreeing yesterday to buy at least a 50 percent interest in the USA Network, the country's third-largest advertiser-supported cable service.

title: ARREST OF INNIS BRINGS MORE CONTROVERSY TO CORE
description: The arrest last week of Roy Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, was yet another controversial development in the life of the man and his organization.

title: The Noose Loosens
description: For August, the weather is good and so is the news. To recognize how good, one need only think back two summers:

title: BEGIN ASSERTS P.L.O. VIOLATES CEASE-FIRE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin contended today that Palestinian forces had deployed 18 Soviet-made artillery pieces in Lebanon since the cease-fire took effect July 24, but he said that Israel would take no action against the batteries as long as they remained silent.

title: Alberta Fund To Try U.S.
description: The province of Alberta will begin diverting some of its $9 billion Heritage Fund, often described as the world's biggest public savings account, into United States investments for the first time, provincial officials said today.

title: SOME OF OUR 'RICH' MAKE A BARE LIVING
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Gains Seen At Card Maker
description: THE out-of-favor shares of the American Greetings Corporation could become more popular, if management's efforts to raise prices and upgrade the product line are successful.

title: INVESTEX INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in Jan 1981; revs for the previous yr includes $140,000 gain on the sale of a building

title: Executive Changes
description: * Allegheny Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company, Baltimore, has appointed James P. Sheridan vice president for manufacturing.

title: Advertising; Beef Industry Council Picks Botsford Agency
description: The Beef Industry Council, which has its headquarters - where else? -in Chicago, has named Botsford Ketchum Advertising of San Francisco as its new agency, replacing Lee King & Partners of Chicago, which had the account for more than six years. The council has budgeted $7.8 million for advertising next year - $6 million more than was budgeted for 1981.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; 2 NEW SHOWS AT COOPER-HEWITT
description: The Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the stately pile at 2 East 91st Street that once was Andrew Carnegie's mansion, has two new exhibitions: one of magazine covers, the other of glass. The 130 magazine covers are both European and American, and while some are of recent times, others reach back to the emergence of the illustrated periodical in the mid-1800's. Has commerical art gotten more interesting since then? The Cooper-Hewitt collection will persuade you it has not. The glass exhibition, meanwhile, is all recent - studio pieces that have been blown, cast, fabricated and engraved by 75 American artists. Besides the magazine covers and glass there are all the Cooper-Hewitt's standbys: drawings, prints, textiles, furniture and wallpaper, not to mention bird-cages, book papers and trade cards. The museum, which is also the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, is open today 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $1.50 for adults and $1 for students.

title: The City; RCA Building Disrupted by Fire
description: A grease fire in a kitchen exhaust duct at Hurley's restaurant disrupted office workers at the adjacent RCA Building, forcing hundreds to leave some floors of the building.

title: DR. DONALD LANCEFIELD
description: Dr. Donald E. Lancefield, professor emeritus of biology at Queens College, died Tuesday at his home in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Information on Shots Is Available by Phone
description: The New York City Health Department has set up a special number for parents and pupils who want to find out what shots are needed and where to get them.

title: AT THE CONTROLS OF PAN AM
description: ''I was thinking about finding a more challenging job,'' said C. Edward Acker, ''and I asked about being the captain of the Titanic. But they said I was years too late. So I decided to take the job of Pan Am chairman.''

title: WITH THE JOY SHE REQUESTED, ANITA LOOS IS BADE FAREWELL
description: With laughter, music and sparkling anecdotes, some 250 friends of Anita Loos paid tribute to her at a memorial service yesterday. Miss Loos, who wrote for the stage and screen but whose name is indelibly linked with her novel ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,'' died Aug. 18 at the age of 93.

title: Ian Smith Charges Mugabe Injures Zimbabwe's Economy
description: Ian D. Smith, Prime Minister before Rhodesia became Zimbabwe, said in an interview today that the nation's economy was ''deteriorating rapidly'' after 16 months of black majority rule.

title: Around the Nation; Key Witness Challenged At Kleindienst's Trial
description: Attorneys for Richard G. Kleindienst sought today to discredit a key prosecution witness whose testimony contradicted sworn statements by the former United States Attorney General.

title: POLLS FIND BLACK-WHITE GAPS ON VARIETY OF ISSUES
description: . By ADAM CLYMER

title: No Headline
description: TOURS FACTORY: Stanislaw Kania, at right, head of the Polish Communist Party, with workers at the Cegielski plant in Poznan. Yesterday, Mr. Kania warned union members not to take part in anti-Soviet activities, while union leaders threatened a second printers' strike in an effort to gain more access to news outlets.

title: C.P. SNOW REMEMBERED, FOR HIS ERROR
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''At this stage, our relations are somewhat like riding a bicycle: if we don't move forward, at a good pace, our relations may become unstable.'' - Former President Jimmy Carter, speaking in China. (A4:4.)

title: Topics; TWO STEPS FORWARD...  TELEPHONE PROGRESS; Telephone Progress
description: People in tiny Bryant Pond, Me., have telephones that will ring the house when the children get home from school and tell them where you are and when you'll be home. It sounds like one of those elaborate new electronic phone systems; in fact, that is only one of the services routinely supplied by the country's last crank telephone operation.

title: Bridge; WORLD TEAM COMPETITION HASGROWN IN COMPLEXITY
description: The organization of the World Team Championships, scheduled for Oct. 20-30 in Port Chester, N.Y., will be vastly more complex than when the same Bermuda Bowl event was last played in the New York metropolitan area, almost two decades ago.

title: RADIATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $136,000 from proceeds of a January 1981 stock offering; yr-ago shr earnings restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid may 28, 1981

title: The Region; Food Chain Fined In Coupon Fraud
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Village Supermarkets Inc. was fined $40,000 after pleading guilty to mail fraud in a $2.4 million scheme against the manufacturers of discount food coupons.

title: JAZZ: THE RICHARDSON QUARTET
description: WHEN Jerome Richardson left New York for California 10 years ago, he was one of the busiest and most versatile saxophonists and flutists in town. He has come back for a week at Sweet Basil, through tomorrow, but this visit, he says, is just a prelude to a return to the Big Apple, which has looked increasingly enticing during his decade on the West Coast.

title: Taiwan Buys U.S. Grain
description: Taiwan will sign an agreement Sept. 11 in Chicago to buy $4.5 billion worth of farm products consisting of 17.25 million tons of maize, soybean, barley and sorghum over a five-year period from July 1 this year, the Board of Foreign Trade said today. Further details were not disclosed.

title: Formation of No.1 Bank In Connecticut Is Near
description: The Hartford National Bank and the Connecticut National Bank are to merge to form the largest commercial bank in Connecticut under terms of a $57 million agreement announced jointly by the banks last night. The venture is subject to approval by shareholders of both companies and by the Controller of the Currency.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Richard Eder THE BEECHERS. An American Family in the 19th Century. By Milton Rugoff. 653 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Tampa Team in Final Of Little League Series
description: Derek Bell drove in three runs and Derrick Pedro threw out the potential tying run at the plate to end the game as Tampa, Fla., beat Barrington, Ill., 11-10, today to earn a spot in the Little League World Series final.

title: Economic Scene; Inconsistency In Fiscal Aims
description: WHEN Alexander Hamilton persuaded Congress to honor the Revolutionary War debt in 1790, even though the tax increase needed to carry this policy out was patently not in the immediate interests of the citizens of the United States at the time, the central element in his argument was the recognition that a policy decision taken today is, like it or not, an announcement of general principle by which analogous situations are to be treated in the future.

title: ON COLUMBUS, THE FIRST AVENUE OF THE WEST SIDE
description: Ann Belsky was sitting at one of the little white ice cream parlor tables at Ruelles the other night when one of her Columbus Avenue neighbors ambled by, stopped, stared and said with a certain amount of wonder: ''What are you doing there? You're a West Sider!''

title: GAYLORDS, NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
AUTOPSY BEGINS IN CASE WITH LINK TO THE C.I.A.
description: The body of a Queens man whose death has been linked to the resignation of an official of the Central Intelligence Agency was exhumed yesterday from a cemetery in southwestern Maine, after two days of unsuccessful legal maneuvering by the man's relatives.

title: ALEXANDRIA DEAL A SURPRISE TO U.S.
description: Administration officials said today that they had been caught by surprise by the announcement that President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel had set a time and place for renewed talks on Palestinian autonomy.

title: MYOPIA IN STUDY OF CRIME
description: Let's not be mistaken about the purpose of the Attorney General's recent Task Force on Violent Crime. This was not a panel that hoped to address the problems of reform of the criminal justice system nor did it address the issues of crime prevention. The purpose of the task force was to shift constitutional law in the direction of growing conservative sentiments in the country, or, in the words of its report, ''to insure punishment of violent offenders.'' Whether or not its recommendations will have any impact whatsoever on the level of violent crime is debatable.

title: THE 'CRIME' OF ARSENY BORISOVICH ROGINSKY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSOLIDATED FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: Yr-ago fourth qr net income has been restated for the adoption of LIFO accounting for 22 percent of the company's inventories

title: Energywatch
AMATEUR, 16, HALTS CLERC'S STREAK, 7-6, 6-2
description: The 25-match winning streak of Jose Luis Clerc, during which he won four tournaments, came to an unexpected end tonight.

title: Mets Rally in 8th, Top Astros
description: For more than seven innings yesterday, the Mets were again falling victim to an overdose of Niekro knuckleballs. A week ago in Atlanta, it was the Braves' Phil Niekro and his knuckler that helped turn back the Mets, 6-4. This time Phil's brother Joe was holding a one-run lead for the Houston Astros going into the eighth inning at Shea Stadium. But in the eighth, Joe tired, and the Mets rallied for two runs against him and another Joe, Sambito, his reliever, to defeat the Astros, 3-2.

title: Topics; TWO STEPS FORWARD...  GRACIOUS LIVING; Gracious Living
description: On 42d Street, tourists and passersby are eschewing three-card monte for chess with players of such local fame and Runyonesque flash as Broadway Bobby and Freddy the Fish.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, AUGUST 28, 1981; Markets
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.18 points, to 889.08, its lowest close in more than a year, as investor concern about high interest rates and inflation continued to weaken the market. Declines exceeded advances by more than 2-to-1. (Page D1.)

title: JACKSON IS GIVEN PHYSICAL
description: Reggie Jackson underwent a day-long series of tests at New York University Medical Center yesterday, then had a long telephone conversation with George Steinbrenner in which Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, said he made it clear how important Jackson is to the team's hopes for success in postseason play.

title: Salvador Frees Suspect In Killing of Americans
description: A wealthy Salvadoran landowner accused in the killing last January of two American advisers to the Government's land-redistribution program has been ordered freed by a judge, court officials said today.

title: PLANS CONSIDERED FOR INOCULATIONS AT CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: New York City health and education officials, concerned that many thousands of students could be barred from school next month because they lack five required inoculations, are working to devise a plan to resolve the problem before schools open Sept. 10.

title: Wetterau Opposes Empire Share Bid
description: Wetterau Inc., a St. Louis-based food distributor, said its directors had unanimously recommended rejection of a $21-a-share tender offer by Empire Inc., the holding company for the Empire Gas Corporation, for 1.2 million shares, or about 21 percent, of Wetterau stock.

title: Capitals Sign Carpenter, Schoolboy Star
description: Bobby Carpenter, considered the best hockey player ever produced in the United States, announced today that he had signed with the Washington Capitals.

title: Investment Discrepancy
description: American companies trying to escape high domestic interest rates may be secretly increasing their borrowings from foreign countries, a Government report that was released today indicates.

title: Irish Night in Queens
description: An afternoon of Irish music and dance will close the fifth annual Summer Diversions '81 tomorrow at 7 P.M. at the Forest Park bandshell, Woodhaven Boulevard, Queens.

title: IMMIGRATION SERVICE REFUSES TO FREE 83 HAITIANS IN A FORMER NAVY PRISON IN BROOKLYN
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has refused to release 83 Haitians from a former Navy prison in Brooklyn where they have been held for more than a month pending hearings on their requests for political asylum.

title: The Region; Valhalla Officers Tell of Jail Riot
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - Several Westchester County corrections officers testified at a county legislative hearing that four correction officers were taken hostage by inmates during a riot at the county jail last month but were freed by an anti-riot squad.

title: Notes on People; Two Actresses Discuss Life With Fathers
description: During most of a four-hour Los Angeles radio talk show on which Jane Fonda and her husband, Tom Hayden, political activists of a liberal bent, were hosts, the conversation was mostly critical of President Reagan.

title: Article 250036 -- No Title
description: The nation's savings and loan associations had a record $3.5 billion net outflow of savings in July, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: U.S. DROPPING EFFORT TO INTEGRATE HOUSTON SCHOOLS
description: The Justice Department today decided not to appeal a court order dismissing its effort to force crossdistrict school desegregation between Houston and 22 of its suburbs.

title: SIMPLICITY PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes $3.1 million pre-tax provision for reorganization of product production process and $513,000 investment gain... C-Net income...D-Includes $3.1 million pre-tax provision for reorganization of product production process, and $845,000 investment gain

title: MEN'S OPEN PAIRING REVISED
description: For the purists, there will be Stan Smith-John Sadri and Elliot Teltscher-Victor Amaya. For the romantics, Jimmy Connors and John Lloyd will play. Teen-agers will have Kathy Rinaldi-Kathy Horvath, and Ilie Nastase will return against Mel Purcell in the first round of the United States Open tennis championships.

title: Around the Nation; Sirhan Says He Merits Parole in Kennedy Case
description: Sirhan B. Sirhan, jailed in California for assassinating Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968, said in an interview recorded for broadcast tonight that he was a ''changed man'' and deserved parole.

title: Advertising; Sasson's Economical Campaign
description: ''C ATCH them before they take off!'' is the tag line of the $6 million Sasson Corporation's television advertising campaign that will have its debut in September and November - and Sasson's in-house agency, GSN Advertising, is setting a brisk pace by having 55 spot television commercials shot on one sound stage in a mere two weeks, from Aug. 21 to Sept. 3.

title: Bronx Concerts
description: Stanley Simon, the Bronx Borough President, will make a brief conducting appearance with the Bronx Arts Ensemble on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the mansion in Van Cortlandt Park in the first of two performances marking the ensemble's last weekend of free concerts.

title: Around the World; Belgian Cabinet Backs End of Death Penalty
description: The Belgian Cabinet has approved a bill abolishing the death penalty, the Justice Ministry announced today. The French Cabinet approved a similar measure yesterday, fulfilling one of the promises Francois Mitterrand made in the French presidential campaign.

title: Around the World; 8 Reported Wounded In a Clash Near Beirut
description: Rival political militias using mortars and automatic weapons battled for six hours in a suburb south of Beirut today, and the police said eight people were wounded in the clash.

title: Briefs
description: * AMF Inc. said it had signed a $23 million, three-year contract to build a tobacco processing plant in Iraq.

title: DUTCHESS COUNTY FAIR, 140 ACRES OF FUN FOR $2
description: The Dutchess County Fair, less than a two-hour drive north from Manhattan, is a $2 bargain, offering continuous entertainment and instruction at one of the oldest and largest livestock and agricultural exhibitions in the state.

title: China Signs Deere Aid Pact
description: China has signed a contract to buy technical aid from Deere & Company, of Moline, Ill., on how to build combine harvesters, the company said. Value of the accord was not disclosed, but Deere said it would provide China with data on quality control, product experimentation, maintenance and management, and would train Chinese technicians, administrative personnel and workers and send experts to China to give technical direction.

title: BAKER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW TAX LAW IS SAID TO ENDANGER BILLIONS IN GIFTS TO PRIVATE GROUPS
description: Contributions from individuals to universities, museums, hospitals and antipoverty and religious groups may decline by billions of dollars in the next four years, according to an analysis of the new tax act.

title: DATE WITH JUDY COLLINS AT THE SAVOY
description: WHILE pop music today has many fine interpretive singers, perhaps none is as discriminating in the choice of material as Judy Collins, who will appear at the Savoy, 141 West 44th Street, tomorrow night at 9 with a four-piece band (tickets are $10.50 and $12.50; information: 921-9490). In the last 20 years, Miss Collins has helped establish a canon of modern pop standards that spans 50 years, embraces several languages and treats such disparate songwriters as Bob Dylan, Stephen Sondheim, Jacques Brel, Ned Rorem and Leonard Cohen as artistic equals. Even so, Miss Collins, a 42-year-old veteran of 18 albums (including three anthologies), is still often routinely labeled a folk singer.

title: WEAPONS LIMITATION
description: To the Editor:

title: DETROIT SUBURB HOUSING RIGHTS CASE GOES TO COURT
description: A longstanding dispute between the United States Department of Justice and Detroit's wealthy suburb of Birmingham went to Federal court here this week, with the suburb charged with illegally refusing to build subsidized low-income housing.

title: FREDERICK & HERRUD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: OAKLAND (A.L.) - Recalled Kevin M oore, first baseman, and Mike Davis and M ickey Klutts, outfielders, from Tacoma o f the Pacific Coast League. Released Tim H osley, catcher.

title: RATE FEARS SEND DOW DOWN 10.18
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday as investor apprehension over high interest rates and inflation continued to weaken the market. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 10.18 points, to 889.08, its lowest close in more than a year, since it finished at 885.92 on July 10, 1980. So far this week, the blue-chip barometer has tumbled 31 points.

title: Edward Corn to Head Wolf Trap Foundation
description: Edward Corn, director of the opera and musical theater program of the National Endowment for the Arts, will become executive vice president and general director of the Wolf Trap Foundation on Tuesday. His job will be to oversee programming, with emphasis on the local production company, at Wolf Trap Farm Park, the national park for the performing arts in the Virginia countryside near Washington.

title: INDIA IS WORKING ON SPORTS IMAGE
description: On the one hand, more than 125,000 men and women are energetically building $80 million worth of sports facilities for the two-week Asian Games to be held here 15 months from now. On the other, India, a nation of 684 million, has a dismal sports record, and its junior soccer team just lost in an international tournament to Brunei, a country of 212,000.

title: U.S. Favored in Golf
description: A young American team, with seven of its 10 players in their early 20's, is favored over Britain in the 28th Walker Cup golf matches, which will be played tomorrow and Saturday at Cypress Point here.

title: TV Weekend; HEMINGWAY AND THE FIRST 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE'
description: ''THE BEST OF FRIENDS,'' which will be shown Sunday night at 8 on Channel 5, is billed as a screen adaptation of an Ernest Hemingway short story titled ''The Three Day Blow.'' In fact, it bears no resemblance to the story, which is just as well. ''The Best of Friends'' is Hemingway lobotomized for dopes, something straight out of the ''Bad Playhouse'' parodies on ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: STAGE: CAST OF 70 AT LA MAMA
description: WHILE Wallace Shawn's unabashedly nasty farce, ''The Hotel Play,'' may not be everybody's idea of a play, it is unassailable as a mad theatrical stunt. This 75-minute outing, which ends its brief, limited run at the La Mama annex Sunday night, has the largest cast to be seen on a New York stage in memory: There are 70-odd players, of whom over 50 have speaking roles. Even if you loathe ''The Hotel Play'' - and be warned, you might - you're unlikely to get totally bored. At the very least, you can kill the time reading the cast biographies in the voluminous program.

title: CORE Theft Suspect Arrested Once Again
description: Amstead Rice, who the police said had been severely beaten last week in Harlem when he was discovered trying to steal a radio from a car owned by the Congress of Racial Equality, was arrested Wednesday night near Yankee Stadium for possession of burglar's tools.

title: REAGAN SAYS BOTH LIBYAN JET PILOTS SURVIVED
description: President Reagan said tonight that the pilots of the two Libyan jets shot down last week by Navy fighters apparently parachuted to safety.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Including $108,000 extraordinary credit

title: The City; Mother Finds 2 Sons Slain
description: Two brothers were found stabbed to death in their Bronx home late last night by their mother, the police said. The brothers, 18-year-old William Jackson, and Noel, 10, were found dead by their mother, Dolores, 39, when she returned to the home at 1358 Washington Avenue after a funeral, a police spokesman said.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $47,000 for the qr and $187,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $59,000 income from discontinued operations

title: Aramco Oil for Italy
description: Agip, the Italian state oil company, has signed a six-month contract with Aramco to buy 200,000 barrels a day of Saudi light crude, a spokesman for Italian state energy corporation said today.

title: Man Here Enjoys Parties
description: IT isn't every day that you interview some guy in sports and he tells about the time he pulled a gun on his trainer with intent to do bodily harm. In dry spells, it doesn't happen every week, though it might if there were more Shelly Silvermans around.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid July 1

title: JAMESBURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $3.7 million extraordinary credit from the settlement of a patent infringement suit against the federal government

title: 83 Hurt in Austrian Crash
description: At least 83 people were injured today, three seriously, in Austria's second train crash in 10 days, railroad officials said. The accident involving a passenger train carrying about 400 people bound for West Germany and a freight train occurred this morning in Wels. Ten days ago three people were killed and more than 100 injured when a commuter train crashed into buffers at Vienna's Southeast railway station.

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Includes tax credits of $38,300,000 for qr and $36,500,000 for 9 mos...C-Net income

title: Langer Posts a 68 to Share 3-Way Lead
description: Bernhard Langer of West Germany had two birdie putts of less than two inches today on his way to a tie with Bill Rogers and Hale Irwin for the lead in the opening round of the World Series of Golf.

title: FUGITIVE AGENT SAYS FORMER GREEN BERETS STILL WORK IN LIBYA
description: A former Central Intelligence Agency agent wanted in the United States on charges of supplying explosives to Libya said yesterday that four former Green Berets were still working for the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, but he denied that they were helping train terrorists.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $57,519 gain from accounting adjustment

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
A BRITISH LAW BARS PRESS FROM VIOLATING JURY ROOM SECRETS
description: Britain instituted a law today that makes it illegal for reporters and researchers to question jurors about their deliberations or for jurors to discuss their deliberations.

title: Seagram Gets Conoco Shares
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., an unsuccessful bidder for Conoco Inc. in last month's dramatic battle to take over the oil company, said it had received nearly 28 million Conoco shares by its deadline Wednesday for accepting shares offered under its $92-a-share bid.

title: THE LEGITIMATE USES OF U.S.-SUPPLIED ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title: HARRY BELAFONTE SINGS AGAIN
description: Harry Belafonte is in the midst of a tour that started last April in Australia and is continuing through the United States and into Europe until December. Tonight and tomorrow evening he is singing at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., sharing the bill with his protegee, Letta Mbulu. He has undertaken this strenuous sevenand-a-half-month tour, Mr. Belafonte says, ''to clean it up and tie it off.''

title: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-Includes $6,283,000 or 80 cents a shr after-tax loss from default of large regional customer, an increased charge of $1.3 million on bad debt and $2,364,000 charge for extension of LIFO

title: VALENZUELA TOPS CUBS FOR 11TH
description: Fernando Valenzuela pitched a fourhitter to lead the Los Angeles to a 6-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight, the Dodgers' fourth straight victory.

title: SCHWARTZ PLANS TO RESIGN POST AS CITY COUNSEL
description: Allen G. Schwartz, New York City's Corporation Counsel and one of Mayor Koch's closest advisers, said yesterday that he would leave his post at the end of the year.

title: ART: THINGS THAT CAN HAPPEN TO A PRINT
description: IF the A.A.A. Galleries, 663 Fifth Avenue, at 53d Street, have been in and out of this column all month, it is not because I view them with special favor. It is because they take the trouble to put on interesting and thoughtful exhibitions at a moment in the year when almost everyone else is away at the beach.

title: Notes on People; Trying to Limit Clashes to the Gridiron
description: One of two feuding stars of ''NFL Today,'' Phyllis George Brown, agreed to return this fall to the CBS Sports show for professional football fans on one condition - that she would not have to appear on the set live with Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder.

title: DOMINION MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Including $1,051,954 tax credit...C-Including $1,157,000 tax credit and $3,058,000 gain from the extinguishment of debt

title: CONGRESS ON RECESS KEEP POLITICS IN SESSION
description: What do politicians do on their summer vacation? If the Congressmen from the New York metropolitian area are representative, they are mostly spending time politicking: Meeting, greeting and doing a lot of talking.

title: CASEY AMENDS LIST OF LAW CLIENTS SUBMITTED TO PANEL ON INTELLIGENCE
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, has provided information to a Senate committee showing that he did not disclose more than 70 law clients in a financial statement filed at Senate confirmation proceedings earlier this year.

title: CITY JAZZ IN COW COUNTRY
description: An attempt to recreate the jazz of New York City's 52d Street, once known as the jazz capital of the world, will be made tomorrow night in the bucolic setting of the village of Margaretville in New York's rural Delaware County, where there are more cows (62,000) than people (45,000).

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The City; Suspect Is Seized Posing as Doctor
description: A 38-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday on charges that he had posed as a pediatrician in a Jamaica health center since mid-July.

title: PAY 'N SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Funds' Assets Rose in Week
description: The assets of the nation's money funds rose $2.95 billion, to $148.7 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the 13th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: ART IS FLOURISHING IN COUNTRYSIDE MUSEUMS
description: A SWING through the museums and galleries just outside New York City can hold a number of happy surprises for even the most sophisticated habitue of the salons of SoHo and upper Madison Avenue, and a day or a weekend in the country may be just the tonic for the late-summer doldrums.

title: GAINS FOR AMERICANS WHO WORK ABROAD
description: If there was ever a time to live and work abroad, it is now - at least the tax experts say so. The new tax law will usher into effect on Jan. 1 some of the most favorable provisions for taxing expatriates in 20 years.

title: DIPLOMACY SWIRLS AROUND PAKISTAN
description: As Nikolai P. Firyubin, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, ended a two-day visit here today and flew off to New Delhi, two American missions were arriving for talks on economic aid and on the fighting in Afghanistan.

title: ANDREA DORIA YIELDS A SAFE TO DIVERS
description: They have lost more than four days of precious diving time because of punishing high seas, with waves reaching 15 feet. They have had to dig through tons of debris, far more than they thought they would encounter. And now, as they are running out of time, the treasure hunters' major objective still remains inaccessible.

title: Cities Service Pays Record Loan Rate
description: The Cities Service Company is raising $150 million through a seven-year Eurobond with a record coupon of 17 percent, Credit Suisse-First Boston Ltd., the lead manager, said.

title: TRADE GAP NARROWED LAST MONTH
description: The nation's trade deficit for July fell to $1.46 billion, the Commerce Department reported today, as oil imports ran at an average of 5.1 million barrels a day, the lowest level since the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo.

title: CUSTOM ALLOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
5 Banks Lower Broker Loan Rates
description: Five of the nation's largest commercial banks lowered their broker loan rates yesterday, but there was little indication that the move signified anything more than marginal fluctuations in other interest rates.

title: IF UNESCO INSISTS ON A WORLDWIDE SYSTEM OF PRESS CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: LOS ANGELES COUNTY PRESSES BATTLE AGAINST THE FRUIT FLY
description: The authorities battling the Mediterranean fruit fly in Los Angeles County said yesterday that they had thrown all their chips into a fast aerial attack and quarantine that they hoped would stop the fly from gaining a stronger foothold in southern California.

title: KATHRYN C. HULME, AUTHOR WHO WROTE 'NUN'S STORY,' DEAD
description: Kathryn C. Hulme, the author of ''The Nun's Story,'' a 1956 best seller that was made into an award-winning movie starring Audrey Hepburn, died on Tuesday at Wilcox Hospital in Lihue, Hawaii. She was 81 years old and lived on the Hawaiian island of Kauai.

title: GIANTS SET BIGGER ROLE IN BACKFIELD FOR JACKSON
description: If the Giants are to improve significantly on last year's 4-12 record, their running game must become respectable enough to keep defenses from ignoring it and concentrating on stopping the pass.

title: Falsely Accused Priest Sues Over 'Gentleman Bandit' Case
description: The Rev. Bernard T. Pagano, who was accused of a series of robberies in 1979 until the real ''gentleman bandit'' confessed, has filed a $5 million suit against the State of Delaware, four police officers and a magistrate.

title: Kuwait Oil Output
description: Kuwait's daily oil production has fallen to about 600,000 barrels, but should recover in coming weeks to nearly a million, industry analysts said here today. Kuwaiti officials said last month that the country was producing about 900,000 barrels daily and denied press reports that output had dropped to 500,000 barrels. But the analysts said that, since then, a fire at the Shu'aiba refinery and resistance by Japanese buyers to Kuwait's prices had depressed daily output to about half of the ceiling set last April of 1.25 million barrels.

title: Canadian Oil Talks
description: In what may be the first sign of a breakthrough in the year-old oil pricing dispute between Ottawa and Alberta, the two sides announced today that they will continue negotiating tomorrow for a third day.

title: CARTER SAYS REAGAN'S CHINA POLICY IS 'COMPATIBLE' WITH '78 ACCORDS
description: Former President Jimmy Carter today described Reagan Administration policies toward China, including the ''prudent'' sale of defensive weapons to Taiwan and the offer of such arms to the mainland, as ''compatible'' with the agreements he negotiated three years ago with Peking's Deputy Party Chairman, Deng Xiaoping.

title: BONN AIDES DEBATE PACIFISTS OVER U.S. MILITARY INFLUENCE
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's governing Social Democratic Party opened a nationwide debate with representatives of West Germany's peace movement today in an attempt to move the subject of nuclear defense away from neutralism and anti-American emotions.

title: CORNELIUS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including $70,000 extraordinary gain...C-Including $196,000 extraordinary tax credit and $569,000 extraordinary gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting

title: MCNEIL NEARING A STARTING JOB
description: Ever since training camp opened last month, Scott Dierking, in the face of competition from a first-round draft choice, had held on to his job as the Jets' starting halfback.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Including $202,000 or 35 cents a shr gain from discontinued operations...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $274,000 for the qr and $127,000 for the 9 mos

title: Fire I. Opera Night
description: Selections from operas and operettas will be sung by the Chamber Opera Theater of New York tomorrow at 11 P.M. at the Pines Community House on Fire Island.

title: BARBARO QUESTIONS DONATIONS TO KOCH
description: Frank J. Barbaro said yesterday that Mayor Koch had accepted campaign contributions from real-estate people who had received city tax abatements and added that the action ''stinks.''

title: Credit Markets; Treasury Note at Peak Yield; Rate Is Put At 16.14%
description: The Treasury's needs for new money to finance the Federal deficit helped to produce a record yield of 16.14 percent for the Government's five-year two-month note auctioned yesterday. Trading on a ''when-issued'' basis, the note had finished Wednesday at a return of 16 percent.

title: TRAVELER'S CHECK PACT
description: LONDON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) Mastercard International Inc. of New York has agreed with Midland Bank Ltd. on an association with the Thomas Cook worldwide traveler's checks business, a Midland Bank spokesman said today. The agreement with Mastercard includes cooperation with Thomas Cook Ltd., a Midland Bank subsidiary, on check design to enhance check acceptance, identification, servicing and refunds.

title: About Real Estate; NEW 'VILLAGE' CONVERSION OFFERING UNUSUAL DESIGNS
description: The triangular shape of a 12-story brick and limestone Greenwich Village loft building recently converted into condominiums has resulted in plans of unusual angular design for its 44 apartments.

title: Soviet Rescues U.S. Boat
description: The Soviet trawler Betelgeuse has rescued the crew of a disabled American fishing boat, the Lat Windjammer, that drifted in the Atlantic Ocean for five days without food and water, the Soviet press agency Tass said today. The trawler radioed the news to the Baltic port of Kaliningrad, Tass said.

title: L.I. Pops Concert
description: The last concert in a free Summer Performing Arts Festival at Eisenhower Park, Hempstead Turnpike, East Meadow, L.I. will feature the American Concert Band in a program of popular works by Leroy Anderson on Sunday at 8 P.M. Conducted by Kirby Jolly, its founder, the band features Theodore Mordoff, flutist; Joseph Title, clarinetist; Douglas Mendocha, trumpet player; Sheldon Henry, French horn player, and David Apt and Jeremy Kempton, trombonists. If it rains, the concert will be in the Calderone Concert Hall, 169 North Franklin Street, in Hempstead, L.I. Information: (516) 292-4175.

title: Goodspeed Opera to Honor Gershwins; The Goodspeed Opera To Honor Gershwins
description: Ira and George Gershwin will be honored with the first annual Award for Excellence in Musical Theater, to be given by the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn.

title: F.D.A. Refuses to Block Lethal-Drug Execution
description: The Food and Drug Administration has rejected a request by five condemned prisoners to use Federal drug regulations to block their executions by injection of lethal drugs.

title: CULPRIT SOUGHT FOR FERTILE FRUIT FLIES
description: California officials sought today to determine who was legally liable for the shipment of the purportedly sterile Mediterranean fruit flies from Peru that are believed to have spawned the current reinfestation of the fly.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: Corey Pavin, a 21-year-old Californian competing in the Walker Cup for the first time, played two rounds of sub-par golf today and paced the United States team to an 8-4 lead over Britain.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The index is telling us the economy is stalled, but I don't think it's pointing to collapse.'' - Robert Ortner, senior vice president of the Bank of New York. (1:1.)

title: CITY OPERETTA: 'STUDENT PRINCE' OPENS THE SEASON
description: By every known manner of measurement, the operetta is as dead as the era that gave it birth. Cloying tonality, lachrymose tunes and cardboard nostalgia lasted a few decades longer in operetta than they did in opera, and another few years more again in America than in Europe. But eventually they gave way to the more astringent musical and theatrical idioms that speak of our time, if not to the paying public.

title: Army Completes Airlift Of 888 Nerve Gas Bombs
description: The Army today safely completed the airlift of 888 Weteye nerve gas bombs from Colorado's Rocky Mountain Arsenal to this munitions storage area in western Utah.

title: Developer of Bingo Gambles on a New Play
description: During a spur-of-the moment visit to a roadside carnival in 1929, Edwin S. Lowe, then a struggling young toy manufacturer, was intrigued with a game called Beano, a variation on an ancient gambling pastime.

title: ZINC PENNY RULING IS EXPECTED SOON
description: First the silver that lined American pockets lost out to alloy coins. Now, even the lowly copper penny may lose its integrity. The Treasury plans to introduce copper-plated zinc pennies later this year - enriching some coffers and depleting others - if it gets a favorable ruling in a court case to be decided soon.

title: NASA Shifts Launching Date Of Space Shuttle to October
description: The launching date for the second mission of the space shuttle Columbia has been pushed back to Oct. 9 from Sept. 30, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Australian Group In First Artists Bid
description: A group of Australian companies indicated in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing their intent to seek a controlling interest in the First Artists Production Company Ltd., a company founded in 1969 by Barbra Streisand, Paul Newman, Sidney Poitier and the late Steve McQueen to make and distribute their motion pictures.

title: Dow Chemical Expands in Spain
description: The Dow Chemical Company's Spanish subsidiary, Dow Chemical Iberica S.A., has purchased a 350,000-tonsa-year ethylene cracker from state-owned Empresa Nacional del Petroleo S.A., or Enpetrol, a Dow spokesman said.

title: 2 RUSSIANS SPEED PAST GUARDS INTO U.S. EMBASSY
description: A middle-aged Russian engineer and his mother touched off a minor diplomatic incident today by driving a car past Soviet policemen guarding the entrance to the United States Embassy. The two then obtained a hearing for what they described as personal grievances against the Soviet authorities.

title: RULING AIDS DOME IN ITS ACQUISITION
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. has cleared the first obstacle to its effort to acquire the remaining shares of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company over the objections of a key minority stockholder.

title: REAGAN MUST DECLARE WAR ON ACID RAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICE CUTS THAT DON'T THREATEN INFLATION
description: With productivity declining and companies failing to give consumers what they want, the public begins to idolize Japanese business and forgets just how ingenious the American private sector can be - when it wants to.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: MAN TEAM: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California playing basketball in Sacramento to cool off after jogging. He has been jogging since last May and ran six miles yesterday, giving him a total of 50 miles for the week.

title: Gaines, Testing Leg, Will Face the Eagles
description: Clark Gaines, once the Jets' starting fullback, makes his first game appearance tomorrow night since breaking his left leg in five places last October.

title: Templeton of Cardinals To Get Psychiatric Help
description: The team doctor for the St. Louis Cardinals said today that Garry Templeton, who was suspended by Manager Whitey Herzog two days ago for making obscene gestures at fans in Busch Stadium, had agreed to seek psychiatric help.

title: SOCIAL CONTRACTS FOR $25
description: ''The last time I looked, the arrow was green.'' ''I couldn't see the light, the bus got in my way.'' ''I'm not familiar with this area.'' ''I didn't see you.'' ''There's a red light there?'' Anyone who entertains lingering doubts about the traffic anarchy in this city would have been entertained -and disabused of doubt - by the snappy dialogue offered to two highway policemen by red-light runners one day this week at a major intersection in Brooklyn. The two policemen, Thomas Crowley and Angelo Martinez, are part of a 12-week test at high-risk locations to see if something can be done about the drivers who are ignoring traffic signals and killing pedestrians and other motorists in record numbers.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL DEADLOCKED ON SOUTH AFRICA'S ANGOLA RAID
description: The Security Council was deadlocked today over how to react to South Africa's incursion into Angola. The 15 members were prepared to agree, Western diplomats said, on a demand for an immediate withdrawal of South Africa's forces, which Pretoria has announced is already taking place.

title: HINCKLEY, JUDGED AS MENTALLY FIT, DENIES ATTEMPTING TO KILL REAGAN
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. pleaded not guilty today to charges of attempting to kill President Reagan and assaulting three other men last March.

title: SEAVER, REDS DEFEAT METS, 5-2
description: The Mets' second-half momentum was put to a severe test last night, and did not pass: They suffered a 5-2 loss to Tom Seaver and the Cincinnati Reds, and even Neil Allen finally ran out of tricks.

title: Still Out of Work
description: As summer vacation draws to a close, the problem of teen-age joblessness vanishes from public and political discourse as surely as the evening light. But the tragedy, especially among minority groups in inner-city neighborhoods, does not. Not even a period of austerity has to mean ignoring this problem, the core of multiple social ills. Like the chess hustlers do in Times Square, governments should try more imaginative solutions - especially when the stakes are so high.

title: United to Lay Off 2,100
description: United Airlines said today that it would lay off 800 flight attendants and 1,300 ground employees after Labor Day, Sept. 7, because of flight cutbacks in the controllers' strike. The airline currently employs 48,300 people.

title: Dow Adds 3.14; Loss Is 28 in Week; Rise Is Tied to Bargain Prices
description: The stock market overcame its interest rate jitters temporarily yesterday and scored a moderate gain after weeks of heavy selling. There was little in the way of economic developments to account for the small rebound, but analysts said that, with some stock prices at bargain levels, the market was due for an upswing.

title: The Talk of Coney Island
description: ''Don't be shy - getchyer red-hots!'' growled a short, stout grayhaired man behind the Nathan's counter on Surf Avenue in Coney Island. ''Step up!'' he barked. ''Getchyer franks, have your money ready, hot doggies here, all you can eat!

title: NEVADA GOVERNOR WOULD ACCEPT MX
description: Gov. Robert F. List of Nevada told President Reagan's top aide today that his state could accept deployment of the MX missile if it was kept on military land.

title: BUD DELP FOSTERS ANOTHER BID
description: The horse's silks are black and blue, his coat is gray, his owner is Hawksworth Farm, his trainer is Bud Delp, his jockey is Bill Shoemaker, and his last name is Bid, but his first name is not Spectacular.

title: Grain Sale to Soviet
description: The Agriculture Department said today that private exporters had sold an additional 300,000 tons of American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Patents; Checking For Breast Cancer
description: WASHINGTON A DIAGNOSTIC instrument using ordinary light for breast examination to detect cancer or other abnormalities will be patented next week by a French engineer and manufacturer of medical equipment. The instrument, called Diagnoscope, is to be marketed in this country.

title: RADAR DETECTOR ABOARD SR-71 ALERTED PILOT TO MISSILE ATTACK
description: The American SR-71 reconnaissance plane that was fired at on Wednesday from a North Korean ground-launched missile site first detected the attack through a radar warning device, an Administration official said today.

title: SALVADOR REBELS GAIN NEW SUPPORT
description: Mexico and France recognized El Salvador's guerrilla-led opposition today as a ''representative political force.''

title: TRUDEAU DEFENDS MOUNTIES' SECURITY SERVICE
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau defended the security service of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police today against some of the charges of illegal activities brought by a Government commission.

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Asserts Pakistan Will Get Arms
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, arrived in Islamabad for talks today and immediately responded to a suggestion by Pakistan's leader that the United States might delay a promised shipment of nine F-16 fighter jets.

title: Lieutenant Taken to Maryland For Espionage Court-Martial
description: Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke of the Air Force arrived at Andrews Air Force Base today where he will be court-martialed next week on charges that he passed military secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: RECAPTURED CONVICT RELEASED
description: An escaped convict who spent his 27 years of freedom as a model citizen before his recapture Monday was back home today with his wife and two boys.

title: Your Money; Social Concern And Investing
description: THE general perception is that the average investor in stocks and bonds thinks along the lines of the old saying, ''Money isn't everything, but it's way ahead of whatever is in second place.''

title: Boy, 3, Pulls Trigger; Mother Shot in Chest
description: A 3-year-old boy, playing with a .357 magnum pistol, asked his mother, ''Do I pull this?'' The boy pulled the trigger and the bullet hit the mother, Judy McCall, in the chest.

title: RECIPE FOR A BEST-SELLER
description: BREAD UPON THE WATERS. By Irwin Shaw. 438 pages. Delacorte. $14.95.

title: No Headline
description: An article by The Associated Press printed yesterday gave an incorrect list of cities where Braniff International is suspending service. The airline will drop service to Albany but continue to New York City.

title: Luther D. Lewis, 74, Founder Of Chain of Food Stores, Dies
description: Luther D. (Sunshine) Lewis, who parlayed a hot dog stand into a multimillion-dollar chain of food stores in the South, collapsed at his desk and died Tuesday.

title: The Region; Couple Sentenced In Child's Death
description: WHITE PLAINS (UPI) - A Peekskill, N.Y., woman and a male friend were sentenced to terms of up to 25 years for beating the woman's 4-year-old daughter to death Oct. 31.

title: The City; Royal Ballet Case May Be Dismissed
description: The cases of four persons charged with disrupting a performance of the Royal Ballet during Prince Charles's visit to the Metropolitan Opera House on June 17 were adjourned ''in contemplation of dismissal'' in Criminal Court in Manhattan.

title: India Acts on Burmah
description: The Indian Government introduced a bill in Parliament today to take over the Burmah Oil Company's holdings in India, a move that would leave India without foreign oil companies.

title: 2 FATAL DISEASES FOCUS OF INQUIRY
description: Two rare diseases have struck more than 100 homosexual men in the United States in recent months, killing almost half of them, and a medical study group has been formed to find out why, the national Centers for Disease Control said today.

title: Yugoslavia Says Purge Has Started in Albania
description: The official Yugoslavian press agency reported today that a major purge was under way in neighboring Albania for the first time in more than six years.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 21.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS A WITHDRAWAL FROM ANGOLAN AREAS HAS BEGUN
description: South African forces have started to withdraw from the areas of southern Angola that they attacked this week in their largest cross-border operation of the year, the head of the Defense Forces announced today.

title: BOESKY HAS 9.3% OF GARFINCKEL STOCK
description: Ivan F. Boesky, a leading Wall Street arbitrager, disclosed yesterday that he had purchased almost 10 percent of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., the big retailing company.

title: CANADA REBUFFED ON SAFETY TOUR
description: Legal actions against striking air traffic controllers mounted yesterday and the Government said it still intended to prosecute some strikers but had yet to decide whether to seek jail terms.

title: JOAN EDWARDS, RADIO SINGER AND STAR OF 'YOUR HIT PARADE'
description: Joan Edwards, a popular singer and star of the 1940's radio show ''Your Hit Parade,'' died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at her Manhattan apartment. She was 61 years old.

title: Santa Fe Music Festival Opening in New York
description: The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival will open tonight at Alice Tully Hall in the first of six consecutive evenings' performances.

title: HAIG SAYS REBELS ENGAGE IN TERROR AGAINST SALVADOR
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. accused the rebels in El Salvador today of engaging in ''straight terrorism'' and again accused Cuba and the Soviet Union of playing major roles in fomenting the country's civil war.

title: No Headline
description: Cuba said today that its troops in Angola would go into action if South African forces approached Cuban positions there.

title: SALVAGE SHIP PROTECTING AN ANDREA DOREA SAFE
description: A slightly rusty but sturdy-looking safe from the luxury liner Andrea Doria is aboard the salvage ship Sea Level 11 off Nantucket, where efforts are underway to keep it covered with water so that any paper currency inside is not destroyed by exposure to air.

title: The Region; Danbury Gets A Water Plan
description: Mayor James Dyer announced a threepoint plan intended to improve the city's waning water supplies and said that the last 30 days had been the driest in the city's history.

title: Eva Le Gallienne to Do Tony Role in Westport
description: Eva Le Gallienne, who was nominated for a Tony for her performance last season in the Broadway production of ''To Grandmother's House We Go,'' will repeat her characterization at the Westport (Conn.)

title: Heating Up the Atmosphere
description: For years there have been doomsday predictions that burning of fossil fuels might bring about a climatic catastrophe. According to the most alarming theories, fossil fuels release carbon dioxide into the atmosphere where it acts as a greenhouse, blocking the escape of heat into space and thus warming the Earth's surface. The ice caps could melt, sea levels could rise, agriculture could be disrupted and vast coastal areas might be inundated.

title: GAF Plans to Shut 2 Roofing Plants
description: The GAF Corporation said it will reduce its roofing manufacturing capacity by about 10 percent by shutting down plants in Denver and Kansas City, Mo., next week.

title: NEW YORK POLICE LIMIT FIRE, BUT CRITICS SAY NOT ENOUGH
description: Lieut. Arthur Dallas's longest day in the Police Department began when he fired two shots from his service revolver at a man who was waving a pistol at motorists on a South Bronx Street in June.

title: A Larger View of the Nurse Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. IS AFRAID ALLIES WILL BACK OUT OF MISSILE PLAN
description: Administration officials are increasingly concerned that European members of NATO, in the face of growing opposition at home, may not be able to carry out the alliance's decision to start deployment of modernized American medium-range nuclear weapons in late 1983.

title: YANKS' MICHAEL REPORTS THREAT OF HIS DISMISSAL
description: Manager Gene Michael said tonight that George Steinbrenner had again threatened to dismiss him, and that Michael had told him not to wait if he wanted to do so. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, arrived here later for the game against the White Sox. He refused to discuss plans for a managerial change but was clearly angered by Michael's remarks.

title: Bridge: Morton's Fork Coup Can Snare the Unwary Player
description: The conniving Cardinal Morton seems to have been responsible for casting Richard III, the last Plantagenet, as the archetypal Wicked Uncle. But he is remembered by English schoolboys as the author of Morton's Fork, which worked like this:

title: Patents; New Process Detoxifies Air in Submarines
description: A process for the extraction of carbon dioxide from the breathing air of submarines was patented this week an industrial hygienist at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., was granted patent 4,285,918.

title: NORTH KOREA DISPUTES U.S. OVER MISSILE-FIRING INCIDENT
description: North Korea today denied American charges that its forces fired a missile Wednesday at a United States SR-71 reconnaissance plane flying in what the Pentagon called ''South Korean and international airspace.''

title: Polish Debt Delay Signed
description: The United States and Poland have signed an agreement reached earlier to defer most loan payments due from the Government in 1981 for five to eight years, PAP, the official Polish press agency, reported.

title: SIFTING DIFFERENT VIEWS OF THE SAME FATAL EVENT
description: James Robert Bruinel Herbert, a 32-year-old dealer in antique weapons, a Vietnam War veteran and the former armorer in his National Guard company, was shot to death by a police officer just after midnight on April 24 in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan.

title: 'PHILLY FLASH,' A BURNETT-ARKIN ROMP
description: Considering the caliber of its leading players, ''Chu Chu and the Philly Flash'' is an amazingly charmless movie. Alan Arkin and Carol Burnett might be expected to generate some interest by virtue of their mere presence in the film, but they are teamed up for a painfully contrived tale, playing lovable losers who aren't lovable at all.
