Flash (Mr. Arkin) is a dim-witted derelict graced with childlike innocence, and Emily (Miss Burnett) gets to wear bananas in her ears, so the roles are not without their appealing sides. But the movie itself is almost entirely flat.

title: CARTER FINDS CHINESE REASSURED BY REAGAN ON TIES
description: After months of ''deviation,'' the Reagan Administration appears to have succeeded in reassuring Peking that it will abide by commitments made when China and the United States established diplomatic relations, former President Jimmy Carter said today.

title: Briefs
description: * Cullen-Frost Bankers agreed in principle to acquire Union National Bank of Laredo, Tex., for common and preferred stock valued at $21.3 million.

title: WHEN ONE STATE DUMPS POLLUTION ON ANOTHER
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Charts Gas Cost to Consumers
description: Total decontrol of natural gas prices will increase costs to homeowners by 30 percent in the first year but will mean lower prices in the long run, the Energy Department said today.

title: John Henry Gets Outside Post
description: John Henry, who is expected to be the favorite in Sunday's Arlington Million, a mile-and-a-quarter turf race with a purse of $1 million, drew the outside post position among a field of 14 in the draw Friday.

title: POLICE AIDE TELLS OF LIBYAN BID
description: Libyan agents tried unsuccessfully to recruit the head of the city's police bomb squad for terrorist training in Tripoli, officials confirmed today.

title: JONES BEACH TEACHES THE CYCLES OF THE AGES
description: My father liked to tell us it was the best beach in the world and that it had been built by New York's great builder, Robert Moses. I understood that this Robert Moses my father so admired had built the bathhouse, roads and parking lots of Jones Beach, but I couldn't shake my peculiar mental image of a man actually building a beach. In my head there was a picture of a middle-aged man in a business suit shoveling great piles of sand, singlehandedly ''building'' Jones Beach. Robert Moses began shoveling that sand again in my mind recently when I read about his death.

title: Patents; Two Inventions For Nuclear Reactors
description: Important inventions related to the core and fuel assemblies of nuclear reactors were patented this week by engineers for two companies. The method and arrangements patented for the General Electric Company, San Jose, Calif., are reported to achieve more efficient use of the uranium fuel and easier operation.

title: Burt's Play is Right on Nose
description: Last Saturday night, when the Jets beat the Giants in an exhibition game, Jim Burt of the Giants played against Joe Fields, one of the best blocking centers in the league. Tomorrow night, when the Giants close their exhibition season against the Steelers here, Burt will play against Mike Webster, a perennial allpro center.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Called up M ickey Mahler, pitcher, and Brain Harp- e r, catcher, from Salt Lake City of Pacific C oast League. CHICAGO (NL) - Completed sale of c lub for $20.5 million to Chicago Tribune C orp.

title: No Headline
description: John W. Hinckley Sr. president and chairman of Vanderbilt Energy Inc., told shareholders Thursday the company was for sale.

title: VOYAGER RESUMES PHOTOS OF SATURN
description: Voyager 2 resumed its photography of Saturn tonight after engineers radioed commands to reorient the spacecraft's troubled camera platform, thus ending a three-day blackout from the robot explorer.

title: Index; International
description: U.S. concerned that NATO will re- nege on new missiles plan 2 North Korea disputes U.S. over missile-firing incident 3 Carter says Reagan seems to have reassured Peking 3 SR-71's radar warning device de- tected North Korean attack 3 Trudeau defends Mounted Police security service 3 South Africa says its forces are leaving southern Angola 4 Security Council deadlocked on South African raid 4 Two drive car past guards at U.S. Embassy in Moscow 4 Around the World 5 U.N. Gribbin, former adver- tising executive 11 Joan Edwards, singing star of 1940's ''Hit Parade'' 11 Paul Herget, a pioneer in the space program 11 Sports Michael, Yankee manager, re- ports a new threat of dismissal 13 Coe runs mile in 3:47.33; 3d world record in event in 10 days 13 Reds defeat Mets, 5-2 13 Irwin birdies 18th for 68-136 and one shot lead 13 Another Bid, Spectacular Bid's namesake, is a top prospect 13 Yankees and Guidry beat White Sox, 6-1 14 Giants' Burt is man of persever- ance 14 Gaines returns to Jet lineup 10 months after breaking leg 14 Ira Berkow on umpires under as- sault 14 Pam Casale upsets Virginia Ruzici and gains semifinals 15 Brown, 16, is ousted by Nastase 15 Features/Notes Notes on People 21 Saturday News Quiz 21 About New York 27 Going Out Guide 48 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: THE PROVEN AMERICAN SOLUTION TO POVERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S., IN A REVERSAL, SUPPORTS CHICAGO ON DESEGREGATION
description: The Justice Department reversed itself today and said that it was satisfied with this city's proposals to desegregate its schools.

title: CHINESE WRITERS ARE REBUKED
description: Wang Renzhong, a high-ranking Communist Party official, has called for public criticism of Chinese authors and editors who believe that they should have more freedom to write and publish what they like.

title: GEORGE H. GRIBBIN, EXECUTIVE, IS DEAD
description: George H. Gribbin, the retired chairman of Young & Rubicam, the advertising agency, died Wednesday while vacationing with his wife in Portugal. He was 74 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: HELPING PARENTS TO COPE
description: ''T HIS is not a grown-up place,'' announced Adam, aged 3, as he tried to shoo some chattering adults out of the Parenting Center office at the 92d Street Y. The little boy obviously felt right at home at the center, one of the runaway successes of the Y since it opened officially two years ago. Its object is to help parents cope in an increasingly complicated world.

title: IN CONNECTICUT, A TOWN AND CITY BATTLE EACH OTHER
description: It was a town meeting to end all town meetings. When it adjourned at 2:15 this morning, after more than six hours of screaming and insult-trading and the forcible removal of three unruly citizens by the police, many of the 1,643 voters present wondered if the community had outgrown its 300-year-old form of government.

title: LISBON TO OPEN THE DOOR A BIT TO FOREIGN BANKS
description: Portugal, the last country in Western Europe still off-limits to foreign bankers, is finally planning to open its frontiers. And there is a long line of bankers from the United States and elsewhere waiting to get in.

title: Patents; TV Producer Invents Ping-Pong Poker
description: A television writer and producer with a secondary interest in games was granted a patent this week for Ping-Pong poker. Jose E. di Donato of Wantaugh, L.I., got patent 4,285,519 for an invention that combines paddles and cards.

title: PAUL HERGET, 73, ASTRONOMER
description: Paul Herget, an astronomer and a pioneer in the space program, died yesterday. He was 73 years old. Mr. Herget retired in 1978 as director of the Minor Planet Center of the International Astronomical Union and head of the astronomy department at the University of Cincinnati.

title: A CORRECTION: NOT INDICTED
description: We erred Monday in writing, "Surely citizens of Newark deserved a better response from Mayor Gibson to the indictment of Carl Sharif, the city's school board president, for attempted murder." Mr. Sharif has not been indicted. He has been charged by the Essex County Prosecutor, George Schneider, with assaulting a man and tying a rope around his neck, and with shooting at another man a week later. At his arraignment, Mr. Sharif pleaded innocent to both charges. Mr. Schneider says he will present the charges to the grand jury when it resumes next month.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT REAFFIRMS OPPOSITION TO BOY'S RETURN TO SOVIET
description: The Justice Department said today that it would ''continue to defend vigorously'' the asylum granted a 13-yearold Ukrainian boy who stayed in Chicago last year rather than return with his parents to the Soviet Union.

title: Bombing in Wellington Before a Rugby Match
description: A bomb exploded in the railway yards today, blocking all train traffic into the capital hours before a rugby match between New Zealand and South Africa.

title: Two Die in Crash of 26 Cars
description: Diesel fuel spilling from a tractor-trailer rig involved in a five-vehicle crash sparked a chain-reaction accident, killing two persons, injuring 18 others and wrecking 26 cars, the police said early today. Killed were Darrell D. Riddle, 48 years old, and Louise G. Riley, 60, both of West Lake, La., a police spokesman said.

title: Golden Gate Suspends Service
description: Golden Gate Airlines, which serves 19 cities in six Western states, today announced an immediate suspension of service.

title: RJR Foods Adds ITT Baking Unit
description: RJR Foods Inc., an operating unit of the Del Monte Corporation, announced acquisition of the Continental Kitchens division of the ITT Continental Baking Company.

title: NATURAL DEATH CITED IN REPORT IN MCNELL CASE
description: No evidence of foul play was found in an autopsy performed on a Queens man whose two brothers made accusations that led to the resignation of an official of the Centeral Intelligence Agency, authorities said yesterday.

title: Former Argentine President Jailed for Criticizing Regime
description: Former President Juan Carlos Ongania today began a 10-day period of detention ordered by the army commander because he criticized the current military Government.

title: Auto Makers' Layoffs Level
description: The number of open-ended layoffs in the United States auto industry was virtually unchanged this week, despite an expected 1 percent increase in car production, according to industry reports released today.

title: The Region; Ruling Upholds Rifle Association
description: TRENTON (AP) - The state has dismissed charges that the National Rifle Association broke election laws when it mailed 50,000 brochures endorsing Representative James J. Florio in the Democratic gubernatorial primary, a lawyer said.

title: Frank McConnell, 83, Retired Army General
description: Brig. Gen. Frank C. McConnell of the Army, retired, who commanded antiaircraft defense forces in World War II, died last Sunday of cancer in Cape Coral, Fla. He was 83 years old.

title: INQUIRY IS SAID TO FIND MISCONDUCT BY BORDER PATROL
description: Those who conducted a five-month investigation have reported misconduct by eight Border Patrol employees in Arizona, Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, said today.

title: No Headline
description: NEW MEMBER OF THE FLEET: The Callaghan, a guided missile destroyer, during sea trials. The ship, which can reach speeds in excess of 30 knots and is armed with the most sophisticated medium-range air defense system in the Navy, will be commissioned today at Ingalls Shipbuilding in Pascagoula, Miss.

title: Christianne Schoedel Wed to Barnaby Starr
description: Christianne Schoedel and Barnaby Starr were married yesterday in the Finch Arboretum in Spokane, Wash. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert R. Coombs, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist in Spokane.

title: Barrington Takes 3d
description: Michael Bradley hit two home runs and drove in five runs as Barrington, Ill., defeated Trail, British Columbia, 7-3, today for third place in the 35th Little League World Series.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS TAX ON HEALTH BENEFITS PROVIDED TO WORKERS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a proposal to make workers pay income taxes on part of their employer-paid medical insurance premiums in an effort to cut health costs, a top policymaker said today.

title: MET MUSEUM SAMPLING IS THE TOAST OF BORDEAUX
description: It was like asking Vladimir Horowitz to play for a high-school graduation. But as Gilberte Martin-Mery discovered, it never hurts to ask.

title: COMPUTING'S LUSTY OFFSPRING
description: In 1956, Thompson Publishing bought a sickly trade publication called Research and Engineering. Prospects were bleak, and Thompson soon thought it would probably close the magazine.

title: The Attack on Angola, 'in Context'
description: To Pretoria, it is a ''so-called invasion'' or ''simply a follow-up operation.'' But by international standards, there is nothing socalled about the violation of Angolan territory by South African forces. Flagrant would be more like it. London, Paris and Bonn strongly condemned the aerial and ground attack. Not Washington, which used every possible locution to avoid doing so. That puts the United States at odds with its allies over an adventure contrary to law or sense. Why? It looks as if an ambiguous policy is bearing bitter fruit.

title: ECONOMIC NATIONALISM AND PRIDE IN CANADA
description: Toronto - Canada's major cities and many of its 10 provinces are experiencing the largest flow of American tourists in history, and the Americans are doing everything they can do in the United States in summertime for about 20 percent less.

title: EX-MUIR MAN PICKS UP PIECES
description: Eleven years ago, a young trainee with a large regional brokerage firm decided that the firm's training program was inefficient and wrote a memo to the chairman suggesting various changes he thought appropriate.

title: 'TAKE THIS JOB,' A MAN GOES BACK HOME
description: The song ''Take This Job and Shove It'' delivers that line right off the bat, whereas the movie takes 90 minutes to get around to it. That ought to give some idea of the relative directness of the two undertakings. The movie, which opened yesterday at the Cinerama and other theaters, has a tendency to meander and no real reason not to. Its most memorable sequences are its time-wasting interludes, like the mud fight and the water fight and the football game staged entirely in a barroom, with pool tables for goal posts and a roll of toilet paper for a ball.

title: Senior Director Quits at Bendix
description: The senior director of the Bendix Corporation, declaring that he had lost confidence in the conglomerate's management, has resigned from its board.

title: NO ACCOUNTING FOR MAVERICK TASTES
description: ''Any man who would wear a brown suit is a cad,'' Winston Churchill is reported to have said. In much the same way there are certain brown-suit foods, often preferences of generally wonderful people, whose food judgment is open to question because of a few inexplicable lapses. As with Churchill's declasse brown suit, it is difficult to explain exactly what is wrong with such preferences; you either understand or you don't.

title: Poland Averts a Strike And Sets Union Talks
description: The Polish Government averted a strike in the city of Radom today. At the same time, it agreed to negotiate with Solidarity, the independent trade union movement, on demands for extensive television coverage of the union's first national congress next month.

title: Brown Lung Disease Gains New Recognition
description: The American Lung Association of North Carolina and the North Carolina Thoracic Society have acknowledged for the first time that byssinosis, or brown lung disease, exists in acute and chronic forms and may incapacitate textile workers.

title: AQUARIUM CODDLING ITS NEW BELUGA CALF
description: A 153-pound female whale born five days ago at the New York Aquarium is already something of a star because she is only the fourth beluga whale born in captivity. But she is causing some worries because none of the others survived and she is refusing her mother's milk.

title: JAZZ: BIG NICK NICHOLAS PLAYS AT WEST END
description: The musical history of Big Nick Nicholas associates the tenor saxophonist with several prominent jazz names from the 1940's through the 60's. He was in Earl (Fatha) Hines's big Swing Era, in Dizzy Gillespie's big be-bop band, and John Coltrane acknowledged Mr. Nicholas as an influence on his development by composing a piece called ''Big Nick,'' which Mr. Coltrane recorded with his own group and, more significantly, did when he was asked to record with Duke Ellington.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR AGENCY IS PRESSED FOR INDIAN POINT SAFETY PLAN
description: Thirteen New York Representatives have accused the Nuclear Regulatory Commission of inaction regarding safety conditions at the Indian Point nuclear power plant.

title: Soccer Chiefs Fold, Citing 3-Year Losses
description: The Atlanta Chiefs, eliminated from the North American Soccer League's playoffs three days ago, announced the termination of the franchise today, citing low attendance and the loss of nearly $7 million in three years.

title: THE RIGHT OF PATIENTS TO READ THEIR CHARTS
description: The most important document affecting the care of every hospital patient - the chart containing test results, diagnoses, medical history and the all-important treatment plan established by the attending physician -has long been forbidden to patients.

title: Irwin Posts a 68-136 And Leads by Shot
description: The pace perked up today in the second round of the World Series of Golf, with three players posting rounds of 65, 66 and 67. But in the end it was Hale Irwin, playing mainly for pars, who led. Irwin, who is riding the momentum of his victory last Sunday in the Buick Open, shot a second 68, two under par for Firestone Country Club.

title: S.&P. MAY ADD RATINGS
description: Standard & Poor's, the bond rating firm, said yesterday that it might make further gradations in its rating system for commercial paper.

title: DAILY NEWS PUBLISHES LAST TONIGHT EDITION
description: The Daily News yesterday ceased publication of its unsuccessful and costly year-old afternoon edition, Tonight. The move had been announced two weeks ago, along with the planned layoff of 320 employees and other cost-cutting measures, to meet an anticipated $11 million Daily News deficit this year.

title: Gasoline Prices Up At Cities Service
description: The Cities Service Company increased the minimum retail gasoline prices at company-operated service stations by 1 cent to 2 cents a gallon, a company spokesman said.

title: Productivity Unit Weighed
description: President Reagan will announce ''within a week or two'' the creation of a United States productivity committee with the aim of halting America's industrial decline and coping with problems posed by Japan's aggressive export industries, Edwin J. Gray, deputy assistant to the President for policy development and director of the Office of Policy Development, said here today.

title: Elias Picheny Is Dead at 76; Former Jewish Welfare Official
description: Elias Picheny, a former social worker and official of the National Jewish Welfare Board in New York and Chicago, died Sunday in Berkeley, Calif., at the age of 76. A former resident of New York City and Chicago, he had moved to Berkeley a year ago.

title: Earthquake Shakes Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake measuring 5.3 on the Richter scale shook the northwest section of Anchorage during the night, the United States Geological Survey said today. There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage.

title: TOO SHORT A CUT TO CASINO GAMES IN NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today scoffed at a North Korean statement denying it had fired on a United States fighter jet and warned that the United States would take steps to meet any new acts of ''international piracy'' by North Korea or Libya. He did not specify what steps he had in mind.

title: RCA to Sell Satcom 5 Unit
description: The RCA Corporation said it would sell its planned fifth telecommunications satellite, Satcom 5, to Alascom Inc. of Anchorage, in an agreement worth $180 million.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Duquesne Light Company said it would sell four million common shares through an underwritten public offering with an option to the underwriters to buy an additional 400,000 shares to cover overallotments.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 36.

title: Earnings; MIDYEAR LOSSES AT BL AND VAUXHALL
description: With the British economy in recession and auto sales in a slump, two of Britain's leading automomobile manufacturers yesterday reported a total loss of more than $525 million for the first half of this year.

title: Oil and Gas Off Indonesia
description: Marathon Petroleum Indonesia Ltd., in association with the Coastal Corporation, both of the United States, and the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company of Canada, have completed tests on an oil well in the South China Sea, Pertamina, the state oil company, announced today.

title: TWO WORKMEN IN QUEENS SAVED FROM A CAVE-IN
description: Two workmen were trapped under tons of dirt and rock yesterday - one for more than three hours - when a 14-foot sewage ditch collapsed at a construction site in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: THE SUPREME COURT REFUSES TO BAR SECRET HEARINGS IN '.22 KILLER' CASE
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday denied a request by news organizations in Buffalo to halt secret pretrial hearings for a white Army private accused of shooting three black men to death last fall in Buffalo's so-called ''.22-caliber killings.''

title: Walter Thomas, 74; Calloway Saxophonist
description: Walter (Foots) Thomas, a saxophonist and flutist who was in Cab Calloway's band for 14 years, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 74 years old.

title: IVY LEAGUE LETS DOZEN ATHLETES KEEP ELIGIBILITY
description: The Ivy League said yesterday that it had decided not to disqualify 12 athletes from participating in sports next season, even though they committed technical violations of the league's financial aid rules by accepting short-term loans from a private benefactor.

title: Brown, 16, Ousted By Nastase, 6-3, 6-2
description: Jimmy Brown, the 16-year-old national junior champion who created a sensation in the round of 16 by upsetting Jose-Luis Clerc, lost to Ilie Nastase in the quarterfinals tonight at the AMF Head Cup U.S.A tennis tournament.

title: STATEN I. DEMOCRATS ENGAGED IN LIVELY RACES FOR 2 COUNCIL POSTS
description: One evening soon after Mary T. Codd decided to give up her job as a City Councilwoman at Large from Staten Island and run for Mayor of New York, her daughter Melinda came home from work to find a caucus of relatives and friends in the living room of the family's home.

title: Insurer Seeks Strike Ruling
description: The Birmingham Fire Insurance Company of Pennsylvania, based in New York, has asked a Federal court to declare that an air traffic controllers' strike does not exist in order to avoid paying on a policy taken out by a medical laboratory to cover losses in the event of such a strike.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 29, 1981 International Cuba and Russia were again accused by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. of playing major roles in the fomenting of civil war in EL Salvador, and he accused the country's rebels of engaging in ''straight terrorism'' against the civilian population. His remarks were made at a news conference at the State Department after an announcement by France and Mexico that they had recognized the rebels as a ''representative political force.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) The joint French-Mexican statement presented to the United Nations Security Council was apparently a challenge to American policy on El Salvador. It said that, in addition to recognizing the Salvadoran guerrilla-led opposition as a ''representative political force,'' the opposition had a right to participate in negotiations aimed at ending the fighting. The statement also called for reorganization of the Salvadoran armed forces before ''authentically free'' elections could be held. The French-Mexican proposals run directly counter to the Reagan Administration's policy, which seeks the military defeat of the guerrillas and their exclusion from elections for a constitutionl assembly, scheduled in March. (1:5.)

title: CAESARS PLANNING TO SELL MOST OF ITS JERSEY SHARES
description: Caesars World has made tentative plans to sell most of its interest in its Atlantic City casino but to retain control.

title: IN LIEU OF THE CAVALRY: HIGH COURT VS. INDIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, AUGUST 29, 1981; The Economy
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to show the direction the economy is taking, fell by onetenth of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported. The decline was the third in a row, but it was so small that economists viewed it, in relative terms, as mildly encouraging. The index now stands at 133.7, down from 135.2 in May and 133.9 in June. (Page 1.)

title: Patents; New Method Devised For Culturing Microbes
description: Corning Glass Works, Corning, N. Y., received a patent this week on a method for the continuous culturing of microbes.

title: Esmark Earnings Rise By 16% in Third Quarter
description: Esmark Inc. yesterday reported $23.9 million in earnings for its third quarter, ended Aug.1, up 16 percent from the $20.6 million earned in the similar period of 1980.

title: COLT MERGER IS SET WITH PENN CENTRAL
description: The Penn Central Corporation and Colt Industries said yesterday that they had reached definitive agreement on a merger worth an estimated $1.4 billion, and Penn Central said it would sell off its real estate and amusement park operations to concentrate on manufacturing.

title: Ex-Hostage in School
description: He was the youngest of the 52 Americans held hostage in Iran, and when he was released in January, Kevin Hermening decided to finish out his tour with the Marines before deciding what to do next.

title: COE REGAINS MILE MARK
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain ran the mile in 3 minutes 47.33 seconds at an international track and field meet in Brussels last night, marking the third time in 10 days that the world record for the distance had been broken.

title: Roseland Is Sold to a Real-Estate Man
description: For 61 years, the world-famous Roseland ballroom has been a Brecker family operation, but the institution on West 52d Street, just off Broadway, has been sold. Nancy Brecker Leeds, who's run it for four years, is turning it over to the new owner on Monday.

title: KLEBER GUIDE SHUTS DOWN
description: The Kleber Guide, France's second oldest hotel and restaurant guide, is going out of business. Founded in 1954 as Le Guide des Touristes Gastronomes, the book became the Kleber Guide in 1961.

title: A 13-Year-Old Offers Help to the Frustrated
description: He's only 13 years old, but Patrick Bossert is a mathematics whiz who can solve the Rubik's cube puzzle in 53 seconds and, as a result, he has become a best-selling author.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX HAD SLIGHT DROP OF 0.1% IN JULY
description: The Government index intended to forecast movements in overall economic activity fell by one-tenth of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PRECEDENT FOR A PARDON OF U.S. AIR CONTROLLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Percy Warns On Takeovers
description: Legislation to limit Canadian takeovers of United States companies is not an idle threat, according to Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: SEX, AS THERAPY, SAID TO HARM CLIENT
description: An investigation into the effects of sexual relations between psychotherapists and their patients has found that such intimacy is damaging to at least 90 percent of the patients involved, sometimes resulting in despondency, loss of motivation, exacerbation of the patient's alcoholism or other drug dependency, hospitalization and even suicide.

title: German Plan on Checks
description: West German commercial and savings banks plan to form a group to issue international traveler's checks, a spokesman for the savings bank association said today. Other details were not disclosed. The move follows failure of negotiations in Brussels yesterday between German commercial banks and Thomas Cook Ltd., aimed at developing sales of Cook's traveler's checks in Germany, the spokesman said.

title: U.N. LAW OF SEA PARLEY ENDS '81 SESSION ON CONFIDENT NOTE
description: A United Nations conference that has been at work for nearly eight years ended its 1981 session today by vowing to complete work at a meeting in New York next spring on a global charter governing uses of the seas' resources.

title: Going Out Guide
description: ST.VINCENT MILLAY NIGHT

title: Kenyan Is Convicted In Death of Joy Adamson
description: A teen-ager was convicted and sentenced to jail today in the death last year of the naturalist and author Joy Adamson.

title: The City
description: A 23-year-old Ethiopian, the brother-in-law of that country's deputy permanent representative to the United Nations, surrendered to the police to face charges of sexual abuse, assault and burglary.

title: About New York; AMBULANCE CORPSMEN TEND TO CITY'S PAINS
description: The banshee wail of an ambulance, the song of its siren, is the stuff of awful visions. When it sounds on a street, mothers picture their children running in front of cars, wives see their husbands clutching chest and vena cava, the elderly envision broken hips, falls, cardiac arrest.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 29, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the situation in Angola - 10:30 A.M.

title: CONTRACTOR FOR CARGO PLANE IS PICKED
description: The Air Force named the McDonnell Douglas Corporation today as the prime contractor for the C-X cargo aircraft, should the Defense Department decide on the plane as the transport for the nation's Rapid Deployment Force.

title: YANKS WITH WITH GUIDRY, 6-1
description: The Yankees, with their owner, George Steinbrenner, in a front-row box seat, and Reggie Jackson back in right field, combined strong hitting and pitching tonight and beat the Chicago White Sox, 6-1.

title: Williams Attorneys Seek Poll on Fair Trial Issue
description: Attorneys for Wayne B. Williams, charged with two of the 28 slayings of blacks in Atlanta, have asked the state to pay for a poll to determine whether their client can get a fair trial in Atlanta.

title: Union Loses Election At J.P. Stevens Plant
description: Employees at a J.P. Stevens & Company plant voted 433 to 299 today against joining the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union.

title: Pam Casale In Semifinal
description: Pam Casale, the 17-year-old from Fairfield, who turned professional in April, reached a pro semifinal for the first time tonight by upsetting fifth-seeded Virginia Ruzici of Rumania, 7-6, 6-3, in the $100,000 Volvo Women's Cup tennis championships at Ramapo College.

title: COMPASSION'S REWARD
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $3.7 BILLION
description: After a week of rising interest rates and growing fears that rates would increase still further, the money markets were buoyed late yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board's report of a $3.7 billion decline in the basic measure of the nation's money supply.

title: 201 ARRESTED IN FIRST SWEEP BY NEW POLICE DRUG SQUAD
description: The Police Department's new 100-member narcotics enforcement team made its first boroughwide sweep yesterday in Manhattan. By early evening, 140 people had been arrested on charges of selling or using marijuana and other drugs.

title: Sylvia Howe Wed to Dodge Thompson
description: Sylvia Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Murray Howe of Weston and Dennis, Mass., was married yesterday to Dodge Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradbury Thompson of Riverside, Conn. The ceremony was performed at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Barnstable, Mass., by the Rev. David E. Allen, the rector, and the Rev. David B. Van Dusen of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Dining Out; A SWING BACK INTO THE OLD FORM
description: AFTER an absence of two years, Ciro Trotora is back at Ciro's in Yorktown Heights. Having had enough of retirement, the skillful, loquacious chef is cooking and happy at his old post. Although the restaurant has not quite swung back into smooth operation, service seems to improve weekly, and the welcome couldn't be warmer. A wieldy menu, primarily of restrained Southern Italian persuasion scattered with international offerings, favors seafood, veal and chicken - dishes that can be cooked last-minute-fresh. Indeed, this is an advantage; the main courses, however, were not up to the level of the stunning pasta dishes.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: ABOUT one of five municipalities that asked the state's Department of Agriculture to spray for gypsy moth infestation this year chose a natural biological agent rather than a chemical pesticide.

title: LENDL TOPS VILAS IN SEMIFINALS
description: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, the secomdseeded player, will face Ilie Nastase of Rumania, who was unseeded, in the final of the $50,000 AMF Head Cup tournament tomorrow.

title: THE OMINOUS SONGS OF THE YOUNG RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: KIM WICHMANN BETROTHED
description: Jean Wichmann of Syosset, L.I., and John Wichmann of Cooper City, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kim J. Wichmann, to David E. Michael, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Michael of Syosset.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Egg on the Face

title: JERSEY CASINO FIGHTING TO CUT COST AND OPEN
description: The Tropicana casino-hotel, which has yet to open, sent most of its 1,400 employees on two-week vacations this week, some unpaid and some in lieu of next year's vacations.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Dining Out; NOUVELLE CUISINE INFLUENCES MENU
description: A NEW menu and an elaborate wine list were inaugurated at La Mascotte in Commack earlier this summer. A nouvelle cuisine influence is now evident. Entrees studded with pink peppercorns or with sauces of fruit-flavored vinegar, dessert platters of assorted fruits with sorbet and dishes that combine variations on the same theme, such as cold mussels with three dressings or steak with three kinds of pepper, are some of the ''nouvelle'' touches that have been added.

title: COMING ATTRACTIONS THIS FALL
description: ''One From The Heart,'' a romance with music starring Frederic Forrest, Teri Garr, Nastassia Kinski, Raul Julia. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola.

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC For reasons that are not entirely clear, we are suddenly being deluged with Latin popular music, or ''salsa.'' Salsa is the modernday, mostly Puerto Rican form of the Cuban-based dance music that has been a fixture of American musical life for decades.

title: NATURE PHOTOS WED MAJESTY AND FANTASY
description: ROSLYN DESERTS, canyons and icebergs are among the titans of nature. We cannot be indifferent to them, for they are regally majestic, extraordinarily strong and seemingly invincible. They can be aweinspiring, demanding reverence mixed with fear.

title: Antiques; FOLK ART IS THE SEASON'S KEYNOTE
description: Between now and Christmas, folk art will star in museum and gallery exhibitions, at auction and in antiques fairs. Other events that will share the limelight in the weeks and months ahead are presentations of 19th-century Federal and Shaker furniture, glorious examples of Galle glass, English furniture boasting royal pedigrees, dazzling costumes and the ornithological and zoological fantasies wrought in ceramics by the Martin Brothers of London.

title: Alvin Levy, Ex-Copy Editor At The Times, Dies in Florida
description: Alvin Levy, a former sports copy editor at The New York Times, died Friday of a heart attack at his home in Plantation, Fla. He was 53 years old.

title: GREEK DEMOCRACY'S GOOD CHANCE TO SURVIVE THE NEXT ELECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics; O'NEILL SEES NO NEED TO RUSH INTO 1982 RACE
description: IN politics, a year is an eternity, James M. Fitzgerald, the Democratic state chairman, is fond of saying. Maybe that accounts for the benevolence that Gov. William A. O'Neill has displayed in public so far toward two of his potential Democratic challengers for Governor next year - the Speaker of the State House of Representaives, Ernest N. Abate of Stamford, and Representative Toby Moffett of Litchfield.

title: Business Forum; HAIL TO THE CHIEF, AS EXECUTIVE
description: E XECUTIVE anxiety is a growing contagion. More and more corporate chiefs are getting fired, often within the first year of their tenure in office. How does an executive survive in these volatile times?

title: Topics; MOVING AROUND THE CITY; Camouflage Chic
description: A friend came to town the other day and noticed that half the people on the street seem to be dressed for tropical warfare - combat camouflage fatigues and boots. ''It's camouflage chic,'' she observed, ''but I don't get it.

title: RUSSIAN CAMP RUFFLES AN EAST END LAKE
description: SOUTHAMPTON IT has been a summer for Russian music and culture on Wildwood Lake, and some of the neighbors are complaining. The music comes from the Alonushka Camp, where, beginning in July, emigres from the Soviet Union, most of them Jewish, have been vacationing in a Russian atmosphere provided on a 10-acre camp by the new owners, Marianna and Victor Shulman.

title: POP SINGER: CHAKA KHAN SHOW A WIDE RANGE OF STYLES
description: ''I'm Every Woman,'' Chaka Khan's signature song, is a proud affirmation of erotic and musical self-confidence. And at the Savoy, where Miss Khan used it as her encore to the first of three shows on Thursday and Friday, the anthem rang as more than an idle boast. For Miss Khan has developed into one of the two or three most compelling young black singers in America - one with an enviable stylistic range that includes funk, rock, pop, soul, and now jazz. But Miss Khan doesn't just jump from idiom to idiom depending on the song. Her stylistic vagaries come as the natural extensions of a vivid and integral musical personality. And on the stage at the Savoy on Thursday, where she was backed by an excellent eight-piece band, that personality was in full flower.

title: 2 KILLED IN ATTACK BY ARABS ON VIENNA SYNAGOGUE
description: Two men identified as Arabs attacked a synagogue here today with grenades and automatic pistols, killing two persons and wounding 16, the authorities said. Both assailants were captured.

title: MAJOR EVENTS OF THE SEASON
description: dance box

title: THEY'RE FLYING IN ANOTHER ERA
description: BAYPORT THE little blue and white plane taxied slowly along, jolted by the ruts and weed clumps. Near the line of trees it turned. The grassy fields stretched away in front. There was no control tower, no need to radio for permission to take off. The air traffic controllers and their strike meant nothing here.

title: Roni J. Arons Is Bride Of Dr. Steven Schloss
description: At the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center in Hewlett, L.I., yesterday, Roni J. Arons was married to Dr. Steven J. Schloss. Rabbi Stanley Platek and Cantor Tyrone Bauer officiated.

title: NINA CANNON ENGAGED TO JEFFERY ADAM LIND
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Cannon of New York and Pompano Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nina Louise Cannon, to Jeffrey Adam Lind, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lind of New York.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LURE OF MAIN STREET
description: CHESTER ROUTE 24 from Morristown, after a dozen or so miles, leads into Chester's Main Street. Busy Route 206 leads into town also, and with the expansion of the suburbs and business plants into the countryside, the traffic gets a little heavier each year.

title: TURNING LITERATURE INTO THEATER
description: ''WHERE is the world?'' wonders young Eugene Gant, after he has packed his bags and is about to flee Altamont, N.C., for college and less determinate points.

title: Indian Court Curbs Age Rules For Female Flight Attendants
description: The Supreme Court has ruled that female flight attendants can work until the age of 45 and that regulations requiring them to retire at 35 are unconstitutional.

title: Almond Growers to Get Aid
description: Twenty-five percent of this year's record California almond crop will be set aside in hopes of relieving depressed prices for growers, Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block said this week. The almonds in the pool, which was requested by producers, are to be sold gradually into ''noncompetitive outlets at salvage prices,'' he said. Noncompetitive outlets could include nuts sold to make almond oil, for export to new foreign markets or for livestock feed.

title: Dance View; ANNABELLE GAMSON AS ISADORA
description: More than half a century after her death, Isadora Duncan continues to fascinate choreographers, dancers and dancegoers. Thus, earlier this summer, the Royal Ballet offered the American premiere of ''Isadora,'' Kenneth MacMillan's controversial new evening-long ballet about Duncan's life and art, and solo choreography by Duncan was featured at the Carnegie Hall recital that Annabelle Gamson shared with pianist Garrick Ohlsson.

title: Major News in Summary; To Saturn And Beyond
description: Voyager 2 traversed 1.24 billion miles in four years to reach Saturn last week, somewhat the worse for wear but nevertheless able to reveal the largest, deepest crater in the Saturnian moon system - a rift 250 miles wide and 10 miles deep on Tethys.

title: Topics; MOVING AROUND THE CITY; Time Travel
description: Another friend, who lives in the city, is a great fan of a novel called ''Time and Again,'' in which a New Yorker learns to go in and out of the Manhattan of the 1880's. She reports that she herself took a similar trip a few Sundays ago.

title: Negro Ensemble Group To Salute Black Artists
description: Dance by a variety of choreographers and music by classical and jazz composers will be presented by the Negro Ensemble Company, prior to its 15th annual theater season, in a series of programs called ''Salute to the Black Classics of Dance and Music.''

title: RIGHTING COLLEGES' WRONGS
description: IF all the proposals intending to right the wrongs in major sports played at the college level were laid from end to end they would almost equal Dave Winfield's yearly salary paid in one dollar bills. But, like dinner at mother's table there is always room for one more. So here goes:

title: Photography View; THE SPOTLIGHT IS ON EUGENE ATGET
description: The photographer at the center of this fall season is Eugene Atget, turn-of-the-century recorder of Paris and environs. The Museum of Modern Art, which has had some 5,000 of his prints and negatives in its possession since 1968, is finally ready to present Atget's work in what promises to be a comprehensive and impeccably scholarly account of the photographer's career. This fall's installment, ''Old France'' (Oct. 3-Jan. 3), is the first of four major annual exhibitions collectively titled ''The Work of Atget.'' Each show is to be accompanied by a book authored by John Szarkowski, the museum's director of photography and a long-time Atget afficianado. Meanwhile Marcuse Pfeifer and Zabriskie galleries, not to let the anticipated wave of enthusiasm pass unembellished, have scheduled Atget exhibitions of their own (Oct. 17-Nov. 27 at Pfeifer, Oct. 21-Nov. 21 at Zabriskie).

title: AIR FORCE ACTS TO KEEP MINORITIES IN ACADEMY
description: Cadet Cynthia Willis is confident that she will win an Air Force commission next May and graduate near the top of her class.

title: DISCOVERING CO-OPS THAT ARE AFFORDABLE
description: After shopping in vain for a Manhattan apartment she could afford, Margaret Erlanger, a marketing assistant at American Express, recently purchased a 3 1/2-room co-op in a high rise in Forest Hills, Queens, for $26,000.

title: BATTERY PARK--OUT OF THE FINANCIAL DESERT
description: When the Battery Park City Authority recently announced the tentative selection of six development teams to build the second group of apartments on the waterfront site in lower Manhattan, news organizations and government officials and other commentators were quick with opinions on the design and guidelines and the timetable for completion. Nearly overlooked by many was the fact that not long ago the question was not what the design of Battery Park City would be or when it would be finished, but whether the project would be at all.

title: LOUISIANA SEARCHES FOR WAY TO SAVE COASTLINE
description: Legislators heard two days of testimony this week on ways to slow the deterioration of Louisiana's wetlands and coastline, which are now sinking at a rate that one witness called ''staggering.''

title: Soviet Cyclist Scores
description: Andrei Vedernikov of the Soviet Union outdueled Belgium's Rudy Rogiers over the final eight and one-half miles and won the gold medal in the men's amateur road race at the world cycling championships today. His margin was a length, and he averaged 25 miles an hour.

title: Business Forum; DEREGULATION: A LETTER TO GEORGE BUSH
description: side effect, the resources released by tax cuts have to be put to use for more productive purposes than meeting more regulatory requirements.

title: MAKEUP CHOICES
description: nlike some seasons in which experts have recommended a single, particular beauty style for women seeking the newest fashion look, this fall there are a proliferation of looks that are equally current. For women who would like to update their use of makeup, leading stylists who conceive and execute the looks shown on fashion models on the runways and in magazines suggest ways of using different colors and applications to achieve similar effects.

title: CARDINALS 6, PADRES 1
description: SAN DIEGO (UPI) - George Hendrick drove in two runs and scored twice, and Ken Oberkfell collected three hits, including a one-run homer, to spark St. Louis in the first game of a doubleheader.

title: 'STING' BY F.B.I. RECOVERS $50 MILLION IN BONDS
description: Federal agents posing as underworld dealers in stolen securities seized three men, an arsenal of weapons and more than $50 million in negotiable bonds Friday night in a sting operation that unfolded in a midtown hotel suite and cloak-and-dagger chases through New York City.

title: The World; RESCUING POLAND MAY BE BEYOND THE KREMLIN'S CONTROL
description: The Soviet Union implicitly acknowledged last week that Poland's vast debts to Western banks and governments have hobbled the Kremlin's ability to respond to ''acute crisis phenomena'' in Poland, while providing the West with a rare chance to influence the struggle between Polish reformers and party hard-liners. Moscow newspapers front-paged a Politburo warning to Warsaw Pact Communist parties to ''pursue a realistic economic policy without running into excessive debt to the capitalist states.''

title: PROPERTY INSPECTIONS: JUST THE FACTS; BY ELLEN RAND
description: THE phrases usually used to describe the phenomenon of condominium and cooperative conversion in New Jersey are images of feverish, if not maniacal, activity. Indeed, the pace of conversions seems to be stepping up despite a sluggish economy; since the beginning of the year, some 10,000 units have been registered with the state's Department of Community Affairs.

title: Headliners; Thunder Over China
description: Former President Jimmy Carter suggested in China last week that his hosts, having gotten a normalization commitment from an American President, should not feel they need a new one just one election later. Despite President Reagan's pre-election ''deviation'' from commitments made during the Carter Administration, the former President said, the present Administration's China policy appeared to be compatible with his 1979 agreement with Deputy Party Chairman Den Xiaoping. Mr. Carter, who was in China on a 10-day private visit, also said that if he were still President, he, too, would have continued to supply defensive weapons to Taiwan. But in an unintentionally ironic parting statement, he said there had been ''more thunder than beneficial rain'' in Chinese-American relationships. Mr. Reagan's name often is translated in China as ''Old Thunder Roots.''

title: Notes; A MUSEUM'S CELEBRATION OF LABOR DAY; by SUZANNE DONNER
description: The men and women who worked at machines between 1800 and 1920 are the focus of an exhibit called ''The Workers' World: The Industrial Village and the Company Town,'' opening on Labor Day (which falls this year on Sept. 7) at the Hagley Museum, the site of E. I. du Pont's first black-powder mills, near Wilmington, Del.

title: Rutherford Wins Title
description: Joe Manina and Dave Wernick hit two-run homers in leading Rutherford, N.J., to a 10-3 victory over Youngstown, Ohio, in the championship game of the Senior Babe Ruth World Series today.

title: Sound; AUDIO SEEKS AN ELUSIVE GOAL- SILENCE
description: Ludwig van Beethoven was the first musician deliberately to employ silence as an element of composition. His pauses are spectacularly pregnant; and it is a poignant thought that it was a deaf composer who invested silence with music.

title: U.S. SEEMS ISOLATED IN U.N. DEBATE ON ANGOLA RAID
description: The United States appeared to be increasingly isolated today as the Security Council sought a formula to condemn South Africa's incursion into Angola.

title: Kellie A. Jewell, Therapist, Married to A. Jay Baldwin
description: Kellie Ann Jewell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Jewell of Westfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to A. Jay Baldwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Baldwin of Morris Plains, N.J. The Rev. Michael J. Desmond officiated at a nuptial mass in Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: THOMAS COLE'S HOME AND STUDIO UP FOR SALE AGAIN
description: For the second time in two years, the studio and home of Thomas Cole, the founder of the Hudson River School of painting in the early 19th century, are for sale.

title: Television Week
description: Teen-age Crisis It is apparent from two forthcoming television documentaries that life for children and adolescents is hard, harder it seems than it used to be. ''Kids of the next generation are being destroyed while they are being formed,'' says Christopher Jeans whose hour-long documentary, ''Runaway ...Where Are They Now?'' will be broadcast Sunday on Channel 5 at 9 P.M.

title: Perspectives; THE COLLEGES AND BUSINESS COMPETITION
description: IT is a company catalogue, and you can order from it -semiconductor devices, radar systems, programmable calculators and electro-optical systems - but only if you are an employee. It is not a catalogue of equipment, actually, but a catalogue of how to make the equipment, a catalogue of courses to improve efficiency, morale and chances for advancement.

title: Around the Nation; Aerial Fruit Fly Spraying Resumes in Tampa Area
description: Aerial pesticide spraying against the Mediterranean fruit fly resumed today over a 24-square-mile area, but Florida agriculture officials said they were confident the state had no major problems with the pest.

title: GREAT ADVENTURE SAYS ITS BUSINESS IS GREAT
description: JACKSON DESPITE the recent death of an employee who fell off a roller coaster, business is booming at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park here. Before the park closes for the year in mid-October, 3.6 million persons are expected to have visited it.

title: WILD GRAPEVINES CAN BE TWISTED INTO FANCY WREATHS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Holly K. Emmons is assistant professor in the plant science department, SUNY-Cobleskill, N.Y. By HOLLY K. EMMONS

title: Bears 31, Cardinals 27
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Vince Evans led the Chicago victory with touchdown passes of 24 yards to Rickey Watts and 2 yards to Mike Cobb and a 1-yard run for a third score.

title: Sports; 3 FROM L.I. LOOKING FOR TENNIS UPSETS
description: PORT WASHINGTON IF you are a tennis fan and like to cheer for the home players, keep your eyes on Vitas Gerulaitis, Ricky Meyer and Eric Fromm at the United States Open championships starting Tuesday at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens. They are the top representatives from the Long Island area among the 128 players in the men's draw for the world's richest tennis tournament - $1 million in prize money.

title: Brady, at 41, Is Given Presidential Greeting
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, today received a phone call from President Reagan and a salute in song from White House reporters on his 41st birthday.

title: On Language
description: Cocktail Talk

title: THE SUPERCREAMS
description: etter looks through chemistry, these days, means more than just a pretty face. Cosmetics laboratories are in a more scientific, more serious phase than they have ever been. Their aim is more ambitious - they would like to stop the signs of aging right in their tracks. And, to do this, they have created ''supercreams,'' which, they say, go further than moisturizing or stimulating or lubricating.

title: THE NEWARK NEWS: IN MEMORIAM
description: IT WAS late afternoon, Aug. 31, 1972, when the telephone rang in my office in Munich. The secretary said it was my wife calling from New Jersey. My first thought: It must be a death in the family.

title: Robert Beck, Pamela Witte Are Married
description: Pamela Lee Witte, daughter of Mr. Eugene Burton Witte and the late Mrs. Witte of Bernardsville, N.J., was married there yesterday to Robert Childress Beck, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Childress Beck of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Alfred Niese Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain.

title: The World in Summary; Mounties Are Off the Case
description: As in the United States, the late 1960's and early 70's were a time of civil ferment in Canada. And the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, like the Federal Bureau of Investigation, sometimes broke the law in trying to uphold it.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART It's not every great institution that would open three consequential shows in the week before Labor Day, but the Morgan Library will have on view, as of Tuesday, a triple bill as inventive in its way as any that we can hope to see in the theater.

title: Recordings; SMALL LABELS FOSTER THE OFFBEAT
description: There is a new adventuresome spirit abroad on the classical record scene. Judging from the vast numbers of disks due for release over the coming months, many producers are responding to a consumer demand for novelties of all kinds. This trend is not necessarily being set by the traditional leaders in the field - CBS, EMI, Polygram and RCA - as these companies, for the most part, continue to follow an ever more cautious and conservative policy in the selection of artists and repertory. No, the impetus is coming from dozens of small, recently established labels, both in this country and in Europe, and they are catering to a wide variety of specialized tastes that the majors for the most part prefer to ignore in their feverish search for a broadbased market.

title: AT 86, GOLFER 'PLAYS HIS AGE'
description: JAMES GAVIN may not look very spry as he waits his turn on a bench near the first hole of the Maple Moor Golf Course. But once he steps up to that first tee, his head straightens up, his shoulders go back and his step becomes brisk.

title: MARKET TESTED FOR SALE OF OFFICES
description: Owners and developers in New York City are beginning to test the market for commercial condominiums. While the few such conversions completed to date have been in smaller, older buildings, two major projects are now underway that are far more ambitious, and - if successful - could significantly broaden the potential commercial condominium market.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Washington Eases Up on Hiring Rules
description: Given the Reagan Administration's well-known feelings about ''burdensome'' regulations, its revised rules for Federal contractors were hardly unexpected - and neither were the reactions. The proposals, published in the Federal Register last week and open for 60 days of comment, would relax antidiscrimination rules for companies doing business with the Federal Government.

title: TAIWAN'S AID TO REFUGEES GOES UNRECOGNIZED
description: In the flow of statistics from the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to record the number o people fleeing from Indochina, more than 12,000 men, women and children have never been taken into account. They are the Vietnamese and ethnic Chinese form Vietnam who have made their way to Taiwan.

title: OF MICE AND MEN AND NOW COMPUTERS
description: How can mothers control young children's behavior in supermarkets? What is the linguistic potential of gorillas? What sort of sexual fantasies do college students have? These and a thousand - by official count - other questions were posed, discussed and digested this week as 10,000 members of that eclectic profession, psychology, held their annual meeting here.

title: STUDENTS WHO BANK ON WHAT THEY LEARN
description: ERIC COMPTON, an instructor for the New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking, was painting a grim picture of the industry's future for the students in his Banking for Professionals seminar.

title: The Nation in Summary; Two Allies Go Their Own Way On El Salvador
description: The Reagan Administration has called El Salvador's civil war a ''textbook case'' of Communist subversion, but many of Washington's allies hold a different interpretation. Mexico has long sought to promote negotiations to end the conflict. Last week, joined by the new Socialist Government of France, it recognized El Salvador's guerrilla-led opposition as ''a representative political force'' entitled to take part in negotiations.

title: Westchester Housing; BEHIND THE DECISION ON RENT GUIDELINES
description: ALTHOUGH many tenants under the jurisdiction of the Westchester Rent Guidelines Board now face rent increases of from 12 to 18 percent, they won two concessions last week: a smaller charge than last year if they move within the building and no possibility of a fuel pass-along charge.

title: Bridge; 'DR. CONVENTIONS'
description: Aman who is a strong candidate for the title of the world's most prolific bidding theorist is likely to be even more productive in the future. He is Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City, and for the past two decades he has thought up a string of important innovations, some of which have been widely adopted by experts.

title: Taiwan Nine Retains Title
description: Chang Cheng-ching's two-run triple paced Taiwan to a 4-2 victory over Tampa, Fla., today and a record fifth straight championship in the Little League World Series. It was the 35th renewal of the annual event.

title: DISPARITY IN SOCIAL SECURITY LAW TO AFFECT SOME RETIRING IN '82
description: For recipients of Social Security, it turns out that 1916 was a good year to be born. But 1917 was not. Because of a change in the law that Congress made four years ago to curb a runaway benefits formula, people who reach the age of 65 in 1982 will find their monthly Social Security checks are up to $110 smaller than those of people who mark their 65th birthdays this year.

title: Food; FIRST THE GOAT, THEN THE CHEESE
description: PECONIC ''GOAT cheese and a vineyard - what could be nicer?'' remarked Patricia Lenz as she discussed Long Island goat cheese, her latest culinary adventure. Mrs. Lenz and her husband, Peter, who owned the Movable Feast, a superb restaurant in Westhampton, for seven years, bought a farm in Peconic two years ago to start a vineyard.

title: METS BEAT REDS FOR SCOTT BY 3-2
description: The Mets drew 44,598 persons into Shea Stadium last night, their biggest crowd in more than a year, and treated them to a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: MARSHALL ISLANDERS PRESS CLAIMS AGAINST U.S.
description: Marshallese families have begun repossessing islets in the Kwajalein Atoll, which they had relinquished for American missile tests, in a move foreshadowing a confrontation with the United States over claims for millions of dollars.

title: DOGFIGHT: A LESSON FOR U.S.
description: 2,64.4,0,404.8,2WASHINGTON - News of the dogfight over the Gulf of Sidra struck the Law of the Sea Conference in Geneva last week at an awkward moment for the American delegation. Lacking instructions that would permit us to seek specific changes in the Draft Convention, we were already on the defensive. The Libyans, surely, would attempt to orgainze some kind of a blast. The blast never came. Why not?

title: Elizabeth Hudson Valentine Married To Philip Bennett, Graduate Student
description: Elizabeth Hudson Valentine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Valentine of Carlisle, Mass., and Holderness, N.H., was married yesterday to Philip Davies Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Franklin Bennett of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Burrett E. McBee of Center Sandwich, N.H., performed the Protestant ceremony outdoors on Chocurua Island in Squam Lake, N.H.

title: Business Conditions; OVERSEAS SPENDING
description: Continued recession in major overseas markets is forcing American companies to scale back growth in planned foreign capital spending this year, a recent survey shows.

title: STUDY SHOWS CO-OP PRICES NEARLY QUINTUPLED
description: The average selling price of a 4 1/2 room, two-bedroom, "luxury" Manhattan apartment in the first six months of the year was $255,000, according to a survey prepared by The Corcoran Group. This figure compares with $225,000 in 1980, $180,000 in 1979, $135,000 in 1978, $81,000 in 1977 and $51,750 in 1973.

title: Essay; THE JEWISH DEGAULLE
description: .4,0,156.4,2,496.8,0JERUSALEM - Menachem Begin is not exactly a pressagent's dream. He lectures television newsmen about their questions; he makes ultra-assimilated American Jews uncomfortable with his accented English and pricks other consciences with unwanted reminders of the holocaust; after his Beirut bombing blunder, he seems bellicose, rigid, didactic. I like him.

title: Nicholas Benson, Carolyn Mindnich Married in Jersey
description: Carolyn Lisa Mindnich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John David Mindnich of Short Hills, N.J., was married in Rumson, N.J., yesterday to Nicholas Day Benson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Kenneth Benson of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas E. Davis performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Charles Amstein of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Coe Sees 3:46 Mile Coming Up
description: Sebastian Coe, again the world record-holder in the mile run, predicted today that he would do faster times in the near future.

title: SCHOOL DESEGREGATION IS SENT TO THE BACK OF THE BUS
description: When schools reopen here Sept. 15, it will be the first time in three years that the Los Angeles Unified School District hasn't had a mandatory busing program to integrate the district. Twenty-eight years after the United States Supreme Court's decision ordering an end to segregated schools, the nation's second largest school system will resume classes with almost 300,000 of its 530,000 pupils in racially segregated schools.

title: Translators
description: To the Editor:

title: Comptroller Proposes Indexing of City Taxes
description: New York City income taxes should be indexed to keep up with inflation, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday. He said that his proposal, although ''not a cure for inflation,'' would give some protection to taxpayers who can be pushed into higher brackets by inflation without an increase in real income.

title: BOYLE PROSECUTOR DEFENDS CONDUCT
description: A serpentine sequel to the 12-year-old murder plot against Joseph A. Yablonski is unfolding here, where the trials of those who killed the dissident leader of the United Mine Workers began.

title: Art; EXPLORING ART OF STAINED GLASS
description: MOUNT VERNON ''ENGLISH streaky,'' ''crackle'' and ''reamy'' are all terms that describe, not imported chocolates, but sheets of glass used in the art of stained-glass design and production. Examples of each can be found in a white clapboard building at 783 South Third Avenue here, formerly a cabinet workshop and now the overflowing quarters of Rohlf's Stained and Leaded Glass Studio.

title: Headliners; New Chief for Pan Am
description: ''Once you get hooked on the airline business it's worse than dope,'' said C. Edward Acker - whose associates might have thought he was one last week for resigning his $300,000 a year job as chairman of Air Florida, one of the nation's fastest-growing airlines, and assuming the same position with Pan American World Airways, which lately has been anything but. Can the 52-year-old executive turn around a carrier that has suffered huge losses and cut back its service by 10 percent? Mr. Acker is betting that he can; he said his contract, not yet approved by his new employer, was ''heavily oriented'' toward incentive payments. ''If Pan Am does well,'' he added, ''so will I.''

title: EARLY NEW HAVEN PLANNED AS A UTOPIA
description: IN the 1630's, the founders of New Haven had in mind a utopian Christian settlement based on the Puritanism that was out of favor at home in England. At the same time, they hoped the settlement would prosper by handling the commercial trade between the Old World and much of the New, from the hinterlands of Connecticut, down the Atlantic Coast as far south as the Delaware Bay.

title: Personal Finance; THE NEW TAX BILL: NOW SOME QUESTIONS
description: T HE following are answers to some recent reader questions about the implications of the new tax bill. Q. I can only afford to save $2,000 a year for retirement and am considering whether to begin one of the new Individual Retirement Accounts that will become available to people already covered by company pension plans. If I decide rather to put money into my company's thrift plan instead of an I.R.A. can I take a tax deduction for it?

title: HOW TO STOP A TAKEOVER
description: T HERE isn't just Conoco, which after fending off Seagram and Mobil has disappeared into Du Pont. Cities Service is fretting over the flirtations of Nu-West and Mesa Petroleum. Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads is on the run from Allied Stores. Nowadays executives of even the largest corporations are whispering among themselves: How do we defend our company when a corporate raider tries to snatch it up?

title: A FALL GUIDE TO GALLERIES
description: IN the old days, the art world didn't observe seasons. It was small, made up of an elite group of connoisseurs, historians, collectors and a few hangers-on and they went to the museums whenever they felt the inclination. It didn't make any difference what season it was.

title: IT'S SO NICE TO GO AWAY FOR VACATION- OR IS IT?
description: I MAY be wrong, but I don't think any relationship can be expected to survive a driving vacation. There is no way you can lock two adults in a car for two weeks straight and expect them to get out as friends, much less lovers.

title: SCHOOL TENURE CASE CAUSED BY MISTAKE
description: SOMETIME this fall, Michael Cohen, who used to be the coordinator of special education for the East Brunswick school system, will try to prove to an administrative law judge that he still ought to be the coordinator. He was, he said, dismissed by mistake - after he had tenure.

title: Art Sale and Exhibition To Benefit the Kitchen
description: A benefit art exhibition and sale will take place at the Paula Cooper Gallery from Sept. 19 to Sept. 26 to raise money for the Kitchen, a SoHo center for video work and experimental music and dance now entering its second decade.

title: Martin Drops His Appeal
description: Billy Martin, manager of the Oakland A's, said today he had decided to drop the appeal of his one-week suspension and $1,000 fine for a May 29 incident involving Umpire Terry Cooney.

title: PRO FOOTBALL'S KEN STABLER IS LINKED TO A GAMBLER
description: Despite repeated warnings from executives of the Oakland Raiders, Ken Stabler, one of the most successful quarterbacks in professional football, persisted in his association with a well-known New Jersey gambling figure who is an associate of the Princeton-based Simone DeCavalcante organized crime family.

title: ENGLEWOOD TACKLES ITS 'TICKY-TACKY'
description: ENGLEWOOD OFFICIALS of this city, concerned about the decline of urban centers, have a plan that they hope will keep the downtown business district bustling despite the lure of Bergen County's five major shopping malls.

title: The Air Strike Is Lost. Now What?
description: President Reagan has done it: he has proved that the air controllers' union could not extort a favorable wage settlement by stopping the planes. But now that his victory is obvious, it's time to change strategy. Everyone's interest, that of the President, the strikers and the public, would now be served by offering to rehire the controllers - on the Government's terms.

title: DUBLIN IS PRESSURED BY HUNGER STRIKE
description: The prisoners' hunger strike in Belfast is putting increasing pressure on the fragile new coalition Government in the Irish Republic.

title: LUGANO
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME AND HOPE FADING FOR EQUAL RIGHTS PLAN
description: The proposed Federal equal rights amendment, which seemed on the verge of success just five years ago, now appears doomed.

title: Crime
description: In APPLE CRUNCH (Seaview, $10.95), Frederic Vincent Huber has a computer expert raise hell with New York City's systems. A paycheck for a sanitation man is two cents, ''for level of service.'' The greatest traffic jam in history demonstrates how bad gridlock can get. Hospitals receive no blood but millions of rolls of toilet paper.

title: THERE MAY BE LOTS OF FIGHT IN BLUE-COLLAR NEWSPAPERS YET
description: Since it is a well-known fact that the working-class world is filled with people who do not read newspapers, it is possible that the people at The Delaware County Times are out of their minds. What else would explain the paper's switch two months ago from a 25-cent afternoon broadsheet to a 10-cent morning tabloid with double the number of stories told in half as many words?

title: THE DANCE: MCCANDLESS WIT ON VIEW
description: Dee McCandless's ''Ziggurat,'' a full-evening work performed on Thursday at the American Theater Laboratory, begins with a witty conceit. The stage is filled with joined screens that look like the outside of a maze. Two men - looking, in their black pants, tops, headbands and eye smudges, like those onstage Asian theater-set changers - proceed with a robot's tiny even step to rearrange the screens. Unfolded, the screens reveal a row of four bright-faced women, ready to dance, and a somewhat glummer band behind.

title: 'MARTIAN INVASION' HELPS HEART GROUP
description: THE Central New Jersey chapter of the American Heart Association has something for the souvenir hunter who has everything - dirt from a Martian landing site.

title: BRONCOS 24, BENGALS 20
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Mark Herrmann, Denver's rookie quarterback, and Dave Preston combined on a 9-yard pass play with nine seconds left that produced the exhibition victory. Preston took the ball on the 1-yard line, fell, recovered and scrambled into the end zone for the winning points.

title: WOMEN IN CONSTRUCTION
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE boom in building here has led four women in the industry - Nadine Samuel, Carole Kangeiser, Michael Ford and Martha Rusciani - to join the National Association of Women in Construction, which formed an Atlantic City chapter as a result of the construction surge.

title: No Headline
description: Due to a transmission error, an article in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly section about tennis events to be held in the county omitted the dates of the Carte Blanche Tennis Legends tournament. It will be played Sept. 17 through Sept. 20 at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.

title: UTAH TRIAL IN SNIPER SLAYING OF BLACKS TO BEGIN
description: Joseph Paul Franklin argued again this week that his state trial on murder charges, which begins Monday, would constitute double jeopardy. The motion was again denied.

title: The Nation in Summary; Strike Catching Up With Airlines
description: In a report on the likely effects of the air controllers strike, the Commerce Department insisted last week that, in the long run, ''business and the economy in general will probably be able to adjust easily to the reduced availability of flights.''

title: STRANGE RADIO SIGNALS DETECTED FROM SATURN
description: Strange pinging radio signals and a doughnut-shaped cloud of energetic particles, features perhaps associated with Saturn's inner moons, have been discovered by instruments on the Voyager 2 spacecraft.

title: Jessica Ellen Robins Wed
description: Jessica Ellen Robins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Robins of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married there yesterday to Peter Michael Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Miller of Rochester.

title: Mamby Retains W.B.C. Title
description: Saoul Mamby, the World Boxing Council light-welterweight champion from the United States, retained his title tonight with a decision over Thomas Americo of Indonesia.

title: Westchester Journal
description: ACCORDING to Westchester County officials, purchase of the vacant building at 110-112 East Post Road in downtown White Plains as a site for county offices would be an economically feasible and practical move, in line with the county's long-range planning for office needs.

title: Headliners; Last Resort
description: It was bad enough for cancer victim James Grant George, who was raised by adoptive parents, that perhaps the only person who could save his life through a bone marrow transplant refused.

title: WORKING OUT
description: Exercise is creating a new esthetic for women of the 80's. The soft, plump, limp odalisque is passe because it is unhealthy. And some women are actually actively reshaping their bodies so their muscles are delineated. They may not be as devoted to body building as the extraordinary Lisa Lyon, who won the first women's body-building championship in 1979, but they are enchanted with their own highly toned bodies.

title: Emily Anthony, Publishing Aide, Wed To David Masters Garratt, Consultant
description: Emily Brooke Anthony, daughter of Mrs. L. Bradford von Weise 3d of Gates Mills, Ohio, and the late Gerard M. Anthony of Dayton, Ohio, was married yesterday to David Masters Garratt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Masters Garratt of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Elizabeth Eckel Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Carter Eckel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Eckel of Far Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Theodore Wagner Neff 4th, son of Marilyn J. Neff and Theodore P. Neff, both of Miami. Msgr. William Capik performed the ceremony in St. James' Roman Catholic Church in Basking Ridge, N.J. The bride's father, who is retired, was managing director and chief executive of Chrysler Colmotores in Bogota, Colombia, a former subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation. Mr. Neff's mother is director of basic skills in the Dade County schools.

title: Revisiting a Favorite Salmon Stream
description: ADDINGTON TOWNSHIP, New Brunswick REVISITING a beloved Atlantic salmon river after the hiatus of a year is like encountering a friend after a similar separation. Will all be the same or will the former magic be gone?

title: The World in Summary; Libya Seeks Sympathy
description: When two of his air force's Soviet-built planes were brought down by Navy F-14 jets two weeks ago, Libya's Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi was off visiting. Last week, he continued his travels, citing the air battle to drum up support.

title: WHITE HOUSE TOUR LEADER COURTED AND CRITICIZED
description: Six thousand visitors troop through the White House each day, and there are days when an equal number must be turned away. A Brownie troop from Indiana, an elderly group from Des Moines, 1,500 members of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the Gay Men's Chorus from San Francisco, a needlepoint club from Detroit, 350 contestants in the National Spelling Bee and 30,000 Boy Scouts in town for their National Jamboree - all want the tour. Saying no is not easy.

title: 40 HAITIANS ARE HELD UPSTATE UNDER RIGID CONTROL
description: Forty Haitians, confined in the Federal prison here are subject to more stringent controls than those imposed on the convicted inmates, according to the prison warden. In addition, two of the Haitians have been held in solitary confinement.

title: JOAN JETT ARRANGING A COMEBACK AT 22
description: LONG BEACH AS a teen-ager in the mid-1970's, Joan Jett achieved a degree of notoriety as the rhythm guitarist of the Runaways, a Los Angelesbased band consisting of four adolescent women who played loud, aggressive music that exploited their youth and sexuality. But the Runaways, while highly successful in Japan and Australia, had only a limited following in the United States and disbanded in 1979.

title: BY PAT TURNBULL
description: HIS name is Michael. That's all. Just Michael. Somewhere in the reams of paperwork and records that have been kept on him throughout the years he is recorded as Michael J. Brandigan, or Jones, or Goldman, but here in the wards he is simply referred to as Michael, and that seems to suit him fine. Most things do.

title: ISLE OF ITHACA VOTES FOR TOURISM OVER TRADITION
description: The people of Ithaca, the home of the legendary hero Odysseus, have voted overwhelmingly in favor of developing the island's tourist potential, even at the expense of its traditional architecture.

title: The Mile Is a Mockery
description: ONE opinion that has been held here too long to be lightly dismissed is that if God had intended man to run He would have given him four legs, or at least made him late for a bus. To be sure, speed afoot might have been useful to some of the young ladies pursued by Jack the Ripper, but unnecessary running is a crime against nature. This goes for the joggers who clutter our country roads and infest our parks, and young men like Sebastian Coe and Steve Ovett who perform publicly in their underwear.

title: LUGANO
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region in Summary; Richard Levine and Carlyle C. Douglas; Koch Gets Static On Party Line
description: Fellow party members forgive each other much in their common quest for political victory. But as Mayor Koch's likely ''coronation'' as both Democratic and Republican nominee for Mayor draws near, some of his fellow Democrats sound as though they would like to crown him even sooner.

title: Reality News; Church Street
description: The 22-story office building at 100 Church Street has been sold by the Prudential Insurance Company of America to the Mackenzie Hill 100 Church Corporation for $42 million.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Park It in Tokyo'
description: As winter approached last year in the car-building centers of the Middle West, months of unemployment were taking their toll at the headquarters of the United Automobile Workers union.
