title: Art View; FROM A NEW WING TO MAJOR RETROSPECTIVES
description: How it is with the weather, the economy and the three-and-a-half minute mile is not for me to say, but the outlook for museum exhibitions this fall is as lively and as innovative as anyone could wish. What more could we want than a whole new wing at the Metropolitan Museum? (Devoted to primitive art, it will open to the public in January 1982). Or a whole new museum building of high quality by Edward Larrabee Barnes? (The new Asia Society gallery, it opens to the public at 725 Park Avenue on Oct. 15.) Or a well-planned retrospective of one of the most elusive of this century's master painters - Giorgio Morandi? (It opens at the Guggenheim Museum on Nov. 20). Or a crossbreeding of photography and literaure, like the ''Kafka-Prague'' exhibition at the Jewish Museum? (It opens on Sept. 22).

title: ALABAMA PRISONERS ARE ACCUSING POLICE OF USING 60'S CATTLE PRODS
description: A lawsuit in Federal court contends that the cattle prods that became symbolic of Southern resistance to the civil rights movement in the 1960's are still being used by the Bessemer police to torture prisoners.

title: LUGANO
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBYAN ENCOUNTER BUOYS JET FIGHTERS' MORALE
description: Comdr. Jim Lois was grinning from ear to ear. ''Welcome to fighter town east,'' he said, and then told reporters about the exploits that morning of the ''Black Aces'' F-14 fighter squadron.

title: Chess; COMING FROM BEHIND AND FINISHING IN THE MONEY
description: Had there been a prize for the most rousing finish in the United States Championship (as there is in Russian tournaments), it would have gone without demurrer to Walter Browne. In his last seven rounds, the Berkeley, Cal., grandmaster blasted his way to five victories while conceding only two draws.

title: Andrea LeeBlickman, Engaged to a Physician
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Barkin Blickman of Englewood, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Lee Blickman, to Dr. Marc Rubin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Rubin, also of Englewood.

title: Miss McWhirter Becomes the Bride Of Brian Hughes
description: The marriage of Cynthia Rae McWhirter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William R. McWhirter of Greenville, Pa., and Rancho Mirage, Calif., to Brian Blake Hughes took place at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenville yesterday. Capt. Milton U. Ray, Chaplains Corps, U.S.N., retired, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas T. Crenshaw, pastor of the church.

title: Numismatics; THE 1943 COPPER 'CENT' IS MORE THAN A RUMOR
description: Fact and fantasy sometimes overlap in the realm of coins. There is perhaps no better illustration than the ''copper'' Lincoln cent of 1943. For years there has been doubt that such a coin existed. The United States Mint refuses to admit having made it. Yet, persistent rumors and fanciful stories have made it one of the most famous rarities - real or imagined - in American numismatics.

title: At Home
description: THE woman across the hospital corridor whimpers in her sleep every night. ''Sarah?'' she says. ''Sarah, are you there?'' The nurse's shoes make a sucking sound on the linoleum. ''Of course, Sarah's here,'' she says. ''Go back to sleep.''

title: A THIRD-WORLD CINDERELLA
description: WASHINGTON T HE figures are staggering. Those third-world nations without the blessing of oil revenues have run up debt approaching $400 billion. Countries in arrears on current payments have risen from three in 1974 to 22 at the end of 1980, and the amount in arrears has jumped from $500 million to $5.5 billion.

title: U.S. TO HALT ITS AUTO GUIDE AFTER DEBATE OVER FINDINGS
description: ''The Car Book,'' popular with consumers but viewed by many in the automobile industry as the symbol of a Government assault on Detroit, will not be reprinted, according to a spokesman for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: GREAT FALLS!
description: The Great Falls Festival, held in Paterson's 119-acre Great Falls Historic District and its two parks, has become a Labor Day tradition, and the 11th one will get under way Friday night, running through Sept. 7.

title: PILOTS 'BACK TO THE OLD DAYS'
description: DANBURY THE control tower at Danbury's Municipal Airport looked like an abandoned lighthouse. The road that leads to its site in a grassy area near the intersection of the airport's two runways was blocked by an iron gate, and a sign on the door said the tower was closed because of the strike by air traffic controllers.

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: I visited China in March 1978, and while there went on a healthcare delivery-system tour with a group of physicians and psychiatric social workers.

title: The Region; THERE MAY BE NO RELIEF FOR DEMOCRATS' ABSCAM PAIN
description: Although it may be impossible to gauge the impact of the Abscam investigation on public confidence in government, its toll on the Democratic Party in New Jersey is readily apparent. Of its three most durable elected officials, two have become casualties of the F.B.I.'s undercover operation to expose public corruption.

title: CONSUMER RATES
HANOVER, N.H.
description: RONALD M. GREEN, associate professor of religion at Dartmouth College, stood before a class of about 50 students in a small lecture hall and talked briefly about the Holocaust. Millions of those who died in the Holocaust were religious, he noted, and as many as two million were children. Then he posed the question:

title: THE FULL STORY
description: Last year, hair had volume; this year it still does, but it has acquired elegance as well. While the big head of hair is back for fall, it is no longer wild and rebellious, but controlled. "The teased look is out," says Marc Pipino of Pipino-Buccheri Salon, a top stylist.

title: Music; FESTIVAL SALUTES JOHN CAGE
description: IN an appreciation that appeared in last Sunday's Arts and Leisure section, Donal Henahan referred to John Cage as ''one of the leading philosophers and wits in 20th-century music,'' and no doubt other congratulations will be tendered as the composer-author-artist approaches his 69th birthday, which is Saturday.

title: Noble Nashua's 1:33 1/5 A Record
description: Noble Nashua rushed along the rail in a stretch run that shattered the Belmont Park record for the mile yesterday in the 112th running of the Jerome Handicap.

title: Editors' Choice
description: ANGEL OF LIGHT, by Joyce Carol Oates. (E.P. Dutton, $15.50.) A modern retelling of the Atreus story.

title: Brock Confers in Hong Kong
description: Bill Brock, the United States special trade representative, held informal discussions with Hong Kong officials today on matters of mutual interest, a spokesman for the British crown colony said.

title: MEET BERGEN'S UNDERSHERIFF
description: HACKENSACK IN a move hailed by feminists as long overdue and by political observers as a master stroke, Sheriff Joseph F. Job of Bergen County has appointed Vivian Avella of Palisades Park as an Undersheriff. Mrs. Avella, who has been Sheriff Job's confidential assistant for six years, succeeds Peter Curcio, who retired in March. She is junior to Undersheriff John Stasse of Westwood, who has been in his post for 13 years.

title: Mailbox; Springboks Not a 'Club'
description: To the Sports Editor: I would like to take issue with Ira Berkow's comments on the banning of the South African rugby team. First, ''This Sporting Life'' is about rugby league - a mostly professional game something akin to football without the padding.

title: U.S. Swimmers Capture 7 of 14 Events in Tokyo
description: American swimmers captured seven of 14 gold medals today in the opening of a six-nation invitation swimming meet.

title: MOZART: CHAMBER TRANSCRIPTION FROM 1808
description: The reputation of the transcription has suffered in recent years. We prefer an authentic scoring to an evening of piano transcriptions of Beethoven symphonies; much music is lost when contrapuntal lines are simplified, orchestral colors muted and melodic ranges reduced.

title: The World in Summary; Long Shot Fired Over Korea
description: The geopolitical game of testing wills and military capabilities produced a new incident last week. North Korea fired a surface-to-air missile at a United States Air Force SR-71 spy plane which, the State Department said, was on a routine mission ''in South Korean and international air space.''

title: MUHAMMAD HELPED
description: WOMEN IN ISLAM Tradition and Transition in the Middle East. By Naila Minai. 283 pp. New York: Seaview Books. $12.95. By NAHID RACHLIN

title: MONEY ALONE WON'T SOLVE ILLS OF THE ELDERLY
description: MRS. D. owns a home in one of the area's poshest neighborhoods but all of its 13 antiques-filled rooms stand empty as she pays close to $100 a day to stay in a suburban nursing home. ''I'm here almost five years; it seems like I'm staying here,'' she says, seated in the same chair she goes to every day. ''But I want to go home. I wish it were time to go to bed ... No, I'm not sleepy. I just want to go away, to go away from everything.''

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: A.M. Rosenthal's definition of what China needs from, and is prepared to give to, America - ''a certain amount of unsentimental friendship, respect, recognition of accomplishment and mutual national interests and refusal to pretend'' - is an admirable capsule description of the desideratum in all of our international relationships. S. RALPH COHEN

title: AT LONG LAST--LUXURY
description: Thank goodness, it's back - that froth in the confection of language, that lovely whipped cream of a word - luxury.

title: When Death Becomes Routine
description: This much has been proved by the 11 hunger strikers who have died to protest British rule in Northern Ireland: they put their lives at risk for a passionately felt cause, and gave their beliefs a powerful resonance. But something else has also been shown. In the cold coinage of global attention, when death becomes routine, shock fades.

title: THE BASIC SKILLS, COMPANY STYLE
description: TWENTY students sit attentively at their desks while a teacher asks for the spelling of vocabulary words and the correct punctuation of sentences printed on a work sheet.

title: Dumont Is Defended; Writer Apologizes
description: In his attempt to localize Richard M. Nixon's venality within the borders of New Jersey, Wayne University Assistant Prof. Terence Ripmaster wrote a catchy melody, but his lyrics were faulty (''About Those New Folks in Town, Opinion page, Aug. 23). Professor Ripmaster has done a great injustice to State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr., to whom he inaccurately attributed the bigoted notion that Jews were ''too liberal'' to hold public office within the government of the community of Wayne.

title: SCREENING IDEA IRKS ANTIQUES DEALERS
description: SEA CLIFF ''ALL this fuss in a little one-square-mile village; it's a tempest in a teapot.'' The speaker was an antiques dealer, Lois Eklund, commenting on the storm that broke at a recent hearing on a proposed ordinance in this picturesque village south of Glen Cove. If enacted, the law would mandate photographing and fingerprinting, licensing and bonding of all dealers in secondhand goods, including owners of antiques shops.

title: Music View; SINGING PRAISES OF MEDIOCRITY
description: As the summer draws to a close, and curtains in concert halls across the city begin drawing open, the prospect for the musical season is not only of great performers giving great masterworks the sort of sterling performances that will be invoked with reverence generations hence. No, however many such memorable moments there may be, most of what a regular concert-goer hears during a season is likely to fall far below those heights - somewhere between intelligent meditation and mediocrity.

title: Julie Nelson Is Married
description: Julie Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Nelson of Bay Shore, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Mercer. son of Mr. and Mrs. William Mercer of Vergennes, Vt.

title: Gardening; SPIDER MITES, A LATE SUMMER MENACE
description: PLANT pests have taken their toll this season. Gardens have suffered from the voracious feeding of tent caterpillars, canker worms, gypsy moths and Japanese beetles.

title: LOWELL THOMAS, A WORLD TRAVELER AND BROADCASTER FOR 45 YEARS, DEAD
description: Lowell Thomas, the radio and television broadcaster, author and world traveler, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in his sleep at his home in Pawling, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

title: PUTTING CAROUSELS IN RACING FORM
description: go-round horses in Maine, repaint them and sell them to members of the Farmington Polo Club.

title: Avon's Tiffany
description: To the Business Editor: In reference to your article about Avon and Tiffany, ''Avon's Calling a Familiar Tune'' (Aug. 23), a few observations are in order. The article quoted David Mitchell, chairman of Avon, saying that last year Tiffany had an outstanding year in sales, but profits were ''negatively impacted'' by the high cost of inventory.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: MOVIE CRITICIZED AS GLAMORIZING POLICE CORRUPTION
description: In the late 1960's and early 1970's, corruption on an unprecedented scale was uncovered within the New York City Police Department.

title: EAST END REPORTS BUSINESS UP 20%
description: THE season is winding down this weekend, but it's not over yet. By nearly all accounts, it has been a record breaker for many East End businesses, which have never done better despite inflation.

title: Tennis Umpire Has Best View
description: To the Sports Editor: For 25 years I have been a tennis umpire, with a stadium umpire status for the past five, but events during the last several years have caused me considerable concern.

title: Television Week
description: Salute to Workers In celebration of Labor Day, Channel 13 is presenting a collection of labor films beginning on Tuesday and running through Sept. 12. The first presentation at 10 P.M. on Tuesday is ''Free to Choose,'' in which Milton Friedman, the conservative economist, examines Spartanburg, S.C., where the closed shop was eliminated.

title: MANUFACTURING REMAINS KEY TO STATE'S ECONOMY
description: HARTFORD BECAUSE it is a region devoid of natural resources, it must import energy, food and raw materials, such as steel, and rely on a costly, vulnerable transportation network. To pay for those essential goods, it must export ever more sophisticated manfactured products and services, using technology and an educated work force to replace declining industries such as textiles and primary metals.

title: THE BIG QUESTION
description: As long, full skirts, big, loose tops, wide belts and swashbuckling capes and shawls were being paraded along the runways at the fall ready-to-wear shows on Seventh Avenue, the question in the mind of the watchers could not help but be: But how will they look on the average American woman?

title: At Home
description: THE woman across the hospital corridor whimpers in her sleep every night. ''Sarah?'' she says. ''Sarah, are you there?'' The nurse's shoes make a sucking sound on the linoleum. ''Of course, Sarah's here,'' she says. ''Go back to sleep.'' The whispered exchange in the darkness invites fear into my room that has become as palpable as a presence. The presence - particularly vivid when my fever is high - has a round, female form. Its borders frame thinly stretched cellophane etched with ghostly children, family, friends, like an overexposed photographic slide. The barely perceived figures do not look at me as they recede into a vast and milky distance, and one night, echoing the unknown woman's cry, I call to them. ''Laura, John, Lee - are you there?'' A sucking noise in the hall, and then a gentle voice from my doorway. ''They're here,'' the nurse says. ''Go to sleep.''

title: HOW WILL THE BIG 3 FARE AT U.S. OPEN
description: SHORT HILLS WHEN the United States Open tennis championships start Tuesday at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, New Jersey will be strongly represented by its big three - Fritz Buehning of Short Hills, Peter Fleming of Chatham and Pam Casale of Fairfield.

title: The Nation in Summary; Postal Contracts Approved
description: Two big postal unions overwhelmingly approved new contracts last week. The vote probably had less to do with fear of the White House - like the controllers, the American Postal Workers Union and the National Association of Letter Carriers are barred by law from striking - than with spotting a goody, in this case a clause providing for unlimited cost-of-living increases, in addition to a raise of $2,100 spread over three years for most postal workers.

title: Practical Traveler; WHEN A PACKAGE CAN BE A BARGAIN
description: If you write to the Mayfair Hotel in London and ask to reserve a double room, you will be quoted a rate of 56 to 60 a night, including a 15 percent service charge but not the 15 percent tax. The total would thus come to 64.40 to 69 or, at the late August exchange rate of roughly $1.85 to 1, the equivalent of $119 to $128.

title: Elizabeth Henderson Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Mason Henderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Welles Henderson of Philadelphia and Manchester, Mass., was married in Manchester yesterday to Peter Bush Hoagland, son of Mrs. Stanley M. Cohen of Bridgeton, Me., and the late Peter Hoagland. The Rev. Dr. David B. Watermulder, minister of the Bryn Mawr (Pa.)

title: Wendy Frieze Wed to Peter Bepler 2d
description: Wendy King Frieze, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Savage C. Frieze Jr. of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter T. Bepler 2d, son of Mr. Bepler of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Bepler.

title: EAT WELL, BE WELL
description: JANE BRODY'S NUTRITION BOOK By Jane Brody. Illustrated. 552 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $17.95 By JEAN MAYER

title: Around The World; Student Slashes Portrait Of Princess of Wales
description: A man wielding a knife today slashed a portrait of the Princess of Wales that was on display at the National Portrait Gallery here, gallery officials reported.

title: HOW TO GET THERE
description: All the wineries have retail stores on premises and all welcome visitors. Except for J. Jacob Lee, all have chilled wines available for tasting before a purchase. The retail stores and tasting facilities range from elaborate, special-purpose rooms at Renault and Gross Highland to a desk and cash register at Tomasello's.

title: Long Islanders; BEFORE THE EXAM, HIS WORD IS LAW
description: IF there is such a thing as a slack season in the life of J. Gardiner Pieper of Hicksville, this is it. When the tide of his activity is at its peak, the 37-year-old lawyer can be found specializing in corporate, real-estate and litigation practice as a partner in Doran, Buckley, Kremer, O'Reilly & Pieper of Mineola, writing books on the law and teaching - a vocation that in the past has had him commuting to Boston to teach at two law schools and rushing off at the behest of Hofstra students to teach them New York's civil-practice law.

title: More on the Madeleine
description: To the Editor:

title: Architecture View; THE BUILDING BOOM GIVES BIRTH
description: The talk in architecture this fall is likely to be of quantity as much as of quality, of numbers as much as of style. For now is when we are beginning to see the buildings of Manhattan's latest construction boom come to completion. This is also the season when the city's proposed new zoning regulations, barring unexpected political opposition, will become law, as will the Landmarks Preservation Commission's plan to designate an immense stretch of the Upper East Side as a historic district, thus sharply cutting back on future development there. And this will be the season when the vestry of St. Bartholomew's Church, which has been talking for months about selling off part of its valuable Park Avenue property to a real estate developer, is expected to come forth with an actual plan to do so - and thus set in motion the next phase of a landmarks battle that is likely to be the most passionate New York has seen since the fight over Grand Central Terminal.

title: COSTUMING A SHOW: SEQUINS AND SWEAT
description: WHEN is a basement not a basement? When summer theater turns it into a combination sweatshop and medieval armory. The change is almost instant. Two days after our daughter, Susy, home from college for the summer, signed on as costume designer for the Saw Mill Summer Theater's production of ''Pippin,'' our basement began to disappear under a mountain of chiffon, velour, satin, burlap, fake fur and sequins.

title: by John Wain
description: Wales is a green country, well wooded though the trees are not usually very large, with winding lanes and small swift rivers that broaden out into lovely shining estuaries. It is a country of hills; in the north, the hills are abrupt and jagged, with plenty of bare rock face, and are commonly known as the Welsh mountains; statistically, their altitudes are modest, but they are dramatic and wild and seem much bigger than they are. In mid- and south Wales, the hills are green to their rounded tops.

title: Soviet Is Silent About Couple Who Drove Into U.S. Embassy
description: There was no word today on the fate of a Soviet engineer and his mother who drove into the United States Embassy in Moscow yesterday and left three and a half hours later followed by Soviet security officers.

title: THERE'S MORE THAN ONE WAY TO SAY 'SORRY' TO THE PENTAGON
description: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF. AS a candidate, Ronald Reagan liked to ridicule former President Carter for suggesting that the American people ought to lower their expectations. But since taking office, Mr. Reagan has had to lower his own expectations.

title: LUGANO
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolyn Wirth Is Bride
description: Carolyn Victoria Wirth, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl J. Wirth of Chatham, N.J., was married at Christ Church (interdenominational) in Summit, N.J., yesterday to Douglas R. Long, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Long of Pittsfield, Mass. The Rev. Allen Tinker performed the ceremony.

title: 'LETS DONT' IS WINNER OF FUTURITY
description: Lets Dont Fight came from far behind on a track that seemed to be composed of quicksand and won the $508,975 Arlington-Washington Futurity for 2-year-olds today at Arlington Park.

title: Thomas Hodgson Weds Patricia A. Thompson
description: Patricia Anne Thompson, corporate bond liaison for E.F. Hutton & Company in New York, was married yesterday to Thomas McEver Hodgson, a management consultant. The Rev. James Wilson performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan.

title: Irwin Takes 2-Stroke Lead With 70-206
description: Hale Irwin acknowledges he does not have the spectacular kind of game that makes headlines, but he is confident in it and, more important, his opponents in the World Series of Golf respect it.

title: KLENETSKY CALLS KOCH A SPECIAL-INTEREST TOOL
description: Squaring his shoulders in his gray suit, Melvin Klenetsky turned toward the midday sandwich-eaters on the steps of the Federal Hall National Memorial, pushed the button on his bullhorn and explained how he wanted to be Mayor of New York City.

title: RUNAWAYS: WHY THEY GO
description: SOME runaways run to a friend's house for the night. Some take to the road for a week. And some run to the nearest telephone hot line to tell a Youth Department counselor of their decision to leave.

title: A FORMER 'BAD BOY' OF TENNIS SAYS THAT TEMPERS MUST COOL
description: AS a boy in St. Louis, my constant dream was to be a professional tennis player. On the junior circuit and then at Wimbledon, Forest Hills and other major amateur tournaments, I treated each bad call and every one of my own mistakes as a life-or-death matter. Before open tennis only one or two players could turn pro each year, and I didn't want anything to stand in my way.

title: About Long Island
description: IN early June, on the kind of day that is a sultry harbinger of summer, I hollered for help from the family's home-improvement expert.

title: MOON CHURCH REPORTED TO OWE $300,000 IN TAXES
description: AFTER failing to pay taxes on most of its landholdings for more than a year, representatives of the Unification Church, one of Westchester's largest property owners, recently paid approximately $100,000 in back taxes on four parcels of land in Tarrytown and Greenburgh.

title: The Nation in Summary; For Hinckley, the Epilogue Begins
description: Almost five months to the awful day, John W. Hinckley Jr. was indicted last week on charges of attempting to kill the President. At a hearing in Washington on Friday, Mr. Hinckley pleaded not guilty, and his lawyer said defense psychiatrists think he is competent to stand trial.

title: EASING THE PROBLEMS OF COLLEGE RE-ENTRY
description: FOR many adults who want to return to college, something as simple as walking into the admissions office can lead to a feeling analogous to being put on an Inquisition rack.

title: DID WOMAN MAKE MAN?
description: ON BECOMING HUMAN By Nancy Makepeace Tanner. Illustrated. 373 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $10.95. MISSING LINKS The Hunt for Earliest Man. By John Reader. Illustrated. 272 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: F.B.I. Says Bombings in U.S.  Have Declined 15% This Year
description: Bombings in the United States decreased 15 percent in the first six months of this year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says.

title: Topics; Making Welfare Work
description: In this time of government budget cuts, New York's Department of Social Services has come up with an intriguing welfare plan. It hopes to help recipients of home relief obtain jobs by converting public assistance payments into paychecks.

title: ZAIRE'S BLOODY PAST MAKES COBALT'S FUTURE UNCERTAIN
description: Like the country itself, Zaire's natural resources have a history studded with bloodshed and uncertainty. As often as not, the violence has stemmed from the interplay between the activities of foreigners, attracted by the resources, and the vast nation's own capacity for bloodletting.

title: Around The World; Schmidt Voices Unease On Neutron Weapons
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, meeting with Norwegian leaders, today reiterated his uneasiness about the timing of President Reagan's decision to begin full production of neutron weapons.

title: Business Conditions; FOR SOME, HIGH RATES AREN'T BAD
description: While high interest rates have depressed much of the economy, at the same time they have boosted incomes in numerous households. Economists at Manufacturers Hanover Trust have found that income accrued from interest-bearing investments like money market funds and Treasury bills has risen 42 percent since September 1979, to an annual $312 billion in July.

title: A CALL FOR A STATE-CITY SUMMIT
description: REPRESENTATIVE Toby Moffett has likened the recently enacted budget cuts to ''dropping a bomb on a densely populated area,'' and early projections for the proposed Federal and state cutbacks lend increasing reality to this image.

title: Drs. Virginia Riggs, R. W. Lyons Wed
description: At St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Brattleboro, Vt., yesterday, Dr. Virginia Palmer Riggs, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas Shepard Riggs of Halifax, Vt., was married to Dr. Robert W. Lyons, son of William J. Lyons of North Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Ann Sullivan Lyons. The Rev. Howard Van Dyne performed the ceremony.

title: GOLDIN ADS ON RADIO AND TV CALLED OUTRAGEOUS BY DEARIE
description: John C. Dearie has criticized radio and television commercials by the New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, as ''outrageous.'' He said his own ads had gone off the air briefly while his campaign staff decided whether to respond with ''positive'' messages extolling him, or ''negative'' messages criticizing Mr. Goldin.

title: 'I'M A SUCKER FOR HERO WORSHIP'
description: WHEN politicians are asked which books influenced them, they often find one answer most expedient, the Bible. In fact, this was Ronald Reagan's reply when The New York Times queried him about his favorite books shortly after he was elected President. But when asked the question in 1977, the then-retired Governor of California responded less predictably.

title: Headliners; The Shortest Mile
description: He has yet to meet his chief rival for the world record in the mile run in head-to-head competition, but Sebastian Coe nevertheless beat Steve Ovett for the second time in 10 days last week. In setting a new record of 3 minutes 47.33 seconds in Brussels, Mr. Coe cut more than a second off the record Mr. Ovett had posted in West Germany two days before.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BOSTON
description: GETTING ACQUAINTED - Boston, originally a narrow peninsula that was extended and changed over the years by land-filling, is made up of clusters of distinctive neighborhoods. Some of them, such as the financial district and the North End, are a maze of streets going off in all directions, like a mini-London. A map helps greatly. The Boston Visitors Services Center, 15 State Street, Boston 02109 (617-367-9275), has a good one for $1 (in fiscally strapped Boston, some things are no longer free), and it contains a lot of additional information. There is a large information booth at the Tremont Street side of Boston Common; more information can be obtained at the National Park Service Visitor Center, 15 State Street (at the foot of Washington Street, behind the Old State House). There is also a recording of daily events (617-338-1976).

title: U.P.I. REPORTER IN SOUTH AFRICA IS CHARGED FOR RIOTS ARTICLE
description: A United Press International reporter has been charged under South Africa's defense act with writing an article ''calculated to alarm or depress members of the public.''

title: TEXTBOOK LOANS IN CALIFORNIA BANNED BY STATE HIGH COURT
description: The California Supreme Court has ruled that it is unconstitutional for the state to lend public school books to parochial or private schools.

title: THE GREAT OCEAN ROAD LEADS TO A CLOSE-UP OF AUSTRALIA
description: Many visitors drawn to Melbourne's spacious gardens and Victorian atmosphere venture no farther south. But beyond lies one of the finest drives in Australia, the Great Ocean Road to the isolated coast of southwestern Victoria.

title: AMUSEMENT PARK BUSINESS OFF
description: WITH only eight days to go before the effective end of summer, amusement business proprietors at the Shore have already begun to assess the season. And many are finding it to have been something less than booming.

title: Shawna Deery Wed to Donald Barrett
description: Shawna Elizabeth Deery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Deery of Marblehead, Mass., was married there yesterday to Donald Vail Barrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Halsey V. Barrett of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Gerald C. Frasier, assisted by the Rev. Edward O. Miller, performed the ceremony at Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church.

title: Stamps; GENUINE NON-STAMPS
description: This is about stamps, not postage stamps, but stamps of the world that never - well, hardly ever - carry mail to any country. These stamps are works of art, yet are not prized by philatelists and never appear in albums.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Trendy fare. It's a game that many a publisher is tempted to play - putting out a book that capitalizes on the fad of the moment. It's a risky game, because it usually takes 18 months or longer to transform the gleam in an author's or editor's eye into a hardcover book on sale in stores across the country - and in the interval the public's interest may have moved on to another fancy.

title: Giants Defeat Pirates
description: With the bases loaded in the first inning, Tim Foli dropped a pop fly that allowed three runs to score and started the San Francisco Giants on their way to an 8-3 victory today over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: New Jersey Department of Energy
description: In my article, which appeared last week, I mistakenly attributed to Senator Dumont the remark that, because of their religious convictions, Jews should not hold positions in the Wayne government. The comments were not made by Mr. Dumont, and I apologize for the inadvertent use of his name. TERENCE RIPMASTER Haledon

title: JOB HELP FOR WIVES
description: I T'S a problem that has become the bane of the personnel office: A company tries to transfer a promising executive, but his wife, happy in her own job, won't budge without assurance of a good new job for herself.

title: SOUTHERN CHANGES
description: UNLIKELY HEROES By Jack Bass. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. By LINCOLN CAPLAN

title: JACQUELINE KAY AFFIANCE
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Andrew Kay of New Canaan, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Kay, to Edward Mackintosh Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mackintosh Brown of Denver.

title: JAPANESE SAYS HE HAS FOUND KUBLAI KHAN'S FLEET
description: Seventy-two rotting wooden hulks resting on the sea bottom just off the Japanese coast are "without doubt" the remains of the fleet of Kublai Khan that tried to invade Japan 700 years ago, says the leader of the salvage expedition.

title: Miss Borden, D.W. Bunnell Wed in Jersey
description: Rebecca Grosvenor Borden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Borden Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Douglas Walls Bunnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard W. Bunnell of Madison, Conn. The ceremony was conducted at the Stony Brook Meeting House under the care of the Princeton Monthly Meeting of the Society of Friends.

title: THE YANKEES' STICK IS STANDING TALL
description: CHICAGO F OR more than 12 hours, George Steinbrenner had been aware that Gene Michael had dared the Yankees' principal owner to discharge him. ''It's not fair that he criticizes me and threatens to fire me all the time,'' Gene Michael said at an impromptu news conference before Friday night's game here. ''I'd rather he do it than talk about it. I told him exactly that today - don't wait.''

title: AVOIDING THE TRAPS IN PICKING SKILL SCHOOLS
description: HIGH SCHOOL graduates and adults re-entering the job market or changing their careers are discovering that training for some of the fastest-growing job fields - such as machinery repair, word processing and dental hygiene - is more readily available in vocational schools and community colleges than in four-year institutions.

title: Major News in Summary; Pieces Added To Mideast Chess Board
description: The Reagan Administration, whose Middle East forays to date have been mostly to maintain a shaky status quo, last week put forward what it called the cornerstone of its own strategy - an $8.5 billion package of advanced radar planes, range-extending fuel tanks and airto-air missiles for jet fighters that will give Saudi Arabia a credible air force.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ

title: Miss Powers To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Augustin Jay Powers Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Mathilde Powers, to Brian Edward Swiggett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lewis Swiggett of Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: CONCERT: MOSTLY MOZART CONCLUSION
description: The last of the Mostly Mozart programs, heard on Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall, was a fitting conclusion of the festival. It featured Pinchas Zukerman conducting the orchestra in a sampling of four concertos with three virtuosos as soloists - the cellist Lynn Harrell, the violist Michael Tree, and the violinist, Mr. Zukerman himself. It was, that is, a varied gathering of big-name talents that is one of the trademark of the annual summer series - along with its logo that graces towels, aprons and teacups.

title: BONN CUTS ITS BUDGET FOR NATO WAR GAMES
description: As part of West Germany's economy drive, the Defense Ministry has ordered stringent cuts in a large field exercise next month in the Stuttgart area that will involve West German, American and Canadian troops, a military spokesman said yesterday.

title: U.S. PERSONNEL CHIEF ASSAILS FREEZE ON EXECUTIVE SALARIES
description: Thousands of Federal executives whose salaries are frozen at $50,112 a year deserve raises but are not likely to get more money until the public thinks they have earned it, according to the Administration's chief personnel officer.

title: Other Business; 40 PERCENT A YEAR ON SAVINGS? NOT FOR LONG
description: Open any newspaper last week and the luggage and television sets were all but gone. Banks and savings and loan institutions were again promoting the interest they pay depositors, and the rates were extraordinary.

title: ASPEN: A 4TH DECADE FOR ANCESTOR...OF A GROWING BUSINESS BREED
description: running continuing-education program for business leaders, the executive seminars of the institute have attracted more than 5,000 captains of industry who have left their corporate command posts for an average of two weeks of animated discussion on topics ranging from Aristotle to ''The Federalist Papers.''

title: 'SUPERMAN IS HERE AMONG US'
description: IN her letter to Superman (''At Home,'' Aug. 9), Shelby Moorman Howatt professes love for the man who could leap tall buildings in a single bound. As a child listening to radio adventures of the Man of Steel, she would shut her eyes tight and ''nothing was more beautiful than the Superman I saw soaring behind my closed eyelids.'' Comic book drawings, early Superman movie serials, the more recent ''Superman'' and even ''Superman II'' depict a hero falling short of her visions.

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: I am, in a way, an old China hand, since I grew up in Shanghai and have been involved in Chinese studies most of my life. A.M. Rosenthal is dead right that it is the system, more than individual leaders, that brings about the frightful situation in China that one knows about.

title: The World; FRENCH RIGHT YET TO LEARN THE MEANING OF BEING OUT
description: Bernard Stasi, leader of a small liberal group in the coalition that supported former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, recently compared the French political scene to a soccer match just after the half-time switch of goals. ''For a little while,'' he wrote, ''the players are disoriented, retaining a tendency to kick the ball the wrong way.''

title: OFFICIAL SAYS U.S. WILL BE NEUTRAL ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Reagan Administration said today that despite its opposition to South Africa's racial separation policies, it would not take sides between blacks and whites in that country or try to undermine the South African Government ''in order to curry favor elsewhere.''

title: Connecticut Journal
description: MANCHESTER appears to be moving toward hiring black or Hispanic police officers, but some black residents are not happy with the way town officials are handling the application process.

title: LIFE BEGINS AT 50-PLUS ON A TREK IN THE WILDS
description: Mention wilderness canoeing or backpacking and the image immediately conjured up is of a well-conditioned person, probably young, who jogs, skis cross-country, climbs mountains and scuba dives. It might seem that hardly anyone over 40 would qualify; people of that age ought to be warming themselves by the glow of their television screens and not cluttering up the wilder-ness or careering down fast rivers. But perhaps not. My wife and I, both over 50, have grown increasingly fond of camping in the Hiawatha National Forest in Michigan's Upper Peninsula, taking part in fairly strenuous pursuits. Last time we were there, during the waning days of a glorious autumn, we packed into the woods, hiked more than 20 miles and then canoed down the Indian River and through the Chain of Lakes area. We are not particularly athletic nor did we engage in any rigorous preparations. It was fairly easy terrain, actually, and not quite whitewater canoeing, but it beats television watching by a million miles.

title: SOVIET PRESS ACCUSES HAIG OF ARROGANCE
description: The Soviet press today characterized Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s accusations of Soviet interference in El Salvador as an exercise in ''imperial arrogance,'' and countered with similar charges against Washington.

title: BOAT SAFETY URGED ON SOUND
description: FOR thousands of recreational sailors, Long Island Sound is a vast nautical playground, dotted with picturesque ports. But to the Coast Guard, it is also a waterway fraught with danger.

title: Frances Armstrong Boyd Is Married
description: The marriage of Frances Armstrong Boyd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wetherall Boyd of Westport, Conn., to Carlos S. Velazquez Gloria took place yesterday in Easton, Conn. The Rev. Leland O. Hunt, assistant to the rector of Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Boyd, uncle and aunt of the bride.

title: CAN WE BE SURE THE FISH WILL LIKE OUR GARBAGE?
description: To the Editor Is it possible that Charles Osterberg's Aug. 9 Op-Ed article, ''Seas: To Waste or Not,'' is a trial balloon lofted by his employer, the Department of Energy, to test public acceptance of ocean dumping?

title: BARBARO AND ESPOSITO EXAMINE CRIME IN THE CITY AND HOW TO DEAL WITH IT
description: Assemblymen Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and John A. Esposito of Queens, candidate for the Republican nomination, were asked by The New York Times for their views on major issues confronting New York City. Following are their replies on crime: Esposito: Notice to Criminals

title: WHEN THE MEDIAN AGE OF FRESHMEN IS 33
description: MARIA SANCHEZ is executive assistant to the senior vice president of a prominent New York concern in the dress-pattern industry. Married, with no children, articulate and ambitious, she is typical in most respects of successful young businesswomen. Yet, at the age of 31, Maria is a college freshman preparing for a new career.

title: Mr. Exxon
description: To the Business Editor: It is depressing to have a reputable business leader such as Clifton C. Garvin Jr. put down solar energy as he did in your article, ''An Audience With Mr. Exxon'' (Aug. 9). In the same breath, while acknowledging that the technology of solar is simple and good, he bemoans the fact that, ''the sun's not out around here,'' and since he's getting older, he would like something about 80 degrees.

title: Protest by Salvadoran Leader
description: The President of El Salvador's ruling junta today protested the recognition of his country's guerrilla-led opposition by France and Mexico.

title: Dining Out; INFORMAL, FAMILY-STYLE DINING
description: MADISON ALTHOUGH it is not on the shore, Friends & Company - located in a modern-looking shingled building on the Post Road - is reported to be one of this resort town's most popular restaurants.

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: A.M. Rosenthal's story is full of humor, charm, poignancy and, above all, warmth. I guess one reason I feel very sentimental about his article is that I am Chinese, born in China, and have many relatives in China and, therefore, have some idea about what life is really like there.

title: The Club
description: To the Business Editor: ''Pittsburgh's Top Brass Love the Duquesne Club'' (Aug. 9) noted that the venerable institution now counts three women members.

title: TEXAS LEGISLATOR SUSPECTED IN OWN SHOOTING
description: Last summer, Texans were caught up in the fictional shooting of J.R. Ewing. This summer they are talking about a real shooting that involves, depending on the teller, either a satanic cult or a politician ready to give an arm to advance his career.

title: 13 INDICTED FOR SMUGGLING 4,000 ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced today that they had broken a smuggling operation that they said had transported 4,000 illegal aliens from Tijuana and Baja California, Mexico.

title: Cathleen Costello Is Married to Dr. Marc Reitman
description: Cathleen Costello, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Costello of Sun City, Ariz., was married yesterday to Dr. Marc Weil Reitman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Reitman of West Orange, N.J. Judge Harold Ackerman of the Federal District Court of Trenton performed the garden ceremony at the Reitman home.

title: The Region in Summary; New Jersey Dams In Poor Repair
description: Not that it can afford it, since the weather has been unusually dry lately, but New Jersey seems to have trouble with its water system as well as its water supply. According to a report released last week, many of the state's 1,000 aging and long-neglected dams have sprung leaks, suffered erosion damage or fail to meet modern safety standards.

title: UTILITY CANCELS NUCLEAR PLANT NEAR INDIANA DUNES
description: The Northern Indiana Public Service Company has announced that it is scrapping the $1.8 billion Bailly nuclear power plant on the shore of Lake Michigan.

title: ARLINGTON MILLION COMES UP SHORT ITS BILLING
description: kept grass course and try to get some top runners from other countries to show up. If that had remained the goal of the Arlington Million, no one could be disappointed by what will happen this afternoon at Arlington Park in this suburb 15 miles northwest of Chicago. The race that includes such horses as John Henry, Argument, Key to Content and Rossi Gold and such jockeys as Lester Piggott, Steve Cauthen and Bill Shoemaker is well worth even the inflated $4 grandstand admission.

title: MODERNISM IN MORRISTOWN
description: MORRISTOWN MODERNISM, the demise of which has been much proclaimed of late, is alive and well and living here in Morristown. Nene Humphrey's ''Meadow Passage/Forest House,'' which will be on view in the backyard of the Morris Museum of Arts & Sciences through Sept. 6, is an uncompromisingly new and innovative work of art.

title: CITY MAKES A BIG ISSUE OF LITTLE CRIMES
description: Assessing a change he insisted did not begin until he started speaking out on the matter, Mayor Koch last week congratulated New York judges for their tougher attitude on crime. ''This is not an open city,'' he said, promising that the stern measures, including arrests for such ''quality-of-life'' offenses as prostitution, gambling and low-level drug trafficking, would continue.

title: Reader Comment; THE AIR CONTROLLERS
description: I FOUND your discussion of the air controllers' strike, ''The Air Strike Is Ominous for Labor'' (Aug. 16), lacking in its definition of the problem and misleading as to possible solutions.

title: Television Week
description: Music's Calm William Congereve said ''music hath charms to soothe the savage breast, to soften rocks or bend a knotted oak.'' Calm should prevail, then, after two special two-hour concerts this week devoted to American music.

title: CLASSICAL LIBERAL
description: 1832 Volume II. By Robert V. Remini. Illustrated. 469 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $20.

title: BROADWAY IS THINKING - AND HOPING - BIG
description: Start with what is unassailable, or at least as unassailable as anything on Broadway can be. Last season was not great; this season may not be either, but there is a chance, a hope, a stirring in the breasts of producers, that greatness, if not exactly thrust upon the season, at least will not be utterly beyond it. Actually, all seasons look great before they begin, and it is the chance, the hope and the stirring that run Broadway as much as the theater owners, the critics, or even the William Morris Agency. The happy thing, however, is that this season really does look better than seasons past. You cannot be sure it will be better; you can only hope. But that, of course, is what Broadway does, too.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Treasures of The Andrea Doria
description: They aren't doing it for the love of money - probably no treasure they retrieve will compensate for the costs of the expedition - but still, finding a sturdy Bank of Rome safe on the sunken Andrea Doria last week was an exciting moment for a salvage team of 40 people, who included sea divers and diver-cameramen.

title: RED SOX DEFEAT SKIDDING A'S
description: Carney Lansford drove in four runs with a single and a homer today to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 7-6 victory over Oakland. The A's suffered their fourth straight loss.

title: Perspectives; COURSES BY TV REAFFIRM VALUE OF CLASSROOM
description: WITH cable-television spreading and videodisks spinning at an everquickening pace and Walter Annenberg sponsoring $150 million worth of public-television courses, we are again hearing that siren song about educational technology displacing classroom instruction, especially for the millions of Americans engaged in adult education.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; M. M. KAYE
description: ''I'm a writer entirely by mistake,'' says Mary Margaret Kaye. ''My hope was to make my living as a painter, but I was a failure at it.'' She has been anything but a failure as a writer, however, having written a number of children's books under the name Molly Kaye, as well as nine mysteries and three big-selling historical romances under the name M.M. Kaye. Her most recent book is ''Trade Wind'' (St. Martin's Press), currently No. 9 on the fiction best-seller list, and the successor to her previous big sellers, ''The Far Pavilions'' and ''Shadow of the Moon.''

title: LOUNGING IN LUXE
description: Lounge wear in champagne-colored silk satin is elegant enough for a party at home. By Sami. Camisole, $60. Short jacket, $125. Pants, $115. Henri Bendel. Ultimo, Chicago. SILKY SLEEPERS These pajamas are cut as straight-forwardly as a man's cotton pair but are luxuriously made in white silk satin. By Samantha Robbins for Sami, $200. At Saks Fifth Avenue. Also at Lina Lee, Beverly Hills.

title: WALL ST. LOOKS FOR LIGHT AT END OF REAGANOMICS
description: How many legs does a horse have, Abraham Lincoln once asked an adversary, if you call the tail a leg? No, he said after eliciting the obvious answer, calling a tail a leg does not make it one. It's a bit like that with the Reagan Administration's economic program these days.

title: The Region in Summary; New York Shifts Power Stratregy
description: The cost of energy has forced officials at the State Energy Office, just like drivers and homeowners, to change many of their assumptions about its use. Revising a master plan issued three years ago, they said last week that with energy consumption at its lowest since 1967, New York would need only three new coal-fired power plants, two less than they had thought, and no new nuclear ones.

title: Janet Geerlings, Violinist, Is Wed
description: Janet Lynn Geerlings, daughter of Mrs. Clarence Johnson of Springfield, Ohio, and Henry J. Geerlings of Newport Beach, Calif., was married in Cincinnati yesterday to Alexander Macdonald Doman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas R. Doman of New York and Shelter Island, N.Y. The Rev Paul L'Herrou performed the ceremony at St. John's Unitarian Church.

title: BOATERS URGED TO HEED SAFETY RULES
description: LATE last summer, a 20-foot powerboat attempting to pass between a tugboat and the barge it was towing off Stratford struck the steel towline and capsized, resulting in the drowning of one of the two men aboard. Coast Guard officials said the men in the powerboat had assumed the tug and barge were traveling independently and apparently had not understood that the three vertical white lights atop of the tug were a signal that the barge was in tow.

title: Prospects
description: Stocks Should Get Cheaper

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE Great Falls of Paterson -the city's premier tourist attraction and the initial reason that Paterson grew - will become the site of an operating hydroelectric generating plant and, said Tippie Krugman, chairman of the newly formed Municipal Utilities Authority, there is a global lesson in the fact.

title: Miss Gignoux, Designer, Bride of D.P. Wipper
description: Marguerite Jay Gignoux was married yesterday in an outdoor ceremony to Dennis Paul Wipper at St. Matthew's Chapel-in-the-Woods in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Leslie John Alden Lang of St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York performed the ceremony.

title: Kramer of Vikings Doubtful for Opener
description: The status of Tommy Kramer for the Minnesota Vikings' season opener at Tampa Bay next Saturay night is doubtful.

title: JETS TOP EAGLES BY 14-3
description: The New Yorkers ended their exhibition season with a stunning defensive effort against the Philadelphia Eagles, a team that went to the Super Bowl last year. The Eagles, led by the quarterback Ron Jaworksi, were easily contained, 14-3.

title: CONDUCTING TRAFFIC IN 3-4 TIME
description: HAMPTON BAYS IT all started this summer when Craig Boyd looked at the cars coming at him as he attempted to direct traffic at a busy intersection and heard music in his head. ''I decided to conduct,'' said the 30-year-old member of the Southampton Town Police traffic control squad, who is also a musician schooled in composition, arrangement and conducting.

title: A PICNIC HELPS SPIRIT OF SYNAGOGUE
description: DANIELSON THE scene appears typically American. There are wire mesh racks on which to barbecue chicken, wooden picnic tables draped with paper tablecloths, buckets of water in which to cook the fresh native corn, and watermelon being sliced.

title: Another John Paul Starring on Track
description: John Paul Jr. has raced at Le Mans, been courted by factory teams and is generally acknowledged to be as fast as any driver in America's top road-racing series, the International Motor Sports Association's Camel GT. At times it is hard to believe that he first lowered his lanky frame into the cockpit of a racing car less than three years ago.

title: BRAILLE BOOKBINDING TRADITION AT TEMPLE
description: WHAT might a college student in Pakistan, a psychologist and educator in Michigan and a student in a Westchester vocational course have in common? They are blind, and in the course of their studies have used textbooks bound at the Braille bookbindery at Temple Israel in New Rochelle.

title: PHILIPSBURG BARN REPLACEMENT WEIGHED
description: THE fire that leveled an 18th-century barn at the Philipsburg Manor restoration site in North Tarrytown late last Sunday night was still being called suspicious last week by North Tarrytown fire officials, but officials at Sleepy Hollow Restorations, operators of the site, said they would soon begin the process of replacing the historic structure.

title: REALTORS SEE THREAT TO THEIR BUSINESS
description: FEARFUL that the real-estate business could be invaded by what an official of the Connecticut Association of Realtors calls ''opportunists who could do us irreparable damage,'' the association has been seeking support from its 10,000 members and the public to avoid what it sees as a threatened curtailment of the powers and duties of the State Real Estate Commission.

title: Leslie Ann Rubenfeld Bride of Kevin John Dealy
description: Leslie Ann Rubenfeld and Kevin John Dealy, who received master's degrees in social work this year from Boston College, were married at the Pleasant Valley Country Club in Sutton, Mass., yesterday. Rabbi Samuel Umen and the Rev. Edward Moran, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The World in Summary; South Africans Go Marching Into Angola
description: South Africa holds undisputed military superiority over black guerrillas based in neighboring Angola, but when it comes to international relations, Pretoria has a long way to go. By sending two armored columns into Angola last week, it transformed what would probably have been a lackluster United Nations debate on South Africa's refusal to give up South-West Africa into a raging controversy that served to clarify - and isolate - American policy toward the region.

title: REAGAN PRESCRIPTION FOR GREATER INFLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 Food-Handling Concerns Cited for Health Violations
description: The New York City Health Department has released the names of 12 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named two restaurants that have reopened after correcting earlier violations and two that have been closed for failing to do so.

title: I.B.M.: A GIANT AMONG GIANTS IN THE CLASSROOM AS WELL
description: THE catalogue listings look like those for any university computer science department: Introduction to Computer Architecture; Data Logic and Set Theory; Man and Machine. Each course is listed with its prerequisites, meeting times, instructor and textbooks. But the Systems Research Institute is not an academic place. ''It's all business,'' said its associate director, Joseph E. Flanagan.

title: Elizabeth Marsh Is Wed
description: At the Hamilton College Chapel in Clinton, N.Y., yesterday, Elizabeth Glyde Marsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James I. Marsh of Barneveld, N.Y., was married to Peter Mitchell Wenigmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. C Mitchell Wenigmann of Dublin, N.H. The Rev. Samuel Hale performed the Episcopal ceremony. The bride and bridegroom teach science and English, respectively, at the Shore Country Day School in Beverly, Mass. She was graduated from Middlebury College and he from Hamilton.

title: ADULT STUDENTS START A BUSINESS TREND
description: AS usual this fall, American adults will be going back to school in growing numbers, choosing from an array of courses that range from heraldry to real estate. But if the present trends prevail, more and more of these continuing-education students will be choosing courses that affect their working lives.

title: WARSAW OFFERS SOLIDARITY 2 TV SLOTS
description: The Government offered the Solidarity union two half-hour slots on prime-time television next week, as talks began today over the union's demand for access to the state-controlled press and broadcasting.

title: THE LITTLE MISSILE THAT COULD AND THEREFORE IS
description: WASHINGTON IN about one year, the first cruise missiles will be attached to a long-range B-52 bomber. Over the next six years, thousands of these torpedo-like pilotless aircraft, some with nuclear warheads and some with conventional warheads, will be loaded onto submarines, surface ships, ground launchers and tactical aircraft. The cost of it all will be at least $15 billion - not that expensive by Pentagon standards but higher than anticipated. The repercussions of the deployments will be enormous - in added American firepower, in relations with Western European allies (it is slated for deployment in Europe in 1983) and for the future of arms control.

title: RACE IN QUEENS TURNS INTO G.O.P. POWER BID
description: A hotly contested primary for a City Councilman-at-Large nomination - unusual for Queens Republicans - is also a struggle for the Republican leadership of Queens, one of the most Republican counties in the state.

title: HE'LL TRY TO KEEP BRITIAN IN COMPUTERS
description: LONDON T HE first clue to the personality of Robert W. Wilmot, the 36-year-old American-trained executive who recently became managing director of Britain's ailing International Computers Ltd., came when he scheduled an interview for 7:45 on a Friday morning in August. At an hour that finds most people blearyeyed, in a month that finds many executives on holiday, Mr. Wilmot was spilling forth phrases like ''It has impacted computer procurements significantly.''

title: Music Manuscripts On View Sept. 29-Dec. 6
description: The New-York Historical Society will present an exhibition from its music collection Sept. 29-Dec. 6 entitled ''Anacreon Revisited.'' The exhibition will include a number of manuscripts of early American music, some of them shown to the public for the first time.

title: Reality News
description: Most property owners whose holdings would be taken over to make way for the proposed 42nd Street Redevelopment Project are not expected to be among the developers included in the plan sponsored by the city and the New York State Urban Development Corporation. They simply do not have the financial resources to carry out the ambitious plans envisioned by the U.D.C.

title: August 30, 1981
description: NONFICTION ANDREW JACKSON AND THE COURSE OF AMERICAN FREEDOM, 1822-1832. Volume II. By Robert V. Remini. ............................... 1 ASKING FOR TROUBLE: Autobiography of a Banned Journalist.

title: Around the Nation; Union Says Controllers Got Illegal Compensation
description: Striking air traffic controllers charged yesterday that Federal Aviation Administration supervisors and working controllers in more than two dozen cities illegally accepted free food and beverages from airlines.

title: John Scally Jr., Lawyer, Weds Karen Scofield
description: Karen Elizabeth Scofield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lewis Scofield of Abington, Pa., was married yesterday to John Joseph Scally Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scally of Bloomfield and Branchville, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Kaluzny performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield.

title: Other Business; CITIBANK WITHDRAWS ITS MONTHLY LETTER
description: After 77 years and seven months, Citibank has laid to rest its Monthly Economic Letter, one of the best-known, best-written and most widely read bank-produced publications in the nation.

title: SCHOOLS ARE FOCUS OF ITALY QUAKE AID
description: It took six months for the State Department's Agency for International Development to complete plans for spending the $50 million that Congress allocated for the victims of last November's earthquake in southern Italy.

title: A 'PORTAIT' OF OYSTERING
description: OYSTER BAY IT was not a typical day aboard the Ida May, a 45-foot trawler that plies the creeks and shallow waters here to harvest the elusive oyster for F.M. Flower and Sons, one of the last two oystering companies left on the Island.

title: FROM EUROPE
description: hen top ready-to-wear designers from Milan and Paris showed their fall collections, the message was clear: Their designs reflected luxury and sophistication. Gone were the gimmicks of seasons past, what often seemed to be a self-conscious striving to create something ''new.'' It has been replaced by a rigor in design and innovation that is derived from sure, experienced hands. Quality, luxurious fabrics and superb workmanship are evident in many top designers' offerings, and the resulting clothes have a uniquely European ''touch of class'' that makes them desirable at any price - and perhaps this is just as well, as their prices are in the highest ranges.

title: Muriel L. Kappenberg Bride of John B. Rand
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton, L.I., yesterday, Muriel Louise Kappenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Kappenberg of Westhampton, was married to John Bradstreet Rand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo C. Rand of East Patchogue, L.I. The Rev. George Busler, assisted by the Rev. John Coakley, performed the ceremony.

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: Mr. Rosenthal's horror, experienced at the sight of 18-year-old girls who were in state reformatories for ''having affairs with boys'' is one I, and many others, would understand. Yet, we have today, in this country, a growing and vocal group of people who would plunge us into similar practices.

title: Index; FASHIONS OF THE TIMES
description: FROM EUROPE By Mary Russell 84 The fall ready-to-wear collections from Paris and Milan reflect luxury, sophistication and innovation derived from sure, experienced hands. MAKEUP CHOICES By Jani Wooldridge 112 Instead of creating one new look, the experts suggest using the new fall palette in different ways.

title: TRANSLATING FOWLES INTO FILM
description: Leslie Garis writes frequently on the arts. By Leslie Garis ''The French Lieutenant's Woman,'' one of the most highly acclaimed and complex novels of recent decades, has been tempting film makers since 1969, the year of its publication. John Fowles's best-selling tale of a young Victorian gentleman who falls in love with a mysterious woman of tarnished reputation has the romantic sweep of a great film, but it has a problem: Although the story takes place in the late 1860's, it is narrated by a distinctly 20th-century author whose wry, intellectual asides enable us to see the story from both a Victorian and a modern point of view. It's a dazzling design for a novel, but it couldn't be less cinematic, and distinguished directors such as Lindsay Anderson, Michael Cacoyannis, Richard Lester and Fred Zinnemann all came to grief trying to develop a script - or even a concept.

title: WHAT DOES 'NONTRADITIONAL' REALLY MEAN?
description: THIS fall, as I begin my 31st year of teaching sociology at Rutgers, I remember how students behaved when I arrived in 1951. In those days, students came to class on time and stayed until the end of the scheduled period. They rarely missed classes, perhaps because the equivalent of three weeks of unexcused absences meant an automatic failure for the course. We did not speak of ''traditional'' and ''nontraditional'' students; all students assumed that they were supposed to read assigned books, listen in class and take examinations.

title: CASTILIANS TRY TO INFUSE LIFE INTO OLD AREA
description: In Spanish history, Castile is a proud name. Today it is a lament. Castile once sallied out to conquer the world. Today it is merely a region.

title: JAZZ TURNS TO THE PAST
description: Jazz is following the elections this season. The conservative trend shown by the voters is reflected in a more conservative outlook in the jazz bookings for the coming months. There is a general movement toward the central, mainstream areas of jazz primarily at the expense of the avant-garde, which, after spreading through a rabbit's warren of lofts in the early 70's and then moving on to more established clubs, has been receding in the past couple of years. Now the eperimental fringe of jazz has lost its last fulltime showcase, the Public Theater, which is planning a more mixed type of presentations this season.

title: TOURS AND ALBUMS STIR POP
description: The Rolling Stones will be touring this fall for the first time since 1978. They expect to play a number of local venues - Giants Stadium in New Jersey and Manhattan's Roseland ballroom have both been suggested as possible locations - and to make unannnounced appearances in small halls and possibly in night clubs. Their performances in the New York area, which will undoubtedly cause more of a stir than any other events of this fall's rock concert season, could begin as early as mid-October.

title: EXPOS 4, BRAVES 3
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Tim Raines, a rookie who was back in the lineup after a two-day absence because of a sore ankle, scored the winning run in the seventh inning on an error by Glenn Hubbard at second, enabling Montreal to defeat Atlanta for its fifth straight victory.

title: The Region in Summary; Lodging for The Asking
description: It is difficult to go anywhere in New York City without encountering those who have no place to go, be they alcoholic vagrants, subway mutterers or merely old and broke. Amid growing concern for such souls, state and local officials last week signed an agreement guaranteeing that those who ask the city for shelter will have to be taken in.

title: Television; IT'S PRIME TIME FOR VETERAN ACTORS AND WOMEN AT WORK
description: Something curiously contradictory characterizes prime-time television this fall. On the one hand, the networks are looking to the past by recycling an older generation of macho male stars, such as James Garner, Robert Stack, Mike Connors and Lee Majors, in alltoo-familiar roles as cops, private detectives and even bounty hunters. But what's less apparent is a quiet step forward for women. Where last fall most females were still confined to playing emptyheaded sex symbols, this season's prime-time woman is suddenly sophisticated, independent and professionally capable.

title: LUGANO
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME MUSICAL HIGHLIGHTS
description: Haydn-Stravinsky Celebration, at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Alice Tully Hall, Sept. 13. Music Today series with Gerard Schwarz, Merkin Concert Hall, Abraham Goodman House, Sept. 23.

title: LUGANO
description: To the Editor:

title: STRAPPED DISTRICTS TRYING SELF-INSURANCE
description: SQUEEZED between rising costs and mandatory budget caps, municipalities, counties and school districts are searching for ways to cut costs and make limited resources go as far as possible.

title: Antiques; HOUSE BUILT IN 1692 REMAINS A HOME
description: WETHERSFIELD ALMOST three centuries have passed, but if David Buttolph and his wife, Mary, were to return to the house they built late in 1692, they would feel right at home. For their mansion house, as neighbors called it in the 17th century, still stands at the corner of Broad and Marsh Streets here and appears much as it did when the Buttolphs moved in. The great difference is that the oak clapboards are stained and weathered, darkened by time and no longer have the bright, fresh look of newly hewn wood the Buttolphs would expect.

title: PHONE LINES CREATE DELAYS ON COMPUTERS
description: WHEN the Social Security Administration's computers in its offices on the Island go awry - as they have twice this month - the trouble may have nothing to do with bureauc@racy or inefficiency or anything else that can be blamed on the Government.

title: NEW ENTREPRENEURS MAKE THE FAR-OUT IN
description: ''YOU'RE here because you have a dream - the dream to open your own restaurant,'' the instructor tells his dozen students seated around an immaculately set table in an East Side restaurant.

title: U.S. Expected to Close Paula Parkinson Case
description: The Justice Department has decided to bring no charges as a result of its inquiry into the activities of Paula Parkinson, according to department sources who declined to be named.

title: Soviet Cotton Crop Hurt
description: The Soviet Union's cotton crop, one of its most reliable hard-currency earners, appears to have suffered from heavy rains and unseasonably cool temperatures in central Asia this year, according to the newspaper Izvestia. The Soviet Government daily described this year's crop as ''not bad,'' but suggested that a record crop was unlikely.

title: HOSPITAL ENJOYING A NEW TRANQUILITY
description: WESTWOOD NOT too many months ago, labor relations at the Pascack Valley Hospital here were at a low ebb. Unionized nurses contended that they were grossly underpaid and viewed as second-class citizens by an administration they said was obstinate about their grievances and bent on union-busting.

title: RUSSIA: SHADOW AND SUBSTANCE
description: Anthony Austin, an editor of this Magazine, recently completed a two-year assignment as a New York Times correspondent in Moscow. By Anthony Austin I met Igor at one of those dissident press conferences that were still being held in those poky little apartments around Moscow in the summer of 1979. This particular turnout of Western correspondents was in response to a telephone call from some new group styling itself the Committee for the Right of Free Emigration, an idea whose prospects in the Soviet Union were about equal to those of a snowball in hell.

title: The Region in Summary; Albany Tries A New Twist On 'Workfare'
description: Programs that pay employers to provide on-the-job training for welfare recipients have the net effect, critics contend, of taking people off the dole and putting companies on it. But the experimental ''workfare'' program unveiled in Albany last week is different, according to its sponsors.

title: Customs Turns Off Computer For a Month to Test Its Value
description: The United States Customs Service has done without its expensive crime-detection computer system at the nation's five busiest border crossings for at least a month.

title: USONIA COMMUNITY REMEMBERS ITS PAST
description: DRIVING north along Route 120 from the Kensico Reservoir, on streets with names such as Orchard Brook Drive and Nanny Hagen Lane, lies a community of striking architectural specimens. Frank Lloyd Wright's ''Round House of the East'' - with its castlelike turrets of local fieldstone -sits perched on a hill, and nearby stand 47 other modern homes designed by such architects as Ulrich Franzen, K. Domoto, Aaron Resnick and David Henken. But behind this cluster of original architecture lies the story of a group of idealistic New Yorkers who decided that by banding together they could build their own homes and design the kind of community that they'd like to raise their families in.

title: YANKEES RESPECT MICHAEL'S CANDOR
description: Bob Watson leaned back in his chair last night with a thoughtful expression on his face and listened to an account of what the Yankee manager, Gene Michael, had said about George Steinbrenner's constant threats of dismissal.

title: Ideas & Trends; PLANETARY QUESTIONS...AND ANSWERS
description: With Voyager 2's mission to Saturn last week, Earth satellites have surveyed all planets known to the ancient world - those visible to the naked eye. Strange to recall, as Voyager transmitted spectacular photographs of Saturn's rings and moons, that before the planets came under spacecraft scrutiny, they seemed pale in comparison to such intergalactic delights as comets, carrying messages from unknown reaches of space. In fact, the solar system is a source of wonder. Within its bounds lie planets and moons torn by violent storms, cut by canyons that could hide Mount Everest, wrapped in atmospheres generating complex organic molecules and, in at least one case, humming with life. Recent planetary exploration has both deepened the mystery and our understanding. The following quiz is a test of your planetary knowledge.

title: Business Conditions; FARM INCOMES FADE
description: Despite the July uptick in food price inflation, developments during the first half of 1980 - weak agricultural commodity prices, rising costs and a strong dollar - have not been appreciated down on the farm.

title: No Headline
description: JoAnne Carner shot a five-under-par 67 today and took a three-stroke lead after three rounds in the $150,000 Columbia Savings Classic.

title: BRYANT, WALKER AND FAUST SHARE THE CENTER OF ATTENTION
description: COLLEGE football's multi-million dollar battle over control of future television rights to major college games will be waged throughout the coming season with as much intensity as any contest on the nation's 137 major college gridirons. The lines have been drawn between the new College Football Association and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which has managed regular-season college football television for three decades.

title: Patricia R. Burns, Joshua Stiles Wed
description: Patricia Rose Burns and Joshua Kent Stiles, candidates for M.B.A. degrees at New York University, were married at SS. Joseph and Patrick Roman Catholic Church in Utica, N.Y., yesterday.

title: 5 Baby Whoopers Die,
description: Wildlife Aide Reports

title: EQUITABLE ERROR
description: LETTERS Equitable Error To the Editor:

title: Long Island Guide; ENERGY EFFICIENCY
description: Today's the day that the Brookhaven National Laboratory will open its energy-efficient passive solar house to public viewing. Developed with funds from the United States Department of Energy as a prototype for fuel-conserving housing, the home is currently being monitored at the lab for its heating performance. And so far, scientists report that without any complex construction technology, such energy-conserving concepts as south-facing windows, house siting and a nonmoving heat storage system can result in bringing heating use down to 170 gallons each winter for an average Long Island house. Brookhaven House can be seen from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. during the final free summer tour of the lab, which is off William Floyd Parkway in Upton. SEA CHANTIES

title: Arthur Miller's 'Vichy' To Be Revived Sept. 10
description: ''Incident at Vichy,'' Arthur Miller's drama about the persecution of Jews in the Nazi-dominated Vichy sector of France in World War II, will be revived by the Jewish Repertory Theater for three weeks, beginning Sept. 10, at the Emanu-El Midtown Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association, 344 East 14th Street, between First and Second Avenues.

title: Reading and Writing; JOHNSON'S DICTIONARY
description: In catechism lessons, nuns used to ask, ''Why did God make the world?'' and the answer was ''For His glory.'' Samuel Johnson might be said to have made the first great English dictionary in the same way.

title: Home Clinic; REPAIRING TOOL HANDLE REMAINS A PRACTICAL THING
description: MORE often than not, when a homeowner breaks the handle on a wellworn shovel, rake, hoe or other yard and garden tool, the first thing he or she will think of is to throw the old tool away and go out to buy a new one. But with today's inflationary prices, more and more people find that it pays to fix what they have when this is practical - and repairing a broken tool handle or replacing it with a new one is almost always practical.

title: FILM BOARD SEEKS NEW CHIEF
description: NEWARK THE New Jersey Film and Television Development Commission, formed by Governor Byrne five years ago to attract revenue to the state by providing movie settings, has recently fallen on hard times, in large part because of changing executive directors.

title: Food; WINGING IT IN BUFFALO
description: About a year ago, during a visit to Buffalo, N.Y., we were taken to lunch at a raffish but delightful place on Main Street called Frank & Theressa's Anchor Bar. This particular establishment, now owned by Frank's and Theressa's son, Dominic Bellissimo, was chosen because of the house specialty: a chicken-wing dish said to rival chicken preparations worldwide. Indeed, the residents of Buffalo are so enamored of these chicken wings that the city officially declared July 29, 1977, to be Chicken Wing Day. The city's proclamation noted that, because of Mr. Bellissimo's kitchen, ''thousands of pounds of chicken wings are consumed by Buffalonians in restaurants and taverns throughout the city each week.''

title: Theater; 'BAGGY PANTS' A HIT AT EVENING DINNER
description: THERE was a time when burlesque acquired a bad reputation because of strippers who went too far and removed too much. That was when the late Mayor of New York City, Fiorello La Guardia, closed down the burlesque houses. But in 1981, when just about anything you can think of is legal and available, burlesque has acquired a respectable glow of nostalgia. Its reputation can only be enhanced by ''Baggy Pants,'' which recreates a time when burlesque was merely a rougher form of vaudeville. For the record, there are no strippers in An Evening Dinner Theater's production of ''Baggy Pants,'' but there are comics and classic sketches and blackouts.

title: U.S. Open Symbolic of Spectator Boom
description: The signs are everywhere - increased prize money, record ticket sales, stronger television ratings, positive national surveys. After years of selling itself as a participant sport, tennis finally is attracting broad spectator appeal to its major events.

title: FROM SATURN TO NEWINGTON
