description: ''AT a time like this, I can't help but think that Galileo would be envious of us,'' David Menke said Tuesday night as he sat in the Newington home of a radio operator who was able to pick up pictures of Saturn transmitted from California moments after they were received from the Voyager 2 spacecraft.

title: FROM NUCLEAR CASUALTY TO HEALTH HAZARD
description: To the Editor:

title: LUGANO
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Ex-G.M. President's Son Questioned About Loans
description: The son of a former president of General Motors Corporation is being investigated by the Federal authorities, who say he forged letters to obtain more than $800,000 in bank loans to pay gambling debts, a G.M. spokesman said today.

title: TV View; DIAGNOSING AN IDENTIFICATION CRISIS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Walter Goodman is director of humanities programming at WNET/Channel 13. John J. O'Connor is on vacation.

title: Teresa Jo Kovach Is Wed in Capital
description: Teresa Jo Kovach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bill Kovach of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Nicholas Wedd Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Freeman Brown of Washington. Gerard D. Reilly, retired Chief Judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, performed the ceremony at the Brown home.

title: Long Island Journal
description: GREENPORT officials have decided that a rumor-control bureau, designed to insure smooth public relations with the local population in crisis situations, would be too expensive.

title: CORRESPONDENCE COURSES FLYING AGAIN
description: STEPHEN ALTFEDER of Great Neck, L.I., was just nine credits short of his management degree at Indiana State University when he ran out of funds to finance his education.

title: Westchester Show Draws 2,904 Dogs
description: Seventy-six years ago, the first Westchester Kennel Club show was held in White Plains. Next Sunday, the East's premier outdoor dog event will be staged at Lyndhurst, a national historic landmark in Tarrytown, N.Y., and one of the most beautiful show sites in America.

title: Hana Mandlikova Gains Final, 6-1, 6-3
description: Hana Mandlikova, who has not lost a set in five matches, beat Regina Marsikova today, 6-1, 6-3, in an all-Czechoslovak semifinal that lasted only 50 minutes in the $100,000 Volvo Women's Cup at Ramapo College.

title: THE NEW LUXURY
description: Evoking as it does all that is voluptuous, sensual and extravagant, the word luxury has always had a slightly sinful allure. But nowadays, it has acquired another dimention. It is equated with quality, and at a time whenfle up or down, waistlines shift shoulders stretch or shrink, silhouettes get pared down or filled out,but that is not what fashion is about today. For the cognoscenti, fashion is the quest for the best--making an investment in the finest fabric, workmenship and design.

title: ATTORNEY FOR HOMELESS WORKED IN TWO WORLDS
description: New York City's tens of thousands of homeless men did not appoint Robert Hayes to represent them, nor did a social service agency knock on his door and ask him to take their case.

title: Design; TALES OF TABLES AT TIFFANY'S
description: ll is readiness, at last. For hours, the hostess, a well entrenched figure on the New York social scene, has been hovering -adjusting a fork here, a service plate there. Now, candlelight flashes off the sterling silver, and clusters of goblets stretch like newborn birds, mouths upturned, waiting to be filled. But no wine will splash against this immaculate crystal, no crumb will sully the napery. This is not, after all, reality; this is Tiffany's.

title: DREAMS OF LUXURY
description: If you had an unlimited amount of money to spend on one luxurious item for your wardrobe for fall, what would it be?Ask prominent women this same question and they conjure up fantastic personal visions, as fanciful and extravagant as the question itself.

title: DESPITE SECURITY, THEFTS STILL PLAGUE YACHTSMEN
description: One night recently, someone sidled up to Burt Sloane's 36-foot Trojan cabin cruiser moored in Long Island's Manhasset Bay, boarded the boat and, after kicking in a starboard window, made off with $700 worth of electronic equipment.

title: Nancy J. Chapel Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Nancy Jane Chapel and Brian Earle Fortini, 1978 graduates of Ohio Wesleyan University, took place yesterday at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Lloyd Seiler, granduncle of the bride and pastor of Zion Lutheran Church in Boalsburg, Pa., performed the ceremony.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, AUGUST 30, 1981
description: International A policy statement on South Africa by the Reagan Administration said that despite the Administration's opposition to South African apartheid policies it would not take sides between South African blacks and whites or try to undermine the Government ''in order to curry favor elsewhere.'' Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said the United States wished to remain neutral in order to be in a better position to pursue diplomatic solutions and to protect Western strategic and economic interests in Africa. (Page 1, Col. 6.)

title: 'HOW DO YOU LOOK WHEN I'M SOBER'
description: THE OXFORD BOOK OF AMERICAN LITERARY ANECDOTES Edited by Donald Hall. 360 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $15.95.

title: BUSINESS IS CUTTING INTO THE MARKET
description: WITHIN a short drive of Boston, a city with no shortage of higher education, are four new degree-granting programs that are not even affiliated with a college or university. They are sponsored by a hospital, a bank, a consulting firm and a computer manufacturer.

title: OPERETTA: 2D CAST IN 'PRINCE'
description: A second cast took over the four principal roles in Friday night's performance of ''The Student Prince'' at the City Opera.'' Without having seen the first set of singers, one suspects that the overall flavor of the production changed only in details.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Margiotta Case
description: Fraud and extortion, the prosecutor called it. Last November, Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman, was indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that he had defrauded the county and the Town of Hempstead by devising a scheme in which he and others received kickbacks on public insurance payments.

title: Andre De Shields In a New Play
description: Andre De Shields, who played the title role in the Broadway musical ''The Wiz'' and was in the original cast of ''Ain't Misbehavin','' will next appear in ''Risin' to the Love We Need,'' the play that will open the Stonewall Repertory Theater's second season on Sept. 11.

title: SOME SHOWS TO WATCH FOR
description: ''A Talent for Murder,'' by Jerome Chodorov and Norman Panama; with Claudette Colbert. Oct. 1, Biltmore. ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' the extravaganza adapted from the Charles Dickens novel and performed by the Royal Shakespeare Company. Oct. 3, Plymouth.

title: Sally Weaver Married To John M. Holahan
description: Sally Clark Weaver of Narberth, Pa., and John Michael Holahan were married yesterday in St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Middleport, N.Y. The Rev. Samuel J. Faiola performed the ceremony.

title: The Careful Shopper; Children's Outlet Opens in Scarsdale
description: Shoppers from this county are used to trekking to Nanuet, N.Y., or to Teaneck, N.J., for Joey's Children's Wear at 25 to 60 percent off manufacturer's suggested prices. That became unnecessary a month ago, however, when a new Joey's opened with its usual range of nationally advertised wares in the Scarsdale Park Mall on Central Avenue. Periodic specials take prices to below the routine discounts. Sizes are layette to 14 for girls (and preteen in designer jeans) and to 20 (or prep and student sizes of designer shirts) for boys and men's Lee and Levi jeans and corduroys.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS LAND PRESERVES FOR OIL DRILLING
description: Before the end of November, the Forest Service must recommend whether the Interior Department should approve or deny 145 applications from energy companies and speculators to lease more than 350,000 acres of the Washakie Wilderness for oil and gas exploration.

title: Suit Tests Yacht Union Rules By JOANNE A. FISHMAN
description: Tom Dreyfus, the former co-owner of the yacht Louisiana Crude, which was involved in alleged handicap irregularities during the 1981 Southern Ocean Racing Conference, has filed a $5 million damage suit against the United States Yacht Racing Union, the sport's national authority.

title: Stage View; RIVETING SUMMERTIME SHAKESPEARE; STRATFORD, Ct.  Iam greatly cheered to report that with ''Othello,'' now entering its final week at Stratford, Ct., the American Shakespeare Theater and director Peter Coe have suddenly and rather startlingly got hold of two things: a system and a show.
description: The system, described in a program note by the newly appointed Mr. Coe, promises to forget all about the gimmickry and even the lavish scenery so often associated with current mountings of Shakespeare and to focus on the tumbling, thundering, waterspill of speech. To this end, the acting area is now composed of the same neutrally colored but strangely warm wood that circles the auditorium; it is also compressed into quite a limited space, offering us Venice and Cyprus in a bandbox.

title: Connecticut Guide; by Eleanor Charles; A PORTRAIT OF ITALY
description: New Haven, which has a large Italian population, will be one of a handful of American cities to benefit from a major exhibition of Italy's cultural heritage.

title: AT HOME
description: THE woman across the hospital corridor whimpers in her sleep every night. ''Sarah?'' she says. ''Sarah, are you there?'' The nurse's shoes make a sucking sound on the linoleum. ''Of course, Sarah's here,'' she says. ''Go back to sleep.''

title: Helen Aline Kraft, Banker, Married
description: Helen Aline Kraft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren George Kraft of Cold Spring Harbor,L.I., was married there yesterday to Alan Roland Buckwalter 3d, son of Mary Ackerman Buckwalter of Flemington, N.J., and the late Mr. Buckwalter Jr. The Rev. T. Carlton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: 260 Employees of Ford Plant In Canada Are Struck by Fever
description: About 260 employees of a Ford Motor Company plant here have fallen ill, and officials are awaiting tests to determine whether the malady is a rare disease known as Pontiac fever.

title: Table of Contents; New York Times Magazine August 30, 1981
description: William Safire 10 On Language Cocktail Talk Russell Baker 14 Sunday Observer Egg on the Face Steve Lohr 20 The Great Oil Rush of the 80's Spurred by decontrol, Americans are prospecting for oil with a vengeance. Leslie Garis 24 Translating Fowles Into Film For a decade, the complexity of John Fowles's acclaimed novel, ''The French Lieutenant's Woman,'' defied filming.

title: WAYS TO SURVIVE WHEN TRAINS FAIL
description: DEEP within the confines of the Dobbs Ferry railroad station, the thoughts of a long-waiting Conrail commuter have been penned indelibly on a wall.

title: RISQUE COMEDY, 'PRIVATE LESSONS'
description: Remember the one about the French maid and the young master of the house? Do they still tell stories like that? You bet they do; in fact, they make them into movies. ''Private Lessons,'' which opened at neighborhood theaters Friday, is an adolescent's dream, the kind the Boy Scout manual told you a cold shower would help you forget. Ah, the days of Alex Portnoy's youth, and the middle-aged men who sat alone at the noontime showing at Loew's Paramount Friday earnestly trying to recall them.

title: GREENWICH PONDERS A RENTAL PANEL
description: GREENWICH LEGISLATION to establish a Fair Rent Commission here will be proposed here next month, 11 years after a similar proposal was resoundingly defeated. Indications are that the new proposal may fare no better than its predecessor, , even though the need for some kind of vehicle for arbitrating housing disputes is now generally acknowledged.

title: INTEREST BONUSES MAY IMPERIL BREAK ON TAXES, I.R.S. SAYS
description: The Internal Revenue Service warned today that it had ''substantial doubt'' that the tax-free savings incentives of the newly revised tax code would apply to the highinterest investment packages that banks are offering to attract customers.

title: IT'S SO NICE TO GO AWAY ON VACATION- OR IS IT?
description: MY husband and I just got back from our summer vacation. It was terrific, thank you, but I can't prove it with postcards, slides, mementos or bumper stickers. This year we stayed at home on the Island, and we didn't regret it a bit.

title: 20-TON EXPLOSIVES SHIPMENT TO LIBYA LINKED TO EX-AGENT
description: Twenty tons of plastic explosives were secretly and illegally shipped from the United States to Libya in 1977 for use in the manufacture of bombs for terrorism, in a deal organized by a former agent for the Central Intelligence Agency, according to Federal investigators and participants in the transaction.

title: The Week in Business; AN ASSAULT ON REAGANOMICS
description: The President's economic program, hailed just a few weeks ago on passage as the greatest economic innovation since the New Deal, was under attack last week from liberal and conservative economists alike. They described an unresolved dichotomy in the Reagan camp between the economic-growth goal of the supply-siders and the tight money and economic-contraction policies of the monetarists. The Reagan program received a resounding no-confidence vote in the place it might be expected to be most welcome - on Wall Street, where the stock and bond markets were sagging.

title: Theory Z
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE NAZI QUESTION An Essay on the Interpretations of National Socialism (1922-1975). By Pierre Ay,coberry. Translated by Robert Hurley. 257 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: BRADSHAW PASSES HELP SINK GIANTS, 31-6
description: The Steelers looked wonderful, especially with Terry Bradshaw passing for two touchdowns and Cliff Stoudt, his replacement, for two more. The Giants looked awful. Coach Ray Perkins said so. The Giants' players said so, those who would say anything.

title: At Home; by Shelby Moorman Howatt
description: THE woman across the hospital corridor whimpers in her sleep every night. ''Sarah?'' she says. ''Sarah, are you there?'' The nurse's shoes make a sucking sound on the linoleum. ''Of course, Sarah's here,'' she says. ''Go back to sleep.'' The whispered exchange in the darkness invites fear into my room that has become as palpable as a presence. The presence - particularly vivid when my fever is high - has a round, female form. Its borders frame thinly stretched cellophane etched with ghostly children, family, friends, like an overexposed photographic slide. The barely perceived figures do not look at me as they recede into a vast and milky distance, and one night, echoing the unknown woman's cry, I call to them. ''Laura, John, Lee - are you there?'' A sucking noise in the hall, and then a gentle voice from my doorway. ''They're here,'' the nurse says. ''Go to sleep.''

title: ELK GROVE VILLAGE, Ill.
description: THE American flag and the McDonald's flag fly high over the expressway running through the backyard of Hamburger University in this suburban Chicago town. Inside, McDonald's franchisers and company managers learn skills to reinforce what the golden arches of 614,000 similar square brick buildings in mostly suburban and rural communities have come to symbolize: predictability in atmosphere and taste, or, as McDonald's founder, Ray Kroc, put it, ''the gospel of quality, service, cleanliness and value'' that are as American as, well, McDonald's hot apple pie.

title: THE CORPORATE HALLS OF IVY GROW
description: WHEN Jonathan S. Kamkwalala, an investment banker from Malawi, decided to return to school for a graduate degree in management, he asked his supervisor to recommend the best educational program. His answer was brief: Try an American corporation.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Where Labor and Life are Cheap
description: Slavery is usually thought of as a pre-modern style of political abuse -but that's not entirely accurate, according to a report under study by the United Nations Human Rights Commission. The document, based on an inquiry by the Anti-Slavery Society of London, says that in Mauritania, a poor nation of 1.5 million on the western end of the Sahara, there are at least 100,000 slaves and 300,000 serfs and exslaves, subject to severe discrimination.

title: Reality News; Studio 54
description: The 17-story office building and adjoining two-story theater building at 246-256 West 54th Street that houses ''Studio 54,'' the discotheque, has been sold by JISA Associates, of which Steven Rubell was a principal, to Philip Pilevsky, one of the more active purchasers of Manhattan properties in recent years.

title: LUGANO
description: To the Editor:

title: Martin Drives Temujin To Fox Stake Victory
description: Temujin, winner of the first heat in a record 1:54.4, broke stride in the second today but rallied to win the 55th running of the Fox Stake, the world's richest harness race for 2-year-old pacers.

title: DANCE: TAP SHOW IN A LOFT
description: It was as if Andrea Levine, who performed with five ''friends'' on Friday at a loft theater on West 22d Street, had said to herself on some rainy day in the attic, ''Why don't I put on a show?'' She did, and because they were good performers it came close to working.

title: The World in Summary; In Poland, It's All Prime Time
description: The two-day printers' strike seems to have been only a preliminary round in a battle between Polish Communists and workers for control of the press. Solidarity, the independent trade union, last week demanded editorial control, or else, over television coverage of the union's first national congress, a world-class event opening Saturday with Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., among the invited guests.

title: Camera; SOME PRACTICAL GADGETS TO KEEP IN THE BAG
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- William K. Longcor is a freelance photographer and writer.

title: Investing; THE GROWING APPEAL OF C.D. FUTURES
description: F OR many commodities speculators, the new futures in certificates of deposit are all they ever wanted. Offering a potentially big return on a small investment, large and swift swings in prices and widely understood market dynamics, trading in these futures is currently growing faster than any other.

title: Art; WORKS BY 84 AREA ARTISTS IN KATONAH EXHIBITION
description: KATONAH THE Katonah Gallery, at 28 Bedford Road here, has used all available wall space, plus extra partitions and much of the floor, to mount what it calls its ''more or less annual show for area artists.'' As a result, more than 200 juried paintings, drawings, prints, photographs and sculptures by 84 protagonists will be vying for attention through Sept. 13. Most of the works are for sale.

title: Barbara A. Craemer Wed To John Griffiths Howard
description: Barbara Ann Craemer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Craemer Jr. of Brookfield Center, Conn., was married yesterday to John Griffiths Howard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Howard of Washington. Comdr. John Bevins, Chaplains Corps, U.S.N., and Capt. Alfred Saeger, Chaplains Corps, U.S.N., performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the United States Coast Guard Memorial Chapel in New London, Conn.

title: AN AUTHOR WHO COMBINES TWO CULTURES
description: Bette Bao Lord tells the story of the Chinese woman who was about to be mugged and cried out, ''Don't come any closer or I'll kill myself.''

title: art; ART'S ROLE IN GOVERNMENT ARCHITECTURE IS EXPLORE
description: HAUPPAUGE THE commissioning of monumental sculpture has long been the province of government. Government agencies, after all, frequently construct the type of architectural spaces that large-scale works demand.

title: FOREIGN SETTINGS AND DOMESTIC SCENES
description: STILL MISSING By Beth Gutcheon. 364 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $11.95. FINAL CUT By Pamela Chais. 304 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95. BRICK ALLEY By David Chacko. 276 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $11.95.

title: THE ULTIMATE LUXURY
description: Nowhere in the world is luxury traditionally so untrammeled as it is in the haute couture salons. Handwork, fabrics of surpassing beauty and the availability of skilled artisans make the clothes that emerge from them approach an art form.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Federal Theater Plans Louis Armstrong Show
description: ''Louis,'' a musical based on the early career of Louis Armstrong, will open the 1981-82 season of the New Federal Theater, 466 Grand Street, with a 12-performance run beginning Sept. 18 in the Harry deJur Playhouse. Directed by Gilbert Moses, the production has book and lyrics by Don Evans and music by Michael Renzi; choreography is by Billy Wilson.

title: The Nation in Summary; Less Heat on State University
description: In the case of Louisiana's universities, the Reagan Administration decided last week, separate and less unequal is better than separate and unequal - but also better than the Carter White House's demand that duplicate programs at black and white schools be eliminated and that some black and white schools be merged.

title: EXCERPTS FROM POLICY SPEECH ON SOUTHERN AFRICA
description: Following are excerpts from a speech delivered today in Honolulu by Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. The prepared text was made available here by the State Department.

title: Theater in Review; A COUP: LIZARDI'S IBSEN
description: EAST FARMINGDALE WHEN he was a junior high school student in Puerto Rico in the early 1950's, Joseph Lizardi was swept away by the passion of a play he was reading - ''La Comedia del Amor.'' Henrik Ibsen wrote it, and the boy had been told that the playwright was called ''the father of modern drama.'' He immersed himself in Ibsen's plays to find out why.

title: CABARET: STEPHANE DONET OF FRANCE
description: Since Maurice Chevalier came to the United States 50 years ago, Americans have proved to be easy marks for singers with French accents. Lucienne Boyer, Edith Piaf, Georges Ulmer, Charles Trenet, Charles Aznavour charmed their way across the ocean in the wake of Mr. Chevalier.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 3 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 2 2 17 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 5 5 10 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) The Rev. Stephen Foote performed the ceremony.

title: Topics; MOVING AROUND THE CITY; Mugging Premiums
description: In recent years, some states have set up programs to provide payments to crime victims. Now private enterprise senses opportunity. The American Bankers Insurance Company of Miami is marketing mugging insurance.

title: AFTER SUMMER'S SUPERHEROES COMES A SERIO-COMIC AUTUMN
description: The cartoon superheroes we've been watching all summer have finally zoomed back to the planets they came from, making room for the more substantial films coming up. The coming season looks like it will be the movies' serious one. Last year's somber hit, ''Ordinary People,'' made such a successful September debut that a number of similarly weighty-sounding projects are now scheduled for the autumn of 1981.

title: WALKER: MOVING UP IN CLASS
description: time fullback for the University of Georgia last year, a junior whose college career began on the junior varsity and was interrupted by injury. His job was to help create a hole wide enough for Herschel Walker to run through. ''It was an honor,'' Stewart said.

description: The marriage of Kathleen Courtenay Stone to Edward Wood Dunham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Dunham of Lyme, Conn., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence H. Stone, parents of the bride, in Wellesley Hills, Mass. The Rev. Ward Smith performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: STATE PONDERS SCHOOL RULES ON OUTSIDE INFLUENCE
description: HARTFORD THE State Department of Education has recommended that the State Board of Education adopt a policy aimed at preventing religious and politically conservative groups from exerting undue influence over public schools.

title: Maureen Freeman W- ed To Terence O'Brien Jr- .

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: I must confess that Mr. Rosenthal's factual observations are correct. China is poor, has unfortunately arid or untillable land. There is a small transportation network.

title: NORTHERN ROCK BARNACLE; Balanus balanoides
description: Size: To one inch. Color: White, often discolored by algae. Where found: Coastal waters throughout the Island; on rocks, piers and pilings, often in enormous numbers.

title: REAGAN CUTS WORRY HEAD OF A CHARITY
description: The new executive vice president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York says he is concerned about the likely effect of the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts on ''human beings and the human condition.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Amtrak Trims Its Service
description: For all its warnings about the ruin that Reaganomics would bring, Amtrak will apparently be able to keep most of the nation's remaining passenger trains rolling after all. The agency's executive board last week voted to eliminate several runs that weren't breaking even and rearrange other routes, but most of the system was left intact.

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: I follow the current writing on China and can truthfully say Mr. Rosenthal's articles make a substantive contribution to the literature - an artful, yet unpretentious, blend of keen personal observation and thoughtful conclusions about China's destiny, and the future of Chinese-American relations.

title: MISSISSIPPI COLLEGE ENROLLS FIRST MAN
description: The Mississippi University for Women, the first public college in the nation established solely for women, became the last to break with that policy this week when, under protest, it enrolled its first male student.

title: Ann E. McLarty, C.H. Knauss Wed
description: Ann Elizabeth McLarty, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Robert Neil McLarty of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married there yesterday to Charles Howland Knauss, son of Robert Lynn Knauss of Houston and Barbara Brown Knauss of Ann Arbor. The Rev. Gordon Jones Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Follow-Up on the News; A Victory, of Sorts
description: Last December, in another case with political overtones, the campaign committee that had worked unsuccessfully to re-elect Senator George McGovern in South Dakota found itself in some legal difficulty, too.

title: Buckle Deflects Bullet Fired at Police Officer
description: An off-duty police officer escaped serious injury in Brooklyn last night when a bullet fired at him was deflected by his belt buckle, the police reported.

title: Chinaglia-Weisweiler Split Widening
description: There was a time early in the North American Soccer League season that Giorgio Chinaglia and Coach Hennes Weisweiler of the Cosmos were inseparable. They had a harmonious relationship and satisfied their egos by never failing to compliment each other to outsiders.

title: INDISPENSABLE NUISANCE
description: THE SPECULATOR Bernard M. Baruch in Washington, 1917-1965. By Jordan A. Schwarz. Illustrated. 679 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: University of North Carolina Press. $27.50

title: EVA LE GALLIENNE IS 'HOME' IN WESTPORT
description: WHEN ''To Grandmother's House We Go'' closed on Broadway in March, after a mere two-months' run, its imposing setting - a living room in a grand old house just outside Hartford - was shipped for storage to the Westport Country Playhouse in logical anticipation of the play's summer afterlife.

title: Around The World; New Zealanders Protest Pretoria's Rugby Team
description: Several thousand anti-apartheid demonstrators clashed with policemen in riot gear today as South Africa's touring Springboks rugby team played a New Zealand national team.

title: Politics; COHALAN INFLUENCE TESTED
description: THE strong influence of Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan in the County Legislature will be tested in the Sept. 10 Democratic and Republican primaries as three of his most vocal critics face contests in which their political careers will be on the line.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Fall of a Falcon
description: With considerable fanfare, and not a little fluttering of feathers, the peregrine falcons returned to Manhattan last year. They were released in an effort to rebuild their population in New York City, where - as in the rest of the Eastern United States - they had been wiped out by the effects of DDT.

title: Ann Lindeman Bride Of Donald C. Monsees
description: Ann Bernice Lindeman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Lindeman of Tenafly, N.J., was married there yesterday to Donald Charles Monsees, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Monsees of Red Bank, N.J. The Rev. John L. Fredriksen performed the ceremony at Trinity Lutheran Church.

description: CALI, Colombia The stone facade of the corporate headquarters of Carvajal S.A. looks imposing enough, and the polished conference tables inside suggest there's serious business going on.

title: THE OMINOUS SONGS OF THE YOUNG RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: RIVALS AT FLUSHING MEADOWS
description: Bud Collins, a frequent tennis commentator for NBC-TV and PBS, is a columnist for The Boston Globe. By Bud Collins Could you envision Bjorn Borg as Gary Cooper without a horse? Or, what about John McEnroe as Lee Van Cleef minus a black hat, challenging Borg and the sheriffs of tennis to gun it out on the mean green pavement at Flushing Meadows. The recent fall of the Italian Government got less attention than John McEnroe's villainy at Wimbledon and his near hanging in the British press, or than the subsequent defeat of Bjorn Borg at the hands of that same John McEnroe. So you don't have to be an old-time film buff to get the idea that what everybody wants to see now in the annual rerun of an Eastern melodrama called the United States Open Tennis Championships is another showdown -Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe fighting it out in the end.

title: Power Line Problems Cause Short Blackouts in the West
description: A power line interruption in Arizona caused widespread blackouts in California and Nevada this afternoon.

title: HELLO L.A.? MIAMI? HONG KONG? COME IN TO THE CONFERENCE ROOM
description: T WO months before he was elected President, after shaking countless hands and meeting thousands of people face-to-face, Ronald Reagan addressed an estimated 50,000 campaign workers, with a ringing recruiting and morale-building speech.

title: A DELIGHTFUL SURPRISE IN HARRISON
description: IN the middle of Harrison's industrial area stands a square white building, unremarkable apart from the brown and white striped awnings and a sign identifying it as a restaurant named Le Saucier.

title: SHERRY TO CHAMPAGNE STATE'S WINERIES PRODUCE IT
description: WHEN the subject of domestic wine comes up, most New Jerseyans think of California or New York. Yet there are seven wineries holding plenary licenses in their own state with no legal limits on their output.

title: STEELWORKERS' DISSIDENT BOWING OUT
description: "The job is so important to them they can't afford to lose it," James Balanoff, steelworker and union officer, said not long ago about the kind of union man he calls a porkchopper. "The money. The position. The Trips, payoffs, to Europe or Japan. They sit silent. Get along and go along, that's the rule. That's the difference between them and me."

title: STRAVINSKY, HAYDN DOMINATE SEASON
description: One way to look at the deluge of upcoming musical events that constitutes the 1981-2 classical music season in New York is to consider what it is not. It is not threatened by any looming labor crisis, for instance, like the one that disrupted the Metropolitan Opera last season - and which has had a ripple effect on this season, in that some of the Met's plans had to be shifted around because of lost rehearsal time and new productions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In South Africa, the region's dominant country, it is not our task to choose between black and white.

title: No Headline
description: In last Sunday's Westchester Guide, the dates for the Israeli Fair and Festival were incorrect. The event will be held next Sunday and Monday, Sept. 6 and 7, from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. at the Monsey Jewish Center in Rockland County.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS SAY 240 ANGOLANS DIED IN 5-DAY INCURSION
description: South Africa said today that it had destroyed Angolan radar installations and killed at least 240 Angolan Government troops in its assaults this week in southern Angola.

title: COMING ATTRACTIONS IN POPULAR MUSIC
description: The Rolling Stones, who have not toured since 1978, will be performing at various large and small venues in the New York area this fall, probably in October.

title: Marsha Mason to Star In Love Canal TV Film
description: Marsha Mason will star in ''Lois Gibbs and the Love Canal,'' a made-for-television film scheduled to be produced in November for broadcast on CBS-TV.

title: Justine Paul Wed To Denis Hynes
description: Justine Anne Ghislaine Paul, daughter of Franck Paul of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and the late Mrs. Paul, was married there yesterday to Denis J. Hynes, son of Mrs. John J. Hynes of Huntington, Md., and the late Mr. Hynes. The Rev. Joseph Lafontant performed the ceremony at Sacre Coeur Roman Catholic Church.

title: o; THE GREAT OIL RUSH OF THE EIGHTIES
description: Steve Lohr is a reporter for The Times. By Steve Lohr The heavy steel floor of the oil rig vibrates, and the diesel motor groans as it drives giant winches and pulleys to hoist another 90-foot length of drill pipe up above the opening of the well. Two filthy young ''roughnecks'' in hard hats, jeans, flannel shirts and boots struggle to guide the 900-pound section of carbon steel into place - and to keep themselves in place on the rig floor slick with mud. They do not talk to each other; they shout, because of the noise. An oil rig is a giant monument to Rube Goldberg, and the young laborers on it work in exhausting, perpetual motion, pushing at it here, pulling there, adjusting here, readjusting there. ''This pace goes on around the clock,'' yells Dale H. Shoemaker, a lean, crisp 28-year-old petroleum engineer for Standard Oil Company (Indiana), ''... 24 hours a day, seven days a week.'' But the roughnecks don't complain. They're making as much as $60,000 a year.

title: The World; Canada Asks U.S. Help In Rash of Killings
description: Canadian authorities have begun working with officials in the United States in an effort to track down a suspect in a rash of disappearances and killings of young people since Christmas, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: ICE-NINE, RUSSIAN STYLE
description: POLYWATER By Felix Franks. 208 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $15.

title: UTILITY-BILL BOYCOTT PLANNED
description: BRICKTOWN HOPING to make its weight felt during the coming bid by Jersey Central Power and Light for a $238.5 million rate increase, a coalition of activist groups is calling for a bill-payment boycott.

title: THE EMPHASIS IS ON THE AVANT-GARDE
description: It's been called just about everything. But whether you refer to it as ''experimental,'' ''post-modern'' or simply ''new,'' avant-garde dance will be the keynote of the dance year in New York. The dance that grew from traditional American modern dance in the 1960's, when choreographers became concerned with everyday movement and activities performed in any space that would hold them, and set to anything from wolf howls to silence, has come into its own of late. It's not that ballet will be underrepresented. The New York City, American Ballet Theater and Joffrey Ballets, for instance, will all have their day. And the opening in early February of the Joyce theater, a new Manhattan dance space, will be a major event of the season. But avant-garde dance is in for a year of exceptional vigor and variety.

title: THE ROAD TO PREDICTABILITY IS PAVED WITH COVENANTS
description: In one development in Denver, there is a restriction on leaving garage doors open. In a suburban Maryland communty, houses must be painted earthen colors. In some Levitt subdivisions, homeowners may not put up fences in their front yards.

title: Julia Merriam Bride in Noroton of Kenneth Kamp
description: Julia Clapp Merriam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Thayer Merriam Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Kenneth Kamp, son of Dr. Robert L. Kamp and Mary Kamp of Beulah, Mich. The Rev. H. Lawrence Whittemore Jr., an Episcopal minister and dean of the Cathedral Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, Pa., performed the ceremony at the Noroton (Conn.)

title: MAILBOX
description: To the Sports Editor: Having played third base in 1919 for Black River Academy in Ludlow, Vt., I believe I am qualified to criticize the manner in which pinchhitters are used by major league managers.

title: U.S. BEATS BRITAIN 15-9, IN WALKER CUP
description: The United States lost three of four morning matches, but Jodie Mudd and four other Americans won afternoon singles matches today that gave the team a 15-9 victory over Britain in the 28th Walker Cup amateur golf competition.
