title: Joan Brooks Jersey Bride
description: Joan Kingsland Brooks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Benjamin Brooks Jr., of Cresskill, N.J., was married yesterday to James Clay Crumbliss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Crumbliss Jr. of Lookout Mountain, Tenn. The Rev. Roger Weir performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: MORIBUND BONDS: HOW THEY HURT CITIES AND STATES
description: T HE bridges, the roads and the tunnels, like so many concrete ribbons, tie America together. And everywhere, the power generators, the industrial parks, the sewage treatment plants and the recreation areas bring life and economic vitality. But these municipal edifices are under assault, not by age or neglect, but by something as distant and complex as the municipal bond market.

title: Connecticut Housing; WEST HAVEN SALES BEGIN TO ACCELERATE
description: WEST HAVEN DURING a recent spell of cool, dry weather, Ed Warner, a highschool art teacher and metalsmith, donned his work clothes - a worn undershirt and denim shorts - and resumed unloading boxes and refinishing the furniture in his plant-filled living room.

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: To a capitalist whose ancestral roots go back centuries to imperial China, Mr. Rosenthal's articles were thought-provoking and delightful. Yes, a little bit of self-doubt and self-mockery is imperative in rendering a judgment on China, after a visit of only four weeks.

title: Major News in Summary; Bad News With A Long Fuse
description: Though he has been accused of many things, no one is likely to charge Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. with failing to put a good face on bad news. Convicted in court of bribery and conspiracy, the New Jersey Democrat was condemned by his peers last week for conduct ''ethically repugnant to the point of warranting his expulsion from the United States Senate.'' Nevertheless, Mr. Williams pronounced himself ''gratified'' that in recommending the harshest possible punishment, the Select Committee on Ethics asked the Senate to postpone its imposition until a Federal judge ruled on his appeal.

title: Television Week
description: Indian Film The filmmaking industry in India is the world's largest - in any given year the country might produce 800 movies.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: 1976), leader of the Chinese Revolution, that goes a long way toward demystifying the ''inscrutable'' man and in so doing throws much light on a vast nation in modern times. Our reviewer Stanley Karnow called it ''journalistic yet reliable, lively and readable.''

title: OPEN SEASON SOON IN ITALY FOR TERRORISTS, POLITICIANS
description: Parliament has shut down for the annual Ferragosto holidays when everybody - even terrorists - goes to the beaches or mountains. The new Prime Minister, Giovanni Spadolini, who likes to strike the pose of steadfast captain, took only two days off, but he told his Cabinet to be back in three weeks and ordered the Ministers of Finance and Budget to stay close to Rome.

title: About Westchester
description: NORTH SALEM THE canoes were aluminum and the dirt parking area near the water was filled with late-model sedans and station wagons. But the lake, green with the reflection of surrounding poplars, looked as it might have years ago, when there were no cars, and when any boats surely would have been made of bark.

title: CONNECTICUT PRICES ON THE INCREASE
description: HARTFORD THE end of a balmy August, too cool to require air-conditioning but still too warm for winter heating to begin, hardly seems the proper time to think about energy bills. But utility prices are going up virtually everywhere in Connecticut.

title: AWACS: WINNABLE BUT NOT WORTH IT
description: .4,2,294.4,0,294.4,2WASHINGTON - Every August our legislators recess and head for parts known and unknown to escape the sweltering heat of the nation's capitol. When they return this year, things will really start to heat up as Congress battles the Reagan Administration over a host of military issues: the MX, the B-1 and stealth bombers and others. But the first and perhaps for President Reagan the most crucial battle is likely to be over the proposed sale to Saudi Arabia of Awacs aircraft, tanker aircraft, Sidewinder air-to-air missiles and fuel tanks for F-15 fighter planes.

title: MEMOIRS OF A NEW CHINA HAND
description: A.M. Rosenthal's articles, ''Memoirs of a New China Hand'' (Part I, July 19; Part II, July 26), were the first I came across following my own return from China (after lecturing at the Academia Sinica for three weeks). Judging from his remarks, we must have arrived within days, or a week, after his departure.

title: FLORIO AND KEAN GET THE RACE INTO HIGHER GEAR
description: TRENTON THE race for Governor of New Jersey began in earnest last week as the two major-party candidates, Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of Runnemede, and Thomas H. Kean, Republican of Livingston, met in their first debate.

title: JEWELRY OF SEMIPRECIOUS STONES
description: Marieluisa Stern has been designing oversize but not overpowering jewelry and belts for the last five years, mostly using hand-cut, hand-hammered metals. Her line, called Stigi, has been sold in stores all around the world and featured in all the fashion magazines.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Choreographing for Broadway musicals or - heaven forfend - the operetta is looked down upon in some ballet circles. So what is a serious choreographer like Eliot Feld doing in ''Song of Norway,'' a frothy look at the life and music of Edvard Grieg? He's following in the footsteps of George Balanchine, for one thing, whose choreography enlivened the original production in 1944.

title: PAUL MAZURSKY BREWS A 'TEMPEST'
description: It used to be a nice peaceful retreat on a quiet residential block in the West Village where a few small children playing desultory sidewalk games constituted major activity. But then Hollywood came to Horatio Street.

title: IT'S IN THE BAG
description: The seemingly countless odds and ends women store in their handbags have long been the butt of jokes. And since many women have assumed careers, the number of things they back along has increased: In addition to personal items--makeup, glasses, gloves, perfume and the like--working women must now tote the physical trappings of their jobs.

title: No Headline
description: 14 INJURED IN PARIS HOTEL BLAST: A chef at the Intercontinental Hotel surveying the damage in main lobby after a bomb exploded yesterday.

title: A POLITICAL EDUCATION
description: ASKING FOR TROUBLE Autobiography of a Banned Journalist.By Donald Woods. Illustrated. 373 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95.

title: Westchester Guide; 2D LEHMAN SEASON
description: Lehman College for the Performing Arts enters its second season with an impressive schedule beginning in mid-October. Divided into five categories for subscription purposes, guest artists include the Boris Goldovsky Opera Company (Oct. 30) and Henny Youngman (Nov. 15).

title: Water Emergency in Peking
description: Plagued by the worst water shortage in 32 years, the Peking authorities have declared an emergency, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: PROFS NIX PREZ FILES
description: The August dog days, usually a somnolent time on any university campus, this year witnessed a vigorous controversy at Duke University, where president Terry Sanford let it be known that he was negotiating with Richard M. Nixon for the acceptance of a presidential library and that he hoped to sign a contract within a week.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE on-again, off-again plan to rebuild the burned-out Garden State Park race track in Cherry Hill has won some support from an Assembly committee that is concerned about the financial future of that area of the state. But committee members indicated there might be no action until after the November elections.

title: Fluoridation Plan Is Called a Hoax
description: New Jersey teachers will soon have to add a fourth R - for ''Rinse and Swish'' - if Project Supertooth, the most recent hoax to be foisted on parents of children in grades K-6, is allowed to continue.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Nixon Library: Duke's Dilemma
description: If ever a man was without honor in his own alma mater, it's Richard M. Nixon. Indeed, Duke University, whose law school class of 1937 included the President-to-be, seems to have made rebuking Mr. Nixon a habit.

title: Penalty to Increase In Driving Offense
description: ALBANY (UPI) - Legislation effective tomorrow sets a mandatory jail term of seven to 180 days and a fine of $200 to $500 for motorists convicted of driving while their license is suspended or revoked because of an alcohol-related offense. The Motor Vehicle Commissioner, Leslie Foschio, said the penalty would also apply to motorists caught driving while their license was suspended or revoked for refusing to submit to a Breathalyzer test.

title: North Korean Visits Soviet
description: The North Korean Prime Minister, Li Jong Ok, stopped off in Moscow today on his way to Syria for an official visit, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: CHASE STUDIES TRUCK SALES
description: A new family of light pickup trucks will be the domestic auto industry's strongest defense against imports, Chase Econometrics, an economics forecasting concern, said today.

title: SHOOTINGS BY A ROOKIE STIR NASHVILLE
description: Joyce Faye Allen had been on the Nashville Police Force for three months and had every reason to expect a good career. Instead, she and her partner got involved in a robbery in progress, she shot three innocent persons, one fatally, and one other person was killed. She is off the force before her career ever properly started and her partner faces a hearing on whether he behaved as required.

title: A BOOK FAIR IS PALNNED FOR EXILES FROM SOVIET
description: Just about a week after the end of the Moscow Book Fair, which will run from Wednesday through Sept. 8, The Association of American Publishers and the Fund for Free Expression will sponsor a smaller but related affair of their own. Named the Third Moscow Book Fair Reception in Exile, it will be held at the New York Public Library on Sept. 14, and its purpose will be to honor Soviet writers who have emigrated or been exiled from the Soviet Union. At least 17 of them are expected to be present.

title: Big Kids' Camp
description: Little kids go to basketball camps run by big-name players in the sport. Big kids, among them big names in pro basketball, go to a camp at run by Pete Newell. The two-week camp, attended by 14 pros, all centers and forwards, which ended Friday at Dominguez Hills College in Carson, Calif., has no name. Newell does not charge a fee.

title: ANALYSTS READY FOR A PRICE RISE
description: The fixed-income market opens today with a ray of hope in the wake of a sharp price drop that lifted yields to record levels last Monday afternoon and Tuesday morning.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE. By John Irving. 401 pages. A Henry Robbins Book/E.P. Dutton. $15.50.

title: Arab Girl Dies in Blast In Nablus Marketplace
description: Explosives inside a cart blew up today in the occupied West Bank town of Nablus, killing an 8-year-old Arab girl and wounding 14 people in the open-air market, an Israeli military spokesman said.

title: NEW METHOD HELPS ATTACK CANCER CELLS
description: The 67-year-old man had lymphoma, a form of cancer. The disease was tightening its grip, attacking his skin and his lymphatic system. Chemicals and radiation were failing.

title: STUDYING THE TEEN MARKET
description: A NEW Simmons survey of American teen-agers shows that only 26 percent agree with the statement that "advertising presents a true picture of products of well-known companies."

title: PATROITS SET BACK REDSKINS BY 19-10
description: John Smith kicked four field goals, and Matt Cavanaugh threw a 5-yard touchdown pass in the fourth quarter to lead the New England Patriots to a 19-10 exhibition victory over the Washington Redskins yesterday in Foxboro, Mass.

title: WHEN THE NEST FILLS UP AGAIN
description: W HATEVER happened to the Empty Nest Syndrome, which struck when the the young chicks flew off leaving the old birds alone? It is rapidly being replaced by the Not-So-Empty Nest Syndrome that occurs when the chicks flock back. Symptoms include ruffled feathers.

title: DISNEY ATTEMPTS TO REVERSE MOVIE DIVISION'S PROFIT SLIDE
description: The executive offices of Walt Disney Productions are located along streets called Mickey Mouse Avenue and Dopey Drive, named for some of the studio's most famous characters.

title: KOCH JOINS DEMOCRATIC RIVALS IN FIRST DEBATE
description: In their first confrontation of the Democratic mayoral primary campaign, Mayor Koch and Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro disagreed heatedly yesterday about whether the Mayor had saved the city from fiscal insolvency and whether the city should grant tax abatements to real estate developers.

title: Girl Electrocuted
description: A 13-year-old girl was electrocuted when she tried to grab a karate weapon caught on high-tension wires and touched one of the wires, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Friday incorrectly described the pub- lic schedule this summer of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey. Senator Williams has been making speeches, attending pub- lic functions in his district and per- forming various constituent services.

title: Marla Glanzer Is Married To Lawrence H. Curtis
description: Marla Glanzer, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Murray Glanzer of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel to Lawrence Henry Curtis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Curtis of Massapequa Park, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal performed the ceremony.

title: CITY SEEKS TO BLUNT A U.S. HOUSING REGULATION
description: Seventeen Representatives from New York City are seeking to blunt the effect of a new regulation designed to restrict public housing to families with the lowest incomes.

title: Pinero Captures Swiss Open Golf
description: Manuel Pinero of Spain rallied from a seven-stroke deficit, then birdied the first hole of a suddendeath playoff to win the $105,000 Swiss Open golf tournament today.

title: Market Place; Kroehler Gains Despite Woes
description: THE stock of the Kroehler Mfg. Company was a bear market curiosity last week. A potential candidate for delisting by the New York Stock Exchange, the Naperville, Ill., furniture manufacturer managed to establish a 12-month high on Thursday and again last Friday at 9 3/8 during a week in which the market generally was sliding to its lowest level in a year. The Kroehler stock closed Friday at 8 7/8, down 1/8.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Cyanamid Company has named Gordon D. Sterling president of its Formica Corporation subsidiary.

title: Natural Gas, Unnatural Cost
description: Natural gas regulation: just mentioning the subject makes Congressmen uneasy. The last time Congress rewrote the laws that limit natural gas prices, it took more than a year of bitter struggle. And the result, the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978, is badly flawed. Unless Congress and the Reagan Administration can clean it up, there might well be significant losses to the economy and an even nastier political battle in 1984.

title: C.A.R.E. for Athletes
description: The National Football League Players Association and the National Conference of Black Lawyers have joined with Sports for the People to create the Center for Athletes Rights and Education, called C.A.R.E. The project, funded by a $250,000 grant from the United States Department of Education, plus other grants, is committed to defending the educational and legal rights of high school and college athletes.

title: Moving Along
description: To hear Jody Johnson, an 18-year-old pitcher, tell it, he has been improving ever since the day last September when he accidentally shot himself in the head with a .22 caliber pistol. Johnson is currently pitching for Lynchburg, a Mets farm club. He has been asked to attend the instructional league in September.

title: 'STRONGEST' JETS IN YEARS PROMPT MICHAEL'S OPTIMISM
description: In some ways it had been a harrowing night for the Jets. But this morning, with the exhibition season over and Richard Todd, the quarterback, apparently healthy, Coach Walt Michaels finally relaxed and contemplated the opening game next Sunday at Buffalo.

title: MORE ACTIVITY SEEN FOR NEW ISSUES
description: Activity promises to pick up this week in the new-issue market for corporate and municipal bonds, following last week's promised lull resulting from high interest rates. Meanwhile, the Treasury will continue to tap the market with a variety of short-term bill sales.

title: White Sox Get Koosman
description: The White Sox acquired Jerry Koosman from the Minnesota Twins today for two minor league infielders, a player to be named later and about $250,000.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A TALK ON WRITING

title: MARSCHALK GETS STEEL - A PEPPERMINT DRINK
description: For some time now, the advertising for Heublein Inc.'s Smirnoff, Yukon Jack and Arrow Cordials - a truly heady mixture - has been in the steady hands of the Marschalk Company.

title: Panning Out
description: John Davidson has a financial interest in a gold mine in Dawson City in the Yukon. But when the New York Ranger goalie wants to relax, he gets together with several friends and they drive to Finley Creek in British Columbia, about 30 miles from his home, and spend the weekend fishing and panning for gold.

title: BONDS IN 'STING' TAKEN AT BANK, AUTHORITIES SAY
description: The $50 million in negotiable bonds recovered by Federal agents in a sting operation Friday at a midtown hotel were ''picked up by someone'' on Aug. 20 from a counter in a Wall Street bank where a messenger had left them unattended briefly, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: MYTHS ON MINIMUMS IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 18 Trade Schools To Give Job Data
description: Eighteen private trade schools in New York City have agreed to provide students with information on the schools' success in finding jobs for their graduates, Robert Abrams, the State Attorney General, announced.

title: 6 MORE HELD IN VIENNA SYNAGOGUE RAID
description: Six more people were arrested today in connection with a terrorist attack on a synagogue that spilled out into Vienna's old Jewish quarter, killing two people.

title: Jazz Ensemble to Reunite
description: The New Jazz at the Public will open its fall season Sept. 18-19 at the Public Theater with a reunion of the Revolutionary Ensemble. The ensemble, which disbanded in 1977, will be celebrating its 10th anniversary with this one-time-only reunion. Its members are Leroy Jekins, violinist and violist; Jerome Cooper, percussionist, and Sirone, bassist.

title: MANY DISABLED STILL NOT PLACED BY CITY SCHOOLS
description: The New York City school system, under court order to accommodate handicapped children of all kinds, is grappling with one of the most complex challenges it has faced.

title: SALVADOR OPPOSITION PLANS DIPLOMATIC DRIVE FOR NEW SUPPORT
description: Cheered by their recognition as a ''representative political force'' by France and Mexico, El Salvador's guerrilla-led opposition groups are now planning a diplomatic offensive to rally support for their cause among other Western and third-world countries.

title: CRIME IS TOP ISSUE IN RACES ON COAST
description: The signing by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. last week of a legislative proposal to seek voters' permission to spend $495 million on new state prisons was added proof that a soaring crime rate has pushed inflation, taxes, and the costs of fuel and housing aside. Now it has become the paramount issue facing California's politicians as they gear up for the 1982 elections.

title: AS PRIMARY CAMPAIGN WINDS DOWN, CANDIDATES GO WHERE THE VOTERS ARE
description: Entering the last days of the 1981 primary campaign, candidates both familiar and not so familiar fanned out across New York City over the weekend to rouse a mostly languorous voting public.

title: MOHAMMED ALI RAJAI, 47, HARD-LINE PRESIDENT OF IRAN
description: Mohammed Ali Rajai, who attributed a deformed foot to torture suffered as a political prisoner under the Shah of Iran, became his country's President after rallying hard-liners to carry on a fundamentalist Islamic revolution.

title: Lendl Takes Final On Nastase Default
description: Ivan Lendl, without swinging a racquet, won the $50,000 AMF Head Cup tennis tournament today. Lendl, the No. 2 seeded player, won by default when his opponent, Ilie Nastase of Rumania, forfeited. Nastase had a previous contractual agreement to play in an exhibition match for the Hamlet Group, a resort and condominium organization in Jericho, L.I.

title: To the Editor:     I read with interest the Aug. 7 Op-Ed article by Prof. Eric Davis on ''Iraq's Risk in Its War'' and particularly his assessment that ''the Iran-Iraq war ... has increased the potential for sectarian strife between the country's Shiite majority in the south and the Sunnite-dominated central Government in Baghdad.''
description: Based on close observation of the Iraqi situation over the past year, as well as conversations with a number of Iraqis in the Middle East this summer, I have come to the opposite conclusion. There has been less sectarian strife in Iraq since the start of the war than at any time in the previous few years.

title: New-Dance Conference in Minneapolis; New-Dance Conference Oct. 3-10 in Minneapolis
description: ''New Dance, U.S.A.,'' a week-long conference on post-modern dance, will be held starting in Minneapolis on Oct. 3 under the auspices of the Walker Arts Center there.

title: ALONE WITH SOUTH AFRICA
description: The new U.S. attitude of ''evenhandedness'' after South Africa's heavy raids on Angola is shortsighted. There are moral questions, quite unsatisfied by Washington's condemnation of ''all acts of violence in the area.'' But the stand is also a regressive move likely to undermine American interests not only in Africa but within the Atlantic alliance.

title: MOHAMMED JAVAD BAHONAR, PREMIER
description: When he was killed in a bomb blast yesterday at his offices in Teheran at the age of 47, Mohammed Javad Bahonar had been Prime Minister of Iran for a little less than a month. Although Dr. Bahonar was largely unknown in the West, former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr had described him as one of the five most important men in Iran.

title: The Economy
description: Chase Manhattan announced it was abandoning its 40 percent interest bonus for investors who sign up early for the new ''All Savers'' certificate program. The development came after an unusual warning by the Internal Revenue Service over the weekend that the bonuses might not allow savers certain tax deductions. (Page A1.)

title: Rugby Team Tour Upstate Opposed
description: Delmar Leach, the Rochester Police Chief, says that a rugby match scheduled for next month involving a team from South Africa should be canceled because it poses a threat to public safety.

title: News Analysis
description: Civil rights advocates see the Reagan Administration's move to relax antidiscrimination rules for Federal contractors as a sharp departure from a trend that has developed with bipartisan support over the last 40 years.

title: Most Beaches in State Closing on Labor Day
description: Swimming will end on Labor Day in most New York State Parks, according to Park Commissioner Orin Lehman. Mr. Lehman said today that the exceptions to the Sept. 7 closing date for beaches and pools were the Lake Taghkanic State Park, Jones Beach State Park, Robert Moses State Park, Hither Hills State Park and Sunken Meadow. These swimming areas will be open until Sept. 13, he said.

title: SHIFT AT DOUWE EGBERTS
description: ''I like being the person held responsible,'' said Jason C. Becker. ''If I do well, it's me. If I don't do well, there's no one else to blame.''

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: A Libyan diplomat said today that his country was seeking help from the Soviet bloc because it expects an invasion by Israel and Egypt with support from the United States.

title: Headsets Incur the Wrath of Chicago Councilman
description: The way Louis P. Farina tells it, he was driving his car in Chicago last week when he had to swerve to avoid a bicyclist who was heading straight for him and didn't hear his warning horn blast.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''She is a shipwreck full of astonishments.'' - Peter Gimbel, who helped organize the exploration of the Andrea Doria. (A10:2.)

title: SCIENTISTS IN DEBATE: DOES MONSTER DWELL IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN?
description: Scientists and others interested in speculating about monsters convened here yesterday to discuss the possibility that a large creature lurks in Lake Champlain. None of the scientists would say that such a creature existed, but they did call for renewed study.

title: No Headline
description: Dave Anderson The Straw Stirs Again

title: MEARS WINS 500-KILOMETER COAST RACE
description: Rick Mears, escaping accidents and mechanical problems, won the Los Angeles Times-California 500 today. Mears, who won the Atlanta Twin 125's earlier this year after recuperating from facial burns suffered at Indianapolis, took the lead for good on the 45th lap of the 95-lap event for Indy cars at Riverside International Raceway. Mears averaged 108.300 miles an hour in his Penske-Cosworth for the 500 kilometers (313.5 miles) over Riverside's 3.3-mile road course.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT TRIED TO GET AMIN'S AID TO FREE HOSTAGES
description: Frank E. Terpil, a former Central Intelligence agent who is now under Federal indictment, attempted last year to enlist Idi Amin, Uganda's exiled dictator, in an effort to help free the American hostages held in Iran, according to a former Government official.

title: REDS, PACED BY GRIFFEY,TRIUMPH OVER METS, 6-3
description: The Mets, who live by small things, wasted a number of large things yesterday in Shea Stadium and paid the price by losing, 6-3, to the Cincinnati Reds.

title: RAPE CRISIS CENTERS REDUCED
description: About one-fourth of the approximately 600 rape crisis centers that sprang up around the country during the early 1970's have closed their doors as government funding has become scarce and the feminist fervor of volunteers has been spread thin, according to Pamela Klein, the immediate past president of the National Coalition Against Sexual Assault.

title: All American Derby to Higheasterjet
description: Higheasterjet became the first quarter horse to reach $1 million in career earnings with a nose victory today in the All American Derby at Ruidoso Downs.

title: Door Prize on the Menu
description: They like to call themselves ''the cookingest company in town'' and, for Big Bertha and Her Touring Company from ''One Mo' Time,'' yesterday's party at the Village Gate was just one more time they had shared their favorite dishes.

title: OUTDOORS: ANGLERS BEGIN LATE - SUMMER COUNTDOWN
description: degree temperature at dawn, reassured me that the truly glorious days of surf fishing are nigh.

title: Family Hears Praise For Lowell Thomas
description: The family of the late Lowell Thomas received messages of condolence today from mourners around the world who had followed the broadcaster's career through five decades, his secretary said.

title: EX - WIFE OF SLAIN CONGRESSMAN
description: Margaret Ryan, the first wife of Representative Leo J. Ryan of California, who was slain outside the People's Temple commune in Guyana in 1978, died Firday at Peninsula Hospital here. She was 59 years old.

title: MOSCOW - Dangerous madness has seized the ruling circles of the United States. Only thus can one assess President Reagan's decision on neutron weapons production and the reasons behind it.
description: The main rationale is a no-proof assertion that the neutron bomb is a defensive weapon designed to prevent war. Nothing could be further from the truth because the bomb lowers the threshold of nuclear conflict and thereby makes it more likely and because in combat qualities it undoubtedly is one of the most sophisticated types of offensive thermonuclear arms.

title: YANKEES' MAY FINALLY WINS
description: Since late April, even during the leisurely days of the baseball strike, Rudy May had watched the video cassettes of his dismal pitching performances over and over. He had carried the tapes from his house in New Jersey to his home in California and back again, speeding up the replays, slowing them down and trying to figure why he had not won a game since April 29.

title: 3 Officers Investigated On Misuse of Navy Craft
description: The Navy is investigating allegations that three officers used Navy planes and vessels for private purposes, which is barred by regulations.

title: NEW YORK STATE MOVES TO CONTROL PURCHASERS OF MILK AT WHOLESALE
description: New York State's Department of Agriculture and Markets has proposed rules that would require state approval for groceries, restaurants and other wholesale customers to switch from one milk dealer to another.

title: FRANCE PURSUES BROADER MIDEAST ROLE
description: France's Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, met with Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, today during a tour that appears to signal the ambitions of the new Socialist Government in France to play a greater role in the Middle East.

title: AMERICA'S TROUBLED AGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: CABLE, CHAINED
description: ''Laverne and Shirley'' and ''The Gong Show'' got you down? Perhaps you'd prefer to watch an off-Broadway play, a heavy metal concert in stereo or a 20-minute summary of world news. That will soon be possible, in some cities. Thanks to the diversity made possible by cable television, broadcasters are starting to offer programming geared to much smaller audiences.

title: Natural Gas Decontrol Assailed
description: Most Americans will see their new tax cuts eaten up by increased costs of natural gas if President Reagan decides to speed up decontrol, a consumer group charged today.

title: Miss Pincus Wed To Steven F. Satz
description: Diane Pincus, assistant prosecutor of Middlesex County in New Jersey, was married yesterday to Steven F. Satz, a deputy attorney general for New Jersey. Rabbi Barry Friedman of Temple B'Nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J., performed the ceremony at Mayfair Farms in West Orange, N.J.

title: Red Smith The Forecast: Storm Watch
description: IN the dark backward and abysm of time when television was little more than a rumor, Mike Jacobs, who ruled the Sweet Science from his throne room in Madison Square Garden, conjured up visions of a future when live boxers could perform before studio audiences and the miracle of electronics would make the million-dollar gate commonplace. Mike's dream has long since been realized, with major fights being held in a Las Vegas parking lot or an African jungle while followers of The Fancy laid out millions for closed-circuit TV.

title: U.S. Speeding Reports In Hot-Weather Deaths
description: The national Center for Disease Control has been searching for a quick way to warn public health authorities when heat illness is a danger. It may have found a simple solution.

title: HEARING TODAY ON RAIL TAKEOVER
description: HARTFORD (AP) - A public hearing today is expected to establish rules for negotiations in connection with bidding to take over Conrail's 500 miles of freight lines in Connecticut.

title: KEY SYSTEMS TO BE EXCLUDED FROM 5 AWACS FOR THE SAUDIS
description: The five radar surveillance and battlecontrol aircraft that the Reagan Administration proposes to sell to Saudi Arabia will not have the same key technological systems as United States Air Force models, according to a Defense Department document,

title: Mrs. Carner Wins by 2 Shots
description: JoAnne Carner shot a one-under-par 71 today to win the $150,000 Columbia Savings Classic and reach the $1 million mark in career earnings.

title: NOT ONLY FEDERAL PARKS NEED FEDERAL DOLLARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Drops Infant Into Niagara Falls
description: A young woman dropped her 2-month-old son into Niagara Falls after suffering what she said was a fainting spell, the police said today. The child was swept over the Canadian Horseshoe Falls and was presumed to have been killed.

title: BUSINESS GROUP VOTES CHARTER
description: About 100 people from four cities who dropped out of the United States Jaycees because the organization would not admit women met here over the weekend to elect leaders and ratify a constitution for a new organization.

title: HANA MANDLIKOVA DEFEATS PAM CASALE
description: The gap that exists on the women's tennis tour between the top five players and their peers was dramatized again today with Hana Mandlikova's 6-2, 6-2 victory over Pam Casale for the $20,000 first prize in the Volvo Women's Tennis Cup.

title: John Henry Captures Arlington Million
description: The richest horse in training and the leading money rider in history teamed to win the richest thoroughbred race ever presented today as Bill Shoemaker drove John Henry to a nose victory in the inaugural running of the Arlington Million at Arlington Park.

title: Sue Kwak Bride Of Donald Gross
description: Sue Kwak, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Kwak of Pusan, South Korea, and the late Mr. Kwak, was married yesterday to Donald Gene Gross. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gross of Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Mayer I. Perelmuter of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: ROGERS GETS BIRDIE ON 18TH FOR VICTORY
description: Bill (Buck) Rogers knew what he had to do and he did it. And so Rogers surveyed a 15-foot putt, slightly downhill with a little break left to right, and sank it for birdie. With that putt, the last stroke of the tournament, Rogers won the World Series of Golf by one shot today.

title: Leona Schumer Bride Of Howell M. Newman
description: Leona J. Schumer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Schumer of Babylon, L.I., and Key Largo, Fla., was married yesterday to Howell M. Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Newman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Jay Glaczer of Flushing, Queens, performed the ceremony at the Fox Hollow Inn in Woodbury, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: EROSION WEARS DOWN VOLCANO CRATER: Photograph made recently inside the crater of Mount St. Helens in Vancouver, Wash., shows dust rising from its walls as small avalanches of rocks tumble down.

title: POLAND, ONE YEAR LATER, IS A SOCIETY TRANSFORMED
description: One year ago tomorrow, the Solidarity trade union was born. After 18 days of strikes, under floodlights from television crews from around the world and to the strains of the Polish national anthem, Lech Walesa and a deputy prime minister signed a document that, for the first time, ceded representation o the workers to an organization outside the control of the Communist Party.

title: To the Editor:     In your Aug. 18 Business Day section, the article ''Revolutionary Changes for Solar Field'' illustrated how the inequity of Federal support of energy technologies has been exacerbated by cuts in President Reagan's solar budget.
description: If the $707 million in Federal funds previously requested by the Carter Administration supported ''solar socialism,'' as the President claims, then the current $1.6 billion continues nuclear totalism.

title: SUBWAY SERVICE DURING SUMMER GETS LOW MARKS
description: After showing some improvement this spring, service on the city's subway system declined in June and July, setting summer failure records, according to Transit Authority statistics.

title: Solaita Standout
description: Tony Solaita, former major leaguer, drove in two runs with a single, powering the Nippon Ham Fighters to a 5-3 Japanese League baseball triumph over the Seibu Lions today.

title: News Analysis
description: The case of Mark David Chapman, the confessed killer of John Lennon, illustrated the degree to which the courts and district attorneys have come to rely on plea bargaining to dispose of cases - even those in which the basic facts about a crime are never really in dispute.

title: Richard Activated
description: The Houston Astros today activated J.R. Richard, the star pitcher who has been sidelined since suffering a stroke in July of last year.

title: COALITION PROVES ELUSIVE FOR AFGHAN REBEL GROUPS
description: Somewhat like the forlorn policeman here who perfunctorily tries to wave and whistle the ox carts, buses, camels and humans of the bazaar into some kind of order, Afghan rebel leaders are for the fourth time in a year seeking to unite the major guerrilla organizations.

title: Priscilla Leviten Married
description: Priscilla Leviten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Leviten of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to James Alan Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Warner of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Theodore Lewis of the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I., performed the ceremony. The bride is an art director at D'Arcy MacManus & Masius Advertising in New York, where her husband is a programming executive at Home Box Office, a division of Time Inc.

title: BELL CREATES POST ON REGIONAL BASIS
description: The huge American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in a restructuring of its efforts to serve business customers, has created new vice presidencies for sales and service for six major regions of the country. But the Bell System's planners have placed the new marketing and servicing posts within the structures of its local operating companies.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 31, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Angola's complaint against South Africa - 10 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Western Officials Unsure Of Blackout's Cause
description: Lightning or forest fires may have caused a blackout that left two million people without electricity in California and Nevada for up to three hours, officials said today.

title: GLOBAL PARLEY IN CANADA IS NOT ALL SMOOTH GOING
description: A cooperative effort by some 130 scientists from 53 countries to find ways to limit the arms race and reduce international tensions has run into some tensions of its own.

title: EXPOS STREAK HALTED
description: Phil Niekro of the Atlanta Braves had to rely almost exclusively on his well-known knuckleball yesterday in Montreal. ''I don't think I threw 10 fastballs all day,'' he said. But he helped to stop the surging Montreal Expos, 5-4, in 12 innings with the help of Gene Garber's fine relief pitching.

title: VIEW OF I.R.S. CITED
description: In a move that could set a precedent for other banks and thrift institutions and materially affect investment decisions by individuals, the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday announced that it was abandoning its much-publicized 40 percent interest bonus for investors who sign up early for the Government's new ''All Savers'' certificate program.

title: AT LAST A'S GAIN VICTORY AT BOSTON
description: An Oakland team that had not beaten the Red Sox in their last 10 games, dating from last year, finally broke the Boston jinx yesterday. The A's beat the Red Sox, 5-3, at Fenway Park but their manager, Billy Martin, says that he didn't relax until the final out.

title: Klan Leader Reportedly Informed for F.B.I.
description: According to a confidential memorandum, Bill Wilkinson, an Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, became an informant for the Federal Bureau on Investigation in 1974, a Tennessee newspaper reported today.

title: G.M. Extends Low Interest
description: At the request of dealers, the General Motors Corporation is extending its program of reduced interest rates on loans for new cars through Sept. 23, the company said today. The program, which provides loans at 13.8 percent annual interest, began July 28 and was to have expired tomorrow.

title: Bridge: A Chinese Team Confronts Taiwanese in Hong Kong
description: Contract bridge made a contribution to peace last week when players from China and from Taiwan met across the table in Hong Kong. This was the first head-to-head meeting of the two countries in any adult sport or recreation, other than a recent girls' softball clash in Canada.

title: 'CONDORMAN,' ESPIONAGE SPOOF
description: IT'S a bird! It's a plane! It's a spoof, although you can't be sure because these days who can tell? ''Condorman,'' the new Walt Disney film at the Guild and other neighborhood theaters, is a spy movie, sort of, that looks a little like ''Superman'' and a lot like a James Bond, and is meant for the family trade. It is painless and chaste, and it has a lot of beautiful scenery and beautiful clothes. There are worse things to watch while you eat popcorn.

title: Index; International
description: Afghan rebel leaders again seek- ing to unite guerrilla factions A2 French Government is seeking a broader role in the Middle East A3 Paris police have description of suspect in hotel bombing A3 Scientific parley in Canada runs into trouble A5 Salvadoran opposition plans dip- lomatic offensive A6 Around the World A7 Government/Politics Rebirth of a battleship is raising nostalgia A14 Subway service declines again after improving in the spring B1 Candidates take primary cam- paign to where the voters are B2 General Around the Nation A10 Ex-C.I.A. agent reportedly tried to get Amin's aid on hostages A12 Scientists ponder possibility of monster in Lake Champlain A13 85 persons are arrested in a police narcotics sweep B1 Produce farming resurging in New York State B1 Some details given on how $50 million in securities was lost B3 Health/Science Discharges of electricity found coming from a ring of Saturn B6 Technique for producing anti- bodies to fight cancer cells B6 Education/Welfare Town uses fees to cover schools' extracurricular activities A10 College expenses will make a record jump this year A13 Style Relationships: When the nest fills up again B4 Children's video games: Who wins (or loses)? B4 Rape crisis centers reduced B4 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Mears captures California 500-kilometer test C11 Baseball: Yanks win as May gets first victory since April 29 C1

title: M.O. Mathai, a Top Official In India During Nehru's Rule
description: M.O. Mathai, a former special assistant to India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, has died of a heart attack in Madras. He was 72 years old.

title: Pope Appeals for Peace And Atomic Disarming
description: Pope John Paul II made an appeal today for world peace and nuclear disarmament, recalling the 42d anniversary of the Nazi invasion of his native Poland as well as the American atomic bombing of Hiroshima in August 1945.

title: Jennifer Cowles, Violinist, Bride of John Bescherer
description: Jennifer Edith Cowles, a violinist, was married yesterday to John Edwin Bescherer at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William W. Cowles of Redding, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Bescherer of Wilton, Conn.

title: DISCORAMA $18.80, WINS
description: Ruben Hernandez was booked for a Chicago flight Saturday night to ride Ben Fab in yesterday's Arlington Million. But when Ben Fab's trainer, Jacques Dumas, failed to confirm the commitment, Hernandez canceled the reservation. Ben Fab was subsequently scratched.

title: SLUMP FOR JULY MACHINE TOOL ORDERS
description: Orders for machine tools dropped sharply in July from already depressed levels the month before, the National Machine Tool Builders Assocation reported over the weekend. Analysts expressed concern that the industry, which has so far been buffered from the economic downturn by a large order backlog, may have to begin resorting to layoffs.

title: Arthur D. Weekes Jr. Is Dead; Senior Stockbroker Partner
description: Arthur Delano Weekes Jr., senior partner of the stockbroker concern of H. N. Whitney Goadby & Company, died Friday at his home on Cove Road in Oyster Bay Cove, L. I., after a long illness. He was 73 years old and also lived in Boca Grande, Fla.

title: FED POLICY ON CREDIT REAFFIRMED
description: Despite the urging of many economists, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today reiterated his intent to maintain a credit policy that critics say has led to record high interest rates and has slowed the United States economy.

title: Dollar/Mark Rate
description: The president of the West German central bank, Karl Otto Pohl, said in a television interview today that the dollar/mark exchange rate was ''unrealistic.'' He urged the Government to adopt a ''thrifty'' budget, saying this would have a positive effect on the mark. The dollar closed at about 2.44 marks Friday.

title: Mr. Mayor
description: Ever since football practice began this month at Wilkes College in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., nobody has called Tony Madden, the co-captain and flanker, by his name. Instead, the players, the coaches and most every one else calls him, ''Mr. Mayor.''

title: Steel Imports Are Debated
description: The American steel industry says it is ''intensely concerned'' with the recent level of imports, but a group representing foreign mills called the complaints far-fetched.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO DEPORT 40 HAITIANS WHO LACK LEGAL REPRESENTATION
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has begun deportation proceedings against 40 Haitians who are without individual legal assistance and are being held in a Federal prison near Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: OPEN AND BORG: THE PERFECT MATCH?
description: HE has slipped to No. 2 on the computer, shuns Davis Cup commitments, plays more exhibitions than tournaments and lost more events than he won in the last year. And as Bjorn Borg prepares for the one championship that has become his obsession, the United States Open, there are whispers that maybe, just maybe, the Garbo of tennis may be more vulnerable than he looks on the court.

title: KUWAIT URGES UNITY IN OPEC TO HEAD OFF 'DISINTEGRATION'
description: Kuwait urged the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today to close ranks ''to avert any disintegration'' of the 13-nation cartel.

title: RAYMOND CHANDLER, A MASTER LETTER - WRITER, TOO
description: DURING the long, insomniac evenings after his wife had gone to bed, Raymond Chandler sat in the study of his home in Southern California and corresponded with people from all over the world. For almost 20 years he expressed a wide range of opinions to editors, publishers, agents, authors and admirers of his detective fiction.

title: Japan Video Recorders
description: Japan surpassed the 800,000 mark in production of home videotape recorders for the first time in July, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said Friday. July's production of 802,000 units was more than double the figure for July 1980, the group said. Exports in July totaled 642,000 units, up 110.7 percent from July 1980.

title: LANDMARK STATUE BEING RESTORED
description: A painstaking restoration is under way in a West Side warehouse of a 20,000-pound bronze statue that once was a familiar landmark in lower Manhattan.

title: Woman Murdered In Child's Presence
description: A pregnant woman was found stabbed to death in her apartment in lower Manhattan and the police said her 3-year-old daughter might have have witnessed the slaying.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Washington Watch; U.S.-Canadian Tensions Grow
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN and Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau have hit it off badly. Administration officials are still incensed over what they describe as the truculent approach adopted by Mr. Trudeau in his June visit to the White House, a week before the seven-nation meeting in Ottawa on economic affairs.

title: 5 OTHERS REPORTED KILLED
description: President Mohammed Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar of Iran were killed yesterday when a powerful bomb exploded in the offices of the Prime Minister in central Teheran.

title: REAGAN MAKING BAD START ON NATURE
description: ''Mr. President, I am not some 'environmental nut' as some of your advisers seem to regard all who care about the environment. I am a lifetime Republican, a strong supporter of the Reagan-Bush ticket, a businessman, a longtime advocate of the strengthening of states' rights, responsibilities and powers, a former State Commissioner of Environmental Protection in the state of Connecticut, and, what to me is most ironic, chairman of the task force you established as President-elect to advise you on the environment.''

title: WASHINGTON - There is a serious crisis in the structural design of America's long-span, column-free buildings, and considering the frightening number of collapses and near-collapses in recent years, perhaps our desire for attractive, open-space buildings has exceeded our ability to design and construct them safely.
description: It is not a question of technology but of slumping on-the-job competence that victimizes an innocent public. For several reasons, far too many architects and structural engineers in this country - at our peril - are guilty of negligence.

title: 35TH EDINBURGH FESTIVAL ON WAY TO BIG SUCCESS
description: The 35th Edinburgh Festival, an ever-expanding celebration of the arts, will come to a close Saturday, more successful than many of its predecessors by statistical, if not artistic, measures.

title: TURNABOUT BY CHICAGO BANKS
description: A new banking law in Illinois is off to an odd start, and bankers say it may be a preview of what will happen when, and if, Congress finally loosens the restrictions on banks nationally.

title: HELD SEVERAL ECONOMIC POSTS
description: Kenneth R. Hansen, an economic consultant who held high-level posts in the Federal Government under several administrations, died Thursday of leukemia at Stanford University Medical Center, Palo Alto, Calif. He was 58 years old and lived in Los Altos Hills, Calif.

title: GIANTS END PRESEASON ON A BATTERED NOTE
description: When the Giants' players are in their locker room, conversations are often muffled by disco music. There was no disco music today. There were few conversations and fewer smiles. This was the day after the Steelers overran the Giants, 31-6, in Pittsburgh on the final weekend of exhibition competition. The Steelers, who entered the game with many problems, were in midseason form. The Giants, who had shown signs that they would improve on last year's 4-12 record, looked terrible.

title: Pro Golf Tour Changes Name
description: The PGA Tour, with a membership of 355 professional golfers, changed its name today to the Tournament Players Association, to be known as the TPA Tour.

title: MONDAY, AUGUST 31, 1981
description: International A bombing in Teheran at the offices of the Prime Minister killed killed five persons and injured 15, including President Mohammed Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar. The bomb, which started fires in the block containing the central Government offices, apparently exploded in a room where the President and the Prime Minister were meeting with other officials. It was the severest attack in a growing guerrilla war conducted by opponents of the clergy-dominated Government since a bomb in June killed more than 70 people. (Page A1, Column 6.) Cocaine trafficking in Bolivia involves senior military officers who have been profiting from the extremely lucrative drug trade and other corruption since the armed forces took power 13 months ago, according to foreign and Bolivian officials and others wih close knowledge of the drug flow. Some officers have received millions of dollars for protecting traffickers or for trafficking themselves in the processed and semiprocessed cocaine leaving Bolivia, which is the source of most of the cocaine that reaches the United States, officials of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency said. (A1:3-5.)

title: Lauren Ann Peery Is Wed
description: Lauren Ann Peery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Charles Peery of Westerleigh, S.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Samuel Brattlie, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Samuel Brattlie of Brooklyn.

title: COSMOS SET BACK BY BRAZILIANS, 3-1
description: An uninspired Cosmos team lost, 3-1, to Gremio of Porto Alegre, the Brazilian soccer champion, at Giants Stadium tonight before a crowd of 30,523.

title: Budget Near In Germany
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt today put finishing touches on an austerity budget that has sharply divided his coalition Government and drawn criticism from Washington on military expenditures.

title: Swiss Named To Play Borg
description: Marcus Gunthardt of Switzerland was named yesterday the openinground opponent of Bjorn Borg when Borg begins his 10th quest for the United States Open tennis championship tomorrow.

title: A WESTWAY PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Hotel New Hampshire'
description: Perhaps John Irving will now calm down and return to his typewriter. He has, in recent weeks, told so many readers of so many magazines so much about himself and the various meanings of his new novel and why the reviewers aren't going to like it or him that the book itself - quite a good one, incidentally - all but snores under a pile of symbolic spinach. Mr. Irving, like a Nabokov in jogging shorts, commits pre-emptive criticism.

title: INMATE FOUND HANGED IN CELL
description: A guard at the state's maximum security prison was stabbed to death early today during an escape attempt, the prison warden said.

title: News Analysis
description: The crux of the Reagan Administration's policy on southern Africa, as it was expounded yesterday by Assistant Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker, is that the United States will not allow itself ''to be forced to align ourselves with one side or another'' in the region's disputes.

title: Hysteria and the Homeless
description: There are 36,000 homeless people in New York City, according to a Community Service Society study. No, say city officials, that's an exaggeration; there are probably fewer than 12,000. Whatever the number, it is small in a city of seven million.

title: Wendy E. Schwab Is Wed To Stuart Mark Schnall
description: Wendy Ellen Schwab, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Schwab 2d of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stuart Mark Schnall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schnall of Middletown, N.J. Rabbi Michael A. Robinson performed the ceremony at the Colonial Terrace in Peekskill, N.Y.

title: ALEXANDER TURYN, 80, SCHOLAR
description: Alexander Turyn, a classics scholar who was a member of the Center for Advanced Study at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, died Wednesday at his home in Urbana after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: CARD CHIEF FOR CITICORP
description: Ira S. Rimerman, who has been with Citicorp since 1971, was named Friday as chairman of its Citicard Credit Services subsidiary, the unit that runs its Mastercard and Visa bank card business. But it was business as usual for Mr. Rimerman, and these days one of the prime orders of business is the development of more credit card customers for Citibank, the big New York bank owned by Citicorp.

title: 85 ARE ARRESTED IN POLICE SWEEP OF DRUG SELLERS
description: Eighty-five persons were arrested over the weekend as the Police Department's new narcotics-enforcement team continued to round up people who sell or possess narcotics on the streets of Manhattan, authorities reported yesterday.

title: CLONING IS USED TO CREATE UNUSUAL ANTIBODIES
description: Antibodies are proteins produced by the body's immune defense system in response to almost any foreign invasion. An antibody is aimed exclusively at a specific target on a cell or other substance. The individual targets are called antigens.

title: BOLIVIAN LEADERS TIED TO LUCRATIVE COCAINE TRADE
description: Senior military officers here have been involved in extraordinarily lucrative drug trafficking and other corruption since the armed forces took power 13 months ago, according to foreign and Bolivian officials and two individuals with first-hand knowledge of the drug flow.

title: Carter's Chinese Catch
description: Using a borrowed bamboo fishing pole, Jimmy Carter pulled two carp out of a pond during his weekend visit to central China's Xian area. The Chinese grow them up to 40 pounds or more, but the carp were described only as ''good sized'' by aides.

title: Philippines Expels Priest On Charge of Subversion
description: The Government of the Philippines today expelled an American missionary who had been the spokesman of a committee that criticized what he called violations of human rights by the military authorities in Davao Province. The Government order charged that the priest, the Rev. Ralph Kroes of the Maryknoll Order, was politically active and was guilty of subversion.

title: VENTURE CAPITALISTS' NEW ROLE
description: Last year T.A. Associates, a venture capital firm, sensed a ready market in gene-splicing technology. But combing the field for a likely prospect, the firm found no candidate worth the investment. So T.A. Associates formed its own company by bringing together leading scientists in the field.

title: U.S. Seniors Win
description: The United States team of King Van Nostrand, of Brightwaters, L.I., and Marty Devlin, Princeton, N.J., won the Stevens Cup, an international senior men's team tennis event by defeating Canada, 3-0, in the final at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

title: PRODUCE FARMS RESURGING IN NEW YORK STATE
description: Agriculture in New York State is taking a marked turn for the better, with production and acreage of fruits and vegetables rising after a century of steady decline.

title: ROCK BANDS: OINGO BOINGO AND GO-GO'S
description: THE Go-Go's and Oingo Boingo, the two Los Angeles-based new wave bands who appeared at the Ritz on Friday and Saturday, offer an interesting contrast between music made for sheer fun and pop with a misanthropic message. But if the attitudes of the two bands differ, the jerky, speeded-up rhythms and blunt local styles of both bear more than a passing resemblance to the B-52's.

title: CABARET: JUDY COLLINS AND HER ART SONGS
description: JUDY COLLINS'S concert at the Savoy on Saturday included nearly two dozen songs of almost every size and shape. Working with a four-piece combo, whose pianist, Shelton Becton, proved to be an ideally sensitive accompanist, Miss Collins delivered what amounted to an art-song recital, even though the bulk of the material clearly belonged in the pop sphere.

title: WILLIAM H. ADAMS
description: William H. Adams, a senior vice president and director of administration services of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died of a heart attack yesterday at New York Hospital.

title: Dr. Jonathan Schonfeld Weds Miss Gorenstein
description: Jonina Tessa Gorenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gorenstein of Medford, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Furth Schonfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel B. Schonfeld of White Plains.

title: VOYAGER FINDS ELECTRICAL CHARGES FROM RING OF SATURN
description: Crackling, lightning-like discharges of electricity have been discovered coming from one of Saturn's major rings, Voyager 2 scientists reported today.

title: Teacher Triumphs
description: Brian Teacher defeated Yannick Noah of France, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, today in the final of the $30,000 Hamlet Challenge Cup. Teacher won $12,000 and a trophy valued at $100,000.

title: Sale to Soviet
description: The Commerce Department is reviewing a letter from an American manufacturer asking whether it would approve resumption of equipment sales to a heavy-truck manufacturing plant in the Soviet Union, officials said.

title: New Demolition Set for Westway
description: Demolition of the remaining 2.3 miles of the elevated West Side Highway south of Jane Street will begin this week, according to Michael J. Cuddy, project director for the Westway.

title: COACHES SEE LEVELING OFF OF SPLURGE BY OFFENSES
description: THE games played in the National Football League have changed significantly in the last four seasons with more passing, less running and more scoring. From 1977 through 1980, total yards gained passing went up 27 percent and scoring by 16 percent in the 224 regular-season games.

title: Ballet Fund Picks Manager
description: Charles Dillingham has been appointed general manager of Ballet Theater Foundation Inc. Mr. Dillingham succeeds Joyce A. Moffatt. Managing director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music Theater Company since 1979, Mr. Dillingham was general manager of the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco for 10 years.

title: Neptune's Day Length Now Put Near 18 Hours
description: Three astronomers have determined the length of a day on the distant planet Neptune is 18.2 hours, plus or minus 24 minutes, the National Science Foundation reported today.

title: Number of Calls Raiders Made On Stabler Activities Disputed
description: The former director of security for the National Football League today disputed assertions by Oakland Raider officials that they had ''talked to the league office a minimum of 15 times'' about their concern over the continuing association of Ken Stabler with a convicted New Jersey gambler. The Raiders traded Stabler, a quarterback, to the Houston Oilers in 1980.

title: PRO FOOTBALL 1981
description: THE National Football League's 62d season, which begins on Saturday night in Tampa where the Minnesota Vikings play the Buccaneers, will resemble those of recent years as to format and structure. There is nothing dramatically new about pro football, which as a highly successful arm of the entertainment business finds few reasons to fumble with its success. In 1980 pro football had the highest attendance in its history - a game average of 59,787 which represented 96 percent of stadium capacity - and its television ratings remained high.

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Visits Camp Of Afghans at Khyber Pass
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, visited an Afghan refugee camp today and then drove through the Khyber Pass to view the Afghan border.

title: WORKSHOP TO BE HELD ON ISSUE ADVERTISING
description: "How to make issue advertising work on television" is the topic of a workshop for agency, advertiser, public relations, utility and television professionals to be held Sept. 15 at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York.

title: Whaling Enthusiast Sets Sail on New Career
description: She has spent nearly 25 years accumulating the world's largest private collection of whaling items, including two of the famous scrimshaw pieces known as ''Susan's Teeth.'' But now Barbara Johnson of Princeton, N.J., who earned her law degree in 1978 at the age of 46, plans to start a practice.

title: Firemen Rescue Elizabeth Taylor, in a Way
description: The firefighters of Engine Company 54 were making a routine inspection last evening at a restaurant on West 45th Street when they noticed a crowd of about 100, many of them autograph seekers waiting for Elizabeth Taylor, surging past the police barricades in front of the Martin Beck Theater.

title: Jodi Hamburger Married to Robert Gordon Fately
description: Joanne Hamburger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Edward Hamburger of Kings Point, L.I., was married in the garden of her parents' home yesterday to Robert Gordon Fately, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman A. Fately, of Eastchester, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson of Great Neck, L.I.

title: REBIRTH OF A BATTLESHIP IS RAISING WAVES OF NOSTALGIA
description: This summer, Russell W. Brown tried to steam back 35 years in time and rejoin the Navy and his beloved old battleship, the New Jersey, journeying with her from mothballs to resurrection in the modern Navy.

title: Commodities; Tax Hopes Misled the Experts
description: COMMODITY futures traders who were battered by the convulsions in the market earlier this month may take some small comfort in the fact that many professionals who manage commodity pools were also misled by the euphoria that accompanied passage of the Administration's taxcut and budget bills.

title: CHAMBER: SANTA FE FESTIVAL IS HERE
description: THERE may be something about the sunlight in Santa Fe, N.M., that allows no masking of architectural line, or it may be the landscape that imposes on the senses a clarity and intensity, undiminished by the torpor or melodrama of mists and overgrown greenery.

title: Official's Brother Shot in Apartment
description: The brother of a Westchester legislator was in stable condition in a hospital yesterday after he was shot twice during an apparent robbery at his Eastchester apartment, officials said.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A player in the National Basketball Association goes up for a jump shot. While he is in the air, the ball pops out of his hands, but he catches it immediately and makes the basket before his feet touch the floor. Is this considered a legal play?

title: PARIS POLICE CALL MOTIVE UNCLEAR IN HOTEL BOMBING
description: The police said today that they had a description of a suspect in the bombing last night of the Inter-Continental Hotel, but that they had no idea of the motive.

title: RIGHTS: ASSERT OR LOSE
description: 0,0,3100,2The phrase civil liberties has a long history in English and American political usage, but it was the American Civil Liberties Union that first adopted it in an organization's title and so brought it into a wider public vocabulary. Civil liberties has always described the freedoms of the people in a democracy to speak, publish and organize.

title: LOOKING AHEAD, TOWN USES STUDENT FEES, NOT TAXES, TO COVER SCHOOL FRILLS
description: Financially pressed school officials here have looked at the future and decided to try it now. Moving toward what they see as the ultimate result of a national mood of resistance to tax increases, they have established a system of fees for activities that have historically been covered by taxes. Now, they say, students must pay to play at sports and even to enter any of several classes.

title: SEARCHERS SURPRISED BY SIZE OF HOLE IN DORIA WRECKAGE
description: The reason that the Andrea Doria sank so quickly after she was rammed by the Stockholm 25 years ago is that the Stockholm's prow made a hole much larger than anyone has realized, the research expedition at the sunken liner said yesterday.

title: CHILDREN'S VIDEO GAMES: WHO WINS (OR LOSES)?
description: Teen-age and younger children are feeding more and more quarters into such electronic video games as Asteroids, Space Invaders, Gorf, Defender and Pac-Man as the machines proliferate in arcades, supermarkets, restaurants and movie lobbies. And parents are wondering whether the games are harmful to children or in any way addictive.

title: 'PERSONAL GROWTH' IN THE WORKPLACE
description: Lee Farmelo, the director of control development at the Scott Paper Company, may talk too much. Mr. Formelo's boss, Vincent Russo, vice president of research and development, sometimes has trouble controlling his temper.
